Source: 323[78{S.v. Paš. šā 'back' "No connection seems possible with Mj škyī, Yd. šīlë 'neck' (or Av ušaδā- a hapax, prob. also 'neck', Sogd B šδʾkw 'neck', GMS §96), whose similarity with Turki šillä (Menges, Glossar zu den Volltexten aus Ost-Turkistan, Wiesbaden, 1955) is only coincidental. There is conceivably a connection with šamz'əy f. šamjº, šənjº PQ 'spine', Wan mula-š'amzi 'back' < *ša-məzay 'back-cord, -wire'."}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):78 for suggestions.
Parallel loans from Persian خراب / xarāb (< Arabic 'destruction')

Source: 83[303{*pau̯s- 'to dress, clothe, cover'}]

172[II:370-371{S.v. Ved. mr̥gá- 'wild animal', from Proto-Indo-Iranian *mr̥gá- 'wild animal'.  The meaning of the lexeme is transferred to 'bird' in Proto-Iranian, as already attested by Avestan mərəγa- 'bird'. Further etymology unclear.}];442[593{S.v. 10265 *mr̥gacī- 'small animal, bird' [mr̥gá-] > Ash. niṅasäˊ ʻ bird, sparrow ʼ NTS ii 269, Wg. nĩgaċá, Kt. mŕəṅéċ.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([EWAia](src-172) II:370-371, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):593 no. 10265).

Source: 323[82{Av. tąϑra-| Khot. ttāra- (DKS 126), Sogd. tʾrʾk 'dark', Prs. tār 'id.'| Y[i]d[gha]-M[un]j[i] t'ū/īro 'darkness'.- *tanϑra-.}];172[I:627{Cf. s.v. Ved. támisrā- 'finstere Nacht' (IIr. cf. YAv. tąθra-, Khot. ttāra- 'dunkel', MP tār, NP tārīk 'dunkel', Pašto tōr 'schwarz', Oss. tar 'finster, Finsternis' usw.), from PIE *témH-s-reh₂- (Lat. tenebrae 'Finsternis') to PIE *temH- 'finster sein'.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *temH- 'to be dark' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):82, [EWAia](src-172) I:627). Cf. Avestan tąθra- ᾽darkness᾽.

Source: 442[807{S.v. 13952 Skt. haḍḍa- n. 'bone' lex.}];399[III:573{S.v. Skt. haḍḍam 'Knochen / bone'. Unexplained.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone', only attested in lexicographical works. Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):807 no. 13952; [KEWA](src-399) III:573).

Source: 141[331{S.v. 1. ?*k̑eu̯k- (IEW 597), but cognates are only from within Indo-Iranian.}];172[II:655-656{S.v. Ved. √śoc- 'leuchten, glühen, brennen', probably from PIE *k̑eu̯k-.}];156[III:165-167];83[338-340{S.v. Proto-Iranian *sauč¹ 'burn, emit flames'. "The IE origin of *sauč¹ cannot be ascertained, perhaps it is a "Reimbildung" with *rauč?.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn' (Proto-Iranic *sauč- 'to burn, emit flames'). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):338-340, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:208-210).

Source: 323[10{or'ǝ, owr'ǝ, war'ǝ, etc. m., Kak[ari Pashto] aw'ar 'a cloud'.- *abrya- (but why no palatalisation of the vowel?)| w(ǝ)ryaj, w(ǝ)rej f. 'cloud(s)' < *abračī.}]
Comment: This seems to be a compound with the first part "or" being the actual word for "cloud" (given variously as orǝ́, owrǝ́, warǝ́, which derives from common *nebʰ- (cf. NP abr).

Source: 141[323{S.v. *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren' (IEW 551), cf. n1 comparing Ved. śíśira- 'kühl, kalt', YAb. sarəta- 'kalt', root noun in YAv. sarə-δā 'Kälte bringend'.}];274[416–417{S.v. *k̑elH ‘kalt werden, frieren’ (LIV 323, IEW 551), cf. n6 suggesting the Iranian lexemes are rather reflexes of 2. *k̑el- 'warm werden'.}];353[439-440{S.v. Lith. šáltas 'cold' (Latv. salts 'cold'), cognate with YAv. sarəta- 'cold' and also connected within Baltic to Lith. šálti 'freeze', Latv. salt 'freeze, clot', which in turn reflect a root *k̑olH- which may have been of denominative origin.}];172[II:641{Regarding the Iranian nominal forms, cf. notes s.v. Ved. śíśira- 'Vorfrühling, kühle Jahreszeit', where YAv. sarəta- 'kalt', Lith. šálti '[ge]frieren, abkuhlen, kalt werden' are connected to PIE *k̑elH- 'frieren'.}];83[336-337{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *sarH- 'to cool, become cold', from PIE *k̑elH- 'to freeze' (cf. Lith. šálti 'to freeze, to cool (off), become cool', Latv. sal̃t 'to freeze').}];352[1008-1009{Cf. s.v. OLith. šálti 'frieren' (derived adj. šáltas 'kalt'), from PIE *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren'.}]
Justification: Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ([NIL](src-274) 416-417, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:641, [Cheung 2007](src-83):336-337, [ALEW](src-352) 1008-1009, [Derksen 2015](src-353):439-440, [LIV²](src-141) 323).

Source: 83[372-374{S.v. Proto-Iranic *tač- (1) 'to flow, run, walk', from PIE *tekʷ- 'to hurry, rush, walk, flow' (cf. Skt. tak- 'to rush, hurry', Hitt. u̯atk- 'to jump from', OIr. tech- 'to flow' OCS tešti, Lith. tekė́ti 'to run, flow', etc.).}];323[81-82{S.v. tl- 'to go', rā-tl- 'to come'| pres. j- < *t-j- < Ir. *tač-.}];141[620-621{Cf. s.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).}];172[I:610-611{Cf. s.v. Ved. √tak- 'stürzen, dahinschießen, eilen (von Tieren, Strömen), from PIE *tekʷ- 'eilen, stürzen, laufen, fließen' (cf. OIr. tech- 'fließen', W go-deb 'Zuflucht', Lith. tekė́ti 'laufen, fließen', OCS tešti 'laufen, eilen', tokъ 'Lauf, Strom', TochB cake 'Fluß' Hitt. watku- 'springen, entspringen').}]
Comment: The Pashto form ra-tlal literally means "to go hither" (cf. rā in Morgenstierne 2003: 69).
Justification: A derivative of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk' + preverb rā- 'hither' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):81-82, [Cheung 2007](src-83):372-374), further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, to flow' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:610-611, [LIV²](src-141) 610-611).

Source: 141[439-440{S.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735)}];156[II:89-90{Ossetic forms from Indo-Iranian *mar-.}];567[232-233{Bactrian μιρ- / μιρδο from Proto-Iranian *mr̥ya-/*mr̥ta- (cf. MPers. mīr-/murd).}];79[463{S.v. Arm. meṙanim, 'to die', a present stem which was back-formed on the basis of the active root aorist (3.sg. *mér-t), ultimately derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear, vanish' (cf. Skt. mar- 'to die', Hitt. mer- 'to disappear, vanish', Lat. morior, OCS mrěti, etc.).}];172[II:318-319{S.v. Ved. √mar- 'sterben', from PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, hinschwinden, sterben' (cf. Lat. morior 'sterbe', Goth. maurϸr 'Mord', Lith. mir̃ti, OCS mrěti 'sterben', etc.).}];81[308{S.v. Proto-Slavic *merti 'die', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *mer-/*mir- (cf. Lith. mir̃ti, Latv. mìrt 'die'), derived from PIE *mer- (cf. Skt. mriyáte 'die, Lat. morior 'die').}];54[389-390{S.v. Lat. morior, morī 'to die', from PIE *mr̥-i̯e-, from root *mer- 'to disappear, die' (cf. OIr. marb, W. marw 'dead' < *mr̥-u̯o-| Hitt. mer- 'to disappear, vanish' < *mer-/*mr-| Skt. mriyáte < *mr-ie-| YAv. miriia- 'to die', Gk. (Hesych.) ἔμορτεν [3.sg.ipf.act.] 'died', Arm meṙani- 'to die', Goth. maurϸr 'murder', Lith. mir̃ti 'to die', OCS mrěti 'to die', etc.).}];50[259{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *marwo- 'dead' (adj.), from which the Brit. Celtic forms are denominative verbal formations. The PIE adjective *mrto- (cf. Skt. mr̥tá-, Lat. mortuus) as remodelled in Celtic on analogy with *gʷiH-u̯os 'alive' (cf. Lat. uīuus, etc.).}];353[321{S.v. Lith. mir̃ti (Latv. mìrt) 'die' from Proto-Balto-Slavic *mer-/*mir- (cf. OCS mrěti 'die'), derived from PIE *mer- (cf. Skt. mriyáte 'die, Lat. morior 'die').}];352[660-661{S.v. OLith. mir̃ti 'sterben' (BSl. cf. Latv. mir̃t, 'sterben', OCS mrěti 'stermen', etc.), from PIE *mer- 'sterben, verschwinden' (cf. Hitt. merzi 'verschwindet', Ved. mar-, mriyáte 'sterben', YAv. mar-, miriiete 'stirbt', Lat. morior, morī 'sterben').}]
Justification: Lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ([LIV²](src-141) 439-440). Note that the semantic extension 'to disappear' as a euphemism 'to die' appears to be a post-Anatolian innovation, where the Hittite cognate mer-/mar- retains the original meaning 'to disappear' (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):8).

Source: 274[436-440{S.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' (IEW 632f.).}];80[505-506{S.v. Hitt. (LÚ)kuu̯an-/kun- 'hound-man' (a type of cult functionary), elsewhere in Anatolian cf. Lith. šuõ 'dog' (Latv. suns, OPr. sunis), from PIE *k̑uōn, G.sg. k̑un-ós (cf. Skt. śván-, Gk. κύων, Lat. canis, OIr. cú, Goth. hunds).}];165[256{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hunda- (2) 'dog', from the IE word for 'dog' *k̑u-on- (cf. Hitt. kuu̯an- ~ kun- 'dog-man', TochAB ku, Skt. śván-, YAv. span-, Arm. šun, Gk. κύων, Lat. canēs, -is, OIr. cú, Lith. šuõ, etc.).}];54[87{S.v. Lat. canēs, -is 'dog', from PIE *k̑uōn 'dog' (cf. OIr. cú [G.sg. con], Hitt. kuu̯an-/kun- 'dog-man', HLuw. swan(i)- 'dog' Skt. svā́ 'dog', YAv. span- 'dog', Gk. κύων, Arm. šown, OPr. sunis, Lith. šuõ, Goth. hunds, OIc. hundr, TochAB ku, etc.).}];50[181{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷon- 'dog' (nom.sg. *k(w)ū, gen.sg. *kunos), from PIE *k̑(u)u̯ōn 'dog' (cf. Skt. śvā́, Gk. κύων, Lat. canis, Germ. Hund, Lith. šuõ, TochA ku, Arm. šun). NB Proto-Celtic *kʷ < PIE *k̑w was delabialised before *ū̆.}];352[1054-1055{S.v. OLith. šuõ, šuõj, šuõn 'Hund' (BSl. cf. Latv. suns 'Hund, OPr. sunis 'Hund'), from PIE *k̑u̯on- 'Hund' (cf. Hitt. kuwas 'Hundemann', HLuw. zuwan(i)- 'Hund', Ved. śvā́ 'Hund', YAv. spā 'Hund', Gk. κύων 'id.', OIr. cú 'id.', TochA ku, TochB ku 'Hund').}];657[168{S.v. DOG *k̑(u)u̯ón (gen. *k̑unós) 'dog (canis familiaris)'.}];149[187{S.v. TochB ku, kū, TochA ku, kū 'dog', clearly continuing the IE word for 'dog' (cf. Skt. ś(u)vā́, Gk. κύων, etc.).}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'dog' ([NIL](src-274) 436-440, [EIEC](src-657) 168, cf. [Melchert 1989](src-692), [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):505-506, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):187, [Adams 2013](src-345):190, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):520-522, Beekes 2010}:811, [EWAia](src-172) II:674-675, [ALEW](src-352) 1054-1055, [Derksen 2015](src-353):455, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):256, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):87, [Matasović 2009](src-50):181).

Source: 83[35-36{S.v. Proto-Iranian *caš² 'to drip| to drink, eat?'.  The root is exclusively Iranian| Skt. caṣ- 'to eat' is attested late and likely to be a loanword.}]
Comment: Klingenschmitt (2000: 216 fn. 86) sets these words together with Pashto caṣǝl in relation to Old Ind. *cakṣ.
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *čaš- 'to drip; to drink, eat'? ([Cheung 2007](src-83):35-36).

Comment: Horn (1893: 201) suggests a derivation from the verbal root 'wart' "to turn". If so, all those languages that would preserve *#w would have to have loaned this word from languages like Persian.

Source: 172[I:518-519{Cf. s.v. ghoṣ- 'klingen, ertönen, ertönen machen' (cf. Ir. *(-)gauš 'hören' in MPers. niyō(x)šidan, NPers. niyōšīdan, Parth. nγwš, Baluči niγōšaγ, Oss. qūsyn, etc.). The IE origins of PIIr. *gʰau̯š- '(ein Getön) hören' are not securely determined.}];141[200{Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s- '(Geräusche) hören' (IEW 454). Only Indo-Iranian (cf. Ved. ghóṣati 'ertönt, hört')| PIE reconstruction uncertain.}];83[115-116{S.v. Proto-Iranian gauš- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Skt. ghoṣ- 'to sound'). Cognate forms outside of IIr. are not attested.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([Cheung 2007](src-83):115-116, [EWAia](src-172) I:518-519; [LIV²](src-141) 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).

Source: 83[147{S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar¹ 'consume, eat'. The root is probably secondary to Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar³ 'to take'. Further IE connections are uncertain and postulating a PIE root *su̯el- (as in LIV², IEW) is probably unwarranted.}];141[609{Cf. s.v. ?2.*su̯el- '(ver)schlucken' (IEW 1045).  Only Iranian (cf. YAv. xᵛaraiti 'ißt, trinkt'), so the Indo-European root reconstruction is only hypothetical.}];567[279{Bactrian χοαρ-/χοαρδο 'have, possess, take (possession of)| eat' < Proto-Iranian *hwara-/hwarta- (cf. Khot. kvar-/hvaḍa- 'consume, eat' Tumshuqese hvārya- 'to be taken').}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):147-150, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 609).

Source: 66[1681{S.v. ᾠόν 'egg' < PIE *h₂ōui-o- 'egg'.}];165[17{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ajja- 'egg' from PIE *h₂ōu-ió-, generally taken to be formed as a vr̥ddhi-formation to the Indo-European word for 'bird' *h₂éu-is, *h₂u-éi-s. Cf. entry in Kroonen for a relative chronology of the sound changes that led to the Proto-Germanic form.}];130[60{Contra Orel (1998:497), considers the Alb. ve ~ vo inherited. (All other loans from Lat. ō- result in (h)u-.)}];105[497{S.v. Alb. ve ~ vo 'egg', considers the lexeme a loan from Lat. ōvum on the basis of Old Albanian voe (Buzuku, Bardhi) where the correspondence of Tosk va- ~ Gheg vo- is typical of Latin loanwords. [But cf. objections of Holm 2011:60.]}];79[439{S.v. Arm. ju 'egg', derived from the PIE word for 'egg' (cf. Gk. ᾠόν, Lat. ōvum, Celt. *āwyo- 'egg', OCS aice, etc.), the Armenian form is usually explained from *i̯ō(w)i̯o- with assimilatory addition of *i̯-, but the initial j- remains unclear.}];320[30{S.v. Khot. āhā- 'egg' < *āvyā- (cf. Av. aēm [Yašt 13.2] 'egg'(?), Oss. D. ajkä, NPers. xāyah, Pašto hā, etc., from the PIE word for 'egg' (Gk. ᾠόν, Welsh wy, Lat. ōuum, ONor. egg, etc.).}];81[27{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ajьce 'egg', originally a diminutive of Proto-Slavic *aje 'egg' from PIE *h₂ōui-om (cf. Gk. ᾠόν, Lat. ōvum, OIc. egg, OHG ei, W wy).}];54[438{S.v. Lat. ōvum 'egg', from PIE *h₂ōuiom 'egg', preferring the explanation deriving 'egg' as a vr̥ddhi-derivative of 'bird', hence 'what belongs to a bird', against Schindler (1969), who reconstructs ō-h₂uiom with a preposition *ō, thus 'toward the bird'.}];653[144-167{Derives the IE word for egg from *ō-h₂uiom.}];50[50{S.v. Proto-Celtic *āwyo- 'egg', from PIE *h₂ōu-io- 'egg' (cf. Lat. ōuum, Gk. ᾠόν, etc.).}];269[{Cf. Western Armenian hawkitʿ as a compound 'bird-produce' [cognate set 6057](cog-6057). Within PIE 'bird' and 'egg' must have been separate lexemes, therefore these classes have been separated.}];458[1: 61-64{PS *aje < PIE *ōi̯om. Cf. also PS derivatives *ajĭce and *ajĭko.}];657[176{S.v. EGG *hₐō(u̯)iom 'egg' [[IEW](src-49) 783-784 *ō(u̯)i̯-om)]. Arm. ju 'egg' and OInd. aṇḍa- cannot be derived from this IE proto-form. It is quite possible that the word for 'egg' is a vr̥ddhi-derivative of the IE word for 'bird' *hₐeu̯ei-.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg', which may be a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Indo-European word for 'bird' *h₂eu̯-i- ([EIEC](src-657) 176, cf. [cognate set 856](cog-856)); alternatively [Schindler 1969](src-653) reconstructs an adpositional construction *ō-h₂uiom 'towards the bird'. For individual branches, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1681, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):439, [Orel 1998](src-105):497, [Holm 2011](src-130):60, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:41, [Bailey 1979](src-320):30, [ESSJa](src-458) 1:61-64, [Derksen 2008](src-81):27, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):17, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):438, [Matasović 2009](src-50):50.

Source: 323[77{S.v. Pashto st'ərga f. 'eye'. Diminutive * stṛ-kā-, which he compares with Balochi čamm-istār "pupil of the eye". Since he also refers to the meaning "planet" of the Pashto word, he probably suggests the "star"-word as etymology.}];442[330{Cf. s.v. 5798 Skt. tārā f. 'fixed star'| 4. tāraká- 'belonging to the stars' > B. tārā 'star| pupil of the eye'}];172[II:755-756{S.v. Ved. stár- 'Stern' (RV ins.pl. stŕ̥bhiḥ, nom.pl. tā́raḥ [RV 8.55.2]| OAv., YAv. star-, etc.), from PIE *h₂stér- (cf. Hitt. ḫa-aš-te-er-za, Gk. ἀστήρ, Arm. astł, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno, etc.).}]
Justification: According to [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):77, as though from an Iranic diminutive *str̥-kā, and in view of the meaning 'planet' (cf. Avestan star- 'star', Vedic stár- 'id.) probably to be further connected to the Indo-European word for 'star', *h₂stér- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:755-756). The same semantic development is also attested in Modern Indic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5798).

Source: 320[56{S.v. Khot. kava- 'fish', from Iranic *kapā- (Sogd. kpy, Yidγa kap, Waxī kūp, Pašto kab| Oss. DI. käf| possibly from OInd. kap- 'grey' in OInd. kapila-.}];321[458{S.v. Wa. kup 'руба' < *kapā- (Khot. kava, Sogd. kpy, Mdzh. kop, Yid. kap, Afg. kab. Oss. kæf.}];331[4:241-242{S.v. *kapa- 'руба', considered an East Iranian word in contrast to Western Iranian which continues reflexes from *matsi̯a-. Perhaps to the root *kap- 'grey', cf. Ved. kapila- (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):56).}]
Comment: Bailey (1979: 56) suggests a relation to *kap- "grey" in O.Ind. kapila- and to the blue/grey word *kapauta-, weiter dazu EWAia I: 303
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kapā̆- 'fish', generally found in Eastern Iranic as a replacement for inherited Proto-Indo-Iranic *matsi̯a- 'fish' ([ESIJa](src-331) 4:241-242, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):56, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):458). Perhaps further to an Indo-Iranic root *kap- 'grey', maybe in Vedic kapila- 'tawny, brown, reddish', but cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:300-303.

Source: 342[383-569{From *pénkʷe, the first of the indeclinable numerals in PIE. Cf. discussion pp.383-569.}];345[415-416{S.v. TochB piś 'five', which with TochA päñ reflects Proto-Tocharian *pi̯ä́ñćä- with differing reflexes of the final cluster. PToch *pi̯ä́ñćä- is from PIE *pénkʷe (cf. Skt. páñca, Arm. hing, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, OE fīf, Lith. penkì, etc.).}];105[316{S.v. Alb. pesë ~ pêsë 'five', from PAlb. *pentše going back to PIE *pénkʷe 'five' (cf. Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, etc.).}];369[315-316{S.v. Alb. pésë / pẽs(ë) 'fünf', to be connected with PIE *pénkʷe 'five'. Cf. entry in Demiraj for discussion of the Albanian stem formation.}];79[409{S.v. Arm. hing 'five', from PIE *pénkʷe 'five' (cf. Skt. páñca, YAv. paṇca, MPers. panǰ, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, etc.).}];172[II:65-66{S.v. páñca 'fünf' (IIr. cf. YAv. paṇča 'fünf'), from PIE *pénkʷe (cf. Gk. πέντε, Arm. hing, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, TochA päñ, TochB piś, etc.).}];353[351{S.v. Lith. penkì 'five' (Latv. pìeci), from PIE *penkʷe (cf. OCS pętь, Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf).}];81[400{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pętь 'five', from PIE *penkʷe (cf. Lith. penkì, Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Go. fimf).}];165[140{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fimfe 'five', from PIE *pénkʷe (cf. Hitt. panza-, TochA päñ, TochB piś, Skt. páñca, YAv. paṇca, MPers. panǰ, Oss. fondz, Arm. hing, Alb. pesë / pẽsë, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, OIr. cóic, MW pymp, W pimp, Bret. pemp).}];54[509{S.v. Lat. quīnque 'five', from Proto-Italic *kʷenkʷe (cf. O. pumperIas, púmperias U. pumpeřias prob. 'fifth day', etc.), from PIE *penkʷe 'five' (cf. OIr. cóic, MW pymp, Skt. páñca, YAv. paṇca, Gk. πέντε, Arm. hing, Alb. pesë, OCS pętь, Lith. penkì, Goth. fimf, TochA päñ, TochB piś 'five').}];50[176-177{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷenkʷe 'five', from PIE *penkʷe 'five' (cf. Skt. páñca, Gk. πέντε, Lat. quīnque, Goth. fimf, Lith. penkì, OCS pętь, Alb. pesë).}];352[756-757{S.v. OLith. penkì 'fünf' (BSl. Latv. pìeci, OCS pętь, etc.), from PIE *pénkʷe 'fünf'.}];66[1172-1173{S.v. AGk. πέντε 'five' (Aeol. πέμπε) < PIE *penkʷe 'five'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *pénkʷe 'five', generally considered to be the Indo-European inherited numeral for 'five' (not attested in phonetic spellings in Anatolian languages). See [Eichner 1982](src-342):383-569 for extensive discussion, cf. also [Adams 2013](src-345):415-416, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1172-1173, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):409, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):315-316, [Orel 1998](src-105):316, [EWAia](src-172) II:65-66, [ALEW](src-352) 756-767, [Derksen 2015](src-353):351, [Derksen 2008](src-81):400, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):140, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):509, [Matasović 2009](src-50):176-177.

Source: 363[I:399-400{S.v. Kurd. gul (f.) | guł 'цветок| роза', cf. Pers. gul 'rose, flower', Middle Persian varδa, Av. varəda-, cf. OInd. vardh-, [IEW](src-49) 1167 *u̯erdh-.}];172[II:520-521{Cf. s.v. Ved. √vardh- 'wachsen lassen, mehren', connected with Avestan vərəzda- 'vermehrt, zugewachsen, groß'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are difficult.}]
Comment: The Avestan word varǝδa- refers to a plant "v[ie]ll[eicht] Rose" (Bartholomae 1904: 1369). The Sogdian word "ward" means "rose", which is a common meaning of 'flower' in most modern Iranic languages. Also attested in Parthian as wār.
Justification: Lexemes reflecting Proto-Iranic *u̯arda-, traditionally further connected to Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow' and further to an IE root *u̯erdʰ- (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:399-400, [IEW](src-49) 1167), but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:520-521, [LIV²](src-141) 228 against connections of this proposed root outside of Indo-Iranic.

Source: 66[1077{S.v. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog', from PIE *h₃migʰ-l(e)h₂. The Greek forms are identical to Balto-Slavic words for fog attested by Lith. miglà, OCS mъgla.}];79[466{S.v. Arm. mēg 'mist, fog, darkness', usually understood to be cognate with Skt. meghá- 'cloud, gloomy weather', Av. maēγa- 'cloud', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'mist, fog', Lith. miglà 'fog', etc. From PIE *h₃meigʰ-o- or *h₃meigʰ-eh₂-. The possibility remains that Arm. mēg might also be an Iranian loan (cf. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):474 s.v. mez 'urine').}];172[II:374-375{S.v. Ved. meghá- 'Wolke, trübes Wetter' (root noun mih- 'Nebel, Niederschlag, Regen'). IIr. cf. YAv. maēγa- 'Wolke', MPers., NPers. mēγ 'Wolke, Nebel', Oss. mīg/megæ 'Wolke, Nebel', etc., from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ-, from which nominal derivations like *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- (meghá-), *h₃migʰ- (mih-) and *h₃migʰ-leh₂ (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'Nebel', Lith. miglà, OCS mьgla 'Nebel').}];353[317{S.v. Lith. miglà 'mist, haze', from PIE *h₃migʰ-leh₂- (cf. OCS mьgla, Skt. meghá- 'cloud, gloomy weather', míh- 'haze, rain', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'mist, haze', YAv. maēγa- 'cloud', Arm. mēg 'mist').}];81[338-339{S.v. Proto-Slavic *mьgla, mьga, miglъ 'mist, haze' (ESSJa XXI 92-94), from PIE *h₃migʰ-leh₂ (cf. Lith. miglà 'mist, haze', Skt. meghá- 'cloud, gloomy weather', Skt. mih- 'haze, rain', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'mist, haze', Av. maēγa- 'cloud', Arm. mēg 'mist'). Cf. entry for extensive discussion of the PIE root reconstruction.}];352[649{S.v. OLith. miglà 'Nebel' (BSl. Latv. migla 'Nebel', OCS mьgla 'Nebel', etc.), from PIE *h₃migʰ-leh₂- 'Nebel' (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'Nebel'). The Balto-Slavic words agree with Gk. ὀμίχλη with an *-leh₂- suffix| other nominal formations of the same root include Ved. meghá- 'Wilke, trübes Wetter', YAv. maēγa- 'Wolke'. Further connections to PIE *h₃mei̯g̑ʰ- 'harnen' (LIV² 301f. cf. Lith. mỹžti) or *mei̯gʰ- 'blinzeln' (LIV² 427, cf. Lith. miegóti) are often considered.}];458[21: 93-94{S. v. *mĭɡla.}];84[{Cf. s.v. ModEng. mist "Cognate with Middle Dutch mest, mist (Dutch mist), Middle Low German mist, Middle High German mist, Icelandic mistr, mistur, Norwegian (regional or archaic) mist, Swedish mist, Danish mist < an extended form of the Indo-European base of Sanskrit mih mist, vapour, megha cloud, ancient Greek ὀμίχλη mist, cloud, Old Church Slavonic mĭgla mist, cloud, Russian mgla haze, Lithuanian migla mist, Albanian mjegull cloud, mist."}];757[3:140{S.v. Du. mist, to be connected with Greek ὀμίχλη ‘nevel’| Sanskrit megha- ‘wolk’| OIr. mēgha ‘wolk’| Lith. miglà ‘nevel’| OCS mĭgla ‘nevel’ (Ru. mgla)| Arm. mēg ‘nevel’| from the PIE root *h₃meigʰ- (IEW 712).}]
Comment: Wakhi: There is no reason to assume an Indic loanword, as the phonology is completely regular and the lexeme is robustly attested in Iranic.
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1077, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):466, [EWAia](src-172) II:374-375, [ALEW](src-352) 649, [Derksen 2015](src-353):317, [ESSJa](src-458) 21:93-94, [Derksen 2008](src-81):338-339, [EWNl](src-757) 3:140, [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 342[298-382{Cf. discussion pp.298-382.}];345[703{S.v. TochB śtwer 'four, which with TochA śtwar reflects Proto-Tocharian *ćätwerä < PIE *kʷetu̯ores (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, Av. čaθwārō, Arm. čorkʻ, Hom.Gk. τέσσαρες (cf. Att. τέτταρες), Lat. quattuor, OIr. cethair, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, etc.).}];105[173-174{S.v. Alb. katër 'four', from PIE *kʷetur- ~ *kʷetu̯er- 'four'.}];66[1471-1472{S.v. Gk. τέσσαρες 'four', from PIE *kʷetu(e)r-.}];172[I:526-527{Cf. s.v. Ved. catvar- 'vier' (PIE *kʷétu̯or-es > Ved. nom.sg. catvā́ras)}];54[505-506{S.v. Lat. quattuor, cf. entry for notes on peculiarities of the Latin form.}];79[546-547{S.v. Arm. čʻor-kʻ 'four', from PIE *kʷetuores 'four' (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, YAv. caθβārō, TochA śtwar, B śtwer, Gk. τέσσαρες, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, etc.)}];50[179{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷetwores 'four', from PIE *kʷetu̯ores (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, Lat. quattuor, Gk. τέτταρες, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, ToA śtwar, Arm. čorkʻ).}];81[87{S.v. Proto-Slavic *četyre 'four' (ESSJa IV 97-98), from PIE *kʷétur- (cf. Lith. keturì, Skt. catvā́ras, etc.).}];353[241{S.v. Lith. keturì 'four' (Latv. četri), from PIE *kʷétur- (cf. OCS četyre, Skt. catvā́ras).}];352[483-485{S.v. OLith. keturì, kẽturios 'vier' (BSl. cf. Latv. četri 'vier', OCS četyre 'vier', etc.), from PIE *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur-.}];165[133{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fedwar- 'four' < PIE *kʷét-uor-.}]
Justification: The reflexes found in the individual languages reflect different generalised accent/ablaut classes of PIE *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur- 'four'. For extensive discussion cf. [Eichner 1982](src-342):298-382, cf. also [Adams 2013](src-345):703, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1471-1472, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546-547, [Orel 1998](src-105):173-174, [EWAia](src-172) I:526-527, [ALEW](src-352) 483-485, [Derksen 2015](src-353):241, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:97-98, [Derksen 2008](src-81):87, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):133, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):505-506, [Matasović 2009](src-50):179.

Source: 156[I:560{Cf. s.v. Oss. īx | ex 'лед', from Proto-Iranian *aixa- (cf. Pers. yax, Kurd. yex, Yag. īx, Sogd. *yīx, Chores. ēx, Av. aexa-).}];331[I:140-143{S.v. Proto-Iranic *aixa- : *īxa- 'лёд, холод, мороз'.}]
Justification: The Iranic lexemes in this class represent light verb constructions with Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ([ESIJa](src-331) I:140-143) constituting the semantic head. Cf. 'ice' in [cognate set 5932](cog-5932) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 763[56{"(23) mygdyyn " consisting of fruit ". In M 93, 14b, mygdg "' fruit " occurs. Sogdian myδ'kw (etc.) =maγδe " fruit " and MPers. myw (Mir.Man., i), Pers. meve "fruit " (for which Morgenstierne proposed a different origin, Acta Orientalia, i, 272) belong here| MPers. mew < *mey from *maδg (miδg ?) with metathesis. The Parthian, Sogdian, and Persian words, in conjunction, prove Old Iranian *migda- (and *migdaka-) " fruit "| all of them are collective nouns. This Old Iranian migda- " fruit " cannot well be separated from the Aramaic and Hebrew migdā (etc.) "fruit ", words which are often mis-translated because of etymological considerations (√mgd in Arabic and Palmyrene). Syriac maγδā means nothing but "fruit ", and so does Talm. mygd' (mgd'), for which Levy, iii, 12, gives Kostbarkeit, kostliche Frucht, while the passage he quotes has b-'sprmqy w-mgdy, evidently " with flowers (MPers. isparhmag) and fruit . Biblical Hebrew mä́gäd, in Deut., 33:13 sqq., and unquestionably in Cant., 413, 16, 714, means " fruit ", both literally and metaphorically (" fruit of heaven ", etc.)| Brown-Driver-Briggs say " excellence: excellent or choice things| always of gifts of nature…"}]
Comment: Morgenstierne (2003: 53) quotes Henning (BSOAS 12/1: 56) for *migda-, cf. Sogdian mγδˀk. The COBL comment on Sogdian "fruit" considers it possible for this word to be a Semitic loanword. The reason that Sogdian in COBL does not show mγδˀk is that the source that was used to fill the Sogdian list uses another word instead.
Justification: As though continuing a Iranic stem *migda(ka)- 'fruit'; a probable loanword from West Semitic, cf. Biblical Hebrew מֶגֶד 'choice produce', Syriac maγδā 'fruit', etc. (cf. [Henning 1947](src-763):56).

Source: 184[1414, 1416{S.v. j., g. vāstra- n. ‘Weide’ (p.1414)| j., g. vāstrya- Adj. ‘was zur Weide-, Landwirtschaft, zum Feldbau gehört, sich darauf bezieht (usw.)’ (p. 1416).}];323[93{S.v. Pashto wāx̌ə 'grass, fodder', from Ir. *wāstr(iy)a-, cf. Av. vāstra- 'pasture, grass', Pth. wʾš 'straw', Bact. οαϸο 'straw' or 'hay', Khwar. wš 'grass', Khot. kvāṣṣa- 'id.'.}];321[403{S.v. Wa. wыṣ̌ 'трава, сено', from Old Iranian *vāstra- (Av. vāstra-, Sogd. wyš, Yaghn. wayš, weš, Parth. wāš).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯āstra- 'pasture, grass' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):93 [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):403, cf. [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):1414, 1416).

Source: 172[II:638-639{S.v. Ved. śíras- 'Kopf, Haupt, Spitze' < PIE *kŕ̥h₂-os/k̑r̥h₂-s-n-ós (cf. Gk. κάρᾱ [G.sg. κρᾱ́ατος] 'head', Lat. cerebrum 'brain', OHG hirn(i) 'brain').}];567[263{Bactrian σαρο 'head' < Proto-Iranian *sarah- (cf. Av. sarah-).}];66[641{S.v. κάρᾱ 'head' < PIE *k̑rh₂-(e)s-n- 'head'.}];544[{Cf. for an exhaustive discussion of formations meaning 'head' and 'horn' built to this root.}];269[{For the root *k̑er- as the basis of this stem, cf. 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457).}];364[237{Albanian lexemes ~ Gr. κρᾱνίον 'upper part of the head, skull', Ved. śīrṣṇá- 'id.'| < Early Pr. Alb. *krōna- <(--) PIE *k̑roh₂sno- 'head'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. [Nussbaum 1986](src-544) for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root), cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):641, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):237, [EWAia](src-172) II:638-639.

Source: 323[10{S.v. Paš. arw-, awr- : -ed-, etc. : Wan awr 'to hear' – Av. hauuruua-, √har- 'to observe'| Par. harw- 'to hear'.}];83[129{S.v. Proto-Iranic *har- (1) 'to guard, observe' (> Pash. arwēdəl ‘to hear’ = arw-, awr- / -ed-, (Wan.) awr-). From PIE *ser- 'to look after, protect' (cf. Gk. ὄρονται 'they respect' (Hom.), ?Lyd. kaτared- 'stands guard', sarẽta- 'protector'.}];141[534{S.v. 1. *ser- 'aufpassen auf, beschützen' (IEW 910).}]
Comment: Original meaning "to observe".
Justification: Ultimately a derivative of PIE 1. *ser- to look after, protect' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):10, [Cheung 2007](src-83):129, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 534).

Source: 323[23{S.v. Paš. drund, m. dran'a f. 'heavy'. "Prob. with secondary -d, cf. Pash gərānd 'heavy, pregnant' < Prs girān| Waz armond, darmond < armān, darmān. Perhaps a contamination of an old LW< Prs girān with *drūnd < Av ϑrqfδa- 'satisfied, replete'?"}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):23 for a conjectural loanword hypothesis from Persian.

Source: 83[439{related to Ir. *xad- 'to beat, strike, hurt'?}]

83[346{S.v. Proto-Iranic *skar- 'to pursue, drive, look for (cattle)', no certain cognates outside of Iranic. Cf. also Middle Persian šklk /škarag/ '(bird of) prey', (+ *u̯i-) wškl /wiškar/ 'hunting-ground, wilderness'.}]
Comment: cf. Parthian iškar- and Zoroastrian Middle Persian wiškar "hunting ground, wilderness"; Cheung (2007: 345) puts this verb to an Iranic root *skar- "pursue, drive, look for (the cattle)".
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives and light-verb constructions continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *skar- 'to pursue, drive'; no known etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):346).

Comment: Not in Morgenstierne (2003)

Source: 156[IV:245-246{S.v. Oss. xūdyn : xūdt | xodun : xudt 'смеяться', from Ir. *xand- 'смеяться'.}];83[442-443{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *xand- 'to laugh'. "This root is most likely expressive/onomatopoeic in origin, cf. Gk. καχάζω 'I laugh', Lat. cachinnō 'laugh loudly', OCS xoxotati 'to laugh loudly', Lith. kikénti 'to giggle', etc."}];269[{In view of Nuristani cognates, we should reconstruct Proto-Indo-Iranian *kʰand- for root ref. form.}];442[200{For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 3815 *khandati 'laughs'.}]
Justification: Nuristani and Iranic lexemes fom Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand- 'to laugh' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):200 no. 3815, [Cheung 2007](src-83):442-443).

Source: 165[48{S.v. Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg'. No further etymology.}];397[105-106{S.v. NHG Bein (MHG bein, OHG bein, OS bēn), from Gmc. *baina- 'Knochen', also in ON bein, OE bān, OFr. bēn. A word with this meaning is not attested in Gothic. A Germanic replacement for the IE inherited word for 'bone' (cf. Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.). The etymology of this new word is unclear.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (North and West Germanic, but no attestation from Gothic), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):48, [Kluge 2011](src-397):105-106).

Source: 141[215-216{S.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (IEW 467-9).}];567[213{Bactrian ζο-, ζοο- 'to live' < *ǰīwa- (cf. Khot. juv-).}];172[I:594{S.v. Ved. √jīv- 'leben', a secondary root re-analysed from a present stem < *gʷih₃-u̯e- (to PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- ~ *gʷei̯h₃-).}];83[222-223{S.v. Proto-Iranian *ǰaiH-¹ 'to live' < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-, *gʷi̯eh₃-/*gʷh₃i- 'to live'.}];66[505{S.v. ζώω 'to live' < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-, *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live'.}];345[683-684{S.v. TochB śāy- 'live', with TochA śo- from Proto-Tocharian *ćaw-, from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃-u̯-e/o-.}];79[356-357{S.v. keam 'to live', from PIE *gʷeih₃-, *gʷih₃-, or *gʷh₃i- 'to live'. Arm. keam probably reflects athematic *gʷeih₃-.}];81[562{S.v. Proto-Slavic *žiti 'live', from PIE *gʷh₃i(-u)-.}];54[685-686{S.v. Lat. vīvō, -ere 'to live', from PIE *gʷih₃-ue/o- 'to live'.}];50[67{S.v. Proto-Celtic *biwo- 'alive', from PIE *gʷiHu̯o- 'alive'.}];352[338-340{Cf. s.v. OLith. gývas 'lebend, lebendig' (from which gyvénti 'leben, existieren, sich aufhalten, wohnen')| BSl. cf. Latv. dzîvs 'lebendig, frisch, wach| ganz, heil, unverletzt| lauter, echt', dzîvuôt 'leben| wohnen| arbeiten, beschäftigt sein', OPr. adj. a.pl.m. geiwans 'lebendig', OCS živь 'lebendig' etc., from PIE *gʷih₃-u̯ó/éh₂- 'lebendig' (cf. Ved. jīvá- 'lebendig', OAv. juua- 'lebendig, lebend', OPers. jīva- 'id.', Gk. ζωός 'lebendig', Lat. vīvus 'lebendig', Osk. n.pl.m. bivus 'id.', OIr. béo 'lebendig', MW byw 'id.', Goth. qius 'lebendig').}]
Justification: Tocharian, Greek, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ([LIV²](src-141) 215-216, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):683-684, [Beekes 2010](src-66):505, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):356-357, [EWAia](src-172) I:594, [Cheung 2007](src-83):222-223, [ALEW](src-352) 338-340, [Derksen 2008](src-81):652, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):685-686, [Matasović 2009](src-50):67).

Source: 81[330{S.v. Proto-Slavic *mǫžь, from PIE *mon-g⁽ʷ⁾io- and to be connected with Sanskrit mánu- 'man, mankind' and OHG mann 'man, husband'.}];399[II:575-576{S.v. mánuḥ 'Mensch, Mann, Menschheit', to be connected with Germanic lexemes via Goth. manna, OHG man, etc. and OCS mǫžь, etc. The cognates should thus be derived from one of the PIE *men- roots. However, due to several homophonous *men- roots reconstructable for PIE it is difficult to determine from which one exactly [cf. LIV²: 435-437].}];269[{On the proposed cognacy of the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *mannan- to this class, cf. the notes in [cognate set 8248](cog-8248).}];458[20: 158-161{PS *mǫžĭ is related to Old Indic manu-, manus-, Old High German mann etc. and derived from PIE *manu-(s) or *monu-(s) 'man', further probably from *men- 'think'. The exact protoform for Slavic is *mon-g-i̯o-.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from a PIE root *men- ([KEWA](src-399) II:575-576, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:158-161, [Derksen 2008](src-81):330). Quite possibly (but not certainly) also cognate with Proto-Germanic *mannan- in [cognate set 8248](cog-8248), cf. further discussion in that cognate set.

Source: 320[89{S.v. Khot. ggūśta 'flesh, meat', from Iranian *gau-šti- 'produced from bovine'.}];172[I:478-480{S.v. Ved. gáv- 'Rind, Stier, Kuh', from PIE *gʷou̯- (cf. Gk. βοῦς, Umb. bum (acc.sg.), OIr. bó, OHG chuo, Latv. gùovs, TochA ko, TochB keᵤ 'Kuh', Luw. uu̯a-, Lyc. uwa- 'Rind', etc.).}]
Justification: Derived from IE *gʷou̯- 'cow' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):89, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:478-480).

Source: 567[206{Bactrian γαρο < *gari- (cf. Av. gairi-).}];172[I:487{S.v. Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe' (Iranian forms via YAv. gairi-, Khot. gara-, ggari-, Sogd. γar, Pashto γar), probably PIE *gʷr̥H-i- (cf. Alb. gur 'stone' OCS gora, 'mountain', Lith. girià 'forest').}];81[177-178{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gora 'mountain' (ESSJa VII 29-31), a derivative with the o-grade of the root *gʷrH- (cf. Lith. girià 'woods', Skt. girí- 'mountain, hill').}];458[7: 29-31{PS *gora is derived from PIE *gʷer- and related to Old Indic girí- 'mountian', Avestan gairi- 'mountian', Lithuanian girià 'forest' and Albanian gur 'rock'.}];352[332-333{Cf. s.v. Lith. girià 'Wald, Wüste, Wildnis', from PIE *gʷorH-/*gʷr̥H- 'bewaldeter Berg' (cf. OCS gora 'Berg, Gebirge, Höhe', Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe', YAv. gairí- 'Berg, Gebirge', Gk. βορέας, -ου 'Nordwind, Norden', Alb. gur 'Stein, Fels').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ([EWAia](src-172) I:487, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:29-31, [Derksen 2008](src-81):177-178, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 332-333).

Source: 315[53-59{Discusses the different reconstructions of the PIE word. }];80[517-519{S.v. Hitt. lāman- / lamn- 'name| reputation', from PIE *h₃néh₃mn (cf. Lat. nōmen, Skt. nā́man-, Goth. namo, Gk. ὄνομα, Phr. onoman, Arm. anun, OIr. ainm 'name', etc.). In Proto-Anatolian there was a nasal dissimilation *n … mn > *l … mn.}];66[1084-1085{S.v. ὄνομα, -ατος 'name' gramm. 'word', from PIE *h₃neh₃-mn, *h₃neh₃-mn-, *h₃nh₃-men- 'name'.}];345[288{S.v. TochB ñem* 'name', which along with TochA ñom reflect Proto-Tocharian *ñēmä, as though from PIE *h₁nēmn̥, a variant of the more usual *h₁nōmn̥ (cf. Skt. nā́ma, Av. nāma, Gk. ὄνομα, Arm. anun, etc.).}];79[96-97{S.v. Arm. anun 'name| fame', connected to the IE words for name (Gk. ὄνομα, Lat. nōmen, Skt. nā́man-, Goth. namo, OCS imę, etc.), from PIE *h₃éh₃-mn.}];105[87{S.v. Alb. emër ~ emën 'name', from Proto-Albanian *enmen- or *inmen, from PIE *(o)noHmn̥.}];172[II:35-37{S.v. Ved. nā́man- 'Name, Benennung, Kennzeichen, Wesen, Eigentumlichkeit', from PIE *Hnéh₃-men- (in paradigmatic ablaut with *Hnh₃-mn-, *Hnh₃-mon-), cf. Gk. ὄνομα (Dor. ενυμα- in personal names, Hom. νώνυμ[ν]ος 'nameless'), Arm. anown, Lat. nōmen, Goth. namo, OIr. ainm, OCS imę, Hitt. lāman- TochB ñem, TochA ñom, etc. 'Name'.}];353[556-557{S.v. OPruss. emmens. The Anlaut of the Old Prussian form points to an original zero-grade *h₃nh₃-men-.}];81[212{S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьmę 'name', from PIE *h₃nh₃-men- (cf. Skt. nā́man-, Gk. ὄνομα, Lat. nōmen, etc.).}];54[412-413{S.v. Lat. nōmen 'name', from PIE *h₃neh₃-mn, *h₃nh₃-men- 'name' (cf. OIr. ainm, Hitt. lāman, HLuw. álaman-, Skt. nā́man-, Av. nāman-, Gk. ὄνομα, Phryg. onoman, Arm. anown, Alb. emër (< *emën)| TochA ñom, TochB ñem, OPruss. emmens, OCS imę, Goth. namo, OE nama, OIc. nafn).}];50[38{S.v. Proto-Celtic *anman- 'name', from PIE *h₃nomn 'name' (cf. Hitt. lāman-, Skt. nā́man-, Lat. nōmen, Gk. ὄνομα, Goth. namo, OPruss. emmens, Russ. ímja, Alb. emër, TochB ñom, Arm. anun).}];269[{Certain details of the reconstruction of the PIE word are disputed (cf. Stüber 1998:53-59), but a general shape *Hneh₃-mn̥ with different ablaut variants of the root and suffix tend to be agreed upon. Debate on the identity of the initial laryngeal as *h₁ or *h₃ hinge on interpretation of the Doric Greek forms in ἐνυμα- versus the ὄνομα forms more commonly found elsewhere.}];369[165{S.v. Alb. ém/ër, -ri 'Name| Benennung'. From the IE inherited word for 'name' (cf. OCS imę, OPr. emnes, OIr. ainm, etc.).}];165[382-383{S.v. Proto-Germanic *namōn- 'name', from PIE *h₃nh̥₃-men- (cf. Hitt. lāman- 'name', HLuv. álaman- 'id.', Lyc. alãman 'id.', TochA ñom, TochB ñem 'id.', Skt. nāman-, Av. nāman 'id.', Gk. ὄνομα 'id.' Phryg. onoman 'id.', Arm. anun 'id.' Alb. emër 'id.', OCS imę, OPr. emmens 'id.').}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting the Indo-European inherited word for 'name' (cf. [EIEC](src-657) 390-391). Certain details of the reconstruction of the PIE word are disputed (cf. [Stüber 1998](src-315):53-59), but a general shape *Hneh₃-mn̥ with different ablaut variants of the root and suffix tend to be agreed upon. Debate on the identity of the initial laryngeal as *h₁ or *h₃ hinge on interpretation of the Doric Greek forms in ἐνυμα- versus the ὄνομα forms more commonly found elsewhere (cf. esp. discussions of [EWAia](src-172) II:35-37, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1084-1085). Cf. also [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):517-519, [Adams 2013](src-345):288, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):96-97, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):165, [Orel 1998](src-105):87, [Derksen 2015](src-353):556-557, [Derksen 2008](src-81):212, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):382-383, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):412-413, [Matasović 2009](src-50):38).

Source: 172[620 (Vol. I){"Diese Grundform is nicht ganz sicher [...]"}];363[II:337-338{S.v. Kurd. tang 'тесный, узкий, стесненный, тонкий, тугой, душный', from IIr. *tanka-, cf. Pers. tang, MPers. tang, Bel. tanak, Zaza tang, etc.}]
Justification: Iranic words for 'narrow' are better derived from *temk-, cf. already Horn 1893: 89 and Cheung 2007: 377f. Derivation from *tanu-ka- (thus e.g. Korn 2005: 168) might be formally possible but does not really explain the semantic difference found in Persian tang 'narrow' vs. tanuk 'thin'. None of the Iranic forms meaning 'narrow' require *tanu- or *tana-, while there is good evidence for a root *tank-/tanč- 'tp strain, press'.

Source: 320[174{S.v. Khot. naysda- 'near', from base nazda-, (Av. nazdyō 'nearer', nazdišta- 'nearest', NPers. nazd, nazdīk, Balōčī nazīk, nazī, Pašto nažde, etc.), cf. Ved. nédīyas-.}];172[II:55-56{Cf. s.v. Ved. nédiyas- (comp.) 'näher, sehr nahe', from PIIr. *nazdii̯as-. The analysis of the stem from an Indo-European perspective is unclear. The positive, attested via OAv. asna-, YAv. asna-, OPers. ašna- 'near' may perhaps be from *n̥sd-no-, perhaps to *na- 'dazu' + IE *sed- 'sitzen'| also questionable is the possible connection to Osc. nessimas 'proximae' to IE *ned-.}]

Proto-Celtic *nowyo- 'new', from PIE *neuos 'new'.}];352[690-691{S.v. OLith. naũjas 'neu, jung' (BSl. OPr. nawans 'neu', OCS novъ 'neu', etc.), from PIE *néu̯-i̯o-, 'neu', *néu̯-o- 'id.' (cf. Hitt. nēwa- 'neu', Ved. návya- 'id.', YAv. nauua- 'neu, frisch', Gk. νέος 'neu, jung', Myc. ne-wo, ne-wa 'neu', Lat. novus, -a, -um 'neu', OIr. núae 'neu', MW newydd  'id.', Goth. niujis 'neu', TochA ñu, etc.).}];458[26: 9-13{S.v. Not the same root as PIE *neu̯- 'to nod, tilt (the head)' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 455-456)

Source: 172[I:424{S.v. Ved. kṣap- 'Nacht', from a PIIr. root noun *kšap-, from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- (cf. Hitt. ispant- 'Nacht').}];156[IV:230-231{S.v. æxsæv | æxsævæ 'ночь', from Ir. *xšap- or *xšapan- (cf. OPers. *kšap-, Pers., Tadj. šab, Kurd. šäw, šəv, Yaghn. xšap-, Sogd. *axšap- ('γšp-, 'xšp-), Khot. ṣṣava, Av. xšap-, xšapan-).}];80[404{S.v. Hitt. išpant- 'night'. Source: 323[68{S.v. Paš. pˈoza 'nose', "hardly directly < *pauzā- […] but via Prs poz(a) 'muzzle, snout, parts around the mouth'" cf. Bal. pō(n)z 'nose' (LWs < Prs or Pš?).}]

Source: 81[138-139, 212-213{S.v. Proto-Slavic *edinъ, *edьnъ 'one' from *h₁ed -(H)iH-no-.  The origin of the initial element *ed- < *(h₁)edʰ- is unclear. Source: 156[III:208-210{S.v. Oss. syrx | surx 'красный', from Proto-Iranian *suxra- (cf. Av. suxra- 'red', OPers. θuxra-).}];172[II:645, 655-656{Cf. s.v. Ved. śukrá- 'klar, licht, hell, lauter, weiß, weißlich' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. suxra- 'rot, feuerfarben', OPers. θuxra-, MPers. suxr, Oss. syrx/surx 'rot', etc.). Derived to √soć-, possibly from PIE *k̑eu̯k- (connections outside of IIr. uncertain).}];567[265{Bactrian σορχιυο 'red'? attested in the name of an estate σορχιυο λιζακο, perhaps 'the red fort' (cf. Av. suxra-, NP surx 'red') + suffix -ιγο. Alternatively possible is 'the fort on the river Surkhab'.}];141[331{Cf. s.v. 1. *k̑eu̯k- 'aufflammen, erglühen' (IEW 597). Only Indo-Iranian, probably not to be connected with Gk. κύκνος 'Schwan' as 'der leuchtend Weiße'.}]
Justification: Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:208-210).
Parallel loans from Persian دريا / daryā; cf. 'lake' in [cognate set 2771](cog-2771) and 'sea' in [cognate set 2011](cog-2011).

Source: 172[II:728{S.v. Ved. síkata- 'Sand, Kies, Grieß' not to be separated from Iranian cognates: OPers. θikā- 'Kies, Schotter', Khot. siyata, Sogd. šykth, Pashto šəga, səga 'sand', Oss. syǵyt/sigit, sik’it 'Erde', etc.}];529[{The initial consonant cannot be reconstructed for PII because Vedic si : OP θi- does not conform to any regular Indo-Iranian sound correspondence. This word is highly likely to be a parallel loan with initial sound substitution or the like.}];442[772{S.v. 13386 Skt. síkatā f. 'grain of sand', (usu. pl.) 'sand, gravel'. Nuristani and Dardic forms attest IA ś- corresponding to Ir. θ- and s- (OPers. θikā-, Bal. six, Pasht. šəga, etc.), suggesting that the s- forms of Skt. and Dardic may be loans or influenced by Iranic.}]
Comment: cf. Vedic síkatā-, later sigatā- unlike Old Persian θikā- 'pebbles', cf. also cognate/7858/
Justification: The correspondence of Indic initial *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):772, no. 13386); [EWAia](src-172) II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

Source: 363[I:110{S.v. Kurd. bahr, bar, bár | baḥr 'море', loanword from Arab. baḥr 'море'.}]
Justification: Loan from Arabic بحر / baḥr 'sea' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:110).

Source: 83[60{S.v. Proto-Iranian *darb- (*darf-) 'to join, tie, sew (together)', from PIE *derbʰ- 'to bind together, braid' (cf. Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *derb- 'to join, tie, sew (together)', and further to PIE ?*derbʰ- 'to bind together, braid' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 121).

Source: 172[I:645, 668-669{S.v. Ved. tigmá- adj. 'scharf, spitzig, heiß'| cf. Gk. στιγμός 'a prick'. Derived from Ved. √tej- 'scharf machen, zuspitzen', from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein'.}];156[I:325{S.v. Oss. cyrǧ | cirǧ 'острый', from PIIr. *tigra-, cf. Av. tiγra-, Ved. tigra-.}];141[592-593{Cf. s.v. *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (IEW 1016-7).}];442[332-333{S.v. 5839 Ved. tīkṣṇá- 'sharp' RV., 'hot, pungent' MBh. 2. *trīkṣṇa- 'sharp'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *√tej- 'to sharpen' from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'prick, be sharp' ([EWAia](src-172) I: 645, 668-669, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 592-593). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes attached to this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):332-333, no. 5839.

Source: 271[1168{S.v. πετσί, from Medieval Greek πετσί(ο)ν < πέτσ(α)-ίον or *πεσκίον, diminutive of Hellenistic Greek πέσκος 'skin'.}];66[1180{S.v. πέσκος 'skin, rind'. No clear etymology.}];270[890{S.v. πέσκος 'peau, écorce'. An obscure technical term. Cf. entry for references to various suggestions.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes, ultimately from an Ancient Greek diminutive formation πέσκος 'skin, rind'. Further etymology uncertain cf. [Andriotis 1999](src-271):1168, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):890, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1180.

Source: 80[439{S.v. Hitt. kappi-/kappai- 'small, little', from PIE *kmb-(e)i- (cf. also Lyd. καμβειν 'grandchild'), cognate with Iranian words for 'small', e.g. Av. kamna-, OPers. kamna-. The Iranian cognates which must reflect *km̥b-no- (*kembʰ- would be against IE root constraints).}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of PIE *kemb- 'small', assuming a connection with Proto-Iranic *kamb- 'lesser' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):439, cf. [Schmitt 2014](src-358):198-199 s.v. OPers. *kamna-).

Source: 81[132{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dỳmъ m. 'smoke' (ESSJa V 203), from PIE *dʰuH-mó- (cf. Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, vapour', Gk. θυμός 'heart, passion, courage', Lat. fūmus 'smoke, vapour').}];141[158{Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen' (IEW 262-263).}];80[895{Cf. s.v. Ved. dhūmá- 'Rauch' (Ir., cf. Khot. dumä 'Rauch', etc.), from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- (cf. Lat. fūmus, Lith. dū́mai, Latv. dũmi, OCS dymъ 'Rauch', Gk. θυμός 'vitale und physische Energie, seelische geistige Instanz, Geist, Sinn, Mut, Zorn).}];353[145{S.v. Lith. dū́mai 'smoke' (Latv. dũmi 'smoke'), from PIE *dʰuH-mó- (cf. OCS dymъ, Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, vapour', Gk. θυμός 'heart, passion, courage', Lat. fūmus 'smoke, vapour').}];54[249{S.v. Lat. fūmus 'smoke, fumes', from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- 'smoke, fume' (cf. Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, fume', Gk. θυμός 'spirit', OPr. dumis 'smoke', Lith. dū́mai 'smoke', OCS dymъ 'smoke', OHG toum 'steam').}];50[111{S.v. Proto-Celtic *dwīyot- 'smoke' [Noun], probably from PIE *duh₂-i̯o-, which developed to *dʰu̯īi̯o- (the immediate proto-form of Lat. suf-fio, to which a dental suffix was added in Celtic > Proto-Celtic *dwīyot-.}];299[61{Cf. for discussion regarding the stem formation of Old Irish dé and related Celtic forms.}];352[243{S.v. OLith. dū́mas 'Rauch' (BSl. cf. Latv. dũmi 'Rauch', OPr. dumis 'Rauch', OCS dymъ 'Rauch, Dampf, Dunst', etc.), from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- 'Rauch, Dampf' (cf. Ved. dhūmá- 'Rauch', Gk. θῡμός 'Mut, Gemüt, Sinn', Lat. fūmus 'Rauch, Dampf'.}];458[5: 203{PS *dymŭ is related to Old Indic dhūmá-, Latin fūmus, Lithuanian dū́mai etc. and derived from PIE *dhūmo-.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):895, [EWAia](src-172) I:795, [ALEW](src-352) 243, [Derksen 2015](src-353):145, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:203, [Derksen 2008](src-81):132, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):249, [Matasović 2009](src-50):111, [Irslinger 2002](src-299):61; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158).
Loanword from Arabic صاف / ṣāf

Source: 49[1149{Cf. s.v. *u̯ep- : u̯ō̆p- : up- ‚Wasser‘.}];320[305-306{S.v. Khot. baura 'snow', from PIr. vafrā- to base *vap- 'throw up, heap up' (cf. Av. vafra-, Zor.P. vafr, NPers. barf, barfēn, Sogd. (Bud.) wβrh, M.Pers.T. wpr wdzyd 'snow melts', Pašto wāwra, Orm. yōṣ̌r, yōṣ̌, Parāčī γarp. Yidγa warfo, Waxī warf), to IEW 1149 *u̯ep- (Ved. vápati 'scatters (seed)', vápra- 'earth mound').}];172[II:503-505{Cf. s.v. Ved. vaprā- 'Feuerstätte', vafra- 'Erdaufwurf, Wall', derived from Ved. √vap-¹ 'streuen, ausstreuen' (further connections unclear). Ved. vapra- is formally comparable to Ir. *u̯afrā̆- 'Schnee' (cf. YAv. vafra-, Khot. borā-, MPers. wafr, NP barf).}];399[III:145{S.v. Skt. vápraḥ 'Aufwurf von Erde, Erdwall / mound, earth raised as a wall'. Iranian forms in the meaning 'snow' from *vap-ra- are comparable. [Cf. entry in KEWA for further references].}];83[418-419{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ap- (1) 'to disperse, scatter' (cf. Skt. √vap- (1) 'to scatter, strew (out), spread (out)'). "The root is apparently IIr.: an IE provenance cannot be ascertained."}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯afra- 'snow', derivatives of an Indo-Iranic root *u̯ap- 'to disperse, scatter' to which there are no certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):418-419,[Bailey 1979](src-320):305-306, [EWAia](src-172) II:503-505, [KEWA](src-399) III:145).

Source: 274[348-354{S.v. *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ f. 'Stern' (IEW 1027f. EIEC 543). Cf. fn.1 with a discussion of a possible underlying verbal root as well as the assumption of a Semitic or Sumerian loanword.}];327[274{Proposes an etymology PIE *h₂h₁stér- 'star' < 'celestial fire', internally derived from an adverb *h₂h₁stér- 'pertaining (by contrast) to the burning', based on the root noun *h₂óh₁s- 'burning', whence 'fire'| cf. PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry up/wither by heat' (LIV² 257f.).}];54[585{S.v. Lat. stēlla 'star', from PItal. *stērla-, derived from PIE *h₂stēr-s, *h₂ster- 'star' (cf. OIr. ser, W. seren, Co. sterenn, Bret. sterenn < PCl. *ster-, OIr. sell 'iris' < *stillo-, MIr. sellaid 'to see', MW syllu 'to gaze', Bret. sellout 'to watch' < PCl. stīrlo- 'star' < PIE *h₂stēr-lo-| Hitt. hašter(a)- 'star' < *h₂ster-| Skt. tā́raḥ (nom.pl), stŕ̥bhiḥ (instr.pl.), Av. star-, Khot. stārra- 'star', Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, Arm. astł, Goth. stairno, TochB ścriye 'star'). The Italic forms reflect an additional adjectival suffix *-lo- added to nom.sg. stem *h₂stēr-, from which the new substantive 'star' was taken from the feminine form, i.e. Proto-Italic *stēr-lā- > Lat. stēlla.}];80[326{S.v. Hitt. ḫašter(a)- 'star', from PIE *h₂ster- (cf. Gk. ἀστήρ, Arm. astł, Skt. stár-, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno 'star').}];66[156-157{S.v. ἀστήρ, -έρος 'star', from PIE *h₂ster- 'star' (cf. Hitt. ḫašterza, Arm. astł, OIr. ser, Goth. stairno, ToB ścriye, Av. stār-əm (acc.sg.), Skt. tā́raḥ (nom.pl.), stŕ̥-bhiḥ (ins.pl.), Lat. stēlla).}];345[701{S.v. TochB ścriye 'star', which with TochA śre* reflect PToch *scär-ii̯ē, which seems evidently to be related to Gk. ἀστήρ, Hitt. ḫaštēr-, Skt. ins.pl. str̥bhiḥ, nom.pl. tāraḥ, OIr. ser, Goth. stairno, Lat. stēlla, all 'star'.}];79[120-122{S.v. Arm. astł 'star'. Since long compared with Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, Skt. nom.pl. tā́raḥ, ins.pl. stŕ̥-bhiḥ, Av. star-, Pers. sitāra, Goth. stairno, Lat. stēlla, etc. from PIE *h₂ster-. The 'prothetic' a- in Greek and Armenian is the regular outcome of PIE *h₂-.}];172[II:755-756{S.v. Ved. stár- 'Stern' (RV ins.pl. stŕ̥bhiḥ, nom.pl. tā́raḥ [RV 8.55.2]| OAv., YAv. star-, etc.), from PIE *h₂stér- (cf. Hitt. ḫa-aš-te-er-za, Gk. ἀστήρ, Arm. astł, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno, etc.).}];179[322{S.v. Goth. S131. *stairno 'ἀστήρ', 'star' (Crimean Gothic *stern 'stella', misprinted as stein), from PIE *(s)tēr- (cf. Skt. stár-, Av. stārəm (acc.sg.), Gk. ἀστήρ, Lat. stella, etc.).}];165[478{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ster(r)a/jōn- 'star', as though from PIE *h₂stér-on- (cf. Hitt. ḫašter- 'star', TochA śre, TochB ścriye, 'id.', Skt. stár-, OAv., YAv. star-, NP sitāra, Oss. st’aly | (æ)st’alu, Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, OIr. ser < *h₂ster-| Arm. astł, Lat. stella < *h₂ster-l-eh₂).}];50[355{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sterā 'star', from PIE *h₂stēr- 'star' (IEW 1028), cf. Hitt. hasterz, Gk. ἀστήρ, Lat. stēlla, Goth. stairno. OIr. ser is a hapax in one of the Leinster eulogies, therefore the PCelt. reconstruction is unknown. Gaul. sirona, if it is from the same etymon, perhaps contains the original lengthened grade of the nom.sg. *h₂stēr >> PCelt. *stīr-ōnā.}];673[110{S.v. No. 10 [Arm.] astł 'star', derived from PIE *h₂ster-, where the final -ł- has been suggested as due to a blend with PIE *seh₂u̯ol 'sun', otherwise lost in Armenian (cf. Olsen 1999:159-160, partly followed by Martirosyan 2010:122).}];442[330{S.v. 5798 Skt. tārā- f. 'fixed star' Yājñ., tā́raḥ nom.pl. RV. 2. tā́rakā- f. 'star' AV. 3. *tārikā-. 4. tāraká- 'belonging to the stars' VS.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ 'star' ([NIL](src-274) 348-354, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):326, [Adams 2013](src-345):701, [Beekes 2010](src-66):156-157, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):120-122, [Clackson 2017](src-673):110, [EWAia](src-172) II:755-756, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5798, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):322, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):478, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):585, [Matasović 2009](src-50):355). For a proposed deep etymological connection with PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry up/wither by heat' cf. [Pinault 2007](src-327).

Comment: Not listed in Morgenstierne 2003.

Justification: Light verb constructions with loanwords from Arabic فكر / fikr 'thought' as the semantic head.

141[373{S.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾su̯ei̯bʰ- '(sich) schwingen' (IEW 625, 1041).}];399[I:289{S.v. Skt. kṣipáti 'wirft, schleudert / throws, flings'. Further connections are hardly certain| the closest possibilities are Ru. šibátь 'werfen', šibkij 'schnell'.}];172[I:437{S.v. Ved. √kṣep- 'schleudern, werfen', not to be separated from YAv. xšuuaēβa- 'sich rasch schwingend, schnellend'.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 373, [EWAia](src-172) I:437, [KEWA](src-399) I:289 for discussion of potential Slavic comparanda). [LIV²](src-141) reconstructs as though from ?*k⁽ʷ⁾su̯ei̯bʰ- 'to swing (oneself)'.

Comment: The alleged similarity with cognate 503 is probably accidental. Korn (2005: 189) seems to follow Horn (1893: 121) who derives these words from the PP of the Old Iranic verb *drang- "make strong/firm". Cf. Cheung (2007: 76) *dregʰ-.

Source: 342[1-141{For a survey of the numeral 'two' in Indo-European, cf. pp. 1-141.}];80[826-827{Cf. s.v. Hitt. tān 'for the second time, again, subordinately'. 274[311–317{S.v. *h₂ep- 'Wasser, Fluß' (IEW 1,51f., 1149, EIEC 486, 636).}];172[I:81-82{S.v. Ved. áp- 'Wasser', from PIE *h₂ep- (cf. Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE root noun *h₂ep- 'water, river' ([NIL](src-274) 311-317, [EWAia](src-172) I:81-82, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):19 no.407).

Justification: Probably a loanword from Turkic, but not fully certain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:259-260).

Source: 141[478–479{Cf. s.v. *peth₂- ‘ausbreiten’}];389[71{1.*peth₂- → *(s)peth₂-| S mobile wegen lat. spatium ‘Raum’, SCHUMACHER/MATZINGER 974 }];49[824–825{1. pet ‚ausbreiten‘, bes. die Arme}];325[67{Sarikoli < **fraϑna-?}]

Comment: Cognate class A should be reserved for borrowings from Persian, not for Persian itself.

Justification: Etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) I:427).
