Manichaean Sogd. kyrm- 'Schlange', MPers. klm (kirm) 'Wurm, Drache, Schlange', NPers. kirm 'Wurm, Schlange'), from PIE *kʷr̥mi- (cf. OIr. cruim, W., Bret. pryf 'Wurm', Lith. kirmìs 'Wurm, Schlange', Sloven. čr̂m 'Fingerwurm, Karbunkel', etc.). Beside *kʷr̥mi- exists "a rhyme formation in Indo-European probably for reason of tabu" *u̯r̥mi- (NHG Wurm, cf. Lat. vermis), (so Watkins 1987:288).}];696[288{"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu| kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'| compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."}];353[246{S.v. Lith. kirmìs 'worm, maggot, snake' (Latv. cirmis 'worm, maggot, snake, caterpillar', OPr. girmis 'maggot'), from PIE *kʷr-m-i- (cf. OCS črъvь 'worm', Skt. kŕ̥mi- 'worm, maggot', OIr. cruim 'worm', W. pryf 'id.').}];105[197{S.v. Alb. krimb ~ krym 'worm', reflecting PAlb. *krim- and to be connected with IE *kʷr̥mi- 'id.' (cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Lith. kìrmis etc.).}];369[225-226{S.v. Alb. krimb, -i 'Wurm, Raupe, Made', the inherited word for 'Wurm', with Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made', Lith. kirmìs 'Made' and formally identical with PIE *kʷr̥mi-.}];50[181-182{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrimi- 'worm', from PIE *kʷrmi- 'worm' (IEW 1152), cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Alb. krimb, Lith. kirmìs, Sloven. črm.}];81[93-94{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot' (ESSJa IV 171-172), from Balto-Slavic *kir-m/w-i- (cf. Lith. kirmìs 'worm, maggot, snake', Latv. cirmis 'worm, maggot, caterpillar', OPr. girmis 'maggot'), from PIE *kʷr-m-i- (cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi- 'worm, maggot', OIr. cruim 'worm', W pryf 'worm'). Note the Balto-Slavic vocalisation *ir (instead of *ur) after an original labiovelar is unexpected.}];458[IV:171-172{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrvь, very close to *čьrmь in the same meaning as attested in PSl. *čьrmelь, *čьrmъ, *čьrmьnъ. IE correspondence can be given for *čьrmь, but *čьrvь is less convincing. Possibly formed to the same element with different *-m-/*-v- formants. Alternatively perhaps the form in *-v arose under influence from other lexemes.}];352[493-494{S.v. OLith. kirmìs 'Wurm' (BSl. Latv. cirmis 'Wurm, Made, Raupe' OPr. ? girmis 'Made', OCS črьvь 'Wurm', etc.), from PIE *kʷr̥-mi- 'Wurm, Made', Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made', NPers. kirm 'Wurm', Alb. krimb 'Wurm, Raupe, Made', OIr. Cruim 'Wurm, Made| Drache', MW pryf 'Insekt, Larve, Made, Wurm| Schlange', etc.).}];54[665{Cf. s.v. Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot', from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' (cf. Goth. waurms 'snake', OIc. ormr, OEng. wyrm, OFr. wirm 'snake', OS wormo, OHG wurm, 'worm' < PGmc. *wurma/i-). Cf. the PIE doublet *kʷrmi- 'worm, maggot', possibly secondarily from PIE *kʷrmi- > *wrmi- in Lat. and Germanic.}]
Justification: Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. [Watkins 1987](src-696):288). Cf. also [Demiraj 1997](src-369):225-226, [Orel 1998](src-105):197, [EWAia](src-172) I:394-395, [ALEW](src-352) 493-494, [Derksen 2015](src-353):246, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:171-172 [Derksen 2008](src-81)93-94, [Matasović 2009](src-50):181-182.

Source: 165[38{S.v. Proto-Germanic *askōn- f. 'ashes', but notes that it remains problematic to bring the Gothic form and the North and West Germanic forms together. Thus he proposes an alternative source form gmc. *adᶻdʰgʰ- from a compound formed from the roots ie. *h₂ed- 'to desiccate' and *dʰegʷʰ- 'to burn'.}];383[365f.{Also reconstructs Proto-Germanic *askōn from Proto-Indo-European *az-g-, inspite of the problem to connect the Gothic form to it. The extended stem *az-g- might appear in Armenian ačiwn, as well.}];80[318-319{S.v. Hitt. ḫāšš- (c.) 'ashes', from PIE *h₂eh₁s- (cf. Skt. ā́sa- 'ash', OHG essa 'ash', ON aRina 'ash', Lat. ārēre 'to dry', OLat. āsa 'altar', TochAB ās- 'to dry out', Hitt. ḫāšša- 'hearth').}];179[54{S.v. Goth. A245. *azgo 'σποδός', 'ashes' (OI aska, OE asca, æsca, OHG asca 'ashes'). From PIE *ā̆s- 'burn' (Arm. ačiun, Skt. ā́sas 'ashes, dust', Lat. areō 'to dry', Hitt. ḫašša- 'ashes, hearth').}];397[64, 260{S.v. NHG Asche (MHG asche, OHG asca, MLG asche) from Germanic *aska- 'Asche', also found in ON aska, OE æsce, beside *azgo- in Goth. azgo. Probably a formation belonging to IE *has- 'Herd' (cf. similarly Ved. ā́sa- Hitt. hašš- 'Asche')| cf. also NHG Esse 'Feuerherd, Schmiedefeuer' (MHG esse, OHG essa, from Gmc. *esjō 'Esse', also in OSw. æsja), outside of Germanic compare Lat. āra 'Brandaltar' Hitt. hašš- 'Herd, Feuerstelle')}];172[I:182-183{S.v. Ved. ā́sa- 'Asche, leicht verfliegender Staub', connected with an IE root *h₂es- 'brennen, vertrocknen' (cf. Lat. āridus 'trocken', OHG asca 'Asche', etc.).}];755[6];141[257-258{Cf. s.v. *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).}];442[67{Cf. s.v. 1476 ā́sa- (2) *'throwing', m. 'ashes, light dust' AV.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry out (by means of heat)'. The Germanic forms in this class are generally connected to this group although the morphological derivation remains obscure, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):54, [EWA 1](src-383):365-366, [Kluge 2011](src-397):64, 260, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):38. Cf. also [Lubotsky 1985](src-755):6. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257-258, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):318-319; see also [EWAia](src-172) I:182-183). For Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes connected to this class cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):67 no.1476.

Source: 165[48{S.v. Proto-Germanic *baka-, as though from PIE *bʰog-o-, but there are no clear cognates outside of Germanic. Borrowed into Slavic as OCS bokъ m. 'side'. Cf. n-stem *bakan- > OHG bahho, MHG bache, MDu. bake m. 'bacon'.}];397[80-81{Cf. NHG Bache '(wildes) Mutterschein', by semantic extension from the earlier meaning 'Schinken, Speckseite', cf. OHG bahho, MLG bake 'Rücken, Speckseite'| English bacon via Old French bacon borrowed from OHG bahho), probably based on Germanic *baka- 'Rücken' (cf. ON bak, OE bæc, OFr. bek, OS bak, OHG bah).}];383[418{S.v. OHG bacho. pacho 'Rücken, dorsum| Schinken, Speckseite'. The form is an exclusively Germanic formation, but one might consider a root *bʰeg- : *bʰog- '(sich) biegen, wölben' and in this case consider is applied to the parts of the human or animal body.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *baka-, possibly to a root *bʰeg- 'to bend, arch', but there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ([EWA 1](src-383):418, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):48, [Kluge 2011](src-397):80-81).

Source: 141[566-567{S.v. *slei̯g̑- 'schmieren, glatt machen' (IEW 663-664). OHG slīhhan 'schleichen' is a secondary e-grade thematic e-present.}];397[809{S.v. NHG schlecht (MHG sleht, OHG sleht, sliht, OS sliht), from PGmc. *slihta- 'eben, geglättet', also in Goth. slaihts, ON sléttr, OE sliht, OFr. sliuht, an adjective from an original to-participle to the verb schleichen (cf. MHG slīchen, OHG slīhhan, MLG sliken), to which can be compared outside of Germanic to OIr. fo-slig 'überschmiert'.}];556[428-429{Cf. s.v. *sleik-a- 'schleichen', with derived adj. *slih-ta- 'schlicht, glatt' (cf. OIr. fo-slig 'überschmiert', (OCS) slьzъkъ 'schlüpfrig, glatt', Gk. λίγδην 'oberflächlich berührend, streifend'), perhaps to be analysed as a more basic root *(s)lei̯- 'schleichen, kriechen' or a contamination with *lei̯- 'kleben, schleimig sein'.}];269[{Root reconstruction *(s)lei̯g̑- follows LIV² (cf. s.v., n1 comparing Gk. λίγδην 'oberflächlich berührend', OCS slьzъkъ). For older hypotheses connecting the lexemes related to OHG slīhhan, etc. to a potentially unextended root *(s)lei̯-, cf. Seebold (1970:428-429). No lemma for OHG slīhhan, etc. in Kroonen (2013).}]

54[138{S.v. Lat. cortex, -icis 'bark of a tree', from PIE *k(o)rt- 'a cutting' (cf. Skt. kr̥ntáti, YAv. kərəṇta- 'to cut', Arm. kʻertʻem 'to peel off the skin', Lith. kir̃sti 'to hew off, cut', OHG herdo 'skin, hide', OE heorda 'hide'. Latin cortex was formed with a productive suffix -ek- (also found in caudex 'tree-trunk', frutex 'shrub').}];316[144-145{S.v. Lat. cortex, -icis 'écorce', connected to the group of Lith. kertù 'je coupe, j'abats', OCS črъtǫ, črěsti 'couper', kratъkъ 'court', Skt. kr̥ntáti, Av. kərəntaiti 'il coupe', etc.}]
Justification: Derivatives from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):144-145, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):138, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560), often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 556-7).

Source: 165[187, 189{S.v. Proto-Germanic *grauta- 'coarse' from PIE *gʰroud-o-, a regular o-grade adjective to the strong verb *greutan- 'to grind, crush' (< *gʰréud-e-, cf. Lith. grū́sti 'to thrust, pestle, stamp' < *gʰrud-ie-, Ru. grúda- 'heap, pile', SCr. grȕda 'clod, lump' < *gʰroud-eh₂-). In the West-Germanic languages, a meaning shifts towards 'big' took place replacing *mekila- 'big'.}];352[374{Cf. s.v. OLith. grū́sti 'stampfen, stoßen, härten' (BSl. Latv. grûst, 'stoßen, stampfen'), from PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'zerstoßen, zerstampfen' (cf. ON grjót 'Gestein, Geröll', grautr 'Grütze', OE grēot 'Sand, Kies' [LIV² -, IEW 460f.].}];397[376-377{S.v. NHG groß (MHG grōz, OHG grō, OS grōt), from West Germanic *grauta- 'groß' also found in OE grēat, OFr. grāt, ON grautr 'Grütze', so that it is developed from a meaning 'grob gemahlen'. Formally the adjective corresponds to Lith. graudùs 'spröde, bröckelig'. Cf. the verb *greut-a 'zerreiben, zermahlen'.}];556[242{Cf. s.v. PGmc. *greut-a- (2) '(zerreiben)', only attested through a past passive participle, may be compared with Lith. grū́džiu (grū́du), grū́sti 'stampfen, zerstoßen, drängen'.}]
Comment: from PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'to pound, to mash' (Kroonen 2013:187, Kluge 2002:375, ALEW 374; not in LIV²).
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *grauta- 'strong, thick, big', further from PIE *gʰrou̯d-o-, cf. the Germanic strong verb *greutan- 'to grind, crush' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):187, 189, [Kluge 2011](src-397):376-377, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):256, [Seebold 1970](src-556):242, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 374).

Source: 165[146, 157{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fugla- 'bird'. The form is likely to have developed from *flug-la- (by dissimilation) and may have been derived from *fleugan- 'to fly' (< *pléuk-e-, cf. Lith. plaũkti 'to swim, float' < *plouk-ie- and Lith. plùnksna 'feather' < *plu-n-k-sneh₂-).}];179[130{S.v. Goth. F101. *fugls 'πετεινόν', 'bird'. "Probably from *flug-la- with loss of l by dissimilation". If so, then from PIE *pleu-k- (as in Lith. plaũkti 'swim', plùnksna 'feather'). Cf. entry in Lehmann for references to other hypotheses.}];141[488{Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An enlargement of *pleu̯- only found in Germanic and Baltic.}];441[433-436{S.v. OHG fogal 'Vogel'. The most probable etymology is from a Proto-Germanic original form *flugla- with a -la- suffix, in which the first resonant was dissimilated, and connected to Pre-Proto-Germanic *pleuk-e/o- 'schweben, schwimmen', to the -k- enlarged root *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (to more widespread attested *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben').}]
Justification: Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.

Source: 165[65{S.v. Proto-Germanic *bītan 'to bite, be sharp', from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' (cf. Skt. binátti 'to split, break, destroy', Lat. findō, -ere, 'split, cleave' < *bʰi-né-d-ti, *bʰi-n-d-énti, Gk. φείδομαι 'to spare, save, refrain from').}];141[70-71{S.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).}];179[68{S.v. Goth. B41. *beitan 'δάκνειν', 'bite', from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' (cf. Skt. bhinádmi, aor. bhed 'split'| Gk. φείδομαι 'spare', from 'separate oneself from'| Lat. findō, pf. fidī 'split').}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *bītan- 'to bite, be sharp', further derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' ([LIV²](src-141) 70-71, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):65, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):68).

Source: 388[392{S.v. Proto-Germanic *su̯artaz, related to Lat. sordēs 'dirt' from *sordus < *su̯ordo- 'dirty'.}];179[333{Gothic s.v. S177 *swarts (only acc. swart), from PIE *swordo-s 'black, dirty', cf. Lat. sordēs 'dirt', sordidus 'dirty', sordeō 'be dirty' from adj. *sordus 'dirty'.}];397[833{S.v. NHG schwarz (MHG swarz, OHG swarz, OS swart), from Germanic *swarta- (adj.), also found in Goth. *swarts (Goth. swartizl 'Tinte'), ON svartr, OE sweart. Outside of Germanic one may perhaps compare Lat. sordēs 'Schmutz', sordidus 'schmutzig'. Further provenance unclear.}];49[1052{Cf. s.v. *su̯ordo-s 'schwarz, schmutzfarben'.}];269[{Generally connected to Lat. sordēs 'dirt' and derivatives (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1052, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):333, [Orel 2003](src-388):392| tentatively [Kluge 2011](src-397):833| cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):637, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):576 cited in [cognate set 4865](cog-4865)) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic. [Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)].}];697[574-575{S.v. Proto-Germanic *swarta- 'schwarz', to be connected with Latin sordeō 'bin schmutzig', sordēs 'Schmutz', sordidus 'schmutzig', based on an original adjective *sordus 'schmutzig', this is either identical via a preform *su̯ordo-, or corresponds to a zero-grade *su̯r̥do-.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes generally connected to Latin sordēs 'dirt' and derivatives (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1052, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):333, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):574-575, [Orel 2003](src-388):392; tentatively [Kluge 2011](src-397):833; cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):637, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):576 cited in [cognate set 4865](cog-4865)) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic. [Not [Kroonen 2013](src-165)].

Source: 165[70{S.v. Proto-Germanic *blōda-, a neuter collective created to either *blēan- 'to blow' or *blōan- 'to flow'.}];179[76-77{S.v. Goth. B85. bloϸ 'αἷμα', 'blood'. Etymology unclear. With a suffix *-to- Possibly to PIE *bʰlō- < *bʰel- 'swell, gush' as in *bloma-| alternatively *bleh₂- 'blow' as in *uf-blesan.}];397[135-136{S.v. NHG Blut (MHG bluot, OHG bluot, OS blōd), from Germanic *blōda- 'Blut' also in Goth. bloϸ, ON blóð, OE blōd, OFr. blōd. An exclusively Germanic word, which replaced the inherited IE words for 'blood', probably an epithet (or euphemism?), probably to PIE *bʰel- 'schwellen' ~ 'platzen' ~ 'fließen' (cf. Lat. fluere 'fließen', etc.) but the details remain unclear.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *blōda- 'blood'. The further root etymology remains uncertain, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):76-77, [Kluge 2011](src-397):135-136, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):68-70 for various proposals.

Source: 165[48{S.v. Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg'. No further etymology.}];397[105-106{S.v. NHG Bein (MHG bein, OHG bein, OS bēn), from PGmc. *baina- 'Knochen', also in ON bein, OE bān, OFr. bēn. The lexeme is not attested in Gothic. The word is a Germanic replacement for the IE inherited word for 'leg' (attested via Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.), but its origin is unclear.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (unattested in Gothic), further etymology obscure (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):105-106, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):48).

Source: 165[119-120{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ēϸman- ~ *ēdman- 'breathing, breath', from PIE *h₁eh₁t-mon- (cf. Skt. ātmán- 'soul, breath').}];172[I:164{Cf. s.v. Ved. ātmán- 'Hauch, Seele, Selbst', pointing to an apparent PIE paradigm with mobile ablaut *éh₁-mō(n), dat.sg. *h₁t-mén-ei̯, cf. OS âthum 'Atem'.}];383[393-394{Cf. s.v. OHG âtum 'Atem, Hauch', from Proto-Germanic *ǣđma-, related to Ved. ātmā́- 'Hauch, Seele, Selbst' from PIE *ētmē̆n-/mō̆n-.}];397[67{Cf. s.v. NHG Atem, (MHG ātem, OHG ātum, OS āđom < West Germanic *ǣd(u)ma-). From PIE ētmó- ‛Atem’, also in Ved. ātmā́ ‛Hauch, Seele’ (n-stem) and perhaps OIr. athach f. ‛Hauch, Wind’.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₁eh₁t-mon- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):119-120, [EWA 1](src-383):393-394, [Kluge 2011](src-397):67, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:164).

Source: 141[92-93, 219-220{S.v. *bʰrei̯H- 'schneiden' (IEW 166-7) and *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).  It is unclear to which root got. (+) brinnan 'brennen' belongs.}];165[77-78{S.v. Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn', assuming an etymology from a derived n-present from PIE *bʰreu̯h₁- 'to boil, brew' (cf. OIr. do-bruinn 'to flow, trickle' < *bʰru-n-h₁-ie-| Lat. ferveō, -ere 'to be hot, to boil' < *bʰéru̯h₁-e-).}];556[137-138{S.v. Gmc. *brenn-a- 'brennen'. If the sound law of PIE *gʷʰ- > IE *b- is accepted, then we may consider a comparison with PIE *gʷʰer- as a nu-present (as attested in Indic [grammatical texts], and in Armenian), thus *gʷʰr̥-nu̯- > *br̥nn- > brenn-. Other possibilities include comparisons to IE *bʰreu- 'wallen' (cf. Gmc. *breww-a-) and *bʰereg- 'glänzen'.}];386[342-345{S.v. OHG brinnan, prinnan 'brennen, verbrennen, entbrennen, glühen, leuchten'. The verb has no secure etymology| firstly there is no formally corresponding IE root in a similar meaning, and secondly the forms in -nn- in contrast to those in -n- in OE bryne, 'Feuer, Glut', OIc. bruni 'Brand' are in need of an explanation. Cf. entry in EWA 2 for discussion and extensive references to further literature.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn'. The Indo-European root etymology remains unclear: either to (1) PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ([LIV²](src-141) 92-93, [IEW](src-49) 166-7) or (2) *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ([LIV²](src-141) 219-220, [IEW](src-49) 493-5); cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):77-78; [Seebold 1970](src-556):137-138, [EWA 2](src-386):342-345.

Source: 141[676, 679{Cf. s.v. ?2. *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145), as a verbal root only in Balto-Slavic, where a denominal origin cannot be ruled out (cf. Lith. válgau, válgyti 'essen', Russ. volóžit' 'anfeuchten| mit Butter kochen'). Cf. n1 comparing OHG welc 'feucht' wolchan 'Wolke'. Cf. also variant ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein/werden' (IEW 1145) in Celtic (OIr. folcaid 'wäscht' MW golch- 'waschen' < *u̯olk-éi̯e-).}];397[994-995{S.v. NHG Wolke (MHG wolken, OHG wolcan, OS wolkan), from Germanic *wulkna- also in OE wolcen, OFr. wolken. Perhaps an auslaut variant *u̯l̥g- to OCS oblakŭ 'Wolke'?}];50[427{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- 'rain, wet weather', from PIE *u̯elk- (IEW 1145f.). The relationship of the Celtic lexemes with PIE *u̯el(H)g- (Lith. vìlgyti 'make wet', CS vlaga, Russ. dial. vológa, Cz. vlaha 'wetness', OHG welk 'wet, moist' is unclear. The two roots *u̯elk- and *u̯elg- should be somehow related. Perhaps there was an original root noun *u̯ōlg-s 'rain' (phonetically *[u̯ōlks]), gen.sg. *u̯olg-os and assume that some languages generalised the voiceless velar from the nom.sg. throughout the paradigm.}];352[1242-1243{Cf. s.v. Lith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen', from PIE *u̯elg- (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter' folcaid 'waschen (Kopf)', MW gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke'). The reconstruction of the root with final *g is based on Balto-Slavic and Germanic, the Celtic lexemes reflect *u̯elk-. The reason for this deviation is unclear, but could be due to an assimilation of final *g in the 2nd or 3rd person singular in the present or aorist stem.}];269[{Root reconstruction follows LIV² 676, ALEW 1242-1243. Cf. ALEW 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and Matasović (2009:427) s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.}]
Justification: Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 676, [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243. Cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and [Matasović 2009](src-50):427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic cognates. Cf. also [Kluge 2011](src-397):994-995.

Source: 165[277-278{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kalda- 'cold', originally a past participle to the verb *kalan- 'to be cold' (cf. s.v.) from PIE *g̑ólH-e-, cf. Lat. gelus 'cold, frost, ice' < *gel-u-.}];179[214{S.v. Goth. K3. kalds (adj.) 'ψυχρός', 'cold' from PIE *gel- 'cold', cf. Lat. gelū 'cold, frost, ice'.}];388[208-209{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kalđaz derived from Gmc. *kalanan (cf. Lat. gelū 'cold, frost, ice', Slav *zolь 'bad weather'). "Somehow related to Slav. sb. xoldъ 'cold', despite the phonetic difficulties".}];556[288-289{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *kal-a- 'frieren' (derived adj. kal-da- to be connected with nominal formations in other languages under a probable basis *g̑el- (cf. Lat. gelū 'Frost, Kälte', gelāre 'gefrieren', Lith. gélmenis, gelumà 'heftige Kälte, Frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis').}];703[109{Cf. PIE *gol- 'cold' (o-grade| cf. Lat. gelū, Lith. gelumà 'frost') in PGmc. *kalaną 'to be cold, to freeze' and *kaldaz 'cold' (Goth. kalds, ON kaldr, OE ċeald).}];141[185{Cf. s.v. *⁽g̑⁾el- 'frieren, kalt sein' (IEW 365-6). [No cognates outside of Germanic or Italic listed.]}];269[{The IE root underlying the Germanic forms in this class is generally reconstructed as *⁽g̑⁾el- on the basis of Germanic and Italic correspondences (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 185). The reconstruction of a palatovelar or plain velar depends on whether one additionally accepts cognacy with Balto-Slavic forms (cf. Lith. gelumà 'frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis'), cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):288-289, [Ringe 2017](src-703):109. The Germanic forms are considered by some scholars (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):209) to be related to Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'cold', but the correspondences of Slavic initial *x and medial *d to Germanic *k and *d is irregular. Consequently the connection of Slavic *xoldъ to the Germanic and Italic lexemes from IE *⁽g̑⁾el- must remain at least uncertain, if not outright rejected.}]
Justification: The IE root underlying the Germanic forms in this class is generally reconstructed as *⁽g̑⁾el- on the basis of Germanic and Italic correspondences (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 185). The reconstruction of a palatovelar or plain velar depends on whether one additionally accepts cognacy with Balto-Slavic forms (cf. Lith. gelumà 'frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis'), cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):288-289, [Ringe 2017](src-703):109. The Germanic forms are considered by some scholars (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):209) to be related to Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'cold', but the correspondences of Slavic initial *x and medial *d to Germanic *k and *d is irregular. Consequently the connection of Slavic *xoldъ to the Germanic and Italic lexemes from IE *⁽g̑⁾el- must remain at least uncertain, if not outright rejected.

Source: 80[819{Cf. s.v. Hitt. tallii̯e/a- 'to pray to, to evoke (a deity)', from ?*de/olH-i̯e/o-? (cf. ON talja, OE talian 'to tell', Gk. δόλος 'list').}];165[508{S.v. Proto-Germanic *tala- 'number| speech', from PIE *dolH-o- (cf. Hitt. tallii̯e/azi 'to pray to, evoke (a deity) < *dlH-ie-| Gk. δόλος 'bait, trick', Arm. toł 'row' < *dolH-o-).}];389[{New root: *del(H)- ‘ziehen, anziehen’ (Not in LIV²). In LIV² there is only a root *delh₁- 'to hew, to split' which does not show any connection to the words here in question.}];397[1001{S.v. NHG zählen (MHG zel(e)n, OHG zellen, OS tellian, OE tellan, ON telja), from PGmc. *tal-ja- 'zählen', a derivative from the same root as in NHG Zahl 'number', in turn perhaps to be connected to Lat. dolāre 'to hew', with a special development 'to notch, to score'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):1001 s.v. Zahl; [Kroonen 2013](src-165) postulates *dolH- following [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80) who compares the Germanic forms via ON telja, OE taljan 'to tell' with Hitt. tallii̯e/azi 'to pray, evoke (a deity)'. The connection between the Germanic words and the Hittite verb as well as Greek δόλος 'bait, trick' is accepted by [Kroonen 2013](src-165). However, the situation may be more complex with several similar roots side by side, cf. the new entry of *del(H)- ‘ziehen, anziehen’ in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) where it supposes the Hittite and Greek forms to belong together but not the other words mentioned here.

Source: 165[86-87, 97{S.v. Proto-Germanic *daga- 'day', from PIE *dʰog̑ʰ-o-, a thematic noun related to PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' < *dʰṓg̑ʰ-r/n- (cf. Skt. áhar-, gen. áhnas, loc. áhan, áhani 'day' OAv. gen.pl. asnąm 'id.'). "In Early Indo-Iranian, this formation lost its initial dental, possibly in the locative *dʰgʰ-én-i, where the root had a zero-grade."}];179[86-87{S.v. Gothic dags (D3). Possibly from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- burn, with modifications (cf. Skt. ni-dāghás 'heat, summer', Lith. dãgas, dagà 'heat, sultry harvest time', OPruss. dagis 'summer', Skt. dāhas 'burning, heat', OIr. daig, gen. dega 'fire| Skt. dáhati, Av. dažaiti 'burns', Lith. degù, Latv. dęgu, OCS žegǫ < *degǫ 'burn', etc.). "dags would then refer to the period 'when the sun burns down'".}];172[I:154{Cf. s.v. Ved. áhan- (~ áhar, Heterokliton) 'Tag, Tageschelle'. Perhaps from PIE *(h₂)eg̑ʰ-r/n- [cognate set 8124](cog-8124), which has been attempted by some scholars to be connected with Germanic words for 'day'.}];269[{Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:154 and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.}]
Justification: Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:154 and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.

Source: 141[147-148{S.v. *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen' (IEW 259-60, 262)| primary verb in ON deyja 'sterben' < *dʰou̯-éi̯e-.}];165[90{S.v. Proto-Germanic *daujan- 'to die', from PIE *dʰouh₂/h₃-ie-, (cf. Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'| Lat. fūnus 'funeral' < *dʰuh₂-n-es-(?)). On the PIE level the verb has usually been compared to *dʰeu- 'to run, to rush' (Skt. dhávate, Gk. θέω 'to run' and to *dʰueh₂- 'to blow, smoke, be misty' (cf. Seebold 1970:148| LIV² s.v.), but Kroonen finds it preferable to assume a link with Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'. The forms based on Goth. dauϸs 'dead', ON dauðr, OE dēad, OHG tōt, etc. are from PGmc. *dauda-, the original past participle to *daujan-.}];556[147-149{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dau-ja- 'sterben', belonging to isolated words from *dʰeu̯-, meaning 'die' and similar things. This probably goes back to *dʰeu̯(ə)- 'rauchen, stieben', whose meaning presumably developed from 'atmen, hauchen' (cf. Lith. dvė̃sti 'verenden' beside dvėsúoti 'schwer atmen, keuchen').}];269[{The IE root etymology of PGmc. *daujan- given here follows [LIV²](src-141) to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):90-91 (but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of [Kluge 2011](src-397):919 s.v. Tod).}]
Justification: The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanic *daujan- given here follows [LIV²](src-141) to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):90-91 (but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of [Kluge 2011](src-397):919 s.v. Tod).

Source: 66[1342-1343{S.v. σκάπτω 'to dig, dig out, work the earth'. There are many difficulties in the reconstruction of the original root.  Not unproblematic is the fact that it is no longer possible to postulate an e~a morphophonological ablaut in PIE.  Within Greek there is the additional problem of an alternation with voice and aspiration in the root final labial. /p/ ~ /pʰ/ ~ /b/, and the Greek vocabulary show no trace of ablaut.  Lat. scapulae and Umbrian scapla (acc.sg.) ‘shoulder-blade’ have been compared suggesting a possible original instrument *’shovel’ that formed the basis of the verb.  As a solution Beekes suggests that the word was a loan from a European substrate language.}];141[549{S.v. *skabʰ- 'kratzen, schaben' (IEW 931-2).}];270[1011{S.v. AGk. σκάπτω 'creuser'. Two possibilities: σκαπ- with final aspiration on analogy to θάπτω 'bury', vs. τάφος 'tomb', ταφῆναι 'to bury' or from σκαφ- with σκαπ- either phonetically or analogically. In the first case it may resemble Lat. scapulae 'épaules', Umb. scapla (acc.sg.)| one finds a large group of for σκαφ- with a general meaning 'râcler, gratter': Lat. scabō, in Germanic OHG scaban, etc., in Baltic Lith. skabiù 'tailler, couper'.}]
Justification: The root etymology in this set follows [LIV²](src-141) 549 and the latter of the two possible etymologies suggested by [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1011 to a PIE root *skabʰ- 'to scratch, shave'. Cf. however [Beekes 2010](src-66):1342-1343 favouring a substrate origin.

Source: 757[{S.v. Du. vies. First attested in Early Modern Dutch vijs (1539). Etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: From Early Modern Dutch vijs; further etymology uncertain, cf. [EWNl](src-757) for discussion.

Source: 165[103{S.v. Proto-Germanic *drinkan 'to drink'. The Germanic verb contains a nasalized variant of the root *dʰreg- as found in Baltic, cf. Lith. *drė́gti 'to become moist'.}];352[226-27{Cf. s.v. Lith. drė́gti 'to become moist, to thaw', to be interpreted as a denominal verb, the basis of which is not found in Lithuanian, but in Latvian drē̡gs m. 'thawing, muddy weather'. The latter seems to originate from a Vṛiddhi-derivation of pre-Proto-Balto-Slavic *dʰréh₁gʰo-, cf. PIE *dʰroh₁gʰ-/*dʰr̥h₁gʰ- 'deposit, yeast'.}];179[94-95{S.v. Gothic D33 drigkan. No accepted etymology. Possibly from PIE *dʰerH-gʰ- (cf. Lith. dìrgti, drė́gti 'become damp, etc.) or from PIE *dʰreg̑- 'move, glide' (cf. Skt. dhrájati 'glide', Lith. drė́zti 'tear', Latv. dragât 'pull'), alternatively borrowed from a pre-Germanic source, but this conjecture is unverifiable.}];556[165-166{S.v. Gmc. *drenk-a- 'trinken', no certain etymology outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *drinkan- 'to drink'. Further etymology uncertain; a proposal to connect it with Lithuanian drė́gti 'to become moist, to thaw' to a basic root *dʰreg- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):103) has not been widely accepted ([Seebold 1970](src-556):165-166, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):94-95, [ALEW](src-352) 226-227).

Source: 697[157-158, 162-163{Cf. s.v. Germanic *draugi- 'trocken' (> MLG droge 'trocken, dürr, unfruchtbar'), *drūgi- 'trocken' (> OE drȳge) , *drukna- 'trocken'.}];165[100{S.v. Proto-Germanic *draugja- ~ *drūgja- ~ *drukknu- 'dry'. An adjective whose Proto-Germanic reconstruction is problematic because of the co-occurrence of at least four different formations, namely 1) drūgja- (OE drȳge)| 2) *drūga- (OFris. drūch)| 3) draugja- (MDu. droge), and 4) *drukkna- (OS drocno, OHG trockan). The correlation between the different formations is unclear.}]
Justification: The reconstruction of the Proto-Germanic form of this adjective is problematic, therefore connections outside of Germanic are difficult to ascertain (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):157-158, 162-163; [Kroonen 2013](src-165):100).

Source: 179[328{S.v. Goth. *stubjus (S157). From Proto-Germanic *stewb- (cf. OHG zestiuben 'disperse', Du. stuiven 'fly about, scatter'| OHG stoup 'dust'). No accepted etymology outside of Germanic.}];556[474{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *steub-a- 'stieben'| no secure etymology.}];397[878, 884{S.v. NHG Staub (MHG stoup, stoub, OHG stoub), a derivative to the verb stieben (OHG stiuban), of unclear etymology.}];165[475{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *staubjan- 'to make steam(?)', cs. to *steuban- ~ *stūban-. G Staub 'dust' is derived from *stauba-.}];782[{The Frisian form is suspicious and its phonological form may be influenced by Dutch}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stauba- 'dust', a derivative of the strong verb steuban- 'to scatter, drift', further etymology generally considered uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):474, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):328, [Kluge 2011](src-397):878, 884, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):475). Cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):478 s.v. *steuban- ~ *stūban- proposing a connection to Lithuanian siaũbti 'to dash about' via *tséubʰ-ié- (with metathesis of initial *ts- > *st-).

Source: 66[1130-1131{S.v. οὖς 'ear' < *h₂ōu̯s, *h₂ou̯s-n-.}];274[339-343{PIE *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂au̯s-os-, *h₂us-es- n. 'Ohr' (IEW 785).}];54[63{S.v. Lat. auris 'ear'. Latin has remodelled the inherited PIE s-stem *h₂eu̯s- 'ear' as an i-stem: *ausi- > auri- (with rhotacism).}];105[501{S.v. Alb. vesh 'ear', from Proto-Albanian *wausi-, from PIE *ōus- ~ *əus- 'id.'.}];79[637-638{S.v. Arm. unkn 'ear', to be connected with the PIE word for 'ear'| the Armenian form is derived from the stem *(H)us-n-.}];165[44{S.v. Proto-Germanic *auzōn- 'ear', from PIE *h₂e/ous-n-.}];50[48-49{S.v. Proto-Celtic *awsos- 'ear', from PIE *h₂eus- 'ear'.}];81[507{S.v. Proto-Slavic *uxo 'ear', from PIE *h₂eus- (cf. Lat. auris, Goth. auso, OIr. áu, etc.).}];353[71{S.v. Lith. ausìs 'ear', from PIE *h₂eus-.}];369[415{S.v. Alb. vesh 'Ohr', from PIE *h₂eu̯s-, cf. entry for further discussion on possible stem formations in Albanian.}];352[74{S.v. OLith. ausìs 'Ohr' (BSl. cf. Latv. àuss 'Ohr', OPr. ausins 'Ohren', OCS uxo 'Ohr', etc.), from PIE *h₂eu̯s-es-, *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂us-s- 'Ohr' (cf. YAv. uši- 'Ohr', OPers. uši- 'id.' Gk. οὗς, ὠτός 'Ohr' (hom. G.sg. οὔατος), Myc. ti-ri-jo-we 'dreihenklig', Arm. ownkn 'Ohr', Lat. auris, -is, OIr. áu, Goth. auso 'Ohr', OHG ōra 'id.').}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂au̯s-os-, *h₂us-es- 'ear' ([NIL](src-274) 339-343, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1130-1131, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):637-638, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):415, [Orel 1998](src-105):501, [ALEW](src-352) 74, [Derksen 2015](src-353):71, [Derksen 2008](src-81):507, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):63, [Matasović 2009](src-50):48-49).

Source: 165[118-119{S.v. Proto-Germanic *erþō- f. 'soil, earth, land'.  If the comparison with the Ancient Greek lexeme ἔρα f. 'earth' the forms may be respectively reconstructed *h₁er-t-eh₂- > PGmc. *erþō-, *h₁er-eh₂- > AGk. ἔρα, but this comparison is tenuous.  Within Germanic the lexeme is probably cognate with *erwan- m. 'sand, soil'.}];179[18{S.v. Goth. A85. airϸa 'γῆ', 'earth', from PGmc. *erϸō, an extension of PGmc. *erō in the OHG hapax ero 'earth', cf. Gk. ἔρα 'earth', (Hom. ἔρα-ζε 'earthward'), Welsh erw 'field', OBret. ero 'furrow'.}];66[449{Cf. s.v. Gk. ἔρα explained by grammarians as with γῆ 'earth'. A general resemblance is shown by a few Germanic and Celtic expressions for 'earth' (OHG ero 'earth', ON jǫrvi 'sand(bank)', MW erw 'field', all with a suffix -u̯-| with a suffix -t- (Goth. airϸa, ON jǫrðm MIr. ert 'earth'. Connections with Arm. erkir 'earth' are unclear.}];397[253-254{S.v. NHG Erde (MHG erde, OHG erda, OS ertha), from PGmc. *erϸō, also Goth. airϸa, ON jǫrð, OE eorϸe, OFr. erthe. Outside of Germanic in the same one compares in the same meaning Gk. ἔρα (gloss, more widely attested in ἔραζε 'to the earth, on the earth') and within Germanic OHG ero. Semantically deviating is Welsh erw 'Feld, Land'. Further connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *erþō-, generally considered a dental-stem to a PIE root *h₁er- seen elsewhere in Ancient Greek ἔρα 'earth', Welsh erw 'field', cf. also the Old High German hapax ero 'earth' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):18, [Kluge 2011](src-397):253-254, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):118-119, cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):449).

Source: 141[230-231{S.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (IEW 287-289).}];66[375{S.v. ἔδω 'to eat' < PIE *h₁ed- 'eat'. Thematic ἐσθίω is formed on the basis of the inherited athematic imperative ἔσθι (Ved. addhí). < *h₁ed-dhi.}];165[119{S.v. Proto-Germanic *etan- 'to eat', from PIE *h₁ed- 'eat' (cf. Skt. ad- 'to eat', Gk. ἔδμεναι 'to eat', Lat. edō 'to eat', Lith. ė́sti 'to eat', OCS jasti 'to eat', Goth. itan 'to eat').}];686[183-184{S.v. OPr. īst (inf.) 'essen', directly comparable to OLith. ė́sti 'essen' (Lith. 'fressen'), Latv. êst, ultimately from PIE *h₁ed- 'beißen| essen'.}];353[157-158{S.v. Lith. ė́sti 'eat (of animals)' (Latv. êst, OPr. istwei), from PIE *h₁ed- 'eat' (cf. OCS jasti, Skt. átti, Hitt. ed-/ad-, Gk. ἔδμεναι| Lat. edere, Goth. itan).}];79[644{S.v. Arm utem 'to eat', since long connected to Gk. ἔδω, Lat. edō, Skt. ad-, OCS jasti, Goth. itan, etc. from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'.}];172[I:61-62{S.v. Ved. √ad- 'essen, verzehren', from PIE *h₁ed- (cf. Hitt. e-id-mi 'esse', Gk. ἔδμεναι 'essen', Lat. edō 'esse', ēst 'ißt', Lith. ė́sti 'fressen', OCS jasti 'essen', Goth. itan 'essen', etc.).}];81[154{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ěsti 'eat', from PIE *h₁ed- (cf. Lith. ė́sti, Latv. êst, OPr. īst, īstwei, Skt. átti. Hitt. ed-/ad-, Gk. ἔδμεναι, Lat. edō, Goth. itan).}];54[185-186{S.v. Lat. edō, ēsse 'to eat', from Proto-Italic *ed- 'to eat' (cf. Osc. edum 'to eat'), from PIE *h₁ed-.}];50[113{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ed-o- 'eat' (OIr. ithid), from PIE *h₁ed- (cf. Skt. ádmi, Gk. ἔδομαι, Lat. edō, Goth. itan, Hitt. ēd-, Lith. ė́sti, OCS jasti).}];352[269-270{Cf. s.v. OLith. ė́sti 'essen, fressen' (BSl. cf. Latv. êst 'essen, fressen, verzehren', OPr. inf. īst, ist 'essen', inf. istwei, OCS jasti 'essen', etc.), from PIE *h₁ed- 'essen' (cf. Hitt. ēdmi, adanzi 'esse', CLuw. ad- 'essen', HLuw. ad- 'essen', Ved. ad- 'essen', Gk 1.sg.fut.med. ἔδομαι 'werde essen', Arm. owtem 'esse', Lat. edō, ēsse 'essen', Osc. EDUM 'essen', Goth. itan 'essen', OHG ezzan 'essen').}];458[6: 53-54{PS *ěsti < PIE *ē̆d-.}];444[196{For Sp., Pg. comer, cf. s.v. 2077 Lat. comedere 'essen'.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Greek, Armenian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' ([LIV²](src-141) 230-231, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):261-263, [Beekes 2010](src-66):375, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):644, [EWAia](src-172) I:61-62, [ALEW](src-352) 269-270, [Derksen 2015](src-353):157-158, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):183-184, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:53-54, [Derksen 2008](src-81):154, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):119, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):185-186, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):196, [Matasović 2009](src-50):113).

Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes continuing or derived from PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ([NIL](src-274), cf. Source: 165[125-126{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fallan- 'to fall'.  K. adopts a new Indo-European etymology following Praust ("What Greek can tell us about the prehistory of English 'to fall'" unpublished paper at the conference Greek and Latin from an Indo-European from an Indo-European Perspective, Cambridge, July 2005) and [Neri 2007](src-635) as from a univerbation of the preverb *h₂po- and the root *h₃elh₁- 'to fall' (cf. Hitt. ḫallannai ~ ḫallannii̯anzi 'to trample down, flatten', Gk. ὄλλυμι 'destroy, kill, lose').}];141[463-464{[Germanic verbs listed in the LIV² under *peh₃lH- 'fallen'. New etymology to *h₃elh₁- accepted in the LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda.]}];389[{New etymology to PIE *h₃elh₁- 'zugunde gehen' has been accepted and included in the addenda and corrigenda to LIV².}];635
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing preverb *pe-/po- + PIE *h₃elh₁- 'to decay, perish' ([Neri 2007](src-635), cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):125-126, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389); formerly reconstructed as *peh₃lH- 'to fall' in [LIV²](src-141) 463-464).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. scare (v.), from Middle English skerre, borrowed from Old Norse skirra (cf. Icelandic skirra vandræðum 'to avoid strife', reflexive skirra-sk 'to shrink from'| Norwegian skjerra, Swedish dialectal skjarra 'to scare').}];468[494{Cf. s.v. ON skirra (v.) 'erschrecken| abwenden, entfernen' (< urn. *skerrian), Ic. skirra, NNw. skjerra, NSw. skärra, dial. skjärra (> MEng. skerren, skarren, NEng. scare 'einschüchtern'.}]
Justification: Passive form of English 'to scare', continuing Middle English skerren, and ultimately a loanword from Old Norse skirra 'to frighten; to shrink from', cf. also Old Norse skjarr 'timid, shy, afraid of' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84), [de Vries 1977](src-468):494).

Source: 165[134{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fehtan- 'to fight'.  Often assumed to be connected with LIV² 1. *pek̑- '(Wolle oder Haare) rupfen, zausen' (cf. Gk. πέκω 'kämme, schere', Lith. pešù 'rupfen', Lat. pectō 'kämmen, krempeln'), but this depends on a conjectural semantic shift from 'pluck, pull hair' > 'fight'.}];141[467{Cf. s.v. 1. *pek̑- '(Wolle oder Haare) rupfen, zausen' (IEW 797), cf. n2, where the semantics of the Germanic lexemes are derived from earlier *'sich raufen'.}];441[108-112{S.v. OHG fehtan 'kämpfen, fechten, ringen, streiten'. The verb is based on a t-extension of PIE *pek̑- '(Wolle oder Haare) rupfen, zausen' (cf. Lat. plectō 'flechte', Gk. πέκτειν 'scheren').}];556[190-191{S.v. Gmc. feht-a- 'fechten', going with certainty back to the common-IE verbal root *pek̑- 'rupfen, raufen'.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes, generally considered derivatives of PIE *pek̑- 'to pull hair, fight' ([LIV²](src-141) 467, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):190-191, [EWA 3](src-441):108-112, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):134).

Source: 66[1260-1261{S.v. πῦρ, πυρός 'fire' < PIE neuter heteroclite-stem *peh₂-u̯r̥, ph₂-u̯en-s. In Greek πῦρ was generalised as an r-stem, πῦρ, πῠρ-ος.}];274[540-545{S.v. *péh₂-u̯r̥(?), *p(e)h₂u̯ōr, *ph₂ur/n-, *p(e)h₂-u̯er/n- n. 'Feuer' (IEW 828, EIEC 202).}];80[613-614{S.v. paḫḫur / paḫḫuen- (n.) ‘fire, campfire, embers| fever’, from PIE heteroclite stem *péh₂-ur / *ph₂-uen-s (cf. Gk. πῦρ, OHG fuir, Arm. hur, Goth. fon, OPr. panno 'fire').}];345[421-422{S.v. TochB pūwar 'fire', which with TochA por probably reflects Proto-Tocharian *puwār and generally connected with PIE *peh₂u̯r̥ and related forms.}];79[426-427{S.v. Arm. hur 'camp-fire', long since connected with PIE *péh₂-ur, *ph₂-uén-s 'fire' (cf. Hitt. paḫḫur, paḫḫuenaš 'fire', Gk. πῦρ, πυρός 'fire', OHG fuir, Goth. fon, OPr. panno 'fire', etc.).}];54[500{Cf. s.v. Lat. pūr(i)gō, -āre 'to clean, clear', derived from Proto-Italic *pūr, *pun- 'fire' (cf. U. pir 'fire'), from PIE *péh₂-ur, *ph₂-uén-s 'fire' (cf. Hitt. pahhur / pahhuen- 'fire, embers, fever', Gk. πῦρ, πυρός, Arm. howr, Goth. fon, TochA por, B puwār).}];165[151{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fōr ~ *fun- 'fire', from PIE *péh₂-ur, *ph₂-uén-s (cf.
