Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, Germanic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *péh₂-u̯r̥, *ph₂-u̯én-, an inherited r/n-heteroclitic nominal stem (cf. [NIL](src-274) 540-545, [EIEC](src-657) 202, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):613-614, [Adams 2013](src-345):421-422, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1260-1261, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):426-427, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):151, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):500).

Source: 49[796{S.v. *peisk-, *pisk- 'Fisch'.  In the general meaning 'fish' the word is a Western Indo-European isogloss shared between Celtic, Italic, and Germanic.  The word may also be found in Slavic designating specific species of fish ('loach, 'gudgeon'), e.g. Pol. piskorz 'Peißker', Russ. пискаръ 'Gründling'.}];165[142{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fiska- 'fish' < PIE *pisk-o- (cf. Lat. piscis < *pisk-i-, OIr. íasc < *peisk-o-).}];50[128{S.v. Proto-Celtic *fēsko- 'fish' < PIE pei̯(k̑)sk̑o-.}];54[467-468{S.v. Lat. piscis 'fish' < Proto-Italic *piski- 'fish', an i-stem derivative of PIE *pisk- 'fish' (cf. OIr. íasc < *peisko-, Goth. fisks, OHG fisk < *pisko-).}]
Justification: Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pisk- 'fish', cf. [IEW](src-49) 796, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):142, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):467-468, [Matasović 2009](src-50):142.

Source: 54[227-228{S.v. Lat. flōs, -ris 'flower'. The Italic cognates reflect PIE *bʰleh₃-ōs- 'blossoming' > 'flower'.}];141[88{Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₃- 'blühen' (IEW 122).}];165[70{S.v. Proto-Germanic *blōman- 'flower', as if from PIE *bleh₃-mon-.}];50[67-68{S.v. Proto-Celtic *blātu- 'flower', which may be derived from either *bʰleh₃-tu- or *bʰlh₃-tu-, an abstract nominal derivative 'blossoming'.}]
Justification: Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing different derivatives from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):70, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):227-228, [Matasović 2009](src-50):67-68, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 88).

Source: 165[146{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fleugan- 'to fly'. The PIE root is the k-extended variant of *pleu̯- > *pleu̯k- (cf. LIV² 487-488).}];141[487-488{Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An enlargement of *pleu̯-, only found in Germanic and Baltic.}];441[385-388{S.v. OHG fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugan- 'to fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):146, [EWA 3](src-441):385-388).

Source: 66[1227-1228{S.v. ποῦς, ποδός 'foot' < PIE *pod-. The Greek form has generalised o-grade ablaut throughout the nominal paradigm, but the e-grade is attested in some other derivative forms: πέδη 'fetter, shackles', πέζα 'instep', πέζος 'walker, footsoldier', πέδον 'soil, earth, ground', πέδλιον 'sandal', πεδά 'after, with, amidst'.  A zero-grade is also attested in ἐπίβδα 'the day after a festival'.}];274[526-540{S.v. *ped- 'treten| fallen, sinken' (LIV² 458, IEW 790ff.).}];80[653-654{S.v. Hitt. pāt- / pat-, pata- 'foot, leg', from a PIE athematic root noun *pód-/*pd-. New Hittite texts attest a thematised noun pada-, cf. CLuw. pāta/i-, HLuw. pada/i-, Lyc. pede/i-.}];345[432{S.v. TochB paiyye 'foot', TochA peṃ and TochB *peine must represent an older dual form *pei to which the dual ending *-ne has been added. This Proto-Tocharian *pei is the phonologically expected reflex of PIE dual *póde (cf. Gk. πόδε) of the PIE word for foot *ped-/*pod-.}];79[534-535{S.v. Arm. *ot- 'foot'. The Armenian singulative ot-n reflects the PIE acc. *pód-m̥, from PIE *ped-/*pod- 'foot'.}];172[II:77-78{S.v. Ved. pád- 'Fuß'. In Ir. cf. YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Khot. päa-, Parth. p'd-, etc. From PIE *ped- (~ *pod-, *pd-) 'Fuß' (cf. Arm. ot-, Gk. πούς, OEng. fēt, Lat. pēs, ped-is, etc.).}];165[152{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fōt- 'foot', from PIE *pōd- (cf. Hitt. pāt- ~ pat-, Skt. pā́t, pad-, YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Arm. otn, etc.).}];54[462{S.v. Lat. pēs, pedis 'foot', from PIE nom.sg. pōd-s, acc. po/ed-m, loc.sg. ped-i.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ([NIL](src-274) 526-540), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):653-654, [Adams 2013](src-345):432, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1227-1228, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):534-535, [EWAia](src-172) II:77-78 [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):462, [LIV²](src-141) 458).

Source: 165[154-155{S.v. Proto-Germanic *freusan- 'to freeze' < PIE *préus-e- (cf. W. rhew 'frost, rhime' < *preuso-).}];141[493f.{S.v. *preu̯s- 'sprühen, spritzen' (IEW 809-10, 846).}];50[140{S.v. Proto-Celtic s.v. *freswo- 'strong cold', which may be from PIE *preu̯s- 'freeze' (cf. Skt. pruṣvā́- 'drops of dew', Lat. pruīna 'hoarfrost', Goth. frius 'hoarfrost'), but one must assume a metathesis *-u̯s- > *-su̯- from earlier *preu̯s-o-.}];240[137{Cf. s.v. Old Welsh reulaun 'icy' (lit. ice-full), with W rhew 'frost, ice', OIr. réud, < *preuswo-.}];296[R:24-25{S.v. OIr. réud 'grand froid'. The connection with Skt. pruṣvā́- 'glace', Lat. pruīna < pruswinā-, Goth. frius 'gel' is not certain as the Proto-Celtic form is difficult to reconstruct.}];236[{S.v. W rhew '(hoar-)frost, ice' (cf. OCo. reu, Bret. rev, etc. < PIE *prēuso-, cf. Goth. *frius).}];269[{The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class follows [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):140, but cf. doubts in [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:24-25, [EIEC](src-657) 287.}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 493-494). The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class follows [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):140, but cf. doubts in [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:24-25, [EIEC](src-657) 287. For Germanic lexemes in this class, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):154-155.

Source: 54[244-245{S.v. Lat. fruor, frui 'enjoy (the produce of)' (vb.), from which Lat. frūctus, -ūs 'enjoyment, revenue' is a derived noun'| Umbrian frif, fri is a root noun < *bʰrūg-. Verbal fruor is from PIE *bʰruHg-ie/o- 'to use' (cf. Goth. brukjan, OE brūcan).}];141[96{Cf. s.v. ?*bʰreu̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'genießen, gebrauchen' (IEW 173). Only Italic and Germanic (cf. Goth. brūkjan 'brauchen').}];279[297-298{S.v. U. frif 'Feldfruchte' (A.pl.) < bʰrūg-n̥s, like Lat. frūges a root noun to the same root found in Lat. frūi 'genießen, Nutzen haben', cf. Goth. brūkjan, OHG brūhhen 'brauchen, gebrauchen'.}];444[303{S.v. 3537 Lat. frūctus 'Frucht, Obst'.}]
Justification: Italic and Romance lexemes continuing nominal derivatives of PIE ?*bʰreu̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'to enjoy, use' ([Untermann 2000](src-279):297-298, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):244-245, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):303). The attestation of this lexical root is restricted to Italic and Germanic (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 96).

Source: 141[193{S.v. *gʰebʰ- 'fassen, nehmen| geben' (IEW 407-409). Not always easy to distinguish from *gʰeHb- 'ergreifen, nehmen' [cf. 'take' in [cognate set 5345](cog-5345)].}];556[217-218{S.v. Proto-Germanic *geb-a- 'geben'. Probably to be compared with a European root *g̑ʰabʰ- 'nehmen, bringen, halten', the e-vocalism of Germanic is then secondary. (Cf. Lat. habeō 'halten, besitzen, haben', OIr. gaibid 'nimmt, ergreift', Lith. gabénti 'befödern, herbeischaffen, fortschaffen'| with e-vocalism gebė́ti 'pflegen, gewohnt sein').}];165[172-173{S.v. Proto-Germanic *geban- 'give'. The verb is often compared with OIr. gaibid 'to take, hold' < *gʰHbʰ-ie-, but this is formally impossible because of the laryngeal. LIV² 193 connects with Lith. gebė́ti 'to be able, to be used to' < *gʰebʰ-eh₁-ie-, but the semantics are problematic. Kortlandt (1992:104-5) assumes a remodelling of *ga-ef- < *k̑o(m)-h₁ep-, to be directly connected with Lat. coēpī 'seized' < *k̑o(m)-h₁eh₁p-.}];269[{The exact connections outside of Germanic are disputed. For the purposes of cognacy, this class follows the reconstruction of LIV² with possible but uncertain connections to ?*g̑ʰeHb- (cf. OIr. gaibid). But cf. the hypothesis of Kortlandt (1992:104-5), followed by Kroonen (2013:172-173), who suggests a remodelling of earlier *ga-ef- from *k̑o(m)-h₂ep-.}];683[104-105{"The usual connection of *geb- 'give' with Latin habeō 'hold' and OIr. gaibid 'takes' must be rejected because the vocalism is incompatible. This verb can be derived from the Germanic prefix ga- plus the root of Hitt. epzi 'seizes', Lat. apīscor 'reach', coēpī 'have begun'."}]
Justification: Precise connections outside of Germanic are disputed. For the purposes of cognacy, this class follows the reconstruction of [LIV²](src-141) with possible but uncertain connections to ?*g̑ʰeHb- (cf. OIr. gaibid), but cf. the hypothesis of [Kortlandt 1992](src-683):104-5, followed by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):172-173, who suggests a remodelling of earlier *ga-ef- from *k̑o(m)-h₂ep-.

Source: 165[162-163, 184{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gōda- adj. 'suitable, good', an o-grade adjective to a lost strong-verb *gadan- 'to fit' < *gʰedʰ-.  Cf. denominal verb *gadōjan- 'to fit (together)' (pp.162-163).}];415[694-697{S.v. OHG guot 'gut, brauchbar, verwendbar, etc.', from PGmc. *gōđa-, which is based on the verbal root *gʰedʰ- 'zusammentreffen, sich vereinigen'.}];141[195{Cf. s.v. ?*gʰedʰ- '(zusammen)treffen, sich vereinigen' (IEW 423-4).}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *gōda- 'suitable, good', a derivative of PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):162-163, 184, [EWA 4](src-415):694-697, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 195).

Source: 54[269-270{Cf. s.v. Lat. grāmen, -inis 'grass', from PIE *g̑ʰr̥h₁-(s-)mn̥- 'grass', cf. Goth. gras, OHG gras, OIc. gras 'grass'| OE grōwan, OIc. gróa, OHG gruoen 'to grow' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ie/o-| OS grōni, OHG gruoni 'green' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ni-.}];141[192{Cf. s.v. *gres- 'fressen, verschlingen' (IEW 404), cf. n1 possibly also to be reconstructed as *gras- in view of Lat. grāmen if from *gras-mn̥- 'Gras' or as *grens- if the Vedic verbal forms have generalised the zero-grade. Against the latter, however, Vedic grásiṣṭha- should contain an e-grade (and yet does not contain a nasal).}];693[116{Argues for a PIE root rather *gras- ~ *gʰras- ~ *kras-, pointing to onomatopoetic ideophonic origin and a meaning 'to devour, graze', cf. Vedic grásate 'devours‘, Greek Cypr. γράσθι (see LIV, 192, note 1)| for *gʰras- cf. English grass, German Gras < Proto-Germanic *ɣrasa- n. and Latin grāmen (< *g(ʰ)rásmn n. 'grass')| for *kras- cf. Greek κράστις f. 'grass, hay'.}];165[187, 191{S.v. Proto-Germanic *grasa- 'grass'. Lat. grāmen, from either *g̑ʰrh₁-mn- or *g̑ʰrh₁s-mn-, is the most evident comparandum for PGmc. *grasa-. However, PGmc. *grasa- cannot be straightforwardly be derived from *g̑ʰrh₁s- since this would yield *gurs-. Instead this should be regarded as a secondary s-stem to the verb *grōan- 'to grow' < *gʰróh₁-e-, an o-grade strong verb to the root *gʰreh₁-.}];269[{Proto-Germanic *grasa- is generally compared with Lat. grāmen [cf. [cognate set 8369](cog-8369)] but details of the etymology remain disputed. The Leiden dictionaries ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):187 s.v. PGmc. *grasa-, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):269-270) argue to reconcile the reconstructions through postulating a root *⁽g̑⁾ʰreh₁- (not in LIV²) underlying PGmc. *grōan- 'grow', from which the Germanic forms would be a secondary s-stem. [Seebold 1970](src-556):242-243 also suggests the possibility of a connection of Gmc. *grōan- with Lat. grāmen, but has reservations whether the two forms can be compared. Similarly, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):371-372 s.v. NHG Gras, where two possibilities are offered: Either to (1) PGmc. grōan- (as [Kroonen 2013](src-165):187 and tentatively [Seebold 1970](src-556):242-243), or alternatively to PIE *gras- (cf. Gk. γράω 'I devour', Ved. grásate 'devours', [LIV²](src-141) 192 s.v. *gres-) with an variant in initial position| cf. also [Pooth 2015](src-693):116 arguing for an onomatopoeic root *g⁽ʰ⁾ras- ~ *kras- (Gk. κράστις 'grass, hay'). It seems very likely that there is a connection between the Germanic lexemes and Latin grāmen, but the problem has not yet been solved in a satisfactory way. [Cogsets for Proto-Italic *grā̆men- [cognate set 8369](cog-8369) and Proto-Germanic *grasa- [cognate set 230](cog-230) have been cross-indexed at value 5/6: large majority view]}];556[242-243{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *grō-a- 'wachsen'. "Gm. grō-a-, intr. 'wachsen' hat keine genaue Vergleichsmöglichkeit. In der Regel wird als Erweiterung gm. gras-a-m (n) 'Gras' (in gt., awn. gras, ae. græs, afr. gres, gers, ahd. gras) mit lt. grāmen 'Weide, Gras' verglichen. Letzteres kann aber auch zu idg. gras- 'weiden, fressen' gehören. Vielleicht ist das gm. Verbum eine Variante zu krē- 'wachsen' in lt. crēsco."}];397[371-372{S.v. NHG Gras (MHG gras, OHG gras, OS gras) from Germ. *grasa- 'Gras, Kraut', also in Goth. gras, ON gras, OE græs. The closest relative in IE seems to be Lat. grāmen (from *grasmen) '(Gras)Stengel', (especially as animal feed). It can also belong to Gk. gráō 'ich fresse', Gk. grástis 'Futterkraut, Grünfutter', Ved. grásati 'verschlingt, frißt'. On the other hand, maybe related to Germ. grō-a- 'wachsen' as a morphologically unclear derivative.}]
Justification: Possibly (but not certainly) cognate with Latin grāmen 'grass' in [cognate set 8369](cog-8369). Cf. discussion in citations below.

Source: 165[191-192{S.v. Proto-Germanic *grōni- 'green', an adjective related to Proto-Germanic *grōan- 'to grow', an o-grade strong verb from the root *gʰreh₁- 'to grow' (cf. Lat. grāmen 'grass').}];397[378{S.v. NHG grün (MHG grüene, OHG gruoni, OS grōni) from Gmc. *grō-ni- adj. 'grün', also in ON grœnn, OE grēne. Derived with a *-ni- suffix to Gmc. *grō-a- 'wachsen'.}];697[260-261{S.v. Gmc. *grōni- 'grün', a verbal adjective to the verb *grōa- 'wachsen'.}];556[242-243{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *grō-a- 'wachsen'. No clear cognates outside of Germanic.}];269[{A verbal adjective from the strong verb *grōan- 'grow', cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):260-261, [Kluge 2011](src-397):378, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):191-192. Extra-Germanic connections unclear, but perhaps further connected to Lat. grāmen 'grass', but the latter may also be connected with IE *gras- 'fressen' (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8369](cog-8369), and in [Seebold 1970](src-556):242-243, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):191-192.}]
Justification: A verbal adjective from the strong verb *grōan- 'grow', cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):260-261, [Kluge 2011](src-397):378, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):191-192. Extra-Germanic connections unclear, but perhaps further connected to Lat. grāmen 'grass', but the latter may also be connected with IE *gras- 'fressen' (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8369](cog-8369), and in [Seebold 1970](src-556):242-243, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):191-192.

Source: 165[207-208, 227{S.v. Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand', as though from *k̑ont-ú-, a u-stem derived from the strong verb hinϸan- 'to reach for' (< *⁽k̑⁾ént-e-). [Not in LIV².]}];179[176-177{S.v. Goth. H40. handus 'χείρ', 'hand'. Etymology uncertain. A Germanic innovation, possibly with the stem of *(fra-)hinϸan 'grasp' with 'hand' from the sense of 'grabber'.}];556[255-256{S.v. Gmc. -henϸ-a- '(fangen)'. The derivation of 'hand' from the strong verb is accepted by Seebold, but the verb itself has no certain comparisons outside of Germanic.}];397[391{S.v. NHG Hand (MHG hant, OHG hant, OS hand), from Gmc. *handu- 'Hand', also in Goth. handus, ON hǫnd, OE hond, OFr. hand, hond. Origin disputed. Conceivably there is a connection with Gmc. *henϸ-a- 'fangen, ergreifen' in Goth. frahinϸan with the original meaning of 'hand' being 'grabber'. Morphologically, however, this connection is problematic because no Germanic agent noun is formed in this way.}]
Comment: Derivation within (and therefore further connections outside of) Germanic uncertain.
Justification: Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Frequently considered a derivative of the strong verb *hinϸan- 'grasp, seize' with the original sense of the word being *'grabber', but there are no clear morphological parallels for the stem formation, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):255-256, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):176-177, [Kluge 2011](src-397), [Kroonen 2013](src-165):207-208, 227 for further discussion.

Source: 66[55{S.v. Gk. ἀκούω 'hear', from PIE *h₂keu̯s- 'hear' (cf. Gothic hausjan 'hear'). The verb has often been explained as a compound from ἀκ- 'sharp' and οὖς, but this is not certain.}];165[217{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hauzjan- 'to hear' < PIE *h₂kous-ie-, cf. Gk. ἀκούω.}];395[71{Perhaps originally a compound *h₂k̑-h₂ou̯s-iéti '(s)he is sharp-eared' > PGmc. *hauziϸi '(s)he hears' (cf. Goth. hauseiϸ, OE hīerϸ), cf. Gk. ἀκούειν 'to hear'. [Cf. *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (LIV² 261, NIL 287-300, IEW 18-22), *h₂ou̯s- 'ear' (NIL 339-343, IEW 785).]}];179[180-181{S.v. Goth. H52. hausjan 'ἀκούειν', 'hear', from PIE *(s)keu̯-s- 'note, perceive, hear' (cf. Skt. kaví- 'wise| seer', Gk. κοέω 'note', ἀκούω 'hear')| others have attempted to analyse Gk. ἀκούω < *ak-ous-yō 'I hear distinctly', although this is less likely than a derivation from *keu̯-.}];270[50-51{S.v. Gk. ἀκούω. Generally two explanations have been considered for an etymology: Either (1) as a compound *ἀκ-ουσ-i̯ω 'to extend the ear' or (2) to be connected with Goth. hausjan 'entendre', in which ἀ- may be the zero-grade of *en- 'dans'| for the forms without the prothesis, cf. κοέω 'entendre, comprendre'. The second explanation is the one generally given [at the time of this lexicon's composition].}];269[{The cognacy of the Greek and Germanic forms is generally agreed, but the derivation of the forms from a common IE proto-form is disputed. An explanation from a compound stem *h₂k-h₂ou̯s-i̯e- 'is sharp-eared' is commonly considered (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):71), but this analysis remains uncertain (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):55). For references to older literature, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):50-51| [Lehmann 1986](src-179):180-181.}]
Justification: The cognacy of the Greek and Germanic forms is generally agreed, but the derivation of the forms from a common IE proto-form is disputed. An explanation from a compound stem *h₂k-h₂ou̯s-i̯e- 'is sharp-eared' is commonly considered (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):71), but this analysis remains uncertain (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):55). For references to older literature, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):50-51; [Lehmann 1986](src-179):180-181.

Source: 165[499{S.v. Proto-Germanic *swēra- 'heavy', a vr̥ddhi-adjective to an unattested strong verb *sweran-| derivationally parallel to *wēta- 'wet'. Cf. Lith. sver̃ti 'to weigh, to balance' < *suer-e-, Lith. svarùs 'heavy' < *suor-u-.}];697[578-579{S.v. Gmc. *swǣra- 'gewichtig', a lengthened-grade formation, beside the primary verb attested by Lith. sver̃ti 'wägen'.}];352[998-999{Cf. s.v. Lith. sver̃ti 'wägen, abwägen| wiegen, Gewicht haben', cf. Goth. swers (adj.) 'geschätzt, ehrenvoll', ON svárr 'schwer', OHG swār 'id.'. The Baltic and Germanic correspondences could go back to a PIE root *su̯er(H)- 'wiegen'.}]
Justification: The only extra-Germanic correspondences are found in Baltic (cf. Lith. sver̃ti 'to weigh') which could go back to an original IE root *su̯er(H)- (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):578-579, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499, [ALEW](src-352):998-999).

Source: 165[271-272{S.v. Proto-Germanic *jakk/gōn- 'to rush, chase'. No certain etymology. Perhaps to the root *Hig̑ʰ- found in Greek and Indo-Iranian (cf. Gk. ἰχανάνω 'to desire', Skt. sam-ī́hate 'to strive/desire', OAv. iziiā 'I wish').}];80[235-36{Proposes a cognacy with Hitt. ekt- c. '(hunting) net (?)' from PIE *i̯ek-t-. [Not in LIV².]}];397[453{S.v. NHG jagen (MHG jagen, OHG jagōn, MLG jagen). Etymology uncertain.}];398[252-257{S.v. OHG jagôn 'jagen, (an-)treiben, verfolgen, hetzen, vertreiben, in die Flucht schlagen'. As with other words attested in continental west Germanic with initial j-, the etymology of OHG jagôn is unclear. All previous attempts are not persuasive. Cf. entry for discussion of five different proposals.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [EWA 5](src-398) s.v. OHG jagôn with extensive discussion of previous proposals.

Source: 165[271{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *īsa- 'ice'. There are no certain cognates outside of Germanic. "Av. aexa- can only be related if it continues a form *h₁eiH-ko- that developed into *HeikHo- by laryngeal metathesis."}];398[195-199{discusses several possibilities of reconstruction and connection with other branches, not only Iranian on the one hand, but also Balto-Slavic on the other, and with more presuppositions also that with Arm. ełeamn 'hoar frost'.}];352[II: 397f.{s.v. ýnis (1), ỹnis (2) sm. 'hoar frost, frozen dew'. Apart from Balto-Slavic, the entry also connects Armenian ełeamn, G. Sg. ełeman 'hoar frost', but not the Germanic lexemes.}];49[301{Cf. s.v. 2. ei-s-, ei-n- 'Eis, Frost', where the Germanic lexemes are taken to be cognate with the 'ice' words in Iranian (cf. Av. aexa-).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):271, [EWA 5](src-398):195-199 for further discussion).

Source: 141[153{S.v. ?*dʰreb- 'stoßen, treffen' (IEW 272-3). Root only Germanic and (?)Slavic.}];165[101-102{S.v. Proto-Germanic *drepan- 'to hit', assuming a back-formation to the iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip, droop| to drop', a zero-grade variant of *drapp/bōn- 'to hit'. Both iteratives can be derived from *draban- 'to hew' < *dʰróbʰ-e- (cf. OCS drobiti (drobljǫ) 'to crumble, chop, break').}];556[166-167{S.v. PGmc. *drep-a- 'schlagen', no suitable comparisons outside of Germanic.}];397[927-928{Cf. s.v. NHG treffen (MHG treffen, OHG treffan, OS -drepan), from Germ. *drep-a- 'schlagen' also in ON drepa, OE drepan. No clear comparanda outside of Germanic.}];468[83{S.v. ON drepa 'schlagen, stossen| töten' (within Germanic cf. Ic., Far., Nw. drepa, Sw. dräpa, Da. dræbe, OE, OS drepan, MLG drepen, OHG treffan| outside Germanic cf. drobiti 'entzweireissen' [IEW 272-273]).}]
Justification: IE root etymology unclear. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. [Seebold 1970](src-556) and [Kluge 2011](src-397) see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. [Kroonen 2013](src-165) derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.

Source: 141[168-170{S.v. *g̑neh₃- 'erkennen' (IEW 376-8).}];156[IV:315-316];567[211{Bactrian ζαν- < *zāna- (cf. Parth. zʾn 'to know', Sogd. ʾnzʾn 'to acknowledge').}];83[466-467{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian zanH-² 'to know' from PIE *g̑neh₃-.}];172[I:599-601{S.v. Ved. √jñā- 'kennen, erkennen, wissen' < PIE *g̑neh₃-.}];341[609-611{S.v. TochA kñas- 'kennen', 'know', from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'erkennen' (LIV² 168ff.).}];81[546{S.v. Proto-Slavic *znati 'know', from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'know' (cf. Skt. jānā́ti 'know', Gk. γιγνώσκω 'perceive, realize', Goth. kunnan 'know').}];353[519-520{S.v. Lith. žinóti 'know', from PIE *g̑n-ne/n-h₃- (>> *g̑nh₃-ne/n-h₃-).}];165[311-312{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kunnan- 'to know (how), be able', (as though) from PIE *g̑onh₃-neh₂-.}];442[286{S.v. 5193 Ved. jānā́ti 'knows' RV. [√jñā].}];149[160-161{S.v. A knā- 'to know', connected to IE *g̑neh₃- 'to know' and the A pres. stem *knānā- is more or less equivalent to the stem of Ved. jānā́ti on the basis of an IE stem *g̑n̥-n-(e)h₃-, but remodelled in a different manner.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'to perceive, recognise' ([LIV²](src-141) 168-170, cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):160-161, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):609-611, [EWAia](src-172) I:599-601, [Cheung 2007](src-83):466-467, [ALEW](src-352) 1311-1313, [Derksen 2015](src-353):519-520, [Derksen 2008](src-81):546, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):311-312)

Source: 165[354-355{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Oss. mal 'stagnant water', Lat. mare 'sea', OIr. muir 'id.', MW mor 'id.' < *mor-i-| Lith. mãrios (f.pl.) 'id.' < *mor-ieh₂-, OCS morje, Ru. móre, SCr. mȍre, môre 'id.' < mor-io-).}];657[503-504{Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' may also be cognate to this class, [cf. Abaev 1959-1995 Vol. II, pp.68-69]. If the Ossetic form it is not a loanword, then the distribution of the lexeme is not exclusively to the European branches of IE.}];156[II:68-69{Cf. Oss. mal 'глубокая стоячая вода', from IE *mōri or *mōryo- 'sea' with regular *r > l before *i.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', further from PIE *mor-i- 'id.'. Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):354-355, cf. [EIEC](src-657) 503-504, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:68-69).

Source: 165[228{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hlah(j)an- 'to laugh' as though from *klok-ie-, perhaps to be compared with Ru. klekotát' 'to scream (of bird of prey)'| cf. ON hlakka 'to scream (of birds)| to rejoice'. If so, perhaps a root *klek-.}];556[257-258{S.v. Gmc. *hlah-ja- 'lachen'. No precise comparanda. It belongs to a group of onomatopoeic words with the meaning 'cackle, chortle', etc. with the phonetic form tectal + l + vowel + tectal| cf. Lat. glōciō, Lith. klagė́ti, klukšė́ti, Gk. κλώσσω, etc.}];179[185{S.v. Goth. H70. *hlahjan 'laugh', from PIE *kel- 'shout, call' as in Gk. καλέω, (IEW 548-50) + -eH-g- as in Gk. κλώζω 'croak', κλωγμός 'signal to a horse', κλάζω 'cry out', Lith. klegė́ti 'cackle', Latv. kladzêt 'chatter'| with nasal infix Gk. κλαγγή 'clang', Lat. clangō 'cry', clangor 'noise'. Individual forms influenced by onomatopoeia.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; likely to be of onomatopoeic origin. Cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):257-258, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):185, and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):228 for various proposals and references to further literature.

Source: 66[1596-1597{S.v. φύλλον 'leaf' from a PIE root *bʰel- or *bʰelh₃-.  The Greek formation φύλλον may be directly cognate with Latin folium 'leaf' if from original < *bʰol-i̯o- (the raising o > u in the root may be explained by Cowgill's Law). Forms with a dental stem are found in Germanic (OHG blat, NHG Blatt 'leaf'), TochA pält, TochB pilta 'leaf' (with a zero-grade), and Celtic bláth 'blossom, flower' < *bʰlō-tu- (cf. OHG bluot 'flowering, blossom', etc.) (with a full-grade).}];165[66{S.v. Proto-Germanic *blada- 'leaf, blade', derived from a strong verb *blōan- 'to bloom', as though from PIE *bʰlh₁-tó-, however the form is an internal Germanic derivation, as PIE *bʰlh₁-tó- would have yielded PGmc. **bulda-.}];345[415{S.v. TochB pilta 'leaf, petal', which with TochA pält reflects Proto-Tocharian *pältā as if from PIE *bʰl̥h₁t-os- or *bʰelh₁t-os-. The closest relatives appear to be in Germanic, e.g. OE blæd 'leaf, blade', OHG blat, etc. as though from PIE *bʰl̥h₁-tó-.}];141[88{Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₃- 'blühen' (IEW 122).}];270[1232-1233{S.v. Gk. φύλλον 'feuille (d'arbre ou de plante)'. The old word for 'leaf', to be connected with Lat. folium with an o-grade to a root *bhel-. In several IE languages (Germanic, Celtic, and Tocharian) there are diverse forms showing a dental (cf. Germ. Blatt).}]
Justification: The Tocharian, Hellenic, and Germanic lexemes in this class are generally considered derivations from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom', although certain derivational details remain disputed. Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 88, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):415, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1232-1233, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1596-1597, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):66). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 8247](cog-8247).

Source: 397[579{S.v. NHG link adj. (with derived adv. links| MHG linc, lenc, OHG lenca 'linke Hand'). The adjective originally meant 'ungeschickt', 'clumsy' and possibly to be connected to the late attested Ved. laṅga- 'lahm'.}];398[1172-1175{S.v. OHG *lenc only as substantive f. 'die Linke, linke Hand', from Proto-Germanic *(s)lenka-, whose original meaning was probably 'clumsy, unskillful'. Proto-Germanic *(s)lenka- goes back to Pre-Proto-Germanic/PIE *(s)lengo-. The connection with extra-Germanic lexical material is difficult. Perhaps to post-Vedic Sanskrit laṅga- 'lahm', m. 'Lahmheit', Lat. languēre 'matt sein', Gk. λαγγάζω 'lasse nach, erschlaffe', λαγαρός 'matt'. Cf. entry for extensive discussion of the further literature and difficulties of connecting the Germanic material.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. discussion in [EWA 5](src-398):1172-1175.

Source: 141[408-409{S.v. 1. *lei̯p- 'kleben bleiben' (IEW 670-671).  The Germanic forms reflect an essive form *lip-h₁i̯é-.}];165[335-336{S.v. Proto-Germanic *libēn- 'to be left| to live', the stative to *līban- 'to stick' which is in turn from PIE *leip- (cf. Gk. λιπαρός 'fat, gleaming (of oil or unguent), Skt. limpáti 'to smear, adhere to, to deceive', Lith. lìpti, Latv. lipt 'to stick', etc.).}];556[326-327{S.v. Gmc. *-leib-a- '(bleiben)', to be connected with the IE root *lei̯p- 'kleben, schmieren' (cf. Lith. limpù, lìpti 'kleben, klebrig sein, ansteckend sein', OCS pri-lьpljǫ, -iti 'kleben'. Less certain are connections to Gk. formations, e.g. λίπτω 'begehre'| ἀλείφω 'einölen, salben'| λίπα 'fett, glänzend'. Cf. also Ved. limpáti 'beschmieren, salben', TochB lip-, lyip- 'übrig bleiben').}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯p- 'to stick' ([LIV²](src-141) 408-409, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):326-327, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):335-336).

Source: 165[336{S.v. Proto-Germanic *librō- 'liver'. Etymology unclear| it may possibly be an irregular continuation of PIE *iekʷ-r/n-, if the Germanic form represents an intermediate form *lipr-eh₂- with unetymological initial *l- and sporadic change of *kʷ > *p in the vicinity of resonants (cf. *fimfe 'five' < *pénkʷe).}];397[565{S.v. NHG Leber (MHG leber(e), OHG lebara, lebera, MLG, MNL lever(e), from Germanic *librō(n), also in ON lifr, OE lifer, OFr. livere. The word perhaps originally meant 'the fat', maybe actually 'the fattened liver', cf. It. fegato 'liver' < Lat. iecur fīcātum 'fattened liver', and in this case one might compare Gk. λιπαρός 'fat' to λίπος 'fat, oil, unguent'. Alternatively it is not to be fully ruled out that the word continues the Indo-European word for 'liver' *i̯ekʷr (cf. Lat. iecur, etc) with some irregular phonological alteration (cf. e.g. the initial l- in Armenian, if the Armenian word also belongs to this word family).}];398[1082-1084{S.v. OHG lebara 'Leber| iecur', from Proto-Germanic *liƀ(a)rō⁽ⁿ⁾, a substantive in *-ō(n)- *'die Fett(ig)e' from an adjective *liƀ(a)ra- 'fett(ig)' no longer attested in the Germanic languages < PIE *lip-ró- 'fettig, schmierig', in turn a zero-grade *-ro- formation to the verbal root *lei̯p- 'kleben bleiben| klebrig, schmierig sein' which is also continued in OHG bilîban and leiben'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Perhaps to the PIE word for 'liver' *(H)i̯ekʷ-r/n-, if certain irregular sound changes took place (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):565, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):336). An alternative possibility is an original meaning 'fat', if compared to the root of Gk. λιπαρός 'oily, fatty, greasy' if in Germanic an adjective was substantivised as similarly in Romance from Lat. (iēcur) fīcātum (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):565; [EWA 5](src-398):1082-1084).

Source: 80[819-821{S.v. Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long'. K. reconstructs as a preform for Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long' a PIE i-stem *dólugʰ-i-.  The exact reconstruction of the root is difficult, since forms elsewhere in IE (Ved. dīrghá-, OAv. darəga-, OCS dlьgъ, Lith. ìlgas) all reflect *dl̥h₁gʰ-o-, where the identity of the laryngeal is determined on the basis of Greek ἐν-δελεχής 'lasting long' < *delh₁gʰ-.}];172[I:728-729{S.v. Ved. dīrghá- 'lang [zeitlich, räumlich], weitreichend, langdauernd'  (OAv. darəga-, YAv. darəγa- 'lang') which reflect PIE *dl̥h₁gʰ-ó- (OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas 'lang', cf. Gk. δολιχός, ἐν-δελεχής 'langdauernd, ununterbrochen', Hitt. daluki- 'lang').}];81[133{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dьlgъ adj. 'long' < PIE *dl̥h₁gʰ-ó-, (cf. Skt. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός).}];54[348{S.v. Lat. longus 'long' from PIE *dlongʰ-o- (cf. *dólugʰ- in Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long', PIE *dlh₁gʰ-o- in Skt. dīrghá- OAv. darəga-, OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas, Alb. gjathë (+ *-tā-)| Gk. δολιχός (< *dolh₁-i-gʰo-?), ἐνδελεχής 'lasting long, uninterrupted' < *delh₁gʰ-| PIE *dlongʰ-o- in Goth. laggs, OHG lang, OIc. langr, etc.). The root might be *de/olh₁-, cf. Cz. dél (poet.) 'length' < PSl. *dьlь, etc.}];269[{The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. esp. Kloekhorst 2008:819-821, EWAia s.v. Ved. dīrghá- cited in this class), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed. The reconstructed root form for this class follows the LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.}];105[130{S.v. Alb. gjathë 'long', from Proto-Albanian *dlata continuing IE *dln̥gʰ-to- and related to other IE adjectives for 'long' from *(d)longʰ-o- (Lat. longus, Goth. lagga, etc.).}];353[199-200{S.v. Lith. ìlgas 'long' (Latv. il̃gs 'long (of time)', from PIE *dlh₁gʰ-ó- (cf. Skt. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός).}];165[327{S.v. Proto-Germanic langa- 'long', identical to Lat. longus 'long', a nasalised version of the PIE root *dlh₁gʰ- 'long'. "The adjective thus implies a nasal present *dlénh₁gʰ-e-, which, however, is not attested."}];389[{Cf. in LIV addenda and corrigenda – Neu: ?2.*delh₁- 'verlängern'       (IEW 194‑6), Präsens ?*dl̥h₁-éi̯o-   aksl. (+) pro-dьľǫ, -dьliti 'verlängern' (Anm. 1 Verbal nur slav. (primär?), Basis vieler Nomina, z.B. aruss. dьlja ‘Länge’ und v.a. die Adj. *dl̥h₁-gʰó- in ved. dīrghá- = av. darəga-, aksl. (+) dlъgъ sowie *dolh₁-i-gʰo- > gr. δολιχός neben *dolh₁-u-Ki- > heth. daluki-, alle ‘lang’| *h₁ wegen gr. ἐν-δελεχής zu einem neugebildeten *δέλεχος n. < *délh₁gʰos, vgl. Stüber 172-4 mit Lit.).}];369[184-185{S.v. Alb. gjáthë 'lang', generally connected to Ved. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός, OCS dlъgъ, etc., perhaps from PIE *dlh₁gʰó- > Proto-Albanian *glag(h)V́- or (?) *glág(h)a-tV- > Old Albanian glatë.}];352[392-393{S.v. OLith. ìlgas 'lang' (BSl. Latv. il̃gs 'lang, langdauernd', OPr. ilga (adv.) lange', OCS dlьgъ 'lang', etc.), from PIE *dlh₁gʰó- 'lang' (cf. Ved. dīrghá- 'lang, weitreichend| langdauernd', OAv. darəga- 'lang', YAv. darəγa- 'lang', Alb. gjátë 'lang'. For the lack of the dental in initial position of the Proto-Baltic adjective for 'long' there is no commonly accepted explanation.}];697[360-361{S.v. Gmc. *langa- 'lang', an inherited adjective identical with Lat. longus 'lang' < PIE *dlongho-, next to this stands *dl̥əgho- in Ved. dīrghá-, OAv. darəga-, Gk. δολιχός, OCS dlьgъ, cf. also Hitt. dalugai- 'lang'. Probably related to Ved. drā́ghate 'macht lang, ermüdet, quält'.}]
Justification: The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. esp. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):819-821, [EWAia](src-172) I:728-729), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):819-821, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):184-185, [Orel 1998](src-105):130, [EWAia](src-172) I:728-729, [ALEW](src-352) 392-393, [Derksen 2015](src-353):199-200, [Derksen 2008](src-81):133, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):360-361, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):327, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):348). The reconstructed root form for this class follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Source: 441[370-371{S.v. OHG fleisc 'Fleisch, Fleischstück'. The word has correspondences in all Germanic languages except Gothic| from Proto-Germanic *flajska-. The gender is consistently neuter. Secure connections outside of Germanic are lacking. Occasionally compared to the verbal root in Lith. plė́šiu (plė́šti) '(ab-)reißen, abschälen' and the Germanic strong verb *flaχan- (OIc. flá, OE flēan, MDu. vlaen 'schinden').}];388[104{S.v. Proto-Germanic *flaiska-, of uncertain origin.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *flaiska-, without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([EWA 3](src-441):370-371, [Orel 2003](src-388):104, not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).

Source: 165[60{S.v. Proto-Germanic *berga- 'mountain', from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ-o- (cf. OIr. bri 'hill, plain' < *bʰrg̑ʰ-eh₂-| Arm. barjr 'high', Hitt. parku- 'id.' < bʰrg̑ʰ-u-| Skt. br̥hánt-, Av. bərəz(ant)- 'high' < *bʰrg̑ʰ-ent-).}];274[30{S.v. *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'hoch werden, sich erheben' (LIV 78f., IEW 140f.).}];141[78–79{Cf. s.v. *bʰerg̑ʰ- ‘hoch werden, sich erheben’ (IEW 140-1).}];50[77{S.v. Proto-Celtic *brig- 'hill', from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'be high, hill' (Gaul. -briga [in Toponyms], Brig-antes [Ethnonym]).}];157[87{S.v. Gaul. briga 'colline, mont' > 'forteresse', cf. in Insular Celtic OIr. brí 'colline' < *brigs < *bʰr̥g̑ʰs, W, Co. Bret. bre 'id.', from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'haut'.}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to be(come) high, to rise up' ([NIL](src-274) 30, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):60, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):87, [Matasović 2009](src-50):77, [LIV²](src-141) 78-79).

Source: 165[376-377{S.v. Proto-Germanic *munþa- 'mouth', from PIE *mnt-o- (cf. Lat. mentum 'chin', MW mant 'mandible, gums' < *mnt-o-. The root may also be identified in Gk. μασάομαι 'to chew, bite' (as though from *mnt-i-eh₂-ie-) and Lat. mandō 'to chew' < *mnt-néh₂- (with dissimilation of the first n, schwa secundum from the resulting form *mt-nā-, and prenasalisation under Thurneysen's Law).}];179[261{S.v. Goth. M83. munϸs 'στόμα', 'mouth' (cf. OI munnr, mūðr, OS muð, 'mouth, opening', OFris 'mūth, mund' OHG munt 'mouth'| possibly also to OI mēl 'minþla, OE miþl, OHG mindil 'bit, bridle'). Two possible etymologies: (1) to PIE *menth- 'chew, mouth' (Gk. μασάομαι, Lat. mandō 'chew', or, less likely, (2) PIE *men- 'project' (Lat. ē-minēre 'stand out', mentum 'chin' < *mn̥-to- (cf. Wel mant 'jaw(bone)', MIr. mant 'gum, jaw(bone)' (cf. IEW 732-33 menth-, 726 men-).}];269[{Generally considered to be of IE origin, but the precise IE etymology is disputed. From PIE *ment-, if [Kroonen 2013](src-165):376-377's reconciliation of the two earlier possible etymologies from [IEW](src-49) (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):261) is correct. Etymology outside of Germanic otherwise uncertain| cf. [Boutkan & Siebinga 2005](src-82) for extensive discussion of alternative hypotheses.}];82[272-273{Cf. s.v. OFris. muth 'mouth, [fig.] opening, wound', from Proto-Germanic *munϸa-. No certain IE etymology. The word is generally believed to be IE| there are several possible derivations, but none are generally agreed. Cf. entry for further discussion and extensive references to further literature.}]
Justification: Generally considered to be of IE origin, but the precise IE etymology is disputed. From PIE *ment-, if [Kroonen 2013](src-165):376-377's reconciliation of the two earlier possible etymologies from [IEW](src-49) (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):261) is correct. Etymology outside of Germanic otherwise uncertain; cf. [Boutkan & Siebinga 2005](src-82) for extensive discussion of alternative hypotheses.

Source: 274[301-303{S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (LIV 264f., IEW 42f.).}];81[388{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ǫzъkъ 'narrow', from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-u- (cf. Skt. aṃhú-, Lat. angustus, Goth. aggwus).}];172[I:39{S.v. Ved. aṁhú-, only in aṁhú-bhédi- 'engspaltig', from PIE *h₂eNg̑ʰ-ú-, (cf. Lat. angi- in angi-portus, Goth. aggwu, OCS ǫzъkъ).}];165[28-29{S.v. Proto-Germanic *angwu- 'narrow', from PIE h₂emg̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Skt. aṃhú- 'narrow', MP hnzwg- 'id.', Arm. anj-uk 'narrow, difficult', OCS ǫzъkъ 'narrow'| OIr. cumung, < *(kom-)h₂emg̑ʰ-u-).}];54[42{S.v. Lat. angō, -ere 'to strangle, to choke', from which Lat. angustus 'narrow' is a derived adjective. Lat. angō goes back to PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-e/o- 'to tie, tighten', whereas angustus is as if from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-os-to- 'characterised by narrowness'.}];141[264-265{S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (IEW 42-3).}];50[36, 214{S.v. Proto-Celtic *angu- and *kom-angu- 'narrow', from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-u- 'tight, narrow, contricted' (cf. Skt. aṃhú- 'narrow', Lat. angō 'strangle', OHG engi 'narrow', OCS ǫzъkъ).}];259[682{PS *ǫzŭkŭ is derived from PIE *ang̑ʰ- 'narrow', cf. German eng, Latin angustis, Old Indic aṁhús etc.}];79[74-75{S.v. Arm. anjuk 'narrow| difficult', long since connected to PIE *h₂(e)ng̑ʰ-u- 'narrow' (Skt. aṁhu-, Goth. aggwu, etc.).}]
Justification: Armenian, Indic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to hinder, restrict' ([NIL](src-274) 301-303, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):94-95, [EWAia](src-172) I:39, [Derksen 2008](src-81):388, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):28-29, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):42, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36, 214)

Source: 165[387{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nēhwa- 'near', a lengthened-grade adjective derived from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach'.}];397[647{S.v. NHG nah(e) (MHG nāch, nācher, OHG nāh, OS nāh), from Gmc. *nǣhwa- (adj.) 'nah', also in Goth. neƕ(a), ON ná, OE nēah, OFr. nēi.). Most likely to be an adjectival formation to a local particle *nē which appears in OCS mna, Ru. na 'auf, an, zu'. Perhaps further to OCS vъznakъ 'zurückgeneigt, rücklings', Ved. nāka- 'Firmament, näherer Himmel'.}];179[265{S.v. Goth. N14. neƕ adv. (only atiddja neƕ razn / ἤγγισεν τῇ οἰκίᾳ 'he approached the house'), neƕa adj. 'ἐγγύς', 'near'. Within Germanic OI nā-, OE nēah, OFris. nēi, nī, OS, OHG nāh, OS, OHG nāhōr 'closer, near', etc. Etymology obscure, possibly to Skt. náśati, Lat. nanciō 'draw near, arrive'.}];698[409-412{S.v. Gmc. *nǣhwa- 'nah'. No direct correspondences outside of Germanic. Seebold (cf. [Kluge 2002](src-350):644 [= [Kluge 2011](src-397):647]) considers in Proto-Germanic *nǣhwa- an adjectival formation to IE local particle *nē and connected with OCS vъznakъ 'zurückgeneigt, rücklings', Ru. na (prep.) 'auf, an, zu', and perhaps further to Ved. nā́ka- 'Firmament, näherer Himmel' which would have developed from an original meaning 'zugeneigt, in Richtung auf, da', while Bammesburger 1990:257f. (following [IEW](src-49) 316f. and others) suggest a connection to *h₂nek̑- 'reichen'. In the latter case Gmc. *nǣhwa- would have to be explained as a lengthened grade formation.}];84[{S.v. Engl. near (adv.2). The comparative degree of the adjective replaced the original positive degree i.e. *'nearer' > 'near', probably after the same development in Scandinavian (cf. OIc. nær 'nearer' having taken over the positive sense 'near').}]
Justification: Connections outside of Germanic disputed: the principal hypotheses are (1) an adjectival formation based on a local particle *nē- (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):647) or (2) a lengthened-grade formation to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain; accomplish' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):387). See [Faltings 2010](src-698):409-412 for further discussion (not in [Heidermanns 1993](src-697)). The Scandinavian and Modern English forms in this class are originally the comparative degree of the adjective which had taken over the meaning of the positive degree, i.e. *'nearer' > 'near' (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 54[125{S.v. Lat. collus 'neck (of men and animals)', from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ol(H)s/no- (cf. Goth. hals, OHG hals, ONor. hals, etc.). The word may be derived from the word for 'wheel' (cf. Lith. kãklas 'neck' < *kʷo-kʷl-o- from PIE *kʷel(H)- 'to turn'. The Germanic forms are often related to the same root as the Baltic ones, but it is uncertain whether *kʷo- was regularly unrounded to *ha- in Germanic.}];165[205{S.v. Proto-Germanic *halsa- 'neck', from PIE *kols-o- (cf. Lat. collum 'neck| hill' from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ols-o-).}];395[95{Reconstructs (post-)PIE *kólso- 'neck' (cf. Lat. collum) > PGmc. *halsaz (cf. Goth. hal, OE heals).}];269[{Root etymology disputed. Root ref. form follows [Ringe 2006](src-395):95. If ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388), then these lexemes may be root-cognate with the Baltic lexemes in [cognate set 1868](cog-1868), but the etymology of the Baltic lexemes is less than certain| cf. further discussion in that cognate class. Alternatively a root etymology has been proposed to PIE *kelH- 'to tower, soar' (cf. [EWA 4](src-415) 477-480).}];415[777-780{S.v. OHG hals 'Hals, Nacken| cervix, collum', from Proto-Germanic *χalsa- and generally connected with Lat. collum 'Hals'. The IE root etymology is difficult to ascertain| the most attractive candidate semantically is *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen' (> *kʷolso-), however the necessary delabialisation of the labiovelar would be irregular. Alternatively one could propose PIE *kolH-so- to PIE *kelH- 'aufragen, hochragen'.}]
Justification: Germanic and Italic lexemes as though from PIE *kólso- 'neck' (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):95, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):205, [EWA 4](src-415) 777-780, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):125). Root etymology disputed. Root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of [Ringe 2006](src-395):95. If ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388), then these lexemes may be root-cognate with the Baltic lexemes in [cognate set 1868](cog-1868), but the etymology of the Baltic lexemes is less than certain; cf. further discussion in that cognate class. Alternatively a root etymology has been proposed to PIE *kelH- 'to tower, soar' (cf. [EWA 4](src-415) 477-480).

Source: 274[504-513{S.v. 1. *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' (LIV 449, IEW 762f.). PIE nom.sg. *nokʷt-, gen.sg. *nekʷt- 'night' from the root *negʷ- 'to become dark' (LIV 449) with devoicing of the final consonant next to *-t-. See fn. 1 with a discussion of the different stem analyses and inflectional patterns which have been suggested for PIE.}];66[1027{S.v. νύξ, νυκτός 'night' < PIE *nekʷt-, nokʷt- 'night' (perh. from *negʷʰ- 'become dark' with a *-t- root extension).}];105[282-283{S.v. Alb. natë 'night', from Proto-Albanian *nakti- corresponding to IE *nokʷt- (cf. Skt. nakt-, Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, etc.).}];172[II:2-3{S.v. Ved. nakt- 'Nacht' (YAv. upa.naxtar- 'an die Nacht angrenzend', Wakhi naγd 'Nacht'), from PIE *nókʷt-s (nom.sg.) ~ nékʷt-s 'Nacht', perhaps assimilated from *ne/ogʷ-t-, cf. Hitt. ne-ku-[uz]-zi 'wird Abend' < *negʷ-ti. Cf. Hitt. nekuz (gen.sg.) 'of the evening', Gk. νύξ (νύκτ-), Lat. nox (noct-), Goth. nahts, Lith. naktìs, OCS noštь, etc. 'Nacht'.}];141[449{Cf. s.v. *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' (IEW 762-3). As a verbal root only Hittite (Hitt. nekuzzi 'es wird dunkel, es dämmert' < *negʷ-/n̥gʷ-). Cf. n1 regarding the derived t-stem *nógʷt-/*négʷt- 'Abend, Nacht'.}];80[602{Cf. s.v. Hitt. neku- 'to become evening', reconstructing the original root alternatively as *negʷʰ- on the basis of Gk. ἔννυχος 'nightly' and the Hitt. velar <-ku->.}];353[327-328{S.v. Lith. naktìs 'night', from PIE *nokʷ-t- (cf. Skt. nákt-, Hitt. nekuz [gen.sg.] 'in the evening', Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, Goth. nahts).}];81[355{S.v. Proto-Slavic *noktь 'night', from PIE *nokʷ-t- (cf. Skt. nákt-, Hitt. nekuz [gen.sg.] 'in the evening', Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, Goth. nahts).}];165[381{S.v. Proto-Germanic *naht- 'night', from PIE *nokʷ-t- (cf. Hitt. nekuz 'in the evening' < *nekʷ-t-s| Gk. νύξ, νυκτός 'night', Lat. nox, noctis 'id.', Lith. naktìs 'id.', OCS noštь 'id.' < *nokʷ-t-).}];54[416-417{S.v. Lat. nox 'night', from PIE *nógʷʰ-t-s (nom.sg.), négʷʰ-t-s (gen.sg.) 'night', following the root reconstruction of Kloekhorst (2008:602).}];50[293-294{S.v. Proto-Celtic *noxtV- 'night', from PIE *nokʷt- 'night' (cf. Hitt. nekuz (mēhur) 'at the time of night', Skt. nákt-, Gk. νύξ, Lat. nox, Lith. naktìs, OCS noštь, Alb. natë, TochB nekcīye 'at night'). Matasović considers the Middle Welsh nos a loanword from Lat. nox., but cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):121 who considers it inherited.}];369[283-284{S.v. Alb. nát/ë, -a 'Nacht, Morgendämmerung, früher Morgen', from the inherited IE word for 'night' (cf. Ved. nák, Lith. naktìs, Lat. nox, noctis, etc.).}];352[683-684{S.v. OLith. naktìs 'Nacht' (BSl. Latv. nakts 'Nacht', OPr. naktin 'Nacht', OCS noštь), from PIE *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' *nókʷ-t-, *nekʷ-t- 'Nacht' (cf. Hitt. nekuz (mēhur) 'Abend(zeit)', Ved. nákt- 'Nacht', Gk. νύξ, νυκτός 'Nacht', Alb natë 'Nacht, Morgendämmerung', Lat. nox, noctis 'Nacht', OIr. innocht 'heute Nacht', OW nos 'Nacht', Bret. noz 'id.', Goth. nahts 'Nacht', TochA nokte (adv.) 'nachts').}];240[121{S.v. Old Welsh nos 'night' (MW nos, OC nos, OB nos| cf. OIr. innocht < PIE *nokʷt-stu-, IE *nekʷ-(t-), *nokʷ-(t-).}];309[539-540{S.v. Bret. nos 'nuit, soir', from Old Breton nos 'nuit', corresponding to Co. nôs (OCo. nos), W nos, and OIr. nocht, all going back to Celtic *nok-ti-, apparently from Lat. nox.}];458[25: 175-177{S.v. PS *noktĭ.}];321[242{S.v. Wa. naɣ̌d 'ночь', from Old Iranian *naγda- < *naxta(r)- (cf. Av. [upa.]naxtar-, Ved. nákt-, Lat. noct-is).}];328[173-174, 24{The Brittonic forms MW, MCorn., OBr., MBr. nos 'night' etc. are based on *nox(s)s < PIE *nókʷts. Contrary to this, it is traditionally assumed that nos is based on a suffixed form PCl. *noxt-stu-, as suggested by Pedersen (1909, 123) and followed e.g. by Fleuriot (1964a, 271), Matasović (2009, 294). PIE *nokʷ-t- is also found in the adverb OW henoid, MW henoeth, MBr. henoez, MCorn. haneth 'tonight', lit. 'this night', which contains pronominal *se- or *so- as a first element and Dat/Loc.Sg. PCl. *noxt-i or AccSg. *noxt-am as a second (Schrijver 1997, 24).}]
Justification: Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *nógʷt-/*négʷt- 'evening, night', a dental-stem derivative of PIE *negʷ- 'to become dark, dawn' ([NIL](src-274) 504-513, [LIV²](src-141) 449, cf. {ref {Beekes 2010}:1027, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):283-284, [Orel 1998](src-105):282-283, [EWAia](src-172) II:2-3, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):242, [ALEW](src-352) 683-684, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327-328, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:175-177, [Derksen 2008](src-81):355, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):381, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):416-417, [Matasović 2009](src-50):293-294). The Brythonic lexemes in this class are sometimes considered to be (parallel?) loanwords from Latin (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):293-294, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):539-540), but by others to be inherited (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):121, [NIL](src-274) 509n10). The assumption that these lexemes are inherited has been followed here.

Source: 165[383{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nasō- ~ *nusō- 'nose', as though from PIE *nh̥₂-s-eh₂-. Traditionally the root is reconstructed as *nā̆s- with a-vocalism (Pokorny IEW: 755), but Kortlandt (1985b:119) postulated an ablauting s-stem nom. *néh₂-s, gen. *nh₂-s-ós, acc. *nh₂-és-m in order to account for the ablaut of e.g. Lith. nósis  < *neh₂-s- vs. Ru. nos < *nh₂-es-.}];49[755{S.v. nas- ‚Nase‘ (näs- aus den dehnstufen Kasus dieses kons. St., ursprüngl. dem Nom. Sg.), ursprüngl. wohl ‚Nasenloch‘}];172[II:30-31{S.v. Ved. nás- 'Nase' (YAv. nā̊ŋha), from PIE *(H)nas- (cf. Lat. nāris, Lith. nósis, OHG nasa, Russ.-CS nosъ 'Nase', etc.).}];81[357{S.v. Proto-Slavic *nosъ 'nose', following Kortlandt (1985b:119) from PIE *nh₂-es-/*neh₂-s- (cf. Skt. nás-, Lat. nāris, OHG nasa 'nose').}];353[336-337{S.v. Lith. nósis, following Kortlandt (1985b:119) from PIE *nh₂-es-/*neh₂-s- (cf. Skt. nás-, Lat. nāris, OHG nasa 'nose').}];54[400{S.v. Lat. nāris 'nose| pl. nostrils, nose', from PIE *Hneh₂-s-, *Hnh₂-es-, *Hnh₂-s- (cf. Skt. nas- 'nose', YAv. nā̊ŋha, (nom.acc.du.?), Lith. nósis, Latv. nãss, RuCS nosъ, OHG nasa, OE nasu 'nose').}];640[119{Reconstructs a paradigm nom.sg. *neh₂s, acc.sg. *neh₂sm, gen.sg. *nh₂os.}];269[{The reconstruction for the PIE form underlying this class is disputed. Traditionally *(H)nas- (cf. IEW 755, Mayrhofer, EWAia s.v. Ved. nás-, ALEW s.v. Lith. nósis), elsewhere Kortlandt (1985b:119) argues for a reconstruction as an s-stem to a root *neh₂-. For the purposes of a root ref. form I give *(H)nā̆s-.}];352[711{S.v. OLith. nósis 'Nase' (BSl. Latv. nãss, nãse 'Nasenflügel, Nüster', OPr. nozy 'Nase', OCS nosъ 'Nase'), from PIE *nā́s-/*nas- 'Nasenflügel, Nüster' (cf. Ved. n.du. nā́sā, g.du. nasóṣ 'Nase', YAv. n.du. nā̊ŋha 'Nase', OPers. a.sg. nāham 'Nase', Lat. naris 'Nasenloch, Nüster', nāsus, nāsum 'Nase', ON nǫs, n.pl. nasar 'Nasenloch, Nüster', OE nasu, etc.).}];458[25: 212-216{S.v. PS *nosŭ.}];657[395{Cf. s.v. NOSE *hₓnáss ~ *hₓnā́s (gen. hₓnasos) 'nose'.}]
Comment: Vedic -:nas(-a)- as a second member in compounds confirms *H in root onset, ergo PIE *Hnas-
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing an Indo-European word for 'nose' traditionally reconstructed as *(H)nā̆s- ([EIEC](src-657) 395, cf. [IEW](src-49) 755), although Leiden school of Indo-European reconstructs an ablauting s-stem *neh₂-s- (cf. [Kortlandt 1985b](src-640):119). The traditional reconstruction has been followed here for the purpose of a root reference form. For individual branches cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:30-31, [ALEW](src-352) 711, [Derksen 2015](src-353):336-337, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:212-216, [Derksen 2008](src-81):357, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):383, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):400)

Source: 165[20{S.v. Proto-Germanic *alda- adj. '(grown) old' from PIE *h₂el-tó- (cf. Lat. altus adj. 'high', OIr. alt m. 'height, cliff'.  From fem. *h₂el-teh₂- > Welsh allt 'hill'). From the same root *h₂el- found in Proto-Germanic *alan- 'to grow up| to rear' (cf. Lat. alere 'to nourish', OIr. alid 'to feed').}];141[262{Cf. s.v. *h₂el- 'nähren, aufziehen' (IEW 26-7).}];697[97-98{S.v. Gmc. *alda- 'alt', an inherited formation identical with Gk. (Hom.) ἄν-αλτος 'unersättlich', just as Lat. altus 'hoch, tief', adultus 'erwachsen'. The verbal basis is attested in Lat. alō, OIr. ailid, Gmc. *ala- 'nähren, aufziehen'.}];179[29-30{S.v. Goth. A137. alϸeis 'γέρων', 'old'. Differing in suffix from CrimGo. alt 'senex', OE eald, OFris, OS ald, OHG alt, 'old', etc. but from the same root, PIE *al- 'grow' + -to- (cf. Gk. ἄν-αλτος 'insaitiable, Lat. altus 'high', ad-ultus 'adult', OIr. al 'bank').}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *alda- '(grown) old', further from PIE *h₂el-tó-, a verbal adjective to PIE *h₂el- 'to nourish, rear' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):29-30, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):97-98, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):20, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 262).

Source: 165[467{S.v. Proto-Germanic *spila- 'play| game'| Also cf. the apparently denominal OE spilian, OS spilon, Du. spelen, OHG spilon, G spielen w.v. 'to play' < *spilōjan-. No certain etymology.}];397[867{Cf. s.v. NHG Spiel (MHD spil, OHG spil, MLG spel(e), spil, spol(e), MDu. spel), to which the verb MHG spil(e)n, OHG spilōn. The original meaning seems to be 'Tanz', 'tanzen'| everything else is unclear.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing denominal verbal formations from Proto-Germanic Proto-Germanic *spila- 'play, game', further etymology unclear (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):867, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):467).

Source: 165[522{S.v. Proto-Germanic *trek(k)an- 'to pull', from PIE *drég⁽ʰ⁾-e- (cf. Lith. dìrginti 'to pull (the trigger)' < *drg-neh₂-| OCS drъgati 'to shudder', Ru. dērgat' 'to jerk' < *drg⁽ʰ⁾-eh₂-, etc.).}];556[506-507{S.v. Gmc. *trek-a- 'ziehen', probably belonging to the complex of variants related to Germanic *drag-a-. The gemination of -k- > -kk- probably originated in a North Sea Germanic dialect, similarly to bak-a- and skrekk-a-.}];757[{S.v. Du. trekken 'naar zich toe halen, slepen| gaan'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([EWNl](src-757)). Often assumed to be connected in some way with Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry' (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):506-507, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):522) but the sound changes necessary to make this connection are irregular.

165[408{S.v. Proto-Germanic *regna- 'rain'. There are not yet any convincing etymological proposals outside of Germanic.  Connections with Lat. irrigāre and Albanian rjedh are possible but uncertain.}];397[753{S.v. NHG Regen (MHG regen, OHG regan, OS regan-, regin) from Gmc. *regna- m./n. 'Regen', also in Goth. rign, ON regn, OE regn, rēn, OFr. rein. Origin unclear.}];179[284{S.v. Goth. R20. rign 'βροχή', 'rain'. Etymology unclear| cf. entry for various uncertain proposals.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *regna- 'rain', further etymology unclear (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):284, [Kluge 2011](src-397):753, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):408).

Source: 141[304–305{Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-7).}];165[408{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rehta-, from PIE * h₃reg̑-to- (cf. Av. rāšta- 'right', Gk. ὀρεκτός, Lat. rectus 'right').}];443[3:87-91{S.v. Lat. directus (= di-rectus), from which Fr. droit, etc.}];54[517-518{S.v. Lat. regō 'to direct, guide, govern', from PIE *h₃reg̑-e/o- 'guide, direct' (p.p.p. rēctum).}];172[II:425, I:252-253{Cf. s.v. Ved. √raj-² 'sich gerade ausstrecken, sich in gestreckte Bewegung setzen', from PIE *h₃reg̑- (Gk. ὀρέγω, Lat. regō, OIr. rigim, etc.). For YAv. ərəzu- cf. s.v. Ved. r̥jú- < *h₃r̥g̑-ú-.}];179[231{S.v. Goth. R5. *raihts 'εὐθύς', 'straight' with derived stem ga-raihts 'δίκαιος', 'just, righteous', from PIE *reg̑-, *rek̑-to/u- (cf. OPers. rāsta-, 'straight (way)'| Lat. rēctus 'straight, upright', OIr. recht 'law, authority', etc.).}];444[241{S.v. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade', 2. dērēctus.}];321[459{S.v. Wa. wʊrzg(ə) 'правый' (о руке), cf. Av. ərəzu-.}]
Justification: Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ([EWAia](src-172) I:252-253, II:425, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):459, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):231, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):408, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):517-518, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):241 no. 2648, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:87-91, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 304-305).

Source: 468[452{S.v. ON rotinn 'verfault', cf. OE rotian 'verfaulen, verwesen'.}];556[381{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *reut-a- '(faulen)'. The Old West Norse past passive participle rotinn 'verfault' may go back to *reut-a- 'faulen'. There are no secure cognates outside of Germanic. (Cf. secondary formations via OE rotian-, OHG rozzen, as though from *rut-ǣ-.)}];388[303{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *reutanan- (II) (str.vb. I). Of unknown origin.}]
Justification: No certain cognates outside of Germanic, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):381; [Orel 2003](src-388):303. No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 317[424, fn. 2103{The reconstruction of the PIE form is difficult. The underlying noun may be either root noun or an l-stem, belonging to one of several possible accentual patterns. The proto-forms of the individual branches display thus varying degrees of analogical levelling. Possibilities: *săl- < *sh₂l- or *sh₂al-| *sāl- < *sah₂l-| alternatively < *sh₂ḗl- or *sh₂ṓl- with analogical influence of *săl-.}];72[177{Reconstructs a hysterokinetic l-stem with the following ablaut: NSg. *séh₂‑l‑s, ASg. *sh₂‑el‑m, GSg. *sh₂‑l‑ós, cf. Kortlandt (1985:119).}];274[586-590{S.v. *sal- 'Salz' (IEW 878f., EIEC 498).  Cf. n1 on possible alternative reconstructions and references to further literature.  Cf. esp. Rieken (1999:424f.) for further discussion.}];165[425{S.v. Proto-Germanic *salta- 'salt', a neuter collective noun derived from the strong verb saltan- 'to salt (down), pickle', from *sh₂ld-ie-, an extended form of the stem *sh₂el-, cf. (Lith. saldùs 'sweet', OCS sladъkъ 'id.', Ru. dial. solódkij 'id.').}];66[74-75{S.v. ἅλς, ἁλός 'salt' < PIE *seh₂-l- 'salt'.}];640[119{Reconstructs N.sg. *seh₂ls, A.sg. *sh₂elm, G.sg. *sh₂los.}];345[742{S.v. TochB salyiye 'salt', reflecting pre-Proto-Tocharian *sali-h₂en-, a derivative of PIE *sali- 'salty' (cf. Skt. sali-la- 'salty, ocean', Arm. sał (an i-stem), Old Lat. sale 'salt', OCS salь| more distantly Gk. ἅλς, Lat. sāl, etc.).}];79[24, 40-41{S.v. Arm. ał 'salt' and ałt 'salt'| connected to Gk. ἅλς, Lat. sāl, etc.}];81[461{S.v. *solь 'salt', from PIE *sh₂el- (cf. Gk. ἅλς, Lat. sāl, OHG salz, OIr. salann).}];353[548-549{S.v. Latv. sā̀ls 'salt', from PIE *seh₂-l-, *sh₂-el-. Latv. sā̀ls reflects the N.sg. *sēh₂-l-s of a hysterodynamic paradigm according to Kortlandt (1985b:118-119).}];50[319{S.v. Proto-Celtic *salano- 'salt', a derivative of PIE *seh₂l- 'salt'.}];54[535{S.v. Lat. sāl, salis 'salt', from PIE *sē̆h₂-l-s (nom.), *sh₂-él-m (acc.), *sh₂-l-ós (gen.) 'salt'| *sh₂l-d- (or *sh₂el-d- or *seh₂l-d- 'salt'), cf. OIr. salann 'salt', Gk. ἅλς 'salt', Latv. sā̀ls 'salt', OCS solь, 'salt', Lith. saldùs 'sweet', OCS sladъkъ 'sweet', Goth. salt, OHG salz, etc.}];352[887-888{Cf. s.v. OLith. sálti 'süß werden' (BSl. Latv. sā̀ls 'Salz', OPr. sal 'Salz', OCS solь 'Salz', etc.), from PIE *sal- 'Salz' (cf. Gk. ἅλς, ἁλός 'Salz', Arm. ał 'Salz', Lat. sāl, G.sg. sălis 'Salz| Meerwasser', OIr. sál 'Salzwasser, Meer', MW halwyn 'Salz', Goth. salt 'Salz', TochB salyiye 'Salz').}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ([NIL](src-274) 586-590, [EIEC](src-657) 498, [IEW](src-49) 878-879, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):742, [Beekes 2010](src-66):177, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):24, 40-41, [ALEW](src-352) 887-888, [Derksen 2015](src-353):548-549, [Derksen 2008](src-81):461, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):425, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):535, [Matasović 2009](src-50):319). The root is difficult to reconstruct; the traditional reconstruction as *sal- has been followed here after [NIL](src-274), but note in order to avoid reconstructing PIE *a the Leiden school reconstructs a hysterokinetic l-stem: nom.sg. *séh₂‑l‑s, acc.sg. *sh₂‑el‑m, gen.sg. *sh₂‑l‑ós ([Kortlandt 1985b](src-640):119, [Beekes 1995](src-72):177, cf. also [Rieken 1999](src-317):424n2103). The Germanic forms in this set show an extension in *d which may be on analogy to *su̯eh₂d- 'sweet' [cognate set 5109](cog-5109), alternatively the *-d- might be explained as a compound with the root *deh₃- 'give' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 886-887 s.v. Old Lithuanian saldùs 'sweet' and further discussion in [cognate set 5157](cog-5157)).

Source: 47[22{Connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to the same original stem *samdʰo-.}];395[11, 101{Reconstructs *sámh₂dʰos > (cf. Gk. ἄμαθος) > *sámədʰos > *sámdʰos > PGmc. *samdaz > ONor. sandr, OEng. sand, OHG sant.}];657[499{Cf. R.S.P. Beekes s.v. SAND: "?*samh̥ªdhos 'sand' [IEW 146 (*bhes-)| Wat 8 (*bhes-)| Buck 1.215]. Lat. sabulum 'sand' ?saburra 'sand in a ship as ballast', ON sandr 'sand', NE (dial.) samel 'sand bottom', OHG sant, MHG sant ~ sampt 'sand', Grk ἄμαθος 'sand'. The Greek form cannot be separated from ψάμαθος and ψάμμος 'sand', while the MHG sampt can hardly represent an old variant and, even if it is one, it can hardly be an alternative development of a PIE form. A reconstruction along the lines of *samhªdhos is impossible and the a vocalism suggests a non-IE status for the word. This is even more evident if Lat. sabulum is regarded cognate. The status of Arm awaz 'sand' is unclear."}];269[{Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.}];165[425-426{S.v. Proto-Germanic *samda- 'sand'. "Most forms point to *sanda- but MHG sampt can only be explained from *samda- < *samdʰ-o-, which is close to Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ-o- […]. Given the formal irreconcilabilities between Gm. *samda-, Lat. sabulum < *sadʰ-lo- and Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ- (the ψ of ψάμαθος was used to substitute s- after the Greek shift to h) the conclusion must be that the word is of non-IE origin ([Kuiper 1995](src-658):67): it was probably adopted from a set of linguistically affiliated languages when Germanic, Italic, and Greek arrived in West-Europe. In view of the meaning 'sand', it is extremely unlikely, at any rate, that the word spread across Europe as a Wanderwort."}];79[149-150];658[67]
Justification: Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Source: 165[420{S.v. Proto-Germanic *sagjan- 'to say, recount' from PIE *sokʷ-éi̯e/o-  (cf. SCS sočiti 'to indicate', Ru. sočít' (sočú) 'to look for, track down, summon', SCr. sòčiti 'to establish the guilt of, reveal, find'| Lat. īnsece 'to tell', Gk. ἐν(ν)έπω 'to say, recount, announce').}];141[526-527{S.v. 2. *sekʷ- 'sagen' (IEW 897-8).}];353[387{S.v. Lith. sakýti 'say' from PIE *sokʷ-eie- (cf. OIc. segja 'say', OS seggian 'say', Proto-Slavic *sočìti 'indicate, accuse' > SerbCS sočiti 'indicate', etc.).}];50[328{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sekʷ-o- 'say', from PIE *sekʷ- 'say' (cf. Gk. ενν-έπω 'tell', Lat. in-seque 'say!', inquit 'says', OHG sagen).}];352[884-886{S.v. OLith. sakýti 'sagen, verkünden, predigen' (BSl. cf. Latv. sacît, saku, sacĩju 'sagen', etc.), from PIE *sekʷ- 'sagen', *sokʷ-éi̯e/o- (cf. ON segja 'sagen', saga 'Erzählung, Sage', OE secgan 'sagen', sagu 'Aussage, Erzählung', OHG sagēn 'sagen', saga 'Aussage, Erzählung').}];304[565-568{S.v. Proto-Celtic 2. *sekʷ-e/o- 'sagen', Anm. d) (PIE 2. *sekʷ-, LIV² 526f.). MW heb serves as a citation verb (cf. Latin inquit) which is usulally unmarked with regard to time, person and number. The 1sg. hebaf and the verbal noun hebu both occur only once in a poetic context involving a word play.  OBr. hep is attested twice as a citation verb, cf. Fleuriot (1964a, 209).}];301[209{OBr hep is attested twice as a citation verb, cf. hep Augustus 'says Augustus' (Angers 477A fo. 47b) and hep Teopil in suo libro 'says Teophil in his book' (Angers 477A fo, 80b). The fragmentary OBr sources do not contain any information about further finite forms of this verb, but it seems likely that OBr hep is defective like MW heb and that its use was restricted to the marking of citations. OBr hep is thus not the target.}]
Justification: Baltic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE 2. *sekʷ- 'to say' ([LIV²](src-141) 526-527, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 884-886, [Derksen 2015](src-353):387, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):420, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):565-568, [Matasović 2009](src-50):328).

Source: 54[365{S.v. Lat. mare 'sea| sea-water'. From PIE *mor-i- 'sea, lake' (cf. OIr. muir, W mor 'sea', Oss. mal 'stagnant water', OPr. mary, Lith. mãrės < *moriā, OCS morje, Ru. móre < *morio-, Go. mari-saihws, OIc. marr 'sea', OHG mari meri 'sea, lake'). If Ossetic mal 'stagnant water' is a loan-word from Gothic, then the word is exclusive to European branches of Indo-European.}];657[503-504{Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' may also be cognate to this class, [cf. Abaev 1959-1995 Vol. II, pp.68-69]. If the Ossetic form it is not a loanword, then the distribution of the lexeme is not exclusively to the European branches of IE.}];81[325{S.v. Proto-Slavic *moŗe 'sea' (ESSJa XIX 227-230), from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Lat. mare, OIr. muir, Goth. marei).}];156[II:68-69{Cf. Oss. mal 'глубокая стоячая вода', from IE *mōri or *mōryo- 'sea' with regular *r > l before *i.}];353[305-306{Cf. Lith. mãrios 'isthmus| (dial.) sea', from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Lat. mare| OIr. muir, Goth. marei).}];165[354-355{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', from PIE *mor-i- (cf. Oss. mal 'stagnant water', Lat. mare 'sea', OIr. muir 'id.', MW mor 'id.' < *mor-i-| Lith. mãrios (f.pl.) 'id.' < *mor-ieh₂-, OCS morje, Ru. móre, SCr. mȍre, môre 'id.' < mor-io-).}];50[277{S.v. Proto-Celtic *mori- 'sea', from PIE *mori- 'sea, standing water' (cf. Lat. mare, OHG mari, meri 'sea, lake', OCS morje 'sea', Oss. mal 'standing water').}];458[19: 227-229{PS *moŕe is derived from PIe *mori 'sea'.}];301[259{In OBr. attested as the first member of several compounds like mor-bran gl. merges 'cormoran', lit. 'sea-raven' or mor-moch gl. delphini 'dolphin', lit. 'sea-pig'.}];309[519{The simple noun is attested in the Catholicon (1499), but the compound armor m. 'coast' is found already in 1384.}]
Justification: Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mor-i- 'lake, sea' (ESSJa} 19:227-229, [Derksen 2008](src-81):325, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):354-355, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):365, [Matasović 2009](src-50):277; cf. also [Derksen 2015](src-353):305-306 for Lithuanian mãrios 'isthmus; (dial.) sea'). Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' (cf. [EIEC](src-657) 503-504, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:68-69).

Source: 141[525-526{S.v. 1. *sekʷ- 'sich anschließen' (IEW 986-7)| Germanic forms are only questionably attached, cf. n7 often connected under the assumption of a semantic development 'see, have one's eye on' < *'follow (with one's eyes)'.}];165[431-432{S.v. Proto-Germanic *sehwan- 'to see', from PIE *sékʷ-e- (cf. Skt. sácate 'to follow', Gr. ἕπομαι 'id.', Lat. sequor , sequī 'id.', OIr. sechid 'id.'). "The Germanic verb corresponds to the PIE root *sekʷ- 'to follow'| apparently, the meaning shifted from 'to follow' to 'to keep an eye on'."}];556[387-388{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *sehw-a- 'sehen'. No certain comparisons| frequently connected with the IE root *sekʷ- 'follow' under the assumption of a semantic development 'follow with the eyes'.}]
Justification: Often connected to PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' under the assumption of a semantic development 'follow with the eyes'; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):431-432; [LIV²](src-141) 525-526; [Seebold 1970](src-556):387-388. Probably to be connected with Hitt. šākuu̯a- 'eye' in [cognate set 3305](cog-3305).

Source: 54[557{S.v. serō 'to plant, sow (seeds)' from a PIE reduplicated present *se-s(é)h₁-| Lat. sēmen < PIE *seh₁-mn̥-.}];141[517{Cf. s.v. *seh₁- 'eindrücken, einsetzen' → 'säen' (IEW 889-90).}];81[446{S.v. Proto-Slavic *sěmę 'seed', from PIE *seh₁-men- (cf. Lat. sēmen) 'seed').}];353[392{S.v. Lith. sė́kla 'seed, sperm' and Lith. sė́ti, from PIE *seh₁- 'to sow' (cf. Lat. serere 'sow', Goth. saian 'sow').}];165[428-430{S.v. Proto-Germanic *sēda- 'seed' and *sēdi- 'seed', respectively *-to- and *-ti- derivatives from PGmc. *sēan- 'to sow' from PIE *séh₁-e-.}];50[336{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sīlo- 'seed, descendants', to be derived from PIE *seh₁- 'sow' (cf. Lat. sēmen 'seed', OEng. sāwan 'sow').}];352[906-907{Cf. s.v. OLith. sė́ti 'säen', from which is derived sė́kla (1), sėklà (3) 'Same, Saat' (BSl. cf. Latv. sẽt 'säen',, sȩ̃kla 'Samen, Saat', OCS sěti 'säen', etc.) from PIE *seh₁- 'säen, eindrücken' (cf. Hitt. sai-, si- 'einprägen, sigeln, eindrücken, werfen', Lat. serō, -ere 'säen, anpflanzen', OIr. síl 'Samen, Nachkommenschaft', Goth. saian 'säen', etc.).}];259[546{PS *sěmę, sěmene 'seed' is related to Old Prussian semen, Latin sēmen, seminis, Old High German sāmo etc. and derived from PIE *sē-men- < PIE *sē- 'sow'.}];301[76{OBr. att 'seed, grain' with ommission of etymologic initial h-.}];309[319{OBr att, MBr., NBr., MW, W had, Corn. has from PCl. *sato-.}];305[377{Celtic has two different stems:  PIE *seh₁-lo- in W, B, hil, OIr. síl 'seed, offspring'| PIE *sh₁-to- > PCl. satom in W, B had, Corn. has 'seed, grain'}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁- 'to press in' → 'to sow' ([ALEW](src-352) 906-907, [Derksen 2015](src-353):392, [Derksen 2008](src-81):446, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):428-430, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):557, [Matasović 2009](src-50):336, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 517).

Source: 141[571-572{S.v. *sneh₁- ‘spinnen’ (IEW 973).}];165[385{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nēan- 'to sew', a strong verb derived from a PIE root *(s)neh₁- (cf. Gk. νέω 'to spin', Lat. neō, nēre 'id.', OIr. sníid 'to tie', W. nyddu 'to spin' < *snéh₁-, Ru. nit' 'thread', Lith. nýtis '(warp) thread' < nh₁i-ti-), cf. also PGmc. *nēϸlō 'needle'.}];556[447{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *snōw-a- 'winden', with related forms in OHG nāen 'nähen', etc.}];397[647{S.v. NHG nähen (MHG næjen, OHG nājan, MLG neien, neigen, etc., MDu. n(a)eyen| from pre-German *nǣ-ja-. Outside of Germanic one compares W nyddu, 'nähen', Lat. nēre, Gk. νεῖν| cf. also OIr. státhat 'Nadel', MIr. snīid 'dreht, bindet', Latv. snāt 'locker zusammendrehen, spinnen'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nēan- 'to sew', a strong verb continuing PIE *sneh₁- 'to spin (wool, etc.)' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):647, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):385, [LIV²](src-141) 571-572, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):447).

Source: 165[440-441, 444{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skarpa- ‘sharp’, an o-grade adjective derived to Proto-Germanic *skerban- ~ *skerpan- ~ *skrepan- 'to scrape, scratch', a strong verb based on the IE root *skrebʰ- (cf. Russ. skrestí, Latv. šķir̃ba 'fissure', Lith. skir̃bti 'to become sour', Lat. scrobis 'hole in the ground, pit').}];141[557-558{Cf. s.v. *(s)kerbʰ- 'scharf sein' (IEW 943-4)| cf. n1 with variant *b in Gmc. *skerpa- 'rauh, scharf'.}];697[487{S.v. Gmc. *skarpa- 'zusammengeschrumpft, rauh'. Only attested in North and West Germanic. The adjective can have a precise correspondence in Latv. skarbs 'scharf, streng, rauh' (if it is not a loanword). The ablauting adjective in ORu. ščьrbъ 'unvollständig, schadhaft' and OIr. cerb 'scharf, schneidend' (without s-mobile). The basis of these words is IE *(s)ker- 'schneiden'.}]
Justification: Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 557-558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):487.

Source: 397[551{S.v. NHG kurz (MHG kurz, OHG kurz, kurt), a loanword from Lat. curtus 'kurz'.}];398[927-929{S.v. OHG kurz, kurt 'kurz', a borrowing from Lat. curtus 'kurz'.}]
Justification: An early loanword into West Germanic from Latin curtus 'short' (cf. [EWA 5](src-398):927-929, [Kluge 2011](src-397):551).

Source: 141[532{S.v. *sengʷʰ- 'singen, verkünden' (IEW 906-7).}];165[437{S.v. Proto-Germanic *singwan- 'to sing', from PIE *séngʷʰ-e- (cf. Gk. ὀμφή 'divine voice or revelation, oracle, emblem' < *songʷʰ-eh₂-). A Germanic-Greek isogloss.}];556[392-393{S.v. Gmc. *sengw-a- 'singen', comparable with some isolated forms in other languages. The basis *sengʷʰ- 'sagen' is therefore not very certain. Cf. W dehongli 'aussagen, erklären, übersetzen', OCS sętъ, sęti 'inquit' ('sagen'), Gk. ὀμφή 'Stimme (der Götter), melodiöse Stimme'.}]
Justification: Proto-Germanic *singwan- 'to sing', probably from PIE *sengʷʰ- 'to sing, proclaim' ([IEW](src-49) 906-7, [LIV²](src-141) 532, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):437, [Seebold 1970](src-556):392-393).

Source: 141[513-515{S.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (IEW 884-887).}];79[506{S.v. Arm. nist 'seat, site, standing, situation, location, abode, base', from which nstim 'to sit, be seated, rest' is derived. To be connected with IE words belonging with *sed- 'to sit', (cf. nominal Skt. nīḍá- 'nest, lair, bird's nest', Lat. nīdus 'bird's nest, residence', OHG, OEngl. nest, etc. < *ni-sd-o-| verbal Gk. ἵζω, Skt. sī́dati, MPers. nišastan, etc.). It often assumed that Arm. verbal nist-, Skt. sī́dati, etc. reflect *ni- + reduplicated present *si-sd-. [For further discussion and references pertaining to the derivation of the Armenian forms, cf. the entry in Martirosyan.]}];341[926-927{S.v. TochAB ṣam- 'sitzen, bleiben', 'sit, remain'. To be derived from PIE *sed- (LIV² 513-514, without Tocharian)| "root-final *-d- was bound to be lost by sound law, but the loss compensated by -m- taken over from the suppletive root läm- in order to regain a suitable root structure, according to G.-J. Pinault (p.c.)".}];66[376{S.v. ἕζομαι 'to sit (down)', from IE *sed- 'sit down'. The form ἕζομαι is a thematic yod-present *sed-ie/o-, whereas ἵζω derives from reduplicated *si-sd-e/o-. Both are IE formations.}];83[125-126{S.v. Proto-Iranian *had- 'to sit, be seated', from PIE *sed- (cf. Skt. sad- 'to sit', Gk. ἕζομαι, ἱζω, Lat. sīdō, OCS sěděti, Lith. sėdė́ti, Latv. sêdêt, Goth. sitan, Engl. sit, etc.). Note the Middle Persian, etc. forms have taken the preverb *ni- 'down'.}];172[II:692-693{S.v. Ved. √sad- 'sitzen', from PIE *sed- (cf. Gk. ἕζομαι, ἵζω 'sitze, setze mich', ἔδρα 'Sitz, Wohnsitz', Lat. sedēre, Goth. sitan, Lith. sėdė́ti, OCS sěděti, etc.).}];81[445{S.v. Proto-Slavic *sěděti 'sit', from PIE *sed-eh₁- (cf. Lith. sėdė́ti, Lat. sedēre).}];353[391{S.v. Lith. sėdė́ti 'sit', from PIE *sed-eh₁- (cf. Lat. sedēre). NB: an example of Winter's Law.}];50[325-326{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sed-o- 'sit', derived from PIE *sed- 'sit' (cf. Skt. sī́dati, Lat. sedeō, Goth. sitjan, Lith. sė́sti, OCS sěsti).}];165[434{S.v. Proto-Germanic *set(j)an- 'to sit', from PIE *sed-ie-. Formally identical to Gk. ἕζομαι 'to sit (down)', Arm. nstim 'to sit' < *(ni-)sed-ie-. Cf. also Gk. ἵζω, Skt. sī́dati, OAv. hīšasat̰ (3.sg.des.) 'to sit' < si-sd-e-| Lat. sedeō, -ere 'to sit, be seated', OIr. saidid, 'to sit', MCo. hedhi, MBret. hezaff, 'to stop', < *sed-e-| Lith. sėdė́ti, Latv. sêdêt, OCS sěděti < *sed-eh₁-.}];54[551-552{S.v. Lat. sedeō, 'to sit, be seated', from Proto-Italic sed-ē- (cf. U. sersi 'seat', sersitu (3.sg.imptv.), zeřef, serse [pr.ptc.act., nom.sg.m.] 'to sit'), ultimately from PIE *sed-eh₁- 'to be seated' (cf.
