OIr. saidid, ·said 'to sit', MCo. hedhi MBret. hezaff 'to stop' < *sede/o-, OIr. síd 'peace', W hedd 'peace', Skt. pf. sasā́da 'to sit down, settle down', OPers. niyašādaya- 'to set down, establish', Gk. ἕζομαι 'to sit down', Lith. sėdė́ti, Latv. sêdêt, OCS sěděti, Goth. sitan 'to sit').}];352[895-896{S.v. OLith. sėdė́ti 'sitzen' (BSl. Latv. sêdêt 'sitzen', OPr. sindats 'sitzend', OCS sěděti 'sitzen', etc.), from PIE *sed- 'sich setzen' (cf. Ved. sad- 'sitzen', YAv. had- 'sich setzen', Gk. ἕζομαι 'setze mich', Arm nstim 'sitze', Lat. sedeō -ēre 'sitzen', OIr. saidid 'sitzt', Goth. sitan 'sitzen', etc.).}];442[422{S.v. 7467 Ved. níṣīdati 'sits down' RV. 2. *nisīdati. [√sad].}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sed- 'to sit (down), seat onself' ([LIV²](src-141) 513-515, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):926-927, [Beekes 2010](src-66):376, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):506, [EWAia](src-172) II:692-693, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):422 no. 7467, [Cheung 2007](src-83):125-126, [ALEW](src-352) 895-896, [Derksen 2015](src-353):391, [Derksen 2008](src-81):445, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):434, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):551-552, [Matasović 2009](src-50):325-326).

Source: 165[135{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fella- 'membrane, skin, hide', from PIE *pel-ni- (cf. Gk. πελλο-ράφος 'sewing skins together' < *pel-no-| Lat. pellis < *pel-ni-| OCS pelena 'band for swathing children', Ru. pelená 'shroud, nappy', SCr. pelèna 'bandage, shroud' < pel-en-eh₂-). Cf. Proto-Germanic *felma(n)- 'membrane' (OE ǣger-felma 'skin of an egg', E film, etc. < *pel-mon-).}];54[455{S.v. Lat. pellis 'skin, hide', from PIE pel-ni- 'skin, hide' (cf. Lith. plėnė̃ 'membrane', Ru. plená 'shroud, (dial.) nappy', OCS pelena 'band for swathing children', Sln. plẹ́na 'bandage' < *pel-en-h₂-| OHG fel, OE fell, OIc. fjall 'hide' < PGmc. *fel-n-). "The structure of the IE derivatives suggests a root *pel-, which may have meant 'to strip, skin', but no independent forms of such a root are attested."}];441[122-{S.v. OHG fel 'Haut, Häutchen, Fell', from Proto-Germanic *fella- (< pre-PGmc. *pel-no-) and close to Lat. pellis, -is 'Fell, Haut, Pelz, Leder' < PIE *pelni-.}];444[525{Cf. s.v. 6377 Lat. pellis 'Fell'.}]
Justification: Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pel-. The Germanic forms in this class reflect *pel-no- ([EWA 3](src-441):122-126, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):135), while the Italic/Romance forms reflect an i-stem *pel-ni- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):455, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):525 no. 6377).

Source: 165[290{S.v. Proto-Germanic *klainja- 'fine'. An adjective to be derived from the same root found in ON, Far. klína 'to smear' < *klīnjan- and OHG klenan- 'id.' following [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):332-323.}];697[332-333{S.v. Gmc. *klaini- 'fein'. Only attested in West Germanic. The Gmc. verb *klina- continues an old nasal present that is also seen in OIr. glenaid 'haftet an, bleibt kleben' and also in Gk. γλίνη  'klebrige Substanz', OCS glьna 'Lehm, Ton', to PIE *g̑lei̯- / *glei̯- 'beschmieren, haften'.}];397[498{S.v. NHG klein (MHG klein(e), OHG klein(i), OS klēni) 'zierlich, fein'. The present-day meaning is a more recent semantic shift post-MHG, from West Germanic *klaini-, also attested in OE clǣne 'rein'. Etymology unclear. According to [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):332f. to the nasal present *kli-na- 'beschmieren' as 'fein geputzt' to PIE *gloi- 'glänzen'.}];398[581-584{S.v. OHG kleini, klein 'klein geformt, winzig, kurz, gering(fügig), beschränkt, unerheblich, dünn, schwach, fein, zart, kostbar, hell (von Farbe), klug, schlau, (arg-)listig, tief, gründlich im Denken' from West Germanic *klai̯nii̯a-, likely to have been originally from PGmc. *klai̯ni-. The further etymology is disputed due to the varying semantics of the lexemes in the Germanic languages, and lack of convincing comparisons in another IE language. According to [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):332, to have a semantic development 'fein verschmiert, fein verputzt' can connected to PGmc. *klinō/a- 'bestreichen' (and further to *gleiH-nó- 'fein wegen Bestreichung'. [IEW](src-49) 336f. on the other hand compares a verbal root *g̑el- 'hell glänzen', heiter sein', although as [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):333 points out this interpretation is to be dismissed since in Germanic it is not attested with the meaning 'shining'. Not seriously considerable is the assumption of a substratum word.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed ([Kluge 2011](src-397):498; [EWA 5](src-398):581-584). According to [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):322-323, followed by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):290, to the root underlying OIr. glenaid 'adhere, stick' and also in Gk. γλίνη 'sticky substance', OCS glьna 'mud, clay', to PIE *g̑lei̯- / *glei̯- 'smear, stick' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 190 s.v. *gleiH- 'bestreichen, kleben bleiben').

Source: 165[410{S.v. Proto-Germanic *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke| to drift, fly'. A word without a generally accepted etymology. The connection with e.g. Lith. rū̃kas 'haze' and Lith. rokė̃ 'cloud of dust' [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):705-706 is unlikely as these may have been borrowed from Low German.}];556[379-380{S.v. Gmc. *reuk-a- 'rauchen'. There is only a possibility for comparison in Baltic via Lith. ráugti 'säuern', intr. 'aufstoßen', Latv. rûgt 'säuern, aufgehen, rauchen'.}];352[878-879{Cf. s.v. OLith. rū̃kti 'rauchen, qualmen' and s.v. ruokė 'Sprühregen', most likely to be loans from Germanic.}]
Justification: Without clear etymology outside of Germanic; proposed Baltic cognates could well be loans from Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):410; [ALEW](src-352) 878-879; cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):379-380).

Source: 165[406, 410{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rauki- 'smoke', an i-stem noun derived to PGmc. *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke', a verb with no generally accepted etymology.}];397[748{S.v. NHG Rauch (MHG rouch, OHG rouh, OS rōk), from Gmc. *rauki- also in ON reykr, OE rēc, OFr. rēk| derived from the strong verb underlying NHG riechen, whose original meaning was 'to smoke'.}];556[379-380{Cf. s.v. PGmc. reuk-a- 'rauchen', with deriv. rauk-i-z 'Rauch', possibly comparable with Lithuanian ráugti 'säuern| aufstoßen', although the connection is very uncertain.}]
Justification: Lexemes derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' ([Seebold 1970](src-556)379-380, [Kluge 2011](src-397):748, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):406, 410). No further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 299](cog-299).

Source: 415[478-480];81[162-163{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gladъkъ 'smooth, plain' (ESSJa VI 115-116), derived from PIE *gʰleh₂dʰ- (cf. Lith. glodùs, Lat. glaber 'smooth, hairless', OHG glat 'shining').}];353[183{S.v. Lith. glodùs 'smooth' (Latv. gluõšs 'smooth'), derived from PIE *gʰleh₂dʰ- (cf. OCS gladъkъ 'smooth', Lat. glaber 'smooth, hairless', OHG glat 'shining').}];165[179{S.v. Proto-Germanic *glada- 'bright, happy'. According to K., while this form superficially appears to continue * gʰlodʰ-ó- or *gʰladʰ-o- (Lat. glaber 'bald'), it actually represents an 'intra-Germanic quasi-PIE zero-grade derivation *gʰlh̥₁-tó- to *glōan- < *gʰlóh₁-e-'.}];269[{Against Kroonen (2013:179) who derives from PGmc. glōan- 'to glow', the cognacy in this class follows the usual proposed connection of PGmc. *glada- to Lat. glaber 'smooth, hairless', Lith. glodùs 'tender', Slav. *gladъkъ 'smooth'.}];388[135{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ʒlađaz, related to Lat. glaber 'smooth', Lith. glodùs 'tender', Slav. *gladъkъ 'smooth'.}];352[345{Cf. s.v. OLith. glodùs 'glatt' (BSl. Latv. glãstit 'streicheln, liebkosen', OPr. glosto 'Wetzstein', OCS gladъkъ 'glatt, flach, eben', etc.), from PIE *gʰleHdʰ- 'glatt' (cf. Lat. glaber 'glatt, unbehaart, kahl', ON glaðr 'hell, klar', OE glæd 'hell, leuchtend', OHG glat 'glatt, schlüpfrig| hell leuchtend').}];397[{S.v. NHG glatt (MHG glat, OHG glat, OS glad- 'froh') from Germanic *glada- 'glatt, schlüpfrig'. Outside of Germanic one compares Lat. glaber 'glatt, kahl' (*gʰladʰ-ro-) and with full-grade Lith. glod(n)ùs, OCS gladŭkŭ- 'glatt, eben'. Further origins uncertain.}];458[6: 115-116{PS *gladŭkŭ is most closely related to Lithuanian glodus, German glatt and Latin glaber.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic and Germanic lexemes generally connected to a common IE root *gleh₂dʰ- ([ALEW](src-352) 345, [Derksen 2008](src-81):162-163, [Derksen 2015](src-353):183, [Kluge 2011](src-397):361, [EWA 4](src-415):478-480, [Orel 2003](src-388):135), but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):179 who prefers an alternative etymology.

Source: 165[453{S.v. Proto-Germanic *slangan- 'snake', an agentive formation to the PIE root *slenk- 'to creep' (cf. PGmc. *slingan-, *slinkan-, *slunkōn-).}];141[567{Cf. s.v. *slenkʷ- 'gleiten' (IEW 961), from which *slénkʷ-e- > ON(+) slyngva 'schwingen, schleudern', OHG slingan 'verfallen' (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):432-433).}];556[432-433{Cf. s.v. PGmc. *slengw-a- 'gleiten', from which PGmc. *slangw-ōn 'Schlange' (OHG slango).}];397[808{S.v. NHG Schlange (MHG slange, OHG slango), a nomen agentis to schlingen 'wenden, flechten, etc.' as 'sich Windende'. Outside of Germanic one compares it to a (west) IE formation *slongʷʰ- (cf. Lat. lumbrīcus 'Eingeweidewurm', W llyngyr 'Eingeweidewurm' < *slonkʷ-?).}]
Justification: Originally an agent noun to the same root as OHG slingan ([Kluge 2011](src-397):808, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):453). The Germanic forms must continue a Verner variant *-gʷ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. *slenkʷ-, n1).

Source: 269[{On the TochB form *śiñce, this form is usually derived to *snigʷʰ-en- (cf. [NIL](src-274), [EIEC](src-657), [Adams 2013](src-345)), but cf. Adams (2013) for other proposals for the Tocharian stem formation.}];274[622-625{S.v. *snei̯gʷʰ- 'kleben bleiben' (LIV 573, IEW 974).}];345[689-690{Cf. s.v. TochB śiñcatstse* 'snowy', a derivative of the unattested noun *śiñce 'snow'. Possibly from PIE *snigʷʰ-en- (cf. Pkt. siṇeha- 'snow', Av. snēža- 'to snow', Gk. νίφα (acc.) 'snow', νείφει 'it snows', Lat. nix, nivis 'snow', OIr. snigid 'it drips, rains', Goth. snaiws 'snow', OEng. snāw [> Engl. snow], OHG snīwan 'to snow', Lith. sniẽgas 'snow', OCS sněgъ 'snow'). N.sg. *snigʷʰēn would give PToch *ṣñäćśe > *ṣn̥će. Less likely, Van Windekens proposes from *k̑u̯indeto-, comparing Skt. śvind- 'be white'.}];657[530{S.v. SNOW, under *snigʷʰ-s, *snoi̯gʷʰ-os 'snow', to which TochB śiñcatstse 'snowy' from implied *śiñce 'snow' < *snigʷʰi- or *snigʷʰen-).}];81[457{S.v. Proto-Slavic *sněgъ 'snow', from PIE *snoi̯gʷʰ-o- (cf. Lith. sniẽgas, Latv. snìegs, OPr. snaygis, Goth. snaiws).}];353[416{S.v. Lith. sniẽgas 'snow' (Latv. snìegs 'snow', OPr. snaygis 'snow'), from PIE *snoi̯gʷʰ-o- (cf. OCS sněgъ 'snow', Goth. snaiws 'snow').}];165[460{S.v. Proto-Germanic *snaiwa- 'snow', from PIE *snoigʷʰ-o- (cf. OCS sněgъ, Lith. sniẽgas, Latv. snìegs 'snow' < *snoigʷʰ-o-| Lat. nix, nivis 'snow' < *snigʷʰ-).}];54[409-410{S.v. ningit, -ere 'it snows', to which nix, nivis 'snow' is a derivative. The noun nix, nivi- is from PIE *sn(e)igʷʰ- 'snow'.}];50[349{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *snigʷ-(y)o- 'snow' (vb.), from PIE *snei̯gʷʰ- 'snow'. OIr. snechtae 'snow' (n.), etc. is a derived noun.}];141[573{Cf. s.v. *snei̯gʷʰ- 'kleben bleiben' (IEW 974).}];352[951{S.v. OLith. sniẽgas 'Schnee' (BSl. Latv. snìegs 'Schnee', OPr. snaygis 'Schnee', OCS sněgъ 'Schnee', etc.), from PIE *snoi̯gʷʰo- 'Schnee' (cf. Goth. snaiws 'id.', etc.).}]
Justification: Tocharian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *snei̯gʷʰ- 'to stick, adhere to' ([NIL](src-274) 622-625 [EIEC](src-657) 530, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):689-690, [ALEW](src-352) 951, [Derksen 2015](src-353):416, [Derksen 2008](src-81):457, [Kroonen 2013](src-165)460, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):409-410, [Matasović 2009](src-50):349, [LIV²](src-141) 573).

Source: 141[590-592{S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (IEW 1004-1008). Cf. LIV entry for variety of derived verbal stems attested in the individual branches.}];66[601{S.v. ἵστημι 'to make stand, set up, take position, bring to a standstill, etc.' < PIE *steh₂- 'stand, set'.}];172[II:764-766{S.v. Ved. √sthā- 'stehen, dastehen, still stehen, verweilen' (OAv., YAv. xšta-, YAv. hišta- 'stehen'), from PIE *steh₂- (cf. Gk. ἵστημι, Lat. sistere, status 'stellen', OHG stān 'stehen', Lith. stóti 'sich hinstellen', Latv. stât 'stellen', OCS stati 'sich stellen, treten', Luw. ta- 'stehen, zum Stehen kommen').}];80[879-880{Cf. s.v. tii̯e/a- 'to step, to go stand, to place oneself, to set in' (cf. CLuw. tā- 'to come to stand', HLuw. ta- 'to come to stand', tanu- 'to set up, erect, establish', from PIE *(s)th₂-i̯e/o-.}];81[465-466, 468{S.v. Proto-Slavic *stati 'stand, become' from PIE *steh₂- and Proto-Slavic *stojati 'stand' from PIE *stoh₂- (cf. Skt. tiṣthati, Gk. ἵστημι, Lat. stāre).}];353[430{S.v. Lith. stovė́ti 'stand' (Latv. stãvẽt), from PIE *sth₂-ẽu- (cf. OE stowian 'keep from').}];165[473, 477{S.v. Proto-Germanic *standan- 'to stand', and *stēn- 'to stand', two stems in suppletion with one another, but both ultimately derivatives of PIE *steh₂- 'stand'. The vocalism of *stēn- can be accounted for in different ways (cf. entry s.v. *stēn- for further discussion), but the best solution for the root vocalism is probably on analogy to *gēn- 'go' (cf. Seebold 1970:464-465).}];556[464-465{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *stǣ- 'stehen'. The vocalism ē against ā in other languages is unexplained. One generally assumes an original *stō- modified on analogy to *gǣ- 'gehen', although other explanations are possible.}];50[338{S.v. Proto-Celtic *si-sta- 'put, stand', from PIE *steh₂- (cf. Lat. stō, stāre, Gk. ἵστημι, Lith. stóti, OCS stojati, OHG stān).}];54[589-590{S.v. Lat. stō, stāre 'to stand| to halt', from PIE *sth₂-eh₁-i̯e/o- 'to stand'.}];352[981-982{S.v. OLith. stovė́ti 'stehen' (BSl. Latv. stãvêt 'stehen| sein, bestehen, bleiben, dauern, währen', OCS staviti 'stellen, zum Stehen beginnen', etc.). Lith. stovė́ti and its cognates become to the IE root *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (cf. Lith. stóti). The following u̯-element in the stem formation (as though from *steh₂-u̯- has been variously explained [cf. ALEW entry for further discussion and references to further literature].}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ([LIV²](src-141) 590-592, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):879-880, [Beekes 2010](src-66):601, [EWAia](src-172) II:764-766, [ALEW](src-352) 981-982, [Derksen 2015](src-353):430, [Derksen 2008](src-81):465-466, 468, [Seebold 1970](src-556):464-465, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):473, 477, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):589-590, [Matasović 2009](src-50):338).

Source: 165[476, 487{S.v. Proto-Germanic *stukka- 'stick', derived from the strong verb *stekan- 'to stick', in turn as though from *stig-e- (cf. Lat. īnstīgō, -ere 'to stimulate, set on, incite, rouse or urge' < *-steig-e-).}];397[887{S.v. NHG Stock (MHG stoc, OHG stoc, OS stokk), from Gmc. *stukka- 'Stock, Balken, Baumstumpf', also in ON stokkr, OE stocc, OFr. stokk. Together with stauchen and stochern to be connected to a common root *steu-, which is also found in stoßen, cf. Skt. tujáti 'drängt, stoßt'.}];697[562-563{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *stukka- 'steif' (an adjectivisation of *stukka- 'Stock, Baumstumpf').}];388[383{S.v. Proto-Germanic *stukkaz, with an irregularity in the inlaut geminate to be related to Skt. stúkā 'tuft of wool, of hair'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):562-563, [Orel 2003](src-388):383, [Kluge 2011](src-397):887, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):476, 487 for various proposals and references to further literature.

Source: 141[603{Cf. s.v. ?*sti̯eH- 'steif werden' (IEW 1010-1).  Only verbal in Indo-Iranian.  Cf. AGk. στέαρ 'hard fat', Germ. *staina- m. 'stone'| cf. Mayrhofer, EWAia II:762-763 s.v. √styā- 'fest werden'. }];165[472{S.v. Proto-Germanic *staina- 'stone', from PIE *stoiH-no- (cf. OCS stěna, Russ. stená 'wall' < stoih₂-neh₂-| Gk. στία, στῖον 'small stone, pebble' < *stih₂-io/eh₂-), a no-stem created to the PIE root *steih₂- 'to stiffen' (cf. Skt. styā́yate 'to coagulate').}];468[546{S.v. ON steinn 'stein, edelstein, steinhaus', cf. Goth. stains, OCS stěna 'Mauer', Gk. στία, στῖον 'steinchen', Skt. styāyate 'gerinnt, wird hart'.}];179[321-322{S.v. Goth. S.130 stains 'λίθος', 'stone', 'πέτρα', 'rock', from PIE *stāy- 'thicken', cf. Skt. styā́yate 'coagulate', Gk. στία, στῖον 'pebble', στέαρ 'tallow'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staina- 'stone', reflecting PIE *stoiH-no- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):472, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):546, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):321-322). Further derived from PIE *sti̯eH- 'to become stiff' (following the reconstruction of [LIV²](src-141) 603).

Source: 141[304-305{Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-857).}];316[566{Lat. rēctus a verbal adjective to regō 'rule, guide, control, direct'.}];156[II:350-352{S.v. Oss. rast 'прямой, правый, правильный, etc.', from PIr. rāšta-, ultimately from PIE *rek̑to (*reg̑-to-), cf. Pers. rāst, Parth. rāšt, Chores. rašt, Sogd. rašt, Khot. rraṣṭa, Av. rāšta-, OPers. rāsta-, Goth. raihts, Germ. recht, Lat. rēctus.}];172[I:252-253, II:425{S.v. Ved. r̥jú- 'gerade (vom Weg), richtig, recht, gerecht' (OAv. ərəzu- 'gerade, richtig', to Ved. √raj-² 'sich gerade ausstrecken, sich in gestreckte Bewegung setzen' < PIE *h₃reg̑- (cf. Gk. ὀρέγω 'strecke aus, reiche dar', Lat. regō 'richte gerade, lenke', OIr. rigim 'strecke aus', OHG re(c)chan 'recken', etc.).}];165[408-409{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rehta- 'straight', from PIE *h₃reg̑-to- (cf. Av. rašta- 'straight', Gk. ὀρεκτός 'id.', Lat. rectus 'id.').}];54[517-518{S.v. Lat. regō -ere 'direct, guide, govern', past-participle rēctus < *h₃reg̑-to- with lengthened root -ē- by Lachmann's Law.}];227[119{Cf. s.v. §192 discussing reflexes of PIE *r in Old Irish. OIr. díriug, díriuch 'straight', where the root is comparable to Lat. regere, rectus, Gk. ὀρέγειν, Goth. uf-rakjan 'to stretch out', Skt. r̥jú-, Av. ərəzu- 'straight', etc.}];50[308{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *reg-o- 'extend, stretch, straighten' (vb.), from PIE *h₃reg̑-o- 'extend, stretch, rule' (cf. Skt. r̥ñjánti 'rule', Gk. ὀρέγω 'extend, stretch', Lat. regō 'rule', Goth. rikan 'heap up', TochB räk- 'extend, cover').}];296[D:96{S.v. OIr. diriug 'droit, juste', an old u-stem formed with the prefix di- + the root *reg- corresponding exactly to Indo-Iranian r̥jú- 'droit, juste', Av. ərəzu- 'id.'}];444[241{Cf. s.v. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade', 2. dērēctus.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ([EWAia](src-172) I:252-253, II:425, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:350-352, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):408-409, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):566, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):517-518, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):241 no. 2648, [Thurneysen 1946](src-227):119, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:96, [Matasović 2009](src-50):308).

Source: 274[606-611{S.v. *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- n. 'Sonne' (IEW 881f.).}];156[IV:246-248{S.v. Oss. xūr | xor 'солнце', from Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar- (Pers, xur, Kurd. xūr, xor, xwar, Yaghn. xur, Sogd. *xōr, *xwer [Budd. γwr, Man. xwr, Chr. xer], Chores. xwyr, xyr, 'xr, Av. hvar), from PIE *su̯el- (cf. Lith., Latv. sáulė, Goth. sauil, Lat. sōl, OCS слъньцє, etc.).}];66[516{S.v. ἥλιος 'sun' from PIE *seh₂u-el- 'sun'. Note dialectal varieties Ion. ἠέλιος, West Greek ἀέλιος (Cretan ἀϝέλιος) more closely preserve the structure of earlier *seh₂u̯-el- (with e-grade ablaut generalised in both stem and suffix).}];172[II:742{S.v. Ved. sū́rya- 'Sonne, Sonnengott', from a PIE stem *suh₂l-ii̯o- (or *-iHo-) from an original heteroclite *-l/n- stem *suh₂el/n- : *sh₂uu̯el/n-. A related formation *seh₂u̯el-ii̯o- is found in Proto-Greek *hāu̯elii̯o- (cf. Cret. ἀβέλιος, Dor./Aeol./Arc. ἀέλιος, Hom. ἠέλιος, Att. ἥλιος), cf. also Goth. sauil, Lith. sáulė, Lett. saũle 'Sonne').}];353[390{S.v. Lith. sáulė 'sun' (Latv. saũle 'sun', OPr. saule 'sun'), from PIE *seh₂u-l, *seh₂u-en- (cf. OCS slъnьce 'sun', Skt. svàr- 'sun, sunlight', Skt. sū́rya- 'sun, deity of the sun', Av. huuarə̄ 'sun' (gen.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg), Gk. (Hom.) ἠέλιος 'sun', Lat. sōl 'sun', Goth. sauil 'sun', OE sunne 'sun'). Proto-Balto-Slavic *saʔul ~ *sʔul appears to still exhibit ablaut in the root, which was subsequently generalised in Baltic (full-grade) and Slavic (zero-grade).}];81[479-480{S.v. Proto-Slavic *sъlnьce 'sun', from PIE *s(e)h₂-ul- (cf. Lith. sáulė, Skt. svàr- 'sun, sunlight', Skt. sū́rya- 'sun, deity of the sun', Av. huuarə̄ 'sun' (gen.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg), Gk. (Hom.) ἠέλιος 'sun', Lat. sōl 'sun', Goth. sauil 'sun', OE sunne 'sun').}];165[463-464{S.v. Proto-Germanic *sōel- ~ *sunnōn- 'sun', from PIE *séh₂u-l/n- (Skt. svàr-, gen. sū́ras 'sun', OAv. huuarə̄ 'sun', gen. xᵛə̄ṇg 'id.', NP xwr 'id.', Oss. xur / xor 'id.', Gk. ἥλιος (Dor. ἀέλιος) 'id.', Lat. sōl, sōlis, 'id.', OIr. súil 'eye', Lith. sáulė 'sun', OCS slъnьce). The original heteroclite -l/n- inflection survived in Germanic and is possibly still intact in Gothic (cf. Goth. nom. sauil, dat. sunnin).}];54[570{S.v. Lat. sōl, sōlis 'sun', from PIE *seh₂u-l (nom., acc.), *sh₂u-én- (obl.) (cf. W. haul 'sun', OIr. súil 'eye', Skt. svàr 'sun' OAv. huuarə̄ 'sun' (gen.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg), Skt. sū́rya- 'sun, deity of the sun', Gk. ἠέλιος (Hom.), ἀέλιος (Dor., Aeol., Arc.) < PGk. *σᾱϝέλιος < *seh₂-uel-io-, Lith. sáulė, Latv. saũle, OCS slъnьce, Goth. sauil, OIc. sōl).}];50[324{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sāwol- / *sūli- 'sun', from PIE *seh₂u̯ōl 'sun' (cf. Skt. sū́rya- 'sun', Gk. ἥλιος, Lat. sōl, Goth. sauil, Lith. sáulė). The change of meaning in OIr. súil 'eye' is understandable from the mythological context where the sun is viewed as 'the eye of the sky'.}];677[5-8{Cf. for an influential discussion of the unique stem-formation and ablaut of this nominal stem.}];352[892{S.v. OLith. sáulė (1), saulė̃ (3) 'Sonne' (BSl. Latv. saũle 'Sonne| Welt', OPr. saule 'Sonne', OCS slъnьce 'Sonne', etc.), from PIE *séh₂u̯el/n- 'Sonne' (cf. Ved. svàr, sū́raḥ, sū́r(i)ya- 'Sonne', OAv. huuarə̄, G.sg. xᵛə̄ṇg 'id.', YAv. huuarə, G.sg. hū, hūrō 'id.', Gk. ἥλιος 'Sonne', ἠέλιος (Hom.), ἀέλιος (Dor., Aeol., Arc.), 'id.', Lat. sōl, -lis 'Sonne', OIr. súil 'Auge', OW houl 'Sonne', MW heul 'id.', Goth. sauil 'Sonne', ON sōl 'id.', OE sunna 'id.', OHG sunno 'id.').}];442[782{S.v. 13574 sū́ra m. 'sun' RV. 2. sū́rya- m. 3. sū́riya- m. (metr.) RV. 4. sūrī- f. 'a name of Kuntī as wife of the sun' Pāṇ.vārtt. 5. saurī́-.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ([NIL](src-274) 606-611, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):516, [EWAia](src-172) II:742, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):782 no. 13574, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:246-248, [ALEW](src-352) 892, [Derksen 2015](src-353):390, [Derksen 2008](src-81):479-480, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):463-464, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):570, [Matasović 2009](src-50):324). For an influential analysis of the nominal formation cf. [Beekes 1984](src-677).

Source: 165[499{S.v. Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', an exclusively Germanic verb.}];556[489-490{S.v. PGmc. swell-a- 'schwellen'. There is no secure etymology outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', without certain connections outside of Germanic ([Seebold 1970](src-556):489-490, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499).

Source: 165[501{S.v. Proto-Germanic *swimman- 'to swim, float'.  No good etymology outside of Germanic.}];556[491-492{S.v. Proto-Germanic *swemm-a- 'schwimmen'. There are no persuasive possibilities for comparison outside of Germanic. The verbal root is only indirectly attested in Gothic via swumfsl 'Teich'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swimman- 'to swim, float', further etymology uncertain ([Seebold 1970](src-556):491-492, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):501).

Source: 468[547{S.v. ON stertr 'schwanz' (cf. OE steort, OHG sterz 'schwanz'), according to IEW 1023 from a root *(s)terd- (cf. Gk. τόρδυλον 'doldenpflanze', Latv. stersk 'wagenrunge').}];397[877, 883{Cf. s.v. NHG Schwanz (MHG sterz, OHG sterz, MLG stērt, MDu. stert), from Gmc. *sterta- 'Schwanz' also in ON stertr, OE steort, OFr. stert| presumably to the group including starr as 'aufgerichtet, steif'. If so, then to be connected with Gk. στερεός 'steif, hart, fest', Lith. stérti 'erstarren, den Mund aufsperren'.}];757[{S.v. Du. staart 'achterste uitsteeksel', from Proto-Germanic *sterta-, with -e- > -aa- before r + dental just as in haard. From PIE *sterd-, probably a dental enlargement of the root *(s)ter- ‘stiff'.}];388[376{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *stertaz.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterta- 'tail', possibly a dental-enlarged root *sterd- to PIE *ster- 'stiff' but uncertain, cf. [EWNl](src-757), {ref Kluge 2011:877, 883, [de Vries 1977](src-468):547, [Orel 2003](src-388):376).

Source: 50[377{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tegu- 'thick', from PIE *tegu- 'thick' (IEW 1057), cf. OHG dicchi, OE ðicce 'thick'. Reflexes of this PIE root are attested only in Celtic and Germanic. Both branches point to an original u-stem.}];165[537{S.v. Proto-Germanic ϸeku- 'fat', from *tegu- (cf. OIr. tiug 'fat'), probably a Celtic-Germanic isogloss. Further connections are unclear.}];697[617-618{S.v. Gmc. *ϸeku- 'dick', an inherited adjective identical with the u-adjective in OIr. tiug, W tew 'dick, dicht' < Western Indo-European *tegu-, further connections are unclear.}];296[T:76{S.v. OIr. tiug 'épais, dense, solide', from earlier *tegu-, common to Celtic and Germanic (cf. OIc. ϸykkr, ϸjukkr 'épais', OE ϸicce, OHG dicki <*tegw-yo-, IEW 1057).}]
Justification: A Germanic-Celtic isogloss with further connections uncertain (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1057, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:76, [Matasović 2009](src-50):377, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):617-618, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):537).

Source: 141[629{S.v. 2. *ten⁽g̑⁾- 'dünken, scheinen (unpers.)' (IEW 1088). Only Italic and Germanic (cf. OLat. tongēre 'wissen'). Cf. n1 "Grundbedeutung wohl 'jmdm. in den Sinn kommen".}];165[533-534{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸankjan- w.v. 'to think', as though from PIE *tong-éie- (cf. Lat. tongō, -ēre 'to know'| TochA tuṅk, TochB taṅkw 'love' < PToch. *tənkw < *tng-u-).}];179[353{S.v. Goth. Ϸ2. *ϸagks 'χάρις', with denominal verb ϸagkjan 'βουλεύεσθαι', 'think, plan'. From PIE *tong- 'think, feel' (cf. Lat. tongēre 'know', Osc. tanginom = Lat. sententiam 'thought', Osc. tanginúd = sententiā).}]
Justification: Germanic forms identical to Old Latin tongēre 'to know' < *ton⁽g̑⁾-éi̯e- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 629, [IEW](src-49) 1088, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):533-534, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):353).

Source: 141[689{S.v. *u̯ergʷ- 'werfen' [IEW 1153].}];81[515{S.v. Proto-Slavic *vergti 'throw', from PIE *uergʷ- (cf. Goth. wairpan 'throw').}];165[581{S.v. Proto-Germanic *werpan- 'to warp, sling, throw', from PIE *uérgʷ-e- (cf. Gk. ῥέμβομαι 'to roam, go around' < *uré-m-gʷ-e-| ῥόμβος 'top, wheel, spinning motion' < *uro-m-gʷ-o-).}];259[696{PS *vergti is derived from PIE *u̯er-ɡ- < *u̯er- 'turn'.}]
Justification: Germanic and Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯ergʷ- 'to throw' (cf. {ref LIV² 689, [Derksen 2008](src-81):515, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):581).

Source: 141[75{S.v. *bʰendʰ- 'binden' (IEW 127).}];83[4-6{S.v. Proto-Iranian *band- 'to bind' < PIE *bʰendʰ- 'id.'. (cf. Gk. πεῖσμα 'rope, cord', Thrac. βενδ-, Goth. bindan, OHG bintan, Engl. 'to bind', etc.).}];172[II:208{S.v. Ved. √bandh- 'binden, fesseln, zusammenbinden, festbinden', from PIE *bʰendʰ- (cf. Gk. πεῖσμα 'Tau, Seil', OHG bintan 'binden', Goth. bandi 'Fessel, Band', etc.).}];165[64{S.v. Proto-Germanic *bindan- 'to bind', from PIE *bʰéndʰ-e- (cf. Skt. badhnāti 'to bind, tie, fix' < *bʰndʰ-néh₂-, Av. basta-, OPers. basta- 'bound' < *bʰndʰ-to-, Gk. πεῖσμα 'rope, cable' < *bʰendʰ-s-men-).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind' ([LIV²](src-141) 75, [EWAia](src-172) II:208, [Cheung 2007](src-83):4-6, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):64).

Source: 79[307-308{"The word is a blend of PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu(e)h₂- ‘tongue’ (OIr. tengae, Goth. tuggō, OHG zunga, Skt. jihvā́-, juhū́- f., Av. hizuuā-, hizū- m., etc.) and PIE *leig̑ʰ- > Arm. lizem ‘to lick’ (q.v.)| cf. especially Lat. lingua vs. OLat. dingua and Lith. liežùvis ‘tongue’."}];345[147{TochA käntu and TochB kantwo reflect PTch *käntwo which, by metathesis, presupposes an earlier *täkwo (as if) from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eH-n-, which matches the form found in Germanic (e.g. Goth. tuggō).}];172[I:591-593{S.v. Ved. jihvā́- 'Zunge'. cf. further notes by Scarborough in this cognate class regarding the cognacy of the Indo-Iranian forms to the rest of the forms in this class.}];269[{Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- 'tongue'. The forms as attested appear to have undergone multiple contaminations in several daughter languages: (1) The Tocharian forms reflect *ĝn̥dʰu̯éh₂- ← PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- by metathesis of place of articulation (cf. [Ringe 1996](src-695):45-6). (2) Balto-Slavic lexemes appear to have lost initial *d- already at a common Balto-Slavic stage ([Derksen 2008](src-81):159, [Derksen 2015](src-353):285, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 6:74-75). (3) Armenian, Italic, and Lithuanian lexemes appear to have independently contaminated with initial l-, probably under influence of their respective regular reflexes of PIE *lei̯g̑ʰ- 'to lick' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):307-308, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):343, {ref Derksen 2015:285). (4) Celtic forms appear to have undergone a distance assimilation *dengʷāt- > *tengʷāt-  ([Matasović 2009](src-50):368). (5) Indo-Iranic forms have a similar preform *ºg̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*ºg̑ʰuh₂- to the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂- found in other branches, but instead appears to i-reduplicate the initial syllable (cf. notes to Ved. jihvā́- in [EWAia](src-172) I:591-593). Additionally, the Iranian forms appear to show a different Anlaut from the Indic ones (Indic *j-, Iranian *s-). This small deviation aside, the Indo-Iranian. forms surely go back to basic form *ji-ju̯aH-/*ji-juH- (vel sim.) in Proto-Indo-Iranian. This apparent reduplication could be secondary reanalysis of an original *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰuh₂- > *daju̯aH-/dajuH- as a reduplicated form *ji-ju̯aH-, (cf. forms such as *kʷe-kʷl-o- > cakra- 'wheel'), cf. [Mallory & Adams 2006](src-75):175. For the purposes of root-cognacy, The Indo-Iranic forms are treated in this class as cognate with the other forms which are more clearly from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂-. The least disturbed forms appear to be found in Germanic, for which see [Lehmann 1986](src-179):349, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):526-527.}];54[343{S.v. Lat. lingua. The basic Italic preform closely matches the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂ found in Germanic, Tocharian, etc. but with a secondary (and evidently late) contamination of original d- to l- from Lat. lingō 'lick' (cf. Old Latin dingua). Sabellic forms with initial f- presuppose initial *dʰ-, but the origin of the aspiration of original *d- in these forms is unclear.}];81[159{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ęzykъ, which is regular from*n̥g̑ʰ-uh₂- < *dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂- with the addition a secondary suffix *-kъ in Slavic. The loss of initial *d- also apparent at the Proto-Balto-Slavic stage, cf. Old Prussian insuwis.}];353[285{S.v. Lithuanian liežùvis 'tongue'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic form *inźuʔ- apparently lost initial *d- from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂- (cf. Old Prussian insuwis, Proto-Slavic *ęzy-kъ). The Lithuanian form was secondarily influenced by Lith. liẽžti 'lick'.}];179[349{S.v. Goth. T37. tuggō 'γλῶσσα', 'tongue', from PIE *dʰn̥g̑ʰu-, *dʰn̥g̑ʰu̯ā with varied reflexes due to taboo deformation.}];50[368{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tengʷāt- 'tongue', generally connected with PIE *dng̑ʰuh₂- with initial *t instead of initial *d best explained as the result of assimilation *d … t > t … t. Elsewhere in IE cf. Skt. jihvā́, Lat. lingua, OHG zunga, OPr. insuwis, ToB kantwo.}];75[175{PIE root widely remodelled| some forms seem to be blends of PIE 'tongue' and root *leig̑ʰ- 'lick'| Proto-Indo-Iranian *j́ij́ʱū́- (**j́ij́ʱú-) may continue a simple PIE (masculine) u-stem *dʰng̑ʰú-, but it shows reanalysis of the initial syllable as reduplication *j́i- ~ *j́u- to *j́i-j́ʱū́- (cf. *babʱrú- adj., etc.), cf. Vedic (RV) juhū́- f. 'tongue'| cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 591f.}];458[6: 74-75{PS *ęzykŭ is related to Latin lingua, Gothic tungō, Old Prussian insuwis etc. It is, however, impossible to give an universal PIE protoform.}];165[526-527{S.v. Proto-Germanic *tungōn- 'tongue' < *dng̑ʰ-u̯eh₂- (cf. TochA käntu, TochB kantwo 'tongue' < *g̑ʰnd⁽ʰ⁾-ueh₂- (with metathesis), Skt. jihvā́ 'id.', Av. hizuua-/hizu- 'id.' < *d(i)ng̑ʰ-ueh₂-| Lat. lingua 'id.' < *lng̑ʰ-ieh₂-, OIr. tengae| Lith. liežùvis 'id.', OPr. insuwis < *ng̑ʰ-ueh₂-, OCS językъ, Ru. jazyk, SCr. jèzik < *ng̑ʰ-u-(ko-)| Arm. lezu, gen. lezvi 'id.').}]
Justification: Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- 'tongue'. The forms as attested appear to have undergone multiple contaminations in several daughter languages: (1) The Tocharian forms reflect *ĝn̥dʰu̯éh₂- ← PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- by metathesis of place of articulation (cf. [Ringe 1996](src-695):45-6, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):79, [Adams 2013](src-345):147). (2) Balto-Slavic lexemes appear to have lost initial *d- already at a common Balto-Slavic stage ([Derksen 2008](src-81):159, [Derksen 2015](src-353):285, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 6:74-75). (3) Armenian, Italic, and Lithuanian lexemes appear to have independently contaminated with initial l-, probably under influence of their respective regular reflexes of PIE *lei̯g̑ʰ- 'to lick' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):307-308, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):343, {ref Derksen 2015:285). (4) Celtic forms appear to have undergone a distance assimilation *dengʷāt- > *tengʷāt-  ([Matasović 2009](src-50):368). (5) Indo-Iranic forms have a similar preform *ºg̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*ºg̑ʰuh₂- to the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂- found in other branches, but instead appears to i-reduplicate the initial syllable (cf. notes to Ved. jihvā́- in [EWAia](src-172) I:591-593). Additionally, the Iranian forms appear to show a different Anlaut from the Indic ones (Indic *j-, Iranian *s-). This small deviation aside, the Indo-Iranic forms appear to go back to basic form *ji-ju̯aH-/*ji-juH- (vel sim.) in Proto-Indo-Iranic. This apparent reduplication could be secondary reanalysis of an original *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰuh₂- > *daju̯aH-/dajuH- as a reduplicated form *ji-ju̯aH-, (cf. forms such as *kʷe-kʷl-o- > cakra- 'wheel'), cf. [Mallory & Adams 2006](src-75):175. For the purposes of root-cognacy, The Indo-Iranic forms are treated in this class as cognate with the other forms which are more clearly from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂-. The least disturbed forms appear to be found in Germanic, for which see [Lehmann 1986](src-179):349, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):526-527.

Source: 274[208-220{S.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (LIV² 230f., IEW 287ff.).}];66[1049{S.v. ὀδών 'tooth' < *h₃d-(o)nt- 'tooth'.}];79[124{S.v. Arm. atamn 'tooth', derived from PIE *h₃dont- (cf. Gk. ὀδών, ὀδόντος, Lat. dēns, dentis, Skt. dán, dántam, Lith. dant-ìs, etc.).}];172[I:693-694{S.v. Ved. dant- 'Zahn', from PIE *h₁d-ónt- *'beißend' (~*h₁ed-) (cf. Gk. ὀδὠν, ὀδόντ- [Aeol. ἔδοντ-ες], Arm. atamn, Lat. dēns, dent-, OHG zan(d), Lith. dantìs 'Zahn', etc.).}];353[115{S.v. Lith. dantìs 'tooth' (OPr. dantis 'tooth'), from PIE *h₃d-(o)nt- (cf. Skt. dánt- 'tooth', Gk. ὀδών 'tooth', Arm. atamn 'tooth', Lat. dēns, 'tooth', OHG zan(d) 'tooth').}];165[509-510{S.v. Proto-Germanic *tanϸ- ~ *tunϸ- 'tooth'. The ablaut of NWGerm. *tanϸ- and EGerm. *tunϸ- points to an original paradigm *tanϸ-, gen. tundiz < *h₃d-ónt-, *h₃d-nt-és, an archaic participle to the root *h₃ed- 'to bite, be sharp'.}];54[166-167{S.v. Lat. dēns, -tis 'tooth', from PIE *h₃d-nt- 'tooth' (cf. OIr. dét 'tooth', Skt. dánt-, Gk. (Ion.) ὀδών, νωδός 'toothless' (< *n-h₃d-o-), Aeol. ἔδοντες 'teeth' (only in a 12th c. AD gloss in a grammatical text), Arm. atamn, OPr. dantis, Lith. dantìs, Lith. úodas, Latv. uôds 'gnat', Gk. ὀδυνή 'pain').}];50[90{S.v. Proto-Celtic *danto- 'tooth', from PIE *h₁dont- 'tooth' (cf. Lat. dēns, Skt. dánt-, Gk. ὀδών, Lith. dantìs, OHG zand). The reconstruction of the initial laryngeal is uncertain. Some prefer to see an original participle of the verb 'to eat' *h₁ed-, but others reconstruct *h₃- from which Gk. ὀδών is derived more straightforwardly.}];269[{Widely considered to continue a participle *h₁d-ónt- to the verbal root *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', lexicalised as 'tooth' already in PIE ([NIL](src-274) 208-220, [LIV²](src-141) 230-231, [EIEC](src-657) 594). Under this explanation the original Ancient Greek form would be continued by Aeolic ἔδοντ-, which underwent vowel assimilation in other dialects. The Leiden School of Indo-European reconstruction alternatively reconstructs a distinct root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' following [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):77, who argues that it would better account for ὀδών much more straightforwardly, and it would also much better account for the Ancient Greek privative adjective νωδός 'toothless' < *n̥-h₃d-ó-, (expected †νηδός < *n̥-h₃d-ó-)| as for Aeolic ἔδοντ-, it only occurs in late grammatical texts and could have itself been created on the basis of an analogy to Greek ἔδ- 'eat'. For individual branches, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):776, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1049, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):1049, [EWAia](src-172) I:693-694, [ALEW](src-352) 174-175, [Derksen 2015](src-353):115, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):169, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):166-167, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:62-63 [Matasović 2009](src-50):90).}];141[230-231{Cf. s.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (IEW 287-9), to which LIV² reconstructs a participle already in PIE *h₁d-ónt- 'Zahn'.}];352[174-175{S.v. OLith. dantìs, dantỹs, dañtis 'Zahn' (BSl. OPr. dantis 'Zahn', etc.), from PIE *h₁d-ont-, *h₁d-n̥t- 'Zahn' (cf. Ved. dánt- 'Zahn', Gk. ὀδών -όντος, ἔδοντες (Aeol.) 'Zähne', Mycen. o-da-twe-ta 'mit Zähnen versehen', Arm. atamn, Lat. dens, OIr. d´t, Goth. tunþus, etc.). Traditionally analysed as a early lexicalised derivative of the root *h₁ed- 'essen' (cf. NIL 210), cf. however Kortlandt (2003:77, 94) skeptical and suggests alternatively a derivation from *h₃ed-.}];316[169{S.v. Lat. dēns, dentis 'dent de l'homme ou des animaux'. A pan Indo-European word. The Greek forms ὀδών, ὀδόντος (Aeolic ἔδοντες) indicate a connection with the group of words related to edō, etc., of which this is the participle.}];270[776{S.v. AGk. ὀδών. Given the variation, two etymologies have been proposed: (1) Traditionally one considers a participle of *ed- 'manger' with a zero-grade, with an e-grade in ἔδοντες, like ἔων beside ὤν. The second hypothesis of Benveniste (BSL 1931 74ff.) considers the character of the vocalic alternation *ed-, the semantic difficulty of calling the tooth 'the eater' instead considering a prothesis to a base *den-t-, *don-t-, *dn̥t-, parallel to *den-k-, *dn̥k- in Greek δάκνω, Skt. dáśati.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing an inherited word for 'tooth', widely considered to continue a participle *h₁d-ónt- to the verbal root *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', lexicalised as 'tooth' already in PIE ([NIL](src-274) 208-220, [LIV²](src-141) 230-231, [EIEC](src-657) 594). Under this explanation the original Ancient Greek form would be continued by Aeolic ἔδοντ-, which underwent vowel assimilation in other dialects. The Leiden School of Indo-European reconstruction alternatively reconstructs a distinct root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' following [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):77, who argues that it would better account for ὀδών much more straightforwardly, and it would also much better account for the Ancient Greek privative adjective νωδός 'toothless' < *n̥-h₃d-ó-, (expected †νηδός < *n̥-h₃d-ó-); as for Aeolic ἔδοντ-, it only occurs in late grammatical texts and could have itself been created on the basis of an analogy to Greek ἔδ- 'eat'. For individual branches, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):776, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1049, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):1049, [EWAia](src-172) I:693-694, [ALEW](src-352) 174-175, [Derksen 2015](src-353):115, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):169, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):166-167, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:62-63 [Matasović 2009](src-50):90).

Source: 165[47{S.v. Proto-Germanic *bagma- 'beam, tree' < PIE *bʰh₂g̑ʰ-mo-.  The word is most likely related to PGmc. *bōgu- 'shoulder, upper arm) in OE bōg m. 'shoulder' < PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u- (cf. Gk. πῆχυς, Skt. bāhu- 'forearm', etc.). The widely spread idea that the word continues *baww-ma- and derived to PIE *bʰh₂u- 'to grow' is flawed because the original meaning 'beam' instead of 'tree', therefore the proposed connection to *bōgu- 'shoulder, upper arm' < PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u-.}];179[55-56{S.v Goth. B5 bagms 'δένδρον', 'tree', precise etymology difficult, but assumed to be connected to PIE *bʰeu̯- with a laryngeal extension (cf. Gk. φῦμα 'growth', Skt. bhū́ma 'being, earth'. Other hypotheses such as mixture with reflexes of *bagʰ- or relationship with Skt. bahúṣ 'arm' are dubious.}];388[32, 39{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ƀaʒmaz ~ *ƀaʒnaz, an irregular phonetic transformation of *ƀaumaz 'beam' and further connected with PIE *bheu- 'to grow', cf. Gk. φῦμα 'growth', bhū́man- 'being, world, earth'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside Germanic disputed; either (1) to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):55-56, [Orel 2003](src-388):32, 39; for the root cf. [LIV²](src-141) 98-100); or (2) to PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ- and related to the IE word for 'upper-arm' *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):47).

Source: 141[647{S.v. ?*treh₁- 'drehen' (IEW 1072), cf. n1 mostly considered as somehow belonging to *terh₁- 'bohren'.}];165[546{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸrēan- s.v. 'to turn', from PIE *tréh₁-e- (cf. Gk. τετραίνω 'to pierce, perforate'| Lat. terō 'to rub' < *terh₁-e-| Lith. trìnti 'to rub, file' < *tr-n-h₁-e-). "A strong verb from a root *treh₁-, apparently a variant of the more wide-spread *terh₁-."}];556[519{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *ϸrǣ-a- 'drehen', belongs probably to the IE root *ter- with a development in meaning 'rub' > 'bore' > 'turn'.}]
Justification: Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ([LIV²](src-141) 632), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):546, [Seebold 1970](src-556):519.

Source: 141[91-92{Cf. s.v. *bʰre⁽g̑⁾- 'brechen (intr.)' (IEW 165).}];397[149{Cf. s.v. NHG brechen (MHG brechen, OHG brehhan, OS brekan), from Gmc. *brek-a- s.v. 'brechen', also in Goth. brikan, OE brecan, OFr. breka, from PIE *bʰreg- (often elsewhere in IE as a nasal-present stem, cf. Lat. frangere 'brechen' [pf. frēgī]).}];165[75{S.v. Proto-Germanic *brekan-, from PIE *bʰrég-e-, a strong verb closely related to the *bruk(k)ōn-, which may be etymologically identical to Lat. frangō 'break' < *bʰrg-néh₂-.}]
Justification: Lit. 'to break (open)'.

Source: 141[219-220{Cf. s.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).}];172[I:513{Cf. s.v. Ved. gharmá- 'Glut, Hitze, Wärme' < PIE *gʷʰor-mó- (cf. Lat. formus 'warm').}];66[541-542{S.v. θερμός 'warm' < PIE *gʷʰer-mó- 'warm'.}];105[303, 525{Cf. s.v. Alb. nxeh 'to heat, to warm', continuing Proto-Albanian *en-dzerska. The root is the same as Alb. zjarr 'fire' < PIE *gʷʰer- 'be warm'.}];369[298{S.v. Alb. ngroh 'erwärmen, warm machen', cf. for discussion of the derived stem forms in Albanian.}];79[556-557{S.v. Arm. ǰer 'warmth| warm and bright weather', 'warm', derived from PIE *gʷʰer(-mo)- 'warm' (cf. Ved. gharmá-, Gk. θερμός, etc.).}];165[575{S.v. Proto-Germanic *warma- 'warm', from PIE *gʷʰor-mo- and identical in derivation to Lat. formus 'warm'.}];274[196-199{S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ([NIL](src-274) 196-199, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):541-542, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):556-557, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):298, [Orel 1998](src-105):303, 525, [EWAia](src-172) I:513, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575). Most lexemes in this class (Greek, Armenian, Iranic, Germanic) reflect a PIE adjectival stem *gʷʰer-mó-. Albanian is only root-cognate with the rest of the forms and has a distinct stem formation (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):298 for further discussion).

Source: 165[575{S.v. Proto-Germanic *waskan- 'to wash', a ske-present derived from *watar- ~ *watan- 'water' (< *uod-r/n-).}];556[539{S.v. Gm. *wask-a- 'waschen'. Germanic *wask-a- 'waschen' has no clear possibilities for comparison. The connection taken up by dictionaries to wet- 'Wasser' is wholly improbable on the basis of morphological grounds ("aus morphologischen Gründen völlig unwahrscheinlich").}];397[972{S.v. NHG waschen (MHG waschen, weschen, OHG wascan, OS waskan), from West Germanic *wask-a- 'waschen', also in OE wascan. Etymology unclear. A derivation from the word 'Wasser' would be semantically close, however that would not explain the strong stem in Germanic.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain; occasionally attempted to be derived from the root *u̯ed- underlying the IE word for 'water' (cf. [cognate set 335](cog-335), [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575), but such a secondary formation does not easily explain the strong stem formation in Germanic ([Seebold 1970](src-556):539, [Kluge 2011](src-397):972).

Source: 274[706-715{S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).  Originally a heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥-/*u̯ed-en-.}];80[987-988{S.v. Hitt. u̯ātar / u̯itēn- 'water', from PIE *uód-r, ud-én- (cf. Skt. udán-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, OCS voda, Goth. wato, ON vatn, OSax. watar, OHG wazzar 'water').}];345[627-628{S.v. TochB war 'water', which with TochA wär reflect Proto-Tocharian *wärä, probably a regular reflex of PIE *udrom, a regular thematisation of *wodr-/udn-.}];66[1526-1527{S.v. ὕδωρ, -ατος 'water', from PIE *u̯od-r̥, *ud-n-, coll. udōr 'water'.}];279[815-816{S.v. U. utur 'Wasser', the inherited word for water < PIE *u̯edōr (cf. Gk. ὕδωρ, ὕδατος, Hitt. u̯atar, u̯etenaš, etc.).}];81[523{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *voda 'water' from PIE *uod-r/n- 'water' (cf. Skt. udan-, Hitt. u̯ātar, u̯etenas, Gk. ὕδωρ, Lat. unda, 'wave', Goth. wato, OSax. watar, OIc. vatn).}];172[I:215-216{Cf. s.v. Ved. udán- 'Wasser', from PIIr. *ud-r-/*ud-n-, derived to PIE *u̯ed- (cf. YAv. vaiδi- 'Wasserlauf', Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, OS watar, ON vatn, OCS voda 'Wasser', etc.).}];353[488{S.v. Lith. vanduõ (Latv. ûdens, OPr. wundan), from PIE *uod-r/n- (cf. OCS voda, Skt. udán-, Hitt. u̯ātar / u̯iten-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Go. wato, OIc. vatn, OS watar).}];165[575-576{S.v. Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', from PIE *uod-r/n-.}];50[394{S.v. Proto-Celtic *uden-sk-yo- 'water', from PIE *wod-r / *uden- 'water' (cf. Skt. udán-, Hitt. watar-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Lat. unda 'wave', OCS voda, Germ. Wasser). Matasović gives this as the standard etymology, although he expresses reservations that the Proto-Celtic stem formation is correct. See entry for further discussion.}];105[482-483{S.v. Alb. ujë 'water', from PAlb. udrjā and derived from the IE word for water *u̯ed-. The connection to *u̯ed- is generally agreed since Meyer (1891:456) [cf. entry in Orel for references to further literature], but note Demiraj (1997:401-402) alternatively derives PAlb. *urjā, related to Skt. vā́r- [< *u̯eh₁-r].}];369[401-402{S.v. Alb. új/ë 'Wasser', D. alternatively derives Albanian forms from PIE *(H)uh₁r̥-i̯o/e-, cf. Skt. vā́r < *(H)u̯(e)h₁-r-.}];352[1185-1186{S.v. OLith. vanduõ, vánduõ 'Wasser' (BSl. Latv. ûdèns 'Wasser'. OPr. wundan, wunda, unds 'Wasser'), derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'benetzen' (cf. Ved. 3.sg.pres. unátti, 3.pl.pres. undánti, 3.pl.pf. ūdur 'quellen, benetzen'). Cf. notes in ALEW for the unusual nominal stem found in Old Prussian.}];296[U:21{S.v. OIr. uisce 'eau', evidently derived to the root which designated in Indo-European a liquid element *wed-/*ud- (cf. Skt. udán-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Hitt. watar, Goth. wato, OCS voda). Cf. for various proposals for explaining the Celtic stem formation.}]
Comment: a PIE variant is cognate/2394/
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ód-r̥-, *u̯ed-en- 'water', a heteroclite r/n-stem derived to PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):987-988, [Adams 2013](src-345):627-628, [Beekes 2010](src-66):5126-1527, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):401-402, [Orel 1998](src-105):482-483, [EWAia](src-172) I:215-216, [ALEW](src-352) 1185-1186, [Derksen 2015](src-353):488, [Derksen 2008](src-81):523, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575-576, [Untermann 2000](src-279):815-816, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:21, [Matasović 2009](src-50):394).

Source: 179[264{Cf. s.v. Goth. N9. natjan 'βρέχειν', 'moisten', derived from PGmc. *nata- as in OS, Du nat, OHG naz (adj.) 'wet', nazi 'moisture', naz(z)ēn 'become wet, rain', nez(z)en 'moisten', NHG nass 'wet'. No further etymology.}];697[422{S.v. Gmc. *nata- 'naß', only attested as an adjective in West Germanic, also indirectly attested in East and North Germanic. If one assumes pre-Proto-Germanic *nod-, then there are only vague possibilities for comparison (perhaps Ved. nadī́- 'Fluß', W nodd 'Feuchtigkeit').}];165[384{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nata- 'wet'. Of uncertain origin, but possibly to be continuing *unod-o-, an o-stem adjective derived from an n-present 3.sg. *u-né-d-ti, 3.pl. *u-n-d-énti (cf. Skt. 3.sg. unátti, 3.pl. undánti 'to well up, moisten').}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):264, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):422, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):384 for various proposals.

Source: 172[II:679-680{S.v. Ved. svetá- 'weiß, hell' (cf. YAv. spaēta- 'white', OPers. *sai̯ta-), from PIE *k̑u̯ei̯tó- (cf. OCS světъ 'φῶς', Germ. xu̯ei̯ta- 'weiß' in Goth. ƕeits, ONor. hvítr, OHG (h)wīz, etc.). Based on the verbal root *k̑u̯ei̯t- (cf. Lith. švintù, švìsti 'hell werden, aufleuchten', OCS svьtěti (sę) 'leuchten, scheinen').}];141[340{Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'hell aufleuchten' (IEW 628-629).}];165[267{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hwīta- ~ *kwitta- 'white', from PIE *k̑u(e)it-nó- (cf. Skt. śvítna- 'white, whitish' < k̑uit-no-| Skt. śvetá- 'white, bright', YAv. spaēta-, MPers. spēd, NPers. sapēd 'white' < *k̑uoit-o-).}];697[316-317{S.v. Gmc. *hʷeita- 'weiß', in the pre-Germanic form *k̑u̯ei̯d- without clear comparisons, but with IE *-t- cf. Ved. śvetá-, Av. spaēta- 'weiß', Ved. śvítna- 'weißlich', śvitrá- 'weiß, weißlich'| the verbal basis in Ved. śvit- 'hell, weiß sein', Lith. šviẽsti, OCS svьtěti 'leuchten, scheinen'.}];397[980{S.v. NHG weiß (MHG wīz, OHG (h)wīz, OS hwīt), from Gmc. *hweita- 'weiß', also in Goth. ƕeits, ON hvítr, OFr. hwīt, as a variant in final position corresponds to IE *kʷei̯t- 'glänzen, hell sein, weiß sein' in Ved. śvit-, Lith. šviẽsti, OCS svĭtěti. The Germanic final *-t- can be explained as either due to the influence of the geminate *-tt- in OFr. hwitt. MLG wit(t), MDu. wit(t)e < an n-assimilation (cf. Ved. śvítna- 'hell, licht', although the attestation of this geminate is late. Also considerable is secondary influence from the Auslaut of Gmc. *swart- 'black' (cf. NHG schwarz).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯eit- 'to shine brightly' [EWAia](src-172) II:679-680, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):316-317, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):267, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 340). The Germanic forms irregularly reflect final *-t-, but this is generally explained by a secondary gemination *-tn- > -tt- or secondary influence from Gmc. *swart- (< IE *su̯ord-o-, cf. [cognate set 188](cog-188)), cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):980.

Source: 397[980{S.v. NHG weit (MHG wīt, OHG wīt, OS wīd), from Germanic *weida- (adj.) 'weit' also found in ON víðr, OE wīd, OFr. wīd. Origin unclear. May formally correspond to Ved. vīta 'gerade', but the semantics are divergent and they are not readily connected.}];165[584-585{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wīda- 'wide, distant', as though from PIE *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- (cf. TochAB wätk- 'to separate, distinguish' < *h₁ui-dʰh₁-sk-e- (cf. Lat. dīvidō, -ere 'to separate, divide' *-h₁ui-dʰh₁-). "A full-grade adj. created to a verbal formation *h₁ui-dʰeh₁- 'to set apart', with *h₁ui- being dissimilated from *dui- 'in two' due to the following dental ([Lubotsky 1994](src-706))."}];706[203-204];697[678-679{S.v. Gmc. *wīda- 'weit'| several possibilities at a formal connection with Ved. vītá- from different sources: (a) 'gerade, nicht krumm, eben' (RV, of uncertain origin)| (b) 'eingehüllt, bedeckt, verbogen' (RV, to vyáyati 'umhüllt, bedeckt, birgt')| (c) 'unternommen, angenommen' (RV, to véti 'wendet sich zu, trachtet nach'), (d) vergangen, gewichen' (to vi-i- RV 'in verschiedene Richtungen gehen, sich verbreiten, sich verstreuen, sich verschwinden'), but nevertheless unclear.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):678-679 and [Kluge 2011](src-397):980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by [Lubotsky 1994](src-706):203-204, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

Source: 50[47{S.v. Proto-Celtic *awelā 'breeze, wind', cf. PIE *h₂uh₁-el- (IEW 81ff.). Neuter l-stem, probably with nom. sg. *h₂ewh₁-l, gen. sg. *h₁uh₂-el-s, cf. Gk. ἄελλα 'stormwind'.}];141[287{Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯eh₁- 'wehen' (IEW 81-4). Cf. n1: The majority of forms found among the IE languages are adjectives derived from participles of the verb 'to blow', i.e. ptc. *h₂u̯éh₁-n̥t- → adj. *h₂u̯ḗh₁n̥to-.}];80[368{S.v. Hitt. ḫuu̯ant- 'wind', from PIE *h₂uh₁-ent-, which exactly matches Gk. ἀέντ-, functioning as the participle of the verb 'to blow'. Other cognates from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- include Skt. vā́nt- 'blowing', vā́ta- 'wind', Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, TochA want-, TochB yente.}];345[546{S.v. TochB yente 'wind', which with TochA want reflect Proto-Tocharian *wi̯ente from a PIE *h₂u̯eh₁n̥to- (cf. Skt. vāta-, Av. vāta-, Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, Hitt. hwant-, etc.).}];172[II:542{S.v. Skt. vā́ta- 'Wind, Windgott' (cf. IIr. in OAv. vāta- 'wind', YAv. vāta- 'wind', etc.), from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁-n̥t-o- to √*h₂u̯eh₁- (cf. Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, etc.).}];81[519-520{S.v. Proto-Slavic *větrъ 'wind', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *ueʔtr- (cf. Lith. vė́tra 'storm', Latv. vȩ̄tra 'storm', derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *vějati 'blow (of wind), winnow' from PIE *h₂ueh₁- (cf. Skt. vā́ti 'blow (of wind)', Gk. ἄησι (Hes.) 'id.', OHG wāen 'id.').}];54[662-663{S.v. Lat. ventus 'wind', from PIE *h₂ueh₁-nt-o- 'wind' (cf. W. gwynt 'wind', Hitt. huu̯ant- 'wind', Skt. vāta- 'wind, god of wind', OAv., YAv. vāta- 'wind', Gk. ἄησι 'to blow', Goth. winds, OHG wint, TochB yente, TochA want (~wänt) 'wind').}];353[496{Cf. s.v. Lith. vė́jas 'wind' (Latv. vẽjš 'wind') from PIE *h₂ueh₁-iu- (cf. Skt. vāyú- 'wind, air, god of the wind').}];165[587{S.v. Proto-Germanic *winda- 'wind', from PIE *h₂uéh₁-ent-o- (cf. Hitt. huu̯ant- 'wind' < *h₂uh₁-ent-| TochA want, wänt, TochB yente 'wind', Lat. ventus, W. gwynt < *h₂ueh₁-(e)nt-o-, Skt. vā́ta-, OAv., YAv. vāta-, NPers. bād, Oss. wad / wad(æ) < *h₂ueh₁-nt-o-).}];352[1226-1227{S.v. OLith. vė́ti 'wehen', with derived noun vė́jas 'Wind' (BSl. Latv. vẽjš 'Wind', OCS vějati 'wehen', etc.) from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'wehen' (cf. Ved. vā- 'wehen', YAv. vā- 'weht', Gk. ἅημι 'wehe', Goth. waian 'wehen', etc.).}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):368, [Adams 2013](src-345):546, [EWAia](src-172) II:542, [ALEW](src-352) 1226-1227, [Derksen 2015](src-353):496, [Derksen 2008](src-81):519-520, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):587, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):662-663, [Matasović 2009](src-50):47, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 287).

Source: 441[386-389{S.v. OHG flioga 'Fliege' and vb. fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.}];141[488{Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An extension of *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7), only Germanic and Baltic.}];397[306{S.v. NHG Flügel (MHG vlügel, MLG vlogel, MDu. vleughel), as with ON flygill, an recent instrumental formation in -ila- to fliegen 'to fly'.}]
Justification: Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.

Source: 165[153{S.v. Proto-Germanic *frauja(n)- 'lord'. Unclear etymology. "The assumed etymological link with Skt. pū́rva- adj. 'front, first', YAv. pauruua-, paouruua-, pouruua- adj. 'being in front, first, former', OCS prъvъ 'first' < *prH-uo- is problematic, since the full-grade form *proHu-io- would yield PGm. **frōjan- (with *-ōu- giving -ō-) rather than *fraujan-."}];294[645{Cf. s.v. *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft. mit Abl. PGmc. *frau̯i̯a- 'vorderer| Herr' (ON Freyr m., Freyja f.| OHG frouwa 'Herrin, Frau', Goth. frauja 'Herr < *frau̯i̯an-), commonly assumed to be a derivation in *-u̯o- to PIE *pro- 'forwards, ahead'.}];269[{Traditionally derived from PIE *pro-u̯o-, remodelled in PGmc. as *frau̯i̯a- 'the one in front, lord' (cf. [NIL](src-274) 645, [Kluge 2011](src-397):314). Doubted by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):153) on account of phonological difficulties. Consequently only a Proto-Germanic root ref. form has been assigned for this class, but cf. the standard handbooks for their arguments for or against positing an IE proto-form.}];179[126-127{Cf. s.v. Goth. F87. frauja 'κύριος, δεσπότης', 'lord', from PIE *prō- + -wo- (cf. Skt. pū́rvas, Av. paurva-, etc.).}];397[314{S.v. Germ. Frau (MHG vro(u)we, OHG frouwa, OS frūa, from *frawjōn 'lady', a feminine stem formation based on *fraw-jōn 'lord' (cf. Goth. frauja, OHG frō). Considered to go back to *prō-wo- or *prH-wo- with the meaning 'first' (cf. Ved. pū́rva- 'vorderer, früherer', OCS prĭvŭ 'erster'.}]
Justification: Traditionally derived from PIE *pro-u̯o-, remodelled in PGmc. as *frau̯i̯a- 'the one in front, lord' (cf. [NIL](src-274) 645, [Kluge 2011](src-397):314). Doubted by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):153) on account of phonological difficulties.

Source: 443[15/1:192-210{S.v. Germanismes *bosk-, considering Fr. bois, etc. as loans from Germanic *bosk- 'bush'.}];444[131{S.v. 1419b busk (fränk.) 'Wald'}]
Justification: Usually considered a loanword into Romance from West Germanic *bosk- 'forest' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):131, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:192-210).

Source: 54[665{S.v. Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot', from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' (cf. Goth. waurms 'snake', OIc. ormr, OEng. wyrm, OFr. wirm 'snake', OS wormo, OHG wurm, 'worm' < PGmc. *wurma/i-). Cf. the PIE doublet *kʷrmi- 'worm, maggot', possibly secondarily from PIE *kʷrmi- > *wrmi- in Lat. and Germanic.}];696[288{"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu| kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'| compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."}];165[600{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wurmi- 'worm', from PIE *urm-i- and identical to Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot' < *urmi-, further cf. Gk. ῥόμος 'wood-worm' < *urm-o- (with dialectal vocalisation of *r̥?)| Lith. var̃mas 'insect, mosquito' < *uorm-o-| OCS vьrmьje 'insects' < *urm-io-| OPru. wormyan (adj.) 'red' < urm-io-).}];179[397{S.v. Goth. W42. waurms 'ὄφις', 'snake', from PIE *u̯er- 'turn, wind' (cf. Gk. Hesych. ῥόμος· σκώληξ ἐν ξύλοις 'woodworm', Lith. var̃mas 'mosquito', Lat. vermis 'worm', OSl. vermije 'grasshoppers, insects').}]
Justification: Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. [Watkins 1987](src-696):288). Cf. also [Lehmann 1986](src-179):397, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):600).

Source: 165[273{S.v. Proto-Germanic *jēra-, from PIE *i̯éh₁-r̥, i̯éh₁-n̥-s. Generalised with an r-suffix in Germanic, Avestan (nom.sg. yārə, gen.sg. yā̊) has preserved the original heteroclitic inflection. Cf. also Gk. ὤρα 'season, year, hour, time' < *i̯oh₁-reh₂.}];172[II:98-99{Cf. s.v. Ved. paryāríṇi- 'nach einem Jahr erst kalbend(e Kuh)' based on *pari-yārám 'a year long' < pári and *yār 'year' (=Av. yār- 'year', OHG jār, etc.).}];331[4:130-131{S.v. Proto-Iranic *i̯ār(a)- 'год| период, времени', derived from PIE *i̯ēro- : i̯oro- ~ i̯əro-, cf. OHG jār, NHG Jahr, Engl. year, Gk. ὤρα, etc.}]
Justification: Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE heteroclite stem *i̯eh₁-r/n- ([EWAia](src-172) II:98-99, [ESIJa](src-331) 4:130-131, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):273).

Source: 105[18{S.v. Alb. bark 'belly, womb, abdomen', from PAlb. *baruka-, continuing *bʰor-uko-, a derivative of IE *bʰer- 'to carry' (Meyer 1891:27).}];369[92{S.v. bark, -u 'Bauch, (Unter)leib, Mutterleib, Uterus, (dial.) Schwangerhaft'. The usual etymology as an o-grade derivation *bʰor-k- to the root *bʰer- 'tragen' is phonologically flawless, but semantically weak. Semantically better, but formally more difficult to reconcile is the comparison with OIr. brú 'Bauch, Leib', W. bru 'venter, uterus', Russ. brjúcho 'Unterleib, Bauch' < *bʰr̥k-?, *bʰr̥Hu-(k⁽ʷ⁾-)?}];130[51-52{Rejects the traditional connection with *bʰer- 'to carry' (cf. Orel 1998:18, doubted by Demiraj 1997:92) as problematic, suggests instead a connection with IEW 110 *bʰarekʷ- 'vollgestopft/jammed'.}];585[27{Derives from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry'.}];269[{I do not understand the alleged semantic difficulties of the traditional etymology from *bʰer- 'carry' (so Demiraj 1997:92, Holm 2011:51-52), if the semantic development could have been from *'womb' > 'belly'. For the purposes of a root-ref. form, the traditional etymology has been maintained, but cf. the discussion of Demiraj and Holm for skepticism of the usual etymology.}];571[40-41{S.v. Alb. bark, -u 'belly, womb, abdomen', following Meyer (1891:27) to PIE *bʰer- 'carry'.}]
Justification: Usually derived to PIE *bʰer- 'carry' [Meyer 1891](src-585):27, [Huld 1984](src-571):40-41, [Orel 1998](src-105):18 (but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):92, [Holm 2011](src-130):51-52 with some skepticism).

Source: 274[468-478{S.v. *meg̑- 'groß' (IEW 708f., EIEC 344). Cf. entry for extensive discussion of stem derivations found in individual IE branches.}];50[253{S.v. Proto-Celtic *magyo- < PIE *meg̑h₂-. The Irish and Gaulish forms go back to PCelt. *magi̯o-. According to NIL this in turn maybe from PIE *m̥g̑-i̯o/i̯ah₂-.}];66[917-918{S.v. μέγας 'great, big, large' < PIE *meg̑-h₂- 'much, many'. Greek μέγας reflects a stem *meg̑-h₂- which is also found in Sanskrit maha- 'great, mighty, strong'.  (In Skt. *-g̑h₂- > -h-).  (This additional *-h₂- on the stem is however not found in the comparative μεῖζων/μέζων << *még̑-i̯os- and superlative μέγιστος < *meg̑-is-to-.)  The oblique and feminine stem of the positive form of the adjective μεγάλο-, μεγάλη have an enlargement *-l-, the origin of which is unclear, but is also found in other lexemes in Goth. mikils 'great' and Lithuanian dìdelis 'great' < dìdis.}];165[361-362{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mekila- 'large, great, much'. The Germanic forms based on the root *meg̑- exhibit the same derivational suffix *-ila- as in Proto-Germanic *lītila- 'small'. This is due to analogy in one direction or the other between these semantically similar lexemes.}];105[240{S.v. Alb. madh 'big, large' < Proto-Albanian *madza and related to Hitt. mekkiš, Skt. mahā́nt-, Gk. μέγας, Lat. magnus, etc.}];79[458-460{S.v. Arm. mec 'great, big, large' (a-stem). Arm. *mec-a- reflects PIE *meg̑-h₂-.}];172[II:337-338{Cf. s.v. Ved. mahā́nt- 'groß, ausgedehnt, mächtig, bedeutend'. The IIr. forms are based upon PIE *meg̑- 'big' with an ablauting suffix *-(é)h₂-. Cf. entry in Mayrhofer for detailed discussion of the stem formations to this root in Indo-Iranian.}];54[358-359{S.v. Lat. magnus 'great, big, large' < Proto-Italic *magno/ā- < PIE *mg̑-no- 'great'.}];369[250-251{S.v. Alb. 2. madh (i) 'groß', from PIE *meg̑-, but with some difficulties in establishing the exact stem formation.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *meg̑- 'big' ([NIL](src-274) 468-478, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):917-918, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):458-460, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):250-251, [Orel 1998](src-105):240, [EWAia](src-172) II:337-338, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):361-362, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):358-359, [Matasović 2009](src-50):253). For Tocharian lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):479-480.

Source: 105[525{S.v. Alb. zog 'bird' "An Oriental Wanderwort, presumably of Iranian origin, cf. Arm. jag 'chick', NPers zaq 'cub'."}];49[409{From PIE *g̑ʰāgʷʰ- 'young of an animal, especially of a bird'. Cognate with Mod. Pers. zāq 'young animal, esp. chick' (the orthography repesents zāɣ). Borrowed from Persian: Arm. jag 'young of an animal, nestling'.}];364[239{~ Arm. jag(-owc') 'fledgling,sparrow'| < Early Pr. Alb *j́u̯āgV- > PIE *g̑ʰu̯eh₂gʰV-}];369[429-430{S.v. Alb. zog, -u 'Vogel', originally proposed by [Meyer 1892](src-752):18 not to be separated from Arm. jag 'young bird'. Not conclusively convincing ("Im übrigen nicht eindeutig.") Probably to be accounted for onomatopoeically.}];130[52-53];571[135-136{S.v. Alb. zog, -u '(young) bird', probably a culture word rather than the widespread idea that the Albanian is to be related with Arm. jag 'chick'.}];752[18{S.v. zok 'junger Vogel', stem zog-, cf. Arm. jag 'junger Vogel', which can be both reconciled to a proto-form *g̑ʰāgʰos.}]
Justification: Since [Meyer 1892](src-752):18 compared with Armenian jag 'small bird' with various proposed reconstructions to reconcile the comparison (for further discussion cf. [IEW](src-49) 409 s.v. *g̑ʰāgʷʰ-, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):429-430, [Holm 2011](src-130):52-53, and [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):239 most recently proposing a pre-form *g̑ʰu̯eh₂gʰV-). Alternatively [Huld 1984](src-571):135-136, [Orel 1998](src-105):525 assume that the forms are an Oriental Wanderwort comparing also Persian zāq 'chough', but cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):52 rejecting this hypothesis on the grounds that it is not a typical case of a Wanderwort. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):430 remains unconvinced and instead suggests an onomatopoeic origin.

Source: 105[164{S.v. Alb. kafshoj 'to bite', borrowed from Lat. capessere ~ capissere 'to seize, snatch at', alternatively Rom. *capsāre based on Lat. capere 'to take' cf. Meyer (1891:176). Cf. entry in Orel for other proposals that are to be rejected.}];585[176];130[53{Loan from Lat. capessere possible (so Orel 1998:164), alternatively loan from Lat. *captiare 'beißen, verschlingen'.}]
Justification: Probably a loanword from Latin capessere 'to seize, snatch at' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):176, [Orel 1998](src-105):164, [Holm 2011](src-130):53), but other Latin loan sources are theoretically possible.

Source: 130[53{Rejects Orel (1998:524) with IEW 483-5 who give a semantic development of 'unlucky, mourning' > 'black' as semantically and phonetically questionable, and far-fetched. Offers as an alternative a comparison with *gʷʰHi-d- 'light, grey coloured' (so Demiraj 1997:427-428, cf. Gk. φαιός 'brownish, grey', but admits 'albeit uncertain'.}];105[524{S.v. Alb. zi, 'black', O. connects the term to MHG quāt 'dirt', OE cwéad 'bad', Lith. gė́da 'shame', Slav. *gadъkъ 'disgusting', *gadъ 'reptile, worm', as derivatives of a PIE root *gʷed-.}];369[427-428{S.v. Alb. zi 'schwarz'. Uncertain etymology, rejecting previous connections with Lith. gedù 'trauern' < *gʷedʰíi̯o- and *gʷōu- 'Mist, Exkremente', suggests a connection with Gk. φαίδιμος 'glänzend' < *gʷʰHi-(d-), *gʷʰiH-(d-) as a possible alternative.}];269[{Etymology ultimately uncertain, cf. Demiraj (1997:427), Holm (2011:53).}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):427-428, [Orel 1998](src-105):524, [Holm 2011](src-130):53 for discussion of various proposals.

Source: 130[53{With IEW (1044) from PIE *s(u̯)ekʷ-o-s 'Pflanzensaft / juice of plants' > *sokʷo- > PAlb. śak-.}];105[129{S.v. Alb. gjak 'blood', from PAlb. *saka related to Gk. ὁπός 'juice', Lith. sakaĩ 'resin', Slav. *sokъ 'juice', continuing an IE *sokʷo- 'juice'.}];369[181-182{S.v. gjak 'Blut', very likely to be derived from *sokʷo- (Gk. ὀπός 'Pflanzensaft', Lith. sakaĩ 'Saft der Pflanzen und Früchte', etc. with the semantic development *'Pflanzensaft' → 'Blut').}];571[67{S.v. Alb. gjak 'blood', since [Meyer 1891](src-585):136 connected with OCS sokъ 'juice' and Lith. sakaĩ 'resin'| later also Gk. ὀπός (Pedersen 1937:128). Cf. [IEW](src-49) 1042 s.v. *s(u)ekʷo- 'pflanzlicher Saft, Harz'.}]
Justification: Generally connected to PIE *sokʷo- 'juice of plants and fruit' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):196, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1042, [Huld 1984](src-571):67, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):181-182, [Orel 1998](src-105):129, [Holm 2011](src-130):53).

Source: 105[103{S.v. Alb. fryj ~ frŷj 'to blow', from which the noun frymë is derived. If from PAlb. *sprūgnja, as O. suggests, then possibly connected to Lith. sprūgstu, sprūgti 'to escape, to get out', Slav. *prygati 'to jump, to spring'.}];571[65{S.v. Alb. fryj, fryta, fryrë 'blow'. [Meyer 1891](src-585):112 gave no etymology but connected to Alb. frymë 'breath', Tagliavini (1937:98) notes Barić's derivation from *sphrugniō without comment. Çabej (1962a1:108) suggested the verb is of onomatopoeic origin.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):65, [Orel 1998](src-105):103 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 352[187-189{S.v. OLith. dègti 'brennen, in Flammen stehen| brennen, anzünden, verbrennen' (BSl. cf. Latv. degt, OCS žešti, etc.), from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'verbrennen' (cf. Ved. dah-, dáhati 'verbrennen', YAv. daž-, dažaiti 'verbrennt', Alb. djeg 'verbrennt', Lat. foveō. -ēre 'wärmen', TochA tsāk- 'aufleuchten, leuchten', TochB tsäk- 'verbrennen', tsāk- 'aufleuchten, leuchten').}];141[133-134{S.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' Skt. dáhati, Av. dažaiti, Lith. degù, OCS žegǫ, Alb. djek 'burn', etc.).}]
Justification: Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to incinerate, consume by fire' ([LIV²](src-141) 133-134, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):802, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):138-139, [Orel 1998](src-105):68, [Holm 2011](src-130):55, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):970, [EWAia](src-172) I:712-713, [ALEW](src-352) 187-189).
