Skt. kṣám- 'earth', Gk. χθών 'earth', Hitt. tēkan 'earth').}];353[516{S.v. Lith. žẽmė 'earth, land', from PIE *dʰg̑-em- (cf. Skt. kṣám- 'earth', Gk. χθών 'earth', Hitt. tēkan 'earth').}];369[155-156{S.v. Alb. dhe 'Erde, Boden, Festland, Land', from the inherited IE word for 'earth' (cf. Hitt. tekan, Ved. kṣā́s, Gk. χθών, OIr. dú, OCS zemlja, Lat. humus, etc.).}];352[1296-1298{S.v. OLith. žẽme 'Erde, Welt| Erdboden, Land, Gebiet' (BSl. cf. Latv. zeme 'Erde, Welt, Boden, Land', OPr. semmē, same 'Erde, Acker, Land', OCS zeml’a 'Erde, Boden, Land' etc.), from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om- 'Erde' (cf. Hitt. tēkan 'Erde', CLuw. tiyammi- 'Erde', Ved. kṣam- 'Erde', Gk. χθών 'Erde, Boden, Land', OIr. dú, 'Ort, Stelle', TochA tkaṃ 'Erde, Boden', TochB keṃ 'id.').}];149[128{S.v. B keṃ, A tkaṃ 'earth, ground', from CT *tkænä(-ṃ), reflecting the IE acc.sg. *dʰg̑ʰom-m̥, cf. Gk. χθών 'earth, ground', Hitt. tēkan 'id.'.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, etc. 'earth' ([NIL](src-274) 86-99, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):858-863, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):128, [Adams 2013](src-345):205, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):155-156, [Orel 1998](src-105):80-81, [EWAia](src-172) I:424-425, [ALEW](src-352) 1296-1298, [Derksen 2015](src-353):516, [Derksen 2008](src-81):542).

Source: 141[359-360{Cf. s.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- '(zer)quetschen' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Only Indo-Iranian cognates.}];172[I:451-452{S.v. Ved. √khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen, verzehren'. Cf. NPers. xāyīdan 'kauen' if from *kʰād-, Baluči khāδαγ 'eat', Khot. khaca 'food' (if from *xad-čā). Further connections are not certain.}];442[203-204{S.v. 3865 Ved. khā́dati 'chews, bites' RV.}]
Justification: Modern Indic cognates to be connected with Vedic khād- 'chew, bite; eat' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):203, no. 3865). No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:451-452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 359-360).

Source: 141[80{S.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-5). The Albanian forms are from a secondarily derived e-grade thematic i̯e-present *bʰerH-i̯e/o- (= Lat. feriō 'stoßen, schlagen').}];364[966{S.v. Alb. bie 'fallen| schlagen| Musikinstrument spielen'. Belongs to PIE *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten', but the formation of the present stem is unclear.}];105[24-25{S.v. Alb. bie 'to fall, to hit, to strike, to beat', from PAlb. b(e)rja and derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to strike' (cf. Lat. feriō, OHG berjan, etc.).}];571[43-44{S.v. Alb. bie 'strike, fall' (aor. rashë, rarë). Cognate with Lat. feriō, ON berjask 'strike'.}]
Justification: Generally derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):43-44, [Orel 1998](src-105):24-25, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):966).

Source: 105[214{S.v. Alb. larg 'far (away)', borrowed from Lat. largus 'big, large'.}];571[85{S.v. Alb. larg 'far (away)'. A loanword from Lat. largus 'big, large, great (of distances)'| unlikely is the proposal of [Meyer 1891](src-585):238 from Turkish alargu since intervocalic -l- should invariably yield ł.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin largus 'big, large, great (of distances)' ([Huld 1984](src-571):85, [Orel 1998](src-105):214).

Source: 364[970-971{S.v. OAlb. drúan (intrans.) 'Angst haben, sich fürchten, erschrecken', may be best connected to a root *dʰreh₂s-, which is to be understood as a parallel root to *dʰreh₂gʰ- 'aufgewühlt werden, in Aufruhr geraten' ([LIV²](src-141) 154f.)}];105[76{S.v. druaj ~ druej 'to be afraid', derived from dre, droe 'fear' < PAlb. drāwā and further related to Latv. druvas 'fear' and further to Lith. draudžiù , draũsti 'to forbid, to deter, to scare off'.}]
Justification: Root etymology in this class follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):970-971 to *dʰreh₂s-, a parallel root to dʰreh₂gʰ- 'aufgewühlt werden, in Aufruhr geraten' (LIV² 154f.). For older proposals, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):76.

Source: 105[525{S.v. Alb. zjarr 'fire' < PIE *gʷʰer-es- (cf. Skt. háras- 'flame, heat', Gk. θέρος 'summer', Arm. ǰer id.).}];141[219-220{Cf. s.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-495).}];130[62{From PIE *gʷʰer-mo-, cf. dialectal Gheg zjarm (overlooked by Orel 1998:525, who alternatively postulates *gʷʰoros, which would not explain the -rr).}];369[428-429{S.v. Alb. zjarr 'Feuer, Brand, Feuersbrunst| Fieber'. The variant zjarm may be formally compared with Gk. θερμός 'warm' and Arm. ǰarm 'warm' < *gʷʰer-mo-, but whether zjarr comes from the same stem formation remains disputed. An e-grade formation in *-no-, i.e. *gʷʰer-no- could be possible (cf. Latin fornus beside formus 'warm'). Cf. entry in Demiraj for further discussion regarding the possible stem formations in Albanian.}];274[196-199{S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).}]
Justification: Albanian lexemes generally derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ([NIL](src-274) 196-199, [LIV²](src-141) 219-220), although the stem formation of Albanian zjarr is uncertain (cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):62, [Orel 1998](src-105):525 and especially the detailed discussion of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):428-429).

Source: 105[234{S.v. Alb. lule 'flower', singularised plural of lulë < PAlb. *lulā. "Ancient Balkan loanword from an oriental source, probably Copt hrêri, hlêli 'lily'".}];571[87-88{S.v. Alb. lule 'flower', origin uncertain. Possibly a Wanderwort in view of similar forms as names of flowers in various languages (cf. Burushaski lilio 'violet', Coptic hlēli, Basque lili, Estonian lill, Hittite alel). In view of the recent vowel shift *i > u (cf. luvadh 'meadow' < NGk. λείβαδι) [Meyer 1891](src-585):250 proposed a loan from Lat. lilium, but this is uncertain.}]
Justification: In all likelihood a loanword but of uncertain origin (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):87-88, [Orel 1998](src-105):234).

Source: 105[101{S.v. flutur 'butterfly'. Alb. fluturoj 'to fly' was a borrowed from Romance *fluctulāre (cf. Lat. fluctuāre 'move in waves, move to and fro'). [NB: Orel does not have an independent lemma for fluturoj.]}];130[63];369[172-173{Cf. s.v. Alb. flúg/ë 'Schindel'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Romance *fluctulāre < Latin fluctuāre ([Orel 1998](src-105):101, cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):63, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):172-173, [Meyer 1891](src-585):109).

Source: 105[177{S.v. Alb. këmbë ~ kambë 'leg, foot', from Rom. *camba ~ *gamba 'leg'.}];130[63{Loan from Lat. camba.}];571[80{S.v. Alb. këmbë, -a 'leg, foot'. Ultimately a loan from VLat. camba 'leg'. "The relation to the Vulgar Latin form is clear but the direction of the borrowing is uncertain."}]
Justification: Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ([Huld 1984](src-571):80, [Orel 1998](src-105):177, [Holm 2011](src-130):63).

Source: 81[326, 342-343{S.v. Proto-Slavic *mьrznǫti 'freeze' (ESSJa XXI 163-165), and related stems, cf. Proto-Slavic *mьrzěti 'freeze', a verb with the zero-grade of *morzъ 'frost'. Possibly a case of Winter's law, in which then *morzъ must be accounted for via *merg̑-o- (cf. Alb. mardhë 'frost').}];105[245{Cf. s.v. Alb. mardhë 'chill, frost, ice', etymologically identical with Slav. *morzъ 'frost' (cf. Meyer 1891:260), both continuing *merg̑ʰ- 'to rot, to soak'. Derivative verbs: mardh 'to chill, to freeze', mërdhij 'id.'.}];369[256{Cf. s.v. Alb. márdh/ë, -a 'Frost', an old word for 'Frost', which can be identical with OCS mrazъ 'Frost', cf. IEW 740 *merg̑- 'morschen', alternatively from *morg̑⁽ʰ⁾-.}];458[20: 10-14| 21: 163-165{PS *morzŭ 'frost' and *mĭrznǫti 'freeze' are related to Albanian marth 'frost' etc. and derived from PIE *merg̑-.}]
Comment: There might be another root *merk⁽ʷ⁾- with a meaning pertaining to the same semantic field, cf. e.g. Ukrainian dialectal morokvá 'quagmire, swamp', Lith. mer̃kti 'to wet, to moisten (flax, linen)' and maybe as a cognate Latin marceō 'to be withered, droop', cf. also Derksen, EtymDictSlav 325f. s.v. *morky, ALEW 637 and de Vaan, EtymDictLat 364f. (Freiberg).
Justification: Albanian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾- ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):256, [Orel 1998](src-105):245, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:10-14; 21:163-165, [Derksen 2008](src-81):326, 342-343).

Source: 105[314{S.v. Alb. pemë 'fruit-tree, fruit', borrowed from Lat. pōmum 'fruit', pōmus 'fruit tree'.}];585[326{Borrowing from Lat. pōmum 'fruit'.}];130[85-86{Loan from Lat. pōmum.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):326, [Orel 1998](src-105):314, [Holm 2011](src-130):85-86).

Source: 66[331-332{S.v. δίδωμι 'give' < PIE *di-deh₃- 'to give'.}];141[105-106{S.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5).  Reconstructs present stem *dé-doh₃-/dh₃- whence Ved. dádāti, YAv. daδāiti. See n14 regarding Greek  δίδωμι "Mit sekundärer i-Redupl."}];54[174-175{S.v. Lat. dō, dare 'to give'. The uncompounded stems dō, dāre must go back to *deh₃- 'give', but note that verbal compounds in -dō could in principle reflect either *deh₃- or *dʰeh₁-.}];83[45-47{S.v. Proto-Iranian *daH-¹ 'to give' < PIE *deh₃-.}];567[226{Bactrian λαυ-, λα- / λαδο 'to give, grant, allot, assign, pay' < Proto-Iranian *daθa-/dāta- (cf. Parth. dh-/dʾd).}];79[595{S.v. Arm. *ta- / *tu- 'to give, bestow| to hand| to pay, etc.'. Arm. ta- and tu- respectively reflect PIE zero-grade *dh₃- and full-grade *deh₃-.}];172[I:713-715{S.v. Ved. √dā-¹ 'geben, schenken, spenden' < PIE *deh₃-.}];353[146-147{S.v. Lith. dúoti 'give' < PIE *deh₃- | *didh₃- 'give'.}];81[96{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dati 'give', from PIE *deh₃- / *didh₃- 'give'.}];50[86{S.v. Proto-Celtic *dā- 'give', from PIE *deh₃- 'give'. "Gaulish dede and Lepontic tetu might also be from PIE *dʰeh₁- rather than from *deh₃-, but this appears less probable."}];352[246-248{S.v. OLith. dúoti 'geben' (BSl. Latv. duôt, OPr. dāt, dātwei 'geben'), from PIE *deh₃- 'geben' (cf. Ved. dā- 'geben', YAv. dā- 'geben', Gk. δίδωμι 'geben', Arm. 1.sg.pres. tam, 3.sg.aor. et 'geben', Lat. dō, dāre 'geben', etc.).}];458[4: 194-195{S.v. *dati.}];442[489{For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 8655 Ved. prádadāti 'gives away' RV.}];369[154{Cf. s.v. Alb. dáshë, aor. to ap 'geben', to be connected with PIE *deh₃-, cf. for further discussion on the possibilities of stem-formation.}];687[42-43{Cf. s.v. Alb. (Arb.) jap 'to give', to which aor. dha stem continues PIE *deh₃-.}];105[157{Cf. s.v. Alb. jap (aor. dashë) 'to give'. The aorist dashë continues Proto-Albanian *e-das-a based on the zero-grade of PIE *dō- 'to give'.}];157[138-139{S.v. Gaul. dede 'a offert', the word dede has been compared to Lat. dedit 'a donné', although Szemerényi KZ 88 (1974) 281-282 and others prefer to see a reduplicated perfect from the root *dʰē- (*dʰeh₁-) 'poser, mettre, établir'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ([LIV²](src-141) 105-106, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):331-332, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):595, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):154-155, [Orel 1998](src-105):157, [Rohr 2000](src-687):42-43, [EWAia](src-172) I:713-715, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):489 no. 8655, [Cheung 2007](src-83):45-47, [ALEW](src-352) 246-248, [Derksen 2015](src-353):146-147, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:194-195, [Derksen 2008](src-81):96, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):174-175). The connection of Gaulish dede to this class is tentatively accepted (so [Matasović 2009](src-50):86), but cf. the discussion of [Delamarre 2003](src-157):138-139 regarding the possibility alternatively deriving the Gaulish form from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place'.

Source: 105[267{S.v. Alb. mirë 'good', from Proto-Albanian *mira-. Further IE connections are possible but debated.}];130[64{Either a loan from Lat. mīru(s) 'wonderful' or from IE *meiH- 'lieblich/mild' > *mi-ro- (IEW 711, so Demiraj 1997:268, Orel 1998:267).}];369[268]
Justification: Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):268, [Orel 1998](src-105):267, [Holm 2011](src-130):64) for various proposals).

Source: 105[16-17{S.v. bar 'grass', from Proto-Albanian *bara, etymologically related to Lat. far 'sort of grain, spelt' < *bhars-, ON barr 'spelt', etc.}];165[52-53{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bariz- ~ *barza- 'barley' < *bʰar-es-.}];54[201-202{Cf. s.v. Lat. far, -rris 'husked wheat, emmer| grain, flour' < *bʰars-, possibly an early European loanword into PIE.}];369[89-90{S.v. Alb. bar 'Gras, Grashalm, Kraut, Heilkraut'. An old neuter without certain connections outside of Albanian (cf. entry with various proposals).}];269[{Etymology here tentatively follows Orel (1998:16-17), de Vaan (2008:201-202), etc., but cf. the objections and further discussion of Demiraj (1997:91-92).}]
Justification: Etymology here tentatively follows [Orel 1998](src-105):16-17, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):201-202, but cf. the objections and further discussion of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):89-90).

Source: 130[64{Obvious loan from Turkish yeşil 'green'.}]
Justification: Loan from Turkish yeşil 'green' ([Holm 2011](src-130):64).

Source: 66[1620-1621{S.v. χείρ, χειρός 'hand, fist' < PIE *g̑ʰés-r-.}];274[170-173{S.v. *g̑ʰes- *'fassen?', 'Hand', 'Griff' (IEW 446f.).  Indo-Iranian cognates reflect *g̑ʰes-to-, other languages reflect an r-stem g̑ʰes-r- or thematised r-stem *g̑ʰes-r-o-.}];80[471-472{S.v. Hitt. keššar / kiššer- / kišr- 'hand'. Hittite kiššar- reflects forms reflect an original r-stem from PIE *g̑ʰes-r-.  The forms found in the Luwic subgroup, CLuw. īš(ša)ra/i-, HLuw. istra/i- and Lyc. izre/i- reflect a secondarily thematised form (as though from) *g̑es-r-o-, from Proto-Anatolian *g̑es-r- 'hand'.}];567[227{Bactrian λιστο 'hand' < Proto-Iranian *dasta- (cf. Sogd. δst-).}];345[711-712{S.v. TochB ṣar 'hand'. TochA tsar and TochB ṣar do not regularly go back to a single Proto-Tocharian preform, but they are normally understood to both go back to PIE *g̑ʰesr- 'hand' via different accent/ablaut stems. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to literature.}];105[70{S.v. dorë 'hand', a singularised neut. plural from Proto-Albanian *dārā from PIE *g̑ʰesr- 'hand'.}];79[431-432{S.v. *jeṙ-, from PIE *g̑ʰes-r- 'hand'. The Armenian singulative jeṙn derives from the PIE acc. *g̑ʰés-r-m̥.}];172[II:812{S.v. Ved. hásta- 'Hand, Oberarm'. Indo-Iranian uniquely attests a *-to-  suffix reflecting PIE *g̑ʰés-to- (cf. OAv., YAv. zasta- 'Hand', OPers. dasta- 'Hand', Khot. dasta-, Sogd., Khwarez. δst, Parth. dst, MPers, NPers. dast, Pashto lās, Shughni δust 'Hand', etc.).}];369[140{S.v. Alb. dórë, -a 'Hand, Handvoll, Griff'. The inherited word for 'hand' to be connected with Gk. χείρ, Hitt. keššar, TochA tsar, TochB ṣar, etc. Cf. entry in Demiraj for discussion regarding possibilities regarding the stem formation in Albanian.}]
Comment: Although Common Iranic would continue *g̑ʰ as /z/ (as with Avestan), Klingenschmitt (2000: 200, fn. 30) emphasises that /d/-forms are not a sign of loans from Persian, but the result of an early dissimilation of *d͜zasta- > *dasta-: "Die Bedeutung des Wortes und die weite Verbreitung der Lautform *dasta- schließen aus, daß es sich um eine Entlehnung aus dem Persischen (ap. dasta-, mp. dast) handelt. Die Lautform *dasta- muß vielmehr durch Dissimilation entstanden sein (vgl. Morgenstierne, EVP, S. 39)."
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *g̑ʰes- *'grasp'(?), 'hand', 'grip' ([NIL](src-274) 170-173). Indo-Iranic cognates reflect *g̑ʰes-to- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:812), other languages reflect an r-stem g̑ʰes-r- or thematised r-stem *g̑ʰes-r-o- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):471-472, [Adams 2013](src-345):711-712, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1620-1621, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):431-432, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):140, [Orel 1998](src-105):70).

Source: 105[62{S.v. Alb. dëgjoj 'to hear'. Dialectal forms ndëgoj, dëkgonj, diligonj reveal that this is a loanword from Lat. intelligere 'to perceive'.}];130[66{Loan from Lat., either from (1) degāvo 'have learned' or (2) intelligere (so Orel 1998:62).}]
Justification: A loanword from Latin intelligere 'to perceive' ([Orel 1998](src-105):62, cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):66).

Source: 105[520-521{S.v. Alb. zemër 'heart| middle'. No certain etymology.}];130[66-67{With Demiraj (1997:426) and Orel (1998:520) as a "difficult word without any reliable explanation", cf. further for an overview of rejected etymologies.}];369[426-427]
Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: No certain etymology ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):426-427, [Orel 1998](src-105):520-521, [Holm 2011](src-130):66-67).

Source: 105[370{S.v. Alb. rëndë ~ randë 'heavy'. Continues PAlb *raunta derived from the verbal stem of aor. rashë < *rauša 'to fall' (s.v. bie), a sigmatic aorist of IE *reu- 'tear'.}];571[108{S.v. Alb. i, e rëndë 'heavy'. Difficult. [Meyer 1891](src-585):365 suggested a loan from Latin grandis 'large', to which [Jokl 1911](src-661):74 objected on semantic grounds, instead considering Alb. rëndë a participle of a now lost verb cognate with Lith. rė́ju 'put together'. "The failure of this verb to be attested is a serious handicap, but Jokl's assumption of an underlying verb stem *reE- is the best solution yet advanced."}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. [Meyer 1891](src-585):365 proposed a loan from Latin grandis 'large', rejected by [Jokl 1911](src-661):74 considering Alb. rëndë a participle of a now lost verb cognate with Lith. rė́ju 'put together' (followed by [Huld 1984](src-571):108. [Orel 1998](src-105):370 supposes a connection with a stem *raunta- derived from rashë, the aorist stem of bie 'fall', although his proposed further IE connections for this verb are uncertain (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):343 "Eine sichere etymologische Deutung für dieses ohne Zweifel uralte suppletive Verb ist nicht in Sicht.").

Source: 141[698{Cf. s.v. *u̯reh₁g̑- 'brechen, reißen (intr.)' (IEW 1181-2), to which LIV follows the traditional etymology deriving Alb. rreh 'schlägt' as a secondary *-sk̑e- present.}];105[377{S.v. Alb. rrah 'to beat, strike'. Orel takes this to be from Proto-Alb. *wragska and connected with Greek ῥάσσω from PIE *u̯rāgh-.}];364[994{S.v. rreh 'schlagen'. Usually connected with *u̯reh₁g̑- 'brechen, reißen' (LIV² 698). While this is not implausible phonologically, this is not persuasive semantically. A possible alternative is to Old Albanian rā-, the suppletive aorist to bíe 'fall'. Despite these etymological uncertainties, the paradigm must continue a primary verb with a present stem suffix *-sk̑e/o-.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. Traditionally derived to PIE *u̯reh₁g̑- 'break, tear' ([Orel 1998](src-105):377, [LIV²](src-141) 698), but [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):994 consider this unconvincing semantically and suggest alternatively a possible connection to rā-, the suppletive aorist to Albanian bie 'hit; fall'. In either case the verb must be a *-sk̑e/o- derived present stem.

Source: 105[137-138{S.v. gjuaj ~ gjuej 'to hunt'. Orel prefers an etymology to Proto-Albanian *jāgnja based on a noun *jaga > gjah 'hunt, hunting' (cf. OHG jagōn 'hunt'). Other proposed etymologies include connections to (1) Gk. δίζημαι, (2) Slav. ženǫ, *gъnati 'drive away', Lith. genù, giñti 'id.', (3) to Lat. sāgiō 'to feel, suspect', OIr. saigim 'to go towards, to seek'. Cf. entry for references to further literature.}];269[{Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain. [Orel 1998](src-105):137-138 prefers a connection to Old High German jagōn (cf. [cognate set 243](cog-243)), which has no certain etymology outside of Germanic itself| [Demiraj 1997](src-369):191-192 who rejects the connection with the Germanic lexemes and suggests instead a connection with Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'. If so, perhaps to be connected within Albanian to 'hear' in [cognate set 8546](cog-8546). Undiscussed, however, in connection to Albanian gjegj in [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974-975.}];369[191-192{S.v. Alb. gjúaj / gjúej 'jagen, erjagen'. An inherited word for 'hunt' with a disputed etymology. The comparison with MHG, NHG 'jagen' is semantically close, but phonologically and structurally facile. Additionally, the etymology of the Germanic lexemes are themselves disputed. It is probably to come up with a different etymology. D. ultimately suggests a connection to Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain. [Orel 1998](src-105):137-138 prefers a connection to Old High German jagōn (cf. [cognate set 243](cog-243)), which has no certain etymology outside of Germanic itself; [Demiraj 1997](src-369):191-192 who rejects the connection with the Germanic lexemes and suggests instead a connection with Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'. If so, perhaps to be connected within Albanian to 'hear' in [cognate set 8546](cog-8546). Undiscussed, however, in connection to Albanian gjegj in [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974-975.

Source: 105[3-4{S.v. Alb. akull 'ice', a loanword from Germanic *jakulaz 'icicle, glacier', cf. ON jǫkull 'icicle', OE gicel 'id.', cf. also for a discussion of alternative etymologies.}];369[74-75{S.v. Alb. ákull, -i 'Eis, Frost, (dial. Arb. It.) Pfeil'. Cf. for a discussion of older etymologies, considers Orel's suggestion of a loan from Germanic very attractive, but difficult to maintain.}];571[37-38{S.v. Alb. akull 'ice' [cf. for a survey of older uncertain hypotheses].}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Possibly a loan from Germanic *jakulaz 'icicle, glacier' (so [Orel 1998](src-105):3-4), but cf. objections from [Demiraj 1997](src-369):74-75); cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):37-38 for various unconvincing alternative hypotheses.

Source: 141[510{Cf. s.v. *reu̯H- 'aufreißen' (IEW 868). [Without Albanian forms given.]}];105[515{S.v. Alb. vras (aor. vrava) 'to kill', from Proto-Albanian *awa-rautja, a prefix derivative based on IE *reu- 'to tear, destroy' (cf. Skt. rutá- 'broken', Lat. ruō 'to fall down, to rush down', etc.).}];130[68{Possibly to PIE *reu̯H- 'auffreißen / to tear, wound' (LIV² 510, without Alb. so Orel 1998:515, Matzinger 2005:99), also possible are to PIE *u̯er- 'aufreißen / to tear, to wound' with different variants, or loan, presumably by OCS u-rasiti 'durchbohren' or some other South Slavic source.}];663[99]
Justification: Etymology in this class follows [Orel 1998](src-105):515, [Matzinger 2005](src-663):99, but cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):68 for further discussion.

Source: 141[141-142{S.v. *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (IEW 243).}];364[969{S.v. di 'wissen, kennen, können, beherrschen'. Continues a present stem *dʰiH-i̯é/ó- or *dʰiH-e/o- of the root *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (LIV² 141f.)| other solutions are improbable. The aorist is based on the *-to- verbal adjective.}];369[132-133{S.v. Alb. 'wissen, kennen, können', an inherited word commonly agreed to be connected with Ved. dhītí- 'Wahrnehmung, Andacht' (√*dʰei̯H-).}];130[68-69{To be connected with LIV² 141, IEW 243 *dʰei̯H- 'see, regard'.}];105[64-65{S.v. Alb. di 'to know', connected with IE *dʰei̯(ə)- 'to see' (cf. Skt. dhyāti 'to observe, to feel, to think', Av. dā(y)- 'to see').}];585[66]
Justification: Generally derived from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, consider' ([LIV²](src-141) 141-142, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):132-133, [Orel 1998](src-105):64-65, [Holm 2011](src-130):68-69, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):969).

Source: 105[359{S.v. Alb. qesh 'to laugh', from Proto-Albanian *kaksja related to similar onomatopoeic verbs in Skt. kákhati, Gk. καχάζω, etc.}]
Justification: Pace [Orel 1998](src-105):359, because of the onomatopoeic nature of the lexemes in this meaning it is difficult to establish an etymology outside of Albanian with certainty.

Source: 105[242{S.v. majtë ~ mâjtë 'left', borrowed from Rom. *manctus, based on Lat. mancus 'maimed, infirm'| cf. It. manca 'left hand'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Romance *manctus ([Orel 1998](src-105):242). On the semantic development within Romance from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' > 'left', cf. discussion in [cognate set 2071](cog-2071).

Source: 364[979{Cf. s.v. Alb. jet 'bleiben, dableiben' pret. intrans., trans. 'warten, empfangen', from PIE *i̯et- 'sich (fest) hinstellen'.}];141[313-314{Cf. s.v. *i̯et- 'sich (fest) hinstellen' (IEW 506-7).}];105[158, 343-344{Cf. s.v. Alb. jes 'to remain', a denominative of *jetë 'life' (cf. Gk. ἐτεός 'true, real', etc.).}]
Justification: To be derived from PIE *i̯et- 'to place oneself (firmly)' ([Orel 1998](src-105):158, 343-344, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):979).

Source: 105[259{S.v. mëlçi 'lung, liver', used in phrases mëlçi e bardhë 'lung' and mëlçi e zezë 'liver', originally a word for 'spleen' borrowed from Italian milza.}];130[69-70{Loan, perhaps already from Goth. *milti (cf. Catalan melsa) 'milt, spleen', or via Italian milzi (so Orel 1998:259) from the same source with shifted meaning.}]
Justification: Probably a loanword from Italian milza 'spleen' ([Orel 1998](src-105):259), but possibly even earlier from Gothic *milti-, cf. Catalan melsa 'spleen' ([Holm 2011](src-130):69-70).

Source: 130[70{Rejects Orel (1998:274)'s etymology from PIE *mer- 'to die' > PAlb. mērwa, preferring a connection to PIE *merh₂- 'zerdrücken, to squeeze'.}];105[274{S.v. Alb. morr 'louse', from PAlb. mērwa based on PIE *mer- 'to die' as Gk. φθείρ 'louse' is based on φθείρω 'destroy', alternatively to Lat. mordeō (cf. Meyer 1891:287) or Skt. marcáyati (cf. Jokl 1911:58).}];585[287];661[58];369[277{S.v. Alb. morr 'Laus (als Hauptbezeichnung für alle Laussorten, wie Kopflaus, Filzlaus, Kleiderlaus, Blattlaus, u.a.)'. An isolated word in Albanian with a phonological form that cannot be connected to forms for louse in other Indo-European languages. Under the assumption of a semantic development *'scratching' > 'louse', one could consider Alb. morr a deverbative formation from the root *mer(H)- 'aufreiben'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Albanian unclear, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):274, [Jokl 1911](src-661):58, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):277, [Orel 1998](src-105):274, [Holm 2011](src-130):70} for various proposals.

Source: 81[315{S.v. Proto-Slavic *męso- 'flesh, meat' from PIE *mēms-om (cf. Skt. mām̆̇sá- 'flesh, meat', Goth. mimz 'κρέα').}];172[II:343-344{S.v. Ved. mām̆̇sá- 'Fleisch', from PIE *mēms- (cf. Arm. mis, Goth. mimz, OPruss. mensā, menso, OCS męso, TochB mīsa- all 'Fleisch').}];345[498{S.v. TochB mīsa 'meat, flesh', from PIE *memseh₂-, the plural to PIE *memsom (nt.) (cf. Skt. māṃsá- 'flesh, meat', Arm. mis 'id.', OPruss. mensā, Alb. mish 'id.', Goth. mimz 'id.').}];79[469-470{S.v. Arm. mis 'flesh, meat', connected with the PIE word for 'meat' *mēmso- (cf. Skt. māṃsá-, Goth. mimz, OCS męso, OPruss. menso, mensā, TochB mīsa, Alb. mish, etc.).}];105[267{S.v. Alb. mish 'flesh, meat', from Proto-Albanian *miša, further to PIE *memso- 'id.' (cf. Skt. mām̆̇sá-, Goth. mimz, Arm. mis, Slav. męso).}];353[312-313{S.v. Lith. mėsà 'flesh, meat', from PIE *mēms- (cf. Skt. mām̆̇sá- 'flesh, meat'| Skt. mā́s- n. 'flesh, meat', Goth. mimz n. 'meat').}];165[369{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mimza- 'meat', from PIE *mēms-ó- (cf. TochB mīsa, Skt. māṃsá- 'meat', YAv. mā̊ŋhəm 'meat, board', Arm. mis 'flesh, meat', Lat. mēnsa 'table', Alb. mish 'meat' OCS męso, Lith. mėsà, etc.).}];369[269-270{S.v. Alb. mish, -i/-të 'Fleisch', since long connected with several related words in IE languages, cf. Ved. māṁsá-, Arm. mis, OCS męso, Goth. mimz 'Fleisch', etc. The diachronic analysis of the Albanian cognate remains disputed. [cf. entry in Demiraj for further discussion.]}];274[486-488{S.v. *mē(m)s- 'Fleisch' (IEW 725, EIEC 374).}];352[638-639{S.v. OLith. mėsà, męsà 'Fleisch' (BSl. Latv. mìesa 'Fleisch, das ungeteilte, lebendige Fleisch des Körpers', OPr. mensā 'Fleisch', OCS męso, etc.), from PIE *mē(m)s-, *mēms-ó- 'Fleisch' (cf. CLuw. mi(ya)sa- 'Fleisch', Ved. mām̆̇s-, mām̆̇sá- 'Fleisch', Gk. μηρός, μῆρα 'der obere, fleischige Teil des Schenkels, Schenkelknochen, Schenkelbein', Arm. mis 'Fleisch', Lat. membrum 'Glied, Körperglied', Teil', Alb. mish 'Fleisch', OIr. mír 'Bissen, Stück, Portion', Goth. mimz 'Fleisch', TochB misa 'Fleisch').}];458[19: 7-11{PS *męso < PIE *mēms- / meməs.}];442[574{Cf. s.v. 9982 Ved. māṁsá- n. 'flesh'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Armenian, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ([NIL](src-274) 486-488, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):498, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):469-470, Demiraj 1997}:269-270, [Orel 1998](src-105):267, [EWAia](src-172) II:343-344, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):574 no. 9982, [ALEW](src-352) 638-639, [Derksen 2015](src-353):312-313, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:7-11, [Derksen 2008](src-81):315, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):369).

Source: 105[243{S.v. Alb. mal 'mountain', from PAlb. mala and connected with Lith. malà 'land', Latv. mala 'bank, shore'. Cf. also *mal- in Balkan toponomy (Illyr. Maluntum, Dac. Dacia Maluensis vs. Dacia Ripensis), borrowed into Rumanian as mal 'bank'.}];369[254-256{S.v. Alb. mal, -i 'Berg, Gebirge, (Berg)wald'. There are several attempts at explanation: (1) connections with Rum. mal, maluri 'Flußufer', Latv. mala 'Rand, Ufer, Gegend', Lith. lýgmala(s) 'Höhe des Randes'| (2) via PIE *ml̥dʰ-o- (cf. Ved. mūrdhā́- 'Spitze, Gipfel, Kopf', OE molda 'top of the head' (although one would expect a differing reflex for a long syllabic resonant in Albanian (e.g. **blad(h)-, **blan-, cf. s.v. plak). (3) other researchers consider a Thracian or non-IE origin, (cf. thr. malva(?), Basque Malh). The connection with Rumanian mal 'Flußufer', Latv. mala 'Rand, Ufer, Gegend' is semantically appealing. In the case of an IE origin one would suppose an original o-grade root (cf. Gk. aor. μολεῖν 'gehen, kommen', προμολή 'Vorsprung, Auslauf', Serb. izmòlīti 'hervorzeigen'. If one considers a connection with Rum.(-Dac.) mal, then one would consider a neuter i-stem *m(o)lH-i-.}];130[72{Two possibilities, both from IEW 721 *mel- 'Erhöhung / elevation', either (1) *ml̥h₃-dʰo-, or (2) PAlb. mall via IE *molH-(i-) (so Demiraj 1997:254, uncertainly, while noting the possibility of non-IE substratum), similarly Orel (1998:243) from PAlb. *mala, mentioning the Balkan toponyms without further comment.}];571[89{S.v. Alb. mal 'mountain'.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):89, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):254-256, [Orel 1998](src-105):243, [Holm 2011](src-130):72 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 105[1-2{S.v. Alb. afër 'near', from Proto-Albanian *apsera representing a contamination of *aps, a variant of IE *apo reflected by Gk. ἄψ 'backwards' and *apero, a derivative of *apo (Skt. ápara- 'posterior, later', Goth. afar 'after', etc.).}];294[66-86{Regarding the proposed comparison of [Orel 1998](src-105) to PIE *ap-, cf. s.v. *áp, *ápo 'weg, fort, ab| zurück, wieder| hinter, nach' (Adverb, lokal und temporal), without Albanian afër connected.}];571[36{S.v. Alb. afër 'near' (adv., prep.), cf. for discussion of various proposals, none of which can be considered definitive.}];369[70-71{S.v. Alb. afër (prep.) 'bei, an'| (adv.) nahe, bei, herbei| beinahe, etwa'. Etymology disputed, cf. for further discussion.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):36, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):70-71, [Orel 1998](src-105):1-2 for discussion of various proposals.

Source: 105[353{S.v. Alb. qafë 'neck', borrowed from Turkish kafa 'occiput, head'.}];130[72-73{Loan from Turkish kafa 'back of head' (with Orel 1998:353).}];571[106{S.v. Alb. qafë 'neck'. Earlier [Meyer 1891](src-585):219 rejected the view that qafë is a Turkish loanword and instead attempted to connect to Germanic *xalsa- 'neck', however there is no good reason to reject the Turkish loan hypothesis and Alb. q has been observed as the usual reflex of dorsals in Albanian.}]
Comment: Loan from Turkish
Justification: Loanword from Turkish kafa 'back of the head' ([Huld 1984](src-571):106, [Orel 1998](src-105):353, [Holm 2011](src-130):72-73).

Source: 105[371{S.v. Alb. ri 'new, young, recent', from Proto-Albanian *rija, a zero-grade derivative of IE *er- ~ *or- 'to rise, to make move'.}];141[299-301{Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).}];130[73{Presumably from *h₁ere(i)- 'something freshly coming into motion' (cf. IEW 330).}];369[251, 344{[Does not make an attempt at an etymology.]}]
Justification: Probably a derivative of PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ([Orel 1998](src-105):371, [Holm 2011](src-130):73; cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):251, 344 without attempting to assign a root etymology). For the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-301.

Source: 105[152{S.v. Alb. hundë 'nose', from Proto-Albanian *skuntā, from skuna > hu (after Meyer 1891:153-154).}];130[73{Rejects earlier scholars attempts to derive from PIE *neh₂s- 'nose'. Instead perhaps via Proto-Albanian *skun-tā, from PIE *(s)keu̯- (IEW 951), often with extensions meaning something like 'shelter, canopy' (cf. Gk. σκύνια 'brows').}];684[73-81{In addition to connections with Alb. hu 'penis' and hedh 'to throw', suggested by Meyer (1891:153-154), followed by Orel (1998:152) and others, Hyllested also proposes cognacy to PGmc. *skuna- 'snout' reflected in Faroese and SW Norwegian skon 'snout'.}];585[153-154{S.v. Alb. hu-ri (Gheg. hûni 'Pfahl| männliches Glied', which M. proposes a root connection to hundε, Cal. γundε, Scut. hun 'Nase, Spitze| Vorgebirge'.}]
Justification: Etymology difficult, [Meyer 1891](src-585):153-154, [Orel 1998](src-105):152, [Holm 2011](src-130):73, [Hyllested 2012](src-684):73-81 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 269[{Etymological authorities differ on whether Alb. një 'one' should be assigned to PIE *sem- (Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi, etc.) [cognate set 6066](cog-6066) or *Hoi̯-no- (Lat. ūnus, Goth. ains, etc.) [cognate set 91](cog-91) (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):101, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):207, [Orel 1998](src-105):304-305, [Holm 2011](src-130):74 for various assessments).  Consequently the Albanian numeral '1' has therefore been placed in its own cognate class reflecting this etymological uncertainty.}];105[304-305{S.v. një ~ nji 'one', Orel derives from Proto-Albanian *ainja < PIE *oi-no- (Lat. ūnus, etc.), rejecting Huld's theory (1984:101) that një is a back-formation from the feminine *smi̯eH.}];571[101{Suggests that Proto-Albanian *ni- is back-formed from PIE feminine *smyā (*sem-) with dissimilation of *m > *n preceding *y.}];130[74{Either from PIE *oi-nos with the Western IE words for 'one', but considers the inner-Albanian derivation phonologically doubtful, therefore considers the connection to PIE *sem- more likely. Ultimately a debatable case.}];369[207{Only mentions the lexeme in a marginal comment s.v. Alb. inj 'da! hier!' without its own entry.}]
Comment: Formally unclear whether the etymology goes back to *Hoi̯-no- or *sem-.
Justification: The etymological handbooks differ on whether Alb. një 'one' should be assigned to PIE *sem- (Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi, etc.) [cognate set 6066](cog-6066) or *Hoi̯-no- (Lat. ūnus, Goth. ains, etc.) [cognate set 91](cog-91) (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):101, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):207, [Orel 1998](src-105):304-305, [Holm 2011](src-130):74 for various assessments).  Consequently the Albanian numeral '1' has therefore been placed in its own cognate set reflecting this etymological uncertainty.

Source: 66[412{S.v. ἕλκω 'draw, drag' < PIE *selk- 'draw' (cf. TochB sälk- 'to draw out', pret. sälkāte, secondary nasal pres. slaṅktär) with nominal formations found in Arm hełg 'slow', Lat. sulcus 'furrow', OE sulh 'furrow, plow'. Less certain is the connection of Alb. helq, heq 'draw (off)' (if from IE *solk-ei̯e-)).}];141[530-531{S.v. *selk- 'ziehen' (IEW 901), a Tocharian, Greek (and Albanian?) isogloss.}];345[753{S.v. TochB sälk- 'pull/draw (out/away), tear (out) [normally toward the agent], pluck [of fruit]| [metaphorically] produce, show, present', from PIE *selk- 'pull, draw' (Gk. ἕλκω 'pull, draw', Alb. helq 'id.' (< *solk-ye/o-), Lat. sulcus 'furrow', Lat. sulcāre 'to plow', OEng. sulh 'furrow| plow').}]
Justification: Hellenic and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *selk- 'to pull' ([LIV²](src-141) 530-531, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):753, [Beekes 2010](src-66):412).

Source: 165[445{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash'. Extra-Germanic etymology unclear. Cf. entry for previous proposals that can no longer be maintained.}];556[417-418{S.v. Gmc. *skeut-a- 'schießen', probably doesn't belong to skeud- 'eilen, treiben', but rather to *sk̑eu- 'schießen, eilen' only otherwise securely attested in Baltic (Lith. šáuju, šáuti 'schießen, schnell laufen'). Less certain is the connection to OCS isunǫti 'herausziehen, zücken (Waffe)' sovati vъnъ 'überschäumen'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):445, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):417-418 for older proposals).

Source: 105[205{S.v. Alb. kuq 'red', borrowed from Romance *cocceus, cf. Lat. coccineus 'scarlet'.}];130[75{Loan from VLat. *coccu(m) < Lat. coccineu(s) 'scarlet'.}];571[84{S.v. Alb. kuq 'red', since [Meyer 1891](src-585):210 considered a loan from Lat. cocceus 'red'.}]
Comment: Loan from Romance.
Justification: Loan from Late Latin cocceus 'red, scarlet' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):210, [Huld 1984](src-571):84, [Orel 1998](src-105):205, [Holm 2011](src-130):75).

Source: 105[219, 234{S.v. Alb. lumë (pl. lumenj) 'river', from Proto-Albanian *luma, to be connected with Gk. λῦμα 'dirt', further connected to PIE *leu(ə)- 'dirt'. Cf. also lerë 'dirt, mud' from PIE *leu-.}];66[878{Cf. s.v. Gk. λῦμα, -ατος 'dirt, waste, garbage', corresponding to Alb. lum 'slime, mud' < *lum-, cf, also Alb. lerë 'dirt, mud' < *leu-d⁽ʰ⁾r-, based on PIE *luH- 'dirt, pollute' (cf. Lat. pol-luō < *por-luō, Lat. lutum = OIr. loth 'excrements, dirt').}];369[246-249{S.v. lúm/ë, -i 'Fluß, Strom'. The oldest forms go back to a primary form lym(ë), apart from that the etymology is difficult. Meyer's (EWA) derivation from Lat. flūmen is difficult phonologically (cf. flok 'hair' < Lat. floccus with initial fl- retained). Possibly with Huld from *(s)leub-no- to the root *(s)leub- 'be slick, wet', alternatively with Çabej a relatively recent new lexeme from lym 'Flußschlamm, Lehm'. If from the latter, then to be connected with Gk. λῦμα 'Schmutz, Schmach' (cf. IEW 681 *leu̯(ə)- 'beschmutzen').}]
Justification: Etymology disputed, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):246-247, [Orel 1998](src-105):219, 234 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 105[165, 355{Cf. s.v. kalb 'to let rot' from Proto-Albanian *kalba, (cf. qelb 'pus'). No further certain etymology. Cf. entry for references to further literature and various suggestions.}]
Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: Albanian forms derived from verbal kalb 'to let rot', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):165, 355 for various proposals).

Source: 105[197{S.v. Alb. kripë ~ krypë 'salt', from Proto-Albanian *krūpā connected with ON hrufa 'scab', Lith. kraupìs 'rough', kraupis 'scab', Latv. kraûpis 'frail, brittle', Slav. *krupa 'groats'. Alternatively a borrowing from Slavic *krupa (so Meyer Et.Wb. 206).}];585[206{S.v. kripε, geg. krüpε 'Salz', a borrowing from Slavic (cf. OSlov. krupa 'mica', Cz. kroupa 'Graupe, Hagel', Pol. krupa 'id.'). Similarly cf. Lith. druskà 'Salz', Latv. druska 'Krume' where the inherited word for 'salt' has been lost in Baltic.}];571[82-83{S.v. kripë 'salt', according to [Meyer 1891](src-585):206 a loan from OSlov. krūpa 'mica', a phonetically plausible solution but semantically weak. Alternatively krypë is a native word cognate to and not loaned from Slavic, but Albanian -y- is a secondary Gheg rounding of -i- after kr- and before a labial stop.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Considered a loanword from Slavic according to [Meyer 1891](src-585):206 and others, alternatively an inherited lexeme (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571)82-83}, [Orel 1998](src-105):197).

Source: 105[61{S.v. Alb. det 'sea', from Proto-Albanian *deubeta 'depth', based on PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' (cf. Gmc. *deupiϸο 'depth').}];661[14-15];274[122-124{S.v. *dʰeu̯b- 'tief' (IEW 267f., EIEC 154).}];571[50{S.v. Alb. det 'sea'. [Jokl 1911](src-661):14-15 reconstructed *dʰeu̯b-etos connecting to Germanic words for 'deep' and has been generally accepted| earlier proposed etymologies are very uncertain.}]
Justification: Since [Jokl 1911](src-661):14-15 generally derived from PIE *dʰeu̯b- and compared with Germanic 'deep' words, cf. Goth. diupiϸa, ON dýpt, although there is some uncertainty over the stem formation in Albanian (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):50, [Orel 1998](src-105):61-62, [NIL](src-274) 124n16).

Source: 105[357{S.v. Alb. qep 'to sew (together), to seize'. Several proposed etymologies: (1) From Pr. Alb. *klepa, related to Slav *klepati 'to beat, to knock', cf in particular Russ klepat' 'to join together by riveting' (Orel's preferred etymology)| (2) Related to Gk καπτω 'to swallow, gulp down' (Camarda)| (3) < IE *skep- 'to split' (Meyer)| (4) to Lat capiō 'to take' (Pedersen)| and (5) onomatopoeia (Trubačev).}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):357 for a summary of various proposals.

Source: 228[{Friulian uçât is derived from the verb uçâ < Lat. *acutiare derived from Lat. acutus, -a, -um (–G. Cadorini, p.c.)}];141[261{Cf. s.v. *h₂ek̑- 'scharf sein/werden/machen' (IEW 18-22).}];274[287-300{S.v. *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz (sein / werden / machen)' (LIV 261, IEW 18ff.).}];345[5{S.v. TochB akwatse 'sharp', which reflects a putative *hₐek̑utyo-, a derivative of the root *hₐek̑- 'sharp'.}];105[86{Cf. s.v. Alb. eh 'to sharpen', from Proto-Alb. *akska, derived from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp'.}];81[379{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ostrъ 'sharp', from PIE *h₂ek̑-ro- (cf. Gk. ἄκρος 'pointed', Lat. ācer 'sharp').}];353[64{S.v. Lith. aštrùs 'sharp' (Latv. ass 'sharp'), from PIE *h₂ek̑-ro- (cf. Gk. ἄκρος 'pointed', Lat. ācer 'sharp').}];54[22{S.v. Lat. ācer, -is, -e 'sharp', from PIE *h₂ek̑-ro- 'sharp' (cf. Gk. ἄκρος 'highest, outermost', OLith. ãštras, Lith. aštrùs, Latv. ass, OCS ostrъ, Ru. óstryj 'sharp').}];352[62{S.v. OLith. ãštras 'scharf, streng' (BSl. Latv. asrs 'scharf', OCS ostrъ 'scharf, rauh', etc.), from PIE *h₂ek̑ro- (cf. Ved. -aśra- '-eckig', Gk. ἄκρος 'äußerst, oberst, höchst', OIr. ér 'hoch(gestellt), edel').}];458[36: 63-66{PS *ostrŭ is derived from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp' > *ak̑-ro-, cf. Lithuanian ašrùs, Old Indic aśtrā, Latin ācer etc.}];444[11{S.v. 134 Lat. *acūtiāre 'wetzen' and 135 Lat. acūtus 'spitzig, scharf'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ([NIL](src-274) 287-300, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):5, [Orel 1998](src-105):86, [ALEW](src-352) 62, [Derksen 2015](src-353):64, [ESSJa](src-458) 36:63-66, [Derksen 2008](src-81):379, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):22, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):11 no. 134, 135).

Source: 105[386{S.v. Alb. rri 'to sit, stand, stay, remain' (suppletive aorist ndej). The form of the present stem goes back to Proto-Albanian *rina, etymologically close to Skt. r̥ṇóti 'to arise, to move', Gk. ὄρνυμαι 'move up, and related forms'. Meyer (1891:374) derives to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean, bend' but O. deems the phonological changes impossible.}];585[374{S.v. r̄i 'sitze, halte mich auf, wohne, ruhe aus'. Compares Ved. śrayati 'lehnt sich an', Lith. szlëjù [sic!] 'lehne an' Gk. κλίνω, Lat. clinare, OHG hlinēn.}];130[81{Proposes deriving from an essive form *h₁/h₃r-h₁ié- (cf. LIV² 25) of PIE *h₁/h₃r- 'set in motion, arrive somewhere' (cf. LIV² 238, 299).}];571[109{Cf. s.v. rri, ndenja, ndejtur 'sit, remain' for a discussion of various proposals.}];364[994-995{S.v. Alb. rri 'sitzen| sich setzen, sich niederlassen| bleiben, verweilen'. It is usually considered to be unexplained, but there is no good reason not to connect it with PIE ?*(h₁)rei̯d- '(sich) anlehnen' (LIV² 503).}]
Justification: Root etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):109, [Orel 1998](src-105):386, [Holm 2011](src-130):81, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):994-995 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 105[211-212, 222{S.v. Alb. lëkurë 'skin, hide'. O. derives from lakur 'naked', in turn from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine, be white'. Cf. s.v. lakur 'naked' for alternative etymological proposals.}];130[79{Many possibilities. Reject's Orel (1998:222)'s connection with lakur 'naked', where the further derivation from *leu̯k- 'shine' is too semantically remote from 'hide'. Proposes an etymology of prefix lë- + kur = loan from Lat. corium 'thick skin, leather'.}];369[240-241{S.v. Alb. lëkúr/ë. -a 'Haut| Leder| Fell| Schale| Rinde| Hülse'. "Nicht sicher erklärt." Cf. entry for a survey of proposals.}];571[86{S.v. Alb. lëkurë 'skin'. "Regarding lëkurë as native, Meyer (1891b:236) related it to Gk λέπω 'strip, peel'. Jokl (1911:39) instead derived lëkurë from Lat lacer 'naked' as a loan. His etymology was accepted by Tagliavini (1937:166)."}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. For various proposals and further discussion, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):86, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):240-241, [Orel 1998](src-105):211-212, 222, [Holm 2011](src-130):79).

Source: 105[99{S.v. Alb. fle ~ flê 'to sleep'. O. derives PAlb. *awa-leja and connects with Slav. *lějǫ, *lějati 'to doze, slumber'.}];130[80{Rejects connections to IE *k̑lei̯- (so Matzinger in review of Orel 1998, in Die Sprache 40 (2) 1998, p.234| continued in Schumacher & Matzinger 2013:973-974), as well as to IE *legʰ- (so Orel 1998:99 comparing Slavic *lějati, with problematic derivation?)| instead suggests connection to *lei̯h₂-i̯é- (LIV² 406, without Albanian) with a prefix f-.}];364[974-975{S.v. Alb. fle 'schlafen', connects to IE *k̑lei̯-e/o- 'sich anlehnen' (LIV² 332f.).}];269[{Several attempts at a root-etymology, but no consensus (cf. Orel 1998:99, Holm 2011:80, Schumacher & Matzinger 2013:973-974). Etymology ultimately uncertain.}]
Justification: No consensus on an IE root etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):99, [Holm 2011](src-130):80, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):973-974 for various proposals.

Source: 130[80{Rejects the etymology of Orel (1998:513), who attempts to derive from PAlb. *wagla, comparing Lat. vagor 'to roam around', on the basis of relying on the outdated etymology of IEW (cf. now de Vaan 2008:651 s.v. vagus 'roaming, wandering', LIV² 682 s.v. ?*u̯eng- '(sich) krümmen') and also for being semantically implausible. H. alternatively suggests a loanword from Turkish ufaklik 'tinyness' (< Arab. faqīr 'poor').}];105[513{S.v. Alb. vogël 'small'. O. derives from PAlb. *wāgla, *wāgra 'undersized, dwarfed, small', connecting to Lat. vagor 'to roam around' with the semantic development *u̯əg- 'to be crooked' > 'small' (IEW 1120).}];571[131-132{S.v. Alb. vogël 'small'. Inconclusive. No clear etymology.}]
Comment: Etymology disputed.
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):131-132, [Orel 1998](src-105):513, [Holm 2011](src-130):80 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 105[470-471{S.v. Alb. tym 'smoke', rejecting the possibility of a loanword from Greek θυμός 'soul, spirit' on the basis that it "is unknown in any meaning close to 'smoke'". Rather reconstructs PAlb. *ātuma, connected with Gmc. *ēðumaz and Skt. ātmán- 'blow, breath, soul'.}];130[81{Against Orel's rejection of a loan from Greek θυμός, H. points out several derivatives with related semnatics: θυμήριον 'Räucher-pfanne / smoke-pan', θῦμάλ-ωψ 'Kohlenmeiler / charcoal kiln', as verbal nouns from *dʰu̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen / make smoke'. Huld (1984:117) favours a recent loan since old /y/ would have changed to /i/ in Tosk| recent sources could have been Old Bulgarian dymъ or Turk. duman.}];571[117{S.v. Alb. tym, -i. Meyer (1891:93) noted verbal tymós, which he derived as a loan from OCS timijasati 'burn incense', in turn borrowed from Greek θυμιάμα 'incense'. The consistent -y- even in Tosk dialects where native -y- becomes -i- points to a recent loan.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Loan from Greek θυμός?, Bulgarian dymъ?, Turkish duman? (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):117, [Orel 1998](src-105):470-471, [Holm 2011](src-130):81 for various proposals and further discussion).

Source: 369[106-107{S.v. Alb. bór/ë, -a 'Schnee'}];105[32{S.v. Alb. borë 'snow'. The element -bārā is to be linked to bie 'fall' (with similar semantics to Rom. zapadă 'snow' borrowed from Slav. *zapada 'falling down (snow)').}];667[93-94];571[45-46{S.v. Alb. borë 'snow'. Meyer (1891:42) related 'snow' to Rum. boură 'drizzle, mist', NGk. μπόρα 'drizzle', OCS burja 'storm' and derived all from Lat. boreus 'northwind'. Jokl (1916:93) noted the use of bie 'fall' for precipitation and proposed a productive lengthened grade form *ds-bhērā, comparing the semantics of Rum. zapadă 'snow' (borrowed from Slav. zapasti 'fall down') for the semantics.}];269[{Within Albanian borë 'snow' is generally linked to bie 'fall' following [Jokl 1916](src-667):93, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):45-46, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):106-107, [Orel 1998](src-105):32. For etymology of Alb. bie < PIE *bʰerH-, cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):966 and further references in [cognate set 388](cog-388).}]
Justification: Within Albanian borë 'snow' is generally linked to bie 'fall' following [Jokl 1916](src-667):93, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):45-46, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):106-107, [Orel 1998](src-105):32. For etymology of Alb. bie < PIE *bʰerH-, cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):966 and further references in [cognate set 388](cog-388).

Source: 105[386{S.v. Alb. rri 'to sit, stand, stay, remain' (suppletive aorist ndej). Meyer (1891:374) derives to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean, bend' but O. deems the phonological changes impossible.}];585[374{S.v. r̄i 'sitze, halte mich auf, wohne, ruhe aus'. Compares Ved. śrayati 'lehnt sich an', Lith. szlëjù [sic!] 'lehne an' Gk. κλίνω, Lat. clinare, OHG hlinēn.}];130[81{Proposes deriving from an essive form *h₁/h₃r-h₁ié- (cf. LIV² 25) of PIE *h₁/h₃r- 'set in motion, arrive somewhere' (cf. LIV² 238, 299).}];571[109{Cf. s.v. rri, ndenja, ndejtur 'sit, remain' for a discussion of various proposals.}];364[994-995{S.v. It is usually considered to be unexplained, but there is no good reason not to connect it with PIE ?*(h₁)rei̯d- '(sich) anlehnen' (LIV² 503).}]

Source: 130[81-82{Rejects deriving from *sk̑eh₂i- (cf. IEW 917), likewise Orel (1998:518), without citation to IEW, who derives from *skī̆w-ila- related to hije based on the Geg form hyll. H. suggests semantically better from PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, glow' following Huld (1984:132) via *h₁us-li- (similarly Demiraj 1997:206).}];105[518{S.v. Alb. yll 'star'. O. derives from PAlb. *skī̆w-ila, which he takes to be a derivative from *skijā > hije 'shadow'.}];369[206{S.v. Alb. hyll 'Stern'. A common comparison is made with OIr. súil 'Auge', OCS slъnьce 'Sonne' (cf. Meyer 1891:460)| an alternative assessment following Huld (1984:132) could be from *h₁us-lo- (cf. ON usli 'glühende Asche') > PAlb. *ūl- > yll.}];571[132];585[460]
Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: Etymology disputed; the best etymology would tentatively appear to be some sort of derivative to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, glow' (so [Huld 1984](src-571):132, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):206, but cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):460, [Orel 1998](src-105):518 for alternative proposals).

Source: 571[114{S.v. Alb. shkop, -i 'stick, shepherd's crook, sceptre', an early loan from either Lat. scāpus or Gk. σκᾶπος ~ σκήπων.}];105[421{S.v. Alb. skop 'stick, cane', O. considers the word inherited from PAlb. *skāpa further related to Gk. σκᾶπος· κλάδος, σκῆπτρον 'staff', Lat. scāpus 'shaft, stem', OHG skaft 'shaft, spear'.}];585[408{S.v. Alb. škop 'Stock, Szepter, Massstab', cf. Lat. scāpus 'shaft', Gk. σκᾶπος with Alb. o corresponding to PIE *ā.}];66[1350{Cf. s.v. Gk. σκήπτομαι 'to support oneself, lean, pretend something, use as pretention| to throw down, sling'| also several related words for stick σκᾶπος· κλάδος (H.), σκηπτός 'stick, scepter', etc. All these forms point back to a root *σκᾶπ-. The noun σκᾶπος can be equated with Lat. scāpus 'shaft, stalk' and Alb. shkop 'stick' < *skeh₂p-o-, with zero-grade forms in Germanic words for 'shaft, spear, lance' (OHG skaft, ON skapt, etc. < *skh₂pt-. "Although formally these words could certainly be of IE origin, the distribution of forms and the semantics rather point to a European substrate origin."}];54[546{Cf. s.v. Lat. scōpae 'branches of a plant, broom', with derivative scāpus 'stem, stalk, shaft' (cf. Gk. σκᾶπος 'stick' [Hesych.], σκήπτομαι 'to support oneself' < *skāp-| Latv. šķèps 'spear, javelin', CS štapъ 'stick' < *skēp-?| OHG skaft, OWNo. skapt 'shaft'). "Latin scāpus might be a borrowing from Gr. σκᾶπος, but scōp- must be older and both could go back to ablaut within a PIE root *sk(e/o)h₂p-. Yet a verbal root of this form is not attested [in Latin], and the words might also be (independent?) borrowings."}];269[{IE inherited status uncertain. Certainly there is enough comparative material between Italic, Germanic, Greek, and Albanian to posit a (European) IE word *skeh₂p-, but due to the geographical proximity of the branches the possibility of (independent?) early loanwords cannot be entirely excluded (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):408, [Huld 1984](src-571):114, [Orel 1998](src-105):421, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):546, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1350 for further discussion).}]
Justification: IE inherited status uncertain. Certainly there is enough comparative material between Italic, Germanic, Greek, and Albanian to posit a (European) IE word *skeh₂p-, but due to the geographical proximity of the branches the possibility of (independent?) early loanwords cannot be entirely excluded (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):408, [Huld 1984](src-571):114, [Orel 1998](src-105):421, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):546, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1350 for further discussion).

Source: 130[82{Alb. gūr|i From PIE *gʷer- 'Berg / mountain' > *gʷr̥H(i)- > PAlb. gur(i).}];571[66-67{S.v. Alb. gur 'stone, rock', connected with OCS gora, Ved. girí-, Av. gairi- 'mountain', Lith. gìrė 'woods'.}];105[127{S.v. Alb. gur 'stone, rock' from PAlb. gura continuing a zero-grade of IE *gʷer- 'mountain' (cf. Skt. girí-, Av. gairi-, Lith. girià 'wood', Latv. dziria 'id.', Slav. *gora 'mountain, wood'.}];369[181{S.v. Alb. gur, -i 'Stein, Fels, Felsgestein', an inherited word generally agreed to be connected with Ved. girí- 'Berg', Lith. gìrė 'Wald' < *gʷr̥H-í-.}];172[I:487{S.v. Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe' (Iranian forms via YAv. gairi-, Khot. gara-, ggari-, Sogd. γar, Pashto γar), probably PIE *gʷr̥H-i- (cf. Alb. gur 'stone' OCS gora, 'mountain', Lith. girià 'forest').}];331[3:191-193{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *gari- ' гора, холм| валун, скала', cf. Ved. girí-| from PIE *gʷr̥-i-, *gʷer-i-.}];321[187{S.v. Wa. ɣ̌ar 1. 'камень', from PIr. *γar(i)-, cf. Av. gairi-, Ved. girí-, Khot. ggara-, Sogd. γr-, Yaghn. γar, etc.}];442[233{S.v. 4161 Ved. girí- m. 'rock, mountain' RV.}]
Justification: Albanian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ([Huld 1984](src-571):66-67, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):181, [Orel 1998](src-105):127, [Holm 2011](src-130):82, [EWAia](src-172) I:487, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):223 no. 4161, [ESIJa](src-331) 3:191-193 [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):187). Note Sinhalese gala appears to be a contamination of the inherited lexeme with Tamil kal 'stone'.

Source: 571[55{S.v. Alb. drejtë 'straight, right, correct', ultimately a loan from Lat. directum.}];105[73{S.v. Alb. drejtë 'straight, right', a borrowing from Lat. directum.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin directum 'straight, not curved' ([Huld 1984](src-571):55, [Orel 1998](src-105):73).

Source: 130[82{Rejects connection with PIE *su̯el-u̯o- (cf. Gk. ἕλη, so Huld 1984:50, 148), claiming a development *su̯V́- > *dV́- (but against this cf. Demiraj 1997:48 who argues **su̯V́- > *vV́-). Considers Orel (1998:65)'s proposal from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-u̯o- 'yellow' possible, but suggests alternatively from PIE *dei̯h₂- 'glänzen / to shine' (LIV² 108) + suffix *-lo- as in Gk.  διη-λός 'clear'.}];571[50-51{S.v. Alb. diell, -i 'sun', favours a hypothesis first put forward by Pedersen deriving from the IE word for sun *su̯el- with *su- > d- before a stressed vowel.}];105[65{S.v. Alb. diell 'sun'. O. derives from PAlb. *delwa, a tabooistic substitute for the original word for sun based on a colour adjective, comparing Skt. harí- 'pale, yellowish', Av. zairi- 'id.', Lat. helvus 'yellowish', Lith. žel̃vas 'id.'| acknowledging alternative etymologies (cf. entry for references) but making no effort to refute them.}];269[{Many attempts at an etymology outside of Albanian in the standard literature with no consensus| extra-Albanian connections ultimately uncertain.}];585[69{S.v. Alb. djeł or dieł 'Sonne', suggests either from PAlb. *deglo- from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' or from *delno- from PIE *dʰal- 'sprout, grow'.}];369[48{Cf. against the assumption of *su̯V́- > dV́- by Huld (1984:50, 148).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):69, [Huld 1984](src-571):50-51, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):82, [Orel 1998](src-105):65, [Holm 2011](src-130):82 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 130[83{Rejects connections to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen / to grow' (so Orel 1998:27) as semantically idiosyncratic and phonetically problematic. Instead Holm prefers the conjecture of Demiraj (1997:103) to PIE *bʰei̯H- via derived *bʰi(H)-st-o- 'schlagen / to beat' > *bi-śt-, seeming to express a semantically characteristic property.}];105[27{S.v. Alb. bisht 'tail'. O. proposes an etymology from PAlb. *būšta, derived from PIE *bʰū- 'to grow' (semantically viewing the tail as a bodily outgrowth), without attempting to refute other proposed etymologies.}];369[103{S.v. Alb. bisht, -i 'Schweif, Schwanz'. Without a satisfying etymology. Proposed connections to Basque bustan, or PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' are unlikely| otherwise unclear. Perhaps to Alb. bij '(auf)keimen, sprossen' from PAlb. (?)*b(h)ī̆-st-o-?}];571[45{S.v. bisht, -i 'tail (of fish, animals, birds, reptiles)'. Etymology obscure.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):45, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):103, [Orel 1998](src-105):27, [Holm 2011](src-130):83 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 105[462{S.v. Alb. trashë 'thick, fat'. Orel prefers to derive from a putative Proto-Albanian *trauša, which he connects to Lith. trąšùs 'fat, fertile (of the soil)' and (despite phonetic difficulties which he admits), also connects to Slav. *truxa- '(hay) dust', which he ultimately derives from PIE *treu- (cf. Gk. τρύω 'to destroy, exhaust', Slav. *trovǫ 'to destroy', etc.). Alternatively borrowed from Lat. crassus ~ Rom. grassus 'solid, thick, fat' (so Meyer 1891:435).}];585[435]
Comment: etymology unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):462 for various proposals.

Source: 141[403{S.v. *lei̯g̑- 'bind' (IEW 668).}];54[341{S.v. Lat. ligō, -āre 'to fasten, bind', from PIE *lig̑- 'to tie'? (cf. Alb. lidh 'to tie') "Apart from Alb. lidh, which can be explained in various ways, there are no certain cognates."}];369[242-243{S.v. Alb. lidh 'binden, verbinden, vereinigen'. An inherited word which is semantically and formally closest to Lat. ligō 'binden, zusammenziehen'.}];105[226-227{S.v. Alb. lidh 'to bind, tie', from PAlb. līdza and etymologically close to Lat. ligāre 'id.'.}];571[86-87{S.v. Alb. lidh 'bind, tie', related to Lat. līgāre 'bind' (so Meyer 1891:245), from PIE *lei̯g̑- 'binden' (IEW 668).}];585[245];444[407-408{S.v. 5024 Lat. ligāre 'binden'.}]
Justification: Albanian and Italic derivatives from PIE *lei̯g̑- 'to bind'. In this set only Albanian lidh may be a primary verbal derivative, while the Italic and Romance forms probably denominal in origin ([LIV²](src-141) 403, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):86-87, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):242-243, [Orel 1998](src-105):226-227, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):341, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):407-408).

Source: 130[85{Considers the derivation from *gal-so- 'schreien, to shout' (IEW 350) semantically unconvincing| similarly from a proposed zero-grade Orel (1998:138) *gl̥-so- > PAlb. *glūsa because of gl- in dialectal forms. Holm prefers alternatively from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯ā 'tongue' via metathesis to *g̑ʰnud- + -sk̑e- with *gn- > gl- > gj- (as in gju 'knee'), cf. Huld (1984:71).}];105[138{S.v. Alb. gjuhë 'tongue, language'. On the basis of dialectal gluhë (Cham), gl'uγε (Calabr), O. adduces PAlb *glusā and connects with IE *golso- 'sound' (ON kall 'shout', Lith. gal̃sas 'echo', Slav. *golsъ 'voice'. Because of PAlb. *-ul-, O. suggests that this must go back to a zero-grade *gl̥so- as opposed to the full grade forms of Balto-Slavic and Germanic.}];369[342{Only mentions gjúhë in passing to doubt proposed etymological connections to qúaj 'to name'.}];571[71];269[{Connections outside of Albanian unclear. The two main hypotheses connect the word either (1) to Germanic and Balto-Slavic words for 'sound' < *g(o)l-so- (so [Orel 1998](src-105):138, cf. [IEW](src-49) 350), or (2) with the IE inherited word for 'tongue' *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- (so [Huld 1984](src-571):71, [Holm 2011](src-130):85).}]
Justification: Connections outside of Albanian unclear. The two main hypotheses connect the word either (1) to Germanic and Balto-Slavic words for 'sound' < *g(o)l-so- (so [Orel 1998](src-105):138, cf. [IEW](src-49) 350), or (2) with the IE inherited word for 'tongue' *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- (so [Huld 1984](src-571):71, [Holm 2011](src-130):85).

Source: 81[549{S.v. Proto-Slavic *zǫ̑bъ 'tooth', from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- (cf. Lith. žam̃bas 'sharp edge', Latv. zùobs 'tooth', Skt. jámbha- 'tooth', Gk. γόμφος 'pin, nail', OIc. kambr 'comb, jagged edge').}];345[208{S.v. TochB keme 'tooth| dentition', which with TochA kam reflects PToch *keme from PIE *g̑ómbʰos 'tooth' (cf. Skt. jámbha- 'tooth', jambhya- 'molar tooth', Gk. γόμφος 'tooth| bolt, dowel', γομφίος 'molar tooth', Alb. dhëmb 'tooth', dhëmballë 'molar tooth', OCS zǫbъ 'tooth', Latv. zùobs 'tooth', Lith. žam̃bas 'edge, brim', OHG kamm 'comb', etc.).}];353[512{Cf. s.v. Lith. žam̃bas '(sharp) edge, flap' (Latv. zùobs 'tooth'), from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- (cf. Lith. žam̃bas 'sharp edge', Latv. zùobs 'tooth', Skt. jámbha- 'tooth', Gk. γόμφος 'pin, nail', OIc. kambr 'comb, jagged edge').}];369[158{S.v. Alb. dhëmb 'Zahn', the inherited word for 'tooth' which is identical with Ved. jámbha-, OCS zǫbъ, Gk. γόμφος, etc., from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o-s.}];105[82{S.v. Alb. dhëmb ~ dhamb 'tooth' from PAlb. dzamba and cognate with TochA kam 'tooth', TochB keme 'id.', Latv. zùobs 'id.', Slav. *zǫbъ 'id.', cf. also Gk. γόμφος 'peg', Skt. jámbha- 'bit, peg'.}];352[1289{Cf. s.v. OLith. žam̃bas 'Ecke, Rand, Saum' (BSl. Latv. zùobs 'Zahn, Sägezahn, Schlüsselbart', OCS zǫbъ 'Zahn', etc.), from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- 'Beißen' (cf. Ved. jámbha- 'Gezähn', du. 'beide Zahnreihen', pl. 'Zähne', Gk. γόμφος 'Verbindungsstück: Pflock, Dübel, Zapfen', γομφίος 'Backenzahn', Alb. dhëmb 'Zahn', ON kambr 'Kamm', OHG camb 'id., TochA kam 'Zahn', TochB keme 'id.').}];259[733{PS *zǫbŭ is derived from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o-.}];149[126-127{S.v. B keme*, A kam 'tooth', thematic nouns from CT *kæmæ < *kæmbʰæ from IE *g̑ombʰo-s 'tooth', cf. Gk. γόμφος 'id.', Skt. jámbha- 'id.'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Albanian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- 'peg; tooth' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):126-127, [Adams 2013](src-345):208, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):158, [Orel 1998](src-105):82, [ALEW](src-352) 1289, [Derksen 2008](src-81):549, [Derksen 2015](src-353):512).

Source: 66[315-316{S.v. δένδρεον 'tree'. Ancient Greek δένδρον is generally connected with PIE *deru-/*doru- 'wood' (cf. also Chantraine, DELG pp.262-263). Δένδρεον < *δενδρεϝον agrees with the Germanic word for 'tree' (Goth. triu, OE trēow 'tree', etc.), but the form of reduplication to the stem is rare in Greek. Cf. also Gk. δόρυ 'wood, tree (trunk), spear' from *dóru-.}];80[849-850{S.v. Hitt. tāru- 'wood', from PIE *dóru- (cf. Gk. δόρυ 'wood', Skt. dā́ru- 'wood', OE trēo(w) 'tree', OCS drěvo 'tree').}];270[262-263{S.v. AGk. δένδρεον 'arbre', the noun based on *drew-, *dru- etc. (cf. Gk. δρῦς, δόρυ, etc.). The stem *drewo- is attested in Goth. triu- OEng. treow 'arbre', etc. Expressive reduplication rests on *δερ-δρεϝ-ον, developed to δένδρον by dissimilation of the first ρ > ν. The same treatment is found in *θορ-θορυζω > τονθορύζω, *γαρ-γραινα > γάγγραινα.}];172[I:721{Cf. s.v. Ved. dā́ru- 'Holz' (IIr. cf. YAv. dāuru-, OPers. dāruv 'Holz', NPers. dār 'Holz, Baum' šughni δōrg 'Holz, Scheit', etc.), from PIE *dóru-, *dréu̯-s, *dru- (cf. Gk. δόρυ 'Holz, Baumstamm, δρῦς 'Baum', Hitt. ta-a-ru 'Holz, Baum', OE trēo(w) = engl. tree, OCS drěvo 'Baum', etc.).}];369[146-148{Cf. s.v. Alb. dru, -ri / drû, -ni 'Baum, Baumstamm, Holz| Brennholz, Bauholz' for discussion of the possible stem formations underlying the forms in Albanian.}];105[76{S.v. Alb. dru ~ drû 'tree| wood', from PAlb. *druwa to be compared with Slav. *drъvo 'wood', Skt. dru- 'id.', Av. 'dru- 'id.', Gk. δρῦς 'tree, oak'.}];331[II:357-365{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *daru-, *dāru- : dārau-, *dram(?), *drau- : *dru-, *druu̯a- : *dru̯a- 'дерево' (etc.), from PIE *deru-, *dō̆ru-, *dreu- : *dru-, *dru(u̯)-, *dreu-, *drou-| *dreu̯ə- : drū- 'дерево'.}];81[99{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *dervo 'tree, wood' (ESSJa IV 211-213), from PIE *deru-o- (cf. Lith. dervà 'chip of kindling wood', Skt. dā́ru- 'wood', Gk. δόρυ 'tree-trunk, wood, spear', Goth. triu 'wood, tree', OIc. tyrvi 'coniferous wood', OE teoru 'tar')| and Proto-Slavic *drъvo 'tree, (pl.) wood' (ESSJa V 141-142), from PIE *dru(H)-o- (cf. Gk. δρῦς 'tree, oak').}];165[522-523{S.v. Proto-Germanic *trewa- 'tree', from PIE *dréu-o- (cf. Hitt. tāru- 'wood', ToAB or 'id.', Skt. dā́ru- (gen. dróṣ, drúṇaḥ 'id.'), YAv. dāuru- (gen. draoš) 'wood| tree-trunk', OPers. dāruv 'wood', NP dār 'wood| tree', Gk. δόρυ 'wood, tree(stem), spear', OIr. daur, dair 'oak', W dar 'id.' < PIE *dor-u-| OCS drъva 'wood', Alb. dru / drū 'wood| tree| stem, trunk' < *dru-). The Indo-European word for 'wood' and 'tree'.}];49[214-217{Cf. s.v. *deru-, *dō̆ru-, *dr(e)u-, *drou-| *dreu̯ə : drū- 'Baum'.}];269[{The forms in this class all go back to an original stem in IE, probably u-stem noun with different Ablaut variants *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dréu̯- ~ *dru-, etc. (cf. IEW 214-217), with individual branches levelling out different variants. IEW reconstructs a paradigm *dṓru n., Gen. *dreu-s, *dru-nó-s, with further derivatives *deru̯o-, *dreu̯o-, *dru-mó-s, *dru-nó-s, *druu̯-ó-s, *drū-tó-s.}];458[4: 211-213{PS *dervo is derived from PIE *deru-, cf. Old Indic dāru-, dru-, Avestan dauru-, dru-, Greek δόρυ, Hittite taru- etc.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- 'wood, tree' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):849-850, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):262-263, [Beekes 2010](src-66):315-316, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):146-148, [Orel 1998](src-105):76, [EWAia](src-172) I:721, [ESIJa](src-331) 2:357-365, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:211-213, [Derksen 2008](src-81):99, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):522-523, cf. [IEW](src-49) 214-217).

Source: 105[200, 482{S.v. kthej 'turn', O. considers a prefixal derivative of thyej 'to break', would continue PAlb. *tsā(i)nja from PIE *k̑ēi- 'to sharpen' (cf. Skt. śiśāti 'to sharpen', Arm. sur 'sharp| knife', etc.).}];585[185{S.v. Alb. kεθéń, kθeń 'wende um, zurück, ändere, übersetze, schenke ein', a loan from Lat. convertere : co(n)vertebam.}];661[94{Follows Meyer (1891:185).}];269[{Etymology disputed. Possibly to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- ([IEW](src-49) 541-2) if one follows [Orel 1998](src-105):200, 482 to Alb. thyej 'break' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 319-320, without Albanian lexemes listed)| older etymologies (e.g. [Meyer 1891](src-585):185, [Jokl 1911](src-661):94) suggest a borrowing from Lat. convertere. The verb is not discussed in [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364).}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. Possibly to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- ([IEW](src-49) 541-2) if one follows [Orel 1998](src-105):200, 482 to Alb. thyej 'break' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 319-320, without Albanian lexemes listed); older etymologies (e.g. [Meyer 1891](src-585):185, [Jokl 1911](src-661):94) suggest a borrowing from Lat. convertere. The verb is not discussed in [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364).

Source: 369[229-230{S.v. Alb. lag 'naß machen, anfeuchten| mit Wasser bespritzen| eintauschen| bewässern' (adj. lagur 'naß, durchnäßt| feucht, klamm'). Not certainly explained. Demiraj prefers (though still doubting) a connection with OCS vlaga 'wetness, moisture' (no loan because a late loss of #v- is unexpected) and Lith. vìlgau, vìlgyti 'make wet', vìlgti 'become wet' pointing to a root PIE *u̯el(H)g- (= LIV: 676 ?2. *u̯elg-, where OHG welc 'wet' is connected).}];105[210, 221{Cf. s.v. Alb. lag 'to wet, to soak, to bathe, to wash', from PAlb. *lauga and to be further compared with lëgatë 'marsh'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):229-230, [Orel 1998](src-105):210, 221 for various suggestions and further discussion.

Source: 105[17{S.v. Alb. bardhë 'white', from Proto-Albanian *bardza, continuing *bʰorəg̑o-, a derivative of PIE *bʰerəg̑- 'to shine| white', cf. Skt. bhrājate 'shines, beams, glitters', Goth. bairhts 'light, shining'.}];141[92{Cf. s.v. *bʰreh₁g̑- 'erstrahlen, erglänzen' (IEW 139-40).}];369[90-91{S.v. Alb. bardhë 'weiß, glänzend'. Meyer (1891:27)'s comparison with Goth. bairhts 'hell', Lith. béržas 'Birke' is generally accepted. The reconstruction of the form ancestral to the Albanian is not agreed, although Meyer's reconstruction of an o-grade form is phonetically unobjectionable, thus probably Alb. bardhë can be accounted for from a putative PIE *bʰorHg̑-o-.}];585[27{S.v. Alb. barθ 'weiss', to be connected with Ved. bhrājate 'er glänzt, schimmert', Av. barāzaiti 'er schimmert', Goth. bairhts.}];571[40{S.v. Alb. bardhë 'white', following the etymology of Meyer (1891:29) to Lith. bèržas, etc., from *bʰr̥Hg̑- (IEW 139 *bherəg̑-).}];130[88-89{From PIE *bʰerh₁g̑-o- 'bright' > *bʰorh₁g̑-o- > barða-. The exact ablaut grade reflected by the Albanian form is disputed, cf. Huld (1984:40) for a zero-grade, Demiraj (1997:90), Orel (1998:17) arguing for an o-grade.}]
Justification: Albanian lexemes generally connected with PIE *bʰerh₁g̑- 'shine, gleam' ([LIV²](src-141) 92), but the precise stem derivation is uncertain (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):27, [Huld 1984](src-571):40, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):90-91, [Orel 1998](src-105):17, [Holm 2011](src-130):88-89).

Source: 105[133{S.v. Alb. gjerë ~ gjanë 'broad, wide', from PAlb. *saina, a zero-grade derivative in *-no- based on PIE *sēi- 'long, late' (cf. OE síd 'long, wide', Goth. seiϸus 'late', OIr. síth 'long', Lat. serus 'late', etc.), so Jokl (1911:28).}];661[28];165[437{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *sīϸu- 'late' < PIE *sh₁-éi-tu- (cf. Lat. sērus 'belated, slow', OIr. sír 'lasting, eternal' W hir 'long' < *seh₁-ro-).}];571[68-69{S.v. Alb. i, e gjërë 'wide, distant, far'. "[Meyer 1891](src-585):140 failed to etymologise this word. [Jokl 1911](src-661):27 saw a possible relation to Lat sērus 'late' and W hir  'tall' from *sē̆i- […] but the Welsh and Latin forms clearly point to a long vowel and the Gheg forms require an intervocalic *n not *r."}]
Justification: The most promising etymology derives from a zero-grade form of PIE *seh₁- comparable to full-grade forms found in Celtic, Italic, and Germanic, cf. Old Irish sír 'long', Latin sērus 'belated, slow', Proto-Germanic *sīϸu- (so [Jokl 1911](src-661):28, [Orel 1998](src-105):133, but cf. the reservations of [Huld 1984](src-571):68-69).

Source: 571[62{S.v. Alb. erë 'wind, scent, smell', of Latin or Romance origin.}];105[89{S.v. Alb. erë 'wind', from Rom. *er(a), based on Lat. aer 'air'.}];585[96{S.v. Alb. erε 'Luft, Wind, Geruch', from Rom. *aira = It. aria, Span., Prov. aire, Fr. air.}]
Justification: Loan from Romance *era < Latin āēr ([Meyer 1891](src-585):96, [Huld 1984](src-571):62, [Orel 1998](src-105):89).

Source: 105[100{S.v. Alb. fletë 'wing, leaf', from Alb. awa-lekta, a prefixal derivative of IE *lek- 'to fly' (cf. Lith. lekiù, lė̃kti, OHG lecken 'to jump, to kick').}];585[108{S.v. Alb. fl'etε 'Blatt am Baum, Papierblatt| Flügel, Fensterladen', loanword from Italian foglietta.}];141[411{Regarding the root *lek- postulated by [Orel 1998](src-105):100, cf. s.v. ?*lek- 'die Gliedmaßen bewegen' (?) (IEW 673).}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. [Orel 1998](src-105):100 connects to PIE *lek- (of uncertain reconstruction in [LIV²](src-141) 411 s.v. ?*lek- 'die Gliedmaßen bewegen'(?)). [Meyer 1891](src-585):108 assumed a loan from Italian foglietta 'leaf'; cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):100 for a summary of various other proposals.

Source: 105[125{S.v. Alb. grua ~ grue 'woman', from Proto-Albanian *grāwā, to be connected with Gk. γραῦς 'old woman', derivatives of PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to become old'. Alternatively Meyer (1891:132) derives from *gʷnōn- to PIE *gʷen- 'woman, wife', but *-n- would be preserved in Gheg.}];369[180-181{S.v. Alb. grúa, -ja 'Frau, Weib, Ehefrau'. Morphologically isolated and etymologically disputed| Against the older, formally easier comparison with Gk. γραῦς 'alte Frau' stands the (only) semantically more convincing connection to OCS žena 'Frau', Ved. gnā́ 'unirdische Frau' (cf. Meyer 1891). Against this, one must assume an interior dissimilation. Despite the unclear history of the word, the connection with Gk. γραῦς 'old woman' is to be preferred.}];571[66{S.v. grua, -ja 'woman', lists both the etymologies from *gʷn̥-ōn- after Meyer (1891:132) and the proposed connection with Gk. γραῦς (cf. Hamp 1960:276) without deciding which of the two is to be preferred.}];585[132];668[276];130[89-90{Either to PIE *gʷe(h₁)n-ah₂ 'woman' or PIE *g̑reh₂- 'ripe, ready (of grain), grown up (of people)'. "[T]he case remains debatable."}]
Justification: Etymology in this class follows [Hamp 1960](src-668):276, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):180-181, [Orel 1998](src-105):125 to PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to become old'; but cf. also discussion of [Huld 1984](src-571):66, [Holm 2011](src-130):89-90.

Source: 105[353{S.v. Alb. pyll 'forest', a loan from Balkan Romance *padūlem (cf. Rum. pădure 'id.') < Lat. palūdem 'swamp' (so Meyer 1891:360).}];585[360{Loan from Romance.}]
Justification: Loan from Balkan Romance *padulem (< Latin paludem 'swamp'), cf. Romanian pădure 'forest' ({ref Meyer 1891:360, [Orel 1998](src-105):353).

Source: 66[476-477{S.v. ἔτος 'year' from PIE *u̯et-os, gen.sg. *u̯et-es-os (s-stem neuter derivative).}];172[II:495{S.v. Ved. vatsá- 'Kalb, Junges' (m.) and vatsará- 'Jahr'.  Ved. saṃ-vatsará- is a secondary derived form from vatsá-, which is in itself a thematised form of the original s-stem *u̯et-es- >> (transponat) *u̯et-s-o-.}];80[1014-1015{S.v. Hitt. u̯itt- 'year', a root noun from PIE *u̯et-.}];369[419-420{S.v. Alb. vit, -i 'Jahr, Jahrgang'. The Albanian forms go back to a neuter form *u̯et-, which is formally identical with Gk. ϝέτος, ἔτος 'year'. [Cf. entry in Demiraj for further discussion on the stem formation within Albanian.]}];105[509{S.v. Alb. vit, vjet 'year', from PAlb. *weta to be connected with Hitt. u̯itt- 'year', Gk. ἔτος 'year', etc.}];571[129-130{S.v. Alb. vit, -i 'year', to be connected with Gk. ϝέτος 'year', Lat. vetus 'old', etc. derived from PIE *u̯et- 'year'.}]
Comment: Nuristani lexemes from *u̯et-so-
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *u̯et- 'year' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):1014-1015, [Beekes 2010](src-66):476-477, [Huld 1984](src-571):129-130, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):419-420, [Orel 1998](src-105):509, [EWAia](src-172) II:495).

Source: 585[466{S.v. Alb. verθ, verδi 'gelb', a borrowing from Lat. viridis, virdis (cf. It., Sp. verde, Fr. vert, etc.).}];105[499{S.v. Alb. verdhë 'yellow', borrowed from Lat. viridis 'green'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin viridis 'green' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):466, [Orel 1998](src-105):499).

Source: 66[1119{S.v. ὀστέον 'bone' < PIE *h₃esth₂-i- 'bone' (cf. Av. ast-, Lat. os < oss < *ost, gen. ossis, Skt. ásth-i, Hitt. ḫaštāi). Ancient Greek ὀστέον is clearly connected to the inherited word for 'bone'| Beekes reconstructs *h₃esth₁-i-, but supposes a thematised full-grade of the suffix *-i-, yielding *-ei̯-o-, which in turn would have given ὀστέον as it is attested.}];80[325-326{S.v. Hitt. ḫaštāi- / ḫasti- (n.) 'bone(s)| (metaphorically) strength| a measure of length (GÌR.PAD.DU)', from PIE *h₃ést-ōi, *h₃esth₁-i-. cf. CLuw. ḫāš- 'bone'.}];345[48-50{S.v. TochB āyo 'bone'| most likely from PIE *h₂ést-, pl. *h₂ést(e)h₂ with the e-grade generalised, perhaps extended by PIE *-yo/eh₂- suffix found in body-part terms. (Cf. entry in Adams for further discussion of the Tocharian stem formation.).}];79[533{S.v. Arm. oskr 'bone', to be derived from the PIE word for 'bone' found in Skt. ásthi, asthnás 'bone', Gk. ὀστέον 'bone', Lat. os, ossis 'bone, leg', Hitt. ḫaštāi-, ḫašti- 'bone', CLuw. ḫāš- 'bone'.}];172[I:150-151{S.v. Ved. ásthi- 'Knochen, Bein' (cf. OAv., YAv. ast-uuaṇt- 'mit einem knochenhaften Leib versehen', OAv. astəṇ-tāt- 'Körperhaftigkeit', MPers., NPers. ast), probably from PIE *h₂ost-h₂/n- (cf. Hitt. hastai- 'Knochen, Gebein', Gk. ὀστέον 'Knochen', Lat. os, oss-is 'Bein, Knochen', etc.).}];54[436-437{S.v. Lat. os, ossis 'bone', from PIE *h₃o/est- 'bone' (cf. MW ascurn, OCo. ascorn 'bone' < *ast-k-, OCo. asen, MIr. asna 'rib' < *astVn-| Hitt. haštāi-/hašti- 'bone(s), strength', CLuw. hāš- 'bone' < *h₃esth₁-ōi, -i-| Skt. ásthi- 'bone', YAv. ast- 'bone, body with bones', Gk. ὀστέον 'bone', Arm. oskr, OAlb. ashtë 'bone').}];50[44-45{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *astn(iy)o- 'rib', from PIE *h₂osth₁- 'bone' (cf. Hitt. hastāi-, Luv. hās-, Skt. ásthi- Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, ossis, Alb. asht, Arm. oskr).}];105[11{S.v. Alb. asht 'bone', from PAlb. ašti or ašta and further connected with PIE *ost(i)- 'bone' (cf. Hitt. ḫaštai-, Skt. ásthi, Gk. ὀστέον, etc.).}];369[82-83{S.v. Alb. ásht, older áshtë (Buzuku, Budi) 'Knochen', from the IE inherited word for bone (cf. Ved. ásthi, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, ossis, etc.), from PIE *h₃ost-.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ost-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'bone' ([EIEC](src-657) 77, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):325-326, [Adams 2013](src-345):48-50, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1119, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):533, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):82-83, [Orel 1998](src-105):11, [EWAia](src-172) I:150-151, [ESIJa](src-331) 1:232-234, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):436-437, [Matasović 2009](src-50):44-45). Perhaps cognate with the lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kost- with [cognate set 1114](cog-1114) but the explanation of the initial k- is unclear (cf. further discussion in that cognate set). The PIE stem is usually reconstructed with initial *h₂- on the basis of Greek ἀστραγαλός 'knucklebone' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):129), but the etymological connection of this word to the lexemes in this class is rejected by [Beekes 2010](src-66):157-158 who prefers to see Greek ἀστραγαλός as a substratum loanword.

Source: 165[554{S.v. Proto-Germanic *þurzu- 'dry' from a PIE u-stem *tr̥s-u- (cf. Ved. tr̥ṣu- 'avaricious', YAv. taršu- 'dry, not fluid'.}];179[358{S.v. Gothic þaursus (Þ25), an old u-stem *tr̥s-u- from PIE *ters- 'dry' (cf. Skt. tr̥ṣú- 'greedy, desirous', Av. taršu- 'dry', Lat. torrus, OIr. tur 'dry, dried out', tīrim 'dry' etc.).}];50[379-380{S.v. *tīros 'land, earth', from PIE *ter-s- 'dry' (cf.
