Hitt. tars- 'become dry', Lat. terra 'land'). The derived adjective in OIr. tírimm, tirimm 'dry' is from Proto-Celtic *tīrs-es-mi- (for the formation cf. PCl. *tefesmi- 'warm').}];697[632-633{S.v. Gmc. *ϸurzu- 'dürr', an old verbal adjective to the strong verb only attested through the past passive participle *ϸursa-, an inherited u-stem identical with Skt. tr̥ṣú- 'gierig', Av. taršu- 'trocken, fest', OLat. torrus 'verdorrt'| cf. OIr. tur, taur 'trocken, vertrocknet'.}];296[T:74-75{S.v. OIr. tírim 'sec', the root is *ter-s- 'sécher' and tírim is from tír 'terre, sol'}];141[367-368{Cf. s.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen| durstig werden' (IEW 1078-9).}];274[701-704{S.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen, durstig werden' (LIV 637f., IEW 1078f.).}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out, become thirsty' ([NIL](src-274) 701-704, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):358, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):632-633, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):554, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:74-75, [Matasović 2009](src-50):379-380, [LIV²](src-141) 637-638).

Source: 423[III:666-667{S.v. Sp. liso, a word common to the Romance languages of Iberia, France, the Alps, Italy, and Sardinia. They presuppose a Romance stem *līsĭus of uncertain origin, probably expressive.}];443[5:381-384{S.v. Lat. lĭxare 'glätten' > OFr. lisé, MFr. lissé, NFr. lisser.}];444[411-412{S.v. 5081 Lat. *līsius 'glatt'.}]
Comment: Uncertain if all of these belong together. Iberian lexemes are of uncertain origin, von Wartburg FEW suggests Lat. lixare for Fr. lexemes. Initial g- for Franco-Provençal seems unexpected for the suggested etymologies for other branches (isolated blend?). We may also be dealing with contamination/blending/expressive distortions. Class needs careful reviewing language by language (-MJCS 31.10.2017).

Source: 141[572-73{S.v. *(s)neh₂- 'baden, schwimmen' (IEW 971-2).}];66[1012-1013{S.v. νέω 'to swim', from PIE *sneh₂- 'swim'.}];54[411{S.v. nō, nāre 'to swim' < PIE *(s)neh₂-(ie/o-) 'to swim'.}];345[354-355{S.v. TochB nāsk- 'swim, bathe, take a bath', from PIE *(s)n(e)hₐ-sk̑e/o- 'swim, bathe, wash' (cf. Skt. snā́ti 'bathes', Av. snayeitē 'washes, purifies', Gk. νήχω 'swim', Lat. nāre 'swim', MIr. snáid 'swims').}];50[348{S.v. Proto-Celtic *snā- 'swim', from PIE *sneh₂- (cf. Skt. snā́ti 'bathes', Lat. nō, nāre, TochB nask- 'bathe').}];172[II:769-770{Cf. s.v. Ved. √snā- 'baden, sich waschen', from PIE *(s)neh₂- (cf. Lat. nāre, 'schwimmen', OIr. snām 'das Schwimmen', TochB nāsk- 'sich Baden', Hitt. sanh- 'ausspülen', etc.).}];83[348-349{S.v. Proto-Iranian *snaH- 'to wash, swim', from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to wash, swim' (cf. Skt. snā- 'to bathe, to wash', Lat. nāre 'to swim', OIr. snaid, -sná 'swims', TochB nāsk- 'to bathe').}];156[II:152{S.v. Oss. (Digor) nakæ 'плавание'| nakæ kænun 'плавать', from Ir. *snāka- to *snā- 'плавать'.}];442[39{For Khowar, cf. s.v. 876 *avasnāyati 'bathes'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 572-573; cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):354-355, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1012-1013, [EWAia](src-172) II:769-770, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):39, [Cheung 2007](src-83):348-349, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):411, [Matasović 2009](src-50):348).

Source: 141[691-692{Cf. s.v. *u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8), with OCS vraštǫ, vratiti etc. listed as a cognate.}];259[694-695, 710{PS *vortiti, cf. Lithuanian ver̃sti, verčiù, Gothic wairþan and Latin vertō, vertere. PIE *u̯ert- < *u̯er-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn (around)' ([Boryś 2005](src-259):694-695, 710; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 691-692).

Source: 105[193-194{S.v. Alb. krah 'arm, shoulder, side', a loan from Slav *krajь 'end, side, extremity'. Etymologies proposed by other scholars are also mentioned: (i) comparison with Lith kárka 'shin, shank' and Slav korkъ 'id' but this is morphophonologically difficult, (ii) comparison with Skt kisku- 'forearm', (iii) < IE *kar-skā and compared with Skt kará- 'hand, elephant's trunk', (iv) to Arm. srunk' 'calf (anat.)', Lat crūs 'shank'.}];369[224{S.v. Alb. krah '(Ober)arm, Schulter, Flügel'. Inherited word, probably originally a neuter. Unclear. Perhaps from Alb. *kri-, which allows the assumption of a possible etymological connection with Arm. srownkʻ "Scheinbein, Wade", Lat. crūs, -ris, from Proto-Albanian *krū : *k̑ruh₂(s), krah(-) < *krav- : Pl. *k̑rh₂-eu̯-es.}];571[81-82{S.v. Alb. krah 'arm, shoulder', compared by [Meyer 1891](src-585):203-204 to Lith. kárka 'upper arm', SCr. krák 'leg, femur', althernatively Tagliavini and Wiedemann derived *krok-sk̑ā, compare Ved. kara 'hand'. Both of these formations could give krah but morphological parallels are lacking. "The Baltic form seems to reflect an o-grade with a lost interconsonantal laryngeal| the Albanian on the other hand seems to be a zero-grade syllabic liquid plus laryngeal while the Serbo-Croatian form seems to be a lengthened grade, probably without a laryngeal. If, as seems reasonable, these central European forms are all related, there must be some borrowing in at least one form, but the direction is obscure."}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):81-82, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):224, [Orel 1998](src-105):193-194 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 105[296{S.v. Alb. ngrij ~ ngrîj 'to freeze'. Orel derives from PAlb. *en-kreinja, a denominative verb related to Lith. krenà 'film, thin skin (on milk)', Latv. kriena 'id.'. Alternatively Meyer (1891:306-307) to Gk. κρύος 'frost', or Jokl (1911:63-64) to Slav. čьrstvъ 'hard, dry'.}];585[306-307];661[63-64]
Justification: Connections outside of Albanian disputed (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):306-307, [Jokl 1911](src-661):63-64, [Orel 1998](src-105):296 for various proposals).

Source: 105[119{S.v. Alb. godas 'to strike, to beat', borrowed from Slavic *goditi used in a meaning unattested in South Slavic.}];585[126{S.v. Alb. godís, godiń 'treffe, schlage', a borrowing from Slavic goditi.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic *goditi ([Meyer 1891](src-585):126, [Orel 1998](src-105):119).

Source: 141[342-43{S.v. *⁽k̑⁾an- 'singen, klingen' (IEW 525-6).}];54[87-88{S.v. Lat. canō, -ere 'to sing', from PIE *kh₂n-e- 'to sing' (cf. OIr. cainid, ·cain, pf. cechain, W canu, Bret. cana 'sing', Gk. ἠι-κανός 'singing early' = 'cock', Goth. hana, OHG hano 'cock', OIc. hœna, OHG huon 'hen' < PGmc. *xan-, *xōn-).}];50[187-188{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-o- 'sing', derived from PIE *kan- (cf. Lat. canō 'sing', Goth. hana 'cock').}];304[387-390{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-e/o- 'singen' (PIE *kan- or *k̑an-, cf. LIV² 342f.).}]
Justification: Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'to sing, sound' ([LIV²](src-141) 342-343, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):87-88, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):387-390, [Matasović 2009](src-50):187-188).

Source: 276[{Perhaps identical with մուխ mowx 'smoke' ([Olsen 1999](src-180): 33)| if so then related to [cognate set 647](cog-647) [cf. cognate set 8305].For comparison, Classical Armenian աճիւն ačiwn (Bible 2x) seems to specifically refer only to the remains of a fire (cf. աճիւնախառն ačiwn-a-xaṙn 'mixed with ashes', աճիւնացուցանէմ ačiwn-a-c'owc'anem 'I reduce to ashes')| whereas մոխիր moxir (Bible 43x) has a wider, more general scope, including 'dust', etc. (cf. մոխրագոյն moxr-a-goyn 'gray, i.e. ash-colored', մոխրամած moxr-a-mac 'prostate in the dust', մոխրաթաւալ moxr-a-tᶜawal 'rolling in ashes, dirt', etc.).}]
Justification: Origin uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:341). Perhaps related to Classical Armenian mowx 'smoke' of uncertain etymology (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):33 and further discussion in cognate set 8305). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *moxir-o-].

Source: 180[932{Possibly from Syriac qəlāfā 'folium libri', qəlāfəθā 'cortex, squama, putamen mali granata'. Jahukyan (1987:482| 2010:398) suggests the form reflects PIE *(s)kel-. This is however phonetically problematic.}];540[398]
Justification: A probable loanword from Syriac qəlāfāʼ 'folium libri', qəlāfəθā 'cortex, squama, putamen mali granata' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):932), but cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):398 who less plausibly argue for an Indo-European origin. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełeu̯-o-].

Source: 172[II:661{Cf. s.v.  Ved. śyāva- 'dunkelbraun, schwarzbraun, dunkel' (IIr. YAv. siiāuuaº 'dunkel', Khot. śāva- 'Kupfer, kupferfarben', Parth. sy'w, MP siyā, NP siyaāh, Oss. sau 'schwarz', etc.) from PIE *k̑i̯eh₁-u̯ó- (cf. Lith. šývas 'weiß, schimmelfarbig', ORuss. sivъ, Sloven. sìv 'grau') and s.v. Ved. śyāmá- 'schwarz, dunkelfarbig' (IIr. YAv. sāma- 'schwarz') < PIE *k̑i̯eh₁-mó-.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑i̯eh₁- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:661).

Source: 274[499-504{S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV² 448, IEW 315f.).}];172[I:94{Cf. s.v. Ved. *abhrá- 'Gewitterwolke, Gewölk, Regenwolke' < PIE *n̥bʰ-ró- (*nebʰ-), cf. YAv. aβra- 'Regen[wolke]'.}];66[1012{S.v. νέφος 'cloud, mass of clouds' < s-stem PIE *nebʰ-os, *nebʰ-es-. The alternative form νεφέλη (s.v.) (= Lat. nebula) is formed to the same root but with an l-suffix.}];79[49-51{S.v. amp (spelled also as amb) 'cloud'. The Armenian form reflects a pre-form *n̥bʰos, which may either consist of "a compromise between *m̥bʰro- and the original s-stem" (so Olsen 1999:45) or, as Martirosyan proposes, a generalisation of a zero-grade genitive from the PD paradigm of the s-stem *nbʰ-és-s.}];180[45{Cf. for discussion regarding the formation of the Armenian stem.}];353[118{S.v. Lith. debesìs 'cloud' (Latv. debess, var. debesis), from PIE *nebʰ-es-. The initial *n of the etymon was apparently replaced with d- in East Baltic.}];352[186-187{S.v. OLith. debesìs, debeỹs 'Wolke' (BSl. cf. Latv. debess, OCS nebo, etc.), from PIE *nebʰ-es- 'Himmel, Luftraum, Wolke' (cf. Hitt. nepis-, 'Himmel', HLuw. tipas- 'id.', Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke| Himmel', OAv. nabah- 'Luftraum, Himmel', Gk. νέφος 'Wolke, Bewölkung').}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504). Cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 186-187, [Derksen 2015](src-353):118, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1012, [EWAia](src-172) I:94, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):49-51).

Source: 79[196{S.v. Arm. gam, suppletive aor. ek- 'to come', usually interpreted as an athematic verb *u̯eh₂(-dʰ)-mi (cf. Hitt. uu̯ami 'to come', Lat. vādere 'to go, walk, rush', Welsh go-di-wawd 'overtook' < *u̯eh₂dʰ-, OIc. vaða, OHG watan 'to advance, wade' < *u̯h₂dʰ-. The connection of the Hittite verb is uncertain ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):992)). The comparison with Greek κιχάνω 'to reach, arrive, meet' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):441, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):86 is untenable since this root has an initial palatovelar *g̑ʰ- (cf. Av. za-zā-mi 'to leave' Skt. já-hā-ti 'to leave, abandon', etc. (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:813-814).}];141[196, 664{S.v. *gʰeh₁- 'kommen, erreichen' (IEW 418-9, 1109)| cf. s.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten' (IEW 1109), without Armenian lexemes connected.}];558[86{Armenian ga- has been considered since Meillet, Esquisse, S.134 to a root *u̯ā- that may be seen in an extended form *u̯ā-dʰ- in Latin uādō, uādere 'gehen, schreiten', uadum 'seichte Stelle im Wasser', Furt' and Germanic *u̯ada- 'waten' (cf. OHG waten, ON waϸa 'waten', etc.). This possibility cannot be a priori excluded, cf., e.g. *leh₂-dʰ- in Gk. λανθανε/ο- 'verborgen sein' < *lh₂-n-dʰ-, ληθε/ο- < *lah₂dʰe/o- vs. *leh₂- in Lat. lateō 'verborgen sein'. There are semantic difficulties, however, since Latin uadum and the Germanic cognates have the connections to wading or moving through water. Better is a connection to the root *gʰeh₁- 'erreichen, kommen zu' (cf. Gk. κικη- 'erreichen').}]
Justification: Possibly an unextended form of the root *u̯eh₂dʰ- found in Latin vādo, -ere 'to go, walk, rush' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):196; cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):86). The alternative proposed etymology to *⁽g̑⁾ʰeh₁- 'to come, arrive' depends on whether the Indo-Iranic lexemes (Av. za-zā-mi 'to leave' Skt. já-hā-ti 'to leave, abandon') are to be connected with the Germanic and Armenian ones (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:813-814, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):196 for further discussion). The root etymology here follows [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), but cf. [LIV²](src-141) 196 s.v. *gʰeh₁- and 644 s.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten'.
Denominal to Classical Armenian pʿor 'hole, cavity; belly'. Further origin unknown ([Olsen 1999](src-180):942, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-].

Source: 740[III:122-123{S.v. Arm. ՀՈՒՄԵԼ}];540[467{S.v. Arm. ՀՈՒՄԵԼ}];269[{Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian xmem 'to drink, to imbibe'. Further origins uncertain, probably a more recent loanword on the basis of dialectal variation but the exact source is difficult to establish ([HAB](src-740) III:122-123, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):467) Not in [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).}]
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian xmem 'to drink, to imbibe'. Further origins uncertain, probably a more recent loanword on the basis of dialectal variation but the exact source is difficult to establish ([HAB](src-740) III:122-123, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):467) Not in [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xi/um-].

Source: 180[442-443{Cf. for a critical discussion of previous etymological proposals.}];740[IV:516-517]
Justification: Etymology uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:516-517, for further discussion cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):442-443). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰoʃ-i-/-o-].

Source: 66[606-607{S.v. ἰχθῦς 'fish' < PIE *dg̑ʰuH- 'fish'.}];270[474{S.v. ἰχθῦς. The initial i-prothesis in Ancient Greek ἰχθῦς is secondary, as also in ἰκτῖνος 'kite, Miluus regalis'. Cf. Lejeune 1972, Phonétique historique du mycénien et du grec ancien p.182, Schwyzer 1939, Griechische Grammatik I, p.413}];352[1331-1332{S.v. žuvìs 'Fisch' (BSl. Latv. zivs 'Fisch', OPr. suckis 'Fisch'), from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ-úH- 'Fisch' (cf. Gk. ἰχθῦς, -ύος 'Fisch', Arm' jowkn, gen.sg. jkan 'Fisch').}];79[439-440{S.v. Arm. jukn 'fish', to be connected with Greek and Baltic words for 'fish' (Lith. žuvìs, Lat. zuvs, Gk. ἰχθῦς) < PIE *dg̑ʰuH-.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, and Baltic lexemes from PIE *dʰg̑ʰuH- 'fish' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):474, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1331-1332, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):439-440, [ALEW](src-352) 1331-1332).

Source: 79[567-568{Cf. s.v. Arm. saṙn 'ice', cf. ON hjarn n. < *her(z)na- 'frozen snow', OHG hornung 'February', Russ. serën , serená 'crust over snow| frozen hard snow', Lith. šer̃kšnas m. < *k̂(e)r-sno- 'hoarfrost', adj. 'grey, whitish', šarmà < *k̂or-meh₂- 'frost', etc.}];352[1019{Cf. s.v. OLith. šer̃kšnas 'Reif' (BSl. Latv. sę̄̀rsna 'Reiffrost, Nachtfrost im Frühling| Harsch über dem Schnee'. Sloven. srẹ̑n 'Raureif| Harsch', ORuss. serenъ 'Harsch, Eisregen, Raureif', Ru. séren, serën 'Schneekruste| Raureif| Frost nach Tauwetter', Pol. śrzon, szron 'Reif'), Elsewhere in IE ON hjarn 'gefrorener Schnee| mit Eiskruste bedeckte durchgefrorene Erde'.}];165[223{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *herzna- 'hard snow' (< *k̑ers-nó-), close to Lith. šer̃kšnas 'hoarfrost', Latv. sȩ̄rsna 'id.' < *sers-neh₂-, Ru. dial. serēn, séren 'crust of ice' < *k̑ers-n-o-/eh₂-| with zero-grade Lith. šir̃kšnas 'hoarfrost' < *k̑rs-no-.}];180[137{Arm. saṙn 'ice| crystal' has cognates in ON hjarn, Russ. serën 'frozen snow' < *k̑erno- which might also account for the Armenian form except for the vocalism of the root, which could have been influenced by the verb saṙnowm 'freeze' (suggested by Godel 1972:64). It is also possible that the original formation was an n-stem, in which case *k̑érōn, loc. k̑r̥én- > Arm. *sarin → saṙin. The exact stem formation is uncertain.}];740[IV:176-177]
Justification: Derived from Armenian saṙn 'ice' and generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ([Olsen 1999](src-180):137, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):567-568; cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, [ALEW](src-352) 1019, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.

Source: 740[2:401-403];180[936{Of unknown origin.}];540[342-343{Suggests the direction of the borrowing is uncertain, and the Caucasian parallels (Archi xotu 'grass', Udi xod 'tree') could be borrowings from Armenian.}]
Justification: Origin uncertain. Of unknown origin according to [Olsen 1999](src-180):936. Some Caucasian parallels exist (Archi гьоти 'grass', Udi xod 'tree') although [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):342-343 rather consider it more likely that these are loans from Armenian. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xot-o-].

Source: 180[963{Of unknown origin, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:510f.}];740[II:510-511]
Justification: Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):963, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:510-511). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kanatʃʰ-].

Source: 180[932{This cognate set is originally a loan into Classical Armenian from Syrian mezze 'crines parvi'.}]
Justification: A loanword from Syriac mezzē 'crines parvi' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *maz-o-].

Source: 141[334-335{S.v. *k̑leu̯- 'hören' (IEW 605-7). Cf. n1: the root *k̑leu̯s- (LIV² 336) is probably originally a derived desiderative form from this root, probably already of PIE date.}];172[II:666-667{S.v. Ved. √śrav- 'hören', from PIE *k̑leu̯- (cf. Arm. aor. low(a), pres. lse- 'hören', Gk. ἔκλυον 'hörte', κλυτός 'berühmt', Lat. cluēre 'heißen, genannt werden', OIr. ro-cluinethar 'hört', OHG hliumant 'Ruf, Gerücht, Leumand', Latv. sludinât 'verkünden', Toch AB käln- 'tönen').}];83[356-357{S.v. Proto-Iranian *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' (cf. Ved. śrav- 'to hear', Gk. ἔκλυον 'heard', κλυτός 'famous', Lat. cluēre 'to be called, to be mentioned', Toch. käln- 'to sound', Latv. sludinât 'to declare', etc.).}];79[313-315{S.v. Arm. lsem (aor. lu-a) 'to hear, to listen| to obey', derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' (cf. Skt. śrav- 'to hear', Gk. κλύω 'to hear, obey', Lat. clueō 'to be called, be named, be reputed', OCS sluti 'to be called', etc.).}];50[208{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kli-nu- 'hear', from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'hear' (cf. Gk. κλύω, Skt. śru-, OCS sluti).}];442[730{S.v. 12598 Ved. śr̥ṇṓti 'hears' RV. [√śru].}]
Justification: Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ([LIV²](src-141) 334-335, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):313-315, [EWAia](src-172) II:666-667 [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):730 no.12598, [Cheung 2007](src-83):356-357, [Matasović 2009](src-50):208). The parallel verbal root *k̑leu̯s- 'listen to' is a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336).

Source: 180[168-169{Etymology obscure.}];740[II:445]
Justification: Of obscure etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):168-169; cf. [HAB](src-740) II:445). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsan-u-(r)]

Source: 558[215-216{The paradigm present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair of Proto-Armenian or Proto-Indo-European roots. Probably present to *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', ḫarnik- 'vernichten, zugrunde richten'), aorist stem to *per- 'schlagen' (Lith. per̃ti '(im Dampfbad) mit dem Badequast schlagen', Latv. pḕrt 'schlagen, prüglen| (mit dem Badequast) schlagen'.}];141[473{S.v. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-9). Root aorist *pér-/pr- > Arm. ehar 'schlug'.}];276[{Arguably from earlier *z-ar-an-e-, the root morpheme /-ar-/ from PIE *(-)pr̥- of 3.*per- (Lith. per̃ti| OCS pьrati| OIr. orgaim 'to slay'| Ved. prt- 'battle'')| cf. LIV² 473| Klingenschmitt (1982: 215). See also [lexeme 28521](lex-28521).}]
Justification: Arguably from the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)-. The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):215-216 for further discussion). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 79[544{S.v. Arm. ors 'hunt, catch| hunted animal, game'| denominal verb orsam 'to hunt' Traditionally compared to Gk. πόρκος 'kind of fish-trap' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):13, accepted by [HAB](src-740) III:588 with reservation). [Clackson 1994](src-319):164 rejects this etymology and prefers the suggestion of [HAB](src-740) III:588 of a connection with Lat. porcus 'pig' with a semantic development '(young pig)' > 'animal for hunting' or 'game' (meaning only preserved in Armenian) > '(young) pig'. Alternatively Martirosyan proposes a connection with the Greek and Celtic words for 'roe' (Gk. δορκάς, ζορκάς, δόρξ, δόρκος, ζόρξ, ἴορκος, etc. 'a kind of deer, roe, antelope, gazelle', Corn. yorch 'roe' MW iwrch 'roe-deer' via PIE *i̯ork̑-o-.}];180[13{Arm. ors 'hunting, fishing| venison, draught of fish' "formally identical with Greek πόρκος 'sort of fishing net' < *pórk̑os, apparently a *bʰóros-derivative, even though the underlying verbal root is otherwise unknown."}];740[III:588];319[164]
Justification: Armenian denominal verbs from Classical Armenian ors 'hunt, catch; hunted animal, game'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with Greek πόρκος 'a kind of fish trap' (cf. {HAB} III:588, [Olsen 1999](src-180):13), but disputed by others (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):164 and [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):544 for further discussion and alternative propsals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *ors-].

Source: 79[567-568{S.v. Arm. saṙn 'ice', cf. ON hjarn n. < *her(z)na- 'frozen snow', OHG hornung 'February', Russ. serën , serená 'crust over snow| frozen hard snow', Lith. šer̃kšnas m. < *k̂(e)r-sno- 'hoarfrost', adj. 'grey, whitish', šarmà < *k̂or-meh₂- 'frost', etc.}];180[137{Arm. saṙn 'ice| crystal' has cognates in ON hjarn, Russ. serën 'frozen snow' < *k̑erno- which might also account for the Armenian form except for the vocalism of the root, which could have been influenced by the verb saṙnowm 'freeze' (suggested by Godel 1972:64). It is also possible that the original formation was an n-stem, in which case *k̑érōn, loc. k̑r̥én- > Arm. *sarin → saṙin. The exact stem formation is uncertain.}];352[1019{Cf. s.v. OLith. šer̃kšnas 'Reif' (BSl. Latv. sę̄̀rsna 'Reiffrost, Nachtfrost im Frühling| Harsch über dem Schnee'. Sloven. srẹ̑n 'Raureif| Harsch', ORuss. serenъ 'Harsch, Eisregen, Raureif', Ru. séren, serën 'Schneekruste| Raureif| Frost nach Tauwetter', Pol. śrzon, szron 'Reif'), Elsewhere in IE ON hjarn 'gefrorener Schnee| mit Eiskruste bedeckte durchgefrorene Erde'.}];165[223{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *herzna- 'hard snow' (< *k̑ers-nó-), close to Lith. šer̃kšnas 'hoarfrost', Latv. sȩ̄rsna 'id.' < *sers-neh₂-, Ru. dial. serēn, séren 'crust of ice' < *k̑ers-n-o-/eh₂-| with zero-grade Lith. šir̃kšnas 'hoarfrost' < *k̑rs-no-.}];740[IV:176-177]
Justification: Armenian lexemes generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ([Olsen 1999](src-180):137, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):567-568; cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, [ALEW](src-352) 1019, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.

Source: 673[104-105, 112-113{Suggested to be a blend of the roots found in Greek σφάζω 'kill' and κτείνω 'kill' (Klingenschmitt 1982:227), or the root of Greek σφάζω 'kill' and the PIE root *gʷʰen- (Watkins 1995:521).}];558[227];674[521]
Justification: Uncertain origin. Suggested to be a blend of the roots found in Greek σφάζω 'kill' and κτείνω 'kill' [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):227, or the root of Greek σφάζω 'kill' and the PIE root *gʷʰen- [Watkins 1995](src-674):521 (cf. [Clackson 2017](src-673):104-105, 112-113). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *span-].

Source: 540[297{From *lēg-i̯- (cf. OIr. legaim 'flow'| OE leccan 'to wet, moisten| water, irrigate')| cf. also լիկ lik 'lagoon| wash pot' and cognate set 2767}];180[70{Arm. lič 'lake, pond' ([IEW](src-49) 657), reconstructed as *lēgi̯a- (collective formation?) from *leg- 'tröpfeln, sickern, zergehen'. The lengthened grade is consistent with other derivatives (e.g. *to-stem W. llaith, Bret. leiz 'humid' < *lekto-).}];740[II:282-283];141[397{Cf. s.v. ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'tröpfeln' (IEW 657). Only Germanic and Celtic.}]
Justification: Generally derived from a (collective?) formation *lēg-i̯a- to PIE *le⁽g̑⁾- 'to drip, trickle' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):70, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):297, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:282-283, [IEW](src-49) 657, [LIV²](src-141) 397). Possibly cognate with Modern English 'lake' if not a loanword from Old French (cf. further discussion in [cognate set 5612](cog-5612)). Alternatively, derived from the analogous formation *plēh₂g-i̯o/a- to root *pleh₂g- 'flat, wide', which is better supported by semantic parallels, cf. [Kölligan 2019](src-795): 248.

Source: 564[317{S.v. տերեւ terev 'Blatt', a loan from Syriac טרפא ṭarpā.}];740[IV:398{S.v. Arm. *տերեի 'տերեւ'. A loanword from Syriac.}];180[933{A loanword from Syriac ṭarpā (stat.abs. ṭǝref 'leaf').}]
Justification: Loanword from Syriac ṭarpā 'leaf' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):933, [HAB](src-740) IV:398, [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):317). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tereu̯-o-].

Source: 180[964{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:436).}];740[III:142-143{S.v. Arm. ձախ.}]
Justification: Unknown etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):964, [HAB](src-740) III:142-143). [MM: Proto-Armenian *dzax-o-/-u-].

Source: 540[70{denominative of ապուր apur 'salvation, deliverance| life| nourishment, soup| (perhaps also) booty (if not a different item)'}];276[{Of unknown origin. Apparently a denominative of ապուր apur 'salvation, deliverance| life| nourishment, soup| (perhaps also) booty (if not a different item)', attested in compounds such as անձնապուր(ծ) anjn-(a-)apowr(c), մազապուր maz-(a-)apowr, մարդապուր mard-(a-)apowr, դիւրապուր diwr-(a-)apowr, all denoting riddance or escape, esp. from harm or death.}];740[I:239-240]
Justification: Denominal formation based on Classical Armenian apowr 'salvation, deliverance; life'. Further etymology uncertain ([Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):70, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:239-240). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) or [Olsen 1999](src-180). [MM: Proto-Armenian *apur-].

Source: 79[266-267{S.v. Arm. erkayn 'long' and Arm. erkar 'long'. The majority opinion connects the Armenian forms with Gk. δηρός 'lasting long', Lat. dūrō 'to last out', and Skrt. dūrá- 'far' < *du̯eh₂-ró-. Cf. possibly also Lith. er̃dvas 'wide, spacious', however this Lithuanian connection is uncertain since the Lith. accent and Skt. árdha- 'side, part, region' point to a *-dʰ-.}];180[198-199{Generally derived from a full grade *du̯āró- < *du̯eh₂ró-, but preferably directly from *duh₂ró- = Skt. dūrá- 'far, distant', Av. abl. dūrat̰ 'from afar', Lat. dūrus 'hard'.}]
Justification: Generally derived from *du̯eh₂ró- or *duh₂ró- to √*du̯eh₂- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):198-199, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):266-267).

Source: 49[335];540[603];369[81{Cf. s.v. Alb. arg, -u 'picolo, pidocchio| uovo di pidocchio| gancetto che sta al lato della pezza di stoffa nel telaio' (cf. dialectal forms including ergjëz, ergjíz). Without certain comparisons within Albanian, outside of Albanian one first compares Arm. o(r)ǰil 'Nisse'| Lith. érkė 'Milbe, Zecke' which shows a voiceless velar. From *Hor(H)gʷʰ-???}];352[265-266{Cf. s.v. OLith. érke 'Zecke, Milbe', no certain comparisons outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *Horgʰi-, cf. Alb. ergjëz 'nit'; Lith. érkė 'tick, mite' ([IEW](src-49) 335, cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):603). This is remotely plausible, but the development of the Armenian form is irregular or phonetically unexpected, presumably due to taboo deformation. Cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):81 and [ALEW](src-352) 265 respectively for the proposed Albanian and Lithuanian cognates. [MM: Proto-Armenian *odʒil-o-/-a-].

Source: 79[306{S.v. Arm. leaṙn 'mountain'. Etymology uncertain ([HAB](src-740) II:270). Traditionally derived from *k̑l(e)i̯-tr- (cf. Gk. κλιτύς,  Lat. clīvus 'slope, rise| hill'| Goth. hleiþra 'booth, tent' (PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean'). Alternatively, from *lḗh₂-sr̥ ‎(cf. Alb. lerë '(heap of) stone(s)', Gk. λᾶας, OIr. líe 'stone' according to [Hamp 1967](src-744):16-17, accepted by [Olsen 1999](src-180):122. Both etymologies are ultimately rejected by Martirosyan as unconvincing.}];740[II:270];744[16-17];180[122]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived from *k̑l(e)i̯-tr- (cf. Gk. κλιτύς,  Lat. clīvus 'slope, rise; hill'; Goth. hleiþra 'booth, tent' (PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean') (rejected by [HAB](src-740) II:270). Alternatively, from *lḗh₂-sr̥ ‎(cf. Alb. lerë '(heap of) stone(s)', Gk. λᾶας, OIr. líe 'stone' ([Hamp 1967](src-744):16-17, accepted by [Olsen 1999](src-180):122). Both etymologies rejected by [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):306. [MM: Proto-Armenian *liar-in-].

Source: 79[451-452{S.v. Arm. mat- in matčʻim, matnum 'to approach, come close', mawt 'near, close', connected to ON mót, OE mōt, etc. '(town-)meeting| assembly'| mawt presumably from Proto-Armenian *maʷt-u- due to labial epenthesis| cf. mat-čʿ-i-m 'I approach, come near'.}];180[49-50{Arm. mōt 'near' ([IEW](src-49) 746) with the related verb matčʻim 'approach' is related to Goth. gamōtjan 'meet' etc. Proto-form is *mā̆du- < *mHdu- or *maHdu- and the o-inflection should probably be ascribed to secondary thematicisation of the u-stem by epenthesis.}];179[145{Cf. s.v. Goth. G46. ga-motjan ἀπαντῆσαι 'meet' (within Gmc. cf. OIc. møta, OE (ge-)mētan, OFris mēta OS mōtian 'meet', etc.), from PIE *mōd- 'meet, approach', cf. Arm. matčʻim 'approach'.}];165[372{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *mōtan- 'to approach, concede to(?)', a preterite-present probably based on the root *mod- as attested by Arm. matčʻim 'to approach, come close' < *mod-.}]
Justification: Generally connected to Germanic words for 'approach, meet', cf. Goth. ga-motjan 'to meet', but a more precise root reconstruction is remains uncertain (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):49-50, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):451-452, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):145, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):372).

Source: 79[215-216{S.v. Arm. gišer 'night'. Generally connected with different IE words for 'evening', cf. Gk. ἕσπερος 'evening(-star)', Lat. vesper 'evening(-star), West', Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ 'evening'.}];81[513{S.v. Proto-Slavic *vȅčerъ 'evening' from PIE *uekspero- (cf. Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, Arm. giser).}];66[470-471{Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος 'evening', an inherited word for 'evening' from *u̯e-kʷsp-er-o- *'towards the night, evening' (cf. Lat. vesper 'evening'). Element *-kʷsp- 'night' from PIE *kʷsep- 'spend the night' (cf. Ved. kṣáp- 'night').}];269[{While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form for this class, we have followed the analysis of [Beekes 2010](src-66):470-471) s.v. ἕσπερος, cf. also [Beekes 2004](src-702). Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-.}];294[843{Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯é 'weg, ab| ohne'. A reconstructed compound *u̯é-kʷsp-ero- 'Abend' is commonly assumed to underlie Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, ?PGmc. *u̯est(r)ō, Arm. gišer, OCS večerŭ, Lith. vãkaras, etc. (although LIPP rejects this reconstruction). Cf. p.843n20 for extensive references to further literature.}];702[59-62{For Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, Beekes argues for a connection with the root *kʷsep- '(spend the) night', with a prefix *u̯e- (of less certain origin, cf. article for discussion of alternative possibilities).}];352[1174-1175{S.v. OLith. vãkaras 'Abend', under which is included vãkar (adv.) 'gestern' (BSl. Latv. vakars 'Abend', OCS vьčera 'gestern', etc.), certainly cognate with Gk. ἕσπερος 'abendlich| westlich', ἑσπέρα 'Abend| Westen', Arm gišer 'Nacht', Lat. vesper (adj.) 'abendlich, zum Abend gehörig', vesper sf. 'Abend', MW ucher 'Abend'. The precise reconstruction is however disputed, cf. Beekes (2004) for the most recent attempt.}]
Justification: While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of [Beekes 2004](src-702), cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. Cf. also [Derksen 2008](src-81):513, [ALEW](src-352) 1174-1175, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):215-216. If *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- is the lexical root underlying this formation, then these lexemes may ultimately be cognate with Hittite išpant-, Vedic kṣáp- 'night', etc. in [cognate set 87](cog-87).

Source: 741[147-148{No clear etymology according to [HAB](src-740) IV:577-578, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):783. The only clear parallel to Armenian kʻitʻ can be found in Khinalug, an isolated North Caucasian language in North-Eastern Azerbaijan: Khinalug k’ɨtʰ-ɨr 'nose' (cf. k’ɨtʰ-ɨri 'nasal, of nose'), which appears to be inherited from Proto-North Caucasian *k’ʷēmtī-. If this parallelism between Arm. kʻitʻ 'nose' and Khinalug k’ɨtʰ- 'id.' is valid, then the Armenian lexeme may be an element of a South Caucasian adstratum.}];740[IV:577-578];540[783];180[942{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:577-578).}]
Justification: A probable North Caucasian loanword, cf. Khinalug k’ɨtʰ-ɨr 'nose' ([Asatrian 2014](src-741):147-148). No etymology in [HAB](src-740) IV:577-578, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):783, [Olsen 1999](src-180):942. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰitʰ-a-].

Source: 79[408-409{S.v. Arm. hin 'old, ancient, worn-out', from PIE o-stem *seno- 'old' (cf. Skt. sána- 'old', YAv. hana- 'old, grey', Gk. ἕνος 'last year's, old' < *seno-| Lat. senex 'old, aged, old man', senior 'older', etc.).}];172[II:695{S.v. Ved. sána- 'alt, ehemalig, früher' (Av. hana- 'alt, greis'), from PIE *séno- (cf. Gk. ἕνος 'alt, vom vorigen Jahr', Arm. hin 'alt', OIr. sen 'alt', Lith. sẽnas 'Greis', Lett. sens früherm ehemalig').}];353[393{S.v. Lith. sẽnas 'old', from PIE *sen-o- (cf. Skt. sána- 'old'| Lat. senex 'old man'| OIr. sen 'old').}];50[330{S.v. Proto-Celtic *seno- 'old', from PIE *seno- 'old' (IEW 908), cf. Skt. sána-, Gk. ἕνος, Lat. senex, Goth. sineigs, Lith. sẽnas, Arm. hin.}];352[901-902{S.v. OLith. sẽnas 'alt' (BSl. Latv. sȩns 'alt, aus alter Zeit stammend, ehemalig', etc.), from PIE *sen- 'alt', *sén-o/eh₂- 'id.' (cf. Ved. sána- 'alt', YAv. hana- 'alt, greis', Gk. ἕνος, -η, -ον 'alt, vormalig', Arm. hin 'alt', Lat. senex, senis 'alt| Greis', OIr. sen 'alt', Goth. sineigs 'alter Mann', etc.).}];274[613{S.v. *sen- 'alt' (IEW 907f., EIEC 409).}]
Justification: Armenian, Indic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sen- 'old' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):, [EWAia](src-172) II:695, [ALEW](src-352) 901-902, [Derksen 2015](src-353):393, [Matasović 2009](src-50):330).

Source: 66[1608-1609{S.v. Greek χαλάω 'to slacken': "The connection with Arm. xał 'game', xałam 'to play' by Meillet (1936:36) would require IE *kʰ-, and should therefore be abandoned."}];319[144-145{Traditionally Arm. xał- and Greek χαλάω 'slacken', χαλία 'rest' (Hesych.) have been connected (cf. already Meillet 1936:36). The connection, however, requires the postulation of a PIE voiceless aspirate *kʰ-. Clackson concludes "The etymological connection between Greek χαλία and Armenian xałał is possible and the two languages may share a common root not found in other Indo-European languages, or they may both have borrowed the terms from the same source. However, the phonetic correspondence between Greek χ- and Armenian x- is uncertain and the two words show no agreement on their morphological formation. The significance of the correspondence is therefore slight."}];644[36{Connects Arm. xał 'game', xałam 'play' with Greek χαλάω 'slacken'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected since [Meillet 1936](src-644):36 to Greek χαλάω 'to slacken', but this etymology requires postulating an initial voiceless aspirate *kʰ-, and given that voiceless aspirates are no longer reconstructed for PIE this etymology should be abandoned ([Clackson 1994](src-319):144-145, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1608-1609). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xał-].

Source: 564[257{S.v. Arm. քարշ kʻarš 'Schleppen'. A loan from Iranian, cf. NPers. kašīdan 'ziehen, schleppen', Pahl. kašītan 'to draw, pull, drag'.}];740[IV:562-563]
Justification: Loan from Iranic, cf. Av. karš- 'drag, plough' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):257, [HAB](src-740) IV:562-563). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karʃ-].

Source: 141[473{Cf. s.v. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-9).}];540[471];558[215-216{The paradigm present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair of Proto-Armenian or Proto-Indo-European roots. Probably present to *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', ḫarnik- 'vernichten, zugrunde richten'), aorist stem to *per- 'schlagen' (Lith. per̃ti '(im Dampfbad) mit dem Badequast schlagen', Latv. pḕrt 'schlagen, prüglen| (mit dem Badequast) schlagen'.}]
Justification: From the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)- (cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):471). The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):215-216 for further discussion). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 180[424{Proto-Indo-European origin unclear. Possibilities include *sm̥-gʰδʰr-eto- (cf. Skt. kṣárati 'flows, streams'), *(sm̥-)g̑ʰrei̯(H)-etó- ← *g̑ʰréi̯(H)-os (Skt. jráyas-, Av. zraiiah-, OP draya- 'sea, ocean, river'), *g̑ʰeu̯-(t)ro-.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):424 for various proposals. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *an(-)dzreu̯-o-/-a-].

Source: 564[167{S.v. կարմիր karmir 'roth' = Heb. כרמיל karmīl 'Carmoisinfarbe und die damit gefärbten Zeuge', via Persian?}];180[887{Loanword from Iranian (cf. Sogd. krmʾyr).}];740[II:558-559]
Justification: Loanword from Iranic, cf. Sogdian krm’yr 'red' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):167, [HAB](src-740) II:558-559, [Olsen 1999](src-180):887). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karmir-a-].

Source: 79[205{S.v. Arm. get 'river', from PIE *u̯ed-os- n. 'water' (cf. Gk. ὕδος 'water'| cf. also Skt. útsa- 'spring, fountain' < *ud-s-o-). The same root found in the PIE heteroclite stem *u̯od-r̥, *u̯ed-n-s (Hitt. u̯ātar/u̯eten-, Gk. ὕδωρ, -ατος, etc.).}];274[706-715{Cf. s.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).}];81[523{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *voda 'water' from PIE *uod-r/n- 'water' (cf. Skt. udan-, Hitt. u̯ātar, u̯etenas, Gk. ὕδωρ, Lat. unda, 'wave', Goth. wato, OSax. watar, OIc. vatn).}]
Justification: Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):205, [Derksen 2008](src-81):523).

Source: 180[337{"Armat (-oy, -ocʿ) 'root', also arm*, armn, has an aberrant o-stem inflection and a somewhat unclear etymological background, but in view of the alternative meaning 'stem' some connection with Gk. ὄρμενος 'Schoß, Stengel' (< *h₃r̥mǝ₁no-? IEW 328f), probably contaminated with the stem of Gk. ῥάδιξ, Lat. rādix (IEW 1167), seems possible."}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected Gk. ὄρμενος 'shoot, sprout, stem, stalk' (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):337). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 79[117-118{S.v. Arm. asem 'to say, tell, speak', usually compared with Gk. ἦ < *h₁e-h₁eg̑-t 'he said', Lat. aiō 'say', etc.}];141[256{S.v. 2. *h₂eg̑- 'sagen' (IEW 290-1). Classical Armenian present formation from *h₂eg̑-i̯é/o-.}]
Justification: Armenian forms generally derived from PIE 2. *h₂eg̑- 'to say' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):117-118, [LIV²](src-141) 256).

Source: 180[955{Of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:541f.).}];740[II:541-542]
Justification: Denominal verbs derived from Classical Armenian kar 'rope, string'. Further origins uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):955); perhaps originally a loanword from Caucasian, cf. Georgian ḳerva 'to sew' ([HAB](src-740) II:541-542). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kar-].

Source: 141[319-320{Cf. s.v. *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'schärfen' (IEW 541-2).}];172[627{Cf. s.v. Ved. √śā- 'schärfen, wetzen', from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- (cf. Arm. sowr 'scharf', Lat. cōs, cōt- 'Wetzstein', catus 'scharf, scharfsinnig', etc.).}];442[720{For Nuristani cognates, cf. s.v. 12438 Skt. śitá- 'whetted, sharp' RV.}];180[55{Arm. sowr n. 'sword, dagger'| adj. 'sharp', traditionally reconstructed as *k̑ō-ro- (< *koh₃[i̯]ro-), cf. Lat. cōs, cōtis 'whetstone'.}]
Justification: Armenian and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):55, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):720 no. 12438, [EWAia](src-172) II:627, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 319-320).

Source: 443[2:1585-1588{Fr. court < Lat. cŭrtus 'kurz'}];54[158{S.v. Lat. curtus 'mutilated, circumcised| imperfect'. There are two possible root etymologies| either (1) to *(s)ker-, via *kr-to- > *korto- > *kurto- with the development *orC > *urC (cf. Hitt. karš(ii̯e/a)- 'to cut, separate, stop', CLuw. *karš- < *kers-| Gk. κείρω 'to cut off, shave', καρτός 'cut off, shorn', Arm. kʻerem 'to scratch, cut off', etc.), or (2) to PIE *kʷer- (cf. Hitt. kuerzi 'cut', Ved. kr̥ṇóti 'make'). In view of the fact that the latter only means 'cut' in Hittite, while the forms of *(s)ker- have the meanings 'cut, shave' and the semantics of curtus meaning 'mutilated, circumcised', de Vaan's preferred etymology is to *(s)ker- (but cf. Ernout & Meillet, Meiser 1998, who prefer *kʷer-).}];316[160-161{S.v. curtus, -a, -um 'tronqué, écourté', d'où 'châtre' ou 'circoncis'. An adjective in -to- from the root *kʷer-. Alternatively to *(s)ker-.}];444[225{S.v. 2421 Lat. curtus 'kurz'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin curtus 'short' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):225, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:1585-1588); further root etymology uncertain, either to 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ([LIV²](src-141) 556-557, [IEW](src-49) 938-940) or to *kʷer- 'cut (off), incise' ({ref LIV² 391-392, [IEW](src-49) 641-642). The former etymology is preferred by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):158, whereas the latter by [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):160-161).

Source: 141[240-241{S.v. *h₁erkʷ- 'strahlen, singen' (IEW 340). Pres. *h₁erkʷ-/*h₁r̥kʷ- > [khot. āljs- 'singen'.}];79[259{S.v. Arm. erg 'song, poem', whence ergem 'to sing| to play a musical instrument' (cf. Ved. arká, 'ray (of light)| praise| hymn, song'| arcati 'praises'| Hitt. arku- 'to sing', Toch.B yarke 'worship', cf. also OIr. erc 'sky, heaven'). The assumption that Arm. erg is a loan is improbable and unnecessary.}];320[25{Cf. s.v. Khot. āljs- 'to sing'.}];172[I:114-115{Cf. s.v. Ved. √arc- 'strahlen, glänzen| singen, lobsingen, preisen' (IIr. cf. Khot. āljs- 'singen' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):25b), from PIE *(h₁)erkʷ- 'strahlen' (OIr. erc 'Himmel') and 'singen' (TochA yärk, B yarke 'Verehrung', Arm. erg 'Lied').}]
Justification: Armenian and Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₁erkʷ- 'to shine, to sing' ([LIV²](src-141) 240-241, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):259, [EWAia](src-172) I:114-115, [Bailey 1979](src-320):25).

Source: 180[941{Of unknown etymology (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:348f.).}];740[III:348-349]
Justification: Of unknown etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941, cf. [HAB](src-740) III:348-349). [MM: Proto-Armenian *mortʰ-o-].

Source: 66[1121{S.v. ὀσφραίνομαι 'to catch scent of, smell'. A compound verb containing two roots: *h₃ed-gʷʰreh₁-i̯é-. This class encodes the first member ὀσ- < *h₃ed- '(begin to) smell'.}];141[296{S.v. 1. *h₃ed- 'zu riechen beginnen (intr.)' (IEW 772-3).}];54[425-426{S.v. Lat. odor 'smell, odour'. The verb ol(e)facere is a compound verb. with first member ol- < *h₃ed-/h₃d- 'to smell' (cf. ὄζω 'to smell', Arm. hot 'smell', Lith. úosti, Latv. uȏst 'to smell, sniff', OCz. jadati 'to investigate, explore'. The main verbal element -facere is from *dʰeh₁-k- 'do' [cf. [cognate set 5125](cog-5125)].}];353[482{S.v. Lith. úosti [úo, uõ] 'smell, sniff' (Latv. uôst 'smell'), from PIE *h₃ed- (cf. Gk. ὄζω 'smell').}];79[420{S.v. Arm. hot 'smell, odour', from which also verbs hotim 'to smell' and redupl. hotot- 'id.'. Since long connected with Gk. ὀδμή 'smell', Lat. odor, odōris 'smell, scent, odour, perfume', etc.}];352[1154{S.v. OLith. úosti 'riechen' (BSl. Latv. uôst 'riechen' OCz. jadati 'undersuchen, erforschen'), from PIE *h₃ed- 'zu riechen beginnen' (cf. Gk. ὄζω, 1.sf.perf. ὄδωδα 'riechen, duften', Arm. hot 'Geruch', hotim 'riechen, stinken', Lat. olō, -ere, 'riechen, duften' Alb. ãmë 'Duft, Geruch, Gestank').}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃ed- 'to catch scent of (intr.), begin to smell' ([LIV²](src-141) 296, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1121, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):420, [ALEW](src-352) 1154, [Derksen 2015](src-353):482, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):425-426.  For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element *ὀσ-.

Source: 352[947{Cf. s.v. OLith. smáugti 'würgen, erwürgen', from PIE *smeu̯g- 'ersticken', cf. OE smēocan 'rauchen, räuchern'. Outside of Balto-Slavic a similar root is found in words for σμῡ́χω 'lasse verschwelen', Arm. mowx 'Rauch', NIr. múch, MW mwg 'Rauch, Dunst' which seem to expect deviant forms like *(s)muHgʰ-, *muk- and this still requires an explanation.}];165[458-459{S.v. Proto-Germanic *smeukan- ~ *smūkan- 'to smoke', from PIE *smeugʰ-e-(?). Cf. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'to burn up, smoulder away' < *smuHgʰ-e-| Lith. smáugti (smáugiu) 'to choke' < *smouHgʰ-ie-, Arm. mux, mxoy 'smoke' < *smoukH-o-| OIr. múch 'fire' < *smuHk-| MW mwg 'fire' < *smukH-. The underlying root is difficult to reconstruct| extra-Germanic evidence points to three different roots *smeuHgʰ-, *smeuHk-, and *smeukH-.}];556[440-441{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *smeuk-a- 'rauchen'. Germanic smeuk-a- can be connected with some extra-Germanic words, but the formal and semantic aspects are less secure. The Germanic forms formally correspond to Lith. smáugiu, -ti 'erwürgen, quälen' and Gk. (aor.) ἐσμύγην 'schwelte' (auch vom Schmerz), but because of the semantics the comparison is very uncertain. Formally less secure, but semantically better are *smeu-k- found in OIr. múch 'Rauch' and *smeu-gh- in Gk. σμύχω 'schwele'.}];296[M:69-70{S.v. OIr. múch 'fumée'. The root appears to have the form *smeugʰ- in Greek σμύχω 'je broule à petit feu' (cf. Arm. mux, gen. mxoy 'fumée'), and the form *smeug- in Gk. σμυγῆναι and in Germanic (cf. OE smocian 'fumer', smoca 'fumée'. Is there also a connection between these words and the root of Lat. mūcus, Gk. ἀπομύσσω and the Germanic words designating 'le nuage, l'humidité' in OIc. mygla, 'moisissure' and mugga 'pluie fine'? Starting from a root *smeu- with various enlargements we can account for a series of forms which occur among the languages (cf. IEW 971).}];50[281{S.v. Proto-Celtic *muk-V- 'smoke' [Noun]. The Brittonic forms must be from *muk- with a short vowel. A connection with PIE *(s)meu̯g̑ʰ- 'smoke' (IEW 971) appears probable, but there are many irregularities in the reflexes of this root. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'burn in smouldering fire' presupposes PIE *smuHg̑ʰ-, while OE smeocan 'to smoke' appears to be from *smeu̯g̑-.}];79[484{Cf. s.v. Arm. mux 'smoke', cf. MIr. múch 'smoke', W mwg 'fire', MBret. mog, moug 'hearth', MHG smouch 'smoke', OE smoca 'smoke', smēocan 'to smoke', Gk. σμύχω 'cause to carbonise, be consumed in a slow fire, smoulder away'. "The etymon presents as with difficulties concerning the vocalic length and the velar. We may be dealing with a European substratum word *(s)m(e)u/ūK/G⁽ʰ⁾-."}];66[1371{Cf. s.v. Gk. σμύχω 'to cause to carbonise, be slowly consumed in a fire, smoulder away' < IE ?*smeug⁽ʰ⁾- 'smoke'. "Beside the primary verb σμύχω, we find a noun in Arm. mux, gen, mxoy 'smoke'. In Celtic, OIr. múch, MW mwg 'fire' may go back to IE *muk-. In Germanic, there is a primary verb with a diphthong and a root-final IE voiced stop, e.g. OE smēocan 'to smoke, fumigate' < IE *smeug-, beside the zero-grade smoca [m.] 'smoke' < IE *smug-on-, smocian 'to smoke'. An Indo-European reconstruction for all these forms is difficult, as a voiceless aspirate *kʰ (PIE *(s)mūkʰo-| Meillet MSL 8 (1894): 294, followed by Frisk) is not reconstructed anymore for PIE. Lith. smáugti, 1sg. smáugiu 'to strangle, string together, plague' should probably be explained differently (Fraenkel 1955 s.v.), while for Ru. smúglyj 'dark, brown' etc., other interpretations are possible (Vasmer 1953 s.v.)."}]
Justification: Possibly related to Celtic [cognate set 8304](cog-8304) and Armenian cognate set 8305 lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. Possibly related Germanic [cognate set 647](cog-647) and Celtic [cognate set 8304](cog-8304) lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 947 (Baltic material), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1371 (Greek material), [Seebold 1970](src-556):440-441, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):458-459 (Germanic material), [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:69-70, [Matasović 2009](src-50):281 (Celtic material), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):484 (Armenian material).

Source: 290[163{Reconstructs *h₃egʷʰi-, but the precise PIE reconstruction is disputed as not all reflexes attested can be reconciled to a single reconstruction. There is likely some taboo distortion occurring in this lexeme in independent branches.}];66[1134-1135{S.v. ὄφις 'snake'. Probably identical to Skt. áhi-, Av. aži- from PIE *h₃égʷʰi- 'snake'. The lack of Brugmann's Law in Sanskrit points to an original e-grade.}];464[{Tsakonian ού(ι)θι < ΑG ὄφις. All changes are regular: fi > θi, e.g. θίλε (< φίλος) ‘friend’, νύθη (< νύφη) ‘bride’ etc.| i-metathesis next to dentals, e.g. λαλούδι > λαλού(ι)δι etc.}];382[1535{S.v. φίδι, from Hellenistic ὀφίδιον, diminutive of Ancient Greek ὄφις 'snake'.}];79[153{S.v. Arm. awj 'snake'. Since long connected with Lat. anguis 'snake', assuming a development *angʷʰ-i- (*h₂engʷʰ-i-) > PArm. *anʷgi- > *awg̑ʰi- > awj-i-.}];456[317-334{Cf. for extensive discussion of the words for 'snake', 'eel', etc. in Indo-European.}];172[I:157{S.v. Ved. áhi- 'Schlange, Natter' (YAv. aži- 'Schlange, Drache', MPers. až 'Drache). Several connections possible to vocabulary outside of Indo-Iranian. The exact connections are exacerbated through possible taboo distortions.}];81[388{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ǫžь 'snake', from PIE *h₂engʷʰ-i- (cf. Lith. angìs 'snake', Latv. uôdze 'adder', Lat. anguis 'snake', OHG unc 'snake', MIr. escung 'eel').}];353[55{S.v. Lith. angìs 'snake' (Latv. uôdze 'adder'), from PIE *h₂engʷʰ-i- (cf. Lat. anguis 'snake', MIr. escung 'eel', OHG unc 'snake', Arm. awj 'snake').}];54[42{S.v. Lat. anguis 'snake', from PIE *h₂(e)ngʷʰ-i- 'snake' (cf. MIr. escung 'eel' (lit. water-snake), OPr. angis, Lith. angìs < *h₂e/ongʷʰ-, Ru. už, Po. wąż, OHG unc < *h₂ngʷʰ-). Several IE languages have a similar preform *h₂e/ogʷʰ- without an internal nasal (Gk. ἔχις 'snake', Arm. iž, Gk. ὄφις 'snake', Skt. áhi-, Av. aži- 'snake, dragon'. Perhaps *n was introduced into this stem on analogy to verbs for 'to twist, wind'.}];352[40-41{Cf. s.v. OLith. angìs 'Giftschlange, Otter' (BSl. Latv. ùoc, 'Otter, Kreuzotter', OPr. angis 'Schlange', Slovene vọ̑z 'Grasschlange', etc. from PIE *n̥-ngʷí- 'Schlange' (cf. Lat. anguis 'Schlange', OIr. escung 'Aal', MW llysywen 'Aal', OHG unk 'Schlange, Natter', etc.).}];259[683{PS *ǫžĭ is related to Lithuanian angìs, Latin anguis and Old High German unc. PIE *angʷ(ʰ)i- 'snake, viper, worm'.}];442[44{Cf. s.v. 994 Ved. áhi 'snake' RV.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes generally considered to be cognate, although the precise reconstruction debated; some taboo distortion is likely to have occurred in some branches ([Sihler 1995](src-290):163, [Katz 1998](src-456); cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1134-1135, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1535, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):153, [EWAia](src-172) I:157, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):44 no. 994, [ALEW](src-352) 40-41, [Derksen 2015](src-353):55, [Derksen 2008](src-81):388, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):42).

Source: 66[1619-1620{S.v. χεῖμα 'winter, winter weather, storm' < PIE *g̑ʰ(e)i̯-m- 'winter'. Ancient Greek χιών 'snow' is a derivative of this root < *g̑ʰiōm, corresponding exactly to Arm. jiwn 'snow'.}];382[1599{S.v. SMG χιόνι, from Hellenistic Greek χιόνιον, diminutive of Ancient Greek χιών 'snow'.}];79[434-435{S.v. Arm. jiwn < PIE *g̑ʰ(é)i-ōm (cf. Gk. χιών 'snow', Av. ziiā̊ 'winter', Lat. hiems 'winter').}];172[II:815-816{S.v. Ved. himá- 'Kälte, Frost' < PIE *g̑ʰi̯em-/*g̑ʰim- (cf. Av. ziiā̊ 'Winter').}];274[162-169{S.v. ?*g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- 'Winter, Schnee' (IEW 425f., EIEC 504).}];442[815{S.v. 14096 Ved. himá- m. 'cold, frost, snow' (in himávant-) RV., 'snow, hoarfrost' ṢaḍvBr.}]
Justification: Greek, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´-; based on the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted ([NIL](src-274) 162-169, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1619-1620, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1599, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):434-435, [EWAia](src-172) II:815-816, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):815 no. 14096).

Source: 79[656, 685-686{S.v. Arm. kʻar 'stone'| for etymology, cf. s.v. mountain name Kʻarkʻ-ē, a mountain in the province of Turuberan in the districts of Tarōn and Palunikʻ, on the river Euphrates-Aracani. "The Armenian Kʻarkʻē, the name of a mountain of a considerable religious importance, reflects substratum *kar-k- 'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)', itself a derivative of *kar- > Arm. kʻar 'stone'. Particularly impressive is the Germanic cognate, *karko/u- *'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)" (cf. OE hearg 'heathen temple, altar, sanctuary, idol', OHG harug (referring to an area in the open for cult practice), OIc. harg (referring to clumps of stones in an area for cult practice), cf. also Welsh carrog 'stony river' < *karrākā, OIr. carrac 'cliff', carn 'stone grave').}];540[778{Cf. OIr. carrac 'rock| cliff', Welsh carn 'stone, cairn', carrog 'stony river'| OE hearg 'heathen temple| altar', OHG harug, OIc. harg 'open area for worship| *heap of stones, stone rise (for practicing cultic rites)'| cf. also Skt. kar-kar-a- 'hard, firm'| Gk. κάρκαρος 'rough'| etc.}];180[176{Arm. kʻar 'stone' (i-stem in sg., n-stem in the pl.) has been suggested to be connected with Old Irish carrac 'rock' ([Pedersen 1905](src-747):220, cf. [IEW](src-49) 532, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:42f.), but it is also possible that this is a word of non-IE origin (and in which case the irregular inflection cannot be determined).}];747[220{Suggests "vielleicht gehört kʻar 'stein, fels' zu ir. carric 'stein, fels'."}];740[IV:558-560];296[C:42-43{Cf. s.v. OIr. carrac 'roche'. There is no need to posit a root *kar- 'dur' but it's rather a derivative of an Ibero-Mediterranean *carrā 'pierre' which is found, among others in Basque harri 'pierre', Béarnese carroc and with various suffixes in the languages of Western Europe. Cf. also MW carrawc, Modern Welsh carrog 'torrent' (= le ruisseau rempli de cailloux?). Cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):23, 83| [IEW](src-49) 532.}]
Justification: Origin uncertain. Since [Pedersen 1905](src-747):220 connected with OIr. carrac 'rock', further compared to Classical Sanskrit karkara- 'hard, firm', Greek κάρκαρος 'prison' by [HAB](src-740) IV:558-560, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):778. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):685-686 considers a substratum loanword which is also shared with Germanic via pre-Proto-Germanic *karko/u- *'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)" (> OE hearg, OHG harug, OIc. harg), comparable to Armenian Kʻarkʻē the name of a mountain of religious importance. Cf. also [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:42-43 who rather assumes a Western Mediterranean substratum origin for the proposed Celtic cognates. If this is the same substratum word as in Celtic and/or Germanic, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.

Source: 79[135-138{S.v. Arm. *areg- : *areg-i-, an old genitive of Arm. arew 'sun', which derives from IE *h₂reu̯-i-, cf. Skt. ravi- m. 'sun, sun-god' < PIE *h₂reu̯-i-, Hitt. ḫaru(u̯a)nae- 'to become bright, get light, dawn'. Classical Arm. areg-akn lit. = 'eye of the sun'.}];172[II:440{Cf. s.v. Ved. ravi- 'Sonne, Sonnengott', from PIE *h₂reu̯-i- (cf. Arm. arew 'Sonne', Hitt. haruu̯anai- 'hell werden, dämmern').}]
Justification: Armenian forms reflect a derived i-stem *h₂reu̯-i-, and are directly cognate with Vedic ravi- 'sun, sun-god' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):135-138, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:440). NB: Classical Armenian aregakn is a nominal compound of arew 'sun' with akn 'eye' (cf. [cognate set 211](cog-211)).

Source: 79[188{Cf. s.v. Arm. bor 'leprosy' a loan from Iranic *bor 'leprosy', only preserved in Sogd. βr'wk'. In view of the Iranic alternation b- : v- one might also assume that Arm. uruk 'leprous' could have been borrowed from Iranic *vorūk- via an intermediary *wuruk.}];558[255, 257{Arm. owṙnowm is probably to be connected with Arm. owrowk 'leprous, suffering from elephantiasis'. If owrowk is enlarged from a more basic adjective *uru- or *ou̯ru- (cf. manowk 'Kind', manr, gen. manow 'small' < *manu-) we could be dealing with a denominative from an u-stem adjective *urnu- or *ou̯rnu-. The Armenian words have no certain etymological correspondences in related languages.}];740[III:606-607];276[{Perhaps an Iranian loan. Denominative of ուռ owṙ 'swelling, tumor', cf. CA ուռնում owṙ-nu-m (intr.) 'I am swollen, bloated| (fig.) grow proud"| ուռուցանեմ owṙ-owcʿ-an-e-m (tr.) 'I swell| stuff'| ուռոյց owṙ-oycʿ 'swelling| blister', etc.}]
Comment: Perhaps an Iranian loan. Denominative of ուռ owṙ 'swelling, tumor', cf. CA ուռնում owṙ-nu-m (intr.) 'I am swollen, bloated; (fig.) grow proud"; ուռուցանեմ owṙ-owcʿ-an-e-m (tr.) 'I swell; stuff'; ուռոյց owṙ-oycʿ 'swelling; blister', etc.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes derived from Classical Armenian owṙnowm. Further etymology obscure. Probably to be connected with Armenian owrowk 'leprosy' according to [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):257, which in turn may plausibly be considered an loan from Iranian. cf. Sogdian βrʾwkʾ 'leprous' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):188; cf. also [HAB](src-740) III:606-607 for older hypotheses). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(u̯)uṙ-].

Source: 540[300{S.v. Arm. ԼՈՂ, comparing Old Indic lelāyati 'to move to and from| shake'| Lithuanian leliúoti ‎'to swing', etc. to a putative IE root *lel-.}];740[II:292]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. According to [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):300 to an Indo-European root *lel- 'to move, to shake' (not in [LIV²](src-141)) comparing Vedic lelāyati 'to move to and from; shake' (but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:480 assigning to PIE *rei̯H-, also not in [LIV²](src-141)); Lithuanian leliúoti ‎'to swing', etc. (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:292).

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian počʿ 'tail'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:98, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):641 for various proposals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *potʃʰ-o-]

Source: 180[16, 887{Uncertain, but probably a loanword from Iranian.}];740[2:519-521]
Justification: Denominal to Armenian kap 'bond, fetter'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly an Iranian loanword ([Olsen 1999](src-180):16, 887, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:519-521). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kap-].

Source: 180[193{Cf. related noun darj 'turning| return, departure' (vb. daṙnam) to root *dʰreg̑ʰ- or *dʰerg̑ʰ- (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):111f.).}];558[110-111{Arm. daṙna-, aor. darj(a)- belongs to a root *dʰr̥g̑ʰ- which is also found in Alb. dreth, aor. drodha 'zusammendrehen, zwirnen, spinnen'.}];141[146{S.v. *dʰerg̑ʰ- '(sich) wenden' (IEW 258). Probably to be connected with the Schwebeablaut variant dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- (Gk. τρέχω, ON dragan etc.).}];79[234{S.v. Arm. daṙnam (3.sg.aor. darj-a-w) 'to go/come back, return| to turn, become' connected with Alb. dredh, aor. drodha 'to turn, wind' on one hand, and to Gk. τρέχω 'to run', τρόχος 'wheel| potter's wheel', OIr. droch 'wheel', and Arm. durgn 'potter's wheel'| these forms are often assumed to be two different lexemes.}]
Justification: Armenian lexemes reflecting a root *derg̑ʰ- 'turn (oneself)' together with Albanian dreth ([Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):110-111, [LIV²](src-141) 146, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):193, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):234). Possibly a Schwebeablaut variant of *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'pull, drag' in which case to be further connected with 'walk' in cognate set 5824, 'run' in [cognate set 5027](cog-5027) 'pull' in [cognate set 2839](cog-2839), 'carry' in [cognate set 5330](cog-5330).

Source: 141[487-488{S.v. *pleu̯-º 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).  See under 'Neubildungen (Nasalpräs.)' and footnote 8.}];382[1115{Modern Greek present stem πλένω [ˈple̞no̞] was backformed from aorist ἔπλυνα [ˈe̞plina] on analogy to pairs like aorist ἔμεινα [ˈe̞mina] ~ present μένω [ˈme̞no̞].}];66[1212{S.v. Gk. πλύνω 'to wash, clean', from PIE *pleu- 'flow, swim'. The vowel length in πλῡ́νω points to a thematized nasal present < *πλύ-ν-ι̯ω, an inner-Greek formation from the root *plu- (cf. πλέω < *pleu-e/o-). A nasal present of the same meaning is also found in Armenian lua-na-m 'to wash, bathe'.}];79[316{S.v. Arm. luanam 'to wash| to bathe', most commonly derived from PIE *pleu- 'to wash' (cf. Gk. πλύνω 'to wash, to clean', Skt. plávate 'to float, swim', Lith. pláuti 'to rinse, wash off' etc.).}]
Justification: Hellenic and Armenian lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1212, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1115, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):316).

Source: 180[50, 787{"The etymological connection with Lith. júrės 'sea' < *i̯ūr- (*i̯uhr-?) seems quite plausible, although the evidence for a development *i̯- (or *hi̯-) > ǰ- in Arm. is meagre, but the suggested further connection with Skt. vā́r 'water' etc. can hardly be carried through."}];549[122–124{[=Kortlandt 1998].}];742[15{Rejects the usually given etymology with Lithuanian jū́ra 'sea' on the grounds it cannot be separated from OPr. wurs 'pond', Skt. vā́r 'water', TochA wär, TochB war 'id.' with an initial j- of secondary origin.}];352[423{Cf. s.v. OLith. jū́ra 'Meer' (BSl. Latv. jũŗa 'Meer, großer See', OPr. juriay 'Meer', from PIE *i̯uHr- 'Wasser' (cf. Arm. ǰowr, G.pl. ǰowrcʻ, ǰrocʻ 'Wasser').}];740[IV:134-136]
Justification: Generally connected with Baltic words for 'sea', cf. OLith. jū́ra 'sea', etc. ([Olsen 1999](src-180):50, [ALEW](src-352) 423), although this etymology is disputed by [Kortlandt 1998](src-742):15 (= [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):122) on the grounds that the proposed Baltic cognates cannot be separated from Sanskrit vā́r 'water'. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:134-136.

Source: 564[240{S.v. սպիտակ spitak 'weiss', a loan from Middle Iranian (cf. Pahlavi spētak).}];180[907{An Iranian loan.}];740[IV:264-265]
Justification: Loan from Middle Iranian, cf. Pahlavi spētak, Parthian spytk' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):240, [HAB](src-740) IV:264-265, [Olsen 1999](src-180):907). [MM: Proto-Armenian *spei̯t-aka-].

Source: 50[135{S.v. *flitano-, *flitawī 'broad', from PIE *plth₂u- 'broad', *plth₂u̯ih₂ 'the broad one' (cf. pr̥thivī́- 'earth', Gk. Πλάταια (toponym)). Proto-Celtic *flitawī directly represents the feminine form, while *flitano- is from derived *plth₂-no- (cf. Hitt. paltana- 'shoulder').}];66[1205{S.v. Gk. πλατύς 'wide, broad, flat, level', from PIE *pl̥th₂-ú- 'broad' and identical to Skt. pr̥thú-, Av. pərəθu- 'wide, broad' (root *pleth₂-).}];274[564{S.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (LIV 486f., IEW 833).}];141[486-487{Cf. s.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (IEW 833).}];180[767{Arm. layn 'wide' < *pl̥th₂ni- (cf. Gk. πλάτανος, OIr. lethan).}];353[362{S.v. Lith. platùs 'broad, wide' (Latv. plašs 'broad, wide', var. plats), from PIE *plth₂-u- (Skt. pr̥thú- 'wide, broad', Av. pərəθu- 'wide, broad', Gk. πλατύς 'wide, broad, flat, level'). Baltic apparently has an o-grade in this adjective.}];172[II:162-163| 179{S.v. Ved. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit, ausgedehnt groß, zahlreich, umfänglich' (cf. IIr. OAv. pərəθu- 'breit, weit'), from PIE *plth₂-ú- (cf. Gk. πλατύς 'weit, breit, flach, eben', Lith. platùs 'weit, breit, ausgedehnt', etc.). p.179 "práthas- n. Weite, Breite, Ausdehnung [...] Iir., jav. fraϑah- n. "Breite" - Idg. *pléth₂-es-"}];564[451{S.v. Arm. լայն lain 'breit', an inherited word (cf. Skt. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit', práthate 'breitet sich aus', práthas- 'Breite, Ausdehnung', Av. fraθah- 'Breite', Gk. πλατύς 'breit', πλάτος 'Breite', Lith. platùs 'breit', OIr. lethan, W. litan 'breit').}];352[787-789{S.v. OLith. platùs 'breit, weit, ausführlich' (BSl. Latv. plašs 'weit, breit, gräumig, ausgedehnt, etc.), from PIE *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (cf. Ved. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit', OAv. pərəθu-, YAv. pərəθu- 'id.', Gk. πλατύς 'weit, breit, flach, eben', OHG flado 'Fladen, flacher, Kuchen, Honigscheibe').}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'become wide, spread oneself out' ([NIL](src-274) 564, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1205, [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451, [Olsen 1999](src-180):767, [EWAia](src-172) II:162-163, 179, [ALEW](src-352) 787-789, [Derksen 2015](src-353):362, [Matasović 2009](src-50):135, [LIV²](src-141) 486-487).

Source: 274[177-185{S.v. *gʷen-, *gʷon-, *gʷ(e)n-(a)h₂- f. 'Frau' (IEW 473f.)}];345[242{S.v. TochB klīye ~ klyīye 'woman', 'female (of animals)', which with TochA kᵤli reflects Proto-Tocharian *kʷliye.  Adams takes the Proto-Tocharian form to reflect PIE *gʷneh₂-h₁en- with a "definitizing" suffix to the normal PIE word for 'woman' *gʷen(e)h₂, which appears in TochB as śana- 'wife'.  The initial -l- in the Tocharian forms is the result of dissimilation *n … n  > *l … n.  Cf. entry in Adams and NIL s.v. *gʷenh₂-, n22 for discussion.}];66[291-292{S.v. γυνή 'wife, woman' < PIE *gʷen-h₂ 'woman', cf. dial. (Boeot.) βανά.}];80[501-505{S.v. Hitt. *kuu̯an- 'woman' (Anatolian cognates: CLuw. u̯ānā- 'woman', u̯(a)natti- 'woman'| HLuw. FEMINA-nat(i)- 'woman', Lyd. kãna- 'wife'). It is quite obvious that the other Anatolian cognates are cognate with other words like Gk. γυνή, Skt. jánis (gen.sg. gnā́s), OIr. ben (gen.sg. mná), OCS žena, etc. 'woman' that reflect *gʷen-h₂, *gʷn-éh₂-s.}];79[363-364{S.v. Arm. kin (GDSg.knoǰ) 'woman, wife', from PIE *gʷén-(e)h₂-, gen. gʷn-éh₂-s 'woman' (cf. Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', OAv. jə̄ni- 'woman, wife', YAv. jaini- 'woman, wife', MPers., NPers. zan 'wife', Parth. jn 'wife', OAv. gənā 'woman', YAv. γənā 'woman', Gk. γυνή (gen. γυναικός, Boeot. βανά 'wife, woman', OIr. ben, mná 'woman, wife', Goth. qino 'wife', OCS žena 'woman, wife', Luw. wana- 'woman', TochA śäṃ, B śana 'woman, wife' vs. TochA kᵤli, B klīye 'woman', etc.).}];172[I:568-569{S.v. Ved. jáni- 'Weib, Frau' (IIr. cf. OAv. ǰə̄ni-, YAv. jaini- 'Weib, Frau', Parth. jn, MPers. NPers. zan 'Frau, Gattin', etc.), from PIE *gʷénh₂-, originally in paradigmatic ablaut with *gʷnéh₂- (> Ved. gnā́-, cf. EWAia I:504).}];81[558{S.v. Proto-Slavic *žena 'woman, wife', from PIE *gʷen-eh₂- (cf. OPr. genno 'woman', Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', Goth. qino 'woman', OIr. ben 'woman', etc.).}];353[558{S.v. OPr. genno 'woman', from PIE *gʷen-eh₂- (cf. Proto-Slavic *ženà 'woman, wife', OCS žena 'woman', Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', Goth. qino 'woman', OIr. ben 'woman', etc.).}];165[317{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kwenōn- 'woman, wife', a Germanic ōn-stem based on a PIE proterodynamic h₂-stem (nom. *gʷén-h₂, gen. *gʷn-éh₂-s), cf. Skt. jáni- 'woman, wife', gnā́- 'goddess', OCS žena, Lith. ženà, OPr. genno 'woman', Arm. kin 'id.', Gk. γυνή, gen. γυναικός 'id.', OIr. ben, gen. mná 'id.', etc.}];50[61{S.v. Proto-Celtic *benā, *bena 'woman', from PIE *gʷenh₂ 'woman' (cf. Skt. jáni-, gnā́, Gk. γυνή, CLuw. wānā-, OE cwen, OPr. genno, ToB śana, OCS žena).}];149[157-159{S.v. TochB klyiye, kliye, TochA kᵤli 'woman', cf. for further discussion of the Tocharian forms.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *gʷen- 'woman' ([NIL](src-274) 177-185, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):501-505, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):157-159, [Adams 2013](src-345):242, [Beekes 2010](src-66):291-292, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)363-364, [EWAia](src-172) I:568-569, [Derksen 2015](src-353):558, [Derksen 2008](src-81):558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):317, [Matasović 2009](src-50):61).

Source: 79[95–96{S.v. Arm. antaṙ 'forest'. Several interpretations from different IE sources are possible, but ultimately the origin is uncertain. Cf. entry in Martirosyan for an examination of possible proposals.}];180[939{Uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) I:180).}];740[I:211]
Justification: Origin uncertain. Traditionally thought to reflect PIE *sm̥-doru- lit. "together-tree/wood", which is, however, both formally and semantically quite speculative ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):95-96, [Olsen 1999](src-180):939, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:211). [MM: Proto-Armenian *antaṙ-i-].
Etymology uncertain ([HAB](src-740) III:577). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *ord-].

Source: 180[442{Arm. tari 'year' has no generally accepted etymology.}];740[IV:385-386];540[724]
Justification: No generally accepted etymology (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:385-386, [Olsen 1999](src-180):442, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):724 for various proposals; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tar-i̯a-].

Source: 141[411-412{Cf. s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen' (IEW 652). Cf. n1: An alternative reconstruction for the root is *labʰ-, but in which case the Vedic forms exhibiting a nasal in the root would have to be a secondary innovation. [Baltic forms not connected in this entry.]}];352[547-548{S.v. OLith. lãbas 'gut' (BSl. Latv. labs 'gut, vollkommen', OPr. labs 'gut, tüchtig', etc.). The common Baltic word for 'good'. Slavic connections are lacking. The proposed connection to Vedic rabh-, rábhate 'to seize, to grasp' / labh-, lábhate 'to get' and Greek ἀμφιλαφής 'comprehensive', λαφύρα 'haul, spoils' is only possible if the root form is *labʰ- (cf. LIV² 412n1 s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen').}];360[327{S.v. Lith. lãbas 'gut', connected with Ved. rabh- 'angreifen'.}];269[{Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. lãbas, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 speculatively considered a connection with Arm. law (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8081](cog-8081)), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352). A lemma for Lith. lãbas is lacking in [Derksen 2015](src-353). Besides the still uncertain proposal to Ved. rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.}]
Justification: Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. lãbas, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8081](cog-8081)), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352). A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in [Derksen 2015](src-353). Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

Source: 66[264-265{S.v. γελάω 'to laugh' < PIE *g̑elh₂- 'laugh' (cf. Arm całr 'laughter').}];141[162{S.v. *g̑elh₂- 'in Lachen ausbrechen' (IEW 366). A Greek-Armenian isogloss.}];79[336-337, 340-341{S.v. Arm. *cicał 'laughter', cicałim 'to laugh', from the same root as całr 'laugh, laughter', to be connected with Gk. γελάω 'to laugh', etc. from PIE *g̑elh₂-.}];270[214{S.v. AGk. γελάω 'rire, se rire de', etc. To be connected to the Armenian word in the same sense całr, (gen. cału).}];319[126-132{A unique Greek-Armenian lexical isogloss. Cf. for an extensive discussion of the derived vocabulary.}]
Justification: A unique Greco-Armenian isogloss ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):214, [Beekes 2010](src-66):264-265, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):336-337, 340-341, [LIV²](src-141) 162; cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):126-131 for extensive discussion of the various reflexes and derivatives from this root).

Source: 321[401{S.v. Wakhi *wəx̌ə́n, *wux̌ə́n 'кровь', from Old Iranian *vahvan(i)- (cf. Av. vohuna-, vohunī-, Khot. hūnä, MSogd. yxwn-, ywxn-, Budd. γwrn wγrn [wuxʳn], Yaghn. wáx(í)n, Ishk. wen, Sangl. wēn, Shugn., Rush. wixín, etc. Tadj., Pers. xun, etc.).}]

442[213{S.v. 3993 Skt. gaṇáyati 'counts'.}];172[I:458-459{Cf. s.v. Ved. gaṇá- 'Schar, Reihe, Gefolge, Anhang, kleinere Heeresabteilung'. Ved. gaṇá- probably originally meaning *'Zahl', to judge from the verb gaṇá-y° 'zählen', cf. also *gr̥nti- 'counting' (T. 4234). No further consensus on an etymology.}]
Comment: denominal derivative, cf. Vedic gaṇá- m. 'row, crowd, entourage, a number of fellows' (RV+); see also 'think' in lexeme 25989; cf. JB+ gaṇáyati, Sanskrit gaṇayati ʻcountsʼ (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3993
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit gaṇáyati 'counts' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):213 no.3993), a denominal formation to Sanskrit gaṇá- 'multitude, number, series', without further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:458-459).

Source: 172[II:463-464{Cf. s.v. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen' < PIE *leu̯k- 'shine'.}];83[316{S.v. Proto-Iranian *rauč- 'to shine, radiate'.}];567[261{Bactrian ρωσο 'day' < Proto-Iranian *raučah- (cf. OPers. raucah-).}];141[418-419{Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č-, from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):316, [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464, [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Source: 172[II:332-333{S.v. Ved. mála- 'Schmutz, Unreinlichkeit, Unrat, Dreck', probably to be derived from PIE *mélo-, cf. Gk μέλας 'black', Lith. mė́las 'blue', mel̃svas 'blueish'.}];66[923-924{Cf. s.v. μέλας 'dark-colored, black' < PIE *mel(h₂)-n- 'black'. The feminine stem μέλαινα is traditionally identified with Skt. malinī < *melh₂-n-ih₂ and the masculine/neuter stem μελαν- would be a modification of an earlier thematic *μέλανο- equivalent to Skt. malina- 'dirty'. It should be noted, however, that malinī is only known in the form of a gloss 'menstruating woman' and malina- is an epic classical Sanskrit derivative from Ved. mála- 'dirt', which could in principle also be derived from *molh₂-o-. There are additional colour words which may be compared from Baltic: Latv. męl̃ns 'black', OPruss. melne 'blue spot', Lith. mul̃vas 'yellow (of clay)'.}];270[680-681{Cf. s.v. μέλας 'sombre, noir', compared by [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) with Skt. malinī- which corresponds to μέλαινα but is a term that signifies 'femme qui a ses règles', malina- 'sale' (attested only late), and very simple comparisons with terms in Baltic *mēlna- < *melə-no- in Latv. męl̃ns 'noir', OPr. melne 'tache bleue', Lith. mė́las, mė́lynas 'bleu'.}];353[544{Cf. s.v. Latv. mȩl̃ns 'black' (cf. OPr. melne 'blue spot, bruise'), from PIE *melh₂-n- (cf. Gk. μέλας 'dark, black').}];442[569{S.v. 9905 Skt. maliná- 'dirty'.}]
Comment: cf. Vedic mála- n. 'dirt'; cf. *mel- 'black', presumably originally *mel- 'earthy' (RP); cf. also *mel- 'soft'
Justification: Indic lexemes generally connected with Greek and Baltic lexemes designating dark colours ([EWAia](src-172) II:332-333; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):680-681, [Beekes 2010](src-66):923-924, [Derksen 2015](src-353):544). For the Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):569, no. 9905.

Source: 442[594{10286 S.v. Ved. mr̥ttikā- f. 'earth, clay' VS. [*mr̥tti- in Pk. and some cmpds. √mr̥d-]}];172[II:386-387{Cf. s.v. Ved. √mrad- 'sanft machen, weich machen', not to be separated from Ved. mr̥dú- (PIE *(h₂)ml̥d-ú-).}];141[431{Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594 no. 10286, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ([KEWA](src-399) II:675-677, [EWAia](src-172) II:386-387, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 431).

Source: 156[I:304-305{S.v. Oss. cæst | cæstæ 'глаз', from Iranian *čašman- (cf. Pers. čašm, Sogd. *čašm- (čšm), Av. čašman-| also Ved. cakṣu-).}];172[I:523-524{S.v. Ved. cakṣús- n. 'Auge, Sonnenauge, heller Blick' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. čašman- 'Auge', MPers. čašm, etc.), derived from √cakṣ- < PIE *kʷek̑-s- 'erscheinen ~ sehen ~ zeigen'.}];141[383-385{Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9).}];331[II:238-242{S.v. Proto-Iranian *čašman- < *ča(ś)š-man- 'глаз', derived from Proto-Iranian *čaš-, from IE *kʷek̑-s- (cf. Ved. cákṣus-, cákṣ-as-).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ([EWAia](src-172) I:523-524, [ESIJa](src-331) II:238-242, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).

Source: 83[234-235{S.v. Proto-Iranian *kap/f-¹ 'to (be)fall, strike (down)' < PIE *kop- 'fell, chop' (LIV 555, IEW 930ff.).}];141[555{S.v. 1.*(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' (IEW 931-2).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down' and further to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):234-235, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).

Source: 141[72-73{S.v. *bʰei̯h₂- 'in Furcht geraten' (IEW 161-2).}];81[50{S.v. Proto-Slavic *bojati sę 'fear, be afraid' < PIE *bʰoi̯H-eh₂-.}];352[112-113{S.v. OLith. bijóti 'fürchten', derived from PIE *bʰei̯h₂- 'in Furcht geraten' (cf. Ved. bhay- 'sich fürchten').}];172[II:245-246{S.v. Ved. √bhay- 'sich fürchten' < PIE *bʰei̯H-.}];458[2: 163-164{The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian bijóti(s), Old Indic bháyate, Avestan bayente etc.}];353[89{S.v. Lith. bijóti 'fear, be afraid', from PIE *bʰ(o)iH- (cf. OCS bojati sę, Skt. bhay- 'fear, be afraid').}]
