Justification: Indic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *bʰei̯h₂- to get scared' ([LIV²](src-141) 72-73, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:245-246, [ALEW](src-352) 112-113, [Derksen 2015](src-353):89, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:163-164, [Derksen 2008](src-81):50).

Source: 172[I:97{S.v. Ved. parṇá- 'Flügel, Feder, Pfeilfeder, Blatt' (IIr. cf. YAv. parəna- 'Feder', Khot. pārra- 'Flügel', MPers., NPers. parr 'Feder', etc.), probably from PIE *(s)por-no- (cf. OHG farn 'Farn', Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Schaufel, Blatt').}];141[579-580{Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)per- 'fliegen' [IEW 817, 850].}];81[396{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pero 'feather', from PIE *perH-o- (cf. Skt. parṇá- 'wing', Gk. πτερόν 'feather, wing', OE fearn 'fern', OIr. raith 'fern'). The reconstruction of a laryngeal is based on Lith. papártis 'fern'. [Corrigendum to Derksen: The Greek comparandum πτερόν listed does not belong here, but rather belongs to *pet-, not *(s)per-, cf. [cognate set 7563](cog-7563) (MJCS).]}];178[II:343{S.v. перо 'Feder', related to Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Fittich', Latv. sparns 'id.', Ved. parṇám 'Flügel, Fittich', Av. parəna- 'Feder', OHG farn 'Farnkraut'. Less likely is the comparison with Gk. πτερόν 'Feder, Flügel', πέτομαι 'fliege', Ved. pátram 'Fittich, Flügel, Feder', etc.}];345[383{S.v. TochB parwa 'feathers', which reflects Proto-Tocharian *pärwā, as though from PIE *p(e)rweh₂ (nt.pl.). The best potential cognate is OCS pero 'feather' as though from PIE *peróm (nt.), both derivatives of the PIE root *per- 'move (tr./intr.)| fly (intr.) (cf. OCS perǫ 'fly', Skt. pipárti 'brings', Gk. περάω 'pierce', Lat. portō 'bring', Goth. faran 'travel', etc.).}]
Justification: Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)per- 'to fly' ([Adams 2013](src-345):383, [EWAia](src-172) II:97, [Derksen 2008](src-81):396, [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) II:343, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 579-580).

Source: 172[II: 297-298{S.v. Ved. mátsya- 'Fisch' < PIIr. matsi̯a- (YAv. masiia- 'fish', Parth. mʾsyʾg (māsīg), MPers. māhīg, NPers. māhī, Kumzārī mī < PIr. *maθi̯a- 'Fish'). Further etymology unclear, cf. notes in Mayrhofer for previous speculations.}];442[560{S.v. 9758 Ved. mátsya- m. 'fish'. 2. *matsiya-.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:297-298, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):560, no. 9758).

Source: 442[511{S.v. 9092 Skt. phulla 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' MBh.}];399[II:398{S.v. Skt. phullaḥ 'aufgeblüht, blühend / blossoming', possibly from a p.p.p. *phal-na- to phálati 'birst', corresponding to Buddh. phulla- 'gebrochen', Pāli phulla- 'gebrochen' and 'blühend'| the formation no-longer associated with the verb *phalla- would have then would have taken on a labial vowel -u-.}]
Comment: from Sanskrit (Mbh.) phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers),Pali phulla- 'blossoming', Prakrit phulla- 'opened, blossoming', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 511, no. 9092
Justification: As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ([KEWA](src-399) II:398).

Source: 363[II:242{S.v. Kurd. sawz 'зеленый', cf. Pers. sabz| two possible etymologies given after Morgenstirne Etymological Vocabulary of Pashto (cf. now [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):73) and [Henning 1947](src-763):47.}];323[73{Cf. s.v. Paš. sāb'ə 'greens, vegetables', also 'fodder grass' "sābə is apparently the pl. of *sob- < *sāpa-| semantically a connexion with Prs sabz 'green, fresh', sabzī 'vegetable' seems likely, and the derivation of this < *sapa-čī- [is] possible (in spite of Henning's daring etymology < *spiz-, ultimately < *spr̥ǰ, √sparg- BSOAS 12/1, 1947, 47)."}];763[47{"As [Parth.] spc-/'spyz- (a)spez- can mean "to be verdant", should one not connect with it Persian sabz "green, fresh, in full bloom", sabz sudan "sprout, shoot, germinate " (etc.)? Although there are difficulties, this etymology of sabz may seem better than the one proposed by Morgenstierne, EVP., 66| NTS., i, 66. To come to the origin of 'spyxt/'spyz- itself, the obvious etymon is the Iranian base sprg (sparg) "to sprout, blossom". The past participle *sprxta- would become sprixt in early Middle Persian: for the rule is that -r̥- becomes brief vowel + r before a simple consonant, but r + brief vowel (generally -i-) before two consonants. As a word may not begin with three consonants, irrespective of a prothetic vowel, sprixt was necessarily shortened and became spixt| but where it was preceded by a preverb, no change took place, cf. Parth. wyspryxt (or Saka hasprīya as against spätai). The present stem, *sprjya-, would develop in the same manner, spriǰy- > spiǰy- > spiǰ- > spiz- > (ə)spiz-. We have to call in the help of analogy to explain the noun 'spyg, -spyg (Pahl. spyk, inverse spelling), i.e. (ə)spig < *sprig < *spr̥ga- (which should have become *spurg). Nyberg, Texte zum mazd. Kal., 77 sq., has a different etymology."}]
Justification: Etymology disputed, cf. [Henning 1947](src-763):47, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):73, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:242.

Source: 83[456-457{S.v. Proto-Iranian *xšnau-¹ 'to hear (< 'to sharpen (the ears)')', from PIE *ksneu̯- 'to whet, sharpen' (cf. Ved. kṣṇav- 'to whet, sharpen').}];141[373{S.v. *ksneu̯- 'schärfen' (IEW 585).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *xšnau- 'to hear', further from PIE *ksneu̯- 'to whet, sharpen', presumably via an intermediary sense *'to sharpen (the ears)' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):456-457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 373).

Source: 172[II:318-319{Cf. s.v. Ved. √mar- 'sterben', from PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, hinschwinden, sterben' (cf. Lat. morior 'sterbe', Goth. maurϸr 'Mord', Lith. mir̃ti, OCS mrěti 'sterben', etc.).}];442[578-579{S.v. 10066 Skt. māráyati (1) 'kills' AV. [√mr̥]. [cs. of √mar- 'causes to die']}];141[439-440{Cf. s.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735)}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):578-579 no. 10066 Vedic māráyati (1) 'kills', the causative stem formation to Vedic √mar- 'to die', further to PIE *mer- 'to disappear, to die' ([EWAia](src-172) II:318-319, [LIV²](src-141) 439-440).

Comment: cf. Bailey (1979: 420) who connects NP čap with Sogdian sʾpt deriving both from *k̑am- "to bend over" (cf. *kamp- in LIV 342). However, while Sogdian requires the input *k̑e, NP requires *ke.

Source: 274[392-395{S.v. *i̯e/okʷ-r/n- n. 'Leber' (IEW 504).}];66[522{S.v. ἧπαρ 'liver' < PIE *(H)i̯ekʷ-r 'liver'.}];79[306-307{S.v. Arm. leard 'liver', usually connected with PIE *Hiekʷr(-t), *Hiekʷn-ós 'liver'. The initial l- is unexpected, but cf. luc 'yoke' < *i̯ugom. It has been suggested that leard may be connected or has been contaminated with Gk. λιπαρός 'oily, shiny with oil, anointed| fatty, greasy'. A minority view has compared Arm. leard with Hitt. lišši- 'liver'.}];172[II:391{S.v. Ved. yákar- (yakn-) 'Leber', from an IE heteroclite stem *Hi̯ekʷ-r-/*Hi̯ekʷ-n- (cf. Gk. ἧπαρ, ἥπατος, Lat. iecur, iocineris, 'Leber', etc.).}];353[211{Cf. s.v. Lith. jẽknos (OLith., dial.) 'liver', from PIE *iekʷ-r/n- (cf. Skt. yákar- 'liver', Gk. ἧπαρ 'liver'). Other Baltic cognates include Latv. aknas (nom.pl.) 'liver', OPruss. lagno [iagno] 'liver'.}];54[296{S.v. Lat. iecur 'liver' (gen.sg. iocineris), from PIE *iekʷ-r/n- 'liver'.}];352[413-414{Cf. s.v. OLith. jẽknos 'Leber' (BSl. Latv. (tahm.) jȩknas 'Leber', Latv. aknis, Latv. (hll.) aknys 'id.', OPr. jagno 'Leber'), from PIE *Hi̯ekʷ-r/n-, *Hi̯okʷ-r/n- 'Leber' (cf. Ved. yákr̥t, G.sg. yaknás 'Leber', OAv. NA.sg. yākarə 'Leber', Gk. ἥπαρ, G.sg. ἥπατος 'Leber', Lat. iecur, iocur, G.sg. iecinis, iecinoris, iocineris, iocinoris 'Leber').}];442[601{S.v. 10394 Ved. yákr̥t- , gen. yaknás n. 'liver' RV. NB: Khowar ṣeɣún with initial ṣ- for expected ž- from contamination with ṣaṅgur 'entrails'.}];657[356{Cf. s.v. LIVER: *i̯ekʷr̥(t) 'liver' "Presumably the most likely candidate for the PIE word for 'liver'", but not entirely certain in view of Hitt. lissi-, which might be a very old word for liver replaced everywhere else by *i̯ekʷr̥(t), or more likely an Anatolian innovation.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *i̯e/okʷ-r/n-, generally presumed to be the PIE inherited word for 'liver' ([NIL](src-274) 392-395, [EIEC](src-657) 356, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):522, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):306-307, [EWAia](src-172) II:391, [ALEW](src-352) 413-414, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):296).

Source: 172[II:99{S.v. Ved. párvata- adj. 'felsig', m. 'Berg, Gebirge, Fels', from PIE *péru̯n̥to- 'felsig, mit Fels versehen', cf. Hitt. peru- (peruni, dat.-loc.) 'stone' < *perur < *peru̯r̥, *perun-/*peru̯n̥-.}];80[668-669{Cf. s.v. Hitt. peru / perun- 'rock, cliff, boulder', generally assumed from PIE *pér-ur / *pér-un- (cf. Skt. párvata- 'rocky, rugged| mountain' < *pér-u̯n̥-to-) with dissimilation of final -r in the nom.sg. form.}]
Justification: Pāli pabbata 'mountain' from Vedic párvata- (adj.) 'stony', (n.) 'mountain, mountains, stone', as though from PIE *péru̯n̥to-, cf. Hitt. peru- 'stone' ([EWAia](src-172) II:99, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):668-669).

Source: 764[345{S.v. Khw. kʾm 'Mund' (cf. Oss. kom 'id.', Pers. kām 'Gaumen, Mund').}];156[I:598-599{S.v. Oss. kom 'рот', etc., from a Common Iranic word, although there are no attestations from Old Iranian languages.}];331[4:169-170{S.v. Proto-Iranic (1) *kah- : kas- 'открывать(-ся), отверзать, разверзать', cf. Ved. kas- 'трескаться, раскалывать(-ся) from PIE *kas- or *kʷas- (not *kes-), from which is derived Proto-Iranic *kāhman-, or *kāman- > Oss. kom 'рот', Chor. bž-kʾm, pž-kʾm 'криворотый, тот, у кого кривой рот'.}];172[I:332-333{Cf. s.v. Ved. √kas- 'bersten, sich spalten, brechen', etymology unclear. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:599 connects Iranian words like Oss. kom 'Mund, Öffnung, Spalte' < *kahman-.}]
Comment: cf. Ossetic kom and NP kām „gums, palate“
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kāhman- 'mouth, opening', further connected in Indo-Iranic to the Vedic root √kas- 'to burst, split, break' according to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:598-599, [ESIJa](src-331) 4:169-170, although cf. the scepticism of further connections to Vedic √kas- in [EWAia](src-172) I:332-333.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron fənz 'nose' might be loan from W. Caucasian according to Abaev. According to Rastorgueva & Èdelʼman (2007:49), rather related to the PIr. root *faź- etc., cf. Classical Persian pōz 'frontal part of the face', Kurdish pūz, pōz 'nostril', Balochi pōnz, pōz 'nose', Khwarezmian pncwk 'nose'. A third option is that this word is onomatopoeic.}];156[I:497]
Justification: Etymology disputed, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:497, [ESIJa](src-331) III:49-51 for various proposals.

Source: 172[I:215-216, II:705{S.v. samudrá- 'breiter Strom, der durch die Vereinigung von zwei oder mehr Flüssen gebildet wird| Flut, Meer', formed from sam- (preverb 'together, with') and *udr- 'Wasser'. (cf. s.v. udán- 'Wasser' from Indo-Iranian *ud-r- / *ud-n-, based on PIE *u̯ed-).}];274[706-715{Cf. s.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).}];442[764{S.v. 13236 Skt. samudrá- m. (n. once) 'sea' RV. [udán-].}]
Justification: Originally in the sense 'delta, confluence of (river) waters' with preverb sam- 'together with, along with' + *udra- 'water' ([EWAia](src-172) II:705, I:215-216, [NIL](src-274) 706-715; cf. the Skt. n-stem udan- abstracted from the original heteroclite -r/n-stem derived from PIE *u̯ed-). For the Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):764, no. 13236.

Source: 172[II: 227{S.v. Ved. bī́ja- 'Same (des Mannes, der Pflanzen), Saat', cf. IIr. Buddh. Sogd. byz'k 'Saat, Same', parāčī bīz 'Korn, Saatkorn', Old Iranian *bīza- in proper names. Further etymology unclear.}];442[523{S.v. 9250 Skt. bī́ja- n. 'seed, semen'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:227). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):523, no. 9250.

Source: 83[67{S.v. Proto-Iranian *dau̯č-² 'to sew'. The root is exclusively (West) Iranian and is probably a borrowing from a substrate language.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *dau̯č- 'to sew', a root restricted to West Iranic and possibly substratum loanword ([Cheung 2007](src-83):67).
Parallel loans from Turkic *küčik

Source: 172[II:463-464{Cf. s.v. Ved. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen', under which Ved. rucá- 'hell, licht', roka- 'Licht' is comparable to Ir. forms (OAv., YAv. raočah- 'Licht, Lichtraum, OPers. raučah- 'Tag', Khot. rrus- 'leuchten', Parth. rwčyn 'erhellen, leuchten lassen', MP, NP rōz 'Tag', Oss. rūxs/roxs 'Licht', etc.), and ultimately based on PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten' (cf. Gk. λευκός 'licht, weiß, hell', Lat. lūx 'Licht', Goth. liuhaϸ 'Licht', Hitt. lukkizzi 'zündet an', TochAB luk- 'leuchten', etc.).}]
Justification: Connected with Avestan raočah- 'light', Old Persian raučah- 'day' ([Korn 2005](src-344)), further from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464).

Source: 83[455-456{S.v. Proto-Iranian *xšaud- 'to wash' (cf. Skt. kṣod- 'to dissolve, disintegrate'). Correspondences for this Proto-Indo-Iranian root outside of IE are unclear.}];172[I:439{Cf. s.v. Ved. √kṣod- 'zerstieben' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. xšusta- 'geschmolzen, flüssig (vom Metall)', MPers., NPers. šustan 'waschen', etc.).}];141[372{Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'zerstieben, in kleine Teile zerfallen' (IEW 625). [Verbal only IIr.]}]

Comment: Horn (1893: 85) suggests a relation to Avestan tauruna- "young", Old Indic táruṇa- "jung, zart" (probably via "fresh"). Kurdish and Kumzari suggest a simplification of *rn > r.

Source: 567[194, 203, 251, 262{Bactrian σαρδο (earlier *σαρλο, preserved in compounds e.g. βιδδιγονωγοσαρλο 'second new year (name of a month)', ασαρολο 'this year' < *ā-sardV- [cf. Chor. ʾʾsrδ, Shughni asid, etc.], παρασαρλο 'last year' < *parā-sardV- [cf. Yidgha prasāl]) < Proto-Iranian *sardV- (cf. OPers. θard-, Chor. srδ)}];172[II:616{Cf. s.v. Ved. śarád- 'Herbst [auch 'Jahr']'. The Indo-Iranian forms represent an ablauting form *ćarad-/*ćard-. Further origins of Proto-Indo-Iranian *ćar(a)d- are not certain. Perhaps as *k̑el-(e)d- to *kel-h₁- 'become warm' (Lat. calēre, Lith. šìlti, etc.), but this connection remains speculative.}];274[414-416{Cf. discussion p.415n7 to ‡k̑el-ed- and ‡k̑el-d-.}];681[46-47{S.v. Khw. srδ 'year', from Av. sarəd-, as Sogd. srδ.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes reflecting Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćar(a)d-, cf. Vedic śarád- 'autumn; year'; no further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:616, cf. also [NIL](src-274) 415n7).

Source: 442[274{S.v. 5005 Skt. challi- 'bark'.  Probably of non-Indic origin.}];399[I:405-406{S.v. Skt. challī- 'Rinde / bark' (Pāli challi, Prākrit challī), probably from the same non-IE source as colakam (coḍaḥ). Probably Dravidian, but a Munda origin is not to be ruled out.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:405-406).

Source: 442[475{S.v. 8376 *pēṭṭa (2) 'belly', 2. *pēḍḍuka- . 3. *pōṭṭa- 2. 4. *pōtta- [similar words pēṭa-, *pēṭṭa- meaning 'basket' in Middle Indic / Prakrit which may be identical].}];69[388]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from *pēṭṭa- (with variant *pōṭṭa-) (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):475, no. 8376). No further etymology.

Source: 442[654{S.v. 11225 vaḍra 'big' lex. [Scarcely with F. Edgerton JAOS 60, 229 < vr̥ddhá- ]}];399[III:130{S.v. Skt. vaḍraḥ 'groß', 'big' (prākr. vaḍḍa-, Hindī baṛ 'groß' etc. Not entirely clear| an origin from Middle Indic vaḍḍa- (~ Old Indic lex. vaḍra-) from vr̥ddhá- 'erwachsen, groß, hoch' with loss of aspiration remains possible. Alternatively a Munda origin has been postulated. [Cf. entry for references to further literature.]}]
Justification: No certain etymology, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):654 no. 11225, [KEWA](src-399) III:130 for further discussion.

Source: 172[II:62{S.v. Ved. pakṣá- 'Flügel, Fittich, Schwinge'. pakṣín- is a derived possessive adjective originally meaning 'winged', whose sense was transferred from 'winged' to 'winged creature, bird'.  pakṣín- is the source of pakkin- m. 'bird' in Pāli and other later languages, but earlier etymological origins remain unclear.}];442[430{S.v. 7636 Ved. pakṣín 'winged', m. 'bird' RV., pakṣi- m. MBh. [pakṣá-]}]
Justification: Originally a possessive adjective formation to Vedic pakṣá- 'wing' > pakṣín- 'winged'; no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:62). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):430, no. 7636.

Source: 442[255{S.v. 4711 Skt. cárvati, carváyati 'chews' Dhātup., Pañcat. [√carv: but NIA. points to both *cavv- and *cabb- (as well as *camb- , *cabbh- , *cibb- , *cobb- ) in MIA. and therefore supports F. B. J. Kuiper (EWA i 379) in separating cūrṇa- : cf. onom. *cappayati]}];399[I:379{S.v. Skt. cárvati, carváyati 'zermalmt, zerkaut / grinds with the teeth, chews', cf. cūrṇam n. 'feiner Staub, Mehl'. Etymology difficult to determine.}];172[I:547{Cf. s.v. Ved. cūrṇa- 'feiner Staub, Mehl'| etymology unclear.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4711 s.v. Sanskrit carvati, carvayati ʻchewsʼ (Dhātup.); further etymology unclear (< *kerH-?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 379, EWAia I, p. 547

Source: 172[I:343{S.v. Skt. kāla- 'schwarz, blauschwarz', not certainly explained. Perhaps from Dravidian kāḍu 'blackness, black' etc.?}];442[157{S.v. 3083 Skt. kāla- (1) 'black, dark blue' MBh. Probably a loanword from Dravidian according to [KEWA](src-399) I:203.}];756[139{Cf. no. 1494 (Ta. kār̤ 'blackness, blemish, defect', Ka. kār̤, kāḍu 'blackness, black', etc.) for Dravidian parallels.}];399[I:203{S.v. Skt. kālaḥ 'blauschwarz, schwarz / dark-blue, black', probably a loanword from Dravidian (cf. Ka. kāḷ 'Schwärze', kāḍu 'Schwärze, schwarz', Tel. kaṟa 'schwarz', etc.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kāla- 'dark-blue, black' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):157, no. 3083). Etymology uncertain, but probably a loanword from Dravidian ([KEWA](src-399) I:203, [EWAia](src-172) I:343, cf. [Burrow & Emeneau 1984](src-756):139 for Dravidian parallels).

Source: 442[292{S.v. 5306 Skt. jválati 'burns brightly' TS. [~ jvárati. -- √jval]}];141[170-171{Cf. s.v. *g̑u̯elH- 'brennen, flammen' (IEW 479).}];172[I:607{Cf. s.v. Ved. √jvar-ⁱ 'leiden', differing from √jval-ⁱ 'brennen' synchronically, but certainly from the same origin. Without certain etymology.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit jválati 'burns brightly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):292,  no. 5306). Indo-European root assignment in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 170-171, but cf. the reservations of [EWAia](src-172) I:607.

Source: 172[II:374-375{S.v. Ved. meghá- 'cloud', from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ- (via nominal derivative *h₃moi̯gʰ-o-)| cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη 'Nebel', Lith. miglà, OCS mьgla 'Nebel'.}];156[II:117{S.v. mīǧ (Iron) | meǧæ (Digor).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ([EWAia](src-172) II:374-375, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:117).

Source: 442[788{S.v. 13676 stabdha- 'firmly fixed' ŚvetUp. 2. 'stiff, paralysed, dull' MBh., 'solidified (as water)' Hariv. [√stambh].}];172[II:754{S.v. Ved. √stambh- 'befestigen, stützen', from PIE *stembʰH- something like 'stützen, versteifen, festtreten' (cf. Gk. ἀστεμφής 'fest, starr', Lith. stem̃bti 'widerstreben', etc.).}];141[595-596{Cf. s.v. *stembʰH- 'sich stützen, sich stemmen' (IEW 1012-3).}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Sanskrit stabdha- ʻfirmly fixedʼ, originally the past passive participle to Ved. √stambh- 'to affix, secure' and ultimately from PIE *stembʰH- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):788, no. 13676; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:754, [LIV²](src-141) 595-596).

Source: 172[I:456{Cf. s.v. Ved. √khod- 'hineinstoßen [des Penis]'. 'Nicht sicher erklärt'.}];442[209{S.v. 3934 *khōdd- 'dig'. 2. *khōḍḍ- . 3. *kōḍḍ- . 4. *gōdd- . 5. *gōḍḍ- . 6. *guḍḍ- . [Poss. conn. with khudáti ʻ thrusts (penis) into ʼ RV., prákhudati ʻ futuit ʼ AV.]}]
Justification: Indic lexemes possibly to be connected with Vedic √khod- 'thrusts (penis) into' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):209, no. 3934; no certain etymology outside of Indic for Ved. √khod- cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:456).

Source: 172[1:372{S.v. Ved. kurkurá- 'Hund', probably onomatopoeic after the barking 'kur kur' of a dog.  The possibility of borrowing from a Dravidian language is also possible, but not provable (cf. [KEWA](src-399) 1:237 s.v. kurkuráḥ).}];442[172{S.v. 3329 Skt. kurkurá- m. ʻ dog ʼ AV., kukkurá- m. Mr̥cch., °rī- f. VarBr̥S. 2. *kuṅkara- . [Onom. EWA i 237: cf. *karkuṭaka- , *kuccura- , *kutta- 1, *kukka- 1]}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kurkurá- 'dog', probably imitative after the sound of a dog barking 'kur-kur' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):172, no. 3329; [EWAia](src-172) I:372).

Source: 172[I:314-315{S.v. Ved. kárṇa- 'Ohr', cf. YAv. karəna-, Khot. kārra- from Proto-Indo-Iranian *kárna- 'ear'.  Etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not securely determined.}];442[143-144{S.v. 2830 Ved. kárṇa- m. 'ear, handle of a vessel' RV.}]
Justification: No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:314-315). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):143-144, no. 2830.

Source: 172[I:162{S.v. Ved. āṇḍá- 'Ei', perhaps to go back to a Proto(-Indo-Iranian?) form *ānd(r)á-.  The connection made by older literature with Proto-Slavic *jędro- 'kernel| testicle' remains worth consideration.}];81[157-158{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *ę̄drò 'kernel, core' (ESSJa VI 65-66). "The connection with Skt. āṇḍá- (RV, AV+) n. 'egg| testicle' has generally been abandoned."}];442[50{S.v. 1111 Ved. āṇḍá n. 'egg' RV.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Possibly to be connected with Proto-Slavic *ę̄drò 'kernel, core' ([EWAia](src-172) I:162), but cf. the scepticism of [Derksen 2008](src-81):157-158. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):50, no. 1111.

Source: 80[904-905{S.v. Hitt. tūu̯a (adv.) 'far', from PIE *dueh₂m (cf. Skt. dūram 'far away', Gk. δήν 'a long time', Lat. dūdum 'for a long time already').}];172[I:739{S.v. Ved. dūrá- 'fern' (adj.), 'Ferne' (n.), IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. dūrat̰ 'von fern', OAv. dūirē, YAv. dūire 'fern', etc., from PIE *duh₂-ró- to PIE *du̯eh₂- 'sich entfernen, räumlich und zeitlich erstrecken'. Cf. *du̯eh₂-m > Gk. δήν, *du̯eh₂-ró- > Skt. dūrá-, Gk. δηρός, Arm erkar 'lange dauernd| Hitt. tūu̯a- 'fern' < *duh₂-i̯o-| Lat. dūdum.}];442[370{S.v. 6495 Ved. dūrá 'distant' RV., n. 'distance' ŚBr., dūrám, dūr adv. 'far away' RV. [~ *dūna -- 2. -- √du3]}]
Justification: Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *du̯eh₂- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):904-905, [EWAia](src-172) I:739, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):370 no. 6497).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing a stem *laḍ(h)- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):633 no. 10920). Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 172[I:44-45{S.v. Ved. agní- 'Feuer| das vergöttlichte Feuer, Gott Agni', from Proto-Indo-Iranian *agni- (Ved. agní-, YAv. ºāγni- in Dāštāγni-), and certainly also cognate with Lat. ignis, Lith. ungìs, OCS ognь, all 'fire'.  The precise reconstruction of the Proto-Indo-European form is uncertain, however, since it is difficult reconcile the vocalism of the initial syllable in all varieties.}];81[364{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ogņь 'fire' (ESSJa XXXII 30-33), from PIE *h₁ngʷ-ni- (cf. Lith. ungnìs, Latv. unguns, Skt. agní-, Lat. ignis).}];54[297{S.v. Lat. ignis 'fire', from PIE *h₁ngʷ-ni- 'fire' (cf. Skt. agní- 'fire', Lith. ugnìs, OCS ognjь, Skt. áṅgāra- 'coal', Sogd. ʾnkʾyr 'hearth', Arm. acowl 'coal', Lith. anglìs, Latv. ùogle, OCS ǫglь 'coal').}];353[478{S.v. Lith. ugnìs 'fire' (Latv. uguns), from PIE *h₁ngʷ-ni- (cf. Skt. agní- 'fire| Agni', Lat. ignis 'fire', OCS ognь).}];352[1145-1146{S.v. OLith. ugnìs, ùgnis 'Feuer' (BSl. Latv. ugùns 'Feuer', OCS ognь, etc.), from PIE *h₁óngni- / *h₁n̥gnéi̯- 'Feuer' (cf. Ved. agní- 'Feuer', Lat. ignis 'Feuer'). The Indo-European lexeme is difficult to reconstruct, cf. entry in ALEW with discussion and references to further literature.}];458[32: 30-33{S.v. ognĭ.}];442[3{S.v. 55 Ved. agní- (1) m. 'fire' RV.}]
Justification: Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes, generally accepted as cognates, but a precise reconstruction of the original Indo-European proto-form remains difficult and controversial, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:44-45 [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):3 no. 55, [ALEW](src-352) 1145-1146, [Derksen 2015](src-353):478, [ESSJa](src-458) 32:30-33, [Derksen 2008](src-81):364, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):297 for further discussion. Possibly further connected to *Hengl- in [cognate set 6119](cog-6119), but the details remain uncertain.

Source: 442[77{S.v. 1697 Skt. uḍḍīyatē 'flies up' MBh. 2. uḍḍayatē MBh. 3. X *uddrāti. 4. Caus. uḍḍāpayati.}];399[I:460{S.v. Skt. ḍáyate, dī́yate 'fliegt / flies'. The retroflexion is perhaps taken over from *niẓ-ḍī- (cf. nír adīyam RV 4.27.1).}];172[700-701{S.v. Ved. √day-ⁱ 'fliegen (von Vögeln, Rossen, Wagen, Göttern)'. Further etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *uḍḍīyate ~ *uḍḍayate 'flies up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):77, no.1697), further derived from Vedic √day-ⁱ (1) 'fly'; no further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:700, [KEWA](src-399) I:460).

Source: 69[209{S.v. Nepali jamnu 'to coagulate, freeze', from Sanskrit yamáte 'is fixed'.}];172[II:399-400{S.v. Ved. √yam- 'halten, festhalten, zügeln, lenken, ausstrecken, darreichen'. Only Indo-Iranian, further connections remain uncertain.}];141[312{Cf. s.v. ?*i̯em- 'ausstrecken, hinstrecken' (IEW 505). Only Indo-Iranian.}];442[603{S.v. 10428 yamyátē '*is fixed' ('is proffered' KauṣUp.). 2. yamáyati 'controls' ŚBr. 3. yāmáyati AV. 4. *yāmana- 'fixing'. [√yam]}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √yam- 'to sustain, hold, hold up, support', further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):603 no. 10428, [EWAia](src-172) II:399-400, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 312).

Source: 172[II:201-202{S.v. Ved. phála- 'Frucht, Baumfrucht'. The etymology of Proto-Indic *pʰal-/*pʰar- is unclear.}];442[508{S.v. 9051 Ved. phála- (1) n. 'fruit' RV.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic ([EWAia](src-172) II:201-202), for Middle and Modern Indic cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):508, no. 9051).

Source: 442[673-674{S.v. 11549 Ved. vā́ra- 4 'sheep's wool (as sieve)' RV & Skt. vā́la- 'hair of tail,  tail, hair'.}];172[II:545{S.v. Ved. vā́ra-¹ 'Schweifhaare, Pferdeschweif'. The -r- ~ -l- alternation within Indic points to a probable non-Indo-European origin.}]
Comment: < Vedic vā́ra- ~ vā́la- m. 'tail hair', 'hair of animal, wool', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 545, Turner 1962-66, no. 11549, 11572
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vā́ra- (~ Sanskrit vā́la-) 'hair of tail, tail, hair' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):673-674 no. 11549). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:545 for further discussion.

Source: 54[457{Cf. s.v. Lat. pendō, pendere 'to weigh, pay', from which Lat. pensāre 'to weigh, weigh out' is a derived frequentative verb, from PIE *(s)pend-e/o- 'to spin'.}];141[578{Cf. s.v. ?2.*(s)pend- 'spannen' (IEW 988).}];423[IV:503-504{S.v. Sp. pesar, from Lat. pensare (Sp. derived adj. pesado).}];444[526{Cf. s.v. 6391 Lat. pē(n)sare 1. 'wiegen' 2. 'drücken', 3. 'denken'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):526, [DCECH](src-423) IV:503-504), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 578).

Source: 156[II:75{S.v. Oss. maryn : mard | marun : mard 'убивать'  (cf. Ved. mārayati 'убивает' OCS moriti, Russ. морить, Lith. marinti 'убивать', Germ. Mord 'убийство', etc.).}];141[439{Cf. s.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735). Cf. cs. ?*mor-éi̯e- > Ved. (AV) mārayáti 'tötet', OCS -morjǫ, -moriti 'töten'.}];172[II:318-319{Cf. s.v. Ved. √mar- 'sterben', from PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, hinschwinden, sterben' (cf. Hitt. merzi 'schwindet', Arm. meṙani- 'sterben', Gk. (Hesych.) ἔμορτεν· ἀπέθανεν, etc.).}];50[259{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *marwo- 'dead', from which OIr. marbaid is a denominative verbal formation. The original PIE adjective *mrto- (PIE *mer- 'disappear, die') was remodelled in Celtic → PCl. *marwo- on analogy to PIE *gʷiH-u̯o- 'alive' (cf. Lat. uīuus, etc.).}];442[578-579{S.v. 10066 Ved. māráyati (1) ʻ kills ʼ AV. [√mr̥].}];165[378-379{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *murϸa- 'murder', a *-to-stem to the IE root *mer- 'to die', whence the derived weak verb *murϸjan- (ON, Ic. Far. myrða, OHG murdjan, MHG mūrden 'to kill' (NB: Goth. maurϸr, OE murðor 'murder' continue an instrumental formation *mŕ-tro- to the same root).}];296[M:19{S.v. OIr. marb 'mort' (derivative marbaid 'il met à mort, il tue'), cf. W. marw 'mort', Co. marow, MBret. marf, and maru, Bret. maro. Derived fro the root *mer- signifying death and preserved in most IE languages (Skt. mriyáte 'il meurt', Lat. morior, OCS mrěti, Lith. mir̃ti). The adjective in Celtic is formed with the suffix *-wo- (cf. Lat. uīuos, Ir. beo 'vivant').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ([LIV²](src-141) 439, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:318-319, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):578-579 no. 10066, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:19, [Matasović 2009](src-50):259). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):378-379.

Source: 172[II:811-812{S.v. Ved. √has- 'lachen', possibly from Proto-Indo-Iranian *gʰas-/ǰʰas- if the connection to YAv. ǰahī-, ǰahikā- 'Dirne, Prostituierte' is accepted.}];442[811{S.v. 14021 Skt. hásati ʻ laughs ʼ ṢaḍvBr. [√has].}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:811-812). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):811, no. 14021.

Source: 172[II:71-72, 75-76{S.v. Ved. pátra- Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', derived from a heteroclitic *pat-r-/*pat-n- and cognate with Germ. Feder, Engl. feather, Old Welsh eterin 'bird', atan 'wing', etc., cf. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschießend fliegen, stürzen, fallen' from PIE *pet- (cf. Lat. petō, Gk. πέτομαι, etc.).}];141[476{Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}];442[436{S.v. 7733 Skt. páttra n. 'wing, feather' VS., [< earlier pátra-].}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):436, no. 7733). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ([EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, 75-76; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 476, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 442[115{S.v. 10951 Skt. lamba-  'pendent' MBh. ('long' in lamba- karṇa-), lambaka- m. 'plumbline' W.}];172[II:436-437{Cf. s.v. Ved. √ramb- 'schlaff herabhängen (vom Penis). Later √lamb- 'hängt herab (vorwiegend von Körperteilen gesagt)', perhaps to PIE *(s)lembʰ- (cf. Engl. limp, MHG lampen, slampen).}];141[411{Cf. s.v. *lembH- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 656-7).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10951 lamba- ʻpendentʼ MBh. (ʻlongʼ in lamba-karṇa-); PIE *lemb(H)- 'hang loosely, droop, sag, cf. LIV, p. 411
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', cf. Sanskrit lamba- 'pendent', 'long' in lamba-karṇa- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):636 no. 10951), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ([EWAia](src-172) II:436-437, [LIV²](src-141) 411).

Source: 274[387-390{S.v. *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os n. 'Mund' (IEW 784f., EIEC 387).}];80[166-167{S.v. Hitt. aiš / išš- 'mouth', from PIE *h₁eh₃-es-.  Cf. within Anatolian: CLuw. āaš- 'mouth', āaša- 'to speak(?)', HLuw. ásaza- 'to speak'| elsewhere in IE: Skt. ā́s-, Av. āh-, Lat. ōs, OIr. á 'mouth'.}];172[I:181-182{S.v. Ved. ā́s- 'Mund, Gesicht, Antlitz', probably from PIE *h₃éh₁-s-, *h₃éh₁-es- (cf. YAv. āh- 'Mund', Hitt. ai̯is-, Lat. ōs, OIr. ā 'Mund').}];54[436{S.v. Lat. ōs, ōris 'mouth', from PIE *h₃eh₁-os, -es- 'mouth' (cf. OIr. á 'mouth', Hitt. aiš- / išš- 'mouth', CLuw. āaš- 'mouth', Skt. ā́s- 'mouth', Av. āh-).}]
Justification: Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ([NIL](src-274) 387-390, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):166-167, [EWAia](src-172) I:181-182, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):436).

Source: 442[744{S.v. 12828 Skt. saṁkula- 'crowded together, dense, disordered', n. 'battle' MBh., 'crowd'.}];399[I:211, III:416{S.v. saṁkulaḥ 'full, filled with, abounding in', probably from kírati 'pours out, spreads, throws' probably to TochB kär- 'abschneiden' and perhaps Gk. σκαίρω, MHG scher(e)n, but not fully clear.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit saṁkula- 'crowded together, dense, disordered' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):744 no. 12828). further etymology unclear, cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:211, III:416 for further discussion.

Source: 66[469{Cf. s.v. Gk. ἐρωή (2) 'withdrawal, rest', from PIE *h₁reh₁-u-eh₁ (cf. Gmc. *rōwō in OHG ruowa 'silence', OE row, ON ró 'rest' beside PGmc. *rēwā- > OHG rāwa 'rest'.}];172[II:443-444, 447{S.v. Ved. rā́trī- 'Nacht'. Originally an epithet to either nákt- or kṣap- and probably to be analysed as rā́-tr-ī *'still machende, beruhigende' to √rā-³ 'ruhen, still sein', PIE *(H)reh₁-.}];442[619{S.v. 10702 Ved. rā́trī- f. 'night' RV.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁reh₁- 'be calm' ([EWAia](src-172) II:443-444, 447; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):619, no. 10702). The reconstruction of the root-initial laryngeal as *h₁ rests on comparison to Greek ἐρωή 'rest' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):469, not in [LIV²](src-141)). A distinct root from PIE 1. *h₁reh₁- 'to question' and 2. *h₁reh₁- 'to row' in [LIV²](src-141).

Source: 442[524{S.v. 9271 *buḍḍha (2) 'old'. [Initial b- in all lggs. seems to preclude direct derivation < vr̥ddhá- 2. Either same as *buḍḍha (1) (but infl. by MIA. vuḍḍh-- < vr̥ddhá -- 2) or < *br̥ḍḍha- replacing *br̥ḍha -- (√br̥h1)].}]
Justification: Initial b- in all languages seems to preclude direct derivation from vr̥ddhá- 'grown, increased, large', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):524 no. 9271.

Comment: cf. Sanskrit kṣvelati 'leaps, jumps, plays' and keli- f. 'play, sport, fun', -d- may stem from blend with Sanskrit krīḍa-, cf. Maryhofer EWAia I, p. 413, Turner 1962-66, no. 3918 s.v. *kheḍ- vel sim: "if krī́ḍati is IE., it has crossed with these"

Source: 442[205{S.v. 3881 *khiñc- 'to drag, pull'}]
Comment: Turner 1931: 128
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):205 no. 3881 *khiñc- 'to drag, pull'. No further etymology.

Source: 442[383{S.v. 6701 *dhakk- 'push, strike'. [dhakkayati 'annihilates' Dhātup.]}];399[II:88{S.v. Skt. dhakkayati 'destroys, annihilates'. Etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a root √dhakk- (cf. Sanskrit dhakkayati 'destroys, annihilates', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):383 no. 6701, [KEWA](src-399) II:88).

Comment: Parallel loans from Arabic 'carnelian, cornelian, garnet' لَعْل via Persian 'ruby'; also Indo-Iranian surname and given name ('darling'), cf. Persian لعل‎‎, Hindi लाल, Urdu لال‎, Pashto lāl‎, but cf. also ep. Sanskrit lálati , Sanskrit root lal- 'cajole, play, dally, caress' ~ laḍ- cf. Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 91, Turner 1962-66, p. 633, no. 10922, p. 640, no. 11030; epithet of Agni 'fire' is lālela-, lālilá- (Up+) - Krishna is also called "lalla" लल्ला - some conflation?
Justification: Parallel loans from Persian لال‎ / lāl 'red'.

Source: 172[II:8-9{S.v. Ved. nadī́- 'Fluß', perhaps as 'rauschend, brüllend' to Ved. √nad- 'dröhnen, brüllen, schreien, rauschen', perhaps from PIE *ned- if one may compare river names like Νέδα (Arcadia), Νέδων (Messenia), Modern German Nette, Netze.}];141[448{Cf. s.v. ?*ned- 'tönen, dröhnen' (IEW 759). The comparanda for this root outside of Indo-Iranian rely on river-names, which are not wholly reliable (cf. EWAia II 8).}];442[399{S.v. 6943 Ved. nadī́- f. 'river' RV. [√nad-].}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic; proposed etymologies outside of Indo-Iranic rely on comparisons with hydronyms which are not wholly reliable comparanda (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:8-9, [LIV²](src-141) 448). For Middle and Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):399, no. 6943.

Source: 172[II:475-476{S.v. lavaṇá- 'Salz, Seesalz', probably from *lavaná-, √lav- 'cut' < PIE *leuH-, cf. Lith. liáutis 'be cut off', Hittite (GIŠ) lu-ut-ta-i 'window' < *leu̯H-to- 'cut out'.}];141[417{Cf. s.v. *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (IEW 681-2).}];442[637{S.v. 10978 Skt. lavaṇá n. 'salt'.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes, probably originally *lavaná- 'cutting' derived to Vedic √lav- 'cut' < PIE *leu̯H- 'cut off, release' ([EWAia](src-172) II:475-476, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 417). For the Middle and Modern Indic forms attached to this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):637, no. 10978.

Source: 442[626{S.v. 10816 Skt. retra- n. 'perfumed powder' lex. [Scarcely with F. B. J. Kuiper IL xix 352 sanskritization of *reṭ- ← Mu. - *rē- ]}];399[III:73{S.v. Skt. retram, cf. s.v reṇuḥ 'Staub, Staubkorn' / 'dust, grain of dust'. "Zu riṇā́ti?" Uncertain. Cf. for further discussion on possible IE correspondences and loan hypotheses.}]
Comment: retra- n. 'perfumed powder', presumably of non-Indic origin (according to Kuiper apud Turner 1962-66, p. 626, no. 10816 "Sanskritization" of a Munda loan)
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit retra- 'perfumed or aromatic powder' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):626 no. 10816). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:73 for further discussion.

Comment: cf. Vedic bálbalī́ti (ŚB 2.3.2.11), malmalāyati  (ŚBK), balbalā kar- (Br), Sanskrit barbara- 'stammering' (cf. Greek bárbaros) - thus among the ideophonic roots *bal- ~ *bar- ~ *blV- ~ *mal- ~ *mlV-  vel sim. for 'babble, stammer, say blabla', cf. Vedic brav(i)- 'speak'; remodelled independently due to ideophonic needs, but in one or some forms inherited from PIE, cf. Mayrhofer  EWAia II, p. 217

Source: 141[122-123{S.v. *derk̑- 'hinblicken, erblicken' (IEW 213).}];172[704-706{S.v. Ved. √darś- 'sehen, Medium erscheinen, aussehen, sich zeigen' (cf. OAv. darəsānī 'ich werde erblicken', darəsəm 'ich erschaue, etc.), from PIE *derk̑- 'einen Blick auf etwas werfen' (cf. Gk. δέρκομαι 'sehe, blicke', OIr. derc 'Auge', Goth. ga-tarhjan 'kennzeichnen', OEng. torht 'klar, hell').}];442[371{S.v. 6507 *dr̥kṣati or *drakṣati ʻ sees ʼ. 2. *dēkṣati.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes backformed from the Old Indic suppletive aorist √dr̥ś- and replacing the inherited present stem paśya- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):371, no. 6507). Ultimately to be derived from PIE *derk̑- 'to see' ([EWAia](src-172) I:704-706, [LIV²](src-141) 122-123).

Source: 141[545{S.v. *si̯eu̯H- 'nähen' (IEW 915-6).}];172[734{S.v. sī́vyº- 'nähen', from PIE *si̯eu̯h₁-/*si̯uh₁- (cf. Lat. suere, Goth. siujan 'nähen', Lith. siū́ti 'nähen, benähen, schneidern' Hitt. šum(m)anzan- 'Strick, Seil', etc.).}];83[136-137{S.v. Proto-Iranian *hi̯au̯H- 'to sew', from PIE *si̯eu̯h₁- 'to sew'.}];81[487{S.v. Proto-Slavic *šiti 'sew', from PIE *siuH- (cf. Skt. sī́vyati, Lat. suere, Go. siujan).}];165[437-438{S.v. Proto-Germanic *siujan- 'to sew', from PIE *siHu-ie-.}];54[600{S.v. Lat. suō, -ere 'to sew', from PIE *siuH-ie/o- 'to sew'.}];442[776{S.v. 13444 Ved. sī́vyati 'sews' RV. 2. sīvayati Lalit. [√siv].}];353[400{S.v. Lith. siū́ti 'sew' (Latv. šũt 'sew'), from PIE *sih₂u- (< *sh₂-i-u-), cf. Proto-Slavic *šìti, Skt. sī́vyati, Lat. suere, Goth. siujan).}];352[917-918{S.v. OLith. siū́ti 'nähen' (BSl. Latv. šũt 'nähen', OCS šiti 'nähen, sticken', etc.), from PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'nähen' (cf. Ved. sīvy- 'nähen', Lat. suō, -ere 'nähen', Goth. siujan 'nähen', etc.).}];595[4: 50-51{PS *šiti is derived from PIE *si̯uh₁/h₃-.}];444[203{Cf. s.v. 2174 Lat. consuere 'nähen'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'to sew' ([LIV²](src-141) 545, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:734, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):766 no. 13444, [Cheung 2007](src-83):136-137, [ALEW](src-352)  917-918, [Derksen 2015](src-353):400, [Derksen 2008](src-81):487, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):437-438, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):600, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):203 no. 2174).

Source: 172[I:789{Cf. s.v. Ved. dhā́ra-² 'Schneide (des Schwertes, des Messers)' (cf. YAv. dārā- 'Klinge', tiži.dāra- 'mit scharfer Schneide', Khot. dārā- 'Schneide' CSogd. xγry d'r 'sword-blade', Pašto lōr 'Seite, Rand', from IIr. *dʰārā- 'Klinge, Schneide'). Outside connections not certain.}];442[389{Cf. s.v. 6793 Ved. dhā́rā2 f. 'sharp edge, rim, blade' RV., 'edge of mountain' lex.}]
Comment: cf. Proto-Indo-Iranian *dʱā́rā- f. 'blade, cutting edge' > Vedic dhā́rā- f. 'id.'; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 789; parallel Indic noun to adjective derivations
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic dhā́ra- 'blade (of a sword, knife)' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):389 no. 6793), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'id.', but without certain comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:789).

Source: 141[183{S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾eH(i̯)- 'singen' (IEW 355).}];83[94{S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaH-³ 'to sing, call', from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eH-(i)- 'to sing' (cf. ORuss. gajati 'to croak [ravens]', Lith. giedóti 'to sing').}];172[I:482-483{S.v. Ved. √gā-² 'singen, besingen, in singendem Ton sprechen', probably PIE *geh₂-i̯- (cf. ORuss. gajati 'krächzen' (Rabe), Lith. giedóti (1.sg. gíedu) 'singen').}];353[174{S.v. Lith. giedóti 'sing' (Latv. dziêdât 'sing'), from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eHi- (cf. Skt. gā́yati 'sing'). "In Baltic the root *g⁽ʷ⁾eHi- apparently received an enlargement *-d⁽ʰ⁾-."}];442[221{Cf. s.v. 4135 Ved. gā́yati 'sings' RV. 2. gāpayati MBh. [√gai].}];352[320-321{S.v. OLith. giedóti 'singen, krähen (Hahn)'. The East Baltic family is connected with ORu. gajati, gaju 'krächzen' and Ved. gā-, gā́yati 'singen' to a root *geH(i̯)- or *gʷeH(i̯)- 'singen'. To this the Baltic forms alone show a -d- after the original root, which is analysed as an enlargement or a reanalysed present-stem formation in *-d⁽ʰ⁾-e/o-. A further possible point of departure could be a connection of *geH(i̯)- (vel sim.) as a root noun with a continuation of IE *dʰeh₁- 'place, set, lay', originally the univerbation of a light-verb construction.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eH(i̯)- 'to sing' ([EWAia](src-172) I:482-483, [Cheung 2007](src-83):94, [ALEW](src-352) 320-321, [Derksen 2015](src-353):174, [LIV²](src-141) 183). The Baltic forms show an extra *-d- added to the basic root, sometimes considered a root enlargement, but may be also accounted for via various other explanations (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 320-321 for further discussion).

Source: 54[151, 160{Proto-Italic *kuti- from PIE *(s)kHu-t-i- 'skin, hide', cf. AGk. σκῦτος 'leather, skin', Middle Welsh eskit 'shoe' < *ped-skūt-| Old Prussian keuto 'skin', Lith. kiáutas 'shell, rind' < *keHu-to-. - s.v. cūlus: Maybe PIE *keh₂u- 'to cleave'?}];165[251f.{Also cognate: OPru. keuto 'skin', Lith. kiáutas 'shell, rind, peel'| MIr. codal 'hide, skin' and Lith. kiáuklas 'shell'. Does not mention the Greek forms.}];66[810, 1363{s.v. κύτος and σκῦτος. Beekes reconstructs a root form *(s)keHu- s.v. κύτος and *(s)keh₁u- s.v. σκῦτος.}];352[486-487{Cf. s.v. OLith. kiáutas 'Schale' Either PIE *(s)keu̯h₂- 'stochern' or PIE *(s)keu̯H- ~ 'bedecken, umhüllen'.}];415[1296-1298{S.v. OHG hût 'Haut, Fell, Trieb', from Proto-Germanic *χūđi-. Different derivations in the individual language branches from PIE *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover' (cf. the explanation of Greek σκῦτος as a nominalisation of a past participle *skuH-tó- 'covered' with an accent shift as suggested by S. Neri).}]
Comment: A general shape of the root as *(s)keu̯H- seems probable. Only Beekes assumes *(s)keHu-. However, alternative explanations of the Greek forms are presented by ALEW and EWA.The root might be identified with  *(s)keu̯h₂- 'stochern, ritzen' (LIV² p. 561) or for the time being accepted as *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover' without laryngeal identification (cf. IEW 951ff.).

Source: 141[126-127{S.v. ?*dreh₁- 'schlafen' (IEW 226). Only Ved., perhaps a contaminated form of 2. *drem- (Lat. dormiō, possibly also OCS -drěmljǫ), but alternative explanations are also possible.}];442[411{Cf. s.v. 7200 nidrā- f. 'sleep' RV. and 7201 nídrāyati 'falls asleep, sleeps' ŚBr. [√drai]}];172[I:757-758{S.v. Ved. √drā-² 'schlafen, schlummern', from PIE *dreH-, probably an extended root (*dr-eH-) related to *dr-em- (Lat. dormīre, ORuss. drěmati) and *dr-dʰ- (Gk. δαρθάνω).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √drā- 'to sleep, slumber' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):411 no. 7200, 7201). Further root etymology uncertain, perhaps to ?*dreh₁- 'to sleep' ([LIV²](src-141) 126-127) if OCS -drěmljǫ is a contamination of this root with PIE 2. *drem- ([LIV²](src-141) 128), but this remains uncertain (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 126-128, [EWAia](src-172) I:757-758 for further discussion).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):279 no. 5071).

Source: 141[536{Cf. s.v. *serp- 'kriechen, schleichen' (IEW 912).}];369[183-184{S.v. Alb. gjárp/ër, -ri / gjárpën 'Schlange'. Since long generally connected to PIE *serp- (cf. Ved. sarpá- 'Schlange', Lat. serpēns 'ds.') via a Proto-Albanian nomen actionis *sérp-e/ono-.}];105[130{S.v. Alb. gjarpër ~ gjarpën, from Proto-Albanian *serpena and to be connected with Lat. serpēns 'snake, serpent', serpō 'crawl', derived from PIE *serp- 'to crawl'.}];172[II:710{S.v. Ved. √sarp- 'kriechen, schleichen', from which Ved. sarpá- 'Schlange, Natter' is derived. Ultimately from PIE *serp- (cf. Gk. ἕρπω 'schleiche, gehe', Lat. serpō 'krieche, schleiche', etc.).}];54[558{S.v. Lat. serpō, -ere 'to crawl, glide', from which Lat. serpēns 'snake, serpent'. The verbal stem is derived from PIE *serp-e/o- 'to creep' (cf. Skt. sárpati 'to creep, crawl', sarpá- 'snake, adder', Gk.  ἕρπω 'to creep, crawl', ἑρπετόν (Lesb. ὄρπετον) 'animal that goes on all fours', Alb. gjarpër 'snake').}];442[766{S.v. 13271 sarpá- m. 'snake' RV., sarpī- f. MBh. [√sr̥p].}];444[648{S.v. 7855 Lat. serpens, -ente 'Schlange', 2. *serpes, -is.}]
Justification: Albanian, Indic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *serp- 'to creep' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):183-184, [Orel 1998](src-105):130, [EWAia](src-172) II:710, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):766 no. 13271, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):558, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):648, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 536).

Source: 442[497{S.v. 8857 Skt. prastará- m. 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' RV., 'flat surface' Mn., '(v.l. prastāra -- ) plain' Hariv., 'rock, stone' Hit. [√str̥].}];172[II:187, 756-767{S.v. prastará-, cf. s.v. √star-¹ 'ausbreiten, streuen', from PIE *sterh₃-, cf. Gk. ἐστόρεσα 'habe ausgebreitet', στόρνυμι 'breite aus, streue hin', Lat. sternere 'hinbreiten', OIr. sernaid 'breitet aus', etc.}];141[599-600{Cf. s.v. *sterh₃- 'hinbreiten, ausbreiten' (IEW 1029-30).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 497, no. 8857 s.v. prastará- m. 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV), later 'flat surface' Mn., 'plain', 'rock, stone' Hit.; Pali Prakrit patthara- m. 'stone', from PIE 'strew' cf. LIV, p. 599
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic prastará- 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV.), later 'flat surface', 'stone', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):497 no. 8857, [EWAia](src-172) II:187, II:756-757, [LIV²](src-141) 599-600).

Source: 442[733{S.v. 12632 śōdhya- 'to be cleaned' Mn. [√śudh]}];172[II:657{S.v. Ved. √śodh- 'reinigen, rein machen'. IIr. *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- perhaps from PIE *(s)k̑eu̯-dʰ- with a root enlargement of *(s)k̑eu̯-, but connections outside IIr. otherwise unclear.}];141[330{S.v. ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'rein werden' (IEW 595). Root mechanically reconstructed for PIE| there are no cognates outside of Indo-Iranian.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12632 s.v. śodhya- 'be clean(sed)'; cf. LIV, p. 330
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit śodhya- 'to be cleaned' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):733 no. 12632), further derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make clean', but further cognates outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:657). [LIV²](src-141) 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9106; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):512 no. 9106.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3949, Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 314
Justification: Only attested in Sanskrit lexicographical works as gaccha- 'tree' (cf. Pāli gaccha- 'tree') but comparative phonology of Modern Indic forms point back to an original unattested form *gakṣa- 'tree'. Further etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) I:314, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):211 no. 3949).

Source: 141[680{S.v. *u̯emh₁- 'erbrechen' (IEW 1146).}];460[245{Tsakonian τσ̔ιμού < AG ἐξ-ἐμῶ.}];66[416-417{S.v. ἐμέω 'to vomit', from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'vomit' (cf. Skt. vam-ⁱ 'to vomit, spit out', Gk. ἐμέω, Lat. vomere, Lith. vémti 'to vomit').}];172[II:534-535{S.v. Ved. √vam-ⁱ 'ausspeien, erbrechen, von sich geben', from PIE *u̯emh₁- (cf. Ved. vam- 'speit aus', Gk. ἐμέω 'erbreche', Lat. vomō, -ere 'erbrechen').}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic Lexemes from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'to vomit' ([LIV²](src-141) 680, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):416-417, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):245, [EWAia](src-172) II:534-535, [Cheung 2007](src-83):417, [ALEW](src-352) 1216, [Derksen 2015](src-353):497, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):690).

Source: 442[389{S.v. 6803 Skt. dhā́vati (2) 'rinses, washes, polishes' RV. 2. dhāvayati (2) 'washes' Mn. 3. dhāvita -- 'purified' MBh. [√ dhāv2]. For Pāli cf. no. 6886 *dhauvati 'washes' SV.}];172[I:782-783{S.v. Ved. √dhav-ⁱ 'schütteln, rasch hin und herbewegen, erschüttern', from PIE *dʰeu̯H- (cf. ON dȳja 'schütteln', prob. also Gk. θυνέω 'stürme, bewege mich schnell', θῡ́νω 'tobe, wüte').}];141[149-150{Cf. s.v. *dʰeu̯H- 'rasch hin und her bewegen, schütteln' (IEW 261-3).}]
Comment: cf. Skt. dhávati 'cleans' (Turner 1931: 329)
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √dhav-ⁱ 'to run, flow, stream, glide, swim', further to PIE *dʰeu̯H- 'to move quickly back and forth' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):389 no. 6803, [EWAia](src-172) I:782-783, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 149-150).

Source: 442[456{S.v. 8082 Skt. pānī́ya 'water' MBh. [√pā1].}];172[II:113-114{Cf. s.v. √pā-² 'trinken', from PIE *peh₃-/*ph₃- (~ *peh₃-i̯-/*ph₃-i- → *pih₃-).}];141[262{Cf. s.v. *peh₃(i̯)- 'trinken' (IEW 839-40).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit pānīya- 'water' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):456 no. 8082), a derivative of Vedic √pā- 'to drink' and further to PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ([EWAia](src-172) II:113-114, [LIV²](src-141) 262).

Comment: extracted from compounds in catur- via 'square', thus 'squared', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4534 and 4595ff.

Source: 172[II:62{S.v. Ved. pakṣá- 'Flügel, Fittich, Schwinge' (Ind. Pā. pakkha- 'Flügel, Seite', pakkin- 'Vogel', etc.). Further connections remain unclear.}]

54[115{S.v. Lat. cinis -eris 'residue of fire, ashes, ashes of a dead person'. From an s-stem *ken-is-.  de Vaan reconstructs the s-stem as an extension of an earlier PIE i-stem noun *kon(H)-i- / *ken(H)-i- 'dust', of which Latin cinis continues the e-grade.  Compares to Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' from the o-grade, TochB kentse 'dust' < *koniso-.  Dismisses Walde-Hofmann (1938-1954)'s connection to PIE *kneh₂- 'to plane, rub' (Ancient Greek -κναίω) as 'not compelling).}];105[147{S.v. Alb. hi ~ hî 'ash', from Proto-Albanian *skina, with s mobile, related to Lat. cinis 'dust, ash'.}];345[207{Pace [de Vaan 2008](src-54):115 TochB kentse is to be glossed as 'rust' not 'dust' and the Tocharian cognates proposed there are not to be connected.}];571[74{S.v. Alb. hi 'ash', following Meyer (1891:152) to be connected with Lat. cinis, cineris via an s-mobile root variant.}];585[152];444[182{Cf. s.v. 1929 cinis, -ere 'Asche'.}]
Justification: Italic and Albanian lexemes from PIE *(s)ken(H)- ([Meyer 1891](src-585):152, [Huld 1984](src-571):74, [Orel 1998](src-105):147, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):115). Pace [de Vaan 2008](src-54) lexemes from Tocharian B kentse 'rust' are not to be connected (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):207). For Romance lexemes from Latin cinis, cineris, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):182 no. 1929. Cf. Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' in [cognate set 6166](cog-6166).

Source: 54[180, 667{S.v. Lat. dorsum 'the back, a ridge', a compound of dē- 'away from' and versus 'turned towards', i.e. *dē-worsum 'turned away from' > *dēorsum > deorsum > dorsum, as Paul. ex F. considered. In the sense 'the turned away part'| Lat. versus 'turned towards' from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around' (cf. s.v. ve/ortō, -ere 'to turn around').}];316[184{S.v. dorsum, -ī 'le bossu, le gros dos', the etymology conjectured by P. F. 60,18 'dorsum dictum qui pars ea corporis deuexa sit deorsum' is no doubt a popular etymology, but there are no better suggestions.}];444[247{S.v. 2755 Lat. dorsum 'Rücken', 2. dossum.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin dorsum 'back' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):247). The etymology as though from Latin *dē-uorsum is based on a popular etymology from Festus, but there are no better suggestions. If so, then the lexemes continue a derivative of PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):184, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):180, 667).

Source: 316[380{S.v. Lat. malus 'mauvais, méchant', Etymology uncertain. Appearance of Oscan dolud malud, perum dolom mallom in the Tabula Bantia may give evidence for Proto-Italic *malo-, however this legal phraseology in Oscan may have been borrowed from Latin.  Scattered attestation of lexemes such as Old Irish mell 'destruction', Ancient Greek μέλεος 'idle, unhappy', Classical Armenian meł 'sin', Lithuanian mẽlas 'lie', Latv. màlds 'mistake', suggest a possible PIE *mol-o-.  Because of the different semantics, however, this connection remains uncertain.}];54[360{S.v. Lat. malus 'unpleasant, bad', from Proto-Italic *malo- (cf. O mallom, malom [acc.sg.], either from O. *malu̯o-/*mali̯o- or a borrowing from Latin), from PIE *mol-o- 'bad'? (cf. OIr. mell 'destruction', Gk. μέλεος 'idle| unhappy', perh. βλασφημέω 'to slander'| Arm. mel 'sin', Lith. mẽlas 'lie', Latv. màlds 'mistake'. "The etymology given here is proposed by [[Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316)]. It is semantically fine, but since it concerns a collection of largely isolated words in different IE branches it remains uncertain."}];444[429{S.v. 5263 Lat. malus 'schlecht'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):380, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):360 for a survey of proposed extra-Italic cognates. For the Romance lexemes cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):429.

Source: 54[647, 662{S.v. Lat. venter, -tris 'belly, abdomen'. Latin uenter is generally agreed to be from PIE *(H)ued-ro- 'belonging to the belly' however the exact origins of the word-internal nasal is unclear.  Cf. also s.v. uterus  'womb, belly' < *(H)ud-ér-o- for the sound change of medial *-d- > -t- in this word.}];172[I:216{S.v. Ved. udára- 'Bauch'. The precise reconstruction is difficult to ascertain, but the word should not be split from OPruss. weders 'belly, stomach', Lith. vė́deras 'guts, belly, abdomen', Lat. uterus 'abdomen, belly, uterus'.}];352[1204{Cf. s.v. OLith. vė́daras 'gefüllter Schafsmagen, Wurst' (BSl. cf. Latv. vȩ̂dȩ̀rs, vȩ̂dàrs 'Bauch', OPr. weders 'Bauch', etc.), connected with Ved. udára- 'Bauch| Mutterleib', YAv. udarō.θrąsa- 'auf dem Bauch kriechend' (epithet of snakes). The Proto-Baltic form probably goes back to a Vr̥ddhi formation (cf. entry in ALEW for extensive discussion of the stem-formation in Baltic).}];353[494{Cf. s.v. Lith. vė́daras 'sausage, (coll.) belly, intestines', from PIE *ud-ero-m (cf. Skt. udára- 'belly, womb', Gk. ὕδερος 'dropsy', Lat. uterus 'belly, womb'). Other cognates in Baltic include Latv. vȩ̂dȩrs 'belly', OPruss. weders 'belly'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes generally considered cognate, but the specific root reconstruction is difficult. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:216, [ALEW](src-352) 1204, [Derksen 2015](src-353):494, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):647, 662 for further discussion.

Source: 54[270{S.v. Lat. grandis 'grown up, big, tall'. Etymology unclear.  Previous proposals in Walde-Hofmann (1938-1954) to connect Lat. grandis to a root *gʷʰrnd- (Ancient Greek βρένθος 'pride' OCS grǫdь 'breast') dismissed on the basis of poor semantic comparison.}];444[327{S.v. 3842 Lat. grandis 'groß'.}];316[281{S.v. Lat. grandis 'grand'. The etymology of this word is unknown.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin grandis 'full-grown, large, great', further etymology obscure ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):327 no. 3842, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):281, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):270).

Source: 54[65-66{S.v. Lat. avis 'bird', from Proto-Italic *awi- (Umbrian avif), from PIE *h₂eui- 'bird' (cf. Skt. váy- [nom.sg. véḥ/viḥ], YAv. vii- 'bird', Gk. αἰετός (< *h₂eu̯i-eto-), Arm. haw 'bird').}];172[II:507-508{S.v. Ved. váy- 'Vogel' (cf. Kho. boik, Singh. viyā 'Vogel') < PIE *h₂u̯ei̯- (cf. Arm. haw, Lat. auis 'bird', Gk. αἰετός 'eagle', etc.).}];79[398-399{S.v. Arm. haw₁ 'bird', connected with Lat. avis, -is, and other words belonging to the PIE word for 'bird' (Gk. αἰετός < *awi-etos 'eagle', Skt. váy- YAv. vaii-, etc.).}];442[659{S.v. 11304 váyas- (1) n. 'bird' RV. [ví-]. Kho. boik 'bird' (< *vayaska- ?), Si. viyā.}];444[65-66{S.v. 827. Lat. avicella 'kleiner Vogel', 2. aucella.| 828. Lat. avicellus 'Vogel', 2. 'aucellus'| 831 Lat. avis 'Vogel'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' ([EWAia](src-172) II:507-508, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):659 no. 11304, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):65-66, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):65-66, nos. 827, 828, and 831). For Hellenic and Armenian lexemes attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):35, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):398-399).

Source: 54[409{S.v. Lat. niger 'black, dark'. Unknown etymology.}];316[441{S.v. Lat. niger 'noir'. Etymology unknown.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):441, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):409).

Source: 80[256-260{S.v. Hitt. ēšḫar-/išḫan- 'blood, bloodshed', from PIE *h₁ésh₂-r̥, gen. *h₁sh₂-én-s (cf. Ved. ásr̥k/asnás, TochA ysār, TochB yasar, Gk. ἔαρ, Latv. asins, Lat. sanguen/sanguis).}];345[525{S.v. TochB yasar 'blood', which with TochA ysār reflect Proto-Tocharian *i̯äsār from the PIE 'collective' form *h₁ésh₂ōr (cf. non-collective in Hitt. ēshar, CLuw. āshar-sa, Gk. ἔαρ, Skt. ásr̥k (gen. asnás), Arm. ariun, Old Lat. as(s)er, Latv. asins, all 'blood').}];79[138{S.v. Arm. ariwn 'blood', to be connected with Gk. ἔαρ 'blood', Skt. ásr̥j-, from PIE *h₁esh₂r. One assumes a development *h₁esh₂r > *ehar > *ar- + suff. -iwn, although the function/origin of the suffix is unclear.}];353[526{S.v. Latv. asins 'blood', from PIE *h₁esh₂-r-, h₁sh₂-én-s (cf. Hitt. ešḫar / išḫan- 'blood, bloodshed', Skt. ásr̥k 'blood', Gk. ἔαρ 'blood').}];54[537-538{S.v. Lat. sanguīs, sanguinis 'blood'. Generally agreed to be cognate with the old IE word for blood *h₁esh₂-r/n-. The element san- can go back to the oblique stem *h₁sh₂-(e)n-, but the origins of the element -guen or guin is less certain.}];172[I:149{S.v. Ved. ásr̥j- 'Blut' (heteroclitic with asn-), from PIE *(h₁)ē̆sh₂r̥(-gʷ?), G.sg. *(h₁)sh₂n-ós (cf. Hitt. e-eš-ḫar, G.sg. e-eš-na-aš, TochA ysār, TochB yasar, Gk. ἔαρ, Latv. asins 'Blut').}];657[71{Cf. s.v. BLOOD *h₁ésh₂r̥ ~ *h₁ésh₂ōr (nom.), *h₁sh₂nós (gen.).}];442[43{S.v. 971 Ved. ásr̥j, nom. ásr̥k, gen. asnáḥ 'blood' RV., asra- n. Kālid. 1. asn- > Pr. usũ̄̈. 2. ā̆sr- > Paš. lauṛ. ār, kuṛ. ōel, dar. āš, ar. ōstr.}];444[627{S.v. 7574 sanguis 'Blut', 2. sanguen, -ine.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁ésh₂-r̥, *h₁sh₂-én-, a heteroclitic r/n-stem, generally assumed to be the inherited Proto-Indo-European word for 'blood' ([EIEC](src-657) 71, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):256-260, [Adams 2013](src-345):525, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):138, [EWAia](src-172) I:149, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):42 no. 971, [Derksen 2015](src-353):526, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):527-528, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):627, no. 7574)

Source: 141[267{S.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9)}];274[307-311{S.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (LIV² 267f., IEW 38f.)}];165[26-27{S.v. Proto-Germanic *anan- 'to breathe' and *anadan- m. 'breath, spirit'. The simple verb PGmc. *anan- < PIE *h₂enh₁- is preserved in Gothic uz-anan. The Old Norse etc. forms anda 'breathe' go back to a denominal verb *anadōjan- from the noun *anadō-.}];345[12-13{S.v. TochB anāsk- 'breathe, inhale', without doubt a reflex of PIE *h₂en(h₁)- 'breathe' (cf. Skt. ániti 'breathes', Gk. ἄνεμος 'breath, wind', Lat. animus 'spirit, soul', OIr. anál 'breath', Goth. uzanan 'exhale', etc.).}];172[I:72{S.v. Ved. √an-ⁱ 'atmen' (IIr. cf. YAv. ā̊ṇtiiā̊ parā̊ṇtiiā̊ 'des Ein- und Ausatmens'), from PIE *h₂enh₁- (cf. Gk. ἄνε-μος 'Wind', Osc. ana-múm 'animam', Lat. animus 'Seele, Geist', anima 'Lufthauch, Atem, Seele', TochB anā-sk- 'einatmen', W. ana-dl 'Atem', Goth. uz-anan 'ausatmen', etc.).}];50[35{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *anatlā 'breath', from *h₂enh₁-tlo- based on PIE *h₂enh₁- 'breathe' (cf. Lat. animus, Gk. ἄνεμος < *h₂enh₁-mo-). [NB: the Celtic cognates in this set are either light-verb constructions with this noun, or have formed denominal verbs from this noun.]}];54[43{Cf. s.v. anhēlus 'gasping, panting', from PIE *h₂enh₁-slo- 'a breathing' (cf. OIr. anaid, ·ana 'to stay, wait', Skt. ániti 'to breathe', prāṇá- 'breath, breathing out, air', Goth. *-anan 'to breathe', TochB anāṣṣāṃ 'breathed in').}];444[38{Cf. s.v. 472 anhēla 'Atem', 2. alēna, 473 'anhēlāre 'atmen'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ([LIV²](src-141) 267, [NIL](src-274) 307-311, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):12-13, [EWAia](src-172) I:72, [Seebold 1970](src-556):78-79, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):26-27, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):38 no. 473, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):43, [Matasović 2009](src-50):35).

Source: 54[417{S.v. Lat. nūbēs, -is 'cloud', from PIE *(s)ne/ou̯dʰ- (cf. Welsh nudd 'haze', YAv. snaoδa- 'clouds').}];444[491{S.v. 5974 Lat. nūbes 'Wolke'.}];316[448-449{S.v Lat. nūbēs 'nue, nuage', cf. W nudd 'nuage', Baluči nōd 'nuée' and perhaps the hapax in Av. snaoδō which may be interpreted as 'nuée'.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neu̯dʰ- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):448-449, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):417, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):491).

Source: 54[243{S.v. Lat. frīgus, -oris 'cold, frost', from which Lat. frīgidus 'cold' (adj.) is a derived adjective. Lat. frīgor 'cold, frost' reflects PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- (cf. ῥῖγος 'cold, frost', pf. ἔρριγα 'to be cold').}];141[587{Cf. s.v. ?*srei̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'frieren, schaudern' (IEW 1004). Only Greek and Italic. The e-grade of the root is not attested and therefore uncertain.}];316[254{S.v. Lat. frīgus, -oris 'froid, froidure', seems to have an exact correspondence in Greek ῥῖγος < *srīgos.}];444[301{S.v. 3512 Lat. frīgidus 'kalt', 2. frigidus.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes from Latin frīgidus 'cold' (adj.), a derivative of Latin frīgus 'cold, frost' (n.) < PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):254, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):243, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):301 no. 3512; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 587)

Source: 443[II:992{S.v. Lat. computāre 'sum up, reckon' > Fr. compter.}];54[451-452, 502{S.v. Lat. putō, -āre 'to prune (trees), scour (wool)| make up (accounts), think, reckon' (with preverb: computō, -āre 'to calculate, reckon'), from Proto-Italic *puto- 'cut off, clean', PIE pHu-tó-. The adjective putus must be primary (and to the same root as Lat. paviō 'to thump, pound, strike' < PIE *ph₂u-i̯e/o-, cf. LIV² 481-482 s.v. *pi̯eh₂- 'schlagen'), with putāre a verbal derivative.}];444[199{S.v. 2107 Lat. computāre 'rechnen, zählen, erzählen'.}]
Justification: Romance forms from Latin computāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):199), further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- ([LIV²](src-141) 481-482), cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):451-452, 502 for an account of the stem formation within Italic.

Source: 54[101-102{Cf. s.v. Lat. cavus 'hollow, excavated, concave, deep (of water)', from which Lat. cavāre 'to make hollow' is a de-adjectival verb. Lat. cavus may be derived from PIE *k̑ouH-ó- 'hollow' (cf. OIr. cúa 'hollow', Bret. keo, kev 'cave' < PIE *k̑ouio-| Gk. pl. κόοι 'hollows, excavations, gaps, crevices, gorges' (Hesych.) < *k̑óu̯o-, Gk. κοῖλος 'hollow').}];444[172, 262{Cf. s.v. 1788 Lat. cavare 'graben, ausgraben' and 2964 Lat. excavare 'aushöhlen'.}]
Justification: Modern Romance forms from Latin (ex-)cavāre 'to dig (out)' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):172, 262), originally a deadjectival verb to Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' < PIE *k̑ou̯H-ó- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):101-102).

Source: 444[676{S.v. 8194 Lat. spŭrcus 'schmutzig'.}];316[645{S.v. Lat. spurcus, -a, -um 'sale, impur', etymology uncertain, perhaps connected to Lat. spurius 'bâtard'?}]
Justification: Romance forms from Latin spurcus 'dirty' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):676), further connections uncertain, perhaps to Latin spurius 'bastard'? (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):645).

Source: 141[523-524{Cf. s.v. *sek- 'versiegen, austrocknen (intr.)' (IEW 894-895).}];54[562{S.v. Lat. siccus 'dry', from PIE *si-sk-u- 'dry'? (cf. MIr. sesc 'dry, barren, infertile', Skt. á-saścuṣī- 'not drying up', Av. hišku- 'dry', Khot. ṣkala 'dry places', Gk. ἕσκετο φωνή 'the voice broke down', ἰσχνός 'dry, arid', Lith. sèkti 'to lower oneself, sink, dry out').}];320[414{S.v. Khot. ṣkala- 'dry places', from hišku- > ṣka- (cf. Av. hišku- 'dry', Sogd. Man. šqwyy 'dry' (*hiškuvaka-), šwkčʾ 'dry', prʾškwč 'dry'. IEW 894-895 *sek- (cf. OIr. sesc W. hysp, Bret. hesp, hesk 'dry').}];172[II:687-688{Cf. s.v. Ved. √sac-² 'versiegen, stocken, trocken sein' (IIr. cf. YAv. hi-šk-u- 'ausgetrocknet', Man. Sogd. škw- 'trocken', Khot. ṣkala 'dry places'), from PIE *sek- (cf. Lith. sèkti 'sich senken, sinken, versiegen', Hom. ἔσκετο φωνή 'es stockte die Stimme', MIr. sesc 'trocken, unfruchtbar', etc.).}];316[623{S.v. Lat. siccus 'sec'.}];444[651{S.v. 7897 Lat. siccus 'trocken'.}]
Justification: Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sek- 'to run dry, dry out' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):414, [EWAia](src-172) II:687-688, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):623, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):562, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):651 no. 7897, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 523-524). For the Goidelic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:96, [Matasović 2009](src-50):337.

Source: 54[440, 498{S.v. Lat. pulvis, -eris 'dust', from PIE *pe/olH-u- 'chaff', which was further extended in Italic with an *-is- suffix| cf. Lat. palea 'chaff, husk' from PIE *pelh₁- 'chaff' (cf. Skt. palā́va- < *pelH-ō̆u̯(-)| OPr. pelwo, Lith. pẽlūs, Latv. pęlus 'chaff', OCS plěvy, Ru. polóva, SCr. pljȅva 'chaff' < PIE *plH-u-(eh₂-)| Gk. πάλλω 'to swing, sway' < *plh₁-n-, aor. πάλτο). The stem could have been derived from an original root that specified a threshing motion and thus might be connected with PIE *pelh₁- 'to swing'.}];141[469{Cf. s.v. *pelh₁- 'in Schwung bringen' (IEW 801).}]

274[701-704{S.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen| durstig werden' (LIV² 637f., IEW 1078f.). The Italic forms are from *ters-eh₂-, the Celtic ones from *tērs-es- n.}];279[736, 745{Oscan tera- < *ters-ā < *ters-eh₂. Cf. O. terúm < *ters-o-.}];54[616{S.v. Lat. terra 'dry land, earth' < Proto-Italic *tersā- 'earth', terso- 'area'. Cf. PIE *ters-h₂- 'dry land' (OIr. tír 'territory| dry', OWel. tir < *tērs-o/es-).}];50[379-380{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tīros- 'land, earth' < PIE *ter-s- 'dry'.}];296[T:74-75{S.v. OIr. tír 'terre, sol'}];316[687-688{S.v. Lat. terra 'terre' < *ters-ā (cf. v. torreō).}]
Justification: Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out; become thirsty' ([NIL](src-274) 701-704, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):687-688, [Untermann 2000](src-279):736, 745, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):616, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:74-75, [Matasović 2009](src-50):379-380).

Source: 141[318{S.v. *k̑ad- 'fallen' (IEW 516).}];54[78-79{S.v. Lat. cadō 'to fall, sink' < ?*(k̑e-)k̑h₂d- 'to fall' (cf. Skt. śad- 'fall', Gk. κεκαδών 'robbing', ὑπὸ … κεκάδοντο 'they receded').}];444[135{S.v. 1451 Lat. cadere 'fallen', 2. cadēre.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑ad- 'to fall' ([LIV²](src-141) 318, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):78-79, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):134 no. 1451).

Source: 54[620{S.v. Lat. timeō, -ere 'to fear'. Etymology outside of Italic unclear. Older proposed connections with words for 'stiff' (IEW 1010-1011) are implausible, as that root (if it exists at all) must now be accounted for as ?*sti̯eH- (LIV² 603) would have yielded Lat. †tīm- < *(s)tiH-m- with a long vowel in the stem.}];316[691-692{S.v. Lat. timeō, -ēs, -uī, -ēre 'craindre, avoir peur'. Without clear etymology.}];444[724{S.v. 8737 Lat. timēre 'fürchten'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic unclear ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):691-692, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):620, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):724 no. 8737).

Source: 54[228-229{S.v. Lat. focus 'hearth, fireplace'. The etymology of focus is disputed and there are no straightforward PIE solutions.}];316[243{S.v. Lat. focus, -ī 'foyer (domestique, demeure des dieux Lares, Penates)'.}];444[292-293{S.v. 3400 Lat. focus 'Feuer'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin focus 'hearth, fireplace' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):292-293). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):243, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):228-229 for further discussion).

Source: 54[687-688{S.v. Lat. volō, -āre 'to fly', from Proto-Italic *gʷela-i̯e/o-, PIE *gʷelh₁-ie/o- 'to raise the arm, to throw' (LIV² 208). De Vaan suggests to come back to the etymology proposed by Müller, Altitalisches Wörterbuch, (1926:213), rejected by [Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954](src-175) II:828. If the original meaning was 'to raise the arm', a shift to 'fly' is quite conceivable in the connection with birds.}];141[208{Cf. s.v. *gʷelh₁- 'treffen, werfen' (IEW 471-2), without Italic cognates.}];444[788{S.v. 9431 Lat. volāre 'fliegen'.}];316[570-571{S.v. Lat. uolō, -āre 'voler (de l'oiseau)'. The connection with Ved. garútmān 'ailé' name of a celestial bird and Skt. garuḍáḥ (prakritised form of ?*garutra-?) is attractive.}];175[II:828{S.v. Lat. 1. volō 'fliege'.}];737[213]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic disputed; most recently [de Vaan 2008](src-54):687-688 favours a return to an etymology to PIE *gʷelh₁- 'hit, throw' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 208, without Italic lexemes connected) as proposed by [Müller 1926](src-737):213, but rejected by [Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954](src-175) II:828. Cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):570-571. For the Romance lexemes, see [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):788.

Source: 54[256{S.v. gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *g̑el-u- 'cold, frost, ice' (cf. Goth. kalds 'cold', OE calan 'to freeze', OIc. kala 'to freeze'). Connections with Gk. γελανδρόν 'cold' (Hesych.) are uncertain. Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS xladъ 'coolness, cool breeze', Ru. xolod' 'cold' < Proto-Slavic *xoldъ '(the) cold' may be from an extended root *g̑oldʰo-? Lat. gelāre 'to freeze' is a denominal verbal derivative from Lat. gelu- 'cold, frost, ice'.}];444[317{S.v. 3714 Lat. gelāre 'gefrieren'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin gelāre 'to freeze', derived from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):317), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):256).

Source: 54[73-74{S.v. Lat. bonus 'good', from Proto-Italic *dweno- 'good', cf. Very Old Latin duenos, duenoi CIL 1.4 (Duenos inscription), duonus (Carmen Saliare), Faliscan duenas [gen.sg.f.], duenom [nom./acc.sg.n.]. Further IE connections are disputed, cf. entry for various proposals.}];316[73{S.v. Lat. bonus (OLat. duenos, duonus).}];444[106{S.v. 1208 Lat. bonus 'gut'.}]
Justification: First attested via Very Old Latin duenos (CIL 1.4) prior to the Latin sound change *du̯- > b- (cf. also Faliscan duenas [gen.sg.f.]) permitting the reconstruction of Proto-Italic *du̯eno-; further connections uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):73, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):73-74 for further discussion). For Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):106 no. 1208.

Source: 54[269-270, 282{S.v. herba 'small plant, weed'. The earlier connection with Lat. grāmen supposed by IEW (p.454) via a dental-extended root is formally impossible if Lat. grāmen is now to be accounted for via *g̑ʰrh₁- (cf. s.v. grāmen). No further etymology.}];316[291-292{S.v. herba 'herbe'. No known cognates, without doubt a survival of a pre-Latin rural word.}];269[{Against the derivation by de Vaan (2008:269-270, 282) of Lat. grāmen to *g̑ʰrh₁-(s)men-, cf. discussion to Proto-Germanic *grasa- in [cognate set 230](cog-230) and Proto-Italic *grā̆men- in [cognate set 8369](cog-8369). In either case, the etymology of Lat. herba is uncertain (cf. also Ernout & Meillet 1985:291-292).}];444[344{S.v. 4109 Lat. herba 'Kraut| Gras'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin herba 'a small plant or herb' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):344), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):291-292, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):269-270, 282 for further discussion).

Source: 54[681-682{S.v. Lat. vireō 'to be green'. Unclear etymology.  Lat. uiridis is a derived adjective, which has been compared to isolated forms in Baltic and Germanic (Lith. veĩsti 'to breed, rear', vaĩsius 'fruit', ONor. vísir 'sprout'(?), OEng. wīse 'sprout, stem', OHG wīsa 'meadow'), but the comparisons are very uncertain.}];444[782{S.v. 9368a Lat. viridis 'grün', 2. virdis.}];316[739{S.v. Lat. uireō, -ēre 'être vert (en parlant des plantes)', with derived adjective uiridis 'vert'. No clear etymology. Celtic words such as OW guird 'herbida' are borrowings from Latin.}]
Justification: Originally a derived adjective from Latin uireō 'to be green', no further etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):739, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):681-682). For the Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):782.

Source: 54[89{S.v. Lat. capillus 'hair'. Etymology unclear. Attempts to derive capillus from caput 'head' are formally difficult.  From a phonological point of view one expects capillus to be derived from a stem *kap-n- or *kap-r-, but there are no good candidates that have a good semantic match.}];316[95{S.v. Lat. capillus 'cheveu, poil de barbe, chevelure des plants, des arbres', reminiscent of caput 'head', but the connection is not obvious formally or semantically.}];444[153{Cf. s.v. 1628 Lat. capillus 'Haupthaar'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):95, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):89, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):153 no. 1628).

Source: 54[363-364{S.v. manus, -ūs 'hand', from Proto-Italic *manu- 'hand' from PIE *mon-u- 'hand' (cf. OIr. muin 'protection, patronage'| Hitt. manii̯aḫḫ- 'to distribute, entrust' < *mn̥-i̯eh₂-| OHG munt , ONor. mund 'hand').}];80[553-554{Cf. s.v. Hitt. manii̯aḫḫ- 'to distribute| to entrust' < PIE *mn-ieh₂- (cf. Lat. manus 'hand', ON mund, OE mund, OHG munt 'hand', OIr. muin 'patronage, protection').}];269[{The abstracted IE root common to these forms would be *men-, to conventionally cite it in the full grade. This however would be a homophonous root separate from the roots 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' (IEW 726-8), 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' (IEW 729), or 3. ?*men- 'emporragen' (IEW 726) reconstructed by the LIV² (435-437).}]
Justification: Certainly to an IE root *men-, but it is not certain whether this is yet another independent root *men- or etymologically related to existing formations (cf. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' ([LIV²](src-141) 435-436, [IEW](src-49) 726-8), 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' ([LIV²](src-141) 437, [IEW](src-49) 729), or 3. ?*men- 'emporragen' ([LIV²](src-141) 437-438, [IEW](src-49) 726)).

Source: 54[61{S.v. Lat. audiō, -īre 'to hear', from Proto-Italic Pit. *au̯izdi̯e/o- 'to hear', probably based on a compound of PIE *h₂eu-is 'clearly' (cf. Hitt. au-/u- 'to see, look' < *h₂ou-, CLuw. au̯a (interj.) 'look!', Skt. āviṣ 'evidently', Av. āuuiš < IIr. Hāu̯iš, Gk. ἀΐω 'to perceive, hear', αἰσθάνομαι 'to perceive' < *h₂(e)u̯i-s-(dʰ)- '(to make) manifest', Lith. ovyje 'in reality', OCS (j)avě 'manifestly' < *h₂ēu-ēis [or loanword from Iranian?]) + *dʰh₁-ie/o- 'to render'.}];269[{As an original compound or light verb construction that has been univerbated, the morpheme being coded for cognacy here is *h₂eu̯i(s)- << *h₂eu-.}];444[61{S.v. 779 Lat. audīre 'hören'}];316[55{S.v. Lat. audiō 'entendre'. "On rapproche gr. ἀίω 'j'entends' (sans doute ancien *αϝιω), ἐπ-άϊστος, αἰσθάνομαι, et skr. āviḥ 'évidemment', gāth. āvišya- 'évident', v. sl. avě 'manifestement'. Mais la formation du mot latin est obscure".}];141[288{Cf. s.v. ?*h₂u̯ei̯s- 'hören' (IEW 78)| cf. n1 "Verbal nur gr., hierher u.U. lat. audīre 'hören', vgl. dazu Meier-Brügger, FT Wien 287-92."}]
Justification: Italic lexemes generally compared to Ancient Greek ἀΐω 'to perceive, hear', possibly from a root ?*h₂u̯ei̯s- 'to hear', but the details of the Latin stem-formation remain obscure, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):55, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):61, [LIV²](src-141) 288 for further discussion. For Romance cognates, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):61 no. 779.

Source: 423[III:166-167{S.v. Sp. golpe, from Lat. *colupus, Lat. colaphus 'puñetazo', from Greek κόλαφος 'befetón'. Sp. golpar is a secondary denominal formation from the borrowed noun golpe.}];316[131{Cf. s.v. Lat. colaphus 'taloche, coup de poing', a transcription of Gk. κόλαφος, already in Plautus colaphizō| reflexes in Romance reflect a popular word colpus with syncope of interior -a-.}];444[193{S.v. 2034 Lat. colaphus 'Schlag', 2. *colpus, 3. kolaphos (griech.).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):131).

Source: 443[2:319{S.v. Lat. *captiare 'jagen' > Old French chacier.}];54[89-90{S.v. Lat. capiō -ere 'to take', from which captāre 'to try to touch, grasp at' is a secondary derivative. Ultimately from either PIE *kh₂p-i- or non-IE *kap-i- 'to seize'.}];141[344-345{S.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-8).}];444[157{S.v. 1662 Lat. captiāre 'jagen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *captiāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):157), a secondary derivative from Latin capiō 'to take', ultimately from PIE *keh₂p- 'grasp, snatch' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):89-90, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 344-345).
