Source: 316[275{S.v. Lat. glaciēs 'glace'. Appears to be derived in some way from the same root as gelu 'cold' (adj.), but the stem formation is obscure.}];54[263{S.v. glaciēs 'ice'. "The meaning is the same as gelus, but glaciēs cannot be derived from a root *g̑l- 'to be cold' in any meaningful way."}];444[322{S.v. 3771 Lat. glacies 'Eis'.}]
Justification: Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):275, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):263 for further discussion). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):322.

Source: 423[III:878-881{S.v. Sp. matar. Etymology uncertain, possibly from a Latin verb *mattare, a derivative of mattus 'estúpido, embrutecido'| the proposed etymology to Lat. mactare 'sacrificar' is absolutely impossible from a phonological point of view.}];444[442-443{S.v. 5401 māt (pers.) 'tot' from the expression in a chess game schach māt 'the king is dead', from which the derived verbs in Spanish and Portuguese.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain (for various proposals cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):442-443, [DCECH](src-423) III:878-881).

Source: 443[11:193-201{Fr. savoir 'know' from Lat. sapere 'schmecken| wissen'.}];54[538-539{S.v. Lat. sapiō, -ere 'to taste, be intelligent, know', from PIE *sh₁p-i- 'to notice' (cf. OS an-sebbian 'to remark, notice', OHG int-seffen 'to remark, taste', OIc. sefi 'thought').}];141[519{S.v. *seh₁p- '(durch Schmecken) wahrnehmen' (IEW 880).}];444[628{S.v. 7586 Lat. sapere 'wissen'. 2. sapēre.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin sapere 'to have a good taste, taste of' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):628 no. 7586, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 11:193-201, further to PIE *seh₁p- 'to perceive (by taste)' ([LIV²](src-141) 519, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):538-539).

Source: 54[522{S.v. Lat. rīdeō 'to laugh'. There is no good Indo-European etymology.}];316[573{S.v. Lat. rīdeō 'rire', no certain etymology.}];444[603-604{S.v. 7302 Lat. rīdēre 'lachen', 2. rīdere.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):573, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):522). For the Romance lexemes attached to this set cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):603-604.

Source: 54[566{S.v. sinister 'left, on the left side, adverse'. "Next to laevus and scaevus, the meaning 'left' for sinister must be a more recent development. If -is- represents the PIE comparative suffix *-w-, to which an extra *-tero- was added, the root can be *sin(H)- or *sen(H)-. WH connect the root *senh₂- 'to obtain' (Skt. sanóti), which would imply something like 'the more favourable (side)' for *senH-is-tero- > sinister. This remains gratuitous, because the semantics are not specific enough."}];290[40{Reconstructs a form *senisteros prior to initial-vowel weakening "but the etymology is very uncertain".}];316[628{S.v. Lat. sinister, -tra, -trum 'gauche'.}];444[655{S.v. 7947 Lat. sinister 'links', 2. sinexter (after dexter).}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):628, [Sihler 1995](src-290):40, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):566). For Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):655 no. 7947.

Source: 423[IV:538-539{S.v. Sp. pierna, from Lat. perna 'muslo y pierna juntos en un animal', 'muslo del cerdo', 'zanca, en el hombre'.}];54[460-461{S.v. perna '(upper) leg, thigh', from PIE *tspērn-eh₂- 'heel' (cf. Hitt. paršna- 'unknown body part, heel?' < *persno-, paršnae- 'to squat down, crouch'? Skt. pā́rṣṇi-, YAv. pāšna-, Khot. pārrā-, Gk. πτέρνη, Goth. fairzna, OS fersna 'heel'). For the IE reconstruction given, cf. [Lubotsky 2006](src-560).}];316[499{S.v. Lat. perna 'jambe tout entière (cuisse et mollet)', in particular 'cuisse de porc, jambon', corresponding to Hitt. paršna- 'haut de la cuisse, jambon', Gk. πτέρνα, Skt. pā́rṣṇi-, Goth. fairzna 'talon'.}];172[II:123-124{Cf. s.v. Ved. pā́rṣṇi- 'Ferse', from PIE *persneh₂- 'Ferse' (cf. Lat. perna 'Hinterkeule', Goth. fairzna, OS fersna 'Ferse', Gk. πτέρνη 'Ferse', Hitt. paršina- 'Hinterbacke').}];560[1005-1101{Reconstructs IE *tpērsneh₂- 'heel', connecting with *sp⁽ʰ⁾erH- 'to kick with the foot' (Skt. sphuráti, Av. sparaiti, Lat. spernere 'to push away, despise, reject'), and positing a new verbal root reconstruction *TsperH-.}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin perna 'haunch, ham together with the leg' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:538-539). For the IE reconstruction given, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:123-124; for a proposed derivation to a verbal root *TsperH- 'to kick with the foot', cf. [Lubotsky 2006](src-560) and the discussion of [de Vaan 2008](src-54):460-461.

Source: 443[3:490-493{From Lat. iēcur fīcātum 'fig-stuffed liver'.}];54[218{Cf. s.v. Lat. fīcus 'fig-tree'. An early Mediterranean loanword, cf. Gk. σῦκον (Boeot. τῦκον), Arm. tʻowz 'fig'.}];316[232{S.v. Lat. fīcus 'figuier| figue', appears to be a Mediterranean loanword, as in other languages (cf. Gk. σῦκον, [Boeot.] τῦκον 'fig', Arm. tʻuz 'dried fig').}]
Justification: A transferred adjective from the noun phrase iēcur fīcātum 'fig-stuffed liver' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:490-493), further etymology uncertain; Latin fīcus 'fig' appears to be a Mediterranean Wanderwort, cf. Attic Greek. σῦκον, (Boeotian τῦκον )'fig', Armenian. tʻowz 'dried fig' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):232, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):218). A similar lexical replacement also occurred in the history of Greek (cf. [cognate set 1505](cog-1505)).

Source: 54[454{S.v. Lat. pēdis 'louse', from PIE *pesd- 'annoying insect' (cf. PIIr. *pazdu- 'beetle, maggot' : Skt. pedú- PN, paídva- 'the snake-killing horse of Pedu', 'an insect harming horses', YAv. pazdu- 'beetle, maggot').}];316[493{S.v. Lat. pēdis, -is 'pou'. The name of this insect differs from one language to another. Av. pazdu- designates a small annoying insect. Cf. perhaps pēdō 'péter'?}];269[{The proposed connection of [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):497 to Lat. pēdō 'to fart' is not particularly convincing semantically. We could well be dealing with a homophonous root *pesd-, distinct from PIE *pesd- 'leise furzen, fisten' ({LIV²} 829), perhaps originally onomatopoeic of a 'buzzing' noise?}];444[523-524{S.v. 6361 Lat. pēduculus 'Laus'.}]
Justification: Italic and Romance lexemes typically compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *pazdu- 'beetle, maggot'. If so we may consider a root *pesd-, perhaps identical with PIE *pesd- 'to fart quietly', although it may well be we are dealing with an independent onomatopoeic formation within PIE as *pesdu- 'annoying insect' vel sim. (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):493, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):454, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):523-524).

Source: 274[86-99{Cf. s.v. *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, *dʰg̑ʰ-ém-, *dʰg̑ʰ-m-´-, *g̑ʰ-m̥-m-´-, f. 'Erde' (IEW 414ff.).}];429[115-132];352[1323{Cf. s.v. OLith. žmuõ, žmuõj 'Mensch, Mann' (BSl. OPr. smoy 'Mann, Mensch'), from PIE *(dʰ)g̑ʰ-m-on- 'Mensch, Mann' (cf. Lat. homō, -inis 'Mensch, Mann', Osc. humuns 'Mensch', Umbr. homonus 'id.', Goth. guma 'Mensch, Mann', ON gumi 'id.', OHG gomo 'id.').}];165[195{S.v. Proto-Germanic *guman- 'man', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰm-on- (cf. Lith. žmónės (m.pl.) 'men', Lat. homō 'man' < *dʰg̑ʰm-on-).}];54[287-288{S.v. homō, -inis 'human being, man', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ(e)m-ōn- (nom.sg.), *dʰg̑ʰm-on-m (acc.sg.) 'earthling, human' (cf. OIr. duine, W. dyn, Co., Bret. den 'man' < Proto-Celtic *doni̯o-| OPruss. smunents, smūnets 'man', OLith. žmuõ 'person', Goth. guma 'man', OHG gomo, OIc. gume).}];50[156{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gdonyo- 'human, person', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰom-i̯o- 'human, earthling' (cf. Lat. homō, Goth. guma).}];269[{On the proposed cognacy of the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *mannan- to this class, cf. the notes in [cognate set 8248](cog-8248).}]
Justification: Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om- 'earth' ([NIL](src-274) 86-99, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):195, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):287-288, [Matasović 2009](src-50):156, [ALEW](src-352) 1323).

Source: 54[94{S.v. Lat. carō, carnis 'flesh, meat', from PIE *k(e)rH-n- 'piece' (cf. OIr. scaraid*, ·scara, MW yscar 'to separate', MBret. discar 'to sever' < Proto-Celtic *skara-, Lith. skìrti 'to separate', distinguish').}];141[558{Cf. s.v. *(s)kerH- 'trennen, teilen' (IEW 938-40).}];316[101{S.v. Lat. carō, carnis 'morceau de chair, de viande' originally in the sense 'part' as seen elsewhere in Italic (cf. Osc. carneis 'partis', Umb. karu 'pars', abl. karnus 'partibus'), to the same root as Gk. κείρω 'je coupe', etc.}];444[162{S.v. 1706 Lat. carō, -nis 'Fleisch'.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes continuing an n-stem to PIE *(s)kerH- 'to split, separate' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):94, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):101, [LIV²](src-141) 558). For Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):162 no. 1706.

Source: 54[388{S.v. Lat. mōns, -tis 'mountain', from Proto-Italic *monti- < PIE *mon-ti- 'protrusion, height', (cf. W. mynydd OCo. menit, OBret. monid 'mountain' < *mon-io-| Av. maiti- 'mountain, height' from zero-grade *mn-ti-| OIc. mønir 'ridge of a roof' < *mōni-, mœna 'to tower').}];141[437{Cf. s.v. ?3.*men- 'emporragen' (IEW 726)| verbal only Italic via *mn̥-h₁i̯é- > [Lat. ē-/prō-minēre 'heraus-/hervorragen'].}];236[{S.v. W mynydd 'mountain, large hill', from *monijo-, derived from IE *men- 'stretch out'.}];309[502{S.v. Bret. menez 'mont, montagne', from Old Breton monid 'montagne' corresponding to Co. meneth, W mynydd, and ScG. monadh from Proto-Celtic *mon-iyo-.}]
Justification: Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to rise, stick up' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):388, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):502, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 437).

Source: 54[76{S.v. Lat. bucca 'puffed, filled out cheek| mouth'. Etymology unclear, possibly of Celtic origin.}];316[77{S.v. bucca, -ae 'bouche'. Perhaps of Celtic origin, cf. beccus 'beak', a Gaulish loanword, and proper names Buccus, Buccō, Bucciō of Celtic origin.}];444[122{S.v. 1357 Lat. bucca 'Wange', 2. 'Mund'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin bucca ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):122). Possibly a loanword from Celtic (cf. Proto-Celtic *bek(k)o- in [cognate set 6204](cog-6204)), but ultimately unclear ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):77, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):76).
First element seems related to Lat. post ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):555 no. 6684).

Source: 54[672-673{S.v. Lat. uetus, -eris 'old', from Proto-Italic *wetos- 'year' (Umb. vesune, Mars. uesune [dat.sg.] 'the goddess *wetsōna-, lady of the year'). Ultimately from PIE *u̯et-os-Ø [n.] 'year'.}];172[II:495];352[1228{Cf. s.v. OLith. vẽtušas 'alt' (BSl. cf. Latv. vęcs 'alt| abgenutzt| vormalig, ehemalig', etc. OCS vetъxъ 'alt (Dinge)', etc.| extra BSl. cf. Lat. vetus, -eris 'alt'). The Baltic lexemes must be root-cognate with vocabulary elsewhere in IE from PIE *u̯et-, but a direct equation with the s-stem *u̯etos- (cf. Gk. ἔτος, Alb. vit) is semantically difficult and formally not probable. Cf. ALEW for further discussion of issues in the stem formation in Baltic.}];705[{Re: Sogd. wcny: Rejects Henning's etymology < *witacina- and proposes derication from *watuša- < *wetuso-. This view is also supported by the fact that the development *čn > *šn postulated by Henning (followed by Gershevtich) is ad hoc. The rare spelling appears to support Henning, but may possibly be secondary (influence of following /č/ or just for [ə]). The absence of in all other attestations is rather unusual for original *wi-.}];534[II:497-498{S.v. Latv. vecs (Lith. vẽtušas), cf. Hitt. u̯itt-, Skt. vatsaráḥ, Gk. étos, Lat. vetus from PIE *u̯et- 'gads'.}];444[775{Cf. s.v. 9291 Lat. vetulus 'alt', 2. veclus| and 9292 Lat. vetus 'alt'.}]
Justification: Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯et- 'year'. For the connection of Iranic lexemes, cf. [Szemerényi 1951](src-705) and further [EWAia](src-172) II:495. For Baltic, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1228, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:497-498. For Italic, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):672-673, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):775 no. 9291 & 9292.

Source: 443[5:36-41{Fr. jouer from Lat. iocāri 'scherzen, spassen'.}];54[308{S.v. Lat. iocus 'joke, jest', from PIE *iok-o- 'word, utterance' (cf. MW ieith, W iaith, Bret. yezh 'language', MIr., MoIr. icht 'people' < PCl. *iextV-, OHG jehan, OS gehan 'to express, utter', OHG jiht 'confession'. Lith. juõkas 'laugh, laughter', Latv. juõks 'joke' are probably borrowings from German.)}];141[311{Cf. s.v. *i̯ek- 'sprechen' (IEW 503-4).}];444[374{S.v. 4585 Lat. jocāre 'spielen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin iocāri 'to joke, jest' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):374, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 5:36-41), a denominal verb to Latin iocus 'joke, jest' and further to PIE *i̯ek- 'speak' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):308, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 311).

Source: 141[470-471{Cf. s.v. *pelh₂- 'sich nähern' (IEW 801-2).}];54[455-456{S.v. Lat. pellō, -ere 'to beat against, push, strike', from PIE *pl-n(e)-h₂- 'to approach' (cf. OIr. ad-ella* 'to visit', MW el, MCo. ello, MBret. yel, yal 'to go', Gk. πίλναμαι 'to approach'). The p.p.p. is pulsus, from which Lat. pulsāre 'to strike, beat'.}];444[566-567{S.v. 6837 Lat. pulsāre 'stoßen' > pg. puxar.}]
Justification: From Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):455-456, [LIV²](src-141) 470-471).
Loan from Spanish empujar 'to push'.

Source: 54[474-475{S.v. Lat. pluō, pluit 'to rain', from which Latin pluuia 'rain' is a derived noun. Cf. PIE *pleu̯-e/o- 'swim, float' (LIV² 487-488, IEW 835-837).}];141[487-488{Cf. s.v. *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).}];444[550{S.v. 6620 Lat. pluvia 'Regen', 2. plovia, 3. ploia.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes continuing Latin pluvia 'rain', a derived noun to Latin pluō, -ere 'to rain' and further to PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):474-475, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):550).

Source: 141[108-109{S.v. 1. *dei̯k̑- 'zeigen, weisen' (IEW 188-9).}];54[169-170{S.v. Lat. dīcō, -ere, from Proto-Italic *deik-e/o-, from PIE *dei̯k̑-e/o-| perf. stem dīxī from s-aorist *dei̯k̑-s-, (cf. Skt. diś- 'show', Gk. δείκνυμι 'to show', Goth. ga-teihan 'to indicate, proclaim', OHG zīhan 'to show, incriminate').}];444[240{S.v. 2628 Lat. dīcere 'sagen'.}]
Justification: Latin dīcere, from PIE 1. *dei̯k̑- 'to indicate, show' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):169-170, [LIV²](src-141) 108-109). For the Romance lexemes attached to this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):240.

Source: 81[521{S.v. Proto-Slavic *vìděti 'see' < PIE *u̯ei̯d- (cf. Lith. veizdė́ti 'look, look for').}];141[665-667{S.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-1127).}];66[379-380{Cf. s.v. Gk. εἴδομαι 'to appear, seem, resemble', from PIE *ueid- 'see' (thematic aorist ἰδεῖν).}];54[676{S.v. Lat. videō 'to see', from PIE *uid-eh₁- 'to see'.}];686[403-404{S.v. OPr. widdai (pret.3.sg.) 'sah', based on a secondarily lengthened zero-grade *u̯id- of PIE *u̯eid- 'erblicken'.}];259[691{PS *viděti is derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'look, see', cf. Latin videō vidēre etc.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ([LIV²](src-141) 665-667, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):379-380, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):403-404, [Derksen 2008](src-81):521, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):676).

Source: 54[80-81{S.v. Lat. caelum 'sky, heaven, vault of heaven'. Various hypotheses.}];316[83-84{S.v. caelum 'ciel', there are only uncertain hypotheses. The Indo-European inherited words for 'sky' (cf. diēs, Iuppiter) were preserved with different semantic values and renewed forms.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):83-84, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):80-81 for various hypotheses.

Source: 141[128{S.v. 2. *drem- 'schlafen' (IEW 226). Forms from Latin reflect a PIE zero-grade yod-present *dr̥m-i̯é-.}];54[179-180{S.v. Lat. dormiō, -īre 'to sleep', from PIE *drm-i̯e- 'to sleep' (cf. CS drěmati, Ru. dremat', SCr. drijèmati 'to doze, slumber' < *drēm-, Gk. δαρθάνω 'to fall asleep'.}];444[247{S.v. 2751 Lat. dormīre 'schlafen'.}]
Justification: Italic and Romance lexemes continuing Latin dormīre 'to sleep', further derived from PIE 2. *drem- 'to sleep' ([LIV²](src-141) 128, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):179-180, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):247).

Source: 423[IV:484-486{S.v. Sp. pequeño, probably of expressive origin, similar to other Romance expressions for smallness like It. pìccolo, piccìno, Fr. petit, Sard. pithinnu, etc.}];444[544{Cf. s.v. 6550 pitzinnus 'klein', 2. pīsinnus.}]
Justification: Probably of expressive or onomatopoeic origin ([DCECH](src-423) IV:484-486, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):544).

Source: 444[298{S.v. 3476 Lat. fragrare 'riechen, duften' 2. flagrare.}];54[238{S.v. Lat. fragrō, -āre, from PIE *bʰrh₁g-ro- 'smelling' (cf. MIr. brén 'putrid, foul', MW braen, Bret. brein 'putrid, corrupt' < PCl. *bragno- < *bʰrh₁g-no-| OIr. braig(a)id* -braig 'to fart' < *brag-ie-, etc.), following [Schrijver 1991](src-679):185f., [Schrijver 1995](src-305):170f., [IEW](src-49) 163.}];316[251{S.v. Lat. fragrō 'exhaler une odeur forte ou agréable'. The connection with Skt. ghrā́ti and jíghrati is attractive semantically, but phonologically problematic. Another possibility is a connection with OHG bracko 'chien de chasse', a simple possibility.}];679[185-186{[Rehearses the two possible etymologies suggested by [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316), favouring the latter to OHG but considering both uncertain.]}];305[170-171{[Proposes a connection of MIr. brén 'putrid, foul', MW braen 'putrid, corrupt', B brein 'id.' to the OHG and Latin forms, but ultimately considers the etymology uncertain.]}];776[70-71{[Regarding the proposed comparison of OIr. braigim (1sg.) 'fart' etc.] "Schrijver (1995: 170–171) suggests an alternative etymology, connecting braigim with MHG. brǣhen ‘smell’ < *brēhia̯ n, Lat. fragrāre ‘emit a (sweet) smell’ < *bʰreh₁g-, which suggest a development *brag(i̯)-e/o- < *bʰr̥h₁g-(i)̯ e/o- as well as *bʰr̥h₁g-smn̥ > bram. The closer semantics perhaps make this etymology more likely than the connection with *bhreg- ‘break’, but it is not at all certain."}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Late Latin flagrāre, Classical Latin fragrāre 'to smell strongly' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):298). Further etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected with OHG braccho 'hound', Middle Irish brén 'putrid, foul' from a root *bʰreh₁g-, in which case the Latin verb would have been deadjectival from an unattested *frag-ro- 'smelling', although this proposal remains quite uncertain (cf. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):185-186, [Schrijver 1995](src-305):170-171, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):238; further to the proposed Celtic comparanda cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):232-233, [Zair 2012](src-776):70-71). Alternatively a connection with Sanskrit ghrā́ti, jíghrati 'smells' has been considered but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):251, [Schrijver 1991](src-679):185-186).

Source: 316[504{S.v. Lat. petra, -ae 'rocher, pierre', an old borrowing from Gk. πέτρα perhaps through the language of sailors. The normal Latin word is saxum and petra is avoided by good Latin writers.}];443[8:313{S.v. Lat. pĕtra 'Stein, Fels', whence OFr. peddre, Fr. pierre.}];444[531{S.v. 6445 Lat. petra 'Stein'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin petra ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):531), an old loanword from Ancient Greek πέτρα 'rock; cliffside' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):504)

Source: 141[654{S.v. *tu̯em- 'anschwellen' (IEW 1082).}];54[663{S.v. Lat. tumeō 'to swell, be swollen', from PIE *tum-eh₁- 'to be swelling' (cf. MW tyfu, MCo. tevi, Bret. teñviñ 'to grow' < PCl. *tum-ī- < PIE *tum-eh₁-| Skt. túmra- 'strong, thick', Lith. tumė́ti 'to become thick', OIc. ϸumal-fingr 'thumb').}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of PIE *tu̯em- 'to swell up' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):663, [LIV²](src-141) 654).

Source: 54[99{S.v. Lat. cauda 'tail', from PIE *keh₂u̯- (LIV² s.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' IEW 535) via PIE *keh₂u-d- 'cleaved, separate', considering that words for 'piece, part' are often semantically derived from words for 'cut, cleave'.  Thus the 'tail' may be considered the loose 'part' of an animal.}];316[106{S.v. Lat. cauda, -ae 'queue', a popular word of unknown origin| rejects the proposed connection with Lat. cūdō 'beat, strike'.}];269[{The etymology given by de Vaan (2008:99) and others (cf. entry for further literature) has been followed in this class.}];444[170-171{S.v. 1774 Lat. cauda 'Schwanz', 2. coda.}]
Justification: Root etymology in this class follows [de Vaan 2008](src-54):99, but cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):106. For Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):170-171.

Source: 54[273{S.v. Lat. grossus 'immature fig| thick, unripe'. Etymology unclear. IEW had earlier connected Lat. grossus with Welsh bras 'thick'.}];444[330-331{S.v. 3881 Lat. grossus 'dick'.}]
Justification: From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):273), formerly connected by [IEW](src-49) 485 with Celtic *brasso- in [cognate set 4355](cog-4355).

Source: 444[526{Cf. s.v. 6391 Lat. pē(n)sare 1. 'wiegen' 2. 'drücken', 3. 'denken'.}];54[457{Cf. s.v. Lat. pendō, pendere 'to weigh, pay', from which Lat. pensāre 'to weigh, weigh out' is a derived frequentative verb, from PIE *(s)pend-e/o- 'to spin'.}];141[578{Cf. s.v. ?2.*(s)pend- 'spannen' (IEW 988).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):526), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 578).

Source: 54[50{S.v. Lat. arbor, -oris 'tree' (non-rhotacised nom.sg. arbōs found in Vergil, Ovid), from *h₃rdʰ-ōs 'uprightness' → 'upright tree', cf. arduus 'high' < *h₃r̥dʰ-u̯-o-.}];316[43{S.v. Lat. arbōs, arboris 'arbre', no certain etymology. Latin shows no trace of the IE inherited word for tree found in Hitt. taru, IIr. dāru, dru-, Goth. triu, CS drěvo, Gk. δρῦς, etc.}];444[49{S.v. 606 Lat. arbor, -ore 'Baum'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. For Latin arbor [Schrijver 1991](src-679):69 cautiously suggested a possible preform *h₃r̥dʰ-ōs to a root *h₃erdʰ- 'be upright, high' which is further tentatively considered a possibility by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):50; cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):43. For Romance forms in this set, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):49 no. 606.

Comment: fr. CeltLat. *VIRARE, cf. Gael. gwyro 'turn away, make a detour, remove' (Spanish dictionary online)

Source: 269[{Pace [Kroonen 2013](src-165), the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by [Beekes 1998](src-709)), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. [EWA 1](src-383) 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)). Regarding the Oscan form in this class, an alternative root etymology to PIE *h₂ep- is sometimes considered on the basis of the apparent lengthened root vowel as in the Indo-Iranian forms (e.g. Skt. āp-) cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):42-43, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):19), however it is possible that the lengthening of the vowel could be secondary. While it is possible that the Oscan form could preserve an isolated reflex of the root *h₂ep- as found in Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Tocharian, given that there are no other potential reflexes of the root *h₂ep- in Italic connections with Latin aqua cannot be ruled out, and it seems preferable, on the balance of probability, to connect Oscan aapam with Latin aqua < *h₂ekʷ-(e)h₂ (acknowledged by both Untermann & de Vaan). (NB: In Oscan PIE *kʷ > p).}];165[7{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *ahwõ- 'river', from PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂-. A Germanic-Italic isogloss (cf. Lat. aqua 'water'). "The word is claimed to stem from a non-IE language ([Beekes 1998](src-709)), but it is more likely to be a formal variant of Hitt. ḫapa- c. 'river', Skt. áp-, OAv. ap- f. 'water' < *h₂ep-, Lat. amnis f. 'stream, river' < *h₂ep-ni- and OIr. ab, aub f. W afon f. 'river' < *h₂epHon- (with *-pH- > *b) as in Skt. píbati 'to drink' < PIE *pi-ph₃-é-). Perhaps the cluster *-pH- developed into *-kʷ- in Germanic and Latin."}];54[19, 48{Cf. s.v. Osc. aapam [acc.sg.], aapas [gen.sg. or acc.pl] 'water', 'water basin' vel sim. "In theory, O. -p- could correspond with -qu- in Lat. aqua 'water'| but in view of long initial /ā-/ in Oscan, it seems preferable to derive it from PIE *h₂ē̆p- 'water' as attested in IIr., Baltic and Tocharian." and s.v. Lat. aqua 'water', from Proto-Italic *akwā- 'water' (cf. Goth. aƕa, OHG aha < PGmc. *aχʷō 'water'). "According to [Beekes 1998](src-709), other suggested cognates, such as OIc. ægir 'sea, ocean' are very uncertain. Even if cognate, Germano-Italic *akwā- may well be a loanword from a non-IE language."}];383[99-103{Cf. s.v. OHG aha 'Wasser(lauf), Fluß, Strom'. Outside of Germanic only the Italic cognates (Lat. aqua) are unobjectionable. < *akʷā < *h₂ekʷeh₂. Less certain are further connections to river names in Baltic and Slavic, and the word for 'river' in Celtic (W afon, Gaulish -apa) and Anatolian (Hitt. ḫapa-).}];316[41-42{S.v. Lat. aqua, -ae 'eau, considérée comme élément'. Lat. aqua has a precise correspondent in Germanic (cf. Goth. ahwa 'ποταμός', etc).}];279[42-43{S.v. Osc. aapam "Vielleicht zu idg. *ə₂ep- 'Wasser' in ai.ap- 'Wasser' und den europäischen Flußnamen mit ap-. (…) Anders Mommsen, Muller: zu aqua| [lang] a- statt a- muß dann als sekundäre Dehnung (Pisani) oder Vermischung mit ap- (Untermann 304 Anm. 47, Heidermanns § 50) erklärt werden."}];444[46{Cf. s.v. 570 Lat. aqua 'Wasser' for Romance lexemes.}]
Justification: Pace [Kroonen 2013](src-165), the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by [Beekes 1998](src-709)), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. [EWA 1](src-383) 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)). Regarding the Oscan form in this class, an alternative root etymology to PIE *h₂ep- is sometimes considered on the basis of the apparent lengthened root vowel as in the Indo-Iranian forms (e.g. Skt. āp-) cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):42-43, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):19), however it is possible that the lengthening of the vowel could be secondary. While it is possible that the Oscan form could preserve an isolated reflex of the root *h₂ep- as found in Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Tocharian, given that there are no other potential reflexes of the root *h₂ep- in Italic connections with Latin aqua cannot be ruled out, and it seems preferable, on the balance of probability, to connect Oscan aapam with Latin aqua < *h₂ekʷ-(e)h₂ (acknowledged by both Untermann & de Vaan). (NB: In Oscan PIE *kʷ > p).

Source: 444[463{S.v. 5646 Lat. *molliāre 'erweichen' > Cat. mollar, Sp. mojar, Pg. molhar, etc.| 5649 Lat. mollis 'weich' > Fr. mou, Prov. mol, etc.}];423[IV:181-182{Cf. s.v. Sp. muelle from Lat. mollis| cf. related derivative mojar from Late Latin *molliare 'reblandecer'.}];54[386{S.v. Lat. mollis 'soft, gentle', from PIE *mld-u- 'soft' (cf. W blydd 'soft', Skt. mr̥du- 'delicate, soft', Gk. *βλαδύς 'powerless' (in βλαδεῖς Hsch.)| the connection of the Greek forms is uncertain).}];141[431{Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from or derived from Latin mollis 'soft' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):463); the Iberian Romance lexemes are secondarily derived to a de-adjectival verb *molliāre 'make soft' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):463, [DCECH](src-423) IV:181-182). Further to PIE *meld- 'be/make soft' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):386, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 431).

Source: 54[32{S.v. Lat. albus 'white', from Proto-Italic *alfo- 'white', in turn from PIE *h₂elbʰ-o- 'white', cf. Gk. ἀλφούς [acc.pl.] 'white' (Hesych.), ἄλφι(τον) 'barley groats', Alb. elb 'barley' (unless the Albanian is a borrowing from Greek).}];316[20{S.v. Lat. albus, -a, -um 'blanc'. The -f- of Umbrian alfu demonstrates that Lat. -b- must go back to a voiced-aspirate *-bʰ-, cf. Gk. ἀλφούς· λευκούς (Hesych.) and ἀλφός 'éruption blanche'.}];444[26{S.v. 331 Lat. albus 'weiß'.}]
Justification: In all likelihood the lexemes can be accounted for via PIE *h₂elbʰ-o- 'white', however the reflexes of this form are restricted to Italic, Greek, and potentially also Albanian (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):20, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):32). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):26.

Source: 54[327{S.v. Lat. lārgus 'generous, bountiful'. Etymology unclear. The formal derivation and semantics from earlier attempts at an etymology in Walde-Hofmann and Pokorny IEW as though from *lajes-ago- 'carrying fat' are not convincing.}];316[342{S.v. Lat. largus, -a, -um 'abondant', without certain correspondences.}];444[399{S.v. 4912 Lat. largus 'geräumig, weit, breit'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):399), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):342, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):327).

Source: 54[66-67{S.v. axis 'axle, chariot' < PIE *h₂ek̑s-(i-)| de Vaan considers Lat. āla 'wing' is a secondarily derived form via PIt. *akselā-.}];274[259-262{S.v. *h₂ak̑s- '(Drehpunkt:) Achse, Achsel' (IEW 6).  Derives Lat. āla via a derivative in -leh₂ : *h₂ak̑s-lah₂ = PGerm. *ahslō- > OEng. eaxel, OHG ahsla 'axle'.  Cf. p.260n1 on the proposed connections with the root *h₂eg̑- 'treiben'.}]

54[393{S.v. Lat. mulier, -eris 'woman'. Disputed. Earlier connections advocated in older sources (IEW, etc.) to an original *-i̯es- comparative of mollis 'soft', but there are phonological problems in this derivation (cf. entry for further discussion). The etymology of this word is therefore not yet solved.}];316[418-419{S.v. Lat. mulier, -eris 'femme' in the general sense of the word. The popular etymology as a comparative form from mollis 'soft' is not possible.}];444[472{S.v. 5730 Lat. mulier 'Weib', 2. muliere.}]
Justification: No certain etymology (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):418-419, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):393 for further discussion, rejecting formerly proposed connections to Latin mollis 'soft'); for the Romance forms cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):472.

Source: 54[43-44{Proto-Italic *atno- from PIE *h₂et-no- (cf. Goth. aþnam (dat.pl.) 'years' [nom.sg. *aþn 'year' is unattested]).}];165[40{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *aþna- 'year' < PIE *h₂et-no- (cf. Lat. annus, Osc. aceneis [gen.sg.], Umb. acnu [acc.sg]).}]

54[37{S.v. Lat. amārus 'bitter', possibly from PIE *h₂h₃m-ro-? (cf. Skt. amlá- 'sour, acid', OIc. apr 'sharp, cold', etc.). Some morphological details remain unclear.}];423[I:233-235{S.v. Sp. amarillo, from hispanic Latin amarĕllus 'amarillento, pálido' the diminutive of Lat. amārus 'amargo'.}];444[31-32{S.v. 406 Lat. amārus 'bitter', 2. 'gelb'.}];316[25{S.v. Lat. amārus, -a, -um 'amer', one connects Skt. amlá- 'aigre', Sw. & ODu. amper 'aigre'.}];657[69{Cf. s.v. BITTER *h₂em-ro-s 'bitter, sour' (IEW 777-778: *om-): Lat. amārus 'bitter', ON apr 'sharp, hard, cold', OE ampre 'sorrel, dock', OHG ampfaro 'sorrel, dock', Alb. ëmbël 'sweet' (Tosk), tëmbël 'gall', Arm. amok' 'sweet', OInd. amlá- 'sour', from *h₂em- 'raw, bitter'.}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes derived from Latin amārus 'bitter' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):31-32, [DCECH](src-423) I:233-235). Further traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):25, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):37; cf. [EIEC](src-657) 69).

Source: 275[{Based on Proto-Celtic *leu̯-tu- or *lou̯-tu- 'ash' (PIE *leu̯h₃- 'to wash' LIV² 418), but different stems or reshapings in Goidelic and Brittonic. Matasović (2009, 246) postulates MIr. lúaith < *lou̯-tu̯-i-, MW lludw < *low-tw-o-. Alternatively an underlying *le/ou̯-tu̯-ah₂ is possible, see the discussion in Irslinger (2002, 115). Brittonic could continue this stem directly, while the Middle Irish word has become an i-stem. OIr. lúaithred and Scottish Gaelic luaithre (and Manx?) contain the collective suffixe -red (Thurneysen 1946, 169). }];141[418{Cf. s.v. *leu̯h₃- 'waschen' (IEW 692).}];50[246{S.v. Proto-Celtic *lowtu- 'ash', which may be connected with PIE *leu̯h₃- 'to wash' as a derived noun in the sense of 'washing substance'. Alternatively connected to Proto-Celtic *lutā 'mud, dirt', without the laryngeal.}];389[http://www.martinkuemmel.de/liv2add.html#_Toc392257980 , http://www.martinkuemmel.de/liv2add.html#_Neu:_*leh₃u̯-_‘gießen,{It is no longer necessary to postulate two separate roots *leh₂(u̯)- 'pour' for Anatolian and *leu̯h₃- 'wash' for Italic and Albanian. The two roots can be reconciled to *leh₃u̯- (cf. Melchert 2011:127-132). [Cf. discussion in cognate set for 'wash' in [cognate set 8364](cog-8364)].}];690[127-132]
Justification: For root ref. form *leh₃u̯-, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) and [Melchert 2011](src-690):127-132.

Source: 309[379{Also in the placename Cevenna 'Cevennes', which points to Gaulish *Cebenna. From Proto-Celtic *cebn-.}];240[26{S.v. Old Welsh ceng 'back' [ceing, cefn].}]
309[226{S.v. Bret. fall, adjective of quality 'mal, mauvais'. It is most probable that to comes from Old French faloir 'manquer' (1160), itself from popular Latin fallere.}]
Justification: Probable loan from Old French (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):226).

Source: 50[317{S.v. Proto-Celtic *rūsk(l)o-, rusko- 'bark'. It is possible that some of the Brittonic forms (with -u-) were borrowed from Goidelic, or Romance in the prehistoric period. The vocalism of OIr. rúsc is probably original, though DIL states that it was borrowed from Brittonic. If inherited, then the forms may be analysed as *rū-sko- < *ruH-sko-, cf. PIE *reu̯H- 'to rip, to tear' ([LIV²](src-141) 510, [IEW](src-49) 868), i.e. bark is conceived as 'something ripped' (cf. ON rýja 'shear (of sheep)', OCS ryti 'dig', Lat. ruō 'dig out', TochB ru- 'pull out', etc.}];296[R:54{S.v. OIr. rúsc 'écorce'. According to [Pedersen 1909](src-307):332 OIr. rúsc is a borrowing from Brythonic, but it could well be the other way around. In any case this doesn't provide an indication of an etymology.}]
Justification: Cognacy in this class follows [Matasović 2009](src-50):317 in treating the lexemes as inherited, but note that the possibility of some borrowing or loan-adaptation between Brythonic and Goidelic and/or early Romance may still be possible (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:54).

Source: 309[405{S.v. Bret. kof 'ventre', borrowed during the Middle Breton period from Old French *coffe, variant of coffre (1175) from Vulgar Latin *cophinum in turn of Greek origin. First attested in the Catholicon (1499).}]
Justification: Loanword from Old French ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):405).

Source: 193[{< Fr croc.}];309[436{Related to Middle Breton croc adj. 'attached, taken', m. 'catch, hook, efford' from Old French croc (end of 12th cent.) from Scandinavian krôkr. Croc and creguiff are both first attested in the Catholicon (1499).  }];275[{The Middle Breton verb may be productively formed from the noun and is thus not borrowed itself.  }]

274[122-124{S.v. *dʰeu̯b- 'tief' (IEW 267f., EIEC 154). Celtic forms are from Proto-Celtic *dubu- 'black' in OIr. dub 'black, dark', OWel. dub MWel. du, OBret. du-, Middle Cornish duw 'id.', these forms are directly cognate with Lithuanian dubùs 'deep' and may be accounted for via a u-stem adjective *dʰub-u-. The proposed connection with Gk. τυφλός (with an alternative -λο- suffix) is dubious, cf. p.123n4 for further discussion.}];50[107-108{S.v. Proto-Celtic *dubu- 'black'. Matasović reconstructs the root as *dʰubʰ- (zero-grade) based on a comparison Gk. τυφλός 'blind', following IEW 264.}];296[D:210-211{S.v. OIr. dub 'noire| terrible, triste' Ir. dub goes back to *dʰubʰu- and comparable to Gk. τυφός 'aveugle', Goth. daufs 'sourd'.}];269[{Etymology in this class follows [NIL](src-274) 122-124| traditionally (but dubiously) connected to Greek τυφλός 'blind' ([IEW](src-49) 264, followed by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:210-211, [Matasović 2009](src-50):107-108, against which cf. [NIL](src-274) 123n4).}]
Justification: Etymology in this class follows [NIL](src-274) 122-124; traditionally (but dubiously) connected to Greek τυφλός 'blind' ([IEW](src-49) 264, followed by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:210-211, [Matasović 2009](src-50):107-108, against which cf. [NIL](src-274) 123n4).

Source: 309[295{S.v. Bret. gwad 'sang| sève' from Old Breton gouet and corresponding to Cornish gos (Old Cornish guit), Welsh gwaed (Middle Welsh guayt) and to Gaelic féith from Proto-Celtic u̯ait-o-.}];151[67n7{"Fettgedrucktes = unmarkierte Bezeichnungen nach ELSIE 1983/84, S. 112. – Aus den älteren Sprachstadien entsprechen mkymr. gwaet, abret. gouet (wohl für *gwoet| FLEURIOT, DGVB, S. 179 s.v.)| vgl. ELSIE 1979, S. 83| STOKES, ZCP 1 (1897), S. 23| LOTH, RC 36 (1915), S. 158| VG I, S. 385| LP, S. 10| Henry LEWIS, BBCS 15 (1954), S. 123 f.| WG 114| GPC s.v. gwaed. – Die angeführten Belege sind auf proto-brit. *waito- < älter (proto-kelt.?) *woito- zurückzuführen (ebd.). – Die weitere Etymologie ist unbekannt."}];305[130{Assumes Proto-Celtic *u̯aitV- 'blood' > PBr. *u̯ɛ̄tV- > LPBr. *Woed- > SWBr. *gwoed > *goed > OCo. guit gl. sanguis, MCo. goys > B goad, gwad 'blood'| WBr. *gwoed > MW gwaed 'blood'.}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *u̯ait-o- 'blood', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):130, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):295, [Lucht 2007](src-151):67n7).

Source: 141[402{S.v. *leh₂p- 'aufleuchten' (IEW 652-3). OIr. loscaid and MW llosci 'to burn' originate from the causative Proto-Celtic *loskī. The corresponding present stem is Proto-Celtic *laske- 'to shine, to burn' < PIE *l̥h₂p-sk̑é-, the sk̑-present of the root *leh₂p- 'to flash, to light up' (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):194, fn. 40).}];151[76{S.v. OIr. loiscid 'burns, consumes by fire, lays waste by fire', earlier derived to *leu̯k- via a preform *luk-sk̑-(e/o)- ([IEW](src-49) 687 and others), better to the same root as Gk. λάμπω 'leuchte', OPr. lopis 'Flamme' (*leh₂p-) after the analysis of [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):194fn40.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes traditionally derived to PIE *leu̯k- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 687), but better to *leh₂p- after the analysis of [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):194fn40, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 402, [Lucht 2007](src-151):76.

Source: 309[422{S.v. Bret. koumoul 'nuages', corresponding to Co. comol and W cwmwl, all three recall Lat. cumulus, although the conservation of medial -m- is difficult.}];236[{S.v. W cwmwl 'cloud', loanword(?) from Latin cumulus, cf. Medieval Breton commoull.}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes, probably continuing a loanword from Latin cumulus 'heap' although the conservation of medial *-m- in phonetically difficult (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):422, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 50[435{S.v. Proto-Celtic *yegi- 'ice' < PIE *i̯eg- 'ice' (IEW 503), cf. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', ON yaki, Wakhi yaz 'glacier'.}];80[234-235{Cf. s.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', from which Hitt. ekuna-, ikuna- 'cold' is a derived adjective, ultimately from PIE *i̯ég-o- 'ice' and cognate with OIr. aig 'ice', ONor. jaki 'ice-floe', etc.}];406[257-259{S.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice' (n.), with derived adjective ekuna-, ikuna- 'cold', from IE *yeg- (IEW 503), cf. MiIr. aig 'ice' (< *yegis), MiCorn. yeyn 'cold', ON jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier'.}];442[601{S.v. 10396 *yaja- 'cold' [IE. *yeg̑- 'ice' IEW 503?] (cf. Kt. yūċ 'cold', Pr. (y)ǖzu. Wg. yū̆z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz [→Wkh. yaz]).}];49[503{Cf. s.v. *i̯eg- 'Eis'.}];269[{Indo-Iranian-Nuristani cognates from *yaja- 'cold' (Turner 1962-1966:601) probably imply a reconstruction *i̯eg̑- with a palatovelar.}]
Justification: Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ([IEW](src-49) 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):234-235, [HED A+E/I](src-406):257-259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):435).

Source: 275[{In Brittonic, the paradigms of the the verbs 'to go' and 'to come' are highly suppletive. The finite forms are based on the stems a- < *ag- < *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' (LIV 255) and el- < *pelh₂- 'to approach' (LIV 470). In the paradigm of 'to go', these forms are used uncompounded, while in the paradigm of 'to come', they contain the preverb *tu-. In Middle Welsh, some imperative forms are based on *ret-e/o- < *ret- 'to run' (LIV 507). The verbal nouns of 'to come' Welsh mynet, Breton monet originate from PIE *menH- 'to step, to stamp'? (LIV 438). The verbal noun of 'to go', Breton donet contains the same root prefixed with *tu-, i.e. *de-vonet, cf. also Old Breton diminet. The Welsh verbal noun dyfod 'to come' contains *tu- + bod 'to be' based on PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to become, to grow' (LIV 98). See Schumacher (2004, 189-193), Hemon (1975, 236). }];240[44{S.v. OW dibid (3.sg.pres.) 'to come' [deuaf] "This form of the verb contains *do-, and the form of the substantive verb. See also dibu (3.sg.pret.).}]
Comment: dy-bod (GPC)

Source: 309[413{S.v. Bret. kont 'compte| mention, situation', a borrowing from Old French conte, deverbal to conter 'compter, calculer', ultimately from Lat. computāre. Associated verbs kontañ (contaff), kontiñ (contein), conto 'compter, considérer'.}]
Justification: Loanwords, either borrowed directly from Old French conter, or a denominal formation within Breton based on a loanword from Old French conte ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):413)

Source: 50[206{From Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.).  }];304[410-413{From Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.) with a d-extension. }];275[{Proto-Celtic *kla-d- from a collocation / light-verb-construction *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o-, i.e. *kelh₂- + *dʰeh₁- 'to make a stroke/stab' > 'to dig'?}];141[350{Cf. s.v. *kelh₂- 'schlagen' (IEW 545-6).}];296[C:111-112{S.v. OIr. claidid 'il creuse' cf. in Brythonic in W claddu 'creuser, enterrer', Bret. vann. klaouein 'id.', the root is *klad-, cf. clad 'fossé', 1 clas 'id.', claideb 'épée'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):410-413, [Matasović 2009](src-50):206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. [LIV²](src-141) 350, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:111-112)

Source: 309[476{S.v. Bret. lous 'sale', corresponding to Cornish lôs 'vil, souillé, misérable, sordide' and Old French los 'misérable, méchant, taquin'. Of obscure origin.}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes of obscure origin (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):476).

Source: 309[669-70{S.v. Bret. skouarn 'oreille, anse, oreillion', cf. Co. scovarn, W. ysgyfarn, from Proto-Celtic *skob-erna.}];301[302{Ernault, GMB 611 thinks that *skoberna is derived from a base *skob meaning 'to excavate, to dig'. Also the word scau 'elder' would be derived from this root. CHECK}]
Comment: Buck 1949:226 from IE *skeu/*keu 'perceive, hear'
Justification: Root reference form tentatively follows the proposed reconstruction of [Deshayes 2003](src-309):669. No certain etymology outside of Brythonic. Older treatments have various tentative suggestions, e.g. [Buck 1949](src-47):226 suggests perhaps to PIE *skeu̯- 'perceive, hear' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 561 *skeu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen'), [Pedersen 1913](src-308):53 tentatively suggests to Greek κυβερνάω 'to steer'.

Source: 309[197{S.v. Bret. douar 'terre, domaine', from Old Breton doiar with correspondences in Co. dor and W daear. Of uncertain origin.}]
Comment: etym. dub. CHECK VGK I, 66
Justification: A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):197).

Source: 309[173{From Old Breton diprim < *di- + prim. The second element corresponds to Irish crim- in crimóg 'morsel' (where attested? Neither in eDIL nor in Ó Dónaill).}];157[139{S.v. Gaul. depro- 'nourriture', attested in the name of a potter Depro-sagiíos| the second term is interpreted as 'qui cherche', the first term is connected with Breton debri 'manger', Old Breton diprim 'essum, fait de manger', Old Cornish diberi, Cornish dybbry 'id.' Campanile PECA 37 compares to Greek δεῖπνον 'repas', δειπνέω 'je dîne' to a root *deikʷ-. No mention of these words in [IEW](src-49), nor [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270) who consider the Greek word a 'mediterranean word'}]
Justification: Following [Delamarre 2003](src-157):139 connecting Gaulish onomastic depro- to this group, I tentatively reconstruct Proto-Celtic *dēkʷro- underlying these forms (not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)). Enrico Campanile, Profilo Etimologico del Cornico Antico (Pisa 1974, non vidi) tentatively proposed a possible connection to Ancient Greek δεῖπνον 'dinner, supper' which is formally possible and reconcilable to a root *dei̯kʷ- (not in [LIV²](src-141)). [Beekes 2010](src-66):310 considers Ancient Greek δεῖπνον without certain etymology.

Source: 50[248{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *luk-o- 'see, perceive, set eyes upon', from PIE *leuk- 'shine' (IEW 687, cf. Hitt. lukk- 'get light, dawn', Skt. rócate 'shines', OLat. lūceō 'make light', OPr. luckis 'torch, log', TochB luk- 'to shine'). From this root is also derived OW licat (MW llygat) 'well, source', OCo. lagat (gloss 'oculus'), MBret. lagat.}];304[460{Continues a Proto-Brittonic agent noun *luk-ati- m. originally meaning 'seher' (cf. Schrijver 1995, 166), based on the Proto-Celtic verbal stem *luk-e/o- 'to look at', PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' (LIV² 438).}];240[103{S.v. Old Welsh licat 'source of river or well' (< 'eye') [llygad], derived from PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten'.}];309[447{S.v. Bret. lagad (OBret. lagat) 'œil| douille', corresponding to Co. lagas 'œil', etc., from Brythonic *lukato-.}];141[418-419{Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes derived from Proto-Celtic *luk-ati- 'seer', a derivative of Proto-Celtic *luk-e/o- 'to look at', ultimately a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):460, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):248, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):103, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):447, [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Source: 309[420{Cf. the cognate nouns Breton kouez m. 'fall', Welsh cwydd 'fall'. Based on Proto-Celtic *kei̯d-.}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes based on a denominal formation (cf. Breton kouez m. 'a fall'), from Proto-Celtic *kei̯d- according to [Deshayes 2003](src-309):420) but with no correspondences given from Goidelic. Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 50[176{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷello- 'far', perhaps from PIE *kʷel- 'to turn' (IEW 640), although this etymology is speculative.}];294[490{From *kʷé-h₁ le 'far' < 'how far?| how far!', a collocation consisting of the interrogative pronoun *kʷé-h₁ 'how?' (instrumental) and the deictic particle *li, le 'over there, yonder| then'. At an early time, *kʷé-h₁ le was reduced to *kʷéli/e. This latter form underlies among others Brittonic pell < *kʷel-so-.  }]
Justification: From Proto-Celtic *kʷello-,; perhaps further to PIE *kʷel(h₁)- 'turn' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):176, [LIPP 2](src-294) 490).

Source: 54[474{S.v. Lat. plūma 'feather'. Probably a deverbal noun in *-mo- from *pleu̯- 'swim| float' or *pleu̯-k- with a root extension.  Lat. plūma could go back to a derived form *pleu̯-mo-, *plou̯-mo- or *pl(e/o)u̯-smo-, or to pl(e/o)u̯k-smo-, if the connection with OPruss. plauxdine 'feather bed', Lith. plùnksna 'feather' is accepted.}];269[{Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' (LIV² 487-488) → *pleu̯k- 'float, swim' (LIV² 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. Lith. plùnksma in [cognate set 2263](cog-2263).}];141[487-488{Cf. s.v. *pleu̯- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 835-7) and *pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837).}];316[516{S.v. Lat. plūma 'plume qui recouvre le corps'. A popular term without an exact correspondence. The most attractive connection is with that of Lith. plùnksna 'plume', OPr. plauxdine 'lit de plume'| the connection with OHG fliogan 'voler' is to be discarded because of the sense. Other proposed connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes, generally considered derivatives from PIE *pleu̯-mo-, a derivative of PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float'. An alternative possible reconstruction is *pleu̯k-smo- and connected with the extended variant *pleu̯k- which is only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. [cognate set 2263](cog-2263) ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):516, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):474, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 487-488).

Source: 50[375{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tefnet- 'fire' derived from PIE *tep- 'be warm'. The Celtic form presupposes an original s-stem *tepnēs-.}];274[698-700{S.v. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (LIV 629f., IEW 1069f.).}];141[629-630{Cf. s.v. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (IEW 1069-70).}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ([NIL](src-274) 698-700, [Matasović 2009](src-50):375, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 629-630).

Source: 296[S:145-146{Cf. s.v. OIr. sná- 'couler (d'un liquide ou d'un cours d'eau)', going back to the IE root *snā- (cf. Skt. snā́ti 'il se baigne', Gk. νήχω 'je nage', etc.). The Brythonic forms are from the same root in a derived dental stem (cf. Lat. natō 'je nage', Bret. neijal, nijal 'voler').}];309[537-538{Cf. s.v. Bret. nij adj. qual. 'volant', corresponding to Corn. nyj, 'vol, nage, fait de flotter' and W naid 'bond, saut' from Brythonic *natia-, with many derivatives in Breton.}];141[572-573{Cf. s.v. *(s)neh₂- 'baden, schwimmen' (IEW 971-2).}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):537-538, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:145-146, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 572-573).

Source: 50[387, 389{S.v. Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot', cf. PIE *tregʰ- 'run, walk' (IEW 1089).}];275[{The root is controversial, Irslinger (2002, 60) with a discussion of previous research. *tregʰ- matching with the word for 'foot' is not reconstructed by LIV as a PIE root. Schumacher (2004, 635f.) argues on the basis of further Celtic material for the reconstruction of *treHgʰ-/treHg̑ʰ- or *tragʰ-/trag̑ʰ- 'to run away, to recede'. He argues that also Latin trahere 'to pull, to drag' originates from this root, a suggestion followed by de Vaan (2008, 626f.). Matasović (2009, 387, 389) rejects the idea that Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot' belongs here. LIV² 154 groups Lat. trahere, showing an irregular anlaut development, with *dʰregʰ-/dʰreg̑ʰ- 'to pull, to drag'. Schrijver (1995, 136) argues that t- could have developed from *(s)d- with s-mobile, so that the word for 'foot' could originate from *dʰregʰ-/dʰreg̑ʰ-.  Apart from these problems connected to the PIE root, the Proto-Form of the Brittonic cognates is difficult to establish.}];54[646-647];305[136];299[60];304[635-636]
Justification: An Indo-European root etymology outside of Celtic for Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot' is controversial, cf. esp. [Irslinger 2002](src-299):60 for further discussion. Older hypotheses suppose a root *tregʰ- 'to walk' and a connection to Latin trahere 'to drag' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):387, 389 following [IEW](src-49) 1089, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):635-636)

Source: 304[278-282{S.v. Proto-Insular-Celtic *-dī- 'setzen' from PIE *dʰeh₁- (LIV² 136-138) > (+ pro > ro-) Middle Welsh roði 'geben'}];141[105-106{S.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5). Cf. fn17 where it is stated Welsh rhoddaf 'I give' originates from the reduplicated present *dédoh₃/dh₃- of the root *deh₃- 'to give'. The neo-root *rod- was abstracted from *rodā ← *pro-dedō- with loss of reduplication in composition?}];308[473, 380{All Brittonic verbs are cognate, i.e. compounds *(p)ro-d- of *deh₃- 'to give'. In Welsh rhoi as well as in the Breton and Cornish verbs, *đ was lost. }];346[55, 345{As Pedersen 1913.}];309[629{Cf. s.v. Bret. ro 'don, vœu' from Old Breton rod 'don, présent' corresponding to Cornish ro, Welsh rhodd in the same sense.}];347[131-32{Detailed discussion of the hypothesis put forward in Schumacher 2004.}]
Comment: Welsh rhoddi < *ro-dī-, cf. PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to place, to put', does not belong to the same cognate class as Middle Welsh roaf, roi, Middle Breton reiff and Middle Cornish ry. These verbs have lost an intervocalic -g- and belong to Old Irish rogaid*, ·rogai* (*rugaid, *·rugai 'to stretch out' DIL 510/R89, LEIA R-39). Etymology first mentioned by Thurneysen, Review of VGK II, IF (Anzeiger) 33 (1914), 33.
Justification: The Brythonic lexemes in this class are generally considered to be cognate but the ultimate PIE root etymology remains a matter of considerable debate. The two main hypotheses are to PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):278-282) or to PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ([Pedersen 1913](src-308):473, [LIV²](src-141) 105-106), in either case combined with the preverb *pro- 'forth'. Cf. also [Falileyev 2000](src-240):138-139, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. W rhoddaf, and [Deshayes 2003](src-309):629). The root reference form Proto-Insular-Celtic *-dī- follows ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):678.

Source: 50[259-60{S.v. Proto-Celtic *mati- 'good' from PIE *meh₂-t- (cf. Lat. mānis, mānus, Mātūta 'goddess Dawn').}];296[M:12-13{S.v. OIr. maith 'bon, excellent, avantageux'.}];151[181-182{S.v. 'good', etymology of OIr. positive degree maith < Proto-Goidelic *mati-, from Proto-Celtic *mati- < PIE *mh₂-ti- to the root *meh₂- 'gut, zu guter Zeit, rechtzeitig' ({ref IEW 693 mā-), cf. Lat. māturus 'rechtzeitig, zeitig, reif', Osc. maatúís < Mātīs = 'Dī Mānēs', probably also Hitt. mēḫur 'rechte Zeit' < PIE *meh₂u̯r̥ ([Eichner 1973](src-641)).}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mati- 'good', a derivative of PIE *meh₂- 'good; at the right time' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):181-182, [Matasović 2009](src-50):259-260, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:12-13).

Source: 309[115{S.v. Bret. blew 'chevelure, cheveux, poils, robe (d'animal), from Old Breton bleu and corresponding to Cornish blew (Old Cornish bleu) and to Welsh blew, further from Proto-Celtic *blou̯i-, without nay further cognates (cf. Henry, Lexique étymologique du breton moderne, Rennes 1900).}];301[85{S. Lane, Language (7, 1931.4, 279) (review Revue Celtique 7, 279) rejects Henry's reconstruction *blou̯i-. According to him, bleo originates from *bleu̯s < *mleu̯s from the root *mel contained in Greek μαλλός 'hair, mane', Lith. mìlas 'cloth (of wool)', cf. WP 2.294.  }];275[{Lane suggests an u-stem with suffixal full grade nsg. *ml-eu̯-s,  cf. IEW 721 with μαλλός 'flock of wool' < *ml̥-nó-, cognate class H? According to Frisk, GEW II 168, the Greek word is unexplained.}];240[16{S.v. OW bleuporthetic 'wool bearing'. Hapax in Welsh, A compound whose first element bleu was linked by G. Lane Language 7 (1931), 279 to PIE *mel- 'Wolle' ([IEW](src-49) 721)| the second element is porthedig, a loan from Latin portāre.}];49[721{S.v. 7. mel- 'Wolle, Wollgewand'? : Gk. μαλλός (*ml̥-nó-) 'Zotte, Flocke', Lith. mìlas 'Tuch', Latv. mil(n)a 'großes Tuch', OPr. milan 'id.'. [Without Celtic cognates].}];236[{Cf. s.v. W. blew 'hair, hairs, bristles, fur', cf. Old Cornish bleu (en lagat), gl. palpebre, bleuyn (pen), gl. capillus, Middle Cornish blewennow (diminutive fem. pl.), Late Cornish bleaw, Old Breton bleuou, gl. iubis, Middle Breton bleau, Late Breton blew| cf. also Old Welsh blewborthedig. [No etymology outside of Brythonic].}];765[279{2. Welsh blew, Breton bleo: "The common Brythonic word for 'hair', Welsh blew, Bret. bleo, has never received a satisfactory explanation. Henry (Lexique étymologique 37) hazards a comparison with Grk. φλοιός 'bark, peeling' (IE *bhleu- 'swell', cf. further on this group Walde-Pokorny 2. 212f.). The attempt made by Morris-Jones (Welsh Gramm. 157) to link the Celtic words to Lith. plùskos 'hair', NE fleece, etc. (IE *pleus-) is of course to be discarded so long as nothing is established regarding the alternation of initial sonant and surd in Indo-European. Moreover the correct Celtic cognate for the latter group is OIr. lō 'flock of wool' (cf. Walde-Pokorny 2. 96f.). The possibility of deriving Celtic *bleus² from *mleus, an extended form of IE *mel- in Grk. μαλλός 'bunch of hair, wool', Lith. milas 'cloth (of wool)', etc. (cf. id. 2. 294) has been overlooked as far as I can discover The change ml > bl is common enough in Celtic, cf. e.g. Welsh blith 'milk' : OIr. mlicht, blicht, Goth. miluks, etc."}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *blou̯i- 'hair, wool'. Further etymology uncertain: [Lane 1931](src-765):279 attempted to derive from a preform *ml̥-eu̯-s comparable to Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' (< *ml̥-nó-), but this conjecture has not been widely accepted (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):115, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):16, [Fleuriot 1964a](src-301):85, [IEW](src-49) 721 [without Brythonic forms given as cognates]). The proposed comparandum in Ancient Greek μαλλός, moreover, is generally considered without satisfactory etymology ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):663, [Beekes 2010](src-66):899; cf. [cognate set 1492](cog-1492)). [Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)].

Source: 50[108-109{S.v. Proto-Celtic *durno- 'fist', probably a loan from an non-IE language.}];309[196{S.v. Bret. dorn 'main, poing, poignée', from Old Breton durn and equivalent to Co. dorn, W dwrn in the same sense, Ir. dorn 'poing' and Scots Gaelic dòrn, from Proto-Celtic *dur-no-.}];296[D:177-178{S.v. OIr. dorn 'main, poing', corresponding to W dwrn, Bret. dourn, dorn 'poing, main', etc. Root etymology uncertain. Either *der- or *dher- is possible (cf. Hamp ZCP XLI 253).}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:177-178, [Matasović 2009](src-50):108-109).

Source: 50[177{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷenno- 'head'. The ablaut attested in cognate vocabulary within Celtic suggest that the lexeme is inherited rather than borrowed from a substratum, but no successful identification with a known PIE root or cognate vocabulary outside of Celtic has yet been made.}];296[C:65-66{S.v. cenn 'tête, sommet, extrémité, fin, chef', from Proto-Celtic *kʷenno-, with no known cognates outside of Celtic.}]
Justification: No known etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:65-66, [Matasović 2009](src-50):177).

Source: 309[361{S.v. Bret. kalon 'cœur, âme (de cordage)', from Old Breton calonn and corresponding to Co. colon and Welsh calon, from Proto-Celtic *kal-ona-.}];348[50-51{S.v. Bret. kalon, kaloun 'cœur' (Co. colon, W calon 'id.') Proto-Celtic *kal-onā may be cognate to 1) Latin calidus 'warm, hot' or to 2) Latin callidus 'experienced' (the heart was conceived as the organ of intelligence).}];275[{PIE roots of the proposed Latin cognates: 1) *k̑elh₁- 'to be hot' (cf. *k̑el- 'to become hot' LIV² 323) and 2) *kHl-, also in Br. kalet 'hart', cf. De Vaan 2008, s.vv.}];236[{No etymology outside of Brythonic given s.v. W calon.}]
Justification: Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50); no etymology given in [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [Henry 1900](src-348):50-51 for various older proposals.

Source: 309[596{S.v. Bret. pounner 'lourd| exagéré, grave', a borrowing from Latin ponderis 'of weight'.}]
Justification: Loan from Lat. ponderis 'of weight' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):596).

Source: 309[666{S.v. Bret. sko s.m. 'frappe, heurt| échouage'| denominal verb skoiñ (squeiff, 1499). The noun continues Old Breton sco 'coup', but the further etymology remains obscure.}];301[303{The attested form si-scuint is 3pl. pres. subj. with the intensifying prefix si-. It is based on a stem sco-* oder scu-*. Cf. the cognate noun Old Breton sco 'blow, stroke'. From *sk̑eu̯- 'to hit, to throw, to shoot' (IEW 953f.) or *skeu̯d- 'to throw, to shoot' (IEW 954f. = *skeu̯d- 'to drive, to push' LIV² 560)?}]
Justification: Denominal formation from Old Breton sco 'strike, blow', further etymology obscure ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):666).

Source: 309[669{S.v. Bret. skorn 'glace', a word of obscure origin. First attested in the Catholicon (1499).}];235[681{Favereau cites Cornish scorn and Old French sorne (Ernault). Cf. scorne 'scoria, vitrified/petrified mass found in the melting vessel originating from metallurgic processes'. How likely is it that a borrowed technical term like this becomes the Swadesh term for 'ice'? }]
Justification: Breton lexemes, first attested in Middle Breton, but further origins obscure ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):669).

Source: 50[345{S.v. Proto-Celtic *slad-yo- 'to hit, to slay'. No convincing IE etymology.}];304[583-587{S.v. Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯e/o- 'to strike, to kill', PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ-. Schumacher follows [Schrijver 1995](src-305):178 who reconstructs this root, neither contained in IEW nor in LIV².}];305[178]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ([Matasović 2009](src-50):345), cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following [Schrijver 1995](src-305):178. [Not in [LIV²](src-141)].

Source: 50[361{S.v. Proto-Celtic *swar-yo- 'laugh', from PIE *su̯er- 'sound, make a sound' (IEW 1049f.), cf. Skt. svárati, ON sverja 'swear', perh. Lat. susurrus 'whisper'. "The attribution of these Celtic forms to the PIE root *swer- is semantically difficult, but possible (see KPV 609)."}];309[162{S.v. Bret. c'hoarz 'rire' corresponding to Co. warth, W chwardd, going back to Proto-Celtic *su̯er-d-o-.}];141[613{Cf. s.v. 1. *su̯er- 'tönen' (IEW 1049-50). [Without Celtic].}];240[64{S.v. OW guardam 'to laugh' (MW chward-) from IE *su̯ard- 'lachen'.}];304[608-609{S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯ar-i̯e/o- 'lachen', from PIE *su̯er- (LIV² 613, *su̯ard- IEW 1040, *su̯er- IEW 1049f.).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ar-i̯e/o- 'to laugh', a derivative of PIE 1. *su̯er- 'to sound' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):608-609, [Matasović 2009](src-50):361, cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):64, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):162, [LIV²](src-141) 613).

Source: 50[102-103{S.v. Proto-Celtic *dol-V- 'leaf', from PIE *delh₁- 'blossom' (cf. OE dile 'dill', Arm. dalar 'green'). There are different stems formations in Irish, Brittonic and Gaulish: OIr. duille should be derived from *dolnya, while the Brittonic forms are from *dolya, and Gaulish seems to have a reflex of *dola.}];274[83-85{Cf. s.v. *dalh₁- 'herausquellen, hervorsprießen' (LIV 132, IEW 234). Brittonic Middle Welsh deil etc. and Latin folium < *dʰolh₁-(i)yo- (with question mark. Alternative etymology possible).}];141[132{Cf. s.v. *dʰalh₁- 'herausquellen, hervorsprießen' (IEW 234).}];296[D:216-217{S.v. OIr. duille 'feuille, feulliage', to Gk.  θάλος, θαλλός, Arm. dalar 'vert, frais', Alb. dal 'je pousse' from *dhal-/*dhel-. The connection with Lat. folium is uncertain since Lat. folium could reflect either *dholio-, as in Celtic, or *bhol-io- as in Gk. φύλλον.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰalh₁- 'to spring up, sprout' ([NIL](src-274) 83-85, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:216-217, [Matasović 2009](src-50):102-103, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 132). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 8247](cog-8247).

Source: 50[207{S.v. Proto-Celtic *klēyo- 'left', from PIE *k̑lei̯- (cf. Lat. clīuius 'inauspicious, ominous', Goth. hleiduma 'left', Lith. šleĩvas 'bow-legged').}];141[332-333{Cf. s.v. *k̑lei̯- 'sich anlehnen' (IEW 601-2).}];179[187{S.v. Goth. H78. hleiduma 'ἀριστερός, εὐώνυμος', 'left', from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' (cf. Gk. κλίτος 'hill'| OIr. clé OWel cledd < *k̑li-i̯os 'left').}];296[C:114-115{S.v. OIr. clé 'gauche' from *kleiyo- or *kliyo- (cf. Goth. hleiduma 'gauche', Lat. clīuis 'de mauvais augure'), derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'incliner, pencher'.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *klēyo- 'left', further derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:114-115, [Matasović 2009](src-50):207, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 332-333).

Source: 50[152{S.v. Proto-Celtic *garrV- 'calf of the leg, shank'. There is no good Indo-European etymology. Matasović suggests that it may be possible to derive these forms from the PIE word for 'hand' (PIE *g̑ʰesr > Hitt. kissar, Gr. χείρ) and gives two possible developments that would yield the Celtic forms regularly. The semantic development was then 'hand, arm' > 'limb' > '(calf of the) leg'.}];309[266{S.v. Bret. gar 'jambe' corresponding to Co. gar, W gar, Gaul. *garra-, all from Proto-Celtic *garri- 'jarret'. Old French gare 'jambe, cuisse' is a borrowing from Gaulish.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic ([Matasović 2009](src-50):152, cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):266).

Source: 50[49{S.v. Proto-Celtic *awV- (?) 'liver'. The Proto-Celtic reconstruction is very uncertain, therefore an IE etymology based on it is even more speculative.}];296[O:2{S.v. OIr. óa 'foie'. The Celtic languages have replaced the inherited IE word for 'liver' with a new word of unknown etymology and whose proto-form is impossible to reconstruct.}]
Justification: Proto-Celtic reconstruction uncertain; no etymology outside of Celtic (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:2, [Matasović 2009](src-50):49).

Source: 50[337{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sīro- 'long' < *seh₁-ro- 'long lasting' (IEW 891), cf. Skt. sāyá- 'evening', Lat. sērus 'late', Goth. seiþu 'evening'.}];296[S:115-116{S.v. OIr. sír 'long, durable', from Proto-Celtic *sīro-, corresponding exactly to Lat. sērus 'tardif'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *sīro- 'long' < PIE *seh₁-ro- 'long lasting (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:115-116, [Matasović 2009](src-50):337).

Source: 50[204{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kīkā 'breast'. According to DIL there is some evidence that OIr. cích was a neuter s-stem, so perhaps *kīkos- might be a better reconstruction. Matasović assumes that the meaning of MIr. cích 'beast' as primary and that the word is a popular expressive word often used for female body parts.}];296[C:95-96{S.v. OIr. cích (rarely) 'téton, sein'. LEIA assumes that the meaning 'meat' is the original one because of the compound adjective mir. ciccar 'voracious' (LU 2148) < *cig-car 'meat-loving'. Cites an uncertain connection with Greek κῖκυς 'force' by [Pedersen 1909](src-307):51.}]
Justification: Possibly otherwise to be reconstructed as an s-stem neuter *kīkos-; further etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:95-96). [Matasović 2009](src-50):204 considers the words of expressive origin with an original semantic development from '(female) breast' > 'meat', although [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) considers the semantics to have developed in the opposite direction on the basis of compounds in Middle Irish.

Source: 50[158{S.v. Proto-Celtic *genu- 'jaw' from PIE *g̑enu- 'jaw' (IEW 381), cf. Skt. hánu-, Gk. γένυς, Lat. gena 'cheek', OEng. cinn, TochA śanweṃ (du.) 'jaws'. The singular of this word is reflected in OIr. gin u m. 'mouth' and in the Brittonic words for 'cheek', MW gen f.'cheek', OBret. gen gl. maxilla, MBret. guen, MoBret. gen f. 'cheek'. The Brittonic words for 'mouth' is based on the plural Proto-Celtic *genou̯es.}];151[280{S.v. OIr. gin 'a mouth', doubtless to PIE *g̑enu- 'Kinn, Kinnbacke' (cf. Ved. hánu- 'Kinnbacke', Av. zanu- 'id.', Gk. γένυς, -υος 'Kinn, Kinnbacke', Lat. gena 'Wange, genīnus dens 'Backenzahn', Goth. kinnus 'Wange', TochA śanwe-m (du.f.) 'Kinnbacken').}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu- 'jaw' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):280, [Matasović 2009](src-50):158). NB: traditionally considered a separate lexical root from PIE *g̑enu-, *g̑neu- 'knee', cf. [IEW](src-49) 380-382.

Source: 309[732{S.v. Bret. tost (adj. qual.) 'avare| serré, sévère| minutieux' and adv. 'presque' and prep. 'près de', corresponding to W tost 'sévère, dur, véhément, furieux| douloureux' borrowed from Lat. tostus 'grilled, burned'.}]
Justification: A loanword into Brythonic from Latin tostus 'grilled, burned', cf. Welsh tost 'severe, harsh, hard' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):732).

Source: 309[288{S.v. Bret. gouzoug 'cou, col, gorge, goulot', from Old Breton guodoc and corresponding to Co. *ghuduk and W gwddwg from Proto-Celtic *u̯udok-.}];236[{S.v. W gwddf, gwddw, gwddwg 'neck, crag, throat', from Celtic *u̯udu̯o-}];305[52n1{"Pedersen's connection of W gwddw(g), B gouzoug 'neck, throat' with Goth. gatwo 'street, path' ([Pedersen 1909](src-307): 63) is highly uncertain."}]
Justification: A Brythonic word without certain external correspondences (cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):52n1 against an earlier proposal of [Pedersen 1909](src-307):63 to connect to Gothic gatwo 'street'). The reconstruction of a common proto-form is difficult, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) and [Deshayes 2003](src-309):288 for attempts at a Proto-Celtic reconstruction.

Source: 50[352-53{S.v. Proto-Celtic *srognā 'nose', from PIE *sregʰ- 'snore' (IEW 1002), cf. Gk. ῥέγχω 'snore', Arm. ṙngun-kʻ 'nose'.}];296[S:187-188{S.v. OIr. srón 'narine, nez'}];151[295-296{S.v. OIr. srón 'a nostril', in dual 'nose'. Connections outside of Celtic are uncertain, various proposals have been made to (a) Skt. sr̥kván-, srákva- 'Mundwickel', (b) Gk. ῥίς, ῥινός, (c) Gk. ῥέγκω, ῥέγχω 'schnarche' < *srenk- (IEW), (d) Arm. ṙngun-kʻ < *srongh-on-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:187-188, [Lucht 2007](src-151):295-296 for a survey of various proposals. The Proto-Celtic root reference form given for this cognate set provisionally follows [Matasović 2009](src-50):352-353.

Source: 50[218-219{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kotto- 'old'. "According to Sims-Williams (2006: 67) Cat. cot 'hill', Sp. cueto are from the Gaulish reflex of this word. The semantic development was presumably from 'old' to 'curved, humpbacked hillock'. In any case, these words are probably of non-IE origin."}];643[67-69];309[425{S.v. Bret. kozh (adj.) 'vieux, ancien' from Old Breton coth and corresponding to Co. coth 'vieux, ancien, âgé', W coth, and Gaul. cottos 'vieux'.}];157[127{Cf. s.v. Gaul. cottos 'vieux', connected with Bret. coz and OCo. coth 'vieux', a substrate word?}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kotto- 'old', possibly an old substratum borrowing from a non-IE language (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):425, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):127, [Sims-Williams 2006](src-643):67-69, [Matasović 2009](src-50):218-219).

Source: 309[161{Cf. Old Breton guari, huari, Middle Breton hoari, Modern Breton c'hoari m. 'game' from Proto-Celtic *su̯er-o-.}];50[311-312{S.v. Proto-Celtic *rig-o- 'to bind', cf. *(H)rei̯g- 'to bind, to reach' (IEW 861, LIV 503), cf. Lat. rigeō 'be stiff', MHG ricken 'bind', OHG reihhen 'reach', Lith. réižti 'to stretch, tighten'. OIr. con-rig 'binds together' < *kom-rig-o-, MW gwarny 'play' (GPC gwarny, gwary), MBret. hoari 'play' < MW gwarny and MBret. hoari < *ufo-rig-o-.}];304[546-548{S.v. Proto-Celtic 2. *rig-e/o- 'binden' < PIE *rei̯g- or *rei̯g̑- (LIV² 503). The Brythonic forms (W gwarwy, etc.) are compounds with the preverb *u̯o-.}];141[503{Cf. s.v. *rei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'binden' (IEW 861-2).}];240[64{S.v. Old Welsh guarai 'play, amusement, theatre'. No etymology, possibly *worigo-, cf. Ir. fuirech < *fo-rig.}]
Justification: From PIE *rei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bind' via Proto-Celtic *rig-e/o- ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):546-548, [Matasović 2009](src-50):311-312, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):546-548, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 503), but cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):161, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):64.

Source: 309[719{A Common Brittonic (and Irish) borrowing von Latin tendere 'to stretch, to direct'.}];296[T-49{Cites literature for both assumptions.}];301[314 s.v. tinsit{An inherited word based on PIE *ten- 'to stretch, to span' may have mixed up with a Latin borrowing. }]
Comment: Controversial, explained either as loanwords from Latin tendere or as inherited verbs, based on PIE *ten- 'to span, to stretch' (LIV 626). Perhaps related to [cognate set 2837](cog-2837), see citations in class for further references.

Source: 309[127{Cf. Old French boute < bot 'blow, ' (1160), bouter 'to collide, to clash, to push' (1190).}];443[15/1:210-229{S.v. *botan- (anfrk.) 'stossen, schlagen' > Fr. bouter.}];444[109{S.v. 1228c *bōtan (fränk.) 'stoßen'.}]
Justification: Loan into Romance from Old Low Franconian ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:210-229, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):109).

Source: 309[274{From Proto-Celtic *u̯olau̯o-.}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236). [Deshayes 2003](src-309):274 reconstructs Proto-Celtic *u̯olau̯o- which has been tentatively followed here as a root reference form for this cognate set.

Source: 235[641{s.v. rivier 'fleuve, rivière', variant forms riñvier, reñvier, rinier.}];309[629{Br. rivier 'river' is attested from the Middle Breton period onwards. The word is cited as riuyer in the Catholicon (1499). It was borrowed from Old or Middle French riviere f. 'rive, rivage, seashore, coast', first attested in the 12th century.}]
Justification: Loanword from Old/Middle French riviere 'river' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):629, [Favereau 1997a](src-235):641).

Source: 50[73{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bragno-, *bragni- 'rotten, faul' (OIr. brén, MW braen, MBret. brein), cf. PIE *bʰreHg- (IEW 165f.). "Although these words are sometimes derived from the same root as Lat. marceō 'be withered' (PIE *merk-, IEW 739), this is unsatisfactory from the formal point of view, since *mrk-no- would give PCelt. *mrikno-."}];309[134{S.v. Bret. brein 'pourri, en mauvais état, inculte', corresponding to Cornish bryn 'pourri, carié', Welsh braen 'putride corrompu, pourri', MIr. brén. These words are from Proto-Celtic *mrakno-.}];236[{S.v. W braen (1) 'rotten, putrid, corrupt, mouldy, withered, fragile', from IE *bʰreHg-, cf. Lat. fragrāre [entry last updated 2013].}];305[170-171{MIr. brén 'putrid, foul', MW braen 'putrid, corrupt', B brein 'id.' formally reflect PCl. *brakno-, *bragno- or *mr-. The usual reconstruction is *mrakno- in view of the proposed connection to Lat. marcēre 'to be withered, rotten', Lith. mir̃kti 'to become soft as a result of soaking'. [de Bernardo Stempel 1987](src-729):89 assumes a development *mrakno- < *mrHkno-, but the Lat. and Lith. forms clearly indicate that the root did not contain a laryngeal. Proto-Celtic -a- in this form is problematic. A different etymology can account for the Proto-Celtic *-a-: cf. OHG braccho, Du. brak 'hound', MHG brǣhen < *brēhian 'to smell', perh. Lat. fragrāre 'to emit a scent' < *bʰr(e)h₁g- ([Schrijver 1991](src-679):185), hence PCl. *brag-no- would reflect *bʰr(e)h₁g-no-.}];729[87];679[185]
Justification: The IE etymology for the lexemes in this class follows [Schrijver 1995](src-305):170-171, also followed by [Matasović 2009](src-50):73, and [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), occasionally connected by others to Lat. marcēre, cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):170 for further discussion.

Source: 296[T-121{Brittonic (Welsh traeth, Corn. trait, Mbr. trez 'sand') and Goidelic (OIr. tracht 'shore, bank') loanword from Latin tractus 'drawing, trail track'. Loth, Les mots latins dans les langues brittoniques 1892, s.v. traeth considers these words as Celtic however. }];275[{The analysis as a loanword is less probable if one considers that the underlying root is well represented in Insular Celtic (PIE *treHgʰ- / *treHg̑ʰ- or *tragʰ- / *trag̑ʰ- 'to drain off, to ebb away', cf. Schumacher 2004, 635-36) and that there are nouns from this root belonging into the same semantic field: Old Breton tre, MW trei m. 'ebbtide', Old Irish tráig 'i, m/f' 'ebbtide, beach' < Proto-Brit. *trăgi̯o-. The word for sand could thus originate from an inherited tu-stem cognate with Latin tractus, i.e. Proto-Celtic *traxtus. }]

50[231{S.v. Proto-Celtic *lab(a)ro- 'eloquent, talkative', from which the verbs in this class are denominal. Further cognates uncertain. "These Celtic words may have been onomatopoetic in origin| the connection with ME flappen 'hit' suggested by IEW (831) is a mere possibility (if this is correct, the PCelt. form of the root was *flab-), cf. also Germ. labern 'babble'."}];157[194-195{S.v. Gaul. labaro-, labro- 'éloquent, bavard, sonore', corresponding to W. llafar 'loquace', llyferydd 'voix, parole' (< *labaríi̯os), OBret. labar 'parler, dire', OCo. lauar 'sermo' Bret. helavar 'éloquent' < *su-labaros, OIr. labar 'talkative, arrogant', sulbair (*su-lab[a]ris) 'well-spoken', labraid 'il parle', etc. A possible connection with Lat. *labium, labrum 'lèvre'.}];309[453{Cf. s.v. Bret. lavar 'dire, diction, langage', from Old Breton labar 'dit, parole, maxime', corresponding to Co. lavar 'discours, dire, parole', W llafar 'déclaration, discours, parole', Ir. labhar 'sonore', ScG. labhar 'id.', from Proto-Celtic *labaro-.}];301[236{Attested as a second element in the three compounded nouns OBr. he-labar, dar-leber-iat and torleberieti. OBr. he-laber gl. graecus, 'who speaks good, is eloquent' (Fleuriot 1964a, 208) OBr. dar-leber, probably abbreviated for darleberiat gl. phitonicus (for pythonicus) 'soothsayer' (Fleuriot 1964a, 129) OBr. tor-leberieti gl. phitonistarum (pythonistarum) 'of the soothsayers'. Plural of a noun torleberiat, which contains leberiat 'sayer, one who says' (Fleuriot 1964a, 316)}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. [Delamarre 2003](src-157):453, [Matasović 2009](src-50):231 for various suggestions.

Source: 50[412{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wel-o- 'to see', from PIE *u̯el-o- 'see' (cf. Lat. uoltus 'face, facial expression', Goth. wulϸus 'wealth').}];141[675{S.v. 3. *u̯el- 'sehen, wahrnehmen' (IEW 1136-7).}];304[669-675{S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯el-e/o- 'sehen' from PIE 3. *u̯el- (LIV² 675, IEW 1. *u̯el-).}];301[187{In gloss: gueledint ou nimer 'were seen in their (big) number' (Angers 477A, fo. 14b). Seems to correspond to MW gwelydeint 'were seen'. See p. 191 for a list of all instances of the verbal root OBr. guel-, guil- 'to see'.}]
