Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯el-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE 3. *u̯el- 'to see, perceive' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):669-675, [Matasović 2009](src-50):412, [LIV²](src-141) 675).

Source: 309[317{S.v. Bret. gwri 'couture, surjet', corresponding to Co. gwry, W gwni.}];236[{S.v. W. gwnïaf: gwnïo 'to sew, stitch, seam, bind' etc., cf. Co. gwryas, OBret. gruiam, gl. suo, MBret. gruyat| Bret. gwriat, griat from root *u̯er- ‘troi, troelli, plygu’.}];304[346{"Fraglich ist hingegen, ob auch das kymrische Verb für 'nähen' und sein bretonisches Gegenstück auf *gn-ii̯e/o- zurückgehen (vgl. VKG II: 544) und wenn ja, wie. Die beiden Verben lauten mky. gwni-aw (Stamm /gu̯ni-/) bzw. mbret. gruy-at (Stamm /gu̯ri-/, GIB I154f., vgl. auch abret. gruiam gl. suo, DVB I: 180)| hinzuzufügen ist noch das mko. Substantiv gwry 'Naht' (RD 1921, zu lesen als /gu̯ri/). Diese Verbalstämme mky. /gu̯ni-/ und mbret. /gu̯ri-/ sowie das mko. Substantiv /gu̯ri/ müssten ebenfalls auf einer Kontamination von /gu̯ra(γ)-/ 'tun, machen' mit der Kontinuante von *gn-ii̯e/o- basieren."}];308[544]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes without satisfactory etymology. Proposed to be connected with PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to bear, beget; create' by [Pedersen 1913](src-308):544 via the sense 'make, do', although there are formal difficulties with this etymological identification (cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):346). [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) suggests a root *u̯er- 'to turn, spin (wool)' via an nasal-infix stem with an enlargement in *-b⁽ʰ⁾ (after [IEW](src-49) 1153), but this remains highly speculative. [Not in [LIV²](src-141).]

Source: 80[170-171{S.v. Hitt. alpu- 'pointed' Possibly to be connected with Welsh llym, Breton lemm 'sharp' [cf. [cognate set 5421](cog-5421)] via *l̥pu-, but this is ultimately unclear because of the debated semantics of the Hittite lexeme.}]
Justification: The precise semantics of the Hittite lexeme are not entirely clear, and therefore the etymology is also uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):170-171).

Source: 50[66{S.v. Proto-Celtic *birro- 'short' (no IE etymology).}];309[103-104{S.v. Bret. berr 'court, à court, de court', corresponding to Co. ber, W byr, Ir. ber and ScG. beàrr from Proto-Celtic *berso-.}];296[B:42{S.v. OIr. berr 'court'.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:42, [Matasović 2009](src-50):66; cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):103-104). For various suggestions, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:42. Root ref. form for this class follows [Matasović 2009](src-50):66.

Source: 50[226{S.v. Proto-Celtic *krok(ke)no- 'skin'. The reflexes of the individual languages do not point to a common proto-form, i.e. W points to the original *krokno-, while other languages show reflexes of *krokkeno-. The connection with PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, to grate, to cut off' (LIV² 556, IEW 938-40) is difficult. Consequently, we are probably dealing with a loanword from some non-IE language.}];296[C:243-244{S.v. OIr. croiccenn 'peau'| two different proto-forms are required to be postulated: *krokno- > W croen, and with gemination of medial -k-, *krokkeno- > Ir. croccenn, Bret. croc'hen.}]
Justification: Two variants within Celtic: W croen points to Proto-Celtic *krokno-, while the Goidelic and Breton forms point to a variant *krokkeno- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:243-244; [Matasović 2009](src-50):226). Further etymology less certain; traditionally from an extended variant of *(s)ker- 'cut' (cf. {ref IEW 938-940), but the derivation is formally difficult (cf. the entries in Vendryes et al. and Matasović).

Source: 309[423-24{Brittonic borrowing, verb based on Latin quiēscō, quiēscere 'to rest, to take a rest, to relax'. }];275[{Latin quiēscere is based on PIE *kʷi̯eh₁- 'to rest' (LIV² 393). As Brittonic is p-Celtic, the anlaut k- of the verbs in question is not the expected reflex of this PIE root. The assumption of a borrowing is thus highly probable.}]
Justification: Loan into Brythonic Celtic of Latin quiēscere 'to rest' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):423-424, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 50[60-61{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bekko- 'small'. "These words could originally be adjectives derived from the verb 'to break', PIE *bʰeg- (Skt. bhanákti, Arm. bekanem, IEW 114f.). The semantic development 'broken into pieces' > 'small' is possible, and PIE *bʰeg-ko- would yield PCelt. *bekko- regularly. However, an adjective *bʰeg-ko- does not seem to be formed according to the rules of PIE word formation."}];296[B:24{S.v. OIr. bec 'petit'. A word with expressive gemination and of unknown origin, like many words designating smallness.}];151[355{S.v. OIr. becc 'small', with no clear connections outside of Celtic. It could be a loanword from a substratum language or an ad hoc expressive formation (so [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) s.v.).}];301[80{OBr. becan, bican < becc- + suffix -an.}]
Comment: There is a second lexeme for small, PCL. *leg-o, lag-o 'small', from PIE  *h₁le(n)gʷʰ-'small, light' (IEW: 661) Matasović (2009, 236). Does not seem to be the Swadesh term in Brittonic, because of its pejorative connotations, cf. MW 'law 'small, sad', OBr. lau gl. petusculum 'small, bad', MoBret. law 'miserable, bad'.
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:24, [Lucht 2007](src-151):355), cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):60-61 for a derivation from *bʰeg-ko-, although Matasović admits that this proposal is formally difficult and speculative.

Source: 309[397-398{S.v. Bret. klew 'ouïe', from Old Breton clou 'perception, audition', corresponding to Co. clew, W. clyw in the same sense as Ir. cliù 'honneur, réputation', from Proto-Celtic *kleu- and related to Lat. cluere.}]
Justification: Derivatives of PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):413-417, cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):397-398, {ref LIV² 334-335).

Source: 50[284{S.v. Proto-Celtic *natrik- 'serpent', from on PIE *(s)n̥h₂-tr- 'water snake' (IEW 747), cf. Lat. natrīx, Goth. nadre (gen.pl), ON naðr 'viper, snake'. The basic root is PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to swim' (LIV² 572).}];165[381{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nadra- 'adder, snake', from PIE *nh̥₁tr-ó- (cf. Lat. natrix 'water snake', OIr. nathir 'viper' < *nh̥₁-tr-ik-). K. considers the word "[a] West European word of uncertain origin."}];468[403{S.v. ON naðr 'Schlange', generally connected with Lat. natrix 'Wasserschlange', OIr. nathir 'Schlange'.}];179[262{S.v. Goth. N1 *nadrs 'ἔχιδνα', 'snake, viper' (only attested in gen.pl.). Either to PIE *(s)nē- 'twist, wind', or less likely *snā- 'swim'.}];54[402{Cf. s.v. Lat. natrix, -icis 'water-snake| penis', from PIE *snh₁-tr-ih₂ 'who spins around| snake' (cf. OIr. nathir, W neidr, MBret. azr, OIc. naðr < OE nǣddre, OS nādra, OHG nātara 'adder')| derived from the root of sneō 'I spin'.}];296[N:4-5{S.v. OIr. nathir 'serpent', going back to a stem *natrik- ([Pedersen 1913](src-308):98), a stem *natri- is seen in W neidr, etc. [Pedersen 1913](src-308):45 assumes an agent noun in *-te/or with various additional suffixes to the root *(s)nā- 'nager'| [IEW](src-49) 767 attaches to the root *(s)nē- 'tordre, se tordre'.}]
Justification: The cognacy of the Germanic, Celtic, and Italic (cf. Lat. natrīx) lexemes is generally agreed, but the IE root etymology is debated. More commonly ascribed to PIE *(s)neh₁- 'twist, spin' ([LIV²](src-141) 571-572, [IEW](src-49) 973). Also possible, but less likely to *(s)neh₂- 'bathe, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 572-573, [IEW](src-49) 971-972). Cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):403, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):262, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):381, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:4-5, [Matasović 2009](src-50):284, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):402).

Source: 50[41-42{S.v. Proto-Celtic *argyo- 'white' [Adj], 'snow' [Noun], related to Proto-Celtic *arganto- 'silver' < PIE *h₂erg̑-n̥t-o-, cf. IEW 64. Alternative etymology: Hamp 1974, GPC and Deshayes (2003: 218) would relate these words to Olr. arg 'drop' « *argo-), but this word is attested almost only in glossaries, its gender and stem-formation are unknown, and its meaning cannot easily be derived from the original meaning 'white'.}];309[218{S.v. Bret. erc'h 'neige', corresponding to Co. ergh (OCo. irch), W eira (MW eiry) and OIr. arg 'goutte', from Proto-Celtic *arg(i)o-.}];296[A:88{Cf. s.v. OIr. arg 'goutte'. One compares W eiry, eira 'neige', MCo. irch gl. nix, Bret. erc'h starting from a root *(s)perg- or *spreg- 'jaillir, bondir' according to WP II 672ff. but only OIr. arg 'goutte' can be attached to this root. It cannot be excluded that the Brythonic words in the sense 'snow' may have been an adjective meaning 'white' and connected to Gk. ἀργός 'clair, blanc'.}]
Justification: The Brythonic words in the meaning 'snow' in this set are sometimes compared to Old Irish arg 'drop' and connected to a root *sperg- or *spreg-, but this lexeme is only marginally attested. A better etymology for the Brythonic words would be a connection with the IE root *h₂erg̑̑- 'white, bright, shining' via Proto-Celtic *argi̯o- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:88, [Matasović 2009](src-50):41-42). Because of the uncertainties over the proposed Old Irish cognates, this latter etymology has been followed in this class, but note that it is not mentioned s.v. *h₂erg̑- in [NIL](src-274).

Source: 50[252-253{S.v. Proto-Celtic *magino- 'stone, place', cognate with Proto-Celtic *magos 'plain, field'. The Brittonic words are cognate with OIr. magen, magan ā, f 'place' (DIL maigen). "W maen is not just any stone, but one 'having some speciality or a particular use', according to GPC. The Olr. form in -a is a collective built from *magino-, like Lat. loca from locus. The attribution in IEW (709) to the root *meg̑h₂- 'great' is possible, cf. Skt. mahī́- 'earth' < *'the great one')."}];309[484-485{S.v. Bret. maen 'pierre, noyau', from Old Breton maen, main corresponding to Co. mên 'pierre, rocher', from Brythonic *magno-.}];296[M:9{Cf. s.v. OIr. magen 'endroit, place'. Despite the difference in meaning, doubtlessly to be connected with W maen 'pierre' and other Brythonic words for 'stone'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *magino- 'stone, place'. Further connections not fully certain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:9, [Matasović 2009](src-50):252-253 for further discussion.

Source: 50[113{S.v. Proto-Celtic *efino- 'right, correct, equal', from PIE *h₁ep-(i)no- 'even' (IEW 505), cf. Goth. ibns 'flat, even', OHG eban 'equal, same'. "There are some formal difficulties with this etymology| a pre-form *epno-, the exact match of the Germanic words, would presumably develop as *ewno- > *owno- > W **un. Could these words be derived from PIE *h₁epi- 'on, by' with the suffix *-no-? The vowel *-i- could have been lost in Germanic through syncope. The type of formation would be parallel to PCelt. *efirom 'behind'."}];294[248{Dunkel denies the existence of *ep-nó- underlying Proto-Germanic *eƀna- in Goth. ibns, Old Norse jafn, Old High German eban. In addition, he does not reconstruct *h₁epi-no-  proposed by Matasović.  }];309[222{S.v. Bret. eün (effn, 1499, eun 1633), 'droit, simple', from Old Breton eunt 'juste, équitable, égal' with a non-etymological final -t. This word corresponds to Brythonic ebn from *ibn, apparently to Engl. even, OHG eban and to Goth. ibns.}];179[202{S.v. Goth. I3. *ibns 'πεδινός', 'level', only dat.sg. ibnamma, connected with OIc. jafn, OE ifn, OHG eban 'even', etc. No clear etymology outside of Germanic| contrary to [Pedersen 1909](src-307):92 and others, not to be connected with MBret. effen, OCo. eun-, etc.}]
Justification: The Celtic forms in this class are often considered to be connected with Germanic in OHG eben, Goth. ibns, etc. (cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):92), but there are many formal difficulties with this identification (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):222, [Matasović 2009](src-50):113, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):202)

Source: 50[362{S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯ēd-o- 'swell', from PIE *su̯ei̯d- 'to sweat' (IEW 1043, LIV² 607), cf. Skt. svedate, Gk. ἰδίω, OHG swizzen, Latv. svîstu, TochB syelme. For the semantic development 'sweat' > 'swell' see KPV 609.}];304[610-611{S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯ei̯d-e/o- 'anschwellen', from PIE *su̯ei̯d- (LIV² 607).}];141[607{Cf. s.v. 1. *su̯ei̯d- 'in Schweiß ausbrechen' (IEW 1043).}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ei̯d-e/o- 'to swell up', generally connected with PIE 1. *su̯ei̯d- 'to break out in sweat' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):610-611, [Matasović 2009](src-50):362, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 607).

Source: 299[269{From Proto-Celtic *lusto- or *lustā-, based on leu̯s-, as desiderative formation from PIE *leu̯H- 'to detach oneself, to losen' (LIV 374f., fn. 7). Welsh llost f. seems to originate from *lustā-, OIr. los (m. o) from *lusto-. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):412 reconstructs a formation with *-st-, i.e. *lus-sto/eh₂-.}];141[417{Cf. s.v. *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (IEW 681-2).}]

309[713{S.v. Bret. taol 'coup, jet', corresponding to Co. towl, W tafl 'catapulte, jet, fronce', and Ir. tabhall (OIr. tabul) and ScG. tabhal 'fronde', all from Proto-Celtic *tab-allo-.}];296[T:3{Cf. s.v. OIr. taball 'tablette de bois à écrire', a borrowing from Lat. tabellā and probably identical with táball 'sling (with a wooden handle), weapon for throwing missiles'. It is not to be connected with Breton taol etc.}]

50[420{S.v. Proto-Celtic *widu- 'wood', from PIE *u̯idʰu- 'wood' (IEW 1117) (cf. OE widu, wudu, Lith. vidùs 'interior').}];275[{The Brittonic singular guið 'wood' was reinterpreted as a plural 'trees', from which a singulative 'tree' is derived. (Singular: Proto-Brittonic *u̯id-u-s > *guid, plural: *u̯id-ou̯-es (if proterokinetic) > *guidou).}];352[1232{Cf. s.v. OLith. vidùs 'Inneres, Mitte' (derived noun viduriaĩ (sm.pl.) 'Inneres, Eingeweide'| BSl. cf. Latv. vidus 'Mitte, Mittelstück, Inneres', OPr. widus 'Naht im Stiefel'), from PIE *u̯idʰh₁ú- 'Inneres' (cf. OIr. fid 'Baum, Holz', MW gwŷdd, MBret. gwez 'Bäume', ON viðr 'Baum, Holz', OE widu, wudu 'Holz| Baum| Wald', OHG witu 'Brennholz, Bauholz').}]

50[343{S.v. Proto-Celtic *skiy-o- 'vomit, spew', from PIE *sk̑ei̯-(d)- 'defecate' (?) (IEW 920f., cf. Lith. skíesti 'to have diarrhoea', ON skíta 'defecate', Engl. shit.}];304[578-579{S.v. Proto-Celtic *skei̯-e/o- 'erbrechen, speien', cf. PIE *sk̑ei̯-(d)- 'defecate' (?) (IEW 920f.), cf. *sk̑ʰei̯- 'to split, to tear' (LIV² 547f.) and Schumachers remark concerning the final -d- of the root. The Brittonic forms are secondary verbs derived from the verbal noun (MW chwyt).  Later Goidelic verbal forms containing -th- like Middle Irish sceithid are based on the Verbal noun sceith f. ā < *sci-tā.}];296[S:37-38{S.v. sceïd 'il vomit, crache, rejette| il jallit, coule, se déverse', one attaches the verb to the base *skei- 'couper, séparer', an enlargement of sek-, but without the enlargement -d- found in Gk. σχίζω 'je fends, je sépare', Lat. scindō, OIc. skīta, etc. 'cacare'. ([Pedersen 1909](src-307):77, [IEW](src-49) 920).}]
Justification: For the root ref. form, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):578 assuming an unextended root form, probably to be connected with IE *(s)k̑ʰei̯d- ([LIV²](src-141) 547-548); cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:37-38, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):578-579, [Matasović 2009](src-50):343 for further discussion.

Source: 309[315{Cognate with the noun Modern Breton gwolch, Corn. golgh, Welsh golch 'washing, lotion, urine'| all from Proto-Celtic *u̯olk-o-.}];141[679, 676{S.v. ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein/werden' (IEW 1145), probably a variant of *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145).}];50[427{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- 'rain, wet weather', from PIE *u̯elk- (IEW 1145f.). The relationship of the Celtic lexemes with PIE *u̯el(H)g- (Lith. vìlgyti 'make wet', CS vlaga, Russ. dial. vológa, Cz. vlaha 'wetness', OHG welk 'wet, moist' is unclear. The two roots *u̯elk- and *u̯elg- should be somehow related. Perhaps there was an original root noun *u̯ōlg-s 'rain' (phonetically *[u̯ōlks]), gen.sg. *u̯olg-os and assume that some languages generalised the voiceless velar from the nom.sg. throughout the paradigm.}];352[1242-1243{Cf. s.v. Lith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen', from PIE *u̯elg- (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter' folcaid 'waschen (Kopf)', MW gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke'). The reconstruction of the root with final *g is based on Balto-Slavic and Germanic, the Celtic lexemes reflect *u̯elk-. The reason for this deviation is unclear, but could be due to an assimilation of final *g in the 2nd or 3rd person singular in the present or aorist stem.}];269[{Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 676, [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243| cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and [Matasović 2009](src-50):427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.}]
Justification: Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 676, [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and [Matasović 2009](src-50):427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.

Source: 50[107{From Proto-Celtic *dubro-/ā- 'dark', cf. PIE *dʰubʰ- 'black' (IEW 263ff.) In OIr. the adj. 'black' is also used as the substantivized adjective dobur 'water'. Brittonic continues only the word for 'water', Old Welsh dubr, MW dwfr, ModW dŵr, Breton, Cornish dour.}];274[122-124{S.v. *dʰeu̯b- 'tief' (IEW 267f., EIEC 154), the Celtic forms in this class go back to *dʰub-ro/ah₂- > Proto-Celtic *dub-ro- (OIr. dobur, OW dubr, MW dwfr, Bret., OCo. dour 'Wasser').}];296[D:123{S.v. dobur (2) 'eau'}]
Justification: Etymology in this class follows [NIL](src-274) 122-124; cf. also the discussion of [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:123, [Matasović 2009](src-50):107.

Source: 50[426{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wlikʷo- 'wet', from PIE *u̯elk-u̯o- 'wet' (IEW 1145). MoBret. gwleb preserved the feminine form, PCelt. *u̯likʷā| cf. also s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- 'rain, wet weather', from PIE *u̯elk- (IEW 1145f.). The relationship of the Celtic lexemes with PIE *u̯el(H)g- (Lith. vìlgyti 'make wet', CS vlaga, Russ. dial. vológa, Cz. vlaha 'wetness', OHG welk 'wet, moist' is unclear. The two roots *u̯elk- and *u̯elg- should be somehow related. Perhaps there was an original root noun *u̯ōlg-s 'rain' (phonetically *[u̯ōlks]), gen.sg. *u̯olg-os and assume that some languages generalised the voiceless velar from the nom.sg. throughout the paradigm.}];240[70-71{S.v. OW gulip 'liquid, wet' [gwlyb], from IE *u̯l̥k-u-, √u̯elk- 'feucht, naß' ([IEW](src-49) 1145).}];141[679, 676{S.v. ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein/werden' (IEW 1145), probably a variant of *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145).}];352[1242-1243{Cf. s.v. Lith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen', from PIE *u̯elg- (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter' folcaid 'waschen (Kopf)', MW gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke'). The reconstruction of the root with final *g is based on Balto-Slavic and Germanic, the Celtic lexemes reflect *u̯elk-. The reason for this deviation is unclear, but could be due to an assimilation of final *g in the 2nd or 3rd person singular in the present or aorist stem.}]
Justification: Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 676, [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and [Matasović 2009](src-50):427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.

Source: 50[423{S.v. Proto-Celtic *windo- 'white'. No etymology outside Celtic.}];157[320-321{S.v. Gaul. uindos 'blanc| heureux', also attested in insular Celtic (OIr. find 'blanc', W gwynn, OCo. guyn 'albus', OBret. guinn 'blanc, lumineux'. One connects either to the root of Gk. ἰνδάλλομαι 'j'apprais', Skt. vindáti 'il trouve' formed to the nasal-infix stem of IE *u̯ei̯d- 'voir (clairement), savoir' or to the root *su̯ei̯d⁽ʰ⁾- 'briller', cf. Lat. sīdus, -eris 'étoiles', Lith. svidė́ti 'briller'.}];151[430{S.v. OIr. find / finn 'white', from earlier *windo-/ā, but with no certain correspondences outside of Celtic.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. [Delamarre 2003](src-157):320-321, [Lucht 2007](src-151):430 for various proposals. See also ([Matasović 2009](src-50):423.

Source: 50[274{S.v. Proto-Celtic *mogu- 'servant', from PIE *mogʰ-u- 'young person' ([IEW](src-49) 696), cf. Goth. magus 'boy', mawi 'young girl', Av. maγava- 'unmarried').}];309[498{S.v. Bret. maw 'gaillard', from Old Breton mauu 'juvénile, réjoui| jeune homme, serviteur', corresponding to Co. maw 'garçon, serviteur, jeune'| derived form mawes (moues, 1557) 'femme', corresponding to Co. mowes.}];296[M:70-71{Cf. s.v. OIr. mug 'garçon, serviteur', comparable to Germanic *magu- in Goth. magus 'garçon, valet', OIc. mǫgr 'fils, jeune homme', OE mazo 'fils, valet'.}];165[347{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative', from IE *magʰ-u- (cf. OIr. mug 'servant', Co. maw 'id.' < *magʰ-u-). A West European word of obscure origin.}];179[240{Cf. s.v. Goth. M3. magus 'παῖς', 'child, boy'. Etymology disputed, probably a non-IE term for 'son of maternal lineage' beside sunus 'son of paternal inheritance' (cf. OIr. mug, less likely IE *mogus 'boy, servant').}];269[{Derived from Old Breton mauu 'young man, servant' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):498), further connected to Old Irish mug 'boy, servant' and generally compared to lexemes from Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:70-71, [Matasović 2009](src-50):274). Further etymology uncertain| the lexemes may well have been substratum borrowings in the Western Indo-European languages (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):240, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):347 for discussion of the Germanic comparanda).}]
Justification: Derived from Old Breton mauu 'young man, servant' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):498), further connected to Old Irish mug 'boy, servant' and generally compared to lexemes from Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:70-71, [Matasović 2009](src-50):274). Further etymology uncertain; the lexemes may well have been substratum borrowings in the Western Indo-European languages (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):240, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):347 for discussion of the Germanic comparanda).

Source: 50[198{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kayto- 'wood', from IE *kai̯to- 'wood, field' ([IEW](src-49) 521), cf. Goth. haiϸi 'field'. The reflexes *kai̯to- are restricted to Celtic and Germanic| perhaps a borrowing from a NW European substratum language.}]
Justification: Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ([IEW](src-49) 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):198).

Source: 50[69{S.v. Proto-Celtic *blēdanī- 'year'. The forms point to three different stems: an ī-stem in OW bloidin, MW blwyddyn and a thematic stem *blēda, or *blēdom in W blwydd, OBret. blid, MoBret. bloaz m. and Co. bloth 'year'. W blynedd and OBret. blened originate from zero grade *blid-nii̯o- (originally an adjective?).}];296[B:59{S.v. OIr. bliadain 'an, année'. All the Celtic forms appear to be based on a root *bleid-, of unknown origin, to which several derived stems have been formed in Celtic: a nasal stem *bleid-n- / *blid-n-, and an i-stem *bleidnī- from which Ir. bliadain and W blwyddyn.}];733[79{Cf. for a discussion of the stem formation in Goidelic, with references to further literature.}]
Comment: etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 1012)
Justification: The forms seem to point back to a root *blei̯d- / *blid- to which different stems were formed within Celtic; further connections outside of Celtic uncertain (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:59, [Matasović 2009](src-50):69). See [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):79 for a discussion of the stem formation.

Source: 50[263{S.v. Proto-Celtic *melino- 'yellow', derived from Proto-Celtic *meli 'honey' (from PIE *meli cf. Lat. mel, Gk. μέλι, Hitt. melitt-, Arm. mełr, Alb. mjal).}];657[271{S.v. HONEY *mélit (gen. mlitós) 'honey'. We are dealing with an inherited stem *melit-, cf. OIr. mil 'honey', W. mêl 'honey', Lat. mel 'honey', OE mildēaw 'mildew' (< *'sweet sap') (> NE mildew), Goth. miliϸ 'honey', Alb. bletë (< *melitih₂ 'honey-bee'), Gk. μέλι 'honey', μέλισσα (< *melitih₂) 'honey-bee' Arm. mełr 'honey', Hitt. militt- 'honey', Luw. mallit- 'honey'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *melino- 'yellow', a derivative based on PIE *melit- 'honey' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):263, cf. [EIEC](src-657) 271).

Source: 309[366{S.v. Bret. kann adj. qual. 'blanc' from Proto-Celtic *kando-| from the adjective is derived the verb kannañ (cannaff 1499) 'blanchir, laver| se battre, combattre, bagarrir' identical to Cornish canna 'blanchir' and to Welsh cannaf, cannu 'blanchir'. The original meaning of the verb is 'to bleach laundry (by beating)' > 'to beat'.}];236[{Cf. s.v. W. can (1) 'white, shining, brilliant', cf. Lat. candere.}];54[87{Cf. s.v. Lat. candeō 'to shine, gleam' < Proto-Italic *kand-ē- 'to shine', cf. PIE *knd-ro- 'shining' (W cann 'brilliant', MBret. cann 'full moon' *<knd-| Skt. chándas- 'hymn of praise' < *skend-os-, candrá- 'brilliant' < *kend-ro-| Alb. hënë 'moon' < *skondnā-).}];141[554{Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)kend- 'erglänzen' (IEW 526).}]
Justification: Lexemes denominal from Proto-Celtic *kando- 'white', with the sense of 'to bleach laundry (by beating)' > 'to beat; to fight' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):336), further derived from PIE *skend- 'to shine' (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. Welsh cann 'white', [de Vaan 2008](src-54):87, [LIV²](src-141) 554; not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)).

Source: 50[134-135{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gʷeltā 'grass', further derived to Proto-Celtic *gʷel-o- 'graze, eat'. The identification of the IE root from which the related forms in Celtic are not generally agreed upon. Perhaps with Arm. klanem 'swallow', Russ. glotat' 'swallow', Lat. gluttio < PIE *gleu̯- (so [IEW](src-49) 365). Alternatively OE ceole, Germ. Kehle 'throat' < PIE *gel-, but if OIr. gelid is related to the word for grass, then the Celtic proto-form must contain initial *gʷʰ-, since PIE *gʷ- > Proto-Celtic *b-. There does not, however, appear to be evidence for a root *gʷʰel- 'to graze' in Indo-European.}];240[66{S.v. OW guel 'grass' < Brythonic *u̯elt-. According to [IEW](src-49) these words are to be connected with *u̯el- 'Haar, Wolle', but they could also belong to *gel- 'verschlingen'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic disputed; cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):66, [Matasović 2009](src-50):144-145 for various proposals. Root ref. form follows [Matasović 2009](src-50).

Source: 274[726-729{S.v. *u̯iH-ró- (m.) 'junger, kräftiger (Mann)' (IEW 1178).}];172[II:569-570{S.v. Ved. vīrá- 'Mann, kraftvoller Mann, Held, Sohn' (in Ir. OAv., YAv. vīra- 'Mann, Mensch', Sogd. wyr 'Ehemann', MPers. wīr 'Mann, Held', etc.), from PIE *u̯iHró- 'jugendkräftig, (junger) Mann, Krieger' (cf. Lith. výras 'Mann, Gatte', Latv. vir̃s 'Mann', Lat. uir, OIr. fer, Goth. wair 'Mann', etc.).}];353[505{S.v. Lith. výras 'man', from PIE *uiHró- (cf. Skt. vīrá-, Lat. vir, OIr. fer, Goth. wair).}];165[588{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wira- 'man', from PIE *uiH-ró- (cf. Skt. vīrá-, Av. vīra-, Lith. výras, Lat. vir, OIr. fer 'man, hero', etc.). The Germanic form developed from *u̯īró- by Dybo's Law of pretonic shortening.}];54[681{S.v. Lat. vir 'man', from PIE *uiH-ró- 'man, young man, warrior' (cf. OIr. fer, Skt. vīrá-, Lith. výras, Goth. wair). The short vowel in Latin is due to Dybo's law.}];50[423{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wiro- 'man', from PIE *uiHro- 'man' (cf. Skt. vīrá-, Lat. vir, OIr. fer, Goth. wair).}];352[1252-1253{S.v. OLith. výras 'Mann, Ehemann' (BSl. cf. Latv. vĩrs, OPr. wirs, wijrs), from PIE *u̯iH-ró- 'junger, kräftiger (Mann)' (cf. Ved. vīrá- 'Mann, Held', OAv. vīra- 'Mann, Mensch', YAv. vīra- 'id.', MPers. vīr 'id.', Lat. vĭr 'Mann, Ehemann', OIr. fer 'Mann', OW gur, MW gwr 'id.', Celtiberian UIROS 'id.?', Goth. wair 'Mann', ON verr 'id.', OHG wer 'id., OE wer 'Mann, Wergeld', TochA wir 'jung, jugendkräftig').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *u̯iH-ró- 'young, powerful man' ([NIL](src-274) 726-729, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:569-570, [ALEW](src-352) 1252-1253, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):588, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):681, [Matasović 2009](src-50):423).

Source: 296[A:20-21{S.v. OIr. aér 'air, souffle, atmosphère', a borrowing from Lat. aēr, like W awyr, 'air', MCo. awir gl. aer, MBret. aer.}];236[{S.v. W. awyr 'air, layer of air, atmosphere'}];728[4{S.v. Manx aer (cf. OIr. aër, ScG. athar).}];231[24{S.v. ScG. athar 'sky, air', c.f Ir. aieur, air, sky, OIr. aer, aier, W. awyr | from Lat. aer, whence Eng. air.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Latin aēr 'air, atmosphere, sky' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:20-21, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):4, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):24, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 236[{S.v. W clymaf, cylymaf: clymu, cylymu 'to bind, tie, set, unite, couple' (cf. Co. kelmy, Bret. coulmaff, Late Bret. koulma).}]

309[745{S.v. Bret. tro 'tour, alentours, partour' Denominal verb based on Middle Breton tro (1499) from Old Breton tro. This noun is Cognate with Cornish tro 'turn' and Welsh tro 'circuit, instant, occasion'. All originate from Celtic *trog-o- 'traction'.}];301[321{Cites etymological suggestions. CHECK}];348[272{From Proto-Celtic *trog-o- 'to pull' (lat. trahere etc., Celt. *treg-et- 'foot').}]
Justification: Brythonic Celtic lexemes continuing denominal verbs from Proto-Celtic *trogo-, further etymology uncertain (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Deshayes 2003](src-309):745, Schrijver 1995}:133; not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)).

Source: 81[395{From Proto-Slavic *pȅpelъ | *pȍpelъ  m. o (c) ‘ashes’, PIE *pepelh₁-o-, cf. p. 390 for the discussion of the root.}];141[469{Reconstructs the PIE root as *?pel- 'to flame up', i.e. without the laryngeal. }];352[752-753{S.v. OLith. pẽlenas 'Asche| Herd' (BSl. Latv. pȩ̀lni 'Asche', OPr. pelanne 'Asche', pelanno 'Herd'). Different etymological connections are considered:}];259[463{PS *popel- and *pepel-. Reflex of PIE *pel- 'burn' with a reduplication.}];598[234{Related to Old Prussian pelanne, Lithuanian pelenaĩ, Latvian pę́lni 'ash' and probably to Latin pollen 'fine flour', pulvis 'dust', Greek πάλη 'dust, fine flour'. Reduplication of the root.}];591[430{PS *po-pel- is a compound of the prefix *po- and root *pel- with a meaning 'substance that remains after burning'.}];593[488{Two possible etymologies are *po-pel- 'subtance that remains after burning' and a relation to Latin pollen 'dust, flour', Greek πάλη and Old Indic pálala- 'poridge, dust, dirt'.}];595[3: 25{Most probably *pel- 'burn' with a reduplication.}];594[{A reduplicated root *pelH- 'dust, flour', found also in Latin pollen, pulvis Old Indic pálala- Greek πάλη, παιπάλη, and in PS *pelv- 'chaff'. A relation to *pel- 'burn' is less probable.}];608[332-333{Reduplicated root *pel- 'burn'.}];636[117-118{Reduplication of *pel- 'burn', related to Old Indic palalam 'a kind of poridge', Old Prussian pelanne 'ash', Lithuanian pelenaĩ 'ash', Latvian pélni 'ash', Old Greek πάλη 'dust', παιπάλη 'fine flour', παλύνο 'strew', Latin pollen 'fine flour', pulvis 'dust', and palea 'chaff'.}];531[445-446{The etymology is not entirely clear. Most probably a reflex of PIE *pel- 'burn' and related to reduplicated Slavic form *popel-.}];589[638{Reduplication of *pel- 'dust, flour' or *pel- 'burn'. The first variant is more probable.}];249[{There are two hypotheses of the etymology of the Slavic *popel-, *pepel-. The first one assumes here a root ?*pel- 'burn' which has, however, very sparse - if any certain - attestation beyond Slavic (cf. LIV: 469). The second one assumes a relationship to various IE lexemes with meanings 'dust', '(fine) flour', 'chaff', 'poridge', etc. (*pelh₁- and/or *(s)pelH-). However, some of these lexemes are not necessarily related to each other (de Vaan 2008:  440, 477, 498). Some of the cited Slavic sources acknowledge two independent PIE roots in this case, while some other only one root with a strong semantic differentiation. From the semantic point of view the assumption of a separate root ?*pel- 'burn' and assigning the Slavic word for 'ash' to this root seems to be most resonable.}];321[258{S.v. Wakhi parg 'зола, пепел', to IE *pel- (Ru. пе-пел, Lith. pelenaĩ).}]

81[285-286{Proto-Slavic *lòšь adj. 'bad'. The rejection of the traditional comparison with Proto Germanic *lasiwa for semantic reasons is hard to understand.}];458[16: 92-94{It is assumed that PS *loš- is a cognate of Gothic lasiws 'weak', Old English leswe 'weak, bad', Old High German er-leswen 'weaken', Old Icelandic lasenn 'weak, destroyed', and Tocharian A lyäṣk- 'soft'. However, this assumption is not convincing semantically. *loš- is also unlikely to be a cognate of Irish losc 'lame' and Greek λοξός 'crooked'. In the light of (dialectal) Serbo-Croat ļȍhav 'weak, sickly', lohotan 'ulgy', and Russian loh 'lazy-bones, fool', *lošĭ is to be interpreted as *lox-jo-. Its further IE cognacy is unclear. It was possibly used in magic or sacral meanings which could make its structure and cognacy relationships obscure.}];179[227{Slavic lošĭ is a cognate of Gothic lasiws 'weak', along with Tocharian A lyäṣk- and Latin sublestus 'weak'. The PIE root is *ləs- an extended form of *lēy.}];598[526{Russian lošij is assumed to be related to Gothic lasiws and Lower German las 'weak'. Further, a comparison with Greek λοξός 'crooked' and Irish losc 'lame' (*loskos) is also thinkable.}];603[3: 481{Related to Gothic lasiws 'weak', Old Islandic lasinn 'weak, destroyed', Old High German er-leswen 'weaken', Old Low German las 'tired', and Tocharian ljäsk- 'softness'.}];66[871{Further connections of λοξόσ are not very clear.}];249[{There are no semantic obstacles to accept the traditional view, linking the Slavic lexeme to the Germanic ones, even if Old English lyso 'bad, wrong, evil' does not belong here (Derksen 2008: 286), cf. Slovenian slab 'bad' < 'weak'. The Slavic forms with -x- are very likely to be expressive, in particular Russian loh (a derivation like in Polish brach < brat 'brother' or piach < piasek 'sand' is thinkable| note that the morphonological alternation š/x is very common in the Slavic languages, so an analogy is also possible). In any case, -x- can not be original in this phonological context. The reconstuction PS *los-jo- (ultimately PIE *leh₁-?, cf. (Lehmann 1986: 227, 232)) is most reasonable.}];595[2: 151-152{PS *lošĭ < los-jo is likely to be cognate of Gothic lasiws 'weak', Old English leswe 'weak', Middle German erleswen 'weaken'. A relationship to Latin sublestus 'weak' is less probable.}];589[320{It has certain cognates only in the Germanic languages, e. g. Gothic lasiws 'weak'. PS *lošĭ is a reflex of PIE root *lē- with an extention *-s- and suffix *-jo-}]
Comment: Cognate with Gothic 'lasiws'.

Source: 81[174{S.v. Proto-Slavic *golěmъ 'big' (ESSJa VI 202-204). "The root of this adjective may be identified with the root of Lith. galė́ti 'be able' and W gallu 'id.' which is best reconstructed as *gal(H), with "European" a."}];141[185-186{Cf. s.v. *gelH- 'Macht bekommen über' (IEW 351). Cf. n1: May also be reconstructed as *galH- if *a transmitted by the individual languages continues the full-grade| *gelH- is nowhere attested.}];603[262-263{Further etymology is not entirely certain. It is related to Lithuanian galėti 'can', galia 'power', Irish gal 'courage', Old Breton gal 'power, strenght'. PIE *gal- or *ghal-.}];458[202-204{It is related to Lithuanian galėti 'can' and probably to Oscan valaimo- 'best, very good' and Latin valēre 'be strong'.}];601[2: 153-154{It can be related to Lithuanian galėti 'can'.}]
Justification: Adjectives continuing Proto-Slavic Proto-Slavic *golěmŭ 'big', whose root etymology is generally agreed to be related to Baltic lexemes such as Lithuanian galė́ti 'to be able' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):174, [ESSJa](src-458) VI:202-204). Further to PIE *gelH- or *galH- 'to have power over' ([LIV²](src-141) 185-186, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 287-289).

Source: 352[745-746{Cf. s.v. OLith. paũtas 'Ei, Hoden'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'egg' is a a vr̥ddhi derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird', which is found in Baltic through the derivatives pùtė 'Huhn', putýtis 'Küken', Latv. putns 'Vogel'. Further are compounds like Lith. pùt-pela, Latv. putpele 'Wachtel'. In Slavic the diminutives OCS pъtica, SCr. ptȉca, Ru. ptíca 'Vogel' and SCr. pȁtka 'Ente'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' has no plausible connections outside of Balto-Slavic.}];81[424-425{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pъtica 'bird', from Balto-Slavic *put- (cf. also Proto-Slavic *pъtakъ 'bird', *pъtъka 'bird', Latv. putns) [No further cognates given.]}];353[374{S.v. Lith. pùtė 'chicken, bird' (Latv. pùtns 'bird'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *put- (cf. OCS pъtakъ 'bird', etc.). The Balto-Slavic forms are sometimes connected with Skt. putrá- 'son, child, young of an animal', Lat. putillus 'very young, tiny', pullus 'foal, chick, young of an animal'.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes, perhaps to be further connected with PIE *putlo- 'son', but this proposed connection is generally considered to be uncertain ([ALEW](src-352) 745-746, [Derksen 2008](src-81):424-425, [Derksen 2015](src-353):375).

Source: 81[202{S.v. Proto-Slavic *xāpàti 'seize' (ESSJa VIII 18-19). [No etymology outside of Slavic given.]}];458[8: 18-19{Proto-Slavic *xapati. The root has an ideophonic origin and no reasonable further etymology can be given.}]
Justification: Of onomatopoeic origin. No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:18-19, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):202).

Source: 172[I:397-398{S.v. Ved. kr̥ṣná- 'schwarz, dunkel'.  Mayrhofer reconstructs *kr̥snó-, cf. Balt. *kirsna- (OPruss. kirsnan 'black'), Proto-Slavic *čьr(ch)na- > OCS črьnъ 'black, dark', etc.}];81[92{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ (adj.) 'black' (ESSJa IV 155-157), from PIE *kr̥s-nó- (cf. Skt. kr̥ṣṇá- 'black').}];353[247{S.v. Lith. kir̃snas 'black (of a horse)' (OPr. kirsnan 'black'), from PIE *krs-no- (cf. OCS črьnъ, Skt. kr̥ṣṇá- 'black').}];269[{As the only cognates are found in satəm languages, the possibility of a root reconstruction *k⁽ʷ⁾ers- with a labiovelar *kʷ cannot be excluded.}];458[4: 155-157{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ(jъ), from PIE *kirno- or *kirsno- (cf. Ved. kr̥ṣṇá-).}];442[179{S.v. 3451 Ved. kr̥ṣṇá- 'dark blue, black' RV.}]
Justification: An Indic and Balto-Slavic isogloss ([EWAia](src-172) I:397-398, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):179 no. 3451, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:155-157, [Derksen 2008](src-81):92, [Derksen 2015](src-353):247). Because cognates are only found in languages that have undergone the satəm merger, the original identity of the velar as a plain velar *k or labiovelar *kʷ cannot be more precisely determined.

Source: 274[444-448{S.v. kreu̯h₂- '(geronnenes) Blut, Blut außerhalb des Körpers' (IEW 621f., EIEC 71). The Lithuanian and Old Prussian forms go back to PIE *krou̯(h₂)-i̯ó- which is also attested in the Ved. adj. kravya- 'bloody'. The Slavonic forms go back to a root noun with zero grade, PIE *kruh₂-.}];178[I:665{S.v. Russ. кровь 'Blut', from Proto-Slavic *kry, Gen. *krъve.}];81[254{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kry 'blood' (ESSJa XIII 67-70), from PIE *kruh₂-s| *kreuh₂- (cf. Lith. kraũjas, Skt. kravíṣ- 'raw meat', Skt. kravyá- 'raw meat', Gk. κρέας 'meat', Lat. cruor 'raw blood').}];353[255{S.v. Lith. kraũjas 'blood' (OPr. crauyo, krawia 'blood'), from PIE *kruh₂-s| *kreuh₂- (cf. Skt. kravíṣ- 'raw meat', kravyá- 'raw meat', Gk. κρέας 'meat', Lat. cruor 'raw blood'). The Baltic forms reflect a derivative in *-i̯o- to the root noun reflected in Slavic.}];352[520-521{S.v. OLith. kraũjas 'Blut' (BSl. s.v. Latv. kreve 'geronnenes Blut, Schorf', OPr. crauyo 'Blut', OCS krъvь 'Blut', etc.), from PIE *kreu̯h₂- 'Blut außerhalb des Körpers' (Ved. kravíṣ- 'rohes, blutiges Fleisch', kravyá- 'blutig', YAv. A.sg. xrūm 'blutiges (rohes) Fleisch', OAv. xrūra- 'gewalttätig, blutig, grausam', Gk. κρέας 'Fleisch, Fleischstück', Lat. cruor, -ōris 'dickes Blut (außerhalb des Körpers), OIr. crú '(stockendes) Blut' ON hrár 'roh', etc.).}];458[13: 67-70{PS *kry, *krŭve with an original meaning 'driping blood'.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ([NIL](src-274) 444-448, [ALEW](src-352) 520-521, [Derksen 2015](src-353):255, [ESSJa](src-458) 13:67-70, [Derksen 2008](src-81):254).

Source: 54[140{S.v. Lat. costa 'rib', de Vaan acknowledges the possibility of deriving the Slavonic forms from PIE *Host- with a singular development of *H > *k, but he rejects the connection with Latin costa. His argument is the existence of Latin os, ossis. Latin costa is thus "an isolated word without etymology".}];81[239{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kôstь 'bone' (ESSJa XI 167-173). "The relationship with the otherwise isolated Lat. costa ‘rib’ seems quite possible. An interesting hypothesis is to regard the *k of *kȏstь as the reflex of the initial laryngeal of PIE *h₂ost- ‘bone’, cf. Skt. ásthi, Gk. ὀστέον, in an Indo-European substratum language (cf. Kortlandt 1997b: 47, where the option is dismissed, however). Meillet (e.g. 1921, Ét. II: 262) regards the *k as a prefix. If the root is *h₂ost-, we are probably dealing with an original neuter *kosti."}];650[47];651[1-2];652[II:262];458[11: 167-173, 12: 19-21{PS ostĭ 'awn, fishbone' is most probably related to PIE root for 'sharp' [PIE *h₂ek̑-], and not to PIE root for 'bone' [PIE *h₃est-] but the latter hypothesis is also reasonable. Generally, Slavic *kostĭ and *ostĭ seem to be unrelated.  The Latin word costa 'rib' is isolated and its etymology remains unclear. For a comparison with the Slavic lexeme additional closer cognates are necessary. The same applies to Old Indic kāṣṭhá- 'log'. All existing hypotheses linking the Slavic lexeme to Latin os, ossis etc. [PIE *h₃est-] (k- as prefix, borrowing from a substrate IE language, k- as prothesis disposing the hiatus in nominal phrases, metathesis of *osthr̥k or *ostĭka, contamination with other lexemes/roots) are unconvincing. The PS word *koza 'goat' (with analogues like Old Indic ajá or Lithuanian ožỹs) is not a further example for the 'irregular initial k-' in Slavic. This lexeme is most probably a loan from Altaic and the variation in the onset has its sources there (the variation is attested in Turkic). The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *kes- with a suffix *-to- (*kos-to-). The original meaning were 'bone protruding from under the skin, a dangling thing, a ticking thing'.}];259[253{The Slavic lexeme is related to PIE *h₃est-. The irregular k- is probably due to a contamination with another root (maybe related to Latin costa).}];608[216{The lexeme is related to Latin costa 'rib'.}];593[304{The Slavic lexeme is usually linked to Latin os etc. (PIE *h₃est-). However, k- needs an explanation then. Most probably it is a result of a contamination (cf. Latin costa 'rib' or PIE *kes-).}];594[{PIE *h₂osti-. The Slavic lexeme is related to Old Indic ásthi- ‛bone’, Albanian asht, Latin os, Hittite ḫaštāi-. The initial k- is probably due to a contamination with a currently lost word related to Latin costa 'rib'. A simmilar irregular k- is found in Slavic *koza 'goat'.}];595[2: 71{The Slavic lexeme has no clear parallels in IE. It is usually linked to Latin os, ossis, Old Indic ásthi, Greek ὀστέον etc. The initial k- is explained as a result of a contamination (cf. Latin costa 'rib').}];598[2: 349{It is related to Latin costa 'rib'.}];589[2: 163-164{There is no certain etymology.}];636[1: 432{The word is derived from PIE *kes- and related to Latin costa 'rib', Old Indic kastha- 'log' and Albanian kashtë 'straw'.}];602[2: 450{The lexeme is related to Slavic *kositi and *česati [PIE *kes-]. The hypotheses about a relationship to Latin costa 'rib' or Latin os 'bone' etc. are not convincing.}];603[2: 661-663{The lexeme is related to Latin costa 'rib'. The hypotheses about a relationship to Latin os 'bone' etc. (assuming a prefix *k- or a metathesis from *osthr̥k-) is improbable.}];260[633-634{It is usually assumed to be related to Latin os, ossis 'bone'. The initial k- is explained as a prefix or as a special reflex of the initial laryngal. In fact, we deal here most probably with two different etymona. The Slavic lexeme is related to Latin costa 'rib'. PIE *kos-t- [PIE *kes-] 'sharp, cutting, outstanding'.}];249[{There is no clear further etymology of the Slavic lexeme. All hypotheses assuming a relationship to PIE *h₃est- fail to explain the initial k- in a convincing way. Other proposed cognates are etymologically unclear themselves. The proposed relationship to PIE *kes- seems to lack an entirely convincing semantic motivation.}]
Justification: Sometimes considered with cognate with PIE *h₂ost- in [cognate set 519](cog-519) but the details  remain unclear (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):239, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:167-173 for further discussion). This cognate set is otherwise restricted to Slavic.

Source: 141[160{Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯es- '(ein-, aus-)atmen' (IEW 268-71).}];81[124, 131-132{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dyxati 'breathe' (ESSJa V 199), an intensive verb with secondary length of the root, cf. Proto-Slavic *duxъ 'breath, spirit' (ESSJa V 153-154) from PIE *dʰous- (cf. Goth. dius 'wild animal' from *dʰeus-).}];352[252-253{Cf. s.v. OLith. dvãsas 'Atem, Geist, Seele', cf. Latv. dvaša 'Hauch, Atem, Lebewesen| Dampf, Dunst', and s.v. OLith. dvė̃sti 'hauchen, blasen| den Geist aushauchen, sterben', derivatives from PIE *dʰu̯es- 'hauchen, atmen' (cf. OCS dyxati 'wehen, atmen', Gk. θῡ́ω, θυίω 'brausen, stürmen, toben', Goth. dius, ON dýr, OHG tior '(wildes) Tier').}];458[5: 151, 153{The Slavic words are derived from PS *duxŭ 'breath, spirit', ultimately from PIE *dheu̯-s-.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯es- 'to breathe (in, out)' ([LIV²](src-141) 160, [ALEW](src-352) 252-253, [Derksen 2008](src-81):124, 131-132, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:151, 153).

Source: 458[85-87{PS *obvolka / *obvolko / *obvolkŭ is derived from *obvelkťi [*ob-velkťi 'cover, overlie'].}];81[514{The IE backround of *velkti 'drag' is far from solid.}];141[289-290{PIE *h₂u̯elk- > OCS vlěkǫ, vlěšti 'drag, pull' etc.}];249[{In spite of the objections of Derksen the version of LIV is addopted.}]
Comment: PS *ob-volk- with PS *volk < PS *velkti 'pull'. The etymological meaning of the compound is 'something that covers (the sky). The similarity to ?*u̯elg-/*u̯elk- is superficial.

Source: 81[203-204{S.v. Proto-Slavic *xoldьnъ 'cool, cold' (ESSJa VIII 59-60), an adjectival derivative of Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'coolness, cold' (ESSJa VIII 57-58). Possibly cognate with Latin and Germanic words for 'cold' reflecting PIE *gel-, but Slav. initial *x- lacks a convincing explanation.}];458[8: 57-58, 10: 124{A phonetically regular cognate of Lithuanian šáltas 'cold' in PS would be *soltŭ or *soldŭ and a regular cognate of German kalt in PS 'cold' would be *goldŭ. A development of PIE *k̑ into PS *x would be hard to explain even in terms of an expressive pronunciation. An expressive spirantisation of PS *g into PS *x is more probable phonetically and could be supported by the frequent usage of the lexeme accompanied with the lexeme *goldŭ 'hunger' with initial *ɡʷ- (it is very likely that the phrase *goldŭ i xoldŭ 'hunger and cold' existed already in PS). It can be assumed that the lost of the labialisation of *ɡʷ- in the root for 'hunger' induced the spirantisation of *g- in the root for 'cold'. PS *koldęzĭ 'well' is a loan from Germanic. The loan source had probably a meaning 'source' was derived from *kald- 'cold'. It is attested in Gemanic place names like Käldinge (Sweden) or Kolding, Kalding (Denmark).}];593[225{PS *xoldŭ can be related to German kalt 'cold' etc. on the on the one hand and to Lithuanian šáltas 'cold' on the other hand. The PIE roots *gel- and *k̑el- are maybe variants of a single original root. For the Slavic is more reasonable to assume *x < g*, although the reasons of this development are disputable.}];259[62-63{PS *xold- is derived from PIE *gel-. However, the development *g > *x has not been explainded, in spite of many attempts to. A relationship to Lithuanian šáltas 'cold' is also dubious from the phonetic point of view (*k̑- never yields PS *x-).}];594[{The Slavic lexeme is probably related to German kalt 'cold', English cold etc. It is derived from PIE *gel-, although the initial *x- has not been convincingly explained.}];595[195{The Slavic lexeme is linked to Gothic kalds und Latin gelidus on the one hand and to Lithuanian šáltas on the other. Some scholars assume a loanword from Germanic here.}];249[{There are three main hypotheses regarding the etymology of PS *xold-: 1) PIE *gel- (*⁽g̑⁾el-), cf. German kalt| 2) PIE *k̑elH-, cf. Lithuanian šáltas| 3) Loan from Germanic with PIE *gel- (*⁽g̑⁾el-), cf. German kalt. All three hypotheses fail to explain the initial x- in Slavic. The regular reflexes should be: 1) g| 2) s| 3) k (cf. PS *koldęzĭ). A further flaw of the hypothesis 2 is that Slavic has a phonetically regular cognate of the Lithuanian word (*solna). Regarding to the hypothesis 3 it can be assumed that words for 'cold' seem not to be very prone to replacing by borrowings. The only example in the database is Sinhalese lexeme borrowed from Pali| Russian archaic xladnyj borrowed from Old Church Slavonic should also be mentioned here. In these both cases, however, the sociolinguistic conditions were very different from that we assume for Germanic and Proto Slavic. Hence, the hypothesis 1 seems to be better than the other ones. It is also accepted in the most existing Slavic etymology Dictionaries. However, the etymology remains uncertain.}];598[4: 256, 3: 124{The Slavic lexeme is probably derived from a *kh- variant of PIE *geldh- and related to Gothic kalds 'cold' and Latin gelidus. Some scholars linkt the Slavic lexeme to Lithuanian šáltas 'cold'. However, the Lithuanian word (along with another derivative, šalná 'hoar-frost, frost') has a regular Slavic cognate, cf. Old Church Slavocnic slana 'hoar-frost'. The hypothesis about a borrowing from Germanic (Gothic) ist unconvincing phonetically.  Russian oželedica 'black ice' is related to Greek χάλαζα 'hail', New Persian žāla 'black ice, hoar-frost' annd Latvian dzeldêt 'get hard (about snow)'. A relationship to Gothic kalds 'cold' and Latin gelidus 'cold' is less probable.}]
Justification: No convincing etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:57-58, 10:124, [Derksen 2008](src-81):203-204, and further discussion by Lechosław Jocz in the further citations to this class).

Source: 249[{Originally it referred to counting by making scores on a piece of wood with a knife. A description of this method of counting is attested in one of the oldest Slavic texts ("On the Letters" by Chernorizets Hrabar). The meaning 'cut' is attested in Old/Middle Polish.}];141[92-93{S.v. *bʰrei̯H- 'schneiden' (IEW 166-7). Only Church Slavic brijǫ, briti 'shear, shave' listed here.}];589[1: 209-210{PIE *bhrei / * bri- / *bher- 'cut'.}];259[40{Polish broić 'frolic', formerly 'do evil things', in 16th century attested also as 'cut'. Russian dialectal 'poke about, rummage', Serbo-Croatian brojiti 'count'. PS *brojiti 'cut', derived from PIE *bʰrēi̯-, *bʰrī- 'cut with a sharp thing'.}];81[63{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *briti 'shave' (ESSJa III 31-32), from PIE *bʰr(e)iH- (cf. Skt. brīṇā́ti 'injure', OIr. bronnaid 'injure, damage'| OIc. brinna 'cause a cutting, sharp sorrow' NHG brennen 'id.').}]
Justification: Originally referring to counting by making scores on a piece of wood with a knife. A description of this method of counting is attested in one of the oldest Slavic texts ("On the Letters" by Chernorizets Hrabar). The meaning 'cut' is attested in Old/Middle Polish. Cf. Proto-Slavic *briti 'to shave', ultimately derivatives to PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):63, [ESSJa](src-458) III:31-32, [Boryś 2005](src-259):40, [Skok 1971-1974](src-589) 1:209-210, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 92-93).

Source: 249[{If the lexeme share the same root as found in PS *mŭrdati, *mŭrɡati, then it has a widely accepted further IE cognacy. However, this can not be ascertained. Other hypotheses are unconvincing.}];603[4: 291{South Slavic *mŭrsĭnŭ is related to Lithuanian smársas 'suet' and Latin merda 'excrement', cf. also sm"rdâ.}];54[374{Latin merda 'excrement' is related to Lithuanian smirdė́ti 'to stink' (*smrd-) and Russian smórod (*smrd-o-s). PIE *smerd-h₂-.}];458[20: 253-254{The etymology of the root is obscure. Taking some meanings ('disturbe, confuse') into account, it can be related to PS *mŭr-. The underlying verbal form would be *mŭrd-s-iti then. PS verbs *mŭrdati *mŭrkati and mŭrgati also belong here. All these lexemes are related to Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'shimmer, glimmer'.}];81[335{PS *mŭrgati 'blink, wink' is related to Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'twinkle' and Latvian mir̂dzêt 'tiwnkle', further to Old Icelandic myrkr 'dark'. PIE *mr(H)gʷ-.}];259[319, 340-341{PS *mŭrdati 'blink, wave, wag' and *mŭrɡati 'move something fast, blink, wink' are derived from PIE *mer- 'shine, glimmer, brigthen' (*mer-dʰ- and *mer-gʷ-). They are related to  Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'shimmer, glimmer', Latvian mir̂dzêt 'shimmer, glimmer' and to Old Icelandic myrkr 'cloudy'.}];165[366{PG *merkwu 'dark', Old Norsce myrkr 'dark'. Related to Markuu̯ai̯a 'deities ind the depth of the earth', Cuneiform Luvian  maru̯ai- 'black, dark',  Lithuanian mirgė́ti 'twinkle', Latvian mir̂dzêt 'twinkle', Russian morgát' 'blink, wink', Czech Dialectal mrgat 'to move, wave, watch groomily' and Albanian mjergullë 'nebula'. PIE *mergʷ-}]

81[431{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pь̀sъ 'dog'. There is no agreed Indo-European etymology. The main possibilities are: (1) connection with the root of Proto-Slavic *pь̀strъ 'variegated' from PIE *pei̯k̑- (cf. Gk. πικρός 'sharp, pungent, bitter'| ποικίλος 'variegated'| OHG fēh 'variegated'| (2) *pk̑-o- from a zero-grade of the root *(s)pek̑- 'see, watch'| or (3) *pk̑-u-, a zero-grade of the root in Skt. paśú-, kṣu- 'cattle', Lat. pecus, etc.}];259[432{PS *pĭs- has no equivalents among IE languages and no certain etymology. It is most probably derived from an interjection used for luring dogs (ps!).}];595[3: 27, 133{The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian pìktas 'bad, furious', paĩkas 'stupid', and Old Indic piśuna- 'hostile'. Baltic has only variants with *-k- in contrast to Slavic and Indic *-k̑-. Cf. also Slovene psovati 'curse', Polish psuć 'break, corrupt'.}];274[546-548{*pei̯k̑- 'chop down, cut out'. Among derivatives we found *?pik̑-ó-: Vedic piśá- 'a spotty animal, deer?' and Slavic *pisu 'dog', *?pik̑-r-ó-: Slavic pĭstrŭ 'mottled' etc., *péi̯k̑-men Slavic pismę 'letter'. However, the authors note that 1) it is hard to differentiate between *pei̯k̑- and *pei̯g- 'paint'| 2) some entry groups (like Lithuanian pìktas 'bad', paĩkas 'stupid', Old Indic piśuna- 'slanderous, bad', PG *faiha 'hostile') can also belong to *peh₁i̯- 'reprimand' or *pei̯g/g̑- 'irritiate, annoy'.}];141[464-466{Cf. *pei̯g- 'paint', *pei̯g/g̑- 'irritiate, annoy' and *pei̯k̑- 'chop down, cut out'.}];531[446{The further etymology of Lithuanian pìktas 'bad, furious',  paĩkas 'stupid', peĩkti 'reprimand' is obscure.}];598[248-249{The relationship to Slavic *pĭstrŭ 'mottled', farther to Old Indic piçás 'doe', Greek ποικίλος 'mottled' and Old High German fêh 'mottled' is most convincing from the phonetic point of view. It has been also linked to Latin pecus, Old Indic paçu, Old High German fihu 'cattle' (the original meaning would be either 'cattle  guard' or 'furry'). Hypotheses linking PS *pĭsŭ to words for 'urinate' (like French pisser) are unconvincing phonetically (one shoul expect a form **pĭxŭ then) and semantically (parallels for such a semantic development are unknown). The hypothesis about a derivation from an interjection ps! is unconvincing.}]
Justification: Leaving the most unconvincing hypotheses (like the one linking to a hardly if ever attested interjection ps) aside, it still remains obscure which PIE root the Slavic lexeme belongs to. It applies also to a part of (potential) IE cognates, the differentiation between the reconstructed PIE roots relevant here is generally far from clear, cf. [NIL](src-274). Therefore, it is most reasonable not to go beyond the Slavic in the reconstruction.

Source: 141[492-493{Cf. s.v. *pres- 'spritzen' (IEW 823). LIV² assigns Vollstufe II to the root (thus *pres-), but notes that for the Slavonic nouns here in question Vollstufe I (*pers-) is the basis (cf. fn1).}];81[413, 428{S.v. Proto-Slavic *porxъ 'dust', Proto-Slavic *pьrxъ 'dust' < *pr̥s-o- (cf. OIc. fors 'waterfall', Ved. pŕ̥ṣant- 'dappled, with white spots').}];165[161-162{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *fursa- 'gush(?)' < PIE *pr̥s-o-.}];172[II:164-165{Cf. s.v. Ved. pŕ̥ṣant- 'gesprenkelt, weißgefleckt' < PIE *pers- 'sprühen, spritzen' (cf. TochAB pärs- 'besprengen', Hitt. papparš- 'verspritzen', Cz. pršeti 'spritzen', etc.).}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *porxъ 'dust' and Proto-Slavic *pьrxъ 'dust' from PIE *pr̥s-o- (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):413, 428).

Source: 141[458{S.v. *ped- 'treten| fallen, sinken' (IEW 790-2)| the same root as 'foot' with the semantic development 'place one's foot' → 'to go in the direction of the feet' → 'fall', cf. [Rix 1976](src-586):278f.}];172[II:76-77{S.v. Ved. √pad- 'treten, gehen, fallen, niedersinken' < PIE *ped- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten, *fußwärts gehen → fallen', cf. Rix (1976:278f.).}];586[278-279{Cf. for discussion of the semantic development of *ped- as a verbal root.}];81[392{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pasti (II) 'fall', from PIE *pod- (cf. Skt. pádayate 'fall', OE gefetan 'fall').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ([LIV²](src-141) 458, [EWAia](src-172) II:76-77, [Derksen 2008](src-81):392, cf. [Rix 1976](src-586):278-279).

Source: 260[1362-1363{PS *straxŭ is related to Lithuanian strė́gti, stregiu 'harden, freeze', Latvian terglis 'stubborn' and Middle High German strac 'tight, stretched, straight'.}];593[604-605{PS *straxŭ is derived from PIE *strōg-so- or *strōk-so, ultimately from PIE *ster- 'hard, firm'.}];259[579{PS *straxŭ is most probably derived from PIE *strōg-so-, ultimately from PIE *(s)terg- / *(s)treg-. Another PS derivative from this root is probably *strogŭ 'austere'.}];595[3: 323{PS *straxŭ is derived from PIE *strōk-so 'hardening'. The PIE root is *ster(H)- 'hard'.}]
Justification: The further IE cognacy and the PIE root are not entirely clear (cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 3:323, [Boryś 2005](src-259):579, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):604-605, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1362-1363. The Kashubian and Sorbian phrases are calques of German 'Angst haben'.  Probable late parallel replacement/shift found in other Slavic languages.

Source: 81[41{S.v. Proto-Slavic *biti 'beat' < PIE *bʰiH- (cf. OIr. benaid 'strike', pret. pass. -bíth| Lat. perfinēs 2.sg. pres. subj. 'you may break').}];141[72{S.v. *bʰei̯H- 'schlagen' (IEW 117-8).}];458[2: 99-100{PS *biti is derived from PIE *bhei̯ə-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):41, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:99-100, [LIV²](src-141) 72).

Source: 259[528-529{The lexeme is limited to Slavic only and has no certain etymology. The existing hypotheses (linking it to PS *ryti 'dig', *rǫbati 'chop' or Old High German rûp(p)a 'caterpillar') are unconvincing.}];593[552{PS *ryba is an etymologically obscure innovation. There are many etymologies but none of them is convincing.}];595[3: 177{PS *ryba is a taboo innovation.}];598[3: 525-526{The Slavic lexeme is most probably a taboo-word. It has been linked to Old High German rûppa, rûpa 'catepillar', Latin rubēta 'frog', PS *ryti 'dig', Russian ryxlyj 'loose, powdery', Old Icelandic rjúpa 'partridge', Latvian rubenis 'black grouse' and PIE *ūr- 'water'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *ryba 'fish', further etymology obscure (cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:525-526, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):552, [Boryś 2005](src-259):528-529, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 3:177).

Source: 81[258-259{S.v. Proto-Slavic *květъ 'flower' < PIE k̑uoit-o- (cf. Proto-Slavic *kvisti 'bloom, blossom' from PIE *k̑weit-/*kuit-). NB: In Balto-Slavic, PIE *k̑ was depalatalized before *u̯ followed by a back vowel.}];141[340{Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'hell aufleuchten' (IEW 628-629).}];259[278{PS *květ 'flower' and *svět 'wolrd, light' are ultimately derived from PIE *ku̯ei̯-t-.}];458[13: 162-163{PIE *ku̯oi̯to- a depalatalised variant of *k̑u̯oi̯to. The depalatalisation is an internal process, there is no reason to assume a loanword here, cf. Old Indic śaṇa- and kaṇa or *śarkara-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'to shine brightly' ([ESSJa](src-458) 13:162-163, [Derksen 2008](src-81):258-259, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 340).

Source: 81[271{From BSl. *lekt-. According to Meillet (Ét. I: 180), *letěti derives from *letъ  < *lek-to-. }];352[I, 567-68{The Baltic words are based on a root *lek- without any clear PIE cognates| cf. LIV² 411. Contrary to what is stated in the literature, the Baltic words are not cognate with Slav. words for 'fly', e.g. Old Church Slav. letěti, which originate from *let-.}];141[411{PIE ?*lek- 'to move the limbs', IEW 673. Does not contain the Slavic words.}];458[14: 145-148{It is usually assumed that this word is related to Lithuanian lė̃kti, lekiù 'fly, fall' which has been further linked to Greek λακτίζω 'tread, bang' Middle High German lecken 'hit with leg, jump', dialectal Norwegian lakka 'jump' etc. *-te- (*lek-te-) is most probably a verbal stem suffix.}];259[{The PS lexeme is derived from PIE *lek- 'jump, move', directly from *lek-te / *lek-to- with a present tense stem suffix *-te-/-to-. It is related to Lithuanian lė̃kti, lekiù 'fly, run, chase' etc.}];531[343{PS *letěti 'fly' and Lithuanian lė̃kti, lekiù are cognates.}]
Justification: The widely accepted etymology linking the Slavic lexeme to uncertain PIE ?*lek- 'move the limbs' (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 14:145-148) is not entirely convincing. There is no internal Slavic evidence for *k and the hypothesis needs to assume an intensive morphological levelling. Cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 567-568, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):343, [Derksen 2008](src-81):271, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):323.

Source:
49[624{From Slav. *krokъ, PIE *kr(o)k-u-?}];458[11: 50-51, 77-80| 12: 183{There is no single PS form but three: *korakŭ, *korkŭ/*korka and *krokŭ. It is hard to explain this variation. The lexeme was obviously expressive and its nautral usage in Bulgarian is a relatively late innovation. The Slavic word has been linked to Lithuanian kárka '(front) leg of pig'. It is further related to Latvian kar̂cinêt 'shake legs while sitting' and kar̂cinât 'shake, tremble' and to Lithuanian verb kárti 'hang'. Also a derivation from PIE *(s)ker- 'bend, twist' has been proposed.}];259[261{PS *krokŭ / *korkŭ / *korakŭ is probably related to Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's leg, horse's ankle, part of insect's leg' and maybe also to Albanian krahë 'hand, arm' and Old Indic kiṣku- 'forearm'. The Slavic lexeme is probably ultimately derived from PIE *(s)ker- bend, twist, turn' with an original meaning 'bending, movable part of the body'. The reasons of the PS formal variety is hard to determine.}];531[256{Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's or sheep's leg, front leg of pig with scapula, horse's ankle' is related to PS *korkŭ and *krokŭ. The etymology is not entirely clear. It has been linked to PIE *(s)ker- 'bend'. The etymological meaning would be then 'bending part of the body'.
Lithuanian kárti 'hang' is derived from PIE *kerH-, cf. Old English heorr, Old Norse hjarri 'door wing'. If one would assume an s-mobile here, a link to PIE *skerH- 'split off, hang off' would be possible.}];105[193-194{Albanian krah, krahë 'arm, shoulder, side' is borrowed from Slavic *krajĭ 'end, side, extremity'.}];399[213{S. v. kiṣkuḥ, a relationship to Albanian krahë ist not certain. No Slavic cognates listed.}]
Justification: The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.

Source: 397[2, 665{Cf. s.v. NHG Obst (MHG obez, OHG obaz, MLG ovet, avet), from pre-German *uba-ǣtaz 'Dazu-Essen', the latter word from the same word as NHG Aas to the IE root *h₁ed-, and the former identical with NHG ob in the old meaning 'hin(zu)'.}];757[3:463{Cf. s.v. Du. ooft 'boomvruchten (zoals appels en peren)’, from Proto-Germanic uba-etaz 'side-dish' (for etymologies of elements cf. s.v. Du. op, and eten).}]
Justification: West Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *uba-eta- 'side dish', the lexical root of *eta- corresponds to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):2, 665; [EWNl](src-757) 3:463).

Source: 81[109-110{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dobrъ 'good', an adjective in *-ro- to *dʰabʰ- 'time' (cf. Proto-Slavic *doba 'time'). The semantic development appears to have been 'right time' → 'suitable, good'.}];141[135-136{Cf. s.v. *dʰeHbʰ- 'passen' (IEW 233). Verbal only Germanic, cf. n1 for notes on nominal and adjectival derivatives.}];458[5: 45-46{The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *dhabh-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰeHbʰ- 'to be fitting, suitable' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):109-110, [LIV²](src-141) 135-136, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 5:45-46).

Source: 81[496-497, 499{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *trāva 'grass', *trěva 'grass', *truti 'to feed', and *tryti 'rub', all ultimately derivatives from PIE *truH- 'use' (cf. Gk. τρύω 'use up').}];141[652-653{Cf. s.v. *treu̯H- 'aufreiben, verbrauchen' (IEW 1072-3).}];259[640-641, 644{PS *trava (dialectal *trěva) is derived from PS *truti, trovǫ 'use up, eat| poison'. The original meanig was 'things that are used up, feed, fodder' > 'plants used as feed, fodder'. The words belonging here are ultimately derived from PIE *treu̯- 'rub, rub off'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *treu̯H- 'to rub; to use' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):496-497, 499; [Boryś 2005](src-259):640-641, 644).

Source: 352[842-843, 867-868{S.v. OLith. rankà 'Hand' (BSl. Latv. rùoka 'Hand, Arm', OPr. rancko 'Hand', OCS rǫka 'Hand', etc.), an o-grade nominalisation from the same root as the verb riñkti 'suchen, lesen, wählen'. No clear connections outside of Balto-Slavic, for proposed connections in the older literature cf. IEW 1155.}];141[506{S.v. ?*renk- 'auflesen, sammeln' (IEW 1155). Only Balto-Slavic. Cf. n1: An onset *u̯r- would be possible, there are, however, no specific indications for that. Lith. rankà = OCS rǫka 'Hand' are also derivatives of this root.}];81[439-440{S.v. Proto-Slavic *rǭka 'hand, arm', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rónkaʔ (cf. Lith. rankà 'hand', Latv. rùoka 'hand', OPr. rānkan (acc.sg.) 'hand'). According to Derksen the Balto-Slavic word for 'hand' derives from a verbal root *u̯renk- (cf. Lith. riñkti 'gather').}];353[376{S.v. Lith. rankà 'hand' (Latv. rùoka 'hand', OPr. rānkan A.sg. 'hand'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rónkaʔ (cf. OCS rǫka 'hand, arm'), from PIE *uronk-eh₂- (cf. OIc. rá 'corner, berth in a ship'). The Balto-Slavic word for hand derives from a verbal root meaning 'gather' (cf. Lith. riñkti).}];259[514{PS *rǫka is derived from PIE *u̯renk- 'gather', ultimately from PIE root *u̯er- 'to spin, to wind'.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived to a Proto-Balto-Slavic verbal root *renk- 'to gather'; no certain further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):439-440, [Derksen 2015](src-353):376, [ALEW](src-352) 842-843, 867-868, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 506). For proposed connections in the older literature, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1155.

Source: 81[176{S.v. Proto-Slavic *golva 'head' (ESSJa VI 221-222), from PIE *golH-u-eh₂ (cf. Lat. calva 'skull'). [No connection given to Armenian lexemes.]}];353[162-163{S.v. Lith. galvà 'head' (Latv. gal̂va 'head', OPr. galwo 'head'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *golʔwáʔ, from PIE *golH-ueh₂- "[Contrary to what is printed in Derksen 2008:176, a]n etymological connection with Lat. calva 'skull' is formally impossible. Nevertheless, it is tempting to seek a link with these forms, as the same irregular *k : *g correspondence is observed in words for 'bald', where we have Lat. calvus 'bald' and Skt. kulva- 'bald, thin haired' vs. OCS golъ, OHG kalo 'bald'." [No connection given to Armenian lexemes.]}];352[289-290{S.v. OLith. galvà 'Kopf, Haupt| Kapitel' (BSl. Latv. gal̂va 'Kopf, Haupt', OPr. galwo 'Haupt| Schuhspitze', OCS glava 'Kopf| Hauptstück| Kapitel', etc.), IE cf. Arm. glowx, G.sg. glxoy 'Kopf| Ende, Spitze, Anführer'. The Armenian lexeme is a suffixal derivative for a word for 'head' in the proto-language, which is directly continued by the Balto-Slavic lexemes.}];269[{Generally considered to be cognate with the Armenian word for 'head', glowx. The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear. Cf. further discussion and references in [cognate set 8243](cog-8243). Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes, generally considered to be cognate with Armenian glowx 'head' ([ALEW](src-352) 289-290, [Derksen 2015](src-353):162-163, [Derksen 2008](src-81):176). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. further discussion and references in [cognate set 8243](cog-8243)).

Source: 165[551{S.v. Proto-Germanic *þungu- 'heavy', from PIE *tngʰ-u-, identical to Lith. tingùs 'lazy'.}];352[1110-1111{Cf. s.v. Lith. tingùs 'träge, faul, nachlässig'.}];141[657{Cf. s.v. *tʰengʰ- 'ziehen' (IEW 1067).}];389[{Revised root form: *tengʰ-, not *tʰengʰ- as given in LIV².}];81[494{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tęžьkъ 'heavy', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *ting- (cf. Lith. tingùs 'lazy'), from PIE *tngʰ-, cf. OIc. þungr 'heavy'.}];259[83{PS *tęžĭkŭ is derived from PIE *tengʰ-.}]
Justification: Slavic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):494, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):551, [ALEW](src-352) 1110-1111) For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Source: 141[119-121{S.v. *der- 'zerreißen (intr.), zerspringen' (IEW 206-8).}];81[99, 507{S.v. Proto-Slavic *udariti 'strike, hit', a prefixed verb with a lengthened grade of the root, cf. Proto-Slavic *derti 'tear' from PIE *der(H)- (cf. Gk. δέρω 'flay', Goth. distairan 'tear apart').}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):99, 507; [LIV²](src-141) 119-121).

Source: 81[286{S.v. Proto-Slavic *loviti '(try to) catch' (ESSJa XVI 106-108). Cf. Proto-Slavic *lovъ 'hunt, hunting' and *lovъkъ 'adroit, dextrous' (ESSJa 111-113), cf. Lith. lavùs 'adroit, dexterous, clever'. There are no cognates outside of Balto-Slavic| even then one might wonder whether Lith. lavùs is be a borrowing.}];458[16: 106-108, 111-114{PS *loviti is derived from PIE *lāu- / *lau- / ləu- 'catch, gain' and related to Lithuanian lavùs 'dexterous', Greek Attic λεία (*λᾱϝιᾱ), Doric λᾱία 'gain', Latin lucrum 'gain', Gothic laun, Old High German lôn 'reward' and Old Irelandic folad 'richness', lúag 'praise'.}]
Justification:
The vast majority of Slavic etymology dictionaries assume or accept the etymology presented in [ESSJa](src-458): 112, cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 2: 508; [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 351; [Boryś 2005](src-259): 302-303; [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 2: 152; [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594); [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602): 277-278; [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603): 3: 449; [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607): 6: 25; {Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}: 772-773. The hypothesis of {Machek 1968}: 328, assuming a relatedness to Polish polować 'hunt' does not stand up scrutiny (it is impossible phonetically, morphologically and philologically).
According to the mainstream hypothesis, PS *loviti is related to Lithuanian lavùs 'dexterous', Greek Attic λεία (*λᾱϝιᾱ), Doric λᾱία 'gain', Latin lucrum 'gain', Gothic laun, Old High German lôn 'reward' and Old Irelandic folad 'richness', lúag 'praise' and derived from PIE *leh₂u 'aquire by fighting' (for the root reference form see [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 349-350 or [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 329).
However, [Derksen 2008](src-81): 286 does not mention this etymology at all, claiming "To my knowledge, there are no cognates outside Balto-Slavic". The Slavic lexeme is not listed among cognates of the relevant words by [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 329, [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 349-350 and [Matasović 2009](src-50): 397-398. According to [Beekes 2010](src-66): 188, who compares Greek ἀπολαύω with Latin lucrum and Gothic laun, "the appurtenance of OCS lovъ 'catch, chase', loviti 'to catch, chase' would require *lh₂eu-, which is an improbable formation".
The etymology is accepted by [de Vries 1961](src-214): 347-348 and [Lehmann 1986](src-179): 228-229. The mainstream hypothesis is accepted here, although the case needs further investigation.

Source: 353[277{S.v. Lith. lẽdas 'ice, hailstone' (Latv. lȩdus 'ice'). No known cognates outside of Balto-Slavic to support a PIE form *ledʰus. Proto-Balto-Slavic *ledús may be reconstructed to account for the attested forms (cf. Proto-Slavic *ledъ 'ice').}];81[270{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ledъ m. 'ice'.  The PIE proto-form would be *ledʰ-u-s, but there are no known cognates outside of Balto-Slavic.}];352[565{S.v. OLith. lẽdas 'Eis, Hagel' (BSl. Latv. lȩdus 'Eis, Eisscholle', OPr. ladis 'Eis', OCS ledъ 'Eis', etc.). No reliable comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.}];458[14: 91-92{PS *ledŭ is related to Lithuanian lẽdas, ledùs, Latvian ļedus and Old Prussian ladis 'ice'. Further etymology is obscure, the existing hypotheses are inconvincing. [See p. 92 for a overview of the existing comparisons.]}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 565, [Derksen 2015](src-353):277, [ESSJa](src-458) 14:91-92, [Derksen 2008](src-81):270).

Source: 81[41{S.v. Proto-Slavic *biti 'beat', from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' (LIV² 72).}];141[72{S.v. *bʰei̯H- 'schlagen' (IEW 117-8).}];458[2: 99-100{PS *biti is derived from PIE *bhei̯ə-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):41, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:99-100, [LIV²](src-141) 72).

Source: 352[271{S.v. OLith. ẽzeras 'See, Landsee' (BSl. cf. Latv. ȩzȩrs, ȩzars 'See', OPr. assaran 'See', OCS jezero 'See', etc.), from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰer- 'Rand, Ufer' (cf. Arm. ezr, G.D.sg. ezer 'id.').}];81[148{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ezero| *ezerъ 'lake'| from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)r-o- (cf. Arm. ezr ‘edge, border, bank’).}];353[158-159{S.v. Lith. ẽžeras 'lake' (Latv. ȩzȩrs 'lake', OPr. assaran 'lake') from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)ro- (cf. OCS jezero 'lake', Arm. ezr 'edge, border, bank'), cf. also s.v. Lith. ežià 'boundary(-strip)'.}];79[247-248{Cf. s.v. Arm ezr 'edge, shore, bank'. The traditional etymology with Lith. ežià 'boundary(-strip)', etc. is sometimes doubted, but Martirosyan sees no good reason to abandon the IE etymology.}];458[6: 33-34{PS *ezero, *ezerŭ is a reflex of PIE *eg̑ʰ-er-o- or *ag̑ʰ-er-o (cf. PS *ězŭ 'dam').}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)r-o-, cf. Arm. ezr ‘edge, border, bank’ (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 271, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:33-34, [Derksen 2008](src-81):148, [Derksen 2015](src-353):158-159, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):247-248).

Source: 81[456-457{s.v. Proto-Slavic *smьjati 'laugh', from PIE *smei- 'smile' (cf. Skt. smáyate 'smile').}];141[568-569{S.v. *smei̯- 'lachen, lächeln' (IEW 967).}];353[550-551{S.v. Latv. smiêt 'laugh at, mock, (refl.) laugh', from PIE *sm(e)iH- 'laugh' (cf. Skt. smáyate 'smile').}];259[617{PS *smĭjǫ sę, smijati sę is derived from PIE *smei̯- 'laugh' and related to Old Indic smáyate 'laugh'.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *smei̯- 'to smile, laugh' ([LIV²](src-141) 568-569, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):456-457, [Derksen 2015](src-353):550-551).

Source:
81[279-280{PS *listŭ 'leaf' is related to Lithuanian laĩškas, láiškas 'letter', cf. also Prussian crixti lāiskas 'baptism booklet'.
"A reconstruction *leh₁i-sk-to-, containing the verbal root 'let, leave', would raise the question why Hirt's law did not generate fixed stress. Instead, we might posit *leid-sk-to-, cf. Lith. léisti 'let, leave', provided that this root exists (see LIV: 402-403)."}];458[15: 143-144, 147-148{PS *listŭ is probably a back formation from PS *listati 'to foliate, frondescent'. Maybe these word are different derivations from PIE *lei- 'sprout leaves'.}]
Justification: Further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 15:143-144, 147-148, [Derksen 2008](src-81):279-280 for further discussion.

Source: 66[824-825{Cf. s.v. Gk. λαιός, from PIE *leh₂i-uo- 'left' (Lat. laevus, OCS lěvъ).}];81[275{S.v. Proto-Slavic *lěvъ 'left', from PIE *lh₂eiuo- (cf. Gk. λαίος, Lat. laevus).}];458[15: 29-31{PS *lěvŭ is related to Latin laevus 'left', also 'bended', Greek λαιός < λαιϝός 'left' and Lithuanian iš-laivóti 'screw' and derived from PIE *laiu̯o- 'bended'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *lh₂eiuo- or *leh₂i-uo- 'left' ([ESSJa](src-458) 15:29-31, [Derksen 2008](src-81):275), cf. Ancient Greek λαιός 'left', Latin laevus 'left' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):824-825, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):323).

Source:
458[11: 50-51, 77-80| 12: 183{There is no single PS form but three: *korakŭ, *korkŭ/*korka and *krokŭ. It is hard to explain this variation. The lexeme was obviously expressive and its nautral usage in Bulgarian is a relatively late innovation. The Slavic word has been linked to Lithuanian kárka '(front) leg of pig'. It is further related to Latvian kar̂cinêt 'shake legs while sitting' and kar̂cinât 'shake, tremble' and to Lithuanian verb kárti 'hang'. Also a derivation from PIE *(s)ker- 'bend, twist' has been proposed.}];259[261{PS *krokŭ / *korkŭ / *korakŭ is probably related to Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's leg, horse's ankle, part of insect's leg' and maybe also to Albanian krahë 'hand, arm' and Old Indic kiṣku- 'forearm'. The Slavic lexeme is probably ultimately derived from PIE *(s)ker- bend, twist, turn' with an original meaning 'bending, movable part of the body'. The reasons of the PS formal variety is hard to determine.}];105[193-194{Albanian krah, krahë 'arm, shoulder, side' is borrowed from Slavic *krajĭ 'end, side, extremity'.}];531[256{Lithuanian kárka 'part of pig's or sheep's leg, front leg of pig with scapula, horse's ankle' is related to PS *korkŭ and *krokŭ. The etymology is not entirely clear. It has been linked to PIE *(s)ker- 'bend'. The etymological meaning would be then 'bending part of the body'.
Lithuanian kárti 'hang' is derived from PIE *kerH-, cf. Old English heorr, Old Norse hjarri 'door wing'.
