If one would assume an s-mobile here, a link to PIE *skerH- 'split off, hang off' would be possible.}];399[213{S. v. kiṣkuḥ, a relationship to Albanian krahë ist not certain. No Slavic cognates listed.}]
Justification: The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.

Source:
259[125{PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush' is derived from PIE *dʰrebʰ- and related to Gothic ga-draban 'cut off, gouge'.}];81[118{PS *drobiti 'crumble, crush' with Gothic gadraban 'cut out' listed as a cognate ("unnless this is a mistake for gagraban"). "LIV (153) reconstructs *dʰreb- on the basis of Germanic forms such as OIc. drepa ‘beat, kill’, OHG treffan ‘hit’. Since this proto-form is in conflict with Winter’s law, I reconstruct *dʰrobʰ-eie- for Slavic. The discrepancy between Slavic and Germanic may have something to do with the fact that the etymon is of non-Indo-European origin or Kluge’s law may have played a role".}];458[5: 119-121{PS *drobŭ (with meaning 'guts' in many Slavic languages and dialects) is derived from PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush'. PIE *dhrebh-, cf. Greek τρέφω 'make dense, make clotted' and Gothic (ga)draban 'gouge, cut out'.}];165[98{PG *draban 'to hew', cf. Gothic ga-draban 'chip, hew out' < *dʰróbʰ-e- and OCS drobiti 'crumle, chop, break' < *dʰrobʰ-eie-. The root is Germanic-Slavic.
PG *drepan 'to hit': "A back-formation to the iterative *drupp/bōn 1, a zero-grade variant of *drapp/bōn (q.v.). As both iteratives were derived from the strong verb *draban 'to hew' < *dʰróbʰ-e-, the strong verb *drepan- cannot be used to reconstruct a Pre-Gm. formation *dʰréb-e- with root-final *b, as traditionally assumed (cf. LIV²: 153). The late, internally-Germanic origin of the *p further speaks against the assumption of a non-Indo-European loanword [...]".}];141[153-154{?dʰreb- 'hit, push' with Old High German treffan 'hit' und OCS drobljǫ, drobiti 'shatter, crush' listed as cognates (however, the autors point that the Slavic and Germanic meanings are not very close). Gothic ga-draban is most probably a mistake of the writer (instead of ga-graban). The lack of Winter's lengthening in Slavic can be caused by the inter-vocalic position of -b-.
*dʰrebʰ- 'clot, sediment' with Greek τρέφω 'make dense, make clotted' listed as a cognate.}]
Justification: It's disputable if the Slavic word belongs to PIE ?*dʰreb- or *dʰrebʰ-. The majority view is adopted here.

Source: 81[45-46{S.v. Proto-Slavic *blizъ, *blizъkъ 'near, close' (ESSJa II 121-122). An o-stem adjective from PIE *bʰlei̯g̑- 'to beat' (cf. Lat. flīgere 'hit'). Cf. the parallel semantic development of French près 'near' from Latin pressus 'squeezed' [cf. [cognate set 1398](cog-1398)].}];141[88-89{Cf. s.v. *bʰlei̯g̑- 'schlagen' (IEW 160-1).}];458[2: 121-123{PS *blizŭ is derived from PIe *bʰlei̯g̑(ʰ)- 'beat'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰlei̯g̑- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):45-46, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:121-123, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 88-89).

Source: 81[476{S.v. Proto-Slavic *starъ 'old', from PIE *steh₂-ro- (cf. OIc. stórr 'big').}];274[637-659{S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.).}];259[574-576{PS *starŭ is derived from PIE *stā-ro- and directly related to Lithuanian stóras 'thick' and Old Icelandic stórr 'huge, strong, important, male'. The same root is found in PS *stati 'stand'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *steh₂-ro-, derived from PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):476, cf. [NIL](src-274) 637-659).

Source: 81[209-210{S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьgrati v. 'play'.  Rejects the earlier connection with Skt. éjati 'move, stir' < *h₂ei̯g- because it is "semantically unconvincing and formally unattractive because it is in conflict with Winter's Law."}];458[8: 208-211{The original meaning of PS *jĭgra was most probably 'singing with dancing'. It looks archaic has no phonetic variants suggesting a late derivation. It has been linked to Old Indic yájati 'enshrine a deity' and Greek ἅɡιος 'sacred'. A formal issue is that a reconstruction with *-g̑- for these words is probable. A centum-reflex in Slavic can be, however, a result of the context next to *-r-. PIE *i̯aɡ- / *iɡ- / *i̯eɡ- / *i̯əɡ-.}];259[175-176{PS *jĭgra 'ritual event with dancing' is probably derived from PIE *ai̯g- 'move quickly, briskly, shake', cf. Old Indic ejati / ī́jati, iŋgati 'move'.}];598[2: 116{PS *jĭgrati is related to Lithuanian aikštytis 'be fussy, rage'. Latvian aîkstîtiês 'shout, make noise', Old Indic ḗjati, ī́jati 'move' and Old Icelandic eikinn 'wild, strong'. It can not be relateed to Old Indic yájati 'enshrine, sacrifice', Avestan yazaitē and Greek ἅζομαι 'fear, enshrine', ἅγος 'sacred awe'.}];141[223{*Hei̯ɡ- 'move (violently?)' with Vedic iṅgáyati, éjati andn ejayant- listed as cognates. PS *jьgra 'play' may belong here (however, it would be problematic due to the lack of Winter's lengthening). Cf. also Old Nordic eikinn 'furious'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):209-210, [ESSJa](src-458) 8:208-211, and [LIV²](src-141) 223 for further discussion).

Source: 598[252{Russian but, Bulgarian butam, Slovene buti, butiti may be loanwords from Itaian bottare, buttare 'hit, push'.}];603[1: 92{Bulgarian butam etc. is probably related to Italian bottare, buttare 'push, hit'. It can be a loan from Germanic or a native PS word (< PIE *bhout-), related to Armenian but 'dull', Gothic bauþs 'deaf, dumb', Lithuanian butùs 'having no tip, dull', Old Icelandic bauta, Anglo-Saxon beaten, Old High German bozan 'hit', German Am-boss 'anvil' and Latin con-futo 'supress', re-futo 'refute'. It has been interpreted as a derivation of PIE *bheu-, *bhou- 'grow', 'hit, beat'.}];458[3: 101-102{PS *buta, *butati, *butiti are derived from PIE *bʰeu̯t-, *bʰou̯t- 'swell', this root being related to *bʰau̯t-, *bʰūt- 'hit, beat' (cf. Latin futuo 'fuck' and Old Icelandic bauta 'push'). An Italian origin is improbable.}];594[{PS butati, butiti 'push' is derived from PIE *bʰau̯H-t- 'push', cf. Latin confutare 'supress, refute' and futuere 'have sexual contact'.}]
Comment: *bʰeu̯t- violates IE root structure constraints. This etymology is impossible. (–MJCS, 11.07.2018).
Justification:
The etymology and further IE cognacy is not entirely clear.
The most Slavic etymology dictionaries point to a relationship to Latin re(-)futo and Old Norse bauta etc. However, there were a formal issue with the final consonant of the PIE root then, cf. [LIV²](src-141): 82 and [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 253-254. A root *bʰuH- 'hit' wit different extentions could be assumed here [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 253, cf. also [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) and [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) cited below. However, Kroonen points that "the original root-final consonant cannot be identified as *d, but only as *t or *dʰ" [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 56. If the final consonant were *t, Slavic forms could be formally related without any additional assumptions (as root extentions). This view is addopted here.

Source: 81[91-93{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrvjenъ, *čьrvenъ 'red' (adj.), *čьrviti (v.) 'dye, red, lay eggs (of insects), which are derivatives of Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot', from Balto-Slavic *kir-m/w-i-, from PIE *kʷr-m-i-. The Balto-Slavic vocalisation *ir instead of *ur before the labiovelar is unexpected.}];458[4: 149-150, 169-173{PS *čĭrv(j)enŭ is an early adjectivised and lexicalised past passive participle of *čĭrviti, a verbal derivation from *čĭrvĭ 'grub, worm, maggot' (cf. the ancient technology of the red pigment). PS *čĭrvĭ (and a more archaic form *čĭrmĭ) is related to Lithuanian kirmìs and Old Indic kṛmi-ḥ-. PIE *kʷr̥mi-.}];172[I:394-395{S.v. Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made' (IIr. cf. Manichaean Sogd. kyrm- 'Schlange', MPers. klm (kirm) 'Wurm, Drache, Schlange', NPers. kirm 'Wurm, Schlange'), from PIE *kʷr̥mi- (cf. OIr. cruim, W., Bret. pryf 'Wurm', Lith. kirmìs 'Wurm, Schlange', Sloven. čr̂m 'Fingerwurm, Karbunkel', etc.). Beside *kʷr̥mi- exists "a rhyme formation in Indo-European probably for reason of tabu" *u̯r̥mi- (NHG Wurm, cf. Lat. vermis), (so Watkins 1987:288).}]
Justification: Lexemes in the meaning 'red' derived from IE *kʷr̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye. There are some formal difficulties in reconciling Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot' to PIE *kʷr̥mi-, but the cognacy is generally agreed (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4:149-150, 169-170; [Derksen 2008](src-81):91-93 for further discussion). Probable late parallel replacement/shift with Sogdian cognate set 9774.  See 'worm' in [cognate set 172](cog-172) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 81[237{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kory 'root' (ESSJa XI 62-65), from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾or(H)-en- (cf. Lith. kẽras m. 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub'| Latv. cęrs m. 'bush, knotty root of a tree').}];458[11: 62-65{PS *korenĭ is derived from PIE *kʷer- 'make'. The exact meaning the PS lexeme was derived from was 'lay foundation, lay ground', the etymological meaning of the *korenĭ was also 'base, basis' (then 'base of a tree').}];352[478{Cf. s.v. Lith. kẽras 'Baumstumpf, Staude' (BSl. Latv. cȩrs 'Staude, Strauch', comparable in Slavic to -ii̯o-formations in Cz. keř, OPol. kierz 'Strauch, Staude' and the o-grade n-stem in SCr. kȍrēn, Ru. kóren', Cz. kořen 'Wurzel'. No certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic.}];353[238{S.v. Lith. kẽras 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub' from BSl. *ker-, cf. PSl. *černъ *černь 'stem, stub', also to Slavic *kory 'root' (Ru. kóren', etc.). If further connected to OIr. cern 'angle, corner', W cern 'cheekbone, side of the head' then it may be possible that we are dealing with the root *(s)kerH- to which Lith. skìrti 'separate, divide' belongs.}]
Justification: Slavic forms from Proto-Slavic *koren- 'root' and generally connected within Balto-Slavic to Lith. kẽras 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub', etc. Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic are uncertain (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):237, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:62-65, [Derksen 2015](src-353):238, [ALEW](src-352) 478 for discussion of various proposals).

Source: 81[169-170{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gņilъ 'rotten', from PIE *g̑ʰneiH-lo-, cf. Proto-Slavic *gņiti 'to rot' from PIE *g̑n(e)iH- (cf. OHG gnītan 'grind', OE gnidan 'grind').}];458[6: 175-177{PS *gniti is derived from PIE *gʰnēi̯- and related to Anglo-Saxon ɡnídan 'rub' Old High German ɡnītan 'grind' and German χνίει 'fall into small pieces'.}]
Justification: The sources are, in general, consistent as to further IE cognates of PS *gniti 'rot'. A minor formal issue is, however, the reconstruction of the underlying PIE root. In [Derksen 2008](src-81) a form with initial *g̑ʰ- is given, the other sources give a form with *gʰ-, e.g. [ESSJa](src-458): 177, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 205, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 168, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 1: 153, cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 183. A question is, if PS *znojĭ 'heat, sweat' is related. If so, a variation *g̑ʰ- / *gʰ- should be assumed, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81): 546, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 740, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 744.

Source: 81[398{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pěsъkъ m. 'sand', from PIE *pē(n)s-u-ko- (cf. Skt. pām̆̇sú- 'dust, sand').}];657[499{Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.}];593[468{PS *pěsŭkŭ is related to pāṃsú- 'sand, dust' and derived from PIE *pēs- / *pēns-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *pē(n)s-u-ko-, for further discussion cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):398, [EIEC](src-657) 499.

Source: 141[506{S.v. *rek- 'ordnen, festlegen, bestimmen' (IEW 863).}];81[433{S.v. Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say', from PIE *rek- (cf. Skt. racayati 'construct, work', W rhegi 'curse').}];259[532{PS *rekti, *rekǫ is derived from PIE *rek- 'speak, shout'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rekti 'to speak, say', further derived from PIE *rek- 'to order, determine' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):433, [LIV²](src-141) 506).

Source: 141[465{S.v. ?2. *pei̯H- 'singen' (Slavic and Tocharian only).}];81[398{Proto-Slavic *pěti 'sing' < PIE *poiH- (cf. Toch. B pi- 'sing, make sing').}];436[133{TochB 'sing, make sing', TochA hapax pis- 'blow (a musical instrument)' are probably related to OCS pěti.}];345[409-410{S.v. TochB pi- G 'sing'| K 'make sing| blow (a musical instrument)', probably cognate with the TochA hapax pis- and to Proto-Tocharian *päy-, probably to be related to the otherwise isolated OCS pěti 'sing'.  For discussion, cf. [Adams 1982](src-436):133.}];341[723-724{Cf. s.v. TochB pi- 'blasen, trompeten', 'blow, trumpet', doubting the connections of Tocharian forms to Slavic on the basis of reconstructing semantics 'blow, trumpet', rather than 'sing'.}]
Justification: Tocharian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE ?*pei̯H- 'to sing'. The cross-branch cognacy in this class tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 465, [Adams 1982](src-436):133, [Adams 2013](src-345):409-410, [Derksen 2008](src-81):398, but cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):723-724 with some reservations over the proposed Tocharian-Slavic connection.

Source: 81[242{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kòža f. 'skin, leather' (ESSJa XII 35-36), a derivative of Proto-Slavic *kozà f. 'goat', possibly a borrowing from a Turkic language.}];458[12: 19-21, 35-36{PS *koža is derived from PS *koza 'goat'. Its original meaning was 'goat leather'. PS *koza 'goat' itself has probably a non-IE origin.}]
Comment: For the discussion on the further etymology of PS *koza and its relationship to PIE *ag̑- (cf. Old Indic ajā́) see [ESSJa](src-458): 12: 19-21 and 1: 103-104.
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *koža 'skin, leather', further derived from Proto-Slavic *koza 'goat' originally in the sense 'goat leather'; further etymology uncertain but probably a Turkic loanword ([Derksen 2008](src-81):242, [ESSJa](src-458) 12:35-36).

Source: 274[499-504{S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV² 448, IEW315f.). Re *nébʰ-es- n.: fn. 6: Stüber, Die primären s-Stämme, 2002, 129ff. thinks that PIE *nebʰos- denoted the clouded sky in opposition to *di̯ḗu̯s 'clear sky of the day'.  Fn. 21: The inclusion of the Tocharian forms here is disputed. [Cf. notes in [cognate set 7172](cog-7172).]}];81[347-348{S.v. Proto-Slavic *nȅbo n. 'sky, heaven' (ESSJa XXIV 101-104), from PIE *nebʰ-es- (cf. Lith. debesìs 'cloud', Latv. debess 'cloud', Skt. nábhas- 'fog, mass of clouds, sky', Gk. νέφος 'cloud, mass of clouds', Hitt. nēpiš- n. 'sky').}];80[603-604{Cf. s.v. Hitt. nēpiš- 'sky, heaven' < PIE s-stem neut. *nébʰ-os, *nebʰ-és-os.}];156[I:71-72{S.v. Oss. arv 'небо', from Iranian *abra-, cf. Ved. abhrá- 'cloud, thunder cloud'.}];172[I:94{Cf. s.v. Ved. *abhrá- 'Gewitterwolke, Gewölk, Regenwolke' < PIE *n̥bʰ-ró- (*nebʰ-), cf. YAv. aβra- 'Regen[wolke]'.}];353[118{S.v. Lith. debesìs 'cloud' (Latv. debess, var. debesis), from PIE *nebʰ-es-. The initial *n of the etymon was apparently replaced with d- in East Baltic.}];50[288-289{S.v. Proto-Celtic *nemos- 'heaven, sky', from PIE *nebʰos 'cloud, cloudy sky' (cf. Hitt. nēpiš 'sky', Skt. nábhas- 'cloud', Gk. νέφος, OCS nebo 'sky'. "The irregular *-m- of the Celtic forms is best explained as the result of assimilation (n…bʰ > n…m)."}];352[186-187{Cf. s.v. OLith. debesìs, debeỹs 'Wolke' (BSl. cf. Latv. debess, OCS nebo, etc.), from PIE *nebʰ-es- 'Himmel, Luftraum, Wolke' (cf. Hitt. nepis-, 'Himmel', HLuw. tipas- 'id.', Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke| Himmel', OAv. nabah- 'Luftraum, Himmel', Gk. νέφος 'Wolke, Bewölkung').}];458[24: 101-104{PS *nebo, *nebese is derived from PIe *nebʰos- and related to Lithuanian debesìs, Old Indic nábhas-, Greek νέφος, Hittite nepiš etc.}];301[265{If related to OBr. nom 'curve' rather from *nem- 'to bend' (LIV² 463) than connected with words meaning 'cloud'.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):603-604, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:71-72, [ALEW](src-352) 186-187, [Derksen 2015](src-353):118, [ESSJa](src-458) 24:101-104, [Derksen 2008](src-81):347-348, [Matasović 2009](src-50):288-289).

Source: 81[300{S.v. Proto-Slavic *màlъ adj. 'small, little' (ESSJa 17:173-178). Derksen argues for a derivation from PIE *moh₁-lo-.  The semantic shift is one of 'small animal' > 'small' (Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle, goat, sheep' < *meh₁-lo-| OIr. míl '(small) animal'| Goth. smals m. 'small, insignificant'| Old Icelandic smali m. 'small (live) stock, sheep').}];269[{The connection with the Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small' is unclear. An etymological connection is possible, but not fully agreed whether or not the Germanic lexemes are also cognate with Gk. μῆλον, etc. < *meh₁lo- (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8298](cog-8298)). In any case, if this etymology is correct, it could well be a case of parallel semantic shift from *'small animal' > 'small'.}];458[17:173-177{PS *malŭ is most probably related to Greek μῆλον 'small cattle', Latin malus 'bad, evil' (<'small, insufficient'), Gothic smals 'small', German schmal 'narrow' etc. It is derived from PIE *mēlo-/*(s)mēlo- 'small cattle'. As to the semantic development cf. Ukrainian mal' 'small sheep (collective!)'.}];249[{The connection with PG *smala- 'small', Gk. μῆλον etc. is widely accepted in the Slavic etymology.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes considered cognate with Ancient Greek µῆλον 'small cattle, goat, sheep' < *meh₁lo- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):300 arguing for the Slavic forms reflecting an o-grade root form *moh₁-lo-, cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 17:173-177). Further connections with Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small' might be possible, but remain uncertain (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):517-518, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456 and further discussion in [cognate set 8298](cog-8298)).

Source: 274[86-99{S.v. *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, *dʰg̑ʰ-ém-, *dʰg̑ʰ-m-´-, *g̑ʰ-m̥-m-´-, f. 'Erde' (IEW 414ff.)}];81[545{S.v. Proto-Slavic *zmьja 'snake' and *zmьjь 'snake, dragon', a derivative of zero-grade of the word for earth *dʰg̑ʰ-m-.}];259[755{PS *zmĭjĭ and *zmĭja are derived from the same root as PS zeḿa 'earth'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from the zero-grade stem of PIE 'earth' *dʰg̑ʰ-m- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 86-99, [Derksen 2008](src-81):545, [Boryś 2005](src-259):755).

Source: 353[523{S.v. Lith. žvaigždė 'star' (Latv. zvàigzne 'star', OPr. swãigstan (acc.sg.) 'light'), cf. OCS dzvězda, Russ. zvezda, Cz. hvězda, etc. On the basis of Balto-Slavic *g/źwoi⁽ź⁾deʔ, a PIE reconstruction *g̑ʰuoig̑ʰ-dʰeh₁- may be considered, however given the variation of Lith. žvai(g)zdė̃ alongside žvai(g)ždė̃ a reconstruction *g̑ʰuoidʰ-dʰeh₁- is a possible alternative. The reconstruction *g̑ʰu̯oi̯gʷ- found in IEW is based on a comparison with Gk. φοῖβος, which Derksen considers untenable.}];81[195-196{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gvězda 'star' (ESSJa VII 181-183). On the basis of Balto-Slavic *g/źwoi⁽ź⁾deʔ, a PIE reconstruction *g̑ʰuoig̑ʰ-dʰeh₁- may be considered, however given the variation of Lith. žvai(g)zdė̃ alongside žvai(g)ždė̃ a reconstruction *g̑ʰuoidʰ-dʰeh₁- is a possible alternative. The reconstruction *g̑ʰu̯oi̯gʷ- found in IEW is based on a comparison with Gk. φοῖβος, which Derksen considers untenable.}];458[7:181-189{The first part of PS *gvězda / *zvězda is derived from PIE *g̑ʰu̯oi̯- 'glow, glare'. The etymology of the second element is disputable. It can be a deformation of *stā- 'stand'. It has been also interpreted as *dhē 'put'. The West Slavic initial *g- is probably secondary.}];352[1332-1333{S.v. OLith. žvaigždė̃ (4), žvaĩgždė (2) 'Stern' (BSl. Latv. zvàigzne 'Stern', OCS dzvědza 'Stern', etc.). No good etymology outside of Balto-Slavic. The Balto-Slavic forms are to be considered cognates, but the precise reconstruction of a proto-form is difficult. Cf. entry for extensive discussion on the difficulties of reconstructing a proto-form for this lexeme.}]
Justification: Generally agreed that the Baltic and Slavic forms are cognate, but there is debate as to how the Proto-Balto-Slavic word is to be reconstructed. Cf. discussion in [Derksen 2008](src-81):523, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:181-189, [Derksen 2015](src-353):195-196, [ALEW](src-352) 1332-1333.

Source: 259[482, 572{PS *prętati and *prǫtŭ have no certain etymology.}];593[510{PS *prǫtŭ is etymologically obscure. There are similar words in Germanic (cf. German Spross, English sprout, Old Icelandic sproti) but it is complicated to put them together with the Slavic lexeme (the Slavic form points to *pronto- and the Germanic one to *spreudo-). However, the Slavic and Germanic forms could be maybe linked to PIE *(s)per- 'splash, sparkle, sprout'.}];598[3: 396{PS *prętati is usually linked to PS *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig']. However, it has not been proven, that PS *prętati had meanings like 'entwine, wrap'.}];599[2: 79{It is complicated to explain PS *prętati etymologically without linking it to *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig'], although it is not fully convincing semantically. However, if we assume that the meaning 'hide' is not original, this problem can be solved (*prętati could originally mean 'wrap, cover with sprouts' etc.).}];608[372{Russian prâtat' ['hide'] is related to prut ['sprout, sprig']. The original meaning of the verb was 'wrap' (and that of prut 'sprout good for binding, intertwining, wrapping').}];636[2: 240, 241{PS *prętati is related to PS *prǫtŭ 'sprout, sprig'. The PIE root is *preu- / *prou- / *prū- 'jump, burst', cf. also Russian prygat' 'jump'.}]
Justification: There is no certain etymology. The relationship to PS *prętati and Russian prygat' is dubious. Cf. [cognate set 5208](cog-5208).

Source: 172[I:137-138{Cf. s.v. Ved. áśman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Fels' (Av. asman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Himmel'), from PIE *h₂ek̑-mon- (cf. Gk. ἄκμων 'Amboß (auch 'Meteorstein' und 'Himmel'), Lith. ašmuõ (pl. ãšmens) 'Schneide, Schärfe', akmuõ, -ẽns 'Stein'). To PIE *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz'.}];458[9:137-140{PS *kamy, *kamene is related to Old Indic aśma 'stone', Lithuanian akmuõ 'stone', Old High German hamar 'hammer' etc. It is derived from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp'. Note that the depalatalization and the metathesis in Slavic is irregular.}];81[220{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kamy 'stone, rock' (ESSJa IX 137-140), from PIE *h₂ek̑-men- (cf. Lith. akmuõ, 'stone', Latv. akmens 'stone', Skt. áśman- 'rock, stone', Gk. ἄκμων 'anvil, meteor, heaven').}];353[47-48{S.v. Lith. akmuõ 'stone', from PIE *h₂ek̑-men- (cf. OCS kamy, Skt. áśman- 'stone, rock', Gk. ἄκμων 'anvil, meteor, heaven').}];352[28-29{S.v. OLith. akmuõ, ãkmuo, akmuõj 'Stein, Felsen' (BSl. OLith. ašmuõ 'Schneide, Spitze', Latv. akmens 'Stein', asmens 'Schärfe, Schneide, Spitze der Ähre', etc.), from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'Stein', G.sg. *h₂k-n-és- (cf. Ved. áśman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Fels', G.sg. áśnaḥ, YAv. asman 'Himmel', G.sg. ašnō, OPers. asman- 'Himmel', Gk. ἄκμων 'Amboss', G.sg. ἄκμονος).}];157[30-31{S.v. Gaul. acaumon 'pierre', corresponding to IE *ak̑mōn 'pierre', Skt. áśman- 'pierre', Gk. ἄκμων 'enculme, pierre météoritique', Lith. akmuõ 'pierre', etc. with thematisation of the suffix -men- : *ak̑mōn = *akm̥non > *acamnon > acounon.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ([EWAia](src-172) I:137-138, [ALEW](src-352) 28-29, [ESSJa](src-458) 9:137-140, [Derksen 2008](src-81):220, [Derksen 2015](src-353):47-48, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):30-31).

Source: 81[418{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. If from *proH-uo-, then perhaps cognate with Lat. probus 'solid, decent' provided Lat. probus continues *pro-bʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-. No further etymology.}];294[639{Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor| frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.}];594[{PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639).

Source: 141[487-488{S.v. *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).}];172[II:194-196{S.v. Ved √plav- '(im Wasser) schwimmen, (im Luftraum) schweben, gleiten' (cf. YAv. fra-frāuuaiiāhi 'du schwemmest fort'), from PIE *pleu̯- (cf. Gk. πλέω 'schiffe, segle, schwimme', Lat. pluit 'es regnet', OHG flouwen 'spülen, waschen', Lith. pláuti 'spülen, abwaschen', OCS pluti 'fließen, schiffen', etc.).}];81[403, 406{S.v. Proto-Slavic *plavati 'swim, sail' & *pluti 'swim, sail'. "It seems that Balto-Slavic offers evidence for both *pleh₃u- and *pleu- (cf. Derksen 1996:116-117). LIV (485, 487) distinguishes between *pleh₃- and *pleu-, while entertaining the possibility of a *u̯e-present for the former root. Balto-Slavic *pleh₃u- may be a conflation of these two roots. The existence of an acute root *pl(j)ouʔd- < *pleud-, cf. Lith. pláusti 'wash, bathe' (alongside pláuti), OIc. fljóta 'flow', may have added to the confusion."}];66[1208-1209{Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek πλέω 'to travel by sea, sail, navigate', from PIE *pleu- 'sail, flow'. Primary thematic πλέ(ϝ)ω is a PIE formation (cf. Skt. plávate 'to swim, flow', OCS pluti 'to flow, sail', Lat. pluit 'it rains', etc.).}];678[116-117{Proposes a Balto-Slavic reconstruction *pleHutó- or *ploHutó- to account for the acute root (cf. Gk. πλώω < *pleh₃-).}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1208-1209, [EWAia](src-172) II:194-196). Assignment of the Slavic lexemes to this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 487-488 and other sources, but cf. reservations of [Derksen 1996](src-678):116-117, [Derksen 2008](src-81):403.

Source: 458[28: 167-168{PS *obpašĭka is ultimately derived from PS *ob-paxati (*paxati 'sweep, broom, wave').}];603[4: 897-898{Bulgarian opaš, opaška is derived from PS *paxati 'blow'.}];81[389{The etymology of PS *paxati 'blow' and related *paxnǫti 'smell (of)' is unknown. According to Vasmer, it is of ideophonic origin.}];259[406-407{PS *paxati is derived from PIE *pē̆s- 'blow'.}];594[{PS *paxati 'blow' is probably related to Lithuanian puošti 'clean',  Old High German fegōn 'prepare, sweep, arrange', Old Nordic fága 'clean' etc. and derived from PIE *pēk̑- 'clean, tidy, decorate'.}];593[440{PS *paxnǫti has probably an ideophonic origin. It resembles the roots *pyx-, *pux- which, however, have a wider cognacy.}]
Justification: The original meaning was 'a part of the body an animal can chase away (literally 'sweep away') insects with', cf. direct attestations of this motivation in [ESSJa](src-458) 28:141-142. There is no commonly accepted etymology outside of Slavic; all further proposals have formal issues ([Derksen 2008](src-81):389, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):440, cf. also [Boryś 2005](src-259):406-407, [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 4:897-898, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Source: 81[97-98{S.v. Proto-Slavic *debelъ adj. o 'fat' (ESSJa IV 201-202) is based on a Balto-Slavic root *deb-. Cognate with Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debīkan Asg. 'big'| debica (Gr.) 'big'| OIc. dapr 'sad'| Nw. daper 'sad, with young'| dabb(e) (dial.) m. 'small, fat fellow'| OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set'. Derksen: "Formally, the Balto-Slavic and the Germanic forms do not match, considering that in the case of PIE *b the Balto-Slavic evidence would violate Winter’s law. It is by no means necessary, however, to assume that this etymon is of Indo-European origin."}];165[89{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'heavy' (cf. RuCS debelyj 'fat', Ru. debelyj 'plump, corpulent' SCr. dèbeo 'fat' < *dʰebʰ-lo-| OCS doblь 'strong', Ru. dóblij 'valiant', Latv. dabļš 'strong, lush' < *dʰobʰ-l-io-). "This adjective is usually directly compared to the aforementioned forms in Slavic, but the underlying root *dʰebʰ- can only be reconciled with PGm. *dapra- by assuming that it was derived from *dapōn-, an analogical variant belonging to the iterative *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' (q.v.) < *dʰobʰ-néh₂-."}];49[239{S.v. *dʰeb- 'dick, fest, gedrungen'.}];458[4: 201-203{PS *debelŭ is derived from PIE *deb- / *dob- and related to PS *dobrŭ ['good'].}];397[907{Cf. s.v. NHG tapfer (MHG tapfer, dapfer, OHG tapfar 'schwer, gewichtig', MLG dapper, MDu. dapper), from Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'schwer, gewichtig'. Also in ON dapr 'traurig, betrübt', NE dapper 'gewandt'. Comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain. One may compare OCS debelŭ 'dick', OPr. debīkan 'groß', TochA tpär B tapre 'hoch'. The meaning also fits to OCS dobrŭ 'gut', etc.}];353[530-531{S.v. Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debica 'big', A.sg. debijkan, debīkan, debbīkan. From Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- (cf. Proto-Slavic *debelъ 'fat') ultimately from PIE *dʰebʰ- (cf. OIc. dapr 'sad', Nw. daper 'sad| with young' Nw. dabb(e) 'small, fat fellow' OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set).}];269[{Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ([IEW](src-49) 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):97-98, [Derksen 2015](src-353):530-531, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89, [Kluge 2011](src-397):907 for further discussion.}]
Justification: Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ([IEW](src-49) 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):97-98, [Derksen 2015](src-353):530-531, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89, [Kluge 2011](src-397):907 for further discussion.

Source: 259[344{PS *myslĭ 'thought, thinking' is derived from PIE *meu̯dʰ- and related to Lithuanian maũsti 'desire, miss', Gothic ga-maudjan 'remember' and Greek μυ̃θος 'word, speech, mythos'.}];458[21: 47-50{The mainstream view is that PS *myslĭ is derived from PIE *meudʰ- / *mudʰ- 'desire, aim at' and related to Lithuanian maũsti 'desire', Gothic gamaudjan 'remember' and Greek μυ̃θος 'word, speech, mythos'. The Lithuanian word has, however, an alternative explanation. An alternative etymology is to link it to PIE *men and reconstruct it as *monslĭ- (cf. Lithuanian mąslus 'thoughful'.}];81[337{S.v. Proto-Slavic *myslь 'thought, idea' (ESSJa XXI 47-50), to be derived from PIE *muHdʰ- and related to Greek μυ̃θος 'word, fact, purpose'.}];66[976{Cf. s.v. AGk. μῦθος 'word, discourse, conversation, deliberation, story, saga, tale, myth'. There are no certain comparanda, and the word may be a borrowing from a Pre-Greek substrate language.}];270[718-719{Cf. s.v. AGk. μῦθος 'suite de paroles qui ont un sens, propos, discours'. Etymology obscure. Perhaps a popular onomatopoeic expression based on a syllable μῦ according to [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), but the sense of the word in the earliest texts is not in favour of this hypothesis.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *mysliti, a denominal formation to Proto-Slavic *myslь 'thought, idea'. Within Slavic literature, *myslь is generally further compared to Ancient Greek μῦθος 'word, discourse, story' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):337, [ESSJa](src-458) 21:47-50, [Boryś 2005](src-259):344), although within Hellenist literature Greek μῦθος is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):718-719, [Beekes 2010](src-66):976 for further discussion). The etymology of Proto-Slavic *myslь is remains therefore uncertain.

Source: 141[688{S.v. *u̯erg̑ʰ- '(zu)binden' [IEW 1154-5] with OCS -vrŭzǫ, -vrěsti 'tie', Lithuanian veržiù, ver̃žti 'tie, restrict', Old English wyrgan 'strangle' etc. listed as cognates.}];603[1: 188-189{Bulgarian vr"zvam is related to Lithuanian ver̃žti, veržiù 'tie', Old High German wurgen 'strangle', Anglo-Saxon wurgil 'knot' etc.}]
Justification: Cf. OCS vrъzǫ 'tie' from PIE *u̯erg̑ʰ- (cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:188-189, [LIV²](src-141) 688).

Source: 141[691-2{S.v. *u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8)}];172[II:518-519{S.v. Ved. √vart- 'sich drehen, sich wenden, rollen' (IIr. cf. YAv. varət-a- 'wenden', Parth. wrd-/wšt- 'se tourner', Chwaresm. m|ʾwrd- zurückkehren, umkehren', NPers. gard-/gaštan 'wenden, drehen', Sogd. wrtn 'Wagen', etc.). from PIE *u̯ert- 'sich drehen, wenden' (cf. OHG werdan 'werden', ON norðan-verðr 'nordwärts gerichtet', Lat. uertō 'wende, kehre', Lith. vir̃sti 'wenden, kehren', OCS vrьteti 'sich wenden, drehen').}];353[492{Cf. s.v. Lith. vartýti 'turn, turn over' to which also OPr. wartint 'turn', from PIE *uort-eie- (cf. Skt. vartáyati 'turns').}];81[529, 539{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *vortiti 'turn, return' from PIE *uort-eie- (cf. Lith. vartýti 'turn, turn over', OPr. wartint 'turn', Skt. vartáyati 'turns') and s.v. Proto-Slavic *vьrtěti 'turn', from PIE *urt- (cf. Lith. vir̃sti 'fall, collapse, turn into', Skt. vártate 'turn, roll').}];54[666-667{S.v. Lat. ve/ortō, -ere 'to turn', from Proto-Italic wert-e/o- (cf. O. ϝερσορει [dat.sg.] epithet of Jupiter prob. 'who averts' < *uert-tor, U. vurtus, etc. < *urt-us-), from PIE *uert-e/o- (cf. Skt. vártate 'to turn (around), roll', Av. varəta- 'to turn', OPr. wīrst 'to become', Lith. vir̃sti 'to turn (around), fall over, become', OCS vrьtěti, Ru. vertét 'to turn (around)' < *u̯r̥t-, Goth. wairþan, OHG werdan 'to become', etc.).}];352[1197-1198{Cf. s.v. OLith. vartýti 'wenden, drehen, wälzen' (BSl. Latv. vā̀rtit, OPr. inf. wartint 'kehren', OCS vratiti '(sich) umwenden'), from PIE *u̯ert- (cf. Ved. (cs.-iter.) vartáyati, OIr. dofortai 'gießt (aus), Goth. fra-waurdjan 'verderben', etc.).}];259[376, 694-695, 710{PS *obvortiti is derived from *vortiti, cf. Lithuanian ver̃sti, verčiù, Gothic wairþan and Latin vertō, vertere. PIE *u̯ert- < *u̯er-.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ([LIV²](src-141) 691-692, [EWAia](src-172) II:518-519, [ALEW](src-352) 1197-1198, [Derksen 2008](src-81):529, 539, [Derksen 2015](src-353):492, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):666-667).

Source: 81[46{S.v. Proto-Slavic *bļьvàti 'vomit' (ESSJa II 140-141), from PIE *bʰleuH- (cf. Gk. φλέω 'flow over', Lat. fluō 'flow').}];141[90{1.*bʰleu̯H- 'overflow' with OCS bľujǫ, bľĭvati, Latin fluō, fluere, Greek φλέει etc. listed as cognates. Lithuanian bliáuju, bliáuti is given as a questionable cognate.}];593[82{PS *bľĭvati is of ideophonic origin and is maybe related to Lithuanian bliáuti. Cf. plivat ['spit'].}];594[{The meaning of PS *bľĭvati was originally 'generate inarticulate sounds, bleat, grunt', cf. Lithuanian bliáuti. The question is if the Slavic word belongs to PIE *bʰleu̯H-, cf. Latin fluere.}];458[2: 140-141{PS *bľujǫ, bľĭvati is a parallel formation to *pľujǫ, pľĭvati ['spit']. It is possible that -ľ- is an epenthetic consonant here. The most plausible reconstruction would be then *bjou-. In this case, it can not be related to Lithuanian bliáuju, bliáuti, Greek φλύειν and Latin fluō.}]
Justification: It is often assumed that Proto-Slavic *bľĭvati is derived from *bʰleu̯H- and related to Latin fluō, fluere etc. ([LIV²](src-141) 90, [Derksen 2008](src-81):46). This etymology is adopted here, however cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 2:140-141, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):82, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) with skepticism.

Source:
81[338{S.v. Proto-Slavic *mỳti 'wash' (ESSJa XXI 76-79), from PIE *muH- (< earlier *miuH-), cf. Skt. mī́vati 'push, shove'| Lat. movēre 'move'.}];141[445-446{*mi̯eu̯h₁- 'move' with OCS myjǫ, myti 'wash' given (as a possible cognate). The attested Slavic forms go back to *muh₁-, a root variant developed by analogy.}];458[21: 76-79{PS *myti (sę) is derived from PIE *meu̯-, *meu̯ə-, *mū̆- 'wet, damp, dirty, dirty liquid (urine)| wash, clean', cf. Lithuanian máudau, máudyti 'bathe', Latvian maut 'submerge', Greek μιαρός 'dirty', μω̃μος 'shame', μύζω 'suck', μύδος 'dampness', Old Indic mū́tra 'urine', Old Irelandic muad 'cloud', Middle Irelandic mūn 'urine', mosach 'impure', Low German moder 'mildew', Armenian geta-moyn 'submerged in a river'.
Some scholars link it to Latin movēre 'move'.}];54[390-391{OSC myti 'wash' (< *muH-) is a cognate of Latin moveō 'move'.}];259[343{PS *myti is related to Lithuanian máudyti 'bathe, wash', Old High German muzzan 'clean', Old Indic mū́tram 'urine' and Avestan mūŋəm 'dirt'. PIE *meu̯-, *meu̯ə-, *mū̆- 'wet, damp' and 'wash'.}]
Justification:
Some sources assume a derivation from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- and a relationship to Latin moveō, movere, cf. the citations below.
However, this etymology is virtually not present in Slavic etymology dictionaries, cf. the citations below and [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 398, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 185-186, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 3: 26 where a different set of IE comparanda is given. Although the proposed Greek comparanda rather do not belong here [Beekes 2010](src-66): 950-951, 991, 974, 975-976, other IE comparisons as with Old Indic mū́tram 'urine', Proto-Celtic mūno- 'urine' and Lithuanian máudyti with a PIE reconstruction *meu̯H- (and without giving Latin moveō, movere etc. as a cognate) is accepted in branch-specific dictionaries, see [KEWA](src-399): 663-554, [Matasović 2009](src-50): 281, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 378.
PS *myti could not derive directly from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁-. An irregular phonetic change or another special change would have to be assumed here.
Thus, the connection to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- is not accepted here.

Source: 81[322{S.v. Proto-Slavic *mokrъ 'wet, damp' (ESSJa XIX 144), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *mok- (cf. Lith. makõnė 'mud').}];458[19: 144-147{PS *mokrŭ is derived from *mok- (cf. *močiti, *moknǫti). It is related to Armenian mōr 'dirt'. Further, it has been linked to Greek μάκαρ 'blessed' and Lithuanian màkaruoti 'pug, mix, beat', cf. also Lithuanian makõnė 'dirt', maknà 'muddy, damp place'.}]
Justification: There are no certain cognates beyond Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):322, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 369-370), cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 19:144-147, [Beekes 2010](src-66): 893.

Source: 81[40{S.v. Proto-Slavic *bělъ 'white' (ESSJa II 79-81), from earlier *bʰelH- (cf. Lith. bãlas 'white', Latv. bā̀ls, bãls 'pale'| bal̃ts 'white').}];353[80{S.v. Lith. báltas 'white' (Latv. bal̃ts 'white'), from PIE *bʰolH-to- (cf. PSl. *bòlto 'swamp', Alb. baltë 'mud, swamp', Mod.Gk. βάλτος 'swamp', Rom. baltă 'mud, swamp'). For the semantics cf. Lith. balà 'swamp' = PSl. bělъ 'white'.}];352[87, 89-91{S.v. OLith. báltas 'weiß' (BSl. cf. Latv. bal̃ts 'weiß', OCS blato 'Sumpf', etc.). The East Baltic word for white is morphologically closest to the past passive participle of OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden'. The also lexicalised Slavic correspondence shows that the adjective was already Proto-Balto-Slavic. On the semantic development of 'white' > 'swamp' in Slavic, see ESSJa 2:180. Lith. bálti is a denominal incohative to Lith. bãlas 'weiß' which has been replaced by báltas. Lith. bãlas is put together with Gk. φαλός (Hesych.) 'weiß', φαλιός 'hell| weißfleckig' (cf. Frisk 1960-1972 2.988f.), Arm. bal 'Nebel, weißer fleck' (cf. Martirosyan 2010:162f.), and Alb. bálë 'weißer Fleck auf der Stirn von Tieren, Blässe' (cf. Demiraj 1997:87). Lith. bãlas is not to be separated from the Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS bělъ. Ru. bélyj, Cz. bílý, etc., which apparently have a reflex of Proto-Slavic *ē in the root. The morphological relationship within the family and the identification of a common is yet to be explained. The often assumed connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten' (cf. Ved. 3.sg.pres. bhā́ti, Gk. φάντα (Hesych.) 'leuchtend') is conceivable.}];269[{The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. [ALEW](src-352) (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable| [Derksen 2008](src-81):40 and [Derksen 2015](src-353):80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 2:79-81.}];458[2: 79-81{An issue in the reconstruction of PS *bělŭ is the root vowel. However, it can be established that the output form was *belo-, with a short monophthong. It is related to Greek φαλός 'white', Breton bal 'white spot on the forehead (of a horse, cow, dog)' and Lithuanian bãlas 'white'. PIE *bʰel- / *bʰol-.}]
Justification: The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. [ALEW](src-352) (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable; [Derksen 2008](src-81):40 and [Derksen 2015](src-353):80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 2:79-81.

Source: 595[4: 46{PS *širŭ is related to Avestan xšaeta- 'bright, shining' derived from *ksoi̯- < PIE *sk/k̑ei̯- 'shine' (with a consonant metathesis).}];593[629{PS *širŭ is usually linked to Gothic skeirs 'bright' and German schier 'clean' < PIE *skəir- 'bright'. A metathesis *sk- > *ks is assumed here. The semantic development 'bright' > 'open' > 'wide' is plausible.}];259[602{PS *širŭ is related to Gothic skeirs 'bright', German schier 'clean', Old Icelandic skīrr 'clean, bright' < PIE *skei̯- 'bright, light'. In PS a metathesis of the initial consonant group took place.}]
Justification: There is no certain etymology. The widespread hypothesis ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:46,  [Rejzek 2001](src-593):629, [Boryś 2005](src-259):602) assumes an irregular phonetic change, cf. also [LIV²](src-141) 546. [Not in [Derksen 2008](src-81)].

Source: 81[247{S.v. Proto-Slavic *krīdlo- 'wing' < PIE (transponat) *(s)krei-dʰlom. Balto-Slavic has the root *(s)krei- in common, cf. Lith. skriẽti (dial.) 'rotate, circle, fly' (Standard Lith. skríeti), Latv. skrìet 'go, run, fly'.}];141[562{Cf. s.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). As a verbal root only Baltic. In Slavic without s-mobile.}];458[12: 152-154{PS *kridlo / *skridlo is derived from PIE *(s)krei̯-}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *krīdlo- 'wing', further derived from PIE *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'to describe a circle' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):247, [ESSJa](src-458) 12:152-154, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 562).

Source: 352[625-627{S.v. OLith. mẽdis 'Baum, Holz, Wald' (BSl. Latv. mežs 'Wald, Gehölz, OCS mežda 'Straße', etc.), from PIE *médʰi̯o- 'mittlerer, in der Mitte befindlich' (cf. Ved. mádhya- (adj.) 'mittlerer'| (snt.) 'Mitte', YAv. maiδiia- 'mittlerer', Gk. μέσος, μέσσος 'mittlerer', Lat. medius 'mittlerer', Goth. midjis, ON miðr, OHG mitti 'in der Mitte befindlich').}];353[309{Cf. s.v. Lith. medžias 'forest, woods' (Latv. mežs 'forest, woods', OPr. median 'forest, woods'), from PIE *medʰ-i-o- / *medʰ-i-eh₂- (cf. Skt. mádhya- 'middle, located in the middle'| Lat. medius 'middle, located in the middle'| Goth. midjis 'middle').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *médʰ-i̯o- 'middle, located in the middle' ([ALEW](src-352) 625-627, [Derksen 2015](src-353):309).

Source: 81[172-173{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *gȏdъ m. 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o- (cf. Goth. goþs 'good', OHG guot 'good').}];141[195{Cf. s.v. ?*gʰedʰ- '(zusammen)treffen, sich vereinigen' (IEW 423-4) with OCS ugoditi 'please (be liked)', Russian godit'sâ 'to be suitable, useful' etc. listed as cognates.}];165[162-16{OSC godŭ '(suitable) time, year', Serbo-Croat goditi 'please', Russian godit' 'wait, loiter' etc. are related to Old Frisian gadia 'engage in', Middle Dutch gaden 'fit, please, mate', Old High German be-gatōn 'gather' and further to English good, German gut 'good', Dutch goed 'good' etc. PIE *gʰodʰ-o-.}];458[6: 189-192{PS *godŭ is derived from or related to *goditi. PIE *gʰadʰ-, cf. Old Frisian gadia 'unify', Middle High German ergetzen 'gladden, satisfy', gaden 'suit, please', Old High German gi-gat 'suitable' (PG *gattjan).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *gȏdъ 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):172-173, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:189-192, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 195).

Source: 249[{This cognate class is not related to [cognate set 4989](cog-4989), in spite of the superficial similarity. However, it is possible that irregular changes of the initial consonant in Polish, Polabian and Czech etc. are due to a contamination of these two etymona. The irregularities can be explained also phonetically, though. Slavic cognates containing this root show a broad range of meanings, including 'back', 'top', 'hill', 'ridge', '(mountian) range', 'edge', 'sharp' etc. It can not be excluded that there is a relationship to one of the PIE roots with meanings 'cut', 'scratch', 'bend' like *(s)kerb-, *(s)kerbʰ or *(s)kreb- but any hypothesis would be rather very uncertain.}];458[107-109{The root *xrĭb- along with variants *xrib-, *skrĭb-, *skrib- are related to verb *skrebti 'scratch'.}];260[400-402{Reflex of PIE *(s)gerb- 'crimple, squeeze' and/or PIE *(s)kerb- 'sharp, cutting'.}];593[216{There is no clear etymology.}];636[501{It is a reflex of PIE *skerbʰ-, *skorbʰ-, *skrbʰ- with a semantic development parallel to Latin spīna.}];599[355{Reflex of PIE *(s)ker- 'bend' with -b- extention.}];589[685{There are no clear IE parallels.}];595[202, 203{There is no clear etymology.}];259[184{The Slavic lexemes are derivative(s) from *xrĭb- and *xrib- which had also variants *xrip- and *skrip-. The variant whith *sk- is probably the original one. However, there is no certain etymology.}]

352[1328, 1339];598[2: 99{Related to Lithuanian atžū́las, atžūlùs 'harsh, inhuman', įžūlùs 'intrusive', Avestan zūrah- 'unjustice', Persian zūr 'lie', further to Lithuanian žvalus 'sneaky', žvilavo 'he was bending down', Latvian zvel̂t, zveļu, zvēlu 'turn, bend', Old Indic hvárati, hválati 'he goes on croocked ways, goes making loops, he stumbles', Avestan zbaraiti 'he goes on croocked ways, goes making loops, he stumbles', Ossetian æwzær 'bad'.}];531[228-229{Lithuanian įžulnùs 'oblique', Latvian 'roll, wallow, flip over, tip' etc. are related to Slavic *zŭl- 'bad'. The underlying PIE root is *g̑ʰu̯el- / *g̑ʰul- whithout further IE cognates beyond Balto-Slavic.}];259[742{It is a reflex of IE PIE *g̑ʰu̯el- (*g̑ʰŭlo-). The closest cognate is Lithuanian -žūlus (in atžūlùs 'sharp, unmerciful' and įžūlùs 'arrogant, intrusive'). More distant IE cognates are Old Indic hvárate 'diverge from the correct road' and Latin fallō fallere 'bring to downfall, trick, outfox'.}];595[4: 403{The PS *zŭl- is related to Lithuanian atžū́las, atžū́lus, įžulùs etc. The PIE root is *g̑ʰu̯el-. Ossetian zul, zol, zylyn, zolun 'crooked' is likely to be related. Older authors assume a relationship to Old Indic hvárate 'to walk on croocked path', hválati 'stumble on', Avestan zbarəmna 'walking crookedly' and/or to Latin fallere 'cheat'. However, these words are linked to *g̑ʰu̯er- and *(s)gʷHel- roots, respectively.}];636[323{PS *zŭl- is a reflex of PIE *g̑ʰul-, *g̑ʰu̯el-, *g̑ʰu̯ol- 'bend'. It has cognates in the Baltic and Indo-Iranian languages.}];593[739{PIE *g̑hulo-, derived from *g̑u̯hel-. It is closest related to Lithuanian -žūlùs in atžūlùs and įžūlùs, further to Latvian zvelt 'hit', Latin fallere 'lie, cheat', Greek φῆλος 'deceitful', Avestan zūrah- 'unjustice', and Old Indic hvárate, hválati 'goes crookedly, diverges from the correct road'.}];81[551{Derksen gives as cognates only Lithuanian atžū́lus, atžūlùs 'rude' and only cautiously pažvìlti ‘bend, stoop’. He only points that the Balto-Slavic root (*źulʔ-) has been connected with Skt. hvárate ‘go crookedly’.}];249[{The relation to Baltic forms as -žūl(n)ùs and the reconstruction of the PIE root *g̑ʰu̯el- is convincing. The further cognacy is uncertain. Some previous authors give here hypothetical cognates that are currently assumed not to be related to each other and/or that can not be (direct) sources of PS *zŭl- (reflexes of *g̑ʰu̯er- like Old Indic hvárate and hválati and of *(s)gʷʰh₂el- like Latin fallō, fallere). However, a reconstruction of *g̑ʰu̯el- instead of *g̑ʰu̯er- for Old Indic hvárate etc. is possible cf. (LIV: 182). Then the Slavic word would have Indo-Iranic cognates.}]

595[4: 217-218{Although the cognacy of the Slavic word belonging to this class (along with further related lexemes in Slavic lanugages) is obvious, due to irregularities in the root vocalism it not trivial to determine the original PS root and to some extend also the exact morphological structure of the original word. The possibilities are *trěbuxŭ, *trĭbuxŭ, *tribuxŭ, *terbuxŭ, and *tŭrbuxŭ. The inconsistencies can be of expressive nature. If *terb- 'clean, (to) gut' is the input form, the original meaning is 'guts of a killed animal that have to be cleaned, gutted'.}];594[{PS *terbűxъ or *trěbűxъ, *trьbűxъ, *tribűxъ are derivatives from *tȇrbъ or *trě̑bъ, *trь̏bъ, *trȋbъ that do not have any satisfying etymology. It can be related to Latin strebula, stribula 'flesh about the haunches'. Alternatively, it can be related to PS *terbiti 'clean, shell'.}];609[567-568, 574{Polish telbuch, terbuch, trybuch is related to torba 'bag'. However, any etymology of the latter is given by the author.}];589[495{Serbo-Croat trbuh is probably related to Czech břicho, Polish brzuch, Russian brûho which are derived from PIE *bhreus- 'swell'. The first syllable tr- is maybe related to trti 'rub'. The r in *bhreus- was lost due to a dissimilation to the first r.}];591[641{The lexeme (Czech terboch) is common Slavic but its etymology is unclear. Maybe, ter- is related to Latin uterus 'belly, womb'. It is also thinkable that the word is related to Latin strebula.}];260[1499{A reconstruction of a uniform PS form is complicated. Most probably it is a reflex of PS *terb- which is an old -b-extention of *ter- 'rub'. *-ux- is a suffix. Forms without this suffix are also found in Slavic (e.g. Ukrainian tereb 'belly'). The irregular root vocalism is due to an expressive character of this word. The hypotheses of Vasmer, Brückner and Macher are unjustified and inconvincing.}];598[4: 97{It is hard to determine a (uniform) PS form. It can be a compound of *trĭ- (an adjectival prefix with a superlative or superlative-like meaning, also preserved in its original meaning 'triple') and *bux- 'swell'. Some scholars assume here *terb and link the Russian trebuha, trebuh 'glutton' to Ukrainian tereb 'belly', terebuh 'glutton'. Both hypotheses do not explain the West Slavic forms. The hypothesis of Brückner is impossible phonetically, a comparison to Italian trippa 'belly' is dubious [Addendum of Trubačov: -ux- can be a suffix and the word can be related then to Latin strebula].}];602[5: 626-627{There is no commonly accepted etymology. The underlying root is probably PS *terb-, an extention of *ter- 'rub'. Then the word is related also to PS *terbiti 'clean, gut'. In this case, *-ux- is to be assumed as a suffix. The hypothesis of Vasmer is less probable. The comparisons to Polish torba, Latin strebula, Italian trippa, and Latin uterus are not much convincing.}];249[{The most convincing etymology is *terb- 'clean, gut', linking the word ultimately to PIE *terh₁- 'rub'. The irregularities in the root vocalism can be expressive and/or somehow connected to various root vocalisms that are present in Slavic reflexes of *terh₁-. However, the relationship of PS *terb- to PS *ter- (PIE *terh₁) can be disputed, cf. (Boryś 2005: 648).}];141[632-633{Cf. s.v. *terh₁- 'bohren, reiben' (IEW 1071-2).}]

352[919-920{Cf. s.v. OLith. skaitýti 'lesen, zählen' (derived noun skaĩčius, skaičiùs 'Zahl, Anzahl'| BSl. cf. Latv. skàitît 'zählen, rechnen'), from PIE *(s)kei̯t- 'bemerken' (cf. Skt. cetáyati, -te 'erkennen', cs. '(sich) zeigen').}];141[382-383{S.v. *kʷei̯t- 'bemerken, erkennen' (IEW 637).}];81[89-90{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čisti (ESSJa IV 119), from PIE *(s)kʷ(e)it- (cf. Latv. šķist 'think, suppose, seem', Skt. cétati 'perceive, take notice of') and Proto-Slavic *čitati 'read, count' (ESSJa IV 123), likewise from PIE *(s)kʷeit-| *(s)kʷoit- (cf. Lith. skaitýti 'read, count').}];353[401{Cf. s.v. Lith. skaitýti 'read, count' (Latv. skàitît 'count, recite, read'), from PIE *(s)kʷeit-/*(s)kʷoit- (cf. Skt. cétati 'perceive, take notice of').}];458[4: 119]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kʷei̯t- 'to perceive, to recognise' ([LIV²](src-141) 382-383, [ALEW](src-352) 919-920, [Derksen 2015](src-353):401, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:119, [Derksen 2008](src-81):89-90).

Source: 141[80{S.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-5).}];81[57-58{S.v. Proto-Slavic *borti < PIE *bʰorH- (cf. Lat. ferīre 'hit'| OIc. berja 'beat, hit'| OHG berjan 'hit, pound, knead').}];165[53{S.v. Proto-Germanic *berjan- 'to fight', from PIE *bʰorH-ie- (cf. OCS brati (sę) 'to fight' < *bʰorH-ie-| Lith. bárti, Latv. bãrt 'to scold' (refl. 'to quarrel') < *bʰorH-e-, Lat. feriō, -īre 'to strike' < *bʰerH-ie-| OIr. barae 'anger, hostility' < *bʰrH-en-).}];458[2: 203-204, 213-214{PS *borti, *boriti 'fight' is related to Lat. feriō, ferīre 'hit', Old High German berjan 'hit' and Lithuanian barti, baru 'chide'.}]
Justification: Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 2:203-204, 2:213-214, [Derksen 2008](src-81):57-58, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):53).

Source: 81[526-527{S.v. Proto-Slavic *volsъ 'hair', from PIE *u̯olk̑-o- (cf. Skt. válśa- 'sprout, twig', LAv. varəsa- 'hair (on the head)').}];172[II:526-527{S.v. Ved. válśa- 'Schößling, Trieb, Zweig', cf. YAv. varəsa- 'Haar', Sogd. wrs, MPers. wars, NP gurs. From PIE *u̯olk̑o- (cf. OCS vlastъ, Russ. vólos, etc. 'Haar').}];323[94{*wr̩siya- [as input for Pashto]}];259[704{PS *volsŭ is related to Avestan varəsa- 'hair', Middle Persian vars 'hair' and Old Indic válśa- 'young twig, sprout'. These words are derived from from PIE root *u̯el(ə)- with a suffix *-so-, cf. words without that suffix: Lithuanian valaĩ 'hair of horse tail', Old Indic vā́la- 'hair of horse tail' and dialectal Polish włoć 'spike'.}]
Justification: Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯olk̑-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):526-527, [EWAia](src-172) II:526-627; for Pashto cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):94).

Source: 259[610{PS *šĭja 'neck, back of neck' has no certain etymology.}];593[628, 630{PS *šija 'back of the neck' is most probably related to PS *šiti 'sew', cf. Czech vaz ['neck, back, ligament'] and vázat 'tie'. PS *šiti 'sew' is derived from PIE *si̯ū- 'sew' and related to Latin suere, Old Indic sī́vyati, English sew etc.}];594[{PS *šija is probably derived from PS *šiti 'sew'. If this etymology is correct, its etymological meanigs is 'part of body that ties head with thorax'.}];141[545{*si̯eu̯H- 'sew'.}]
Justification: The etymology pointing to PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'sew' is not commonly accepted, cf. also [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 41-42 and [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 4:434-435. It is, however, convincing formally and semantically (and has parallels).

Source: 141[623{Cf. s.v. ?*telk- 'schlagen' (IEW 1062). Only Slavic and possibly Welsh talch 'Bruchstück'.}];259[635{PS *telkti 'hit, beat, press' may be related to Lithuanian tel̃ktì, telkiu 'convoke (for a collaborative work), collect together', tìlkti, tílksu 'be tamed', Latvian nuo-talcît 'to birch, beat up' and Old Welsh talch 'chaff'. PS (Balto-Slavic and Celtic only) *telek- / *telk- 'hit, beat'.}]
Justification: See also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 668-669.

Source:
81[131{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dъzdjь 'rainstorm, rain', from PIE *dus-diu-(s), where *dus- is the prefix 'bad' and *diu-(s) is 'sky' (*di̯eu̯-).}];274[69-81{S.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f., EIEC 513), cf. n56, where the Slavic lexemes in the meaning 'rain, bad weather' are probably to be derived from a compound *dus-di̯u- 'bad day/sky'.}];458[5: 195-197{The etymology of PS dŭždžĭ is problematic. Despite the lack of an internal motivation in Slavic, it is most probably a Slavic-only innovation and has no convincing parallels. The widespread etymology *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day' (with antonymic Greek εὐδία 'serene sky, fair weather' given as parallel) can not be assumed to be entirely convincing. The issue is even not that rain is beneficial for farmers (taboo expressions of this kind are known). The crucial thing that we do not know any ancient names for 'rain' with a motivation of 'bad weather' and it has to be considered as a typological aspect.
Most lexemes for 'rain' are derived from roots meaning 'pour', 'wet', 'water'. PS -ždž- can be also a reflex of palatalized *zg, cf. here cf. Lithuanian dūzgė́ti 'buzz, make noise'. PS dŭždžĭ can be, in the end, ideophonic.
[Cf. also a summary of other etymologies.]}];259[113{It could be an ancient compound *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day'. An issue is that the parts of this compounds are not attested as such in Slavic. Further, the original meaning would be unexpected, as rain is desirable for farmers and shepherds. However, it can not be exluded, that it was originally used for a harmful kind of rain, like a lingering rain during time of harvesting.}]
Justification:
The ingenous and popular etymology as *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day' is kept here. However, is should be born in mind that this etymology is considered to be doubtful or at least not the only thinkable by many scholars, cf. the citations below and [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 1: 521-522, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 129, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 1: 100.
One of the most widespread alternative etymologies assumes a relationship to PG *duska- 'drizzle(?)', see [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 111.

Source:
598[3: 191-193{Russian palka (along with Serbo-Croat palica, Slovene palica, Polish pałka etc.) is most probably not a loanword from Old High German pfâl 'pal' (which is, in turn, a borrowing from Latin pāllus). It is maybe related to Old High German spaltan 'split', Old Indic spháṭati 'split', spuṭáti 'tear' etc. It is also rather unrelated to palec ['finger'].
Russian palec ['finger'] (cf. also Polish palec, Czech palec, Upper Sorbian palc etc.) is derived from PS *palŭ (cf. Russian bespalyj, šestipalyj). It is usually linked to Latin pollex 'thumb, big toe'. It can be further related to New Persian pālidan 'look for' and Old High German fuolen 'feel'.
[Cf. also for a summary of other hypotheses.]}];593[441-443{The etymology of PS *palica is not entirely clear.
It can be related to pálit 'bounce' that is related to Latin pellere 'drive away, kill, beat' and maybe also to Old Indich sphāláyati 'clash, beat'. Then it would be derived from PIE *(s)pel- 'beat'. In Slavic, it has been contaminated with pálit 'glow, burn'. It is also possible that both verbs have a common origin.
Another hypothesis links PS *palica to PS *paliti 'glow, burn' (derived from PIE *pel-/*pol-). The semantic motivatition were that sticks as tools were seared over the fire to get durable.
If the meaning of PS *palica was originally 'thick stick', it could be also compared with PS *palŭ that is derived from PIE *pōlo- 'thick', cf. palec ['toe, thumb'].}];259[408-409{PS *pala 'thick stick' (with diminutives *palŭka and *palica) is probably derived from PIE *pōlo- 'thick', see also palec ['finger' < 'thoe, thumb']. Cf. Latin pollex 'thumb', polleō, pollēre 'be strong'.
Polish pal 'pole' is a loanword from Middle High German pfâl.}];54[478{"The alleged connection with CS palьcь [...] < PSl. *palьcь < *pōl- does not explain Latin pollex. Meier-Brügger 1990 proposes to explain pollex from *por-likʰ-s 'which is licked over' to the root *leiɡ́ʰ- 'to lick' (see Lat. linɡō)."}];595[3: 5{PS *pala (along with *palica, *palŭka, *palĭ) has some possible explanations. Most probably it is related to PS palĭcĭ 'thick finger'. I has been also explainded as derived from PIE *(s)p(ʰ)el- 'chop, bang' or compared to *paliti 'burn'.}];81[390{S.v. Proto-Slavic *palica 'stick, staff' "The obvious connection with forms containing a root *pol- (e.g. *polìca) forces us to reconstruct a lengthened grade *pōl- for *palica. This is not in agreement with the accentual evidence, however. The etymology of the root is unclear."}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):390; cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:191-193, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):441-443, [Boryś 2005](src-259):408-409, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 3:5 for various proposals and further discussion).

Source: 81[308-309{S.v. Proto-Slavic *metati 'throw' (ESSJa XVIII 112-115) & Proto-Slavic *mesti 'throw, sweep' (ESSJa XVIII 105-108). Derksen considers, given the similarity of the movements of 'sweep' and 'mow', LIV² ?1.*met- 'mähen' (Lat. metō 'mow, harvest', W. medi 'reap') these lexemes should also be etymologically connected.}];141[442{Cf. s.v. ?2.*met- 'abmessen' (IEW 703-704), verbal only Balto-Slavic.}];353[313-314{S.v. Lith. mèsti 'throw' (Latv. mest). According to LIV² 442, verbs with the root ?2.*met- 'abmessen' are limited to Balto-Slavic. Given the similarities of the movement 'sweep' and 'mow', Derksen would advocate a connection with Lat. metere 'mow, harvest' (?1.*met- 'mähen'). De Vaan (2008:378) considers a semantic shift from 'measure off' > 'reap' possible and is also inclined to assume a single root *met-.}];54[377-378{Cf. s.v. Lat. metō, -ere 'to reap, harvest'.}];352[639-641{S.v. OLith. mèsti 'werfen, schleudern' (BSl. Latv. mest 'werfen', OPr. N.sg.pres.part.pass. pomests 'unterworfen', OCS mesti 'werfen', etc.), extra-Balto-Slavic connections are uncertain. LIV² assigns to ?2. *met- 'abmessen', alternatively to *met- 'mähen' [cf. LIV² ?1. *met- 'mähen' to Lat. metō 'mähen, ernten'] if the semantic development was originally via 'rotate, wind'.}];458[18: 105-108, 112-115{PS *mesti and *metati are related to each other.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *met-. Further IE root etymology disputed: either to PIE ?1. *met- 'mähen' ([LIV²](src-141) 422) or ?2. *met- 'abmessen' ([LIV²](src-141) 422) ([Derksen 2015](src-353):313-314, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:105-108, 112-115, [Derksen 2008](src-81):308-309); [ALEW](src-352) 639-641 doubts connections outside of Balto-Slavic.

Source: 81[63{S.v. Proto-Slavic *br̡ûxo, *br̡ûxъ 'belly' (ESSJa III 33-34), from PIE *bʰreu̯s-o- (cf. OIr. brú 'abdomen, belly', Welsh bru 'womb, belly').}];458[III:33-34{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *br'uxo, arguing from PIE *bhreu- 'swell', comparing Old Irish brū 'belly', Welsh bru 'womb', but also Ved. bhrūṇá-s 'embryo'.}];50[81{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bruson- 'abdomen, womb', from PIE *breu̯s- 'belly'(?), cf. OE breost 'breast', Russ. brjúxo 'belly, paunch'. Proto-Celtic *bruson- is an n-stem derived from the zero-grade of the PIE root (*bʰrus-on-).}];296[B:99-100{S.v. OIr. 1 brú 'sein, ventre, matrice'. The words suppose a root *bhreus-, *bhrus-, from which Celtic created a stem *bhrusnyo-. The same root is attested in Germanic, cf. Goth. brusts, OHG brust, OE breost, OS briost, etc.}]
Justification: Slavic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:99-100, [Matasović 2009](src-50):81, [ESSJa](src-458) 3:33-34, [Derksen 2008](src-81):63).

Source: 81[514{S.v. Proto-Slavic *velikъ 'big, great', from PIE *uelh₁- 'to be strong' (cf. Lat. valeō 'be strong, well').}];141[676-677{Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯elH- 'stark sein, Gewalt haben' (IEW 1111-2).}];595[294-295{PS *velĭ is most probably a reflex of PIE *u̯elH- 'be strong, have power, rule' and related to Old Nordic olla '(he) ruled', Latin valēre 'be strong', and Tocharian A walo, Tocharian B wäl 'king'. A relationship to PIE *u̯el- 'push, squeeze, turn' and Greek ἅλις is less likely.}];260[1612, 1704-1705{PIE *u̯el- 'to force, press', related to Latin valeo 'be strong, healthy', Greek εἰλω 'I force, I press', Tocharian A wäl 'prince, emperor'. It can be also linked to OCS velěti 'want, order'.}];259[693-694{There is no certain etymology. The meaning points to PS velěti 'command'. It can be related to Latin volgus, vulgus 'people, heap, great ammount', Greek ἅλῐς 'in plenty, numerous', Tocharian B walke 'long, far', wälts 'thousand'.}];598[289{It is related to Tocharian A wäl 'prince, emperor', Tocharian B wal 'prince, emperor' and walke 'long, further', Greek Ϝἄλις 'enough', εἴλω, εἰλέω 'press, squeeze'.}];594[{PIE *u̯elH- 'be strong, have power, rule'. It is related to Old Irish follnadar 'he rules', Old Nordic olla 'he ruled', Latin valēre 'be strong', Tocharian A walo, B wäl ‛king’. Linking to Greek ἅλῐς 'many', Latin vulgus 'people', Old Indic várga- 'group', Breton awalc'h 'enough', Welsh gwala 'a large number, enough' (PIE *u̯el-) is less probable.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes generally connected to PIE *u̯elH- 'to be strong, have power' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):514).

Source: 259[63{PS *xmura / *smura is sometimes linked to Greek ἀμαυρός 'shadowy, pale, dark'. PS *xmara is doubless related to *xmura / *smura. The vowel -a- can be a result of a contamination (for example with *mara 'dream, shadow of a dead person, phantasm, ghost').}];598[3: 212-213, 693-694, 4: 249, 250{Russian words hmura, smuryj, pasmurnyj, xmara, smuryj, muryj (meanings 'cloud', 'dark', 'dark grey' etc.) are related to Old Icelandic meyrr 'dark, friable' and Greek ἀμαυρός 'shadowy, pale, dark'. The initial x- is probably expressive. The internal -a- is possibly a result of a contamination with another word (for example para, par 'vapour' or mar' 'fog').}];458[8: 42-44{PS *xmura (along with *smurŭ) is related to Greek ἀμαυρός 'dark'. PS *xmara is a contamination of *xmura and *mara.}];66[84{"Substrate origin is probable anyhow, as the word has no etymology".}]
Comment: Further Indo-European cognates uncertain. The root is probably dialectal (North Slavic). Variants with a/u s/x can coexist in one single language or its dialects, normally with slightly different meaning (probably the variant with -a- is a result of a contamination with another root).

Source: 458[15: 81-83{PS *ličiti 1. (> Polish liczyć 'count' etc.) ist etymologically related to *ličiti 2. (> derived from *likŭ, *lice, Russian lico 'face' etc.), although the semantic development ist complex to explain: 'show the outer side of something' (literally 'face side') > 'announce, make public' (attested in Slavic) > 'count'. By the interpretation of PS *lice 'face' we have to consider that words for this meaning are often derived from roots for 'to form, to shape, to make' (cf. Polish twarz or Latin facies). The original meaning of PS *lik- coul be 'form by casting, cast'. It would be then derived from the verb *liti 'pour' (formations like *oblikŭ support a verbal derivation here). Cf. Lithuanian lytìs 'form, figure, appearance' and phrases like Russian vylityj otec 'son very similar to his father' [literally 'poured/casted father'].}];259[288{PS *ličiti 'to form, to shape, to embellish', 'be visible, be similar'. The meaning 'count' is North Slavic. The lexeme is related to Lithuanian lykúoti 'count', possibly also with Latvian līkt 'make a deal' and Latin liceō, licēre 'be put up for sale'.}];54[340{"There are no certain cognates of the rot *lik- outside Italic".}];249[{The etymology of *lice, *likŭ 'face' proposed by ESSJa is convincing (regarding to the relationship of words for 'face', 'form, shape' and 'pour, cast' a Polish paralell wykapany ojciec 'son very similar to his father' (kapać 'drip') could be added). The ultimate PIE root would be *lei̯H- 'pour'. However, the semantic relationship to the word for 'count' is much more complicated.}];598[2: 495-496{Russian lik 'face' is related to Irish lecco, leaca 'cheek' and Old Prussian laygnan 'cheek'. Rusian lik 'number' is most probably derived from *ličiti 'make public' which is related to Russian lik 'face'.}]

602[1: 265{Most probably PS *bru-d-ŭ 'something with a hot, bad taste', then 'something ugly, ugliness'. It is related to PS *bridŭ 'ugliness' which is derived from PIE *bher- 'cut, scratch'.}];607[1: 381-382{The origin of PS *brudŭ is uncertain. Some scholars link it to Slovene brûzga 'snow mixed with mud'. There is also a relationship to PS *bridŭ assumed. Both lexemes would be then derived from PS *bher- 'cut'. Some scholars assume that the Ukrainian and Belarusian form are borrowed from Polish.}];259[40-41{PS dialectal *brudŭ has an uncertain origin. It is a relationship to PS *bridŭ 'sharp, cutting, bitter, bad (about taste)', 'ugly, disgusting', cf. Slovac brid 'dirt, garbage', dialectal Ukrainian bryd 'something disgusting, dirty', dialectal Belarusian bryd 'dirt'. However, the middle -u- is hard to explain.}];458[3:44-45{PS *brudŭ is considered as etymologically obscure by some scholars. However, if we assume an original meaning 'dregs, sediment' we can propose a relationship to Latin defrutum 'boiled syrup', Thracian βρῦτος, βροῦτος 'barley beer' and Illirian (rendered as Latin brīsa 'pulp'). PIE *bhereu̯- 'boil, bubble'.}];141[81{*bʰeru̯- 'boil, bubble'.}];249[{The etymology is unclear. Nor de Vaan [de Vaan 2008](src-54) neither Beekes [Beekes 2010](src-66) does not list the PS lexeme among cognates of Latin or Greek (borrowed from Thracian!) words derived from the PIE root *bʰeru̯-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside Slavic uncertain, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 3:44-45, [Boryś 2005](src-259):40-41, [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 1:381-382, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 1:265 for various proposals.

Source:
81[354-355{S.v. Proto-Slavic *noga 'foot, leg', as though from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. Lith. nagà 'hoof'| nãgas 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').}];352[681-682{Cf. s.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' (BSl. Latv. nags 'Finder- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf', OPr. mage 'Fuß'), from PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle' (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ, -υχος, Lat. unguis, OIr. ingen, ON nagl, OE nægel, etc.).}];458[25: 161-164{PS *noga is derived from PIE *onogh- (: *ongh-, *nogh-, n̥gh-) and related to Lithuanian nagas 'fingernail', Latvian nags 'fingernail, claw', Old High German nagal 'fingernail', Old Irish ingen 'fingernail', Latin unguis 'fingernail', Greek ὄνυξ 'fingernail, claw' etc.
It was originally a collective noun with a meaning 'a set of nails/claws' (>'paw, hoof'>'leg, foot').}]
Justification: Related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):354-355, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164).

Source: 81[158{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *ę̄tro 'liver' < PIE *h₁en-tr-om (cf. Ved. āntrá- 'intestine', Gk. ἔντερα 'entrails').}];172[I:76-77, 166-167{S.v. Ved. āntrá- 'Eingeweide', a derivative of Ved. antár- 'inside'. Cf. ántara- 'innerer, im Inneren befindlich, dazwischen stehend, etc.' which is formally cognate with Gk. ἔντερα (cf. YAv. aṇtara- 'innerer').}];458[6: 72-73{S.v. *ętro. The word is derived from *en-tr-o-m, cf. Old Indic antrám, Armenian ənderk', Greek ἔντερα 'guts'.}];442[16-17{S.v. 357 ántara- 'interior, near' RV. & 376 antastya- 'intestines' Ait.Br. (> Gaw. andḗc).}]
Justification: Modern Indic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *h₁enter- 'inner part' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):158, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:72-73, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):16-17 no. 357, [EWAia](src-172) I:76-77, I:166-167).

Source: 141[510{*reu̯H- 'tear (up)' with OCS rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' and ryjǫ, ryti 'dig' given as cognates.}];598[3: 506-507{It is most probably related to ryt' ['dig'] and rylo ['snout'].}];260[208{PS *rŭtŭ is derived f *reu-, *reuə-, *rū̆- 'dig, tear, churn up'. Cf. also another derivatives like Russian rylo 'snout' or Polish ryj 'snout'.}];602[5: 127{There is no commonly accepted etymology. It has been linked to PS *ryti 'dig', Serbo-Croat rupa 'hole', Kashubian retk 'sandbar, bay, puddle' and German Rüssel 'snout.'}];594[{PS *rŭtŭ is derived from PIE *h₃er- 'move forward, raise' [for reflexes of this root see [LIV²](src-141): 299-300].}];593[538{PS *rŭtŭ is often linked to PS *ryti ['dig']. However, it is semantically not convincing. It is rather derived from PIE *(e)r-eu- 'raise'. The original meaning were 'something raised' (> 'tip, top' > 'beak' > 'mouth').}]
Justification: Taking into account lexemes like Polish ryj 'snout' and Russian rylo 'snout' (that can be expressively used also for human mouth), both derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'dig' (the original meanig was probably 'pig snout'), there is no reason to doubt on the relationship of PS *rŭtŭ to PIE *reu̯H-. The alternative etymology is much worse from the semantic point of view.

Source: 598[1: 473-474{The etymology is obscure. It has been (unconvincing) linked to Russian gul 'buzz' (etymologically unclear itself), Serbo-Croat gúliti 'booze' (etymologically unclear itself) and Lithuanian guliù, gulė́ti 'lie down'.}];602[1: 617{There is no commonly accepted etymology.}];607[3: 113-114{It is probably derived from an interjection hu-la! hul!}];458[7: 14-15, 171-173{PS *guľati is derived from PS *guliti. These verbs are related to PS *golŭ ['naked'] which is, ultimately, derived from PIE *gʰel- 'shine'.}];259[196{PS dialectal *guľati 'play, dance, sing, have fun, rave' is, probably, ultimately derived from PIE *gou̯(ə)- 'shout, call', cf. also Polish gaworzyć, gwarzyć 'chat, babble'.}]
Justification: PS *guľati does not have a commonly accepted etymology. From the semantic perspective the hypothesis of [Boryś 2005](src-259): 196 (*geu̯h₂-, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) and [LIV²](src-141): 189) looks most convincinɡ, the -l-/-ľ-, however, needs a formal explanaition.

Source: 141[466-467{Cf. s.v. *pei̯s- 'zerstampfen, (zer)stoßen' (IEW 796).}];81[426{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьxati 'push, shove', from PIE *pis- (cf. Skt. pináṣti 'crush', Gk. πτίσσω 'winnow grain, bray in a mortar', Lat. pīnsere 'to crush').}];259[420{PS *pĭxati is related to Lithuanian paisýti 'thresh', Latin pinsō, pīnsere 'hit, grind', Greek πτίσσω 'grind in mortar and pestle, winnow corn' and Old Indic pináṣṭi 'hit, grind' and derived from PIE *pei̯s- / pis 'hit, crush, crumble'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *pьxati 'push, shove', a derivative of PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, crush' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):420, [Boryś 2005](src-259):420, [LIV²](src-141) 466-467).

Source: 81[418{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. "If *pràvъ < *proH-uo- […] we may compare the formation with Lat. probus ‘solid, decent’ provided that the latter form continues *pro-b ʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-."}];294[639{Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor| frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.}];594[{PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639).

Source:
274[370-387{S.v. *h₃ekʷ- 'ins Auge fassen, erblicken' (LIV² 297f., IEW 775ff.)}];458[26:91-92, 32:41-42{S.v. Proto-Slavic *obačiti, often interpreted as *ob-ačiti with *ačiti related to PS *oko ['eye']. However, the nature of the root vowel lengthening (*o>*a) were obscure then. Further, *ačiti itself is not attested anywhere else in Slavic. Thus, this etymology is doubtful and illusive.
It is commonly accepted that lexemes like Polish baczyć developed through a morphological re-interpreatation (*ob(-)ačiti > *o-bačiti). The East Slavic cognates are also normally treated as loanwords from Polish.
This dialectal Slavic lexeme can be a loanword from Iranian, cf. Avestan *aiwy-āxšayeinti < Eestern Iranian *abi-āxšaya- 'they observe, they guard' (with a long root vowel!).
[Cf. also for a summary of other hypotheses.]
(PS *oko, očese < PIE *okʷ- / *Hokʷ-.)}];602[1: 154-155{Most scholars assume that Ukrainian bačiti is a loanword from Polish where it developed trough a morphological re-interpretation of PS *ob-ačiti > *o-bačiti. PS *-ač(-iti) is considered to be related to PS *oko 'eye'.}];259[19{Polish baczyć 'notice, watch over, guard', Old Polish also 'remember, conclude, know, examine' (cf. dialectal Czech báčit, dialectal Slovac bačic 'observe, realize', Ukrainian bačyty 'see, presume, think', Belarusian bačyc' 'see') developed by a re-interpretation ob-aczyć > o-baczyć from PS *ačiti (probably 'see, perceive'), derived with a lengthening of the root vowel from *oko ['eye'].}];598[1: 138{Russian dialectal (southern, western) bačit', Ukrainian bačiti and Belarusian bačyc' are loanwords from Polish baczyć < PS *ob-ačiti (related to oko 'eye').}];607[1: 337{It is a loanword from Polish. It was borrowed into Russian dialects through Ukrainian.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *obačiti, traditionally explained as a compound verb *ob-ačiti where *-ačiti is interpreted as a derivative of PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' (cf.
