Slavic lexemes for 'eye' in [cognate set 211](cog-211)), although there are some formal issues with this identification (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 26:91-92, 32:41-42). Less plausibly it has been suggested that the lexemes were borrowed through East Slavic from Polish (cf. [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 1:337, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 1:154-155, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:138), however, the presence of cognates in many Russian dialects (Smolensk, Kostroma, Pskov, Tver' Novgorod, cf. [ESSJa](src-458): 26: 91} makes the hypothesis about an ordinary borrowing from Polish somehow questionable.

Source: 259[569, 744-745{PS *zoŕa / *zaŕa 'dawn, aurora' is derived from PS *zĭrěti 'look'. Cf. Lithuanian žarà 'dawn, aurora', žarijà 'glowing coal, embers', žėrėti, žėriù 'shine, glimmer', Old Prussian sari 'embers' and, further, German grau 'gray' and Old Irish grían 'sun'. PIE *g̑ʰer(ə)-.}];141[177{Cf. s.v. ?3. *g̑ʰer- 'strahlen, scheinen| sehen' (IEW 441-2). An exclusively Balto-Slavic root. The reconstruction of aspiration on the initial consonant of the root is uncertain, and the semantics are problematic.}];81[548{S.v. Proto-Slavic *zoŗa 'dawn, aurora', a derivative of the root of *zьrěti 'I see', cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *zьrěti 'see, look at'. "The reconstruction of the root is uncertain. One might posit *g̑⁽ʰ⁾r(H)-." Cf. Lith. žėrė́ti 'shine, sparkle'.}];352[1301-1302{Cf. s.v. OLith. žėrúoti 'glühen, glimmern, schwelen', with Lith. žėrė́ti 'glühen, glimmern| funkeln', a secondary derivative to the root of OLith. žer̃ti, žérti 'zusammenscharren (glühende Kohlen)'. Cf. OLith. *žãras 'Röte am Himmel, Morgenrot, Abendrot', comparable to OCS zor'a 'Licht, Schein, Glanz, Morgenröte', etc. No certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):548, [ALEW](src-352) 1290-1291, 1301-1302; [LIV²](src-141) 177 mechanically reconstructs a root ?3. *g̑⁽ʰ⁾er- 'to shine, radiate').

Source: 141[345-346{Cf. s.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).}];458[12: 10-11| 13: 257-258{PS *kyjĭ is related to PS *kovati and ultimately derived from PIE *kou̯- (cf. German hauen, Latin cūdo, cūdere, Lithuanian káuti etc.).}];81[265{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kyjь 'stick, club' (ESSJa XIII 257-258), a jo-derivative of *ky < *kuh₂-, cf. *kovati 'forge' (ESSJa XII 10-12) < PIE *kouh₂- (cf. Lith. káuti 'murder, beat, hew'| Latv. kaût 'fight', Lat. cūdere 'beat, grind, forge', OIc. hǫggva 'hew, beat'| OHG houwan 'hew, beat').}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *kyjь 'stick, club', a jo-derivative to *ky- < PIE *kuh₂- with regular laryngeal metathesis from zero-grade *kh₂u̯- (full-grade PIE *keh₂u̯- 'hit, split', cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:257-258, 12:10-11; [Derksen 2008](src-81):265, [LIV²](src-141) 345-346).

Source: 81[421f.{For the Polish, Kashubian, Polabian and Belarusian forms: PIE *pro-sth₂o-.}];259[484-485{PS *prostŭ is probably a compound of PIE *pro- 'forward, ahead, in front of' and *sto-, a derivative from *stā- 'stand'. The original meaning would be thus 'something standing in the front of something/someone'.}];141[590-592{S.v. *steh₂-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *prostъ 'simple, straight' as though from PIE *pro-sth₂o-, a derivative to *steh₂- 'to stand, place' + *pro- 'forwards'. ([Derksen 2008](src-81):421-422, [Boryś 2005](src-259):484-485, cf. [NIL](src-274) 637-659).

Source: 458[8:133-134{S.v. Proto-Slavic *xvostъ. Probably, the best explanation is to link PS *xvostŭ to the expressive word family with meanings 'catch' etc. and onsets *xva-, *xvo-, *xu-, *xy-.}];593[220, 231-232, 305{PS *xvostŭ does not have any certain etymology. Taking Slovene hosta 'forest' into account, one could assume a voiceless variant related to hvozd 'huge, thick forest' (then it could be compared to German Quast[e] 'tassel'. It can be also derived from PS *xvostati with an ideophonic origin. The original meaning of PS xvostŭ was probably 'broom'.}];260[398{It does not have any universally accepted etymology. It has been compared to German Quast.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:133-134, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):220, 231-232, 305; [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):398 for further discussion).

Source: 178[III:117{S.v. Russ. толстый 'dick', from Proto-Slavic *tъlstъ, related to Lith. tulžti, tulštù, tulžaũ 'anschwellen, weich werden'.}];141[639-640, 641{Cf. s.v. *teu̯h₂- 'schwellen, stark werden' (IEW 1080-1) and ?2.*teu̯k- 'stark/fett werden, schwellen' (IEW 1081). The nominal forms such as OCS tukъ 'fat', OIr. tón f. 'bottom' and Old Norse þjó 'thigh' are assigned to the latter. Latvian tauks 'fat' and OIr. tón both from *tŭknā-.}];353[459-460{S.v. Lith. taukaĩ 'fat' (Latv. tàuki 'fat', OPr. taukis 'lard'). The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and *teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-. For *teu̯H-, Derksen cites Serbo-Croat tȉti 'become fat' as a derivation. He regards the root form 2.?*teu̯k- postulated by LIV² as shaky, noting that Lithuanian tùkti was no evidence for a non-acute root.}];81[499-500{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tučьnъ 'fat, rich'. The Balto-Slavic lexemes presuppose PIE *tou̯Hk-o-, with the root *teu̯Hk- possibly being a contamination of *teu̯H- and teu̯k- or an extension of *teu̯H-.}];259[636, 652-653{PS *tlŭstŭ is derived from PIE *tu-l- / tū-l-, ultimately from *teu̯(ə)- / *tēu̯- / *tū̆- 'swell'. PS *tukŭ is derived from PIE *teu̯-k-, ultimately from *tēu̯(ə)- / *tēu̯- / *təu̯ / *tū 'swell'.}];352[1081{Lithuanian taukaĩ could be explained as *tou̯h₂-kó- from PIE *teu̯h₂-. The other Baltic lexemes however are better derived from *teu̯k-. This root *teu̯k- would also be sufficient to explain OIr. tón 'bottom'. Thus taukaĩ either is a substantival Vrddhi-form, or we see in Baltic a contamination of two different, pre-existing forms *tou̯h₂-kó- and *tou̯k-ó-.}]
Justification: There are enormous difficulties in reconciling this group of related Balto-Slavic lexemes to a PIE proto-form. Cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1081, [Derksen 2008](src-81):499-500, [Derksen 2015](src-353):459-460 for further discussion. A contamination or blend of between two roots *teu̯h₂- ([LIV²](src-141) 639-640) and *teu̯k- ([LIV²](src-141) 641) is a possibility. Cf. also Proto-Germanic *ϸeuha- 'thigh' in [cognate set 6956](cog-6956). The PIE root reference form *teu̯(h₂)k- is provisional only.

Source: 81[521{S.v. Proto-Slavic *vę̄zati 'tie', from PIE *h₂mg̑ʰ- (cf. Hitt. hamank- 'tie, betroth' [*h₂m-(o)n-g̑ʰ-], Gk. ἄγχω 'squeeze, strangle', Lat. angere 'strangle, choke').}];141[264-265{S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (IEW 42-3).}];259[688{PS *vęzati is related to PS *ǫzŭkŭ 'narrow' and derived from PIE *ang̑ʰ-.}];274[301-303{S.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (LIV 264f., IEW 42f.).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vę̄zati 'tie', a derivative of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'make narrow' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):521, [Boryś 2005](src-259):688; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 264-265, [NIL](src-274) 301-303).

Source:
81[274{S.v. Proto-Slavic *lěsъ 'forest, woods', further etymologies outside of Slavic are not certain (cf. discussion in entry).}];259[280{PS *lěsŭ has no certain etymology. It has been linked to Old English lœ̄s, lœ̄swe 'meadow' or Lithuanian lãiškas 'leaf'. Both etymologies have phonetic issues.}];458[14: 249-252{PS *lěsŭ has been linked to Greek ἄλσος 'sacred grove', Anglo-Saxon læs, læswe 'meadow', Lithuanian laĩškas, láiškas 'leaf', Latin larix 'larch', Latin lūcus 'a grove sacred to a deity', and Latin lignum 'firewood'. Some of these hypotheses show clear formal issues.
A common view is that the meaning 'forest' is secondary. Taking into account lexemes like Old Polish lasa 'small field in a clearing' and the fact that PS *lěsŭ refers often to deciduous forest or bushes (which are first to grow in a clearing), one could assume that the primary meaning was '(artificial) clearing'. The PS lexeme could be then derived from PIE *u̯el- 'tear, rip, hit' (*u̯loi̯-k̑os).}];594[{*PS *lěsŭ is likely to be related to Anglo-Saxon lǣs, lǣsve 'meadow, pasture' which is probably derived from PIE *leh₁- 'leave, abandon'. If it is right, the original meaning would be 'a field that is abandoned, not farmed anymore, where bushes started to grow'. Another possibility were a reconstruction *leg̑-so- with PIE *leg̑- 'to buckle, bend, arch'. The etymological meaning would be 'place where wicker grow, flexible vegetation' then.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 14:249-252, [Derksen 2008](src-81):274, [Boryś 2005](src-259):280 for further discussion of various hypotheses.

Source: 81[188-189{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gręzь 'mud, dirt' (ESSJa VII 125-126), a deverbative i-stem to *gręzti 'sink' and related to Lithuanian grim̃zti 'sink' and Latvian grim̃t 'sink'. Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic are uncertain.}];458[125{PS *gręznǫti can be related to Lithuanian grim̃zti 'sink' if we assume an original root *grĭm- with later extentions.}];531[201{Lithuanian grim̃zti 'sink' is related to Polish grzęznąć 'sink' etc. PIE *grem-g̑-. Cf. Lithuanian grìmti 'sink' and Latvian grimt derived directly from PIE *grem-.}]

81[354-355{S.v. Proto-Slavic *noga 'foot, leg', as though from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. Lith. nagà 'hoof'| nãgas 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').}];353[327{S.v. Lith. nagà 'hoof, nail' (cf. Latv. nagas Npl. 'both hands, hands and feet', OPruss. nage 'foot'), from PIE *h₃n(o)gʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').}];352[681-682{Cf. s.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' (BSl. Latv. nags 'Finder- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf', OPr. mage 'Fuß'), from PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle' (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ, -υχος, Lat. unguis, OIr. ingen, ON nagl, OE nægel, etc.).}];458[25: 161-164{PS *noga is derived from PIE *onogh- (: *ongh-, *nogh-, n̥gh-) and related to Lithuanian nagas 'fingernail', Latvian nags 'fingernail, claw', Old High German nagal 'fingernail', Old Irish ingen 'fingernail', Latin unguis 'fingernail', Greek ὄνυξ 'fingernail, claw' etc.
It was originally a collective noun with a meaning 'a set of nails/claws' (>'paw, hoof'>'leg, foot').}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes, related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):354-355, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164, [ALEW](src-352) 681-682, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327).

Source: 81[393{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pekti 'bake', from PIE *pekʷ- 'cook' (cf. Lith. kèpti 'bake, fry' [with metathesis], Skt. pácati 'cook, bake, fry', Gk. πέσσω 'bake, cook, ripen').}];353[237-238{Cf. s.v. Lith. kepti 'bake, fry' (Latv. cept 'bake, fry'), from PIE *pekʷ- (cf. OCS pešti, Ved. pácati 'cook, bake, fry', Gk. πέσσω 'bake, cook, ripen'). "It is generally assumed that East Baltic *kep- results from metathesis."}];352[477-478{Cf. s.v. OLith. kèpti 'backen, braten', among the derived forms OLith. kẽpenos, kepanos sf.pl. 'Leber' (BSl. Latv. cept 'backen, braten, brennen', OCS pešti 'braten, rösten'), from PIE *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (cf. Ved. pac- 'kocht, brät', YAv. pac- 'kochen', Gk. πέττω 'lasse reifen, verdaue, koche', Alb. pjek 'backen, braten, gären, brennen', Lat. coquō, -ere 'kochen, backen, braten', MW pobi 'Backen', TochA päk- kochen, reifen', TochB päk- 'kochen, reifen lassen'). The East Baltic words continue PIE *pekʷ- if they may be accounted for via a metathesis to *kʷep-.}];141[468{Cf. s.v. 1. *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (IEW 798).}];598[3: 255-256{Russian pečen' (cf. Ukrainian pečìnka 'liver' and Polish pieczeń 'roast') is derived from peku, peč' ['bake, fry, roast']. Originally it referred to 'roasted liver'.}]
Comment: < 'cooked'.
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to make ripe; to cook' ([ALEW](src-352) 477-478, [Derksen 2015](src-353):237-238, [Derksen 2008](src-81):393, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:255-256, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 468).

Source: 141[510{S.v. *reu̯H- 'aufreißen' (IEW 868), with OCS rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' and ryjǫ, ryti 'dig', Latin ruō, ruere Vedic rávat, Tocharian B rwātär etc. given as cognates.}];598[3: 452{Russian rvat' is related to Latin ruō, ruere, Old Indic rávati, Lithuanian ravė́ti, raviù etc.}];259[528{PS *rŭvati is related to Lithuanian ráuti, ráuju 'tear out, pull out', Latin ruō, ruere 'fall down, squirm', Tocharian A, B ru- 'tear'. PIE *reu̯- 'dig, tear'.}];81[441-442{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *rъvati 'tear' from PIE *(H)ruH- (cf. Lat. rūta caesa 'minerals and timber already quarried and felled at the time an estate is put up for sale', OIc. rýja 'tear out wool').}]
Justification: From Proto-Slavic *rъvati 'to tear' and further derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:452, [Derksen 2008](src-81):441-442, [Boryś 2005](src-259):528, [LIV²](src-141) 510).

Source: 443[6/1:160-181{French manger 'eat' from Lat. manducāre 'chew, eat'.}];54[361-362, 442{S.v. Lat. mandō 'chew, bite', from which Lat. manducāre is a secondary derivative via mandūcō 'masked figure with champing jaws' (Pl.+). Against LIV² which derives Lat. mandō from *meth₂- 'rob, snatch away' (IEW 732). De Vaan alternatively argues for a derivation from *menth₂- 'to stir, whirl' via a nasal-infix stem *mt-n(é)-h₂-. with a phonetic development paralleled by pandō < *pt-n(é)-h₂- (*peth₂- 'to spread').}];141[438-439, 442-443{S.v. *meth₂- 'wegreißen' (IEW 732). Cf. n4: thematised *mat-n̥-h₂-e- > *matane- > *matne- > mande-| regarding the semantic development 'wegreißen' → '(Beute) reißen' → 'zerfleischen' → 'fressen' → 'kauen'.}];269[{LIV² is followed representing the usual communis opinio for the root-cognacy from *meth₂-, but cf. arguments of de Vaan for a possible alternative derivation from *menth₂- with further discussion and references to secondary literature.}];444[431{S.v. 5292 Lat. mandūcāre 'essen'.}];316[382{S.v. Lat. mandō 'manger gloutonnement, dévorer'. An expressive word with root vocalism in -a-. The connection with Gk. μάθυιαι· γνάθοι (Hesych.), μασάομαι 'je mâche', μαστάζω 'je mâche', μάσταξ 'bouche| pâtée', μέστακα· τὴν μεμασημένην τροφήν (Hesych.), μοσσύνειν· μασάσθαι βραδέως (Hesych.) is not determinable. Cf. Gall. mant and OHG ga-mindil 'mors'?}]
Justification: Italic lexemes continuing Latin mandūcāre 'to chew, bite' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):431 no. 5292, cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 6/1:160-161). Latin mandūcāre is a secondary derivative to a primary verbal formation attested in Latin mandere 'to chew, bite' (cf. mandūcō 'glutton'). Traditionally attributed to a root *meth₂- 'to tear off' via a semantic development to *'tear (prey)' → 'to lacerate' → 'to devour' → 'to chew' ([LIV²](src-141) 442-443), alternatively [de Vaan 2008](src-54):361-362 sees a development from *menth₂- 'to stir, whirl' ([LIV²](src-141) 438-439) via a nasal-infix stem *mt-n(é)-h₂-. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):382 consider a word of expressive origin.

Source: 443[2:111-120{S.v. Lat. camba 'sprunggelenk der Pferde' > Fr. jambe 'Bein'.}];316[267{S.v. Lat. gamba, -ae 'patte, jarret du cheval et, plus généralement, des quadrupèdes'. A likely borrowing from Greek καμπή 'bending, winding' in the specialised language of Greek veterinarians or breeders.}];444[142{S.v. 1539 Lat. camba (griech.) 'Bein'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):143, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):267).

Source: 423[III:586-587{S.v. Span. largo, from Lat. largus 'abundante, considerable'.}];54[327{S.v. Lat. lārgus 'generous, bountiful'. Etymology unclear. The formal derivation and semantics from earlier attempts at an etymology in Walde-Hofmann and Pokorny IEW as though from *lajes-ago- 'carrying fat' are not convincing.}];316[342{S.v. Lat. largus, -a, -um 'abondant', without certain correspondences.}];444[399{S.v. 4912 Lat. largus 'geräumig, weit, breit'.}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ([DCECH](src-423) III:586-587, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):399), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):342, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):327).

Source: 294[633-649{S.v. *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft mit Abl.)| for Lat. prope, cf. p.641, derived from PIE *pro-pro 'immer weiter, vorwärts' with dissimilatory loss of the second -r-.}];54[492-493{S.v. Lat. prope 'near, near by, close', from PIE *própro 'on and on, ever further' (cf. Skt. prá-pra 'on and on', Gk. πρόπρο 'before| on and on').}]
Justification: The Latin and Romance forms are based on a reduplicated formation *pró-pro with dissimilation of the second *-r- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):492-493, [LIPP 2](src-294):641).

Source: 423[V:505-508{S.v. Sp. tirar, a word common to the Western Romance languages of uncertain origin. Maybe from Germanic teran 'desgarrar'.}];444[725{S.v. 8755 *tīrāre 'ziehen, schießen', of uncertain origin.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):725, [DCECH](src-423) V:505-508 for further discussion).

Source: 444[358{S.v. 4309 Lat. impingere 'hineinstoßen'.}];54[465-466{S.v. Lat. pingō, -ere 'to colour, paint'. Most IE forms show a root *pei̯k̑- (cf. Gk. ποικίλος 'multicoloured', Lith. piẽšti 'to draw lines, adorn', OCS pьsati 'to write', etc.), but Italic seems to require *pi⁽g̑⁾-.}];141[464{S.v. 1. *pei̯g- 'malen' (IEW 794). Cf. n1, probably a variant of the better attested root *pei̯k̑-| verbal only in Latin (and Tocharian?), cf. Ved. piṅgalá-, piṅga˚ 'rötlich', OCS pěgъ 'bunt'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin impingere 'to push, strike, drive at' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):358), further to PIE *pei̯g- 'to paint', probably a variant of the better attested root *pei̯k̑- 'carve out, cut out' ([LIV²](src-141) 464, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):465-466).

Source: 54[320{S.v. Lat. labor 'work, labour'. "Often connected, albeit hesitantly, with labō 'to waver', under the assumption of a semantic shift from 'nearly collapsing under a load' > 'burden' > 'labour'. This seems unconvincing".}];444[391{Cf. s.v. 4809 Lat. labor 'Arbeit' > Catalan llavor 'Samen' (cf. Span. labor 'Bearbeitung des Feldes| Näherei'.}]
Justification: Catalan lexemes from Latin labor 'work, labour' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):391), further etymology uncertain (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):320).

Source: 54[605{Cf. s.v. Lat. tālea 'cutting, thin piece of wood'. Compared to Gk. τᾶλις, -ιδος 'young girl, bride' on the assumption of a basic meaning 'green, to sprout' (cf. IEW 1055), but this seems like a wild guess. No viable etymology unless a derivative of tālus 'knuckle'.}];444[704-705{Cf. s.v. 8542 Lat. taliare 'schneiden'.}];316[673-674{Cf. s.v. Lat. tālea 'rejeton, bouture| piquet, pointe'. Technical term, without doubt borrowed.}]
Justification: Cf. Latin *tāliare 'to cut' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):704-705), a derivative to Latin tālea 'a cutting, piece of wood'. No further etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):673-674, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):605).

Source: 443[8:342-347{S.v. *pettīttus 'klein' > Fr. petit, from a Gallo-Romance word which may be reconstructed as *pettīttus.}];444[543{S.v. 6544a pit (Lallform) 'klein'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes apparently going back to a stem *pe/itt- 'small', probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):543 no. 6544a, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 8:342-347).

Source: 443[13/2:46-80{S.v. Lat. tornare 'drechseln'.}];444[729-730{S.v. 8794 Lat. tornāre 'drehen, wenden, zurückkehren'.}];316[695-696{S.v. Lat. tornus 'trépan, tour', a technical loanword from Greek τόρνος, attested since Lucretius. Derived verb tornō, -āre 'façonner au tour, tourner' (attested since Cicero).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin tornāre 'to turn (in a lathe)' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:46-80, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):729-730). A denominal verb from Latin tornus 'turner's wheel, lathe', in turn an old loanword from Ancient Greek τόρνος 'turning lathe' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):695-696).

Source: 141[323{Cf. s.v. 2. *k̑el- 'warm werden' (IEW 551-2).}];54[83{S.v. caleō 'to be warm'. While Lat. caleō represents a stative verb *k̑lH-eh₁-, calidus may be directly derived from *k̑lH-i-dʰo- (cf. Nussbaum 1999).}];639[377-419{Cf. for a discussion of the IE stem formation of Lat. calidus.}];165[231{For the (non-target meaning) Germanic lexemes attached to this class, cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hlewa- 'shelter (from wind)', *hlēwa- 'lukewarm'.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE 2. *k̑el- 'warm' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):83), cf. [Nussbaum 1999](src-639) for a detailed discussion of the Latin stem formation; for Romance lexemes cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):139 no. 1506 (Lat. caldus 'warm'). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):294, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):231.

Source: 54[40{S.v. Lat. amplus 'large, big', from Proto-Italic *am-lo- 'seizable' to PIE *h₃mh₃- 'to grab'.}];444[35{S.v. 430 Lat. amplus 'weit'.}];423[I:254{S.v. Sp. ancho, from Lat. amplus.}];316[30{S.v. Lat. amplus 'large, ample, vaste, puis', no certain etymology.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):30); possibly to *h₃emh₃- 'to grab' according to [de Vaan 2008](src-54):40.

Source: 54[210{S.v. Lat. fēmina 'woman, female', originally a present middle participle from PIE *dʰeh₁-mh₁n̥-h₂- '(the one) nursing, breastfeeding',  derived from PIE *dʰeh₁-, (cf. Skt. dadhúr 'they have sucked', Gk. pr.inf. θῆσθαι, aor. θῆσατο 'he sucked', Latv. dêt, dêju 'to suck', OCS děva 'virgin, maiden', CS dětь, Ru. déti 'children', PIE *dʰeh₁-i- in Skt. pr. dháyati 'sucks, drinks mother's milk', dhénā 'stream of milk', Oss. dæjyn / dæjun 'to suck', Arm. diem 'id.', OCS doiti 'to breast-feed, nurse', Goth. daddjan, OHG tāju 'to suck', OIr. denaid*, ·den*). Note the Lat. form fēmina does not show the i-extension that the other forms do.}];680[110{S.v. Khw. δy, δyn n.f. 'woman', cf. Av. daēnu-, Skt. dhenu- 'milk-giving'.}];172[I:797{Cf. s.v. Ved. dhenú- 'Kuh, Milchkuh, weibliches Tier' (YAv. daēnu- f. 'weibliches Tier, Weibchen'), cf. Khot. dīnū 'Kuh', MPers. dēnōdag 'female, milch', Khw. δy(n) 'Frau'), derived from Ved. √dhay-ⁱ¹ 'saugen, Muttermilch trinken', derived to PIE *dʰeh₁- (cf. Ved. √dhā-, Gk. θηλή 'Mutterbrust', Lat. felāre 'saugen, etc.').}];141[138-139{Cf. s.v. *dʰeh₁(i̯)- '(Muttermilch) saugen' (IEW 241-2).}];444[281{S.v. 3239 Lat. fēmina 'Frau'.}]
Justification: Iranic and Italic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ([MacKenzie 1990](src-680):110, [EWAia](src-172) I:797, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):210, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):281, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 138-139).

Source: 444[216{S.v. 2337 Lat. crocum 'Safran', 2. 'gelb'.}];316[152{S.v. Lat. crocus, -ī, and crocum, -ī 'saffran', a borrowing from Gk. κρόκος 'id.'.}]
Comment: Lat. crocus (ultimately a LW from Gk. κρόκος).
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin crocum 'saffron flower' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):216), a loanword from Ancient Greek κρόκος 'saffron flower, Crocus sativus' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):152).

Source: 593[638{The etymology is obscure. Existing hypotheses, assuming a relationship to Greek πίνος or Slavic *pěna 'foam' are not convincing.}];591[621{It is related to Greek πίνος, even if the length of the root vowel does not match. Czech š- is a s-mobile.}];249[{There is no convincing etymology.}];638[589{The etymology of this lexeme is not clear. It has been linked to PS *pěna 'foam' and Greek πίνος 'dirty'. It could be also a loan from German Spinne 'spider', cf. Spinnenflecken.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593):638, [Králik 2015](src-638):589 for discussion of various hypotheses.

Source: 81[160-161{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gadъ (ESSJa VI 81-82), from PIE *gʷoh₁dʰ-o- (cf. Lith. gė́da 'shame, disgrace', OPr. gīdan 'id.', Du. kwaad 'angry, evil').}];458[6:81-82{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gadъ (OCS gadъ 'ἑρπετόν, animal, reptile, serpens, гад, пресмыкающееся, змея'), from PIE *gʷōdʰ-, cf. OE cwēd 'дурной, плохой' OHG quāt, Germ. Kot 'гряазь', Du. kwaad 'злой, отвратительный', Lith. gė́da 'стыд, срам', OPr. gīdan.}];352[303-304{Cf. s.v. OLith. *gė́da 'Schande, Scham', from PIE *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'eklig' (cf. OCS gadъ 'Kriechtier, Gewürm, Ungeziefer' SCr. gȁd 'Reptil, Schlange', MLG kwād 'böse, schlecht', etc.).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):160-161, [ALEW](src-352) 303-304, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 6:81-82).

Source: 259[171{The Slavic lexeme is related to German kahl 'bald'. PIE *galo-.}];81[176-177{PIE *golH-o-. The lexeme is related to Old High German kalo 'bald' and Old English calu 'bald'. "In spin of the incompatibility of the initial consonants (*g : *k), it is tempting to connect the (Balto-)Slavic and the Germanic forms with Lat. calvus 'bald' and Skt. kulva- 'bald, thin-haired'."}];458[6: 204, 7: 14-15{PS *gol- 'naked' is often assumed to be related to German kahl 'bald, hairless'. However, the Gemanic root is restricted to West Germanic only and needs itself to be explained etymologicaly. PS *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('naked, smooth, not overgrown' < 'smooth' < 'shining').}];249[{Most scholars assume the relationship of the Slavic root to German kahl 'bald' and its further Germanic cognates. The hypothesis of ESSJa (accepted by some other scholars) is reasonable but more complex.}];165[278{Proto-Germanic *kalwa (PIE *golH-uo-) > German kahl 'bald' etc. It is related to OCS golŭ 'naked' etc. (PIE *golH-o-). It is a Germanic-Balto-Slavic isogloss unrelated to Latin calvus and Sanskrit kulvá- (PIE *klH-uo-).}];593[208{PIE *gal-, related to German kahl 'bald' etc.}];594[{PIE *galo-, related to German kahl and English callow etc.}];598[1: 433{PS *gol- is related do Old High German kalo 'bald' etc.}];636[1: 185{The Slavic *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('shine' > 'smooth, not overgrown' > 'naked').}]
Justification: It is related to PS *golŭ ['naked']. The original meaning was thus 'stick without twigs, naked stick' [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 218.

Source: 178[II: 455{Possibly related to Greek πρόμος 'vorderster, Vorsteher', Oscan promom 'firstly (= lat. prīmum)', Old Norse framr 'tauglich, gut, kühn, tüchtig', fram 'vorwärts, später, weiter', Gothic fram 'ἔμπροσθεν', fruma 'erster', OHG fruma f. 'Nutzen, Vorteil, NHG fromm, MHG vrum 'förderlich, tüchtig, rechtschaffen'.}];441[514-516{Basically aligns with Vasmer's description. Supposed semantic development for the Slavic forms: 'davor' -> 'offen daliegend' -> 'ehrlich', 'einfach'.}];294[607-614| 611{S.v. 1. *pér, *pérā̆, *pérām, *pérti- 'durch, darüber, hinaus, über| sehr' Adverb, lokal| oft mit. Akk. steigerndes Präfix. The Slavic forms rather are derived from PIE *per-mo- which is formed on the basis of PIE 1.*pér 'through', not PIE *pro.}];593[514{It is ultimately derived from PIE *per-, cf. also related PIE *pro-.}]
Justification: Slavic forms continuing a nominal derivative *per-mo- to PIE local adverb *per- 'through, beyond, over; very' ([LIPP 2](src-294):611).

Source:
593[421-422{The etymology of Czech ocas is unclear. For Czech itself a relationship with dialectal cásati 'tear, pluck, pull' could be assumed. However, this hypothesis does not work for other lanugages (cf. Serbo-Croat dialectal oćas, CS očesŭ, Polish dialectal ocas, oczas). Conversely, a link to PS *česati would work only for CS. It is possible that we deal here with a contamination of two etymona or a folk etymology.
An interesting alternative is an interpretation as PS *ot-jasŭ (cf. *po-jasŭ ['belt']) with a meaning 'a thing hanging at the midsection'.}];598[3: 178{As to (Old) Russian očes 'tail', an explanation as a derivative from *česati would be attractive. However, it does not explain forms in other Slavic languages. It has been also reconstructed as *otjas (with PIE *jōs-, cf. poâs 'belt'). However, this hypothesis is improbable from the semantic point of view.}];458[32: 9-10{PS *ocasŭ? (the reconstruction uncertain) is etymologically obscure. The relationship to *česati can be a result of folk etymology. The interpretation as *ot-jasŭ (cf. *pojasŭ) is inconvincing semantically. If one would assume that the original meaning focused on the protruded nature and the hardness of tail, on could link PS *ocasŭ? to PS *ostĭ and other words referring to sharpness.}]
Justification: There is no certain etymology outside of Slavic. All the existing hypotheses (linking it to PIE *kes-, PIE *i̯eh₃s- and PIE *h₂ek̑-, cf. [LIV²](src-141): 261, 311, 357) are unconvincing formally and/or semantically (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 32:9-10, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):421-422, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:178).

Source: 141[195{Cf. s.v. ?*gʰedʰ- '(zusammen)treffen, sich vereinigen' (IEW 423-4) with OCS ugoditi 'please (be liked)' and Czech hoditi 'throw' listed among cognates.}];165[162-163{OSC godŭ '(suitable) time, year', Serbo-Croat goditi 'please', Russian godit' 'wait, loiter' etc. are related to Old Frisian gadia 'engage in', Middle Dutch gaden 'fit, please, mate', Old High German be-gatōn 'gather' and further to English good, German gut 'good', Dutch goed 'good' etc. PIE *gʰodʰ-o-.}];593[206{Czech hodit is related to English good etc. and derived from *gʰedʰ- / *gʰodʰ- 'merge'. The modern meaning 'throw' is easily explainable from Old Czech meanings: 'suit, aim at something, hit'.}];81[172{S.v. Proto-Slavic *godìti v. 'please' (ESSJa VI 188-190), from PIE *gʰodʰ- (cf. Proto-Slavic *godъ 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o-).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *goditi 'please', further derived from PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ([ESSJa](src-458) 6:188-190, [Derksen 2008](src-81):172, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):206, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 195).

Source: 593[607{Czech strom is derived from strmý ['steep']. The latter is ultimately derived from PIE *(s)ter- 'firm, hard'.}];595[3: 329-330{PS *stromŭ, *strĭmŭ is derived from PIE *(s)terH- 'be hard'.}];594[{PS *strĭmŭ is related to German stramm 'tight' and Greek στερέμνιος 'hard' and derived from PIE *(s)terh₁- 'be hard'.}];49[1022{Cf. s.v. *(s)ter-, *(s)terə- : *(s)trē 'starr, steif sein, starrer, fester Gegenstand', etc.}]

81[433, 438{S.v. Proto-Slavic *rokъ 'time', derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say' < PIE *rek-. For the semantics, cf. Lat. fātum [< *bʰh₂-to- 'spoken'].}];141[506{Cf. s.v. *rek- 'ordnen, festlegen, bestimmen' (IEW 863).}];259[517, 532{PS *rokŭ 'something said, appointed, prearranged| date, appointment' is derived from PS *rekti, *rekǫ 'say' < PIE *rek- 'speak, shout'. Cf. Polish rokować 'negotiate, parley'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rokъ, derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say' < PIE *rek- 'to order, determine' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):433, 438; [Boryś 2005](src-259):517, 532; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 506).

Source: 81[177{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ (ESSJa VII 23), from PIE *gʷʰon- (cf. Gk. θείνω 'kill', Skt. hánti 'strike, slay').}];141[218-219{Cf. s.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).}];458[7: 23, 196-197{PS *goniti (sę) is derived from PIE *gʷʰen- and related to Old Indic hánti 'hit, kill', Greek θείνω 'hit', Lithuanian genù, giñti 'chase', Hittite kuen-, kun- 'hit, kill', Latin de-fendere 'defend', Old Icelandic gunnr 'battle', Tocharian kuñac 'quarrel, battle' etc.}];83[224-225{S.v. Proto-Iranian *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen-.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):224-225); Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ and further to PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):177, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:23, 196-197, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 218-219).

Source: 165[418{OCS ravĭnŭ 'open' is derived from PIE *HoruH-ino- (< PIE *Hreu̯H-).}];595[3: 155-156{PS *orvĭnŭ is derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'spread out, open'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *orvĭnŭ, a derivative of PIE *reu̯h₁- 'to open' ([Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 3:155-156, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):546, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 510).

Source: 698[393-394{S.v. *minwizan- (Hm 412) 'kleiner', from PIE *minu- 'klein' (IEW 711), cf. Lat. minus 'weniger'.}];697[412{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *minwizan- (> minnizan-) 'kleiner', to PIE *mei-/*moi- 'klein'.}];141[427{Cf. s.v. 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).}]
Justification: Derived from Proto-Germanic *minwizan- 'smaller', a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'become small, recede' ([Faltings 2010](src-698):393-394, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):412, [LIV²](src-141) 427).

Source: 165[53{S.v. Proto-Germanic *barku- 'bark', cf. PIE *bʰorh₁g̑-. Cognate with Alb. barmë f. 'bast' < *bʰorh₁g̑-mo-. The u-stem *barku- has no parallel outside Germanic and may have split off from the acc. pl. *barkuns < *bʰorg̑-n̥s of a root noun *bʰérHg̑-s 'birch, birch bark'. The same root noun may have served as a source for the related zero-grade formation Middle Low German borke f. 'bark' < *burkō-. Related: *berkō- 'birch-tree' and *berhta- 'bright'.}];397[142{Cf. s.v. NHG Borke 'Rinde' (MLG borke, MDu. bark). The High German word is a borrowing from Low German| the Low German forms are related to ON bǫrkr 'Rinde', allowing the reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *barku-. Further origin uncertain.}];468[70{S.v. ON bǫrkr 'rinde', from Proto-Germanic *barku-. Etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Kluge 2011](src-397):142, [de Vries 1977](src-468):70). Traditionally considered an extended from an extended form of a root *bʰer- 'to cut' according to [IEW](src-49) 166 (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):37). Cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):53 for a proposed comparison to Albanian barmë 'bast'.

Source: 468[508{S.v. ON ský 'wolke' (< Proto-Norse *skeui̯a-), further connections are doubtful.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse ský 'cloud', further connections unclear (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):508).

Comment: < 'excrement'
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):446. cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):410-411).

Source: 97[{S.v. Da. spise (vb.) 'eat', from spise (n.) 'something one can eat', a loan from Middle Low German, in turn from Medieval Latin spesa from Classical Latin expensa (pecunia).}];468[536{Cf. s.v. ON spiza 'speisen' (NNw. spissa 'gut essen', NSw. spisa, NDa. spise) < MLG spīsen to spīse 'essen' < MLat. spesa 'ausgabe' < Lat. expensa.}]
Justification: Originally a loanword in Old Norse from Middle Low German spīsen ([de Vries 1977](src-468):536).

Source: 141[491{S.v. *preK- 'sich fürchten' (IEW 820).  Only Tocharian continues a verb derived directly to the root via PIE *pr̥K-sk̑e/o-.  The Germanic forms are denominal in origin (cf. Goth. faurhts 'furchtsam', denom. faurhtjan 'fürchten').}];345[402{S.v. TochB pärsk- 'feel fear, be afraid', which with TochA pärsk- reflects PIE *pr̥K-sk̑e/o- to the root *p(e)rK- otherwise only seen in Germanic (and there also only in the zero-grade), cf. OE fyrhtu 'fright, fear', Goth. faurhtjan 'to fear'.}];341[711-712{S.v. TochAB pärsk- 'sich fürchten', 'be afraid', which must be derived to a root *pre⁽k̑⁾- or *pre⁽g̑⁾- 'be afraid' (LIV² 491 *preK-), from which the Tocharian forms reflect a zero-grade *-sk̑e/o- present *pr̥K-sk̑e/o-.}];165[161{S.v. Proto-Germanic *furhta- 'fearful', *furhtjan- 'to fear' < *prk-sk- (cf. TochAB präskā- 'to fear').}];179[111{Cf. s.v. Goth. F33. *faurhts ῾δειλός', 'fearful', *faurhtjan wkvI 'φοβεῖσθαι', 'be afraid'| PIE *perg- possibly in TochAB pärsk-.}]
Justification: Tocharian and Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *preK- 'to be afraid' ([LIV²](src-141) 491, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):711-712, [Adams 2013](src-345):402, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):111, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):402). The identity of the root final velar is not certain.

Source: 397[468{Cf. s.v. NHG Kampf (MHG kampf, OHG kampf), cf. also OE comp and ON kapp 'Wettstreit', probably an old borrowing from Lat. campus 'Feld'. Denominal verb kämpfen.}];398[368-370{Cf. s.v. OHG kampf '(Einzel-)Kampf, Zweikampf', borrowing from from Lat. campus 'Feld' in sense 'Kampfplatz'.}]
Justification: Denominal formation to a loanword from Latin campus 'field' in the sense of 'place for fighting' (cf. [EWA 5](src-398):368-370, [Kluge 2011](src-397):468).

Source: 165[11{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ailida- 'fire', a formation derived from *ailjan- (OE ǣlan w.v. 'to burn'), which in turn is factitive to the noun *aila- implied by OE āl 'fire' < *ailla- < *aidla- < *h₂eidʰ-lo- (cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *aida-).}];468[99-100{S.v. ON eldr 'feuer'. Etymology uncertain, according to Sievers (IF 4, 1894), from Germ, *aila < *aiðla, and then to the IE root *aidh- 'burn', but this is not correct phonologically and the difficulty cannot be remedied by assuming contamination from another lexeme.}];388[7{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ailiđaz, derived from PGmc. *ailjanan (w.v.), cf. OE ælan 'to kindle', in turn derived from *ailan (cf. OE ál 'flame' "despite phonetic difficulties probably from *aiđlan connected with *aiđaz, cf. OE ád 'funeral pile', OS ēd 'firebrand', OHG eit 'id.' and identical to Skt. édha- 'fuel', Gk. αἶθος 'firebrand', OIr. áed 'fire').}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain but generally connected to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle' ([LIV²](src-141) 259) despite phonological difficulties, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):11; [Orel 2003](src-388):7; [de Vries 1977](src-468):99-100.

Source: 165[549{S.v. Proto-Germanic *þuka/ōn- 'fog, mist', an exclusively Germanic word.}];468[615{S.v. ON ϸoka 'nebel'. Etymology disputed.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):615, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):549).

Source: 165[423, 435-436{S.v. Proto-Germanic *saiwi- 'sea'. K. favours the connection with OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', etc. from PGmc. *sīhwan- 'to percolate' from PIE *sei̯kʷ-. [No discussion of the word as a possible pre-IE loanword.]}];179[292{S.v. Goth. S12. *saiws 'λίμνη', 'sea' (only dat.sg. saihwa). 'marshland' in gen.pl. -we, *marisaihws 'sea' only acc.sg., from Proto-Germanic *saiwi- (cf. OI sær, sjōr, OE sǣ, sā-, OFris sē, OS, OHG sēo). No accepted etymology. Three main possibilities: (1) a borrowing from a non-IE pre-Gmc. people, (2) a connection to Lat. saeuus 'raging', or (3) a connection with OE sīgan, OFris sīga, OS, OHG sīgan, 'flow down from', 'sink' and OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', ultimately from PIE *sei̯kʷ-: *soikʷis > PGmc. -gw´- > -w-. In view of the absence of an IE word for 'sea' a borrowing from a non-IE, pre-Gmc. people is more likely.}]
Justification: No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

Source: 388[455{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wenistraz, generally assumed to be derived from PGmc. *weniz 'friend' as a taboo motivated name for the 'friendly' left side (cf. similar replacements elsewhere in IE in Gk. ἀρίστερος, Lat. sinister).}];165[579{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *weni- 'friend', as though from IE *Hu̯enh₁-i-, (cf. OIr. fine 'family' < *Huen-ieh₂-| cf. also TochA wañi, TochB wina 'pleasure', Lat. venus, -eris 'love, charm' < *Huenh₁-es-), cf. Proto-Germanic *wana- (2) 'accustomed' < *Huonh₁-o- (cf. Skt. vánate 'love, desire' < *Huenh₁-e-).}];697[623{Cf. s.v. Gmc. ϸeuϸa- 'gut, freundlich, vertraut'| in discussion of the derivation of this adjective, the common assumption of a connection between *wenistra- 'left' and *weni- 'friend' is also repeated.}];141[682-683{Cf. s.v. *u̯enH- 'liebgewinnen' (IEW 1146-7).}]
Justification: The Germanic forms from PGmc. *wenistra- are in all likelihood derivatives from PGmc. *weni- 'friend' as a taboo replacement as 'the friendly side' (cf. similarly motivated replacements in Gk. ἀρίστερος 'left', Lat. sinister 'left'); cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):623, [Orel 2003](src-388):455, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):579. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 682-683.

Source: 165[286{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ketwa- n. 'meat'. "An exclusively Nordic word that has been compared to Icel. kvett(i) n. 'piece of meat', Far. kvett n. 'quick cut| lucky strike' < *kwattja-, which appears to be derived from Far. kvetta w.v. 'to cut, break, bite quickly' < *kwattjan-. This causative must in turn be related to ME cutten, kitten w.v. 'to cut' < *kuttjan-, and MHG kotze m. 'spud' < *kuttan- … No certain etymology. Possibly related to Lith. gùdė f. 'whetstone' < *gudʰ-ieh₂-."}]
Justification: Possibly related to English 'cut' in cognate set 2579, but further etymology uncertain; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):286.

Source: 165[166{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gamala- 'old'. Uncertain etymology. Previous proposals have included a derivation from IE *g̑ʰi-om-, an ablaut variant of *g̑ʰéi-m 'winter' assuming that age was measured in winters, although Kroonen considers this suggesting too far-fetched| perhaps otherwise from *ga-mēla- (prefix *ga- + mēla- 'time'), or similarly *gam-ala- < *k̑om-h₂el-o- to the same root as Gmc. *alda- 'old' < *h₂el-tó-.}];468[154{S.v. ON gamall 'alt'. The explanation is uncertain| cf. entry for a survey of older proposals.}];388[125{S.v. PGmc. *ʒamalaz "Probably related to Lat. humilis 'low', Gk. χθαμαλός 'near the ground, low' (Szemerényi Word VIII 50)."}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *gamala- 'old', of uncertain etymology. Cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):154, [Orel 2003](src-388):125, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):166 for various proposals.

Source: 468[277-278{Cf. s.v. ON -hœgō (only in uhœgō 'ungemach, beschwerde' to which ON hœgr 'leicht, geschickt, sanft' < Gmc. *hōgiaz (Ic. hœgr, Far. høgur), to which cpd. ON hœgri (Ic. hœgri, Far. høgri, Nor. høgre, Sw. höger) 'rechte (hand)'.}];697[265-266, 301-302{S.v. Gmc. *hōgi- 'geschickt| leicht, bequem'. Only attested in North Germanic| outside of Germanic [s.v. (-)haga- 'geschickt, gefällig'| cf. OIc. hagr| hagliga| hagari| hagastr 'geschickt, gewandt, kunstfertig' MHG behac, behage 'wohlgefällig'] the verbal root is most clear in Ved. śaknóti 'kann, vermag, ist imstande'.}];172[II:600-601{Cf. s.v. Ved. √śak- 'können, vermögen, im Stande sein'| possibly from IE *k̑Ek-, if connected with OIr. cēcht 'Macht' and possibly ("möglicherweise") also with OE on-hagian 'passen', NHG behagen'.}]
Comment: North Germanic only.
Justification: Possibly to be connected to the verbal root underlying Ved. √śak- ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):264-265, 301-302), but the etymology is not fully certain; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:600-601.

Source: 468[368{S.v. lukta 'riechen, duften', derived from lukt 'geruch', which is borrowed from Low German lucht [= NHG Luft]. The inherited lexeme is lopt. [cf. 'smell' in Övdalian [cognate set 8301](cog-8301), 'sky' in [cognate set 2903](cog-2903)].}]
Justification: Loan from Early Low German ([de Vries 1977](src-468):368). The inherited lexeme is found in Elfdalian 'smell' [cognate set 8301](cog-8301) and 'sky' in [cognate set 2903](cog-2903).  Since this is present in Old Norse, the case can be made that this is not necessarily a parallel loan, although the inclusion of Faroese in this set suggests the loan must have been particularly early.

Source: 165[203-204{S.v. Proto-Germanic *halan- 'tail, tip', as though from IE *⁽k̑⁾olH-on- (cf. OIr. cail 'lance' < *⁽k̑⁾lH-i-).}];468[204{S.v. ON hali 'schwanz| schaftspitze', to be connected with Gk. κῆλον 'stange, schaft, pfeil', MIr. cail 'speer', Ved. śalá- 'stock, spitze' to IE *k̑el- 'stechen' ([IEW](src-49) 552).}];388[156{S.v. Proto-Germanic xalōn sb.m. "Closely related to Skt. śalá- 'staff', MIr. cail 'spear'."}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *halan- 'tail, tip', traditionally further compared variously with Sanskrit śalá- 'staff', Middle Irish cail 'spear', Ancient Greek κῆλον 'shaft, arrow' from a proposed IE root *k̑el- 'to prick, sting' ([IEW](src-49) 552, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):204, [Orel 2003](src-388):156, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):203; not in [LIV²](src-141)), but more sceptically regarding the proposed comparanda cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:615-616, [KEWA](src-399) III:306, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:10-11, [Beekes 2010](src-66):685.

Source: 468[303, 342-343{S.v. ON kasta, generally connected to ON kǫs 'haufe', kǫstr 'hügel', and kasa 'in einem steinhaufen begraben'. No clear etymology outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: From Old Norse kasta, generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 141[575{S.v. *sneu̯H- 'drehen, winden' (IEW 977).}];165[461-462{S.v. Proto-Germanic *snewan- ~ *snūan- 'to rush', from PIE *snéuH-, *snuH- (cf. RuCS snuti 'to warp', Ru. snovát' 'to warp, dash about', SCr. snòvati 'to warp' < *snouH-eh₂-| Latv. snaujis 'noose' < *snouH-io-).}];556[447{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *snōw-a- 'winden'.}]
468[303, 342-343{S.v. ON kasta, generally connected to ON kǫs 'haufe', kǫstr 'hügel', and kasa 'in einem steinhaufen begraben'. No clear etymology outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: Old Norse kasta is generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 80[1015-1016{Cf. s.v. Hitt. u̯ida- (gender unclear) 'water', cf. CLuw. u̯ida- 'wet', from PIE *u̯ed-o-.}];274[706-715{S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).}];165[575-576{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', from PIE *uod-r/n-.}]
Justification: Anatolian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575-576, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):1015-1016).

Source: 468[671{S.v. vængr 'flügel, fittich| ausbau am hause', from Proto-Norse *wāingja-.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of North Germanic; traditionally considered a derivative of PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):671 citing [IEW](src-49) 81ff. *u̯ē-; not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).

Source: 468[497{S.v. ON skógr 'wald'.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse skógr; no certain etymology outside of Germanic. Traditionally derived from a root *(s)kek- / *skeg- 'springen; lebhafte Bewegung' ([IEW](src-49) 922-923, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):497). Not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 141[560{S.v. ?*skeu̯bʰ- 'stoßen, schieben' (IEW 955). Only Balto-Slavic and Germanic.}];165[444-445{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skeuban- ~ *skūban- 'to shove', from PIE *kséubʰ-e- (assuming a regular metathesis of *ks- > *sk- within PIE), cf. Skt. kṣóbhate 'to shake, tremble', YAv. xšufsąn 3.pl.pres.subj. 'to tremble' < *kséubʰ-e-, Pol. dial. chybać 'to sway, rock| to run, rush' < *ksubʰ-eh₂-| Lith. skubùs, Latv. skubrs 'hasty' < *ksubʰ-(r)o-| unrelated to OCS skubati 'to tear' < *skoubʰ-eh₂-).}];179[6{S.v. Goth. A27 *af-skiuban 'ἀπώσασθαι', 'reject' (OE sceofan, OHG scioban 'shove', etc.), to PIE *skewb(h)- 'throw, shove' (cf. Lith. skùbti 'begin to hurry' CS skubǫ 'pluck').}];556[416-417{S.v. Gmc. *skeub-a- 'schieben'. "Gm. skeub-a-, trans. 'schieben' hat keine überzeugende Vergleichsmöglichkeit."}]
Justification: A Germanic and Balto-Slavic isogloss, therefore postulating a root reconstruction *skeu̯bʰ- to PIE remains uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):6, [LIV²](src-141) 560. Cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165):444-445 who additionally compares Sanskrit kṣóbhate 'to shake, tremble' and postulates a root *kseubʰ- with a metathesis occurring in the Balto-Slavic and Germanic forms; more skeptical to extra-Germanic connections cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):416-417).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. black (adj.), "Cognate with Middle Dutch blac ink, Old Saxon blac ink (Middle Low German blak ink, black dye, black colour), Old High German blah- (only in blah-faro of the colour of ink, blah-māl niello decoration (Middle High German blach-māl), blah-mālōn to decorate with niello)| further etymology uncertain| on formal grounds the word could be from a base related to the Germanic bases of blank adj. and the various forms discussed at blik v., but since this would give an expected meaning ‘shining, white’ there is an obvious semantic difficulty| many have sought to resolve this by hypothesizing that the word meaning ‘black’ originated as a past participle (with the meaning ‘burnt, blackened’) of a verb meaning ‘to burn (brightly)’ derived from this base| this verb may perhaps be reflected by Middle Dutch blaken (Dutch blaken) to flame, to burn."}];386[154-155{Cf. s.v. OHG blah-, only attested in compounds blah-faro 'tintenfarben, tiefblau', blah-mâl 'Niello-Verzierung', blah-mâlôn 'Niello-Verzierung versehen', etc., from Germanic *ƀlaka- 'schwarz| Tinte', almost completely lost in High German| perhaps to be connected with blecken and blanc to the IE root *bʰelg- : *bʰleg- 'glänzen', but because of the semantic chasm between 'glänzend, weiß' and 'schwarz' the immediate derivation from this root is doubtful.}]
Justification: Further connections uncertain. Perhaps to be connected with the complex of 'white' words from PGmc. *blank- but due to the difference in semantics this connection remains unclear, cf. OED, [EWA 2](src-386).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. dig, attested since the 14th cent. and probably from French diguer, 'to dig or hollow out the ground'.}]
Justification: Probably a loan from Old French diguer ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 165[103-104{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *drita- 'shit, dirt' and s.v. *drītan- 'to shit'. No good etymology. Perhaps to Ru. (dial.) dristát', SCr. drískati, dríćkati 'to have diarrhea < *dʰreid-ske-???}];556[164-165{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dreit-a- 'scheißen'.}]
Justification: Derivative to Proto-Germanic *drita- 'shit, dirt' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):103-104, [Seebold 1970](src-556):164-165).

Source: 388[147-148{S.v. PGmc. *xaƀiʒaz ~ *xaƀuʒaz, based on xaƀiz > OE hefe 'weight' derived from *xafjanan.}];556[244-246{S.v. Gmc. *haf-ja- 'heben', cf. derived adjectives *haf-uga- 'gewichtig, schwer' > OWN hǫfugr, *hab-iga- 'gewichtig, schwer' > OE heftig, etc.| the strong verb goes back with certainty to the common IE verbal root *qap- (probably *qǝ₁p-) 'fassen, nehmen', cf. Lat. capiō, Latv. kàmpju, kàmpt, Gk. κάπτω.}];165[198{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic hafjan- ~ *habjan- s.v. 'to raise, lift' < *kh₂p-ie- (cf. ?Gr. κάπτω 'to gulp down', Lat. capiō 'to take' < *kh₂p-ie-| Latv. kàmpt 'to obtain' < *kh₂-en-p-e-).}];141[344-345{Cf. s.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-8).}]
Justification: West Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *habiga- 'weighty, heavy', a derivative from the root as the Germanic strong verb *hafjan- 'to raise, lift', and further derived from PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, snatch' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):244-246, [Orel 2003](src-388):147-148, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):198, [LIV²](src-141) 344-345).

Source: 165[227, 257{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hinϸan- 'to reach for' < *⁽k̑⁾ént-e- and Proto-Germanic *huntōn- 'to chase' from *⁽k̑⁾nt-néh₂-.}];179[122{S.v. Goth. *fra-hinϸan 'αἰχμαλωτίζειν', 'take captive'. (cf. OSw. hinna, hanna 'reach', OE hentan 'pursue', huntian 'hunt', hunta 'hunter'. No accepted etymology outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: According to [Kroonen 2013](src-165):257, Old English huntian continues a Proto-Germanic weak verb *hūnton- as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾n̥t-néh₂-, an iterative formation to Proto-Germanic *hinϸan- 'to reach for' and connects further to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ont-ú-, although there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic; cf. also [Lehmann 1986](src-179):122 and discussion to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' in [cognate set 234](cog-234).

Source: 165[321-322{S.v. Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg| hollow bone| stalk', an etymologically unclear North Germanic word.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg; hollow bone, stalk'. Attestation is restricted to North Germanic and there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):321-322).

Source: 165[358{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mati- 'food', an old i-stem, the basis for the factitive in Goth. matjan 'to eat'. If connected with Gk. μεστός, it possibly continues an PIE root *med- 'to satiate'. Older proposed connections with Skt. mándati 'to rejoice, get intoxicated', Gk. μαδάω 'to drip, melt, be moist', Lat. madeō 'be wet' are erroneous.}];179[247{Cf. s.v. Goth. M35 mats 'βρῶσις', 'food'. Etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):247, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):358).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. play (v.) "Origin uncertain: perhaps cognate with Middle Dutch pleyen to dance, leap for joy, rejoice, be glad (compare also Dutch pleien to play a particular childrens' game), of uncertain etymology| a further connection has frequently been suggested with Old English plēon and related verbs in other Germanic languages (see plight n.1), but this is very uncertain. The Old English verb is recorded in several diverging forms, so that it is difficult to determine its original type and the conjugation to which it belonged (compare the α and β forms). The γ forms appear to mix the other two."}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84) for further discussion.

Source: 165[460-461{S.v. Proto-Germanic *snakan- 'to crouch (?)', which may reflect a Pre-Germanic root *(s)negʰ- ([Kroonen 2011](src-656):333). [No etymology outside of Germanic.]}];656[333];468[522{S.v. ON snaka 'schnüffeln, wittern' and snákr 'Schlange'. Cf. OE snāca, Low German snāke  'Ringelnatter, Schlange', OHG snahhan 'kriechen, schleichen'.}];84[{S.v. Engl. snake, from Old English snaca = Middle Low German snake (Low German snake, snaak), cf. Old Norse snákr (poet.), Swedish snok, Danish snog, which may be from Low German.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):522, [Kroonen 2011](src-656):333, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):460-461 for further discussion.

Source: 165[504{S.v. Proto-Germanic *tagla- 'hair'. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic (cf. Skt. daśā 'fringe' < *dek̑-eh₂-, OIr. dúal 'tuft, plait' < *dok̑-lo-(?) and SCr. dlàka 'single hair' < *dok̑-leh₂- (with depalatalisation and metathesis), but it may also be an inner-Germanic derivation as a diminutive *dHk-ló- to the root of *tahjan- 'tear, unravel', or to *tōgan- ~ *takkan- 'prickle, branch'.}];179[338{S.v. Goth. T1. tagl 'θρίξ', 'hair' (cf. OI tagl 'tail', OE tæg(e)l 'tail', MLG tagel 'rope's end' OHG zagel 'tail'). From PIE *dē̆k-, cf. OIr. dūal 'lock of hair' < *doklo-, possibly Skt. dásā 'fringe of a garment', but cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:27, [[EWAia](src-172) I:710] where the Indic correspondence is considered uncertain.}];84[{S.v. Engl. tail, from Old English tægel , tægl , = ON tagl 'a horse's tail', OHG zagel, MHG zagel 'tail of animal', etc.| Goth. tagl 'hair (of the head, of the camel)'. Further etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Identical with 'hair' in East Germanic. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic, but ultimately uncertain. Cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):338, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):504 for further discussion.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. tie (v.), from Old English tígan, for Old West Saxon *tíegan < *téag-jan 'to bind', a denominal formation to OE téag (f.) 'rope', probably from Gmc. *taug- (cf. ON taug (f.) 'rope').}];468[583{Cf. s.v. ON taug 'faser| tau, strick' (cf. OE teag, NE tie 'band, riemen, fessel').}]
Justification: Old English tígan is a denominal formation as though from earlier *téag-jan 'to bind', based on OE téag 'rope', to be connected with ON taug 'rope', probably from Germanic *taug-.

Source: 84[{S.v. woman, originally a compound formed within the history of English from wīf 'woman, female' + mann 'person' (OE wīf-mann). [Cf. etymological notes in OED for further discussion on this word's development and chronology throughout Middle and Modern English.]}];165[584{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wība- 'woman, wife'. "No clear etymology. Some have connected the word to Go. bi-waibjan, OE wǣfan w.v. 'to cover, wrap', assuming that the primary meaning was a 'veiled woman'. The connection with To A kip, ToB kwipe 'shame| modesty' (Schmidt/Strunk 1989) is possible, too, but requires a considerable semantic shift."}];397[976{Cf. s.v. Weib (MHG wīp, wīb, OHG wīb, OS wīf), from PGmc. *weiba- 'Weib', cf. also in ON wíf, OE wīf, OFr. wīf. An etymologically unclear word.}]
Justification: Etymological connections outside of Germanic unclear. A hypothesis going back to Karl Horst Schmidt supposing a putative PIE *gʷʰei̯bʰom to connect the lexeme with Tocharian A kip, B kwīpe 'shame; modesty' presupposing for Germanic a semantic development 'shame' > 'vulva' > 'woman', but this hypothesis remains uncertain and alternative etymologies are also possible for the proposed Tocharian comparandum, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):976, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):584, [Adams 2013](src-345):257.

Source: 468[392{S.v. ON mold 'erde' (cf. Goth. mulda 'staub', OE, OFr. molde), participle to PIE *mel- 'zermalmen' (Ved. mr̥d- 'lehm, ton, erde', Lith. mìltai 'mehl').}];179[260{S.v. Goth. M79. mulda 'κονιορτός, χοῦς', 'dust' (OIc. mold, OE, OFris. molde, OHG molta 'dust, earth, mold', OE myl, MLG mol 'dust' NLG, NHG müll 'rubbish'), etc., from PIE *mel- 'crush, grind' as *malan (cf. Skt. mlā-tá- (mlā́yati 'wither'), Gk. ἀμαλός| OIr. mlāth, blāith 'soft', Wel. blawd, Lith. mìltai 'flour', OCS mladъ 'soft', mlěti 'grind').}];141[432-433{Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7).}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to grind, crush' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):392, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):260, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 432-433).

Source: 468[263{S.v. ON hræðast 'sich fürchten', hræddr 'furcht, schrecken' (> NNw. rædd, NSw. rädd, NDa. ræd), hræðsla, hræzla 'furcht' (< Gmc. *hrēðislō) (Ic. hræðsla, Far. ræðsla, NNor. rædsla, OSw. rädsla, ODa. rædsle), perhaps to be connected with ON hraðr.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse hræðast 'to fear' (vb.) or light verb constructions based on Old Norse hræðr 'fear' (n.). No certain connections outside of North Germanic (not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165); [de Vries 1977](src-468):263 reconstructs a Germanic stem *hrēð-).

Source: 397[978{Cf. s.v. NHG Weidmann 'Jäger' (MHG weideman to MHG weid(e) 'Jagd, Fischerei', OHG weida 'Jagd, Beute', OS weiđa), from Gmc. *waiϸi-, also in ON veiðr, 'Jagd, Fischfang', OE wāϸ 'Jagd, Umstreiten'. Most closely comparable to OIr. fíadach 'Jagd' and Lat. venari (from *wēidʰ-n-), which may be originally connected to the root *weiə- 'verfolgen'.}];468[650-651{S.v. ON veiða 'jagen, erbeuten', a denominal formation to ON veiðr 'jagd' < Gmc. *waiϸjō and to be further connected to Ved. vēti 'verfolgen, streben', Lith. vejù, výti 'jagen, verfolgen', OCS vojĭ 'krieger', cf. Gk. ἵεμαι 'begehren, trachten'.}];388[441{S.v. Proto-Germanic *waiϸiz ~ *waiϸ(j)ō, continuing *u̯oití- ~ *u̯oi̯tā́ derived from *u̯ei- (cf. Skt. véti 'to have in view, to approach', Gk. ἵεμαι 'to move forward, to hurry', Lith. vejù, výti 'to hunt, to drive'.}];172[II:509-510{Cf. s.v. Ved. √vay-ⁱ 'nachspüren, nachspürend suchen, auf etwas losgehen, nach etwas trachten, verfolgen, hinter etwas her sein, etwas heimsuchen', from PIE *u̯ei̯H- 'auf etwas losgehen, verfolgen', cf. Gk. ἵεμαι (= ϝῑ́εμαι) 'strebe, trachte nach, begehre, eile' Lith. výti 'treiben, verfolgen, nachjagen'.}];141[668-669{Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4).}];83[411{S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯aiH- 'to hunt, chase| run', from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to strive, pursue' (cf. Ved. vay- 'to pursue, seek, strive after').}]
Justification: Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to look, seek after' ([LIV²](src-141) 668-669, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:509-510, [Cheung 2007](src-83):411, [Bailey 1979](src-320):309, [de Vries 1977](src-468):650-651, [Orel 2003](src-388):441, [Kluge 2011](src-397):978).

Source: 274[706-715{S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.). Originally a heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥-/*u̯ed-en-.}];165[575-576{S.v. Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', from PIE *uod-r/n- 'water'.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', further from the PIE heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥- ~ *u̯ed-en- 'water', derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575-576).

Source: 141[124{S.v. *deu̯k- 'ziehen' (IEW 220-1).}];165[515, 525{S.v. Proto-Germanic *teuhan- 'to pull' < PIE *déuk-e- and Proto-Germanic *tukk/gōn- 'to pull, jerk', from PIE *duk-néh₂-, iterative to *teuhan-.}];341[982{S.v. TochA tsäk- 'pull, take (out, away), from PIE *deu̯k- 'ziehen'.}];556[503-505{S.v. Gmc. *teuh-a- 'ziehen', from PIE *deuk- 'ziehen' (cf. Lat. dūcō 'führen, leiten, ziehen', W dwyn, dwgyd (dygaf) 'bringen, stehlen, (ein Leben) führen', etc.).}];179[346{S.v. Goth. T30. tiuhan 'ἄγειν', 'lead, bring', from PIE *dewk- 'lead' (cf. OLat. doucō, Lat. dūcō 'lead', etc.).}]
Justification: Tocharian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- 'to pull' ([LIV²](src-141) 124, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):982, [Seebold 1970](src-556):503-505, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):346, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):515, 525).

Source: 165[152{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fraiwa- 'seed'. Further etymology debated (cf. discussion in Kroonen for various proposals).}];179[123{S.v. Goth. F76. fraiw 'σπόρος, σπέρμα', 'seed'. Etymologically difficult| possibly to PIE *sproywo- without s-| other proposals are less likely.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fraiwa- 'seed', further etymology disputed (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):123, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152).

Source: 165[264, 266{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hwassa- adj. 'sharp', the original participle to PGmc. *hwētan- 'stab, pierce'.  K. mechanically reconstructs *kʷh₁d-to-, but cognates outside of Germanic are uncertain.}];697[315-316{S.v. Gmc. *hʷassa- 'scharf'| an common Germanic verbal adjective beside the reduplicated verb *hʷǣta- 'stoßen'.}];556[284-285{S.v. Gmc. *hwǣt-a- 'stoßen'| the related adjective *hwass-a- 'scharf' is as though from pre-Proto-Germanic *kwəd-to-. There are, however, no convincing possibilities for comparison outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hwassa- 'sharp', further connections outside of Germanic uncertain ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):315-316, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):264, 266, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):284-285).

Source: 697[564-565{S.v. Gmc. *stunta- 'kurz, stumpf'. Probably an old verbal adjective to the root also found in Lat. tundō (pf. tutudī) 'schlage, stoße'.}];165[487{S.v. Proto-Germanic *stunta- 'short'. "No further etymology. The link with the PIE root *steud- (Pokorny [IEW](src-49): 1032-4) cannot be maintained in view of the ablauting formations G stanzen w.v. 'to press, cut out, punch' < *stantōn- and G stenzen w.v. 'to hit, beat' < *stantjan-."}]
Justification: Traditionally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'push' ([IEW](src-49) 1032-1034, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):564-565), but more recently [Kroonen 2013](src-165):487 argues that the Germanic internal evidence cannot support this etymology.

Source: 468[606-607{S.v. ON  ϸefa 'riechen, duften, wittern' (NIc. ϸefa, NNw. teva). Cf. ON ϸefr 'geruch, duft' < Proto-Norse *ϸafiR.}];388[418{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸefōjanan (wk.vb.) (ON ϸefa 'to smell, to sniff', OE ðefian 'to pant, be agitated' and connected with Skt. tápati 'to warm, to burn', Lat. tepeō 'to be tepid', OIr. té 'hot', Slav. *teplъ 'warm' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1069-1070).}];141[629-630{Cf. s.v. 1. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (IEW 1069-1070), without Germanic.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes traditionally compared with PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot' ([IEW](src-49) 1069-1070, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):418, [de Vries 1977](src-468):606-607), but not accepted by [LIV²](src-141) 629-630 s.v. 1. *tep-. Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 165[600{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wurmi- 'worm', from PIE *urm-i- and identical to Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot' < *urmi-, further cf. Gk. ῥόμος 'wood-worm' < *urm-o- (with dialectal vocalisation of *r̥?)| Lith. var̃mas 'insect, mosquito' < *uorm-o-| OCS vьrmьje 'insects' < *urm-io-| OPru. wormyan (adj.) 'red' < urm-io-).}];179[397{S.v. Goth. W42. waurms 'ὄφις', 'snake', from PIE *u̯er- 'turn, wind' (cf. Gk. Hesych. ῥόμος· σκώληξ ἐν ξύλοις 'woodworm', Lith. var̃mas 'mosquito', Lat. vermis 'worm', OSl. vermije 'grasshoppers, insects').}];696[288{"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu| kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'| compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):397, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):600). Perhaps further connected to PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' (cf. [cognate set 348](cog-348) for further discussion).

Source: 165[58{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *belgan- 'to swell' (ON bolginn ptc. 'swollen), from PIE *bʰélg̑ʰ-e- (cf. OIr. bolgaid 'to swell' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-eh₂-ie-).}];556[99-100{Cf. s.v. *belg-a- 'schwellen, zürnen'.}];141[73-74{Cf. s.v. *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'schwellen' (IEW 125-6).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *belgan- 'to swell', further derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):99-100, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):73-74, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 73-74).

Source: 165[252{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hugi- 'understanding, mind', with denominal verb *hugjan- 'to think'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic.}];179[192-193{S.v. Goth. H100. *hugjan 'φρονείν, νομίζειν', 'think'. No etymology| proposed cognates are problematic. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to older literature.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):252, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):192-193.

Source: 165[555{S.v. Proto-Germanic *þwahan- 'wash'.  Possibly connected with OPruss. twaxtan 'brushwood for bathing via a pre-form *tu̯ok-sto-???  No further potential cognates.}];179[389{S.v. Goth. Ϸ63. ϸwahan 'νίπτειν', 'wash'. No etymology.}];556[525{S.v. Gmc. ϸwah-a- 'waschen', is only comparable to OPr. twaxtan 'Badequast', and in this regard maybe also to Lith. tvaskė́ti 'schlagen, klopfen' (vom Herzen, Puls).}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):389, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):555. For older proposed connections to Baltic material, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):525.

Source: 54[53{S.v. Lat. āreō 'to be dry', from PIE *h₂eh₁s-eh₁- 'to be dry' (cf. TochA asatär, TochB osotär 'dries up'), from which the derived adjective ar(i)dus 'dry', from which in turn Lat. ardeō 'to burn' is derived.}];141[257-8{S.v. *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).}];279[130-131{The most probable etymology for Umbrian aso is to *h₂eh₁s- 'burn, dry, desiccate', from a *-to- participle, i.e. *ā̆s-to- > ā̆so-, although connections with *h₂esd- to which may also belong Ancient Greek ἄζω, Czech ozditi 'desiccate' (but cf. LIV² s.v. *h₂ed- 'dry').}];444[50{S.v. 620 Lat. ardere 'brennen'.}]
Justification: Italic and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ([LIV²](src-141) 257-258, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):53, [Untermann 2000](src-279):130-131, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):50 no. 620).

Source: 443[13/2:403-409{S.v. tumb- (schallwort).}];444[747{S.v. 8975 tum(b) (Schallwort) 'Fall, Plumps'. The proposed connection with OHG tūmōn is questionable and does not explain the -b- found in some Romance forms.}]
Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin; the older proposed loanword hypothesis from Old High German tūmōn (cf. e.g. [Buck 1949](src-47):671) is questionable for formal reasons (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):747, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:403-409 for further discussion).

Romance lexemes derived from Old French breu, a loanword on Germanic *brod- 'broth' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443):297, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):118; elsewhere in Romance cf. It. brodo 'broth', broda 'soup', etc.)

Source: 141[639{S.v. ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten| schützen' (IEW 1079-80).}];443[13/2:446-449{S.v. Lat. tutari 'schützen', from which Fr. tuer 'kill' is derived.}];269[{IE root etymology debated, either to ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten| schützen' (LIV² 639-640) or to* teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' (de Vaan 2008:632-633).}];54[632-633{S.v. Lat. tueor 'to look at, watch over', from which Lat. tūtāre / tūtārī is a secondary derivative. Contra LIV², de Vaan argues for a derivation from PIE *teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' (cf. LIV² 639-640, IEW 1080-1).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin tūtāre, tūtārī ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:446-449). Further root etymology disputed: Either to ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten; schützen' ([LIV²](src-141) 639-640) or to* teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):632-633).

Source: 443[17:555-560{S.v. *wenkjan (anfrk.) 'wanken'| Middle, Modern Fr. gauche derived from French gauchir 'to warp, deform' originally in the sense 'mal équerri (bois), mal fait, sans grâce, etc.'}]
Justification: Romance lexemes derived from French gauchir 'to warp, deform', originally a loanword from Old Low Franconian *wenkjan 'to waver, falter' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:555-560 for further discussion).

Source: 443[9:365-367{Fr. près < Lat. pressē 'knapp, kurz'.}];54[487-488{Cf. s.v. Lat. premō, -ere 'to press', from Proto-Italic *pres-. "Italic *pres- might be an s-present to PIE *per- 'to hit', but this remains guesswork."}];444[559{S.v. 6742 Lat. presse 'knapp, kurz'.}]
Justification: Romance forms from Latin pressē, the adverbial form of Latin pressus, -a, -um 'pressed, straitened' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:365-367, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):559), a past passive participle to Latin premō, -ere 'to press'. Further root etymology difficult (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):487-488 for further discussion).

Source: 443[9:552-559{S.v. Lat. pulsāre 'stossen' > Fr. pousser.}];54[455-456{S.v. Lat. pellō, -ere 'to beat against, push, strike', from PIE *pl-n(e)-h₂- 'to approach' (cf. OIr. ad-ella* 'to visit', MW el, MCo. ello, MBret. yel, yal 'to go', Gk. πίλναμαι 'to approach'). The p.p.p. is pulsus, from which Lat. pulsāre 'to strike, beat'.}];141[470-471{Cf. s.v. *pelh₂- 'sich nähern' (IEW 801-2).}];444[566-567{S.v. 6837 Lat. pulsāre 'stoßen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):455-456, [LIV²](src-141) 470-471).

Source: 443[13/2:277-285{From Lat. *trīnicare 'dreiteilen'.}]
Justification: As though from Latin *trīnicāre 'divide into three' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:277-285). Further to PIE *trei̯- 'three' (cf. [cognate set 146](cog-146)).

Source: 443[15/1:219{From Old French de bot 'tout de suite', the lexical element bot is a loan from Germanic *bōtan- 'stossen, schlagen'.}];444[109{Cf. s.v. 1228c *bōtan (fränk.) 'stoßen'.}]
Justification: Light verb construction with French debout as the semantic-bearing morpheme, from Old French de + bot, the latter derived from an Old Low Franconian loanword *bōtan 'strike, hit' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:219, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):109).

Source: 444[83{S.v. 982 *bastum 'Stock'}];316[67{S.v. Lat. bastum 'bâton' (attested only once)| Romance forms must go back to an n-stem *bastō, -ōnis. No further etymology.}];443[I:279{S.v. Lat. bastum 'Stock'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin bastum 'stick' as a secondary n-stem *bastō, -ōnis. No further etymology ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 1:279, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):83, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):67).

Source: 141[225{S.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).  The Lat. present iaciō is backformed from the root-aorist iēcī < *Hi̯eh₁(k)-.  The Italic forms are found with a -k- enlargement to the root which is absent in other cognates (cf. Gk. ἵημι 'throw, send' < *Hi-Hi̯eh₁-/Hih₁-| Hitt. pi-yezzi 'send hither' u-yezzi 'send thither' < *Hi̯eh₁-/Hih₁-). }];54[292-293{S.v. Lat. iaciō, -ere 'to throw', pres. stem based on PIE (aor. stem) *(H)ieh₁-. Cf. secondary intensive/iterative stem iactāre 'to throw, toss, brag'.}];444[372{S.v. 4568 Lat. jactāre 'werfen' 2. jectāre.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin iactāre 'to hurl' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):372), an intensive/iterative stem to Latin iaciō 'to throw' and further to PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):292-293, [LIV²](src-141) 225). The Italic derivatives from this root show an anomalous extension in *-k-.

Source: 443[4:24-27{S.v. Lat. gălbĭnus 'grüngelb', whence OFr. jalne, Modern French jaune.}];316[266, 291, 297{Cf. s.v. galbus 'vert pâle, jaune', attested only in glosses, from which galbinus is a secondary derivative. One is reminded of lexemes like heluos, holus, etc. (< PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-, cf. s.v.), but in the Italic group neither initial g- nor the -al-, nor the -b- can be explained by expected regular sound changes. The hypothesis of a Gaulish loanword is based only upon the phonological difficulties. In sum, the etymology is unknown, except the root *gal- recalls a group of Indo-European words.}];54[282{Cf. s.v. helvus 'yellow, dum', which would be the true cognate from *g̑ʰelh₃-i-uo-. [NB: ≠ galbus or galbinus! There is no lemma for galbus or galbinus in de Vaan 2008.]}];444[312{S.v. 3646 Lat. galbinus 'gelb'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin galbinus 'yellow' [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):312, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:24-27). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Celtic loanword (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):266, 291, 297 for further discussion).

Comment: < Lat. PILA 'bundle (of hair)'? (Dietz 1864:342)
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Latin pilleum 'felt', cf. Old French peille 'rag, cloth' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 8:494-503, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):537, No. 537). Perhaps to be further connected with pilus 'hair' or a loanword from Greek πῖλος 'wool or hair made into felt' but ultimately obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):507, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):465).

Source: 141[66{S.v. *bʰedʰh₂- 'stechen, graben' (IEW 113-4).  Cf. OCS bodǫ (bosti) 'stechen', Lith. bedù (bèsti) 'stechen, graben'.}];80[654-655{S.v. Hitt. padda- / padd- 'to dig (the ground)| to bury(?)', from PIE *bʰedʰh₂- (cf. Lat. fodiō 'to dig', OCS bodǫ 'to stab', Lith. bedù 'to stick, to dig', etc.) The Hitt. forms may be accounted for by an *o ~ *Ø ablauting root present *bʰódʰh₂-/*bʰdʰh₂- ´.}];54[229{S.v. Lat. fodiō 'to pierce, to dig', from PIE *bʰodʰ-i- 'to poke, dig' (cf. Hitt. padda-/padd- 'to dig (the ground) < *bʰodʰh₂-, OPr. boadis 'stab', Lith. bèsti 'to stick, drive (into), dig', etc.).}]
Justification: Anatolian and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰedʰh₂- 'to pierce; to dig' ([LIV²](src-141) 66, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):654-655, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):229).

Source: 275[{PIE *rendʰ- is based on the Germanic words for 'bark' and 'scab' and on Old rándhra- n. 'opening, hole, split'. The Old Indic word is not cognate, but from PIE *lendʰ- 'loin', cf. EWAia II 432. It is thus not possible to postulate a PIE cognate set.}];397[768{S.v. NHG Rinde (MHG rinde, rinte, OHG rinta, rinda, OS rinda), from West Germanic *rendōn 'Rinde', also in OE rind(e). Outside of Germanic one might possibly compare Ved rándhra- 'Öffnung, Spalt, Höhle'.}];172[II:434{Regarding the Kluge-Seebold comparison to Ved. rándra- 'opening, hole, split', Cf. s.v. Ved. rándhra- 'ein Körperteil von Tieren (des Stiers, des Pferdes, der schwarzen Antilope), offenbar die Lende' in later texts the meaning is generalised to 'schwache Stelle', from which 'Schwäche', 'Lücke, Höhlung', originally from PIE *lendʰ- yielding words for 'loins' (cf. Lat. lumbus < *londʰu̯o-, ON lend, OHG lentī 'Lende', OCS lędvьje (f.pl.) 'Lenden, Inneres, Nieren, etc.').}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (pace [Kluge 2011](src-397):768, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:434).

Source: 397[507-508{S.v. NHG Knochen (MHG knoche, MLG knoke, knake). The words can belong to IE *g̑enu- 'knee', if it is from an enlargement like in Gk. γνύξ 'on the knees'.}];165[298{S.v. Proto-Germanic *knuk(k)an- 'knuckle', a Germanic n-stem which is probably to be reconstructed as *knukō, gen. knukkaz < *gnug-ōn, *gnug-n-ós. Outside of Germanic the word has been compared to Lith. gniáužti 'to close one's hand' < *gneug̑-, but a connection with Gmc. *knewa- 'knee' is more likely since the IE predecessor apparently also meant 'node'. If so, then the Gmc. word can be analyzed as the zero-grade *g̑nu- with a suffix *-gon- also found *mankan- 'mane' < *mon-gon-.}];269[{The comparison of Kluge to Gk. γνύξ 'with bent knee' as evidence for a possible extended form of the zero-grade root *gnu-g- is not fully certain, as in Greek the ending -ξ can be accounted for by analogy with other adverbs, e.g. πύξ 'with the fist', λάξ 'with the foot' (cf. Beekes 2010:280 s.v. γνύξ). While the proposed connection with *g̑enu- 'knee' is semantically attractive and a close formal match, the etymology outside of Germanic must remain uncertain. Cf. Kroonen (2013:298) for an alternative proposal, as though from *g̑nu-gon-.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *knuk(k)an- 'knuckle', perhaps a root-extended variant *g̑nu-g- to PIE *g̑enu-, *g̑neu- 'knee' but this is not certain (cf. discussion in [Kluge 2011](src-397):507-508, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):298).

Source: 397[818{S.v. NHG Schmutz, from Early Modern High German smu(t)z from the verb smutzen 'beflecken'. Semantically stands closest to the root of Greek μυδάω 'ich bin feucht, verderbe von der Nässe, verwese' without s-mobile.}]
Comment: etym. dub.?
