Justification: From Early Modern High German smutz, from the verb smutzen 'to spot, speckle, stain', etc. Further connections ultimately uncertain. Seebold ([Kluge 2011](src-397):818) tentatively suggests the root of Ancient Greek μυδάω 'to be damp, dripping' (without s-mobile), although the etymology of this Greek form is not without its own difficulties (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):974, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):717-718, [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:263 for further discussion).

Source: 397[980{S.v. NHG weit (MHG wīt, OHG wīt, OS wīd), from Germanic *weida- (adj.) 'weit' also found in ON víðr, OE wīd, OFr. wīd. Origin unclear. May formally correspond to Ved. vīta 'gerade', but the semantics are divergent and they are not readily connected.}];165[584-585{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wīda- 'wide, distant', as though from PIE *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- (cf. TochAB wätk- 'to separate, distinguish' < *h₁ui-dʰh₁-sk-e- (cf. Lat. dīvidō, -ere 'to separate, divide' *-h₁ui-dʰh₁-). "A full-grade adj. created to a verbal formation *h₁ui-dʰeh₁- 'to set apart', with *h₁ui- being dissimilated from *dui- 'in two' due to the following dental ([Lubotsky 1994](src-706))."}];706[203-204];697[678-679{S.v. Gmc. *wīda- 'weit'| several possibilities at a formal connection with Ved. vītá- from different sources: (a) 'gerade, nicht krumm, eben' (RV, of uncertain origin)| (b) 'eingehüllt, bedeckt, verbogen' (RV, to vyáyati 'umhüllt, bedeckt, birgt')| (c) 'unternommen, angenommen' (RV, to véti 'wendet sich zu, trachtet nach'), (d) vergangen, gewichen' (to vi-i- RV 'in verschiedene Richtungen gehen, sich verbreiten, sich verstreuen, sich verschwinden'), but nevertheless unclear.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):678-679 and [Kluge 2011](src-397):980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by [Lubotsky 1994](src-706):203-204, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

Source: 397[349, 746{S.v. NHG gerade² 'in unveränderter Richtung verlaufend' (MHG gerat, gerade, OHG gihradi 'schnell, verwandt'). For the basic word, cf. under rasch from PGmc. *raska- < *raϸ-ska- 'rasch'. There are two possibilities for a further etymology: either (1) to ONor. rǫskr 'tüchtig, tapfer', MEng. rash, without the suffix to the same root as NHG Rad < PIE *roto- (*ret-)| or (2) to ONor. hraðr 'schnell', OEng. hræð 'schnell', OHG hrad, and ffurther compared to Lith. api-kratai 'schnell' (to Lith krė̃sti 'schütteln, rütteln').}]
Justification: Lexemes apparently continuing earlier *raska-, further root etymology disputed though often assumed to continue a derivative of PIE *ret- 'to run' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):349-746, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):437-438).

Source: 397[832{S.v. NHG Schwanz (MHG swanz), a backformation to MHG swanzen, an intensive formation to schwanken (or maybe schwingen). The original basic meaning was 'was sich hin- und herbewegt', 'what moves back and forth'. NHG schwanken in turn is derived from the adjective schwank.}];697[573{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *swanka- 'schlank, biegsam', perhaps to be compared with OIr. seng 'eng, dünn, schlank'.}]
Justification: From MHG swanz, a backformation to MHG swanzen which is in turn in all likelihood an intensive formation to schwanken 'to waver, oscillate', in turn derived from the adjective schwank 'swaying' < Gmc. *swanka- (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):832, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):573).

Source: 66[1388{S.v. στάζω (< *stag-i̯e/o-).      σταχτή itself from feminine of Ancient Greek στακτός 'oozing out in drops, trickling, distilling'| also as feminine substantive στακτή 'oil of myrrh'.}];141[592{S.v. ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'träufeln| tropfen, tröpfeln' (IEW 1010).  Only as a verbal root in Greek, cf. Lat. stāgnum 'body of water', Old Breton staer f. 'river, creek'. Alternatively perhaps from *sta⁽g̑⁾-.}];382[1324{S.v. στάχτη, from the collocation σταχτή (κονία) 'distilled (ashes)', from the process of distilling ashes to produce lye.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from the collocation σταχτή (κονία) 'distilled (ashes)', from the process of distilling ashes to produce lye (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1324), further to Ancient Greek στάζω 'drop, let fall' from PIE ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1388, [LIV²](src-141) 592.

Source: 66[730-731{S.v. κοῖλος 'hollow, hollowed out, spacious, deep' < PIE *k̑euH- 'hollow' (cf. Lat. cavus 'hollow', MIr. cúa 'hollow', OHG hol 'hollow', etc.).}];382[690{S.v. κοιλιά, from Ancient Greek κοιλία 'cavity of the body| thorax with abdomen'.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιλία 'cavity of the body; thorax with abdomen', further derived from Ancient Greek κοῖλος 'hollow, hollowed out, spacious, deep' < PIE *k̑eu̯H- 'hollow' (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):690, [Beekes 2010](src-66):730-731).

Source: 382[1146{S.v. πουλί < Medieval Greek πουλ(λ)ί(ον), a diminutive of Hellenistic ποῦλ(λ)ας, a loan from Lat. pullus.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation of Hellenistic Greek *πούλλο(υ)ς, a loanword from Latin pullus 'young fowl, chicken' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1146).

Source: 141[117-118, 142{S.v. *denk̑- 'beißen' (IEW 201). The identification of this root with TochAB tsāk- 'bite' is debated.  Ringe (Sprache 34 1988-1990 p.71) plausibly derives the Tocharian forms from *dʰiHgʷ- 'hineinstecken' from *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'hineinstecken, stechen'.  Cf. fn1 s.v. *denk̑- and fn4 s.v. *dʰei̯Hgʷ- for further details.}];274[82-83{Cf. s.v. *denk̑- 'beißen' (LIV 117f., IEW 201).}];66[299{S.v. δάκνω 'to bite' also 'to sting (of insects), wound' < PIE *denk̑- 'bite'.}];592[71{Argues for the separation of the Tocharian forms in this meaning to a different root *dʰei̯Hgʷ-, cf. [cognate set 7228](cog-7228).}];172[I:688{S.v. Ved. √daṃś- 'beißen' (cf. YAv. tiži.dąstra- 'mit scharfem Gebiß'), from PIE *denk̑- (cf. Gk. δάκνω 'beiße', NHG Zange, etc.).}]
Justification: Greek and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *denk̑- 'to bite' ([LIV²](src-141) 117-118, [EWAia](src-172) I:688, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299). Sometimes connected to these lexemes are also  Tocharian AB tsāk- 'to bite', but these lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 142, [Ringe 1988-1990](src-592):71).

Source: 271[828-829{S.v. μαύρος, ultimately from Ancient Greek ἀμαυρός 'dim, faint, lightless'.}];66[84{S.v. ἀμαυρός 'hardly seen, dim, faint'. No etymology.}];270[71-72{S.v. ἀμαυρός, -ά, -όν, first attested in Od. 4.824, 835 as an epithet of a ghost 'sombre, difficile à distinguer'. There is no etymology.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀμαυρός 'dim, faint' ([Andriotis 1999](src-271):828-829). No further etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):71-72, [Beekes 2010](src-66):84).

Source: 270[34{S.v. AGk. αἷμα 'sang'. No convincing etymology.}];66[38-39{S.v. αἷμα 'blood'. There is no established etymology outside of Greek.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):34, [Beekes 2010](src-66):38-39}). It is likely that Ancient Greek αἷμα was a lexical replacement for the inherited word for 'blood', ἔαρ < *h₁esh₂-r̥- (cf. [cognate set 859](cog-859)), which was only retained as a poetic word in the language of Homeric epic and other archaic poetry.

Source: 66[733{S.v. κόκκος  'kernel of fruits, especially of the pomegranate'.  Etymology unknown, possibly a Mediterranean loan.}];382[694-695{S.v. κόκκαλο, from Medieval κόκκαλον with change of gender from Ancient Greek κόκκαλος 'kernel'.}];270[553{S.v. Gk. κόκκος 'noyau, pépin', Modern Greek uses κόκκος 'graine' and κόκκινος 'rouge' with many derivatives, also  κόκκαλον 'os' with many derivatives. Of unknown etymology, possibly a Mediterranean loanword.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel', further etymology unknown ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):694-695, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):553, [Beekes 2010](src-66):733}).

Source: 141[489{S.v. ?*pneu̯- 'hauchen, keuchen' (IEW 838-9). The root is only attested by Greek and possibly Germanic if the comparison to Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff, snort' is correct.}];66[1213-1214{S.v. πνέω 'blow, breathe, respire, smell' < PIE ?*pneu- 'breathe, cough, smell'. The Indo-European origins difficult to ascertain as there are only Germanic cognates that may be compared: Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff', Old Norse fnasa, Old High German fnehan.  Beekes suggests that the entire group may be onomatopoeic.}];270[920{S.v. AGk. πνέω 'respirer', etc. The word may be connected to a family of expressive words which may be more or less based on onomatopeia. In Germanic cf. ON fnýsa 'haleter, souffler bruyamment', OEng. fnēosan 'éternuer'.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes of uncertain etymology, perhaps from a PIE root *pneu̯- if cognate with Germanic lexemes attested by, e.g., Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff, snort' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):920, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1213-1214, [LIV²](src-141) 489).

Source: 66[618{S.v. καίω 'to kindle', med-pass. 'to burn' < PIE *keh₂u- 'burn'. Attic καίω may be explained as a yod-present from *κάϝ-ι̯ω, ultimately from PIE *keh₂u̯-i̯e/o-.  The Greek forms are possibly related to Baltic material in Lith. kū̃lės 'Brandpilze, Flugbrand, Staubbrand des Getreides', kūlė́ti 'brandig werden', Latv. kūla, 'old, dry, grass of last year'.}];141[345{S.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').}];389[{Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).}];270[480-481{S.v. AGk. καίω 'brûler, mettre le feu à, cautériser', based on earlier *καϝ-yω, cf. καῦμα, etc.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to kindle; to burn' ([LIV²](src-141) 345, [Beekes 2010](src-66):618, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):480-481). For the root reconstruction with initial palatovelar *k̑- (rather than plain velar *k-) cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Source: 66[786{S.v. κρύος 'icy cold, frost'. The etymology is difficult to assess. There are two alternatives: Either (1) Possibly from IE *kreu̯s- 'shiver', cf. ON hrjósa 'to shiver', OHG hroso 'ice', to the root *kreus- 'to stamp, strike'. Semantically TochB krośce 'cold' would be a perfect comparison but the -o- in the TochB form is difficult to account for| or (2) a connection of the group of words connected to Av. xrūma- 'horrible' < *kruh₂-mo- and connected with the *kruh₂- 'blood' root.}];270[588-589{S.v. Gk. κρύος 'froid qui glace, qui fait frissoner'. No exact correspondences. The adjective κρυερός recalls to Skt. krūrá-, Av. xrūra- 'écorché, sanglant, cruel', but neither the form nor the sense coincide and there is no reason to recall Lat. cruor (cf. Gk. κρέας). Less clear is the root *qrus- that may be compared with Lat. crusta 'croûte, revêtement', TochB krost, TochA kruaś 'froid'.}];345[236{Cf. s.v. TochB krośce ~ kroṣce 'cold', which with TochA kᵤraś reflect Proto-Tocharian nom.sg. *kʷroscē, acc.sg. kʷroscänä(n) which can reflect PIE *kʷrus-tēn, *kʷrus-tén-m̥. The assumption of a labiovelar explains the TochA nom.sg. kᵤraś, and medial -o-. "The nearest relatives are in Gk. κρυσταίνομαι 'congealed with cold, freeze' (cf. also κρύστάλλος 'ice| numbness| crystal,' κρυμός 'icy cold, frost' < *krusmó-), κρύος (nt.) 'id.' … [Beekes 2010](src-66):786 surprisingly, and surely wrongly, hesitant."}];269[{If [Adams 2013](src-345):236 is correct in his postulation of initial *kʷ-, then the proposed Greek cognates would have yielded †πρύος, †πρυσταίνομαι with regular development of *kʷ- > p / _C in Greek. Adams's reconstruction cannot be correct as such.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek unclear; possibly with 'ice' in [cognate set 4901](cog-4901) (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:28-29, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):588-589, [Beekes 2010](src-66):786). [Adams 2013](src-345):236 attempts to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this is formally problematic (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):786).

Source: 66[468{S.v. ἔρχομαι 'to come', also 'to go, travel'. The precise Indo-European etymology is debated. Possible connection with PIE *h₁ergʰ- (cf. OIr. eirg [imptv.] 'go!', regaid [fut.] 'he will go', Skt. r̥ghāyáti 'tremble, rage', possibly within Greek as an iterative ὀρχέομαι 'dance' < *h₁orgʰ-éi̯e-) or PIE *h₁er- (cf. Ved. r̥ccháti 'to reach, arrive at', Hitt. arške/a- [iter.] 'to reach repeatedly, make incursions'.)}];141[238{S.v. *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-9). LIV² reconstructs a preform *h₁r̥-sk̑e/o- for the Greek forms (= Ved. r̥ccháti 'erreicht, trifft, gerät in', OPers. -arsatiy 'kommt', Hitt. āraškizzi 'gelangt, wiederholt hin').}];270[377{S.v. AGk. ἔρχομαι 'aller, venir', sometimes 'marcher', without certain etymology.}]
Justification: The root etymology in this set tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):377, [Beekes 2010](src-66):468).

Source: 66[518{S.v. ἧμαρ 'day' < PIE *Heh₂mer-.  Attic ἡμέρα was the result of a secondary derivation. The Armenian form awr reflects a form *amōr, which may be found in the Mycenaean attestation of a-mo-ra-ma /āmōr-āmar/ 'day after day'.}];270[412{S.v. ἦμαρ.  The earlier consonant stem ἦμαρ found in Mycenaean Greek and Homer was replaced by Attic-Ionic ἡμέρα, which had been remodelled as a feminine ā-stem noun.  The aspiration found in the Attic form only (West Greek, Arcadian, Lesbian, etc. ἀμέρα) usually considered to be analogical on the basis of ἑσπέρα 'evening'.}];79[156{S.v. Arm. awr 'day| time, age', connected with Gk. ἦμαρ, Arc. ἆμαρ, -ατος 'day', Att. ἠμέρα 'day', etc. and is likely to reflect earlier *āmōr from PIE *Heh₂m-ōr.}];319[96-97{Cf. s.v. *ām-r/n 'day'.}]
Justification: Hellenic and Armenian lexemes as though from a PIE stem *Heh₂m-, an exclusive Greek-Armenian lexical isogloss ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):412, [Beekes 2010](src-66):518, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):156, cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):96-97).

Source: 66[533-534{S.v. θάνατος 'death' < PIE *dʰ(u̯)enh₂- 'die', from which -θνῇσκω 'die' is derived from the same root (via *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o-).}];141[144-145{S.v. *dʰenh₂ 'sich in Lauf setzen, sich davonmachen' (IEW 249).  The Greek present –θνῄσκω must be derived from a zero-grade sk̑é/o-present *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑é/ó-.  The writing of the iota subscript (-ῃ-) is secondary.}];269[{Older etymologies (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):287) compare forms related to Skt. dhvān- 'dark', however the internal structure of the Greek derivatives θάνατος, θνῄσκω must be accounted for in terms of preforms *dʰn̥h₂-eto-, *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o- respectively, thus [LIV²](src-141) reconstructs *dʰenh₂-.  The Modern Greek present πεθαίνω was backformed from Ancient/Medieval Greek aorist (ἀ)πέθανον, with replacement of -ανον with present morph. -αίνω and regular loss of initial unstressed ἀ-.}];322[{Albanian can't be related to Greek| etymology judged unclear by [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364). (See now [cognate set 5258](cog-5258))}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off' ([LIV²](src-141) 144-145, [Beekes 2010](src-66):533-534). Older etymologies (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):287) compare forms related to Skt. dhvān- 'dark', however the internal structure of the Greek derivatives θάνατος, θνῄσκω must be accounted for in terms of preforms *dʰn̥h₂-eto-, *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o- respectively, thus [LIV²](src-141) reconstructs *dʰenh₂-.  The Modern Greek present πεθαίνω was backformed from Ancient/Medieval Greek aorist (ἀ)πέθανον, with replacement of -ανον with present morph. -αίνω and regular loss of initial unstressed ἀ-.

Source: 382[1290{S.v. σκύλος. From Medieval Greek σκύλος, with o-stem inflection regularised from Ancient Greek σκύλαξ (stem: σκύλ-ακ-), replacing the inherited lexeme κύων, cf. [lexeme 18699](lex-18699), [cognate set 21](cog-21).}];66[1361{S.v. σκύλαξ, -ακος 'doggy, puppy'. No certain cognates outside of Greek.}];270[1023{S.v. AGk. σκύλαξ, -ακος 'jeune chien, chiot', an expressive term for which many different etymologies have been proposed.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek σκύλος 'dog', morphologically transferred into the o-stem declension from Ancient Greek σκύλαξ 'whelp, puppy' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1290). No agreed etymology outside of Greek; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1023, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1361 for various proposals.

Source: 319[182{Clackson (among others) regards the connection between Greek ξηρός and Armenian չոր čʻor as doubtful.}];79[546{Martirosyan connects Greek ξηρός with Armenian čʻir 'dried fruit' čʻor (o-stem) 'dry'.  This proposed etymology is usually doubted because one normally expects Armenian cʻ from PIE *ks, *sk, but Martirosyan argues (2.1.12) that čʻ- is the correct reflex of *ks- in initial position.  The etymology is possible, but this word is the only example that Martirosyan cites in favour of this sound law.}];66[1035-1036{S.v. ξηρός 'dry, arid'. Possibly from PIE *ksē̆ro-?  Proposed etymologies outside of Greek are unclear.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. [cognate set 5006](cog-5006)), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):182, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1035-1036, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546).

Source: 382[1619{S.v. χώμα, from Ancient Greek χῶμα 'earth thrown up, bank, mound'.}];66[1654{S.v. χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth'. The present stem of the verb χώννυμι and the derivative χῶμα 'heap, rubbish, dam, wall' are built from the aorist stem χῶσαι, which replaced the unclear form χέαι, from χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯-, or alternatively a contracted denominative or intensive *χοῆσαι to χέω.}];270[1281{Cf. s.v. χώννυμι 'amonceler, terrasser, combler'.}];141[179{Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰeu̯- 'gießen' (IEW 447-8).}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek χῶμα 'earth thrown up, bank, mound' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1619), an abstract noun derived to the same root as Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth' from PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1654, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1281, [LIV²](src-141) 179).

Source: 141[647{S.v. *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- 'zernagen' (IEW 1073), cf. TochB treṣṣäm '(zer)kaut' << *tr̥h₃⁽g̑⁾-sk̑e-.}];382[1461{S.v. τρὠω, from Ancient Greek τρώγω 'gnaw, nibble, munch'.}];66[1514-1515{S.v. τρώγω 'to gnaw, browse, eat'. Beekes rejects LIV²'s explanation of the vocalism of the aorist stem τραγ- as a secondary zero-grade from *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- and consequently rejects IE origins altogether preferring a possible 'Pre-Greek' origin instead.}];269[{IE root cognacy in this class follows LIV².}];270[1141-1142{S.v. AGk. τρώγω 'ronger, croquer' (of herbivore animals, people eating fruits, vegetables, desserts, etc.). The word evokes two Armenian words  distant from each other: aracem 'paître' and tʻurc, (gen. tʻrcoy) 'menton', which may go back to PIE *trōg-. The vocalism of Tocharian AB trāsk- from *trāk-sk- is ambiguous, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1073.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek τρώγω 'to gnaw, nibble, munch' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1461). Generally considered to continue a thematic present stem *tréh₃⁽g̑⁾-e- to a root *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- 'to gnaw away' on the basis of comparison with Tocharian B treṣṣäṃ 'to chew (up)' < *tr̥h₃⁽g̑⁾-sk̑é- ([LIV²](src-141) 647, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1141-1142); alternatively [Beekes 2010](src-66):1514-1515 prefers a 'Pre-Greek' origin.

Source: 382[810{S.v. SMG μακρύς, from Ancient Greek μακρός 'long' with changes to the morphological ending on the analogy to other common adjectives, e.g. βραχύς, βαθύς, βαρύς, εὐρύς etc. The adv. is based on the neuter plural of the adjective.}];66[895{S.v. AGk. μακρός 'long, great, high', from a PIE zero-grade formation *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall', also preserved in Latin and Germanic (cf. Lat. macer 'meagre, thin', OHG magar 'meagre' < *mh₂k̑ró-).}];274[478-481{S.v. *meh₂k̑- 'lang' (IEW 699, EIEC 357, 574).}];270[660-661{S.v. AGk. μακρός 'long, mince, grand', from a well-attested root *māk̑-/*mək̑- (cf. Lat. macies 'maigreuer', macer 'maigre', also in OHG magar, ON magr, etc.| perhaps OIr. mēr 'doigt' < *makro-).}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek μακρός 'long' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):810), ultimately a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):660-661, [Beekes 2010](src-66):895, [NIL](src-274) 478-481).

Source: 141[67{S.v. *bʰegʷ- 'davonlaufen, fliehen' (IEW 116). Greek φοβέομαι < cs.-it. stem bʰogʷ-éi̯e-.}];66[1559{S.v. φέβομαι 'to flee, take flight' < PIE *bʰegʷ-. The forms in Greek reflect the causative-Iterative stem φοβέω 'put to flight, frighten' < *bʰogʷ-éi̯e/o-. Exact cognates to the basic stem exist in Balto-Slavic, e.g. Lith. bė́gti, bė́gu 'to walk, run', OCS běžati 'φεύγειν', etc.}];464[{Tsakonian φοζούμενε < AG φοβοῦμαι. Τhe underlying form is *φο(β)-ιούμαι [fo(v)jume] (the change jV > zV being regular, e.g. υἱός > γιος [jos] > ζε ‘son’, ἐγιώ [ejo] > εζού ‘I’ etc.).}];270[1183-1184{S.v. AGk. φέβομαι 'fuir, spécialement en parlant d'une troupe saisie par la panique| fuir dans la précipitation et le désordre', with related causative verb φοβέω 'faire fuir, mettre en fuite' (Hom., Hes.)| post-Homeric 'terrifier, effrayer'| the basic verb φέβομαι has an exact correspondent in Balto-Slavic, cf. Lith. bė́gti 'courir', Latv. bȩ̄ga 'fuite', etc., and may go back to IE *bʰegʷ-.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' via the causative-iterative stem *bʰogʷ-éi̯e- 'to make run, flee' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 67, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1183-1184, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1559).

Source: 382[1024{S.v. πάλη 'fight' (noun) < from Ancient Greek πάλη 'wrestling'.  From πάλ-, παλεύω is a derived verb in -ευω.  The original semantics 'to wrestle' have been extended to 'to fight' more generally.}];66[1145{Cf. s.v. παλαίω 'to wrestle, survive a wrestling match'.  Beekes suggests a possible connection with *pelh₂- 'to approach' (cf. LIV² 470-471) with a semantic development 'make close contact' → 'wrestle' positing a zero-grade formation *pl̥h₂-e- > παλα-, but there are no synchronic traces of such a stem, thus this remains a hypothetical explanation.}];141[470-471{Cf. s.v. *pelh₂- 'sich nähern' (IEW 801-2).}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing derivatives of Ancient Greek παλαίω 'to wrestle' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1024), and probably further to be derived from PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach, draw near' ([LIV²](src-141) 470-471, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1145).

Source: 66[1551-1552{S.v. φάος 'light, daylight' < PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' (cf.  Skt. bhā́ti 'lighten, shine'). The form φῶς resulted from the contraction of medial -άο-.}];141[68-69{Cf. s.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (IEW 104-5).}];382[1575{S.v. φωτιά, derived from Ancient Greek φῶς -τός 'light'.}];270[1168-1170{S.v. AGk. φάε, φάος, φῶς 'lumière', to be connected with Skt. bhā́-ti 'il luit, il éclaire', bhā-ti- 'lumière' based on the IE root *bhā- (= *bheə₂-).}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek φῶς, -τός 'light', ultimately a derivative of PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to shine' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1575, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1551-1552, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1168-1170, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 68-69).

Source: 141[476{Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6).  See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.}];80[655-660{S.v. pattai-/patti- 'to run, to race| to flee| to fly' (cf. Skt. pátati 'to fly', Gk. πέτομαι 'to fly', etc.). To account for the Anatolian forms Kloekhorst reconstructs PIE pre-forms *pth₁-ói-ei / *pth₁-i-énti.}];66[1181-1182{S.v. πέτομαι 'to fly', derived from PIE *pet- 'fall' (cf. Lat. petō 'make for, reach', MW ehedec 'to fly', OIr. én, W. edn 'bird'| Hitt. pattai-/patti- 'run, fly', Skt. pátati 'to fly, fall', etc.).}];79[286-287, 294{S.v. Arm. *tʻiṙ- 'to fly', derived from the same root as *tʻer 'leaf, etc.' < PIE *pter-, probably a derivative of PIE *pet- 'to fly' (cf. Gk. πτερόν 'feather', πτέρυξ 'wing of a bird', πέτομαι 'to fly', etc').}];172[II:71-72{Cf. s.v. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschließend fliegen, stürzen, fallen', from PIE *pet- (cf. Gk. πέτομαι 'fliege', Lat. petō 'eile, begebe mich wohin' Old Welsh hedant 'volant', Hitt. pít-ti-i̯a-an-zi 'sie laufen', etc.).}];50[129{S.v. Proto-Celtic *fet-o- 'fly', from PIE *pet- 'fly' (Middle Welsh ehedec < *exs-fet-o-).}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ([LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389); cf. [LIV²](src-141) 476, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):655-660, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1181-1182, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):286-287, 294, [EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, [Matasović 2009](src-50):129)

Source: 66[626-627{S.v. καλός 'beautiful, noble, good'. The attestation of Boeotian καλϝός (cf. SEG 29:449.1), Ionic κᾱλός presupposes that the Proto-Greek stem was *kalu̯o–.  All further attempts to find an etymology by comparison with other Indo-European languages have been, however, unconvincing.}];270[486-487{S.v. AGk. καλός 'beau'| the original stem in Greek was καλϝός, but the geminate in κάλλος, καλλίων, κάλλιστος remains unexplained. The etymology is unclear.}]
Justification: Boeotian καλϝός shows that the Proto-Greek stem for the adjective was *kalu̯o-, but there is no secure etymology beyond of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):486-487, [Beekes 2010](src-66):626-627).

Source: 66[1644-1645{S.v. χόρτος 'enclosure, court', from PIE *gʰor-t- 'fence' (cf. Lat. hortus 'garden', Osc. húrz 'enclosure', Wel. garth 'hurdle, field', OIr. gort 'field').}];464[{Tsakonian χόντι < AG χόρτος (for the change rt > nd cf. ἄρτος > Tsak. άντε ‘bread’.}];382[1606-1607{S.v. χόρτο, from Ancient Greek χόρτος 'enclosure, court'. The other Modern Greek forms are also derived from this lexeme.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes directly continuing or continuing secondary derivatives of Ancient Greek χόρτος 'enclosure, court', from PIE *gʰor-to- 'fence, enclosure' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1606-1607, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1644-1645).

Source: 66[1129{S.v. πράσον 'leek, Allium porrum', could be connected with Lat. porrum if from *pr̥s-o- although the non-lenition of medial *-s- > -h- > Ø is unexpected. For this reason Beekes considers both Lat. porrum and Gk. πράσον early borrowings from a Mediterranean substrate language. Cf. also [de Vaan 2008](src-54):481-482 s.v. porrum 'leek'.}];54[481-482{Cf. s.v. Lat. porrum 'leek'.}];382[1150{S.v. πράσινος, originally 'leek-green', cf. Ancient Greek πράσον 'leek', Modern Greek πράσο 'id.'.}];270[934{S.v. AGk. πράσον 'poireau, allium porrum'. The probable relation with Lat. porrum 'poireau' has been long considered. If one postulates an IE etymology on *pr̥som, there is the same problem of the maintenance of intervocalic *-s- as also in the proposed etymology between δασύς and Lat. densus. More likely is a case of parallel borrowings from a third source.}]
Justification: Modern Greek πράσινος 'green' was originally a derived adjective 'leek-green' based on Ancient Greek πράσον 'leek'. Compared with Lat. porrum, one could assume a common pre-form *pr̥som, but the maintenance of intervocalic *-s- in Greek is unexpected. For this reason it is more likely we are dealing with independent loanwords from a third source ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):934, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1129; cf. s.v. Lat. porrum in [de Vaan 2008](src-54):481-482).

Source: 382[811-812{S.v. μαλλί, from Hellenistic Greek μαλλί(ον), the diminutive of Ancient μαλλός 'flock of wool'.}];66[899{S.v. μαλλός 'flock of wool'. Etymology disputed. Previous Indo-European connections with Lith. mìlas 'coarse, homespun wool' have now been abandoned| possible connections with Arm. mal 'ram' are obscure for phonological reasons and because the word may be better explained as a loanword into Armenian from Arabic (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):232fn250).}];319[232fn250{Cf. arguing against proposed connections of Arm. mal 'ram' to the Greek lexemes.}];270[663{S.v. AGk. μαλλός 'touffle de laine'| etymology unclear. Cf. [IEW](src-49) 724 who supposes *ml̥-no- and compares Lith. mìlas 'drap', Latv. mil(n)a 'drap'.}]
Justification: From Hellenistic Greek μαλλί(ον), the diminutive of Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):811-812); further etymology outside of Greek unclear ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):663, [Beekes 2010](src-66):889).

Source: 66[682-683{S.v. κεφαλή 'head, the uppermost or top part, source, etc.' < PIE *gʰebʰ-l- with further suffixation, cf. OHG gebal 'skull', TochA śpāl 'head'.}];345[703{Cf. s.v. śpāl 'head'| on the basis of TochAB śpāl 'head' one must reconstruct *gʰebʰh₂l- or *gʰebʰōl-.}];270[522{S.v. κεφαλή 'tête (d'un homme ou d'un animal)', to be connected with TochA śpāl 'tête', OHG gebal 'crâne', etc.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from a PIE stem *gʰebʰh₂l-. A reconstruction with a laryngeal *-h₂- is required because of the connection with Tocharian AB śpāl 'head'; also connected with OHG gebal 'skull' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):522, [Beekes 2010](src-66):682-683, [Adams 2013](src-345):703).

Source: 269[{A denominative verb to Gk. κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'. The lexical root for the 'leader' element of the verbal governing compound is from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 255f.), compounded with *k̑un- 'dog' (cf. [NIL](src-274) 436-440 s.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' cf. [cognate set 21](cog-21)).}];382[744{S.v. κυνηγός, the verb κυνηγέω 'hunt' (lit. 'drive dogs upon') is denominative to κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'.}];66[18-19{Cf. s.v. ἄγω 'to drive, lead, bring, carry| to draw, etc.' from PIE *h₂eg̑- for the verbal element of the compound.}]
Justification: A denominative verb to Gk. κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'. The lexical root for the 'leader' element of the verbal governing compound is from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 255f.), compounded with *k̑un- 'dog' (cf. [NIL](src-274) 436-440 s.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' cf. [cognate set 21](cog-21)).

Source: 382[1016{S.v. πάγος, from Ancient Greek πάγος 'that which is fixed or firmly set| rock, ice'.}];66[1141, 1184{S.v. πάγη 'snare, trap' < PIE *peh₂g̑- 'make fast, stiff'. From the same root πάγος 'pinnacle, cliff, hill| ice, hoarfrost, frost', cf. πήγνυμι 'to fix, stick, join, congeal or coagulate', from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'coagulate, become fixed' (cf. Lat. pangō, -ere 'to fix firmly', Skt. pajrá- 'solid, firm' with loss of laryngeal by Lubotsky's Law').}];141[461{Cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek πάγος 'that which is fixed or firmly set; rock, ice' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1016), further derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1141, 1184, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 461).

Source: 66[1359-1360{S.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark', from PIE *sk(e)h₃t- or *skoto- 'dark'.}];382[1287{S.v. σκωτώνω, remodelled from Ancient Greek σκοτόω 'to make dark, to blind', a denominal verb from σκότος 'darkness, dark'.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing a denominal formation from Ancient Greek σκότος 'darkness, dark' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1287). For further discussion and justification of the root ref. form, cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 8269](cog-8269).

Source: 66[843-844{S.v. λειμών -ῶνος 'moist, grassy place, meadow' and λιμήν 'harbour, protected creek'. The Greek forms are are generalised from different accent/ablaut forms of PIE N.sg. *lei̯-mōn, A.sg. li-mén-m̥, gen. li-mn-ós.   λίμνη 'stagnant water, pond, lake, marsh' itself appears to be a secondarily derived ā-stem derived from the weakest stem, i.e. (transponat) *li-mn-eh₂}];345[614{S.v. TochB lyam 'lake'. Adams rejects the etymology of [van Windekens 1976](src-76):271-272 with Lithuanian lāma 'place in a field, marsh, ditch' in favour of a derivation from PIE *limn̥, the neuter equivalent to animate *limén- which is Gk. λίμην 'harbour', or its derivatives λίμνη 'pool of standing water, mere', λείμων 'watery meadow'.}];76[271-272];695[109{Derives Tocharian forms via zero-grade *límn̥ > *límə > *lʸímə > PT *lʸə́mə > TB lyam, TA lyäm.}];270[627-628{Cf. s.v. AGk. λειμών, -ῶνος 'prairie humide', with secondary derivative with zero-grade of root and suffix λί-μν-η 'eau stagnante, lac, étang'.}]
Justification: Tocharian and Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):843-844, [Adams 2013](src-345):614). The Tocharian lexemes are generally considered to be based on an *mn-stem neuter to an IE root *lei̯- ([Ringe 1996](src-695):109, [Adams 2013](src-345):614), and connected to the complex of words surrounding Gk. λειμών 'wet, grassy place, meadow' λίμην 'harbour', and λίμνη 'lake', but cf. [van Windekens 1976](src-76):271-272 for older hypotheses.

Source: 269[{Originally a euphemism for the left-side in Ancient Greek.  Formed using the -tero- contrastive suffix to the same root of the suppletive comparative and superlative of 'good' ἀρείων 'better', ἄριστος 'best'| thus ἀριστερός 'better of (the) two' > 'left(hand) side'.  Less-commonly found in Ancient Greek is  εὐώνυμος 'of good name' (lit.) > 'left', but this usage is rare.}];66[128, 131-132{S.v. ἀριστερός 'left'. Generally assumed to be connected with ἄρισ-τος 'best' and the comparative ἀρείων 'better, stronger, nobler', with the contrastive-suffix -τερο-. perhaps further to the root *h₂er- found in Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'to fit, join together' with an original meaning 'more fitting'.}];270[106-107{S.v. AGk. ἀρείων, ἄριστος, ἀριστερός, etc.}]
Justification: Root etymology uncertain. Perhaps to *h₂er- 'to fit (together)' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 269-270) in the original sense 'more fitting' > 'better' > 'the better side, left' via popular euphemism ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):106-107, [Beekes 2010](src-66):128, 131-132).

Source: 382[1354{S.v. συκώτι, from συκώτιον, diminutive συκωτός 'fed on figs'.  This is a transferred epithet from the phrase ἥπαρ συκωτόν 'liver (of an animal) fed on figs'.  Cf. similarly in νερό 'water' from νηρόν (ὕδωρ) 'fresh (water)'.}];66[1421{Cf. s.v. σῦκον 'fig'. Ancient Greek συκωτός is derived from Ancient Greek συκόομαι 'to be fattened with figs', a denominal verb from σῦκον 'fig', ultimately a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean source.  The date of the loan is obviously old, cf. Myc. su-za = Att. συκία 'fig tree'.}]
Justification: From συκώτιον, the diminutive of Ancient Greek σῦκον. The meaning 'liver' was taken on as a transferred epithet from the phrase ἥπαρ συκωτόν 'liver (of an animal) fed on figs' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1354). Further etymology obscure, probably a prehistoric loanword ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1421). For a parallel semantic development in Romance cf. [cognate set 905](cog-905) from Lat. fīcus 'fig'.

Source: 66[895{S.v. μακρός 'long, thin, tall', from a PIE zero-grade formation *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' (cf. Lat. macer 'meagre, thin', OHG magar, ON magr 'meagre').}];382[810{S.v. μακρύς, from Ancient μακρός with the inflection remodelled on analogy to other terms describing weight, depth, etc. with υ-stem inflection, e.g. βαρύς 'heavy', etc.}];270[660-661{S.v. AGk. μακρός 'long, mince, grand', from a well-attested root *māk̑-/*mək̑- (cf. Lat. macies 'maigreuer', macer 'maigre', also in OHG magar, ON magr, etc.| perhaps OIr. mēr 'doigt' < *makro-).}];274[478-481{S.v. *meh₂k̑- 'lang' (IEW 699, EIEC 357, 574).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):660-661, [Beekes 2010](src-66):895, [NIL](src-274) 478-481, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):810).

Source: 66[1569{S.v. φθείρ, -ρός 'louse'. Beekes considers the form a folk etymology with φθείρω 'to ruin, destroy' < *dʰgʷʰer-i̯e/o- 'flow away, disappear'.  Cf. Chantraine (1968-1980:1198), however, who considers the form to be a true root noun.}];270[1198{S.v. φθείρ. Chantraine accepts the etymology of φθείρ as a root noun from the same root as (δια)φθείρω 'destroy'.  Original *φθέρ- or *φθήρ- would have had to take over the root vocalism /eː/ analogically from the verb.}];382[1626{S.v. ψείρα. Modern Greek varieties exhibit lexical contamination of initial consonant cluster. φθ- > ψ- from ψύλλα 'flea'.}];141[213-214{Cf. s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- 'im Wasser dahintreiben, fließen' (IEW 487-8), traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰϸer-| cf. n1 for discussion of the root reconstruction.}];269[{The PIE root reflected in Gk. φθείρω is traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰþer- with a 'thorn' cluster. The root ref. form follows the reconstruction of LIV² as *gʷg̑ʰer-. Cf. n1 s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- in LIV² and Mayrhofer (1986:150-158) for discussion of the difficulties in reconstruction of the initial cluster.}];691[150-158{Cf. for extensive discussion of the 'thorn' cluster in the reconstruction of root initial cluster.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes to be derived from the same root as Ancient Greek φθείρω 'to ruin, destroy' < *dʰgʷʰer-i̯e/o- 'flow away, disappear' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1198, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1569). The onset cluster ψ- found in some Modern Greek dialects has probably come about via contamination with Modern Greek ψύλλα 'flea' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1626).

Source: 274[444-448{S.v. *kreu̯h₂- '(geronnenes) Blut, Blut außerhalb des Korpers' (IEW 621f.)}];66[774{S.v. AGk. κρέας 'meat, piece of meat', from PIE *kreu̯h₂- 'flesh' (cf. Ved. kravíṣ- 'raw flesh', Lat. cruor, -ōris 'blood from a wound', OIr. crú 'gore, blood', OCS kry 'blood').}];270[580{S.v. AGk. κρέας 'morceau de viande, viande', traditionally connected to Skt. kraviṣ-, etc.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body, gore' ([NIL](src-274) 444-448, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):580, [Beekes 2010](src-66):774).

Source: 66[1109-1110{S.v. ὄρος 'mountain, height', an s-stem noun derived from PIE *h₃er- 'rise'.}];270[826{S.v. AGk. ὄρος 'montagne, hauteur', a verbal noun from the same root as the verb ὄρνυμαι, ὀρέσθαι 's'élever' with the vocalism of the verb rather than the expected e-grade| cf. Skt. r̥ṣvá- 'haut'.}];141[299-300{Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set in motion; rise' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):826, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1109-1110; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-300).

Source: 66[1408{S.v. AGk. στόμα 'mouth, muzzle, front, peak edge' < PIE *sth̥₃-mn̥ 'mouth' (cf. Av. staman- (m.) 'mouth (of a dog)', Hitt. ištāman- 'ear').}];270[1058-1059{S.v. AGk. στόμα 'bouche, gueule, embouchure, entrée', to be connected with Av. staman- 'gueule (d'un chien)'.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Hitt. ištāman- 'ear', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1058-1059, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1408, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):411-413).

Source: 66[1399{S.v. AGk. στενός 'narrow, close, small, tight, slim'. Variants in Ancient Greek dialects στενός (Att.), στεινός (Ion.), στεννός  (Aeol., gramm.) point to an original u-stem *sten-u- which was later thematised to *stenu̯-o-. No known cognates outside of Greek.}];270[1051-1052{S.v. AGk. στενός (Ion. στεινός, Aeol. στέννος), going back to an earlier *στενϝός which may have been a thematisation of an original u-stem (cf. compounds such as Στενύ-κληρος), but an etymology outside of Greek is unclear.}]
Justification: Variants among the Ancient Greek dialects point to an original u-stem *stenu- that was later thematised as *stenu̯o- (with subsequent loss of medial *-u̯-), but further connections outside of Greek remain unclear ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1051-1052, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1399).

Source: 66[672-673{S.v. κεντέω 'to sting, goad'. The derivative κοντός 'short' arose from reanalysis of compounds such as κοντο-βολέω 'strike with a pole' where original κοντός [m.] 'pole, crutch, staff to spur on cattle' was taken to mean 'short', ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑ent- 'sting'.}];382[707{S.v. κοντά, an adverb derived from Ancient Greek κοντός 'short'.}];141[326-327{Cf. s.v. *k̑ent- 'stechen' (IEW 567).}];270[563{S.v. κοντός 'petit, court' (Late Greek and Byzantine)| the oldest attestation in the meaning 'short' appears to be κοντοπορεία 'chemin de plus court entre Corinthe et Argos' (Polybius 16.16, Athenaeus 43e)| other early forms appear to be in compounds like κοντο-μάχος, -βόλος, -βολέω. Perhaps this semantic evolution was originally in military vocabulary.}]
Justification: Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):563, [Beekes 2010](src-66):672-673.

Source: 270[613-614{S.v. AGk. λαιμός 'gorge, gosier'. An expressive term with vocalism in -αι- which does not allow for an etymology outside of Greek. None of the hypotheses enumerated by [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) are convincing.}];66[824{S.v. AGk. λαιμός 'throat, gullet'| there seems to be no basis for the Greek-internal comparison to λαῖτμα 'depth, gulf of the sea'. [Furnée 1972](src-665):225 compares λαιμός 'gefrässig' with λαιφός and λαιφάσσω which "proves Pre-Greek origin".}];382[755{S.v. SMG λαιμός, from Ancient Greek λαιμός.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek λαιμός 'throat, gullet' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):755). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):613-614, [Beekes 2010](src-66):824).

Source: 66[616{S.v. καινός 'new, newly found, unexpected' < *kn̥-i̯o- derived from PIE *ken- 'new, fresh' (cf. YAv. kaine 'girl', adj. Ved. kanyā- 'girl', kanīna- (adj.) 'young', -cens in Lat. recens 'fresh, new, young').}];382[609{S.v. καινούργιος 'new', from Hellenistic Greek καινουργός 'newly made', a compound of Ancient Greek καινός 'new, fresh' and ἔργον 'work'.}];141[351{Cf. s.v. *ken- 'entspringen, beginnen' (IEW 563-4).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kn̥-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *ken- 'new, fresh' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):609, [Beekes 2010](src-66):616). As a verbal root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 351.

Source: 141[443-444{Cf. s.v. *meu̯k- 'losbinden, abstreifen' (IEW 744), for Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσω, -ομαι, < *muk-i̯é-.}];66[985-986{S.v. μύσσομαι 'to blow one's nose, snort'. Ancient Greek μύσσομαι is a yod-present formation, and possible cognates are Gael. smùc, smug 'mucus', MIr. mocht 'weak' < *muk-to-, ONor. mjúkr, Latv. mukls 'marshy'. The word might also be of substrate origin.}];382[906{S.v. μύτη. A noun backformed from Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσομαι 'blow (the nose)'.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes backformed from Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσομαι 'to blow one's nose, snort' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):906), further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ([LIV²](src-141) 443-444, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):726, [Beekes 2010](src-66):985-986).

Source: 66[1144-1145{S.v. πάλαι 'of old, formerly, bygone' (adv.). Gk. παλαιός is a derived adjective from πάλαι, a frozen case form like χαμαί 'on the ground', perhaps from *pl̥h₂-ei̯ ([Chadwick 1976](src-718)).  Earlier hypotheses connecting πάλαι with τῆλε 'far away' must be abandoned because the Mycenaean form does not attest a labiovelar.}];270[851{S.v. AGk. πάλαι adv. 'autrefois, il y a longtemps', with derived adjective παλαιός 'vieux (dit de personnes, de vin, de vaisseaux)'. An adverb in -αι with an obscure final, perhaps a locative. Traditionally the etymology was supposed to be a zero-grade formation with the same root as τῆλε 'au loin', Boeot. πήλυι, but the appearance of Mycenaean parajo complicates this problem, as there one would expect an initial labiovelar to be preserved. Therefore this etymology must be abandoned.}];718[68-71{Argues for connecting the root of πάλαι to the same root underlying πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old'.}];269[{From Ancient Greek παλαιός, -ά, -όν 'old, aged, ancient', derived from the adverb πάλαι, probably a fossilised case form of a root noun *pl̥h₂-ei̯ and to be connected with πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old' ([Chadwick 1976](src-718), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1144-1145). Older etymologies attempting to connect to the same root as Att. τῆλε 'far away' (cf. Aeol. πήλυι) cannot be correct since Mycenaean pa-ra-jo does not contain a labiovelar as one would expect ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):851, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1144-1145).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from the adverb πάλαι, probably a fossilised case form of a root noun *pl̥h₂-ei̯ and to be connected with πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old' ([Chadwick 1976](src-718), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1144-1145). Older etymologies attempting to connect to the same root as Att. τῆλε 'far away' (cf. Aeol. πήλυι) cannot be correct since Mycenaean pa-ra-jo does not contain a labiovelar as one would expect ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):851, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1144-1145).

Source: 66[1142-1143{S.v. παῖς, παιδός 'child, boy, son, slave, servant', more rarely 'girl, daughter'. The Greek forms are from PIE *peh₂-u- 'few, little' with further stem enlargements in *-i-d-. Disyllabic forms in epic and dialectal texts point to original *παϝ-ι-δ-. παίζω 'play' is a denominative verb to this lexeme.}]
Justification: A denominal verb from Ancient Greek παῖς (gen. παιδός) 'child', cf. cognate set 1462 for further discussion.

Source: 66[238{S.v. βρέχω 'to wet, drench', from PIE *mergʰ- 'wet, moisten', with βροχή 'rain, moistening, inundation' as an o-grade noun derived from the same root. The forms presuppose a root *mergʰ- that may be related to Latv. merguôt 'rain slowly', merga 'soft rain', but a metathesis (or Schwebeablaut) would be required in the original root form because the Greek forms presuppose a root *mregʰ- in order to yield βρέχω and βροχή as attested.}];382[278{S.v. SMG βρέχω, with associated noun βροχή 'rain' from Hellenistic βροχή 'rain, inundation'.}];270[195{S.v. AGk. βρέχω 'tremper, inonder, remplir d'eau'. Of obscure etymology, long connected with Balto-Slavic terms (cf. Latv. merguôt 'pleuvoir doucement', Ru. morositĭ 'pleuvoir doucement' which can go back to an IE *merg⁽ʰ⁾-, *mregʰ-.}]
Justification: Perhaps to be connected with Balto-Slavic forms (Latv. merguôt 'rain slowly', merga 'soft rain', Ru. morositь) to a root *mergʰ- (with Greek forms reflecting a Schwebeablaut variant *mregʰ-), but this etymology is uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):195, [Beekes 2010](src-66):238; not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 271[729{S.v. κόκκινος, -η, -ο 'που έχει το χρώμα του αίματος' [that which has the colour of blood, red], from Ancient Greek κόκκος 'seed, grain'.}];66[733{S.v. κόκκος 'kernel of fruits, especially of the pomegranate'. Etymology unknown.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes continuing a derived adjective to Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel' used in the production of red dye, further etymology unknown ([Andriotis 1999](src-271):729, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):553, [Beekes 2010](src-66):733}).

Source: 66[1225-1226{S.v. ποταμός 'river'. Etymology uncertain.  In earlier scholarship the word was thought to be connected with the same root as in 'fall' cognate set 1991 found in the verb πίπτω 'fall', with the semantics of 'waterfall' → 'river'.  More recent scholarship has determined that this root ended in a laryngeal *h₁, making this identification formally difficult, as one would expect †ποτεμός < *peth₁-mó-.  A second option connects ποταμός with the verb πετάννυμι 'spread out' (LIV² s.v. 1. *peth₂- 'ausbreiten'), to which can be compared Germanic forms OSax. fathmos, OEng. fæðm 'extension (of the arms), embrace, fathom'.  Another proposal connects ποταμός to the other *peth₂- 'fly' (LIV² 2. *peth₂- [cognate set 1486](cog-1486)) which is formally more satisfactory.  A final possibility that is not excludable in principle is that the word is borrowed from a Pre-Greek substrate language.}];389[{Separate roots in LIV² *peth₁- 'fall', *peth₂- 'fly', now merged as *pet- ‘fliegen, stürzen, fallen’¹ (IEW 825-6).}];382[1144{S.v. ποταμός. Modern Greek ποτάμι is from Hellenistic Greek ποτάμιον, the diminutive of ποταμός.}];269[{Generally connected to the same root as Ancient Greek πίπτω 'fall' to PIE *pet- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270)| cf. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. *peth₁- 'fallen')| the stem formation of Greek ποταμός is suggestive of a formation *peth₂- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen') which would complicate the root etymology (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1225-1226), but cf. now [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) which now merges these two roots as the same basic root *pet- 'fliegen, stürzen, fallen'.}];270[931{S.v. AGk. ποταμός 'course d'eau, fleuve, rivière'. Ποταμός is a suffixival derivative corresponding to the type οὐλαμός, πλόκαμος. It has been long connected with πίπτω, aor. ἔπετον 'tomber' : the torrent, the course of water which falls, but the epithet διιπετής (cf. s.v. πίπτω) does not allow this connection without difficulty. The etymology which evokes the semi-homophonous root of πετάννυμι supposes that the river is considered as a sheet of water that spreads is not very plausible. Cf. also further bibliography apud Frisk 1960–1972.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes whose root etymology is traditionally disputed between the near-homophonous roots *peth₁- 'to fall', 1. *peth₂- 'to spread out', and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):931, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1225-1226, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 477-479). See now, however, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) merging *peth₁- 'to fall' and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' into a single, more basic root *pet- 'to fly; to fall'. In view of this, the basic etymology to *pet- has been tentatively accepted here.

Source: 141[397{S.v. *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' (IEW 658).}];66[841-842{S.v. λέγω 'collect, gather| to count, recount| say', from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' (cf. Lat. legō 'collect', etc.).}];270[625-626{S.v. λέγω, in the original sense 'rassembler, cueillir, choisir' (Hom.), later 'compter, dénombrer', finally 'raconter, dire' (Hes., Att.-Ion., etc.). A thematic root present identical to Lat. legō 'cueillir, choisir| lire'.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leg̑- 'to collect, to pick up' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):625-626, [Beekes 2010](src-66):841-842, [LIV²](src-141) 397).

Source: 66[219-220{S.v. βλέπω 'to see, look, perceive'. No secure etymology.  Dialectal variation between initial β- and γ- (Dor. γλέπω, also in related vocabulary βλέφαρον, γλέφαρον 'eyelid') might be indicative of a substrate origin and initial *gʷ- in the source/borrowed form.}];382[269-270{S.v. βλέπω, from Ancient Greek βλέπω.}];269[{Ancient Greek dialectal variants βλέπω ~ *γλέπω (cf. Alcman 23, 75 ποτι-γλέποι) points to a possible original *gʷ- with an irregular development (*gʷlep- > βλεπ- expected pan-dialectally). Additionally unexplained is the alternation π ~ φ in root-final position in apparently derived vocabulary βλέφαρον ~ γλέφαρον 'eyelid'. A Macedonian gloss also attests γλέπου. A 'Pre-Greek' substrate borrowing hypothesis, as suggested by Furnée (1972:389) and Beekes (2010:219-220) therefore seems likely in this case. Because of the irregular sound changes, I refrain from positing *gʷlep⁽ʰ⁾- as a root ref. form, however this may well have been the shape of the original stem in the source-language of the borrowing.}];665[389]
Justification: Probably a substratum loan in view of the Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Dor. γλέπω) and alternation in final aspiration in related vocabulary (cf. βλέφαρον, γλέφαρον 'eyelid'), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):219-220 for further discussion. In view of these alternations, possibly borrowed as a root ?*gʷlep⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. note by Scarborough in this set).

Source: 66[1379-1380{S.v. σπείρω 'to sow, seed'. Mycenaean Greek pe-ma, pe-mo and Ancient Greek σπέρμα reflect PIE *spér-mn̥.}];141[580{Cf. s.v. 3. *sper- 'ausstreuen' (IEW 933-4).}];382[1316{S.v. σπόρος, from Ancient Greek σπόρος 'sowing, seed-time| seed', cf. Ancient Greek σπείρω 'sow'.}];105[93{S.v. Alb. farë 'seed, semen, kin', from Proto-Albanian *sparā < PIE *sporā, closely connected to Gk. fem. σπορά 'seed', ultimately from PIE *sper- 'to spill, sow' (cf. Gk. σπείρω 'id.', Gk. σπέρμα 'semen, seed').}];130[78{Three possibilities: Either (1) inherited as an old verbal noun from 3. *sper- 'ausstreuen / to scatter' > PIE *spór-eh₂  > PAlb. sparā, accepting a sound-law of *sp- > f- (cf. Demiraj 1997:56), or (2) an early loan from Greek σπορά 'seed' (predating the sound-change *sp- > f-), or (3) a later loan from Lat. far(īna) 'flour, spelt'. H. considers the case 'not decidable'.}];369[56{Assumes a sound-law *sp- > f-, comparing Alb. farë 'Samen, Saat' to Gk. σπορά 'Saat'. [No entry for farë otherwise.]}];270[1035-1036{Cf. s.v. AGk. σπείρω 'semer' with nominal derivative σπέρμα 'semence, fait de semer, origine', from PIE *sper- 'réprandre'.}]
Justification: Hellenic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE *sper- 'to spread, scatter' ([LIV²](src-141) 580). The connection of Albanian lexemes to this class follows [Demiraj 1997](src-369):56, [Orel 1998](src-105):93, but more skeptically cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):78; for Hellenic, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1035-1036, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1379-1380, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1316).

Source: 66[1275-1276{S.v. ῥάπτω 'to sew (together), stitch, instigate'. No etymology.  Previously ῥάπτω was connected to Lith. ver̃pti, 'spin', Latv. virpêt 'spin with a spindle' (cf. IEW 1156, LIV² 590), but the attestation of Mycenaean e-ra-pe-me-na (perf.participle) which does not attest initial *u̯- demonstrates that this old etymology must be abandoned.}];141[690{S.v. *u̯erp- 'hin- und herdrehen(?)' (IEW 1156).  The connection of Greek ῥάπτω with root *u̯erp- (Lith. verpiù, 'spinnen, stochern', Hitt. warapzi 'waschen, baden| reiben') is questioned because the identification is semantically and formally unclear, and the initial cluster could reflect original *sr̥- just as well as *u̯r̥-, see fn3.}];270[967{S.v. AGk. ῥάπτω (Myc. pass.part. erapemena), the evidence of Mycenaean ruins the traditional etymology which connects Baltic lexemes (e.g. Lith. verpiù, ver̃pti 'filer', etc.) due to the lack of initial w- in the Mycenaean form.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes, traditionally connected with Baltic lexemes (Lith. ver̃pti, 'spin', Latv. virpêt 'spin with a spindle' ([IEW](src-49) 1156), but the evidence of Myc. e-ra-pe-me-na without initial *w- makes this etymology impossible ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):967, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1275-1276). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain.

Source: 66[672-673{S.v. κεντέω 'to sting, goad'. The derivative κοντός 'short' arose from reanalysis of compounds such as κοντο-βολέω 'strike with a pole' where original κοντός [m.] 'pole, crutch, staff to spur on cattle' was taken to mean 'short', ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑ent- 'sting'.}];141[326-327{Cf. s.v. *k̑ent- 'stechen' (IEW 567).}];270[563{S.v. κοντός 'petit, court' (Late Greek and Byzantine)| the oldest attestation in the meaning 'short' appears to be κοντοπορεία 'chemin de plus court entre Corinthe et Argos' (Polybius 16.16, Athenaeus 43e)| other early forms appear to be in compounds like κοντο-μάχος, -βόλος, -βολέω. Perhaps this semantic evolution was originally in military vocabulary.}]
Justification: Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):563, [Beekes 2010](src-66):672-673.

Source: 382[1442{S.v. τραγουδώ, from Medieval Greek τραγουδῶ from Ancient Greek τραγῳδέω 'take part in a tragic drama| speak in tragic style, declaim'.}];66[1498{Cf. s.v. τραγῳδός 'singer and dancer in the tragic choir, tragic actor', from which τραγῳδ-έω 'to act as a τραγῳδός, treat in tragedy, to display or relate with tragic pathos' is derived. Further etymology uncertain, but traditionally derived from τράγος 'he-goat', which would have been given to the winner in the oldest dramatic contest.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek τραγῳδέω 'to take part in a tragic drama; speak in tragic style, declaim' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1442), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek τραγῳδός 'singer and dancer in the tragic choir, tragic actor'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1498 for various suggestions.

Source: 66[518{S.v. ἧμαι 'to sit' < PIE *h₁eh₁s- (cf. Skt. ā́s-te, Av. ās-te = ἧσ-ται < *h₁eh₁s-toi, Hitt. eš-/aš-).}];141[232{S.v. *h₁eh₁s- 'sitzen' (IEW 342-3).}];80[252-255{S.v. eš- / aš- '(midd.) to sit down, seat oneself', etc. < PIE *h₁éh₁s- (cf. Skt. ā́ste 'to sit', āsa- 'seat', YAv. āh- 'to sit', Gk. ἧσται 'to sit').}];172[I:181{S.v. Ved. √ās- 'sitzen, wohnen, sich niederlassen, sich aufhalten, weilen' < PIE *h₁eh₁s- (cf. YAv. āh-, Hitt. ēš-/aš- 'sitzen').}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *h₁eh₁s- 'to sit' ([LIV²](src-141) 232, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):252-255, [Beekes 2010](src-66):518, [EWAia](src-172) I:181).

Source: 66[318{S.v. δέρω 'skin, flay', from PIE *der- 'flay'. Greek δέρμα is a derived noun < *der-mn̥ originally meaning '(flayed) skin, leather'.}];141[119-121{Cf. s.v. *der- 'zerreißen (intr.), zerspringen' (IEW 206-8).}];270[265-266{S.v. AGk. δέρω  'écorcher, dépouiller' with derived abstract noun δέρμα, with correspondences in Germanic and Balto-Slavic (cf. Goth. dis-, ga-tairan 'déchirer, détruire', OHG (fir-)zeran, etc., Lith. derù 'dépouiller', OCS derǫ, etc.'}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dér-mn̥ '(flayed) skin, leather' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):265-266, [Beekes 2010](src-66):318; a derivative of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' cf. [LIV²](src-141) 119-121).

Source: 66[1128{S.v. οὐρανός 'heaven, sky'. Probably an enlargement of a noun *u̯orsó- 'rain' (cf. Skt. varṣá- 'rain', √varṣ- 'to rain'). The old etymology to the Skt. theonym Váruṇa- is certainly wrong (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia s.v.). It has also been suggested that the word may be of foreign origin (so Chantraine 1968–1980).}];172[II:522-523{Cf. s.v. Skt. √varṣ- 'regen' (cf. cognate set 1612) for the reconstruction of root initial *H-.}];141[291-292{Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯ers- 'regen' (IEW 80-81).}];270[838-839{S.v. οὐρανός 'voûte du ciel', the old etymology to Skt. Váruṇa- is phonetically impossible (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia s.v.), alternatively as proposed by Wackernagel (Kl. Schr. 1.632) to *ϝορσο- corresponding to Skt. varṣá- 'pluie'. This interpretation is plausible but not certain. Οὐρανός could be borrowed.}];269[{The best IE etymology, is a derivation to *h₂u̯ers- 'rain' (so [Wackernagel 1888](src-670):129 = Kl.Schr. 1.632, tentatively accepted by [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270), [Beekes 2010](src-66)). The hypothesis of substrate borrowing is a possibility but, given that there is no concrete extra-Greek comparison for it, gratuitous. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, Wackernagel's etymology has been followed here.}];174[446-447{Cf. s.v. οὐρανός 'Himmel'.}];670[129]
Justification: The best IE etymology, is a derivation to *h₂u̯ers- 'rain' (so [Wackernagel 1888](src-670):129 = Kl.Schr. 1.632, tentatively accepted by [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):838-839, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1128). The hypothesis of substrate borrowing is a possibility but, given that there is no concrete extra-Greek comparison for it, gratuitous. For the purposes of cognacy Wackernagel's etymology has been followed here.

Source: 382[690-691{S.v. κοιμούμαι & κοιμάμαι, from Ancient Greek act. κοιμάω 'lull, put to sleep' mediopassive κοιμάομαι 'fall asleep, go to bed', with regularisation of stem vowel -α-.}];66[663-664{S.v. AGk. κεῖμαι 'to lie, be somewhere, happen, etc.', from PIE *k̑ei̯- 'lie, rest' (cf. Skt. 3.sg. śaye, 3.pl. śere, Hitt. 3.sg. kitta < *k̑ei̯-to, etc.)| κοιμάω 'lay to rest, put to bed' and κοιμάομαι 'go to bed' are denominative from an unattested noun *κοιμή or *κοιμός.}];141[320{S.v. 1. *k̑ei̯- 'liegen' (IEW 539-40).}];270[509-510{Cf. s.v. AGk. κεῖμαι 'être couché, être placé' with exact correspondences in Indo-Iranian (Skt. śéte, Av. saēte 'être couché, placé', cf. also Hitt. kitta, kittari).}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιμάομαι 'go to bed' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):690-691), a secondary denominal verbal formation from an unattested noun *κοιμή or *κοιμός to the same root as the Ancient Greek primary verbal derivative κείμαι 'to lie' from PIE *k̑ei̯- 'to lie' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):509-510, [Beekes 2010](src-66):633-634, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 320).

Source: 165[456{S.v. Proto-Germanic *smēha- 'small', an exclusively Germanic lexeme. The older proposed connection to Greek (σ)μικρός 'small' from *smh₁-i-k-ro- in untenable on formal grounds.}];468[519{S.v. ON smár 'klein'. An etymology outside of Germanic is doubtful. [Cf. entry for references to earlier proposals.]}];697[519{S.v. Gmc. *smǣha- 'klein, gering'. Without any clear comparisons outside of Germanic. The attempt to connect the word with Gk. σμῑκρός 'klein, kurz, gering' and Lat. mīca 'ein Krümchen, ein bißchen' is uncertain.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *smēha- 'small', further etymology uncertain ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):519, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):519).

Source: 66[1182{S.v. πἐτρα 'rock, rocky mountain, range, cliff, ridge| rock cavern, cave'. No convincing etymology. In all likelihood a borrowing from an old borrowing from a substrate language.}];174[II:522-523{S.v. πέτρα 'Fels, Felsgebirge, Klippe, Riff, Felsenhöhle, Grotte', sek. 'Felsblock, Stein', beside πέτρος 'Felsblock, Stein'. "Unerklärt." Previously proposed explanations remain hypothetical at best.}];270[892-893{S.v. πέτρα 'roche, rocher', of the etymologies enumerated by [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) none are satisfying.}]
Justification: No convincing etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:522-523, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):892-893, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1182).

Source: 66[479{S.v. εὐθύς 'straight'. Etymology obscure| there are no known correspondences outside of Greek. "It may have taken the place of ἱθύς 'id.'. Perhaps a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθύς with assimilation ει : υ > ευ : υ". DELG suggests influence of εὖ 'good'.}];270[384-385{S.v. AGk. εὐθύς 'droit'. Without IE etymology. It evidently substituted Homeric and Ionic ἱθύς. Perhaps we are dealing with a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθυς with an assimilation εἰ : υ > εὐ : υ, or a simple alteration of ἰθύς under the influence of εὖ 'bien, droit'?}]
Justification: No satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some proposed inner-Greek connections cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):384-385, [Beekes 2010](src-66):479.

Source: 66[1192{S.v. πίμπρημι 'to blow (up), fan, kindle, burn up' << *pi-pr̥h₁- (with secondary epenthetic nasal). Ancient Greek πρήθω is a secondary present stem based on the same root.}];141[489{S.v. *preh₁- 'anblasen, anfachen' (IEW 809).}];382[1153{S.v. πρήζω, from Ancient Greek πρήθω 'blow out, swell out by blowing'. The Modern Greek present stem πρήζω is backformed from the aorist stem ἔπρισα on analogy to verbs of the type present σκίζω : aorist  ἔσκισα.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *preh₁- 'to blow on; stoke up' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1192, [LIV²](src-141) 489, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1153).

Source: 270[559{S.v. κόλυμβος 'petit grèbe, podiceps minor', with denominal verb κολυμβάω taking on the sense 'swim' and eliminates inherited νέω 'swim'. Reminicent of Lat. columba, but with difficulty.}];66[741{S.v. κόλυμβος 'little grebe, podiceps minor', from which Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'to dive, submerge, jump into the water, swim' is a denominative verb. No further etymology.}];382[701{S.v. κολυμπώ, from Medieval Greek κολυμπῶ < Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'dive into water'.}]
Justification: SMG κολυμπώ, etc. from Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'dive headlong (like a κόλυμβος-bird)' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):701), a denominal verb to κόλυμβος 'little grebe, podiceps minor'. Further etymology obscure ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):559, [Beekes 2010](src-66):741).

Source: 66[1127-1128{S.v. οὐρά 'tail', from PIE *h₁ors-h₂- 'rear' (cf. OIr. err 'tail' < *h₁ers-h₂-).}];50[118{S.v. Proto-Celtic *errā 'back, hinder-part, extremity', from PIE *h₁erso- 'rear-end, buttocks' (cf. Hitt. ārra- 'rump', Gk. ὄρρος 'backside', OE ears 'arse').}];270[838{S.v. AGk. οὐρά 'queue' notably of lions, dogs, wolves, and horses. Distinct in principle from κέρκος. Οὐρά < *ὀρσά is evidently connected with ὄρρος 'croupion' < *ὄρσος. Outside of Greek to be connected to OIr. err 'queue' with e-grade vocalism.}]
Justification: Greek and Celtic lexemes as nominal derivatives of PIE *h₁ers- 'rear' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):838, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1127-1128, [Matasović 2009](src-50):118).

Source: 66[1347-1348{S.v. σκέπτομαι 'to look around, look back, spy, contemplate, consider, survey', from PIE *spek̑- 'see clearly' (cf. Skt. paśyati, Av. spasiieiti, Lat. speciō 'to see').}];141[575-576{S.v. *spek̑- 'schauen, ansehen, spähen' (IEW 984).  Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι < *spek̑-i̯é-, with metathesis *sp…k > sk…p.}];382[1279-1280{S.v. σκέπομαι, from Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι 'I look about carefully, examine'.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι 'I look about carefully, examine' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1279-1280), further derived from PIE *spek̑-, with metathesis *sp…k > sk…p ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1347-1348, [LIV²](src-141) 575-576).

Source: 141[102{S.v. 1. *deh₁- 'binden' (IEW 183).}];66[321-322{S.v. δέω 1 'to bind' < PIE *deh₁- 'bind'.}];382[338{S.v. δένω, from Ancient Greek δέω, morphologically remodelled as a nasal present δένω.}];172[I:716-717{S.v. Ved. √dā-³ 'binden', from PIE *deh₁-.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from PIE *deh₁- 'to bind' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):321-322, [LIV²](src-141) 102, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):338).

Source: 66[278{S.v. γλῶσσα 'tongue, language'. Derived form in -i̯a- from *γλωχ- 'point' (γλῶχες 'beard of corn', γλωχίς 'end of a yoke strap, barb of an arrow, etc.'). Possibly a PIE preform *glōgʰ-s, gen. gl̥gʰ-ós 'point', but there are no certain cognates outside of Greek.}];270[229-230{S.v. γλῶχες, γλωχίς, γλῶσσα. The etymology of the hapax γλῶχες that is the basis of the word family has not been established. The proposed connection with OCS glogъ 'épine', etc. is uncertain.}]
Justification: Within Hellenic the root of the noun, *γλῶχ- / *glōkʰ 'point', is attested via γλωχίς 'end of a yoke strap, barb of an arrow, etc.', but there are no known cognates outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):229-230, [Beekes 2010](src-66):278).

Source: 66[1413-1414{S.v. στρέφω, -ομαι 'to twist, turn'. No known cognates outside of Greek.}];141[603{S.v. ?*strebʰ- 'drehen, wenden' [IEW 1025]. Only Greek. If the root is inherited from Indo-European a reconstruction *stregʷʰ- is also theoretically possible (cf. fn1).}];270[1063-1064{S.v. στρέφω 'tourner, détourner'. The lexical root forms a coherent system in Greek, but there is no known etymology outside of Greek. If connected to Mycenaean kusutoroqa, then we should reconstruct a final labiovelar.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1063-1064, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1413-1414);  [LIV²](src-141) 603 mechanically reconstructs ?*strebʰ-, but ?*stregʷʰ- also remains theoretically possible.

Source: 382[948{S.v. ξερνώ. From Ancient Greek ἐξερέω 'I speak out, utter' with semantic shift to 'spew out, vomit'. A suffix -νω has analogically replaced the original vowel-stem inflection.}];141[251{S.v. 1. *h₁reh₁- 'fragen' (IEW 337). Greek ἐρέω would be from a zero-grade present stem *h₁r̥h₁-i̯é- and directly comparable to Hitt. ariyezzi 'untersucht (durch Wahrsagerei)'.}];66[391-392{S.v. εἴρομαι 'to ask'. Beekes derives the Greek forms associated εἴρομαι, ἐρέω from PIE *h₁r(e)u- 'ask, enquire', but against this etymology cf. LIV² p.251 s.v. *h₁reh₁- 'fragen', n1, with references.}]
Justification:
Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἐξερέω 'I speak out, utter' with semantic shift to 'spew out, vomit' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):948), further to PIE 1. *h₁reh₁- 
to ask, question' ([LIV²](src-141) 251, but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):391-392).

Source: 141[312-313{S.v. *i̯es- 'sieden, schäumen' (IEW 506). Ancient Greek ζέω < *i̯és-e/o-.}];382[530-531{S.v. SMG ζεστός, a derived adjective from Ancient Greek ζέω 'boil'.}];66[499-500{S.v. ζέω 'boil, seethe' < PIE *i̯es- 'boil, foam' (cf. Skt. yasati [gramm.] 'seethe, boil', OHG jesan 'ferment, foam', TochA yäs- 'boil'| perhaps also Alb. ziej| nominal formations exist in Celtic, e.g. Gallo-Rom. *i̯estā 'foam', MW ias 'boil, foam').}];270[399-400{S.v. AGk. ζέω 'bouillir, chauffer', from a root *i̯es- (cf. Skt. yasati 'bouillonner, bouillr', OHG jesan 'fermenter, bouilloner').}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes derived to the root of Ancient Greek ζέω 'boil, seethe' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):530-531), further to PIE *i̯es- 'to boil, foam' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):399-400, [Beekes 2010](src-66):499-500, [LIV²](src-141) 312-313).

Source: 66[1018{S.v. νηρός 'fresh', from νεαρός 'young, youthful, tender, fresh' (with vowel contraction of medial -εα- > -η-.  The r-formation is paralleled by Armenian նոր nor [lexeme 28560](lex-28560) 'new' < *neu̯-eró- vel sim.}];382[915-916{S.v. νερό. From Medieval Greek νερό(ν) < Ancient Greek νηρόν, 'fresh', with meaning transferred from the collocation νῆρον ὕδωρ 'fresh water'.}]
Justification: Originally 'fresh', a transferred epithet from the phrase νηρόν ὕδωρ 'fresh water' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):915-196), further to PIE *neu̯- 'new, fresh' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1018, cf. [NIL](src-274) 524-526). Not the same root as PIE *neu̯- 'to nod, tilt (the head)' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 455-456).

Source: 382[223-224{S.v. άσπρος. Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as in the phrase nummi asperi 'rough coins', i.e. new coins which had just been cut and had not yet been worn down from circulation.  The semantic development appears to be one via a transferred adjective '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white'.}];66[154{S.v. ἄσπρος 'rough'. A loanword from Lat. asper.}]
Justification: Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white', cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):223-224, [Beekes 2010](src-66):154.

Source: 274[307-311{S.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (LIV² 267f., IEW 38f.). Greek forms via *h₂énh₁-mo-.}];141[267-268{Cf. s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9).}];79[416{S.v. Arm. hołm 'wind', usually derived from *h₂onh₁-mo- (with dissimilation *-nm- > -łm-), cf. ἄνεμος 'wind', Lat. animus 'soul, mind, spirit', etc. The precise Ablaut grade of the root *h₂enh₁- underlying the Armenian form is debated. Cf. entry in Martirosyan for further discussion with references.}];66[101-102{S.v. ἄνεμος 'wind' < PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'wind' (= Lat. animus| cf. Skt. ánila- 'wind, air' < *h₂énh₂lo-| Arm. hołm < *h₂onh₁-mo-, with *n > l dissimilation).}];180[27{Arm. hołm 'wind' is probably dissimilated from *h₂on(h₁)-mo- and cognate with Gk. ἄνεμος, Lat. animus, although this connection is rejected in [IEW](src-49) 39.}]
Justification: Hellenic and Armenian lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ([NIL](src-274) 307-311, [Beekes 2010](src-66):101-102, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):416, [Olsen 1999](src-180):27, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 267-268).

Source: 54[458{S.v. Lat. penna 'wing, feather', from *pet-n-h₂- > *petna > penna (cf. OW eterin 'bird', atan 'wing' < *pt-r/n-| Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- 'wing' < *póth₂-r, *pth₂-én-s or *peth₂-(ō)r, *peth₂-én-s| Skt. pátra- 'wing (of a bird), feather', pataṅgá- (adj.) 'flying', 'bird', Av. patarə-ta- 'winged', NHG Feder 'feather').}];141[479{S.v. 2. *peth₂- '(auf)fliegen' (IEW 825-6)| now *pet- together with *peth₁-, cf. LIV addenda & corrigenda.}];80[658-659{S.v. Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- 'wing, feather', from PIE *póth₂-r / *pth₂-én- or *péth₂(ō)r / *peth₂-én- (cf. OHG fedara, ON fjǫðr 'feather', fiðri 'feathers', Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna, Skt. pátra- 'wing').}];66[1248{Cf. s.v. πτερόν 'feather, wing, pinion', derived from PIE *pet- 'fly' (cf. Skt. pátra- 'wing, feather', Lat. acci-piter, -tris 'hawk', OHG fedara, ON fjǫðr 'feather', etc.).}];79[286-287{S.v. Arm. tʻew 'wing| arm', related to Arm. tʻer 'leaf', together with tʻer 'side', tʻiṙ- 'to fly', and tʻitʻeł/ṙn 'butterfly' based on PIE *pter- 'feather, wing', probably derived from PIE *pet- 'fly' (cf. Gk. πτερόν 'feather', πτέρυξ 'wing of a bird', πέτομαι 'to fly', etc')}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}];165[138-139{S.v. Proto-Germanic *feϸrō- 'feather', from a heteroclitic stem *péth₂-r/n- from the PIE root *peth₂- 'to fly' (cf. Skt. pátra- < *peth₂-ro-| Gk. πτερόν < *pt(h₂)-er-o-, Lat. penna 'feather' < *peth₂-n-eh₂-, OW atar 'bird', MW adar 'id.' < *pth₂-r-| OIr. én 'bird', W. edn 'id.' < *peth₂-no-).}];50[126{S.v. Proto-Celtic *fatar, gen. *fatanos, *fetnos 'wing, bird', from PIE *potr / *ptn-os 'wing' (cf. Hitt. pattar, Skt. pátra-, Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna).}];172[II:75-76{Cf. s.v. Ved. pátra- 'Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', from an old heteroclitic (*pat-r- / *pat-n-), cf. NHG Feder, OW eterin, 'Vogel', atan 'Flügel', etc.}];442[437{S.v. 7733 Ved. páttra- n. 'wing, feather'.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Nuristani, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, to fall'. For the root reconstruction cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389). For individual branches cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):658-659, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1248, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):286-287, {Turner 1962–1966}:437 no. 7733, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):138-139, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):458, [Matasović 2009](src-50):126).

Source: 66[305{S.v. δασύς 'hairy| having a shaggy surface'.  Possibly related to Lat. dēnsus, but the exact reconstruction is problematic.}];382[333{S.v. δάσος, from Ancient Greek δασύς 'thick with leaves, thickly wooded'.}];270[253{S.v. AGk. δασύς 'à la surface hérissée, touffue', 'poilu', etc.| one is reminded of Lat. dēnsus, but reconciling the reconstruction is difficult with the dialectal Greek data. Ultimately no etymology.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek δασύς 'thick with leaves, thickly wooded' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):333). Often further compared to Lat. dēnsus 'thick, close, compact' but the comparison is formally problematic and therefore there is no clear etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):253, [Beekes 2010](src-66):305).

Source: 382[1287-1288{Modern Greek forms from Ancient Greek σκωλήκιον, diminutive of σκώληξ 'worm, earthworm'.}];66[1364{S.v. σκώληξ 'worm, larva'. Beekes dismisses the proposed connection of Ancient Greek σκώληξ 'worm, larva' with σκέλος 'leg' [cf. [cognate set 2785](cog-2785)] as dubious on the grounds of an unmotivated lengthened ō-grade and is necessary, and the suffix -ηξ does not seem to have any clear IE origin.  [The same suffix occurs on μύρμηξ 'ant' cf. cognate set 5010.]}];270[1025-1026{S.v. σκώληξ 'ver' entre autres 'ver de terre', derivative in the suffix -ηκ- (probably earlier -ᾱκ-) used with various small animals, cf. μύρμηξ 'ant'. The base *σκῶλος may perhaps be an analogy to καλύπτω 'hide' or σκολύπτω 'cut short'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside Hellenic uncertain ({ref Chantraine {1968–1980}:1025-1026, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1364).

Source: 66[1651-1652{S.v. χρόνος 'period or course of time, (a definite) time, lifetime, time limit'. Etymology unknown, cf. entry for discussions of earlier but unconvincing attempts at an IE etymology.}];382[1613-1614{S.v. χρόνος, from Ancient Greek χρόνος 'time'.}];270[1277-1278{S.v. AGk. χρόνος 'temps', of unknown etymology| cf. entry for further discussion of previous proposals.}]
Justification: Modern Greek χρονιά 'year' from Ancient Greek χρόνος 'time' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1613-1614), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1277-1278, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1613-1614 for discussion of older but unconvincing attempts at an IE etymology).

Source: 382[677-678{S.v. κίτρινος. Denominal adjective in -ινος derived from Hellenistic Greek κίτρον 'fruit of the citrus tree', a borrowing from later Latin citrium < Lat. citrus 'fruit of the citrus tree'.}];66[705{S.v. κίτριον 'citron tree (Citrus medica), citron'. Loanword from Lat. citrium.}]
Justification: A derived adjective from Hellenistic Greek κίτρον 'fruit of the citrus tree', a loanword from Late Latin citrium, cf. Classical Latin citrus 'citrus tree' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):667-668, [Beekes 2010](src-66):705).

Source: 66[1580{S.v. φλοιός 'bark (of a tree), rind, skin of a fruit, pellicle of a leaf or egg'. Etymology uncertain, may be connected to verb φλέω and φλύω, possibly from a potential root *bʰleu̯(H)- 'overflow' cf. LIV² 90, 1. *bʰleu̯H- 'überströmen' (IEW 158-159).  Beekes, however, argues that the word may be Pre-Greek.}];382[1546, 1547{In Standard Modern Greek φλοιός is a learned reintroduction from Ancient φλοιός.  Ancient φλοιός is directly preserved in part by φλούδα, from a diminutive formation φλούδι(ον) via from Hellenistic Greek contracted φλόος / φλούς, an alternative form of φλοιός.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Hellenic uncertain, possibly to be connected with verbs φλέω 'to teem with abundance, abound' and φλύω 'to boil over, bubble up' as derivatives of PIE *bʰleu̯H- 'to overflow'; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1214, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1580, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1546-1547.

Source: 66[923-924{S.v. μέλας 'dark-colored, black' < PIE *mel(h₂)-n- 'black'. The feminine stem μέλαινα is traditionally identified with Skt. malinī < *melh₂-n-ih₂ and the masculine/neuter stem μελαν- would be a modification of an earlier thematic *μέλανο- equivalent to Skt. malina- 'dirty'.
