It should be noted, however, that malinī is only known in the form of a gloss 'menstruating woman' and malina- is an epic classical  Sanskrit derivative from Ved. mála- 'dirt', which could in principle also be derived from *molh₂-o-. There are additional colour words which may be compared from Baltic: Latv. męl̃ns 'black', OPruss. melne 'blue spot', Lith. mul̃vas 'yellow (of clay)'.}];353[544{S.v. Latv. mȩl̃ns 'black' (cf. OPr. melne 'blue spot, bruise'), from PIE *melh₂-n- (cf. Gk. μέλας 'dark, black').}];270[680-681{S.v. μέλας 'sombre, noir', compared by [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) with Skt. malinī- which corresponds to μέλαινα but is a term that signifies 'femme qui a ses règles', malina- 'sale' (attested only late), and very simple comparisons with terms in Baltic *mēlna- < *melə-no- in Latv. męl̃ns 'noir', OPr. melne 'tache bleue', Lith. mė́las, mė́lynas 'bleu'.}];172[II:332-333{Cf. s.v. Ved. mála- 'Schmutz, Unreinlichkeit, Unrat, Dreck', probably to be derived from PIE *mélo-, cf. Gk μέλας 'black', Lith. mė́las 'blue', mel̃svas 'blueish'.}]
Justification: Hellenic and Baltic lexemes generally connected with Indic lexemes in the meaning 'dirty' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):680-681, [Beekes 2010](src-66):923-924; cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):554, [EWAia](src-172) II:332-333).

Source: 66[1638{S.v. χλοή 'first green shoots, young verdure, etc.' < PIE *g̑elh₃- 'green, yellow' (cf. Lith. žolė̃ 'grass, herb, flower' and other words for 'green' [cognate set 6332](cog-6332), 'yellow' [cognate set 7535](cog-7535)).}];352[1296, 1325-1327{S.v. OLith. žolė̃ 'Gras, Kraut, Pflanze' (cf. OLith. žélti 'grünen, sprießen' < *g̑elh₃-).}];81[542{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *zelьje 'greens, herbs', a derivative of *zel- from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-.}];600[1067-1068{Polabian zilĕ is derived from PS *zelĭje 'herb'.}]
Justification: Hellenic and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑elh₃- 'green, yellow' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):542, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1067-1068, [ALEW](src-352) 1296, 1325-1327, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1263-1264, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1638).

Source: 66[792{S.v. κτύπος 'strong noise, cracking, stamping'. Etymology unknown.}];382[740{S.v. κτύπος. The verb κτυπέω 'crash, resound' is denominal (cf. Hom. κτύπος 'crash, bang, din') and already attested in Ancient Greek.}];270[592-593{S.v. AGk. κτύπος 'bruit fort', probably of expressive origin.}]
Justification: Originally a denominal verb to Ancient Greek κτύπος 'loud noise, crashing sound', probably of onomatopoeic or expressive origin ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):592-593, [Beekes 2010](src-66):792, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):740).

Source: 54[639-640{S.v. ūmeō 'to be wet', from which Lat. ūmidus 'wet, moist' is a derived adjective. Based on Proto-Italic *ūmo- from PIE *uh₁-mo- 'wet', following the arguments of Weiss (1994:143f.) against earlier proposed connections to PIE *u̯egʷ- (cf. Ernout-Meillet 1995:745-746)for semantic reasons. To de Vaan, however, the semantic difference between ūvidus and its derivatives, however, does not seem large enough to warrant giving up the older etymology for those lexemes.}];700[143-145{Argues against the traditional etymology to *u̯egʷ- (cf. Ernout-Meillet 1985:745), instead to *u̯eh₁-.}];316[745-746{Cf. s.v. Lat. ūmeō, -ēs, -ēre 'être humide (surtout poétique)': The origins of the group comprising ūueō, ūuēscō, ūuidus (ūdus), ūlīgō are less clear. We suggest a connection to Greek ὑγρός 'humide', which resembles Arm. oyc 'frais' and OIc. vokr 'humide'. One would start from *ug-sm- or *oug-sm-, and from *e/oug-w-. One cannot trace a precise history.}];269[{Etymology for these lexemes follows that of Weiss (1994:143-145) and de Vaan (2008:639-640) to *u̯eh₁- over the older connection to *u̯egʷ- (cf. Ernout & Meillet 1985:745-746). Romanian ud 'wet' < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class but could also belong to PIE *u̯egʷ- in [cognate set 5276](cog-5276), cf. discussion in [cognate set 8427](cog-8427).}]
Justification: Etymology for these lexemes follows that of [Weiss 1994](src-700):143-145 and [de Vaan 2008](src-54):639-640 to *u̯eh₁- over the older proposed etymology to *u̯egʷ- (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):745-746). Romanian ud 'wet' < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class but could also belong to PIE *u̯egʷ- in [cognate set 5276](cog-5276), cf. discussion in [cognate set 8427](cog-8427).

Source: 81[404{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pletje 'shoulder', a derivative of the root *pleth₂- 'broad'.}];66[1205{S.v. Ancient Greek πλατύς 'wide, broad, flat, level'. The Greek forms derive from a zero-grade *pl̥th₂-ú- which is identical to IIr. forms, e.g. Skt. pr̥thú-, Av. pərəθu- 'wide, broad' (√*pleth₂-).}];382[1113{S.v. πλάτη. The Modern Greek words derive from Ancient Greek πλάτη 'broad, flat object', (as pl. πλάται 'shoulder-blades', cf. LSJ).}];464[{Regarding the lack of -τ- in Italiot, πλάη < πλάτη (with intervocalic -t- deletion in Apulian, cf. Ap. στρα < στράτα ‘road’ etc.).}];259[440{PS *pleťe < *plet-jo 'shoudler, upper back' < PIE *plet- 'wide, flat'.}];595[3: 52{PS *pleťe derived from PIE *pletH-.}];598[281{Taking Russian forms like podoplëka, beloplëkij into account, it can be reconstructed as  PS *plektjo which is then related to Greek πλάξ, πλακός, Old Icelandic flá and Latin placidus. If the mentioned Russian forms with -k- are secondary, it is a reflex of PS *pletjo, related to Irish leithe 'shoulder blade', Greek πλατύς 'wide' and Lithuanian platùs 'wide'.}];636[151{Reflex of IE *plet-, related to Lithuanian plesti 'extend' and platùs 'wide', Middle Irish leithe 'shoulder', and Greek πλατύς 'wide'. The Russian word podoplëka is derived from PIE *plek-.}];260[1098-1099{Most probably a reflex of PS *pletje derived from PIE *plet-jo. In the reconstruction proposed by Vasmer (*plektjo) is -t- hard to explain. Maybe there were two parallel forms with two different roots *plet-je and *plek-je which are attested in simmilar meanings also in Baltic.}];249[{The Slavic lexemes are derived from PIE *pleth₂-. The original meaning of PS *pleťe was most probably 'shoulder'. Note that all Slavic languages using derivatives of this root in the meaning 'back' use the old dual form here ('two shoulders'). All stages of semantic development ('shoulder(s)', 'upper back', 'back') are attested in Slavic.}];274[564{S.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (LIV 486f., IEW 833).}]
Justification: Hellenic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'be(come) wide, broad' ([NIL](src-274) 564-566; cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1205, [Derksen 2008](src-81):404).

Source: 66[748-749{S.v. κόπτω 'to strike, smite, hew, hammer, disable, tire out'. May be Indo-European if cognate with Lithuanian kapiù 'hew, fell', Albanian kep 'hew'. Alternatively, the lexeme may be of substrate origin if related to σκάπτω (cf. notes in [cognate set 202](cog-202)).}];141[555{Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' (IEW 931-932). A Greek, Balto-Slavic and Albanian isogloss.}];382[689{S.v. SMG κόβω, from Ancient Greek κόπτω, from which κοφτερός is a derived adjective from earlier κοπτ-ερός.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοπτερός ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):689). Further root etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 555 to PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop', but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):748-749.

Source: 66[638-639{S.v. καπνός 'smoke, steam'. Walde-Pokorny assumes a pre-form *kwap-nó- on the basis of comparison with Lith. kvãpas 'breath, smell', kvė̃pti 'to gasp, breathe', Latv. kvêpt 'to smoke, smell'.  The comparison is also similar to Gothic af-ƕapjan 'to suffocate, extinguish', af-ƕapnan 'to extinguish', but with final -p- instead of expected -f- or -b-.  Comparison with Lat. vapor 'vapor, smoke' is difficult because of initial v- rather than expected qu-, and in any case Mycenaean does not attest -w-. This has usually been explained as a dissimilation *kʷ ... p > *k ... p, but parallels are doubtful. "Indo-European origin is improbable. […] in view of the similarity of the Balto-Slavic material and of Lat. vapor, it may be best to assume a European substrate word."}];269[{Frequently connected to a common root *kʷu̯ap- or *kʷu̯eh₂p- uniting the Baltic forms with Lat. vapor 'vapour, steam' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):654, and Lith. kvė̃pti 'breathe' (cf. further discussion in [cognate set 6321](cog-6321)), but due to several irregular sound changes necessary to justify the comparison, the etymology is not fully certain.}];270[494-495{S.v. καπνός 'fumée, vapeur, fumet'. A form *κϝαπ-νός corresponds well to the root of Lith. kvãpas 'souffle, haleine'm etc., with e-vocalism Lith. kvėpiù, kvė̃pti 'haleter, respirer', etc. Latv. kvêpstu, kvêpt 'fumer, exhaler', etc., possibly also to Lat. vapor, but the expected initial qu- is lacking. For further uncertain comparisons cf. [IEW](src-49) 596.}];352[545-546{Cf. s.v. OLith. kvė̃pti 'atmen, hauchen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kvêpt 'qualmen, rauchen', etc.). These lexemes are probably not to be separated from Lat. vapor, -ōris 'Dampf, Dunst', Gk. καπνός 'Raum, Qualm, Dunst', continuing a root *kʷu̯ap- or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-. Improbable is an etymological connection with Goth. afƕapjan 'ersticken', etc.}]
Justification: Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Lith. kvė̃pti 'breathe' ([ALEW](src-352) 545-546, [Derksen 2015](src-353):268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison (cf. Chantraine 1968–1980}:494-495, [Beekes 2010](src-66):638-639).

Source: 66[1074-1075{S.v. ὀμαλός 'equal, level, smooth'. Derived form from *sem-| *semh₂-l-. The root vocalism is usually considered to be analogical to ὁμός 'common, one and the same, equal, similar, level'.}];382[973{S.v. SMG ομαλός, from Ancient Greek ὀμαλός.}];270[799-800{S.v. AGk. ὁμός 'un, le même, commun, uni' with related derivative ὁμαλός, a derivative of IE *sem- (cf. Lat. semel, similis, Goth. simlē 'une fois, autrefois', OHG simble, etc.).}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀμαλός 'equal, level, smooth' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):973), further to be considered a derivative of PIE *sem-, cf. Ancient Greek ὀμός 'common, one and the same, equal, similar, level' < *som-o- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):799-800, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1074-1075).

Source: 66[1159-1160{S.v. AGk. παχύς 'thick, fat, well-fed, dense, stout', from old u-stem (with zero-grade) *bʰn̥g̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Skt. bahú- 'many, much, numerous', OAv. bəzuuaite [dat.sg.m.] 'dense', Arm. bazum 'much', Hitt. panku- 'total').}];352[115-116{Cf. s.v. biñgti 'mutig, stattlich, größer werden'. Latv. bìezs, bìežs may be derived from bʰ(e)ng̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Gk. παχύς).}];172[II:220-221{S.v. Ved. bahú- 'viel, reichlich, häufig, dicht, dichtgedrangt', from PIE *bʰn̥g̑ʰ-ú- (cf. Gk. παχύς 'dick, dicht', Hitt. panku- 'gesamt', Iran. *bazu- in Arm. LW bazowm 'viel').}];274[13-15{Cf. s.v. *bʰeng̑ʰ- 'dicht, fest machen' (IEW 127f.).}];325[31{"*dwąza-, Av. bąz-, etc."}];442[518{S.v. 9182 Skt. bahala- 'thick' Suśr.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰeng̑ʰ- ([NIL](src-274) 13-15, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1159-1160, [EWAia](src-172) II:220-221, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):518, [ALEW](src-352) 115-116).

Source: 442[611{S.v. 10552 Skt. rakṣā (2) f. ʻ ashes ʼ lex. [Same as rakṣā- 1? 'protection' √rakṣ-]}];172[II:422{Cf. s.v. Ved. √rakṣ- 'schützen, beschützen, behüten, bewachen', from PIE *h₂leks- (cf. Gk. ἀλέξω 'wehre ab, verteidige').}];141[278{Cf. s.v. *h₂leks- 'abwehren, schützen' (IEW 32).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit rakṣā- f. 'preservation, care; guarding'; 2. 'ashes (used as a preservative)', further derived from Ved. √rakṣ- 'to protect' and derived from PIE *h₂leks- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):611, no. 10551-10552; [EWAia](src-172) II:422, [LIV²](src-141) 258).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10187 s.v. 11./12. *moṭṭ(h)a- 'big, fat'; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Source: 442[145{S.v. 2854 Skt. kártati (1) 'cuts'.}];172[I:315-316{Cf. s.v. Ved. √kart-¹ 'schneiden, abschneiden, spalten, brechen', from PIE *(s)kert- (cf. OHG scrinden 'sich spalten', Lith. kertù 'fälle, haue', RuCS črěsti 'schneiden', etc.).}];141[559-560{S.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' (IEW 941-2). Cf. n1: Probably an enlarged form of 2. *(s)ker- cognate set 5452.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √kart- 'to cut (off), split, break', ultimately from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):145 no. 2854, [EWAia](src-172) I:315-326, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Source: 442[674{S.v. 11567 Skt. vārdala- n.m. 'rainy day, bad weather'.}];399[III:195{Cf. s.v. Skt. vārdalaḥ 'regnerischer Tag, Schlechtwetter, Regenwetter / rainy day, bad weather'. Not satisfactorily explained.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vārdala- vārdala- 'rainy day, bad weather' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):674, no. 11567), further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:195 for various proposals.

Source: 442[168{S.v. 3275 *kutta- (1) 'dog'. [Onom.: cf. Sogd. 'kwt, Shgh. kut 'dog', Sant. kutu kutu 'sound made in calling a puppy'].}];269[{Similar to Iranic *kutī̆- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Iranic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also [ESIJa](src-331) IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.}]
Justification: Similar to Iranic *kutī̆- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Iranic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also [ESIJa](src-331) IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

Source: 172[I:795{S.v. Ved. dhūmá- 'Rauch', from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- (cf. Lat. fūmus, Lith. dū́mai, etc.), derived from the PIE root *dʰu̯eh₂-/*dʰeu̯h₂-/*dʰuh₂- 'rauchen, qualmen, keuchen, erregt sein'.}];141[158{Cf. s.v. *du̯eh₂- 'Rauch machen' (IEW 262-3).}];54[249{Cf. s.v. Lat. fūmus 'smoke, fumes' (denominal vb. fūmāre 'to emit smoke or steam), from PIE *dʰuh₂-mó- 'smoke, fume' (cf. Skt. dhūmá- 'smoke, fume', Gk. θῡμός 'spirit', OPr. dumis 'smoke', Lith. dū̀mai 'smoke', OCS dymъ 'smoke', OHG toum 'steam').}];442[392{S.v. 6849 Skt. dhūmá- m. 'smoke, vapour, mist'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ([EWAia](src-172) I:795, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):392 no. 8649, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):249, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):305 no. 3572).

Source: 442[{S.v. 5539 *ḍavva 'lefthand, crosswise'. 2. *ḍāva- 2. 3. *ḍābba- . 4. *ḍivva- . 5. *ḍēvva- . 6. ḍhēvva- . 7. *dēva- 2. 8. *dēvva- . [Non-Aryan: A. Master BSOAS xii 348 ← Drav.] (M. ḍāvā 'left' < 2. *ḍāva-).}];756[44{Cf. s.v. no. 449 Ta. iṭai, iṭam 'left side', Te. eḍama 'left, left-hand, left-hand side', etc.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5539; non-Indo-Aryan
Justification: A loanword from Dravidian, cf. Telugu eḍama 'left, left-hand, left-hand side', Tamil iṭai, iṭam 'left side' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):311 no. 5539, cf. [Burrow & Emeneau 1984](src-756):44 no. 449).

Source: 442[458{S.v. Skt. pārśvá- n. 'region of the ribs, side' RV., 'nearness' MBh., pārśvaka- m. 'rib' Yājñ.}];172[II:100-101{Cf. s.v. Ved. párśu- 'Rippe', from which pārśvá- 'Rippengegend, Seite, Flanke' is derived. Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are unclear. Perhaps to PIE *perk̑- if connected to OCS prъsi 'Brust', but against this Ved. pr̥thu-párśu- meaning 'mit geschwellter Brust' is difficult.}]
172[II:369{S.v. Ved. mū́la- 'Wurzel'. Etymology unclear.}];399[II:667{S.v. Skt. mū́lam 'Wurzel', 'root'. 'Nicht eindeutig erklärt.'}];442[591{S.v. 10250 Ved. mū́la- (mū́ra- AV.) n. 'root' RV.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indic uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) II:667, [EWAia](src-172) II:369). For Middle and Modern Indic forms cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):591, no. 10250.

Source: 442[135{S.v. 2703 Skt. katháyati 'converses with, describes' MBh. [Denom. from kathā : √kath]}];172[I:294-295, 284-285{S.v. Ved. kathā́ 'wie? woher?' to which ep. kl. kathayº 'erzählen', Pā. kathā- 'Erzählung', katheti 'spricht' etc., cf. Ved. kathám adv. 'wie?, auf welche Weise?, woher?', to Ved. ká- Interrogative pronoun 'wer, welcher?', to PIE *kʷe-/*kʷo- (cf. Hom. τέο 'wessen', πό-θι 'wo', Lat. quod 'was, welches', Goth. ƕas 'wer', Lith. kàs 'wer', etc.).}];294[452-479{S.v. *kʷó-, kʷí- 'wer?| irgendwer' Pronominalstamm, interrogativ| indefinit, wenn enklitisch| ?relativ. Cf. p.467 s.v. *kʷó-th₂ éh₁, *kʷó-tā 'genau wie' > Urar. *katʰā 'wie?' (Ved. kathā́, Av. kaθā̆).}]
Comment: cf. Sanskrit kathayati ʻconverses with, describesʼ (MBh.) (√kath-), derived from kathā- f. 'narration, telling how and why' (MBh.), ultimately derived from kathā 'how, why', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2703f., Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 148f.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit katháyati 'converses with, describes' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):135 no. 2703), derived from the Vedic interrogative adverb kathā́ 'how?' and further to the interrogative pronoun ká- 'who, which?' < PIE *kʷó-, *kʷí- ([EWAia](src-172) I:294-295, 284-285, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294):452-479).

Source: 442[773{S.v. Skt. 13401 siddha- (2) 'accomplished, skilled'.}];172[II:772-773{S.v. Ved. √sādh- 'zum Ziel gelangen, gelingen' (p.p.p. siddha- 'vollendet, erfolgreich'), probably to PIE *seh₁dʰ- ~ *sh₁dʰ- (cf. Arm. aǰ 'recht, dexter' < *sh₁dʰ-i̯o-).}];141[517{Cf. s.v. *seHdʰ- 'zum Ziel kommen, gelingen' (IEW 892).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ([EWAia](src-172) II:722-723, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):773 no. 13401, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 517).

Source: 399[II:298{S.v. Skt. púcchaḥ 'Schwanz, Schweif, Hinterteil', 'tail, hinder part'. Not convincingly explained. Perhaps a connection with OHG fuhs 'fox', etc.}];172[140{S.v. Ved. púccha- 'Schwanz, Schweif, Rute, Hinterteil'. Not satisfactorily explained. Worth considering remains the proposed connections with Germanic words for 'fox' (OHG fuhs, etc.).}];442[467{S.v. 8249 Ved. púccha- m.n. 'tail, hinder part' AV.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, although a connection with Germanic words for 'fox' (cf. OHG fuhs) remains worth considering ([EWAia](src-172) II:140, [KEWA](src-399) II:298; cf. also discussion in [Kroonen 2013](src-165):157-158). For Middle and Modern Indic cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):467, no. 8249.

Comment: cf. Skrt. jaḍa- 'stupid, dumb', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5090
< Skrt. ŚOCYATE 'is purified' (Turner 1931: 622), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12621; LIV, p. 331
Justification: Continuing Skt. śocyate 'is made to feel pain', the Sanskrit the passive of Vedic śocáyati 'sets alight, burns' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):732 no. 12621). The verbal root continues Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331).
Continuing Sanskrit jhāṭa- 'forest, arbour' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):296 no. 5362). Further etymology unclear ([KEWA](src-399) I:454).

Source: 442[510{S.v. 9078 Skt. *phirati intr. 'moves, wanders, turns'. 2. *phērayati 'makes moves &c.' 3. *phēra -- 'turn, turning'. [Cf. *pharati ʻ moves, turns ʼ (with phálati3, phḗlati ʻ goes ʼ Dhātup.). Poss. phar -- and phir -- are MIA. < *spar -- , *spir -- and belong to √spr̥ for which the basic meaning 'convey' (~ √pr̥) would account for the uses 'rescue (from: abl.)', 'help (towards: dat.)', 'attain, win' (cf. *sparati). With this Ir. *spar -- (usu. attributed to Sk. sphuráti: Bartholomae AirWb 1613 for Av. spar -- 'tread, hasten', Horn NPE 155) may be cognate in some of its meanings, e.g. Pers. sipardan 'to travel' (J. C. W.)]}]

Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):111 no. 2368 *ullaṭati 'turns over', 2. *ullaṭyate 'is upset' 3. ullāṭayati 'causes to turn over' from ud- + √laṭ-. Further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:87, III:95.

Source: 442[163{S.v. 3193 Ved. kīṭá- (1) m. 'insect, worm' ŚBr.}];172[I:355-356{Cf. s.v. Ved. kīṭá- 'eine Wurm-Art'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps a loanword.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):163 no. 3193, [EWAia](src-172) I:355-356).

Comment: from Vedic varṣám n. 1. ʻrain ʼ (RV+), pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV), 2. ʻyear' (ŚB) (root vr̥ṣ-), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 446, no. 1139: Pali vassa- m. n. ʻrainʼ, pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ, Prakrit vāsa- m. (or < vārṣa-), varisa- m. n. - NB. New Indo-Aryan forms are Sanskritisms - ultimately cognate with 'rain' in cognate set 1612

Source: 399[II:292{S.v. Skt. pītáḥ 'gelb', 'yellow'. Not satisfactorily explained. Relatively early attested (Sū., Up. etc.) but there are not yet any worthwhile connections in other IE languages.}];442[466{S.v. 8230 Skt. pīta- 'yellow', 8233 Skt. pītala (1) 'yellow' lex. 2. *pīthala- 3. *pīvala- 4. *pīvaḍa-| cf. also 8181 Skt. pittá- 'bile'.}];172[II:137{S.v. Ved. pīta- 'gelb'. Of unclear etymology. Perhaps connected with Ved. pittá- 'Galle'.}]
321[143{S.v. dam 'спина'}];325[29{"Š[ughni]X[ufi]R[oshani] upper part of the back."}]
Justification: Well attested in Pamir languages, origin uncertain.

Source: 442[452{S.v. 8019 Ved. pāṁśu- (MBh.), pāṁsú- (AV.) m. ʻcrumbling soil, dust, sandʼ.}];172[II:114-115{S.v. Ved. pāṁsú- 'Staub, Sand, zerbröckelnde Erde', further connections outside of Indo-Iranian are problematic.}];657[499{Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as from Vedic pāṁsú- 'soil, dust, sand' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):452 no. 452, further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ([EIEC](src-657) 499, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:114-115).

Source: 172[II:62{S.v. Ved. pakṣá- 'Flügel, Fittich, Schwinge' (Ind. Pā. pakkha- 'Flügel, Seite', pakkin- 'Vogel', etc.). Further connections remain unclear.}];442[429-430{S.v. 7627 pakṣá- m. 'wing, feather, fin, shoulder, side'.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *pakšá- 'wing, pinion', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):429-430 no. 7627, [EWAia](src-172) II:62).

Source: 172[I:564{S.v. Ved. jánghā- 'unterer Teil des Beines, Unterschenkel, Bein' (cf. YAv. zaṇga- 'Fußknöchel', Oss. zæng, zængæ 'Unterschenkel, Bein, Stiel'), probably a derivative of PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (cf. Goth. gaggan 'gehen', Lith. žeñgti 'schreiten', etc.).}];141[175-176{Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (IEW 438-9).}];442[280{S.v. 5082 Ved. jáṅghā- f. 'shank (ankle to knee)' RV.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic jáṅghā- 'leg', further derived from PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ([EWAia](src-172) I:564, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):280 no. 5082, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 175–176).

Source: 442[661{S.v. 11348 *varta-³ 'round stone' 2. *vārta -- . [Cf. Kurd. bard ʻ stone ʼ. -- √vr̥t-¹].}];399[III:154-156{Cf. s.v. Skt. vartate 'turns, rolls, revolves', vartulaḥ 'round, circular', derived from the PIE root *u̯ert- (cf. Lat. uertō 'wende, drehe, kehre', OIr. ad-ferta 'aversatur', Goth. wairϸan 'werden', etc.).}];141[691-692{Cf. s.v. u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11348 s.v. *varta- 'round stone', *'rolled / rolling stone', from PIE *uert- 'roll, rolled; turn, spin', cf. Skrt. vartula- 'round, circular', Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 156
Justification: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indo-Iranic *varta- *'turning around, circular object' → 'round stone', further to be derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to revolve' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):661 no. 11348, [KEWA](src-399) II:154-156, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 691-692).

Source: 338[{from PIr. *hvaǰ- / *hvaxšta-. Cf. Sogdian *xwanč in xwnčy, ʼnxwnč, ʼwxwnč 'struggle', Avestan pairiš-xʷaxta 'overtaken', Old Indic svaǰ-, svaǰate 'embrace'.}];172[II:788{Cf. s.v. Ved. √svañj- 'umarmen, umschlingen, umfassen', possibly from PIE *su̯eng- if can be compared to MHG swanc 'schwankend, beweglich' but this is not more than a possibility.}];141[610-611{Cf. s.v. ?*su̯eng- 'umarmen' (IEW 1047).}];156[IV:152-154{S.v. Oss. xæcyn : xæst | xwæcun : xwæst.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hu̯aǰ-, from Proto-Indo-Iranic *su̯aǰ-, cf. Ved. √svaj- ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:152-154). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:788, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 610-611 reconstructing ?*su̯eng- on the basis of the comparison of Old Irish seng 'schlank' < *'biegsam').

Source: 442[175{S.v. 3386 *kuha- (2) 'fog, mist', kuhēḍī-, ˚ḍikā-, kuhēlikā- , kūhā- f. lex.}]
Comment: from *kuha- 'fog, mist' according to Turner 1962-66, p. 175, no. 3386, perhaps related to guh- 'hide, conceil' (?); unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a stem *kuha-, further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):175 no. 3386).

Source: 399[I:456{S.v. Skt. ṭaṅkaḥ 'Bein', 'leg'. Etymology unclear, a few possible Munda correspondences suggested by Kuiper (1955) p.181 in Fs Kirfel.}];442[301{S.v. 5428 ṭaṅka- (3) (a) '*rod, spike', (b) m. 'leg' lex. 2. ṭaṅga- 3 m. 'leg' lex.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit ṭaṅka- ~ ṭaṅga- 'leg', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):301 no. 5428, [KEWA](src-399) I:456).

Source: 442[711{S.v. *śaṭa 'falling, rotting'.}]
Comment: < *śāṭa- ~ *śāda- 'falling, rotting', different blends of Vedic -śada- 'falling' with Sanskrit śāta- m. 'fallout' (śātana- n. 'the cutting off') and MIA -saṭá- (Pali); cf. Vedic (AV) parṇa-śadá- m. 'falling of leaves' ~ Pali paṇṇa-saṭá- 'heap of fallen leaves'; Turner 1962-66, no. 12267, 12381, 12386, Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 323; ultimately from PIE *k̑ad- 'fall', cf. ²LIV, p. 318 (IEW 516) - ATTENTION: Maithili साराब is VERB

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):279 no. 5071).

Source: 442[729{S.v. 12579 *śr̥ṅkhati, śíṅghati 'smells' Dhātup. [upaśiṅghati 'kisses' Bhaṭṭ., upaśiṅghana- n. 'a thing to be smelled at' Suśr. —√*śr̥ṅkh]}];172[II:652-653{Cf. s.v. śr̥ṅkhāṇikā- 'Rotz', perhaps with Pāli śiṅghati 'riecht' to a root *śr̥ṅkh- (cf. Turner 1962-1966:729). Not securely explained.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):729 no. 12579, [EWAia](src-172) II:652-653).

Source: 442[259{S.v. 4782 Skt. cikkáṇa- 'slippery, unctuous'. MBh.}];399[385{S.v. Skt. cikkáṇaḥ 'glatt, schlüpfrig' / 'smooth, slippery'. Perhaps a loan from Dravidian. Cf. Tamil cikku hängen bleiben, verwickelt werden, hängen klebben'.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4782
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit cikkaṇa- 'smooth, slippery' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):259 no. 4782). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Dravidian (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:385).

Source: 399[II:11-12{S.v. Skt. daṇḍáḥ 'Stock, Stab, Prügel', 'stick, staff, club' (since RV). A disputed, still undecided etymological problem.}];172[I:692{S.v. Ved. daṇḍá- 'Stock, Stab'. Etymology unexplained.}];442[350{S.v. 6128 Ved. daṇḍá- m. 'stick, club' RV.}]
Justification: Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick' No certain further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:692, [KEWA](src-399) II:11-12, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):350 no.6128).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10186
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a Sanskrit root √moṭ- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):586 no. 10186). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:692 for further discussion.

Source: 296[D:203-204{S.v. druimm 'dos, côte, colline'. Origin unclear, LEIA cites several suggestions, among others IEW 1075 suggests that Irish druim has been borrowed from Welsh trum, drum '(crest of) mountain or hill, peak, ridge, cliff, slope'. The Welsh word can be reconstructed as *treu̯smn̥.}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish druimm 'back'. Further etymology unclear, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:203-204 for various suggestions.

Source: 50[258{S.v. Proto-Celtic *māro- 'great', from PIE *moh₁-ro- (PIE *meh₁-), cf. OHG māri 'news| known, famous, great', Gk. -μωρος in compounds.}];296[M:18{S.v. OIr. már 'grand', common Celtic adjective (cf. Gaul. maros, W mawr, MCo. maur, Co.. mur, Bret. meur) to a root *mē- with a suffix *-ro-. The same adjective is attested a compound member in Gk. ἐγχεσί-μωρος, Slavic Volodi-měrŭ and Germanic (OHG Hlodo-mâr).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *māro- from PIE *meh₁-ro- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:18, [Matasović 2009](src-50):258).

Source: 50[410{S.v. Proto-Celtic *weli-, *woli- 'blood' from PIE < *u̯elh₂/₃- 'wound' (cf. Lat. uolnus 'wound', Gk. οὐλή 'scar').}];141[679{Cf. s.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' [IEW 1144-5]. If the Greek verb ἑάλων 'würde überwunden, wurde gefangen' does not belong to this root, then a reconstruction with final *h₂ is also possible.}];389[{Cf. now LIV² 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'.}];269[{Cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) for [LIV²](src-141) 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'. Tentatively I assign the lexemes in this class to the new root *u̯elh₂- 'beat, hit' assuming a semantic development 'beat, hit' > 'wound' > 'blood'. See further {ref {Lucht 2007}:65, [Matasović 2009](src-50):410.}];151[65{S.v. OIr. fuil 'blood', cf. W gweli 'Wunde', Co. goly, Bret. goulyow 'id.', generally connected to *wel- 'reißen| verwunden| töten' ([IEW](src-49) 1144f.), *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' ([LIV²](src-141) 679).}]
Justification: Cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) for [LIV²](src-141) 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'. The Celtic lexemes in this set have been tentatively assigned to the new root *u̯elh₂- 'beat, hit' assuming a semantic development 'beat, hit' > 'wound' > 'blood'. See further [Lucht 2007](src-151):65, [Matasović 2009](src-50):410.

Source: 50[211{S.v. Proto-Celtic *knāmi- 'bone' (OIr. cnáim), from PIE *konh₂m 'leg', cf. Gk. κνήμη 'leg', OE hamm 'ham'. The Old Irish lexeme is derived from the oblique stem *knh₂m-.}];66[723{Cf. s.v. Gk. κνήμη 'part between the knee and ankle, leg, shank', from PIE *kónh₂-m, *knh₂-m- 'bone, tibia, shank'.}];296[C:129-130{S.v. OIr. cnáim 'os'. One usually compares Gk. κνήμη 'jambe' and, in another ablaut grade *konmā in OHG hamma 'cuisse, jarret' (cf. OEng. hamm). This comparison is only possible by admitting the words go back to a base *knā- 'ronger'.}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing an Indo-European stem *konh₂m-, cf. Ancient Greek κνήμη 'leg', Old English hamm 'ham' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:129-130, [Matasović 2009](src-50):211, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):723).

Source: 50[301{S.v. Proto-Celtic *owgro- 'cold' (adj.) from PIE *h₃eu̯g- 'cold' (cf. Arm. oyc 'cold', Latv. aũksts 'cold').}];296[U:8{S.v. OIr. úar 'froid', the same lexeme in Brythonic (W. oer 'froid', MCo. oir). It is probable that the name of the month Ogron in the Coligny calendar, which is a month in winter, contains the same root *ougro-. Lidén adds Arm. ojc 'froid' and Lat. autumnus (if from auctumnus?)| this latter connnection is to be rejected. It is less more than doubtful that one can establish a base *ou- which for úar would derive from *oudro- in view of Lith. aušti 'il se refroidit'. But, we cannot separate it from Latv. aũksts 'cold' (cf. Ir. úacht). Cf. IEW 783.}];352[76{Cf. s.v. OLith. áusti 'kühl, kalt werden' (BSl. Latv. aũsît, aũsêt 'mit Kochlöffel schöpfend und zurückgießend abkühlen, damet der Kessel nicht überkocht', aũksts 'kalt', aũkstîgs 'anhaltend kalt', etc.), from PIE *h₃eu̯g̑- 'kalt' (cf. Arm. oyc 'kalt', OIr. úar 'kalt, kühl', úacht 'Kälte' MW oer 'kalt, kühl').}];534[88{S.v. Latv. auksts (cf. Lith. áušti).}]
Justification: Baltic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃eu̯g̑- 'cold' ([ALEW](src-352) 76, [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:22, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:8, [Matasović 2009](src-50):301).

Source: 269[{AGk. ἀριθμέω (and its descendants) is a denominative verb to ἀριθμός 'number', which itself is ultimately a derivative form in -θμ- formed to a zero-grade *h₂ri- from PIE *h₂rei- 'count'. The root without the -θμ- suffix is also found in the negative adjective νήριτος 'countless' < *n̥-h₂ri-to- (cf. Chantraine 1968-1980| Beekes 2010:131). Note *h₂rei̯- is a secondary verbal formation in Greek and not listed in LIV².}];66[131{S.v. ἀριθμός 'number| payment'. Beekes compares nominal forms in Old Norse rím (n.) 'account', Old High German rīm (m.) 'row, number', and OIr. rím 'number' connecting the forms to PIE *h₂rei̯- 'count'.}];179[281-282{S.v. Goth. R9. *raϸs 'λόγος', 'account, explanation' (L 16.2), 'ἀριθμός', 'number, count' (J 6.10, R 9.27)| *ga-raϸjan, only nom. pl. in p.a.pl. -ϸana 'ἀριθμεῖν', 'count', from PIE *ar-, *rē-, *rə- *rī̆- 'fit together' (cf. Lat. reor 'think, calculate', ratiō 'account', OIr. rīm 'number', rīmid 'counts', Wel. rhyf 'number', cyf-rif 'count, recount, narrate').}];50[313{S.v. Proto-Celtic *rīmā 'number, count', derived from PIE *h₂rei̯H- 'count' (IEW 60), cf. Gk. ἀριθμός 'number', OE rím 'number, calculation', TochB yärm 'measure'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂rei̯- 'to count, reckon' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):131, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):281-282, [Matasović 2009](src-50):313).

Source: 50[233-234{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', from PIE *leh₁t- 'warm part of the year(?)' (IEW 680), cf. OCS lěto 'year', Croat. ljȅto 'summer', Swed. (dial.) låding 'spring'.}];81[274{S.v. Proto-Slavic *lě̀to n. 'summer' (ESSJa XV 8-12), from PIE *leh₁-tóm (cf. OIr. laithe n. 'day').}];269[{While the cognacy of the Slavic and Celtic lexemes is not in dispute, the morphological segmentation of the root is less clear. We may be dealing with either an inherited t-stem to a root *leh₁- or a root *leh₁t- with a final dental. Either solution is plausible and both root forms are permissible to IE root structure constraints. The potential additional evidence from dialectal Swedish låding 'spring' (cf. s.v. låding in the Svensk Akademiens Ordbok: https://www.saob.se/artikel/?seek=l%C3%A5ding&pz=2, cf. Old Gutnish laϸigs) does not help settle this matter. [LIV²](src-141) *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' ([IEW](src-49) 666, 682-3) does not seem a semantically convincing candidate for a root etymology, nor is there a comparable verbal root *leh₁t- attested. [Derksen 2008](src-81):274-275 reconstructs *leh₁-tom underlying Proto-Slavic *lě̀to, while [Matasović 2009](src-50):233-234 reconstructs *leh₁ti-/leh₁ti̯o- to a basic root *leh₁t-. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form that is compatible with both the Slavic words meaning 'year' and the Celtic words meaning 'day', I give *leh₁t- as a the basic root.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', as though a *-i̯o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to a primary t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations below for more extensive discussion.

Source: 296[M:6{S.v. OIr. madrad (matrad) 'chien', various possible comparisons with different animal names within Celtic but all rather obscure. Perhaps of onomatopoeic origin?}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps of onomatopoeic origin? (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:6).

Source: 274[606-611{S.v. *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- n. 'Sonne' (IEW 881f., EIEC 556). The Goidelic Celtic forms represented by OIr. súil 'eye', etc. are from Proto-Celtic *sūli- < PIE *suh₂l-i- (cf. fn10 for further discussion and references to further literature).}];275[{Interesting develpment in Celtic: The Irish words for 'eye' are based on the word for 'sun', tne Brittonic ones on the root *leu̯k- 'to shine'.}];50[324{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sāwol-/*sūli- 'sun', from PIE *seh₂u̯ōl 'sun' (cf. Skt. sū́rya-, Gk. ἥλιος, Lat. sōl, Goth. sauil, Lith. sáulė). The semantic change in OIr. is understandable from the mythological context, where the 'sun' is viewed as 'the eye of the Sky'.}];296[S:201-202{S.v. OIr. súil 'œil', the word goes back originally to *sūli- and originally designated the 'sun', like Skt. sū́raḥ, sū́ryaḥ, Alb. hul. The Brythonic forms still designate the sun from *sāwel- (W. haul, MCo. heuul, Co. heul, houl, Bret. heol. The semantic change is explained by the fact that the sun was considered like an eye. This concept is widespread in Vedic, Homeric Greek, and Armenian (areg-akn 'eye of the sun').}]
Justification: From PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ([NIL](src-274) 606-611; for the semantics cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:201-202, [Matasović 2009](src-50):324).

Source: 50[393{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tud-o- 'fall', from PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'hit' (cf. Skt. tudáti, Lat. tundō, Goth. stautan).}];141[601{Cf. s.v. *(s)teu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1033-4). [Without Celtic cognates listed.]}];296[T:177-180{S.v. OIr. tuit- 'tomber'}];304[642-646{S.v. Proto-Celtic *-tud-e/o- 'fallen', derived to PIE *steu̯d- ([LIV²](src-141) 601| cf. [IEW](src-49) 1033f. s.v. *steu-d-).}]
Justification: Generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'hit, beat' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:177-180, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):642-646, [Matasović 2009](src-50):393; cf. {ref LIV² 601).

Source: 296[C:116{S.v. OIr. cleitte 'plume à écrire'. Doubtlessly comparable to eitte 'aile, plume', of which it would be an expressive variant (under the influence of clúm, clúit?). Otherwise maybe connected to the verb cel- 'cacher' and 'couvrir' and have later adapted the form of eitte.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Perhaps an expressive variant of Old Irish eitte 'feather', or a derivative of the verb cel- 'hide, cover' and subsequently contaminated with OIr. eitte ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:116).

Source: 50[205{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kiw-o- 'fog', generally connected to PIE *k̑ei̯H- 'gray' (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'gray', Lith. šývas, but Matasović comments "The derivation from the PIE root is doubtful both formally and semantically (for the phonetic development cf. OIr. béo from PCelt. *biwo- 'alive'). The vowel length could have been lost by Dybo's law if PIE end-stressed *kiH-wó- is posited. OE héow, hiw 'appearance' and the related Germanic words probably do not belong here ([Orel 2003](src-388): 171 relates them convincigly (sic!) to OE heawan 'to hew')."}];296[C:68-69{S.v. OIr. ceó 'nuée, brume, brouillard'. One may compare Goth. hiwi 'apparence', OE héow, hiw 'apparence, forme, visage, couleur', also with enlargement *kiē-wo- (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'brun foncé') or *kī-wo- (Lith. šývas 'blanchâtre', OCS sivŭ 'gris foncé').}];269[{Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:68-69, [IEW](src-49) 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ([Matasović 2009](src-50):205, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, [EWAia](src-172) II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this class).}]
Justification: Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:68-69, [IEW](src-49) 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ([Matasović 2009](src-50):205, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, [EWAia](src-172) II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).

Source: 296[T:112{S.v. OIr. torad 'produit, profit, résultat, fruit'. In all likelihood a compound of rith 'course' < *retu, the verbal noun of reth- 'courir'.}];50[310{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *retu- 'course' > OIr. ruith, rith.}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes probably continuing a compound containing Proto-Celtic *retu- 'course', and ultimately a derivative of PIE *ret- 'to run' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:112, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):310).

Source: 320[499, 270f.{S.v. Khot. heḍä, from *frā̆-bar-.}];50[62{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry, bear, bring', from PIE *bʰer- 'carry'.}];83[6-10{S.v. Proto-Iranian *bar- 'to bring, carry', from PIE *bʰer- 'bear, carry' + preverb *frā̆-.}];680[112{S.v. Khw. hβr- (cf. Sgd. M δβr-, C θbr- [θβar-], Khot. haur- < *fra-bara-).}]
Justification: Iranic (and Celtic) lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):6-10, [Bailey 1979](src-320):499, [MacKenzie 1990](src-680):112, [Matasović 2009](src-50):62). Late parallel replacement/shift in Celtic, [cognate set 1709](cog-1709).

Source: 50[408-409{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wegro- 'grass'. There are competing IE etymologies. Matasović favours a connection with PIE *h₂eu̯g- / *h₂u̯eg- 'grow' (cf. Lat. augeō, Goth. aukan 'increase') if one allows a Schwebeablaut. Alternatively Lubotsky [cited as 'p.c.' in the entry] suggests a connection with Lat. uegeō 'enliven', OHG wahhēn 'to be awake' < PIE *u̯eg̑- 'be lively' (IEW 1117-8, LIV 601) which is formally better, but would involve a more complex semantic development.}]
Justification: Of uncertain etymology, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):408-409 for various proposals.
No certain etymology outside of Goidelic, cf. [Lucht 2007](src-151):199 for further discussion.

Source: 50[132{S.v. Proto-Celtic *flāmā 'palm, hand', from PIE *pl̥h₂meh₂ 'palm, hand' (cf. IEW 833, *pelh₂- IEW 805-07).}];54[441{Cf. s.v. Lat. palma 'front part of the hand', from PIE *plh₂-em-h₂- 'flat, wide' (cf. OIr. lám, W. llaw, Gk. παλάμη 'palm of the hand', OHG folma 'hand', OEng folm 'flat hand').}];274[562-564{S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.). Cf. Celt. *lāma- in OIr. lám, MW llaw, OCo. lof, OBret. lom 'Hand', and etymologically identical with Gk. παλάμη '(flache) Hand, Handhabe, Mittel', Lat. palma 'flache Hand, etc. < *pl̥h₂-mo/ah₂-.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes derived from a stem *pl̥h₂-mo/eh₂- to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, broad' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):132, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Source: 50[391{S.v. Proto-Celtic *trummo- 'heavy', cf. PIE *treu̯d- 'thrust, press' (IEW 1095f.), cf. Lat. trudō 'thrust, push', Goth. us-þriutan 'to maltreat', OCS trudъ 'trouble'. The stem derivation is disputed, perhaps from  *trud-smo-, *trud-mo- or *truks-mo-. Cf. entry for discussion and further references.}];141[651-652{Cf. s.v. *treu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1095-6).}];296[T:149-151{S.v. OIr. trom 'lourd' corresponding exactly to OW trumm, MW trwm, OBret. trom, trum 'lourd', derived from *trud-smo-, cf. Lat. trudō, etc.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes generally derived from PIE *treu̯d- 'to thrust, push', although the specific stem-formation is disputed ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:149-151, [Matasović 2009](src-50):391, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 651-652).

Source: 296[B:109{S.v. OIr. buailid (bualaid) 'il frappe, bat, attaque'. Cf. for a summary of various attempts at an etymology by [IEW](src-49). Possibly of expressive origin.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:109 for a summary of older attempts at an etymology in [IEW](src-49).

Source: 50[329{S.v. Proto-Celtic *selgā 'hunt' (noun), from which the verbal forms are derived, based on PIE *selg̑- 'send away, set loose' (cf. Skt. sr̥játi 'sets loose, discharges', AGk. (dial.) λαγάσαι 'to set free', MHG selken 'to trickle, drip'). MoBret. emholc'h is from *ambi-selg-o-.}];309[325{Cf. s.v. Bret. hel'ch 'fait d'être essoufflé', from Old Breton holg 'recherche, enquête, chasse' and corresponding to Co. helgh 'chasse', and Olr. seilg 'chasse'.}];141[528-529{Cf. s.v. *selg̑- 'loslassen, entsenden' (IEW 900-1).}];240[82{S.v. OW helcha and helgha(ti) 'to hunt', from Britt. *selg- < PIE *selg̑- 'loslassen, ensenden, werfen, ausgießen'.}];296[S:80-81{S.v. 1 selg- 'chasse' and 'fait de chasser', to be connected with a root *selg- seen in Skt. sr̥játi 'il lance, il fait courir'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes, denominal verbal formations based on Proto-Celtic *selgā 'hunt', a derivative of PIE *selg̑- 'to let go, release, send away' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):329, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:80-81, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):82, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):325, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 528-529).

Source: 728[187{S.v. Manx gearaghtee 'laughing' (ScG. gàireachdaich).}];231[186{S.v. ScG. gàir 'laugh', gàire 'a laugh' (Ir. gáirim, gáire, OIr. gáire (n.)) from root *gar- as OIr. gáir, W gawr (cf. Gk. γῆρυς, Doric γᾶρυς 'voice').}];141[161{Cf. s.v. *g̑ar- 'tönen, rufen' (IEW 352).}];304[331-334{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gar-i̯e/o- 'rufen, schreien' (PIE *g̑ar- LIV 161).}];50[153{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gar-yo- 'call, cry', from PIE *g̑eh₂r-, cf. Lat. garrīre, Oss. zaryn/zarun 'sing'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- (?*g̑eh₂r-) 'to sound, call' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):331-334, [Matasović 2009](src-50):153, [LIV²](src-141) 161, cf. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):186, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):187).

Source: 151[241{S.v. OIr. fota, fata 'long'. Internal reconstruction suggests possibly earlier *woddio-/*waddio-. There are no correspondences within Celtic, and no known etymology outside of Celtic. A connection with Lat. vastus 'weit' was considered in older literature (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1113-1114).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ([Lucht 2007](src-151):241).

Source: 50[271-272{S.v. Proto-Celtic *mīlo- 'animal', from PIE *meh₁lo- 'small animal' (IEW 724), cf. Gk. μῆλον, OCS malъ 'small'.}];66[944{Cf. s.v. μῆλον (2) 'small cattle, sheep and goats', from PIE *meh₁lo- 'small cattle'.}];296[M:51{S.v. OIr. míl 'animal en général, surtout animal de petite taille', from IE *mēlo- preserved in Greek μῆλον and Germanic mâla in the Salic Law.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mīlo- 'animal' continuing PIE *meh₁lo- 'small animal' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:51, [Matasović 2009](src-50):271-272).

Source: 151[254{S.v. OIr. feóil 'flesh' both of living and dead bodies, often of meat| internal reconstruction on this word within Irish is not possible and there is no known etymology elsewhere in Celtic.}]
Justification: No known etymology outside of Goidelic ([Lucht 2007](src-151):254).

Source: 296[S:131{S.v. OIr. slíab 'montagne', later also 'terrain de montagne, lande'. Considered an enlargement *sleib- to a root *(s)lei- 'glisser, glissant' (cf. OHG slipf 'lapsus', MHG slīfan 'glisser'. In this case sliab would have originally signified 'pente (glissante)', but this explanation is not semantically satisfactory. Consequently the etymology remains uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally considered to be from PIE *(s)lei̯b- 'drag, glide' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:131, cf. {ref LIV² 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b-, [IEW](src-49) 663) via an original meaning '(slippery) slope', but [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) finds this development semantically dubious.

Source: 50[419{S.v. Proto-Celtic *we-wlo- 'lip' (OIr. bél, MW gwefl). The reconstruction of the Proto-Celtic form is difficult, but the forms are doubtlessly related. No clear etymology outside of Celtic.}];296[B:29{S.v. OIr. bél 'lèvre' in plural 'bouche'. Various etymologies have been proposed that suppose a -l- added to a root which has the form *gʷet- signifying 'parler' or 'enfler, gonfler', or to the form *bʰes- (cf. Lat. basium). These etymologies are valueless. In view of W gwefl 'lèvre, lippe' (des humains ou des animaux), MBret. guefl 'gueule', Bret. geol 'id.' one would like to see in bél an old reduplicated form from a root *bel- preserved in Ir. belach and bil (cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):117).}]
Justification: The Goidelic forms in this class from Old Irish bél 'lip; (pl.) mouth' are doubtlessly connected to Middle Welsh gwefl 'lip', but the reconstruction of a Proto-Celtic preform is difficult ([Matasović 2009](src-50):419), cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:29 for a survey of older, unconvincing suggestions.

Source: 50[220{S.v. Proto-Celtic *koylo- 'thin'. Perhaps from PIE *koi̯Hlo- if connected with Latv. kaîls 'naked, bold', but the reconstruction is uncertain and the semantic comparison is not very good.}];296[C:6{S.v. OIr. cáel 'mince, étroit' later forms cóel, cáel, caol. Corresponds exactly to Brythonic forms in W cul 'étroit', OBret., Corn. cul 'id.', and a Gaulish PN Coilos (gen. Coili) which is perhaps the same word. These forms presuppose Proto-Celtic *koi̯lo-, which may find a connection in Latv. kaîls 'nu, chauve, simple'.}]
Justification: Perhaps further from PIE *koi̯(H)lo- if connected with Latvian kaîls 'naked, bald', but the comparative semantics are rather remote (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:6, [Matasović 2009](src-50):220).

Comment: From Old Irish gar 'short; near'

Source: 50[276{S.v. Proto-Celtic moni- 'neck', from PIE *moni- 'neck' (IEW 747f.), cf. Skt. mányā- 'neck', Lat. monīle 'necklace', OHG mana 'mane', Av. manaoθrī- 'neck'.}];172[II:313{S.v. Ved. mányā- (Du., Plur.) 'Nacken', from PIE *mon- with different stem derivations (OIr. muinēl 'Hals' [*°iklo-], OHG man[a] 'Mähne' [*°eh₂-]).}];296[M:72{S.v. OIr. muin 'cou| partie supérieure du dos'| a word common to Celtic. Outside of Celtic it my be connected with Lat. monīle 'collier' and Skt. manyā 'nuque', as well as ON mǫn, etc. The root of all these words is *men- 's'élever, être proéminent', cf. Lat. ē-minēre, etc. (IEW 726).}];49[726, 747-748{S.v. 1. *men- 'emporragen' & s.v. *mono- 'Nacken, Hals'.}];141[437{Cf. s.v. ?3. *men- 'emporragen' (IEW 726).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *3. men- 'to rise, stick up' ([EWAia](src-172) II:313, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):566 no. 9858, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:72, [Matasović 2009](src-50):276, cf. [IEW](src-49) 726, 747-748, [LIV²](src-141) 437).

Source: 296[A:14{S.v. OIr. adaig 'nuit'. Without certain etymology.}]
Justification: No certain etymology; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:14 for a survey of various hypotheses.

Source: 300[{S.v. OIr. imm-beir 'to carry around| play (a game), gamble, stake| etc.'}];50[62{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry, bear, bring', from PIE *bʰer- 'carry'.}];294[35-40{Cf. s.v. *ánbʰi 'um – herum, ringsum' (Adverb, lokal| oft mit Akk., Lok.). Proto-Celtic *ámbi > OIr. imbᴸ < PIE *án/n̥bʰí.}];304[218-219{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-e/o- 'tragen, bringen' < PIE *bʰer-.}];141[76-77{S.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).}]
Justification: The Goidelic forms in this class are from a compound imm·beir < Proto-Celtic *ambi- (preverb) 'around' (< PIE *h₂(e)mbʰi- or ámbʰi) + *ber- 'carry' (< PIE *bʰer-), cf. {Schumacher 2004}:218-233, [Matasović 2009](src-50):62, [LIV²](src-141) 76-77, [LIPP 2](src-294) 36.

Source: 728[443-444{S.v. Manx tayrn 'drawing, dragging, rowing, pulling| catch (of fish)' = Ir. tarraing.}];296[S:184-185{S.v. OIr. sreng- 'tirer, traîner'.}]
Justification: The Modern Goidelic forms in this class derive from the OId Irish compound do·srenga.

Source: 50[96{S.v. Proto-Celtic *dergo- 'red, blood red', from PIE *dʰerg- 'dark' (IEW 251), cf. OEng. deorc 'dark', Lith. dárgana- 'bad weather', dérgti 'to become dirty', (?) TochB tarkär 'cloud'.}];296[D:57-58{S.v. OIr. derg 'rouge, sanglant', one connects OE deorc 'sombre', Engl. dark, OHG tarchanjan 'obscurcir', which suppose a root *dʰerg-.}];697[153{Cf. s.v. Gmc. derka- 'dunkel', the word can be identical with OIr. derg (o-stem) 'rot (bes. von Blut)', perhaps further to be compared with Lith. dérgti 'schmutzig werden, sich besudeln'.}]
Justification: Generally connected with Germanic words for 'dark' < *dʰerg- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:57-58, [Matasović 2009](src-50):96; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):153, [IEW](src-49) 251).

Source: 274[311-317{Cf. s.v. PIE *h₂ep- 'water, river' (Anatolian and Baltic), ?*h₂ep-h₃on- 'river' (Celtic).}];80[294-295{S.v. Hitt. ḫapa- 'river', (cf. Pal. ḫāpna- 'river', CLuw. ḫāpa/i- 'river', HLuw. hapa/i- 'river') < PAnat. *h₂ebo- < PIE *h₂ebʰ-o-, *h₂ebʰ-n- (cf. OIr. aub, gen. abae), MWe. afon 'river', Lat. amnis 'stream, river'.}];269[{Since [Watkins 1973](src-711) the Celtic words have been connected to Hittite and Palaic words for 'river' from a PIE n-stem *h₂ebʰ-n-, more recently followed by [Willi 2004](src-710) and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):294-295 s.v. Hitt. ḫapa-. A popular alternative analysis reconciles the Celtic words with Indo-Iranic words for 'water' (cf. [cognate set 157](cog-157)) and Baltic and Nuristani lexemes for 'river' (cf. [cognate set 7856](cog-7856)) via a derivation using the 'Hoffmann Suffix' *h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):23-24 s.v. Proto-Celtic *abon-| [NIL](src-274) 311-317 tentatively reconstructs for Celtic ?*h₂ep-h₃on-, cf. [NIL](src-274) with references to further literature), but this analysis must assume an inner-PIE development *-ph₃- > *-b- (e.g. *pi-ph₃-e-ti > Ved. píbati '(s)he drinks'| cf. Lat. bibō with voicing assimilation to the reduplicated syllable). Since the number of examples of *-ph₃- > *-b- are few in number, this must remain a conjectural proposal.  The cognacy in this class therefore follows the etymology of [Watkins 1973](src-711) to a root *h₂ebʰ-.}];50[23-24{S.v. Proto-Celtic *abon- 'river', from PIE *h₂ep-h₃on- 'river' (cf. Hitt. hāpa- Pal. hāpna-, Lat. amnis). The root may be cognate with PIE *h₂ep- (cf. Skt. áp- 'water', OPr. ape 'brook') with a "(?possessive)" suffix *-h₃on- under the assumption that *ph₃ > b (as in *piph₃eti 'drinks' > Skt. píbati).}];296[A-4-5{S.v. OIr. ab 'rivière'. A pre-form *abā is assumed for Germanic which continues river names in -apa, OHG -affa, on the other hand Lat. amnis can come from *abni-. One separates a common root *ab- in the western languages for courses of water. This perhaps corresponds to an Indo-Iranian root *ap- in Skt. āpaḥ 'the waters', Av. āfš 'water'.}];711[80-89{Proposes cognacy of Celtic lexemes for 'river' (OIr. ab, aub, W afon) with Anatolian lexemes for 'river' (Hitt. ḫapa-, Pal. ḫāpna-).}];775[73{Lists place-names containing 'aven', e.g. Coetaven (1444), Pen-Aven (1672). These are all located in the departement Finistère (29).}];275[{In Middle Breton, auon 'river' is known and used by educated people. The example from the Catholicon illustrates its use in a religious context. In this context, it probably was also current to illiterate speakers. It remains however unclear, if it was the Swadesh term for 'river'. Place-names with auon are restricted to Western Brittany, and it is not used any more in Modern Breton. The Catholicon also has an entry for riuyer, borrowed from French. This word is used today in Treger Breton.  The Gwened word gwaz is listed s.v. goaz with the equivalents Middle French russeau, Latin hic riuulus. It denotes thus smaller water courses in Middle Breton.}]
Justification: Anatolian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ebʰ-. Since [Watkins 1973](src-711) the Celtic words have been connected to Hittite and Palaic words for 'river' from a PIE n-stem *h₂ebʰ-n-, more recently followed by [Willi 2004](src-710) and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):294-295 s.v. Hitt. ḫapa-. A popular alternative analysis reconciles the Celtic words with Indo-Iranic words for 'water' (cf. [cognate set 157](cog-157)) and Baltic and Nuristani lexemes for 'river' (cf. [cognate set 7856](cog-7856)) via a derivation using the 'Hoffmann Suffix' *h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):23-24 s.v. Proto-Celtic *abon-; [NIL](src-274) 311-317 tentatively reconstructs for Celtic ?*h₂ep-h₃on-, cf. [NIL](src-274) with references to further literature), but this analysis must assume an inner-PIE development *-ph₃- > *-b- (e.g. *pi-ph₃-e-ti > Ved. píbati '(s)he drinks'; cf. Lat. bibō with voicing assimilation to the reduplicated syllable). Since the number of examples of *-ph₃- > *-b- are few in number, this must remain a conjectural proposal.  The cognacy in this class therefore follows the etymology of [Watkins 1973](src-711) to a root *h₂ebʰ-. Cf. also [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:4-5.

Source: 151[331-332{S.v. OIr. gainem 'sand'. Without secure correspondences in other Celtic languages or elsewhere in Indo-European. The word should possibly be considered of non-IE origin.}]
Justification: Without secure correspondences elsewhere in Celtic or other Indo-European languages; perhaps a non-Indo-European substratum borrowing ([Lucht 2007](src-151):331-332).

Source: 659[312{Suggests a derivation from *foirsge, an abstract noun of fairsing 'ample, broad, spacious'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, an old proposal of [Thurneysen 1917](src-659):312 connects with Old Irish fairsing 'broad, spacious'.

Source: 296[U:3{S.v. 3 úag- 'coudre, lier, assembler'|}]

296[C:203, T:170{S.v. OIr. con-tuili 'il dort, s'endort', a compound of the verb tuil- 'dormir', from the root *tel- 'souffrir, supporter', cf. OCS toliti 'calmer, endormir (causatif), Lith. tyléti 'se taire' (Gk. τλῆναι 'supporter', Goth. ϸulan 'souffrir', Arm. tʻołum 'je laisse', Lat. tollō, etc.).}];50[382-383{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tol-ī-yo- 'sleep', from PIE *(s)telH- 'be quiet, be still' (IEW 1061f.), cf. OHG stillen 'make still', Lith. tylà 'quiet person', tìliti 'fall silent', OCS u-toliti 'quench, soothe'.}];141[621{S.v. *telH- 'still werden' (IEW 1061-2).}]
Justification: From PIE *telH- 'become quiet' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):382-383; [LIV²](src-141) 621). NB: [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:170 conflated two roots *tel- now reconstructed separately as *telH- ([LIV²](src-141) 621) and *telh₂- ([LIV²](src-141) 622); [LIV²](src-141) 621 s.v. *telH- does not connect the Germanic lexemes connected to OHG stillen as [Matasović 2009](src-50).

Source: 50[210{S.v. Proto-Celtic *klukā 'stone, rock' "In all likelihood, this PCelt. etymon was borrowed from some non-IE language."}];296[C:123-124{S.v. OIr. cloch 'pierre, caillou', possibly from Proto-Celtic *klukā (Stokes), but the -u- vocalism is uncertain. No certain connections outside of Celtic.}]
Justification: No certain connections outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:123-124, [Matasović 2009](src-50):210).

Source: 296[A:101{S.v. OIr. att 'tumeur, enflure', from which attaid 'il gonfle'. No plausible etymology, cf. entry for various proposals.}]
Justification: No plausible etymology ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:101).

Source: 296[S:143-144{S.v. OIr. smúain- 'penser, réfléchir, considérer| méditer'| has been connected to Goth. ga-maudjan 'rappeler à la mémoire', Lith. ãp-maudas 'chagrin, souci', OCS myslь, Gk. μῦθος 'parole', μυθέομαι 'je parle, réfléchis' to a root *meudh- 'penser à', etc. The diphthong -úa- of Irish may be a from a long -ō- or diphthong -ou- or just as well a compensatory lengthening from earlier *smudn- and the initial group shows an alternation *sm- : m-, but this is difficult to elucidate given the lack of Brythonic correspondences. (cf. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231) 331, [Pedersen 1909](src-307):113, 185, 296, 317, [IEW](src-49) 743).}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Goidelic difficult to establish with certainty. Cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:143-144 for previous proposals and further discussion.

Source: 296[C:65{S.v. OIr. cengal 'lien, ceinture, attache, entrave' with derived verb cenglaid 'il attache', a borrowing from Lat. cingulum 'ceinture, cinturon, sangle (du harnais)'.}]
Justification: Derived from Old Irish cengal 'link, belt, tie', a loanword from Latin cingulum 'belt' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:65).

Source: 151[397{Cf. Ir. fíacail 'a tooth, a tusk', of unknown etymology, perhaps a loanword from a substratum language. A connection with OIr. fec 'Spaten' (in glosses also 'tooth') is possible.}]
Justification: No known etymology; perhaps a substratum loanword (cf. [Lucht 2007](src-151):397).

Source: 50[181{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷresno- 'wood, tree' from PIE *kʷres- 'bush, thicket' (IEW 633), cf. OEng. hryst 'bushes'.}];296[C:222-223{S.v. OIr. crann 'arbre| bois (matière)', corresponding to W, Co., Bret. prenn 'arbre, bois' and may go back to *kʷr̥sno- for Ir. crann and *kʷresno- for Brythonic and Gaulish, to a base *kʷres- which can be seen in W prys 'buissons, boqueteau'| with the same suffix (*kʷr̥s-to-) in OE hyrst 'broussailles, taillis), cf. [IEW](src-49) 633.}]

50[55{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bāno- 'white, shining', from a PIE deverbal adjective *bʰeh₂-no- 'shining'. For derivatives of the same root, cf. Skt. bhā́ti 'shines', Av. bānu- 'beam of light', Gk. φαίνω 'show, appear'.}];141[68-69{Cf. s.v. 1. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (IEW 104-5).}];274[7-11{S.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (LIV 68f., IEW 104f.).}];296[B:13{S.v. OIr. bán 'blanc', from IE *bhā-no- or *bhō-no- from a root *bhā- or *bhē- 'briller, luire' from which the Sanskrit verb bhā́ti 'il brille' and substantive bhánam 'éclat lumineux', cf. also Gk. φάος 'lumière', etc.}]

Comment: etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 64)

Source: 50[70{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bodyo- 'yellow', from IE *bodyo- 'yellow' ([IEW](src-49) 92), cf. Lat. badius 'bay, chestnut brown'. "Lat. badius can be derived from *bodyos (with *o > a after labials, as in mare < *mori), but the initial *b-, and the fact that this adjective is limited in its distribution to Italic and Celtic, make it likely that we are dealing with a loanword from some non-IE source."}];151[443{S.v. OIr. buide 'yellow' (most unmarked form for 'yellow'). OIr. buide may derive from either Proto-Goidelic *bodio- or *badio-. There are no certain correspondences in Brythonic, but perhaps Gaulish bodio- in Bodio-casses may belong here. The word is generally compared with Lat. badius 'kastanienbraun', without further correspondences. From this comparison three etymologies have been proposed: (1) OIr. buide, Lat. badius < PIE *badios ([IEW](src-49) 92), where the correspondence of the root vowel (Lat. -a-, Celt. -o-) remains unexplained (but there are parallels in, e.g. Lat. lacus, OIr. loch)| (2) OIr. buide, Lat. badius < PIE (Italo-Celtic?) *bodio- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B-113) with *-o- > Lat. -a- as in Lat. mare < PIE *mori- 'sea'| (3) [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):358 suggests Proto-Celtic *ba-dyo- < PIE *bʰə-dyo- to the root *bʰā- / *bʰō- / *bʰə- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen (cf. [IEW](src-49) 104f.), in which case the Celtic word would be borrowed into Latin. In this case however the Gaulish attestation of the form Bodio- would be in need of an explanation.}]
Justification: Generally compared with Latin badius 'bay, chestnut brown', but without any further correspondences elsewhere in Indo-European; cf. [Lucht 2007](src-151) for extensive discussion of alternative proposed etymologies (cf. also [Matasović 2009](src-50):70, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:113, [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):358, [IEW](src-49) 104-105).

Source: 444[536{S.v. 6494 *pīkk- (Schallwort) 'klein'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes based on a stem *pīkk-, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):536)

Source: 442[621{S.v. 10755 Skt. *rukta ʻ bright, liked ʼ. [√ruc]. (> K. r˚tu, f. rüċü 'good, excellent, beautiful, sweet')}];172[II:463-464{Cf. s.v. Ved. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen', from PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten' (cf. Gk. λευκός 'light, white', etc.).}];141[418-419{Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).}]
Justification: As through from Sanskrit *rukta- 'bright, liked' to Vedic √roc- 'to shine', further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to be bright' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):621 no. 10755, [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Source: 442[201{S.v. 3832 Skt. kharvá- (RV. ákharva) 'mutilated, imperfect'.}];172[I:448-449{S.v. Ved. kharvá- (adj.) 'verstümmelt, krüppelhaft, zwerghaft' (cf. Pkt. khavva- m. 'linke Hand', kati kawə 'left-hand' etc. (T. 3832). Cf. YAv. kauruua-, kauruuō if the terms mean 'verstümmelt' (and not 'kahl'). Further connections are unclear.}]
Justification: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Proto-Indo-Iranic kʰaru̯á- 'mutilated, imperfect' (cf. Ved. kharvá- 'mutilated' [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):201 no. 3832), possibly further connected within Indo-Iranic to Avestan kauruua- if the term means 'mutilated', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([EWAia](src-172) I:448-449).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron lenk kɜn-ən 'swim': light verb construction with 'do' [cognate set 5037](cog-5037). Lexical stem is either onomatopoeic or from East Caucasian.  In either case it is an Iron innovation.}];156[II:41-42{Cf. s.v. lenk 'плавание', lenk kænyn 'плыть, плавать'.}]
Comment: Bielmeier (1979: 189 in: Historische Untersuchung zum Erb- und Lehnwortschatzanteil im ossetischen Grundwortschatz, Frankfurt/Bern/Las Vegas: Lang) argues against the assumption that lenk is a loan from Caucasian languages and discusses the possibility of an IE origin by comparing it with Lithuanian leñgvas 'light' and Germanic *lenhw-ta-z (cf. Gothic leihts).

Source: 442[725-726{S.v. 12520 Skt. śuddhá- 'clean, bright, white'.}];172[II:657{S.v. Ved. √śodh- 'reinigen, rein machen'. IIr. *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- perhaps from PIE *(s)k̑eu̯-dʰ- with a root enlargement of *(s)k̑eu̯-, but connections outside IIr. otherwise unclear.}];141[330{Cf. s.v. ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'rein werden' (IEW 595)| only Indo-Iranian cognates.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic śuddhá- 'clean, bright, white', a derivative of Vedic √śodh- 'to clean, to make clean' and further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):725-726 no. 12520, [EWAia](src-172) II:657). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, [LIV²](src-141) 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.

Source: 442[666{Cf. s.v. 11418 Skt. valkala- 'bark, bark garment (worn by ascetics)'.}];172[II:525-526{S.v. Ved. valká- 'Bast, Rinde, Splint'| cf. Middle Indic and Prakrit vakka- 'bark'. Probably to be related to YAv. varəka-, Khot. bāggara-, Parth. wrgr, Sogd. wrkr, MPers. warg, NPers. barg 'leaf'. Perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre'.}];81[526{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *volknò 'fibre' (< PIE *u̯olk̑-nom, cf. OE wlōh 'fibre, fringe' [no connection to Indo-Iranic lexemes mentioned]).}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre' ([EWAia](src-172) II:525-526, but cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):526). For Modern Indic forms in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):666, no. 11418.

Source: 442[304{S.v. 5476 *ṭōkk- 'strike, bite'. 2. *ṭōkka- 3. *ṭōkkarā-.}]
Justification: From Indic *ṭōkk- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):304, no. 5476. No further etymology.

Source: 442[795{S.v. 13776 Ved. sthūlá- 'large, thick, stout' AV. [~ sthūrá- ] >  K. ṭhūl m. 'egg'.}];172[II:768-769{S.v. Ved. sthūra- 'groß, stark, dick, wuchtig' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (cf. Old Swedish stūr 'groß', Middle Dutch stūr 'groß, stark').}]
Justification: From Vedic sthūlá- 'large, thick', a variant of Vedic sthūrá- 'id.' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):795 no. 13776), ultimately from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ([EWAia](src-172) II:768-769, [NIL](src-274) 639). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in [cognate set 7106](cog-7106).

Source: 172[II:815-816{S.v. Ved. himá- 'Kälte, Frost' < PIE *g̑ʰi̯em-/*g̑ʰim- (cf. Av. ziiā̊ 'Winter').}];274[162-169{S.v. ?*g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- 'Winter, Schnee' (IEW 425f., EIEC 504).}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic himá- 'cold, frost' ([EWAia](src-172) II:815-816). From the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted, to which was derived an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- ([NIL](src-274) 162-169).

Source: 759[376{Cf. s.v. no. 114 Skt. khura- 'hoof', KatySrS., Mn., etc. ~ Ta. kuracu, kuraccai 'horse's hoof', Ka. gorasu, gorise, Te. gorije, gorise, korise 'id.'}];172[I:454{S.v. Skt. khura- 'Huf, Klaue'. "Nicht überzeugend erklärt.'}];442[207{S.v. 3906 Skt. khura- m. ʻhoofʼ (KātyŚr̥), 2. *khuḍa (khuḍaka, khula° ʻankle, boneʼ Suśr.) ← Dravidian origin.}];399[I:310{Cf. s.v. Skt. khúraḥ 'Huf / hoof', probably a Dravidian word, cf. Tel. korije, gorije, gorise, Kan. gorasu, gorise = Drav. *kŏr- 'Huf' with typical Dravidian variants (Burrow BSOS 9, 718| 12, 376).}]
Justification: Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):207 no. 3906; [KEWA](src-399) I:310, [EWAia](src-172) I:454, cf. [Burrow 1948](src-759):376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in [cognate set 9630](cog-9630), but these could also be parallel loans.

Source: 442[610{S.v. Skt. rakta- (1) 'coloured, dyed' ŚBr., 'red' ŚāṅkhGr̥., n. 'blood' Mn., °aka -- 'red' VarBr̥S. [√rañj].}];172[II:424-425{Cf. s.v. Ved. √raj-¹ 'sich färben, sich röten, rot werden', from PIE *(s)reg- (cf. Gk. ῥέζω 'färbe', ῥῆγος 'Teppich', ῥογεύς 'Färber' etc.).}];141[587{Cf. s.v. *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- '(sich) färben' (IEW 854).}];681[46{S.v. Khw. rxtk 'red', from Ir. *raxtaka- (cf. Skt. rakta-) with exceptional preservation of -xt-.}];83[313-314{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- 'to colour, dye', from PIE *(s)reg- 'to colour (dark)' (cf. Skt. raj- 'to colour, become red', Gk. ῥέζω 'I dye, paint', ῥῆγος 'carpet, rug', ῥογεύς 'dyer').}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. [cognate set 6611](cog-6611)
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *raktá- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):610, no. 10539; [EWAia](src-172) II:424-425, [Cheung 2007](src-83):313-314 [Henning 1971](src-681):46, [LIV²](src-141) 587).

Source: 442[211{S.v. 3952 Ved. gáṅgā f. 'the river Ganges' RV. (> Si. gan̆ga, pl. gaṅ 'river')}];172[I:457{S.v. Ved. gáṅgā- 'Flußname, Ganges' "Originally only a appellative 'Fluß' and a reduplicated formation to √gam-? Although this etymology might be possible, it is just as likely that it is a pre-IE river name.}]
Comment: originally name of the river Ganges, cf. Vedic gaṅgā f.
Justification: Continuing Vedic gáṅgā- '(river name), Ganges' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):211 no. 3952), further etymology uncertain. Perhaps a reduplicated nominal formation to Vedic √gam- 'to go' (< PIE *gʷem-) or a pre-IE river name.

Source: 399[II:150-151{S.v. Skt. nāgaḥ 'Schlange, Schlangendämon| Elefant', 'snake, serpent-demon| elephant'. Not securely explained.}];442[404{S.v. 7039 Skt. nāgá-¹ m. 'snake' (> Si. nay, nā, nayā 'snake').}];172[II:33{S.v. Ved. nāga- 'Elefant' (AitB.+), 'Schlange' (ŚB +), probably in both meanings 'the hairless, naked animal'.}]
Comment: < Vedic nāgá- m. 'snake' (ŚB); perhaps cognate with [cognate set 1358](cog-1358) - but later also used for 'elephant', perhaps rather < PIE *nogʷó- 'naked', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 151 for further suggestions
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāgá- 'elephant; snake' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):404 no. 7039). Further etymology not certainly explained, possibly a derivative of PIE 2. *negʷ- 'naked' if the original meaning was 'the hairless, naked animal' (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:150-151, [EWAia](src-172) II:33 [NIL](src-274) 513-515 for further discussion).

Source: 442[133{S.v. 2661 Ved. káṇa- m. 'a grain of corn' AV., 'drop (of water)' Kāv., kaṇikā- f. 'a single grain' MBh.}];172[I:291{S.v. Ved. káṇa- 'Korn, Samenkorn'. Etymology unclear.}]
Comment: cf. Old Vedic káṇa- m. 'grain of corn' (AV), later 'drop of water' via 'particle', Turner 1962-66, no. 2661
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):133 no. 2661 s.v. Vedic káṇa- 'grain of corn', further etymology unclear ([EWAia](src-172) I:291.

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 442[247{S.v. 4564  Skt. caṅga- 'of good understanding' Kathās., 'handsome' lex.}];399[I:267{S.v. caṅga 'hübsch' / 'handsome'. Origin uncertain, perhaps a Dravidian loanword.}]
Comment: Kathās., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4564
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit caṅga- 'of good understanding; handsome' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):247 no. 4564). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Dravidian loanword ([KEWA](src-399) I:267).
Parallel loans from Arabic هواء / hawāʾ 'air'.

Source: 352[714{S.v. OLith. nùgara 'Rücken', the word is not to be separated from Latv. mugura 'Rücken', which is also found as mugara. The sound-correspondence Lith. n ~ Latv. m is irregular, and the origins of the lexemes remain unclear.}];531[429{S.v. Lith. nùgara 'grzbiet, plecy'. No etymology.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 714, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):429).

Source: 352[467-469{S.v. OLith. káulas 'Knochen, Bein' (BSl. cf. Latv. kaũls 'Knochen| Stengel, Kern', OPr. caulan 'Bein, Knochen', etc.| IE cf. Gk. καυλός 'Stengel, Stiel, Schaft, Lat. caulis, -is 'Stengel, Stiel, OIr. cúal 'Reisigbündel'). The words of the related languages may go back to PIE *keh₂ul(o)-| further analysis of the word-formation within PIE is less clear.}];353[233{S.v. Lithuanian káulas 'bone' < PIE *keh₂u-ló- (cf. Gk. καυλός 'stem, pole', Lat. caulis 'stem (of a plant), plant, cabbage', OIr. cúal 'faggot, bundle of sticks').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *keh₂u̯l(o)-, further analysis of the word formation within Indo-European is unclear (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 467-469, [Derksen 2015](src-353):233).

Source: 338[{onomatopoeic according to Abaev, but connected by Miller, Benveniste to Old Indic lap-, lapati 'chat' (phonetically and semantically dubious).}];156[IV:14{S.v. Oss. ūlæfyn : ūlæft | olæfun : olæft 'дышать'. Probably onomatopoeic, cf. læf-læf 'одышка', 'breathlessness'.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:14).

Source: 352[315-316{S.v. OLith. gérti 'trinken' (BSl. cf. Latv. dzer̂t 'trinken', OCS po-žrěti, etc.), from PIE *gʷerh₃- 'verschlingen' (cf. Ved. garⁱ- 'verschlingen', Gk. βιβρώσκω 'verzehre, esse auf', Arm. 3.sg.ind.aor. eker 'aß', Alb. 3.sg.aor. an-greh Old Gheg 'aß', OHG querdar 'Köder').}];141[211-212{S.v. *gʷerh₃- 'verschlingen' (IEW 474).}];353[172{S.v. Lith. gérti 'drink' (Latv. dzer̃t 'drink'), from PIE *gʷerh₃- (cf. Skt. giráti, Gk. βιβρώσκω 'eat, digest'| Lat. vorāre 'devour, eat greedily').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' ([LIV²](src-141) 211-212, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 315-316, [Derksen 2015](src-353):172).

Source: 352[1115-1116{Cf. s.v. tolùs -ì 'weit, fern' (BSl. Latv. tâls, 'weit, fern', tâli 'fern') from PIE *teh₂li- (adj.) 'so beschaffen' (cf. Gk. τηλίκος 'so alt, so jung, so groß', Lat. tālis 'solcher, so beschaffen| mancher').}]
Comment: Formerly identical with Lat. tālis 'such', but probably formed independently from the same morphemes.
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *teh₂li- 'as such' ([ALEW](src-352) 1115-1116).

Source: 352[470-471, 517{S.v. OLith. kovà 'Krieg, Kampf, Streit', either a deverbal derivation from OLith. káuti 'kämpfen, streiten' < PIE *keu̯h₂- or from PIE *keh₂u̯-éh₂-. OLith. kovauti 'kämpfen, streiten' is a secondary verbal derivative.}];353[234, 254{Cf. s.v. Lith. kovà 'struggle, fight', an action noun deriving from káuti 'murder, beat, hew' < *kouh₂- (cf. Lat. cūdere 'beat, grind, forge', OIc. hǫggva 'hew, beat', OHG houwan 'hew, beat').}];141[345-346{Cf. s.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes derived to PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, split' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 470-471, 517; [Derksen 2015](src-353):234, 254, [LIV²](src-141) 345-346).

Source: 352[512-513{S.v. OLith. kója 'Bein, Fuß' (BSl. Latv. kãja). No clear connections outside of Balto-Slavic. There are various proposals for an IE root etymology, but not one is convincing (cf. entry in ALEW for references to further literature).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of East Baltic ([ALEW](src-352) 512-513, cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):303-304).

Source: 352[1008-1009{S.v. OLith. šálti 'frieren' (BSl. Latv. sal̂t, OPr. passalis 'Frost', OCS slana 'Reif, Eisniederschlag' etc.), from PIE *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren'.}];141[323{S.v. *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren' (IEW 551), cf. n1 comparing Ved. śíśira- 'kühl, kalt', YAb. sarəta- 'kalt', root noun in YAv. sarə-δā 'Kälte bringend'.}];338[{Ossetic Iron šɜl-ən 'freeze' from PIE *k̑el-. In Iranian, cf. Persian sard 'cold', sarmā 'frost', Balochi sart, sard, etc.}];156[III:64{S.v. sælyn : sald | sælun : sald 'замерзать', from IE *k̑el- (cf. Pers. sard, Sogd. srt, Av. sarəta-, Ved. śiśira-, OCS slana, Lith. šálti, Arm. saṙn, Lat. caleō, etc.)}];353[439-440{S.v. Lith. šálti 'freeze'. The Baltic forms reflect a root *k̑olH- which may have been of denominative origin.}];83[336-337{S.v. Proto-Iranian *sarH- 'to cool, become cold', from PIE *k̑elH- 'to freeze' (cf. Lith. šálti 'to freeze, to cool (off), become cool', Latv. sal̃t 'to freeze').}];274[416-417{S.v. *k̑elH ‘kalt werden, frieren’ (LIV 323, IEW 551), cf. n6 suggesting the Iranian lexemes are rather reflexes of 2. *k̑el- 'warm werden'.}]
Justification: Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ([LIV²](src-141) 323, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:641, [Cheung 2007](src-83):336-337, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:64, [ALEW](src-352) 1008-1009, [Derksen 2015](src-353):439-440, ref NIL} 416-417).

Source: 352[331-332{S.v. OLith. girdė́ti 'hören' (BSl. Latv. dzìrdêt), from a univerbation of a PIE collocation or light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- dʰeh₁- 'Kunde geben', cf. Arm. kardam 'rufe', OIr. bard 'Barde', MW bardd 'id.', cf. *gʷer(H)- 'to consent' (LIV² 210f.) and *dʰeh₁- ''to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). See also PIE *gʷerdʰ- 'to hear, to sound' (LIV² 187).}];141[187, 210-211{S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'hören, tönen' [IEW 478]. Cf. s.v. *gʷerH- 'Zustimmung bekunden' (IEW 478).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound'; possibly in origin an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ([ALEW](src-352) 331-332). Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 210-211.

Source: 352[625-627{Cf. s.v. OLith. mẽdis 'Baum, Holz| Wald'. Lith. medžióti is a denominal verb based words for wood, cf. Lith. mẽdis m. 'wood, tree| forest', mẽdžias m. 'tree', Old Prussian median 'wood, forest', Latv. mežs 'wood, grove'.
