Fraenkel Lingua Posnaniensis 4 (1953, 85-108) assumes a Proto-Baltic neuter 'forest' (Old Prussian median 'wood, forest', Latv. mežs 'wood, grove', Lith. mẽdžias 'tree'), from which in East Baltic a masculine singulative Lith. mẽdis was derived. Both words got mixed up in Lithuanian due to ambiguous forms in the oblique cases. The meaning of the Proto-Baltic neuter 'forest' must have developed from 'boundary ridge, border, frontier', as the latter meanings are found in Slavic cognates like OCSl. mežda f. 'street', Russ. mežá f.'boundary ridge, border, frontier', Čech. mez f. 'lynchet, unploughed strip', meze f. 'border' etc. From PIE *médʰi̯o- adj. 'middle, located in the middle'.}];531[382{S.v. Lith. mẽdžias (1) 'las', (with derived verb medžióti), derived from the PIE adverb *medʰi 'w środku', 'in the middle'.}];274[465-466{S.v. *medʰ- 'mittlerer' (IEW 706f., EIEC 380). (> *medʰ-i̯o/ah₂- > OPr. median 'Wald', Lith. mẽdžias 'Baum, Holz', Latv. mežs 'Wald').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing denominal verbs based on nominal formations in the meaning 'tree, wood; forest' continuing PIE *medʰi̯o- 'middle' ([ALEW](src-352) 625-627, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):382, cf. [NIL](src-274) 465-466).

Source: 165[328{S.v. Proto-Germanic *lauba- 'leaf, foliage', a European word with no clear PIE etymology.}];179[227-228{S.v. Goth. L17. *laufs 'leaf', only nom.pl.m. -ubos 'φύλλα' (Mk 13.28), lauf n.a., only acc.sg.n used collectively φύλλα 'foliage' (Mk. 11.13), cf. OE lēaf, OHG loub, etc.}];398[1454-1457{S.v. OHG loub 'Pflanzenblatt, Laubblatt, Laub, belaubter Zweig, Laubwerk, Blätterdach, Laubkrone, Laubwald| folium, frons, nemus, ramus, silva', from Proto-Germanic *lau̯ƀa- n., a denominal derivation in collective function to Proto-Germanic *lau̯ƀa- m. 'Blatt', only continued in Goth. laufs* 'Blatt'. The basis of Proto-Germanic *lau̯ƀa- m. 'Blatt' is probably a substantivisation of a Pre-Proto-Germanic adjective *lou̯p-ó- to the verbal root *leu̯p- 'abschälen', whose present formation is found in Lith. lùpti '(ab)schälen, abhäuten, schinden, herausreißen, herausgraben', Latv. lupt 'schälen, kahl machen'. Less probable is a connection to the IE root *leu̯bʰ- 'entrinden, abreißen'.}]
Justification: Perhaps to PIE ?*leu̯p- '(ab)schälen' ([LIV²](src-141) 420, [IEW](src-49) 690-1), cf. [EWA 5](src-398):1454-1457; otherwise obscure (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):328).

Source: 352[512-513{S.v. OLith. kója 'Bein, Fuß' (BSl. Latv. kãja). No clear connections outside of Balto-Slavic. There are various proposals for an IE root etymology, but not one is convincing (cf. entry in ALEW for references to further literature).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 512-513 for further discussion).

Source: 352[441-442, 475-476{S.v. OLith. kálnas 'Berg' (BSl. Latv. kal̂ns 'Berg, Schloss, Haufen', etc.). Lith. kálnas and Latv. kal̂ns are o-grade formations to the same root as Lith. kélti, and may be accounted as though from PIE *kolHnós. With an n-suffix cf. Gk. κολώνη, κολωνός 'Hügel, Anhöhe, Stein-, Grabhügel', Lat. collis 'Hügel', OE hyll 'id.'. For Lith. kélti 'heben, erheben| sich erheben, auferstehen' (BSl. Latv. cel̂t 'heben, aufrichten, erheben, etc., OCS čelo 'Stirn', etc., from PIE *kelH- 'aufragen, hochragen' (cf. Gk. κελέοντες 'die Bäume des stehenden Webstuhls', Lat. prae-cellō, -ere 'hervorragen').}];141[349{Cf. s.v. *kelH- 'aufragen, hochragen' (IEW 544).}];353[221, 236{S.v. Lith. kálnas 'mountain, hill' (Latv. kal̂ns 'mountain, hill'), from PIE *kolH-n- (cf. Gk. κολώνη 'hill', Lat. collis 'hill', OE hyll 'hill'). The evidence points to an original n-stem containing the root of Lith. kélti 'lift, raise, wake, arouse, transfer' (Latv. cel̂t 'lift, erect, found, wake', etc.), from PIE *kelH- (cf. Lat. excellere 'excel').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *kelH- 'to rise up, to tower' ([ALEW](src-352) 441-442, 475-476, [Derksen 2015](src-353):221, 236, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 349).

Source: 353[489{S.v. Lith. var̃das 'name', Latv. vā̀rds 'word, name', from PIE *u̯(e/o)rdʰ-o- (cf. Lat. uerbum 'word').  The Old Prussian forms wīrds, wirds 'word' reflect a zero-grade < *u̯r̥dʰ̑-o-, like the Germanic forms attested from Goth. waurd 'word', OEng. word 'word'.}];352[1188-1189{S.v. OLith. var̃das 'Name' (BSl. Latv. vā̀rds, 'Wort| Name', OPr. N.sg. wīrds 'Wort'), from Indo-European *u̯ordʰo-| elsewhere in IE cf. Lat. verbum 'Wort', Goth. waurd, ON orð, OE word 'Wort'. The IE word for 'word' appears in the individual languages with different ablaut grades. It is hypothesised that the PIE lexeme for 'word' ultimately contains the root *u̯erh₁- 'sagen' (Palaic wērti 'sprechen', Gk. ῥητήρ 'Sprecher, Redner', Russ. vrat' 'lügen', cf. LIV² 689), but this conjecture requires an as yet more precise morphological-derivational explaination. Cf. entry in ALEW for references to further literature.}]
Justification: East Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *u̯ordʰo- 'word'. In East Baltic the o-grade of the root was generalised, although Old Prussian wīrds, wirds 'word' reflects a zero-grade < *u̯r̥dʰ-o-, also found in Germanic (Gothic waurd 'word' etc.). The stem is also attested with e-grade vocalism in Latin verbum 'word' ([ALEW](src-352) 1188-1189, [Derksen 2015](src-353):489).

Source: 353[220{S.v. Lith. kãklas 'neck', from PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o-m (cf. Ved. cakrá- 'wheel', OIc. hjól 'wheel', OEng. hweohhol, hwēol 'wheel').}];269[{Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either (1) to *kolso- underlying the Germanic and Italic lexemes in [cognate set 265](cog-265), or (2) to PIE *kʷelh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388) as a reduplicated formation (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 433-434). The latter explanation is favoured by [Derksen 2015](src-353):220. Both proposed etymologies are not precise correspondences and require special pleading to explain the deviations so that it is difficult to favour one etymology over the other (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 434).}];352[433-434{S.v. kãklas 'Hals, Kehle' (BSl. kakls 'Hals'). The East Baltic words for 'neck' may either be explained as a reduplicated form like Ved. cákra- 'wheel', but on the other hand there are similarities to the Germanic words for neck like Goth. hals. Both comparisons nevertheless show marked deviations from the extra-Baltic comparanda. See entry in ALEW for further discussion and references to further literature. Like other Baltic words for body parts like kója 'leg, foot' [cf. [cognate set 1856](cog-1856), [cognate set 1862](cog-1862)], Lith. kãklas 'neck' remains without a clear etymology.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either (1) to *kolso- underlying the Germanic and Italic lexemes in [cognate set 265](cog-265), or (2) to PIE *kʷelh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388) as a reduplicated formation (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 433-434). The latter explanation is favoured by [Derksen 2015](src-353):220. Both proposed etymologies are not precise correspondences and require special pleading to explain the deviations so that it is difficult to favour one etymology over the other (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 434 for further discussion).

Source: 353[284{S.v. Lith. lietùs, Latv. liêtus 'rain', derivatives from the verb 'to rain' (Lith. líeti < *lh₃-(e)i-).}];141[405-406{S.v. 2. *lei̯H- 'gießen| pour' (IEW 664-5).}];352[581-582{S.v. lietùs 'Regen' (BSl. Latv. liêtus, etc.), from PIE *lei̯H- 'gießen', *lei̯H-tu- 'Guss' (cf. Goth. leiϸu sm. (?) 'Obstwein').}]
Justification: East Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE 2. *lei̯H- 'to pour' ([ALEW](src-352) 581-582, [Derksen 2015](src-353):284, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 405-406).

Source: 352[891{Cf. s.v. OLith. sar̃tas 'rotbraun (Pferd)' (cf. Latv. sā̀rts 'rot, frisch aussehend', sar̂kans 'rot'), the (East-)Baltic colour adjective can be connected to a PIE root *ser- 'rot' (IEW 910f.), but closer correspondences in related languages are lacking.}];531[534{Cf. s.v. Lith. sárkanas 'pink, ruddy, with healthy appearance', to a root *ser-.}];534[II:155-156{S.v. Latv. sarkans, following [IEW](src-49) 910 to *ser-.}];49[910-911{S.v. 3. *ser-, *sor- 'rot, rötlich'.}]
Justification: Traditionally postulated to a root *ser- 'red' ([IEW](src-49) 910-911, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):763), although this etymology is no longer accepted by [ALEW](src-352) 891. Cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):534, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:155-156.

Source: 353[439{Cf. s.v. Lith. šakà 'branch', from PIE *k̑ok-eh₂- (cf. Skt. śā́khā- 'branch, twig', Goth. hoha 'plough').}];352[1003-1005{S.v. OLith. šakà 'Zweig, Ast| Zacken', derived form šãknis 'Wurzel' (BSl. Latv. saka 'Verästelung (bei Bäumen), sakns, sakne, 'Wurzel', OPr. sagnis 'Wurzel', SCr. sòha 'Gabelholz', etc.). Generally agreed to be connected to Ved. śā́kha- 'Ast, Zweig', Arm. cʻax, I.sg. cʻaxov, cʻaxiw 'grüner Zweig mit Blättern'. The continuants of this word in the individual IE branches show several anomalies that are not satisfactorily explained. The best explanation for Ved. śā́khā- is probably the reconstruction of an ablauting o-grade root, e.g. *k̑ók-eh₂- ~ *k̑ek-h₂-.}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes, to judge from cognates such as Ved. śā́kha- 'branch', probably continuing an ablauting h₂-stem, like PIE *k̑ók-eh₂- ~ *k̑ek-h₂- (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1003-1005, [Derksen 2015](src-353):439).

Source: 141[432-433{Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7).}];165[351{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', from PIE *mólh₁-e- (cf. Hitt. mallai- ~ mallanzi 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei, *mlh₁-énti| Lat. molō, -ere 'id.', Arm. malem 'to crush', Lith. málti (malù), Latv. mal̃t 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei| OCS mlěti 'id.', Ru. molót' (meljú), SCr. mljȅti 'id.', OIr. meilid 'id.' < *melh₁-ie-| Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti 'crush, grind' < *ml-néh₁-).}];179[242-243{S.v. Goth. M16. malma 'ἄμμος', 'sand' derivation with PIE *-mo- to the same root as Goth. *malan 'grind', from PIE *mel- 'crush, grind'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing a derivative with PIE *-mo- to Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', further from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):242-243, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):351, [LIV²](src-141) 432-433).

Source: 353[215{S.v. Lith. jū́ra 'sea' (Latv. jũra, OPruss. luriay, iūrin 'sea'), from PIE *u(e/o)h₁-r- (cf. Skt. vā́r 'water', OIc. úr 'drizzle').}];352[423{S.v. OLith. jū́ra 'Meer' (BSl. Latv. jũŗa 'Meer, großer See', OPr. juriay 'Meer', from PIE *i̯uHr- 'Wasser' (cf. Arm. ǰowr, G.pl. ǰowrcʻ, ǰrocʻ 'Wasser').}];742[15{Rejects the usually given etymology of Armenian ǰowr with Lithuanian jū́ra 'sea' on the grounds it cannot be separated from OPr. wurs 'pond', Skt. vā́r 'water', TochA wär, TochB war 'id.' with an initial j- of secondary origin. [= [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):122]}]
Justification: Cognacy in this class follows [ALEW](src-352) 423, but cf. [Kortlandt 1998](src-742):15 (= [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):122) who rejects the etymology with Armenian, assuming that Baltic initial j- is secondarily acquired (similarly cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):215).

Source: 345[549{S.v. TochB yetse '(outer) skin', which with TochA yats reflect Proto-Tocharian *i̯ētse, which could possibly reflect PIE *h₁ēd-so- (*h₁ed- 'eat').  Terms for 'flesh' (what one eats) and 'skin' are frequently related in cognate languages, cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):200-202.}];47[200-202{Cf. s.v. 4.12 'SKIN, HIDE' and 4.13 'FLESH'.}]
Justification: Possibly from an IE formation *h₁ēd-so- *'flesh (for eating' > 'skin' according to [Adams 2013](src-345):549, but this proposal remains uncertain.

Source: 360[I:422-423{S.v. Lith. mãžas 'klein, gering, wenig'. The etymology of Lith. mãžas, Latv. mazs, etc. is disputed.}];352[623-625{S.v. OLith. mãžas, -à 'klein| noch nicht erwachsen' (BSl. cf. Latv. mazs 'klein, gering', OPr. massais (comp.adv.) 'weniger', etc.). No known etymology outside of Baltic. The often considered connection with PIE *meg̑- 'groß' is fraught with formal and semantic difficulties (cf. ALEW for references to further literature).}]
Justification: East Baltic lexemes, without certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 623-625, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):422-423 for further discussion).

Source: 352[1100-1102{Cf. s.v. OLith. tiẽsti 'ebnen, richten, strecken, dehnen', among derived stems tiẽsus 'gerade, aufrecht, richtig' (BSl. Latv. tìešs 'gerade, direkt, unmittelbar', etc.). No convincing connections outside of Baltic. Comparisons with the group of lexemes stemming from OCS tixъ 'still, ruhig, leise', and OCS těšti 'trösten' are formally possible, but semantically unconvincing.}]
Justification: Cf. Old Lithuanian tiẽsus 'straight, direct', without certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1100-1102).

Source: 595[4: 159{PS *teťi 'go, run, flow' is derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'run, flow'.}];81[489{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tekti 'flow, run', from PIE *tekʷ- (cf. Skt. tákti 'rush', OIr. techid 'flee').}];141[620-621{S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):489, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:159, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Source: 352[1042{S.v. OLith. šlãpias 'nass' (BSl. Latv. slapjš 'nass', SCr. slȍta, slotà (dial.) 'feiner Regen mit Schnee', Russ. slotá (dial.) 'Matschwetter, Schneeregen', Pol. słota 'schlechtes, regnerisches Wetter'), from PIE *k̑lep- 'nass, feucht' (cf. Gk. κλέπας 'something wet' (Hesych.), OIr. clúain 'meadow, pasture').}];269[{Pace ALEW, the etymology to PIE *k̑lep- (cf. IEW 603) is not certain. Cf. discussion s.v. Gk. κλέπας 'moist, muddy, or clayey, bushy, wet' (only attested in lexicographical works) in Beekes (2010:713), Chantraine (1968-1980:541), Frisk (1960-1972), and s.v. Proto-Celtic *klowni- 'meadow' in Matasović (2009:209) where the etymology to a putative PIE *k̑lep- is not completely certain. There is no lemma for Lith. šlãpias, Latv. slapjš in Derksen (2015).}];66[713{Cf. s.v. Gk. κλέπας· νοτερόν, πηλῶδες, ἣ δασύ, ἣ ὑγρόν 'moist of muddy or clayey, bushy, wet' (Gloss from Hesychius' lexicon). The meaning 'moist' suggests a connection to OIr. cluain 'meadow' and the Baltic group of Lith. šlàpti 'to become wet', but the formation of the Greek gloss does not match the proposed cognates, which makes the etymology uncertain.}];270[541];174[870];49[603{Cf. s.v. *klep- 'feucht'??, (cf. Gk. κλέπας (Hes.), Lith. šlampù, šlapti 'naß werden', possibly also OIr. cluin < *k̑lop-ni- but *k̑leu̯-ni- is also possible, cf. s.v. IEW 607 *k̑leu̯- 'spülen, rein machen').}];50[209{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *klowni- 'meadow' (OIr. clúain, OW clun, MW clun). IEW hesitates between assigning these lexemes to roots *klep- (IEW 603) or *k̑leu̯- (IEW 607), but neither etymology is completely persuasive. The connection to a putative *k̑lopni- in connection to Lith. šlãpius 'wet', Gk. κλέπας 'swamp' somewhat more probable.}]

360[45-46{Cf. s.v. Lith. blagnas 'ungeeignet, schlecht, böse'. The variant blõgas 'schlecht, gering, mager' is a loan from Belorussian.}];531[65-66{S.v. Lith. blõgas, -à 'niedobry, zły, marny, chudy, słaby'. A loan from Old  Belarusian blágij 'lichy, marny, zły'.}]
Comment: Loan from Belarusian
Justification: Loan from Old Belarusian blagij 'shame, miserable, bad' prior to the spirantisation of /g/ > /h/, cf. Modern Belarusian благі / blahi 'bad' ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):65-66, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):45-46).

Source: 352[1307{S.v. OLith. žievė̃ 'Rinde, Baumrinde' (BSl. cf. Latv. zievis 'Baumrinde'). Etymologically isolated. The traditional connection with Lith. žydė́ti 'blühen' is not semantically convincing. No reliable comparisons outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of East Baltic, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1307, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):784 for further discussion.

Source: 352[773-775{S.v. OLith. pil̃vas 'Bauch, Wanst, Magen| Kropf', traditionally interpreted as a derivation to Lith. pìlti 'gießen, schütten', in turn from PIE *pleh₁- 'sich füllen' (cf. Ved. parⁱ-, Gk. πίμπλημι, Arm. lnowm, Alb. mblon, Lat. pleō, plēre. OIr. do-lin 'fließt').}];360[592-593{S.v. Lith. pil̃vas '(dicker) Bauch, Magen, Wanst, Magen'.}];531[460{S.v. Lith. pil̃vas 'brzuch', a derivative of PIE *pleh₁- / *pelh₁-.}]
Justification: Traditionally derived from Lith. pìlti 'to pour (out); to fill' and further to PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, become full' ([ALEW](src-352) 773-775, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):460, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):592-593).

Source: 352[204-205{S.v. OLith. dìdis 'groß, bedeutend' (BSl. dižs 'groß| vornehm, herrlich'). No certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic (but no known Old Prussian correspondences. Commonly conntected with PIE *dei̯h₂- 'to light up' ([LIV²](src-141) 108, [IEW](src-49) 183f.), which is however problematic, as Winter's lengthening is lacking.}]
Justification: No certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. Latv. dižs 'great'). Commonly conntected with PIE *dei̯h₂- 'to light up' (LIV² 108, IEW 183f.), which is however problematic, as Winter's lengthening is lacking ([ALEW](src-352) 204-205; not in [Derksen 2015](src-353), cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):107-108).

Source: 352[419-420{S.v. OLith. júodas, -à (3), júodas -a (1) 'schwarz' (BSl. cf. Latv. juõds 'Waldteufel, böser Geist, Teufel'), cf. Lith. juodàsis 'Teufel'. The Proto-East-Baltic word for 'black' is etymologically isolated. Proposed connections with Lith. jùsti 'sich regen' are phonologically difficult and from a semantic point of view not close.}];531[238{S.v. Lith. júodas, -à 'czarny'. Etymology unclear.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of (East) Baltic (cf. Latv. juõds 'demon, evil spirit'). See [ALEW](src-352) 419-420, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):238 for further discussion.

Source: 353[231{S.v. Lith. kàsti 'dig, rake' < PIE *kes- (cf. Hitt. kiš- 'comb, card').}];141[359{S.v. *kes- 'ordnen' (IEW 585).}];352[463-464{S.v. OLith. kàsti 'graben, scharren, begraben' (BSl. cf. Latv. kast 'scharren, die Erde aufwerfen, harken'), usually taken to PIE *kes- 'ordnen' (LIV² 357) but the original semantics of the root may need to be revised in view of other Balto-Slavic lexemes| cf. also OLith. kasà 'Zopf, Haarzopf'.}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes generally considered derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ([LIV²](src-141) 359, [ALEW](src-352) 463-464, [Derksen 2015](src-353):231).

Source: 352[404, 829{S.v. OLith. pur̃vas 'aufgeweichte Erde, Schlamm, Schmutz' (derived adj. pur̃vinas, -à 'schmutzig, unflätig' (BSl. cf. Latv. pùrvs 'Morast, Sumpf', etc.), a suffixival derivative to Lith. pùrti 'locker werden, sich auflockern (Schnee, Erde)| porös werden, aufgehen (Teig)'. For Baltic root, cf. s.v. OLith. išpur̃sti 'weich, schwammig, morsch werden', perhaps to be connected with Cz. poura 'Hochmut, Stolz', but no secure connections outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Comment: Cf. Lith. pur̃vas 'dirt', Latv. pùrvs 'swamp'
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 404, 829).

Source: 352[1178-1179, 1242-1243{S.v. OLith. válgyti 'essen, speisen, sich ernähren', which is not to be separated from OLith. vìlgyti 'befeuchten, benetzen, bestreichen' (BSl. cf. Latv. vel̂gt 'einweichen, feucht machen', OPr. welge 'Schnupfen', OCS vlaga 'Feuchtigkeit, Saft (Pflanzen)', etc.), from PIE *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (cf. OIr. folc 'starker Regen, Regenwetter', MW 3.sg.pres. gwylch 'waschen', Bret. gwalc'hiñ 'waschen', OS wolkan 'Wolke', OHG wolkan 'Wolke').}];141[676{S.v. ? 2. *u̯elg- 'feucht werden' (IEW 1145). Verbal only Balto-Slavic. Possible related nominal forms in Germanic like OHG welc 'feucht', wolchan 'Wolke', cf. also ?*u̯elk- 'feucht sein / werden' (IEW 1145) (verbal only Celtic).}];353[486{S.v. Lith. válygti 'eat' (Latv. val̃ģît 'eat in a hurry, gobble' [LW from Lith.], OPr. walgeit 'eat'), from PIE *uolg- (cf. OHG wolchan 'cloud').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯elg- 'to become damp' ([ALEW](src-352) 1178-1179, 1242-1243; [Derksen 2015](src-353):486, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 676).

Source: 352[469-470, 486{S.v. OLith. kiaušìnis 'Ei', originally a substantivised adjective from OLith. káušas 'Schale' in the sense of 'mit einer Schale versehen'| cf. s.v. OLith. káušas 'Schale, Becher, Kelle' (BSl. Latv. kaûss 'Schädel, Hirnschale'). No clear further etymology. Several proposals to link words from other IE branches, cf. ALEW 469-470 for further details.}];353[234, 243];531[282]
Justification: Further etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 469-470, 486, [Derksen 2015](src-353):234, 243, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):282 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 353[485, 495{S.v. Lith. vaĩsius 'fruit' (cf. OIc. vísir 'bud, sprout'), from the same root as Lith. veĩsti 'to breed, rear' from PIE *u̯ei̯s- (cf. Lat. virēre 'be green, fresh').}];141[671{Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯ei̯s- 'sprießen, gedeihen' (IEW 1133).}];352[1170-1171{Cf. s.v. OLith. vaisùs 'fruchtbar', from which the derived noun vaĩsius 'Frucht, Leibesfrucht', an o-grade formation to OLith. veĩsti 'zeugen, erzeugen' (BSl. Latv. viest 'aufziehen, erziehen, entstehen lassen, verbreiten', OPr. wēisin 'Frucht'), from PIE *u̯ei̯s- 'sprießen, gedeihen' (cf. Alb. vesh 'Traube, Weintraube', Lat. vireō, -ēre 'grün sein', ON vísir 'Keim, Spross').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯ei̯s- 'to sprout, thrive' ([ALEW](src-352) 1170-1171, [Derksen 2015](src-353):485, 495; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 671).

Source: 353[171, 178-179{S.v. Lith. gẽras 'good', a derivative of gìrti 'praise', from PIE *gʷrH- (cf. Skt. gr̥nā́ti 'greet, praise').}];141[210-211{Cf. s.v. *gʷerH- 'Zustimmung bekunden' (IEW 478).}];352[335-336{Cf. s.v. OLith. gìrti 'loben, rühmen' (BSl. Latv. dzir̃t 'rühmend nennen', OCS žrьti 'opfern', etc.), from PIE *gʷerH- '(Positives) künden| Zustimmung bekunden' (cf. VEd. garⁱ- 'rühmen, ehren, ehrend aufnehmen, preisen', YAv. (auui)gərəṇte 'preist', Lat. grātēs 'Dank', etc.).}]
Justification: Derived from Lithuanian gìrti 'to praise', further derived from PIE *gʷerH- 'to express agreement' ([ALEW](src-352) 335-336, [Derksen 2015](src-353):171, 178-179, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 210-211).

Source: 352[802{Cf. s.v. OLith. plùnksma 'Feder, Federkiel. Schreibfeder'. Possibly related to Lat. plūma, which might continue earlier *plūksma or *plouksma. The origins of the nasal in plunk- in Lithuanian is obscure. Cf. [cognate set 2263](cog-2263).}]
Justification: Cf. Old Lithuanian plùnksma 'feather' ([ALEW](src-352) 802). Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.

Source: 352[990-991{S.v. OLith. sunkùs 'schwer, schwierig'. This lexeme and its derivatives are widely attested in Lithuanian, but there are no clear external connections. For older, no longer tenable proposals cf. IEW 1048 s.v. *su̯enk-.}]
Justification: No certain etymology (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 990-991).

Source: 352[1328-1330{S.v. OLith. žū́ti 'verloren gehen, zugrunde gehen, umkommen', (derived form: žū́dyti 'umbringen, töten, vernichten'), BSl. s.v. OLatv. pazūt 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', etc.| no good comparanda outside of Baltic.}];353[522{S.v. Lith. žudýti 'kill, torment' (Latv. zudîtiês 'take care of, get excited'). Root reconstruction unclear, cf. entry for further discussion.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1328-1330, [Derksen 2015](src-353):522).

Source: 353[214{Cf. s.v. Lith. juõkas 'laugh, laughter', which is most likely a (dialectal) German loanword (cf. Prussian dialect jōk vel sim., itself a loan in Germanic from Latin iocus 'joke').}];531[239{S.v. Lith. juõkas "żart, śmianie się (z żartu), śmiech", without a good etymology.}]
Justification: Lithuanian júoktis 'to laugh' is derived from juõkas 'laugh, laughter'; probably a German loanword (cf. Prussian jōk 'joke') according to [Derksen 2015](src-353):214; cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) who considers there to be no good etymology.

Source: 50[342-343{S.v. Proto-Celtic *(s)kītto- 'left, clumsy'. Possibly to be connected with Lat. scaeuus, Gk. σκαιός < *skh₂ei̯-u̯o-, however in order to account for the Celtic forms one must assume a zero-grade *skh₂it-and 'expressive' gemination > *skh₂i-tto- which makes this etymology somewhat speculative.}];236[{S.v. W chwith 'left' from Celtic *skittu- (cf. *skaiu̯os, Lat. Scaeuus, Gr. σκαιός). [entry published 1959].}]
Justification: Possibly to be connected with PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- in [cognate set 7189](cog-7189), but the stem-formation in Celtic is difficult to reconcile (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):342-343, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 353[61{S.v. Lith. artì 'near, close', from PIE *h₂er-t- (Gk. ἄρτι 'just, just now, recently', Arm. ard 'just now'). "Originally we are dealing with the Lsg. of a derivative of the root of Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'fit, join together' etc."}];352[56-57{S.v. OLith. artùs, -ì 'nahe', derived from PIE *h₂er- 'zusammenfügen' (cf. Ved. ará- 'Radspeiche' r̥tá- 'Wahrheit', r̥tú- 'richtige Zeit, bestimmte Zeit', OAv. aṣ̌a- 'Wahrheit', Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'zusammenfügen', Arm. ard, G.sg. ardow 'Anordnung, Ordnung', ard (adv.) 'soeben, jetzt', Lat. artus 'eng in Raum und Zeit', artē 'eng, dicht, fest', ars, -tis 'handwerklickhe Kunstfertigkeit, Kunst', artus, -ūs 'Gelenk'). Lith. artùs is clearly a lexicalised past passive participle to a  primary verb that has been lost in Baltic.}]
Justification: Originally fossilised past passive participle to a primary verbal derivative of the PIE root PIE *h₂er- 'to fit together', now lost in in Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 56-57, [Derksen 2015](src-353):61).

Source: 352[1118-1119{S.v. OLith. tráukti 'ziehen, schleppen' (BSl. tràukt/traũkt 'schlagen, etc.). The well-attested Baltic family of words have no clear further connections. The comparison with ON ϸrúga 'drohen', OHG drucken 'drücken' could go back to a common PIE root *treu̯Hk- ~ 'gewaltsam in Bewegung setzen (?)', but this form is structurally striking and would need to be more precisely semantically defined.}];269[{Etymology unclear| cf. ALEW for older proposed connections to Germanic lexemes. This verb is not listed in LIV² or Derksen (2015).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1118-1119).

Source: 353[142{S.v. Lith. druskà 'salt' (Latv. druska 'crumb, scrap, bit', Old Prussian dmskins [druskins] 'earwax'), from *dʰrus-k-eh₂- (cf. Goth. drauhsos N.pl.f. 'crumbs, lumps'| Welsh dryll m. (< *dʰrus-lo-) 'piece, lump').}];141[157-158{Cf. s.v. ?*dʰreu̯s- 'fallen, herabfallen' (IEW 274-5).}];352[234{S.v. OLith. druskà 'Salz' (BSl. Latv. druska 'Brocken, Krümchen'), generally attempted to be derived (as though) from IE *dʰrus-ko/eh₂- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 157-158n1 s.v. *dʰreu̯s- 'herabfallen, abbröckeln), with a primary verb attested in Germanic (cf. Goth. driusan, OE drēosan, OS driosan 'fallen').}]
Justification: Generally attempted to be derived (as though) from IE *dʰrus-ko/eh₂- to a root *dʰreu̯s- 'herabfallen, abbröckeln', and cognate with a primary verb attested in Germanic (cf. Goth. driusan, OE drēosan, OS driosan 'to fall'), cf. [ALEW](src-352) 234, [Derksen 2015](src-353):142, [LIV²](src-141) 157-158.

Source: 353[307{S.v. Lith. matýti 'look at, watch' (cf. CS motriti, Ru. motrit' (dial.), SCr. mòtriti, Sln. mótriti). "For the *-r-, cf. → matrus. Fraenkel (LEW: 416) advocates an etymological relationship with → mesti 'throw', which he also connects with → matas and forms reflecting *mē-, i.e. *meh₁- 'measure' (I: 415, 418). I prefer to dismiss the connection between *met- 'measure' and met- 'throw' (pace LIV: 422), but I am inclined to derive matyti from the former root. As to the semantics, we may com pare Cz. metit ( dial.) 'watch assiduously', Ru. metit' 'aim at', 1sg. meču, zametit' 'notice, remark, observe', which I assume to contain *mě- < *meh₁, or Gk. μέδομαι 'care for, think of' < *med- 'measure', cf. Go. mitan."}];352[620-621{S.v. OLith. matýti 'sehen, wahrnehmen' (BSl. Latv. matît, fühlen, empfinden, merken', a further connection may be sought in the family of Slavic lexemes around SCr. mòtriti, mòtrȋm 'zusehen'.}];81[327{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *motriti 'look at, watch' (ESSJa XX 65-67), From BSl. *mot(r)-, cf. Lith. matýti 'look at, watch'. For the -r- cf. Lith. matrùs 'sharp eyed, vigilant'.}]
Comment: Cognate with e.g. Russian смотреть 'look at'
Justification: Baltic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate with Proto-Slavic *motriti 'look at, watch' from a Proto-Balto-Slavic stem *mot(r)-, but a further IE root etymology remains disputed (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 620-621, [Derksen 2015](src-353):307, [Derksen 2008](src-81):327 for further discussion).

Source: 360[1131-1132{S.v. Lith. trum̃pas 'kurz, zu kurz, eng, zusammengepreßt'. [No etymology outside of Baltic given.]}];531[691{S.v. Lith. trum̃pas, -a 'krótki'.}]
Justification: Uncertain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1131-1132, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):691 for further discussion. [Not in [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Source: 353[112{S.v. Lith. dainúoti 'sing', a denominative verb to Lith. dainà 'song'. The root of the noun is to be connected with Latv. diêt 'hop, dance, sing', and the underlying form may be reconstructed as *doih₁-n-.}];352[169, 189{S.v. OLith. dainà 'Lied, Volkslied', with derived verb dainúoti 'singen'. The further etymology is unclear. Perhaps to either (1) to Lith. dejà 'Wehklage' (without certain etymology), or (2) to be connected with Latv. diêt 'hüpfen, tanzen, singen', in which case could be connected to PIE *dei̯h₁- 'dahinjagen' (LIV² 107).}]
Justification: Possibly, but not certainly, to be connected with Latv. diêt, in turn from PIE *dei̯h₁- 'dahinjagen' ([LIV²](src-141) 107), cf. [ALEW](src-352) 169, [Derksen 2015](src-353):112), alternatively to Lith. dejà 'Wehklage', without certain etymology (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 189).

Source: 353[115, 121-122{S.v. Lith. dengùs 'sky, heaven' (OPr. dangus), related to Lith. deñgti 'cover, thatch, clothe, shelter, conceal', from PIE *dʰengʰ- (cf. OHG tungen 'oppress, manure'| MHG tungen 'manure, cover, oppress, scare' < *dʰngʰ-).}];352[174, 192-193{S.v. OLith. dangùs (4), dángus 'Himmel' (BSl. OPr. dangus 'Himmel, Daumen'), a lexicalised τομός-formation to Lith. deñgti 'decken, bedecken, bekleiden', derived from PIE *dʰengʰ- 'bedecken' (cf. ON dyngja 'Frauengemach', OHG tung 'Keller, Erdhaus, Webstube, unterirdisches Gemach').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives to the same root as Lithuanian deñgti 'to cover', further from PIE *dʰengʰ- 'to cover' ([ALEW](src-352) 174, 192-193; [Derksen 2015](src-353):115, 121-122, cf. [IEW](src-49) 250 [not in [LIV²](src-141)]).

Source: 353[315-316{S.v. Lith. miegóti 'sleep' (OPr. miecte 'sleep')}];352[644-645{S.v. OLith. miegóti 'schlafen' (BSl. OPr. meicte 'schlafen', SCr. mȉgati 'blinzeln', etc.).}];141[427{S.v. *mei̯g⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- 'blinzeln, zucken' (IEW 712).}];531[395-396{S.v. Lith. miegóti, from PIE *mei̯gʰ-.}];389[{S.v. *mei̯gʰ- '(die Augen) schließen, blinzeln'}];686[240{S.v. OPr. moicte 'schlaffen', meicte 'schlaffen'.}]
Justification: Root reference form for this class follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) to PIE *mei̯gʰ- 'to close the eyes, blink', cf. also [LIV²](src-141) 427, [ALEW](src-352) 644-645, [Derksen 2015](src-353):315-316, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):240, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):395-396 for further discussion.

Source: 353[180{S.v. Lith. gyvatà 'life', a derivative in *-ot- based on the BSl. root *gʔiw- [< PIE *gʷi̯eh₃-, cf. Lith. gývas 'alive' < *gʷh₃i-u̯o-| Lat. vīvus 'alive', Skt. jīvá- 'alive']. The meaning of Lith. gyvãtė 'snake, adder' must have developed from 'living creature'.}];352[340{S.v. OLith. gyvãtė 'Schlange, Otter, Natter', a derivative of Lith. gyvatà 'Leben', cf. OLith. gýti 'heilen, genesen, leben' from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃-.}]
Justification: A derivative of Lithuanian gyvatà 'life', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 340, [Derksen 2015](src-353):180 for discussion of the nominal derivation).

Source: 352[625-627{S.v. OLith. mẽdis 'Baum, Holz, Wald' (BSl. Latv. mežs 'Wald, Gehölz, OCS mežda 'Straße', etc.), from PIE *médʰi̯o- 'mittlerer, in der Mitte befindlich' (cf. Ved. mádhya- (adj.) 'mittlerer'| (snt.) 'Mitte', YAv. maiδiia- 'mittlerer', Gk. μέσος, μέσσος 'mittlerer', Lat. medius 'mittlerer', Goth. midjis, ON miðr, OHG mitti 'in der Mitte befindlich').}];353[309-310{S.v. Lith. mẽdis 'tree, log, wood', cf. Lith. mẽdžias 'forest, woods', to be derived from PIE *medʰ-i-o-/*medʰ-i-eh₂- (cf. Skt. mádhya- 'middle, located in the middle', Lat. medius 'middle, located in the middle, Goth. midjis 'middle').}]

81[304{Cf. s.v. mazati 'smear, anoint'. Derksen groups the Slavic lexemes with Lith. mė́žti 'manure, muck out', Latv. mêzt 'muck out, sweep' < Balto-Slavic *moʔź-, although he also admits that the connection with Gk. μάσσω 'knead', Arm. macanem 'thicken, stick together' < PIE *mag̑- (cf. LIV² 421).}];141[421{Cf. s.v. *mag̑- 'streichen, schmieren' (IEW 696-7).}];458[18: 23-25{The root vocalism makes a relationship to Lithanian mė́žti 'manure, muck out' problematic. The Slavic lexeme *mazati is related to German machen 'do, make', English make, Greek μάσσω 'knead'. PIE *mag̑-.}]

81[158{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *ę̄tro 'liver' < PIE *h₁en-tr-om and *ǭtròba < *h₁on-tro- (cf. Ved. āntrá- 'intestine', Gk. ἔντερα 'entrails').}];458[6: 72-73{S.v. *ętro. The word is derived from *en-tr-o-m, cf. Old Indic antrám, Armenian ənderk', Greek ἔντερα 'guts'.}];260[1714{S.v. wutroba.}]
Justification: Identical to 'liver' in other Slavic languages ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1714, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 6:72-73, [Derksen 2008](src-81):158).

Source: 458[7: 23, 196-197{PS *goniti (sę) is derived from PIE *gʷʰen- and related to Old Indic hánti 'hit, kill', Greek θείνω 'hit', Lithuanian genù, giñti 'chase', Hittite kuen-, kun- 'hit, kill', Latin de-fendere 'defend', Old Icelandic gunnr 'battle', Tocharian kuñac 'quarrel, battle' etc.}];141[218-219{Cf. s.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).}];259[383-384{PS dialectal *ogonŭ is derived from *o(b)-goniti sę 'keep off, drive off', cf. PS *goniti 'chase, drive, run'.}];81[177{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *gonìti 'chase, persecute' (ESSJa VII 23), to be derived from PIE *gʷʰon- (cf Skt. hánti 'strike, slay', Gk. θείνω 'kill').}]
Justification: West Slavic lexemes as though from Proto-Slavic *ogonъ and derived from *o(b)-goniti sę 'keep off, drive off' in the sense of 'a part of the body an animal can swat away insects with' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):383-384). Further derived from an o-grade form of PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([ESSJa](src-458) 7:23, 196-197; [Derksen 2008](src-81):177, [LIV²](src-141) 218-219).

Source: 81[274-275{S.v. Proto-Slavic *lě̀to n. 'summer' (ESSJa XV 8-12), from PIE *leh₁-tóm (cf. OIr. laithe n. 'day').}];50[233-234{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', from PIE *leh₁t- 'warm part of the year(?)' (IEW 680), cf. OCS lěto 'year', Croat. ljȅto 'summer', Swed. (dial.) låding 'spring'.}];269[{While the cognacy of the Slavic and Celtic lexemes is not in dispute, the morphological segmentation of the root is less clear. We may be dealing with either an inherited t-stem to a root *leh₁- or a root *leh₁t- with a final dental. Either solution is plausible and both root forms are permissible to IE root structure constraints. The potential additional evidence from dialectal Swedish låding 'spring' (cf. s.v. låding in the Svensk Akademiens Ordbok: https://www.saob.se/artikel/?seek=l%C3%A5ding&pz=2, cf. Old Gutnish laϸigs) does not help settle this matter. [LIV²](src-141) *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' ([IEW](src-49) 666, 682-3) does not seem a semantically convincing candidate for a root etymology, nor is there a comparable verbal root *leh₁t- attested. [Derksen 2008](src-81):274-275 reconstructs *leh₁-tom underlying Proto-Slavic *lě̀to, while [Matasović 2009](src-50):233-234 reconstructs *leh₁ti-/leh₁ti̯o- to a basic root *leh₁t-. For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form that is compatible with both the Slavic words meaning 'year' and the Celtic words meaning 'day', I give *leh₁t- as a the basic root.}];458[15: 8-12{The etymology of PS *lěto is still disputable. Most probably is related to Lithuanian lė̃tas 'soft, easy, amenable', Latvian lė̃ts 'light' and derived from PIE *lē- 'become weak'. Cf. also Gothic lētan 'leave, let out, refuse'. Thus, the original meaning was 'part the year without cold'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lě̀to 'summer', as though an o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to an original t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations for further discussion.

Source: 458[18: 23-25{PS *mazati 'smear' is derived from PIE *maĝ-.}];141[421{Cf. s.v. *mag̑- 'streichen, schmieren' See n1: Not *meh₂g̑- (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):219n75).}];603[3: 613{Mazen is derived from maz 'fat' or maža 'smear'.}]
Justification: Traditionally derived to PIE *mag̑- 'to spread, smear' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 3:613, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:23-25, [LIV²](src-141) 421). Cf., however, [Derksen 2008](src-81):304 s.v. Proto-Slavic mazati 'smear, anoint' with an alternative proposed etymology to Lithuanian mė́žti 'manure, muck out', etc.

Source: 458[8: 135{PS *xvŭrliti has an ideophonic origin.}]
Justification: Onomatopoeic in origin, no further etymology outside of Slavic ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:135).

Source: 249[{If the phonetic irregularities are in fact expressive then the Serbo-Croat words has cognates amont the Slavic. However, due to the nature of the root, no reasonable further etymology can be found.}];589[2: 469{There are three (dialectal) variants of the root the lexeme is derived from (initial p-, b- and m- are possible, cf. mrljav, prljav, prljati, brljati, burljati). The root has an ideophonic (expressive) origin. The lexeme is solely Serbo-Croat and does not have any Slavic or further IE cognates.}];458[3: 167-170{Serbo-Croat prljati / brljati 'to dirty' along with its Slavic cognates is derivered from PS *bĭrlati / *bĭrľati. The root itself is ideophonic, irregular correspondences are secondary and of expressive nature.}];259[22{Polish barłóg 'lare, pallet, shakedown' etc. and Serbo-Croat bŕljati are related and both derived from PS *bĭrliti 'to dirty'.}]

Justification: As though continuing an Indic stem *ḍoka- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):313 no. 5566). No further etymology.

Source: 338[{Loan from Persian qiži 'dirty' (through some other language?)}]
Justification: Loanword ultimately from Persian qiži 'dirty', possibly via an intermediary language ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:635, Oleg Abaev, p.c.).

Source: 338[{originally ni-waž-ən, from pv. nə- < *ni- 'down' and the stem *waz- 'flow' in causative wāz-aya-. Cf. Khotanese nuvays- (*niwaz-) 'flow down', Avestan nivaz- 'carry downwards by stream', Old Indic nivah- 'flow'.}];172[II:535-537{Cf. s.v. Ved. √vah- 'fahren, Wagen lenken, Wagen ziehen, herbeiführen, befördern, bringen' < PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ-.}];141[661-662{S.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben| fahren' (IEW 1118-20).}];83[429-432{S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)' < PIE u̯eg̑ʰ-.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ni-waz- 'to carry/flow downwards', further to PIE *u̯eḡ- 'to float; to drive' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):429-432, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:535-537, [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).

Source: 141[257{S.v. *h₂eh₁- 'heiß sein' (not in IEW). The root is perhaps found verbally in Palaic ḫāri, ḫanta 'heiß sein' < *h₂eh₁-, which may be an unextended form of *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).}];54[60{Cf. s.v. Lat. āter, -tra, -trum 'black' < PIE *h₂eh₁-t(-)r- 'fireplace' (cf. OIr. áith, W. odyn 'furnace, oven' < PCl. *āti-| Pal. hāri 'to be warm', Av. ātarš, gen.sg. āθrō 'fire' < PIr. *ātr-).}];331[I:318-324{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *ātr-, *ātar- 'огонь' and derivatives, from PIE *āter-/*ātr- (cf. Lat. āter 'черный, темный'), based on an IE root *ā- or *ai- 'светить, гореть'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ātr-, *ātar-, a derivative of PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ([ESIJa](src-331) 1:318-324, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257).

Source: 338[{For Ossetic Iron χorž 'good' there are two possibilities: (a) PIr. *hwarza- 'sweet' (cf. Avestan xʷarəzišta- 'sweetest')| (b) Avestan hvarəz- < hu-wārz- 'well-doing'. Abaev considers the former to be more plausible.}];156[IV:217-219{S.v. Oss. xorz | xwarz 'хороший, добрий, славный'.}]
Comment: Sims-Williams (2000: 232f., quoted from Korn 2005: 132) suggests *su̯l̥g̑ʰ-su- in order to explain Bactrian χοζο. Korn (l.c.) assumes *su̯elk̑s for xwaš-forms.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron wɜžžaw 'heavy' : cf. Avestan wazya- 'weight'}];156[IV:105{Proto-Iranian *wazyāwan-, cf. Av. uaziia- 'weight, load' + formant -wan(t)-.}];269[{The Proto-Indo-Iranian suffix *-u̯an(t)- is cognate with PIE *-u̯ent- which formed adjectives attributing a particular quality (cf. Ancient Greek χαρίεις 'graceful, possessing grace' (m.), χαρίεσσα (f.) < Proto-Greek *kʰarí-u̯ent-, *kʰarí-u̯ent-i̯a etc. from χάρις 'grace').  Thus Proto-Iranian *u̯azi̯āu̯an(t)- 'heavy, possessing weight' from Proto-Iranian u̯azi̯a- 'weight'.}]
Justification: As though from Proto-Iranic *u̯azi̯ā̆-u̯ant- 'possessing weight', cf. Avestan uaziia- 'weight, load' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:105).

Source: 156[II:19-21{S.v. Oss. læg 'мужчина', 'муж', 'человек'. An East Caucasian loanword, cf. Abkhaz ləgaž 'old man' from *ləg 'person', etc.}]
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Abkhaz ləgaž 'old man' from *ləg 'person' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:19-21).

Source: 358[202-203{S.v. OPers. kau̯fa- 'Berg, Gebirge', from Iranic *kau̯fa- = YAv. kaofa- 'Berg| (Kamel-)Höcker'. The word, which has no certain relations outside of Iranic has apparently replaced the more widely distributed inherited word from Iranic *gari- 'Berg' (= YAv. gairi-) = Ved. girí- 'id.'. Its original meaning was perhaps 'hump'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kau̯fa-, perhaps originally 'hump', without certain cognates outside of Iranic ([Schmitt 2014](src-358):202-203).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron raχiž 'right' is from *frā-xaiza-, cf. Shughni xēz 'right', Rushan xīz etc. (Abaev only gives Pamir examples).}];156[II:353-354];83[440-442]
Comment: for Ossetic *frā-xai̯za-

Source: 83[412-413{S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ai(H)n-, a denominal formation from *u̯ai(H)na- 'watch, survey(or)' < PIE *u̯ei̯(h₁)-no- 'survey'  (cf. LIV² s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' pp.668-669, n5| IEW 1123-1124).  Forms a suppletive system with *daiH- [cognate set 2012](cog-2012) in many Iranian languages.}];567[245{Bactrian οην-, οιην-, οιν- < *waina- (cf. MPers. wēn).  Suppletive past stem λιδο < *dīta- (cf. MPers. dīd).}];141[668-669{S.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4).}]
Comment: Iranic forms that derive from MIr. *wind- would belong to cognate set 8643
Justification: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, already attested in Old Iranian (Avestan vaēnaiti, Old Persian vainatiy; cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.

Source: 344[349];83[345{"The nominal forms, NP šikam, Bal. šikam (< NP), uškumag (< NP ?) ‘belly’, Chor. šknbyk ‘entrails’, etc. may derive from this root [PIE *skep-] too, cf. NP šikaft."}]
Comment: Cheung (2007: 345) suggests a derivation from PIE *skep- ‘to cut, split (with a sharp tool), make a crack’

Schmitt (2014: 278): "Offenbar handelt es sich um eine jüngere Ersatzbildung für ein Erbwort und am wahrscheinlichsten um eine -ka-Ableitung von heteroklitischem *vaz-r̥/*vaz-n- „Kraft, Größe“; es gehört dann letztlich zu der Wurzel idg. *u̯eǵ „kräftig sein/werden“." Schmitt emphasises that connections to vazra- "weapon" are to be discarded.

Justification: Light-verb constructions construed with (parallel) loans of Arabic نفس / nafs 'breath'.

Source: 172[I:651, 670{Cf. s.v. Ved. toká- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'| tókman- n. 'junger Getreidehalm, grüner Sproß von Getreide' (IIr. YAv. taoxman- 'Same, Keim, Verwandschaft'| OPers. tauma- 'Familie, Geschlecht'). Cf. root noun túc- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'. Correspondences of IIr. *tau̯k- outside of IIr. are not certainly ascertained.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:651, 670).

Source: 141[661-62{S.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben| fahren' (IEW 1118-20.).}];83[432{S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' (cf. Pamphylian Greek ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Gk. ὄχος 'car', Lat. vehō 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride', Lith. vežù 'I ride, procure', OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', further from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):432, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).

Source: 680[125{S.v. Khw. xwb 'good' < Av. xwapah-, as Sogd. xwp, MP xwb.}]
Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia II 658) suggests a PIE extended root *(s)k̑eu̯-bʰ. Klingenschmitt (2000: 205) *huu̯-apah- "gutes Werk verrichtend", cf. Old Ind. sv-ápas- 'gut wirkend' (Mayrhofer EWAia I 84), then identical with 3165.

Justification: Parallel loans from Arabic علف / ʿalf 'feed, fodder'.

Comment: Korn (2005: 142 fn. 348) discusses a derivation of *mū "to bind", Old Ind. mū́ta- "basket", but it is not certain whether MIr. has *mūd or *mōd (Klingenschmitt 2000: 196 argues for MP mūy).

Source: 567[212{Bactrian ζιν-/ζιδο 'to strike' < Proto-Iranian *ǰana-/ǰata- (cf. Khot. jsan-/jsata-).}];83[224-225{S.v. Proto-Iranic *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen-.}];141[218-219{S.v. PIE *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).}];172[II:800-801{S.v. Ved. √han- 'schlagen, erschlagen, töten', from PIE *gʷʰen- (cf. Hitt. ku-(e)-en-zi, Gk. θεἰνω, etc.).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 218-219, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:800-801, [Cheung 2007](src-83):244-245).

Source: 320[275{S.v. Khot. bāggara- 'leaf', from Ir. *u̯arka-ra- (M.Parth.T. wrkr, Sogd.Bud. wrkr) to base *u̯ark- (Av. varəka-, Zor.P. vark, valg, NPers. barg. To [IEW](src-49) 1139 *u̯el- (of hair, wool, grass'), with -k- Skt. valká- 'bark', with -k̑- Skt. válśa- 'twig, sprout', Av. varəsa- 'hair', OCS vlasъ 'hair'.}];172[II:525-526{S.v. Ved. valká- 'Bast, Rinde, Splint'| cf. Middle Indic and Prakrit vakka- 'bark'. Probably to be related to YAv. varəka-, Khot. bāggara-, Parth. wrgr, Sogd. wrkr, MPers. warg, NPers. barg 'leaf'. Perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre'.}];81[526{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *volknò 'fibre' (< PIE *u̯olk̑-nom, cf. OE wlōh 'fibre, fringe' [no connection to Indo-Iranic lexemes mentioned]).}];363[I:123{S.v. Kurd. barg, balg, barū (m.) | barg, balg 'лист', from OIr. *varka- (cf. Av. varka- 'лист (растения)', Skt. valka- 'древесная кора' < [IEW](src-49) 1139 *u̯el-k-.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes probably to be related to Vedic valká- 'bark' ([EWAia](src-172) II:525-526, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):275, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:123). Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre', but cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):526.

Korn (2005: 88) assumes a (dialectal?) substitution of f > h; cf. Avestan zafar/n-. She follows Bailey (1979: 351b) in connecting this word with "tooth", cf. Old Ind. jámbʰa-. This evidence suggests an input *g̑m̩bʰ- > *zaβ- > *zaf- and > *δaβ- > (*daf- >) dah- respectively. Avestan shows cases of β > f, e.g. “navel” nāfa- vs. Vedic nā́bʰi- (Hoffmann/Forssman 1996: 98). I [TJ] don't see the need to assume a root without nasal for the Iranic forms (cf. Bailey, l.c.; but see Pokorny 1959: 382).
Loan from Arabic, cf. Standard Arabic دِمَاغ / dimāḡ 'brain'.

Source: 567[{Bactrian ναμιλγο 'salt' < *namadkā- (cf. Pth. nmydk, Sogd. nmʾδkh, Pashto mālga).}]
Comment: The Avestan context is about firewood "which is called nǝmaδka". Bartholomae (1904: 1068) connects this word to nǝmata- in comparison to Old Indic avatká- of avatá-. nǝmata- is interpreted as brushwood ('Reisig') and derived from the verbal root "nam" i.e. 'to bow'. If this is correct, the PIE origin would be the verbal root "nem".
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *namadkā-.

Source: 83[113-114{S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaub- 'to say (positively/negatively)' (OPers. gaub- (med.) 'to call oneself', MMP mw-, BMP gwb- /gō(w)-/ 'to say, speak', BSogd. γwβ- CSogd. γwb-, MSogd. γwβ- 'to praise', Chor. γwβ(y)- 'to boast, be proud', Bactr. γοβ- 'to make a (legal) statement, invoke the law', NP guftan/gōy-, Kurd. (Kurm.) gōtin, guhtin 'to speak'). No etymology. Cf. the Arm. loanword from Iranian govem 'I praise'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gau̯b- 'to say (positively/negatively)', no certain etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):113-114).

Source: 172[I:606-607{Cf. s.v. Ved. jráyas- 'Strecke, Erstreckung' (YAv. zraiiah-, OPers. drayah- 'Meer', MPers. drayā(b), NPers. drayā(b) 'Meer', Parth. zryh, MPers. zrēh 'Meer'). The Indo-European origins of √jray-, jráyas- are not securely determined.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:606-607).

Source: 83[48-50{S.v. Proto-Iranic *daiH- 'to look, see'.  Forms a suppletive preterite with *u̯aiHn- [cognate set 1969](cog-1969) in many Middle and New Iranian languages. Cf. Sanskrit *dhay- 'to look at, perceive'. "An IE etymology for this IIr. root is uncertain, in the absence of any credible cognates. Only Alb. di 'knows' can be cited in the LIV: l.c., which is hardly encouraging."}];172[I:777-778{S.v. Ved. √dhay-ⁱ (2) 'hinblicken, schauen, wahrnehmen, ersinnen, nachdenken, denken' (IIr., cf. OAv. daidiiat̰ 'ob er sieht| ob sie sehen' Y 44.10, YAv. ā-diδaiia 'betrachtet', OPers. dīdiy 'betrachte, schaue an!', Khot. dai-/däta-, MPers., NPers. dīdan 'sehen', Parth. dydn⁽ʾ⁾ 'apparition', etc. Further is uncertain. Formally PIE *dʰei̯H- or *dʰeH-i-?}];141[141-142{S.v. *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (IEW 243). Only IIr. and Albanian (Alb. di 'weiß, kennt' < ?*dʰiH-i̯é-).}];364[969{Cf. s.v. OAlb. di (trans.) 'wissen, kennen, können, beherrschen', continuing a present stem *dʰiH-i̯é/ó- or *dʰiH-e/o- from the root *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen'| other solutions are improbable.}]
Justification: An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ([LIV²](src-141) 141-142, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):969; however doubted by [Cheung 2007](src-83):48-50, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:777-778 without Albanian).

Source: 567[270{Bactrian τοχμανο < *tauxman-a- (cf. Av. taoxman-, Khot. ttīman-).}];172[I:651, 670{Cf. s.v. Ved. toká- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'| tókman- n. 'junger Getreidehalm, grüner Sproß von Getreide' (IIr. YAv. taoxman- 'Same, Keim, Verwandschaft'| OPers. tauma- 'Familie, Geschlecht'). Cf. root noun túc- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'. Correspondences of IIr. *tau̯k- outside of IIr. are not certainly ascertained.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:651, 670).

Source: 83[387{related to NP ANDŌXTAN 'to acquire, collect'?, maybe = Skt. TUJÁYE 'to procreate'}]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *ham-tač-, cf. PIr. *tač- 'reach for, attain, receive', and further to PIE 1. *tek- 'to stretch the land, receive, reach' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):374-375, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 618-619).

Source: 81[194-195{S.v. Proto-Slavic *grỳzti 'gnaw' (ESSJa VII 160-161), from Balto-Slavic *gr(o)uʔź- (cf. Lith. gráužti 'gnaw', Latv. graûzt 'gnaw'). [No etymology given outside of Balto-Slavic].}];353[185{Cf. s.v. Lith. gráužti 'gnaw'. [No etymology given outside of Balto-Slavic.]}];458[7:160-161{PS *gryzti / *gryzati, related to Lithuanian gráužti and Latvian graûzt. PIE *g(ʰ)reu̯- 'rub, crumb' with a root extention.}];259[183{PIE *gʷrēu̯-g̑ʰ-.}];594[{S.v. Sloven. gristi < PIE *gʷreu̯Hg̑-.}];352[356{Cf. s.v. Lith. gráužti 'nagen, benagen' (BSl. cf. Latv. graûzt 'nagen| reiben, wund reiben' OCS grysti, gryzǫ 'nagen, beißen), from PIE *gʷreu̯g̑- 'nagen', cf. Gk. βρύχω 'mit den Zähnen knirschen', βρύκω 'beißen, gierig abfressen', βρύγμος 'beißend, schlingend| mit den Zähnen klappernd, schaudernd'.}];66[244{Cf. s.v. AGk. βρῡ́κω 'to bite, eat greedily' beside βρῡ́χω 'grind the teeth' < PIE *gʷruHg̑ʰ- (cf. OCS gryzǫ, grysti 'gnaw', Lith. gráužiu, gráužti 'id.').}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷreu̯Hg̑ʰ- ([ALEW](src-352) 356, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594). This root is not reconstructed by [LIV²](src-141), nor are any comparanda outside Balto-Slavic given by [Derksen 2008](src-81), [Derksen 2015](src-353), but the comparison with AGk. βρῡ́χω 'grind the teeth' < *gʷruHg̑ʰ- appears reasonable formally and semantically (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):244).

Source: 141[446-447{S.v. *mleu̯h₂- 'sprechen' (not in IEW).}];172[II:235-236{S.v. Ved. √brav-¹ 'sprechen, sagen, reden', probably from PIE *mleu̯H- (cf. Cz. mluvati 'sprechen, reden', ORuss. mъlva, Russ. molvá 'Gerede, Gerücht', etc., TochB pälw- 'klagen').}];83[274-275{S.v. Proto-Iranic *mrauH- 'to say', from PIE *mleuH- 'to speak' (cf. Ved. brav- 'to say, speak' TochB pälw- 'to complain, bewail one's fate', Cz. mluviti 'to speak', ORu. mъlva 'chatter, murmur').  "The root *mrauH- is clearly attested only in Avestan: it has apparently been ousted by the other roots for 'to speak', *u̯ač and *gaub- respectively, in the other Iranian languages"}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-European *mleu̯h₂- 'to speak' ([LIV²](src-141) 446-447, [EWAia](src-172) II:235-236, [Cheung 2007](src-83):274-275).

Source: 607[53{Belarusian vanìtavac' is loanword from Polish wonitować, womitować which is, in turn, a loanword from Latin vomere.}]
Justification: Loanword from Polish ([Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607):53).

Source:
259[241{It is an expressive word without certain etymology. All existing, numerous etymologies are unjustified and inconvincing. Also the morphological structure is obscure, a putative suffix -'et(a) does not exist anywhere else.}];458[10: 88-91, 101{It is an exclusively Polish lexeme and it has been attested relatively late. Thus, its PS origin is dubious. Even the original phonetic form is hard to determine (*kobita or *koběta). The only solution is to link this lexeme to PS *kobĭ. It would be originally an adjective which could occure in phrases like *kobita žena 'capricious women'.[See also for a summary of other etymologies.]
PS *kobĭ [with meanings 'divination', 'bad fate', 'meeting', 'evil thing', 'bounder', 'obstinacy' attested in Slavic languages and dialects] has been linked to Old Icelandic happ 'luck, success' (with formal issues) and Irelandic cob 'victory'.}]
Comment: sporadic Slavic ?*kob(-)ě/it-
Justification: Polish kobieta is a Polish-only innovation (originally the word was abusive). It has no certain etymology despite of many attempts to explain it ([Boryś 2005](src-259):241). It is often linked to kobyla 'mare'. [ESSJa](src-458) links the lexeme to *kob- 'divination, fate', so the original meaning could be 'witch'. However, all etymologies are highly speculative.

Source: 444[536-537{S.v. 6182 Lat. palus 'Pfahl'.}];316[478-479{S.v. Lat. pālus 'pieu, pal, échlas, pilori, poteau', from pā̆k-slo- to the same root as Lat. pangō, a nasal-infixed root derived from IE *pā̆g̑-.}];54[442-443{Cf. s.v. Lat. pangō, -ere 'to insert firmly, fix' < PIE *ph₂-n-g̑-| the noun pālus is derived from an instrument noun *pā̆g-slo-.}];141[461{Cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin pālus 'stake, wooden post' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):536-537), continuing an Italic instrument noun *pā̆g-slo- derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm', cf. Latin pangō, -ere 'to insert firmly, fix' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):478-479, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):442-443, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 461).

Source: 468[73-74{S.v. ON dár (2) 'unangenehm, gewalttätig', cf. also dáligr 'schlecht, schädlich, elend'.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes from ON dáligr 'wicked, harmful, miserable' (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):73-74; no lemma in [Heidermanns 1993](src-697), [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 165[20{S.v. Proto-Germanic *albī- 'river' (ON elfr 'river', Elfd. ōve 'river', MLG elve 'riverbed'). Likely to be related to the name of the river Elbe. No further etymology outside of Germanic.}];468[100{S.v. ON elfr 'fluss', probably to Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός 'white'.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):20). For older proposals to Lat. albus 'white' in [cognate set 955](cog-955), cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):100.

Source: 141[524{S.v. *sekH- 'abtrennen' (IEW 895-6).  Italic forms come from a zero-grade i̯e-present *skH-i̯é-, from which the compositional form *ne-skH-ii̯e- > ne-sciō backformed a simplex form sciō 'weiß' (cf. n4 to lemma).  Hitt. šākki < Perfect *se-sokH- (cf. n6 to lemma for further discussion).}];80[695-697{S.v. šākk- / šakk- 'to know (about), to experience, to heed, to pay attention to, to recognize| to remember, to be expert in| to be acquainted with', from PIE *sekh₁- with the Hittite forms reflecting *o ~ *Ø ablaut: 3.sg. *sókh₁-ei, 3.pl. *skh₁-énti (cf. Lat. secō 'to cut', OCS sěšti 'to cut', PGerm. *sagṓ(n) 'to saw').}];54[545{S.v. Lat. sciō, scīre 'to know', from PIE *skh₁-i(e/o)- 'to incise' (cf. Skt. chyáti 'to cut open, skin', Gk. σχάω 'to make an incision, slit open').}]
Justification: Anatolian and Italic lexemes from PIE *sekH- 'to divide, separate' ([LIV²](src-141) 524), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):695-697, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):545).

Source: 178[II: 708{The word may (in Russian) either be a loanword from Polish spina which in turn is a loan from Latin spīna, or it is a direct cognate of Latin spīna, OHG spinula etc.}];54[580-581{De Vaan apparently regards the Slavic lexemes as cognates of Latin spīna and not loanwords derived thereof.}];609[509{The word spina was borrowed from Latin into Polish and then from Polish into Russian.}];599[193{There is no reason to assume that the Russian word was borrowed from Polish. According to Pokorny, it is a cognate of Latin spīna etc.}];636[365{The Russian word was borrowed from Latin.}];608[424{The etymology is unclear. It is either a borrowing from Latin or a cognate of Latin spina along with Latvian spina 'stick' and Old High German spinula 'pin'.}];602[371{There is no certain etymology. It is either a borrowing from Latin (via Polish) or a cognate of Latin spīna along with Latvian spina 'stick', Old High German spinula 'pin', and Tocharian A spin- 'hook'.}];607[12: 266{The word is assumed to be a loan from Polish spina < Latin spīna.}];249[{There is no certainty which of the alternative etymologies is correct.}]
Justification: It is uncertain whether this lexeme is a loanword from Latin spīna (via Old Polish?) or a cognate of it (cf. [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) II:708, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:735). [Not in [Derksen 2008](src-81) and therefore implicitly not considered a part of the Slavic inherited lexicon in that work.]

Source: 81[163{S.v. Proto-Slavic *glazъ (ESSJa VI 117-118): "Etymology unclear. If we accept that here the *z arose from *s as a result of Zupitza’s law (cf. Shevelov 1964: 147-148), it is possible to establish a connection with OHG glas ‘glass, amber’, MoE glare, etc. The correctness of the law is doubtful, however."}];599[1: 190{The word is Common Slavic but there is no convincing Slavic etymology. It is not excluded that it is a loanword from Germanic, cf. Old High German glas 'amber'.}];608[104{Russian glaz 'eye' does not have any commonly accepted etymology. Most probably it is derived from the same root as Russian gladkij 'smooth'.}];458[117-118{PS *glazŭ is most probably *gl-a-zŭ, derived from PIE *g(h)el- 'something round, spherical| small stone'. There are many other disputable hypotheses.}];259[161-162{PS *glazŭ 'small, smooth, spheric stone| peeble| amber, glass ball| bead'. There is no clear etymology. It is often assumed that the Slavic lexeme is a loanword from PG *glāza (c.f Old High German glas 'amber') which is derived from PIE *g̑ʰel- / gʰel- 'shine, glitter'.}];598[1: 409-410{Russian glaz is possibly related to CS gleznŭ, glezno 'malleolus' and further to Old Icelandic klakkr 'clod'. Other hypotheses (assuming a relationship to PS *gladŭkŭ 'smooth', *ględati 'see, look', to Old High German glas 'amber, glass' or a borrowing of its PG cognate) are inconvincing.}]
Justification: Russian glaz 'eye' has without any doubt a PS origin (*glazŭ '(small, round,) smooth stone' with a semantic development that has parallels in Slavic, cf. Russian expressive šary 'eyes' < 'ball(s)' or Polish expressive gały 'eyes' < 'ball(s)'). However, the further etymology is uncertain.

Source: 598[3: 176{Russian oxota, dialectal oxvota is derived from xotet', xoču ['want'].}];458[8: 83-84, 123{PS *xotěti ['want'] is most probably related *xvatati 'catch, take'. The *xvot- grade, PS *xotěti would be directly derived from, has not been attested elsewhere. The further etymology is obscure. It can be derived from an expressive form of the pronominal root *su̯e- (cf. PS *svojĭ ['one's own'], as to the semantic development cf. Russian prisvoit' 'grab').}];593[230{PS *xotěti does not have any convincing etymology. The hypothesis that is was derived from original *xvotěti, related to chvátat ['catch', *xvatati], is problematic due to a weak attestation of *xvo- (only in Russian dialectal ochvota 'desire').}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:83-84, 123; [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:176, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):230).

Source:
81[246{Proto-Slavic *krasnьnъ (adj.) 'beautiful'. Etymology unclear.}];598[2: 367-368{Russian krasa 'beauty', krasivyj 'beautiful' etc. are probably related to Old Icelandic hrósa 'display', Icelandic hrós 'glory', further Old Icelandic hróðr 'glory', Gothic hrōþeigs 'victorious' and Old High German hruom 'glory'. A relationship to Lithuanian krósnis 'oven' and Latin corpus 'body', Old Incdic kr̥p̩- 'shape, beauty' is less likely. It can not be related to krutit' ['curl, spin']. It has been also linked to Lithuanian grõžis 'beauty' (an irregular correspondence *k- / *g- is assumed here).}];593[310{PS *krasa. The original meaning was probably 'glare, red(ness), colour of fire'. Then it can be linked to PS *kresati. The latter has no entirely clear etymology. If related to *krasa and *krěsiti, the original meaning was 'make fire' and the maning 'hit' is secondary. Then it is derived from PIE *ker-s- < *ker- 'burn' (cf. Lithuanian kárštas 'hot'). If the meaning 'hit' is primary, then it is derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'. PS *krěsiti 'ressurect' < 'set in someone the fire of life'.
A relationship to Latin crassus 'fat' or Lithuanian grõžis 'beauty' is less probable.}];259[256{PS *krasa 'colour of fire, red(ness), brightness, beauty, brilliance, adornment' is related to Lithuanian kárštas 'hot' and derived from PIE *ker- or *kʷer- 'burn'.}];458[12: 95-97, 124-126, 140{PS *krasa shows formal features of an ancient derivative from an e-grade verbal root. It is related to *kresati which is derived from PIE *kē̆r-s- 'create, make', cf. Latin creō 'create, produce' and crēscō 'grow'.
Meanings of *kresati referring to fire ('making fire'!) developed in phrases like *kresati *ognĭ 'create fire', cf. Lihuanian kùrti 'make, do' and secondarily 'make fire' that developed in the phrase ugnį kùrti 'make fire'.
The verb *kresati had a connotation 'create (a living being)' (note that the fire was considered as a living being in the ancient time| the verb *kresati was also just the right for the phrase *kresati *ognĭ). This connotation was realized derivative *krasa which orignally referred to the semantic field of 'life, colours of life' etc. with a later development into 'red colour, blush, flower' > 'beauty'.
Cf. related lexemes *krěsiti (with meanings 'resurrect, inspirit, revive, bring to life' and also 'make fire, spark, start fire with flint' in Slavic languages and dialects) and *krěsŭ (referring to 'ceremonial, ritual fire', 'solstice, solstice rituals', 'hot weather' in Slavic languages and dialects). Porównania do Lit grożis, karśtas, Staroisl hrós nieprawidłowe}];141[391-392{S.v. *kʷer- 'cut off, carve'.}]
Justification:
I find the etymology presented in [ESSJa](src-458) as to the underlying PIE root *kʷer- and its original meaning 'make, do, create' (probably derived from a more primitive meaning 'cut', see [LIV²](src-141)) convincing.
However, I think that the proposed order of the semantic development is unconvincing and that the reconstructed connotation of the *kresati with 'life' is unnecessary. Words referring to the look of humans and animals are very often derived from verbs meaning 'make, create, form, give birth', cf. PS *tvoriti 'make, create', Polish tworzyć 'make, create' and Polish twarz 'face' > twarzowy 'about a clothing a person looks pretty in' (cf. also Polish potwór 'monster' > potworny 'horrible, ugly'), PS ličiti 'to form, to shape' (< PIE *lei̯H- 'pour', also originally 'formed by casting', cf. [cognate set 1223](cog-1223)) and PS *lico 'face', Polish śliczny 'beautiful', Macedonian ličen 'pretty' or PS *roditi 'give birth', Polish rodzić 'give birth' and Polish uroda 'look, beauty' (cf. also Russian urod 'monster, ugly person' > urodlivyj 'ugly'). We can assume a similar development in PIE *kʷer- > PS *krasa. The meaning 'red' in Russian is a later development from 'beautiful' and not the opposite way. It is limited to Russian, where the meaning 'red' is attested much later (11th century vs. 15th century) than 'beautiful' [Černyh 1999](src-599): 1: 440.

Source: 444[613{S.v. 7423 Lat. ruere 'stürzen' > Log. ruere 'fallen'.}];54[530{S.v. Lat. ruō, -ere (1) 'to rush, hurry on| tumble down, collapse', from PIE *h₃reu-e/o- 'to run, hurry' (cf. OIr. rúathar 'assault'| Gk. ὀρούω 'to hurry', Alb. ra 'to fall (down)| strike, hit' (< PAlb. *(a)rau-?)| Bel., Ukr. rux 'movement, bustle', Cz. ruch 'movement' < *(H)rous-o-)| possibly a neo-root to PIE *h₃er- 'to set in motion' according to [Meiser 2003](src-762):236.}];762[613]
Justification: Italic lexemes from Latin ruere 'to rush, hurry on; tumble down, collapse' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):613 no. 7423), further to PIE *h₃reu̯- 'to run, hurry', perhaps further derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set (oneself) in motion'? (cf. [Meiser 2003](src-762):613, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):530). [Verbal root not in [LIV²](src-141) or {ref [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)].

Source: 444[199{S.v. 2112 Lat. concha 'Muschel' (> nlog. konka 'Backtrog| Kopf').}];316[136{S.v. Lat. concha 'coquille, coquillage, conque', loan from Gk. κόγχη (already Plautus conchita, κογχίτης).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin concha 'shell, seashell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):199), an old loanword, already attested in Plautus, from Ancient Greek κόγχη, κόγχᾱ 'mussel' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):136).

Source: 54[361{S.v. Lat. mancus 'maimed, crippled (at the hand)', from Proto-Italic *manko-? "If cognate with manus 'hand', mancus must contain the athematic stem *man- 'hand'. This etymology would imply a semantic shift *man-ko- 'handy' > 'handicapped, having a defect of the hand'."}];316[382{S.v. Lat. mancus 'manchot, infirme de la main', from *man- + -ko-, with a suffix characteristic of physical qualities (cf. caecus and peccāre?).}];444[431{S.v. 5285 Lat. mancus 'verstümmelt'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):431), perhaps further derived from Latin manus 'hand' in [cognate set 888](cog-888) (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):382, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):361 for further discussion).

Source: 444[532{S.v. 6450 *pettia (gall.) 'Stück'.}]
Justification: From Proto-Romance *pettia ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):532), generally regarded as a borrowing from Celtic (cf. Welsh peth 'thing, object')

Source: 54[267{Cf. s.v. Lat. gnārus 'knowing, experienced', whence Lat. narrāre 'to relate, tell'. Lat. gnārus from PIE *g̑nh₃-ro- 'knowing' (cf. Gk. γνώριμος 'well-known', etc.). The gemination in the verb narrāre can be explained from *nārāre by the littera-rule, which must have operated by Proto-Italic to judge from U. naratu 'speak, recite' (3.sg.imptv.), etc.}];141[168-170{Cf. s.v. *g̑neh₃- 'erkennen' (IEW 376-8).}];444[481{S.v. 5829 Lat. narrāre 'erzählen'.}]
Comment: From Lat. narrāre.
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin narrāre 'to relate, tell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):481), further to PIE *g̑neh₃- 'know' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):267, [LIV²](src-141) 168-170).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan 'nfuso < Lat. infūsu(m), p.p.p. of in infŭndere.}];54[249-250{S.v. Lat. fundō 'pour, let go, emit' < PIE *g̑ʰu-n-d- 'to pour'.}];141[179-180{Cf. s.v. ?*g̑ʰeu̯d- 'gießen' (IEW 448)| cf. n1: Only Italic and Germanic  (cf. Goth. giutan). A post-PIE enlargement of *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour' for phonotactic reasons?, cf. also s.v. *g̑ʰeu̯- 'gießen' (IEW 447-448).}];444[363{Cf. s.v. 4415 Lat. infundere 'hineingießen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin infūsum (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), the past passive participle of Latin infundere 'pour in' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):363). Further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯d- 'pour', possibly a post-PIE enlargement of *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour' for phonotactic reasons ([LIV²](src-141) 179-180n1, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):249-250). Root assignment in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) in reconstructing a separate root *g̑ʰeu̯d-.

Source: 458[7: 177{PS *gurati, *guriti is related to Lithuanian gū́ra 'person walking bended down' and Greek γῡρός 'round, curved' (other forms linked here are Norwegian kūra 'lie huddled' and German kauern 'be huddled') and derived from PIE *geu̯-r- < *geu̯- 'bend'.}];66[290, 293{S.v. γῡρός 'round, curved'. "Connection with *gou- 'hand', *guH- 'curved' (see Frisk) seems quite possible."}]

392[{S.v. Sw. skratta, an intensive formation to skrata, of onomatopoeic origin, cf. Sw. dial. skrata 'scare, chase away', Nw. dial. skrata 'cackle (of birds)', Da. dial. skrade 'make a loud noise', etc.}]
Justification: An intensive formation to Swedish skrata 'scare, chase away', of onomatopoeic/imitative origin ([Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

Source: 165[88{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dampa- 'vapour', derived from PGmc. *dimban- ~ *dimpan- 'to fog' < PIE *dʰembʰ-e-.}];392[{S.v. Sw. damm (2). To be connected with Germ. Dampf, etc.}];397[180{Cf. s.v. NHG Dampf (MHG dampf, tampf, OHG dampf, MLG damp, MDu. damp), from Gmc. *dampi- 'Ausdünstung, Dampf', considered to a be a labial extension of the same root also found in OHG toum 'Dampf, Dunst' and with s-mobile OE stēam, NE steam (cf. Lat. fūmus < *dʰūmo-), based on a meaning 'blasen, fauchen' (cf. similarly Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen, schnuppern', with labial extension dùmples 'Blasebalg').}];388[68{S.v. Proto-Germanic *đampaz, based on strong verb *đempanan > MHG dimpfen 'to steam, to smoke', and related to Lith. dùmpti 'to blow'. ([IEW](src-49) 247-248 to Skt. dhámati 'to blow').}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ([IEW](src-49) 247-248, [Orel 2003](src-388):68, [Kluge 2011](src-397):180; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158). Alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in [LIV²](src-141).).

Source: 83[117-118{S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaz-? 'to bite, sting'. An exclusively Iranian root, only attested from Middle Iranian onwards. Earlier suggestions by Korn (2005:80fn27) deriving from PIE *geg̑ʰ- 'to enter, seep in', Skt. gāh-) and Bailey (1979:349a) to PIE *g̑eg̑⁽ʰ⁾- are semantically (Korn), or formally (Bailey) unconvincing.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Iranic, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):117-118 for further discussion.

Source: 83[144-145{S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯anH- 'to call', from PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' (cf. Ved. svan- 'to sound', Lat. sonere, sonāre, 'to sound, ring', sonus 'noise, sound', OE swinn 'music').}];141[611{S.v. *su̯enh₂- 'tönen, klingen' (IEW 1046-7).}];50[360-361{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *swan-na- 'sound, play (an instrument)', whence OIr. seinnid, -seinn. From PIE *su̯enh₂- '(produce) sound' (cf. Skt. svan-, Lat. sonō, sonus 'sound', OE swinn 'music').}];304[607-609{S.v. Proto-Celtic *su̯an-na- 'zum Ertönen erbringen', from PIE *su̯enh₂- (LIV 611), cf. IEW 1046f. *su̯en-.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯an-na- 'to sound, play an instrument', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ([LIV²](src-141) 611, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):607-609, [Matasović 2009](src-50):360-361).

Source: 50[105-06{S.v. Proto-Celtic *druko- 'bad'. The etymology is quite uncertain. One might want to try to relate Proto-Celtic *druko- to PIE *dʰreu̯gʰ- 'deceive' (IEW 276, Skt. drúhyate 'deceives', OHG bi-triugan 'decieve', gi-trog 'deceit') from an appealing semantic connection 'false, deceitful' > 'bad', but the the voiceless *-k- in Celtic (instead of *-g-) is problematic.}];296[D:198-199{S.v. OIr. droch (1) 'mauvais'. The Celtic forms may be related to an earlier *druko-, for which there are no plausible further connections. Cf. entry for a survey of older literature.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *druko- 'bad', further connections uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996 D:198-199, [Matasović 2009](src-50):105-106).

Source: 50[64{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *bēto-, *biyato- 'food' (OIr. bíad, MW bwyd), derived from PIE *gʷei̯h₃- ~ *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' (cf. Lat. uīta 'life', Lith. gyvatà. The Brythonic words can be derived from *bēto- < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-to-.}];236[{S.v. W bwytâf: bwyta, byta, derived from W bwyd 'food'.}];141[215-216{Cf. s.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (IEW 467-9).}]
Justification: Derived from Middle Welsh bwyd 'food' (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)), further from Proto-Celtic *bēto- < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-to- ([Matasović 2009](src-50):64), cf. PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' ([LIV²](src-141) 215-216).

Source: 50[295–296{S.v. Proto-Celtic *obnu- 'fear'. "The PIE etymology is unknown, but a connection with Croat. jéza 'fear, terror' appears plausible. Cf. also Lith. éngti 'to strangle', ON ekki 'convulsive sobbing', OE 'doubt, complaint' ([Orel 2003](src-388): 84). The Slavic forms presuppose Early PSl. *endzā or *indzā, and can be derived from PIE *h₁engʷ-, with the nasal infix from the verbal base (present stem) [...] The PIE root would be *h₁egʷ-. PCelt. *obno- or *obnu- can be from PIE *h₁ogʷno- or *h₁ogʷnu-."}];332[{derives from Common Celtic *fowno-, cf Old Irish úath 'horror, fear', Lat. pauor}];296[O:22];157[170{Cf. s.v. Gaul. exobnos 'hardi, sans crainte'}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic disputed, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:22, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):170, [Matasović 2009](src-50):295-296, for various proposals.

Source: 50[345{S.v. Proto-Celtic *slad-yo- 'to hit, to slay'. No convincing IE etymology.}];305[178];304[583-587{S.v. Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯e/o- 'to strike, to kill', PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ-. Schumacher follows [Schrijver 1995](src-305):178 who reconstructs this root, neither contained in IEW nor in LIV².}]
Justification: Cf. Middle Welsh lladd 'to kill', further derived from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ([Matasović 2009](src-50):345), cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following [Schrijver 1995](src-305):178. [Not in [LIV²](src-141)].

Source: 274[499-504{S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV² 448, IEW 315f.).  Germanic and Italic forms reflect a derived noun *nebʰ-elo/ah₂- > Lat. nebula, PGerm. *nebela- 'dunkel'.}];172[II:13{Cf. s.v. Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke, Gewölk, Nebel', an s-stem noun from PIE *nebʰ- 'befeuchten'.}];165[386{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nebala- 'fog', an l-extension to PIE *nébʰ-os, gen. *mbʰ-és-os 'cloud, sky'.}];54[404{S.v. Lat. nebula 'mist, fog', from PIE *nebʰ-e-lo- 'small cloud'.}];442[400{S.v. 6955c Skt. *nabhalikā- 'cloud'. [Cf. Lat. nebula, &c., nábhas-]}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:13, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):400 no. 6955c, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):386, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):404).

Source: 50[86-87{S.v. Proto-Celtic *dago- 'good'. No convincing IE etymology.}];296[D:7-8{S.v. OIr. dag 'bon', no plausible etymology.}]
Justification: No convincing etymology outside of Celtic. See [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:7-8, [Matasović 2009](src-50):86-87 for various suggestions.

Source: 50[370-371{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tara-wo- 'hit, strike', from PIE *terh₁- 'drill, rub' (cf. Lat. terō, Gk. τορεύω).}];141[632-633{Cf. s.v. *terh₁- 'bohren, reiben' (IEW 1071-2).}];236[{S.v. W trawaf, tarawaf: taro, trawo, tarawo "to strike, give (a blow, knock, &c.) (to), hit, beat, knock, buffet, pound| ?pound (in mortar, &c.)| beat (of heart, &c.), pulsate| attack, clash, fight, battle." cf. Old Breton toreusit, gl. atriuit, Middle Breton tarauat ‘treulio, rhwbio’, Late Breton (taf. Gwened) torein ‘taro, bwrw’: from PIE *terə-, cf. Latin terō, Gr. τορεύω]}]
Justification: Welsh lexemes derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):370-371, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 632-633).

Source: 50[220{S.v. Proto-Celtic *koxsā 'leg', cf. PIE *kok̑so- 'hollow of joint' (IEW 611), cf. Latin coxa 'hip', OHG hāhsa and Toch. B kakse 'loins'.}];54[140{S.v. Lat. coxa 'hip', from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' (cf. OIr. coss 'foot', Ved. kakṣa-, Av. kaša- 'armpit', TochB kakse 'midriff loins'). de Vaan rejects the connection with the Germanic words as assumed by IEW and Matasović (2009).}];579[{Neapolitan coscia < Lat. cŏxa(m), cf. It. coscia.}];296[C:214{S.v. OIr. cos 'jambe, pied', related to Lat. coxa, cf. OHG hahsa 'creux de l'articulation du genou', Skt. kákṣa- 'aisselle'.}]
Justification: Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):140, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):212 no. 2292, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:214, [Matasović 2009](src-50):220).

Source: 236[{S.v. W ceg 'throat, gullet, windpipe, neck| mouth, opening, entrance', possibly a loanword from Old English céce 'the swallow, fauces| mouth, cheek'? [entry last revised 1959].}]
Justification: [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) suggests a possible loanword from Old English céce 'fauces, mouth, cheek' (> Engl. cheek).

Source: 296[O:8{S.v.
