OIr. ocus 'proche, voisin de' In Welsh the word 'wnc' or 'wng' 'voisin' and 'voisinage' go back to *onk-, that is to say equivalent to Ir. oc| but it has been replaced early by agos. The same in Middle Cornish ogas, Middle Breton hogos 'presque', hogosder 'voisinage'. The g of these forms is embarrassing. Pedersen I 161 considers a borrowing from Irish, where ocus, from *oggu- (Thurn. 525) is derived from oc.}]
Justification: The Brythonic forms in this class may be etymologically separate from the Goidelic lexemes in this class, cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):161, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:8, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236).

Source: 50[353{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *srognā- 'nose'| the relationship of Welsh trwyn, OCo. trein, which appear to be from *trognī, to Proto-Celtic *srognā 'nose' is unclear.}];236[{S.v. W trwyn 'nose, snout| sense of smell' (cf. OCo. trein gl. 'nasus', Late Cornish tron, Gaul. *trugnā (> Fr. trogne).}];305[442n2{"As Pokorny pointed out (1960), MW trwyn, OCo. trein 'nose' reflect *trugnV-, with -u- in view of Continental Celtic *trugna- reflected in Romance ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444): 8947). The different vocalism renders an etymological identification of W ffroen (with -o-, Continental Celtic *frogna) with trwyn, which was advocated by Meid (1960:44| 1960a: 268), impossible."}]
Justification: Welsh lexemes, which along with Old Cornish trein and Gaulish *trugna- (implied through Romance, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):744 no. 8947) appear to reflect Proto-Celtic *trugnV- ([Schrijver 1995](src-305):442n2, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Matasović 2009](src-50):353).

Source: 236[{S.v. gwthiaf, gythiaf: gwthio, gythio 'to push, shove', denominal to gwth 'a push, lunge, thrust'. Root etymology uncertain, either to *ĝhei- or *u̯ei-.}]
Comment: etym. dub.
Justification: Denominal from Welsh gwth 'a push, shove, thrust', further root etymology uncertain, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) for various suggestions.

Source: 236[{Cf. s.v. W pwdr (2) 'rotten, decayed, putrid', a borrowing from Lat. putris, cf. Late Cornish podar.}]
Justification: Loan from Late Latin putris (putridus) 'rotten, putrid' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 240[22{S.v. Old Welsh carrecc 'stone' (MW carrec, C carrag, OB carrec| cf. MIr. carric), from PIE *kar- 'hart' (cf. IEW 532).}];309[373{S.v. Bret. karreg 'rocher' (Old Breton carrec, 1050), corresponding to Cornish carrek, Welsh carreg| Irish carraig is a borrowing from Middle Welsh carric from Welsh. These words go back to Proto-Celtic *kars-ekki-.}];296[C:42-43{Cf. s.v. OIr. carrac 'roche'. There is no need to posit a root *kar- 'dur' but it's rather a derivative of an Ibero-Mediterranean *carrā 'pierre' which is found, among others in Basque harri 'pierre', Béarnese carroc and with various suffixes in the languages of Western Europe. Cf. also MW carrawc, Modern Welsh carrog 'torrent' (= le ruisseau rempli de cailloux?). Cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):23, 83| [IEW](src-49) 532.}]
Justification: A probable Mediterranean substratum word ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:42-43, cf. also [Falileyev 2000](src-240):22, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):373). Perhaps cognate with Armenian kʻar in [cognate set 651](cog-651), but ultimately uncertain. Cf. notes in that class for further discussion. If this is the same substratum word as in Armenian, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.

Source: 236[{S.v. W cynffon 'tail' a compound of cyn- 'before' + ffon 'stick'.}];50[{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff' (cf. MIr. sond 'stake, beam, palisade'), from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' (cf. Lat. sponda 'bedstead, bed', OE spōn 'sliver, shaving', Gk. σφήν 'wedge'). An alternative etymology derives PCelt. *sfondo- and Lat. sponda from PIE *(s)pend- 'to spin' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):582), but the semantics of this comparison are less appealing.}]
Justification: Welsh lexemes consisting of a compound  cyn- 'before' + ffon 'stick' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)); the 'stick' compound member, for which cognacy is being encoded in this set, continues Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):334).

Source: 50[391{S.v. Proto-Celtic *truk-, *truxso- 'trunk, broken part' (cf. MIr. trú 'doomed person, man condemned to death', MW trwch 'wounded, broken, sad, thickness, density', OBret. truch gl. obtusi, MoBret. trouc'h troc'h 'cut', OCo. trech gl. truncus, MoCo. trogh 'broken'), from PIE *treu̯k- 'cut' (IEW 1074), cf. Lat. truncus '1. mutilated, 2. stem'. The meaning 'thickness, density' in Modern Welsh trwch is a secondary semantic shift. "Despite formal and semantic problems, the connection to Lat. truncus 'trunk', trucidāre, Lith. trenkiù 'hit' remains probable, but forms adduced in IEW (1074) belong to several different roots." The Brythonic forms presuppose *trukso- with regular metathesis to *trusko- > W trwch.}];54[630-631{Cf. s.v. Lat. truncus 'mutilated, maimed, trimmed'. There is no compelling reason to connect *tru/onko- with Go. ϸreihan 'to push' or Lith. triñkti 'to thrust' (cf. LIV s.v. *trenk- 'to push').}]

66[1475-1476{S.v. τέφρα 'ash' < PIE *dʰegʷʰ-r-h₂. Cf. PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. Skt. dahati 'burn', etc.).}];270[1112{S.v. AGk. τέφρα 'cendre', plausibly connected with PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn'.}];141[133-134{Cf. s.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' (IEW 240-1).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes as nominal derivatives PIE *dʰegʷʰ-r-h₂ from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1475-1476, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1112; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 133-134).

Source: 442[275{Cf. s.v. 5020 Ved. chādi- *'covering', in cmpd. chādi- muṣṭi- 'handful of ashes' (JaimBr.) (from √chad- 1)| 5021 Skt. *chādi-kūṭa- 'heap of ashes' > Maithili chaur.}];172[I:554-555{Cf. s.v. Ved. √chad- 'bedecken, zudecken, verhüllen'. Morgenstierne connected YAv. sāδaiiaṇtī- meaning something like 'lange Hose', further connections are unclear. Perhaps to IE *sk̑ed- 'bedecken' if connected with OE hætera 'garments' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 919).}];141[546{Cf. s.v. ?*(s)k̑ed- 'bedecken' (IEW 919).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes derived to Ved. √chad- 'to cover' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):275, nos. 5020-5021); further etymology uncertain, perhaps to PIE ?*(s)k̑ed- ([IEW](src-49) 919, [LIV²](src-141) 546) if connected with Old English hætera 'garments' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:554-555 for further discussion). The root reference form for this set tentatively follows this etymology.

Source: 165[250{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'ridge| back'. No certain connections outside of Germanic.}];397[775{S.v. NHG Rücken (MHG ruck(e), rück(e), OHG hrucci, ruggi, rucke, OS hruggi), from Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'Rücken', also found in ON hryggr, OE hrycg, OFr. hregg, of unclear origin. The closest possible comparison is OIr. crocenn 'Rücken' (in which case from PIE *kr̥kn-), but this word is attested only once in a gloss (the corresponding normally has the meaning 'Haut'). Possibly the same basis *keru- might be found in Ved. karū́kara- 'Wirbel des Halses und des Rückgeräts' and Lat. cervīx 'Nacken, Halswirbel', but the part of the k-suffix is unclear.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'ridge; back'. Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):250, [Kluge 2011](src-397):775 for further discussion.

Source: 444[670{S.v. 8128 Lat. spatha (griech.) 'Schwert' and s.v. 8130 Lat. spatula 1. 'Rührlöffel', 2. 'Schulterblatt, Schulter'.}];316[638-639{Cf. s.v. Lat. spatha 'battoir, spatule| épée large et longue', a borrowing from Greek σπάθη, and from which spatula 'épaule (d'animal)'.}];423[II:733-734{S.v. Sp. espalda, from late Latin spatula 'omóplato', earlier 'espátula', 'pala de ciertos instrumentos', diminutive of Lat. spatha, in turn a loanword from Greek σπάθη 'id.'.}]
Justification: Romanian spathe is originally from Latin spatha 'beater, spatula', originally a loanword from Greek σπάθη 'broad blade (of wood or metal)', while the Iberian Romance forms are from Latin spatula, the diminutive of spatha  (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):612, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):638-639, [DCECH](src-423) II:733-734).

Source: 81[276{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *lędvьje| *lędvьja 'loins' < PIE *lendʰ-u- (cf. Lat. lumbus 'loin', OHG lentīn 'kidneys, loins').}];458[15:48-50{It is a reflex of PIE *lendhu̯- and a cognate of Latin lumbus, Old High German lenti, German Lende, Old Icelandic lend etc.}];259[286{It is a reflex of PIE *lendʰ- and a cognate of Latin lumbus, Old High German lenti and Old Icelandic lend.}]
Comment: 'loins'
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *lendʰ-u- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):276, [ESSJa](src-458) 15:48-50).

Source: 172[II:258-59{S.v. Ved. bhásman- 'Asche', either from PIE *bʰes- 'to skew, to crunch' (LIV² 82) or from PIE *bʰes- 'to blow, to breathe'. The latter root is only preserved by nouns.}];274[34-36{S.v. *bʰes- 'reiben, fegen' (cf. LIV² 82 s.v. ?*bʰes- '(zer)kauen), IEW 145f.). NIL treats *bʰes- '(zer)kauen' as the same root as *bʰes- 'reiben, fegen', cf. p.35n1.}];269[{Following NIL 34-36 we might assume that the two Indic roots in Mayrhofer EWAia II:257-258 go back to the same root *bʰes-.}];442[537{S.v. 9425 Skt. bhásman- n. 'ashes'.}]
Justification: [EWAia](src-172) II:258-259 supposes two possible (homophonous) root etymologies either to *bʰes- 'to skew, to crunch' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 82 s.v. ?*bʰes- '(zer)kauen') or *bʰes- 'to blow, to breathe', however [NIL](src-274) 34-36 considers these two postulated roots to be one and the same. For developments in Middle and Modern Indic, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):537, no. 9425.

This word is well attested in Iranian languages. Cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):267 on Khotanese bata- "small" deriving it from a root *vā "be deficient", cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):204 *h₁u̯eh₂- "to be empty, absent, lacking".

Source: 165[573, 587{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wanda- 'turned, twisted' (ON vandr 'difficult, bad, Elfd. uond 'bad', OS wand 'changeable'), an o-grade adjective derived from *windan- 'wind', from PIE *uéndʰ-e-.}];141[681-682{Cf. s.v. *u̯endʰ- '(um)winden' (IEW 1148).}];697[654-655{S.v. Germanic *wanda- 'sich wendend', a verbal adjective to the strong verb *wenda- 'winden'.}];556[554-555{Cf. s.v. Germanic *wend-a- 'winden' (derived adjective *wand-a- > ON vandr 'schwierig', OS un-wand 'wandelbar', from PIE *u̯endʰ- 'flechten, winden'.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *wanda- 'turned, twisted', further derived from PIE u̯endʰ- 'to twist, wind' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):554-555, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):654-655, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):573, 587, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 681-682).

Source: 165[117{S.v. Proto-Germanic *elhja- 'evil', as though from PIE *h₁elk-io- (cf. OIr. elc 'mischievous, capricious' < *h₁elk-o-(?)). "The cluster -ll- can be derived from several sources in Old Norse and has therefore given occasion to many different etymologies. In view of the Finnish loanwords elkiä adj. 'mean, malicious' and ilkeä adj. 'bad, mean, wicked', the derivation of illr from *elhila- (with *-ila- as in *mekila- 'big', and *lītila- 'small'?) through syncope is least problematic. Alternatively it is possible to assume that the root illr arose from *ĭ́li-ligr, cf. ON dælla adv. 'friendly' < *dæli-liga, etc. […] The final i of *ĭ́li- in *ĭ́li-ligr just like Fi. elkiä points to an original ja-stem *elhja-."}];468[285{S.v. ON illr 'schlecht, böse'. Etymology disputed.}];84[{Cf. s.v. Engl. ill, from Early Middle English ill, borrowed from Old Norse illr ill, bad, wicked, difficult, injurious, etc. Further etymology unknown| not related to Old English yfel.}];697[637-638{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *ubela- 'böse' (cf. Goth. ubils, OE yfel, etc.). The North Germanic forms from Old Norse illr perhaps belong here if de-rounded from *yllr and -βl- irregularly assimilated to -ll-.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *elhja- 'evil'; further etymology uncertain ([de Vries 1977](src-468):285). More recently cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):637-638 suggesting a connection to PGmc. *ubila- 'bad' in [cognate set 2195](cog-2195) under the assumption of some irregular sound changes; alternatively cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):117 tentatively suggests a connection with OIr. elc 'mischievous, capricious' via ?*h₁elk-o-. Root ref. form follows the reconstruction of [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. bad (adj.). Of uncertain origin, cf. OED entry for various suggestions and possible early attestations.}]
Justification: Of uncertain origin ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 165[557{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ubila- 'evil, bad'. Meaning of the PGmc. form maybe 'overstepping a boundary'. Perhaps connected to OIr. fel. The connection to Hitt. ḫuu̯appi / ḫuppanzi 'to be hostile towards, to evil against| throw down, hurl' < *h₂uóph₁-ei, h₂uph₁-énti must be rejected because the meaning 'do evil' developed from 'overthrow' in Hittite ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):369-372).}];50[396{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ufelo- 'bad, evil', from PIE *h₂u̯op- 'treat badly' (cf. Hitt. huwapzi 'harrows, despoils', Goth. ubils 'evil'). The development *h₂up-elo- > *ufelo- > welo > OIr. fel is regular. The closest cognates are found in Germanic (cf. also OE yfel 'evil, bad').}];75[339{"A verbal root *h₂/₃u̯op- ‘treat badly’ is recovered from Celtic (OIr fel ‘bad’), Germanic (e.g. NE evil ), and Anatolian (huwappi ~ huwapzi ‘ill-treats, despoils’)."}];80[369-371{S.v. Hitt. ḫuu̯app- / ḫupp- 'to be hostile towards, to do evil against' with derived adj. ḫuu̯appa- 'evil, ill, bad'. Contra [Melchert 2007](src-713), K. argues that the two Hittite verbs ḫuu̯app- / ḫupp-, one meaning 'to hurl, to throw (+ acc.)', one 'to be hostile towards, to be evil against (+ dat.-loc.)', are in fact identical, with the second meaning derived from the first. The date of the semantic shift is unclear| if the Germanic words in question are connected (as suggested by [Juret 1942](src-714):71), then already in PIE.  Possibly also connected: skt. vap- 'to throw', av. vīuuāpat̰ 'to strews apart, plunders, destroys'. - Reconstructed PIE present: *h₂u̯óph₁-/ h₂uph₁-, root form thus *h₂u̯eph₁-.}];389[{Tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- > ?heth. (katta) huwappi ‘wirft, schleudert (herab)’ in view of [Melchert 1988](src-416):233n1, [Melchert 2007](src-713):513-9, but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):369-71.}];416[233 Fn. 1{Hitt. ḫuu̯app- 'hurl, throw' is to be connected with Skt. vap-. Both from PIE *h₂u̯ep- 'to throw'| apart from that also PIE *h₂u̯ep/h₂eu̯p- 'evil' which is the basis for Goth. ubil etc. < *h₂up-é-lo- (for which cf. [Watkins 1969](src-391):30).}];391[30{Goth. ubils (+) < *up-élo- from a nominal root PIE *ə̯u̯e/op-, ə̯up-. Hitt. ḫuu̯apzi also belongs to this root and is a denominative verb.}];179[371{S.v. Goth. U2. ubils 'κακός', 'bad, evil', cf. Tischler (HEG I:331-32) against the connection with Hitt. ḫuu̯appa- 'bad' made by [Watkins 1969](src-391):30.}];397[938{S.v. NHG übel (MHG übel, OHG ubil, OS uƀil), from Gmc. *ubila- 'übel', also in Goth. ubils, OE yfel, OFr. evel. Outside of Germanic one compares OIr. fel 'schlecht', which may go back to IE *upelo-). Further origins unknown. Perhaps to Hitt. hwappa- 'böse, schlecht', in which case the Germanic forms could go back to a zero-grade of an IE root *Hu̯ep-.}];697[637-638{S.v. Gmc. *ubela- 'böse'. The West Germanic form of the adjective *upélo- can be identical with OIr. fel (of uncertain attestation), if this is not a borrowing from Old French fel 'treulos'. [Watkins 1969](src-391):30 further attempts to connect Hitt. ḫuwappa- 'schlecht' and ḫuwapzi 'behandelt schlecht' to a root roun *ḫuwap-, from which the Germanic correspondence may be derived via a root *Hu̯e/op- : *Hup-.}];269[{The further connections of the Germanic adjective *ubila- 'bad' are debated. It is generally agreed that OIr. fel 'bad, evil' may be formally identical with the Germanic lexemes from earlier *upelo-, if the Celtic lexemes are not borrowings from Old French fel 'faithless, unfaithful, disloyal' (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):637-638, [Matasović 2009](src-50):396, [Kluge 2011](src-397):938, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):557). Debated remain the further proposed connections to Hitt. ḫuu̯appa-, connected since [Juret 1942](src-714):71 and further advocated by [Watkins 1969](src-391):30, [Melchert 1988](src-416):233n1, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):369-371, but doubted or rejected by [Lehmann 1986](src-179):371, [Kluge 2011](src-397):938, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):557. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- for the proposed Anatolian cognates.}]
Justification: The further connections of the Germanic adjective *ubila- 'bad' are debated. It is generally agreed that OIr. fel 'bad, evil' may be formally identical with the Germanic lexemes from earlier *upelo-, if the Celtic lexemes are not borrowings from Old French fel 'faithless, unfaithful, disloyal' (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):637-638, [Matasović 2009](src-50):396, [Kluge 2011](src-397):938, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):557). Debated remain the further proposed connections to Hitt. ḫuu̯appa-, connected since [Juret 1942](src-714):71 and further advocated by [Watkins 1969](src-391):30, [Melchert 1988](src-416):233n1, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):369-371, but doubted or rejected by [Lehmann 1986](src-179):371, [Kluge 2011](src-397):938, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):557. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- for the proposed Anatolian cognates.

Source: 54[89-90{S.v. Lat. capiō, -ere 'to take', from PIE *kh₂p-i- or non-IE *kap-i- 'to seize' (cf. Gk. κάπτω 'to gulp down', Go. haban 'to have' < *kap-eh₁-i̯e/o-), secondarily derived noun captiō 'trick, loss', from which captīvus (adj.) 'taken prisoner'.}];141[344-345{Cf. s.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-528)| in addition to Italic cognates are found in Germanic (NHG haben 'to have') and Greek (κάπτω 'gulp down').}];444[157{S.v. 1663 Lat. captīvus 'gefangen, elend' > It. cattivo 'elend', 'schlecht', 'böse'.}]
Justification: From Latin captīvus 'taken prisoner' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):157), derived from Latin capiō, -ere 'take', further to PIE *keh₂p- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):89-90, [LIV²](src-141) 344-345).

Source: 443[14:575{Fr. viande from Lat. vīvenda (vīvō 'live').}];54[685-686{Cf. s.v. Lat. vīvō, -ere 'to live', from PIE *gʷih₃-ue/o- 'to live'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin vivenda 'foodstuffs' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):786 no. 9410, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 14:575), originally a neuter plural gerundive form derived from Latin vivere 'to live' and ultimately to PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):685-686 and further discussion in [cognate set 72](cog-72)).

Source: 165[346{S.v. Proto-Germanic *magan- 'stomach'. A European word with no IE etymology. Similar words also occur in Baltic and Slavic, cf. Lith. mãkas 'purse, pouch, scrotum', Latv. maks 'purse', OPr. danti-max 'gums'| OCS mošьna 'small bag, scrip', Ru. mošná 'pouch, purse'.}];360[399{Cf. s.v. Lith. mãkas '(Geld)beutel'. Whether OHG mago 'Magen' is to be connected with Lith. mãkas is questionable.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):346, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):375). Occasionally compared to Balto-Slavic lexemes, e.g. Lith. mãkas 'purse, pouch, scrotum', but the connection remains uncertain (cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):399).

Source: 345[165-166{S.v. TochB kātso 'belly, stomach, abdomen, womb', which with TochA kāts reflect Proto-Tocharian *kātsān-| further connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, but cf. entry for various proposals.}];149[112{S.v. B kātse, A kāts 'belly, abdomen, womb'| etymology disputed. Traditionally to Goth. qiϸus 'stomach', but there are morphological and morphophonological difficulties. Possibly with TochA kāc 'skin' with semantic development from 'sack' to 'belly', as though CT *kʷātså < IE *kuH-ti̯-eh₂-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian obscure, probably connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kātse 'near'. Cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):112, [Adams 2013](src-345):165-166 for various further discussion.

Source: 81[85-86{S.v. Proto-Slavic *červo 'belly, intestine' (ESSJa IV 82-83), from Balto-Slavic *ker-m/w- (cf. OPruss. kērmens 'body'), cf. also Skt. cárman- 'hide, skin'.}];178[III: 319];172[I:592{For the common comparison to Skt. cárman- 'skin', cf. s.v. Ved. cárman- 'Haut, Fell, abgezogene Haut' < PIE *(s)kér-men- *'cut' → 'removed skin'.}];594[{Cf. s.v. Sloven. črevọ̑, from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'. Initially the word referred to internal organs, guts that are cut off from animal's belly.}];259[649{PS *červo 'internal organs in the abdominal cavity, guts, intestines| skin, especially from animal's belly'. PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.}];458[4:82-83{PS *červo is derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *červo 'belly, intestine' ([ESSJa](src-458) 4:82-83, [Derksen 2008](src-81):85-86) and further derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off').

Source: 69[p. 167f.];399[I:368{Cf. s.v. Skt. caṭakaḥ 'Sperling / sparrow', probably of onomatopoeic origin. Similar words in Dravidian (cf. Kan. ceṭṭi 'Sperlingsweibchen, etc.'.}];442[248{S.v. 4571 Skt. caṭaka m. 'sparrow' MBh., °kā- f. Pañcat., °ṭikā- f. lex. 2. *ciṭaka- . [Onom. cf. *caṭa -- and similar words in Drav. and Mu. EWA i 368]}]
Justification: Cf. Skt. caṭaka- ~ *caṭikā- 'sparrow', Prakrit caḍaa ~ ciḍiga ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):248 no.4571. Of uncertain origin, possibly onomatopoeic ([KEWA](src-399) I:368).

Source: 50[81{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bruson- 'abdomen, womb', from PIE *breu̯s- 'belly'(?), cf. OE breost 'breast', Russ. brjúxo 'belly, paunch'. Proto-Celtic *bruson- is an n-stem derived from the zero-grade of the PIE root (*bʰrus-on-).}];165[76, 80{S.v. Proto-Germanic *breusta- 'breast, chest' (ON brjóst, OE brēost, OFri. briast, OS briost < *bʰreus-sth₂-o-) and Proto-Germanic *brust- 'breast, chest' (Goth. brusts, OFri. brust, burst, OS brust < *bʰrus-sth₂-o-), cf. Russ. brjúxo 'belly, paunch' < *bʰreus-o-, OIr. brú (gen. bronn), MW bru 'womb, belly' < *bʰrus-n-io-.}];296[B:99-100{S.v. OIr. 1 brú 'sein, ventre, matrice'. The words suppose a root *bhreus-, *bhrus-, from which Celtic created a stem *bhrusnyo-. The same root is attested in Germanic, cf. Goth. brusts, OHG brust, OE breost, OS briost, etc.}];179[82{S.v. Goth. B106. brusts 'σπλάγχνα, entrails, heart| στῆθος, chest', derived from IE *bʰreu̯s-, *bʰrus- 'swell' as in OIr. brú, gen. bronn 'breast, belly'.}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):82, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):76, 80, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:99-100, [Matasović 2009](src-50):81).

Source: 259[431{The Slavic lexeme is related to dialectal Lithuanian pìršys 'horse chest', Old Indic párśu- 'rib', Avestan parəsu- 'rib'. It is derived from PIE *perk̑- 'rib'.}];81[429{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьrsь 'chest, breast' < BSl. *pírʔśis (cf. Lith. pìršys Npl. f. 'chest (of a horse)'. "Since the connection with Skt. párśu- 'rib, curved knife' is better abandoned, the etymology must be designated as unclear."}];172[II:100-101{Cf. s.v. Ved. párśu- 'Rippe', where "außer-iir. Anschlüsse sind unsicher".}];353[358{Cf. s.v. Lith. pìršys 'chest (of a horse)'. "In Derksen 2008a (429), l stated that the connection with Skt. párśu- 'rib' is better abandoned, but at least semantically the etymology is plausible ('ribs' → 'chest'). The Balto-Slavic evidence for a laryngeal presents a problem, however."}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes to be further connected with dialectal Lithuanian pìršys 'chest (of a horse)', but further connections outside of Balto-Slavic remain uncertain. Traditionally further compared to Vedic párśu- 'rib' (cf. e.g. [Boryś 2005](src-259):431), but this connection remains unclear for formal reasons ([Derksen 2008](src-81):429, [Derksen 2015](src-353):358, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:100-101).

Source: 458[7: 146-149{PS grǫdĭ is a Slavic lexico-semantic innovation without further IE parallels. It is related to PS *grǫda / *gruda / *grǫdŭ / *grudŭ 'clod, clomp, chunk' and further to PS *grǫbŭ / *grubŭ 'rugged, rough, raw, thick' [that is ultimately derived from PIE *gʰreu̯-]. IE cognates are: Old Icelandic grjót 'stones', German Gries 'sand, gravel', Lithuanian grū́das 'corn', grúodas 'frozen earth', German groß 'big', English great.}];594[{The etymology of PS *grǫdĭ is not entirely clear. It is maybe derived from PIE *gʷrendʰ- 'swell, become big' and related to Latin grandis 'big' and Greek βρένθος 'pride'.}];598[1: 463{The Slavic lexeme is related to Latin grandis 'great' and Greek βρένθος 'pride'.}];593[216{The lexeme is a Slavic innovation and does not have any certain cognates. It can be related to Lithuanian granda 'roughly hewed plank' and Latin grunda 'roof' from PIE *gʰrondʰ-.}];249[{IE cognacy and the IE root are uncertain. A contamination of ultimately distinct etymona is possible.}];260[353{It is related to Latin grandis 'big, great', Armenian argand 'bay', Greek βρένθος 'pride'. It is derived from PIE [*gʷrendʰ-], a nasalized variant of PIE *[*gʷreu̯dʰ-].}]
Justification: There is no consensus etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 7:146-149, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):216, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):353, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:463, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)). Against the older proposed comparisons to Latin grandis 'big', Ancient Greek βρένθος 'pride', cf. respectively [de Vaan 2008](src-54):270, [Beekes 2010](src-66):237-238.

Source: 352[531-532{Cf. s.v. OLith. krūtìs 'Brust' (BSl. Latv. krùts 'Erhöhung, Hügel, Hümpel, Hümpel auf der Weise', etc.), to be connected with the same root at OLith. kráuti 'laden, zusammentragen, aufeinanderschichten| bewahren, behüten' (BSl. Latv. kŗaũt 'häufen, laden, packen', OCS kryti 'decken, bedecken, verbergen, hüllen', etc.). The Balto-Slavic forms can go back to an IE root *kreu̯H- 'aufhäufen, bedecken', but further connections are not very clear. Often compared is the Germanic strong verb *hreu-da- 'bedecken' found in OE hroden 'bedeckt, geschmückt', etc. continuing an original *-dʰe/o- present (cf. LIV² 371).}];353[256, 261{S.v. Lith. krūtìs (Latv. krùts 'hill, heap, breast'), the root is the same as the zero-grade of Lith. kráuti 'heap, pile', from PIE *kr(o)uH- (cf. OE hrēodan 'cover'), perhaps to be more precisely analysed as *kreh₂- if further connected with Latv. krât 'collect, save, stack'.}];141[371{Cf. s.v. *kreu̯H- 'aufhäufen, bedecken' (IEW 616). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, perhaps also OIr. cró, W(+) creu 'Stall' if from *krawo- < *krₔu̯o- (cf. Vendryes et al. C-240).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes, probably derivatives from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up, cover' ([ALEW](src-352) 531-532, [Derksen 2015](src-353):256, 261, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 371).

Source: 66[1403-1404{S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'breast, chest'. [More or less directly translates/paraphrases the discussion of [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:795.]}];270[1054-1055{Cf. s.v. AGk. στῆθος 'poitrine' (de l'homme et de la femme). The etymology is obscure. One frequently compares Hesych. στήνιον· στῆθος, which is directly comparable to Skt. stána- 'poitrine d'une femme', Arm. stin (gen. stean), however the suffix -θος then remains unclear.}];49[990{S.v. speno-, stē̆no-, p(ə)stē̆no- 'Zitze, Brustwarze, Brust'. - However, he finds it hard to believe that στῆθος should be connected. He rather assumes an analogical spread of the σ- to a *θη-θος > *τῆθος, which belongs to the family of θήνιον and τιθήνη, for which στηνίον is the analogical basis.}];174[II:795{Cf. s.v. AGk. στῆθος 'männliche od. weibliche Brust'. Origin unclear, the similarity to στήνιον· στῆθος (Hesych.) (to Arm. stin, Ved. stána- 'weibliche Brust' is hardly coincidental ("kaum zufällig"). (Perhaps an analogy along the lines of στήνιον : στῆθος similarly like Lat. plēnus : πλῆθος???)}];345[386{S.v. paśce* (n.) '(a woman's) breast| [in the plural] the seat of wisdom'.  Connected with other cognates which appear to show thematisation from earlier *pstḗn- (Skt. stána-, Av. fštāna-, Arm. stin, Gk. στήνιον).}];172[II:752{Cf. s.v. Ved. stána- 'weibliche Brust, Mutterbrust, Zitze'.  The form in Proto-Indo-Iranian was evidently *pstana-, cf. Av. fštāna- 'weibliche Brust', ərəduua-fšna- 'mit straffen Brusten', from PIE *psten- (cf. Arm. stin 'weibliche Brust' Gk. στήνιον· στῆθος [Hesych.]).}];79[584-585{Cf. s.v. Arm. stin 'breast of a woman', connected with Skt. stána- 'breast of a woman, mother's breast, nipple', YAv. fštāna- 'breast of a woman', MPers., NPers. pestān 'breast', AGk. στήνιον· στῆθος (Hesychius), Lith. spenỹs 'nipple', etc., cf. also Gr. στῆθος, -εος 'breast (of both sexes)'| the PIE by-form is considered a lexical agreement which unites Indo-Iranian, Greek, and Armenian, but probably also belonging here is TochA päśśäṃ, B päścane (du.) 'woman's breasts' < PToch. *päścäne < PIE thematic dual *pstenō, (cf. Skt. stánā).}]
Justification: Tocharian, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pstḗn ([IEW](src-49) 990, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):386, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):584-585, [EWAia](src-172) II:752). The potential connection of the Greek forms from Ancient Greek στῆθος ([cognate set 8545](cog-8545)) to this class is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:795, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1054-1055, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1403-1404).

Source: 105[277{S.v. Alb. mullë 'stomach', borrowed from Rom. *mula > OFr. mule 'id.'}];585[289{S.v. Alb. mułε 'Magen| Laab', identical with Old French mule 'Magen, Tasche', cf. French mullette 'Fleischmagen der Falken'. Bulgarian mura 'Magen' is borrowed from Albanian.}]
Justification: Borrowing from Romance (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):289, [Orel 1998](src-105):277).

Source: 345[101{S.v. TochB erkent- 'black, dark', which with TochA arkant- reflects Proto-Tocharian *erkent- but further connections are unclear. Most commonly considered to be from a putative PIE *h₁r̥gʷ-ont- 'dark' (cf. Skt. rájanī- 'night', Gk. ἔρεβος 'darkness of the underworld', Arm. erek 'evening', Goth. riqis 'darkness', however one would have expected the Tocharian words to have *-kw- rather than just -k-. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1114 is dubious of the Greek-Tocharian equation, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):260 views it as a possibility only.}];66[1114{Cf. s.v. Gk. ἔρεβος.}];79[260{Cf. s.v. Arm. erek.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes, possibly to PIE *h₁ergʷ- via a derived stem *h₁r̥gʷ-ont- 'dark' (cf. Skt. rájanī- 'night', Gk. ἔρεβος 'darkness of the underworld', Arm. erek 'evening', Goth. riqis 'darkness'), but ultimately uncertain ([Adams 2013](src-345):101).

Source: 54[419{S.v. numerus 'number, rank, category'.  Latin numerāre 'to reckon, count' is a denominative verb from numerus 'number' < PIE *nem-e/os- 'apportioning, sacrifice', cf. Lat. nemus 'wood, forest, (holy) clearance', AGk. νέμω 'dispense, distribute', νομή 'pasture', νόμος 'custom, usage, law, composition'| Hitt. lammar-/lamn- 'moment'.}];141[453{Cf. s.v. *nem- 'zuteilen' (IEW 763).}];316[450-451{S.v. Lat. numerus 'nombre', one connects Gk. νέμω 'je distribue, je partage'.}];444[492-493{S.v. 5993 Lat. numerāre 'zählen'.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes continuing Latin numerāre 'to count', a denominal verb to Latin numerus 'number' and ultimately a derivative to PIE *nem- 'to apportion, allot' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):450-451, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):419, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):492, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 453).
Parallel loans from from Arabic اسم / ism 'name'.

Source: 141[575-576{S.v. *spek̑- 'schauen, ansehen, spähen' (IEW 985).}];172[II:107-108{S.v. Ved. √paś- 'sehen, betrachten, blicken, schauen' (OAv. spasiiā 'ich beschaue [Y 44.11], YAv. spasiieiti 'erspäht, erblickt'), from PIE *spek̑- (cf. Gk. σπέπτεται < *spek̑-i̯e-, Lat. speciō, NHG spähen, etc.).}];442[452{S.v. 8012 Ved. páśyati 'sees' RV. [√paś1]}]
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *spek̑- 'to look (at), see' ([LIV²](src-141) 575-576, [EWAia](src-172) II:107-108, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):452 no. 8012).

Source: 352[634-635{S.v. OLith. mė́nuo (1), mė́nuoi (1), mėnuõ 'Mond, Monat' (BSl. Latv. mẽmesis 'Mond, Monat', mẽness 'id.', OPr. menig 'Mond', OCS měsęcь 'Mond, Monat', etc.), from PIE *meh₁nōt-, *meh₁nes-, *meh₁n̥s- 'Mond, Monat' (cf. Ved. mā́s-, A.sg. mā́sam, 'Mond, Monat' OAv. mā̊, YAv. mā̊, G.sg. mā̊ŋhō 'id.', Gk. μήν, G.sg. μηνός [Ion. μείς, Dor. μής] 'Monat, Mondsichel', Myc. me-no '(des) Monats', Arm. amis, G.sg. amsoy 'Monat', Alb. muoj (altgeg.) 'Monat', Lat. mēnsis 'Monat', Umbr. Abl.sg. menze 'Monat, Mond', OIr. mí, G.sg. mís 'Monat', MW mis, OBret. mis 'id.', Goth. menoþs, D.pl. menoþum 'Monat', mena 'Mond', ON mánaðr 'Monat', TochB meñe 'Mond, Monat'). The PIE word for 'moon' and 'month' would have been inflected as a t/s-heteroclitic in PIE.}];567[230{Bactrian μαο, μαυο 'month' < *māhV- (cf. MPers. māh).}];172[II:352-353{S.v. Ved. mā́s- 'Mond, Monat' < PIE *meh₁-n̥s- (> IIr. *maHas- whence OAv. mā̊ /maHah/), ultimately a derivative of *meh₁- 'messen'.}];141[424-425{Cf. s.v. *meh₁- '(ab)messen' (IEW 703-4).}];345[503{S.v. meñe 'moon', 'month', along with TochA mañ, reflecting Proto-Tocharian *mẽñẽ from PIE *meh₁nē(n)-. This n-stem was rebuilt on the nominative singular *meh₁nē(t), which was in itself analogical for *meh₁nōt, oblique *meh₁nes- (cf. Beekes 2010:945).}];66[945{Cf. s.v. Gk. μήν (2) 'month', also 'moon-sickle', from PIE *meh₁nōt, *meh₁n-es-s 'moon, month'. An original derivation from *meh₁- 'measure' from the role of the moon as a measure of time is possible.}];81[312-313{*měsę̄cь 'moon, month', from PIE *meh₁n-(e)s- (cf. Skt. mā́s 'moon, month', Gk. μείς (Ion.) 'moon', Lat. mēnsis 'month', Goth. mena 'moon', OHG māno 'moon').}];165[365{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mēnan- 'moon', from PIE *meh₁n-os- 'moon'.}];54[373{Cf. s.v. Lat. mēnsis 'month', from Proto-Italic *mēns- 'month, moon' (Umb. abl.sg. menzne 'moon', Marsian loc. or abl. sg. mesene 'month', Umb. gen.pl. anter:menzaru 'new moon'), from PIE *meh₁-n-s-, probably to be derived from *meh₁- 'measure'.}];458[18: 191-194{PS *měsęcĭ < *mē(n)s-en-ko. The ultimate root is *mē- 'to measure'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ([Adams 2013](src-345):503, [EWAia](src-172) II:352-353, [ALEW](src-352) 634-635, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:191-194, [Derksen 2008](src-81):312-313, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):365, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):373).

Source: 345[225-226{S.v. TochB kauṃ, which with TochA koṃ reflects Proto-Tocharian *kāunä- from a PIE verbal abstract *keh₂u-ni- 'burning heat (as of the sun)' from PIE *keh₂u̯- 'ignite, burn' (cf. Gk. καίω).}];141[345{Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').}];389[{Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).}];149[118-119{S.v. B kauṃ, A koṃ 'sun| day', the proposed connection with Gk. καίω 'I set fire to, kindle' is attractive', and simpler than and more preferable than the etymology to IE *kaih₂o- suggested by Hilmarsson 1991a: 187.}]
Justification: Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):118-119, [Adams 2013](src-345):225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) (formerly [LIV²](src-141) 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).

Source: 66[1191-1192{S.v. πίμπλημι 'to fill, make full' < PIE *pleh₁- 'fill'. Greek πλήρης may be compared with Latin plērus 'for the greater part', Armenian lir 'fullness', which presupposes that at least some suffixed form *pleh₁-r- can be dated back to PIE. Synchronically the Greek form has been reanalysed as an s-stem adjective (transponat *pleh₁-r-os-), while Latin plērus may reflect an original suffix -ro- (i.e. *pleh₁-ro-).}];141[482{Cf. s.v. *pleh₁- 'sich füllen, voll werden' (IEW 799).}];54[472-473{S.v. Lat. -pleō 'to fill', from which Lat. plēnus 'full' is a derived form from PIE *pl̥h₁-no-. The root -ē- vocalism was introduced, presumably on analogy to other related vocabulary which inherited a full-grade *pleh₁-, e.g. -plēre 'to fill' (usually found with preverbs: complēre 'to fill, complete', dēplēre 'to drain, empty', etc.) < *pleh₁-.}];79[309-310{S.v. li 'full, abundant| perfect, whole'. Arm. li derives from either *pleh₁-(i)o- or *pleh₁-to- (cf. Gk. πλέος 'full', Skt. prātá- 'filled').}];105[335{S.v. plotë 'full', from Proto-Albanian *plāta, identical with PIE *plēto- 'full' from *pelə- 'to fill' (cf. Skt. prātá-, Lat. com-plētus).}];172[II:156-157{S.v. Ved. pūrṇá- 'voll, gefüllt' (cf. OAv., YAv. pərəna- 'voll, gefüllt' < PIE *pl̥h₁-nó-.}];353[356{S.v. Lith. pìlnas 'full', from PIE *plh₁-nó- (cf. Skt. pūrṇá-, OIr. lán, Goth. fulls).}];81[426{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьlnъ 'full' < PIE *plh₁-nó- (cf. Skt. pūrṇá-, OIr. lán, Goth. fulls).}];165[159{S.v. fulla- 1 'full', from PIE *plh₁-nó- (cf. Skt. pūrṇá-, Av. pərəna-, OIr. lán, Lith. pìlnas, OCS plъnъ 'filled, full').}];50[132{S.v. Proto-Celtic *flāno- 'full', from PIE *plh₁no- 'full'.}];369[327{S.v. Alb. plot 'voll, gefüllt, viel, genau' beside plótë adj. 'voll, gefüllt', the latter of which may be derived from PIE *pleh₁-to- 'full'.}];352[772-773{S.v. OLith. pìlnas 'voll, vollständig, völlig' (BSl. Latv. pil̃ns 'voll, betrunken', OPr. acc.sg. pilnan 'ganz', OCS plьnъ 'voll', etc.), from PIE *pl̥h₁-nó/éh₂- (adj.) 'voll' (cf. Ved. pūrṇá- 'voll, gefüllt, ganz, vollständig', OAv. pərəna- 'voll, gefüllt', Lat. plēnus 'voll', OIr. lán, Goth. fulls 'voll', ON fullr 'id.', TochB obl. pällent 'Vollmond').}];442[457, 472{For Middle and Modern Indic languages, cf. s.v. 8339 Ved. pūrṇá- 'filled, full' RV.| for Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 8107 pāráyati (2) 'fills' Dhātup.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, be(come) full' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1191-1192, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):309-310, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):327, [Orel 1998](src-105):335, [EWAia](src-172) II:156-157, [ALEW](src-352) 772-773, [Derksen 2015](src-353):356, [Derksen 2008](src-81):426, [Kroonen 2013](src-165)159, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):472-273, [Matasović 2009](src-50):132).

Source: 66[1541{S.v. ὕω 'to rain' < PIE *suh₂- 'pour, scatter'. Gk. ὑετός 'rain' a deverbal formation < *suh₂-i̯é-.}];141[545{Cf. s.v. *sh₂eu̯- 'schütten, regnen' (IEW 912).  The weak stem undergoes a laryngeal metathesis to *suh₂- (cf. [Jasanoff 1978a](src-646):89n7, 90n11).}];345[796{TochA swase, TochB swese from Proto-Tocharian *s(u)wese- as though from PIE *suh₃-oso-.}];646[89n7, 90n11];369[380-381{S.v. Alb. shi, -u, an inherited lexeme, to be connected to Gk. ὕει 'es regnet', ὑετός 'Regen', TochA swase, TochB swese 'ds.'.}];105[413-414{S.v. Alb. shi 'rain', from Proto-Albanian *sūja- with an irregular development of initial *s- > *sh- explained by dissimilation in intermediary *jūja-, to be connected with IE *sū- 'rain, to rain' (cf. Gk. ὕει, TochA swase, TochB swese 'rain').}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, and Albanian lexemes from PIE *sh₂eu̯- 'to rain' ([LIV²](src-141) 545, [Adams 2013](src-345):796, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1541, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):380-381, [Orel 1998](src-105):413-414); note the zero-grade of the root was *suh₂- by laryngeal metathesis ([Jasanoff 1978a](src-646):89n7, 90n11).

Source: 141[374{*ku̯ath₂- 'foam up' with Slavic kysnǫti and kvasiti listed as cognates.}];81[266-267{S.v. Proto-Slavic kysati 'turn sour' (ESSJa XIII 269). If one wishes to maintain cognacy with Skt. kváthant- 'bubbling, boiling' after LIV *kuHth₂-s- in order to better account for the root acute (cf. Latv. kûsât 'boil'). Ultimately it is still unclear that the Slavic root is actually cognate with the Sanskrit forms.}];458[13: 277{PS *kyša is derived from PS *kys, cf. PS *kysiti etc.}]

274[185-189{S.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (LIV 215f., IEW 467ff.). Germ. forms reflect ?*gʷih₃-tu- > PGmc. *kʷiþu-, but cf. n5 for possible alternative explanations. Slavic forms reflect *gʷih₃-u̯o-to-.}];179[278{Cf. S.v. Gothic *qiþus in *qiþu-hafto in acc.sg. -ton ἐν γαστρὶ ἔχουσα (1Th 5.3) dat.pl. þaim -tom ταῖς ἐν γαστρὶ ἔχουσα, cf. *laus-qiþrs 'with empty stomach', from Germanic *kveþu, *kveþra 'stomach, belly' (OI. kviðr, OSw. kviþer 'belly, womb', OEng. cwiþ(a) 'belly, womb, body', etc. < PIE *gʷei̯H₂- 'live' (*gʷi(ə)-tu-/-tro- 'womb, stomach').}];598[52];81[563{S.v. Proto-Slavic *životъ 'life', a derivative of *gʷh₃i-u- 'live'.}];178[422{S.v. Russ. живот 1. 'Leben' (ksl.), 'Leib, Bauch', 'Besitz, Gut' (cf. Lith. gyavatà 'Bauerngut, (ewiges) Leben', OPr. giwato 'Leben', Gk. βίοτος, Lat. vita (< *vivitā), Welsh bywyd 'Leben').}]
Justification: Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ([NIL](src-274) 185-189, [Derksen 2008](src-81):563, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):278).

Source: 442[650{S.v. 11165 Skt. lṓhita 'red' AV., n. 'any red substance' ŚBr., 'blood' VS. [< rṓhita-].}];172[II:471{S.v. Ved. róhita- 'rot, rötlich' a derived adjective from PIE *h₁reu̯dʰ- 'be red' (cf. YAv. raoiδita- 'rot, rötlich').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Sanskrit lóhita- 'red' (Ved. róhita- 'red') with semantics generalised from 'red' > 'any red substance' > 'blood' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):650, no. 11165), further derived to PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'red' ([EWAia](src-172) II:471).

Source: 141[469{S.v. *pel- 'aufflammen' (IEW 805), only Slavic cognates listed.}];259[409{The lexeme is derived from PIE *pel- / *pol- and related to Lithuanian pelenaĩ 'ash' and Old Icelandic flōr 'warm'.}];81[390{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pāliti 'burn, singe'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes as though from PIE ?*pel- 'to flame up, blaze up' ([LIV²](src-141) 469, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):390, [Boryś 2005](src-259):409).

Source: 54[142{S.v. Lat. cremō, -āre 'to burn', probably a denominative present. The only possible cognate is the Celtic word for 'beer', PCl. *kormi- (e.g. Gaulish curmi, OIr. cuirm etc.), but the alternation Latin *krem- vs. Celtic *korm- is unexplained.}];316[148-149{S.v. Lat. cremō, -āre 'brûler'. Uncertain, perhaps an enlargement in *-em- of a root attested by OIc. hyrr 'feu', Goth. hauri 'charbon', Lith. kuriù, kùrti 'faire de feu').}];141[369{S.v. ?*⁽k̑⁾remH- 'verbrennen' (IEW 572). Only Latin.}]
Justification: Etymology outside Italic uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):148-149, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):142 for various speculative proposals). [LIV²](src-141) mechanically reconstructs ?*⁽k̑⁾remH-, but without any certain cognates outside of Italic.

Source: 141[219-220{S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).}];81[178-179{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gorěti 'burn' (ESSJa VII 42-43), from PIE *gʷʰor- (cf. Skt. ghr̥ṇá- 'heat, glow', Gk. θερμός 'warm').}];458[7: 42-43{Derived from PIE *gʷher- / *gʷhor-, related to Latin formus etc.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm, hot' ([LIV²](src-141) 219-220, [Derksen 2008](src-81):178-179, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:42-43).

Source: 81[544-545{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic zima 'winter' < PIE *g̑ʰei̯-m-eh₂ (cf. Skt. hímā-, Av. ziiā̊ [gen. zimō], Gk. χειμών, Lat. hiems).}];274[162-169{S.v. ?*g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- 'Winter, Schnee' (IEW 425f., EIEC 504).}];687[124-125{S.v. Arbëresh Albanian tëtimpt (drídhem ka tëtempt 'ich zittere vor Kälte', etc.), probably < të (article, preposition) + tim- <-(dissim./assim.)-<-  dim-ën/dim-ër 'winter', also: 'frost', < PIE *g̑ʰei̯-m-.}];369[133{Cf. s.v. Alb. dím/ër, -ri 'Winter', übertr. 'Frost', an inherited word with many cognates in other IE languages (cf. Gk. χεῖμα, OCS zima 'Winter', etc.), either derived from a zero-grade stem *g̑ʰim-m(e)n-, or if the original accent was on the second syllable (cf. Lith. žiemà 'Winter', Gk. χειμών) the *-ei̯- diphthong of the first syllable would have been contracted to -i- (*g̑ʰei̯-mōn-).}]
Justification: Albanian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 162-169, [Derksen 2008](src-81):544-545, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):133, [Rohr 2000](src-687):124-125).

Source: 141[512{Cf. s.v. *(s)dʰerbʰ- 'fest/starr werden' (IEW 257, 1024-5). As a verbal root only Germanic and Slavic, cf. also Gk. στέρφος 'skin, hide'.}];165[477{S.v. Proto-Germanic *sterban- 'to become stiff, die', from PIE *sterbʰ-e- (cf. Gk. Hsch. στέρφνιος 'hard, firm', Russ. sterbnut' 'to become solid or hard, to die').}];556[472-473{Cf. s.v. Gmc. sterb-a- 'sterben'| only uncertain comparisons (MIr. ussarb 'Tod', W serfyll 'schwach, unbeständig' < *uks-sterbhā-?| Ru. stérbnutь 'hart werden, erstarren, absterben'| Gk. στέρφος 'Haut, Fell' etc.| alternatively without s-mobile and with final p: Lat. torpeō 'steif sein, betäubt sein', Lith. tirpstù, tir̃pti 'erstarren, gefühlos werden, einschlafen', Ru. terpnutь 'erstarren (vor Furcht)'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterban- 'to become stiff, die', further to PIE *(s)dʰerbʰ- 'to become stiff, firm' ([LIV²](src-141) 512; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):477 reconstructing *(s)terbʰ- with the same basic comparanda). For older comparisons cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):472-473.

Comment: blend of *gadda- 'sediment, mud, dirt' with gandhá- 'smell' or Middle Persian and Persian gand 'bad smell' (?); cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4011 and 4014

Source: 50[209{S.v. Proto-Celtic *klowstā 'hearing, ear', from PIE *k̑leu̯s-t- 'hear'.}];141[336{Cf. s.v. *k̑leu̯s- '(zu)hören' (IEW 606-7). Cf. n1: this root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- (LIV² 334-335) already in the protolanguage.}];296[C:126-127{S.v. OIr. clúas 'fait d'entendre'| 'l'ouïe, oreille'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to listen to' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):209, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:126-127). This root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- ([LIV²](src-141) 334-335) already in the protolanguage, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336n1.

Source: 151[241{S.v. OIr. fota, fata 'long'. Internal reconstruction suggests possibly earlier *woddio-/*waddio-. There are no correspondences within Celtic, and no known etymology outside of Celtic. A connection with Lat. vastus 'weit' was considered in older literature (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1113-1114).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ([Lucht 2007](src-151):241).

Source: 54[331{Cf. s.v. Lat. laxus 'spacious, wide, loose', from PIE *sl⁽g̑⁾-so- 'weak, faint' (cf. Lat. langueō < *sl-n-g̑-u-, Skt. ślakṣṇá- 'slippery, meagre, thin', Gk. λάγνος 'lascivious, voluptuous', OIc. slakr, OS slac, OE slæc 'weak, floppy').}];423[III:626-627{S.v. Sp. lejos, from Lat. laxius 'más ampliamente, más libremente, más separadamente', comparative adverb of Lat. laxus 'amplio, suelto'.}];444[403{S.v. 4956 Lat. laxus 'schlaff, weit' > Sp. lejos 'fern'.}];141[565{Cf. s.v. *sle⁽g̑⁾- 'erschlaffen' (IEW 959-960).}]
Comment: Fr. Lat. laxius, comparative to laxus.
Justification: Ibero-Romance lexemes derived from Latin laxius 'more widely, more freely', the comparative adverb to Latin laxus 'spacious, wide' ([DCECH](src-423) III:626-627, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):403 no. 4956), further derived from PIE *sle⁽g̑⁾- 'to slacken, go limp' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):331, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 565).

Source: 442[353-354{Cf. s.v. 6186 Skt. dara- (1) m. 'fear' & 6190 Skt. darati 'is frightened'.}];141[119-120{S.v. *der- 'zerreißen (intr.), zerspringen' (IEW 206-8).}];172[I:701-703{S.v. Ved. √dar-¹ 'zersprengen, zerspalten', cf. dara- m. ʻfearʼ (MBh), Sanskrit vi-dar- 'vor Angst bersten'. From PIE *der- 'abspalten| schinden, Haut abziehen' (cf. Gk. δέρω 'häute ab', Goth. dis-tairiþ 'zerreißt', Lith. dìrti, OCS dьrati 'reißen, schinden' etc.).}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √dar-¹ 'to tear, split' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442) 353-354, no. 6186, 6190), ultimately from PIE *der- 'tear (intr.), split' ([EWAia](src-172) I:701-703, [LIV²](src-141) 119-120).

Source: 352[802{S.v. OLith. plùnksma 'Feder, Federkiel. Schreibfeder'. Possibly related to Lat. plūma, which might continue earlier *plūksma or *plouksma. The origins of the nasal in plunk- in Lithuanian is obscure.}];269[{Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' (LIV² 487-488) → *pleu̯k- 'float, swim' (LIV² 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. [cognate set 999](cog-999).}];141[487-488{Cf. s.v. *pleu̯- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 835-7) and *pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837).}]
Justification: Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. [cognate set 999](cog-999).

Source: 165[452{S.v. Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay'. A Germanic-Celtic isogloss. The root may originally have been onomatopoetic.}];141[564{S.v. ?*slak- 'schlagen' (IEW 959). Cf. n1 "Hierher wohl mir. slacc 'Schwert', neuir. slacairt 'das Schlagen' usw."}];392;179[314{Cf. s.v. Goth. S98. *slahan 'δέρειν, τύπτειν', 'strike', from PIE *slak- 'strike' (only Gmc. & Celt., cf. MIr. slacc 'sword', slachta 'struck').}];556[425-427{S.v. Gmc. *slah-a- 'schlagen', no certain comparisons. In question comes MIr. slacc 'Schwert', slahta 'geschlagen' (both sparsely attested).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', usually compared to Middle Irish slacc 'sword' and slahta 'struck' to a root *slak- as a Celtic-Germanic isogloss. Whether such a root may be postulated for Proto-Indo-European remains uncertain ([Seebold 1970](src-556):425-427, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 564).

Source: 66[1086-1087{S.v. ὄνυξ, -υχος 'nail, claw, hoof'. Greek form presupposes *h₃nogʷʰ- or *h₃nogʰ-u- to account for the raising of radical *-o- > -u- by Cowgill's Law (i.e. -o- > -u- between a labial and a nasal, cf. νύξ 'night' < *nokʷt-s). Similarly Classical Armenian eɫungn must also reflect the same forms, but is also a secondary n-stem from the accusative.}];54[641{S.v. Lat. unguis 'finger-nail, claw', from PIE *h₃ngʰ-u- 'nail'. The PIE u-stem was remade into an i-stem in Latin.}];80[723-725{S.v. Hitt. šankuu̯āi- 'nail| a unit of linear measure', generally connected to the complex of words meaning 'nail' elsewhere among the Indo-European languages (Lat. unguis, Gk. ὄνυξ, etc.).  This connection does not account for the initial š-.  It is possible to assume an s-mobile to account for it via a preform *s-h₃ngʰ-u-oi which would regularly yield Hitt. šankuu̯ai-.  Although the assumption of an s-mobile is here admittedly ad hoc, but other s-mobile forms not attested elsewhere in IE are also possibly found in išḫaḫru- 'tear' and šākuu̯a- 'eye' [cf. [cognate set 3305](cog-3305)].}];172[II:4-5{S.v. Ved. nakhá- 'Nagel, Fingernagel, Zehennagel, Kralle, Klaue'. "Iir. *nā̆kʰ- ist von idg. *h₃Engʰ-/*h₃nEgʰ- 'Nagel, Kralle' (~ lat. unguis, lit. nãgas Nagel u.a. o. I 49) nicht zu trennen." Cf. notes to entry in Mayrhofer for further discussion of the phonetic difficulties of the Indo-Iranian forms.}];352[681-682{Cf. s.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' (BSl. Latv.  nags 'Finder- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf', OPr. mage 'Fuß'), from PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle' (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ, -υχος, Lat. unguis, OIr. ingen, ON nagl, OE nægel, etc.).}];345[502{S.v. TochB mekwa '(finger/toe) nails'. TochA maku and TochB mekwa reflect Proto-Tocharian *mekwā, with assimilation from earlier *nekwā. To be connected with PIE *h₃nogʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw', Lat. unguis 'nail', OEng. nægl 'nail', Skt. áṅghri- 'foot', Lith. nagà 'foot', OCS noga 'foot', etc.).}];79[254-255{S.v. Arm. ełungn 'nail', derived from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ- or *h₃nogʰ-u- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'talon, claw, nail', etc.).}];81[355{S.v. Proto-Slavic *nogъtь 'nail, claw', a derivative of PIE *h₃nogʷʰ- (cf. Skt. nakhá- 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG 'nagal' 'nail').}];353[327{S.v. Lith. nagà 'hoof, nail' (cf. Latv. nagas Npl. 'both hands, hands and feet', OPruss. nage 'foot'), from PIE *h₃n(o)gʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').}];165[381{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nagl- 'nail', from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-l-o- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail', Arm. ełungn 'nail', OPruss. nage 'foot', Lith. nãgas 'nail, claw', OCS noga 'foot, leg' < *h₃nogʷʰ-| Lat. unguis, 'nail, OIr. ingen 'nail' < *h₃ngʷʰ-).}];50[36{S.v. Proto-Celtic *angʷīnā 'nail', from PIE *h₃nogʰu-, gen. *h₃ngʰ-eu-s 'nail'. In Celtic the zero-grade stem of the oblique cases was generalised.}];458[25: 161-164, 170-173{The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian nagùtis 'claw, fingernail' and further to Old High German nagal, Old Icelandic nagl, negl, Old Irish ingen, Latin unguis, Greek ὄνυξ, Old Indic áṅghriḥ and nakhám etc.}];325[50{"našεwr S[arikoli] nail. — **naxōr? Cf. W[akhi] digεr, dγ̌ör (> Khow. doγur) < *n(a)γūr? Very doubtful derivation."}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):723-725, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1086-1087, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):254-255, [EWAia](src-172) II:4-5, [ALEW](src-352) 681-682, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164, 170-173, [Derksen 2008](src-81):355, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):641, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36). Indo-Iranic forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; Indo-Aryan forms go back to nakhá- ~ *nakkha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442), no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914

Source: 352[933-934{S.v. OLith. *skríeti 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen' (BSl. Latv. skrìet 'laufen, rennen, fliegen', with closest possible cognates found in OCS krilo 'Flügel' (etc.). Clear comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking.}];141[562{S.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). Verbal only Baltic. Present stem *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾réi̯-e- > Lith. skrejù (skriẽti) 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen', Latv. skreju (skriet) 'laufen, rennen, fliegen'.}]
Justification: Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ([ALEW](src-352) 933, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 562). Identical to 'run' in [cognate set 6359](cog-6359). On the possibility of the connection of Lithuanian skrìsti 'fly_V' to this class, cf. discussion in [cognate set 9622](cog-9622).

Source: 83[137-138{S.v. Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall| recount' (Av. *(š)mar- 'to remember, recall'), from PIE *(s)mer- 'to observe, consider, think of' (cf. Ved. √smar- 'to remember, to become aware, to be mindful of', Gk. ἱμείρω 'I desire, long', Goth. *maurnan, OHG mornēn, OE murnan, Engl. mourn).}];172[II:78-79{Cf. s.v. Ved. √smar- 'gedenken, sich erinnern, einer Sache bewußt werden, eingedenk sein, ins Herz schließen', probably from PIE *(s)mer- 'an etwas (sorgenvoll?) denken', cf. Gk. μέριμνα 'Sorge, Besorgnis', OE murnan 'sich um etwas sorgen', etc.}];141[569-570{Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)mer- 'denken an, sich erinnern' (IEW 969).}]
Comment: The Avestan form *(š)mar- is attested with the meaning "remember".
Justification: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount', further to PIE *(s)mer- 'to think about, remember' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):137-138, [EWAia](src-172) II:78-79, [LIV²](src-141) 569-570).

Source: 178[III:152{Turkic languages have tunman 'cloud, darkness'. This is in turn probably orginally borrowed from Avestan dunman- 'fog' ([lexeme 27734](lex-27734)), dvąnman- 'cloud'.}];598[4: 119{It is a loanword from Turkic, cf. Kazakh, Kirghiz, Karaim tuman and Turkish duman 'fog, darkness'. The ultimate source is probably Avestan dunman- 'fog'.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Turkic (cf. [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) III:152, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 4:119).

Source: 165[96, 108{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dimma- 'dark'| s.v. *dumbōn- 'fog, haze' (> ON dumba 'dust, cloud of dust', Elfd. dumba 'fog, haze', a zero-grade formation to the strong verb dimban- ~ *dimpan- 'to fog')}];468[77{Cf. s.v. ON dimma (1) 'finsternis' (> NSw. dimma 'dünner nebel', dial. dimba 'dampf'), ON dimmr 'dunkel', ON dumba 'staub, staubwolke' (> NSw. dial. dumba 'nebel, dunst').}];697[151-152{S.v. Gmc. *dem(b)ra- 'dunkel' and s.v. Gmc. *demma- 'dunkel', without certain comparisons outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing a basic stem *dim-, comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):151-152, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):77, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):96, 108).

Source: 80[794{S.v. Hitt. šūu-, šūu̯au̯- 'full', which may go back to either *souh₁-(o)u- or *souh₃-(o)u- by internal reconstruction.  There are no certain cognates outside of Anatolian.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):794).

Source: 353[193-194, 196{S.v. Lith. gulė́ti 'lie, be ill' (Latv. gulêt 'sleep, lie, be ill'), related to Lith. gul̃ti 'lie down, fall ill, hang down', Latv. gul̃t 'go to bed', for which an East Baltic root *gul- may be reconstructed. A full-grade *gval- is attested via Lith. gvaldýti 'cram, pack' < *'lay close together', so we may be dealing with a PIE root *gu̯el-, but there are no convincing cognates to support such a reconstruction.}];352[377-379{Cf. s.v. OLith. gul̃ti 'sich legen' (BSl. gul̃t 'sich schlafen legen, sich lagern'). This (East-)Baltic word family lacks further etymological connections. Various attempts have been made at an IE root etymology (cf. discussion in ALEW for references to further literature) but none of the proposals is satisfactory.}]
Justification: Cf. Lithuanian gul̃ti 'to lie down', which with the Latvian and Latgalian lexemes in this set may go back to an East Baltic root *gul-, but a further IE root etymology remains uncertain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 377-379, [Derksen 2015](src-353):193-194, 196).

Source: 442[8{S.v. 142 Skt. accha 1 'clear, transparent' Suśr. [Poss. ʻ shadowless ʼ cf. acchāyá- RV. Neither *r̥kṣa- (Mayrhofer EWA i 22) nor ā̆rca- (P. Tedesco JAOS 77, 197) are phonet. satisfactory. ]}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit accha- 'clear transparent'; further etymology uncertain, perhaps to Vedic acchāyá- 'shadowless' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):8 no. 142).

Source: 345[241{S.v. TochB klänts- 'sleep', which with TochA klis- reflect Proto-Tocharian *kläns- and may be derived from PIE *klm̥H-s-, otherwise only found in Skt. klām(y)ati 'become tired, exhausted'.  Also semantically possible is a comparison with PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' via an enlarged stem *k̑li-n-s-, but the enlargement of the stem *-n-s- is not well paralleled morphologically.}];341[624-625{S.v. TochB klänts- 'schlafen', 'sleep', TochA klis- 'id.'. "The PT root shape is *klän(t)s-, TA shows i-epenthesis (cf. Hilmarsson, 1996, 142). According to Schneider, 1940, 203f., and Hilmarsson, 1996, 142f. the root is derived from *√k̑lei̯ 'lean', i.e. from a present *k̑li-n-, but this etymology would rather make us expect persistent (*)kly-. Adams, 1988a, 32, and DoT, 223, derives it from PIE *klm̥H-s-, with a cognate in Skt. klāmyati 'become weary' (not in ²LIV)."}]
Justification: Root ref. form tentatively follows the reconstruction of [Adams 2013](src-345):241 to a putative PIE *klemH- (not in [LIV²](src-141) or [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)), rejecting alternative proposals to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' as formally improbable; cf. [Adams 2013](src-345) s.v. TochB klänts- and [Malzahn 2010](src-341):624-625 for further discussion.

Source: 345[184-186{TochAB käly- reflect PToch *käly- from *PIE *kel(h₁)- 'rise up, arise'.  The suppletive stem found in TochA ṣtäm-, TochB stäm- is probably from PIE *stem- a byform of *steh₂-, similarly as *gʷem- 'come' and *gʷeh₂- 'take a step' form a suppletive pair in PIE.}];341[592-593{S.v. TochAB käly- 'stehen, sich befinden', 'stand, be situated' from Proto-Tocharian *kl'æ-. Malzahn prefers an etymology following LIV² to *k̑lei̯-, finding the derivation of Adams in Dictionary of Tocharian B *kel(h₁)- 'raise up' to be derivationally impossible.}];141[332-333{S.v. *k̑lei̯- 'sich anlehnen' (IEW 601-602), on the formation of the Tocharian stem cf. n13.}];149[69-70{S.v. B käly- 'to stand', A käly- 'id.', since van Windekens 1941:33 to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to incline', cf. Skt. śráyati 'to lean'.}]
Justification: Generally derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ([LIV²](src-141) 332-333, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):592-593, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):69-70, also Ron Kim p.c.), less likely [Adams 2013](src-345):184-186 derives to *kel(h₁)- 'raise up', cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):593 for further discussion.

Source: 534[I:572-573{S.v. Latv. mats (Lith. mãtas 'mērs, mērvienība')}]
Justification: Traditionally connected to PIE *meh₁- 'to measure (out)' in the sense 'measure' > 'body part used as measure unit' > 'length of hair used as a measure unit' > 'hair' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:572-573; cf. for the root reconstruction cf. [LIV²](src-141) 424-425).

Source: 172[I:401{S.v. Ved. kéśa- 'Haupthaar'| difficult to separate from Av. (º)gaēsa- 'Kraushaar', gaēsu- 'lockenhaarig', MPers. gēs, NPers. gēsū 'Locken' etc. Perhaps a contamination of *geśa- (= Av. gaēº) and késara- 'Haar, Mähne'. Further etymological connections unclear.}];442[180{S.v. 3471 Ved. kḗśa- m. 'hair of the head' AV.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 180, no. 3471; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 401: "schwerlich zu trennen von jav. (°)gaēsa-", perhaps a blend with *káisra- > Vedic (YV+) késara- n., but phonologically unclear; Indic forms constitue a cognacy subclass *gáića- (*káisra-?)
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic kéśa- 'hair of the head', difficult to separate from Young Avestan gaēsa- although there is disagreement over the voicing of the initial velar; [EWAia](src-172) I:401 suggests a contamination of an original *géśa- the Indic lexemes with Vedic késara- 'hair, mane'. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):180 no. 3471.

Source: 442[330{Cf. s.v. 5803 tā́lu n. 'palate' under which "N. ṭāuko 'head', M. ṭaũkī f. 'forepart of skull' are obscure."}];69[241{S.v. N. टाउको ṭāuko,s. Head. -- ṭ˚ ghumnu c. ko to feel dizzy. -- tero ṭ˚ blockhead. [cf. G. ṭālkũ n. crown of head ? -- but also M. ṭaũkī f. forepart of skull, half of eggshell, coco- nut shell, etc. -- Cf. tālu².]}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Turner 1931](src-69):241, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5803.

Source: 442[571{S.v. 9926 masta- m. 'head' Dhūrtas., mástaka- m.n. 'head, skull' Mn., mastika- n. lex. 2. *mastra- . 3. mastuluṅga- m. (n.?) 'brain' Suśr., mastakaluṅga- m. or n. 'membrane of brain' lex. 4. mastíṣka- 'cranium' RV. [Orig. heteroclite declension: *másti or *mástr̥g nom. ~ *mastnás gen. whence másta-ka- < *mastn̥-ka- , *mastr-a- or *mastrr̥-ka-, combined in *mastr̥ṅga- > MIA. mastuluṅga- (?) as in Av. mastrəgan- m. 'temples' (~ mastíṣka- < *mast-ə-s- ) WP ii 309, EWA ii 606 with lit.]}];172[II:336{S.v. Ved. mastr̥han- 'Gehirn' (IIr. cf. YAv. mastərəγan- 'Gehirn', Orm. mastərγ 'Gehirn'), IIr. *mastr̥gʰan- is not to be separated from RV+ mastíṣka- 'Gehirn', mastaka- 'Schädel, Kopf', etc. The IIr. forms suggest an original *-r/n- stem *mast-r̥-gʰ- / *mast-(a)n-. Perhaps the forms mastr̥han-, mastaka-, mastíṣka-, etc. are to be connected with *mosgʰ- 'Mark, Gehirn' (cf. majján-)?}]
Comment: cf. Sanskrit mastaka- m. n. (Up+) 'skull, head', related to Vedic mastr̥han- m. 'brain' < Proto-Indo-Iranian *mastr̥gʱan- (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 326).
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit masta-, more commonly Sanskrit mastaka- 'skull, head' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):571 no. 9926. The stem appears to continue an r/n-stem with the Sanskrit stem masta- continuing earlier *mastn̥-, while the r-stem is preserved in Vedic mastr̥han- 'brain', YAv. mastərəγan- 'brain'. Further connections uncertain, perhaps a derivative of PIE *mosgʰ- 'marrow'(?), cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:336 for further discussion.

Source: 320[52{S.v. kamala- 'head', from *kamr̥da- (cf. Av. kamərəda-, Zor.P. kamāl 'skull', etc.). For further IE connections, cf. Skt. mūrdhan-, Gk. βλωθρός 'grown high', OEng. molda 'top of head', TochAB malto 'at first'.}];172[II:368{S.v. Ved. mūrdhán- 'Haupt, Kopf, Stirn, Gipfel, Spitze', cf. IIr., YAv. ka-mərəδa- 'Kopf daēuuischer Wesen', MPers. kamāl, Khot. kamala-. Probably from PIE *ml̥h₃dʰ-on- (cf. OEng. molda 'der obere Teil des Kopfes, Scheitel', and probably Gk. βλωθρός 'hochgewachsen' *ml̥h₃dʰ-r-, etc.).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes, as though continuing a prefix *ka- + PIE *ml̥h₃dʰ-, cf. Vedic mūrdhán- 'forehead, head, top part', Ancient Greek βλωθρός 'grown high', Old English molda 'top of head' ([EWAia](src-172) II:368, [Bailey 1979](src-320):52).

Source: 54[612{S.v. Lat. tendō, -ere 'to extend, stretch', from Proto-Italic *tend-, in turn from PIE *ten-d⁽ʰ⁾-, a dental extended form of PIE *ten- 'to stretch'.}];443[4:740-746{S.v. Lat. intendere, > Fr. entendre.}];141[626-628{Either to PIE *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6) or 1. *tend- 'ermatten' (IEW 1065-6). Cf. n8, if tendō developed secondarily as a substitute *tn̥ne- for a *-néu̯/nu- present *tn̥néu̯-. Otherwise, the root of the verb should be separated with 1. *tend- (cf. Ved. tandate 'erlahmt'), possibly the same root as *ten- but with a dental root enlargement.}];444[366{S.v. 4483 Lat. intendere 'hinwenden'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin in-tendere 'to stretch out, stretch forth, extend' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):366 no. 4483, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:740-746). The IE root is either *ten- 'to stretch, extend' or *tend- 'to wear down', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 626-628, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):612 for further discussion.

Source: 442[587{S.v. 10188 *muṭṭa- (2) 'heart'. [Orig. 'lump' cf. *muḍḍha- 2?]}]
Justification: As though from an Indic stem *muṭṭa- 'heart', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):587 no. 10188).

Source: 345[23{S.v. TochB anañce 'heart'. Adams connects Proto-Tocharian *āräñce to a PT root *ār(e)- which he connects with Hitt. ḫaḫ(a)ri-, some part of the body. [HED H](src-407) s.v. hah(ha)ri- translates 'lung(s), midriff'.  From this comparison Adams sets up PIE *h₂eh₂(e)ri- as a proto-form.}];407[6{Cf. s.v. Hitt. hah(ha)ri- 'lung(s), midriff', of obscure etymology.}]
Justification: Etymology outside Tocharian uncertain. [Adams 2013](src-345):23 proposes a connection to Hittite ḫaḫ(a)ri- 'lung(s), midriff' (but this Hittite form remains of obscure etymology according to [HED H](src-407):7).

Source: 50[147{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gʷrensnā 'sun', *gʷrīns-/*gʷrenso- 'heat', derivatives from PIE *gʷʰer- 'be hot' (cf. Gk. θερμός, etc.).}];274[196-199{Cf. s.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).}];151[376{S.v. OIr. grían 'sun', there are no correspondences elsewhere in Celtic, but there are two suggestions of an IE etymology. Either (1) to PIE *gʷʰer- 'warm, heiß', or (2) to PIE *g̑ʰer(ə)-/*g̑ʰrē- 'strahlen, glänzen, schimmern'. Of the two of these *gʷʰer- is probably more plausible since the root is well-attested in Celtic (cf. e.g. OIr. gorim 'Hitze'), while *g̑ʰer(ə)- is unattested, or else OIr. grían would be the only example. In either case, however the stem formation in -i-nā is without parallel and exceptional.}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'be warm, hot' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):376, [Matasović 2009](src-50):147, [NIL](src-274) 196-199).

Source: 54[79-80{S.v. caedō, -ere 'to cut, hew, fell', from Proto-Italic *kaid-e/o-. Lat. occidere is a prefixed form of the verb. Cf. PIE *keh₂id- / *kh₂eid- 'to cut, hew'. Besides Albanian qeth, de Vaan also considers Arm. xaitʻem 'to stab' < *kHei-t-, MDu. heien 'to drive piles', OHG heia 'wooden hammer' < PGmc. *xajjan- < *kh₂ei-(i)e/o- or *kHoi- as potential cognates.}];141[360{S.v. ?*kh₂ei̯d- 'schlagen' (IEW 917). Only Italic and Albanian, if Alb. qeth 'schneidet, schert (Haare)' is truly cognate to the Italic forms. Cf. entry for further references.}];579[{Neapolitan accirere < Lat. occīdere, cf. It. uccidere.}];444[495{S.v. 6030 Lat. occīdere 'töten', 2. *aucīdere.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin occīdere 'strike down, knock down' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):495), possibly further to PIE *kh₂ei̯d- 'hit, beat' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 360, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):79-80) for further discussion).

Source: 444[445{S.v. 5425 Lat. *mattea 'Keule'.}];54[336-337{Cf. s.v. mateola 'wooden hammer', a diminutive of a noun *matea 'hoe' (vel sim.), perhaps from PIE ?*mot-(i-), cf. Ved. matyá- 'club, harrow, roller', OCS motyka, Russ. motyga 'hoe' OHG medela 'plough'.}]
Justification: Romance denominal verbs as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):445), further etymology uncertain, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):366-367 for various proposals.

Source: 141[207{S.v. 1. *gʷelH- 'quälen, stechen' (IEW 470-1). OPr. gallintwei < PIE ?*gʷolH-éi̯e-, secondary with Baltic causative suffix -in-, Neubildung?}];352[286, 309{Cf. s.v. OLith. gãlas 'Ende, Ziel' (BSl. cf. Latv. gals 'End, Spitze, Äußerstes, Wipfel, Gipfel| Tod| Unglück, Pech| Gegend, Wohnung', galinât 'hungern lassen| zu Tode quälen| töten', OPr. gallan 'Tod| (die) Toten', gallintwey 'töten'). Lith. gãlas is an o-grade nominalisation to Lith. gélti 'stechen' (BSl. cf. Latv. zdel̂t, 'stechen, brennen, beißen', PCS žel’a 'Leid, Unglück'), from PIE *gʷelH- 'quälen, stechen' (cf. Arm. kelem 'quäle', keł 'Wunde, Geschwür', MW 3.sg.pres. vel 'schlägt', OE cwelan 'leiden, verderben', OHG quelan 'leiden, sich abquälen, trauern').}];353[170{Cf. s.v. Lith. gélti 'ache, sting, bite', from PIE *gʷelH- (cf. OHG quelan 'be in pain', OE cwelan 'die').}];165[315{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kwaljan- 'to make suffer, pain' (ON kvelja 'to torment, torture', OE cwellan 'to kill', etc.), from PIE *gʷolH-éie-, a causative formation comparable to non-causative Proto-Germanic *kwelan-.}];556[313-314{S.v. PGmc. *kwel-a- 'leiden', probably from an original verb *gʷel- 'sterben', perhaps from an original meaning 'stechen'.}]
Justification: Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷelH- 'to suffer; to prick' ([LIV²](src-141) 207, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 286, 309, [Derksen 2015](src-353):170, [Seebold 1970](src-556):313-314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):315).

Source: 165[90-91{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dauþu- 'death', from PIE *dʰóu(H)-tu-, a tu-stem created to Proto-Germanic *daujan- 'to die' < *dʰouh₂/₃-ié- (cf. Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'| Lat. fūnus 'funeral' < *dʰuh₂-n-es-(?)). On the PIE level the verb has usually been compared to *dʰeu- 'to run, to rush' (Skt. dhávate, Gk. θέω 'to run' and to *dʰueh₂- 'to blow, smoke, be misty' (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):148| LIV² s.v.), but Kroonen finds it preferable to assume a link with Hitt. tuḫḫušzi 'to end'. The forms based on Goth. dauϸs 'dead', ON dauðr, OE dēad, OHG tōt, etc. are from PGmc. *dauda-, the original past participle to *daujan-.}];141[147-148{Cf. s.v. *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen' (IEW 259-60, 262)| primary verb in ON deyja 'sterben' < *dʰou̯-éi̯e-.}];556[147-149{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dau-ja- 'sterben', belonging to isolated words from *dʰeu̯-, meaning 'die' and similar things. This probably goes back to *dʰeu̯(ə)- 'rauchen, stieben', whose meaning presumably developed from 'atmen, hauchen' (cf. Lith. dvė̃sti 'verenden' beside dvėsúoti 'schwer atmen, keuchen').}];468[74, 76{S.v. ON deyða 'töten', to Goth. dauþjan, OE ādīedan, dȳdan, OFr. dēda, OS bidōdan, MLG doden, OHG tōten (cf. ON dauðr = Goth. dauþus, OE dēað, OFr. dāth, OS dōð, OHG tōd).}];269[{The IE root etymology of PGmc. *daujan- given here follows [LIV²](src-141) to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):90-91 (but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of [Kluge 2011](src-397):919 s.v. Tod).}];397[919, 922{Cf. s.v. NHG tot (adj.) (MHG tōt, OHG tōt, OS dōd) from Gmc. *dauda- 'tot', also in Goth. dauϸs, ΟΝ dauðr, OE dēad. The NHG verb töten was historically derived from the adjective. For the etymology given, cf. s.v. NHG Tod 'death', a verbal abstract to G. *dau-ja- 'die' to which may be compared Gk. ἀποθνῄσκω < *dʰu̯enh₂- and perhaps Lat. fūnus.}]
Justification: The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanicc *daujan- given here follows [LIV²](src-141) to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):90-91 (but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of [Kluge 2011](src-397):919 s.v. Tod).

Source: 141[665-667{S.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-7).  See perfect forms *u̯ói̯d-/u̯id- 'weiß, wissen'.}];66[1053{S.v. οἶδα 'to know' < PIE *u̯eid- 'see, look, know'. The stem reflects an old perfect form *u̯oi̯d-h₂e.}];79[211{S.v. Arm. *gēt- 'to know', from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to know, be acquainted with' (cf. Skt. ved- 'to know', Goth. wait 'he knows', etc.).}];172[II:579-581{S.v. Ved. √ved- (1) 'finden, entdecken, erlangen' (2) 'wissen, kennen', from PIE u̯ei̯d- 'sehen, erblicken' (cf. Lat. vidēre, OCS viděti, etc.).}];353[566{S.v. Old Prussian waist 'know', from PIE *uoid- (cf. Skt. véda, Gk. οἶδα, Goth. 3.sg. wait).}];81[518{S.v. Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know', from PIE *uoid- (cf. Skt. véda, Gk. οἶδα, Goth. 3.sg. wait).}];165[589{S.v. Proto-Germanic *witan- 'know', from PIE uoid-.}];50[422-423{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wi-n-d-o- 'find, experience', from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'see, know' (cf. Skt. vindáti 'finds', Lat. videō, Arm. gitem 'know').}];83[408-409{S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯aid- (1) 'to know', from PIE (pf. stem) *u̯oid- 'to know' (cf. Gk. οἶδα, Arm. gitel, OIr. ro-fetar, MW gwyr, OCS vědě, Goth. wait, witum, ON vita, OE witan 'to know', Engl. wit, etc.).}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from the perfect stem *u̯oi̯d- 'to know' (< *'to have seen') from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to catch sight of' ([LIV²](src-141) 665-667, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1053, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):211, [EWAia](src-172) II:579-581, [Cheung 2007](src-83):408-409, [Derksen 2015](src-353):566, [Derksen 2008](src-81):518), Matasović 2009}:422-423).

Source: 80[645-646{S.v. Hitt. paršdu- 'leaf, foliage'. Possibly connected to Old English brord. -es m. 'prick, point, lance, javelin, the first blade or spire of grass/corn, etc.' < PIE *bʰr̥sdʰ-, but the meaning 'leaf' in the Germanic lexeme could well be a secondary.}];412[168-170{S.v. Hitt. parastu- 'shoot, sprout, sprig, (budding) leaf(age), (fresh) foliage, (first) greenery, (new) verdure, (bursting) bloom'| "The basic meaning plausibly has to do with the budding of leaves and flowers of trees and plants alike, pointing to /barstu-/ cognate with Old Slavic *brĭstĭ or *brĭstŭ 'bud, shoot' (Belorussian brost’, Serbian bȓst, etc.), i. e. *bhr̥stu- cognate with Hitt. par(a)s-, parsiya- 'break, burst', and with other springtime "bursts" in the vegetal and animal realms (Lith. brãzdas 'vernal tree sap', ON broddr 'beestings, colostrum')." Older comparisons with Gk. π(τ)όρθος 'shoot, sapling' are to be rejected.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Anatolian debated, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):645-646, [HED PA](src-412) 168-170, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar Vol. 2, 446-447 for various proposals.

Source: 352[332{Cf. s.v. OLith. girià 'Wald, Wüste, Wildnis', under which "Zugehörigkeit von lett. gãrša sf. 'großer Wald' (und lett. garš 'lang' bleibt zweifelhaft." The belonging of Latv. gãrša sf. 'large forest' (and Latv. garš 'long' [to the group of words connected to Lith. girià 'forest, desert, wilderness'] remains doubtful.}];269[{Etymologically isolated. The proposed connection to Lith. girià 'forest, wasteland, wilderness' is doubtful (cf. ALEW 332). Not in Derksen (2015).}]
Justification: Etymologically isolated, the proposed connection with Lithuanian girià 'forest, wilderness' remains doubtful ([ALEW](src-352) 332). For older proposals cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:291-292.

Source: 274[332-335{S.v. *h₂nér-/*h₂nr-´ m. 'Mann' (IEW 765).}];66[103-104{S.v. ἀνήρ 'man' < PIE *h₂ner- 'man' (cf. Ved. nár-, Arm. ayr, etc.).}];79[61-62{S.v. Arm. ayr₁ 'man| husband', to be connected with Gk. ἀνήρ 'man| husband', Skt. nár- 'man, human, hero, warrior', etc. From PIE *h₂ner-.}];172[II:19-20{S.v. Ved. nár- 'Mann, Mensch, Held, Krieger' (in Ir. OAv., YAv. nar- 'Mann', etc.), from PIE *h₂nér- 'Mann' (PIIr. *Hnár-), cf. Gk. ἀνήρ, Arm. ayr, Neo-Phrygian αναρ, Osc. ner-, Welsh ner 'Held', etc.}];54[406-407{Cf. s.v. Lat. Nerō (PN) 'Nero', from Proto-Italic *nēr, *ner- 'man', cf. Oscan niir, South Picene nir, Umbrian nerf 'man', from PIE *h₂nēr (nom.sg.) 'man'.}];105[304{S.v. Alb. njeri 'man, person, human being', from Proto-Albanian *nera and to be connected with Skt. nár- 'man', Gk. ἀνήρ 'man', Arm. ayr 'man'.}];571[100-101{S.v. Alb. njeri, -u njerëz 'human being, man', cognate with Gk. ἀνήρ, Ved. nár-, Arm. ayr, all 'man'.}];279[495-497{S.v. O.u.sp. niir 'Mann', from PIE *h₂nē̆r- 'Mann' also in Gk. ἀνήρ, Arm. ayr, Ved. nā́, cf. W ner 'Chef, Meister', Alb. njer 'Mann'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nér- 'man' ([NIL](src-274) 332-335, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):103-104, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):61-62, [Huld 1984](src-571):100-101, [Orel 1998](src-105):304, [EWAia](src-172) II:19-20, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):406-407, [Untermann 2000](src-279):495-497).

Source: 81[80-81{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čelověkъ 'man'. According to the traditional etymology, this is a compound of čelo- (cf. Lith. kẽlias 'family, tribe, generation') and *věkъ, cf. Lith. vaĩkas 'child'.}];458[4: 40-42, 48-50{It is a compound of *čelo- (cf. kiltìs 'tribe') and věkŭ (cf. Lithuanian vaĩkas 'child').}]

165[285{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kerla- ~ *karla- 'man, freeman', from PIE *g̑erh₂-ol-, (cf. TochB śrāy, pl. śrān- 'adult man' < *g̑erh̥₂-n-| Skt. járant- 'old man', Oss. zærond 'old', Arm. cer(un) 'old| old man', Gk. γέρων, -οντος 'old man' < *g̑erh₂-ont-).}];468[301{S.v. karl 'mann', esp. 'alter mann' (cf. OHG karl 'mann, ehemann', OE ceorl 'freier mann der niederigsten klasse'), outside Germanic cf.
