Gk. γέρων 'greis', Ved. jarati 'lässt altern', OCS žirěti 'reifen', Arm. cer 'greis' (IEW 390).}];388[210{S.v. Proto-Germanic *karlaz ~ kerlaz, further derived from IE *g̑er(ə)- 'to ripen, to grow old, to become frail', cf. Skt. járant- 'old', Arm. cer id., Gk. γέρων 'old man', etc.}];141[165-166{Cf. s.v. *g̑erh₂- 'aufreiben, alt machen' (IEW 390-1).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kerla- ~ *karla- 'man, freeman', a derivative of PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):301, [Orel 2003](src-388):210, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):285, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 165-166).

Source:
598[4: 257{PS *xolpŭ has been compared to Gothic halbs- 'half', Slavic xolstŭ, xolkŭ, Lithuanian šel̃pti, šelpiù 'help', Old Indic jálpati 'gibber', jālmás 'dastard', Lithuanian sil̃pnas 'weak', German Schalk 'scoundrel', Greek σκόλοψ 'sharp pale', Russian paholok and holit'. All these comparisons are unreliable.}];593[225, 440{PS xolpŭ is not entirely clear. It can be related to pachole derived from PS *xoliti 'take care' (with no certain further etymology). However, suffix -p(ŭ) is unusual.}];259[62{PS *xolpŭ without certain further etymology. It is maybe derived from PS *xoliti 'embosom, encompass' > 'take care, nurture, clean' with a rare suffix *-p(ŭ). Other explanations are less reliable.}];458[8: 61-65{Many existing analyses of PS *xolpŭ claim that a morphological interpretatiion as *xol-p(ŭ) is dubious as a suffix -p- does not exist in PS and PIE. However, this suffix does exist. PS *xolpŭ is also related to PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti.
PS *xolstŭ 'unmarried'. Meanings of the related lexemes (PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti) point to the etymological meaning 'to shear, to barber'. For the semantic development cf. Greek κόρος, κοῦρος 'boy, son', κόρη 'girl' and κείρω 'to shear, to barber', τριχοκουρία 'ceremonial hair-cutting by juveniles'.
PS *xolkŭ 'unmarried'. Along the related lexemes it does not have paralells beyond Slavic. The PIE root is *ksol- / *skol-.
PS *xoliti is derived from PIE *ksol- < *ks- 'scratch', cf. Old Indic kṣāláyati 'wash, clean' and Lithuanian skaláuti 'wash, flush'.}]
Justification:
Despite some morphological difficulties, the formal and semantic relationships make a common origin of PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti ver plausible.
According to [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 554-555 the etymology of Lithuanian skaláuti 'wash, flush' is not entirely clear; it can belong to skeliù, skélti 'chop, split', derived from PIE *skelh₁- (cf. *skelH- [LIV²](src-141): 553). Smoczyński gives here only PS *ščelĭ 'aperture' as a Slavic cognate. The etymology is mentioned but not accepted by [KEWA](src-399): 288.
Thus, even if we accept an underlying *xol-, its further etymology is obscure.

Source: 567[231{Bactrian μαρδο < *martiya- (cf. OPers. martiya-, Sogd. mrty).}];172[I:318-319, 327-328{S.v. Ved. mártya- 'Sterblicher, Mensch' (cf. Av. maš́iia-, OPers. martiya-) derived to √mar- 'sterben' < PIE *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben'.}];141[439-440{Cf. s.v. *mer- 'verschwinden, sterben' (IEW 735).}];79[452-453{S.v. Arm. mard 'man, human being', from PIE *mr̥-tó- 'mortal' (cf. Gk. βροτός 'mortal', Av. maš(ii)a- 'man', Skt. mr̥tá- 'died, dead'. Formally mard could reflect an Iranian loanword, but the voiced -d and the inflection in the Armenian o-stem declension favour a native origin.}];680[116{S.v. Khw. mrc 'man' < Ir. *martiya-.}];442[596{S.v. 9888 Ved. mártya- m. 'a mortal, man' RV. [√mr̥]}]
Justification: Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):452-453, [EWAia](src-172) II:318-319, 327-328, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):596 no. 9888, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 439-440).

Comment: Parallel loans from Arabic
Parallel loans from Sanskrit
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit puruṣa- 'man, person'.

Source: 80[670{S.v. Hitt. *pešan- / pešn- / pišen- (c.) ‘man, male person’, from PIE *pés-ōn-s, *pes-én-om, *pes-n-ós. Cognate with various words for male sexual organs in other Indo-European languages: cf. Ved. pásas- 'penis', Gk. πέος 'penis', Lat. pēnis 'penis', OHG fasal 'seed, descendant'.}];413[37-45{S.v. pesna-, pisna-, pisena-, piseni- (c.) ‘man, male’, cognate with Lat. pēnis < *pesni-, Ved. pásas-, Gk. πέος, OE faesl, OHG fisal, fasel 'penis'.}]
Justification: Generally connected to words for male sexual organs in other IE languages, cf. Vedic pásas- 'penis', Gk. πέος 'penis', Lat. pēnis 'penis', OHG fasal 'seed, descendant' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):670, [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413):37-45).

Cognate with Lithuanian peldė́ti 'to swim'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally assigned to PIE *pelǝ-, *plē- 'to fill' (now reconstructed as *pleh₁-, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 482-483) with a root extension in *-d- ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):565, [IEW](src-49) 800-801, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:34-35). Not in [LIV²](src-141), [Derksen 2015](src-353), or [ALEW](src-352).

Source: 345[82-83{S.v. TochB eṅkwe 'man' (as opposed to woman). TochA oṅk, TochB eṅkwe may be derived from a PIE thematised u-stem noun (transponat) *n̥k̑-u̯-o- 'mortal', cf. OIr. éc 'dead' < *n̥k̑-u-, Av. nasu- 'corpse, carrion', Gk. νέκυς 'corpse' from *nek̑- 'die, perish'.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes as though from *n̥k̑-u̯-o- 'mortal', derived from PIE *nek̑- 'to disappear, go missing' ([Adams 2013](src-345):82-83, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 451-452).

Source:
595[3: 171{The etymology of PS *rępŭ is obscure. IE protoforms *u̯repos (with a comparison with Albanian vrap 'run' and Greek ῥεπω 'bend') and *u̯rempi- (with a comparison with Swedish rumpa 'tail' and German Rumpf 'thorax') has been proposed.}];594[{PS *rępŭ does not have any convincing etymology. It has been linked to Swedish rumpa 'tail' and German Rumpf 'thorax'. However, it is not without phonetic issues.}];593[554{PS *rępŭ is etymologically obscure.}];249[{Note that Slavic etymology dictionaries do not compare PS *ręp 'tail' an PS *rěpa 'turnip' at all.}];260[1219-1220{PS *ręp 'chondral vertebra with tail base, backbone' is related to Lithuanian rem̃bti 'become lethargic', rémbėti 'become gnarled, scarred', rim̃bas 'whipcord', rum̃bas 'scar', Latvian rùobs 'notch, gap', Old Icelandic rumpr 'bum', Swedish rumpa 'bum' and German Rumpf ['thorax'].
Lexemes like Upper Sorbian rjapać, Polish rzępolić, Slovene repeti are derived from an ideophonic root *rep-, *rĭp-, *rop-, *rŭp-, *ręp- 'make rattling, drumming, creaky, banging noises, murmur, buzz, grunt (about goats, pigs etc.)'.}];259[535{Polish rzępolić 'play unskillfully a violin [and general any string instrument' and Kashubian rzãpic 'to cut unskillfully (with a blunt knife)' are expressive derivatives, cf. dialectal Polish rzępić 'cut clumsy (with a blunt knife)', rzępieć na kimć 'to annoy someone with speaking', Kashubian rząpic, rzëpic 'breathe with difficulties, rasp, crepitate, rattle, cough strongly', Lower Sorbian rjapaś, rjapiś 'crack the whip, chastise', Upper Sorbian rjapać 'crack, crackle, creak', dialectal Czech řapět 'clatter, knock, make a noise'. All these lexemes are derived from PS *rępiti / *rępati / *rępěti 'make rumbling, creaky, crispy sounds' with an ideophonic origin.}];601[4: 224-225{Kashubian řąp 'a clumsy cut piece of bread, thick slice', 'shred, snippet, rag' is derived from PS *rępiti / *rępati / *rępěti 'make rumbling, creaky, crispy sounds' (> 'cut with a primitive or inappropriate tool with creaky noises').
Kaszubian řąpolëc etc. 'cut clumsy', 'play unskillfully an instrument (especially violin)', 'scrap the fiddle' is derived from PS *rępiti / *rępati / *rępěti 'make rumbling, creaky, crispy sounds'.
A link to Old Polisz rząp (PS *rępŭ 'tail') is inconvincing.}];609[474{Polish rząp 'tail', Upper Sorbian rjap 'backbone' and Polish rzępolić ['play unskillfully an instrument'] have a common origin.}]
Justification: PS *rępŭ does not have any certain further IE etymology and cognates. In any case, I do not see any serious reason to treat PS the lexemes with the meaning 'tail' and lexemes referring to various creaky or crackling sounds as two separate etymona. Note that reflexes of *rępiti refer often to playing string instruments (and especially bowed string instruments) and there are also some attestations referring to whiping. That makes, in my opinion, a very good link to 'tail'. We have doubltess an ideophonic root here.

Source: 352[1150-1151{S.v. OLith. uodegà 'Schwanz, Schweif' a derivative in -ega to úodas 'Mücke', itself traditionally explained as an o-grade derivative from the same root as Lith. ė́sti 'essen, fressen', but other possibilities have also been proposed (cf. entry for further discussion).}];531[704{S.v. Lith. uodegà 'ogon', appears to be a derivative from úodas 'komar'.}];353[480{Cf. s.v. Lith. úodas 'mosquito' for further discussion on the problems of its etymology.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Appears to be a derivative from Lithuanian úodas 'mosquito', which is in turn traditionally derived from the same root of Lithuanian ė́sti 'to eat' < PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat', but many uncertainties remain regarding this etymological connection. Cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):704, [ALEW](src-352) 1150-1151, [Derksen 2015](src-353):480 for further discussion.

Source: 534[I:285{S.v. Latv. gaļa. of uncertain origin. It might be possible that it is a derivative to the same root as galēt 'to kill' with an original meaning 'killed animal'.}]
Justification: Of uncertain etymology, perhaps a derivative to the same root as Latvian galēt 'to kill' (cf. [cognate set 2302](cog-2302)) with an original meaning 'killed animal' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:285).

Source: 80[206-207{S.v. *arma- (c.) 'moon(god)| month'.  No clear cognates outside of Anatolian.  The reading arma- underlying the Sumerograms ᵈEN.ZU, ITU⁽ᴷᴬᴹ⁾, or Akkadogram ᵈSÎN in Hittite is supported by derivatives like armanni- 'lunula' and names like ᵐAr-ma-zi-ti- = ᵐ˙ᵈSÎN-ma-LÚ-i-.  Derivatives are also found in CLuw. armannaima/i- 'decorated with lunulae' (the simple noun 'moon'is attested as [ᵈE]N.ZU-aš in CLuw., (DEUS)LUNA+MI-sa in HLuw.).  Also attested elsewhere in Anatolian are Lyd. armτa- 'belonging to Arma(?)', Lycian arm̃ma- 'moon', rm̃mazata- 'monthly offering(?). }]
Justification: For the interpretation of the Hittite and Luvian forms underlying the Sumerogram ᵈEN.ZU and Akkadogram ᵈSÎN, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):206-207.

Source: 54[352{S.v. Lat. lūna 'moon', from Proto-Italic *louksnā-, ultimately from PIE *le/ou̯k-s-nh₂- 'shiny, bright, gleaming' (√*leu̯k-) (cf. Av. raoxšna- [adj., n.] 'light', Gk. λύχνος 'lamp', OPr. lauxnos [pl.] 'stars', MHG liehsen 'bright'.)}];81[291{S.v. Proto-Slavic *luna 'moon', from PIE *lou̯k-s-neh₂ (cf. Av. raoxšna- 'shining'| Lat. lūna 'moon').}];79[320{S.v. Arm. lusin 'moon', 'month', related to Arm. loys 'light' < PIE *leu̯k-. The Armenian stem formation is either from *loukeno- (cf. Skt. rocaná- 'luminous sphere, firmament') or from *louksneh₂-. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to literature.}];458[16: 173{PS *luna is derived from *luxna < *louk-sn-ā, cf. Latin lūna (< *louxnā), Avestan raoχšna, Old Prussian lauxnos and Old High German liehsen.}]
Justification: Armenian, Slavic, and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *lou̯k-s-neh₂, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine, be(come) bright' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):320, [ESSJa](src-458) 16:173, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):352, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Source: 50[156{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *gelo- 'yellow, white', from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' (cf. Lat. heluus 'honey yellow', Gk. χλωρός 'pale green', Skt. harí- 'green', OCS zelenъ 'green', OE geolu 'yellow').}];151[259-260{S.v. OIr. gelach 'moon', only a few attestations in late texts. Clearly a derivative to the adjective gel (o/ā) 'hell, leuchtend'. There are two formal possibilities at a root etymology, either to *g̑ʰel(ə)- 'glänzen, schimmern' (IEW 429ff.) or *g̑el(ə)- 'hell heiter glänzen, lächeln, lachen' (IEW 366f., cf. LIV² 162 *g̑elh₂- 'in Lachen ausbrechen')| the connection to the former *g̑ʰel(ə)- is preferable. [Cf. also 'white' pp. 431-432.]}]
Justification: From Old Irish gelach 'moon', derived to the Old Irish adj. gel 'fair, white, bright, shining' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):259-260), further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):156, [EIEC](src-657) 654).

Source: 172[I:528-529{S.v. Ved. candrá- 'schimmernd, licht', from √cand- (√ścand-) 'glänzen, schimmern'.  Probably not to be separated from Lat. candēre 'glänzen, schimmern' from PIE *(s)kend-. The compound candrá-māḥ 'glittering moon', used in the sense of 'Mond, Mondgott' in the RV (cf. Mayrhofer EWAIa I:529), whence the semantics were transferred to the epithet candrá- in the sense 'moon', attested already in the Atharva-Veda.}];141[554{Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)kend- 'erglänzen' (IEW 526).}];105[146-147{S.v. Alb. hëne ~ hanë 'moon', from Proto-Albanian *ksandā and further compared with Skt. cándati 'shines, is bright', candrá- 'shining| moon'.}];369[199-200{S.v. Alb. hën/ë, -a / hãnë 'Mond'. Dialectal comparison allows the reconstruction of a Proto-Albanian form *skandanā, which can be further connected to Ved. candrá-, -ścandrá- 'leuchtend, glänzend', candrá-(mās-) 'Mond' (to which further cf. W. cann 'weiß, hell', MBret. cann 'Vollmond').}];130[70-71];442[252{S.v. 4661 Ved. candrá 'shining' RV. 2. m. 'moon' VS.}]
Justification: Indic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *(s)kend- 'to shine' ([EWAia](src-172) I:528-529, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):252 no. 4661, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):199-200, [Orel 1998](src-105):146-147, [Holm 2011](src-130):70-71; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 554).

Source: 534[I:611-612{S.v. Latv. mute, to be connected with Germ. Maul, etc. (cf. also other stem in Germ. Mund, etc.).}]
Justification: Possibly cognate with Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'mouth' and Proto-Germanic *munϸa- 'mouth' according to [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:611-612, although cf. discussion in [cognate set 6017](cog-6017), [cognate set 262](cog-262) regarding uncertainties to the etymologies of the Germanic forms.

Source: 442[639{S.v. 11009 Skt. lāṅgūlá- (lāṅgula- Pañcat., laṅgula- lex.) n. 'tail' ŚāṅkhŚr., adj. 'having a tail' MBh., 'penis' lex. 2. *lāṅguṭa- . 3. *lāṅguṭṭa- (> Si. nan̆guṭa) . 4. *lāṅguṭṭha- . 5. *lēṅgula- . 6. *lēṅguṭṭa-.}];172[II:477-478{S.v. Ved. lāṅgūla- n. 'Schwanz, Schweif'. Etymology unexplained.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Late Vedic lāṅgūla- 'tail' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):639 no. 11009), further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:477-478, [KEWA](src-399) III:98).

Source: 534[I:80-81{S.v. Latv. aste. Two possible etymologies: either to PIE h₂ek̑- 'sharp' and connected with OCS ostьnъ 'sharp point', or to PIE *Host- 'bone' and cognate with Hitt. ḫāstai-, Skt. asthi-, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.}]
Justification: IE root etymology disputed: either (1) to PIE h₂ek̑- 'sharp' and connected with OCS ostьnъ 'sharp point', or (2) to PIE *Host- 'bone' and cognate with Hitt. ḫāstai-, Skt. asthi-, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc. ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:80-81).

Source: 388[308{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rumpaz sb.m. > ON rumpr 'rump, buttocks', MHG rump 'body, beehive'.}]
Comment: Is there any reason to suspect that the Elfdalian is a more recent loanword from Swedish rumpa 'tail' instead of being inherited?

Source: 345[216-217{S.v. koyn* (nnt.) ‘mouth’ "PTch *koyŭ presumably represents a putative PIE *g̑ʰoi̯-u - (nt.) 'a gaping,' a derivative of *g̑ʰh₂(e)i̯ - 'yawn, gape'"}];149[171-172{S.v. B koyṃ, A koyäṣ 'mouth', "traditionally – and correctly – associated with the root *g̑ʰeh₁i- 'to gape, open up' […] [h]owever, various details have under any explanation been left obscure, partly because non-existent A ko has been taken into account."}];141[173-174{Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰeh₁i̯- 'den Mund aufspurren, gähnen' (IEW 419-20).}]
Justification: Traditionally connected to the root *g̑ʰeh₁i̯- 'to gape, open up (the mouth)', although aspects of the stem-formation remain disputed (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):171-172, [Adams 2013](src-345):216-217, [LIV²](src-141) 173-174).
Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived to PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:580, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):403). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353); not in [IEW](src-49)].

Source: 165[234{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck'. "In view of the close formal and semantic similarities to To. kñuk, it seems possible to reconstruct a PIE n-stem *knék-ōn, gen. kn̥k-n-ós, acc. *knok-n-ń̥s (cf. [Kroonen 2011](src-656):167ff.). The regular outcome of this paradigm, viz. *hnehō, *hunkkaz, *hnakkuns was apparently remodelled into *hnekkō, *knukkaz, *hnakkuns. […] [I]t is possible that G Hunke 'hillock' is a vestige of the original genitive form. It is therefore likely that OIr. cnoc, W cnwch m. 'hill' was borrowed from Germanic rather than the other way around."}];656[167ff.];397[646{S.v. NHG Nacken (MHG nac (nackes), nacke, OHG nac, nacko 'Hinterhaupt, Nacken', from Gmc. *hnakka-/ōn 'Hinterhaupt, Nacken' also in ON hnakkr, hnakki and with Ablaut in MLG necke, nec, OFr. hnekka, OE hnecca. Outside of Germanic with differing vocalism cf. OIr. cnocc, MW cnwch 'Buckel, Hügel', TochA kñuk 'Hals, Nacken'. Further origins unclear.}];149[162-163{Cf. s.v. TochA kñuk 'neck'. Two early propsals to either OIc. knjúkr 'round mountain summit', MHG knock 'neck' < *gneugo- (van Windekens 1941: 42), or to IE *kneugo-, cf. OIc. hnjúkr 'rounded mountain summit' (Duchesne-Guillemin 1941: 157) are semantically satisfactory. Pedersen's (1944: 29) connection to OE hnekka- 'neck', OIc. hnakki 'id.' is semantically more satisfactory but there is no evidence in Germanic for a *-kw-. "This proposal might therefore be rejected as well. Instead the following might be considered. Assuming A kñuk, through *kñäkw, reflects CT *kñäkwæ, this word may go back to IE *knigʷʰo- 'neck (lit. 'the one that bows or bends')' to the root *kneigʷʰ- 'to bow', cf. Goth. hneiwan 'to bow', OHG hnīgan 'to bow, bend', OIcel. hníga 'to sink down', hneigja 'to bow' etc."}];76[225-226{Cf. s.v. TochA kñuk 'cou, nuque' For this term we may connect either IE *gneug- with OIc. knjūkr 'cime d'une montagne', MHG knock 'nuque' or with IE *qnequ̯- with OE hnecca, OIc. hnakki 'nuque', or with IE *qneug- with OIc. hnūka 'se tenir accroupi, s'accroupir', Mod. Ic. knjūkr 'cime de montagne ronde', etc.For these three interpretations cf. Van Windekens, Orbis 11 (1962) 506. In any of these cases TochA kñuk may have a common etymon with Germanic.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck', perhaps further comparable with Tocharian A kñuk 'neck' although there is some uncertainty the formal aspects of this proposed etymology. For further discussion cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):646, [Kroonen 2011](src-656):167-169, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):234, [van Windekens 1976](src-76):225-226, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):162-163.

Source: 259[223{PS *kŭrkŭ is related to Old Indic kŕ̥kāta- 'cervical vertebrae' and Gaelic cricon 'throat' and derived from PIE *kr̥ko-, ultimately from PIE *(s)ker-k- 'turn (around).}];593[313{PS *kŭrkŭ is related to Old Indic kŕ̥kāta- and Gaelic cricon 'throat' and derived from PIE *kr̥ko-, ultimately from PIE *(s)ker-k- 'turn (around).}];458[13: 209-211, 218-219{PS *kŭrkŭ is most probably a reflex of PIE *kr̥ko- (cf. Old Indic  kŕ̥kātam and Gaelic cricon 'throat'). Taking into account that lexemes for 'neck' are often derived from the meaning 'turn', it can be related to PS PS *kŭrčiti. The PIE root protoform *kr̥k- is expressive, its further linking to PIE *(s)ker- 'cut' is speculative.}]
Justification: Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ is occasionally compared to Vedic kŕ̥kāṭa- 'joint of the neck' (so [ESSJa](src-458) 13: 209-211, 218-219, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):313, cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):223), although the etymology of the Indic comparandum is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:256-257 and [EWAia](src-172) I:388-389). Consequently the further connections of Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ must remain uncertain.

Source: 353[209{S.v. Lith. jáunas 'young'.  "The Balto-Slavic adjective seems to reflect *h₂ieu-Hn-o-."  PIE *h₂iu-Hon- (Skt. yúvan- adj. 'young, youth'| Lat. iuuenis m. 'young man').}];352[408-409{S.v. OLith. jáunas 'jung, neu' (BSl. Latv. jaûns 'jung, neu', OCS junъ 'jung', etc.), from PIE *h₂i̯u-h₃on- 'jung' (cf. Skt. yúvan- 'jung, jugendlich| Jüngling', YAv. yuuan- 'Jüngling', Lat. iuvenis, -is 'junger Mann, junger Mensch| jung', iūnīx 'junge Kuh, Färse', Gaul. Iovinc(o)- 'jung', OIr. óëc 'jung', MW ieuanc 'id.', Goth. juggs 'jung', ON ungr 'id.', OHG jung 'id.').}];274[277-287{Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- n. 'Leben, Lebenszeit, -erwartung' (IEW 17f., 510f., EIEC 352, 655). Cf. specifically p.278 s.v. *h₂i̯-eu̯-h₃n-ó- > Lith. jáunas, 'jung', Latv. jaûns 'jung, neu' and n36, n37.}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes, generally analysed as containing a PIE noun for 'life, lifetime, life expectancy' *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- combined with the derivational suffix *-h₃en-, i.e. transponat *h₂i̯-eu̯-h₃n-ó- > Old Lithuanian jáunas 'young, new' ([NIL](src-274) 277-287, [ALEW](src-352) 408-409, [Derksen 2015](src-353):209). The nominal stem *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- which serves the basis of this formation appears to have inflected as an ablauting u-stem but a corresponding verbal root *h₂ei̯- has not yet been identified (cf. [NIL](src-274) 279n1 for further discussion).

Source: 363[II:390{S.v. Kurd. t́aza | tāza 'новый| свежий| снова', cf. Pers. tāza, Zaza taza, Tal. toza, Gur. tāza, Sang. tāže, Von., Kokhr. toza, Kash. toǰa, Zef. tože, Siv. toze, Sede, Gazi tože, Kafr. toze, Afg. tāza, Mundzh. toza 'новый', etc.}]
534[I:206-207{S.v. Latv. deguns. Etymology uncertain, there are many competing proposed etymologies.}]
Justification: Etymology not yet satisfactorily ascertained, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:206-207 for various hypotheses.

Source: 165[380{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nabja- 'beak'. No clear extra-Germanic cognates. "Some have compared the word to *nabO- 'nave' < *h3nobh-eh2- through a meaning 'protuberance, knob' (cf. Magnusson 1989: 662). Another potential lead is Gaul. nebba 'bill' as recorded by Pliny (thus already Kilian 1599: 334), but the word is not attested in the later Celtic languages."}];468[406{S.v. ON nef 'nasenbein, nase' < Proto-North-Germanic *nafja-. [No extra-Germanic cognates listed.]}];388[279{Cf. s.v. PGmc. naƀjan, to be derived from naƀō and connected with Skt. nábhya- 'nave (of a wheel)', nā́bhi- 'navel, nave', OPr. nabis 'id.' Latv. naba 'navel'.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nabja- 'beak', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):406, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):380). Cf. however [Orel 2003](src-388):279 and others attempting to connect to Proto-Germanic *nabō- 'nave' via a meaning 'protuberance, knob'.

Source: 66[1288{S.v. ῥίς, ῥινός 'nose' (of man and animal) 'nostrils' (in pl.). No etymology outside of Greek.}];270[975-976{S.v. AGk. ῥῑ́ς, ῥῑ́νος 'nez' Replaced inherited word for 'nose' (cf. Lat. nārēs, Ved. nāsā [du.], Germ. Nase, etc.). The origins of the word remain obscure.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):975-976, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1288).

Source: 534[I:413-414];360[306{Cf. s.v. Lith. kùkis 'Misthaken', kúoka(s) 'Knüttel', connected with Latv. kùoks 'Stock, Baum, Holz'.}];531[324{Cf. s.v. Lith. kúokas, etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Latvian lexemes generally connected with Lithuanian kúokas 'club, stick'; further etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *keu̯- 'to bend' with a velar extension -k- ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:413-414, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):306, [IEW](src-49) 589), but more recently cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):324 regarding the etymology uncertain. [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353), [ALEW](src-352)].

Source: 345[776-777{S.v. TochB stām 'tree', connected since Meillet (1916:383) [ref not in Adams's bibliography] with Proto-Germanic *stamma- 'treetrunk', Lat. stāmen 'warp',  Gk. στήμων 'warp', Skt. sthā́man- 'station, place' < PIE *steh₂-mn̥- '(something) standing'.}];274[637-659{S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.), cf. p.639 s.v. *steh₂-(s)mn̥- > TochA ṣtām B stām 'Baum'.}]
Justification: Generally considered to be an *-mn̥-stem noun derived to *steh₂- 'stand' ([Adams 2013](src-345):776-777, [NIL](src-274) 639).

Source: 172[II:500{S.v. Ved. ván- 'Baum, Holz' (cf. Av. vanā- 'Baum', MPers. wan, Sogd. wn-, Pašto wana 'Baum', etc.). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranian is uncertain.}];442[657{S.v. 11258 Skt. vána- (1) n. (once m. R.) 'single tree' RV., 'forest, timber' RV. 2. vanikā- f. 'grove' MBh.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):657, no. 11258.

Source: 50[394{S.v. Proto-Celtic *uden-sk-yo- 'water', from PIE *wod-r / *uden- 'water' (cf. Skt. udán-, Hitt. watar-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Lat. unda 'wave', OCS voda, Germ. Wasser). Matasović gives this as the standard etymology, although he expresses reservations that the Proto-Celtic stem formation is correct. See entry for further discussion.}];274[706-715{S.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.).}];296[U:21{S.v. OIr. uisce 'eau', evidently derived to the root which designated in Indo-European a liquid element *wed-/*ud- (cf. Skt. udán-, Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, Hitt. watar, Goth. wato, OCS voda). Cf. for various proposals for explaining the Celtic stem formation.}]
Justification: Cf. Old Irish uisce 'water' derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well, to spring' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:21, [Matasović 2009](src-50):394, [NIL](src-274) 706-715).

Source: 352[332-333{Cf. s.v. OLith. girià 'Wald, Wüste, Wildnis' (BSl. Latv. dziŗa 'Wald', dzire 'id.', OPr. garian 'Baum', OCS gora 'Berg', etc.), from PIE *gʷorH-, *gʷr̥H- 'bewaldeter Berg' (cf. Ved. girí- 'Berg, Hügel, Anhöhe', YAv. gairi- 'Berg, Gebirge', Gk. βορέας 'Nordwind, Norden', Alb. gur 'Stein, Fels').}]

81[177-178{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *gora 'mountain' (ESSJa VII 29-31), a derivative of the o-grade of the root *gʷerH- (cf. Lith. girià 'woods', Skt. girí- 'mountain, hill').}];458[7: 29-31{PS *gora is derived from PIE *gʷer- and related to Old Indic girí- 'mountian', Avestan gairi- 'mountian', Lithuanian girià 'forest' and Albanian gur 'rock'.}]
Justification: Originally 'mountain' ([ESSJa](src-458) 7:29-31, [Derksen 2008](src-81):177-178; cf. [cognate set 80](cog-80) for further etymological details).

Source: 50[198{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kayto- 'wood', from IE *kai̯to- 'wood, field' (IEW 521), cf. Goth. haiϸi 'field'. The reflexes *kai̯to- are restricted to Celtic and Germanic| perhaps a borrowing from a NW European substratum language.}]
Justification: Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ([IEW](src-49) 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):198).

Source: 172[II:572{S.v. Ved. vr̥kṣá- 'Baum'. Mi. ni. pkt. vaccha- 'Baum', with metathesis *rukṣá- > pā., pkt. rukkha- etc., IIr. YAv. varǝša- 'Baum', varǝša.ǰī- probably 'Wurzel' or 'Stengel', perhaps from PIE *u̯l̥k̑-s-ó- to Ved. valśa- 'Schößling, Trieb, Zweig'.}];442[622{S.v. 10757 *rukṣa- 'tree', rūkṣa- 2 m. lex. [~ vr̥kṣá- ], cf. 12067 vr̥kṣá m. 'tree' RV. [~ *rukṣa- ]}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Indic *rukṣa- 'tree', a metathesised variant of Vedic vr̥kṣá- 'tree', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá-. Further connections uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Vedic valśa- 'shoot, branch, twig' ([EWAia](src-172) II:572, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):622 no. 10757).

Source: 80[583{S.v. Hitt. mit(t)a- / miti- 'red' (adj.)| 'red wool' (c.). The variety of forms attested suggest that the word is a loanword.  Čop (1958:28-32) attempted to connect it to Slavic *mědь 'copper' from a putative *moid-o-, but the lack of other IE cognates from this postulated form do not make this etymology very likely.}];647[27-32]
Justification: Etymology uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):583 for a critical discussion of previous proposals).

Source: 165[202{S.v. Proto-Germanic *haita- 'hot'. There are no certain extra-Germanic cognates.}];415[887-888, 915-916{Cf. s.v. OHG heiz 'heiß, glühend, etc.', to OHG hei ?, from Proto-Germanic *χai̯(i̯)a-, a term isolated from other IE languages. Perhaps comparable to Lith. kaĩsti 'heiß machen, erhitzen', Latv. kàitêt 'sengen, heiß machen', OPr. enkaitītai 'angefochten'. Such a root *kei̯- would be otherwise isolated among the IE languages.}];697[271-272{S.v. Gmc. *haita- 'heiß'. No precise correspondences outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *haita- 'hot', no certain etymology outside of Germanic ({Heidermanns 1993}:271-272, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):202, cf. [EWA 4](src-415):887-888, 915-916).

Source: 172[I:579{S.v. Ved. jála- 'Wasser, Naß' (Mi. pā. jala-, hi. jal 'Wasser', etc.). Etymology unclear.}]
442[280{S.v. 5086 jáṭā- f. 'hair twisted together' PārGr̥., 'fibrous root, root' Bhpr.}];172[I:564-565{S.v. Ved. jaṭā- 'Flechte, Haartracht der Asketen'. Etymology unclear.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 280, no. 5086 s.v. jáṭā f. ʻhair twisted togetherʼ, PārGr̥. ʻfibrous root, rootʼ Bhpr., Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 564 - further source unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jaṭā- 'hair twisted together', further etymology unclear ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):280 no. 5086, [EWAia](src-172) I:564).

Source: 172[II:544-545{Cf. s.v. Ved. vā́r- 'Wasser' (YAv. vāra- 'Regen', MPers. wārān-, NPers. bārān, etc.), from PIE *(H)u̯eh₁-r- (cf. Luw. u̯a-a-ar 'Wasser', TochA wär, TochB war 'Wasser', ONor. vari 'Flüssigkeit, Wasser').}];274[715-717{S.v. *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'Wasser' (IEW 80f., EIEC 636).}]
Justification: Anatolian and Indic lexemes from PIE *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water' ([NIL](src-274) 715-717, [EWAia](src-172) II:544-545).

Source: 66[125{Cf. s.v. Gk. ἀργής 'brilliant, white, gleaming', from *h₂erg̑- 'brilliant, white'.}];80[307{S.v. Hitt. ḫarki- / ḫargai- (adj.) 'white, bright', from PIE *h₂(e)rg̑-(e)i- (cf. Gk ἀργός 'white', Skt. r̥jrá- 'shining reddishly, brightcoloured| quick, hurrying', TochA ārki, TochB ārkwi 'white').}];345[52-53{S.v. TochB ārkwi 'white'. TochA ārki and TochB ārkwi reflect PToch *ārkw(ä)i, which in turn must reflect (in some way) PIE *h₂erg̑-u(i)-n-.}];172[I:116{S.v. Ved. árjuna- 'licht, weiß, siberfarben', a derivation from PIE *h₂erg̑- (cf. Gk. ἄργυρος 'Silber').}]
Justification: Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂erg̑- 'brilliant, white' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):307, [Adams 2013](src-345):52-53). For non-target Hellenic and Indic lexemes in this class cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):125, [EWAia](src-172) I:116.

Source: 442[675{S.v. 11580 Skt. vālukā- f. 'sand, gravel' ŚvetUp.}];399[III:196{S.v. Skt. vālukā- 'Sand / sand' (pāli vālukā-, prākr. vāluā-, hindī bālū, bārū 'sand'). Not convincingly explained.}];172[II:547{S.v. Skt. vālukā- 'Sand' (Mi. , ni., etc. pā. vālukā- 'Sand', etc.). Etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vālukā- 'sand' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):675, no. 11580). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:196, [EWAia](src-172) II:547 for discussion of various conjectures.

Source: 66[851{S.v. λευκός 'clear, white', from PIE *leu̯k- 'white| (become) light' (cf. Skt. rocá- 'bright', rócate 'to shine, radiate', Lat. lūcus 'wood, forest', Lith. laũkas 'field', OHG lōh 'overgrown glade', Skt. loká- 'free space, world').  Within Greek, cf. λεύσσω 'to see clearly, look, examine' < *leu̯k-i̯é-.}];270[632-633{S.v. λευκός, -ή, -όν, formally corresponding to Skt. rocá- 'brillant' next to the present stem rócate, cf. also OIr. luach, Lith. laũkas, etc.| with o-grade Lat. lūcus, Skt. loká-, Lith. laûkas, OHG loh.}];141[418-419{Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):632-633, [Beekes 2010](src-66):851, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Source: 308[466{From Celt. ber- 'tragen, gebären' with preverb ess-.}];50[62{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry, bear, bring' from PIE *bʰer- 'carry' (IEW 128-132).}];300[{Cf. s.v. OIr. as-beir 'say, speak' < ess-ber [Pedersen 1913](src-308):466.}];294[204-208{Cf. s.v. *ég̑̑ʰ 'aus, von drinnen hinaus' (Adverb, lokal| oft mit Abl.) for the OIr. preverb ess- < *ég̑̑ʰ-s.}]
Comment: Cf. eDIL s.v. as-beir (www.dil.ie/4383)
Justification: A compound of Old Irish -beir 'bear, carry' (< PIE *bʰer- 'carry', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77) with the preverb ess-, es-, e-, as- 'out of' (< PIE *(h₁}eg̑ʰ-s 'out of' adv., cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) 205).

Source: 165[319{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say' < *gʷét-e- (IE?). Possibly comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite' < *gʷot-ie-(?), although this verb can be reconstructed differently and is conspicuously similar to Arm. gočʻem 'to shout' < *u̯okʷ-ie- (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):811).}];141[212{S.v. ?*gʷet- 'sagen' (IEW 480-1).}];556[318-320{S.v. Gmc. *kweϸ-a- 'sagen'. There are no secure comparanda. The the main possibilities are: (1) to Ved. gadati 'spricht' as a blend of the root *u̯ed- 'sprechen' and a root *gʷet-, the basis of which would be in Germanic and perhaps also in Arm. kočem 'nenne, rufe'| (2) to Lat. vetāre (older votāre) 'nicht erlauben, untersagen'| (3) modern Iranian words in a corresponding meaning based on older *ǰat-.}];179[277-278{S.v. Goth. Q9. qiϸan 'λέγειν', 'to say', possibly from PIE *gʷet- 'speak', attested primarily in Gmc., elsewhere Skt. gádati 'say' if from *gatati, Arm. kočʻem < *gʷot-i- 'call'. Not to be connected with Lat. vetō 'forbid', or OIr. bēl 'lip'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say'. Further etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 212, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):319, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):277-278, [Seebold 1970](src-556):318-320, [Olsen 1999](src-180):811.

Source: 352[1084-1085{Cf. s.v. OLith. teĩkti 'geben, gewähren| wünschen, gönnen'. Next to teĩkti 'gewähren' is northern Žemaitian teĩkti 'sagen' corresponding to Latvian tèikt 'sagen, erzählen, berichten'. The etymology is unclear| perhaps a secondary full grade teik- to tik-, which could be the zero-grade form PIE *tek- 'die Hand ausstrecken'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps a secondary full grade teik- to tik-, which could be the zero-grade form of PIE *tek- 'to stretch out the hand' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1084-1085). If so, perhaps further connected to 'right' in [cognate set 7113](cog-7113).

Source: 81[518{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know' from PIE *uoid- (cf. Skt. véda 3.sg.pf., Gk. οἴδα 3.sg.pf., Go. wait 3.sg.pf.).}];141[665-667{Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-7).}];595[4: 288{PS *věděti is derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'see, catch sight of, spot'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know', a derivative of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see, catch sight of' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):518, [LIV²](src-141) 665-667).

Source: 50[156{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gelo- 'yellow, white', from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' (cf. Lat. heluus 'honey yellow', Gk. χλωρός 'pale green', Skt. harí- 'green', OCS zelenъ 'green', OE geolu 'yellow').}];151[431-432{S.v. OIr. gel 'white'. There are two formal possibilities at a root etymology, either to *g̑ʰel(ə)- 'glänzen, schimmern' (IEW 429ff.) or *g̑el(ə)- 'hell heiter glänzen, lächeln, lachen' (IEW 366f., cf. LIV² 162 *g̑elh₂- 'in Lachen ausbrechen')| the connection to the former *g̑ʰel(ə)- is preferable. [Cf. also 'moon' pp. 259-260]}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gelo-, most likely to continue a derivative of PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):431-432, [Matasović 2009](src-50):156).

Source: 341[667{S.v. TochA träṅk-'sagen, sprechen', 'say, speak' (cf. TochB träṅk- 'beklagen', 'lament'). Proposed etymologies are doubtful.}];345[333-334{Cf. s.v. TochB träṅk- 'lament', with TochA träṅk- 'say' from PT *träṅk-, but extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):667 and [Adams 2013](src-345):333-334 for previous proposals.

Source: 141[673-674{S.v. *u̯ekʷ- 'sagen' (IEW 1135-6).}];172[II:489-491{S.v. Ved. √vac- 'sprechen, reden, nennen, sagen' (OAv. vaxšiiā 'ich werde verkündigen'), from PIE *u̯ekʷ- (cf. Gk. εἰπεῖν 'sprechen', OIr. foccul 'Wort' (*u̯okʷ-tlo-), MHG gewahenen 'erwähnen', ON váttr 'Zeuge').}];83[402-404{S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯ač- 'to say, speak', from PIE *u̯ekʷ- 'to speak, say, tell'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ekʷ- 'to say' ([LIV²](src-141) 673-674, [EWAia](src-172) II:489-491, [Cheung 2007](src-83):402-404).

Source: 240[67{S.v. Old Welsh guetid v. pres. 3 sg 'to speak', a cognate of dywedyd, etc.| IE etymology disputed. *u̯et- of this form was claimed by GPC to be a variant of IE *u̯ed- (Skt. vadati) (not in IEW).}];50[418{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wet-o- 'say', from PIE *u̯eth₂- 'say' (cf. Lat. ueto 'forbid', Hitt. uttar 'word, speech').}];141[694-695{S.v. *u̯eth₂- 'sagen' (not in IEW).}];304[679-680{S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯et-e/o- 'sagen, sprechen', from PIE *u̯eth₂- (LIV 694f.).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯et-e/o- 'to say, speak', further derived from PIE *u̯eth₂- 'to say' ([LIV²](src-141) 694-695, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):679-680, [Matasović 2009](src-50):418, cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):67).

Source: 352[855-856{S.v. OLith. regė́ti 'sehen, schauen, bemerken' (BSl. redzêt 'sehen| traümen| sehen nach| aufpassen, sorgen, verlangen' etc.). Etymology unclear. LIV² 498 considers a possible root *(h₂)regʰ- 'sich aufrichten, but the connection is uncertain. Likewise the comparison with Alb. rúaj 'bewachen, bewahren, beobachten' remains doubtful. Cf. ALEW for references to further literature.}];141[498{Cf. s.v. *regʰ- 'sich aufrichten' [IEW 854, 863], under which Lith. regiù (regė́ti) is suggested to be based on an essive formation ?*r̥gʰ-h₁é-, but this etymology is considered to be not fully certain.}]
Justification: Cf. Old Lithuanian regė́ti 'to see', further etymology uncertain. [LIV²](src-141) 498 considers a possible derivation on the basis of an essive formation ?*r̥gʰ-h₁é-, but this is not fully certain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 855-856 for further discussion).

Source: 141[114-116{Cf. s.v. 1. *demh₂- '(zusammen)fügen, bauen' (IEW 198-9).}];54[177-179{S.v. Lat. domus, -ī, / -ūs. The Latin (and Slavic) forms are from a u-stem derivative of PIE *dōm, *dem- 'house' (Skt. dám-, Av. dam- < *de/om-| Skt. dáma- 'house', Gk. δόμος 'house, layer of bricks' < *dóm-o-, Russ. дом 'house', (L.sg. дому) < *dom-u-)}];444[245-246{S.v. 2733 domina 'Herrin', 2. domna.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin domina 'mistress, lady', the feminine equivalent to Latin dominus 'master of a household' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):245-246), further derived from Latin domus 'house' < *dom-u-, cf. PIE *demh₂- 'build' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):177-179, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 114-116).

Source: 341[836-839{S.v. TochAB läk- 'sehen', 'see, look'. It is difficult to choose between the competing root etymologies of *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' and *leu̯k- 'shine'| both possible etymologies have their merits and flaws in formal derivation.  "An ideal solution would be to derive preterital PT *l’æk- from PIE *lēg̑-, and what seems to be PT *läk- from PIE *luk-, but such a strategy would hardly please William of Ockham."}];345[596-597{S.v. TochB läk- 'see| look at, catch sight of| visit, behold| look forward to', with TochA läk- from PToch. läk- probably from PIE *leg̑- 'gather'. Less likely is the connection to PIE *leuk- 'shine' because the change of PIE *-u- > Toch. -ä- appears to be quite late.}];141[397, 418-419{Cf. s.v. *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' (IEW 658) and s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9), both without TochAB läk- listed.}]
Justification: Root etymology uncertain; probably either PIE *leg̑- 'gather' or PIE *leu̯k- 'shine' (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):836-839, [Adams 2013](src-345):596-597).

Source: 172[II:763{S.v. Ved. strī́- 'Frau, Weib, Ehefrau' (YAv. strī- 'Weib', etc.). The PIE etymology of PIIr. *(H?)striH- is not securely ascertained.}];442[792{S.v. 13734 Ved. strī́- 'woman, wife' RV.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:763). For Modern Indic forms cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):792 no. 13734. Cf. parallel loans from Sanskrit into Modern Indic in [cognate set 5789](cog-5789).
Parallel loans from Persian عورت‎ / ʿawrat 'nudity, genitals', ultimately via Arabic عَوْرَات‎ / ʿawrāt 'blemishes; nudity; genitals, pudendum'.

Source: 388[338{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skenϸan- ~ *skenϸō (ON skinn 'skin (of a little animal)', MHG scint 'fruit shell'). Probably related to Bret skant 'dandruff'.}];214[493{S.v. ON skinn 'abgezogene Haut, bes. von kleineren Tieren', from Proto-North-Germanic *skenϸa-.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *skenþan- ([Orel 2003](src-388):338, cf. [de Vries 1961](src-214):493). Further etymology uncertain. [Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)].

Source: 54[116{Cf. Lat. cīvis 'citzen' < PIE *k̑ei̯-u̯o- 'friendly, intimate, dear' (cf. Ved. śivá- 'favourable', Latv. siẽva 'wife', Goth. heiwa-frauja 'master of the household', OEng. hīwan 'members of the household' OHG hīwo 'husband', OIc. hýski 'household, family').  "The IE root behind this formation is often assumed to be *k̑ei- 'to lie', but this is semantically difficult. Vine 2006b: 148 embroiders on an earlier suggestion by Bader: he proposes a derivative in *-uo- from the pronominal stem *k̑i- 'this (here)' (> Skt. siva-), with full grade *k̑eiuo- 'close'"}];352[1016-1017{Cf. s.v. OLith. šeimatìs 'Hausstand, Hausfamilie, Hausgenossen' (cf. Goth. haims 'Dorf' ON heimr 'Wohnort, Heimat', OE hām), to which may probably be connected Latv. siẽva 'Ehefrau' (cf. OHG hīwa 'Gattin', and probably also Ved. śéva- 'lieb, vertraut', śivá- 'freundlich, lieb', Lat. cīvis, -is 'Bürger'). Cf. [Villaneuva Svensson 2011](src-758):32.}];758[32{"Latv. siẽva “wife” […] can hardly be interpreted otherwise than as a vr̥ddhi-derivative of *k̑éi‑u̯o‑ “socially close” (: Ved. śéva- “dear”, śivá- “friendly”, Lat. cīuis “citizen”, Gmc. *heiwa “household”)."}]
Justification: Latvian and Latgalian forms derived from Latvian siẽva 'wife' and further connected to PIE *k̑ei̯-u̯o- 'socially close' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1016-1017, [Villaneuva Svensson 2011](src-758):32). It is not certain whether or not the underlying lexical root is identical with *k̑ei̯- 'to lie' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):116 s.v. Lat. cīvis).

Source: 54[527{S.v. Lat. rota 'wheel', from which Lat. rotundus 'round' is derived. Lat.  rota is from PIE *(H)rot-o/h₂- (cf. Lith. rãtas 'wheel, circle, ring', pl. 'cart', OHG rad 'wheel', Skt. ratha-, YAv. raθa- 'chariot').}];274[575-580{Cf. s.v. *ret- 'laufen' (LIV² 507, IEW 866).}];444[611{S.v. 7400 Lat. rotundus 'rund', 2. retundus.}]
Justification: Latin rotundus 'round' and its Romance continuants, derived from Latin rota 'wheel' and ultimately further to PIE *ret- 'run' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):611, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):527, [NIL](src-274) 575-580).

Source: 165[247, 305{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' as though from *kringʰ-o- (cf. OCS krǫgъ 'circle' < *krongʰ-o-). "An exclusively Slavic and Germanic root that is in violation with the IE constraint against the co-occurrence of plain stops and voiced aspirates. This makes it likely that its origin is to be found in the post-IE phase. Further cf. *hrungō- and - with irregular onset - *kringa-. Gr. κρίκος, κίρκος m. 'ring' is unrelated."}];178[I: 670{Makes the same connection as Kroonen 2013: 247 between the Slavic lexemes and Proto-Germanic *hringa- etc.}];81[251{S.v. Proto-Slavic *krǫglъ 'round' (ESSJa XIII 23-24), an adjective in *-lo- derived to the same root underlying Proto-Slavic *krǫgъ 'circle' as though from PIE *krongʰ-o- (cf. OIc. hringr 'ring').}];141[563{Cf. s.v. ?*(s)krengʷ- 'sich krümmen, schrumpfen' (IEW 936). Verbal only Germanic, cf. OCS krǫgъ m. 'Kreis'.}];385[{*krongʷ-o- seems to be the most viable solution, cf. the citations. Revision might be needed.}];458[13: 25-27{PS *krǫgŭ 'circle' is derived from PIE *kreng(ʰ)- (< probably *(s)kr-en-ɡ(ʰ)- 'twist, circulate, bend') and related to German Ring etc. and Umbrian krenkatrum 'belt, girdle'.}];397[768{Cf. s.v. NHG Ring (MHG rinc, OHG (h)ring, OS hring), from PGmc. *hrenga- 'Ring' also in ON hringr, OE hring, OFr. hring. Outside of Germanic one also compares OCS krǫgŭ 'Kreis' and perhaps Umbr. cringatro 'Schulterband'. Further provenance unclear.}];269[{Etymology difficult. Comparisons are typically made with Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):251, [ESSJa](src-458) 13:25-27, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):247, [Kluge 2011](src-397):768). As [Kroonen 2013](src-165):247 points out, however, the necessary reconstruction of *krengʰ- violates IE root structure constraints and may well point to a post-PIE origin for the Germanic and Slavic lexemes. Inexplicably, Kroonen also appears to consider that the lexemes are also related to Proto-Germanic *kringa- < PIE *greng̑ʰ- (cf. [cognate set 9606](cog-9606)). An alternative possibility would be that both the forms as though from *krengʰ- and *greng̑ʰ- were independent loan events from a third source although without any firsthand knowledge of a substratum source this solution is speculative.}]
Justification: Etymology difficult. Comparisons are typically made with Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):251, [ESSJa](src-458) 13:25-27, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):247, [Kluge 2011](src-397):768). As [Kroonen 2013](src-165):247 points out, however, the necessary reconstruction of *krengʰ- violates IE root structure constraints and may well point to a post-PIE origin for the Germanic and Slavic lexemes. Inexplicably, Kroonen also appears to consider that the lexemes are also related to Proto-Germanic *kringa- < PIE *greng̑ʰ- (cf. [cognate set 9606](cog-9606)). An alternative possibility would be that both the forms as though from *krengʰ- and *greng̑ʰ- were independent loan events from a third source although without any firsthand knowledge of a substratum source this solution is speculative.

Source: 697[318{S.v. Gmc. *-hʷelba- 'rund', a strong adjective to a reconstructable strong verb *hʷelba- ᾽wölben'.}];556[281{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *hwelb-a- (?) 'wölben'. A Germanic strong verb *hwelb-a- 'wölben' is not more securely attested outside of the Old West Norse PPP holfinn 'gewölbt' and the OFr. hapax biwlven, but its original existence is probable. No further useful comparanda outside of Germanic.}];165[262, 265{Cf. s.v. *hwelfan- 'to vault, revolve', a marginally attested strong verb from a European root *kʷelp-| cf. *hwalfa- 'vault' (ON hvalf 'concavity', Far. hválv 'arch, vault', OE hwealf 'arched covering' < *kʷólp-o- (cf. Gk. κόλπος 'bosom| womb| hollow space, pocket' < *kʷolp-o- with dissimilation of *kʷ > *k as in καρπός < *kʷrp-o-).}];269[{Generally connected to a marginally attested strong verb *hwelban- ~ *hwelfan- ([Seebold 1970](src-556):281, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):318, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):265). The cognates within Germanic are generally connected to Gk. κόλπος 'bosom| womb| hollow space, pocket' to a reconstructable root *kʷelp- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):262| cf. also [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270), [Beekes 2010](src-66) s.v. Gk. κόλπος), although not acknowledged by [Seebold 1970](src-556). Root not in [LIV²](src-141), probably due to its marginal attestation as a strong verb in Germanic.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes generally connected to a marginally attested strong verb *hwelban- ~ *hwelfan- ([Seebold 1970](src-556):281, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):318, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):265). The cognates within Germanic are generally connected to Gk. κόλπος 'bosom; womb; hollow space, pocket' to a reconstructable root *kʷelp- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):262; cf. also [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270), [Beekes 2010](src-66) s.v. Gk. κόλπος), although not acknowledged by [Seebold 1970](src-556). Root not in [LIV²](src-141), probably due to its marginal attestation as a strong verb in Germanic.

Source: 353[58-59, 497{S.v. Lith. apvalùs 'round', a compound of ap + valùs, which may be cognate with vélti (II) 'felt, full, tousle' < *uelH- (cf. Goth. wulan 'seethe').}];141[677{Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) walzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].}];352[52{S.v. OLith. apvalùs 'rund| vollkommen' (BSl. cf. Latv. apaļš 'rund'), derived to the same root as OLith. vélti (II) 'walken, zu Filz machen' < PIE *u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, rollen' (cf. OCS valiti 'sich wälzen, Goth. wulan 'sich ausbreiten', ON velta 'sich wälzen', OHG wellan 'wälzen', OS wellian 'rollen').}];458[31: 124-126{PS *obvĭlŭ < *ob-vĭl-. The root *vĭl- related to PS *valiti, cf. also Lithuanian apvalùs, Latvian apvals and Old Icelandic valr.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯elH- 'to roll' ([ALEW](src-352) 52, [ESSJa](src-458) 31:124-126, [Derksen 2015](src-353):58-59, 497; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 677).

Source: 172[II:294{S.v. Ved. máṇḍala- 'Scheibe, Kreis, Umkreis, Ring'. Etymology disputed.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:294).

Source: 80[467-468{S.v. Hitt. genu- / ganu- 'knee'. The Hittite forms appear to reflect a paradigm nom.sg. *g̑én-u, gen.sg. *g̑n-éu̯-s.}];49[381-382{S.v. *g̑enu, *g̑neu- 'Knie'.}];66[283{S.v. γόνυ 'knee' < PIE *g̑enu, *g̑onu 'knee' (cf. Skt. jā́nu, Av. zānu-, Hitt. genu, Lat. genū, TochA kanwe-ṃ, TochB kenī-ne 'knees', Arm. cun-r, Goth. kniu, etc.).}];345[205-206{S.v. keni* 'knees' (du.). The TochA dual kanweṃ and TochB keni reflect Proto-Tocharian *kenwäi vel sim. Proto-Tocharian *kenw- is certainly from PIE *g̑onu- 'knee'.}];79[343-344{S.v. Arm. cung-kʻ, cunr, cungn 'knee', connected with other IE words for 'knee' (Gk. γόνυ, Skt. jā́nu-, Lat. genū, etc.). The Armenian stem *cung- probably reflects an IE dual neuter *g̑onu-ih₁.}];172[I:584-585{S.v. Ved. jā́nu- 'Knie', from PIE *g̑ónu- / *g̑nu-. In Iranic cf. YAv. zānu-, žnūm (acc.sg.), Khot. ysānū-, Parth. z'nwg, MPers. zānūg, šnūg, NPers. zānū 'Knie', etc.}];165[296{S.v. Proto-Germanic *knewa- 'knee', from a thematised zero-grade stem *g̑n-eu-o-.}];105[137{S.v. gju ~ gjû 'knee', from Proto-Albanian *gluna dissimilated from *g(a)nuna, which in turn is a secondary n-stem derivative based on PIE *g̑enu- 'knee'.}];54[259{S.v. Lat. genu, -ūs 'knee', from PIE *g̑en-u(-h₁ dual), *g̑en-u- (obl.).}];50[162{S.v. Proto-Celtic *glūnos- 'knee', ultimately from PIE *g̑onu- 'knee'. The precise derivation of the stem that resulted in Proto-Celtic *gnūnos- is not fully understood, but the etymology ultimately to other IE words for 'knee' is undisputed. On the dissimilation of initial *gn- > *gl- cf. the same sound change which also occurred independently in Albanian.}];369[190-191{S.v. Alb. gju, -ri, gjû, -ni 'Knie', from the IE inherited word for 'knee' *g̑onu-, *g̑nu-.}];423[III:366-367{For Old Spanish finojo, cf. s.v. Sp. hinojo (II) 'rodilla' < Lat. genuculum, diminutive to Lat. genu 'knee'.}];149[129-130{S.v. B keni, A kanweṃ 'two knees' CT *kænw- reflects PIE *g̑onu̯- (cf. Gk. γόνυ 'knee', Skt. jā́nu 'id.').}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu, *g̑neu- ([IEW](src-49) 381-382, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):467-468, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):129-130, [Adams 2013](src-345):205-206, [Beekes 2010](src-66):283, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):343-344, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):190-191, [Orel 1998](src-105):137, [EWAia](src-172): I:584-585, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):296, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):162). NB: traditionally considered a separate lexical root from PIE 2. *g̑enu- 'jaw, chin' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 380-382).

Source: 66[676-677{S.v. κέρας 'horn for blowing and drinking' < PIE *k̑erh₂-s- 'horn'.}];54[136-137{S.v. Lat. cornū, -ūs 'horn' < Proto-Italic *kornu-, *korno-, from PIE *k̑r̥-n-o-, a thematised n-stem derived from PIE *k̑er-,*k̑r̥- 'head| horn'.}];338[{Re Ossetic: from *šə with formant -kʼa. Root from PIr. *sru(wa)-. Cf. Persian surū-, Avestan srū-, srvā- 'horn'.}];156[III:192];80[446-447{S.v. karāu̯ar / karaun- 'horn(s), antler(s)'. The Anatolian forms reflect a heteroclite stem *k̑r-o-u̯r̥ / *k̑r-o-un-.}];544[{Cf. for an exhaustive discussion of formations meaning 'head' and 'horn' built to this root.}];345[235{S.v. TochB krorīya* 'horn| crescent of moon'. TochA kror and TochB  krorīya reflect a Proto-Tocharian *krorŭ| Proto-Tocharian *kror- is a derivative of PIE *k̑r̥h₂s-r- 'horn'.}];172[II:653{S.v. Ved. śŕ̥ṇga- 'Horn', from PIE *k̑r̥-n-g⁽ʷ⁾o-, derived to PIE *k̑er(h₂)- 'Horn ~ Kopf', cf. *k̑r̥-n- in Lat. cornū, Goth. haurn 'Horn'.}];165[259{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hurna- 'horn', from PIE *k̑rn-o- (cf. Skt. śŕ̥ṅga- 'horn' < *k̑r-n-go-, Lat. cornū < *k̑r-nu-, W. carn 'hoof' < *kr-no-, etc.).}];50[190-191{S.v. Proto-Celtic *karno- 'horn, hoof', from PIE *k̑rno- 'horn'.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. [Nussbaum 1986](src-544) for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root). Cf. also [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):456-457, [Adams 2013](src-345):235 [but cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):182 deriving to *gʰreh₁-u̯r̥], [Beekes 2010](src-66):676-677, [EWAia](src-172) II:653, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):259, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):136-137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):190-191).

Source: 352[835-836{S.v. OLith. rãgas 'Horn' (BSl. cf. Latv. kargs 'Horn, Blashorn, Trinkhorn', OPr. ragis 'Horn', ragingis 'Hirsch', OCS rogъ 'Horn', etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can go back to an o-grade nominal derivation to a root *(H)regʰ-. LIV² 498 s.v. *regʰ- 'sich aufrichten' (n1) suggests extra-Baltic connections to forms such as Gk. ἄρχω 'fange an| herrsche', OHG regen 'aufrichten, erregen', Lith. regiù (regė́ti) 'schauen', but this material may have alternative explanations.}];81[438{S.v. Proto-Slavic *rogъ 'Horn', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rogos (cf. Lith. rãgas, Latv. rags, OPr. ragis).}];353[374-375{S.v. Lith. rãgas 'horn' (Latv. rags 'horn', OPr. ragis 'horn'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *rógos (cf. Proto-Slavic *rogъ 'horn').}];141[498{Cf. s.v. *regʰ- 'sich aufrichten' under n1, where a suggested reconstruction *h₂regʰ- is also considered and potential connections of the associated verbal forms to the nominal lexemes in Balto-Slavic 'horn' (Lith. rãgas, OCS rogъ, etc.).}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(H)regʰ- 'to straighten oneself'. For the root reconstruction, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 835-836, [LIV²](src-141) 498. See also [Derksen 2008](src-81):438, [Derksen 2015](src-353):374-375.

Source: 296[A:15{S.v. adarc 'corne'. Gaulish has a word adarca that has been borrowed into Latin and Greek under the form ἀδάρκης or ἀδάρκη, ἄδαρκον, ἀδάρκιον, which designates a kind of seaweed which is attached to reeds and is used in medicine. This is without doubt the same word, but the semantic connection is not clearly visible. One could explain the word as a compound of the preverb ad- and the root *ark- 'protéger, défendre, écarter' (Lat. arceō), the horn being considered as a 'defense', but in the absence of a secure connection, the etymology is difficult to judge.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:15.

Source: 141[159{Cf. s.v. *dʰu̯ens- 'zerstieben, zerbröckeln' (IEW 268-9). As a verbal root only Vedic, but outside of Indo-Iranian, Germanic *dunsta- < PIE *dʰu̯n̥s-tó- is also established (cf. n1).}];165[109{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dunsta- 'powder, dust(?)' < PIE *dʰuns-to- from PIE root *dʰu̯ens- (cf. TochB tänts 'to scatter' < *dʰuns-, Skt. dhváṃsati 'to fall to dust, perish' < *dʰuéns-e-).}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes from PIE *dʰu̯n̥s-tó-, derived from PIE *dʰu̯ens- 'to scatter, to crumble' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):109, [LIV²](src-141) 159).

Source: 165[55{S.v. Proto-Germanic *basta- m. 'bast'. No further connections outside of Germanic. Hardly to Latin fascis 'bundle'.}];397[95{Cf. s.v. NHG bast (MHG bast, OHG bast OS bast), from Germanic *basta- 'Bast (innere Schicht der Pflanzenrinde), Bastseil', also in ON bast, OE bæst. Origins unclear. According to Koivulehto from PIE *bʰes- 'to scrape, to rub' (LIV² 82 *bʰes- 'to scrunch, to chew up', IEW 145-6). According to others a loan word. (Cf. Kluge for references to further literature.)}];269[{Etymology outside of Germanic unclear (cf. Kroonen 2013, Kluge 2011). Cf. Kluge (2011) for references to various attempts at an IE etymology.}];782[{The Frisian form is suspicious and may be a loanword, as archaic Eastfrisian dialects have båårk, etc.}]

352[580{S.v. OLith. líesas, -à 'mager, hager'. No convincing etymology for Latv. liẽls 'big' and a couple of formally similar Baltic words meaning 'meagre, slender'. They point to an underlying root *lei̯H-, such as PIE *lei̯h₂- 'to fade, to stop' (LIV² 406, IEW 661-2), perhaps also *lei̯d- 'to leave alone'(LIV² 402-3, IEW 666). Even if the Latvian word belongs here, the semantic change has to be explained.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Baltic; perhaps to be connected with Lithuanian leĩlas 'slender', but the semantics of the comparison are difficult (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 580). Traditionally to a root 2. *lei̯- 'eingehen, abnehmen, schwinden; mager, schlank' in [IEW](src-49) 661-662, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:525.

Source: 345[606-607{S.v. TochB luwo 'animal| animal/bird' [birds: lwāsa ṣlyamñana| animals sensu stricto: lwāsa ynamñana]. TochA has sg. lu, pl. lwā/lwāk- corresponding to TochB sg. luwā-, pl. lwāsa-| the singular forms can be reconciled to PToch *lŭwā- < PIE *luhₓehₐ- 'animal of the chase' most closely related to OCS lovъ 'the chase' < *louhₓo- and Greek λέων 'lion' (< *'predator'). Plural forms seem to show a contamination with forms of PToch. *tsäuwā- 'animal'.}]
Justification: This cognate class is coded for Proto-Tocharian *luwā- 'animal'; further connections uncertain. Pace [Adams 2013](src-345):606-607, the comparison to Greek λέων is unsatisfactory as this word is likely to be a Near Eastern loanword, cf. Akkadian lābu, Ugaritic lbʾ, Hebrew lābī ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):635, [Beekes 2010](src-66):854). Adams's further comparison to OCS lovъ 'the chase' and other Slavic lexemes in the meaning 'hunt' may be possible, but the etymology of these forms are not certainly established (cf. further discussion in [cognate set 1145](cog-1145)).

Source: 444[44{S.v. 540 appectorare 'an die Brust drücken' > Port. apertar, from which Port. preto, perto 'eng, knapp', 'schwarz'.}];54[453{Cf. s.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'breast, chest'. Originally a proto-Italic s-stem formation *pektos-. The root is likely to be cognate with OIr. ucht < *puktu-, if from earlier *pektu-.}];316[491{S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'poitrine de l'homme ou des animaux'. A similar word differing in -o- root vocalism and u-stem inflection is found in Irish ucht 'poitrine'. There are no other correspondences outside of these two languages.}]
Justification: A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):491, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):453, and further discussion in [cognate set 4015](cog-4015).
Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442), no. 8397 s.v. *pōḍ- 'burn'. No further etymology.

Source: 345[297-298{TochA tärkär, TochB tärkär reflect Proto-Tocharian *tärkär, as though from a PIE verbal noun *dʰr̥g-r-u-.  Cf. *dʰerg- underlying Baltic forms in Lith. dérgia 'there is bad weather', dárgana, dárga 'bad, rainy weather', Middle Irish derg 'red', Old English deorc 'dark', etc.}]
Justification: Connections outside Tocharian unclear. [Adams 2013](src-345):297-298 proposes connections to PIE *dʰerg- comparing Lithuanian dérgia 'there is bad weather', Middle Irish derg 'red', Old English deorc 'dark', but these connections are not fully certain ([ALEW](src-352) 195-196 rejects extra-Baltic connections for the proposed Lithuanian cognates; the appurtenance of the Germanic and Celtic forms to a root *dʰerg- may well be possible, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):153, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:57-58, but the connection of Tocharian forms to this root are questionable. [Matasović 2009](src-50):96 regards the connection of the Tocharian forms to this etymon doubtful; cf. further discussion in [cognate set 1734](cog-1734)).

Source: 458[19: 234-236, 21: 133-135{PS *morkŭ is related to Lithuanian mérkti, mérkiu 'close one's eyes', Gothic maurgins, Old High German morgan 'morning', possibly also Old Indic markás 'solar eclipse'.}];81[325{PS *morkŭ 'darkness' is related to Lithanian mérkti 'close one's eyes' and Gothic maurgins 'morning'. PIE *morHk-ó-}];165[377{German Morgen < *mr(H)k-e/on-, OCS mrakŭ < *mork-o-, OCS mrĭknǫti < *mrHk-ne-, Lithuanian mérkti < mérHk-e.}]

360[I:399-400{Cf. s.v. Lith. makénti, -ė́ti 'in sumpfigem Boden herumwaten' etc., connected with Latv. makņa 'Sumpf, moorige Stelle' and derivative mãkuôņa, -nis, mãkulis 'Wolke'.}];353[301{Cf. s.v. Lith. maknà 'marshy spot, quagmire'. "A connection with Lat. mācerāre 'to soak, wet' is problematic within an Indo-European context'". Cf. Arm. mōr 'mud'.}]
Comment: with Slavic
Justification: Related to Latvian makņa 'swamp, boggy place', cf. Lith. maknà 'id.' ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) I:399-400). Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, possibly to Armenian mawr 'mud' (cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):301). Cf. also Proto-Slavic *mokrъ 'wet, damp' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):322, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:144). [Not in [ALEW](src-352)].

Source: 50[340{S.v. Proto-Celtic *skāto- 'shadow' (cf. OIr. scáth), probably from a PIE root noun *skeh₃t- / *skh₃t-o- with Celtic preserving the full grade of the root, cf. OEng. sceadu 'shadow', Gk. σκότος 'darkness, gloom'.}]
Justification: Cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 8269](cog-8269) for further discussion regarding the root ref. form.

Source: 66[1672-1673{S.v. ψυχρός 'cold' (adj.), which alongside ψῦχος 'cold, frost' (n.) forms a Caland System within Greek suggesting the word is old. It does not however have an Indo-European etymology.  Older suggestions have attempted to derive 'cold, chilly' < 'blowing wind'?, comp. 'blow' in cognate set 190 but Beekes rejects this connection (s.v. ψυχή, ψυχρός.).}];270[1295-1296{S.v. ψῡχρός, ψῦχος, ψῡ́χω : notion de 'froid'. The related forms within Greek conform to Caland's Law which suggest that they are inherited, but the there are no known cognates in other IE languages.}]
Justification: Because the morphology of the related forms within Greek conform to the Caland system is suggestive that they are inherited from Indo-European, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1295-1296, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1672-1673).

Source: 141[601-602{Cf. s.v. ?2.*steu̯d- 'kalt werden' [IEW 1035]. Root only attested in Slavic. The reconstruction is based on Slavic material only. Perhaps it could be related to 1. *(s)teu̯d- 'hit' but it had to be supported semantically.}];81[471{S.v. Proto-Slavic *studenъ (adj.) 'cold' & Proto-Slavic *studъ m. 'cold, shame'. "In view of [...] *stydъ, where *y probably originates from Winter’s law, the root of *stydъ is best reconstructed as *stoud-. This is reminiscent of the more common root *steug-, e.g. Gk. στυγέω 'hate, abhor, fear', Gk. στύξ f., 'Styx, well of fatal coldness, hatred, abhorrence, (pl.) piercing chill', Gsg. στυγός. A relationship is hard to demonstrate."}];594[{PIE *steu̯d- 'get frozen'. It can be related to Old Indic tundate, tudáti '(he) bangs', lat. tundere 'hit, bang', Gothic stautan. A related PIE root can be *(s)teu̯g-, cf. Greek Στύξ 'river Styx'.}];249[{The Slavic lexeme has no certain further cognates among IE. However, the root itself looks very ancient and the etymology of LIV is addopted.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):471, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 601-2 s.v. ?2. *steu̯d- 'kalt werden'). A connection with the more common homophonous root 1. *steu̯d- 'stoßen', 'to hit' might be possible, but is difficult to justify semantically (cf.  [LIV²](src-141) 601-602). The root reference form as PIE ?*steu̯d- tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141).

Source: 442[67{S.v. 1483 Ved. ā́sadati 'sits near, approaches' RV. [√sad] (B. āsā 'to come').}];172[II:692-693{S.v. Ved. √sad- 'sitzen' < PIE *sed-.}];141[513-515{S.v. *sed- 'sich sitzen' (IEW 884-7).}]
Justification: As though from Vedic ā́sadati 'sits near, approaches' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):67 no. 1483), a derivative of Vedic √sad- 'to sit' and ultimately to PIE *sed- 'to seat oneself' ([EWAia](src-172) II:692-693, [LIV²](src-141) 513-515).

Source: 603[3: 160, 167-170{There are three hypotheses on the etymology of Bulgarian kuče 'dog'. 1) It can be derived from an ideophonic interjection kuč-kuč (attested in some Bulgarian dialects), cf. Belarusian kucu-kucu, Serbo-Croat dialectal kuci-kuci, Polish dialectal kuć-kuć, kuciu-kuciu, Romanian cuțiu cutu, Albanian kut, Italian cucciu, Spanish chuchu, Lithuanian čiùčius, cf. also Estonian kutš, Turkish küçük 'pup', Hungarian kutya. These interjections are used for various domesticated animals. 2) It can be related to Old Indic śuna-s, Avestan sūnō etc. PIE *(s)k̑ou- 3) It can have a Turkic (Proto-Bulgar) origin, cf. Kazakh кушIк 'cub of the dog or other predator'. The ultimate source could be an Iranic language. The word is widespread in the Eastern Europe, cf. Russian kutâ, kutёnok 'pup', Turkish küçük 'pup', Hungarian kutya etc.}];598[433-434{Russian kutёnok 'pup' is derived from an ideophonic interjection kut'-kut', used for luring of various domesticated mammals and birds. Cf. also kuč- in Bulgarian kuče 'dog', kučka 'bitch', Serbo-Croat kuče, Polish kuciu-kuciu, Albanian kutsh 'dog', Latvian kuce 'bitch', kucis 'dog', Ossetian kuj, Kurdish kūčik 'dog'. However, if the Slavic *kučĭka is related to Lithuanian kaũkti 'howl', Old Indic kṓcati 'make a loud noise', kṓkas 'wolf', then it is not related to Russian kutёnok etc.}];458[13:81, 139{PS *kučĭka [with attestations from South Slavic only]. It is has an ideophonic origin or was derived from an interjection used for luring dogs. PS *kutę 'pup' was derived from an interjection.}]
Justification: The origin is obscure. It could be derived from an onomatopoeic interjection. An areal spreading is also not to be excluded. It can not be even assumed that the lexeme or the interjection it is hypothetically derived from had been present already in Proto-Slavic. Cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:81, 139, [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 3:160, 167-170, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 2:433-434 for further discussion. [Cf. also Indic *kutta- in [cognate set 1599](cog-1599), Iranic *kuti- in [cognate set 3186](cog-3186)].

Source: 141[231{S.v. *h₁egʷʰ- 'trinken' [IEW 23].}];341[810-811{Contains an extensive discussion of stem-formation to this root in Tocharian languages.}];80[236-237{S.v. Hitt. eku- / aku- 'to drink' < PIE *h₁egʷʰ- (cf. TochAB yok, Lat. ēbrius 'drunk').}];345[551-552{S.v. TochB yok- 'drink', which with TochA yok- is comparable to Hitt. eku-/aku- 'drink' (cf. Lat. ēbrius 'having drunk one's fill, drunk', Gk. νήφω 'be sober'), most likely from PIE *h₁egʷʰ-.}]
Justification: Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived to PIE *h₁egʷʰ- 'to drink' ([LIV²](src-141) 231; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):236-237, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):810-811, [Adams 2013](src-345):551-552).

Source: 345[63{Cf. s.v. ¹ās- 'dry out, dry up (intr.), parch'| 'dry out, dry up (intr.)', to be connected with PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'dry (through heat)', cf. Lat. areō 'am dry', āridus 'dry, arid'.}];54[53{Romance forms from Lat. āridus, derived from āreō 'to be dry' < PIE *h₂eh₁s-.}];141[257-258{Cf. s.v. *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).}];341[533-535{S.v. TochAB ās- 'austrocknen, trocken werden', 'dry (out)', to be derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' or rather *h₂es- as set up by Ringe 1991:86.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):533-535, [Adams 2013](src-345):63, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257-258).

Source: 54[598{S.v. Lat. sūgō, -ere 'to suck', from PIE *seug-e/o- (cf. OE sūcan 'to suck').}];141[539-540{Cf. s.v. *seu̯k̑- 'saugen' (IEW 912-3). Cf. n1: There seem to have been phonetic variants which were generalised as different roots. Italic and Germanic appear to have inherited both variants, cf. Lat. sūgō 'sauge' but sūcus 'Saft' < *sóu̯k̑-o-| OE sūcan zu *seu̯g̑- beside sūgan- < *séu̯k̑-. The identity of the velar as palatovelar is based on the OCS cognate sъsǫ (sъsati) 'saugen'.}];444[268{Cf. s.v. 3074 Lat. exsūctus 'trocken'}];316[664{S.v. Lat. sūgō 'sucer' (cf. OIr. súgim, OE súcan, OHG sūgan, etc.).}]
Justification: Romance forms from Latin exsūctus 'sucked out, dry' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):268 no. 3074), the past passive participle to Lat. (ex)sugere 'to suck (out)', further to PIE *seu̯k̑- 'to suck' ([LIV²](src-141) 539-540, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):664, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):598).

Source: 66[269-270{S.v. AGk. γῆ 'earth'. No certain Indo-European etymology, cf. Doric γᾶ.  The word is probably related to the poetic variant γαῖα, whose earlier form *gai̯a- was likely contracted to *gā at an early date.}];270[218-219{Cf. s.v. AGk. γῆ 'terre' (par opposition au ciel, par opposition à la mer) Neither γῆ nor γαῖα have an established etymology.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):218-219, [Beekes 2010](src-66):269-270).

Source: 172[II:255-257, 268{S.v. Ved. bhū́mi- 'Erde, Erdboden, Land' (cf. Pā. bhūmi- 'Erde', YAv. būmīm [acc.sg.], MPers., NPers. būm 'Land, Erde', BSogd. βwmh 'Welt, Erde', Chwaresm. βwm 'Erde', etc.), derived from PIIr. √*bhav- 'be, exist' < *bʰeu̯h₂-/*bʰu̯eh₂-.}];141[98-101{Cf. s.v. *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen, werden' (IEW 146-150).}];681[34{S.v. Khw. βwm 'earth', from Av. būmi-, as Sogd. βwm.}];442[545{S.v. 9556 Ved. bhūman n. 'earth, world' RV. [√bhū] and 9557 Ved. bhū́mi- f. 'earth, ground' RV., 'place' ŚBr., bhūmikā́- f. Kāś. [√bhū].}]
Justification: Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *bʰau̯H- 'be, exist' < PIE *bʰeu̯h₂-/*bʰu̯eh₂- ([EWAia](src-172) II:255-257, 268, [LIV²](src-141) 98-101, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):545 no. 9556-9557, [Henning 1971](src-681):34).

Source: 141[677{Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].}];352[1214-1215{Cf. s.v. OLith. uolà 'Fels' (BSl. Latv. uõla 'kleiner, runder Stein, Kiesel| Ei'). Traditionally connected to Lith. vélti (II) 'walken, zu Filz machen' (BSl. Latv. vel̂t, OCS valiti, etc.), from PIE *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. Goth. wulan 'sich ausbreiten' ON velta 'sich wälzen', OHG wellan 'wälzen', OS wellian 'rollen').}];353[481{S.v. Lith. uolà 'rock', Latv. uõla 'small round stone, egg'. "The traditional etymology, which involves a connection with vélti 'felt, tousle', does not seem to present any serious formal difficulties. Initial *v- would be lost before uo and the falling tone of the Latvian variant ùolis may result from a retraction of the stress from prevocalic i. As to the semantics, it is not at all obvious that the etymology is correct." Cf. s.v. Lith. vélti (II) 'felt, full, tousle' < PIE *uelH- (cf. Goth. wulan 'seethe').}]
Justification: Originally 'stone' (cf. Lith. uolà 'rock') and traditionally connected with the same root as Lithuanian vélti 'to tumble, tousle' to PIE *u̯elH- (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1214-1215, [Derksen 2015](src-353):481 for further discussion).

Source: 397[146{Cf. s.v. NHG Brand (MHG brant, OHG brant, OS brand), from Germanic *branda- 'Brand', also in ON brandr, OE brond, OFr. brand, brond. A to-formation (perhaps originally older tu) to Germanic *brenn-a- 'to burn'.}];556[137-138{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *brenn-a- 'brennen'. If the sound law of PIE *gʷʰ- > IE *b- is accepted, then we may consider a comparison with PIE *gʷʰer- as a nu-present (as attested in Indic [grammatical texts], and in Armenian), thus *gʷʰr̥-nu̯- > *br̥nn- > brenn-. Other possibilities include comparisons to IE *bʰreu- 'wallen' (cf. Gmc. *breww-a-) and *bʰereg- 'glänzen'. Cf. derived noun bran-da-z > ON brandr, OE brand, OS brand, OHG brant, etc.}];165[77-78{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn', assuming an etymology from a derived n-present from PIE *bʰreu̯h₁- 'to boil, brew' (cf. OIr. do-bruinn 'to flow, trickle' < *bʰru-n-h₁-ie-| Lat. ferveō, -ere 'to be hot, to boil' < *bʰéru̯h₁-e-).}];141[92-93, 219-220{Cf. s.v. *bʰrei̯H- 'schneiden' (IEW 166-7) and *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5). It is unclear to which root got. (+) brinnan 'brennen' belongs.}];386[290-292, 342-345{Cf. s.v. OHG brant, prant 'Brennen, Verbrennen, Brand(legung)| brennendes Holzscheit, Feuerbrand'| derived from Gmc. *brennen- (*brinnan-), for which cf. s.v. OHG brinnan, prinnan 'brennen, verbrennen, entbrennen, glühen, leuchten'. The verb has no secure etymology| firstly there is no formally corresponding IE root in a similar meaning, and secondly the forms in -nn- in contrast to those in -n- in OE bryne, 'Feuer, Glut', OIc. bruni 'Brand' are in need of an explanation. Cf. entry in EWA 2 for discussion and extensive references to further literature.}]

141[487-488{S.v. *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7).}];345[462-463{S.v. TochB plu- G 'soar, fly up', K 'let fly', which with TochA plu- reflects PToch *pläu- from PIE *pleu- 'flow, float, swim, fly' (cf. Skt. plávate 'swims, flies', Gk. πλέω 'ships, swims', Lat. pluit 'it's raining', Lith. pláuti 'to wash', OCS pluti 'to flow', etc.).}];151[165{OIr. fo-luathar 'flies', a compound of the preverb fo- (Proto-Goidelic *wo- < PIE *upo) + the verbal stem lu- 'sich bewegen' with original deponent inflection. The Proto-Goidelic verbal root *lu- can be placed with the PIE root *pleu̯- 'rinnen, rennen, fließen'.}];341[745-746{S.v. TochAB plu- 'schwimmen, schweben', 'float, fly, soar', to be derived from PIE *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben'.}]
Justification: Tocharian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):462-462, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):745-746, [Lucht 2007](src-151):165).

Source: 50[366{S.v. Proto-Celtic *telamon- 'earth, ground', from PIE *telh₂-m- 'surface, support' (cf. Lat. tellus 'earth', OPr. talus 'ground, floor', OCS tьlo 'ground', OE ϸel 'floor', Arm. tʻał 'district'). The IE root is probably *telh₂- 'raise, support'.}];296[T:22-23{S.v. OIr. talam 'terre', to be connected with Skt. tala- 'surface plane', Lat. tellūs 'terre', OIc. ϸel 'sol', etc. to a base *tel-, *telə-.}];141[622-623{Cf. s.v. *telh₂- 'aufheben, auf sich nehmen' (IEW 1060-1).}];157[288-289{S.v. Gaul. talu-, talamon- 'front, surface', cf. OIr. tul, taul < *talu meaning 'bosse, protubérence, umbo de bouclier, front'.  From an IE root *telh₂- (cf. Skt. talam 'surface, paume', talimam 'sol', Gk. τηλία 'table à jeux', OIr. talam 'terre' < *talamon-, Lat. tellūs 'terre', Lith. pã-talas 'lit', OPr. talus 'sol', etc.).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *telamon- 'earth, ground', a derivative to PIE *telh₂- 'to raise, support' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:22-23, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):288-289, [Matasović 2009](src-50):366, cf. {ref LIV² 622-623).

Source: 50[182-183{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrīyet- 'clay, earth, mud'. "These words are probably related to Lat. crēta 'chalk', but details are obscure. [Mallory & Adams 2006](src-75): 121 reconstruct PIE *tkʷreh₁yot- and add ToB tukri 'clay'. Perhaps it is more sensible to start with the root *kʷreh₁- with the suffix (?) *-yet- and assume that the Tocharian words contain some kind of prefix. It is also possible that all these words were borrowed from non-IE languages."}];296[C:224{S.v. OIr. cré 'terre, glaise, boue'. In view of the corresponding Brythonic forms (W pridd 'terre, glaise', Co. pry, Bret. pri 'id.') one may reconstruct Proto-Celtic *kʷrīi̯ets. A connection with Lat. crēta is not impossible in view of IE *ē > PCl. *ī| the connection of these words further to the root *kʷer- seems very adventurous.}]
Justification: From Proto-Celtic *kʷrīyet- 'clay, earth, mud'; perhaps be further connected to Lat. crēta 'chalk' but further connections obscure ([Matasović 2009](src-50):182-183, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:224).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. hit, from Late Old English hyttan, apparently from Old Norse hitta 'to hit upon, light upon, meet with'.}]
Justification: Apparently a loanword from Old Norse hitta 'to hit upon, light upon, meet with' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 141[698{S.v. *u̯reh₁- 'finden' (IEW 1160). Cf. also LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda s.v. *u̯reh₁-.}];382[949{S.v. SMG ξέρω. The new present stem ξέρω was backformed from Ancient Greek aorist ἐξεῦρον from ἐξευρίσκω 'find out, discover'.}];66[482-483{S.v. AGk. εὑρίσκω 'to find, uncover'. Cf. entry in Beekes for a discussion of competing hypotheses for stem formations in Ancient Greek.}]
Justification: The Modern Greek present stem ξέρω was backformed based on the Ancient Greek aorist stem ἐξεῦρον ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):949, cf. ἐξευρίσκω 'find out, discover'). Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 698, but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):482-483 for further discussion.

Source: 79[153-154{Discussed s.v. Arm. awij-kʻ 'collar'. No widely accepted etymology. Possibly to Gk. αὐχήν 'nape' (Aeol. ἀμφήν) to PIE *h₂u̯eg̑ʰ- but the relationship between Armenian viz, dial. xiz, Armenian awji-k‘ and the Greek lexemes are disputed.}];740[IV:337-338];540[711];320[387{Cf. s.v. viysānvā 'in bindings', suggesting Arm. viz, vizi 'neck' is a loan from Iranian.}]
Justification: Of uncertain origin (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):153-154, [HAB](src-740) IV:337-338), perhaps an Iranic loanword according to [Bailey 1979](src-320):387, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):711). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯iz-].

Source: 172[I:684{S.v. Ved. tvác- 'Haut, Fell| die Haut des lebenden Menschen oder Tieres, in Kontrast zu cárman-' (Pā. taca-, tacas- 'Haut, Rinde'). Probably to be connected with Hitt. tu̯ekka- 'Körper, Person'.}];80[886{The Hitt. and the Vedic words originate from a PIE root noun nom.sg. *tu̯ék (without -s), acc.sg. tu̯ék-m, gen.sg. *tuk-ós. The underlying root *tu̯ek- 'physical appearance?' is also attested in Hitt. tukk-āri ‘to be visible’. }];141[654{S.v. *tu̯ek- 'sichtbar sein' (not in IEW), cf. Hitt. dukkāri 'ist sichtbar, wird gesehen| ist wichtig'. Cf. n1, comparing the root-noun *tu̯ek- 'das sichbare, äußere Form' in Hitt. tuekk(a)-/tukk(a)- 'Körper', Ved. tvác- 'Haut' (cf. Schindler, BSL 67 (1972) 36-7).}];442[346{S.v. 6087 Ved. tvác f. 'skin, hide' RV.}]
