Justification: Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:684, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):346 no.6087, [LIV²](src-141) 654).

Source: 423[II:761-762{Cf. s.v. Sp. esquina 'ángulo exterior que forman dos superficies, canto', probably from Germanic *skĭna- 'barrita de madera, metal, o hueso' (cf. OHG scina 'tibia', 'alfiler'.}];444[659{S.v. 7994 skĭna (fränk., langob.) 'schmales Stück Knochen| Schiene'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing *skĭna-, a loanword from Germanic *skĭna- 'small piece of bone, shin', cf. Germanic scina 'thin strip, shin' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):659 no. 7994, [DCECH](src-423) II:761-762).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan rine from Lat. rēnēs 'kidneys'.}];54[519{S.v. Lat. rēnes 'kidneys' from Proto-Italic *rēn- < PIE *h₂r-ēn- 'kidney'? or *srēn- 'loins'? Potential IE cognates are OIr. áru 'kidney, gland', Welsh arenn 'kidney, testicle' < PCl. *āron-| Hitt. ḫaḫ(ḫa)ri- 'lung(s), midriff' TochB arañce 'heart', TochA āriñc 'id.'.}];316[569-570{S.v. Lat. rēnēs 'reins' "Mot d'origine inconnue qui a remplacé nebrundinēs (v. nefrendēs)."}];444[596{S.v. 7206 Lat. ren 'Niere'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin rēnēs 'kidneys' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):596), further etymology obscure ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):569-570, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):519 for various suggestions).

Source: 50[411{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wello-, *wallo- 'error, deceit' (cf. OIr. foll 'crime', MIr. fell 'deceit, treachery, crime'). Connected by [IEW](src-49) 1140 to Lith. vìlti, vìlbinti 'deceive', Skt. valh- 'puzzle (by riddles)', Gk. ἐλεφαίρομαι 'deceive', in which case we should reconstruct *(h₁)u̯elh₁-(bʰ)-. The geminate *-ll- in Proto-Celtic may be from *-ln-, but the loss of the laryngeal is surprising.}]

534[I:264-265{Cf. s.v. Latv. elpa.}];353[52{Cf. s.v. Lith. al̃pti 'faint, crave', probably cognate with Latv. èlpt 'breathe, breathe heavily', elpêt 'breathe, recover', and ȩl̃pa, el̃pe 'breath'. Further etymology unclear.}];352[35-36{Cf. s.v. OLith. al̃pti 'kraftlos sein| schmachten, verlangen nach', traditionally connected with Latv. èlpt 'schwer atmen', elpêt 'atmen, aufatmen, sich erholen'. No certain comparisons outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: Traditionally connected with Lithuanian al̃pti 'to be weak; to crave, to yearn after', but without any certain correspondences outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 35-36, [Derksen 2015](src-353):52, [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:264-265).

Source: 54[581{S.v. Lat. spīrō, -āre 'to breathe', from Proto-Italic *spīr/s-. Possibly an onomatopoeic formation imitative of the sound of breathing. There are no good comparanda outside of Italic exist to postulate a PIE root.}];316[642-643{S.v. Lat. spīrō, -āre, -āuī, -ātum 'souffler (transitif et absolu)'. Without exact correspondences outside of Latin. One can recover here elements that feature in onomatopoeic forms pertaining to breathing. (cf. Gk.  φῦσα 'soufflet', Lith. puntù, pùsti 'souffler', etc.).}];444[366{S.v. 4469a Lat. inspirāre 'einatmen' > OFrz. espirer.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):642-643, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):581).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. breathe (v.), a Middle English formation from ME breth 'odour, smell, scent'. Cf. s.v. breath (n.), ultimately from OE bræϸ, breϸ 'odour, smell, exhalation'.}];165[74-75{Cf. s.v. *brēan- 'to fume, smell', from PIE *bʰreh₁-e-, a marginal strong verb from which OE brǣþ 'breath' is a derivative < *brēþi-.}];388[57{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *ƀrēđaz, derived from *ƀrējanan, possibly distantly connected with Skt. bhuráti 'to move', Gk. πορφίρω 'to heave, to rise'| otherwise unclear.}]
Justification: A denominal formation originating in Middle English. There are some possible correspondences, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):57 for some proposals and references to older literature, but ultimately no clear etymology outside of Germanic. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):74-75 does not provide comparanda to support a root reconstruction *bʰreh₁- (not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 141[201-202{S.v. ?*gʰrebʰ- 'graben' (IEW 455-6). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, connections to *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' are uncertain.}];165[185-186{S.v. Proto-Germanic *graban- 'to dig', from PIE *gʰróbʰ-e- (cf. OCS greti 'dig, scrape' < *gʰrebʰ-, Latv. grebt 'to scrape, excavate, sieze' < *gʰrebʰ-(ie-)).}];556[235-236{S.v. Gmc. *grab-a- 'graben'. The Germanic forms can be securely connected to *gʰrebʰ- also attested in the neighbouring languages to the east. The Germanic verb shows o-Ablaut. Cf. Latv. grebju, grebt 'ausschaben, aushöhlen, eingraben', OCS grebǫ, greti 'rudern, graben', with po- 'begraben, bestatten'.}];782[{The Frisian from < OFri. grava, yet may be a loan word as at the same time 'nicely' identical to Dutch.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *graban- 'to dig', generally postulated to continue a PIE root *gʰrebʰ- 'to dig' ([LIV²](src-141) 201-202, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):185-186, [Seebold 1970](src-556):235-236). This lexical isogloss is, however, restricted to cognates in Germanic and Balto-Slavic and consequently it's PIE status remains uncertain. The potential relationship of this root to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' remains unclear (cf. [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 81[442{S.v. Proto-Slavic *rỳti 'dig, root', from PIE *(H)ruH- (cf. Lith. ráuti 'tear out, pull', Latv. raût 'tear, pull, take').}];141[510{*reu̯H- 'tear (up)' with OCS rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' and ryjǫ, ryti 'dig' given as cognates.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ([LIV²](src-141) 510, [Derksen 2008](src-81):442).

Source: 531[498-499{Cf. s.v. Lith. ràkti, rakù 'kopać, ryć' (Latv. rakt, rùoku).}];360[694{Cf. s.v. Lith. ràkti 'mit einem spitzen Gegenstand stochern, aufstechen, aufstechen, aufpicken, ausgraben'.}];534[II:103{S.v. Latv. rakt (= Lith. ràkti), from PIE *er(e)k- : *rek- (following [IEW](src-49) 335).}];49[335{S.v. 2. *er(e)k-, *rek-, *rok- 'aufreißen, spalten, schinden'.}];172[I:248{For the older proposed comparison of [IEW](src-49) 335, [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:103, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):694 to Ved. r̥kṣá-, cf. [EWAia](src-172) s.v. Ved. r̥kṣá-, considering its etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Cf. Lithuanian ràkti 'to stab, dig'; no further etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):498-499); traditionally compared to Vedic r̥kṣá- 'bald, bare' ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):694, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:103, [IEW](src-49) 335) but cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:248 considering the proposed Vedic comparanda of dubious etymology. [Not in [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Source: 341[812-813{S.v. TochB rāp-, TochA räp- 'graben, pflugen', 'dig, plow' "According to Adams, DoT, 528f., the root is related to "Proto-Anatolian *terep- < *trep-" denoting 'plow' said to come from PIE *√drep 'scratch, tear', but note that ²LIV, 650 derives the Anatolian comparanda from PIE *√trep- 'wenden' (as also did Janda, 1997, 8ff. and most recently Kloekhorst, 2008, 871), from which Toch. rāp(ā)- cannot be derived by sound law."}];345[574{S.v. TochB rāp- 'dig, turn up the soil, plow', which along with TochA  räp- to be connected to PIE *drep- 'scratch, tear' (LIV² 128-129), connecting Hitt. teripp- 'turn the earth, plow', Gk. δρέπω 'pick, cut', Slov. drpljem 'rip' etc.  Note, however, that LIV² connects the Anatolian cognates with 2. *trep- 'wenden' (LIV² 650, IEW 1094).}]
Justification: Possibly to IE *drep- 'scratch, tear' according to [Adams 2013](src-345):574, although note that the Anatolian evidence which he cites for a semantic parallel is not certainly from this root ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):812-813, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):871).

Source: 345[229-230{S.v. TochB krāke 'dirt, filth (e.g. semen)', derived adjective kraketstse 'dirty, filthy'. AB krāke reflect PToch *krāke, probably a borrowing from Khotanese khārgga- 'id.' with metathesis. Cf. entry for a survey of other less plausible proposals.}]
Justification: Derived from Tocharian B krāke 'dirt, filth', which may in turn be a loan from Khotanese khārgga- 'id.' ([Adams 2013](src-345):229-230).

Source: 382[279{Cf. s.v. SMG βρόμα 'stench'| an adjective in -ικος derived from βρόμα 'stench'.  Babinotis considers the etymology from Ancient βρομέω 'I make a noise' with a semantic change via the sense 'I smell bad' → 'I stink' perhaps via an intermediary sense 'I farted'.}]
Justification: An adjective derived to Standard Modern Greek βρόμα 'stench', considered by [Babinotis 2010](src-382):279 to be a derivative of Ancient Greek βρομέω 'I make a noise' with a semantic change via the sense 'I smell bad' → 'I stink' perhaps via an intermediary sense 'I farted'. No further etymology.

Source: 531[679{Cf. s.v. Lith. tyras, -a "nie porosły drzewami, pusty, opustoszały, niezamieszkały, bezludny"| equivalent to Latv. tīrs "czysty, niezmieszany, niesfałszowany"| Proto-Baltic *tī-ra- < *tiH-ró-. Further etymology uncertain.}];534[II:413{S.v. Latv. tīrs, equivalent to Lith. týras, tyrùs 'skaidrs, dzidrs, tīrs| svaigs| klajš, tukšs'.}];360[1109-1100{S.v. Lith. týras 'rein, sauber, klar, lauter, kahl, öde, waldlos, wüst', cf. Latv. tĩrs 'rein, unvermengt, unverfälscht'.}]
Justification: Lit. 'not-clean', cf. Lithuanian týras. Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):679; for older proposals cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:413, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1109-1110). [Not in [ALEW](src-352) or [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Source: 165[241{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hraini- adj. 'pure, clean'.  Kroonen takes the adjective to be a derivative from an unattested nasal-present *hrinan- 'sift, distinguish, decide', comparing Lat. cernõ, AGk. κρίνω 'separate, choose, decide' from *kri-ne-i̯e-.}];141[366-367{Cf. s.v. *kreh₁(i̯)- 'sieben, trennen' (IEW 945-6).}];179[190{S.v. Goth. H92. hrains 'καθαρός', 'clean', un-hrains 'ἀκάθαρτος', 'unclean'| PIE *krey- + -ni- adj. suffix| cf. verbal forms in Gk. κρίνω 'cut, decide', Lat. cernō 'separate, decide'| Gk. κρί-σις 'decision', Lat. cer-tus 'decided, certain'. [Lehmann accepts an inner-PIE root derivation to PIE *(s)ker- 'cut' following [IEW](src-49) 619].}];697[303-304{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hraini- 'rein', a common Germanic adjective| an old verbal adjective to the nasal present in Greek κρίνω, Latin cernō to the IE root *krei-.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *un-hraini- 'un-clean', an old verbal adjective to the nasal-present stem *kri-né/n-h₁- to PIE *kreh₁(i̯)- 'to sift, to separate'; but the verbal stem *hrinan- is not attested in Germanic ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):302-303, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):241, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 366-367, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):190).

Source: 316[76-77{S.v. Lat. brūtus 'lourd', popular word without a doubt a loanword from Oscan with a labial reflex b- from *gʷ-, from the same root as Lat. grauis 'heavy'.}];54[76{S.v. Lat. brūtus 'heavy, inert, brute| brutish', generally regarded as a Sabellic dialect word with PIE *gʷ- > b- and from the same stem as Lat. gravis 'heavy'.}];444[121-122{S.v. Lat. brūtus 'roh', certain Romance forms reflect *bruttus with expressive gemination.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin brūtus 'heavy, brute; brutish' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):121-122), generally considered to be a dialectal loanword from Sabellic with a labial reflex of initial *gʷ- from PIE *gʷr̥h₂-, cf. Latin grauis 'heavy' in [cognate set 6470](cog-6470) ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):76-77, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):76).

Source: 444[694{S.v. 8414 Lat. sucidus 'schmutzig'}];54[603{S.v. Lat. sūs, suis 'pig, sow', from PIE *suh₁/₃-s, gen. *suh₁/₃-os 'pig, swine' (cf. Skt. sūkará- 'wild boar', YAv. hū-, Gk. ὗς, ὑός, Alb. thi 'pig', OHG, OE sū 'sow', etc.), derived noun sūcīdia 'joint of pork'.}];316[670{S.v. Lat. sūs, suis 'sanglier, laie| porc, truie', derivative suc(c)īdia, -ae 'quartier de porc salé', from the IE word designating either a wild boar or a domestic pig (Gk. ὗς, ὑός, OHG sū, Alb. thi, Av. hū, etc.).}];657[425{S.v. PIG, cf. discussion under *sūs (gen. *s(u)u̯ós) 'pig (wild or domesticated)' (cf. [IEW](src-49) *sū̆-s) for discussion of the reconstruction of the IE stem.}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes as though from Latin *sucīdus 'dirty', cf. Latin suc(c)īdia 'side of pork' derived from Latin sūs 'wild boar; pig' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):694, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):670, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):603). For the reconstruction of the Indo-European word for 'wild boar; pig', cf. the discussion of [EIEC](src-657) 425.

Source: 165[406{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rauki- 'smoke'. An i-stem derived to the strong-verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke, drift, fly' (without a generally accepted etymology), cf. also ON ryk 'dust' < *rukja-.}];397[748{S.v. NHG Rauch (MHG rouch, OHG rouh, OS rōk), from Gmc. *rauki- also in ON reykr, OE rēc, OFr. rēk| derived from the strong verb underlying NHG riechen, whose original meaning was 'to smoke'.}];556[379-380{S.v. Gmc. *reuk-a- 'rauchen'. There is only a possibility for comparison in Baltic via Lith. ráugti 'säuern', intr. 'aufstoßen', Latv. rûgt 'säuern, aufgehen, rauchen'.}]
Justification: Derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' [Seebold 1970](src-556):379-380, [Kluge 2011](src-397):748, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):406, 410. There is with no further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 299](cog-299).
Possibly continuing a Proto-Iranic root *du̯ai-, although the evidence for such a root is limited to Middle and Modern East Iranic ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):46, [Cheung 2007](src-83):81-82).

Source: 442[222{S.v. 4159 *girati (1) 'drips, falls'.}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *girati ʻdrips, falls' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) no. 4159). Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 442[203{S.v. 3856 *khasati (1) 'falls, slips'}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *khasati ʻfalls, slips' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) no. 3856), further etymology uncertain.

Source: 352[524, 527{S.v. OLith. krìsti 'fallen'. Zero-grade formation to OLith. krė̃sti < PIE *kret- 'schütteln, rütteln' (cf. Gk. κροτέω 'schlage, rassele', OIr. crothaid 'schütteln, schwingen, erschüttern, erzittern machen', OHG redan 'sieben').}];141[370-371{S.v. *kret- 'schütteln, rütteln' (IEW 620, 621).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *kret- 'to shake' ([ALEW](src-352) 524, 527; [LIV²](src-141) 370-371).

Source: 345[611-612{S.v. TochB lau 'afar| far' Etymology unclear.  Presumably related to TochB lauke, TochA lok 'far (off), remote| away', but further IE connections are dubious.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):611-612).

Source: 231[149{S.v. ScG. eagal, feagal 'fear', Ir. eaguil, eagla, E. Ir. ecla, OIr. ecal (adj.), *ex-gal| see gal 'valour'.}];50[149{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *galā 'valor, ability', from PIE *gelH- 'be able' (cf. Lith. galiù 'be able').}];141[185-186{Cf. s.v. *gelHº- 'Macht bekommen über' (IEW 351).}];728[5{S.v. Manx aggle 'fear' (= ScG. eagal).}];300[{Cf. s.v. OIr. ecal adj. 'timorous, fearful' <*ek(s)gal}]
Justification: Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish ecla 'fear, dread', cf. ecal 'timorous, fearful' < *eks-gal, to which Old Irish gal 'valour' < Proto-Celtic *galā 'valor, ability', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gelH- 'to have power over' ([Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)](src-300), [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):149, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):5, [Matasović 2009](src-50):149, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 185-186).

Source: 141[257{S.v. *h₂egʰ- 'in Furcht geraten, betrübt werden' (IEW 7-8).}];50[26{S.v. Proto-Celtic *āg-V- 'fear', from PIE *h₂egʰ- 'be afraid'.}];179[270{S.v. Goth. O3. *ogan 'φοβεῖσθαι', 'fear', from PIE agʰ- 'fear' (cf. Gk. ἄχυμαι 'be sad, mourn', OIr. ad-āgor 'I fear').}];296[A:23];165[3{S.v. Proto-Germanic *agan- pret.-pres. 'to fear' > Goth. ogan, 3.sg. og 'id.' (cf. Gk. ἄχομαι 'to grieve, lament' < *h₂égʰ-e-, OIr. -ágadar 'to fear' < *h₂e-h₂ogʰ-e-).}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂egʰ- 'to get scared, become distressed' ([LIV²](src-141) 257, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):270, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):3, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:23, [Matasović 2009](src-50):26).

Source: 141[225-6{S.v. *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'in Bewegung geraten (ohne Ortsveränderung)' (IEW 511-2).}];567[219{Bactrian ιωλ-/ιοστο < Proto-Iranian *yauda-/yusta- (cf. Khot. juv-/justa-).}];172[II:418-419{S.v. Ved. √yodh- 'kämpfen' < PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ-.}];83[176-177{S.v. Proto-Iranian *Hi̯au̯d- 'to fight, to struggle (for something), strive, seek', from PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'to fight, to set out, move (to fight)' (cf. Skt. yodh- 'to fight', OLat. ioube-, Lat. iubēre 'to order, command', Lith. judė́ti 'to move', Lith. judùs 'belligerent', Gk. ὑσμίνη 'battle, fight').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'to set in motion' ([EWAia](src-172) II:418-419, [Cheung 2007](src-83):176-177, [LIV²](src-141) 225-226).

Source: 83[298{S.v. Proto-Iranic *part- 'to fight, struggle'. "This IIr. root appears to be an incremented root of IE *per- 'to hit, fight' (*par- 3), but it has no further IE cognates.", cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *par- (3) 'to fight, struggle' < PIE *per- (cf. Arm. [aor.] ehar 'struck', OCS pьrjǫ 'I argue, quarrel', Ru. pru, perét') 'I push, drag', Lith. periù 'I beat, lash with a besom (in the bath)'.}];141[477{Cf. s.v. ?*pert- 'in Streit geraten, kämpfen' (IEW 818). Only Indo-Iranic. [Cf. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-9)].}];172[II:160{Cf. s.v. Ved. pr̥t- 'Kampf, Streit, Schlacht'. The origin of Indo-Iranic *part- is not explained. A pre-IIr. analysis *par-t- < PIE *pER-t remains, however, remains considerable.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *part- 'to fight, struggle', perhaps further related to PIE *per- 'to beat' with a dental extension? (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):298, [EWAia](src-172) II:160, [LIV²](src-141) 447).

Comment: root cī- 'to attempt, fight', no further etymology

Source: 54[350{S.v. Lat. luctor, -āri 'to wrestle, struggle', a frequentative verb based on PIE *lug-to- 'bent' (cf. OIr. fo-loing 'supports' in-loing 'connects' MWel. ellwng- 'to set free' < PCl. *-lunge/o- 'to place', Gk. λύγος 'withy, twigs', Goth. ga-lūkan 'to shut', us-lūkan 'to open').}];141[416{Cf. s.v. 2. *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen' (IEW 685-6).}];444[418{S.v. 5147 lucta 'Ringkampf, Kampf' and 5148 Lat. luctāre 'kämpfen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin luctāre 'to fight' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):418), a frequentative verb based on PIE *lu⁽g̑⁾-to- 'bent' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):350, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 416 s.v. 2. *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen').

Source: 443[{S.v. Lat. battuere 'schlagen' > Fr. battre.}];316[68{S.v. Lat. battuō, -is, -ere 'battre'. A word that is rare in texts, but already attested in Plautus. Similar to Celtic words in the sense but in different form. Origin unknown. As in Lat. fut(t)uō 'I fuck' the consonant gemination is expressive.}];444[85, 196{S.v. 996 Lat. battuere 'schlagen', 2073 Lat. combattuere 'kämpfen, bekämpfen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin (com)battuere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):85, 196), of obscure origin ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):68).

Source: 141[480{S.v. *peu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'stechen' (IEW 828).  Verbal derivatives of the root are only attested in Italic, cf. AGk. πύξ adv. 'with the fist', πυγμή 'fist| fistfight'.  Latin has nouns pugil 'fistfighter, boxer' pūgnus 'fist'.  The exact formation of the verb is unclear| LIV² suggests a nasal-infix present ?*pu-né-/n-⁽g̑⁾-.}];54[499{S.v. Lat. pungō 'to pierce, sting'. Lat. pugnāre 'fight' is denominal from pugnā 'fight' (n.), which in turn is related to the noun pūgnus 'fist' (cf. Gk. πύξ 'with the fist', πύγμη 'fist, fist-fight', etc.).}]
Justification: Derivative from PIE *peu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to pierce, sting', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 480, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):499 for further discussion.

Source: 296[T:148-149{S.v. OIr. troit 'combat, bataille'. [Pedersen 1909](src-307) supposes *trud-no- comparing Lat. trudō 'frapper', Goth. us-ϸriutan 'tomber lourdement'| [IEW](src-49) 1026-1027 supposes a dental-extended root from *streu- (cf. OE strútian, 'se tenir raide', MHG strūz 'opposition, combat', ON ϸrūtinn 'enflé'), where he also cites Ir. trot and W. *trythu 'enfler'. But the latter does not exist, and there is no reason to suppose a development 'enflure' > 'combat' for Irish.}];141[651-652{Cf. s.v. *treu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1095-6).}]
Justification: Possibly continuing a formation (as though) from PIE *trud-no- according to [Pedersen 1909](src-307):160, comparing Latin trudō 'to thrust, push', Gothic us-ϸriutan 'to maltreat' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:148-149, [LIV²](src-141) 651-652). The etymology of [IEW](src-49) 1026 to a dental-enlarged root *streu- is less likely. [Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)].

Source: 345[440{S.v. TochB pyāpyo 'flower', which with TochA pyāpi reflect PToch *pyāpyā(-i̯än)- where *-i̯än- reflects the PIE "definitizing" suffix *-h₁en-. The stem "probably reflects a (reduplicated) PIE *p(e)yehₐ- [: Sanskrit pyā́yate ‘is swollen’ and others from the extensive group of *peihₐ-: Sanskrit páyas- (nt.) ‘liquid, water, milk,’ pā́van- (adj.) ‘fat,’ Greek pī́ōn ‘id.,’ etc. (P:793-794| MA:194, 382)] (VW, 1941:104, 1976:398)."}];172[II:172{Cf. s.v. Ved. √pyā- 'schwellen, strotzen', probably a root restricted to Indo-Iranic. Cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:349 for failed attempts to construe an IE root *pi̯eH-. Possibly a Schwebeablaut variant to *pei̯H- (cf. s.v. Ved. √pay-ⁱ 'schwellen, strotzen, voll sein, reichlich strömen'), but the details remain unclear.}]
Justification: Tocharian forms, according to [Adams 2013](src-345):440, to be connected with PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' via a Schwebeablaut variant *pi̯eH- and connected with Vedic √pyā- 'to swell' but the existence of this variant remains uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:84, II:172; [KEWA](src-399) II:349, [LIV²](src-141) 464-465.

Source: 172[II:153, 171-172{Cf. s.v. Ved. púṣpa- 'Blume, Blüte' and puṣya- 'Blüte, Blume', both derivatives to Ved. √poṣ- (cf. s.v.) < Proto-Indo-Iranian *√pau̯š-. Further etymological connections for PIIr. *pau̯š- remain uncertain.}];442[470{Cf. s.v. 8303 Skt. púṣpa- n. 'flower' and 8306 Skt. púṣya- (1) n. 'vigour'.}]
Justification: Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *pau̯š- 'to blossom, bloom' ([EWAia](src-172) II:153, 171-172). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. For the Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):470, no. 8303 and 8306.

Source: 534[II:85{S.v. Latv. puķe, a loanword from Finnic.}]
Justification: Loan from Finnic, cf. Livonian puk'k' (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:85).

Source: 66[104-105{S.v. ἄνθος 'flower' < PIE *h₂endʰ- 'sprout'. The Greek noun is an s-stem derivative and directly equatable with Sanskrit ándhas- 'sprout of the soma plant', and an s-stem *h₂endʰ-os- may be reconstructed.}];270[89-90{Chantraine has reservations about the comparison with Sanskrit ándhas- on the basis that "le sens propre de plante est mal assuré en skr."  Chantraine notes that ἄνθος is the proper word for flower in the katharevousa register of Modern Greek, but in demotic the lexeme has been replaced by λουλούδι [lexeme 7534](lex-7534).}];141[266{Cf. s.v. ?*h₂endʰ- 'blühen, sprießen' (IEW 40-1). Verbal only Greek, the nominal derivative ἄνθος is comparable to Ved. ándhas- 'soma plant'.}];172[I:79{Cf. s.v. Ved. ándhas- 'zur Somapressung verwendeter Sproß, Schoß (und ähnliches)' < PIE *h₂éndʰes- (cf. Gk. ἄνθος 'Keim, Sproß, etc.'| cf. also Fries. åndul 'feines zartes grünes Gras auf den Hellern').}]
Justification: Generally compared with Vedic ándhas- 'sprout of the soma plant' which can be accounted for via an s-stem *h₂éndʰ-os- from which Greek ἄνθος would also be a regular reflex ([Beekes 2010](src-66):104-105, [LIV²](src-141) 266, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:79). See, however, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):89-90 with some reservations.

Source: 141[588{Cf. s.v. *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' (IEW 1003).}];172[II:784-785{Cf. s.v. Ved. √srav- 'strömen, fließen' (YAv. raonąm G.pl. of the rivers, θraotō.stāt- 'in Flußlaufen befindlich', OPers. rautah-, Parth. rwd, MPers., NPers. rōd 'Fluß', etc.), from PIE *sreu̯- (cf. Arm. aṙogane- 'bewässern', Gk. ῥέω 'fließe, ströme', ῥυτός 'fließend', OHG stroum 'Strom', Lith. sravė́ti 'sickern, langsam fließen', etc.).}]
Comment: Non-Persian words with additional -xVnV might all be loans from early Persian rōdxāna (or a later form), although this can be proved only for Mazanderani.
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ({ref EWAia II:784-785, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 588).

Source: 156[I:366-367];331[II:450-451{S.v. Proto-Iranic *dānu- 'вода, река', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dānu-, cf. Ved. dānu- 'каплющее течение, капающий| капель, роса' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:719-720). Not to be excluded is the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Indo-Iranic *dhan- 'бежать, течь' < PIE *dʰen- 'бежать, течь' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 249, [EWAia](src-172) I:772).}];172[I:719-720{Cf. s.v. Ved. dā́nu-, a Rigvedic word designating rain and by many interpreted as 'träufelend, träufelnde Flüssigkeit', by others as 'Gabe', if the former possibly with YAv. dānu- 'Fluß', Oss. don 'Fluß, Wasser', and further to European river names.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *dānu-, probably to be further connected with Vedic dā́nu- 'dropping flow, dripping; drops, dew'(?); the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Iranic *dan- < Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰan- 'to run, flow' (< PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 144-145) is not to be excluded ([ESIJa](src-331) II:450-451, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:719-720, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:366-367).

Source: 165[7{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ahwõ- 'river', from PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂-. A Germanic-Italic isogloss (cf. Lat. aqua 'water'). "The word is claimed to stem from a non-IE language (Beekes 1998), but it is more likely to be a formal variant of Hitt. ḫapa- c. 'river', Skt. áp-, OAv. ap- f. 'water' < *h₂ep-, Lat. amnis f. 'stream, river' < *h₂ep-ni- and OIr. ab, aub f. W afon f. 'river' < *h₂epHon- (with *-pH- > *b) as in Skt. píbati 'to drink' < PIE *pi-ph₃-é-). Perhaps the cluster *-pH- developed into *-kʷ- in Germanic and Latin."}];269[{Pace [Kroonen 2013](src-165), the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by [Beekes 1998](src-709)), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. [EWA 1](src-383) 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)).}];383[99-103{S.v. OHG aha 'Wasser(lauf), Fluß, Strom'. Outside of Germanic only the Italic cognates (Lat. aqua) are unobjectionable. < *akʷā < *h₂ekʷeh₂. Less certain are further connections to river names in Baltic and Slavic, and the word for 'river' in Celtic (W afon, Gaulish -apa) and Anatolian (Hitt. ḫapa-).}];444[46{Cf. s.v. 570 Lat. aqua 'Wasser' (> Friaul. age, etc.).}];54[48{Cf. s.v. Lat. aqua 'water', from Proto-Italic *akwā- 'water' (cf. Goth. aƕa, OHG aha < PGmc. *aχʷō 'water'). "According to [Beekes 1998](src-709), other suggested cognates, such as OIc. ægir 'sea, ocean' are very uncertain. Even if cognate, Germano-Italic *akwā- may well be a loanword from a non-IE language."}]
Justification: Germanic and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂- 'water' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):7, [EWA 1](src-383):99-103, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):48, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):46). Pace [Kroonen 2013](src-165), the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by [Beekes 1998](src-709)), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. [EWA 1](src-383) 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)).

Source: 54[228{S.v. fluō 'to flow, run (of water)'.  Lat. flūmen 'river' is a derived noun as though from PIE *bʰleu̯H-mn̥-.}];141[90{Cf. s.v. 1. *bʰleu̯H- 'überströmen' (IEW 158-159).}];579[{Neapolitan sciummo < Lat. flūme(n), cf. It. fiume.}];444[292{S.v. 3388 Lat. flūmen 'Fluß'.}]
Justification: Latin flūmen and Romance lexemes from PIE *bʰleu̯H-mn̥- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):228, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):292, [LIV²](src-141) 90).

Source: 165[147-148{S.v. Proto-Germanic *flōdu- 'flood', a tu-stem created to the root of *flōan- 'to flow', as though from PIE *ploh₃-tu-.}];179[118-119{S.v. Goth. F62. flodus 'ποταμός', 'stream'. Goth. flodus is with PIE *-tu- from PIE *plō/ē- in Hom. δακρυπλώειν 'shed tears, πλώω 'navigate', πλωτός 'swimming'.}];141[485{Cf. s.v. *pleh₃- 'schwimmen, fließen' [IEW 836]. Traditionally interpreted as a lengthened-grade form of *pleu̯-, now apparently a parallel root.}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *pleh₃- 'swim, flow' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):147-148; as a verbal root cf. [LIV²](src-141) 485); in earlier literature reconstructed as a lengthened grade of *pleu̯- 'swim, float' (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):118-119).

Source: 345[115{S.v. TochB oko 'fruit| result, consequence'. Clearly related to Tocharian A oko, but the shape of the form suggests that one was borrowed from one language to the other rather than being true cognates. There are two possible etymologies: (1) to PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'grow, increase' (cf. TochB auk- 'grow, increase'), however this assumes that the TochB lexeme would be a borrowing from TochA, but it is difficult to see the B word being borrowed from A rather than A from B, which is far more often the case| more attractive is (2) that the word may be related to PIE *h₂ógeh₂- 'fruit, berry' (cf. Lith. úoga 'berry, cherry', Latv. uôga 'berry| pustule, pockmark', OCS (j)agoda 'berry', Ru. jágoda 'berry', and more distantly with Goth. akran 'fruit', ON akarn 'fruit of a wild plant', OE œcern 'acorn', NHG Ecker 'id.', Old Irish áirne 'plum', aeron 'fruit, berry'| The underlying verb survives in Arm. ačem 'grow'.}];389[{Cf. s.v. *h₂eu̯g-, to which Arm. ačem 'grow' is now connected following [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):43.}];165[18-19{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *akrana- 'tree fruit, acorn' (cf. OIr. áirne 'sloe, fruit of the blackthorn, kernel', MW eirin 'sloes, berries, plums' < PCl. *agrn-io-| W aeron 'fruits, berries' < PCl. *agr-on-ā| Lith. úoga 'berry' < *h₂og-eh₂-| OCS agoda 'fruit', Ru. jágoda 'berry', SCr. jȁgoda 'wild strawberry, berry'| ToB oko 'fruit, effect'). "A clear Europeanism." To be derived with a suffix -ana- (also found in ONor. aldin, Far. aldan, OSw. aldon 'tree-fruit, mast' < *aldana-) on root *agr- which is "derivationally obscure", but is similar to the base reconstructed for account to for Celtic forms (e.g. OIr. áirne 'sloe', Wel. aeron 'fruits, berries' < Proto-Celtic *agrn-io-). "[T]he appurtenance of ToB oko (see Adams 1999:109-110) is uncertain, as it may have been derived from the PIE root *h₂eug- 'to grow'."}];352[1151-1152{Cf. s.v. OLith. úoga 'Beere'. No secure comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic| perhaps root cognate with TochB oko 'Frucht', possibly conceivable is a further connection to the Celtic family of OIr. áirne 'Frucht des Schlehdorns', MW aeron 'Früchte, Beeren', eirin 'Pflaumen, Zwetschgen| Früchte des Schlehdorns| Beeren', which must have started with Proto-Celtic *agr-. Corresponding in Germanic is Goth. akran 'Frucht', akranalaus 'unfruchtbar', and with metathesis ON akarn, OE æcern 'Eichel'. The hypothesis that the Celtic and Germanic words go back to PIE *h₂eg̑ró- or *h₂ég̑ro- 'Feld' (cf. Ved. ájra-, Gk. ἀγρός, Lat. ager, Goth. akrs) is questionable on semantic grounds.}];81[27{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *agoda 'berry' (ESSJa I 57-59). From PIE ?*h₂og-eh₂- (cf. Goth. akran 'fruit (of trees, corn)'). Adams connects TochB oko 'fruit, effect' also to the Balto-Slavic forms (with the Germanic forms being more remote), although the vocalism of the Tocharian form is not without its problems.}]
Justification: [Adams 2013](src-345):115 prefers to connect the Tocharian B forms with Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn'. The proposed etymology is certainly attractive but is not fully certain, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):27, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):18-19, [ALEW](src-352) 1151-1152.

Source: 66[649{S.v. AGk. καρπός 'fruit, fruits of the earth, corn, yields'. The Greek forms are usually compared with the root *kerp- (Lat. carpō 'pluck (off)', Lith. kerpù 'cut with scissors', Hitt. karp(ii̯e)- 'take away, lift, pluck', assuming a zero-grade *kr̥p-o-.}];80[452-453{Cf. s.v. Hitt. karp(ii̯e/a)- 'to take (away), take up, lift, pluck'.}];270[200{S.v. AGk. καρπός 'fruit', to be connected with Lat. carpō 'cueillir', probably a zero-grade| with an e-grade cf. Lith. kerpù 'couper avec des ciseaux'.}];141[559{Cf. s.v. *(s)kerp- 'abschneiden, abrupfen' (IEW 944-5), cf. n1: often of the harvest, cf. Gk. καρπός 'Frucht', Germ. *harbista- 'Ernte' > 'Herbst'.}]
Justification: Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 559; cf. also [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):200, [Beekes 2010](src-66):649, and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):452-453 (s.v. Hitt. karp(ii̯e/a)- 'to take (away), take up, lift, pluck').

Source: 141[482-483{*pleh₁- 'fill up, get full'.}];259[446{PS *plodŭ 'fruit, fetus' is derived from PIE *pel- 'pour, fill'.}]

316[520{S.v. pōmus, -ī 'arbre à fruits'| pōmum, -ī 'fruit'. No known etymology.}];54[188-189, 479{S.v. pōmus / pōmum 'fruit-tree, fruit'. Possibly from *po-emo- 'taken off, picked', from *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po-, cf. [Neri 2007](src-635):71 s.v. emō. If so, the root would be the same as Lat. emō, -ere 'to take' < PIE *h₁em- (cf. OIr. ar-foim 'to receive, allow', OPr. īmt, Lith. im̃ti, Latv. jem̃t 'to take', OCS jęti 'to take| begin').}];635[71{Proposes an etymology from *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po- in Proto-Italic as *po-e/omo- 'taken off, picked'.}]
Comment: If the proposed etymology of [Neri 2007](src-635) holds, then cf. 'take' in [cognate set 5158](cog-5158).
Justification: Etymology outside of Latin traditionally considered uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):520). A recent proposal by [Neri 2007](src-635):71 plausibly considers *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po- in Proto-Italic as *po-e/omo- 'taken off, picked' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):188-189; 479).

Source: 141[461{S.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).}];66[1184{S.v. πήγνυμι 'to fix, stick, join, congeal or coagulate', from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'coagulate, become fixed' (cf. Lat. pangō, -ere 'to fix firmly', Skt. pajrá- 'solid, firm' with loss of laryngeal by Lubotsky's Law').}];270[894-895{S.v. AGk. πήγνυμι 'planter, fixer| rendre solide, geler, coaguler', -ν-υμι verb to the same root as Lat. pangō 'consolider, fixer'.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'become firm' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):894-895, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1184, [LIV²](src-141) 461).

Source: 345[9-10{S.v. TochB atiyo* 'grass'. Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain.  See s.v. for various proposals.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain; cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):9-10 for various proposals.

Source: 360[837-838, 848{Cf. s.v. Lith. smagùs 'schwer (vom Gewicht), fest, stark, kräftig (von Schlagen), laut (von einem Pfiff)'. Usually connected with Greek σμογερόν· σκληρόν, ἐπίβουλον, μοχθηρόν (Hesych.), μογερός 'mühselig', μόγος 'Mühe Anstrengung'| much closer however lies a connection with Lith. smõgti 'peitschen' etc. This etymology is confirmed through idioms like 'árklį smagiaĩ smõgti, sukir̃sti, dróžti' 'dem Pferde einen kräftigen Schlag versetzen'. Lith. smõgti 'peitschen, schlagen', etc. is to be connected with Pol. smagać 'peitschen, geißeln, züchtigen', Ru. smagatь, Ukr. smahnuty, smahaty, etc.}];531[579{Cf. s.v. Lith. smõgti 'ciąć, uderzyć, zadać cios, rzucić (coś ciążkiego)'| adj. smagùs 'rzutki, rączy (koń), gwałtowny, silny (deszcz, wiatr), mocny (o piwie)'. The morpheme smog- < PBSl. smāg- may be related to Ru. smagatь, Ukr. smaháty, Pol. smagać.}];534[II:235-236{S.v. Latv. smags, cf. Lith. smagùs.}]
Comment: cf. Lith. smagùs 'strong, heavy'
Justification: The Baltic adjective is to be connected with the root of Lithuanian smõgti 'to hit, strike' whose root is generally further connected to Polish smagać 'to whip', etc. < Proto-Balto-Slavic *smāg-, further etymology uncertain ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):579, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):837-838, 848; cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:235-236).

Source: 443[5:465-470{S.v. Lat. lūridus 'Leichenblass' > Fr. lourd.}];54[347, 354{S.v. lūridus 'ghastly yellow, colour of bruises'. Etymology ultimately uncertain. Perhaps cognate with MW lleu 'light' < *le/ous-, alternatively with Lat. līvidus 'of a dull or greyish-blue colour| envious' < PIE *(s)l(e/o)iH-uo- (cf. OIr. lí, W. lliw 'colour', Russ. sliva 'plum', OHG slēha, OEng. slāh 'sloe').}];316[371{Cf. s.v. Lat. lūror, -ōris 'teint blême ou jaunâtre', with derived adj. lūridus. No certain connections.}];444[420{S.v. 5176 Lat. lūridus 'gelb, leichenblaß'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin lūridus 'pale yellow, lurid' (([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 5:465-470, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):420), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):371, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):354).

Source: 141[327–328{Cf. s.v. 1. *k̑erh₂- 'brechen, zerbrechen (intr.)' (IEW 578). LIV² etymologises the Tocharian forms to a nasal-present stem *k̑r̥-né/n-h₂- (cf. Ved. śr̥ṇāsi 'zerbrichst')| for the proposed cognacy of [Adams 2013](src-345):173-174, cf. s.v. *kreu̯s- 'stoßen' (IEW 622) [without Tocharian lexemes connected]}];345[173-174{S.v. TochB kärn- 'hit', 'play, strike [a musical instrument]'. Earlier proposals suggested a connection with Greek κεραίζω 'devastate, ravage' and Sanskrit śr̥nā́ti 'harms, destroys', which [van Windekens 1976](src-76) specifically assumed to be based on a past participle *k̑r̥hₓ-no- (cf. Skt. śīrná-), but PIE *-rn- should have given Tocharian -rr-. Because we have -r- and -n- in contact suggests that this is a secondary contact. TochAB kärn- must reflect PToch *krŭn- or *kärCn- with an original meaning something like 'strike'. Thus, Adams assumes Proto-Tocharian *krŭn- to reflect PIE *kru-nehₐ- from PIE *kreu̯-s- 'strike', whence also Greek κρούω 'strike (together), strike a stringed instrument with a plectrum, knock [at the door]' < *kreusye/o-.}];341[575-577{S.v. TochAB kärn- 'schlagen', 'hit, beat'. "The root is traditionally taken for the result of a reanalysis of a nasal present from PIE *√k̑erh₂ 'brechen (itr)' (²LIV, 327f.)| see Hackstein, 1995, 34 with ref., but this etymology could not account for the preservation of -rn-| I therefore follow Adams DoT, 164 in setting up pre-PT *kru-n- (from "PIE *kreu-s- 'strike'")."}]
Justification: From Proto-Tocharian *kər(ə)n-, proposed by [Adams 2013](src-345):173-174 to be based on an unextended root variant *kreu̯- to PIE *kreu̯s- 'hit, beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 371, [IEW](src-49) 622), and accepted by [Malzahn 2010](src-341):575-577.

Source: 442[300{Cf. s.v. 5421 *ṭakk- (2) 'cut, break' and 5424 Skt. ṭakkarā f. 'blow on the head' Rājat.}];399[I:455{Cf. s.v. ṭakkarā 'Kopfnuß, Schlag auf den Kopf', 'a blow on the head'. Not certainly explained.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5424, presumably of non-Aryan origin.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a stem *ṭakk- 'cut, break', cf. Sanskrit ṭakkarā 'a blow on the head' first attested in Rājataraṃgiṇī (12th c. AD). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):300 no. 5421, 5424; [KEWA](src-399) I:455).

Source: 141[72{S.v. *bʰei̯H- 'schlagen' (IEW 117-8).}];81[41{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *biti- 'beat', from PIE *biH- (cf. OIr. benaid 'strike').}];50[65-66{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bi-na- 'strike, hit', from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'strike' (cf. OLat. perfines 'you should strike', OCS biti 'strike').}];296[B:32-34{S.v. OIr. 1 ben- 'frapper, couper, blesser, tuer, enlever', to the IE root *bʰei-ə- 'frapper' ([IEW](src-49) 117).}];304[226-232{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bi-na- 'schlagen', from PIE *bʰei̯H- (LIV² 72).}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 7, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:32-34, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):226-232, [Matasović 2009](src-50):65-66, [LIV²](src-141) 72).

Source: 534[II:188-189{S.v. Latv. sist "Vārda cilme nav pilnigi noskaidrota." Etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:188-189 for further discussion.

Source: 165[452{S.v. Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'beat, strike, slay', a Germanic-Celtic isogloss (cf. MIr. slacc 'sword').}];141[564{S.v. ?*slak- 'schlagen' (IEW 959).  Cf. n1 "Hierher wohl mir. slacc 'Schwert', neuir. slacairt 'das Schlagen' usw."}];179[314{S.v. Goth. S98. *slahan 'δέρειν, τύπτειν', 'strike', from PIE *slak- 'strike' (only Gmc. & Celt., cf. MIr. slacc 'sword', slachta 'struck').}];556[425-427{S.v. Gmc. *slah-a- 'schlagen', no certain comparisons. In question comes MIr. slacc 'Schwert', slahta 'geschlagen' (both sparsely attested).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', possibly from a root ?*slak- 'to hit, beat' only otherwise attested Celtic, cf. Middle Irish slacc 'sword' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):425-427, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):452, [LIV²](src-141) 564).

Source: 141[153{S.v. ?*dʰreb- 'stoßen, treffen' (IEW 272-3). Root only Germanic and (?)Slavic.}];165[98, 100-102, 105{S.v. Proto-Germanic *drepan- 'to hit', assuming a back-formation to the iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip, droop| to drop', a zero-grade variant of *drapp/bōn- 'to hit'. Both iteratives can be derived from *draban- 'to hew' < *dʰróbʰ-e- (cf. OCS drobiti (drobljǫ) 'to crumble, chop, break').}];397[927-928{S.v. NHG treffen (MHG treffen, OHG treffan, OS -drepan), from Germ. *drep-a- 'schlagen' also in ON drepa, OE drepan. No clear comparanda outside of Germanic.}];556[166-167{S.v. PGmc. *drep-a- 'schlagen', no suitable comparisons outside of Germanic.}];468[83{S.v. ON drepa 'schlagen, stossen| töten' (within Germanic cf. Ic., Far., Nw. drepa, Sw. dräpa, Da. dræbe, OE, OS drepan, MLG drepen, OHG treffan| outside Germanic cf. drobiti 'entzweireissen' [IEW 272-273]).}]
Justification: IE root etymology unclear. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. [Seebold 1970](src-556) and [Kluge 2011](src-397) see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. [Kroonen 2013](src-165) derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.

Source: 141[80{S.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-135).}];54[213{S.v. Lat. feriō, -īre 'to strike', from PIE *bʰerH- 'to pierce, strike'.}];165[53{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *berjan- 'to fight', from PIE *bʰorH-ie-.}]
Justification: Italic and Romance lexemes continuing PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):213; for Germanic lexemes in this set not in the target meaning, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):53).

Source: 316[68{S.v. Lat. battuō, -is, -ere 'battre'. A word that is rare in texts, but already attested in Plautus. Similar to Celtic words in the sense but in different form. Origin unknown. As in Lat. fut(t)uō 'I fuck' the consonant gemination is expressive.}];444[85{S.v. 996 Lat. battuere 'schlagen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin battuere 'hit, beat' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):85), of obscure origin ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):68).

Source: 141[660{Cf. s.v. u̯edʰh₁- 'stoßen' (IEW 1115).}];389[{Cf. s.v. ?*u̯edʰh₁- → 2.*u̯edʰ-?. Reconstruction of final laryngeal insecure.}];431[{S.v. kâmvʹiri vʹia- 'beat, hit', from OIA vedh-a-ti ‘pierces’  T. 12109.}];442[701{S.v. 12109 *vēdhati 'pierces'}];172[II:496-497{Cf. s.v. Ved. √vadh- 'schlagen, töten' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. vadar- 'Mordwaffe'), from PIE *u̯edʰ-H- (cf. Gk. ὠθέω 'stoße', OIr. fodb 'Waffenbeute', Lith. vadegà 'eine Art Zimmeraxt', etc.).}]
Justification: From Proto-Indic *vedhati 'pierces' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):701, [Strand 1998](src-431)), further to Indo-European *u̯edʰ(h₁)- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:496-497, [LIV²](src-141) 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 54[662{S.v. Lat. vēnor, -āri 'to hunt', from a Proto-Italic denominal verb *u̯ēnā-i̯e/o- 'to hunt', based on an adjective *u̯ēn-o/ā- 'searching, hunting' or on a noun *u̯ēnā- 'hunt', cf. PIE *(H)uenh₁- 'desire'.}];141[682-683{S.v. *u̯enH- 'liebgewinnen' (IEW 1146-7).}];85[{S.v. Roman. vâna, from Lat. *venare (= venari).}]
Justification: Italic and Romance lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯enH- 'to grow fond of' ([LIV²](src-141) 682-683, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):662, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):766 no. 9186).

Source: 80[234-235{S.v. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *iég-o- (cf. OIr. aig, gen. ega 'ice', MCorn. yeyn 'cold', ONor. jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier', Wakhi yaz 'glacier').}];406[257-259{S.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice' (n.) from IE *yeg- (IEW 503), cf. MiIr. aig 'ice' (< *yegis), MiCorn. yeyn 'cold', ON jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier'.}];50[435{S.v. Proto-Celtic *yegi- 'ice', from PIE *yeg- 'ice' (cf. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', ONor. jaki, Wakhi yaz 'glacier').}];49[503{Cf. s.v. *i̯eg- 'Eis'.}];442[601{Cf. s.v. 10396 *yaja- 'cold' [IE. *yeg̑- 'ice' IEW 503?] (cf. Kt. yūċ 'cold', Pr. (y)ǖzu. Wg. yū̆z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz [→Wkh. yaz]). Turner implies that Wakhi yaz is a loanword from Kaláṣa or Khowār.}];269[{Indo-Iranian-Nuristani cognates from *yaja- 'cold' (Turner 1962-1966:601) probably imply a reconstruction *i̯eg̑- with a palatovelar.}]
Justification: Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ([IEW](src-49) 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601 no. 10396; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):234-235, [HED A+E/I](src-406):257-259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):435).

Source: 369[256{Cf. s.v. Alb. márdh/ë, -a 'Frost', an old word for 'Frost', which can be identical with OCS mrazъ 'Frost', cf. IEW 740 *merg̑- 'morschen', alternatively from *morg̑⁽ʰ⁾-.}];458[20: 10-14| 21: 163-165{PS *morzŭ 'frost' and *mĭrznǫti 'freeze' are related to Albanian marth 'frost' etc. and derived from PIE *merg̑-.}];105[245{Cf. s.v. Alb. mardhë 'chill, frost, ice', etymologically identical with Slav. *morzъ 'frost' (cf. Meyer 1891:260), both continuing *merg̑ʰ- 'to rot, to soak'. Derivative verbs: mardh 'to chill, to freeze', mërdhij 'id.'.}];81[326{S.v. Proto-Slavic *morzъ 'frost' (ESSJa XX 10-14), to be connected with Alb. mardhë 'frost'. "Possibly an example of Winter's Law, in which case we must reconstruct *mórg̑-o-."}]
Justification: From Proto-Slavic *morzъ 'frost' and to be connected with Albanian mardhë 'frost, ice', from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):326, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:10-14, 21:163-165, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):256, [Orel 1998](src-105):245).

Source: 442[297{S.v. 5392 *jhilla- (1) 'swamp, lake'| cf. also 14118 *hilla- (2) 'mud, swamp'.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Middle Indic *jhilla- 'swamp, lake', cf. Prakrit jhillaï 'bathes', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):297 no. 5392).

Source: 442[320{S.v. 5635 Skt. taḍāga- 'pool' ŚāṅkhGr̥., taḍā́ka- n. lex., taṭāka- m. R., ˚kinī- f. MBh. 2. taḍaga- , talaka- m. lex.}];399[I:470{S.v. Skt. taḍāgam n. 'pond, tank, (artificial) lake'. Etymology not securely explained.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit taḍāga- 'pond, tank, (artificial) lake', further etymology obscure ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):320 no. 5635, [KEWA](src-399) I:470).

Source: 172[II:606-607{Cf. s.v. Ved. jráyas- 'Strecke, Erstreckung' (YAv. zraiiah-, OPers. drayah- 'Meer', MPers. drayā(b), NPers. drayā(b) 'Meer', Parth. zryh, MPers. zrēh 'Meer'). The Indo-European origins of √jray-, jráyas- are not securely determined.}];321[449{S.v. Wakhi ẓ̌uy 'водоем, пруд, небольшое водохранилище, озерцо', from PIr. *zraya- (cf. Av. zrayah-, OPers. drayah-, etc.).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:606-607, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):449).

Source: 165[423{S.v. Proto-Germanic *saiwi- 'sea'. K. favours the connection with OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', etc. from PGmc. *sīhwan- 'to percolate' from PIE *sei̯kʷ-. [No discussion of the word as a possible pre-IE loanword.]}];179[292{S.v. Goth. S12. *saiws 'λίμνη', 'sea' (only dat.sg. saihwa). 'marshland' in gen.pl. -we, *marisaihws 'sea' only acc.sg., from Proto-Germanic *saiwi- (cf. OI sær, sjōr, OE sǣ, sā-, OFris sē, OS, OHG sēo). No accepted etymology. Three main possibilities: (1) a borrowing from a non-IE pre-Gmc. people, (2) a connection to Lat. saeuus 'raging', or (3) a connection with OE sīgan, OFris sīga, OS, OHG sīgan, 'flow down from', 'sink' and OI sīa, OE sēon, OHG sīgan 'filter, strain', ultimately from PIE *sei̯kʷ-: *soikʷis > PGmc. -gw´- > -w-. In view of the absence of an IE word for 'sea' a borrowing from a non-IE, pre-Gmc. people is more likely.}]
Justification: No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

Source: 165[196-197{S.v. Proto-Germanic *habanō- 'harbor' < *kap-óneh₂- (cf. OIr. cúan 'port, harbor' < *kap-ono-). The standard etymology connects it to ON haf, OE hæf, OFri. hef, MLG haf, MHG hap 'sea, lake' < *haba- < *k̑h₂p-ó- and *hafjan- ~ *habjan- 'to lift' < *k̑h₂p-ie-.}];141[344-345{Cf. s.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-8). Cf. n1 suggesting that the root is probably onomatopoetic, so perhaps also an a-containing root *kap-.}];50[197{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kawno- 'port, haven', from PIE *kHp-no- 'take' (cf. Lat. capiō, OHG havan 'haven'). The formation of this word with the suffix *-no- is an exclusive Germanic-Celtic isogloss.}];296[C:261-262{S.v. OIr. cúan (2) 'port, havre, baie, golfe', from the IE root *kap- (cf. Lat. capiō 'saisir'| with a nasal suffix *kap-no- > ON hǫfn, OE hæfen, E haven 'port', OHG havan 'port', etc.}]
Justification: The Germanic and Celtic forms in this class reflect a derived stem *kh₂p-no- or *kap-no- (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:261-262, [Matasović 2009](src-50):197, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):196-197}), for the reconstruction of the IE root as either *keh₂p- or *kap- cf. [LIV²](src-141) 345n1.

Source: 341[604-605{Several etymologies possible due to the merger of the velars in Proto-Tocharian.   The present stem seems to reflect Pre-Proto-Tocharian *Korei̯e/o-.  See citation for details of alternative etymologies from PIE sources.}];141[176-177{Cf. s.v. 1. *g̑ʰer- 'Gefallen finden, begehren' (IEW 440-1). [Without Tocharian lexemes]}];389[{See now addenda and corrigenda to LIV² arguing *g̑ʰer- → *gʰer- on basis of Khwarezmian (+) ɣry- ‘sich freuen’.}];345[208-209{S.v. TochB ker- 'laugh, make laugh', from *g̑ʰor(–i̯e/o)- (cf. Skt. háryati 'find pleasure in, desire', Greek χαίρω 'rejoice', Umbrian heriest 'volet', Latin horior 'exhort, incite', OHG gerōn 'want, desire, long for', Old English giernan 'yearn', etc.).}];149[135-136{S.v. B kery- 'to laugh', A kary- 'id.'. "[van Windekens 1976](src-76):188 associates this verb – probably correctly – with Lat. horior 'I encourage', Skt. háryati 'likes, desires', Gk. χαίρω 'I rejoice' to IE *g̑ʰer- 'rejoice in, desire'."}]
Justification: Generally derived from Indo-European *gʰer- 'to desire, be delighted' ({ref LIV² 176-177 s.v. *g̑ʰer-, cf. now *gʰer- in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), [Adams 2013](src-345):208-209, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):135-136, [van Windekens 1976](src-76):188), but cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):604-605 with some doubts and possible alternative proposals.

Source: 172[II:716{S.v. Ved. savyá- 'link, linke Hand' (cf. in Ir. YAv. haoiia- 'link', MPers., Parth. hwy 'link, linke, Hand'), from PIE *(H)seu̯i̯o-, cf. ORuss. šujь 'link'.}];81[487-488{S.v. Proto-Slavic *šujь 'left', from PIE *seu-io- (cf. Skt. savyá-| Av. haoya-| MW aswy| MW aseu).}];345[767{S.v. TochB saiwai 'left'. Related in some way to Skt. savyá-, Av. haoya-, OCS šujь 'left', perhaps with metathesis from PIE *sowyo- or with contamination with the predecessors of Gk. σκαι(ϝ)ός, Lat. scaevus, and laevus 'left'.}];259[608{PS *šujĭ is derived from PIE seu̯i̯o- 'left'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *(H)seu̯-i̯o- 'left' ([Adams 2013](src-345):767, [EWAia](src-172) II:716, [Derksen 2008](src-81):487-488).

Source: 382[530{S.v. SMG ζερβός, from Medieval Greek *ζαβρός / *ζαρβός, with metathesis *-rv- > -vr- and raising of /a/ > /e/ / _r. The connection of ζαβός 'invisible' and ζερβός shows the popular perception of the left side as defective.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek *ζαβρός / *ζαρβός (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):530 for further discussion).

Source: 423[III:469-472{S.v. Sp. izquierdo, vocabulary common to Portuguese (esquerdo) Catalan (esquerre), Gascon (querr, esquerr) and Languedoc (esquer, -rra), from the same origin as Basque esker(r) in the same meaning, probably from a pre-Roman Hispano-Pirenaican language. It can not be guaranteed that the current Basque form is not of Romance origin, it is more plausible that the vocabulary extended from the Basque language area in the Visigothic era.}]
Justification: In all likelihood an old loanword into Iberian Romance from the medieval forerunner of modern Basque eskerr, although it cannot be ruled out that the current Basque lexeme has not been influenced by the Romance forms (cf. [DCECH](src-423) III:469-472 for further discussion).

Source: 274[526-540{S.v. *ped- 'treten| fallen, sinken' (LIV² 458, IEW 790ff.).}];66[1227-1228{S.v. ποῦς, ποδός 'foot' < PIE *pod-. The Greek form has generalised o-grade ablaut throughout the nominal paradigm, but the e-grade is attested in some other derivative forms: πέδη 'fetter, shackles', πέζα 'instep', πέζος 'walker, footsoldier', πέδον 'soil, earth, ground', πέδλιον 'sandal', πεδά 'after, with, amidst'. A zero-grade is also attested in ἐπίβδα 'the day after a festival'.}];165[152{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fōt- 'foot', from PIE *pōd- (cf. Hitt. pāt- ~ pat-, Skt. pā́t, pad-, YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Arm. otn, etc.).}];79[534-535{S.v. Arm. *ot- 'foot'. The Armenian singulative ot-n reflects the PIE acc. *pód-m̥, from PIE *ped-/*pod- 'foot'.}];172[II:77-78{S.v. Ved. pád- 'Fuß'. In Ir. cf. YAv. pad-, OPers. pāda-, Khot. päa-, Parth. p'd-, etc. From PIE *ped- (~ *pod-, *pd-) 'Fuß' (cf. Arm. ot-, Gk. πούς, OEng. fēt, Lat. pēs, ped-is, etc.).}];54[462{S.v. Lat. pēs, pedis 'foot', from PIE nom.sg. pōd-s, acc. po/ed-m, loc.sg. ped-i.}];85[{S.v. Rom. picior, from Lat. petiolus 'small foot'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ([NIL](src-274) 526-540), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1227-1228, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):534-535, [EWAia](src-172) II:77-78, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):438 no. 7747, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):462, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), [LIV²](src-141) 458).

Source: 66[1346{S.v. σκέλος 'thigh, leg' < PIE *skel- 'bend, curve' as a thematic noun *skel-o-, formally comparable to Lat. scelus 'malice, badness, crime' < *skel-o- pointing to an original meaning *'curvation, deflection' (cf. o-grade derivative in Gk. σκολιός 'crooked, bent, twisted, unjust'), also with different derivational morphology in OHG scelah, OE sceolh < *skel-ko-, Alb. çalë 'lame' < *skel-no-.}];270[1013{S.v. AGk. σκέλος 'jambe', which corresponds exactly to Lat. scelus 'crime', which originally signified 'ce qui est courbe, de travers', also found in Germanic with a suffix *-ko-, i.e. PGmc. *skélha- > OHG scëlah, OE sceolh 'de travers, tordu, etc.), with a suffix *-no- in Alb. tshalë 'boiteux, estropié.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *skel- 'bend, curve' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1013, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1346).

Source:
81[228-229{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kolěno 'knee' (ESSJa X 132-134). From the Baltic forms from Lith. kẽlis ‘knee’| Latv. celis ‘knee’ (lacking the suffix found in Slavic) we can reconstruct a basic Proto-Balto-Slavic root *kel-/kol-. There are two possible PIE etymologies to this, either (1) *kʷelH- 'turn, rotate' (cf. LIV² 386-388) or (2) *kelH- 'rise, raise, lift' (cf. LIV² 349), of these Derksen prefers the latter on semantic grounds. The proposed connection with Gk. κῶλον 'limb', which cannot reflect an original labiovelar, is not secure enough to serve as the basis of a formal argument.}];353[235{Cf. s.v. Lith. kelė́nas 'knee, knee-bone, knee-cap', with the same etymology as in Derksen (2008:228-229).}];352[474-475{S.v. OLith. kẽlis (II) (2), kelỹs (4) 'Knie| Knoten| Glied| Stamm| Generation' (BSl. Latv. celis 'Knie', etc.), probably not to be separated from OCS kolěno, SCr. kòljeno, Ru. koléno, Cz. komeno 'Knie, Nachkommenschaft, Generation' (cf. ESSJa 10:132-4, EDSL 228f.). The root relationship is probably also to SCr. člȃn 'Gelenk, Glied', Cz. člen 'Mitglied', Pol. człon 'Glied (einer Kette, eines Rohres)'. Possibly further to Gk. κῶλον 'Körperteil, Glied| Bein| Abschnitt (im Text)', but the morphological relationship of these nouns to each other remain unclear.}];458[10: 132-134{PS *kolěno is doubtless related to Lithuanian kelỹs, Latvian celis 'knee', Greek κῶλον 'limb' and κωλήν 'thighbone'.
A strict semantic and formal discrimination between reflexes of PIE *kel- 'rise, lift' and PIE *kʷel- 'turn (round), spin' is problematic even in languages that make a distinction between PIE *k and *kʷ.}];259[243{PS *kolěno is related to Lithuanian kelỹs, Latvian celis 'knee', Greek κῶλον 'joint', Latin collum 'neck', German Hals 'neck' etc. All these words are derived from PIE *kʷel- 'turn, twist'. The etymological meaning is 'movable, bending part of the body'.}]
Justification:
As [Derksen 2008](src-81): 228-229 points out, there are two candidates for the root etymology: PIE *kelH 'rise, rise above' [LIV²](src-141): 349 and *kʷelh₁- 'turn, rotate' [LIV²](src-141): 386-388 (reconstructed as *kʷel(H) by Derksen). From the formal, phonetic point of view there can not be any clue in Slavic. Moreover, the proximity of two proto-meanings (having the concept of movement in common) makes it in my opinion impossible to raise any convincing semantic arguments even in external comparisons with other IE forms. Cf. [ESSJa](src-458): 10: 133. Therefore, any strict decision would be speculative.
Authors of the Slavic etymology rather tend to see *kʷel(H) here, see [Boryś 2005](src-259): 243 or [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594).

Source: 141[555{Cf. s.v. *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'hinken' (IEW 930).}];165[446{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skinkan- ~ *skankan- ~ *skunkan- 'shank, ham', from *skéng-on- (cf. Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skng-ie-, Skt. khañjati 'id.' < *skeng-e-). The Germanic forms reflect an ablauting n-stem from the PIE verbal root *skeng-.}];397[800{S.v. NHG Schenkel (MHG schenkel, MLG schinkel, MDu. sc(h)enkel), a diminutive formation to OE sceanca, MLG schinke 'Schenkel', To this perhaps a with a dissimilated initial position Ved. sákthi- 'Schenkel'. Cf. also 'hinken' in Ved. kháñjati, Gk. σκάζω, and without s-mobile NHG hinken.}];388[334{S.v. PGmc. *skankaz ~ *skankōn- sb.m. (Norw. skank 'shank', OE sceanca, LG schanke, OHG scanc 'rack, cupboard'), derived from *skankaz adj. related to Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skn̥gi̯ō, MIr. scingim 'to spring'.}];697[485{Cf. s.v. PGmc. *skanka- 'schief', from which E scanca 'Unterschenkel, Schienbein' etc.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):446, [Orel 2003](src-388):334, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):485, [Kluge 2011](src-397):800). For the root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).

Source: 50[220{S.v. Proto-Celtic *koxsā 'leg', cf. PIE *kok̑so- 'hollow of joint' (IEW 611), cf. Latin coxa 'hip', OHG hāhsa and Toch. B kakse 'loins'.}];296[C:214{S.v. OIr. cos 'jambe, pied', related to Lat. coxa, cf. OHG hahsa 'creux de l'articulation du genou', Skt. kákṣa- 'aisselle'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *koxsā/o-, further connected to PIE *kok̑so- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:214, [Matasović 2009](src-50):220).

Source: 54[527{S.v. Lat. rota 'wheel', from PIE *Hrot-o/h₂- adj. 'revolving'.}];141[507{Cf. s.v. *ret- 'laufen' (IEW 866).}];423[V:85-88{Cf. s.v. Sp. rueda 'wheel', from Lat. rota 'id.' with related form rodilla 'knee' from a diminutive.}];444[610{S.v. 7389 Lat. rotella 'Rädchen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin rotella 'little wheel' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):610, [DCECH](src-423) V:85-86), a diminutive formation to Latin rota 'wheel' and further to PIE *ret- 'run' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):527, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 507).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic aṣṭhīvát- 'bony; knees', a derivative of Vedic aṣṭhī- 'bone', further continuing PIE *h₂ost- 'bone' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):41 no. 959, [EWAia](src-172) I:150-151).

Source: 442[166{S.v. 3243 *kuṭṭha- 'knee'. [Conn. √kuṭ- 1 'bend' Grierson Tor 162 with (?). But a long range of names for joints and limbs ʻ ankle, heel, foot, leg, knee, wrist' are characterized by the sequence of guttural u/ō retroflex: *kuṭṭha- , *khuṭṭa- 2, *khuḍa- 1, *guṭṭha- 2, *gōḍḍa- , ghuṭa- , ghuṇṭa- 1] Ash. kuṭäˊ ʻ heel ʼ, Wg. kūṭewīˊ NTS ii 263| Dm. khuṭṭa ʻ knee ʼ, Paš. kōṭa, Bshk. kuṭ, kuṭh, Tor. kūṭh, Kand. kūṭhu, Phal. kuṭho, khūṭu, Sh. gil. kŭṭo m. (→ Ḍ. kuṭá prob. pl.), pales. koh. kūṭhu, jij. kuṭh, K. kŏṭhu m.}];399[I:359{Cf. s.v. Skt. guṭa- 'Fußknochel / Ankle', perhaps Dravidian, cf. Kurukh mal-guṭa- 'Rist', etc. (Burrow BSOAS 11, 342, 12, 377).}];759[377]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Probable parallel loans from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):166 no. 3243, [KEWA](src-399) I:359, [Burrow 1948](src-759):377).

Source: 80[353-355{S.v. Hitt. ḫuiš- / ḫuš- 'to live| to survive', from PIE *h₂u̯es- (cf. Gk. ἰαύω (aor. ἄεσα) 'to spend the night', Skt. vásati 'dwell', TochB wäs- 'to rest, reside', Goth. wisan 'to be').}];141[293-294{S.v. 2. *h₂u̯es- '(ver)weilen, die Nacht verbringen' (IEW 72, 1170-1).}]
Justification: Derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):353-355, [LIV²](src-141) 293-294).

Source: 442[617{Cf. s.v. 10666 *rahati 'remains'. 2. *rahyati. [*√rah-] (> M. rahāṇẽ).}];172[II:442{S.v. Ved. √rah- 'verlassen sein, einsam sein' (IIr. cf. MP, NP rāz, Parth.  rʾz 'Geheimnis', a further etymology has not been ascertained.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10666 s.v. *rahati ʻremainsʼ, *rahyati, cf. raha- m. (RV, BhP.), rahas- n. (MBh.) ʻisolation, secrecyʼ - from 'be isolated, left over' via 'remain' and 'stay' to 'live' - compare the meaning of the root of [cognate set 255](cog-255)
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a Vedic verbal stem *rahati, cf. Sanskrit ráhas- 'loneliness, solitude, secrecy' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):617 no. 10666). There are comparanda in Iranic, cf. Middle Persian rāz, Parthian rʾz 'secret, mystery' etc., but connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:442).

Source: 345[714{S.v. TochB TochB ṣale, which with TochA ṣul reflects Proto-Tocharian *ṣwi̯äle from putative PIE *su̯elo-, related to otherwise isolated Germanic *su̯el- 'swell'.}];165[{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', an exclusively Germanic verb.}];556[489-490{Cf. s.v. PGmc. swell-a- 'schwellen'. There is no secure etymology outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: [Adams 2013](src-345):714 connects the root of the Tocharian forms to Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'swell' (cf. [cognate set 315](cog-315)), but this etymological connection remains uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):489-490, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499).

Source: 66[231-232{S.v. βουνός 'hill'. Etymology unknown. The word appears to be originally a Doric dialectal word that spread in the Hellenistic period.}];382[275{S.v. βουνό, from Medieval Greek βουνόν, from Ancient Greek βουνός 'hill, mound'.}];270[190{S.v. AGk. βουνός 'montagne, colline'. Etymology unknown, attributed to the Cyrenaean dialect by Herodotus.}]
Justification: Modern Greek βουνό 'mountain' from Ancient Greek βουνός 'mountain, hill' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):275), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):190, [Beekes 2010](src-66):231-232).

Source: 442[460{S.v. 8141 *pāhāḍa 'rock, hill'.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 459, no. 8141 s.v. *pāhāḍa- 'rock, hill' and no. 8140; compare RV gen. du. pāṣyóḥ 'stone, rock'
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8141 'rock, hill'.

Source: 274[562-564{S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.) with OCS *poľe 'field' listed as a reflex.}];603[5: 302-303{PS *palninā is derived from PIE *pel- / *pol-, and related to Icelandic fell, fjall 'mountain', German Feld 'field', Latin planus 'flat' and Lithuanian plonas 'thin'.}]

165[134{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fel(e)sa- 'mountain', from PIE *pe/ol-es-o- (cf. OIr. ail 'boulder, rock gravestone' < *pl-s-i-| Gk. (Hsch.) πέλλα 'stone' < *pel-s-eh₂-).}];441[142-145{S.v. OHG felis 'Felsen, Teil eines Berges, Felsabhang, Felsbrocken, Stein'. Comparisons outside of Germanic are Ved. pāṣāṇá- 'Stein' < *parṣ- < PIE *pels-, cf. Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.) < *πελσα, OIr. ail- < *pali-k- < PIE pl̥-i-?, etc. These forms establish IE *pel(i)s- : *pol(i)s, *pl̥(i)s-.}]
Justification: It is unclear whether the *-s- reconstructed is part of the root or s-stem morphology that has been transferred into thematic classes. Cf. [EWA 3](src-441):142-145, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):134 for further discussion.

Source: 81[493-494{S.v. Proto-Slavic těsnъ 'narrow', from the same stem as Proto-Slavic *tiskati 'press, squeeze'. This reflects either *teiH- or *teh₁i-, but such proposed roots cannot be easily linked to non-Slavic forms.}];259[77, 84{PS *těsnŭ (< *těsknŭ < *toi̯sk-no) is related *tiskati 'squeeze, press'. It is ultimately derived from PIE *tei̯sk- 'squeeze, press'.}];594[{PS *těsnъ is derived from *tiskati. It was derived from PIE *tḗh₂isk-, ultimately from *tah₂- 'melt, dissolve'. IE cognates are Ossetic tayun 'thaw, melt', Welsh tawdd 'liquefy', Breton tuezi 'melt, smelt', Latin tābēre, tābēscere 'melt, wilt', Greek tḗkō 'melt'. Cf. also PS *tajati 'thaw'.}];141[616{*teh₂- 'melt, thaw' with OCS tajati 'thaw' and Welsh tawdd 'melt' listed as cognates.}]
Justification: Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ([Derksen 2008](src-81):494, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4:183, [Boryś 2005](src-259):77, 84 for various proposals.

Source: 443[12:298{S.v. Lat. strictus 'eng', whence Fr. étroit.}];54[591-592{S.v. Lat. stringō, -ere 'to bind fast, tighten| to strip off'. The simplex verb stringō has two different meanings (1) 'to tie, tighten', and (2) 'to strip off| bare| to scratch, shave, etc.'. It appears that this was a merger of two different PIE verbs, *strig- 'to brush, strip', and *strengʰ- 'to tie'.}];141[603-604{Cf. s.v. 1. *strei̯g- 'streichen' (IEW 1028) and *strengʰ- 'zusammendrehen' (IEW 1036-7).}];269[{As the etymology of Lat. strictus appears to be a blend from two earlier roots, the root ref. form is only given as Lat. strictus.}];444[686{S.v. 8305 Lat. strictus 'eng'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin strictus 'narrow' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):686 no. 8305, cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 12:298). The further PIE root etymology is difficult as Latin strictus, probably represents a blend / contamination of PIE *strig- 'to brush, strip', and *strengʰ- 'to tie' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):591-592, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 603-604).

Source: 353[396{S.v. Lith. siaũras 'narrow, tight', plausibly derivable from PIE *seu̯-ro- to the root *seu̯- 'press, squeeze' (cf. Skt. sunóti, Av. hunaoiti).}];141[537-538{Cf. s.v. ?*seu̯- 'auspressen' (IEW 912). Cf. n1 "verbal nur iir., weitere Verwandte unsicher, vgl. EWAia II 713-4".}];352[908{S.v. OLith. siaũras 'eng, schmal' (BSl. Latv. šàurs 'eng, schmal, beschränkt'. The (East-)Baltic adjective has no secure etymological connections. Older accounts attempt to connect to an IE root *seu̯- 'biegen' considering a connection to *seu̯- 'auspressen', which is only securely attested for Indo-Iranian (cf. LIV² 537f.).}];172[II:713-714{Regarding the proposed connections to Indo-Iranian *sau̯-, cf. s.v. Ved. √sav- 'pressen, (Soma) auspressen, keltern', "Die idg. Vorstufe von iir. *sau̯ '(aus)pressen, keltern' bleibt unsicher." The IE precursor of IIr. *sau̯- 'press out, squeeze' remains uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymological connections outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *sau̯- 'to press, squeeze' but this etymological proposal is no longer widely accepted ([ALEW](src-352) 908, [Derksen 2015](src-353):396, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:713-714, [LIV²](src-141) 537-538).

Source: 165[456{S.v. Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small', probably an o-grade adjective related to Nw. smula 'to grind' < *smulēn-. Further connections unclear.}];697[517-518{S.v. Gmc. *smala- 'klein'. The adjective has no precise correspondence outside of Germanic. Cf. entry for various uncertain proposals.}];269[{According to Heidermanns (1993:517) the Proto-Germanic adjective meant 'small', while the meaning 'narrow, thin' is a West Germanic development. If so, is the meaning 'narrow' here in Danish and Swedish a semantic calque from West Germanic?}]
Justification: No clear correspondences outside of Germanic, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):517-518, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456.

Source: 165[383{S.v. Proto-Germanic *narwa- 'narrow'. Possibly (but not certainly) related to Latv. nãrs 'clamp'| if so, then possibly from PIE *neh₂r-ú-. No further etymology.}];269[{Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. There are some proposed possible cognates in Baltic, but these comparisons depend on the internal semantic reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *narwa-, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):421, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):383. The proposed cognacy to the Baltic lexemes is rejected by [ALEW](src-352) s.v. OLith. *nérti (II). In the Iranic literature, the Germanic forms are sometimes connected to Indo-Iranian *nāraka- < PIE *ner- following [IEW](src-49) 976, however this view is not followed in the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt')| cf. further discussion in [cognate set 3247](cog-3247).}];697[421{S.v. Gmc. *narwa- '(eingeschürt)'. If the original meaning is correctly means 'constricted', then we may compare some Baltic lexemes: Lith. nérti 'einfädeln, einrenken, schlingen', Latv. nẽrt 'die Spitze des Bastschuhs zusammenziehen', Lith. nãras 'Schlinge', etc.}];352[697-698{Cf. s.v. OLith. *nérti (II) '(Faden, Schnur) durch eine Öffnung ziehen, einfädeln', where the proposed comparison with OE nearu, OS naru, 'eng' is strongly rejected ("unbedenklich").}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. There are some proposed possible cognates in Baltic, but these comparisons depend on the internal semantic reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *narwa-, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):421, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):383. The proposed cognacy to the Baltic lexemes is rejected by [ALEW](src-352) s.v. OLith. *nérti (II). In the Iranic literature, the Germanic forms are sometimes connected to Indo-Iranian *nāraka- < PIE *ner- following [IEW](src-49) 976, however this view is not followed in the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'); cf. further discussion in [cognate set 3247](cog-3247).

Source: 141[427{Cf. s.v. 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).}];165[349{S.v. Proto-Germanic *maiwa- 'slim, narrow', from PIE *moiH-uo- (cf. TochB maiwe 'young', derived from the PIE root *meiH- 'diminish' (cf. PGmc. minniz 'less').}];468[399{Cf. s.v. mær (2) adj. 'schmal, schlank' (also mjár, mjór) < Proto-North-Germanic *maiwaR. This exclusively North Germanic word can be connected to the IE root *mi 'klein sein', cf. Lith. maĩlius 'kleinigkeit', OCS mẽlukŭ 'klein', Gk. μείων 'geringer'.}];697[397-398{S.v. PGmc. *maiwa- 'schmal, schlank', a wa-adjective only attested in North Germanic < *moiu̯o- (cf. TochB maiwe 'klein, jung' on the basis of PIE *meiu̯- in PGmc. *minwizan-.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *maiwa- 'slim, narrow', as though from PIE *moi̯H-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'to diminish' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):399, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):397-398, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):349, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 427).

Source: 165[547{S.v. Proto-Germanic *þrinhan- 'to press' from PIE *trénkʷ-e- (cf. Lith. treñkti 'to bump, hit' < *trenk-ie-). According to Kroonen ON þryngva < *þringwan- points to a root *trenkʷ- with a labiovelar. In West Germanic the original verb *þrinhan- was replaced by *þringan- (cf. OHG dringan, NHG dringen).}];141[649{Cf. s.v. *trenk- 'drängen' (IEW 1093-4).}];179[365{Cf. s.v. Goth. Ϸ53. *ϸreihan 'θλίβειν', 'press, throng, crush', from PIE *trenk- 'push, press on', cf. Av. θracta- 'hemmed in (in the line of battle)', Lat. truncus 'maimed, mutilated', Lith. treñkti 'push roughly', etc.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *þrinhan-; further IE root reconstruction in this set follows [LIV²](src-141) 649, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):365 to *trenk- 'to push', but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):547 who argues for a root reconstruction *trenkʷ- on the basis of ON þryngva.

Comment: Loan from Arabic qarīb

Source: 66[369-370{S.v. ἐγγύς 'near'. The first syllable seems to be the preposition/preverb ἐν 'in', the remainder is etymologically unclear.  Some scholars see an old word for 'hand' in a fossilised prepositional phrase with the first syllable being the preposition/adverb ἐν, but the etymology is nevertheless obscure.}];270[309{S.v. AGk. ἐγγύς (adv.) 'proche'| it is tempting to see in ἐγγύς the old noun for 'hand' as in ἐγγύη (cf. s.v. γύη, γύαλον, etc. with the preverb ἐν in the sense 'at hand').}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):309, [Beekes 2010](src-66):369-370 for various hypotheses.

Source: 697[619-620{S.v. Gmc. *ϸenht- 'dicht, fest'. The adjective an exact correspondence in OIr. técht 'dick, zähflüssig, gefroren' < *ténk-t- and is root-cognate with Lith. tánkus 'dicht', Av. taxma- (Slv. tančista-) 'dicht, fest, kompakt', as well as Goth. ϸaho 'Ton, Lehm'. The basis is the primary verb *tenk-, attested in Ved. ā-tanákti 'läßt gerinnen', OIr. con·téici 'erstarrt'.}];782[{The  Frisian form may be influenced by Dutch dichtbij| njonken = 'next to' (Germ. neben)}]

54[675{Cf. s.v. Lat. vīcus 'village, block of houses', from which Lat. vīcīnus 'neighbour, neighbourhood'. Lat. vīcus ultimately from Proto-Italic *weik-o- 'settlement', derived from PIE *ueik̑-/uik̑- 'settlement' (cf. Skt. viś- 'settlement, dwelling-place, people', YAv. vīs- 'homestead, community', OPers. viθ- 'royal house, palace, house' < *uik̑- Gk. οἶκος 'house, household' < *uoik̑-o-, etc.).}];141[669-670{Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯k̑- 'eingehen in, eintreten' (IEW [1129] 1131).}];444[777{Cf. s.v. 9312 Lat. vīcīnus 'Nachbar' 2. *vecīnus.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin vīcīnus 'neighbour' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):777), further to Latin vīcus 'village, block of houses' and PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'settlement' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):675).

Source: 345[263{S.v. TochB ktsaitstse 'old (of age)', which with TochA ktsets '± finished, perfect, excellent' reflect Proto-Tocharian *kätsaitstse 'finished'. All proposed etymologies beyond Tocharian are speculative. Cf. entry in Adams for various proposals.}];149[186-187{S.v. B ktsaitse 'aged', A ktsets 'perfect, achieved'.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):186-187, [Adams 2013](src-345):263 for various proposals).

Source: 156[IV:304-305{S.v. Oss. zærond 'старый', from Iranian *zar-ant-, cf. Ved. jar-ant- 'old', Gk. γέρων, γεροντ- 'old'.}];66[268-269{S.v. γέρων, -οντος 'old man'| also as an adjective 'old' < PIE *g̑erh₂- 'be(come) old'. Ancient Greek γέρων is derived from an *-nt-participle *g̑érh₂-ont- 'old' (cf. Skt. járant-, Oss. zærond 'old (man)' whose formation is identical| cf. also Arm cer, -oy 'old man' from an o-stem).}];79[338{S.v. cer, o-stem 'old man' from PIE *g̑erH- (cf. Skt. jar- 'to age, grow old', jarant- 'old', YAv. zar- 'id.', Oss. zærond 'old').}];382[296{S.v. SMG γέρος 'old', from Ancient Greek γέρων 'old man', with the inflection transferred into the ο-stem declension.}];172[I:576{S.v. Ved. járant- 'alt, greis, gebrechlich', from PIE *g̑érh₂-n̥t- (cf. Gk. γέρων, γέροντ- 'alt| Greis').}];141[165-166{Cf. s.v. *g̑erh₂- 'aufreiben, alt machen' (IEW 390-1).}]
Justification: Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):338, [EWAia](src-172) I:576, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:304-305, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 165-166). For non-target Modern Hellenic lexemes attached to this set, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):268-269, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):296.

Source: 441[300f.{OHG firni, Gothic fairneis < *Proto-Germanic *fernija- 'old'| North Germanic forms with o-vocalism < Proto-Germanic *furna-. - Derivational basis Pre-Proto-Germanic *perno- whence also Latv. pę̃rns 'vorjährig'. PIE basis thus *perH₂-/*pr̥H₂-. }];294[653, 633{Cf. s.v. *pr̥-, *pró-, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft. mit Abl. and s.v. *pr̥h₂ó- 'vorne, daneben, vor', *pr̥h₂í 'vor| für', pr̥h₂ Adverb, lokal| oft. mit Abl., Lok. The Germanic forms may either go back to PIE *pr̥h₂-no- which is a nominal derivation based on the locative adverb *pr̥h₂-ó 'vorne, daneben, für', *pr̥h₂í 'vor| für', *pr̥h₂, or directly to PIE *pr̥-no- based on the zero grade *pr̥- of the PIE locative adverb *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne'. This zero grade form *pr̥- in turn is the derivational basis of *pr̥h₂ó, *pr̥h₂í, *pr̥h₂.}];172[II:146-147{S.v. Ved. purás (adv.) 'voran, vorne, nach vorn, davor' whence purāṇá- 'alt, vergangen', based on base *pr̥H-es/-os (cf.
