Gk. πάρος, 'vorher, vorn, früher, vor', πρέσβυς 'Alter, Angehörer des Ältestenrates, Vorsteher, etc., Goth. faur 'vor, langs – hin', faura 'vor, davor, vorne' OEng. fore 'vor', etc.).}];165[161{S.v. Proto-Germanic *furi- 'in front of, for', from PIE *prh₂-i (cf. Gk. παρά. παραί (prep.) 'besides, by, from, next to, alongside', Lat. prae (adv./prep.) 'in front of, before' < *prh₂(-ei).)}];442[469{S.v. 8283 Ved. purāṇá- 'ancient' RV. [purás]}]
Comment: cf. Vedic purāṇá- 'prior, former, old', from purā́ adv. < *pr̥h₂éh₁ (instrumental, cf. purás < *pr̥h₂és etc.)
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from a PIE root *perh₂-, secondary to PIE *pr̥-, *pró-, *prí 'forwards, to the front' ([EWAia](src-172) II:146-147, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):469 no. 8283, [EWA 3](src-441):300-301, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):161, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294):653, 633).

Source: 165[323{S.v. Proto-Germanic *laikan- 'to jump', from PIE *lóig-e- 'to play' (cf. OIr. lingid 'to jump' < *li-n-g-e-| Lith. láigyti 'to run around' < *loig-éie- NPers. ā-līxtan 'to jump' < lig-e-).}];141[405{S.v. *lei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'springen' (IEW 667-8).}];556[321-322{S.v. Gmc. *laik-a- 'spielen'. There are some connections of differing value: cf. OIr. lingid 'springt', Lith. láigau, -yti 'mutwillig sein, wild herumlaufen, herumtollen', Gk. ἐλελίζω (aor. ἐλέλιξαι) 'erschüttere, drehe herum, drehe mich', Ved. réjate 'erschüttert, zittert'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *laikan- 'to jump', further derived from PIE *lei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to jump' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):321-322, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):323, [LIV²](src-141) 405).

Source: 66[1455-1456{S.v. ταῦρος 'bull' from IE *teh₂u-ro- 'bull'. Cf. Lat. taurus 'bull' Osc. ταυρομ (acc.sg.), Umb. turuf, toru (acc.pl.), Lith. tauras 'auroch' OPrus. tauris 'bison' OCS туръ, Russ. тур 'buffalo'. OIr. tarb 'bull' shows metathesis.}];382[1446{S.v. τραυώ, from Medieval Greek τραυῶ from earlier τραυίζω < ταυρίζω (with metathesis). Ultimately derived from Ancient Greek ταῦρος 'bull' in the sense of 'pull (like a bull)'.}];270[1096-1097{Cf. s.v. AGk. ταῦρος 'taureau', corresponding to Lat. taurus, Osc. τουρομ (acc.sg.), Umb. turuf, Lith. taũras 'buffle, aurochs', OPr. tauris 'bison', OCS turŭ, Gaul. taruos (with metathesis).}];352[1081-1082{Cf. s.v. OLith. taũras 'Auerochs, Büffel, Stier' (BSl. Latv. tàurs, taũrs 'Auerochse', OPr. tauris 'wesant (Wisent)' OCS turъ 'Stier'), from PIE *tau̯ro- 'Auerochse, Stier' (cf. Gk. ταῦρος 'Stier', Lat. taurus 'Stier', Gaul. tarvos 'Stier', OIr. tarb 'id.', MW tarw 'id.', Alb. ter 'Stier, Rind, Bulle').}]
Justification: Originally a denominal formation from Ancient Greek ταῦρος 'bull' in the sense of 'pull like a bull' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1446), further to be connected with Latin taurus 'bull', Lithuanian taũras 'auroch', Old Prussian tauris 'bison', OCS turъ 'buffalo', etc. ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1455-1456, cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 1081-1082).

Source: 442[636{S.v. 10954 Skt. lámbate 'hangs down, loiters' MBh. [~ rámbatē. - √lamb] (> K. lamun 'to pull, pull at, tow').}];141[411{Cf. s.v. *lembH- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 656-7)| Präsens *lémbH-e- > Ved. rámbate 'hängt (schlaff) herab'.}];172[II:436-437{Cf. s.v. Ved. √ramb- 'schlaff herabhängen (vom Penis). Later √lamb- 'hängt herab (vorwiegend von Körperteilen gesagt)', perhaps to PIE *(s)lembʰ- (cf. Engl. limp, MHG lampen, slampen).}]
Comment: < Sanskrit lambate (MhB), Vedic rámbate, PIE *lemb(H)-, cf. LIV, p. 411
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):636 no. 10954), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ([EWAia](src-172) II:436-437, [LIV²](src-141) 411).

Source: 83[391-392{S.v. Proto-Iranian *θanǰ- 'to pull, draw', from PIE *tengʰ- 'to draw, pull back' (cf. Toch. tänk- 'to check, stop, restrain', OCS rastęšti 'distrahere', Lith. tingė́ti 'to be slow, lazy'. "The initial *θ- of the root is puzzling: does it point to the presence of a following laryngeal ? The assumption of an older IE *tʰ-, as found in LIV, l.c. is unacceptable. One may also think of influence from the antonym *θra(n)č ‘to press’. [...] A slightly different preform is reconstructed by Kümmel in LIV, l.c.: *tʰengʰ-. His objections against the postulation of *tH- (on account of the Iranian evidence) and his explanation (invoking the loss of an s-mobile variant) are incomprehensible to me. *tengʰ- is clearly an enlarged root of *ten- (*tan)."}];141[657{S.v. *tʰengʰ- 'ziehen' (IEW 1067).}];81[493{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tęgnǫti 'pull', from PIE *t(e)ngʰ- (cf. OIc. ϸyngja 'burden').}];389[{Cf. s.v. *tʰengʰ- → *tengʰ-}]
Justification: Iranic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):391-392, [Derksen 2008](src-81):493). For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Source: 141[154{S.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273).}];165[99{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry', as though from PIE *dʰrógʰ-e-, an o-grade intensive verb. Usually compared to Gk. τρέχω (which is more likely to be related to ϸragjan- 'to run'), but no clear etymology.}];269[{NB: S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸragjan- 'to run' Kroonen (2013:544) considers the root *tregʰ- underlying Greek τρέχω rather than *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- as per LIV² 154 s.v. and Beekes (2010:1506-7) s.v. τρέχω.}];179[93-94{S.v. Goth. *dragan (only 3pl. pres. -and 'ἐπισωρεύειν', 'accumulate, take on'. Etymology uncertain| PIE *dh(e)rāgh- 'pull' Walde-Pokorny 1927-1932 I:862, possibly Lat. trahō 'pull' according to Walde 1906 IF 19:106 by dissimilation from *dhraghō.}]
Justification: The root etymology in this cognate set follows [LIV²](src-141) 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165):99, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):93-94, [Seebold 1970](src-556):160-162.

Source: 352[374{Cf. s.v. OLith. grū́sti 'stampfen, stoßen, härten', (BSl. cf. Latv. grûst 'stoßen, stampfen', SCr. grȕda 'Scholle, Klumpen', Ru. grúda 'Haufen (Steine), Stoß (Holz)', etc.) From PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'zerstoßen, zerstampfen' (cf. ON grjót 'Gestein, Geröll', grautr 'Grütze', OE grēot 'Sand, Kies', etc.).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'to crus, pound' ([ALEW](src-352) 374).

Source: 141[601{Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)teu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1033-4). [Without Albanian cognates listed.]}];105[444{S.v. Alb. shtyj ~ shtŷj 'to push' from Proto-Albanian *stūdnja and etymologically close to Skt. tundate 'to push, to strike', Lat. tundō 'to push', OIr. do-tuit 'to fall', Goth. stautan.}];165[476{S.v. Proto-Germanic *stautan- 'to hit, jab, thrust', from PIE *stóud-e-, an o-grade intensive verb (cf. Skt. tudáti 'to beat', Lat. tundō, -ere 'to strike, beat', Alb. shtyn 'to shove, push').}];364[999{S.v. Alb. shtyn 'wegstoßen, -schieben, anstoßen, antreiben', doubtless to be connected to PIE *(s)teud- 'stoßen, schlagen' (LIV² 601).}];369[379-380{S.v. Alb. shty/j '(weg)-stoßen, (weg)schieben| anstoßen, aufschieben', to be connected with Goth. stautan 'stoßen', Lat. tundō 'stoßen, schlagen', etc. to the root *steu̯d- from an Albanian stem *stūd-ni̯o- with a long root vowel.}]
Justification: Albanian lexemes generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'to strike, beat' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):379-380, [Orel 1998](src-105):444, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):999, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 601 [without Albanian]). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning in this set, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):476.

Source: 66[1676-1677{S.v. ὠθέω 'to push, thrust, drive, push away or forward, drive out, throw back' < PIE iterative *h₂u̯odʰh₁-éi̯e-. The reconstruction of the initial second laryngeal is based on the etymological proposal of Kloekhorst (2008:349-352) connecting Hitt. ḫuett- 'to draw, pull, pluck'.}];141[660{S.v. *u̯edʰh₁- 'stoßen' (IEW 1115). LIV² reconstructs a lengthened grade iterative stem *u̯ṓdʰh₁-i̯e- yielding Greek ὠθέω.}];80[348-352{S.v. ḫuett- 'to draw, pull, pluck', suggests a possible etymology with Greek ὠθέω if from *ἀοθέω < *h₂u̯odʰh₁-éi̯e-.}];269[{Pace Kloekhorst (2008:352) and Beekes (2010:1676-1677), there is no good evidence as far as i am aware among the non-Attic Greek dialects to postulate a possible *ἀοθέω justifying the reconstruction of an initial laryngeal to the root *u̯edʰh₁-.}];382[1317{S.v. σπρώχνω, ultimately from Ancient Greek προ-ωθέω. (Initial *s- either from reanalysis with object pronoun τους, τις, etc., or additional prefix εἰσ- with procope of initial unstressed vowel.). The stem was remodelled as a nasal-present in -νω, after which a sound change -θn- > -xn- applied.}];464[{Greek: Italiot πώννω < MedG αμπώθω, αμπώνω < AG ἀπωθέω.}];389[{Cf. s.v. ?*u̯edʰh₁- → 2.*u̯edʰ-?. Reconstruction of final laryngeal insecure.}]
Justification: The Modern Greek forms are from prefixed προ-ωθέω with various sound laws and analogical changes applied (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1317), ultimately to IE *u̯edʰh₁- 'push' ([LIV²](src-141) 660, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1676-1677). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 442[222{S.v. *gicc ʻ press, crowd ʼ. 2. *gacc -- . 3. *gijj -- . 4. *ghicc -- . 5. *ghacc -- . 6. *ghijj -- . [← Drav., J. Bloch BEFEO xliv 49: Kurukh ginjnā 'to beat into pulp'. Cf. Muṇḍārī geje̯ geje̯ ʻ to reduce to a pulp', gijgij 'close'].}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4153: presumably from a non-Indo-Aryan source

Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):308 no. 5512 *ṭhēḍḍ- 'push' with variants 2. *ṭhēll- . 3. *ṭēll-. Further etymology unclear.

Source: 728[356{S.v. Manx puttey 'pushing, shoving, thrusting, stretching' (= ScG. putadh).}];231[284{S.v. ScG. put 'to thrust, push' from Scots put 'push, thrust', M.Eng. putten 'push', now Eng. put.}]
Justification: Loanword from Middle English putten 'to push' ((ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:284, cf. [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):356).

Source: 141[411-412{Cf. s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen' (IEW 652). Cf. n1: An alternative reconstruction for the root is *labʰ-, but in which case the Vedic forms exhibiting a nasal in the root would have to be a secondary innovation. [Baltic forms not connected in this entry.]}];352[547-548{Cf. s.v. OLith. lãbas 'gut' (BSl. Latv. labs 'gut, vollkommen', OPr. labs 'gut, tüchtig', etc.). The common Baltic word for 'good'. Slavic connections are lacking. The proposed connection to Vedic rabh-, rábhate 'to seize, to grasp' / labh-, lábhate 'to get' and Greek ἀμφιλαφής 'comprehensive', λαφύρα 'haul, spoils' is only possible if the root form is *labʰ- (cf. LIV² 412n1 s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen').}];360[327{S.v. Lith. lãbas 'gut', connected with Ved. rabh- 'angreifen'.}];269[{Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. ALEW s.v. Lith. lãbas, LIV² 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. Hübschmann (1897:451) speculatively considered a connection with Arm. law (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8081](cog-8081)), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by Fraenkel (1962-1965) or ALEW. A lemma for Lith. lãbas is lacking in Derksen (2015). Besides the still uncertain proposal to Ved. rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.}]
Justification: Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. lãbas, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8081](cog-8081)), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352). A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in [Derksen 2015](src-353). Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

Source: 141[480-481{Cf. s.v. 2. *peu̯H- 'faulen, stinken' (IEW 848-849).}];156[I:141{Ossetic forms from Proto-Iranian *ham-pūta-, cf. Khot. haṃbūta-, Pers. puda, Pahl. pūtak ( > Arm. putʻ 'rotten').}];172[II:155{Cf. s.v. pūyº 'faulig werden, stinken', from PIE *pū- (cf. Gk. πύον, πύος 'Eiter', πύθομαι 'faule, verwese', Lat. pūs 'Eiter', ONor. fūinn 'verfault', Lith. pū́ti 'faulen, modern', etc.).}];353[374{Cf. s.v. Lith. pū́ti 'rot, decay, decompose', from PIE *puH- (cf. Skt. pū́yati 'rot, stink', Lat. pūtere 'rot', OIc. feyja 'let rot').}];165[132, 158{S.v. Proto-Germanic fūla- 'filthy, foul', from PIE *puH-lo-, cf. also Proto-Germanic *faujan- 'to let rot' < *pouH-éie-.}];54[501{Cf. s.v. Lat. pūs, pūris 'pus', from PIE *puH-o/es- 'pus', from which Lat. putridus 'rotten' is a derived adjective via putrere 'to be in a state of decay', putrescere 'to decay, disintegrate'.}];697[219{S.v. Gmc. *fūla- 'faul, stinkend'. An old primary adjective in Germanic beside the strong verb *fūa- 'faulen' which is only attested as a participle.}];352[834{Cf. s.v. OLith. pū́ti 'faulen' with various derivatives. From PIE *peu̯H- 'faulen, stinken' (cf. Ved. pū-, pū́yati 'faulig werden, stinken', YAv. pū-, puiieiti 'modern, stinken', Gk. πύθομαι 'faule, verwese', ON fūna 'faulen', feyja 'verfaulen lassen, verrotten lassen', prc.part. fúinn 'verfault').}];444[570{Cf. s.v. 6878 Lat. pūtidus 'stinkend', 6887 Lat. putridus 'faul'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *peu̯H- 'to rot, to stink' ([EWAia](src-172) II:155, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:141, [ALEW](src-352) 834, [Derksen 2015](src-353):374, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):219, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):132, 158, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):501, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):570 no. 6878, 6887, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 480-481).

Source: 442[431{S.v. 7654 Skt. pacyátē 'is cooked, is digested' RV., pácyatē 'becomes ripe' RV. [√pac].}];172[II:64{S.v. Ved. √pac- 'kochen, braten', from PIE *pekʷ- (cf. OCS pekǫ 'backe, brate', Lat. coquō 'koche', Gk. πέσσω, etc.).}];141[468{Cf. s.v. 1. *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (IEW 798).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √pac- 'to cook' and further derived from PIE 1. *pekʷ- 'to become ripe, make cooked' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):431 no. 7654, [EWAia](src-172) II:64, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 468).

Source: 442[169{Cf. s.v. 3282 Skt. *kuthati 'rots', kuthita- 'stinking' Suśr. [kúthyati 'rots' Dhātup. – √kuth] (> N. kuhunu 'to rot')}];399[I:228{Cf. s.v. Skt. kuthita- 'stinkend' / 'stinking', only attested quite late.}];172[II:41{Cf. s.v. nikothaka- 'Name eines Lehrers' – Nicht klar. According to Whitney, Roots 19 the only Vedic attestation of √kuth- 'stinken'.}]
Justification: Based on an Indic root *kuth- 'to stink' attested only quite late in Sanskrit, further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):169 no. 3282, [KEWA](src-399) I:228; see [EWAia](src-172) II:41 for an uncertain Vedic attestation of the root).

Source: 442[594-595{S.v. 10299 Ved. mr̥ṣṭá- (1) 'rubbed, washed, pure' RV. 'prepared, savoury' R., 'sweet, pleasant' MBh., miṣṭa- 1 'dainty, sweet' MBh. [√mr̥j or √mr̥ś] (> M. mīṭh n. 'salt', miṭhā 'sweet').}];172[II:324-325{S.v. Ved. √marj- 'putzen, reinigen, abstreifen, streichen', from PIIr. *(H)marj́-, from the collapse of PIE *h₂merg̑- 'abstreifen, streifend berühren, reinigen' (cf. Gk. ἀμέργω, ὀμόργνυμι) and *h₂melg̑- *'abstreifen' > 'melken' (Gk. ἀμέλγω, etc.).}]
Comment: < Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, polished, pure', later R. 'prepared, savoury' via Mbh. miṣṭa- 'dainty, sweet, pure, good', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 594f., no. 10299
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, washed, pure' > Classical Sanskrit 'prepared, savoury', further root etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594-595 no. 10299, [EWAia](src-172) II:324-325).

Source: 165[65-66{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- (adj.) 'bitter, sharp', a ra-stem created to PGmc. *bītan-, ultimately derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' (cf. Skt. binátti 'to split, break, destroy', Lat. findō, -ere, 'split, cleave' < *bʰi-né-d-ti, *bʰi-n-d-énti, Gk. φείδομαι 'to spare, save, refrain from').}];141[70-71{Cf. s.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).}];697[126-127{S.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'beißend, bitter' > North and West Germanic forms| verbal adjective in *-ra- to the strong verb *beita- 'beißen'.}];274[11-12{S.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (LIV 70f., IEW 116f.).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'biting, bitter', an adjectival derivative to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):126-127, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):65-66, cf. [NIL](src-274) 11-12, [LIV²](src-141) 70-71).

Source: 66[236{S.v. βραχύς 'short', a direct reflex of PIE *mr̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'short' (cf. Av. mərəzu- 'short').}];274[497-499{S.v. *mreg̑ʰ- 'kurz' (IEW 750f.).}];172[II:364-365{Cf. s.v. Ved. múhur (adv.) 'plotzlich, sofort, augenblicklich' (cf. YAv. mərəzu- 'kurz', Khot. mulysga-, BSogd. mwrzk- 'kurz'), from PIE *mr̥g̑ʰú- (cf. Gk. βραχύς 'kurz', etc.).}];320[338{S.v. Khot. mulysga- 'short', cf. Av. mərəzu- 'short', BSogd. mwrzk- 'short', from PIE *mreg̑ʰu- (cf. Ved. múhur, Gk. βραχύς, Lat. breuis, Goth. maurg-, gamaurgjan 'to shorten', OHG murgi 'short', etc.).}];54[75{S.v. Lat. brevis 'short', from PIE *mrg̑ʰ-ú- 'short' (cf. Ved. múhuḥ, múhu 'suddenly', Av. mərəzu-, Oss. morz 'short' < PIr. *m(a)rzu-, Gk. βραχύς 'short', Goth. *maurgus in ga-maurgjan 'shorten', OHG murg(i) 'short'). The Latin form must have re-introduced the full-grade, presumably on analogy to the comparative and superlative (cf. Cowgill 1970:127).}];660[127{Cf. regarding the reintroduction of e-grade vocalism in Lat. brevis.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *mr̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'short' ([NIL](src-274) 497-499, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):236, [EWAia](src-172) II:364-365, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):75).

Source: 360[187{S.v. Lith. į́sas 'kurz' (Latv. îss, Pr. īnsan) connected to Ved. īṣát 'ein wenig, etwas, leichthin'.}];531[225{S.v. Lith. į́sas "krótki, kusy", from Proto-Baltic *insa-. One may assume a connection to Proto-Baltic *eis- / *is- from PIE *h₁eish₂- / *h₁ish₂- 'rush| urge on' (cf. Ved. iṣṇā́ti 'rushes, sends', īṣát (adv.) 'a bit, lightly').}]
Justification: Cf. also Lith. į́sas 'short'. Baltic lexemes from Proto-Baltic *insa-. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally connected to Ved. iṣṇāti 'drive, propel' from PIE *h₂ei̯sh₂- 'to invigorate; to drive, propel' (cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):225, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):187). [Not in [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron žar-ən 'sing' from PIr. *žar-, PIE *g̑ar-, cf. Persian zār 'a cry'.}];83[470{S.v. Proto-Iranic *zarH-³ 'to bewail the deceased' from PIE *g̑(e)rh₂-, (cf. Gk. γῆρυς 'voice', OIr. -gair 'to call', OE cearu 'sorrow, care').}];141[161{S.v. *g̑ar- 'tönen, rufen' (IEW 352).}];156[IV:288-289{S.v. Oss. zaryn : zard | zarun : zard 'петь', from Iran. *žar-, IE *g̑ar-.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- 'to sound, call' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:288-289, [LIV²](src-141) 161, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):470).

Source: 141[288{S.v. ?*h₂u̯ei̯d- 'singen' (IEW 77). Only Greek.}];66[23{S.v. ἀείδω 'to sing (the praises of)', from PIE ?*h₂u̯ei̯d- 'sing'. The ablaut (cf. nominal forms ἀοιδή, ᾠδή 'song') suggest a root *h₂u̯ei̯d-, but no cognates are known outside of Greek.}]
Justification: The ablaut and morphology of related vocabulary within Greek suggest a root *h₂u̯ei̯d-, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 288, [Beekes 2010](src-66):23).

Source: 179[237{Cf. s.v. Goth. L58. *luftus 'ἀήρ', 'air'. Etymology unclear.}];165[328, 342{S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'roof, air', a *-tu- stem related to *lauba- 'leaf, foliage'. No clear IE etymology.}];397[586{S.v. NHG Luft (MHG luft, OHG luft, OS luft), from Gmc. *luftu- 'Luft', also in Goth. luftus, OE lyft. Origin unclear.}];398[1488-1491{S.v. OHG luft 'Luft, Luftraum, Atmospäre, Äther, Himmel, Lufthauch', from Proto-Germanic *luftu-, with no correspondences in the other IE languages.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):237, [EWA 5](src-398):1488-1491, [Kluge 2011](src-397):586, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):328, 342).

Source: 345[617{S.v. TochB lykaśke 'small, lesser', which with TochA lykäly goes back to an original Proto-Tocharian stem *li̯äk- with different diminutive suffixes in either language.  Van Windekens suggested that PToch *li̯äk- may go back to PIE *legʷʰ- 'light (in weight)' (cf. Lat. leuis 'light'), but the lack of labialisation **lykw- in Tocharian is difficult to explain. More preferable is a connection with Gk. ὀλίγος 'few, small', Alb. lig 'bad, evil| thin' Lith. ligà 'illness', Latv. liga 'severe illness, pestilence', OIr. líach 'suffering, unfortunate'.}]
Justification: According to [Adams 2013](src-345):617, probably to be connected with Ancient Greek ὀλίγος 'few, small', Albanian lig 'bad, evil; thin' etc. as a derivative from PIE *h₃lei̯g̑-.

Source: 54[554{S.v. Lat. sentiō, -īre 'to sense, feel', from PIE *snt-ie/o- or *sént-i-/*snt-éi- 'to notice' (cf. Lith. sintė́ti 'to think', OCS sęštъ 'sensible, wise' < BSl. *s(e)nt- 'think', PGmc. *sandjan- 'to send').}];141[533{S.v. *sent- 'gehen' → 'wahrnehmen'(?) (IEW 908).}];444[645-646{S.v. 7824 Lat. sentīre 'fühlen, wahrnehmen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):645-646), further to PIE *sent- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):554, [LIV²](src-141) 533).

Source: 442[214-215{S.v. 4014 Skt. gandhá- 'smell' RV.}];172[I:461-462{S.v. Ved. gandhá- 'Geruch, Duft', not to be separated from YAv. gaiṇti- 'übler Geruch', duž-gaiṇti- 'übelriechend, stinkend', Parth. gndʾg 'stinkend', MPers., NPers. gand 'Gestank', etc. Further connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell' in light verb constructions (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):214-215 no. 4014), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:461-462).

Source: 141[685-686{S.v. 3. *u̯er- 'beobachten, wahrnehmen' (IEW 1164). TochB warṣṣäṃ, TochA wräṣ 'riecht' (intr.) < ?*u̯r̥-sk̑é-.}];345[647-648{S.v. TochB wärsk- 'smell', which with TochA wärsk- reflects Proto-Tocharian wär-sk- from PIE *u̯er- 'observe, pay attention to' (cf. Gk. ὁράω 'see', Lat. vereor 'honor, fear', Engl. beware, Latv. véru 'show, remark about').}];341[886-888{S.v. AB wär-/wärsk- 'riechen', 'smell', said to be derived from PIE *u̯er- 'beobachten, wahrnehmen' (LIV² 685f.).}]
Justification: Generally derived to IE *u̯er- 'observe, perceive' ([LIV²](src-141) 3. *u̯er- 'to observe, perceive', cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):886-888, [Adams 2013](src-345):647-648).

Source: 81[91{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čùti 'sense, feel, notice' (ESSJa IV 134-136).}];141[561{S.v. *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' (IEW 587-8). OCS čujǫ (čuti) 'fühlen, merken', either from root present *(s)keu̯h₁-/*(s)kuh₁- or a secondarily re-formed from the aorist (OCS ču 'fühlte, merkte').}];458[4:134-136{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čuti.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' ([LIV²](src-141) 561, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):91, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:136-138).

Source: 165[480-481{S.v. *stinkwan- 'to thrust, to clash| to stink', from PIE *sténgʷ-e- (cf. Lat. re-stinguō, -ere 'to push back, suppress' < -sténgʷ-e-| Lith. sténgti (sténgiu) 'to exert oneself' < *stengʷ-ie-).}];556[471-472{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *stenkw-a- 'stoßen'. NB Seebold regards the comparanda in Lat., Lith. not entirely secure.}];141[596-597{S.v. *stengʷ- 'stoßen' [IEW 1033]. Cf. n2: "An. støkkva 'springen, stürzen', ae. stincan 'springen| riechen', ahd. stinkan 'riechen, stinken' mit weiterer Bedeutungsentwicklung, vgl. Seebold [1970:]471-2."}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stinkwan- 'to thrust, to clash; to stink', a derivative of PIE *stengʷ- 'to thrust, push' ([LIV²](src-141) 596-597, [Seebold 1970](src-556):471-472, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):480-481).

Source: 296[B:66{S.v. OIr. bolad 'odeur, parfum'. No certain etymology. The proposed connections with Latv. buls, bula 'temps lourd, nuageux' or Arm. bal 'obscurité' are less satifying ([IEW](src-49) 162, etc.), and less still to that of Skt. buliḥ 'vulve', Lith. bulis 'derrière, anus' (Stokes, IF II 168).}]
Justification: Of obscure etymology; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:66 for various unsatisfying proposals.

Source: 66[600-601{S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'equal' in number, strength, size, status, etc. (dial. Arc., Cret. Boeot. attests ϝίσϝος). Formally, earlier *u̯itˢu̯o- would work, but the proposed connection to a zero-grade *ϝιδσ- from εἶδος 'shape' is hypothetical. Other proposed etymologies are unconvincing.}];382[592{Cf. s.v. SMG ίσιος, from Medieval Greek ἴσιος, with stem modification from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal'.}];270[470{S.v. ἴσος 'égal, en nombre égal, également partagé, égal en droit'. The original structure of the word ϝίσϝος is certain, but the etymology is not established.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):470, [Beekes 2010](src-66):600-601 for various proposals.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. smooth, from Old English smóð, found only once (the usual form being sméðe smeeth adj.), and not clearly represented in any of the cognate languages.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of English ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 80[583-584{S.v. Hitt. mīu-/mīi̯au̯- from a PIE u-stem *mih₁-(é)u- (√mei̯h₁-), cf. Lat. mītis 'soft', Lith. míelas 'tender, lovely', Russ. милуй 'sweet'.}];54[383{S.v. mītis 'sweet and juicy, soft, gentle', from Proto-Italic *mīti-, from PIE *m(e)h₁i-ti- 'soft' (cf. W. mwydion 'soft parts' < *meit- < *meh₁i-ti-, OIr. mín 'soft' < *miH-ni- < *mh₁i-ni-, W. mwyn 'tender, mild', Bret. moan 'thin, fine' < PCl. *meino/ā/i- < *meh₁i-n-| Skt. máyas- 'refreshment, enjoyment', YAv. maiiah- < *meiH-os-, OPr. mijls, Lith. miélas, Latv. mĩļš 'nice, sweet, dear', OCS milъ 'pitiable', Ru. mílyj 'sweet, dear' < *m(e)iH-lo-).}];141[428{Cf. s.v. 2. *mei̯H- 'heranreifen, gedeihen' (IEW 711-2). Cf. fn1: *H = *h₁ or *h₃. To this Ved. máyas-, YAv. maiiah- 'Erquickung, Behagen' could also belong with the semantic shift 'reifen, reif' → 'weich, mild'| and further with different suffixes Lat. mītis 'mild', Lith. míelas 'sanft, lieb', etc.}];296[M-53{S.v. OIr. mín 'doux au toucher, uni'. The root of Ir. mín may be *mei- designating softness (cf. Skt. mayaḥ 'joie, plaisir', Lat. mītis [IEW 712, 728]).}];50[270{Cf. s.v. OIr. *mēto-, *mēti- 'fat, soft' > OIr. méth 'plump, fat', etc., from PIE *mey(H)-t- (IEW 711f.), cf. Lat. mītis 'mild, mellow, juicy'. The same root could account for OIr. mín 'tender, soft' < PCl. mīno- < *miHno-.}];269[{Some aspects of the root reconstruction are disagreed upon (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):383 s.v. Lat. mītis), but generally the cognacy of the Celtic and Italic lexemes are agreed. [Matasović 2009](src-50):278-279 suggests an alternative etymology s.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object' for potentially connected lexemes (W mwyn 'mild, tender, gentle', MoBret. moan 'tender, thin', OCo. muin 'thin' < *mēnV- < *meyHnV-), but is cryptic as to whether OIr. mín also should belong to this alternative etymology (not mentioned under the lemma for *moyni-).}]
Justification: Some aspects of the root reconstruction are disagreed upon (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):383 s.v. Lat. mītis), but generally the cognacy of the Celtic and Italic lexemes are agreed. [Matasović 2009](src-50):278-279 suggests an alternative etymology s.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object' for potentially connected lexemes (W mwyn 'mild, tender, gentle', MoBret. moan 'tender, thin', OCo. muin 'thin' < *mēnV- < *meyHnV-), but is cryptic as to whether OIr. mín also should belong to this alternative etymology (not mentioned under the lemma for *moyni-).

Source: 345[26-27{S.v. TochB arṣāklo '(poisonous) snake'. Unknown etymology. TochA ārṣal is related to the TochB form in some way, but further details are obscure.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Tocharian ([Adams 2013](src-345):26-27).

Source: 442[272{S.v. 4966 *chaṭa 'stick, cane'. 2. *chaṭṭa- 2. 3. *chiṭṭa- .}]
Comment: < *chaṭa- and variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 271f., no. 4966
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):272 no. 4966 s.v. *chaṭa- 'stick, cane'. Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 399[III:84-85{S.v. Skt. laguḍaḥ 'Knüttel, Stock' / 'club'. Not convincingly explained.}];442[629{S.v. 10875 Skt. lakuṭa m. 'club' Car.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit lakuṭa- (~ laguḍa-) 'club', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):629 no. 10875, [KEWA](src-399) III:84-85).

Source: 165[471{S.v. Proto-Germanic *staba- m. 'staff| letter', cf. also Gothic stabos m.pl. 'letters'. Possibly cognate with OIr. sab m. 'shaft, pole' and Lith. stãbas m. 'post'. < *stabʰ-o- "The correspondence of Celtic a with Baltic a points to original *a rather than *o."}];352[967{Lith. stãbas I (4) sm. 'Götzenbild, Götze', Latv. stabs sm. 'Pfosten, Pfahl, Säule, Pfeiler' and Old Prussian stabis E 'Stein'. PIE ?*stobʰ-ó- sm. 'Erstarren'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staba- 'staff; letter'. Further connections not fully uncertain, possibly with Lithuanian stãbas 'post', Old Irish sab 'shaft, pole' < *stabʰ-o- or *stobʰ-o-? (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):471, [ALEW](src-352) 967).

Source: 534[I:631{S.v. Latv. nūja, loanword from Livonian nuja 'id.'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Livonian nuja 'stick' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:631).

Source: 179[393{S.v. Goth. W27 *walus 'ῥάβδος', 'staff'. To PIE *wel- 'turn'.}];165[572{S.v. Proto-Germanic *walu- 'lump| staff' < *u̯olh₁-u- (cf. Lith. ap-valùs 'round' < *u̯olh₁-u-). The word has sometimes been connected to Lat. vallum 'palisade' < *ueh₂l-so-, Gk. ἧλος 'nail' < *uh₂l-so-, but Faroese vølur 'lump, tumor, growth| steering pole' shows that the original meaning was 'something round'.}];141[677{Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) walzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].}]
Justification: Germanic forms as though from PIE *u̯olH-u-, a derivative of PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):393, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):572; for the root reconstruction cf. [LIV²](src-141) 677).

Source: 54[67{S.v. Lat. baculum 'stick, staff'. "A number of languages show words in *bak- meaning some kind of 'staff or 'peg'. Since *b was very rare in PIE, and Celtic shows an unexplained geminate, we are probably dealing with a loanword from an unidentified source." Cf. Ir. bacc 'hook, crooked staff', W. bach 'id.' < PCl. bakko-, Gk. βάκτρον, βακτηρία, βακτήριον 'stick, staff', OE pægel 'wine jug', MDu. pegel 'peg, pin, bolt' < PGmc. *pagila- < *bak-elo-, ME pegge 'peg', poss. also. Lith. bàkstelėti 'to thrust'.}];316[64{S.v. Lat. baculum 'bâton, canne'. Greek βάκτρον, βακτηρία 'bâton' shows a root *bak- of a popular type in Indo-European with *b and *a. Also found with a geminate *-kk- in Ir. bacc 'bâton recourbé'. In Latin the noun has an instrument suffix as in Greek.}];49[93{S.v. *bak- 'Stab als Stütze', auch 'stechen, stoßen, schlagen'?}]
Justification: Italic lexemes, derived as an instrument noun from a root *bak- whose distribution appears to be an isogloss restricted to Western Indo-European languages. Perhaps a European loanword from an unidentified source ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):67, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):64, cf. [IEW](src-49) 93).

Source: 697[113{S.v. Gmc. *(-)baina* 'gerade', Perhaps Gmc. *baina- 'bone, leg' is a late substantivisation.}];397[105-106{Cf. s.v. NHG Bein (MHG bein, OHG bein, OS bēn), from PGmc. *baina- 'Knochen', also in ON bein, OE bān, OFr. bēn. The lexeme is not attested in Gothic. The word is a Germanic replacement for the IE inherited word for 'leg' (attested via Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc.), but its origin is unclear.}];165[48{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg'. No further etymology.}];468[30{Cf. s.v. beinn (2) 'gerade, richtig, günstig'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, possibly identical with Proto-Germanic *baina- in 'bone' ([cognate set 191](cog-191)) and 'leg' ([cognate set 71](cog-71)), cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):113.

Source: 83[341{S.v. Proto-Iranian *sau̯H-² 'to bulge, swell up, increase', from PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- 'to bulge, swell up' (cf. Skt. śav-ⁱ 'to swell, to become strong, to increase, to prosper', Gk. κυέω 'I am pregnant', κῦμα 'wave', Lat. cavus 'hollow', in-ciēns 'pregnant', MW cyw 'young animal', OE hūn 'young one').}];172[II:623-624{S.v. Ved. √sav-ⁱ 'anschwellen, stark werden, zunehmen, gedeihen', from PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- 'anschwellen' (cf. Gk. κυέω 'bin schwanger', κῦμα 'Woge, Welle' Lat. cauus 'hohl', W cyw 'Tierjunges', OE hūn 'Junges', etc.).}];141[339-340{Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯eh₁- 'anschwellen' (IEW 592-4).}];442[728{S.v. 12565 Skt. śūná- 'swollen, grown', 12568 Skt. śūyatē 'is swollen' Car.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):728 no. 12565, 12568, [EWAia](src-172) II:623-624, [Cheung 2007](src-83):341, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 339-340).

Source: 66[1053-1054{S.v. AGk. οἰδέω 'to swell', from PIE *h₂oi̯d-éi̯e- (*h₂ei̯d-), cognate with Arm. aytnum 'to swell' (cf. primary aor. ayteay and noun ayt 'cheek'), and some isloated nouns in Germanic (cf. OHG eiz, NHG dial. Eis 'abscess, ulcer' < PGmc. *aita- < PIE *h₂e/oid-o-).}];141[258-259{S.v. *h₂ei̯d- 'schwellen' (IEW 774).  Greek οἰδέω is from an iterative *h₂oi̯d-éi̯e-, whereas Armenian aytnum is derived from a nu-present *h₂id-néu̯/nu-. [Without Albanian cognates listed.]}];79[61{S.v. ayt-kʻ 'cheek'| aytnum (aor. ayteay) 'to swell', connected with Gk. οἰδέω 'swell', οἶδος 'swelling', OHG eiz 'abscess, boil', OIr. óil 'cheek', etc., as derivatives from the PIE root *h₂ei̯d- 'swell'.}]
Justification: Greek and Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ei̯d- 'to swell' ([LIV²](src-141) 258-259, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1053-1054, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):61). Albanian forms in [cognate set 8292](cog-8292) might be cognate to this set but ultimately uncertain, cf. discussion in that cognate class.

Source: 353[343-344{S.v. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell' (Latv. pàmpt 'swell'), cf. derivatives in Lith. pámpa 'swelling, lump', Latv. pam̃pa 'swelling', cognate with Proto-Slavic *pǫpъ, *pǫpъkъ 'bud, navel'.}];531[345-346{Lithuanian pam̃pti 'swell' has an ideophonic oriɡin, exactly as Latvian paupt 'swell'. [No Slavic cognates listed.]}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):417, [Derksen 2015](src-353):343-344, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):435-436).

Source:
593[215-216{PS *grubŭ, *grǫbŭ is related to Lithuanian grùbti 'become numb, stiffen' and Latvian grumbt 'dimple'. It is reconstructed as PIE *gʰreu̯-bʰ- < *ɡʰer- 'rub strongly, tear'. Cf. als PS *gruda ['clod'].
PS *gruda is related to Lithuanian grū́das 'corn', English grit, German Grütze 'groats' etc. PIE *gʰreu̯-d- 'rub (to powder)'.}];259[181{PS *grubŭ, *grǫbŭ 'raw, rugged, rough, thick, obese' is related to Lithuanian grùbti, grumbù 'roughen, become numb, stiffen' etc. and derived from PIE *ɡʰru-m-bʰ-o < *gʰreu̯-bʰ- which is an extention of PIE *ɡʰrēu̯-, *ɡʰrəu̯- 'rub'. The semantic development was like 'rub' > 'rugged, rough' [attested in Slavic], > 'raw, clumsy' [attested in Slavic] > 'thick, fat' [attested in Slavic].
PS *gruda 'clod' is derived from PIE *ɡʰreu̯d- 'rub, pound, crumb, shatter'.}];594[{PS *grǫbŭ (originally 'gravelly, rugged' < 'uneven, crooked') is related to Anglo-Saxon crumb, Old High German krump, German krumm 'crooked', further with Lithuanian grùbti, grùmbu 'stiffen', Greek γρυμπάνειν 'bend' and Middle High German krimpf 'crooked'. PIE *gerb 'crooked' < *ger- 'wind, turn, twist'.}];458[7: 145-148{PS *grǫbŭ, *grubŭ is related to PS *grǫda, *gruda, *grǫdŭ, *grudŭ. Semantic and formal connections make it possible, to assume a suffix -d- an a nasal infix in the latter. Cf. Latvian grauds 'corn', Lithuanian grudas 'corn', Old Icelandic grjót 'stones', Anglo-Saxon gréot 'sand', German Griess 'grit' and further Latin grandis 'big' (*gʷrə-n-dʰ-) and forms without the nasal infix like German groß 'big' and English great (West Germanic *grauta-).}];81[192-193{PS *grǫbŭ, *grubŭ 'coarse, rude' is derived from PIE *gru(m)bʰ- and related to Lithuanian grubùs 'uneven, rough', Lativian grum̃bulaȋns 'uneven, rough', Old Icelandic kryppa 'hump' and Old High German kropf 'crop, gizzard'.
PS *grǫda, *grǫdŭ, *gruda, grudŭ 'heap, lump' is derived Balto-Slavic *grouʔd- and grúodas 'frozen earth or mud'. "These words are usually considered cognate with Latv. graûds ‘grain’, OIc. grautr 'groats', etc., in which case the root is *gʰroud-. The nasal in Pl. grąd may be secondary. I have adopted the ESSJa's set of lemmata, but it should be noted that the evidence for a nasalized vowel is very limited. One may wonder if the o-stem *grǫdŭ belongs here. The reconstructions with *ǫ are partly based on the suggested connections with *gręda and grǫ̑dь, neither of which is beyond doubt. Forms such as Bulg. gărdá 'breast', which points to a nasal, may not belong here."}];165[192{PG *gruba- 'coarse' (cf. Middle Dutch grof 'large, crude, loud', Dutch grof 'coarse', Middle High German grop 'thick, strong, big') < *gʰrubʰ-o- is related to Lithuanian ɡrubùs 'uneven, rough' < *gʰrubʰ-u- and OCS grǫbŭ 'coarse, rough, rude' < *gʰru-m-bʰ-o-.
PS *greutan 'grind, crush' (cf. Middle High German ver-griezen 'grind into very small pieces' < *gʰréu̯d-e-) is related to Lithianian grū́sti 'thrust, pestle, stamp' < *gʰrud-ie- and Russian gruda 'heap, pile' < *gʰrou-eh₂-.}]
Justification: Its Slavic and further IE cognacy is not entirely certain.

Source: 443[4:672-676{S.v. Lat. ĭnflāre 'aufblasen', whence Fr. enfler.}];54[226-227{S.v. Lat. flō, flāre 'to blow', from PIE *bʰleh₁-/*bl̥h₁- 'to blow'?}];141[87{Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₁- 'heulen' (IEW 121-2| 154-5).}];444[362{S.v. 4406 Lat. inflāre 'aufblasen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin inflāre 'blow into, inflate, swell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):362), further to PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):226-227, [LIV²](src-141) 87).

Source: 66[1643{S.v.  χόνδρος (n.) 'grain, grain of salt, seed', from which χονδρός (adj.) 'granular, coarse'.  Etymology unexplained.  Older etymological connections with OE grindan 'grind', Lith. grę́sti 'shave, scour, scratch' Lat. frendō 'grind, gnash' require an initial labiovelar *gʷʰ- on the basis of Latin.  For the Greek forms to be connected one would require an ad hoc dissimilation of the labial element.}];382[1604-1605{S.v. χοντρός, from Ancient Greek χονδρός 'granular, coarse'.}];270[1268-1269{S.v. AGk. χόνδρος 'gruau'. Various proposals| perhaps to Lat. frendō 'grincer des dents, broyer' and OE grindan 'moudre' on a base *gʰrendʰ- if from earlier *χρονδρος with dissimilation of the first ρ, although the non-aspirated *d in the Greek and Latin forms would be unexplained. Alternatively, according to Szemerényi (Mélanges Chantraine) the word is a loanword from Semitic (cf. Ugaritic ḫndrṭ 'vieux froment'.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek χονδρός 'granular, coarse' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1604-1605). Further etymology unexplained, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1268-1269, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1643 for various hypotheses.

Source: 54[581{S.v. Lat. spissus 'laborious, slow, dense', possibly from PIE *spid-to- comparing Gk. σπίδιος 'extensive, wide', σπιδνόν 'thick, coagulated', possibly Lith. spìsti 'to begin to swarm (of bees), gather', but the Baltic material is much further removed semantically.}];316[643{S.v. Lat. spissus 'épais', an adjective in *-to- which may be explained in connection to a root attested by Greek σπιδνόν· πυκνόν, συνεχές, πεπηγός (Hesych.), ἀσπιδής 'éntendu', and Latv. spiežu, spiêdu, spiêst 'presser'.}];444[674{S.v. 8160 Lat. spissus 'dicht'.}];66[1382{Cf. s.v. Gk. σπίδιος 'extensive, wide', with derivatives. An obsolete group of words only preserved on learned and poetic language| authors were no longer certain about the original meaning. Comparable to Latin spissus 'laborious, slow, dense' < *spid-to- or *spit-to-), Lithuanian spìsti 'to begin to swarm (of bees), to gather' is probably not related as it requires a different dental *spit-.}];352[959{Cf. s.v. spiẽsti 'schwärmen (Bienen)', from an East Baltic root *spei̯t- without any clear connections outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin spissus 'laborious, slow, dense' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):674). Further etymology uncertain; generally compared to the family of lexemes around Greek σπίδιος 'extensive, wide' and Lithuanian 'swarm (of bees)' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):643, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):581). The proposed Baltic connections should be rejected because the root requires an unvoiced dental and is semantically remote (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 959). The proposed Greek connections might still be possible, but the original semantics of the forms are uncertain (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1382).

Source: 341[715-716, 721{S.v. TochB pälsk- 'bedenken, denken', 'consider, think', TochA päl(t)sk- 'denken', 'think'| a derived present in -sk̑e/o- to the same root as pälk- 'shine'. From IE *bʰle⁽g̑⁾- 'glänzen'.}];345[407-408{S.v. TochB pälsk- 'think about, consider'. "Etymology uncertain. It is probable that AB pälsk- reflect PTch *päl(k)sk- (as if) from PIE *bʰl̥g-sk̑e/o-, with zero-grade and an inchoative suffix from PIE *bʰelg- 'burn' > 'shine' > 'look (at)'" with a semantic development 'come to look (at)' > 'consider' > 'think' (for semantic parallels cf. Gk. σκέπομαι 'look, examine, consider' > Modern Greek 'think'| Skt. dhī- 'think' but Avestan dī- 'look at, observe'). Alternatively AB pälsk- could reflect PToch *pälsk- (as though) from PIE *bʰl̥sk̑e/o-, an inchoative of *bʰel- 'speak, yell| bark' which may also be seen in päl- 'praise' and pälw- 'bewail', with a semantic development something like 'come to say' > 'deliberate' > 'think' (cf. OIr. imrádim 'think' from im- 'about' + -rādi- 'speak').}]
Justification: Root etymology uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):407-408 for two possibilities to either *bʰleg- 'shine' or *bʰel- 'speak, yell; bark' of which [Malzahn 2010](src-341):721 prefers the former etymology.

Source: 571[91{S.v. Alb. mendoj 'to think, count', a denominative verb from Alb. mend 'mind', in turn a loan from Lat. mentem (so Meyer 1891:274).}];585[274];105[256{S.v. Alb. mend 'mind', borrowed from Lat. mentem 'id.', whence the denominative verb mendoj 'to think, to count'.}]
Justification: Denominal verbs to Albanian mend 'mind', a borrowing from Latin mentem 'mind' (acc.sg.) ([Meyer 1891](src-585):274, [Huld 1984](src-571):91, [Orel 1998](src-105):256).

Comment: parallel Sanskritisms, cf. vicāra- m. 'pondering' (MBh.), Prakrit viāra- m. 'thought'

Source: 442[261{S.v. 4815 Skt. cintáyati 'thinks' MBh., 'cares for' Mn.}];172[I:547-548{S.v. Ved. √cetⁱ- 'erkennen, auf etwas achthaben', reconstructed as *kʷei̯-t- and not to be separated from √cay-¹ 'wahrnehmen, bemerken, beachten'.}];141[382-383{S.v. *kʷei̯t- 'bemerken, erkennen' (IEW 637), cf. n1: Traditionally reconstructed as a root enlarged form of 1. *kʷei̯- 'wahrnehmen, bemerken'.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from derived from Vedic √cet- 'to recognise' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):261, no. 4815), ultimately from PIE *kʷei̯t- 'to observe, recognise', traditionally analysed as a root-extended form *kʷei̯-t- to a more basic root *kʷei̯- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:547-548, [LIV²](src-141) 382-383).

Source: 141[435-436{S.v. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' (IEW 726-8). For the Old Breton form monim*, cf. s.v. Kausativ *mon-éi̯e- > ?abret. guo-monim 'zusagen' and n16 "Glossiert lat. polliceri."}];172[II:305-306{S.v. Ved. √man-¹ 'denken, meinen, dafürhalten' (IIr. cf. OAv. mainiiaṇtā 'sie bedenken, verstehen', YAv. mainiiete 'denkt', etc.), from PIE *men- (cf. Gk. pf. μέμονα 'habe im Sinn, strebe' Lat. meminī 'erinnere mich', OIr. do-moiniur 'meine, glaube', Goth. man 'meine, glaube', Lith. miñti 'gedenken', etc.).}];50[256{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *man-yo- 'think, remember' (OIr. muinithir, -muinethar 'think'), from PIE *men- 'think' (cf. Skt. mányate, Goth. munan).}];296[M:35, 38-39{S.v. OIr. men- (verbal root) 'penser', from PIE *men- and to be connected with Skt. mányate 'il pense', mána- 'pensée', Gk. μαίνομαι 'je suis agité de transports', μένος 'esprit, cœur', Lat. (pf.) memini 'je me souviens', Goth. munan 'penser'. Brythonic only preserves this root in more distant derivatives like W mynnu 'vouloir'. Cf. s.v. OIr. menn- (cf. MBret. mennat 'vouloir, souhaiter, demander').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to think' ([EWAia](src-172) II:305-306, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 435-436).

Source: 598[1: 552{Russian dumat' 'think' is a loanword from Gothic dōmjan (it can be also derived from duma 'thought', borrowed from Gothic dōms). The comparison to dym 'smoke', Greek θῡμός 'soul, thought, spirit' and Old Indic dhūmás is inconvincing. This lexeme has been also etymologized as a back-formation from do-uměti [(uměti 'be able, can')].}];259[132{PS *duma does not have any certain etymology. The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic dōms 'judgement' shows phonetic, morphological and semantical issues. Also a reconstruction as *dʰou̯(ə)mā < PIE *dʰeu̯(ə)- 'blow' (cf. PS *dǫti 'blow') is doubtful.}];593[149{This word is etymologically obscure. The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic dōms 'judgement' is nowadays losing support. Alternative etymologies (assuming a metathesis *meu̯dʰ- > *dʰeu̯m- or linking it to duch ['spirit'], dmout ['blow']) are inconvincing.}];458[5: 154-156{The hypothesis about a Germanic loanword is doubtful. First of all, Slavic *duma is incompatible and much richer semantically. Consequently, the Germanic hypothesis should be abandoned. PS *duma is related to *dux- / *dyx- / *dŭx- / *dym- and *dŭmǫ, *dǫti ['blow']. After all, it is the only way to explain the meaning of Polish duma 'pride'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 5:154-156, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:552, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):149, [Boryś 2005](src-259):132).

Source: 309[598{S.v. Bret. preder 'soin, souci, considération, pensée', corresponding to Co. preder 'pensée, souci, soin, anxiété' and W pryder 'soin, souci'. The verb is based on Old Breton pritiri 'thought, reflexion, worry'.}];308[50{Verb based on the noun preder 'thought, reflection, consideration' derived from pred etc. mit Suffix -aro/ā-, i.e. Proto-Brittonic *pritaro/ā-.}]

165[459{S.v. Proto-Germanic *smītan- 'to stroke| to strike', from PIE *sméid-e- (cf. Latv. smaidît 'to laugh, make fun of| to flatter' < *smoid-eie-| OCS smědъ 'brown, dirty' < *smoid-o-| less certain: Arm. mic 'dirt' < smid-io-).}];141[569{S.v. ?*smei̯d- 'schmieren' (IEW 966)| cf. n1 perhaps related to CS smědъ 'dunkelbraun' < 'schmutzig, schmierig'.}];556[437-438{S.v. Gmc. *(-)smeit-a- 'schmeißen'. No convincing etymological connections| the closest possibility is Lat. mittō, mittere 'gehen lassen, werfen', but with formal difficulties and not fully corresponding semantically.}]
Justification: Possibly from IE *smei̯d- 'to smear', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):459, [LIV²](src-141) 569. See [Seebold 1970](src-556):437-438 for older unconvincing proposals to Lat. mittere (ruled out as phonologically implausible by [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 141[242-243{S.v. 2. *h₁es- 'werfen, schießen' (not in IEW).}];172[I:144-145{Cf. s.v. √as-² 'werfen, schleudern, schießen', whose judgement was 'der idg. Ursprung von iir. *as- 'werfen' ist nicht geklärt'.}]
Justification: Possibly cognate with Hittite peššii̯e/a- 'throw', but the connection is disputed; cf. [cognate set 8675](cog-8675) for further discussion and references. Otherwise only Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:144-145, [LIV²](src-141) 242-243).

Source: 458[1: 118-120{The etymology of PS *bacati / *bocati is complicated. One of the main issue is that similar forms in particular Slavic dialects could derive spontaneously and independently from interjections like Russian bac. However, the most forms can go back to PS *bodĭcati (cf. Latin fodicō ['stab, prickle']). PIE *bʰodʰ-.}];589[1: 84-85{Serbo-Croat bacati, baciti is of ideophonic origin.}]
Justification: The etymology is obscure, probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Skok 1971-1974](src-589) 1:84-85). No certain etymology outside of Slavic: the etymology proposed in [ESSJa](src-458) 1:118-120 is ingenious but speculative.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. throw (v.) 1, from Old English þráwan (past tense þréow , past participle þráwen) strong verb, to turn, twist| corresponding to Old Low German *thrâjan, Middle Low German dreien, Low German draien, dreien, Middle Dutch draeien, Dutch draaien, Old High German drâen (< *drájan ), Middle High German dræjen, dræn, German drehen  weak verb, to twist, twirl, turn.}];165[546{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸrēan- s.v. 'to turn', from PIE *tréh₁-e- (cf. Gk. τετραίνω 'to pierce, perforate'| Lat. terō 'to rub' < *terh₁-e-| Lith. trìnti 'to rub, file' < *tr-n-h₁-e-). "A strong verb from a root *treh₁-, apparently a variant of the more wide-spread *terh₁-."}];141[647{S.v. ?*treh₁- 'drehen' (IEW 1072), cf. n1 mostly considered as somehow belonging to *terh₁- 'bohren'.}];556[519{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *ϸrǣ-a- 'drehen', belongs probably to the IE root *ter- with a development in meaning 'rub' > 'bore' > 'turn'.}]
Justification: Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ([LIV²](src-141) 632), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):546, [Seebold 1970](src-556):519.

Source: 444[396{S.v. 4879 Lat. lanceāre 'die Lanze werfen'.}];316[339-340{S.v. Lat. lancea, -ae 'lance' (derived verb lanceō, -āre). A foreign word, Spanish according to Varro, Greek according to Festus who compares Gk. λόγχη. The two words might have come from the same language, perhaps Celtic. The weapon was originally foreign to the Romans.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin lanceāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):396), a denominal verb to Latin lancea 'lance'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly a Celtic loanword ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):339-340).

Source: 444[725{S.v. 8755 *tīrāre 'ziehen, schießen', of uncertain origin.}];423[V:505-508{S.v. Sp. tirar, a word common to the Western Romance languages of uncertain origin. Maybe from Germanic teran 'desgarrar'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):725, [DCECH](src-423) V:505-508 for further discussion).

Source: 444[109{S.v. 1228c bōtan (fränk.) 'stoßen'.}]
Comment: < MHG BOZEN 'to strike' (Diez 1864: 86)

Source: 172[II:720-721{S.v. Ved. √sā- (~ √say-) 'binden, festbinden, fesseln' (cf. IIr. OAv. ā-hišāiiā 'hält gefesselt', YAv. hiiąn 'sie binden', from PIE *seh₂-, pres. *sh₂-i̯-éti (Ved. syáti ~ Hitt. iš-ḫi-an-zi 'sie binden')| from the i-present *sh₂-i̯- apparently *sih₂- (s. Ved. sināti) arose.}];80[391-393{S.v. Hitt. išḫai-/išḫi- 'to bind, to wrap| to obligate with, to impose upon' (Anatolian cogates cf. CLuw. ḫišḫii̯a- 'to bind', HLuw. hishi- 'to bind'), generally connected with Skt. sā-, si- 'to bind', Lith. siẽti 'to bind'. "The exact reconstruction of the root is difficult, however: e.g. Oettinger (1979a: 461) reconstructs a root *seh₂-, LIV a root *seh₂(i)- and LIV² a root *sh₂ei- [sic, in fact it's *sh₂ei̯-]. Apparently there is no consensus whether or not the -i- is integral part of the root." Kloekhorst sets up PIE *sh₂-ói-ei, *sh₂-i-énti to account for the Anatolian forms.}];141[544{S.v. *sh₂ei̯- 'fesseln, binden' (IEW 891-2). It is unclear whether the Baltic lexemes are original primary derivations to the root or they are secondary formations, cf. fn5.}];269[{Anatolian and Baltic lexemes whose cognacy is generally agreed, but root reconstruction difficult. Cf. comments of [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):392-393. LIV¹ reconstructs *seh₂(i̯)-, [LIV²](src-141) *sh₂ei̯-. As a compromise between the two versions of LIV and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80), we give *seh₂(i̯)- as the root ref. form for this class. See also [Derksen 2015](src-353):397-398. For Indo-Iranic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:720-721.}];353[397-398{S.v. Lith. siẽti 'bind, link' (Latv. sìet 'bind, tie'), from PIE *sh₂-(o)i- (cf. Hitt. išḫāi-/išḫi- 'bind, wrap, obligate with, impose upon', Skt. sinā́ti 'bind' (aor. sāt)). Root reconstruction difficult, cf. entry for discussion of previous literature, ultimately following the solution proposed by Kloekhorst (2008:392-393).}]
Justification: Anatolian and Baltic lexemes whose cognacy is generally agreed, but root reconstruction difficult. Cf. comments of [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):392-393. LIV¹ reconstructs *seh₂(i̯)-, [LIV²](src-141) *sh₂ei̯-. As a compromise between the two versions of LIV and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80), we give *seh₂(i̯)- as the root ref. form for this class. See also [Derksen 2015](src-353):397-398. For Indo-Iranic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:720-721.

Source: 341[573-574{S.v. TochAB kärk- '(an)binden', 'bind', connected since [Fraenkel 1932](src-734):229 to Lith. ker̃gti 'bind' from either *kergʰ- or *kergʷʰ- (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):87f.).}];345[171-172{S.v. TochB ²kärk- 'bind', which with TochA kärk- reflect PToch. *kärk- from PIE *kergʰ- 'tie, bind', otherwise only seen in Lith. ker̃gti 'tie, bind' *kergʰ- ([Fraenkel 1932](src-734):229-30).}]
Justification: Generally connected since [Fraenkel 1932](src-734):229-230 to Lithuanian ker̃gti 'tie, bind' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):87-88, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):573-574, [Adams 2013](src-345):171-172) from a PIE root *kergʰ- or *kergʷʰ- (not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 442[{S.v. 4353 Skt. grantháyati 'ties' MBh., gránthati Dhātup. [Cf. grathnā́ti to √granth-].}];172[I:504-505{S.v. Ved. √granth-ⁱ (√grath-ⁱ) 'knüpfen, binden, verbinden' (IIr. cf. Khot. grantha- 'Knoten', MPers. grih, NPers. girih 'Knoten', Pašto gaṛəl 'winden, knüpfen, etc.'). Proposed Indo-European origins of the Indo-Iranian lexical family are only conjectural.}]
Comment: cf. Vedic (Br) grathnā́ti, Sanskrit granthayati (MhB), grathati (Dhātup.), Pali gantheti; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 233, no. 4353, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 504f.

Source: 352[868-869{S.v. OLith. rìšti 'binden', probably to be derived from a PIE root *u̯rei̯k̑- 'drehen, einhüllen' and be connected to Ved. vréśī- 'Wasserwirbel(?)', YAv. uruuaēs- 'sich wenden, drehen', uruuaēsa- 'Wirbel im Wasser', Gk. ῥοικός 'gekrümmt', OE wrēon 'hüllen, bedecken', but alternative root etymologies have also been proposed (cf. ALEW for further discussion).}];353[383{S.v. Lith. rìšti 'tie, bind' (Latv. rist 'tie, separate, separated', OPr. perrēist 'connect'), from PIE *ur(e)ik̑- (cf. YAv. uruuisiieiti 'turn', OE wrīon 'hide').}];141[699{S.v. *u̯rei̯k̑- 'drehen| einhüllen' (IEW 1158-9). Lith. rišù, rìsti is considered to possibly derive from a primary pres. verbal stem ?*u̯réi̯k̑-/u̯rik̑-.}]

444[46{S.v. 563 Lat. aptāre 'anfügen'.}];423[I:389-390{S.v. Sp. atar, from Latin aptare 'adaptar, sujetar'.}];54[47{S.v. Lat. apīscor, -scī 'to seize, get, obtain' with derivative aptāre 'to fit on, fix', from PIE *h₁p-i- (pr.) 'to get, grab' (cf. Hitt. epp-/app- 'to take, grab', Skt. āpa, YAv. āpa 'has reached', OAlb. ep 'gives'?).}];141[237-238{S.v. *h₁ep- 'fassen, ergreifen' (IEW 50-1).}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin aptāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):46, [DCECH](src-423) I:389-390), further to PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):47, [LIV²](src-141) 237-238).

Source: 345[787-788{S.v. TochB spärtt- G 'to turn (intr.), stop (intr.), find oneself| conduct oneself, behave| spend [time]', K 'to turn' (tr.). The basic verb has been generalised from spārttā-, which may have been historically an interative-intensive or denominative built on spertte. The root may be related to the family of Skt. spárdhate 'contends for', Khot. spal- 'twitch', Hitt. ispart- 'escape', Skt. spr̥dh- 'contest, struggle', Av. spərəd- 'effort', Goth. spaurds 'race-course', OE spyrd 'race-course, contest', etc.}];341[963-964{S.v. TochB spārtt- 'sich drehen| sich verhalten| sich befinden', 'turn, behave, be', TochA spārtw- 'id.'. According to Adams a denominative with the underlying noun TochB spertte 'function, behavior (?)' and in TochA spartu 'lock, curled hair'. In any case, the formation does appear to be denominal in formation.}]
Justification: Denominal formation, but further details are disputed (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):963-964, [Adams 2013](src-345):787-788 for further discussion).

Source: 83[104-105{S.v. Proto-Iranic *gar-² 'turn, wind', further IE etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Iranian uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):104-105).

Source: 316[286{S.v. Lat. gȳrus 'round circle, circut', a technical loanword from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'round, curved'. Lat. gyrāre 'turn' is a late Latin denominal verb from this loanword.}];444[335{S.v. 3937 gyrāre 'im Kreise herumdrehen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin gȳrāre 'to turn around in a circle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):335), a denominal verb from Latin gȳrus 'circle', a technical term borrowed from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'ring, circle' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):286).

Source: 595[4: 159{PS *teťi 'go, run, flow' is derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'run, flow'.}];81[489{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tekti 'flow, run', from PIE *tekʷ- (cf. Skt. tákti 'rush', OIr. techid 'flee').}];141[620-621{S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *tekti 'to flow, run', and further derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to flow, run' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:159, [Derksen 2008](src-81):489, [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Source: 352[360-361{Cf. s.v. OLith. grę̃žti 'wenden, kehren' (BSl. Latv. grìezt 'kehren, wenden, drehen'), from PIE *greng̑ʰ- 'drehen' (ON í kring, í kringum 'herum, umher', kringja 'einkreisen, umgeben', kringla 'Kringel, Ring, Kreis', MLG kring 'Ring, Kreis', MDu. kringhen 'sich wenden', MHG krangel 'Kreis, Kranz'. No comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic or Germanic.}];165[305-306{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kringan- ~ *krinkan- 'to fall' as though from PIE *gréng̑ʰ-e- (cf. Lith. grę̃žti 'to turn, wring| bore, perforate' < *greng̑ʰ-).}];141[191{S.v. ?*greng̑ʰ- 'drehen' (IEW 386). Only Germanic and Baltic.}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes as through from PIE *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn' ([ALEW](src-352) 360-361, [LIV²](src-141) 191; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):305-306). The reconstructed root is restricted in attestation to Germanic and Baltic.

Source: 141[681-682{S.v. *u̯endʰ- '(um)winden' (IEW 1148).}];165[587{S.v. Proto-Germanic *windan- 'to wind' (Elfd. winda 'to hurl, sling'), from PIE *uéndʰ-e- (cf. Umb. vetu, aha-uendu, pre-uendu 3.sg.imptv. 'must turn' < *uend-e-tōd, Arm. gind 'ring' < *uendʰ-eh₂-), a strong verb to *uendʰ-.}];556[554-556{S.v. Gmc. *wend-a- 'winden', probably belonging to a reconstructed IE root *u̯endʰ- 'flechten, winden' (cf. Umbr. aha-uendu, Ved. vandhura- 'Wagensitz' (of which on good grounds it can be assumed was weaved), TochAB wänt- 'umhüllen', perhaps also OCS vęžati 'binden' with a root final variant or contamination).}]
Justification: Continuing the Germanic strong verb *wendan-, and further to PIE *u̯endʰ- (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):554-556, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):587, [Kluge 2011](src-397):970, [LIV²](src-141) 681-682).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of the Vedic root √chard- 'to overflow', cf. causative stem chardáyati 'cause to overflow, vomit' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):273-274 no. 4998). Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:557)

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2538, Turner 1931: 565

Justification: Light verb construction with Nepali बान्ता / bāntā 'vomit' as its semantic head. Loanword from Sanskrit vānta- 'vomited, ejected from the mouth' with subsequent sound change of initial v- > b- ([Turner 1931](src-69):434).

Source: 141[583-4{Cf. s.v. *spti̯eu̯H- 'spucken, speien' (IEW 999-1000).}];269[{The forms in this class from Proto-Germanic *spīwan- are generally compared with similar verbs denoting 'to spit' found elsewhere among the Indo-European languages ([LIV²](src-141) 583-584, reconstructing *spti̯eu̯H-, cf. non-Jena 175 'spit' in cognate set 305). Reconstructing a common IE root for these forms, however, is extremely difficult, as the forms in various branches likely underwent deformations or reformations among individual daughter languages due to onomatopoeia or phonotactic reasons. Within Germanic these forms are more-or-less regular from *spīwan- / *speiw-a- (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):450-452, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):468).}];165[468{S.v. Proto-Germanic *spīwan 'to spit'. The Germanic forms almost unanimously point to *spīwan-| only štewwu in the Swiss dialect of Visperterminen points to *stīwan-.}];556[450-452{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *speiw-a- 'speien'.}]
Justification: The forms in this class from Proto-Germanic *spīwan- are generally compared with similar verbs denoting 'to spit' found elsewhere among the Indo-European languages ([LIV²](src-141) 583-584, reconstructing *spti̯eu̯H-, cf. non-Jena 175 'spit' in cognate set 305). Reconstructing a common IE root for these forms, however, is extremely difficult, as the forms in various branches likely underwent deformations or reformations among individual daughter languages due to onomatopoeia or phonotactic reasons. Within Germanic these forms are more-or-less regular from *spīwan- / *speiw-a- (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):450-452, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):468).

A negative verbal derivative of Breton lonk- 'swallow' (Old Breton lunc), i.e. to un-swallow ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):472-473), further connected to Old Irish slucc-, Welsh llyncu 'to swallow' from Proto-Celtic *slu-n-k-e/o- and ultimately derived from PIE *sleu̯k- 'to swallow, gulp' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):593-595, [LIV²](src-141) 568, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):347, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:139).

Source: 141[696-697{S.v. *u̯lei̯kʷ- 'befeuchten' (Not in IEW).}];345[600-601{S.v. TochB lik- 'wash', which with TochA lik- reflect Proto-Tocharian *läik-, probably from PIE *u̯lei̯kʷ- 'liquid' (cf. Lat. liquēre 'be clear, liquid', Lat. liquāre 'clarify, filter, clarify', OIr. fliuch 'humid').}];341[845-846{S.v. TochAB lik- '(ab)waschen', 'wash', to be derived from PIE *u̯lei̯kʷ-  'befeuchten' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 696f., [Hackstein 1995](src-731):122f.).}];731[122f.]

141[572-573{S.v. *(s)neh₂- 'baden, schwimmen' (IEW 971-972).}];338[{Ossetic Iron ɜχšən 'wash' from PIr. *snā-, cf. Persian sinā 'swimming', Avestan snā- / snāta- 'wash'.}];83[348-349{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *snaH- 'to wash, swim', from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to wash, swim' (cf. Skt. snā- 'to bathe, to wash', Lat. nāre 'to swim', OIr. snaid, -sná 'swims', TochB näsk- 'to bathe').}];172[II:769-770{Cf. s.v. Ved. √snā- 'baden, sich waschen', from PIE *(s)neh₂- (cf. Lat. nāre, 'schwimmen', OIr. snām 'das Schwimmen', TochB nāsk- 'sich Baden', Hitt. sanh- 'ausspülen', etc.).}];442[796{S.v. 13791 Skt. snāpáyati 'causes to bathe, washes' >  P. nhāuṇā tr. 'to wash', etc.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 572-573, [EWAia](src-172) II:769-770, [Cheung 2007](src-83):348-349). For Punjabi, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):796, no. 13791.

Source: 141[450{S.v. *nei̯gʷ- 'waschen' (IEW 761).}];66[1020-1021{S.v. νίζω 'to wash, bathe' < PIE *nigʷ-i̯e/o- (*nei̯gʷ- 'wash'), cf. OIr. nigim 'to wash' from the same formation. Elsewhere cf. Skt. nenikté with intensive reduplication.}];50[290-291{S.v. Proto-Celtic *nig-yo- 'to wash', from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'wash' (cf. Skt. nij-, Gk. νίζω, νίπτω).}];296[N:16-17{S.v. OIr. nig- 'laver'.}];172[II:54{Cf. s.v. Ved. √nej- 'waschen, reinigen', from PIE *nei̯gʷ-.}];442[410{S.v. 7167 *nigna- 'washed'. [Cf. niktá- √nij]. > Kho. Kho. nigik 'to wash (hands, clothes, &c.)', nigeik 'to wash something for someone else'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ([LIV²](src-141) 450, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1020-1021, [EWAia](src-172) II:54, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):410 no. 7167, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:16-17, [Matasović 2009](src-50):290-291).

Source: 442[190{S.v. 3664 Skt. kṣálati 'flows' Dhātup. [~ kṣárati, *jharati, *jhalati. -- √kṣal]. (> K. chalun 'to wash')}];172[I:428-429{S.v. Ved. √kṣal- 'abwaschen', a l-variant from √kṣar- 'fließen, strömen', probably from PIE *dʰgʷʰer- (old: *gʷʰþer-) to Gk. φθείρω 'vernichte, zerstöre', etc.}];141[213-214{Cf. s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- 'im Wasser dahintreiben, fließen' (IEW 487-8), traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰϸer-| cf. n1 for discussion of the root reconstruction.}];269[{The PIE root reflected in Ved. √kṣar- is traditionally reconstructed as *gʷʰþer- with a 'thorn' cluster. The root ref. form follows the reconstruction of LIV² as *gʷg̑ʰer-. Cf. n1 s.v. *gʷg̑ʰer- in LIV² and Mayrhofer (1986:150-158) for discussion of the difficulties in reconstruction of the initial cluster.}];691[150-158{Cf. for extensive discussion of the 'thorn' cluster in the reconstruction of root initial cluster.}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Sanskrit kṣálati 'flows' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):190 no. 3664), further to PIE *gʷg̑ʰer- 'to drift in water, flow' ({ref {EWAia} I:428-429, [LIV²](src-141) 213-214).

Source: 141[473{S.v. 3. *per- 'schlagen' (IEW 818-819).}];81[427-428{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pьrati (II) 'beat, trample, wash', from PIE *pr̥- (cf. Skt. pŕ̥t- 'battle, strife, fight').}];259[478-479{PS *pĭrati, *perǫ 'hit, beat' is derived from PIE *per- and related to Lithuanian per̃ti 'lash', Latin premō, premere 'push, squeeze' and Old Indic pŕ̥t- 'battle'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE 3. *per- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):427-428, [Boryś 2005](src-259):478-479, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 473).

Source: 141[441{S.v. *mesg- 'eintauschen (intr.), versinken' (IEW 745-6).  Baltic forms (Lith. mazgóju, Latv. mazgāju) are denominal.}];353[308{S.v. Lith. mazgóti 'wash' (Latv. mazgât 'wash'), from PIE *mosg- (cf. Skt. májjati 'sink', Lat. mergere 'plunge').}];352[622-623{S.v. OLith. mazgóti 'waschen, schwemmen' (BSl. Latv. mazgât 'waschen'), from PIE *mesg- 'eintauschen (intr.), versinken' (cf. Ved. majj- 'untersinken, untertauschen', Lat. mergō, -ere 'eintauschen, versenken').}]

172[I:117-118{S.v. Ved. √ard- 'zerstieben, sich schütteln' (derived adj. ārdrá- 'feucht, naß', Pā, adda- 'naß, schlüpfrig'| further connections perhaps with YAv. arəduš- 'Verletzung, Hieb' and outside IIr. ON erta 'aufstacheln, aufreizen, Lith. ardýti 'zerlegen, auftrennen'.}];442[60{S.v. 1340 Ved. ārdrá- 'wet' RV.}]
Justification: Old and Middle Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √ard- 'to scatter, spray'. Further connections unclear, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:60 for various suggestions.

Source: 66[483-484{S.v. εὐρύς 'broad, wide' < *h₁ur(H)-ú- (cf. Skt. urú-, Av. vouru- 'broad').}];156[IV:90-91{S.v. Oss. wæræx | urux 'широкий, просторний', from Proto-Iranian *waru- ~ *uru- + suffix -ka-, cf. NPers. bar, Av. varu, vouru-, Ved. uru-, Gk. εὐρύς, etc.}];172[I:227{S.v. Ved. urú- 'weit, umfängreich, breit, gegräumig' (IIr. cf. YAv. vouru- in compounds, e.g. vouru.dōiθra- 'dessen Augen weithin gehen', Oss. urux, etc.), from PIE *u̯r̥H-ú- (~ *u̯erH- in váras-, *u̯erH-ú- in Gk. εὐρύς 'weit, breit', etc.).}];279[310{S.v. O. uruvú 'breit', from PIt. *urvo-/-ā, which was remodelled as an o-stem from PIE *ə₁ur-u- 'breit' (cf. Ved. urú-, Gk. εὐρύς 'breit').}];54[645{Cf. s.v. urvum / urbum 'curved part of a plough', under which discussion of Osc. uruvú is given. O. uruvú, if meaning 'broad' could belong to PIE *h₁urHú- 'broad'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁urH-ú- 'broad, wide', presupposing a full-grade root *h₁u̯erH- (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):483-484, [EWAia](src-172) I:227, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:90-91, [Untermann 2000](src-279):310, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):645).

Source: 382[1523{S.v. φαρδύς. From Medieval Greek φαρδύς < Ancient (εὐ-)φραδής 'wise| linguistically correct' (with metathesis /fra-/ > /far-/).}];66[1588{Cf. s.v. φράζομαι 'to consider, think (up), perceive, decide, discern, act'. All forms found in Ancient Greek point to an element *φραδ- which has the appearance of a zero-grade form such as *bʰr̥d-, but the root is isolated in Greek with no known cognates from other Indo-European branches.}]
Justification: From Medieval Greek φαρδύς < Ancient (εὐ-)φραδής 'wise; linguistically correct', with metathesis /fra-/ > /far-/ ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1523), further a derivative from the same root as Ancient Greek φράζομαι 'to consider, think (up), perceive', but with no known etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1588).

Comment: loan, via Hindi farāḵẖ from Persian (Turner 1931: 401)

Source: 165[73{S.v. Proto-Germanic *braida- 'broad'.  No clear cognates outside of Germanic.}];697[136-137{S.v. Gmc. *braida- 'breit'. The Germanic words recall in initial position PIE *bʰer- in Lith. ber̃ti 'streuen, ausbreiten' or *sper- (cf. Gk. σπείρω 'streue, säe'), however the character of such a root-enlargement necessary to explain such a connection remains unclear.}];397[150{S.v. NHG breit (MHG breit, OHG breit, OS brēd, from Gmc. *braida-, also in Goth. braiϸs, ON breiðr, OE brād, OFr. brēd, breid. Further etymology unclear.}]

444[401{S.v. 4935 Lat. latus 'breit'.}];54[329-330{S.v. Lat. lātus 'broad, wide'| [Meiser 2002](src-738):112 sets up *stlātus > lātus positing PIE *stlH-to- 'spread' to Gk. στέλλω 'to prepare, dispatch', OCS stьlati 'to spread', but this root is now reconstructed without a final laryngeal (LIV *stel- 'to place'), perhaps instead to Proto-Celtic *-slā- 'to go away' attested in OIr. con·slá?}];738[112{Sets up *stlātus > lātus positing PIE *stl̥H-to- 'spread' to *stelH- 'ausbreiten', comparing OCS stьlati 'to spread'.}]
Justification: Root etymology and connections outside of Italic disputed, cf. [Meiser 2002](src-738):112, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):329-330 for further discussion. For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):401.

Source: 141[87{S.v. *bʰleh₁- 'heulen' (IEW 121-2, 154-5). The Germanic words without -s- are traced back directly to the IE present formation *bʰléh₁-/bʰl̥h₁-, the forms containing -s- to a desiderative IE *bʰléh₁-/bʰl̥h₁-s-.}];165[67-68{S.v. Proto-Germanic *blēan- 'to blow' and Proto-Germanic *blēsan- 'to blow'. K. considers the Germanic forms without -s- to stem from a Western European thematic present *bʰléh₁-e-, the forms with -s- from a sigmatic aorist *bʰlḗh₁-/bʰléh₁-s-. Cf. Lat. flāre < *bʰlh₁-.}]

382[70{S.v. αέρας, from Medieval ἀέρας, ultimately from Ancient ἀήρ, gen. ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds| air atmosphere'.}];66[27{S.v. ἀήρ 'mist, haze, clouds', later 'air, atmosphere', from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er-.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):70, [Beekes 2010](src-66):27).

Source: 156[I:381-383{S.v. Oss. dymgæ | dumgæ 'ветер' (cf. Sogd. δmʾk), derived from Ir. *dam- 'blow' (cf. s.v. dymyn | dumun).}];141[153{Cf. s.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-248).}];83[55-56{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe| to swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Skt. dham-ⁱ 'to blow, play a wind instrument, fan the fire', OCS dъmǫ 'to blow', Lith. dùmti 'to blow (also of wind)'.}];172[I:775-776{Cf. s.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen' OCS dъmǫ, etc.).}];442[385{S.v.  6732 Skt. dhamana- 'blowing with bellows' lex. [√dham].}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):385 no. 6732, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:381-383, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:775-776, [Cheung 2007](src-83):55-56, [LIV²](src-141) 153).

Source: 156[I:242-243{Cf. Av. bāzura 'arm' in snāuuar-bāzura- (= Ossetic Digor nawær-bazur 'having sinewy hands'), Parth. b’zwr 'wing'.}];172[II:223-224{Cf. s.v. Ved. bāhu- 'arm' < PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰú- (Gk. πῆχυς 'arm', ON bōgr 'arm, shoulder' Germ. Bug 'shoulder').}]
Comment: cf. Urdu lexeme 26095; bāl-forms via *barza-/bazra- ? Note the similarity of bāl-forms with the well-attested Hamito-Semitic *bal- root "wing, feather" (Orel/Stolbova 1995: 52) with a short vowel.

Justification:
Indic lexemes from ḍayana-, derived from dī- 'fly 'via blending with uḍḍī- 'fly up.'
The Pashai form is probably a feminine derivative of *ḍayanaka- or a similar form.

Source: 50[420{S.v. Proto-Celtic *widu- 'wood', from PIE *u̯idʰu- 'wood' (IEW 1117) (cf. OE widu, wudu, Lith. vidùs 'interior').}];165[585{S.v. Proto-Germanic *widu- 'tree| firewood', from PIE uidʰ-u- (cf. OIr. fid 'tree| wood| forest', OW guid, MW gwyd 'trees'). A Celto-Germanic isogloss, but possibly also Lith. vidùs 'middle' if to be further analysed as from *h₁ui-dʰh₁-o- with an original meaning 'set apart, abandoned').}];352[1232{Cf. s.v. OLith. vidùs 'Inneres, Mitte' (derived noun viduriaĩ (sm.pl.) 'Inneres, Eingeweide'| BSl. cf. Latv. vidus 'Mitte, Mittelstück, Inneres', OPr. widus 'Naht im Stiefel'), from PIE *u̯idʰh₁ú- 'Inneres' (cf. OIr. fid 'Baum, Holz', MW gwŷdd, MBret. gwez 'Bäume', ON viðr 'Baum, Holz', OE widu, wudu 'Holz| Baum| Wald', OHG witu 'Brennholz, Bauholz').}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes reflecting a u-stem noun *u̯idʰ-ú- with the zero-grade of the root. For the reconstruction given, see [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. vidùs, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):585, [Matasović 2009](src-50):420.

Source: 165[571-572{S.v. Proto-Germanic *walþu- 'field, uncultivated area, wood', from PIE *uólH-tu- (cf. OIr. folt W gwallt 'hair' < *uolH-to-, Lith. váltis 'panicle', OPruss. wolti 'id.', Ukr. volótь 'id.', SCr. vlȃt 'id.' < *uolH-tio-), derived to a PIE root *uelH-.}];397[968{S.v. NHG Wald (MHG walt, OHG wald, OS wald), from Gmc. *walϸu-, also in ON vǫllr 'Feld, Weise, Boden', OE weald 'Wald, waldbedecktes Hochland'. Outside of Germanic cf. OIr. folt 'Haarschopf, Laubwerk', W gwallt 'Haarschopf, belaubte Zweigspitzen', Lith. váltis 'Haferrispe', from IE (Eur.) *wolət-| zero-grade found in Gk. λάσιος 'behaart, dichtbewachsen', also to Lat. vellere 'rupfen', and probably further to the word for 'Wolle'.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *walþu- 'field, uncultivated area, wood', further from a PIE derived stem *uólH-tu- ([Kluge 2011](src-397):968, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):571-572).

Source: 345[629-630{S.v. TochB warto* ~ wartto* 'forest', which along with TochA wärt reflect PToch wärto/wärtonta, which should be connected with OE worϸ 'piece of land, farm' and Skt. vr̥ti- 'enclosure'.}]
54[564{S.v. silva 'forest, wood'. No etymology.}];316[626{S.v. Lat. silua, -ae 'forêt, bois'. No etymology, all comparisons that have been proposed are forced.}]
Justification: No etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):626, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):564).

Source: 172[II:500{S.v. Ved. ván- 'Baum, Holz' (cf. Av. vanā- 'Baum', MPers. wan, Sogd. wn-, Pašto wana 'Baum', etc.). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranian is uncertain.}];442[657{S.v. 11258 Skt. vána- (1) n. (once m. R.) 'single tree' RV., 'forest, timber' RV. 2. vanikā- f. 'grove' MBh.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):657, no. 11258.

Source: 259[609{PS *šuměti 'hiss, swish, make noise' has an ideophonic origin. It  is derived from a root *šu- with a suffix *-m-.}];589[3: 422{Serbo-Croat šuma is most commonly interpreted as a deverbative from šumiti 'hiss, swish, make noise' (these words have neither Baltic nor further IE cognates). The semantic motivation would be the sound of leaves and branches (in the wind). However, most probably it is a loan from a Thraco-Illyrian language, related to Albanian *shem in proshem 'bushes'.}];595[4: 129-130{Šuma 'forest' is related to šum 'noise, murmur'. The latter is derived from PIE *k̑ēu̯-mó-, ulitmately from the root *k̑eu̯- (or *k̑eH₂u̯-). IE cognates are Old Indic śuka- 'parrot', Lithuanian šaũkti 'call', Greek κωκύω 'lament', Old Indic kū́jati 'growl', Gothic hiufan 'lament', Tocharian B śauśäṃ 'call'. Other Slavic reflexes of this root are sova 'owl', kurŭ 'cock', kavka 'jackdaw'.}];141[331{?2.*k̑eu̯k- 'call, shout' with Lithuanian šaukiù, šaũkti 'call, shout', Tocharian B śauśäṃ 'call' and Vedic śuka- 'parrot' as cognates. No Slavic words listed here.}]
Justification: This lexeme is derived from PS *šum- and has an onomatopoeic origin. Therefore, further IE cognates are uncertain.

Source: 179[247{S.v. Goth. M36. maϸa 'σκώλεξ', 'worm', etymology outside of Germanic uncertain.}];165[358{S.v. Proto-Germanic *maϸan- 'maggot, moth' (cf. Ru. motýl' 'maggot'?), cf. [Kroonen 2011](src-656):218-211 for the stem formation.}];388[264{S.v. Proto-Germanic *maϸōn "Of unknown origin".}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):247, [Orel 2003](src-388):264). [Kroonen 2013](src-165):358 suggests a comparison with Ru. motýl' 'maggot'.

Source: 423[III:287-290{S.v. Sp. gusano, of uncertain origin. It is very doubtful that it comes from Latin cossus 'carcoma de la madera, larva de ciertas mariposas, lombriz instinal' as previously supposed.}];444[221{S.v. 2278 Lat. cossus 'Larve'.}]
Justification: Of uncertain etymology, it is doubtful that the lexemes may be derived from Latin cossus 'a kind of larva' as previously supposed ([DCECH](src-423) III:287-290, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):211).

Source: 345[548{S.v. TochB yel 'worm' which with TochA *wal (pl. walyi) reflect Proto-Tocharian *wi̯el- from PIE *u̯ēl(i)-, a derivative of PIE *u̯el- 'turn, twist' (Lat. uoluere 'roll, revolve', Arm. gelum 'turn', Skt. válati 'turns', vr̥ṇóti 'wraps, covers').}];141[675{Cf. s.v. 2. *u̯el- 'drehen, rollen' (IEW 1140-2).}]
Justification: According to [Adams 2013](src-345):548, to be derived from PIE 2.*u̯el- 'spin, roll' ([LIV²](src-141) 675).

Source: 259[515{West Slavic *xrobakŭ is derived from an ideophonic verb *xrobati 'crackle, scrunch, chomp'.}];458[8: 99{PS *xrobakŭ is derived from *xrobati. The root is ideophonic. However, a relationship to PS *skrobati, *skrebti can not be overseen.}]
Justification: The root is ideophonic. Any further etymology (as *(s)kreb-, cf. [ESSJa](src-458)) is speculative.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8393

Source: 49[1073{Cf. s.v. *terp-, *trep- (nur BSl.) : Lett. tārps 'Wurm' ('der Zerbrechende'), assumed to be an extended form of the root *ter- 'reiben, durchbohren' etc.}];534[II:376{S.v. Latv. tārps, following etymology of [IEW](src-49) 1073.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain.
