Traditionally considered a derivative of a root *terp-, an extended form of the root *ter- 'to bore' exclusive to Balto-Slavic ([IEW](src-49) 1078, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:376), but cf. [LIV²](src-141) 632-633 now reconstructing *terh₁- for the assumed base root.

Source: 345[410-411{S.v. TochB pikul 'year', which with TochA pᵤkul/pᵤkäl reflects Proto-Tocharian *päkwäl. All attempts at an Indo-European derivation are obscure.  Katz (1994) has attempted an explanation from *pi-kʷl̥ < *(h₁e)pi- 'at, upon' + *kʷl̥-, the zero-grade of *kʷel- 'turn, revolve'.  Alternatively Van Windekens suggestion assumes that PT *päkwäl is a verbal noun derived from *päk- 'cook, ripen'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):410-411 for various proposals.

Source: 353[307, 314{Cf. s.v. Lith. mãtas 'measure, index' and s.v. Lith. mẽtas 'time period, year'. The etymological identification of the Indo-European root is difficult. "From an Indo-European perspective, the Baltic root *met- seems to occur alongside *meh₁- and *med-, e.g. SCr. mjȅra f. 'measure, weight' (*meh₁-reh₂-), OE mǣð f. (*meh₁-ti-) 'measure' : Go. mitan 'measure' (*med-e-)."}];352[641-643{S.v. OLith. mẽtas 'Zeit, Zeitpunkt| Jahr' (BSl. cf. Latv. mȩts 'Zeitraum, Zeit', OPr. mettan). Root identification uncertain, either to *meh₁- 'measure' or *med- 'measure'.}]
Comment: Baltic goes back to *met-
Justification: IE root identification uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 641-643, [Derksen 2015](src-353):307, 314 for further discussion.

Source: 80[875-877{S.v. Hitt. tēta(n)- 'breast| teat' (cf. CLuw. tītan- 'breast, teat', Lyc. tideime/i- 'son, child') < *dʰeh₁i-to- from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'suckle' (cf. Skt. dháyati 'sucks', Latv. dêju 'to suck', Gk. θήσατο 'sucked').}];141[138-139{Cf. s.v. *dʰeh₁(i̯)- '(Muttermilch) saugen' (IEW 241-2).}]
Justification: Original sense 'female breast' derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):875-877).

Source: 316[507{S.v. Lat. pilus, -ī 'poil, cheveu', no certain connections. There is no common Indo-European word for this concept.}];54[465{S.v. Lat. pilus 'hair' [No etymology given.]}];444[538{S.v. 6508 Lat. pilus 'Haar (am Körper)'}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin pilus 'hair' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):538 no. 6508), further etymological connections uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):507, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):465).

Comment: Perhaps with Slavic *mězga 'sap'?
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:601 making comparisons to roots in Pokorny [IEW](src-49) 697, 968.

Source: 141[205{Cf. s.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4), to which OIr. baïd 'die' is a secondary zero-grade i̯e-present *gʷh₂-i̯é-.}];50[52, 59{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *bā- 'die' (OIr. baïd) and *bāsto- 'death', derivatives of PIE *gʷeh₂- 'take a step, go'.}];304[214-216{S.v. Proto-Insular-Celtic *bā- 'sterben', from PIE *gʷeh₂- (LIV² 205, IEW 463f.).}];296[B:1{Cf. s.v. OIr. 2 ba- 'mourir', corresponding to W bad 'fléau, peste', Ir. bath 'mort', connected by [Pedersen 1913](src-308):458, Stokes KZ 37 p.254 to the root *gʷā- 'aller' (Gk. ἔβην, Skt. agāt 'il est allé' supposing the semantic evolution 'passer' > 'trépasser'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto(-Insular)-Celtic *bā- 'to die' (cf. OIr. baïd 'die'), further derived from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ([LIV²](src-141) 205, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:1, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):214-216, [Matasović 2009](src-50):52, 59).

Source: 141[168{S.v. *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen' (IEW 400).}];341[922-924{S.v. TochB śuw- 'essen, komsumieren', 'eat, consume', to be derived from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen'.  See entry for detailed discussion of stem formation in the Tocharian languages.}];345[691-692{S.v. TochB śu- 'eat, consume, devour' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ([LIV²](src-141) 168, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):922-924, [Adams 2013](src-345):691-692).

Source: 345[153-155{S.v. TochB kartse ~ krent 'good, beautiful'. Connections outside of Tocharian are uncertain, cf. entry for various proposals.}];149[106-107,]
Justification: Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):153-155 for various proposals.

Source: 80[223-225{S.v. Hitt. āššu- / āššau̯- 'good| dear| favourable'. The connection to Gk. ἐύς 'good' and Ved. sú 'good' < *h₁su- is generally accepted, but the details of the inner-Anatolian stem formation is still debated.}]
Justification: Hittite āššu-/āššau̯- 'good' is generally connected to Ancient Greek ἐΰς 'good, brave, noble' and Ved. sú- 'good' < *h₁su-, but the details of the inner-Anatolian stem formation is still debated ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):223-225).

Source: 345[511-512{S.v. TochB motartstse* 'green'. Must be related to TochA motarci which also reflects a colour term, however TochA motarts- and TochB motärtsts- cannot be reconciled to a common Proto-Tocharian form. Some potential comparisons on Germanic and Slavic.}]
Justification: To be related to Tocharian A motarts- (a colour term) but it is not possible to reconcile these two forms to a common Proto-Tocharian stem. Outside Tocharian some Slavic and Germanic comparanda are possible but remain uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):511-512 for further discussion).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan panza from Lat. acc.sg. pănticem (Lat. pantex 'paunch, bowels').}];316[479-480{S.v. Lat. pantex 'panse'. A popular word for belly (used since Plautus) in origin a transferred adjective panticōsus (uenter). [No further etymology given.]}];444[510{S.v. 6207 Lat. pantex, -ice 'Wanst'}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin pantex 'belly, paunch' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):510), no further etymology (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):479-480).
Loan from Sanskrit pr̥thivī́- 'earth'.

Source: 54[263{Cf. s.v. glaciēs 'ice'. "The meaning is the same as gelus, but glaciēs cannot be derived from a root *g̑l- 'to be cold' in any meaningful way."}];316[275{Cf. s.v. Lat. glaciēs 'glace'. Appears to be derived in some way from the same root as gelu 'cold' (adj.), but the stem formation is obscure.}];444[322{S.v. 3771 Lat. glacies 'Eis'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes derived from Latin glācies 'ice' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):322); Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):275, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):263 for further discussion).

Source: 443[13/1:272-283{S.v. Lat. tĕsta > Fr. tête 'head', etc.}];54[617{S.v. Lat. testa 'earthenware vessel, tile, sherd, shell'. Semantically unlikely to go back to *tek̑- 'build' as suggested by earlier literature. More likely to be a loanword, as words for vessels frequently are.}];316[688-689{S.v. Lat. testa 'coquille (= ὄστρακον), carapace (de tortue)', for the semantic development of Fr. tête, cf. similarly Germ. Kopf, as a loanword from Lat. cuppa.}];444[719-720{S.v. 8682 Lat. testa 'Scherbe', 'Hirnschale', Kopf'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin testa '(pot)sherd, shell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):719-720, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/1:272-283). For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Germanic: NHG Kopf 'head' < MHG kopf 'drinking vessel; skull' in [cognate set 3857](cog-3857). Latin testa 'earthenware vessel, potsherd' is may very well be a prehistoric loanword as suggested by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):617, but this hypothesis remains conjectural as there is no known candidate for a source lexeme.

Source: 54[364-365{Cf. s.v. Lat. marceō 'to be withered, droop', possibly from PIE *mrk-eh₁- 'to be soaked, be weak' if cognate with Hitt. markii̯e/a- 'to disapprove of, refuse', Skt. cs. marcáyati 'to damage, hurt', OAv. marəxšaitē 'to destroy', marəka- 'ruin', Oss. marg 'poison', Lith. mir̃kti 'to become weak, soaked', Ukr. morokvá 'quagmire, swamp', MHG meren 'to dip bread into water or wine'.}];444[436{Cf. s.v. 5345 Lat. marcere 'welk werden', with derivative found in It. marcio.}]
Justification: A derivative from Latin marcere 'be withered' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):436), perhaps further to PIE *merk- if related to Vedic √marc- 'damage, hurt' and Hittite markii̯e/a- 'to disapprove of, refuse' (so [de Vaan 2008](src-54):364-365), but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:323-324, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):559).

Comment: Loan from Middle High German

Source: 444[74-75{S.v. 913 Lat. balneāre 'baden'.}];66[195{Cf. s.v. Gk. βαλανεῖον 'warm bath, bathroom', from which Latin bal(i)neum is a loanword. No certain etymology, probably an Aegean loanword in origin.}];316[65{S.v. Lat. balineum, balneum 'bain, bains', an old loanword from Greek τὸ βαλανεῖον.}]
Justification: Romance forms based on the past passive participle of Latin balneāre 'to bathe' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):74-75), a nominal verb from Latin balneum 'bath, place for bathing', an old loanword from Ancient Greek βαλανεῖον 'id.' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):65, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):195).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron: sɜr-ən 'live' from PIr. *čar-. Persian čarīdan 'graze (intr.)', Avestan čar- 'move'.}];83[33–35{S.v. Proto-Iranian *čarH- 'to come and go, wander', from PIE *kʷelh₁-  'to move, wander, settle, pasture' (cf. Skt. car- 'to move, turn, wander| to pasture| to settle and cultivate', Gk. πέλομαι 'I move [intr.], Lat. colō 'I till, cultivate, inhabit', OIr. bua-chail (m.) 'cowherd, bouvier').}];141[386-388{Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).}];172[I:534-535{Cf. s.v. Ved. √car-ⁱ 'sich bewegen, wandeln, gehen, wandern, fahren', from PIE *kʷel(H)- (cf. Gk. πέλομαι 'rege mich, bewege mich', Lat. colō 'behaue, bewohne', etc.).}];156[I:303{S.v. Oss. cæryn : card | cærun : card 'жить', from Iranic *čar- (IE *kʷel-), cf. Av. čar-, Ved. car-, Lat. colō, Gk. πέλω', etc.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čarH- 'to come and go, wander', further to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:303, [Cheung 2007](src-83):33-35, [EWAia](src-172) I:534-535, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

Source: 338[{PIr. *kuti-, a common East Iranian term, cf. Shughni kud, Yaghnobi kud, kut, Sogdian *kūti (ʼkwty).}];156[I:605-606];567[224{Bactrian κοδο < Proto-Iranian *kuta-/kutī- (cf. Sogd. kwt, Shughni kud, kid).}];331[IV:413-415{S.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-. Similar words also exist in Indic languages (cf. kuttā, kuti, Turner 1962-1966 3275).}];269[{Similar to Indic *kutta- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Indic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also [ESIJa](src-331) IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.}];442[168{In Indic cf. 3275 *kutta- (1) 'dog'. [Onom.: cf. Sogd. 'kwt, Shgh. kut 'dog', Sant. kutu kutu 'sound made in calling a puppy']}]
Justification: Similar to Indic *kutta- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Indic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also [ESIJa](src-331) IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

Source: 444[389{S.v. 4789 kuč, kos (Schallwort) 'Hund'.}]
Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):389 for similar Romance lexemes in the same meaning).

Source: 156[I:449{From Iranian *pa(s)nu-ka- (cf. Av. pąsnu, Ved. pāṃsu- 'soil, dust, sand').}];172[II:114-115{S.v. Ved. pāṁsú- 'Staub, Sand, zerbröckelnde Erde'. Further connections outside of Indo-Iranian are problematic, possibly to *pē-n-s- beside *pēs- in OCS pěsъkъ.}];657[499{Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *pa(s)nu-ka-, cf. Av. pąsnu, Ved. pāṃsu- 'soil, dust, sand' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:449), further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ([EIEC](src-657) 499, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:114-115).

Source: 296[D:169{S.v. OIr. dona 'infortuné, malchanceux, malheureux', derived from OIr. don 'malheur, revers, infortune', but further etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Adjective derived from Old Irish don 'misfortune', further etymology obscure ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:169).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron bur 'yellow': cf. Persian būr, Yaghnobi vur, but this seems to be a Wanderwort.}];156[I:271-272{S.v. Oss. būr | bor 'желтый'. Is inseparable, on one hand from Russ. бурый 'brown', on the other from Pers. būr, bōr 'бурый, рыжый, желтый', Pam.yazg. bər, Pam.sh. vṻr, Pam.m. vūr, Yaghn. vur. With them a Eurasiatic substratum word found in different language groups: Germ. *brūn 'brown', *bero 'bear', Turko-Mongolian in Mong. boro, Turk. bora, boro, boz, and others [cf. entry in Abaev for further comparisons]. A probable Wanderwort.}]

338[{PIr. *gadā-, cf. Avestan gaδā-, Old Indic gadā- 'club', MP gaδ.}];156[II:281-282];172[I:460{S.v. Ved. gadā- 'Keule', cf. YAv. gaδā- 'Wurfkeule' MPers. gad 'Keule', etc. Further etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: To be connected with Avestan gaδā-, Old Indic gadā- 'club', but no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:281-282, [EWAia](src-172) I:460).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron sad 'lake': cf. Persian čāh, Avestan čāt- 'well'.}];156[I:285{S.v. Oss. cad | cadæ 'озеро', an Iranian word, cf. words for 'колодец' ('well'), e.g. Pers. čāh-, Av. čāt-, etc.}];331[II:252-253{S.v. PIr. čāt-, čāθ- 'яма, колодец', from PIIr. *čāt-/*čāth- (cf. Ved. cā́tvala- 'яма'), further derived from the root *kan- 'копать, рыть'.}];172[I:539-540{Cf. s.v. Skt. cā́tvala- 'Grube', perhaps to be connected with YAv. čāt- 'Brunnengrube', BSogd. čʾt, Bactr. σαδο 'Brunnen'.}];701[660{Unlikely that Khowar čhat, čat 'lake' can be a borrowing from Iranian (cf. Av. čāt- 'well').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *čāt⁽ʰ⁾- ([ESIJa](src-331) II:252-253, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:285), on the connection of Khowar čhat to this class, cf. [Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):660.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron kʼɜzil 'tail' is from kʼɜz 'crooked', and according to Abaev connected to Persian kāž, kāǰ 'crooked'. The ejective makes one think that this may be a loanword, even if it is indeed related to the Persian term.}];156[I:623]

338[{Cf. Vedic yoṣit- 'woman'.}];172[II:421{Cf. s.v. yóṣā- 'Mädchen, Jungfrau, Maid, junge Frau, Geliebte, Gattin'.  Mayrhofer doubts the connection of the Ossetic forms with the Vedic ones, the etymology of which he considers to be 'Nicht klar'.}];156[IV:20-21]

338[{Cf. Sogdian *čaβ- / *čaft- 'steal', Persian čāpīdan 'rob', but this is also likely to be a Wanderwort (there are many non-IE North Eurasian comparanda).}];156[I:306-307];83[32-33{S.v. Proto-Iranic *čap- 'to seize, attach, stick, strike'. "This root may have an IE etymology. The connection with Gr. κάπτω, Lat. capere, etc. (cf. IEW, l.c.) is semantically very attractive. IE "a" would not palatalize the preceding velar in (I)Ir. though: Ir. *č- in *čap- is from *čak/g- ?", if this conjecture is correct, then PIE *k(e)h₂p- (*kap-) 'to grab, stick to'.}]
Justification: According to [Cheung 2007](src-83):32-33, from Proto-Iranic *čap- 'to seize, attach, stick, strike'. Further etymology uncertain, [Cheung 2007](src-83):33 further speculates a possible connection to PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, grasp' as semantically attractive; cf. also [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:306-307).

Source: 338[{verbal derivate *vi-tarta. Cf. Old Indic vi-tar- 'carry away', Old Persian vi-tar- 'carry over'}];172[I:629-632{Cf. s.v. Ved. tarⁱ 'durch etwas hindurchkommen, etwas durchdringen, hinübergelangen, überwinden', from PIE *terh₂- (cf. Hitt. tarh-/tarhu- 'überwinden, imstande sein', Lat. trāns 'hinüber, hindurch', etc.).}];156[I:344{S.v. Oss. dard | idard 'далекий, далеко', from *vi-tarta- (cf. Ved. vi-tar-, OPers. vi-tar-).}];83[382{S.v. Proto-Iranic *tarH- (1) 'to cross over' (NEIr. Oss. I. tæryn/tard, D. tærun/tard 'to chase, drive (away, forth, out)' (+ u̯i-) Oss. I. dard, D. idard 'far'). From PIE *terh₂- (*treh₂-) 'to go through, overcome' (cf. Ved. tar-ⁱ 'to pass across, pass through, get across, overcome'| Hitt. tarh(u)- 'to overcome, be able', Lat. intrāre 'to go through', Alb. sh-tir 'crosses' etc.).}];141[633-634{Cf. s.v. *terh₂- 'durchkommen, überqueren' (IEW 1074-5).}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *u̯i-tarta-, a verbal adjective to PIE *terh₂- 'to go through, cross over' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:344, [Cheung 2007](src-83):382, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:629-632, [LIV²](src-141) 633-634).

Source: 156[I:569{S.v. Oss. kalm 'змея, червь' with development r > l, from *kr̥mi-. Within Iranian cf. Pers. kirm, Kurd. kurm, kurum, Yagh. kirm, Sogd. kyrm, qrm, Av. kərəma-(?).  Outside Iranian, cf. Skt. kr̥mi-, Lith. kirmis, OIr. cruim, OCS чрьвь.}];172[I:394-395{S.v. Ved. kŕ̥mi- 'Wurm, Made' (IIr. cf. Manichaean Sogd. kyrm- 'Schlange', MPers. klm (kirm) 'Wurm, Drache, Schlange', NPers. kirm 'Wurm, Schlange'), from PIE *kʷr̥mi- (cf. OIr. cruim, W., Bret. pryf 'Wurm', Lith. kirmìs 'Wurm, Schlange', Sloven. čr̂m 'Fingerwurm, Karbunkel', etc.). Beside *kʷr̥mi- exists "a rhyme formation in Indo-European probably for reason of tabu" *u̯r̥mi- (NHG Wurm, cf. Lat. vermis), (so Watkins 1987:288).}];696[288{"[T]he word for 'worm, serpent, dragon' [in Germanic] is Old English wyrm, Old Norse ormr, Old Saxon and Old High German wurm, Gothic waurms: Germanic *wurmiz exactly cognate with Latin vermis, and presupposing Indo-European *u̯r̥mis. The word is a rhyme formation in Indo-European to *kʷr̥mis, probably for reason of tabu| kʷr̥mis is found in Celtic, Balto-Slavic, Albanian and Indo-Iranian. The usual meaning of *kʷr̥mis is just 'worm' in most traditions, but in Middle Iranian it is also the word for 'dragon'| compare the Pahlavi version of the familiar Indo-European formula: kirm ōzat 'slew the dragon' (Kārnāmak IX). There can be no doubt that in *u̯r̥mis/*kʷr̥mis we have two variants of the same designation of the Indo-European mythological serpent-adversary."}];50[181-182{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrimi- 'worm', from PIE *kʷrmi- 'worm' (IEW 1152), cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Alb. krimb, Lith. kirmìs, Sloven. črm.}]
Justification: Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ([EWAia](src-172) I:394-395, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:569, [Matasović 2009](src-50):181-182). Perhaps connected to PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' (cf. [cognate set 172](cog-172) for further discussion).

Source: 156[IV:148{S.v. Oss. xawyn : xawd | xawun : xawd 'падать, попадать, доставаться', from Iranic *kap- 'to fall', cf. Kurdish kautin 'fall', Zazaki kaun- 'fall', Balochi kap- / kapta- 'fall', Shughni xāfs- / xavd, Khotanese kas-.}];83[442{S.v. Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh| to become tired' (> Oss. ? ? Oss. I. xawyn/xawd D. xawun/xawd 'to (be)fall' (with dissim. of first *u̯- + pres. u̯a-suff.)| or s.v. Proto-Iranic *xa(m)p/b- 'to dismount, descend, move away, leave behind'? (> ? Oss. I. xawyn/xawd D. xawun/xawd 'to (be)fall' (with unexpl. -w-, LW?)). Inner-Iranic difficulties make extra-Iranic connections uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:148, to be connected to lexemes from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' in [cognate set 697](cog-697); [Cheung 2007](src-83):442 hesitates between etymologies to either Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' or Proto-Iranic *xa(m)p/b- 'to dismount, descend, move away'.

Source: 338[{Loan from East Caucasian.  Same as 'leg' [cognate set 3236](cog-3236).}];156[I:619{S.v. Oss. k’ax 'нога', a loanword from East Caucasian (cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc.).}]
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:619).

Source: 156[I:265-266{S.v. Oss. bon 'день', from Ir. *bānu- 'shine' (cf. Av. bānu-, Ved. bhānu- 'ray, shine', from IE *bhā- (cf. Gk. φαίνω, Ir. bān, etc.).}];172[II:259-261{Cf. s.v. Ved. bhānú- 'Licht, Strahl, Erscheinung, Glanz' (cf. Av. bānu- 'Lichtstrahl', Oss. bon 'Tag', etc.), to √bhā- < PIE *bʰeh₂- (cf. Gk. φάε 'leuchtete auf, erschien', etc.).}];141[68-69{Cf. s.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, erscheinen' (IEW 104-5).}];331[2:157-158{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *bānu-, *bānau- 'свет, луч| дневной свет, рассвет(?)', derived to Proto-Iranic *bā-.}];274[7-11{S.v. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (LIV 68f., IEW 104f.).}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *bānu-, connected with Vedic bhānú- 'light, beam' and ultimately derivatives from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to sparkle, to shine' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:265-266, [ESIJa](src-331) 2:157-158, [EWAia](src-172) II:259-261, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 68-69, [NIL](src-274) 7-11).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Digor: fid 'meat' goes back to PIr. *pitu‑ 'food', cf. MP pit 'meat', Avestan pitu‑ 'food, meat'. The word also exists in Iron as fəd, but it is not the Swadesh term (more like 'flesh' than 'meat').}];172[II:130{Cf. s.v. Ved. pitú- 'Nahrung, feste Speise' from PIE *pitu-/*pei̯tu-, cf. OIr. ith 'cereal', Lith. piẽtūs 'lunch, lunchtime', and probably also Arm. hiwt 'juice, substance, stuff'.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE stem *pitu- ~ *pei̯tu- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:130 s.v. Vedic pitú- 'food, solid food).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron swan kɜn-ən 'hunt' uses a light verb construction with kænyn 'do' [cognate set 5037](cog-5037). Lexical stem a derivate in -ɜn from sɜw- 'go' [cognate set 5021](cog-5021).}];156[I:318];172[I:552-553{Cf. s.v. Ved. √cyav- 'in Bewegung geraten, sich bewegen, unternehmen', from PIE *ki̯eu̯-.}];141[394-395{S.v. *kʷi̯eu̯- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (IEW 539).}];83[40-42{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯au- 'move, go'.}]
Justification: Light verb construction with Ossetic cwan | cawæn 'hunt, chase' as the semantic head, from Iranic *či̯āu̯ana- from *√či̯au̯- 'to move, go', further to PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:318, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):40-42, [EWAia](src-172) I:552-553, [LIV²](src-141) 394-395).

Source: 338[{ɜvžɜr 'bad' : cf. Av. zbar-, Old Indic hvar- 'be crooked', hvaras- 'crookedness, deceit' (Hübschmann, Benveniste via Abaev).}];172[II:824-825{Ved. hvar-, Av. zbar- (PIIr. *j́ʰu̯ar-) from possibly PIE *g̑ʰu̯el- or *g̑ʰu̯er-.}]
338[{Abaev believes this is derived from kʼaχ 'leg', an E. Caucasian loanword. In any case, due to the ejective this is most probably either a loanword or an onomatopoeic word.}];156[I:620]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, either an onomatopoeic formation or an East Caucasian loanword (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:620).

Source: 338[{The Ossetic lexemes are Wanderwörter with Caucasian and Uralic comparanda. It is unclear whether they may have an Iranian etymology, or they are loanwords from other languages.  The proposed Indo-Iranian comparanda are not inspiring: Old Indic kaśaku- 'Coix barbata', kaśa- 'whip'| Bailey giveskəžə 'fish' in some Pashto dialect. Consequently the Ossetic lexemes are more likely a loanword in origin.}];156[I:588{S.v. Oss. kæsag | kæsalgæ 'руба'| Wanderwort: cf. Hungarian keszeg 'leuciscus', 'лещ', Khanty kaśeu, Mansi kǟsen 'лещ', Georgian kašaqi 'сельдь'. Perhaps from Iran. *kasāka, if cf. Ved. kaśaku- 'Coix barbata' and kaśa- 'плеть' .}]
Justification: Exact origin uncertain, probably a Wanderwort (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:588).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron denǯəž 'sea' is a Turkic loanword.}];156[I:362{Turkic loanword, cf. Turk. dengiz 'sea'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkic, cf. Turkish dengiz 'sea' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:362).

Source: 338[{W. Caucasian loanword or nursery word.}];156[I:362{S.v. Oss. dīdīnæg | dedenæg 'цветок', likely connection with Kabardian dedī, Svan dadil Lak tuti Tsakhur tet. Further not clear. Nursery word?}]
Justification: Either a loanword from West Caucasian or a nursery word (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:362).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron šəf 'leaf' from *śiph-, cf. Avestan saef-, sif- 'to stroke in a sliding way'.}];83[327-328{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *saif 'to flog, cane, rake?'.  No IE etymology.}];156[III:183-184{Cf. s.v. syf | sifæ 'лист', cf. Av. saef-, sif- 'проводить скользящим, обметающим движением', 'carry out a sliding, sweeping movement'.}];172[II:637{Cf. s.v. Ved. śíphā- 'Name eines Flusses', possibly to YAv. saēf- if something like 'darüberstreichen', further connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Compared by [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:183-184 to the root of Avestan saef- / sif- 'carry out a sliding, sweeping movement', no certain etymology outside of Iranic, sometimes compared to Vedic śíphā- (name of a river) but the connection remains uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):327-328, [EWAia](src-172) II:637).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron žmiš 'sand' is from *uz-maisa-. *maisa- is 'mix'. Avestan myas- 'mix', misva- 'mixed'.}];83[261{Cf. s.v. *maiz- 'to mix, mingle', from PIE *mei̯k̑(-s)- 'mix'}];141[428-429{Cf. s.v. *mei̯k̑- 'mischen' (IEW 714).}];156[IV:281-282{S.v. Oss. yzmīs | (æ)zmesæ, (æ)zmensæ 'песок', from Ir. *uz-maisa- to IE *mei̯k̑- смешивать', cf. Av. myas-, Ved. mikṣ-, etc.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *uz-maisa-, a derivative to PIE *mei̯k̑- 'to mix' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:281-282, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):261, [LIV²](src-141) 428-429).

Source: 338[{Loanword from East Caucasian.  Same as 'foot' [cognate set 3217](cog-3217).}];156[I:619{S.v. Oss. k’ax 'нога', a loanword from East Caucasian (cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc.).}]
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:619).

Source: 156[IV:18-19{S.v. Oss. ūrs | ors 'белый' from Proto-Iranian *aruša- (Av. auruša-), cf. Ved. aruṣa- 'reddish'.}];172[I:113{Cf. s.v. Ved. aruṣá- 'rotlich, hellrot, glänzend, feuerfarben' (cf. Ir., YAv. auruša- 'weiß'). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian unclear.}]

338[{preverbal derivate of sɜw- 'go' < *kʷi̯eu̯- [cognate set 5021](cog-5021). The preverb ɜrba- is historically a combination of ɜr- < *avar-, ba- < *upa- (Thordarson 1989).}];156[I:307-308{Cf. Pers. šudan : šaw-, Chorezm. ciya-, Khot. tsu-, tsuta-, Av. šav-, šyav-, Ved. cyav-, Gk. σεύω.}];83[40-42{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯au- 'move, go'.}];172[I:552-553{Cf. s.v. Ved. √cyav- 'in Bewegung geraten, sich bewegen, unternehmen', from PIE *ki̯eu̯-.}];141[394-395{Cf. s.v. *kʷi̯eu̯- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (IEW 539).}]
Justification: A preverbal derivative of Ossetic cæwyn | cæun 'to go', from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:307-308, [Cheung 2007](src-83):40-42, [EWAia](src-172) I:552-553, [LIV²](src-141) 394-395).

Source: 338[{Loanword from South or East Caucasian.}];156[I:376{S.v. dūr | dor 'камень', an old loanword from Caucasian.}]
Justification: Loanword from South or East Caucasian ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:376)

Source: 338[{Ossetic ždaχ-ən 'turn' from *uz-tak-, cf. Persian tā 'thread', Shughni tōǰ 'branch'.}];156[IV:280{S.v. Oss. yzdaxyn : yzdæxt | (æ)zdaxun : (æ)zdaxt 'поворачивать' from *uz- + *tak-/*tax-, ultimately to the PIE base *tek- 'плести' (Pok. 1058).}];141[619-620{Cf. s.v. 2. *tek- 'weben, flechten' (IEW 1058).}]
Justification: According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:280, continuing Proto-Iranic *uz-tak-, where the root *tak- ultimately continues PIE 2. *tek- 'to weave, plait' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 619-620).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron lɜww-ən 'stand' from East Iranian root *rap-. Cf. Ormuri we-raf-s-, Shughni wi-ruv-d-, Yazg. u-raf-s- etc.}];156[II:37-39{S.v. Oss. læwwyn : læwd | læwwun : læwd 'стоять' (etc.)| A. connects the Ossetic verbs to a root *rap- found in Pamir languages.}];83[{[Ossetic verbs not discussed in Cheung (2007).]}]
Justification: According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:37-39, the Ossetic lexemes in this class continue an East Iranic root *rap- also found in Pamir languages (cf. Ormuri we-raf-s-, Shughni wi-ruv-d-). [Not in [Cheung 2007](src-83)].

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron fɜždɜg 'smoke' from PIr. *pazdaka-. Yaghnobi pazd-, Sogdian *pazd- (pzt-) 'smoke'. Also used in names of pests: Persian pazdak- 'a k. of mite', Avestan pazdu- 'a k. of insect'.}];156[I:467{S.v. Oss. fæzdæg 'дым', from Ir. *pazdaka- (cf. Yaghn. pazd, Sogd. *pazd- (pzt-), derived from Ir. *pazd-, from IE *pesd- 'blow').}];83[304{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *pazd- (1) 'to blow, smoke' "This apparently exclusively Ir. root may in fact reflect a causative da-present stem (cf. Kellens 1984:155 ad 6.2.) of IE *pes- ‘to blow’ (Pokorny: 823 f.), similar to MMP rwzd- ‘to desire’ (*rau²), CSogd. sxwrd- ‘to shout’ (*har²). See also *pazd²."}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):304, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:467 for older hypotheses).

Source: 338[{Ossetic narɜg 'narrow' is from Proto-Indo-Iranian *nāraka-, cf. Old Indic naraka- 'Hades', Khwarezmian narak 'narrow', Pashto narai. Eventually the same PIE root as Germanic terms like English narrow.}];172[II:37{Cf. s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'.  Cf. AGk. νέρθεν, ἔνερθεν 'from below', νέρτερος 'lower, nether'.  Mayrhofer does not connect the IIr. and Greek forms to the Germanic ones in [cognate set 2810](cog-2810).}];156[II:156-157{S.v. naræg 'тонкий, узкий, тесный, тесния, ущелье', from Proto-Indo-Iranian *nāraka- (cf. Skt. naraka-). Abaev connects the root to the Germanic words cognate with Engl. 'narrow' from a possible PIE *(s)ner- on the basis of IEW p.974.}];269[{Abaev follows [IEW](src-49) 976 in connecting the Germanic lexemes in [cognate set 2810](cog-2810) with Indo-Iranian *nāraka-, but this is not followed by the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'). The connection of Greek ἔνερθεν is suggestive of a root with initial *h₁-.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Indo-Iranic *(H)nār-, probably to be further to a root *(h₁)ner- on the basis of the comparison to Ancient Greek νέρθεν, ἔνερθεν 'from below', cf. also Sabellic 'left' in [cognate set 3315](cog-3315). Cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:156-157, [EWAia](src-172) II:37 for further discussion.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron qʷədə kɜn-ən 'think': light verb construction with 'do' [cognate set 5037](cog-5037). Lexical stem is from gen. or in. of past participle of qɜw-ən 'to need' (past stem qʷəd), cf. Yaghnobi ɣāw- 'be needed', Sogdian *ɣaw- (ɣw-) 'be needed', Parthian viɣāj- 'a decrease'.}];83[95{Cf. s.v. *gaHu 'to need, be faulty, wanting| to want, desire' from PIE *gʰeh₂u̯- (not in LIV²).}]

338[{Ossetic Iron uses a light verb construction with 'do'| for the lexical part, cf. Avestan taxma- 'mighty', Old Persian taxma- in proper names.  The Ossetic Digor verbal stem is cognate with the Ossetic Iron lexical part.}];156[III:306{S.v. Oss. tox 'борьба, бой', cf. Av. taxma-, OPers. taxma-.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *taxma-, cf. Avestan taxma- 'mighty', Old Persian taxma- 'id.' (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:306).

Source: 338[{origin unclear, Abaev gives some bird names as potential cognates, e.g. Persian šīšū, šīšak 'a k. of partridge'.}];156[III:114]
Justification: Etymology unclear; [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:114 suggests some bird names, e.g. Persian šīšū, šīšak 'a kind of partridge' as potential cognates (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron lɜzɜg 'stick' probably from *laštyaka-, but no Iranian comparanda (Abaev gives Lithuanian lazdà, lazà 'stick'). Alternatively, an old loan from Armenian lcʼakʼ 'lever'.}];156[II:18-19]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156):18-19 suggests from Proto-Iranic *laštyaka- in comparison to Lithuanian lazdà 'stick' but without further parallels within Iranic; alternatively possibly an old loanword from Armenian lcʼakʼ 'lever' (Oleg Belyaev p.c.).

Source: 338[{PIr. *tak- / *tač- 'flow, run'. Persian tak 'celer incessus, cursus, impetus' (Vullers), MP tak 'running', Sogdian *taxī (tɣyh) 'river', Avestan taka- 'running, flow', etc.}];156[III:286-287];83[373-374{S.v. *tač-¹ 'to flow, run, walk', from PIE *tekʷ- 'to hurry, rush, walk, flow'.}];141[620-621{S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-60).}];172[I:610-611{Cf. s.v. Ved. √tak- 'stürzen, dahinschießen, eilen (von Tieren, Strömen), from PIE *tekʷ- 'eilen, stürzen, laufen, fließen' (cf. OIr. tech- 'fließen', W go-deb 'Zuflucht', Lith. tekė́ti 'laufen, fließen', OCS tešti 'laufen, eilen', tokъ 'Lauf, Strom', TochB cake 'Fluß' Hitt. watku- 'springen, entspringen').}]
Justification: Derivatives of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk', further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:286-287, [Cheung 2007](src-83):373-374, [EWAia](src-172) I:610-611, [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Source: 338[{laš-ən 'pull' from *nas- 'take'. Cf. Yaghnobi nās- / nāta-, Khotanese nās- / nāta- 'take'.}];83[183-184{Cf. s.v. *Hnas-'to reach, attain, take', from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, attain'.}];141[282-284{Cf. s.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-318).}];156[II:14-15]
Justification: According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:14-15, from Proto-Iranic *nas- 'to take' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):183-184 s.v. *Hnas- 'to reach, attain, take'), if so further to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 282-284).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron bɜlaš 'tree' is a West Caucasian loanword. Also possibly related to palāśa- 'foilage' according to Abaev, but I believe borrowing is more likely.}];156[I:247]

338[{Ossetic Iron kɜrdɜg 'grass' is a lexicalised participle from kɜrd-ən 'cut' from PIE *(s)kert- cognate set 762.}];156[I:582-583, 584{S.v. kærdæg 'трава', derived from kærdyn : karst | kærdun : karst 'резать', from Iran. *kart-, from PIE *(s)kert-.}];141[559-560{Cf. s.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' [IEW 941-2].}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing a lexicalised participle of Iron kærdyn, Digoron kærdun 'to cut', continuing Proto-Iranic *kart- 'to cut', and further to PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:582-583, I:584, Oleg Belyaev (p.c.), [Cheung 2007](src-83):243-244, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron widag 'root' from *waitāka, from root *wai. Sogdian *wītāk (wytʼk) 'rope', Persian bīd 'willow', Avestan vaeiti- 'willow'.}];320[274-275];156[IV:106{Goes back to enlarged form *waitāka- from the root *wai- < PIE *u̯ei̯- 'twist' (IEW 1120-1122).  Cf. Ved. vetasá- 'Calamus rotang', etc.}];172[II:578-579{Cf. s.v. Ved. vetasá- from Proto-Indo-Iranian *u̯ai̯-t- to PIE *u̯ei̯(H)-t- (cf. Lat. uītis 'tendril, twine', OHG wīda 'willow', NHG Weide 'id.', etc.).}]
Comment: on words ending in °x: Bailey (1979: 111a) assumes a -xa- suffix for this word. Klingenschmitt (2000: 203) calles this "Suffixtausch" of *-xa- and *-ka-.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron žɜʁ-ən 'say' is from PIr. *zag- vel sim. Often attested in bird names, e.g. Persian zāǧ 'magpie'. But also Sogdian zaɣānt- 'herald', Avestan zaxšaϑra- 'evil saying'.}];83[460{S.v. *zag- ? 'to sound (utter, say, etc.)'.  No etymology outside Iranian.}];156[IV:292-293{S.v. Oss. zæǧyn : zaǧd | zæǧun, ʒæǧun : zaǧd, ʒaǧd 'сказать, говорить'.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes probably continuing derivatives of a Proto-Iranic root *zag-, without certain etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):460, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:292-293).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron mit 'snow': Abaev believes this a Slavic loan and considers phonetic similarity to Sogdian mēϑ, Khwarezmian mīϑ 'day' to be accidental.}];156[II:124{S.v. mīt | met 'снег', a loanword from Slavic *o-met- 'наметенное, снежный сугроб', 'swept (snow), snowdrift'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic *o-met- 'swept snow; snowdrift' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:124).

Source: 338[{Probably onomatopoeic.}];156[I:528{S.v. Oss. g˳ybyn | gubun 'живот, брюхо' Refers to a type of words kpr||kpn meaning 'convex, round'.}]
Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. also [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:528).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron qaž-ən 'play' has no reliable etymology. Abaev compares with Ishkashimi ɣəz-, Khwarezmian ɣāz- 'run'. Alternatively, with PIr. *gāz- 'dive', cf. Old Indic gāh-.}];156[II:276-277]
Justification: Without certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:276-277).

Source: 338[{Loan from East Caucasian.}];156[I:644{S.v. Oss. k’ūx | k’ox 'рука', 'hand'. As with k’ax 'нога', 'foot' a loan from a Caucasian substrate. Cf. Chech. kujg 'рука', 'hand'.}]
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Chechen kujg 'hand' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:644).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron dərʁ 'fruit' is of unknown origin.  It may be an East Caucasian loanword.}];156[I:383]
Justification: Of uncertain origin, perhaps an East Caucasian loanword? (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:383).

Source: 338[{PIr. *tauka, cf. Old Indic toka- 'descendants', tokman- 'sprout', Avestan taoxman-, Persian toxm.}];172[I:670{Cf. s.v. Ved. toká- 'Nachkommenschaft, Kinder'. No clear cognates for IIr. *tau̯k- outside of Indo-Iranian.}];156[III:309-310{S.v. Oss. tūg | tog 'кровь' from Indo-Iranic *tauka- cf. Ved. toka- 'потомство' < 'семя'.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *tau̯ká- 'progeny, children', further etymology uncertain (cf.  [EWAia](src-172) I:670, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:309-310).

Source: 338[{The Ossetic lexemes may be from Iranian *ru-ka-, but Abaev gives no Iranian cognates. They are more likely related to an East Caucasian term (Lezgian rug 'dust', Tabasaran rug 'earth', etc.).}];156[II:443-444{Cf. s.v. Oss. rug | rugæ 'пыль, прах'.}]
Justification: Probably loans from East Caucasian, cf. Lezgian rug 'dust', Tabasaran rug 'earth' (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.). [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:443-444 suggests Iranic *ru-ka- but gives no Iranic cognates.

Source: 338[{Probably onomatopoeic.}];156[I:319-320]
Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:319-320).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron bɜržɜj 'neck', according to Abaev, is related to the stem *barz- 'high', cf. bɜržond 'high'. This, in turn, is from PIr. *bṛz-ant-, *barz-ant-. Cf. Persian buland, Avestan bərəzant- 'high'.}];141[78-79{Cf. s.v. *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'hoch werden, sich erheben' (IEW 140-141).}];156[I:254{S.v. Oss. bærzæj 'шея', to be connected with Ir. *barz- 'высокий' (cf. Oss. bærzond), cf. Av. bərəzant-, Ved. br̥hant- 'tall' etc.).}]
Justification: According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:254 a derivative of Proto-Iranic *barz- 'high', cf. Av. bərəzant-, Ved. br̥hant- 'tall' etc., further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to become tall; raise oneself' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 78-79, [NIL](src-274) 30).

Source: 156[I:333-334{In all probability, a Caucasian loanword.}]
Comment: Loan from East Caucasian
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:333-334).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron šχoj-ən 'push' is from *uz-xwāy-, cf. Yaghnobi suxoy- / suxasta-, Sogdian *əsxwāy-, *səxwāy- / səxūst- (sɣwʼy-, ʼsɣwʼy, sxwʼay-, sxwʼy- / sxwst-, swxst-). The root without preverb also survives in χoj-ən 'hit' (not Swadesh), cf. Avestan xʷah- 'squeeze'.}];83[141-143{Cf. s.v. *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh| [inch., intr.] become tired'.  No IE etymology.}];156[IV:279{S.v. ysxojyn : ysx˳yst | (æ)sxwajun : (æ)sxust.}]

338[{East Caucasian loan.}];156[I:310-311{S.v. Oss. cæxx | cænxæ 'соль'. Cannot be connected with the Iranian or Indo-European words for salt. There are some parallels with Caucasian and Uralic languages.}]
Comment: Loan from East Caucasian
Justification: No clear connection to the inherited Iranic or Indo-European words for salt, probably a loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:310-311).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron galiw 'left' is of unknown origin.}];156[I:507{S.v. galīw | galew 'левый'. Etymology unclear.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Ossetic ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:507).

Source: 352[745-746{S.v. OLith. paũtas 'Ei| Hoden' (BSl. cf. Latv. pàuts 'Ei| Testikel', OPr. paute 'Eier')| the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'egg' is a a vr̥ddhi derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird', which is found in Baltic through the derivatives pùtė 'Huhn', putýtis 'Küken', Latv. putns 'Vogel'. Further are compounds like Lith. pùt-pela, Latv. putpele 'Wachtel'. In Slavic the diminutives OCS pъtica, SCr. ptȉca, Ru. ptíca 'Vogel' and SCr. pȁtka 'Ente'. The Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' has no plausible connections outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Justification: Cf. Old Lithuanian paũta 'egg, testicle', considered a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' *put- (cf. 'bird' in [cognate set 1109](cog-1109)), but further etymology uncertain ([ALEW](src-352) 745-746).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron až 'year', cf. Persian asmān, Avestan/OP asmān- 'sky' etc.}];172[I:137-138{Cf. s.v. Ved. aśman- < PIE *h₂ek̑-mon-.}];156[I:95-96]
Justification: Continuing PIE *h₂ek̑-mon- 'stone; sky', a derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:95-96, [EWAia](src-172) I:137-138).

Source: 50[118-119{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ēskyo- 'moon', from PIE *h₁ei̯sk- 'shine, glitter' (cf. OCS iskra 'spark', Lith. áiškus 'bright', Russ. jáska 'bright star').}];81[214{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic jьskra 'spark', not to be connected with the Celtic lexemes.}];353[45{Cf. s.v. Lith. áiškus 'clear', not to be connected with the Celtic lexemes.}];352[24{Cf. s.v. OLith. áiškus, -i (1), aiškùs -ì (4) 'klar, deutlich', without clear correspondences outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Justification: [Matasović 2009](src-50):118-119 connects to Balto-Slavic lexemes (OCS iskra 'spark', Lith. áiškus 'bright') via PIE *h₁ei̯sk-, however the etymology of these proposed Balto-Slavic cognates are disputed (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):214, [Derksen 2015](src-353):45 connecting instead to *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'kindle' assuming a connection with OIc. eiskra 'rage with heated excitement; [ALEW](src-352) 24 assuming no clear cognates outside of Balto-Slavic). Consequently only a Proto-Celtic root ref. form has been given for this cognate set.

Source: 165[526{S.v. Proto-Germanic *tungla- 'star, celestial body(?)'  Of uncertain etymology.}];179[348{Cf. s.v. Goth. T36. *tungl 'star, constellation'. Only dat.pl. tugglam as a gloss to (uf) stabim (ϸis fairƕaus) / (ὑπὸ) τὰ στοιχεῖα (τοῦ κόσμου). Cf. OI tungl 'moon', himin-tungl 'constellation', etc. No etymology. Older proposals to Lith. dangùs, OPr. dangus 'sky, heaven', Lith. deñgti 'cover' unsatisfactory.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *tungla- 'star, celestial body(?)', further connections outside Germanic uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):348, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):526).

Source: 259[268-269{Polish księżyc 'moon' is derived from PS *kŭnęgŭ 'ruler, duke, regnant'. PS *kŭnęgŭ is a loanword from Germanic *kuningaz 'king', cf. Old High German kuning and German König.}];600[876-878{It is a derivative from PS *kŭnęgŭ 'ruler, duke, regnant', a loanword from Germanic *kuningaz, cf. German König.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kъnęgъ 'ruler, duke, regent', a loan from Germanic *kuningaz 'king' ([Boryś 2005](src-259):268-269, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):876-878).

Source: 345[555-556{Accepts connection of TochB yolo 'bad, evil' to earlier PIE *h₁edu̯ol-ōn-, a derivative of *h₁edu̯ol- 'that which eats', which is possibly connected to the family of words found in Gk. ὀδύνη 'pain, suffering', Arm. երկն / erkn / 'birth pangs, great pain' < *h₁edu̯on-.}];80[420-422{S.v. Hitt. idālu-, idālau̯- 'bad, evil, evilness'. Kloekhorst connects Hitt. idālu- 'bad, evil', CLuw. ādduu̯a- 'evil', HLuw. átuwa- 'evil' to a Proto-Anatolian stem *ʔeduo-(l-), but rejects the proposed connections to a putative stem *h₁ed-u̯ōl- to the root *h₁ed- 'bite' as proposed by [Watkins 1982](src-378).  K. mentions but does not explicitly reject proposed connections with TochB, yolo 'bad, evil'.}];269[{Possibly cognate with Tocharian B yolo 'bad', Gk. ὀδύνη, Arm. erkn, OIr. idu (cf. [Schindler 1975](src-723), [Watkins 1982](src-378), [Adams 2013](src-345):555-556), but these connections are uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):420-422, and more recently regarding the Tocharian lexemes [Peyrot 2016](src-676). Cf. further discussion in [cognate set 7558](cog-7558)).}];378[250-262];406[487-493{S.v. idālu- 'bad, evil', connecting the forms to the complex of forms represented by Arm. erkn 'labour pains, toil', Gk. ὀδύναι 'pain, pangs, distress', OIr. idain '(birth)pangs', as a petrified verbal noun from the root *ed- 'eat', lit. 'eating (away), consumption, ill, pain' (cf. Schindler, KZ [1975] 89:53-65).}];723[53-65];676[327-335]
Justification: Possibly cognate with Tocharian B yolo 'bad', Gk. ὀδύνη, Arm. erkn, OIr. idu (cf. [Schindler 1975](src-723), [Watkins 1982](src-378), [Adams 2013](src-345):555-556), but these connections are uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):420-422, and more recently specifically regarding the Tocharian lexemes [Peyrot 2016](src-676) and further discussion in [cognate set 7558](cog-7558)).

Source: 279[442-43{Perhaps from nom sg. m./f. *mh₂-i̯ōs and cognate with Gothic mais, OHG mē(r),  'more', PCl. *mati- in Irish maith, Breton mat 'good', cf. *meh₂- 'to give sign' (LIV² 425, IEW 693). According to an alternative etymology, Osk. mais, Latin magis originate from *mag-i̯os.}];54[359{Oscan mais 'more', maimas 'greatest' and Umbr. mestru 'greater' are cognate with Latin magnus, thus < PIt. *mg̑-no- 'great', *mg̑-i(V)s- 'greater'. (Also Kroonen 2013, 350).}];275[{Three possible etymologies: 1) PIE *meg̑-, than cognate with Latin magnus| 2) PIE *meh₂- 'to give a sign' (LIV² 425, IEW 693), than cognate with PCl. *mati- 'good'| 3) PIE *meh₁-, then cognate with PCl. *māro- 'big' and Greek.}];274[476, fn. 33{From *meh₁- 'big'.}]
Justification: Indo-European root etymology uncertain (see note by Irslinger to this class); cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):442-443, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):359, [NIL](src-274) 476n33 for competing proposals.

Source: 80[411-413{S.v. Hitt. ištamān- / ištamin- (c. > n.) 'ear'. The noun ištamān- 'ear' is cognate with Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' < PIE (nom.) *stéh₃-mn, (gen.) *sth₃-mén-s.}]
Justification: Lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):411-413).

Source: 80[704-706{S.v. šākuu̯a- 'eye' (Anat. cognates: CLuw. tāu̯a- 'eye', HLuw. tawa/i- 'eye', Lyc. *tewe- 'eye' (coll. pl. tawa), ñtewe 'facing, opposite, toward', from Proto-Anatolian *sṓgʷo- via PIE *sókʷ-o- (cf. PGerm. sexʷan 'to see'). An alternative proposal is a connection with the root *h₃ekʷ- 'see' with an s-mobile, but this is somewhat awkward for the Anatolian-internal evidence.}];699[50-57{S.v. Hitt. sakui- 'eye| opening, hole'.}]
Justification: Generally assumed to be connected with Proto-Germanic *sehwan- 'see' (cf. [cognate set 288](cog-288)) from PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' ([LIV²](src-141) 525-526), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):704-706 (rejected, however, by [HED SA](src-699):50-57 on the grounds that the etymology contravenes Sturtevant's Rule).

Source: 80[571-572{S.v. Hitt. me(i̯)u- / mei̯au̯- 'four'. The Hittite stem is difficult to etymologise. Perhaps to be connected with the root *meh₁- 'to measure', but ultimately unclear. Within Anatolian cf. CLuw. māuu̯a- 'four' and possib. Lyc. mupm̃m- 'fourfold?'.}];410[116-119{S.v. Hitt. me(y)u-, mi(y)u- 'four'. "Pending further illumination, Proto-Anatolian *mēyu- < *meE₂ʸu- can be postulated as an u-stem adjective meaning basically '(firmly) measured, (four)square', comparable to Ved. sam-mā́ya (RV 1.67.10 'staking out' [like craftsmen do an abode]), vi-mā́ya (RV 10.114.6 'measuring out' [a sacrifice, after dividing four catúraḥ) cups of soma]), pra-mā́- 'prime measure, prototype')."}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain, perhaps to the root *meh₁- 'to measure', but  ultimately unclear. Cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):571-572, [HED M](src-410) 116-119 for further discussion.

Source: 172[II:533-534{S.v. Ved. vásu- 'gut, herrlich, trefflich', cf. OAv., YAv. vohu-, from PIE *h₁u̯esu- (cf. Gk. ἐάων, 'der Güter', Luw., Pal. u̯ašu- 'gut', OIr. *feb 'Vortrefflichkeit, etc.).}];373[352-353{Cf. for discussion of the derivation of CLuw. u̯āšu(i)- 'gut' from PIE *h₁u̯ésu- and its derivatives within Luwian.}]
Justification: Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₁u̯és-u- ([EWAia](src-172) II:533-534, [Starke 1990](src-373):352-353).

Source: 80[267-268{S.v. Hitt. ḫāḫḫall- 'greenery, verdure, (wild) vegetation', from which the derived adjective ḫaḫliu̯ant- 'yellow(green)'. The word appears to be genuinely Hittite, already attested in OS documents and with no aberrant case forms or morphological irregularities, but there is nevertheless no good Indo-European etymology. The meaning of the CLuw. ḫaḫḫaluu̯anti- which is marked using the gloss-wedge (Glossenkeil) is not clear and may not belong with the Hittite form (HW² Ḫ: 7f. regards it was not belonging with Hitt. ḫāḫḫall-).}];377[45{Luw. ḫa-aḫ-ḫa-lu-u̯a-an-ti-[ "Prob. cognate of Hitt. word, pace HW² 3.7."}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):267-268, cf. [Melchert 1993a](src-377):45).

Source: 279[492-493{S.v. U. nertru 'links', formally identical with Ancient Greek (ἐ)νέρτερος 'lower', cf. Arm. nerkʻin 'below'.}];269[{The Greek comparandum with initial ἐ- points to a root *(h₁)ner-. The Umbrian and Greek forms therefore reflect a comparative *(h₁)ner-tero-.}]
Justification: Sabellic lexemes continuing a comparative formation derived to PIE *(h₁)ner- ([Untermann 2000](src-279):492-493, Scarborough, p.c.).

Source: 279[493-494{S.v. O.u. nessimas 'der nächste'. Oscan and Umbrian forms from *ned-tm̥(m)o- like Old Irish nessam, Welsh nessaf| isolated superlative to an isolated root *ned⁽ʰ⁾- 'link, connect'.}];240[119{S.v. Old Welsh nes (adj. comp.) 'nearer', from PIE *ned- 'zusammendrehen, knüpfen' (MW nes, MCB nes, OIr. nessa, G neddamon).}]
Justification: Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ned⁽ʰ⁾- 'to link, connect' ([Untermann 2000](src-279):493-494, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):119).

Source: 345[504-505{S.v. TochB meli 'nose' (pl.tant.), which along with TochA malañ, must reflect Proto-Tocharian *mele- (plural tantum).  Extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):504-505 for various suggestions).

Source: 80[554{Cf. s.v. Hitt. maninku(u̯a)- 'near', cognate with CLuw. mannakuna/i- 'short' but the variant forms in Hittite make it difficult to etymologise the forms outside of Anatolian.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):554).

Source: 697[484{S.v. Gmc. *skamma- 'kurz'. Formally and semantically the closest comparison is to Av. kamna- 'wenig, gering', which because of the superlative kambišta- is based on *kombh-no- (also pre-Germanic *skombh-no-?). Further connections are unclear.}];468[482{Cf. s.v. ON skammr 'kurz'.}];388[333{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skam(m)az. Of unknown origin. Probably related to Av. kamna- 'little' < *kombh-no-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):484, [Orel 2003](src-388):333 for a tenuous proposal to Av. kamna- 'few, little'. No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 352[564-565{S.v. lazdà 'Stock, Stab| Haselstrauch' (BSl. Latv. lazda 'Haselstrauch', OPr. laxde 'Haselstrauch', kellaxde 'Speerschaft'). Certainly well established within Baltic, but outside connections less certain. Perhaps to be connected with Slavic words for 'hazel-bush' (cf. SCr. lijèska, Ru. leščína, Cz. líska 'Hasel', Pol. lask 'Stock'), alternatively a direct connection with OIr. slat, MW llath 'Stock, Stab' has been suggested (cf. Kroonen 2011:217f.).}];353[276-277{S.v. Lith. lazdà 'stick, staff' (OLith. dial.) 'hazel' (Latv. lazda 'hazel', OPr. laxde 'Hazel'), in Slavic cf. Ru. ljazgá 'hazel', Bel. ljáska 'stick, cane', Cz. líska 'hazel', Slk. lieska 'hazel', Pol. laska 'stick, staff', SCr. lijèska 'hazel', etc. "In spite of formal differences, there can hardly be any doubt that the Slavic and Baltic forms are cognate." [Cf. entry in Derksen for further discussion on reconstructing the stem in Baltic and Slavic.]}]
Comment: cf. OCS loza 'vine'

Source: 54[326{S.v. lapis, -dis 'stone, pebble'. No Indo-European etymology, but Sabellic and Latin forms may be accounted for by Proto-Italic *l(a/e)ped-.  The Italic words are often compared to Gk. λεπάς [n.] 'bare rock, mountain', also of uncertain etymology (cf. Beekes 2010:848).  This may suggest that there may be a common source for both the Italic and Greek words from a non-Indo-European Mediterranean language.}];66[848{Cf. s.v. Gk. λέπας 'bare rock, mountain'. "The similarity between λέπας and Lat. lapis, -idis [m., f.] 'stone' is hardly accidental| a Mediterranean borrowing is most probable."}];316[340-341{S.v. Lat. lapis, -idis 'pierre', connected to Umbrian vapeř-e 'lapide, sella', but no other clear correspondences. Sometimes compared to the root of Gk. λεπάς 'rocher nu', but the connection is uncertain.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Italic, possibly a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean source (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):340-341, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):326).

Source: 80[515-516{S.v. Hitt. lāla- 'tongue, blade, speech, talk'. No good Indo-European cognates. Hitt. lāla-, CLuw. lāla/i- may go back to PAnat. *lólo- or *lālo-.}];409[40-44{S.v. Hitt. lala- (c., rarely n.) 'tongue' (either in anatomical sense or as ritualistic model, 'blade', metonymically 'speech, talk'.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):515-516, cf. also [HED L](src-409):40-44).

Source: 80[267-268{S.v. Hitt. ḫāḫḫall- 'greenery, verdure, (wild) vegetation', from which the derived adjective ḫaḫliu̯ant- 'yellow(green)'. The word appears to be genuinely Hittite, already attested in OS documents and with no aberrant case forms or morphological irregularities, but there is nevertheless no good Indo-European etymology. The meaning of the CLuw. ḫaḫḫaluu̯anti- which is marked using the gloss-wedge (Glossenkeil) is not clear and may not belong with the Hittite form (HW² Ḫ: 7f. regards it was not belonging with Hitt. ḫāḫḫall-).}];377[45{Luw. ḫa-aḫ-ḫa-lu-u̯a-an-ti-[ "Prob. cognate of Hitt. word, pace HW² 3.7."}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):267-268), cf. [Melchert 1993a](src-377):45).

Source: 406[465-468{S.v. Hitt. istanu-, astanu- 'sun, sun-god(dess), solar deity| majesty'. A loanword from Hattic Eštan-, Aštan-, which matches Hitt. ᵈUTU-uš in a bilingual text, cf. [Laroche 1947](src-573).}];573;578[428-430{S.v. Hitt. ᵈIštanu- 'Sonnengott, Sonne'. ᵈIštanun is given as the equivalent to the Sumerogram ᵈUTU in a parallel passage in a copy of a text.}]
Justification: Loanword from Hattic eštan-, aštan- 'sun(god)' ([Tischler 1983](src-578):428-430, [HED A+E/I](src-406):465-468, cf. [Laroche 1947](src-573)).

Source: 79[178-179{S.v. Arm. bolor 'whole, entire| round, spherical, circle', derived from PIE *bʰel- 'to blow, grow, swell' (cf. Gk. φαλλός 'penis', OIc. boli 'bull', Lat. follis 'leather bag filled with air, ball', OIr. ball 'body part', etc.).}];180[525]
Justification: Generally derived from a basic PIE root *bʰel- 'to blow, swell' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):525, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):178-179).

Source: 180[932{Cf. Arm. hašiw 'account, calculation, consideration', a loan from Syriac (cf. Syr. xəšīw 'gerechnet, geachtet für').}];740[III:43]
Justification: Loan from Syriac, cf. Classical Armenian hašiw < Syriac ḥəšīḇ, 'considered, calculated' ([HAB](src-740) III:43, [Olsen 1999](src-180):932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *haʃiu̯-].
From Classical Armenian gawazan 'rod, stave', a loanword from Iranic *gavāzan- 'oxgoad' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):872, [HAB](src-740) I:525-526). [MM: Proto-Armenian *gau̯azan-a-].

Source: 141[616{Cf. s.v. 2. *teh₂- 'tauen, schmelzen' (IEW 1053).}];740[II:150-151];558[113-114, 285{Cf. for the stem formation of Armenian tʻanam 'to wet, moisten (smth.)'.}]
Justification: Apparently related to tʿacʿ- the aorist stem of Classical Armenian tʿanam 'to (become) wet, to moisten, drench' (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:150-151), further to PIE *teh₂- 'to thaw, melt' ([Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):113-114, [LIV²](src-141) 616).

Source: 180[165{Arm. pʿokʿr 'small, little', traditionally vaguely connected to the root of Gk. παῖς, Lat. paulus, paucus, Skt. putrá-, Osc. puklo-, etc., but this requires the assumption of initial pʿ- < *p instead of expected *h-/Ø- (few parallels, of 'expressive' origin?), intervocalic kʿ < *k (cf. Lat. paucus?) and the root vocalism might be the result of a dissimilatory umlaut *pʰukʰu- > pʰokʰu- in oblique cases of the singular.}]
Justification: Origin uncertain, traditionally connected with PIE *peh₂u̯- 'few; little', but the connection is phonetically difficult to justify (cf. discussion in [Olsen 1999](src-180):165). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰokʰ-u-(r)].

Source: 180[942{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:519).}];740[IV:519]
Justification: Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):942, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-o-/-i-].

Source: 743[599{Arm. tʻiw 'number' < Hurr. tiw- 'to say, speak', tiwǝ 'word, deed'.}];180[23{Arm. tʻiw 'number' is connected with Sanskrit tavá- 'stark, kräftig' (subst. *távas-, Av. tauuah-), vb. tavīti 'ist stark, hat Macht' etc. to a root *teuh₁-. The root vocalism points to a vr̥ddhi formation *tēu̯h₁-esó- based on the s-stem *teu̯Hos.}]
Justification: Denominal to Classical Armenian tʿiw 'number'. Further origins uncertain; either to be connected with Sanskrit tavá- 'strong, powerful' to a root *teu̯h₁- (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):23) or a borrowing from Hurro-Urartian, cf. Hurrian tiw- 'to say, speak', tiwə 'word; deed', (cf. [Diakonoff 1985](src-743):599). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʰiu̯-].

Source: 141[531-532{S.v. *sengʷ- 'herunterfallen, untergehen, sinken' (IEW 906). The Armenian present stem forms are probably from a stem ?*sn̥-né/n-gʷ-. Cf. aor. *séngʷ-/*sn̥gʷ- > Arm. ankaw 'fiel'.}];79[90-91{S.v. ankanim 'to fall down| to come down, hang down| to arrive, come to end, cease, stop| to die, fall (especially in battle)| to fall morally, commit a crime, sin, prostitute, etc.', probably to be derived from PIE *sn̥gʷ- 'to sink, fall' (cf. Goth. sigqan, OHG sinke/an, Germ. sinken, Engl. sink, etc.).}]
Justification: Armenian lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go under, sink' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):90-91, [LIV²](src-141) 531-532).

Source: 540[431{connect CA կռիւ kṙiw 'fight, strife| uproar' (presumably from *gʷēriH-) with Proto-Germanic *krīg- (e.g. MHG kriec) 'id.', Proto-Celtic *brīgos (Irish bríg), both from *gʷriH-g⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. Kroonen 2013, 304)| cf. also Gk. βρίμη 'strength, bulk| censure'.}];740[II:670-671];180[16{[Classical Armenian kṙiw 'fight' included in a list of 'etymologically more opaque' nouns, but not listed in the final index of vocabulary of unknown origin.]}]
Comment: Origin uncertain.
Justification: From Classical Armenian kṙowim 'to fight', denominative to kṙiw 'fight'. Further etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):16, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:670-671, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):431 for various proposals). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) [MM: Proto-Armenian *kiṙiu̯-].

Source: 740[II:438-439];180[459{Arm. całik 'flower' is sometimes assumed to be etymologically connected with całr, całow 'laugh, laughter' < *g̑élh₂ōs (cf. [IEW](src-49) 366f.).}];319[128{Arm. całik is possibly connected to PIE *g̑elh₂-, with the semantics justified on the basis of the gloss from Hesychius's lexicon: γέλειν· λάμπειν, ἄνθειν 'to shine, bloom'.}];79[336{S.v. Arm. cał- 'flower, blossom', some scholars have suggested an etymology to Arm. cał- 'laugh' (< *g̑elh₂-) comparing the Hesychius gloss γελεῖν· λάμπειν, ἀνθεῖν 'shine, bloom'. For discussion cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):128, [Olsen 1999](src-180):459, among others.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Perhaps to be connected to Armenian cał- 'laugh' (< PIE *g̑elh₂-) 'to laugh' on the basis of the Hesychius gloss γελεῖν· λάμπειν, ἀνθεῖν 'shine, bloom', but this is uncertain (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):128, [Olsen 1999](src-180):459, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):336 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsał-ik(-u/an)-].

Uncertain origin. Possibly an Iranian loanword (perhaps) via (inner-Armenian) *ba(δ)r-ii̯o/a- (cf. Skt. bhadrá- 'blessed, fortunate; happy; Av. hu-baδra- 'extremely happy'); cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):436. Cf. [HAB](src-740) I:422-424. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *bar-i̯o-].

Source: 740[II:24];180[155{Arm. ełǰewr 'horn' may be derived from *gʰrḗu̯r̥ (< *gʰréh₁u̯r̥ or *gʰreh₁u̯r̥) if connected with Hitt. karawar 'horn' and TochB obl. krorīyai, A kror 'crescent, horn of the moon'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Formerly compared with Hittite karawar 'horn', Tocharian A kror, Tocharian B (oblique stem) krorīyai 'crescent, horn of the moon' via PIE *gʰréh₁u̯r̥ (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):155, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):182), but these proposed cognates may also be derived from PIE *k̑er- (cf. [cognate set 2457](cog-2457)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)łdʒ-iu̯r-].

Source: 79[99-100{S.v. Arm. aǰ 'right', connected with Skt. sā́dhati 'to succeed, reach the goal', siddhá- , sidhrá- successful', sādhú- 'straight, effective', sídhyati 'to succeed, be successful' from PIE *sHdʰ-i̯o- or *seh₂dʰ-i̯o-.}];172[II:722-723{Cf. s.v. Ved. √sādh- 'zum Ziel gelangen, gelingen', probably from PIE *seh₁dʰ-/*sh₁dʰ-, cf. Arm. aǰ 'recht, dexter' < *sh₁dʰ-i̯o-.}];141[517{Cf. s.v. *seHdʰ- 'zum Ziel kommen, gelingen' (IEW 892).}];180[186{S.v. aǰ 'right', connected with Greek ἰθύς 'gerade, gerecht', Skt. sādhú- 'zum Zeil führend, gerade, richtig, wirksam'.}]
Justification: From PIE *seh₁dʰ-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):99-100, [Olsen 1999](src-180):186, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:722-723, [LIV²](src-141) 517).

Source: 79[140-141{Cf. in an excursus s.v. Arm. arcui 'eagle', where the etymology of cov 'sea' is discussed. Armenian cov 'sea' is sometimes considered a loanword from Urartian ṣûə 'inland sea', but the Urartian word could just as well be a loan from Armenian.}];180[943{Of unknown origin. (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:468).}];740[II:468];743[600{Arm. cov 'sea' considered a loanword from Urart. ṣûǝ (if to be interpreted as /c̣ô(w)ǝ/) 'inland sea'.}]
Justification: Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):943, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:468). Sometimes considered a loanword from Urartian ṣûə 'inland sea' ([Diakonoff 1985](src-743):600), but the Urartian word could just as well be a loan from Armenian (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):140-141). With [Kölligan 2019](src-795), cov could be an original epithet *di̯eu̯-o-bʰh₂u- meaning 'sky blue'. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsou̯-u-].

Source: 141[109-112{S.v. *dek̑- '(an-, auf-)nehmen, wahrnehmen', assuming Arm. pres. tesanem was back-formed from a root-aorist etes < *dek̑-/dk̑-.  See n1 with reference to R. Schmitt (1981:146, 190)| G. Klingenschmitt (1982:228).}];558[228];655[146];673[105-106, 113{Suggested to be a blending of the roots *spek̑- 'see' and *derk̑- 'see' (Meillet 1936:135, Hamp 1984, Klingenschmitt 1982:228). Not in Martirosyan 2010.}];644[135]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Possibly a blend of PIE *spek̑- & *derk̑- (cf. [Meillet 1936](src-644):135, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):228, [Clackson 2017](src-673):105-106); alternatively backformed to a root aorist etes < *dek̑-/dk̑- (cf. [Schmitt 1981](src-655):146, [LIV²](src-141) 109-112).

Source: 673[110{S.v. No. 18 erkinkʻ 'sky', frequently seen as having undergone contamination with its antonym erkir 'earth' (or vice versa), e.g. [Normier 1980](src-685):62-3 who takes erkin from *h₁erki-u̯ent- (cf. Ved. arcivant- epithet of sky), with -k- from erkir. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).}];685[62-63];180[471-472{No consensus for an etymology. Cf. with further discussion and references.}]
Justification: No certain etymology, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):471-472, [HAB](src-740) II:62-64, [Clackson 2017](src-673):110 for further discussion. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)rkin-i-].
Origin uncertain according to [Olsen 1999](src-180):942, a loanword from Caucasian according to [HAB](src-740) II:470-471. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsux-o-].

Source: 540[381{S.v. Arm. ԿԱՆԳ-, deriving the verb from (a conflation of) PIE *gʷem- (cf. Skt. gácchati) and *gʷeh₂- (cf. Skt. á-gā-t), presumably from an original "(come to) stand". Denominative of either կանգ kang 'stop(page), halt, pause' (i.e. < */kang-(a)n-e-l/) or կանգուն kang-own 'standing, upright| remaining, enduring| (also) cubit, arm's length (if the same item and not a loan from Iranian| cf. Persian kang 'wing| arm')' (i.e. <  */kangun-e-l/).}];180[606-607{"Kangown (AG 165, [HAB](src-740) II:511) is attested more than a hundred times in the meaning 'cubit' (measure of length), and it is usually inflected as an o-stem (-oy, -ocʻ) though we find two examples of inst.sg. -aw (Ex.26.13) and John 21.8) and one instance of gen.sg. -ean (Esth.7.9). Further kangown is attested twice (2.Sam.7.26 and Is.17.5) in the meaning 'standing'. It is not quite clear to me whether this is a case of accidental homonymy or originally one lexeme. If kangown 'cubit' is to be connected with NP kang 'wing, arm (from the fingertips to the shoulder)' it is difficult to understand the semantic transfer 'standing, upright', so we may consider a derivation from an otherwise extinct verbal stem (kangnel 'stand' is clearly a denominative of kangown). If we are dealing with an inherited word the best candidate may be the active or middle participle of the root continued in Gk. κιχάνω 'reach' < *-n̥u̯-ō (root *g̑ʰeh₁-, cf. also κίχημι, Skt. jahāti 'goes forth' etc.), i.e. -angown < *-n̥u̯-ont- or *-n̥u̯omǝ₁-no-, though the initial k- is troublesome. For the semantic linking 'reach' ➝ 'stretch, be upright', cf. the expression i kangown ownel 'far, eseguir puntualmente' (Ciakciak 748)."}]
Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: From Classical Armenian kangnem 'to raise, lift up; get up, rise again', further root etymology uncertain, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):607, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):381 for various proposals. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kang-(u)n-].

Source: 740[I:452];180[62{Arm. bir 'rod, staff, stave', but be derived from a root *berH- (IEW 134), also attested in Lith. bárti 'schelten', Gk. φαρόω 'plough', Lat. forāre 'pierce'.}];141[80{Cf. s.v. *bʰerH- 'mit scharfem Werkzeug bearbeiten' (IEW 133-5).}]
Justification: To be derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):62, see which for a discussion of the possible stem formations in Armenian; cf. also [HAB](src-740) I:452, [LIV²](src-141) 80).

Source: 79[502-503{S.v. Arm. net 'arrow'| Middle Armenian netem 'to throw (an arrow, etc.)', derived from PIE *nedo- 'reed', cf. Skt. naḍá- 'reed' ManMPers n'y, Pahl. n'd 'reed, cane| tube, flute, clarion'| Parth. nd 'pipe, flute| cane, rod'.}];180[84{Arm. net 'arrow, dart' is apparently cognate with Skt. naḍá- 'Schilfrohr, Rohr', nādī́- 'Pfeife, Röhre, Flöte, Ader', Hitt. nata- and nati- 'Schlifrohr, Trinkrohr| Pfeil'.}]
Justification: It is difficult to decide whether the Armenian forms continue PIE *nedih₂- or reflects *nēdih₂- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):84), cf. also [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):502-503 who reconstructs *ned-o-.

Comment: Uncertain origin. Formerly connected with Goth. dags 'day', Skt. dáhati 'burns', LIth. dagà 'heat of the Sun', etc; the latter, however, go back to PIE *dʰegʷʰ-, which is incompatible with the Armenian development.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian takʿ 'warm, hot'. Of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:391). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), [Olsen 1999](src-180). [MM: Proto-Armenian *takʰ-i-].

Source: 79[231-232, 237-238{Arm. dełin 'yellow' is probably related to dalar 'green, fresh' and dalukn 'jaundice'. This is usually compared to Greek θάλλω 'to bloom, flourish, grow'. In this case Arm. dalar would be directly cognate with Greek θαλερός, which may be accounted for via *dʰl̥h₁-ro-.}];319[118-120{Cf. under §4.18 *dʰal(e)- (*dʰ(e)h₂l(h₁)-) 'sprout, be fresh, green' for a thorough philological and etymological discussion of the Armenian and Greek forms.}];141[132{Reconstructs for Gk. θάλλω, etc. *dʰalh₁- (cf. IEW 234).}];180[51{Derived from Armenian deł 'herb| drug, medicine| eye-salve, resin| ink', traditionally related to Gk. θαλερός, etc.}]
Justification: Armenian lexemes generally connected to the family of Greek θάλλω 'to bloom, flourish, grow' ([Clackson 1994](src-319):118-120, [Olsen 1999](src-180):51, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):231-232, 237-238). The PIE root reconstruction *dʰalh₁- for this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 132.

Source: 172[II:628{S.v. Ved. śā́khā- 'Ast, Zweig', to which the Iranic vocabulary are possibly connected: cf. MPers. šāk, NPers. šāx 'Zweig', MSogd. šnx, Wakhi šolx 'Zweig'.}];399[III:321-322{S.v. Skt. śā́khā- 'Ast, Zweig' / 'branch'. Not to be separated from MPers., NPers. šāḫ-, Arm. čʻax, 'Zweig, Ahorn', Goth. hōha 'Pflug', Lith. šakà 'Ast, Zweig', Russ. sochá 'Hakenpflug', Pol. socha 'Gabelholz' etc., however not all the details of this connection are fully clear. The initial correspondence of Ved. ś- ~ Ir. š- is irregular (expected **s- in Iranic).}];269[{For lack of a better solution for the problems of phonological reconstruction among the proposed IE cognates, I reconstruct Proto-Iranian *šāxā- for the root ref. form in this set.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes, often assumed to be connected with Vedic śákhā- 'limb, branch', although the correspondence of the word-initial sibilants is inexact. Only a reconstructed Proto-Iranic root reference form has therefore been given here, but cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:321-322, [EWAia](src-172) II:628 with further discussion.

Source: 345[399-400{S.v. TochB pärkare* 'long'. The Tocharian forms reflect a Proto-Tocharian form as if from PIE *bʰr̥g̑ʰ-ró- (cf. Hitt. parkuš, Arm. barjr, 'tall', Skt. br̥hant-, Av. bərəzant- 'tall', Khot. bulysa- 'long').}];320[299{S.v. Khot. bulysa- 'long', to Av. bərəzant- 'high', BSogd. βrzʾk, βrz 'long', Waxī vərz, vorz 'long', Pašto ūẓ̌d, etc., from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ-.}];323[8{S.v. Pashto uğd, from Ir. *br̥za- (Av. ba/ərəz- 'high', Khot. bulysa- 'long').}];172[II:232{Cf. s.v. Ved. br̥hánt- 'groß, umfänglich, reichlich, erhaben, hoch, kräftig, weit, dicht, laut' (YAv. bərəzaṇt- 'hochragend, hoch, laut', Oss. bærzond 'hoch', MP, NP buland 'hoch, groß'), from PIE *bʰr̥g̑ʰ-ént-.}]
Justification: Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'be(come) tall, raise oneself' ([Adams 2013](src-345):399-400, [EWAia](src-172) II:232, [Bailey 1979](src-320):299, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):8, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 78-79, [NIL](src-274) 30).

Source: 567[285{Bactrian þουο < *srū(-kā)- (cf. Av. srū-, MPers. srū 'nail, horn').}];172[II:653{Cf. notes s.v. Ved. śŕ̥ṇga- 'Horn' (as though) from PIE *k̑r̥-n-g⁽ʷ⁾o-. Iranian forms (Av. srū-, Khot. ṣū, MPers. srū, NPers. surū) likely belong to the same basic root *k̑er- as the basis of other 'head' and 'horn' words found in Indo-European, but with an alternative morphological derivation *k̑r-uH-. Cf. notes in Mayrhofer for further literature.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *k̑r-uH- to the same root *k̑er- underlying various derived lexemes in the meaning 'horn' ([EWAia](src-172) II:653, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):285, cf. 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457) for further etymological discussion).

Source: 141[257{Cf. s.v. PIE *h₂eh₁- 'heiß sein' (not in IEW).}];331[I:318-324{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *ātr-, *ātar- 'огонь' and derivatives, from PIE *āter-/*ātr- (cf. Lat. āter 'черный, темный'), based on an IE root *ā- or *ai- 'светить, гореть'.}];269[{Root reconstruction *h₂eh₁- follows LIV², cf. ESIJa for extensive discussion of the Iranian forms from this root. PIE *h₂eh₁- is probably related to the root *h₂eh₁s- in [cognate set 178](cog-178) with an s-extension of the root.}]

105[133-134{S.v. gjeth 'foliage, green leaves', from Proto-Albanian *gadza with an irregular devoicing in Auslaut, or with a secondary th-suffix. Etymologically connected with OHG questa 'tuft', ON kvistr 'branch', Slav. *gvozdь 'wood, forest'.}];369[187-188{S.v. gjéth/e, -ja 'Laub'. The formal comparison to OHG questa, MHG quast, 'Laubbüschel', Serb. gvȍzd 'Wald' is phonologically unobjectionable, therefore possibly from PIE *gu̯osd(o)-. On the irregular devoicing in final position, cf. discussion s.v. djáthë, dríthë.}];130[69{With PIE *gu̯os-d- (IEW 480).}];571[69{S.v. Alb. gjeth 'leaf, blade'| since [Jokl 1912](src-750):204 generally connected with SC gvozd 'wood', OHG questa 'leaf mold'.}]
Justification: Albanian lexemes to be compared with OHG questa 'tuft', Serbian gvȍzd 'forest' and derived from PIE *gu̯osd(o)- ([Jokl 1912](src-750):204, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):69, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):187-188, [Orel 1998](src-105):133-134, [Holm 2011](src-130):69).

Source: 320[400-401{S.v. Khot. śśära- 'good'}];172[II:665-666, 669-670{Cf. s.v. Ved. śrī́- 'Schönheit, Glanz, Pracht, Herrlichkeit', in Iranic cf. Khot. śśära- 'gut', Sogd. šyr- 'gut' (< *ćrīra-), Pašto ṣ̌ə 'gut', Orm. šir 'gut', etc., from PIE *k̑ríH- (cf. Ved. √śray- 'vollkommen machen, glänzen machen' to PIE *k̑rei̯H-, cf. Gk. κρείων, κρέων (epithet of kings and heroes), εὐρυ-κρείων 'weithin Glanz habend').}];323[98{S.v. Pashto x̌ə 'good', cf. Av. sraiiah- 'more beautiful', Skt. śreyas-, Sogd. šyʾtr 'better, more excellent'.}];141[337{Cf. s.v. *k̑rei̯H- 'sich auszeichnen, vortrefflich sein' (IEW 618).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑rei̯H- 'to excel, be excellent' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):400-401, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):98, [EWAia](src-172) II:665-666, II:669-670, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 337).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron quš-ən 'hear' from *vi-gauš-. Same root as 'ear'. Cf. Avestan gaoš- 'listen'.}];83[115-116{S.v. Proto-Iranian gauš- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Skt. ghoṣ- 'to sound'). Cognate forms outside of IIr. are not attested.}];141[200{Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s- '(Geräusche) hören' (IEW 454).  Only Indo-Iranian (cf. Ved. ghóṣati 'ertönt, hört')| PIE reconstruction uncertain.}];172[I:518-519{Cf. s.v. ghoṣ- 'klingen, ertönen, ertönen machen' (cf. Ir. *(-)gauš 'hören' in MPers. niyō(x)šidan, NPers. niyōšīdan, Parth. nγwš, Baluči niγōšaγ, Oss. qūsyn, etc.). The IE origins of PIIr. *gʰau̯š- '(ein Getön) hören' are not securely determined.}];156[I:316-317{S.v. qūs | ǧos.}];567[237{Bactrian ναγαυ-/ναγατο < Proto-Iranian *ni-gauša-/ni-gušta- (cf. Sogd. nγwš/nγwšt).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([Cheung 2007](src-83):115-116, [EWAia](src-172) I:518-519; [LIV²](src-141) 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).

Source: 323[57{S.v. Pashto nund, more commonly lund 'wet'. Most dialects show dissimilations, cf. Phl naft, Sogd. nβtyy, Av. napta- 'damp', Pers. nam 'moisture', Sogd. nmb 'dew' < *namba-, √*nab-, IE *nebh-.}];274[499-504{S.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV 448, IEW 315f., EIEC 110, 477).}]

83[198{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *(H)spar(H)ǰ- 'to break, burst open (of plants), ?release (sound), bloom, blossom, sprout', from PIE *sperh₂g- 'to crack, burst open, sprout'? (cf. Skt. sphūrj- 'to rumble, roar, thunder, crash| to burst forth', Lith. sprógti 'to burst| to open, blossom out', Lith. spùrgas 'sprout, offshoot, bud', Lat. spargō 'I scatter, sow, spread', OE spranca 'twig').}];321[315{S.v. Wa. sprəɣ̌ 'цветок', from Old Iranic *spr̥γ(a)-, cf. Av. sparəγa- 'побег, росток', Khot. spätaa- 'цветок', Oss. sparga-  'отпрыск, лоза' Budd.Sogd. ’sprymk 'цветок’, Khot. haspalgy- 'цвести’ (*fra-sparjaya- < *fra-sparg-, Man.Sogd. 'sprxs- 'цвести’, Parth. wyspryxt (ppp.) 'распустившийся'.}];141[586{Cf. s.v. *spʰerh₂g- 'zischen, prasseln' (IEW 996-7).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾erh₂g- 'to hiss, crackle'(?) (cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):315, [Cheung 2007](src-83):198, [LIV²](src-141) 586).

Comment: Could skarəna- be derived from *kʷelh₁-? *s-kr̩H-na- > skarna-
Justification: No certain etymology. [Bartholomae 1899](src-799):199 proposed a preform *skʰr̥̄na- as a na-participle to a putative Indo-Iranic root *skʰr̥̄-, and suggested a root-etymology to Ancient Greek σφαῖρα 'ball' (repeated in [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):1587). This would require the reconstruction of a phoneme *kʷʰ to account for Av. -k- = Gk. -φ-, but such a phoneme is no longer posited for Proto-Indo-European.

Source: 50[385{From Proto-Celtic torrV- 'belly'.  "MoBret. teur 'belly' seems to come from *tar- with the lengthened grade, but I find it probable, in the absence of a PIE etymology, that these words were borrowed from some non-IE language (cf., however, Pokorny 1024)."}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Celtic ([Matasović 2009](src-50):385). For older proposals, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1024.
Loanword from Arabic قلب / qalb 'heart'.
Parallel loans from Old Turkic arqa.

Source: 83[151{Cf. s.v. PIr. *hu̯ar- (5) ‘to paint, colour| to stain’ > NP xvāl ‘soot, lamp-black’ (< *hu̯ar-da- ?). To PIE *su̯er- (*su̯or-) ‘to darken, make dark, stain’ ?}]
Comment: "to darken, make dark, stain"; consider Turkic kül "ashes", but it is not clear whether Turkic #k can be rendered by Iranic #x (maybe via *q). Kurdish ɫ / ḷ point however to *rd/rz (if not secondary), which would make a derivation from *xwṛta- "consumed" possible. However, the Kurdish vowels point to a historically long vowel (if not loan). Cf. Classic New Persian xwāl "soot (for the production of ink)" < xwārϑa- "substance for colouring" (taken from Rastorgueva/Edelman 2007: 481, Etymological Dictionary of Iranian languages, hu̯ar- „smear“). Note, however, LIV p.609 *su̯el- "schwelen, brennen", which would be equally good.

Source: 172[II:542{S.v. Skt. vā́ta- 'Wind, Windgott' (cf. IIr. in OAv. vāta- 'wind', YAv. vāta- 'wind', Khot. bāta-, Parth. w'd, MPers. wād, NPers. bād, etc.), from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁-n̥t-o- to √*h₂u̯eh₁- (cf. Lat. ventus, Goth. winds, etc.).}]
Comment: lit. "to make wind"
