Justification: Iranic lexemes in light verb constructions, literally 'to make wind'. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:542 and 'wind' in [cognate set 342](cog-342) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Digor χelagɜ 'snake' is a present participle from χel‑un 'crawl', i.e. lit. 'crawler'. χelun is from *khairya‑ cf. Old Indic khelati 'move around'. This word also exists in Iron as χilag, but is not a Swadesh term.}];156[IV:201{S.v. xīlag (xīlæg) | xelagæ 'змея', a participle to the verb xīlyn | xelun 'crawl', cf. Skt. khelati, etc.}]
Justification: A participle to the Ossetic verb xīlyn | xelun 'to crawl'. Further connected to Sanskrit khelati by [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:201, but the etymology of the compared Sanskrit verb is difficult to ascertain (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:312 and cross-references). Ossetic xīlyn | xelun is not listed in [Cheung 2007](src-83).

Comment: unclear why Parthian bāšēd is sorted into this set (TJ)

Source: 363[II:494-495{S.v. Kurd. xwē 'соль', from PIr. *hwā̆d-, PIIr. *su̯ad-, cf. Ved. svad-.}];172[II:788-789{Cf. s.v. Ved. √svad- 'schmackhaft machen, (Med.) schmackhaft werden, schmecken', from which is derived the inherited word svādú-. From PIE *su̯ad- (~ TochA swār, B swāre 'süß' < *su̯ad-ro-).}];141[606-607{Cf. s.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (IEW 1039-40).}];274[670-675{Cf. s.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (LIV 606f., IEW 1039f.).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *hu̯ad- 'to become, make savoury, pleasant', further to PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:494-495, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):141, [EWAia](src-172) II:788-789, [NIL](src-274) 670-675, [LIV²](src-141) 606-607).

Source: 50[300{S.v. Proto-Celtic *org-o- 'to destroy', from PIE *h₃erg- 'to perish' (LIV² 301| cf. IEW 819 *perg-).}];141[301{S.v. *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (not in IEW).  Cf. Hitt. ḫarakzi, ḫarkanzi 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen' < root aorist *h₃érg-/h₃r̥g-, Hitt. ḫarnikzi, ḫarninkanzi 'vernichten', Arm. harkanem 'schlage' < nasal-infix pres. *h₃r̥-né/n-g-.}];296[O:30{Cf. s.v. org- 'tuer, détruire, ravager' with references to older literature.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₃erg- ([LIV²](src-141) 301, [Matasović 2009](src-50):300), formerly reconstructed as *perg- ([IEW](src-49) 819, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:30).

Source: 50[180{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷis-o- 'to see', from PIE *kʷei̯s- 'to perceive' (cf. Av. cinahmi 'determine', Lat. cūra 'anxiety, care').}];141[381-382{S.v. *kʷei̯s- 'auf etwas achten, wahrnehmen' (IEW 637).}];304[431-434{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷis-e/o- 'sehen', from PIE *kʷei̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 381f., [IEW](src-49) 637).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kʷis-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE *kʷei̯s- 'to perceive' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):431-434, [Matasović 2009](src-50):180, [LIV²](src-141) 381-382).

Comment: cf. *kauč- “to bend, draw into, contract”, which is possibly reflected in Abyānei köta/kuǰ- “to gnaw” (Cheung 2007: 249)

Source: 172[I:764-766{Cf. s.v. Ved. √sthā- 'stehen, dastehen, still stehen, verweilen' (OAv., YAv. xšta-, YAv. hišta- 'stehen'| paiti-stā- 'Standort'), from PIE *steh₂- (cf. Gk. ἵστημι, Lat. sistere, status 'stellen', OHG stān 'stehen', Lith. stóti 'sich hinstellen', Latv. stât 'stellen', OCS stati 'sich stellen, treten', Luw. ta- 'stehen, zum Stehen kommen').}];141[590-592{Cf. s.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (IEW 1004-1008).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *steh₂- 'to stand', cf. Vedic stā́na- 'place for standing' ([EWAia](src-172) II:764-766, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 590-592).

Source: 66[1269-1270{S.v. AGk. ῥάβδος 'twig, rod, staff, magic wand| line, stripe, groove'.  Analysed as a root *ῥαβ- + suffix -δο- the word has been compared with Lith. vir̃bas 'twig, rod', Rus. верба (OCS връба) 'willow' from a zero-grade fromation *u̯r̥b-, and Lat. uerbera '(rods for) punishment', uerbēnae 'twigs of the laurel' from the full-grade *u̯erb-. "However, in view of the variants ῥάμνος and ῥαπίς, we can be certain that the word is Pre-Greek".}];174[636-637];382[1200{S.v. SMG ραβδί, from AGk. ῥαβδίον, diminutive of ῥάβδος 'stick'.}];460[476{S.v. AGk. ῥάβδος 'Rute, Stab' > Tsakonian σ̌άμντα.}];270[964{S.v. ῥάβδος 'baguette, badine', probably related to ῥάμνος and ῥαπίς, usually connected to Lith. vir̃bas 'branche, baguette', etc., OCS vrъba, Ru. vérba 'osier' with a zero-grade, with an e-grade in Lat. uerbera 'verges, coups'.}]
Justification: Generally connected to Lith. vir̃bas 'twig, rod', Rus. верба (OCS връба) 'willow' from a zero-grade fromation *u̯r̥b-, and Lat. uerbera '(rods for) punishment', uerbēnae 'twigs of the laurel' from the full-grade *u̯erb- ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:636-637, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):964), but [Beekes 2010](src-66):1269-1270 is inclined to believe the word is of substratum origin.

Source: 83[119-121{S.v. Proto-Iranian *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take' (Av. grab- 'to grab, seize, take'), from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to grab, seize'  (cf. OCS grabiti 'to rob', Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'to rob').}];141[201{Cf. s.v. *grebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).}];172[I:505-507{S.v. Ved. √grabh-ⁱ 'ergreifen, nehmen, fassen, festhalten' (Av. gərəβnāiti 'gewinnt, erlangt'), from PIE (prob.) *gʰreb⁽ʰ⁾H- (cf. Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'rauben', Latv. grebt 'greifen', OCS grabiti 'rauben').}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take', further from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):119-121, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:505-507, [LIV²](src-141) 201).

Source: 323[61{Cf. s.v. Paš. poh 'aware, intelligent'| poha 'intelligence'. A loanword from Indic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442) no. 8699 prabhōdha- 'awakening, knowledge', Lhd *poh. Cf. poh-eğ- : poh-ed- denom. 'to understand'.}];442[491{Cf. s.v. 8699 Skt. prabōdha m. 'awakening' R., 'knowledge' Kāv. [√budh] (> L. *pōh → Psht. pōh ʻ understanding, wise ʼ NTS vii 104).}]
Comment: denominal word, cf. poh "aware, intelligent"
Justification: Denominal verb based on Pashto poh 'aware, intelligent', a loanword from Lahnda *poh- which in turn continues Old Indic prabodha- 'awakening, knowledge' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):491, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):491 no. 8699).

Source: 363[I:242-243{S.v. Kurd. čōk, čawōk, čōng, čōg 'колено', a loanword from Turkish čök 'id.'}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish čök 'knee' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:242-243).

Source: 141[218-219{S.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).}];80[485-486{S.v. Hitt. kue(n)- / kun- / kuu̯a(n)- 'to kill, to slay, to ruin', from PIE *gʷʰén-ti / *gʷʰn-énti (cf. Ved. han- / ghn- 'to strike, kill, slay', OCS ženǫ 'to pursue, hunt down', Lith. genù 'id'., Gk. θείνω 'to smite', Lat. de-fendō 'to keep off, defend').}];172[II:800-801{S.v. Ved. √han- 'schlagen, erschlagen, töten', from PIE *gʷʰen- (cf. Hitt. ku-(e)-en-zi, Gk. θεἰνω, etc.).}];83[224-225{S.v. Proto-Iranian *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' < PIE *gʷʰen-.}];568[261{Manichaean Bactrian ʾwjyd (past stem) 'to kill' from *awa-ǰata- (= MMPers./Parth. ʾwjd).}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 218-219, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):485-486, [EWAia](src-172) II:800-801, [Cheung 2007](src-83):224-225).
Adjective derived from the common Iranic word for 'stone, rock', cf. Old Persian aϑanga-, Avestan asan- 'stone' in [cognate set 1179](cog-1179).

Source: 363[II:75{S.v. Kurd. pirc̑ 'волосы, ворс, пух', cf. Av. parša-, Ved. parṣa- (Kurd. -rc̑- ~ Av. -rša-).}];172[II:101{Cf. s.v. Ved. parṣá- (only RV 10.48.7) 'Garbe (von Ähren), Bündel' (cf. YAv. parša- 'Getreideähre, Ähre', further connections unclear.}];399[II:230{S.v. Skt. parṣá- 'Garbe (von Ähren), Bündel', 'sheaf, bundle', cf. Av. parša- 'Getreideähre'. Further is unclear, comparison with Arm. her 'hair', Lat. jūni-perus 'Wacholder', OE fyrs 'Stechginster', OCS proso 'Hirse', etc. do not bring any clarification.}]
Justification: Cf. Vedic parṣá- 'sheaf, bundle', Young Avestan parša- ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:75), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:101, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:230 for various uncertain proposals).

Source: 47[1176];358[218-219{S.v. OPers. nai̯ba- 'schön, gut'| Iran. *nai̯ba-, perhaps to be derived from PIE *noi̯bʰo- like OIr. noíb 'heilig'.}]
Comment: Buck (1949: 1176f.) derives this word from "*noi-bho- from the root seen in Ir[ish] niam ‘brilliance’, Lat. nitēre ‘shine, glitter’.” For the inner-Iranic development with extension nai̯u̯aka- and accent shift see Klingenschmitt (2000: 212f.).

Justification: This is obviously a complex predicate with an element 'war' + light verb "to do". 'war' could mean "there" (< *awáϑra) and 'kawǝl' in the sense of "put" (cf. German 'hineintun' : "to put in"). Cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):89 and [Cheung 2007](src-83):238 s.v. Proto-Iranic *kar- 'to do, make' > Pashto kawəl (< PIE *kʷer- 'to do, make').

Source: 681[33-34{S.v. Khw. βrk 'fruit', from *baraka- as Sogd. βrʾk, βryy.}];764[201{S.v. Khw. βrk 'Frucht' [< *baraka-, sgd. βrʾk, βryy]}];331[2:100{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *¹bar- < PIE *bʰer-, derived noun *baraka- 'результат, плод' > Sogd. βrʾk, Man. βryy, Khw. βrk 'плод, фрукт'.}]
Comment: probably derived from verb "bar" : "to carry"
Justification: Iranic lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry', as though via Proto-Iranic *baraka- ([ESIJa](src-331) 2:100, cf. [Henning 1971](src-681):33-34, [Benzing 1983](src-764):201).

Source: 338[{ræzæ is a Digor isolate}];156[II:398-399{S.v. ræzæ 'плоды, фрукты, овощи', from Proto-Iranian *raza‑, cf. Persian raz 'vine', "Kurdish" räz, rez 'garden', Old Persian *raza‑ 'vineyard', also not to be separated from Avestan razura‑ 'wood, grove', further from PIE *reg̑-.}]
Justification: Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to [IEW](src-49) 855, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:398-399, [LIV²](src-141) 304-305).

Source: 83[429-432{S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' (cf. Pamphylian Greek ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Gk. ὄχος 'car', Lat. vehō 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride', Lith. vežù 'I ride, procure', OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).}];172[II:535-537{Cf. s.v. Ved. √vah- 'fahren, Wagen lenken, Wagen ziehen, herbeiführen, befördern, bringen' < PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ-.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive', further to PIE *u̯eg̑- 'to ride, drive' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):429-432, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:535-537, [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).

Source: 325[76{"Sok[olova] (Gen.[=1967] 164) suggests a possible derivation < lE *ḱei- 'dark, black' (Av. syāva-), but W[akhi] x̌ǝt, S[an]gl[echi] šǝt/ṭ points to it being a migratory word, < lA ?"}]

Justification: Loan from Arabic أرض / ˀarḍ ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:50-51)

Source: 172[II:114-115{S.v. Ved. pāṁsú- 'Staub, Sand, zerbröckelnde Erde'. Further connections outside of Indo-Iranian are problematic, possibly to *pē-n-s- beside *pēs- in OCS pěsъkъ.}];657[499{Cf. s.v. SAND ?*pē(n)s- (OCS pěsŭkŭ 'dust', SCr. piejèsak 'dust', Av. pąsnu- 'dust', OInd. pāṃsú- 'crumbling soil, sand, dust'). The Indo-Iranian forms may have been *pām/nsnu- while the Slavic forms lack a nasal. The Slavic accentuation points to *ē and not *eh₁-. The long *ē of *pēns- points to a root noun.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes probably continuing PIE ?*pē(n)s- ([EIEC](src-657) 499, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:114-115).

Source: 141[609{S.v. 2. ?*su̯el- '(ver)schlucken' (IEW 1045). Only attested in Iranian, perhaps also in Germanic through enlarged *su̯el-gʰ- in OHG sweigan 'verschlucken', etc. cf. n1.}];83[147-150{S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar¹ 'consume, eat'. The root is probably secondary to Proto-Iranian *hu̯ar³ 'to take'. Further IE connections are uncertain and postulating a PIE root *su̯el- (as in LIV², IEW) is probably unwarranted.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):147-150, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 609).

Source: 141[305-306{Cf. s.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].}];83[188{Cf. s.v. PIr. HraiH- 'to defecate' "The Ir. cognate root fo Skt. rayⁱ has become an euphemism for 'to defecate', [...].", from PIE *h(3)reiH- 'to flow, stream' (cf. Gk. ὀρίνω 'bring in commotion, confuse', Lat rīvus 'brook', OIr. rían 'river, sea', Ru. réjat' 'to stream fast, flow', etc.).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *HraiH- 'to defecate', further to PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to stream, flow' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):188, [LIV²](src-141) 305-306).

Source: 321[285{S.v. Wa. pыṣ̌ : poṣ̌t- 'рыть, копать', cf. Tadj. dial. (gor.) pošidan 'копать, раскапывать', Khow. paṣ̌iman, paṣ̌ik, Yid. paš- : pašč- 'копать'.}]
Justification: No Indo-European etymology or loan source has been proposed.

Source: 680[116{S.v. Khw. myθ 'day' = Sgd. C myθ, Šγn. mēθ < *maiθā- (cf. Av. maēθā- 'change, evolution').}];325[45-46{S.v. Shughni mēθ (Sarikoli maθ) 'day', from Proto-Iranic *maiθā- (cf. Av. maēθa- 'unstable, vacillating' > 'interchanging (with the night??)'.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *mai̯θā-, cf. Avestan maēθā- 'change, evolution' ([Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):45-46, [MacKenzie 1990](src-680):116).

Source: 172[I:240{Cf. s.v. Ved. ū́dhan- 'Kälte', IIr. cf. OAv. aodərəš-čā '(und) vor Kälte', YAv. aodra 'durch Kälte'. "Im weiteren ist ū́dhan- / av. aodº wohl nicht von jav. aota- 'kalt' […] zu trennen."}]
Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia I 240) assume a relation with OInd. ū́dhan- "coldness".
Justification: A connection with Vedic ū́dhan- 'coldness' is assumed by [EWAia](src-172) I:240, but further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear.

Source: 141[153{S.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8)}];83[55-56{S.v. Proto-Iranic *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe| to swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen', OCS dъmǫ 'blase').}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):55-56, [EWAia](src-172) I:775, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 153).

Source: 344[384{cf. "Av. saēni- 'top, peak'"}];172[II:627{Cf. s.v. Ved. √śā- 'schärfen, wetzen' < PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- cf. Arm. sowr 'scharf', Lat. cōs, cōt- 'Wetzstein', catus 'scharf, scharfsinnig' etc. For the expanded -i̯- (beside *k̑eh₃-, *k̑h₃- in Ved. śā- : śi-tá-, Lat. cō-t- : ca-tus, cf. the reflexes in Iranic like Av. saēni- 'spitz' and outside of Indo-Iranic forms like Old Norse hein 'Wetzstein'.}];141[319-320{Cf. s.v. *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'schärfen' (IEW 541-2).}];156[III:199-200{Cf. s.v. Oss. synæg | sinæk, sinæg 'грудь, бок', from Iranian *sainaka-, cf. Pers., Taj. sīna, Pehl. sēnak, Bel. sīnag, Kurd. sīnk, sīng, Av. saēni- 'вышуклый'}]
Comment: original meaning "to sharpen" via "peak" > "breast, chest"
Justification: Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *sainaka- (cf. Avestan saēni- 'top, peak'), ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' via an intermediate sense 'peak; protuberance, top part' ([Korn 2005](src-344):384, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:199-200, [EWAia](src-172) II:627, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 319-320).

Source: 172[II:487-488{S.v. vákṣas- n. 'Brust'.  Etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Of uncertain etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:487-488).

Source: 172[II:116{Cf. s.v. Ved. pā́jas- 'ein Teil des Körpers', related to Iranian forms via Proto-Iranian *pādzah- 'surface' (YAv. *pāzah- in pāzaŋᵛhaṇt-, Khot. pāsya-, Oss. faz/fazæ). The Indo-Iranian forms probably go back to PIE *peh₂g̑- (cf. Lat. pāgina 'side, leaf of paper', Gk. εὐ-πηγής 'well-built' < *'having a nicer side').}];567[250-251{Bactrian παζο 'front (of the body), breast, face' < Proto-Iranian *pāzah- (cf. Sogd. pʾz, Khot. pāysa-, Ved. pājas-).}];320[229-230{Cf. s.v. pāysa- 'surface' connected to *pag̑- (IEW 787-788).}];141[461{As a verbal root, cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes probably reflecting derivatives from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):229-230, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):250-251, [EWAia](src-172) II:116, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 461).

Kurdish lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *raxša- ({ref Cabolov 2001–2010) II:193-194), further connected to Proto-Indo-Iranic *raktá- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:424-425, [Cheung 2007](src-83):313-314).

Source: 363[137 (2010){"Сравн. тюрк. qap 'хватать ртом, зубами', 'кусать' [Радлов, 11, 404]| перс. qāp zadaп, qapıdaп 'хватать', 'схватывать', 'выхватывать'. В.И.Абаев [ИЭС, 1, 627] объясняет осет. kʾæрр kænyn 'цапнуть'' 'щелкнуть' как звукоподражание, объединяемое с тюркским словом звукосимволической природой (отметим, однако, закономерное соответствие осетинского kʾ тюркскому q в заимствованиях из тюркского). Сравн. тж. рус. хапать, укр. хапати 'хватать', болг. хапвам 'кусаю', чеш. chapac 'хватать' и некоторые другие индо-европейские формы, рассматриваемые как продолжение и.-е. *khар- [Фасмер, IV, 222]."}]
Comment: The q-forms make a loan from Turkic likely (cf. kapmak 'to snatch'). Abaev (apud Cabolov) suggestes an onomatopoetic formation and Vasmer (apud Cabolov) noted Slavic verbs like Ukrainian хапати 'to grab, snatch' considering them a continuation of a PIE root *khap-. On this see also Cheung (2007: 234f.) *kop-.
Justification: Etymology unclear. Inheritance of an Indo-European root *kap- (mechanically reconstructed to *keh₂p- in LIV with reflexes principally in Greek, Latin and Germanic) or a tentative Iranic-Slavic *kʰap- has been proposed, but the role of sound-symbolism cannot be securely addressed. Some of the forms in q- are most probably loans from Persian. Loans from Turkic are also assumed, but Edel'man considers the resemblance coincidental as many of the languages in question have no historic contacts with Turkic languages. A very early Turkic loan seems chronologically implausible.

Source: 748[213 fn. 79{"(zu lit. kélti 'auf-, emporheben')"}];141[349]
323[47{S.v. Paš. loy 'big, large, great' "A derivation < Av hu-δāta- 'well-created, -built' is semantically unsatisfactory. [< *dahāka- acc. to Skjærvø 1989, 398.] Cf. Lodi s.v. ¹lo."}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):47 for further discussion. For proposed connections to Wakhi lup and Indic and Nurstani lexemes, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):227.

Source: 321[227{S.v. Wa. lap 'большой, взрослый, много'. A word evidently of expressive origin. "Очевидно, экспрессивная основа звукоизобразительной природы, типа широко распространенной lap ~ 'лопо-’ (см. lар°), ср. в тадж. говорах: бад. lumbuk ’толстяк’, кар. lum(b), дарв. lum(b) ‘большой’, ’огромный’, 'много’, а также в памирских языках: ишк. lip, шугн., руш., хуф., барт., рош., язг. lap ‘очень’, ‘много’, 'большой’. Сюда же, возможно, cap. lεwr, lawr (EVSh 42: ?) и афг. loy, luy| ср. еще кхов. lott 'большой' (Grierson. Piśāca 72), паш., гав., вот. lau, lou ‘много’ (< bahura-? CDIAL 9193), башг. ōla, ашк. aulú, кати al ‘большой’ (< *āpula- CDIAL 1211)| талыш. lap ‘очень’, ‘совсем’."}]
Justification: No etymology given in Morgenstierne (1974:48); onomatopoeic according to [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):227. Possible comparanda given by [ESIJa](src-331): V: 74.

Source: 344[295 fn. 61{"The etymology is not clear yet. The only words which have been considered as possible cognates are NP lambar "bottom" and Gurani lam "belly" (Geiger 1890:134). However, the connection is questionable (note that Kurdish lam means "cheek")."}]
Comment: Cf. Semitic *lib-/lub- "heart"; *lap "spleen, liver, heart"

Source: 442[55{S.v. 1211 *āpula 'abundant'. 2. *āpura -- [Cf. pula- 'extended, wide' lex., vipula-].}];172[II:557-558{Cf. s.v. Ved. vipula- adj. 'umfangreich, ausgedehnt, groß', without certain etymological explanation.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic *āpula- 'abundant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):55, no. 1211), cf. Vedic vipula- 'extended, wide'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:557-558).

Comment: Past. Part. used as adjective 'good'

Source: 66[1324{S.v. σήπομαι 'to rot, become rotten', from PIE *Ki̯eh₂p- (vel sim.). The Greek-internal ablaut variation σηπ- ~ σαπ- points to a root reconstruction *tueh₂p-, *tieh₂p- or *kieh₂p- ([LIV²](src-141) reconstructs *Ki̯eh₂p-), but no cognates are known.}];141[361{S.v. ?*Ki̯eh₂p- 'verfaulen' (Not in IEW).}];382[1244{S.v. σάπιος, derived from σαπίζω, a secondary present stem backformed from aorist ἐσάπην to Ancient Greek σήπομαι 'to rot'.}]
Justification: Internal reconstruction points to a root *tu̯eh₂p-, *ti̯eh₂p- or *⁽k̑⁾i̯eh₂p- ([LIV²](src-141) 361 reconstructs *Ki̯eh₂p-), but no cognates are known outside of Greek ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1324).

Source: 321[267{S.v. prič 'червь', 'гусеница'.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes denoting 'worm', possibly from Proto-Indo-European *per- 'pierce, pass through', a derivation paralleled by Ancient Greek τερηδών 'boring worm' from *terh₁- 'bore, rub', cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320): 239. Another possibility would be a connection with Indo-Iranic lexemes meaning 'flea, noxious insect', Vedic plúṣi, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321): 267 for further references.

Source: 141[536-537{S.v. *ses- 'ruhen, schlafen' (IEW —).}];80[746-747{S.v. Hitt. šeš- / šaš- 'to sleep, to rest, to lie down', from PIE *sés-ti, *ss-énti (cf. Skt. sas- 'to sleep', Av. hah- 'to sleep').}];172[II:716-717{S.v. Ved. √sas- 'schlafen', from PIE *ses- (cf. Hitt. še-eš-zi 'schläft', Luv. šašša- 'schlafen').}]
Justification: Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *ses- 'to sleep' ([LIV²](src-141) 536-537, [EWAia](src-172) II:716-717, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):746-747).

Source: 305[316{MW deifyaw, Bret. deviñ, MCo. dewy, dywy < *dau-i̯e/o-| not cognate with MW de 'burning, warm, fervent', 3sg. 'burns, inflames| grieves'.   }];141[133-134{Cf. s.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' (IEW 240-1). ?MW deifyaw listed as a possible derivative to the it. stem *dʰogʷʰ-éi̯e-, but acknowledges that this assignment is uncertain in fn4, noting the argument of Schrijver (1995:316) connecting this form to *deh₂u̯-.}];50[92-93{Matasović presents contradictory etymologies for the Brythonic forms under different lemmata. Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic daw-yo- 'kindle, burn' > MW deifyaw, MBret. devo 'burn', dev 'burned' to be connected to PIE *deh₂u̯-, but s.v. Proto-Celtic *degʷi- 'flame, blaze' (derived to PIE *dʰegʷʰ-) W deifio 'burn' is derived to PCelt. *degʷ-ye-.}];296[D:8-9{Cf. OIr. daig 'flamme, feu, incendie', cites older literature concerning the etymologies of the Goidelic and Brittonic words and opts for an etymology for W deifio, Br. deuiff, Co. dewi from PIE  from *deh₂u̯-, thus connecting Goidelic forms (cf. OIr. dó-) and and Brittonic forms to the same root.}];269[{Root etymology disputed. Either to *deh₂u̯- in [cognate set 8388](cog-8388) (so Vendryes et al. 1959-1996, Schrijver 1995:316), or *dʰegʷʰ- in [cognate set 368](cog-368) (tentatively LIV²)| Matasović (2009:92-93) gives both etymologies under different lemmata.}];309[180{Cf. s.v. Dev (adj.) 'brûlé', to a Celtic root *deb-, cf. devo (v.) 'brûler' attested in Old Breton in past part. deuuet-, identical to Cornish dywy and Gaulish deifio.}]
Justification: Indo-European root etymology disputed. Either to *deh₂u̯- in [cognate set 8388](cog-8388) (so [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:8-9, [Schrijver 1995](src-305):316), or *dʰegʷʰ- in [cognate set 368](cog-368) (tentatively [LIV²](src-141) 133-134). [Matasović 2009](src-50):92-93 gives both etymologies under different lemmata. Cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):180.

Source: 364[978{S.v. Alb. jep 'geben', likely a causative formation *h₁op-éi̯e/o- from the root *h₁ep- 'fassen, ergreifen' (LIV² 237), cf. also Demiraj (1997:79), Orel (1998:157).}];141[237{Cf. s.v. *h₁ep- 'fassen, ergreifen' (IEW 50-1).}];105[157];369[79];130[64];80[614-616{Cf. s.v. Hitt. pai- / pi- 'to give, to pay, to grant, to hand over'. Kloekhorst prefers to split the Anatolian lexemes from Tocharian and Greek (αἴνυμαι), instead setting up a derived form *h₁p-ói̯-ei̯/*h₁p-i̯-énti, in comparison to Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'to take, seize'.}]
Justification: Generally derived from PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):79, [Orel 1998](src-105):157, [Holm 2011](src-130):64, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):978, [LIV²](src-141) 237); perhaps further connected to Anatolian lexemes in [cognate set 7598](cog-7598) if the etymology of [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 is correct, but this remains disputed (cf. notes in that class).

Source: 105[100{S.v. Alb. flok (pl. flokë) 'hair', borrowed from Lat. floccus 'lock, flock'.}];130[65{Borrowing from Lat. or Rom. floc(cus).}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin or Romance floc(cus) ([Orel 1998](src-105):100, [Holm 2011](src-130):65).

Source: 105[189{S.v. Alb. kokë 'head, bulb, berry, grain'. A loanword from Lat. coccum 'berry'.}];130[65-66{Loan from VLat. coccum 'berry' (so Orel 1998:189).}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin coccum 'berry' ([Orel 1998](src-105):189, [Holm 2011](src-130):65-66).

Source: 141[402-403{S.v. *lei̯d- '(los)lassen' (IEW 666).}];54[350-351{S.v. Lat. lūdō, -ere 'to play, sport', from PIE *loid- 'to let go frequently, play' (cf. MIr. laídid 'impels', Gk. λίνδεσθαι 'to contend' (Hesych.), λίζει 'plays' (Hesych.), Alb. lind 'gives birth', lindet 'is born' < *li-n-d-, OLith. léidmi 'I let', Lith. láidyti 'to throw', Latv. laîst 'let, publish, set in motion').}]
Justification: Root etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 402, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):350-351 to PIE *lei̯d- 'set in motion'.

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri lʹu  NF.  Root.  [OIA. lata-:- ‘creeper’  T. 10928.1 (+)]}];442[633{Cf. s.v. 10928 latā- (1) f. 'creeper' Mn. 2. latikā- f. 'slender creeper'. [Cf. *laṭṭa- 2?]}];399[III:88{S.v. Skt. latā f. 'Schlingpflanze, Schlinggewächs' / 'creeper', etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though continuing Old Indic latā- 'creeper, vine' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):633 no. 10928). Further etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) III:88).

Source: 431[{Cf. s.v. Kâmviri źaňʹa  [-i fem]  Aj.  Red| orange| brown.  [PrAr. *ǰhʹar-i- ‘golden| yellow’  T. 13981 (whence ň?)]}];172[II:805-806{Cf. s.v. Gk. χλωρός 'pale green, green-yellow', OHG gelo 'yellow', Lith. žélti 'to flourish, turn green').}];442[809{Cf. s.v. 13981 Ved. hári- 'golden, yellow' RV., 'green' lex.}]
Justification: According to [Strand 1998](src-431) to be connected with Vedic hári- 'golden, yellow' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):809 no. 13981). If so, further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'.

Source: 431[{Cf. s.v. Kâmviri âgʹol  NSb.  Rain. [OIA. a-kâla- ‘out of time| unseasonable’  T. 11 (modern compound| -T. 1977.2 *ud-ghâla- 'pouring out')]}];442[1, 92{Cf. s.v. 11 akāla- 'out of time' MBh., m. 'wrong time', 1977 *udghāra- 'pouring out'. 2. *udghāla- . [√ghr̥- (1)]}]

Source: 432[{S.v. pamʹařuk  Aj.  Small. [OIA. manʹâk ‘a little’  T. 9824 (+| or < T. 9825 mʹanu- 'man')].}];269[{Etymology unclear, cf. entry in Strand's kâtʹa vari lexicon (Strand 2011a) suggesting either to Skt. manāk 'a little, slightly, to a small degree' [cf. [cognate set 8402](cog-8402)] or to Skt. mánu- 'man'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Strand 2011a](src-432).

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri bâbʹista  NAnF.  Snake.  [pa-büm-ta-], cf. bʹüm  NSb.  Earth| ground.  [büm-]  [OIA. bhʹu:-man- ‘earth| world’  T. 9556]}];442[545{Cf. s.v. 9556 Ved. bhūman n. 'earth, world' RV. [√bhū]}]

Justification: According to [Strand 1998](src-431) from *pa-büm-sta- where Kâmviri büm 'earth' < Vedic bhūman- 'earth, world' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):545 no. 9556).

OAv. skǝṇdō probably 'Beschädigung', YAv. skǝṇdō 'Gebrechen, Körperschaden', further connections uncertain.}]

431[{Cf. s.v. Kâmviri ǰʹukuř, ǰʹukuřo/oa˜ obl.  NHF.  Woman.  [ǰü-kuřa-], cf. ǰʹü  NKF.  Daughter [OIA. duhitʹr̥- ‘daughter’  T. 6481].}];442[370{Cf. s.v. 6481 Ved. duhitŕ̥- f. 'daughter' RV.}];172[I:737-738{Cf. s.v. Ved. duhitár- 'Tochter', from PIE *dʰugh₂tér- (cf. Gk. θυγάτηρ, TochB tkācer, A ckācar, Lyc. kbatra, Arm. dowstr, Osc. futír, NHG Tochter, Lith. duktė̃, OCS dъšti, etc.).}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes for 'woman', continuing compounds containing the word for 'daughter' (cf. Kâmviri ǰʹü 'daughter'), continuing PIE *dʰugh₂ter- 'daughter' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):370 no. 6481, [EWAia](src-172) I:737-738).

Source: 442[622{S.v. 10761 Skt. rucaka- 'pleasing, sharp, acid' W., m. 'natron, sochal salt' lex. [rucá- ʻ bright ʼ VS. - √ruc] (> Ash. ẓōk, žōk 'salt', Wg. wřūk, Kt. ẓuk, Pr. užúx: NTS ii 288.)}];172[{Cf. s.v. Ved. √roc- 'leuchten, scheinen, glänzen', from PIE *leu̯k- 'leuchten' (cf. Gk. λευκός 'light, white', etc.).}];141[418-419{Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though from Indic rucaka- 'pleasing, sharp, acid', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č- 'to shine' and further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):622 no. 10761, [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Continuing derivatives of Indo-Iranic *gʰaná- 'compact, firm, dense', cf. Sanskrit ghaná- 'id.' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):239 no. 4424). Perhaps further to a root *gʷʰen- 'to swell' (tentatively suggested by [EWAia](src-172) I:184-185, I:512, not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 442[384{Cf. s.v. 6724 Ved. dhánu- (2) (dhanū́- AV.) f. 'dry land', dhánvan- (2) m. 'desert' RV.}];172[I:774{Cf. s.v. Ved. dhánvan- 'Wüste, Steppe, trockenes Land, Strand'| no certain etymology.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. Ved. dhánu- 'dry land', dhánvan- 'desert'(?) ([EWAia](src-172) I:774, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):384 no. 6724)

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri gâǰʹâr  NF.  Daytime| day.  [gârešᴺvorᴺ]  (cf. Kâta-vari garǰʹor.), cf. Kâmviri gârʹeš  NF.  Midday.  [gârešᴺ]  [OIA. ghar-asya- ‘sun's heat’  T. 4440]}];442[239{Cf. s.v. 4440 Skt. *gharasya- 'sun's heat' [√ghr̥-] > Ash. gerés 'midday', Kt. gəríš, Wg. garaš, ˚riš.}];172[I:513{Cf. s.v. Ved. gharmá- 'Glut, Hitze, Wärme' < PIE *gʷor-mó- (cf. Lat. formus 'warm' (~ *gʷʰer-mó- > Gk. θερμός) to PIE *gʷʰer- 'brennen, heiß sein'.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes derived from a base *gharasya- 'sun's heat' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):239 no. 4440), ultimately to PIE *gʷer- 'to become warm' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:513, [NIL](src-274) 196-199, [LIV²](src-141) 219-220).

Source: 442[310{S.v. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'. 2. *ḍaṅga- 2. 3. ḍaṅgara- 2 'expression of contempt' lex. (→ Psht. Orm. ḍaṅgar ʻ lean ʼ IIFL i 393, NTS ii 255). 4. *ḍikka- 2. 5. *ḍiṅga- 2. 6. ḍiṅgara- m. 'rogue, servant' lex. 7. *ḍēṅga- 2. 8. *ḍhagga- . 9. *ḍhaṅkha- . 10. *ḍhiṅka- 2. 11. *dhaṅga- . 12. *dhiṅga-.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though from Indic *ḍagga- (2) 'defective' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):310 no. 5524).

Source: 105[314-315{S.v. Alb. pemë 'fruit-tree, fruit', borrowed from Lat. pōmum 'fruit', pōmus 'fruit-tree'.}];130[85-86{Loan from Lat. pōmum.}];585[326{S.v. Alb. pemε 'Obst, Obstbaum, Baum', borrowed from Lat. pōmum, cf. Rum. pom 'Obstbaum, Baum'.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):326, [Orel 1998](src-105):314, [Holm 2011](src-130):85-86).

Source: 397[530-531{S.v. NHG Kopf (MHG kopf 'Trinkgefaß, Hirnschale', OHG kopf, kupf 'Becher', MLG kop), just as OE cuppe 'Becher', ON koppr 'Geschirr in Becherform, kleines Schiff' an early loan from Lat. cūpa, cuppa 'Becher'. For the semantics, cf. similarly the development of Fr. tête < Lat. testa 'aus Ton gebranntes Gefäß, Scherbe' which replaced the inherited form from Lat. caput 'head'.}]
Justification:
Germanic lexemes continuing an early loan into West Germanic from Latin cūpa, cuppa 'cup, bowl'. For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Romance: Fr. tête 'head' < Lat. testa 'earthenware vessel, tile, sherd, vessel' in [cognate set 3171](cog-3171).
The loan event is taken here as so early that it would have introduced e lexeme into a very early form of Continental West Germanic, before these three lineages (standard German , Luxembourgish and Bernese) diverged from each other, so this is not a parallel loan.  Only these three would then have made the semantic shift to the 'head' meaning, whether in parallel or still at the stage of a later, narrower common ancestor of theirs.  That this shift is not yet recorded in our Middle High German list, however, supports the idea of parallel semantic shift, but after an original non-parallel loan to enter the Germanic lexicon (with an originally different meaning).

Source: 172[II:120-121{S.v. Ved. pāpá- 'schlimm, übel, böse', an Indo-Iranian word if YAv. pāpa- 'übel' is attested in the compound pāpō.vačah-. The origin of Ved. pāpá- is uncertain.}];442[456{S.v. 8092 Ved. pāpá- (pā́pa- ŚBr.) 'wicked' RV., n. 'evil, sin' AV., pā́paka- adj. and n. ŚBr.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:120-121).

Source: 69[536{S.v. Nep. narāmro adj. 'bad, evil, ill| ugly' [cmpd. na and rāmro].}];442[615{Cf. s.v. 10636 Skt. ramyà 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ŚBr. [√ram].}];172[II:435-436{Cf. s.v. Ved. √ram- 'zur Ruhe kommen, stillsehen, ausruhen, rasten', from PIE *h₁rem- (cf. Gk. ἠρέμα 'ruhig, sanft', Goth. rimis 'Ruhe', Lith. rãmas 'Ruhe', rìmti 'ruhig werden').}];141[252-253{Cf. s.v. *h₁rem- 'ruhig werden' (IEW 864).}]
Justification: Negative compound as though from Sanskrit na- 'not' + rāma- 'good, pleasant', cf. RV su-rā́ma- ([Turner 1931](src-69):536, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):615, no. 10636). Further to Skt. √ram- from PIE *h₁rem- 'become calm' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:435-436).

Source: 338[{Digor isolate. Probably a W. Caucasian loanword (only Digor, not proto‑Ossetic).}]
Comment: Loan from West Caucasian

Comment: Loan from Sanskrit, cf. Vedic nā́raka-/nāraká-, Pali naraka-
Not in Turner 1962–1966; possibly related to Skt. vana- 'tree; timber' (Turner no. 11258)?

Source: 105[42-43{S.v. Alb. burrë 'man, husband', a borrowing from OHG gibūro 'peasant, villager' with simplification of the initial cluster *gb- > *b-. Other possibilities have been proposed by other scholars.}];130[70-71{Rejects the suggestion of a OHG loanword by Orel (1998:42-43) and the earlier attempts to connect to *bʰer- by Huld (1984:46-47) and other earlier scholars. The suggestion of Demiraj (1997:113-114) to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to be, thrive, dwell' is better formally, but remains semantically doubtful.}];571[46-47{S.v. Alb. burrë, -i 'man, husband', possibly to *bʰərno- (PIE *bʰer-), but the gemination of -rr- in the word is difficult to account for.}];369[113-114{S.v. Alb. búrr/ë -i 'Mann, Ehemann, Gatte'. Since the original meaning is disputed, the etymology remains uncertain. Against the suggestion to *bʰerno-, Meyer's older comparison to Germanic words (NHG Bauer) to *bʰeu̯ə- (*bʰeu̯h₂-, *bʰuh₂-, *bʰh₂u-) formally has no difficulties.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):46-47, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):113-114, [Orel 1998](src-105):42-43, [Holm 2011](src-130):70-71 for various suggestions and discussion.

Source: 105[391{S.v. Alb. rrumbull 'rolled into a ball', borrowed from Rom. rombulus, based on Lat. rhombus 'magic whirligig or wheel' (cf. Ital. dial. rummulu, rumbulu).}];130[76{Loanword, either from Lat. r(h)ombu > Tosk rrum(p), or via Rmc. rombulus > rrumbull 'rolled into a ball' (so Orel 1998:391), or alternatively directly from Gk. ῥύμβος 'Kreisel/top, gyro'?}]
Justification: Loanword, but precise source uncertain. Either from Romance rombulus or from Greek ῥύμβος.

Source: 105[36-37{S.v. Alb. bri ~ brî 'horn', from Proto-Albanian *brina. According to Orel, related to Messap. βρένδον· ἔλαφον| βρέντιον· ἡ κεφαλὴ τοῦ ἐλάφρου (Hes., Et. Magn.), Swed. brind 'deer', Latv. briêdis 'elk', OPruss. brayadis 'id.' (cf. Meyer Wb. 48).}];585[48];369[110-111{S.v. Alb. bri, ri-, -u 'Horn'. The exact stem formations remain disputed, but generally connected with Ved. bhrū́- 'Braue, Augenbraue', Gk. ὀφρῦς 'Braue, erhöhter Rand', ultimately from the root noun *bʰruH- (IEW 172), with semantic development *'brow', *'eyelash' > 'horn'.}];130[67{Many explanations, but generally connected to PIE *h₃bʰreu̯H- 'eyebrow' with differing explanations of stem-formation.}]
Justification: Generally connected with PIE *h₃bʰreu̯H- 'eyebrow' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):67, [Holm 2011](src-130):67), cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):48, [Orel 1998](src-105):36-37 for a more tenuous comparison to a Messapic gloss in Hesychius and the Etymologicum Magnum.

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 442[253{S.v. 4675 *cappayati 'chews'. [Onom., cf. Pa. capucapukāra- 'making the sound of chewing', cf. cárvati]}]
Justification: Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *cappayati 'chews', imitative of the sound of chewing ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):253, no.4675). Cf. cf. Pāli capucapukāra- ʻmaking the sound of chewing'. No further etymology outside of Indic

Source: 442[732{S.v. 12625 Skt. śoṇita- 'blood' Gr̥Śr. | with ending -ita- by analogy to lohita- 'blood', cf. 12623 Ved. śóṇa- (1) 'red, crimson| purple'.}];172[II:656-657{S.v. Ved. śóṇa- adj., 'rot, hochrot' (RV+), śóṇita- n. "nach r/lóhita- umgebildet", from PIE *k̑óu̯-no- 'leuchtend', cf. TochA koṃ, TochB 'Tag, Sonne' Welsh cun 'lieblich'.}]
Justification: From Sanskrit śoṇita- 'blood' created to Vedic śóṇa- 'red, crimson; purple' with the suffix -ita- on analogy to Sanskrit lohita- 'blood' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):732 no. 12625), further from PIE *k̑óu̯-no- 'shining' ([EWAia](src-172) II:656-657).

Source: 399[I:146{Cf. s.v. Skt. káṇṭakaḥ 'Dorn, Stachel / thorn, sting', also kaṇṭaḥ, m. 'id.'. Etymology uncertain.}];442[131-132{S.v. 2670 *kaṇṭa- (3) 'backbone, podex, penis' 2. *kaṇḍa-, 3. *karaṇḍa-, 4. (Cf. *kāṭa- 2. *ḍākka- 2: poss. same as káṇṭa- (1) 'thorn' [no. 2668]]}]
Justification: Derived from Indic *kaṇṭa- (3) 'backbone, podex, penis' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):131-132, no. 2670). Perhaps identical with Skt. kaṇṭa- 'thorn' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):131, no. 2668), of uncertain further etymology (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:146).

Source: 442[275{S.v. 5014 *chātti 'chest, breast'.}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):275, no. 5014; no further etymology.

Source: 141[130{S.v. *du̯ei̯- 'in Furcht geraten, erschrecken' (IEW 227-228).  Armenian root aorist erkeaw from *du̯éi̯–/du̯i-, present erknčʻim < *du̯i-sk̑e-.  Greek δείδω, δείδιμεν, Luw. pres. kuwaya- from perfect stem *de-du̯ói̯-/du̯i-.}];66[308{S.v. Gk. δείδω 'to fear', from PIE *duei- 'fear' (cf. Avestan duuaēθā 'threat' and, with an s-extension, Sanskrit dvéṣṭi '(s)he hates').}];79[268{Cf. s.v. erkn 'labour pains, pang (of childbirth), fear, grief, sorrow', erknčʻim 'to fear' (aor. erkeay), generally connected with Gk. δέος 'fear', δείδω 'to fear', Lat. dīrus 'fearful', Skt. dveṣṭi 'to hate', Av. duuaēθā 'threat', MPers. bēš- 'grief, sorrow, enmity', etc., derivatives from PIE *du̯ei̯- 'to fear'.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, and Armenian lexemes from PIE *du̯ei̯- 'to fear, be afraid' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):308, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):268). For the inclusion of Luvian k(u)u̯ai̯a- in this class, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 130.

Source: 442[535{S.v. 9407 bhaluha- m. 'dog', bhallūka- 2 m. lex. (Si. ballā < *baluvā)}];399[II:483{S.v. Skt. bhaluhaḥ 'Hund / dog' (Lex.). Unexplained.}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *baluvā-, cf. Sanskrit baluha- only attested by lexicographers ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):535, no. 9407). Further etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) II:483).

Continuing Sanskrit vikala- 'deprived of a part or a limb or a member, mutilated, maimed, crippled, impaired, imperfect'. Probably originally a compound of kalā- 'small part' + vi- 'away from', but further etymology obscure ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):678, no. 11623, [EWAia](src-172) II:552, I:321-322, [KEWA](src-399) III:201-202).

Comment: Loan from Dravidian

Source: 399[II:67{S.v. Skt. dolā 'Schaukel, Sänfte', 'swing, litter'. In view of ā̆n-dol° and hindolaḥ a loan from a prefixing (prob. Austroasiatic) language is very likely.}];442[375{S.v. 6582 Skt. dōla- 'swinging' > M. ḍoḷā m. 'eye'}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit dōla- 'swinging' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) no. 6582). Further etymology less certain, but probably a loanword from an Austroasiatic language (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:67 for further discussion).

Comment: Cf.  Turner 1962–1966 no. 11356 vartáyati 'causes to turn, whirls' RV. > Si. vaṭanavā tr. 'to turn round' (can this be a later semantic shift > 'to fall'???)

Source: 172[II:244{Cf. s.v. Ved. bhadrá- 'glückverheißend, glücklich, erfreulich' (Ind. cf. Pā, bhadda- 'glücklich', Ir. cf. YAv. hu-baδra- 'sehr glücklich'). The derivation of IIr. *bʰadrá- from PIE *bʰn̥d-ró- can hardly be doubted (cf. probably Goth. batista 'bester').}];141[75{Cf. s.v. ?*bʰend- 'glücklich sein, sich freuen' (IEW 126-7), Pres. *bʰénd-e- > Ved. bhandate 'fühlt sich glücklich'. Only Indo-Iranian, cf. Ved. bhadrá- 'glückverheißend', YAv. hu-baδra- 'sehr glücklich', if not to also be connected with Goth. batiza 'besser', etc.}];442[533, 535{S.v. 9377 Ved. bhadrá- (1) 'fortunate, delightful' RV. and s.v. 9408 Skt.  bhalla- (1) 'auspicious' lex. [< *bhadla- ~ bhadrá-].}];697[118-119{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *batizan- 'besser'. No certain comparisons| Ved. bhadrá- 'günstig, glücklich, erfreulich', Av. hu-baδra- 'glücklich' are phonologically and semantically close.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic bhadrá- 'fortunate, delightful' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):533, no. 9377). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *bʰend- if connected with Germanic *batiza- 'better', but the comparison is uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:244, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):118-119, [LIV²](src-141) 75). For Assamese and Bengali, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):535 no. 9408.

Source: 79[552-556{S.v. Arm. ptuł 'fruit', put (1) 'poppy', put (3) 'a small swelling' and ptuk 'to bud, germinate'. Traditionally connected with PIE *bud- 'to swell' according to [HAB](src-740) IV:112.}];180[937{Arm. ptowł 'fruit', of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:112f., [IEW](src-49) 100).}];740[IV:112-113];276[{Origin uncertain. Traditionally connected with Proto-Germanic *buddǭ 'bud, seed-pod', which are both taken to reflect PIE *beu̯-d- 'to swell'.  Cf. also պտուկ ptuk (< *put-uk-) 'nipple| bud'.  The Germanic form, however, may also reflect PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'become| come to exist| grow' (cf. LIV²: 98), which is incompatible with the Armenian development.}]
Justification: Of unknown origin. Traditionally connected with Germanic *buddǭ 'bud, seed-pod' but the comparison is uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:112-113, [Olsen 1999](src-180):937, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):552-556 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pi/utuł-o-].

Continuing Sanskrit kāṣāyá- 'brownish red, dyed reddish' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):159 no. 3119), presumably a Vr̥ddhi-formation to Vedic kaṣāyá- 'red, dull red'. Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:332).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Digor zolk’æ 'worm' may be from PIr. *zaluka 'leech', cf. Persian zalū 'leech', but alternatively Turkic sülük etc. is the source of the Iranian words (Abaev believes it is the other way around). The latter looks more probable to me.}]

Comment: MBh.,cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7788
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5574 ?

Source: 399[III:162-163{Cf. s.v. Skt. valāhakaḥ 'Regenwolke, Gewitterwolke / rain-cloud, thunder-cloud'. Etymology unclear.}];442[665{Cf. s.v. 11411 Skt. valāhaká-, ba° m. 'thunder-cloud, cloud' MBh.}]
Justification: Derived from Sanskrit valāhaka- m. 'rain-cloud, thunder-cloud', further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):665, no. 11411, [KEWA](src-399) III:162-163).

Source: 172[I:523{S.v. Ved. √cakṣ- 'see, look at, observe' probably from PIE *kʷek̑- 'appear| see| show'.}];141[383-385{S.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-639).  Vedic cakṣ- reflects a desiderative form *kʷek̑-s- / *kʷək̑s-.  (NB: -ə- in the zero-grade form is schwa secundum.)}]
Justification: The Vedic root √cakṣ- is likely to have been an inner-Indo-Iranic reanalysis of an s-desiderative form of the root *kʷek̑- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:523, [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).

Source: 54[453{S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'breast, chest'. Originally a proto-Italic s-stem formation *pektos-.  The root is likely to be cognate with OIr. ucht < *puktu-, if from earlier *pektu-.}];50[130{S.v. Proto-Celtic *fextu- 'breast' < PIE *pektu- (IEW 792), cf. Lat. pectus 'chest'.}];296[U:14-15{S.v. OIr. ucht 'poitrine (de l'homme et des animaux)'. Older literature compares Latv. pups, Lith. pápas 'id.' from child language. Perhaps better would be to start from *pektu- (becoming *puktu-) and admit an Italo-Celtic origin of Ir. ucht and Lat. pectus. The two words do not have any other known correspondences.}];316[491{S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'poitrine de l'homme ou des animaux'. A similar word differing in -o- root vocalism and u-stem inflection is found in Irish ucht 'poitrine'. There are no other correspondences outside of these two languages.}]
Justification: Italic and Celtic lexemes generally assumed to continue earlier *pe⁽k̑⁾tu- 'chest', although the Celtic forms would appear to continue *pu⁽k̑⁾tu- with secondary *-u- vocalism in the lexical root (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):491, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):453, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:14-15, [Matasović 2009](src-50):130).

Source: 444[223{S.v. 2409 cuppa 'Becher', with derivative kopa(r) 'töten' in Lomb., Venez., Friaul.}];316[158-159{S.v. Lat. cuppa 'coupe'}];54[155{S.v. Lat. cūpa 'cask, tub, barrel' (variant cuppa). "Probably a non-IE loanword *kū̆p- which was borrowed by and from many languages. This explains, among others, the length of the ū̆."}]
Justification: Apparently a derivative of Latin cuppa 'cup, bowl' according to [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):223. Further etymology obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):158-159, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):155).

Comment: could this word be related to the verb var „zusammenhalten, einschließen, umhüllen, bedecken“? cf. EWAia II 512 , cf. Sanskrit vará- and derivations like varimán, várivas, all ≈ “Raum, Gebiet”

Justification: From Old Iranian čakāta- 'front part, forehead'(?), cf. Middle Persian čakāt, Persian čakād 'mountain peak', cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:257-258, [ESIJa](src-331) II:215-216.

Source: 442[437{S.v. 7736 Skt. pattralá- 'leafy' lex. 2. '*leaflike, thin'.}];172[II:71-72, 75-76{Cf. s.v. Ved. pátra- Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', derived from a heteroclitic *pat-r-/*pat-n- and cognate with Germ. Feder, Engl. feather, Old Welsh eterin 'bird', atan 'wing', etc., cf. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschießend fliegen, stürzen, fallen' from PIE *pet- (cf. Lat. petō, Gk. πέτομαι, etc.).}];141[476{Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing adjectival derivatives of Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather; leaf' in the sense 'leaflike, thin' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):437 no. 7736). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ([EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, 75-76, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 476, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 442[60{S.v. āruddha 'blocked' pp. of ā́ruṇaddhi RV.}];172[II:467{S.v. Ved. √rodh-¹ 'hemmen, hindern', probably related to IE *leu̯dʰ- (cf. Welsh arlludd 'obstacle', etc.).}];50[245{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *lowdo- 'obstacle' (MIr. lod 'fence'(?), MW lludd 'obstacle', MBret. luz 'obstacle', from PIE *lou̯dʰ-o- (cf. Skt. rudh- 'hinder', ródhas- 'obstacle').}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1324, s.v. āruddha- 'blocked', ppp. of ā́ruṇaddhi RV, rudh- 'grow'

Source: 50[54{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bando- 'peak, top', from PIE *bend- 'point, pin' (cf. OE pintel 'penis', Middle Low German pin, pinne 'pin, nail').}];296[B:35-36{S.v. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, montagneuse| pignon, pinacle, créneau| corne, pointe (de lance), crête (d'une coiffure)'}];157[66{S.v. Gaul. banna, benna 'pointe > sommet', cf. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, corne' (*bennā), W, Co., Bret. ban(n) 'id.' (*bannā). One may reconstruct a form *bn̥dno- which has correspondences only in Germanic. The alternation -an-/-en- of the reflex of the syllabic sonorant *n̥ is found elsewhere in Gaulish and is perhaps dialectal.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):54, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):66, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:35).

Source: 50[143{S.v. Proto-Celtic *fūro- 'fresh', from PIE *puh₂-ro- 'pure, clean' (cf. Lat. pūrus, Skt. pūtá- 'purified', pávate 'becomes clean', OHG fouwen 'to sieve, sift'. Generally the root is reconstructed as *peu̯H- 'purify' (cf. e.g. [LIV²](src-141) 480, [EWAia](src-172) II:105-106 s.v. Ved. pav-ⁱ). Matasović, however, suggests that the PIE root is presumably the same as *peh₂-u̯r̥- 'fire', so that the original meaning of putative *puh₂ro- would have been 'purified by fire'.}];296[U:26-27{S.v. OIr. úr 'frais, jeune, tendre', also in Brythonic (cf. W ir 'frais, vert, nouveau'. Connected by [Pedersen 1909](src-307):91 with Lat. pūrus, which is acceptable. Cf. entry for other proposals.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes generally connected to Lat. pūrus 'clean, pure, undefiled', Skt. pūtá- 'purified', etc. since [Pedersen 1909](src-307):91 (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:26-27, [Matasović 2009](src-50):143). The PIE root is now reconstructed as *peu̯H- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 480 s.v. 1.*peu̯H- 'reinigen, läutern'), but cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):143 who alternatively suggests a connection to PIE *peh₂-u̯r̥- 'fire' and with an original meaning 'purified by fire', but this proposal has not been widely accepted.

Source: 728[168{S.v. Manx fliaghey 'rain' = OIr. flechud.}]
Justification: Manx fliaghey continuing Old Irish flechud ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):168).

Source: 309[316{S.v. Bret. gwreg 'femme', corresponding to Co. gwrêk, W. gwraig, all from Celtic *urako-.}];240[76{S.v. OW gurehic 'female', cognate to W gwraig, OCo. grueg, greg, MBret. gruec, of uncertain origin.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Falileyev 2000](src-240):76); root ref. form follows [Deshayes 2003](src-309):316.

Source: 172[II:118{Cf. s.v. Vedic pāṇḍú- 'weißlich, gelb, weiß, bleich', further etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Continuing Vedic pā́ṇḍara- 'whitish-yellow, yellow, pale, white', a derivative of Vedic pāṇḍú- 'white, yellow, pale' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):454 no. 8047). Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:118).

Source: 50[167-168{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gremmen- 'seizure, grasp' (OIr. greimm 'seizure, grasp, profit, advantage, sway'), presupposing a stem *greb⁽ʰ⁾(h₂)-(s)men-. For the root *gʰreb(h₂)-, cf. Skt. grabh- 'seize', 3.sg.pres. gr̥bhṇā́ti, Lith. grė́biu, grė́bti 'snatch', OCS grabiti 'seize'.}];141[201{Cf. s.v. *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).}]
Justification: Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish greimm 'seizure, hold, grasp, profit, advantage, sway', ultimately nominal derivatives continuing Proto-Celtic *gremmen-, a derivative to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):167-168, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 201).

Source: 296[D:55-56{S.v. OIr. (1) derc 'œil' and 'lac', also 'ouverture, caverne' and 'tombe', 'fente (d'un vêtement)'. The same root apparently as in drech 'visage', *derk-.}];141[122{Cf. s.v. *derk̑- 'hinblicken, erblicken' (IEW 213).}];157[139-140{S.v. Gaul. derco- 'oeil'| the same word as in Insular Celtic (cf. OIr. derc 'oeil', from the root *derk- 'regarder'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *derk̑- 'to look at, catch sight of' ([Delamarre 2003](src-157):139-140, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:55-56, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 122).

Source: 231[371{S.v. ScG. tóit 'smoke, fume', cf. Ir. tóit, MIr. tutt 'smoke'.}];296[T:189{Cf. s.v. OIr. tút, túth 'odeur, puanteur', of uncertain etymology.}]
Justification: Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish tút, túth 'smell, stench' (cf. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):371). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:189 for references to an uncertain proposal to OHG stiuz.

Source: 728[31{S.v. Manx billey 'tree' (= Ir. bile).}];296[B:50-51{S.v. OIr. bile 'arbre'| etymology uncertain. The proposed connection with Lat. folium, Gk φύλλον is less satisfactory, cf. [IEW](src-49) 122.}];50[61{S.v. Proto-Celtic *belyo- 'tree', from PIE *bʰolh₃i̯o- (IEW 122, cf. Lat. folium, Gk. φύλλον).];157[75{S.v. Gaul. bilio- 'arbre', etymologies outside of Celtic are less convincing, but the existence of loanwords in French bille, billot, Provençal bilha 'tronc d'arbre' argue for the existence of a Gaulish pre-form *bili̯a.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; possibly further to IE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom, blossom' (so [IEW](src-49) 122, [Matasović 2009](src-50):61; cf. 'leaf' in [cognate set 252](cog-252), but rejected by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:50-51, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):75). The proposed connection with Latin folium 'leaf' is uncertain (cf. 'leaf' in [cognate set 8247](cog-8247)).

Source: 66[1386{S.v. σποδός 'ash, ember, metal ashes, dust'. If etymologically connected with ἄσβολος 'soot, dust of coals' and σπολεύς 'a kind of loaf', then σποδός would be a loan from a Pre-Greek substrate language.}];270[1040{S.v. σποδός 'braise, cendre, poussière', of obscure etymology.}];174[771{S.v. σποδός, etymology unexplained.}];460[507{Cf. s.v. AGk. σποδία 'Asche' > Tsakonian σποΐα (< *σποδίλα).}]
Justification: Tsakonian σποΐα, π̔οΐα from Ancient Greek σποδία 'ash' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):507). Further etymology outside of Greek obscure ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174):771, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1040, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1386).

Source: 66[7{S.v. ἀγαθός 'good, fit, noble'. Etymology uncertain. Older attempts to reconcile to Germanic words such as Goth. goϸs, NHG gut 'good', etc. are to be abandoned as these require a root *gʰedʰ-. [Pinault 1979](src-717):165-170 has attempted to derive the word from *mg̑ʰh₂-dʰh₁-o- 'make great' although the semantic development is difficult and the suffix *-dʰo- is rare. Alternatively [Beekes 1996](src-716) considers the word to be from a European substratum language.}];270[6{S.v. AGk. ἀγαθός 'bon'. The etymology is controversial and uncertain (cf. entry for various older hypotheses).}];717[165-170{Attempts to derive Gk. ἀγαθός from a reconstructed IE formation *mg̑ʰh₂-dʰh₁-o- 'make great'}];716[227-230{Argues for a possible loanword from a European substratum language.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):6, [Beekes 2010](src-66):7), cf. [Pinault 1979](src-717), [Beekes 1996](src-716) for competing hypotheses.

Source: 66[556{S.v. θρίξ 'hair'. No clear etymology| older proposals are unsatisfactory.}];270[441-442{S.v. AGk. θρίξ, τριχός 'cheveu, poil'. No etymology, very uncertain hypotheses in [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174).}];269[{Paradigmatic alternations N.sg. θρίξ [tʰríks], G.sg. τριχός [trikʰós], etc. presuppose a Proto-Greek stem *θριχ- which was subject to the Greek version of Graßmann's Law.}];174[I:684{S.v. AGk. θρίξ, τριχός 'Haar'| cf. for references to older literature and very uncertain proposed etymologies.}]
Justification: Stem alternation between, e.g., nominative singular θρίξ, genitive singular τριχός due to Graßmann's Law point to a Proto-Greek stem *tʰrikʰ-, but further connections outside of Greek are unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) I:684, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):441-442, [Beekes 2010](src-66):556).

Source: 270[211-212{S.v. γαστήρ: "On admet sans hésiter l'étymologie habituelle, de *γρασ-τήρ «dévoreur», tiré de γράω avec dissimilation des deux ρ"}];66[262{S.v. γαστήρ 'belly, paunch, womb'. Beekes is not convinced of the usual etymology assuming an agent noun in -τηρ formed to the room *gres- 'to eat, devour', on the basis of the semantics: "the belly is not an "eater"".}];141[192{Cf. s.v. *gres- 'fressen, verschlingen' (IEW 404). If the comparison with *gres- is correct, Ancient Greek γαστήρ would be cognate with verbs meaning 'devour' attested as an athematic root-present in (Anicient) Cypriot 2.sg.imper. γράσθι 'eat!' or thematised γράω 'gnaw, devour', Ved. grásate '(s)he devours'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek difficult; probably to IE *gres- (or *gras-) 'devour' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 192, [IEW](src-49) 404) with dissimilation of *-r- in the root from the suffix *-tēr- (so [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):211-212); but cf. the objections of [Beekes 2010](src-66):262.

Source: 141[186{S.v. *gem- 'drücken, zusammenpressen| fassen' (IEW 368-9).  Ancient Greek γέμω < pres.  *gém-e/o-.}];382[292{S.v. γεμάτος, from Medieval Greek γεμᾶτος 'full', in turn derived from Ancient Greek γέμω 'to be full'.}];66[265{S.v. γέμω 'to be full of' < ?*gem- 'take, seize'.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek γεμᾶτος 'full', a derivative of Ancient Greek γέμω 'to be full' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):292), further derived from PIE *gem- 'to press, press together' ([LIV²](src-141) 186, [Beekes 2010](src-66):265; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):215).

Source: 66[1559-1560{S.v. φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre'. No etymology| often compared with Lith. spingiù (spìngu), spingė́ti 'to give a weak light, glitter', OE spincan 'to spark', OHG funko 'spark', but the suggestion is formally impossible.}];382[1528{S.v. SMG φεγγάρι, from Medieval Greek φεγγαρίον, diminutive in -αριον, derived from Ancient Greek φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre'.}];270[1184-1185{Cf. s.v. AGk. φέγγος, -ους 'lumière, clarté, éclat', φέγγος vaguely resembles Lith. spingė́ti 'louire doucement', OE spincan 'jeter des étincelles' etc. for which [IEW](src-49) 989 reconstructs *speng-, but there are difficulties in reconciling the initial consonant cluster. Another hypothesis is an old blend of *σπεγγος with φάος (so [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174)). In sum, nothing clear or certain.}]
Justification: Modern Greek φεγγάρι from Medieval Greek φεγγαρίον, a diminutive in -αριον, derived from Ancient Greek φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1528). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1184-1185, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1559-1560).

Source: 66[1318-1319{S.v. σελήνη 'moon'. The different dialectal reflexes of Attic σελήνη, West Greek σελάνα, Lesbian σελάννα may be accounted for from Proto-Greek *selas-nā (cf. σέλας 'light, brightness'). No further etymology, although the nominal formation of may be compared to the PIE word for 'moon' *l(o)uksneh₂, as in Lat. lūna 'moon', etc.}];270[995{S.v. AGk. σελήνη 'lune' (Dor. -ᾱ́νᾱ, -ᾰ́ννᾱ), a derivative of σέλας with a derivational suffix in *-nā, cf. further s.v. σέλας, -αος 'éclat, lueur brillante'. Further etymology obscure, cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) for various older proposals.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes, originally from a derived adjective in *-nā to Ancient Greek σέλας 'light, brightness', i.e. Proto-Greek *selásnā- (cf. Lesbian σέλαννα 'moon'). Further etymology obscure ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):955, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1318-1319).

Source: 66[1501{S.v. τράχηλος 'neck, throat'. A Greek innovation, replacing inherited αὐχήν and δέρη. Possibly to τρέχω 'to run', but words for 'neck' typically denominated as 'turner, turn(ing)' (cf. OCS vratъ to vratiti 'turn', and perhaps also Lith. kãklas [to *kʷelh₁- 'turn'?] rather than 'runner'. Note [Furnée 1972](src-665):115 considers the suffix -ηλο- to be common in words of substratum origin, so a borrowing also cannot be ruled out.}];270[1130{S.v. AGk. τράχηλος 'cou, gorge', in contrast to δέρη and αὐχην 'nuque' probably a familiar and expressive creation in Greek. The connection with the family of τρέχω (Pedersen IF 5, 1895, 56, etc.) is the most plausible as 'part of the body that turns'. In many languages  the name of the neck is attached to the notion 'tourner' and 'roue', cf. OCS vratъ to vratiti 'tourner', Lith. kãklas apparently to Gk. κύκλος, etc.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes traditionally considered a derivation to the same root as Ancient Greek τρέχω 'to run' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1130), but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1501 considering this explanation semantically unconvincing, with aspects of the word formation also unclear from an IE point of view.

Source: 382[1343{S.v. στρογγυλός, from Ancient Greek στρογγύλος 'round, spherical'.}];66[1415{S.v. στρογγύλος 'round, spherical, compact'. A formation like γογγ-ύλος, καμπ-ύλος, ἀγκ-ύλος, etc., connected to στάγξ 'squeezed out drop' by [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), but the meanings of the two words are not obviously connected. Possibly of substratum origin in view of the suffix -υλ-.}];270[1064-1065{S.v. AGk. στρογγύλος 'rond, en forme de boule compact, courbe'| the same suffix also appears in γογγύλος, καμπύλος, ἀγκύλος, etc. The word originally signified 'mis en boule, serré', from which 'rond' from the same root as στράγξ with a different meaning 'trickle, drop'. The alternation in o / a vocalism may be seen in OHG strang.}];174[II:810-811{S.v. στρογγύλος 'rund, kugelförmig, gedrungen, kompakt'| a formation like γογγ-ύλος, καμπ-ύλος, ἀγκ-ύλος etc., as *'zusammengezogen, zusammengeballt, gedrungen' to Gk. στράγξ. Here στρογγύλος can contain an old o-grade as in NHG Strang or the -o- can be secondary after γογγ-ύλος.}]
Justification: Modern Greek forms from Ancient Greek στρογγύλος 'round, spherical' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1343). Generally connected to Ancient Greek στράγξ 'squeezed out drop' and further to OHG strang ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174): II:810-811, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1064-1065}), although the semantic connection within Greek not overly persuasive ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1415). Further etymology outside of Greek therefore uncertain.

Source: 66[827-828{S.v. AGk. λαλέω 'to talk, chat, prattle' (Att.) 'to speak' (Arist., Hell.), probably of onomatopoeic or imitative origin, cf. Lat. lallāre, Lith. lalúoti, Germ. lallen.}];270[615-616{S.v. AGk. λαλέω 'bavarder' (Att., etc.), 'parler' (Arist., Hellen., LXX, NT, etc.), an onomatopoeic form, cf. similarly Lat. lallō 'chanter pour endormir un enfant', Lith. lalúoti 'bégayer', Ru. lála 'bavard', etc.}]
Justification: A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):615-616, [Beekes 2010](src-66):827-828).

Source: 66[861{S.v. λίθος 'stone, boulder, rock, precious stones'. Etymology still unexplained.}];174[II:122{S.v. λίθος 'Stein, Steinblock, Gestein, Edelstein'. "Unerklärt." No convincing etymology has been yet proposed.}];270[640{S.v. λίθος 'pierre', etymology unknown.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:122, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):640, [Beekes 2010](src-66):861).

Source: 66[478{S.v. εὕδω, which is compounded with the preposition/preverb κατά 'down' in Attic. Several unconvincing suggestions: 1) related to Goth. sutis 'quiet, calm' and Lat. sūdus 'soft', 2) to IE *seu-d- beside *su-ep-, Skt. svapiti 'sleeps', etc. ([Benveniste 1935](src-720):156), or 3) to OE swodrian 'to sleep tight'.}];270[384{S.v. Gk. εὕδω 'dormir'. No etymology accepted by all, cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) for various proposals. The most ingenious and most probable proposal is that of [Benveniste 1935](src-720):156 who supposes *seu-d- next to *su-ep- of Skt. svapiti 'il dort'.}];174[585]
Justification: No consensus etymology; cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174):585, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):384, and [Beekes 2010](src-66):478 for various proposals.

Source: 165[71{S.v. Proto-Germanic *bōan- ~ *būan- 'to live, dwell', from PIE *bʰeh₂u-, with an assumed laryngeal metathesis from the weak stem *bʰh₂u-.}];141[98-101{S.v. *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen, werden' (IEW 146-50). On the formation of the Germanic stem in this class, cf. n31.}];556[124-126{S.v. Gmc. *bōww-a- 'wohnen, breiten', cf. for discussion of older literature. Generally agreed to be derived from PIE *bʰeu̯ə- 'werden, wachsen, sein' (cf. OCS iz-baviti 'retten, befreien, erlösen', Ved. bhāvayati 'bringt ins Dasein', a regularly formed causative stem).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bōan- ~ *būan- 'to live, dwell', further derived from PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, emerge, become' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):124-126, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):71, [LIV²](src-141) 98-101).

Source: 442[239{S.v. 4424 Skt. ghaná- (2) 'compact, firm, dense' Suśr., 'densely filled, deep (of sound or colour)' MBh. 2. n. 'any compact mass' ŚBr., m. 'cloud' MBh. [*han- 3]}]
172[II:764-765{Cf. s.v. Ved. √sthā- 'stehen, dastehen, still stehen, verweilen' < PIE *steh₂-.}];141[590-592{Cf. s.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (IEW 1004-8).}]
Justification: Nuristani forms refect Old Indic *ut-sthā-ti (-Strand).

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri dʹâ  N.  Mountain.  [dâ]  [OIA. dhʹâra-:- ‘edge| mountain edge’  T. 6793]}];442[389{S.v. 6793 dhā́rā- (2) f. 'sharp edge, rim, blade' RV., 'edge of mountain' lex.}];172[I:789{Cf. s.v. Ved. dhā́rā- 'Schneide (des Schwertes, Messers), Klinge' < IIr. *dʰārā- 'Klinge, Schneide' (cf. YAv. dārā- 'Klinge', tiži-dāra- 'mit scharfer Schneide', etc.).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'cutting edge' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):389 no. 6793, [Strand 1998](src-431), [EWAia](src-172) I:789).

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri mârʹaňiŋ  N.  Back of neck.  [mâraňaᴺi¹ᴺkᴺ]  [pâm'arařiŋ]  [OIA. maṇi- ‘hump| Adam's apple’  T. 9732 (?)]}];442[557{S.v. 9732 maṇi- (2) m. 'hump of camel' MBh., 'glans penis' Suśr., 'clitoris' lex., 'fleshy excrescence on a goat's neck' VarBr̥S., 'thyroid cartilege (= kaṇṭhamaṇi- ), wrist' lex., maṇika- m. 'globular formation of flesh on an animal's shoulder' AitBr., maṇilá- 'having fleshy excrescences (e.g. on the dewlap)' TS. [Semantic development is prob. 'protuberance – Adam's apple <-> throat, neck', hence connexion with mányā- and (despite EWA ii 557) with maṇí- 1 is unlikely]}];172[II:293-294{Cf. s.v. Ved. maṇi- 'am Hals getragener Schmuck', IIr. mani- < PIE *monh₂-i- (~ *moneh₂-) 'Hals' (cf. OHG mana 'Mähne' etc.).}];399[II:556-557{Cf. s.v. Skt. maṇi- 'am Halse getragener Schmuck, Perle, Edelstein, Juwel' / 'necklace, pearl, gem, jewel', to mányā- 'Hals, Nacken', cf. for discussion of proposals of a possible loanword origin.}]
Comment: Sanskrit maṇi- 'hump; Adam's apple' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):557 no. 9732), further considered as though from PIE *monh₂-i- (~ *moneh₂-) 'neck' by [EWAia](src-172) II:293-294 and connected with Vedic mányā- (cf. [cognate set 1728](cog-1728)), although this etymology is doubted by [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):557 no. 9732 on semantic grounds, cf. also discussion in [KEWA](src-399) II:556-557.
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though from *mârâṇik, denoting 'back of neck'. Probably not connected with Sanskrit maṇi- 'hump; Adam's apple'.

Source: 172[I:509{S.v. Ved. grīvā́- 'Nacken, Hinterhals' (YAv. grīuuā- 'Nacken (daēuuischer Wesen)'. IE probably *gʷriH-u̯eh₂- (cf. Russ. gríva 'Mähne, Bergrücken', grivьna 'Halsband, Gewicht, Geldstück', Latv. grĩva 'Flußmündung'| it is also difficult to separate from Gk. δέρη (Arc. δερϝα) 'Hals, Nacken'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes probably reflecting PIE *gʷriH-u̯eh₂- ([EWAia](src-172) I:509). It is difficult to isolate a further root etymology.

Comment: possibly related to Vedic (RV, AV) pavástam n. 'covering' (cf. Old Persian pavastā- f. 'skin, parchment'), cf. entries *pōta-, *pōtta- and *pōttha- 'cloth' (with variants) in Turner 1962-66, p. 477f., no. 8400, 8414

Source: 399[II:110{S.v. Skt. dhūliḥ 'Staub / dust'. Etymology uncertain, cf. entry for various proposals.}];442[391{S.v. 6835 *dhūḍi m., Skt. dhūli- f. 'dust, powder'.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though from Sanskrit dhūli-, Indic *dhūḍi- 'dust, powder' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):391 no. 6835), further etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) II:110).

Source: 442[409{S.v. nikaṭam, °ṭē, °ṭāt adv. 'near' R. [Cf. supplementary note in DSAL Online (http://dsalsrv02.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/contextualize.pl?p.2.soas.559220): Despite EWA ii 158 derivation with P. Tedesco JAOS 65, 161 f. from nikr̥ṣṭa -- is phonet. impossible, and Mu. origin with F. B. J. Kuiper Debrunner -- Festschrift 247 unlikely. Derived from nikr̥ta -- adverbially preserving the mng. ʻ *put at ʼ (semant. cf. saṁnihita -- ʻ near ʼ) afterwards replaced by ʻ put down, humbled ʼ (J.C.W.)]}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 409, no. 7136 s.v. nikaṭam vel sim. adv. 'near' R.

Source: 442[328{S.v. 5762 Skt. tānáyati 'makes stretch' Dhātup. [√tan].}];172[I:618-619{S.v. Ved. √tan-¹ 'spannen, dehnen, sich erstrecken, ausdehnen', from PIE *ten- (cf. Gk. τείνω 'spanne', Lat. tendō 'spanne', OHG den(n)en, NHG dehnen, etc.).}];141[626-627{S.v. *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6).}];364[985{S.v. OAlb. nden 'ausbreiten, ausstrecken', originally early Albanian *ten-i̯e/o- (to *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen', LIV² 626f.) with a preverb *an-. The basic stem formation is comparable to AGk. τείνω.}];105[283{S.v. Alb. ndej ~ ndêj 'to stretch out, spread', continuing PAlb. en-tenja and related to Gk. τείνω 'to stretch', Skt. tanóti 'to expand', OHG denen 'to stretch' and other reflexes of IE *ten-.}];369[284-285{S.v. Alb. nde/j (t.) / ndẽj (g.) 'ziehen, spannen| ausstrecken, ausbreiten'| cf. secondary (dial. south Tosk, Arb. Gr./It.) ndë(n)j 'id.', intr. 'gehen nach, (um)ziehen nach' with dialectally restricted darkening of the root vowel. Generally connected with Greek τείνω via a -i̯o- stem formation *teni̯o-.}]
Justification: Albanian and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *ten- 'to stretch' ([LIV²](src-141) 626-627, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):284-285, [Orel 1998](src-105):283, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):985, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):328 no. 5762, [EWAia](src-172) I:618-619).

Source: 141[431{Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).}];442[594{S.v. 10292 Skt. mr̥dú 'soft' VS., 'weak' AV., 'slow' MBh. [√mr̥d].}];529[{PIE verbs *mel-d- and *mel-dʰ- are two different derivatives of PIE *mel- 'soft' - compare Proto.Germanic *meldi- 'mild' etc., note 1 of *mel-dʰ- (LIV 431)}];172[372-373, 386-387{S.v. Ved. mr̥dú- 'zart, schwach, mild, weich', from PIE *(h₂)ml̥d-ú- (cf. Gk. βλαδύς 'schwach', ἀμαλδύνω 'zerstöre, schwäche', Lat. mollis 'weich, sanft' (< *moldu-i-), to Ved. √mrad- 'sanft machen, weich machen'.}]
Comment: Vedic mr̥dú- 'soft' (VS), 'weak' (AV), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10292

Source: 50[345{S.v. Proto-Celtic *slattā 'stalk, staff' "This could easily be a loanword from some non-IE language of NW Europe. Both the geminate and the a-vocalism testify to a foreign origin. The same source may have been the origin of the Germanic words such as OHG latta 'plank' (but note the absence of the initial *s-)."}];296[S:127-128{S.v. OIr. slat (1) 'tige, baguette, verge', the same word also in Brythonic (W llath 'baguette, tige, canne à pêche', from Proto-Celtic *slattā, which only has a possible correspondence in Germanic (OHG latta 'planche, latte', MHG lade 'planche', OE lætt 'id.'), but the consonantal correspondences are difficult. Perhaps the Germanic words are loans from Celtic.}]
Justification: From Proto-Celtic *slattā; further connections outside of Celtic are difficult (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:127-128, [Matasović 2009](src-50):345).

Source: 165[95{S.v. Proto-Germanic *digra- 'big', "An adjective apparently continuing *dʰi⁽g̑⁾ʰ-ro-. It may have been derived from *dī̆gan- 'to knead' (q.v.), which would imply a more primary meaning 'well-formed'."}];697[156-157{S.v. Gmc. *digra- 'dick, voll', probably related to the strong verb *diga- 'kneten', in which case the meaning 'dick, voll' would have originated from 'festgeformt'.}];556[151-152{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *dig-a- 'kneten', with adjective *dig-ra- (OIc. digr 'dick'), with certainty to be derived from the common IE verbal root *dʰei̯g̑ʰ- (cf. Lat. fingō, -ere 'kneten, formeln, streicheln', OIr. com-od-ding 'bauen, errichten' Gk. θιγγάνω [aor. ἔθιγον] 'berühren, umrühren, sich mit etwas fassen', etc.).}];274[118-119{S.v. *dʰei̯g̑ʰ- 'bestreichen, kneten' (LIV 140f., IEW 244f.). Proto-Germanic *digra- 'dick, voll' in, e.g., ON digra 'dick, stark' < *dʰig̑ʰ-ró-.}]

165[404{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rak(k)an- '(sleuth) dog'. This n-stem has no certain etymology, but might be related to *rakjan- 'to reach out' (cf. OE racian 'to direct| to take a course').}];468[432{Cf. s.v. ON rakki 'hund'.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rak(k)an- '(sleuth) dog'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):432, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):404).

Source: 468[429{S.v. ON pústr 'ohrfeige', Ic. pústur, NSw., ODa. pust 'ohrfeige| schnaufen, blasen', to which NNw. pusta, NDa. puste 'blasen', MLG puster 'blasebalg', poesten, puysten 'blasen'.}]
Justification: From Old Norse pústr 'slap in the face' (n.) 'to pant, blow' (vb.). Probably further connected in some way with Middle Low German puster 'bellows', poesten, puysten 'blow' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):429).
Originally a past participle to Old Norse hefja 'to raise', further to PIE *keh₂p- 'to grab, seize' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):244-245, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):198, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 344-345).

Source: 165[67{S.v. Proto-Germanic *blauta- 'soft', from PIE *bʰloudh₂-o- (cf. Gk. φλυδάω 'to be soft, weak' < *bʰludʰh₂-ie-, φλυδαρός 'weak' < *bʰludh₂-ro-).}];141[90{Cf. s.v. ?*bʰleu̯dh₂- 'zerfließen' (IEW 159), only Greek. [No Germanic lexemes connected.]}]
Justification: Possibly from PIE *bʰleu̯dh₂- if the comparison with Ancient Greek φλυδάω 'to be soft, weak' is correct (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):67, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1579-1581 s.v. φλυδάω and φλιδάω).

Source: 468[15{S.v. ON aldin, aldini 'baumfrucht', traditionally connected with Gk. ἄλθω, ἀλθαίνω 'cure', ἄλθομαι 'wachsen', Ved. r̥dhnóti, r̥náddhi, r̥dháti 'gedeihen, gelingen', to be interpreted as the same root as *al- with a *-dh- root extension.}];269[{Etymology uncertain. The etymology given by [de Vries 1977](src-468) relies on the outdated theory of root-extensions as in [IEW](src-49). Additionally, the etymological connection of the comparanda given by [de Vries 1977](src-468) are questionable (cf. s.v. Gk. ἀλθαίνω in [Beekes 2010](src-66), s.v. Ved. √ardh- in [EWAia](src-172)). Consequently, the basis upon which the traditional proposed etymology of Old Norse aldin rests, remains uncertain. Not in [Orel 2003](src-388) or [Kroonen 2013](src-165).}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. The etymology given by [de Vries 1977](src-468) relies on the outdated theory of root-extensions as in [IEW](src-49). Additionally, the etymological connection of the comparanda given by [de Vries 1977](src-468) are questionable (cf. s.v. Gk. ἀλθαίνω in [Beekes 2010](src-66), s.v. Ved. √ardh- in [EWAia](src-172)). Consequently, the basis upon which the traditional proposed etymology of Old Norse aldin rests, remains uncertain. Not in [Orel 2003](src-388) or [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 392[{S.v. Sw. bra 'good'. Loan from Low German brav, in turn from French brave, from Italian bravo.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Low German brav, further borrowed from French brave, from Italian bravo (cf. [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

Source: 468[425{S.v. ON pinni 'stift, pflock, nagel'.}];392

165[319{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say' < *gʷét-e- (IE?). Possibly comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite' < *gʷot-ie-(?), although this verb can be reconstructed differently and is conspicuously similar to Arm. gočʻem 'to shout' < *u̯okʷ-ie- (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):811).}];141[212{S.v. ?*gʷet- 'sagen' (IEW 480-1).}];556[318-320{S.v. Gmc. *kweϸ-a- 'sagen'. There are no secure comparanda. The the main possibilities are: (1) to Ved. gadati 'spricht' as a blend of the root *u̯ed- 'sprechen' and a root *gʷet-, the basis of which would be in Germanic and perhaps also in Arm. kočem 'nenne, rufe'| (2) to Lat. vetāre (older votāre) 'nicht erlauben, untersagen'| (3) modern Iranian words in a corresponding meaning based on older *ǰat-.}];179[277-278{S.v. Goth. Q9. qiϸan 'λέγειν', 'to say', possibly from PIE *gʷet- 'speak', attested primarily in Gmc., elsewhere Skt. gádati 'say' if from *gatati, Arm. kočʻem < *gʷot-i- 'call'. Not to be connected with Lat. vetō 'forbid', or OIr. bēl 'lip'.}]
Justification: Extra-Germanic etymology unclear. Possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 212, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):319, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):277-278, [Seebold 1970](src-556):318-320, [Olsen 1999](src-180):811.

Source: 165[336-337{S.v. Proto-Germanic *līka- (2) 'similar, equal' < *leig-o- (cf. Lith. lýgus, lygùs, Latv. lĩdzs 'flat, even, equal', OPr. po-līgu 'similarly' < *lig-o-| Lith. lýginti, Latv. lĩdzinât 'to compare, even, equalize', OPr. līginton 'to judge' < *lig-neh₂-. A Baltic-Germanic isogloss.}];352[584-586{Cf. s.v. OLith. lýgus 'eben, gleich, ähnlich'. The obvious possibility for a connection of the Baltic words is found in Germanic, if the formations like Goth. leik, galeiks, and leikan and adjectival *līka- 'gleich' may go back to an IE root formation *lei̯g-.}];97[{S.v. Da. lig, from ON líkr, glíkr (cf. NHG gleich).}]
Justification: May go back to a root etymon *lei̯g- if connected with Baltic words connected with Lith. lýgus 'even, flat, similar' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):336-337, [ALEW](src-352) 584-586).

Derivatives ultimately from Proto-Germanic *dentan- 'to fall', via a nominal derivative *dunti- > Old West Norse dyttr 'a hit' from which a verbal derivative dytta 'to hit', cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):90-91, [Seebold 1970](src-556):154.

Source: 556[352{S.v. Gmc. *merk-a- '(modern)' Not attested in Old West Norse, first attested in Ic. morkinn 'verfault' (Fleisch, Fisch).}];392[{S.v. Sw. murken, cf. Nw. morken, Ic. morkinn, MHG murc.}];697[417{Cf. s.v. Gmc. murka- 'mürbe (machend)' (> MHG murc 'morsch, faul, morastig' etc.). OIc. morkna- 'verwelken' and Ic. morkinn 'verfault' can be relics of a lost strong verb.}];49[739-740{S.v. *merk-, *merg̑-, *merək-, *merəg̑- 'morschen, faulen, einweichen', Traditionally derived to a base *mer-, *merk- 'aufreiben' with various extensions and compared with Lat. marceō, -ēre 'welk, schlaff sein', marcidus 'welk, schlaff', Gaul. bracis 'Getreideart zur Malzbereitung', MIr. mraich, braich, MHG mer(e)n, MLG meren 'Brot in Wein oder Wasser eintunken, Lith. merkiù, mer̃kti '(Flachs) einweichen', etc.}];468[393{Cf. s.v. morkna- 'morsch werden, verwelken', built to an unattested *morkinn 'murbe, morsch' (cf. Ic. morkinn, Nw. morken, Sw. murken, MHG murc 'morsch, mürbe, faul'). Following [IEW](src-49) 739-740 to a root *merg̑- / *merk- and compared to OIr. meirc, Lat. marcēre 'welk, schlaff sein', etc.}]
