Justification: Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Traditionally connected to a root *mer(ə)- with various root extensions (cf. [IEW](src-49) 739-740, [Seebold 1970](src-556):352, [de Vries 1977](src-468):393). [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):417 does not propose an updated etymology. No lemmata in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Source: 165[90-91, 109{S.v. *dūna- 'down (of a bird)' (ON dúnn 'id.', Far. dún 'id.', OSw. dūn 'id.', Elfd. daungen 'id.'), as though from PIE *dʰuh₂-no-, related to Proto-Germanic *dauma- 'vapor' < *dʰuh₂-mo- and *dauna- 'smell' < *dʰouh₂-no-.}];468[74, 87, 89{Cf. s.v. ON dúnn (1) 'daune, flaumfeder', cf. daunn 'gestank', dýja, and dýna (1) 'daunenkissen', from PIE *dʰeu- (cf. Skt. dhūnoti 'schüttelt', Gk. θύνω 'stürme dahin').}]

165[234{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hnefan- 'fist' (cf. ON hnefi 'id.', Far. nevi 'id.', Elfd. nevi 'hand', MHG neve-mez 'a fistful') < *knep-on-. The -v- of the MHG cognate argues for PGmc. *hnefan- rather than *hneban-, precluding any connections to the Baltic root *knebʰ- > Lith. knìbti 'to kink, snap', etc.}];269[{[Kroonen 2013](src-165):234 reconstructs Proto-Germanic *hnefan- as though from *knep-on-, but does not provide any cognates justifying an extra-Germanic etymology.}]
Justification: [Kroonen 2013](src-165):234 reconstructs Proto-Germanic *hnefan- as though from *knep-on-, but does not provide any cognates justifying an extra-Germanic etymology.

Comment: Old Norse skoltr 'bone arch over the eye' (Norwegian skolt, skult, Swedish skult, dialect skulle), cf. ON skál 'skull'. < *skēlo-

Source: 165[587{S.v. Proto-Germanic *windan- 'to wind' (Elfd. winda 'to hurl, sling'), from PIE *uéndʰ-e- (cf. Umb. vetu, aha-uendu, pre-uendu 3.sg.imptv. 'must turn' < *uend-e-tōd, Arm. gind 'ring' < *uendʰ-eh₂-), a strong verb to *uendʰ-.}];141[681-682{Cf. s.v. *u̯endʰ- '(um)winden' (IEW 1148).}];556[554-556{S.v. Gmc. *wend-a- 'winden', probably belonging to a reconstructed IE root *u̯endʰ- 'flechten, winden' (cf. Umbr. aha-uendu, Ved. vandhura- 'Wagensitz' (of which on good grounds it can be assumed was weaved), TochAB wänt- 'umhüllen', perhaps also OCS vęžati 'binden' with a root final variant or contamination).}]
Justification: Continuing the Germanic strong verb *wendan-, and further to PIE *u̯endʰ- (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):554-556, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):587, [Kluge 2011](src-397):970, [LIV²](src-141) 681-682).

Source: 468[390{S.v. ON mjǫrkvi 'dichter Nebel' (> Far. mjørki, NDa. mørke).}];697[409-410{S.v. Gmc. *merkʷa- 'dunkel', with derived nominal in ON myrkvi 'Finsternis, Dunkelheit, dichter Nebel', mjǫrkvi 'id.'. Only North and North Sea Germanic, no precise correspondences outside of Germanic but derived from a root *mergʷ- which may be compared to Lith. márgas 'bunt', mirgė́ti 'glitzern, flackern'.}];165[366{S.v. Proto-Germanic *merkwu- 'dark', from PIE *mergʷ- (cf. Hitt. Markuu̯ai̯a- 'deities in the depth of the earth', CLuw. maru̯ai- 'black, dark' < *m(o)rgʷ-oi-, Lith. mirgė́ti, Latv. mirdzet 'to twinkle' < *mrgʷ-eh₁-, Ru. morgát' 'to wink, blink', Alb. mjergullē 'nebula' < *mergʷ-l-eh₂.}]
Justification: From Old Norse mjǫrkvi 'thick fog', a variant of myrkvi 'id.', to be derived from PIE *mergʷ- (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):390, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):409-410, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):366).

Source: 468[296{S.v. ON kaf (1) 'untertauschen, erstickung, schneetreiben', from which in Modern Icelandic kafi 'dicker rauch', kafaldi 'dichter schneefall', Faroese kavi 'schnee', Shetl. kāvi 'schneesturm'.}]

165[449{S.v. *skufta- (1) 'hair of the head', further connections (e.g. to Ru. čubъ čupъ 'shock') are unclear. Cf. also ON skúfr 'tassel' < *sküba-, G Pal. Schaupe 'forelock' < *skübbōn-.}];179[313{S.v. Goth. S94. *skuft 'θρίξ', 'hair of the head'. Now generally to PIE *(s)kewp-, *skewbh-, elsewhere only Slavic (Ru. čup, čubák, Pol. czub 'tuft').}]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Germanic *skufta- 'hair of the head', further connections uncertain ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):449, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):313).

Source: 388[214{S.v. PGmc. *kip(p)az (ON koppr 'cudgel, club', OE cipp 'log, coulter, plowshare'), related to *kaipaz ~ *kaipō.}];165[289{Cf. s.v. *kippōn- (2) 'to chop(?)' ON kippa w.v. 'to pull, snatch', Icel. kippa w.v. 'to jerk', Far. kippa w.v. 'to cut off, OE cippian w.v. 'to chop, cut', E chip 'to cut away', MDu. kippen w.v. 'to catch'. No certain cognates outside of Germanic.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse keppr 'cudgel, club', further from Proto-Germanic *kip(p)a-, related with Germanic to the weak verb *kippōn- 'to chop(?)', but without any certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):289, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):289)

Source: 392[{S.v. Sw. kräkas, from OSw. kräkias, a derivative of the same root found in MLG kraken, LG kraken, NHG krachen, OE cracian, etc.}];397[535{Cf. s.v. NHG Krach (MHG krach, OHG krah, krac, to OHG krahhen, MHG krachen, OHG krahhōn, MLG kraken, MDu. kraken, OE cracian), to an onomatopoeic interjection Krack, Krach.}]
Justification: To be connected with lexemes meaning 'to crack' in other Germanic languages (cf. OHG krahhōn, OE cracian), but ultimately of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392) s.v. kräkas, [Kluge 2011](src-397):535).

Source: 97[{Cf. s.v. Da. snavse, from which Da. snavset| originally a loanword from dialectal Swedish snafsa 'snappe, snavse til'.}]
Justification: Loanword from dialectal Swedish snafsa 'to snap; get dirty' ([Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)).

Source: 757[{S.v. bot (1) 'been, knook'. From Proto-Germanic *but- 'stump', a derivative of Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat'. The original meaning seems to have been 'blunt, truncated thing' and used in relation to bones with joint bumps at the ends.}];165[56{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat', from *bʰóud-e-(?), (cf. Lat. -fūtō 'to strike' < *bʰou-t-eh₂-ie-, MIr. búailid 'to beat, strike' [a denominal formation from an instrumental formation *bʰou-dʰlo-?]| Alb. butë 'tender' < *bʰu-to-).}];141[82{Cf. s.v. ?*bʰeu̯d- 'schlagen' (IEW 112).}]
Justification: Generally considered a zero-grade derivative of Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat' with an original meaning 'blunt, truncated thing' ([EWNl](src-757)), further possibly to be derived from an IE root *bʰeu̯d- 'to beat' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):56, [LIV²](src-141) 82).

Source: 165[171{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gaujan- 'to throw| to spawn', perhaps related to PIE *g̑ʰeu- 'to pour'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps related to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):171).

Source: 141[191{OCS gnesti, gnetǫ 'press, push', Old English cnedan 'knead'.}];259[167{PS dialectal *gnatŭ 'long bone, crus'. The etymology is not entirely clear. It is possibly related to German Knoten 'knot', Norwegian knott 'burl', Old Nordic knǫtr 'clod', ultimately PIE *gnotu-. The original meaning were 'burly bone'.}];458[6: 164-165{The etymology is complicated. It is not excluded, that it is related to *gnetǫ, *gnesti 'press, push'. Other etymologies are highly questionable, e. g. linking to German Knoten 'knot' or Greek γόνυ, γόνατος 'knee'.}]

Justification: Cf. Standard Swedish slå ihjäl 'beat to death', etymologically, Old Swedish i häl 'into hell' ([Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)). Traditionally further connected to the strong verb *helan- 'to cover, conceal' < PIE *k̑el-, if early Germanic speakers conceived of the realm of the dead as a hidden or hiding place (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):220-221), but as a mythological term this remains simply a conjecture ([Kluge 2011](src-397):422, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):204, not included among the derivatives to *hel-a- 'verbergen' in [Seebold 1970](src-556):252).
According to [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97), a blend of Middle Low German schubben 'rubbing', schuppen 'pushing, bumping', and Low German schüppen 'loosen (with a drawer iron)'.

Source: 697[404{S.v. Gmc. *marwa- 'zart, fein', to which perhaps ON meyrr 'mürbe, weich'. The West Germanic attestations under this lemma go back to an earlier *marwa-. ON meyrr is not satisfactorily explained and the older comparison of Old Norse meyrr with Gk. ἀμαυρός 'schwach scheinend, undeutlich, dunkel, blind' is formally and semantically weak.}];468[386{S.v. ON meyrr 'mürbe, weich'. A difficult word, going back to a proto-form *mauria. Either to be compared with Gk. ἄμαυρος 'schwach' or to be analysed as *mau-r-ia and connected to má (2), or to a root *(s)mēu- / *(s)mu- 'reiben, zerreiben'. The Old Norse word is completely isolated but nevertheless can hardly be separated from Sw. mör, Da. mør, and to OE mearu which go back to a proto-form *marwia, *murwia.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):404). Cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):386 for older proposals.

Source: 296[S:60{S.v. OIr. secc 'desséché, dur, rigide', a borrowing from Lat. siccus. The verb seccaid 'il (se) raidit, (se) durcit, (se) dessèche' is a secondary derivative.}]
Justification: A derivative of OIr. secc (adj.) 'stiff, rigid, hard', originally a loanword from Latin siccus 'dry' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:60), cf. [cognate set 4358](cog-4358).

Source: 296[B:49{S.v. OIr. biast, béist 'bête, animal (grand ou petit), ver, pou, monstre, etc.' a loanword from Lat. bestia.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin bestia ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:49).

Source: 296[C:127{S.v. OIr. cluiche 'jeu, épreuve, sportive', with secondary derived verb cluichigidir. From *kloki̯o-, a form of the verbal root *klek- (cf. OIr. clich- 'il meut, il se meut'), surely of onomatopoeic origin.}]
Justification: Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing secondary derivatives of a Celtic verbal root *klek- (cf. Old Irish clich- '(s)he moves', nominal cluiche 'game, event, sport'), probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:127).

Source: 728[79-80{S.v. Manx chyndaa 'change, changing, turn, turning, transaction' (= NIr. tionntódh).}];296[S:164-165{S.v. soíd-, saíd-, a verbal root which only appears in composition. Etymology uncertain.}];50[360{S.v. Proto-Celtic *suw-o- 'turn, wind', from PIE *seu̯h₁- 'move, set to motion' (cf. Hitt. suwezzi, Skt. suváti').}];141[538-539{S.v. *seu̯h₁- 'antreiben, in Bewegung halten' (IEW 914).}];304[605-607{S.v. Proto-Celtic *suu̯-e/o- 'drehen', to PIE *seu̯h₁- (LIV² 538f.).}]
Justification: Previously considered without a clear etymology by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:164-165), see now [LIV²](src-141) 538-539, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):605-607, [Matasović 2009](src-50):360 to PIE *seu̯h₁- 'incite, set in motion'.

Source: 275[{Buck is cryptic here, but I think that he considers them as cognates as well. This is also the case of Walde-Hofmann, which he cites as a source. A Celtic borrowing from Latin is impossible, as Latin or Vulgar-Latin gr- becomes gr- in Brittonic. e.g. Breton grad from Latin gradus. An eventual loanword from Latin should thus be Breton *grass. A similar loanword is Early Modern Breton gross 'big, coarse' from Latin grossus via French (Deshayes 2003, 294).}];50[74{S.v. Proto-Celtic *brasso- 'great, violent'| etymology disputed, but "the formal and semantic parallelism between these Celtic words and Lat. grossus 'fat' is too obvious to be dismissed lightly." If this is cognate we would have to postulate something like *gʷroD-to-, *gʷrD-to- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 485).}];296[B:79{S.v. OIr. bras 'grand' and 'effronté, vaniteux, violent'. [IEW](src-49) distinguishes two Irish bras words: 1. bras 'rapide, emporté' which he connects with a root *bher-s- (Lat. festinare) [IEW](src-49) 143| 2. bras 'grand' corresponding to Brythonic bras and may be compared with Lat. grossus ([IEW](src-49) 485). One may only see the uncertainty of the etymology and and the unity of the Celtic languages around a stem *brasso- with a variable sense 'grand, gros' from which 'víf, violent' is without doubt an expressive word with vocalism that was subject to variation.}];54[273{Cf. s.v. Lat. grossus 'immature fig| thick, unripe', of uncertain etymology. IEW had earlier connected Lat. grossus with Welsh bras 'thick'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; perhaps to Lat. grossus 'fat' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:79, [Matasović 2009](src-50):74, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):273).

Verbal derivatives from the Middle Welsh noun brath 'a bite, biting' continuing Proto-Celtic *brozdo- 'point, tip' and further to a PIE root *bʰresdʰ- (cf. {ref Geiriadur Pryfsgol Cymru (GPC), [Matasović 2009](src-50):80).

Source: 296[S-60{Cf. s.v. OIr. secc 'desséche, dur, rigide', a borrowing from Lat. siccus, also borrowed in Brythonic, cf. OW sich, MW, W sych 'sec' Corn. sichor 'siccitas' MCorn. sech 'sec', OBret. sech 'sèche'.}];240[142-143{S.v. Old Welsh sich 'dry', borrowed from Lat. siccus.}]
Comment: Listed by Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru to be a Latin loan in Welsh so ultimately deriving from [cognate set 867](cog-867). Alternative forms with initial h- are likely to be inherited, whereas these ones, with initial s- are borrowings.
Justification: Brythonic lexemes derived from a loan event from Latin siccus 'dry' (cf. Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:60, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):142-143)

Source: 309[574{S.v. Bret. pesk 'poisson', first attested in the Catholicon (1499). corresponding to Cornish pysk (Old Cornish pisc) and Welsh pesg. The three are borrowed from Latin piscis.}];236[{Cf. s.v. W pysg 'fishes, fish (pl.), sometimes in a wider sense', loanword from Latin piscis.}]
Justification: Loanword into Brythonic from Latin piscis 'fish' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):574, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. Welsh pysg 'fish').

Source: 309[258{S.v. Bret. frwezh 'fruit', corresponding to Co. fruyth, W. ffrwyth, which are all borrowed from Lat. fructum.}];236[{S.v. W ffrwyth 'fruit' (cf. OCo. fruit, MBret. froez) a loanword from Lat. fructus.}]
Comment: Common Brythonic loan from Latin fructus [cognate set 227](cog-227)
Justification: Borrowing into Brythonic from Latin frūctus ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):258, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. ffrwyth).

Source: 50[239-40{S.v. Proto-Celtic *lindu-, *lindo- 'liquid, lake'. IE etymology unclear.}];309[458{S.v. Bret. lenn 'lac, plan d'eau, bassin, bief, lavoir, viver' from Old Breton linn 'lac, étang| liquide, humeur' corresponding to Co. lyn 'lac, mare', W llyn 'lac| boisson', Ir. linn (OIr. lind 'liquide, étang'), ScG. linne 'lac' and Gaul. lindon 'liquide, étang', all going back to Proto-Celtic *lindos in the primary sense 'liquid'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic difficult to establish ([Matasović 2009](src-50):239-240, cf. also [Deshayes 2003](src-309):458).

Source: 50[54{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bando- 'peak, top', from PIE *bend- 'point, pin' (cf. OE pintel 'penis', Middle Low German pin, pinne 'pin, nail').}];296[B:35{S.v. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, montagneuse| pignon, pinacle, créneau| corne, pointe (de lance), crête (d'une coiffure)'}];157[66{S.v. Gaul. banna, benna 'pointe > sommet', cf. OIr. benn 'sommet, pointe, corne' (*bennā), W, Co., Bret. ban(n) 'id.' (*bannā). One may reconstruct a form *bn̥dno- which has correspondences only in Germanic. The alternation -an-/-en- of the reflex of the syllabic sonorant *n̥ is found elsewhere in Gaulish and is perhaps dialectal.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):54, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):66, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:35).

Source: 240[139{Cf. s.v. Old Welsh rudcoch 'purple-red' (Middle Welsh rudgoch), the second element of the compound -coch is a loan from Medieval Latin coccum (cf. MW coch).}];236[{S.v. W coch, a loan from Late Latin coccum.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin coccum '(berry which was used to produce scarlet dye)' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):139).

Source: 80[829{S.v. Hitt. dankui- / dankuu̯ai- 'black, dark', from PIE *dʰn̥gʷ-(e)i- and comparable to Germanic forms from different stem formations and ablaut variants, e.g. ONor. døkkr 'gloomy, dark (of colour)' < *dʰongʷ-o-,  OFranc. diunk 'dark' < *dʰengʷ-o-, OHG tunkal 'dark' < *dʰn̥gʷ-lo-, OSax. *dʰn̥gʷ-ro-.}];697[146{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *dankʷa- 'dunkel' with a close parallel in Hitt. dankui- 'black, dark'.}]
Justification: Anatolian lexemes generally compared with Proto-Germanic *dankwa- 'dark' derived to a PIE root *dʰengʷ- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):829, cf. also [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):146).

Source: 80[411-413{S.v. Hitt. ištamān- / ištamin- (c. > n.) 'ear', from which ištamašš- 'to hear, listen to, obey' is a denominal verb. The noun ištamān- 'ear' (cf. [cognate set 3304](cog-3304)) is cognate with Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' < PIE (nom.) *stéh₃-mn, (gen.) *sth₃-mén-s.}]
Justification: Lexemes derived from Hittite ištamān- 'ear', further from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):411-413).

Source: 296[C:221-222{S.v. OIr. cráeb 'branche, buisson, arbre'| the suggestion of [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):104 to connect to a root *krei- seems poorly founded.}];231[104{S.v. ScG. craobh 'tree', from OIr. cróeb, cráeb, *croib? 'the splittable' from *krei-, kri- 'separate'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Goidelic uncertain. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):104 proposed an etymology to a root *krei̯- 'split', but this was rejected by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:222.

Source: 309[76{S.v. Bret. askell 'aile, nageoire', from Late Latin *ascella from Classical Latin axilla 'armpit'. Borrowing found in all Insular Celtic languages (cf. Co. askel, W asgell, Ir. ascaill).}]
296[S:43-44{S.v. OIr. scíath 'aile', from Celtic *skeido- but no certain etymology outside of Celtic.}];50[341{S.v. Proto-Celtic *skēdo- 'wing, shoulder'. [No etymology outside of Celtic given.]}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Celtic (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:43-44, [Matasović 2009](src-50):341).

Source: 236[{S.v. W pwys (1) 'weight', a loan from Lat. pēnsum 'weight'.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin pēnsum (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. Welsh pwys).

Source: 141[305–306{Cf. s.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].}];172[II:437-438, 459{S.v. Ved. reṇú- 'Staub', probably to be derived from √ray- 'strömen, rinnen, laufen, wallen' < PIE *(H)rei̯(H)-, cf. Lat. rīvus 'creek', MIr. rīan 'river, sea', OEng. rīd 'stream, creek', Russ. réjatь 'flow quickly', etc.}]
Justification: Probably to be derived from Vedic √ray- 'flow' ([EWAia](src-172):459); for the root reconstruction. cf. [LIV²](src-141) 305–306.

Source: 172[I:664{S.v. Ved. tŕ̥na- 'Gras, Grashalm, Kraut', from PIE *tr̥-no-, (cf. OHG dorn, thorn, OCS trъnъ 'ἄκανθα', etc.). Perhaps derived from PIE *ster- 'starr sein' (cf. Gk. στερεός 'steif, hart'), but this root connection is not entirely clear.}]
Comment: cognate with OHG dorn 'thorn', etc., cf. IEW 1031; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 664
Justification: Indic lexemes generally considered cognate to OHG dorn 'thorn', etc. < *tr̥-no-; perhaps further derived from PIE *(s)ter- 'be rigid', cf. Gk. στερεός 'stiff, hard' but this is less certain ({ref {EWAia} I:664, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1031),

Source: 172[I:78{S.v. Ved. ánti (adv.) 'nahe, in der Nähe, gegenüber, davor', from PIE *h₂ént-i (cf. Gk. ἀντί 'gegenüber, angesichts', Arm. ənd 'für, statt', Lat. ante 'vor', etc.). Originally a loc.sg. of *h₂ent- 'Angesicht' (cf. Hitt. ḫa-an-za 'Vorderseite, Gesicht').}];294[306-311{Cf. s.v. *h₂énti 'vorne, vor', *h₂énto 'gegenüber, entgegen' (Adverbien, lokal| oft mit Gen., Akk.).}]
172[I:413{S.v. Ved. √krīḍ- 'spielen, scherzen, tändeln, tollen, sich heftig bewegen', probably from earlier *kriẓḍ-, PIE *krisd- most presumably to ON hrista 'schütteln', etc.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly to Old Norse hrista 'shake' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:413).

Source: 442[193{S.v. 3712 Skt. kṣudrá 'minute' AV.}];172[I:434, 439{S.v. Ved. kṣudrá- 'klein, winzig', probably to be related to Ved. √kṣod- in its meaning 'erschüttern, klein stampfen, stieben' (cf. YAv. xšudra- 'flüssig, (Samen-)Flüssigkeit'), IIr. cf. YAv. xšudra- 'flüssig'.}];141[372{Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'zerstieben, in kleine Teile zerfallen' (IEW 625). Cf. n1: "Vgl. Ved. kṣudrá- 'klein, winzig', OCS chudъ 'klein, gering'".}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kṣudrá- 'small, minute' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):193, no. 3712), further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:434, 439; [LIV²](src-141) 372).

Source: 442[459{S.v. 8138 Ved. pāṣāṇá 'stone' ṢaḍvBr.}];172[II:125-126{S.v. Ved. pāṣāṇá- 'Stein'. Associated Nuristani forms such as Kati parši perhaps allow that the pre-form for Ved. pāṣ- as *parṣ- and this could support the old connection with PIE *pel(e)s- in Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.), OHG felis = NHG Fels, etc.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Perhaps associated Nūristāni forms (e.g. Kati parši 'mountain' might allow a preform *parṣ- which in turn could be connected to PIE *pel(e)s- in Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.), OHG felis, NHG Fels, etc., but this remains uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:125-126; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):459, no. 8138).

Source: 172[II:645, 655-656{Cf. s.v. Ved. śukrá- 'klar, licht, hell, lauter, weiß, weißlich' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. suxra- 'rot, feuerfarben', OPers. θuxra-, MPers. suxr, Oss. syrx/surx 'rot', etc.). Derived to √soć-, possibly from PIE *k̑eu̯k- (connections outside of IIr. uncertain).}];141[331{Cf. s.v. 1. *k̑eu̯k- 'aufflammen, erglühen' (IEW 597). Only Indo-Iranian, probably not to be connected with Gk. κύκνος 'Schwan' as 'der leuchtend Weiße'.}]
Justification: Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331).

Source: 442[799{S.v. 13828 Skt. sphāta- 'swollen, increased' Vop. [Cf. sphātí- f. 'fattening' RV., Pa. phāti- f. 'swelling, increase', Pk. phāi- f. √sphāy]}];172[II:776-777{S.v. Ved. √sphā- 'fett werden, feist werden, zunehmen', from PIE *speh₁- (cf. Hitt. iš-pa-a-i 'ißt sich satt', iš-pa-a-an 'Sättigung', Lat. spēs 'Hoffnung, Erwartung', OE spōwan 'gedeihen', Latv. spẽt 'können, vermögen', OCS spěti 'gedeihen', etc.).}];141[584{S.v. *spʰeh₁- 'wunschgemäß geraten, gelingen' (IEW 983).}]
Justification: Middle Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √sphā- 'to come fat, plump', further to PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾eh₁- ([EWAia](src-172) II:776-777, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):799 no. 13828, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 584).

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 338[{Digor isolate. Probably a loanword, but it is unclear from where.  Might also be onomatopoeic. Similar c’ammar 'filthy' exists in both dialects.}];156[I:337| 329-330{S.v. c’umur (Digor) 'грязный', further discussion under c’ammar 'мерзкий'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword or of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:337, 329-330).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3624; Pali kiliṭṭha- 'soiled, morally impure'; LIV, p. 363 (IEW 602)
Justification: Continuing a Sanskrit adjective kliṣṭa- 'distressed', derived to the lexical root √kleś- 'to torment, trouble' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):188, no. 3624). Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:419).

Source: 442[3{Cf. s.v. 55 55 agní- m. 'fire'. RV. > OSi. aga (replaced by ginna, stem gini- ← Pa.).}]
Justification: Loanword from Pāli aggini- , gini- 'fire', replacing Old Sinhalese aga 'fire' < Ved. agní- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):3 no. 55).

Source: 442[212{Cf. s.v. 3970 gaḍa- (4) m. 'young of the fish Ophiocephalus lata or Cyprinus garra', ˚aka- m. lex.}]
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit gaḍa- 'young of the fish Ophiocephalus lata or Cyprinus garra' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):212 no. 3970), only attested by lexicographers. Further etymology uncertain.

Comment: presumably from 'to clump together', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4177, 4182, 4271

Justification: Light verb constructions 'to become ice' with loanwords from Persian برف / barf 'snow' as the semantic-bearing head, cf. 'ice' in [cognate set 7952](cog-7952).

Source: 442[664{S.v. 11384 Skt. vardhita 'increased, strengthened, gladdened' MBh. [√vr̥dh].}];172[II:520-521{S.v. Ved. √vardh- 'wachsen lassen, mehren (Akt.), wachsen, groß werden (Med.)'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranian remain difficult. Sandhi evidence argues for a laryngeal in initial position, for Proto-Indo-Iranian.}];141[228{Cf. s.v. ?*Hu̯eRdʰ- 'groß/stark werden' (IEW 1167). No certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11384 s.v. vardhita- 'increased, strengthened' (MBh.), Pali vaḍḍhita
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):664 no. 11384 Skt. vardhita 'increased, strengthened, gladdened', a derivative of Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:520-521; [LIV²](src-141) 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

Source: 442[409{S.v. 7150 Skt. niktá- 'washed, purified' RV. [√nij]. (> Mth. nĭ̄k 'good').}];172[II:54{S.v. Ved. √nej- 'waschen, reinigen', from PIE *nei̯gʷ-.}];141[450{Cf. s.v. *nei̯gʷ- 'waschen' (IEW 761).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7150
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic niktá- 'washed, purified' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):409 no. 7150), further derived from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ([EWAia](src-172) II:54, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 450).

Source: 442[417{S.v. 7366 Skt. nirmala 'spotless, clean' Up. [mála-]}];172[II:332-333{S.v. Ved. mála- 'Schmutz, Unreinlichkeit, Unrat, Dreck'. Probably to be derived from PIE *mélo-, cf. Gk μέλας 'black', Lith. mė́las 'blue', mel̃svas 'blueish'.}]
Comment: < Sanskrit nir-mala- 'spotless, clean' (Up.) ('*having no dirt'), cf. mála-; cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7366; cog. with [cognate set 692](cog-692)
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit nirmala- 'spotless, clean', cf. Vedic mála- 'dirt' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):417 no. 7366). For the further etymology, cf. 'black' in [cognate set 1575](cog-1575), 'dirty' in [cognate set 692](cog-692).

Source: 442[726{S.v. *śudhya ʻto be made pureʼ [√śudh].}];172[II:657{S.v. Ved. √śodh- 'reinigen, rein machen' (cf. YAv. suδu-, prob. 'sieve'), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ-, perhaps from PIE *(s)k̑eu̯-dʰ-.}];141[330{S.v. ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'rein werden' (IEW 595). Root mechanically reconstructed for PIE| there are no cognates outside of Indo-Iranian.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12525 s.v. *śudhya-; from Vedic śúdhyate 'becomes pure, clear; is purified, clear', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 657; thus ultimately from PIE *k̑eu-dʰ- (from *k̑eu-), cf. LIV, p. 330
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make pure', cf. Vedic √śodh- 'to become clean, pure'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):726 no. 12525, [EWAia](src-172) II:657; [LIV²](src-141) 330 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?*k̑eu̯dʰ-).

Source: 442[426{S.v. 7563 Skt. nī́la- 'dark blue, dark green, black' RV., nīlaka- lex. 2. nī́la- n. 'blue substance' ŚBr., ʻ indigo ʼ Yājñ.}];172[II:51{S.v. Ved. nī́la- 'dunkelfarbig, dunkelblau, schwarzblau', not yet convincingly explained.}]
Comment: cf. Vedic nī́la- adj. 'dark coloured, dark blue, black blue, indigo' (also 'dark GRUE' = dark blue-green); further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 51, Turner 1962-66, p. 426, no. 7563; some forms analogically influenced by *lohila-, cf. Vedic róhita- ~ lóhita- 'red'
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic nī́la- 'dark blue, dark green, black' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):426 no. 7563). Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:51).

Source: 442[443, 525{Cf. s.v. 7848 Skt. *paribudhyatē 'understands' [√budh-] (> Ash. puruz-, purez- 'to hear')| s.v. 9279 Skt. *búdhyate 'is awakened, observes, understands' [√budh-] (> K. bōzun 'to hear').}];172[II:233-235{Cf. s.v. Ved. √bodh- 'merken, bemerken, auf etwas achten, achtsam sein', from PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- (cf. Gk. πεύθομαι, Lith. budė́ti, etc.).}];141[82-83{Cf. s.v. *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'wach werden, aufmerksam werden' (IEW 150-2).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bodh- 'to wake up; to perceive, become aware; to know' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):525 no. 9279), further to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'to awaken, become alert' ([EWAia](src-172) II:233-235, [LIV²](src-141) 82-83).

Source: 172[II:246-249{S.v. Ved. √bhar- 'tragen, hegen, pflegen| bringen', from PIE *bʰer-. Ved. bhārá- 'Bürde, Last' is a derivative from this root.}];442[539{S.v. 9459 Ved. bhārá- m. 'burden, weight' RV., bhāraka- m. 'weight' Mn. [√bhr̥] and 9465 Skt. bhārika- (2) 'forming a load, heavy' Suśr. [Cf. bhāri- 'ponderous (of a tone)' Śiś. bhārá-].}];141[76-77{Cf. s.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhar- 'to carry' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):539 no. 9459 and 9465), cf. further PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ([EWAia](src-172) II:246-249, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77).

Derivative adjective based on the outcome of Vedic gárbha- 'womb, foetus, offspring' cf. K. gab 'womb' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):217 no. 4055), further to PIE *gʷolbʰo- 'womb' ([EWAia](src-172) I:474-475).

Source: 172[II:370-371{S.v. Ved. mr̥gá- 'Wildtier, Wild, im Wald lebendes Tier| Antilope, u.a.', with denominal verb mr̥gáyati 'jagen'. Cognate with Avestan mərəγa- 'bird', etc. in Iranian. The origin of Indo-Iranic *mr̥gá- '(wildes) Tier' is unclear.}]
Justification: Denominal formations to Vedic mr̥gá- 'wild animal'; further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:370-371).

Source: 259[460{Polish polować 'hunt' (along Russian polevat', Ukrainian polûvati and Belarusian palâvac') is derived from *poľe 'field' (PIE *pel- 'even, broad'). The original meaning was 'hunt in fields'.}];602[486-487, 506{Ukrainian polûvati is derived from pole 'field'.}];607[8: 137{Belarusian palâvac' is derived from pole 'field'.}];274[562-564{S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.) with OCS *poľe 'field' listed as a reflex.}]
Justification: Derivatives from Proto-Slavic *poļe 'field' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):460, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602):486-487, 506, [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 8:137), and further to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ({ref NIL 562-564, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):411). Taking into account the distribution and a rather non-trivial semantic derivation, one could expect, that this form developed in one of these languages and was diffused into the other. However, the source language is impossible to determine phonetically or morphologically.

Source: 442[350{S.v. 6130 *daṇḍakakarman- 'forest-work'. [daṇḍaka- , kár-man- 1] (> Si. daḍayam 'hunting' (EGS 69) prob. Si. cmpd.)}];399[II:11-12{Cf. s.v. Skt. daṇḍáḥ 'Stock, Stab, Prügel', 'stick, staff, club' (since RV). A disputed, still undecided etymological problem.}];172[I:692{S.v. Ved. daṇḍá- 'Stock, Stab'. Etymology unexplained.}]
Comment: cognate with 'stick' cognate/1680/
Justification: Cf. s.v. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):350 no. 6130 *daṇḍakakarman- 'forest-work'; the semantic head coded for cognacy in this set is Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick', without further etymology outside of Indic ([EWAia](src-172) I:692, [KEWA](src-399) II:11-12).

Source: 172[II:660-661{S.v. Ved. √śyā- 'gefrieren, gerinnen, erstarren', also found in Iranic (Oss. syjyn/sufun 'gefrieren', Yaghnōbī ši- 'frieren, gefrieren', etc.). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not certain.}];83[39{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯aH-³ / *čiH- 'to freeze' > NPers. čā(h)īdan/čay- 'to become cold', Yaghn. ši- 'to freeze', etc.}];399[III:383-384{S.v. śyā́yati 'macht gerinnen, macht gefrieren / causes to congeal, causes to freeze'. "Außerarische Anschüsse bleiben unsicher."}];442[723, 731{For Kashmiri, cf. s.v. 12485 śītá (1) 'cold' RV.| For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 12614 śaítya n. 'coldness' Yājñ. 2. *śaitiya- > Wg. šēi, šē 'ice', Kt. šē̆.}]
Comment: cf. 9360 "freeze"; 9359 "cold"; 9361 "ice" and Cheung (2007: 39): "On *či̯aH³/čiH < (?) PIE *ḱi̯-, cf. *ǰi̯auH ‘to chew’ < PIE *ǵi̯euH-, see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. The variant *saiH/siH may derive from the variant *ḱ(e)iH-."
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *či̯aH-; further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:660-661; cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:383-384 for various older proposals).

Source: 442[318{S.v. 5605 *ḍhōṅga- (1) 'projecting part of body'. [Cf. *ḍhuṅga- ʻ lump ʼ] (> Ash. ḍoṅg, ḍoṅ 'knee', Gaw. ḍuṅgɔ́ 'knee').}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):318 no. 5605 s.v. Indic *ḍhōṅga- 'projecting part of body', probably to be further connected with various words beginning with *ḍh- in the meaning 'lump' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):316 no. 5580) but further etymology obscure.

Source: 442[307{Cf. s.v. 5500 *ṭhiṅga- (1) ʻblock, stick, legʼ, 2. *ṭheṅga-, cf. A. ṭheṅgā, B. ṭheṅg ʻlegʼ, ṭheṅgā ʻcudgelʼ| Or. ṭheṅga ʻlegʼ, etc. - seems to be related to 'leg'}]

Justification: Light verb construction with Marathi माहित / mahit 'know' as the semantic head.
Continuing Sanskrit vāpī́ 'large pond, tank, pool'. For further etymological discussion, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:188.

Continuing a Sanskrit compound agramāṁsa- n. 'heart', lit. 'foremost-meat' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):4 no. 77). The semantic-bearing head, Vedic māṁsa- 'meat', continutes PIE *mēms-ó- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:343-344, [NIL](src-274) 486-488).

Source: 442[229{S.v. 4272 *gōḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee' [Cf. the word-group ʻ heel-ankle, knee-wrist' s.v. *kuṭṭha- : → Brah. goḍ ʻ knee ʼ]}]
Justification: As though from Indic *goḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee'; further connections unclear, perhaps related to *khuṭṭa- 'leg' in [cognate set 9629](cog-9629) ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):229 no. 4272).
From Sanskrit kaṅkāla- 'skeleton' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):129 no. 2603), further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:137 for speculative suggestions.

Source: 442[463{S.v. 8201 Skt. pipīlá- m. 'ant' RV., °laka- m. 'large black ant' ChUp., pipī́likā- f. 'small red ant' AV., pīlaka- m. 'ant' lex.| also reconstructed *piphīla- . 3. *pippīla- . 4. *pipphīla- . 5. *pippīḍa- . 6. *pilīla-. [Variety of MIA. and NIA. forms for 'ant' may be due partly to its (unknown) non-Aryan origin (EWA ii 285), partly to contamination with kīṭá- and kŕ̥mi-, but mainly to some sort of taboo for a noxious insect. Although there appear to be six main types, not all NIA. forms can be grouped exactly under them]}];399[II:284-285{S.v. Skt. pipīláḥ 'Ameise / ant'. An unclear, probably non-Indic word.}];172[II:132-133{S.v. Ved. pipīlá- 'Ameise', of uncertain etymology.}]
Justification: Etymologically connected with the family of words surrounding Vedic pipīlá-, etc. 'ant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):463 no. 8201). Further etymological connections remain unclear, probably of substratum origin (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:284-285, [EWAia](src-172) II:132-133).

Source: 49[855{S.v. *reg̑- 'gerade, gerade richten, lenken, recken, strecken, aufrichten' > Av. raz- (rāzayeiti, part. rašta-) "wohl auch razura- n., razurā f. 'Wald'".}]
Comment: first part would nearly fit with 7747 *leh₁g̑ʰ- which would give rāz-
Justification: Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to [IEW](src-49) 855, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:398-399, [LIV²](src-141) 304-305).

Source: 442[76{S.v. 1670 Skt. ujjvala- 'blazing up, bright, clean' [~ *ujjvara -- : √jval].}];172[I:607{Cf. s.v. Ved. √jvar-ⁱ 'leiden', under which also √jval-ⁱ 'brennen' "synchron/semantisch verschieden, aber sicherlich gleichen Ursprungs (vgl. 'brennen' ~ 'schmerzen, leiden' in √tap-, √śoc-).}];141[170-171{Cf. s.v. *g̑u̯elH- 'brennen, flammen' [IEW 479].}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ujjvala- 'blazing up, bright, clean' > 'white', further to Vedic √jval- 'burn' and ultimately PIE *g̑u̯elH- 'to burn, blaze' ([EWAia](src-172) I:607, [LIV²](src-141) 170-171).

Comment: *grilla- 'wet, damp', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 235, no. 4386; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
Justification: Lexemes continuing Indic *grilla- 'wet, damp', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):235 no.4386).

Source: 172[I:777-778{S.v. Ved. √dhay-ⁱ (2) 'hinblicken, schauen, wahrnehmen, ersinnen, nachdenken, denken' (IIr., cf. OAv. daidiiat̰ 'ob er sieht| ob sie sehen' Y 44.10, YAv. ā-diδaiia 'betrachtet', OPers. dīdiy 'betrachte, schaue an!', Khot. dai-/däta-, MPers., NPers. dīdan 'sehen', Parth. dydn⁽ʾ⁾ 'apparition', etc. Further is uncertain. Formally PIE *dʰei̯H- or *dʰeH-i-?}];141[141-142{S.v. *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen' (IEW 243). Only IIr. and Albanian (Alb. di 'weiß, kennt' < ?*dʰiH-i̯é-).}];364[969{Cf. s.v. OAlb. di (trans.) 'wissen, kennen, können, beherrschen', continuing a present stem *dʰiH-i̯é/ó- or *dʰiH-e/o- from the root *dʰei̯H- 'ins Auge fassen'| other solutions are improbable.}]
Justification: An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ([LIV²](src-141) 141-142, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):969; cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:777-778 without discussion of proposed Albanian cognates).

Source: 363[I:606-607{Cf. s.v. Kurd. mala c. 'плавание'| mala kirdan 'плавать, купаться', Cf. Arab. milāḥa 'плавание, мореплавание', mallāḥ 'моряк'.}]
Justification: Light verb constructions using parallel loans from Arabic as the semantic head, cf. Arabic milāḥa 'swimming, sailing', mallāḥ 'sailor' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:606-607).

Source: 442[810{S.v. 14018 *hallati intr. 'moves, shakes', hallana- n. 'tossing about' lex. [~ *halati. -- See √*hall].}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 14018 s.v. *hallati intr. 'moves, shakes'
Justification: Modern Indic as though from Old Indic *hallati 'moves, shakes', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):810 no. 14018. Further etymology unclear.

Source: 344[319{Its etymology is not clear. It cannot be connected to OInd. kṣupa- "bush" [...] since OInd. kṣ- corresponds to Bal., NP š-"}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain (cf. [Korn 2005](src-344):319).

Justification: Unclear whether T2209 or T11167 or contamination,

Source: 323[74{S.v. Paš. sind 'river, ocean| (fig.) dictionary', loanword from Indic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442) 13415 sindhu- 'river, Indus, sea', Si. sindhu 'Indus', Lhd sidh 'Indus, Sindh', etc.}];442[774{S.v. 13415 Ved. síndhu- f. 'river, the Indus', m. 'flow (in general), sea' RV.}]
Justification: Loanword from Indic ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):74, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):774 no. 13415).

Source: 172[II:572{S.v. Ved. vr̥kṣá- 'Baum'. Mi. ni. pkt. vaccha- 'Baum', with metathesis *rukṣá- > pā., pkt. rukkha- etc., IIr. YAv. varǝša- 'Baum', varǝša.ǰī- probably 'Wurzel' or 'Stengel', perhaps from PIE *u̯l̥k̑-s-ó- to Ved. valśa- 'Schößling, Trieb, Zweig'.}]
Justification: Originally a compound of Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' + √*ǰai- 'to win, conquer' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:572). This cognate set is coded for *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' as the semantic bearing head, cf. 'tree' in [cognate set 2368](cog-2368) for further discussion. For Proto-Iranic *ǰai- 'to win, conquer' < PIE *gʷei̯- 'to win, conquer' cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):222, [LIV²](src-141) 206.

Source: 83[144-145{S.v. Proto-Iranic *hu̯anH- 'to call', from PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' (cf. Ved. svan- 'to sound', Lat. sonere, sonāre, 'to sound, ring', sonus 'noise, sound', OE swinn 'music').}];141[611{S.v. *su̯enh₂- 'tönen, klingen' (IEW 1046-7).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯anH- 'to call', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):144-145, [LIV²](src-141) 611).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10781 s.v. rundra ʻrich inʼ (lex.)
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3945; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8377; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Source: 442[no. 10086{lex., masr̥ṇa- ʻsoft, tenderʼ Kāv. are sanskritized forms of MIA, √mr̥d-, cf. Pk. masiṇa-, masaṇa- ʻsoft, slipperyʼ}]

172[I:330{Cf. s.v. Ved. kaśu- (Name of a Cedi-Prince), probably identical with OAv. kasu-, YAv. kasu- 'klein, gering'.}];269[{If the equation of Av. kasu- with Ved. kaśu- (EWAia I:330) is correct, then we may reconstruct PIIr. *kaću-.}]

249[{It is hard to determine precisely how and when the root arose in Ukrainian (it can be an old Common Slavic loanword but it also could pass to Ukrainian or its ancestor dialects through Church Slavonic, Polish etc.).}];602[4: 472-473]
Justification: Loan from Medieval Latin pāgānus 'non-Christian, pagan'. It is difficult, however, to determine when the lexeme was originally borrowed (cf. [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 4:472-473).

Source: 598[4: 267{This lexeme is most probably derived from a back-formation from xorobryj 'brave'.}];602[6: 203{There is no certain etymology. A relationship to PS *xorostĭ 'beauty' and *xorŭjĭ 'dark, black' (PIE *sker- 'scratch') PS Xorsŭ 'a Slavic deity', Ukrainian harnyj, garnyj 'beuatiful', PS *xoroniti 'protect, hide', PS *korsta 'blotch' has been assumed. Some scholars believe that the lexem is borrowed from East Ossetian horz, West Ossetian hvarz 'beautiful' or Avestan hvarəz- 'beneficent'.}];636[2: 498{It had a meaning 'beautiful, tidied' in 13.-17. centuries in Russian. It is derived from PS *xoroščĭjĭ, which is derived from PS *xorostĭ 'convenience, beauty', ultimately from *xorŭjĭ 'black' (PIE *skoro-). It has been also explained as a loanword from Old Ossetian horz 'good'.}];599[2: 352-353{There is no commonly accepted etymology. Some scholars assume an expressive derivative (back-formation) from xorobrŭ 'brave'. However, this kind of derivatives - known well in other Slavic subgroups - is not widespread in Russian. Moreover, the oldest attested meanings of horošij and horobryj ('beautiful' and 'brave') are clearly distinct. Another possibility is to assume a relationship to a Slavic deity name Xorsŭ which was probably borrowed from Iranian. However, the secondary polnoglasie should be assumed here. This deity was a god of light and sun, so the etymological meaning of horošij could be 'fulgent, beautiful'.}];458[8: 80, 83{Russian horošij can be probably a back-formation from PS *xoroščinŭjĭ, a derivative from PS *xorostĭ 'convenience, beauty' (PIE *sker- / *skor- 'scratch, clean'), words related to PS *xorŭjĭ and *xarŭjĭ 'dark?, black?'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology. All existing hypotheses need special assumptions that are not impossible but hard to prove (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:80, 83, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6:203, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 4:267).

Source: 249[{The etymology of the East Slavic term is unclear. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses links it to Slavic *polx- 'fear, frighten' and further to PIE *pelh₁- (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):410). It is semantically convincing. However, a phonetically regular reflex should have -olo- then, e.g. Russian **polohoj. A solution is to assume a borrowing from Polish płochy (or a phonetic conforming at the Polish word). However, such a borrowing would be very isolated. Further, the Polish-like form of the root has been attested (in derivatives) already from 14th-15th centuries and it is spread in all East Slavic dialects. Another solution is to assume a contamination with ploskij 'flat'. The probability is disputable. Still another solution is to assume an irregular phonetic change driven or supported by the frequency. The phonetic circumstances are very favourable in this case. The (hipothetical) missing vowel was unstressed and East Slavic stress is dynamic and relatively strong (at least nowadays). Further, it stand between a stop and a liquid. In sequences / pR / there is always a short (prothetic, unphonological) vowel with a quality resembling the next vowel. An unstressed and therefore short, etymological vowel in / pVR / can be very easily interpreted as a prothetic, unphonological vowel articulation (and, in fact, vice versa), especially in cases as *polox- with two identical vowels. Further, we can deal with a dialectal, northern Russian feature in this case which could spread as a lexicalized inter-dialectal borrowing (cf. [Zaliznâk 2004](src-596):39-41). Note that the oldest, precisely located attestations of plox-forms are found in texts from northern Russia. A combination of some of the given solutions is also conceivable.}];608[344{The word is attested in Russian from the beginning of the 16th century. Most probably it is a loanword from Polish płochy 'shy, timid'.}];636[140-141{It is a reflex of PS *plox- <*ploks- 'flat' or PS *polx- 'fear' < *pols-. These two etymona were probably contaminated.}];599[43-44{The etymology is unclear. It is often linked to dialectal polóh 'fear, fright'. It is also assumed to be a loan from Polish without any justification.}];602[4: 454-455{There is no convincing etymology. It is most probably an old loanword from Polish płochy.}];598[286{Most probably related to polóh and, with a different vowel grade, to pláha. A relationship to *ploskŭ 'flat' is often assumed.   It is not a loanword from Old High German flah 'flat' nor Middle High German blas 'weak, slight'. Also a borrowing of the East Slavic form from Polish płochy is unlikely.}];259[444-446{East Slavic forms are not listed among the cognates of Polish płochy, płoszyć. (< PIE *pel-).}]
Justification: The etymology of the East Slavic term is unclear. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses links it to Slavic *polx- 'fear, frighten' and further to PIE *pelh₁- (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):410). It is semantically convincing. However, a phonetically regular reflex should have -olo- then, e.g. Russian **polohoj. A solution is to assume a borrowing from Polish płochy (or a phonetic conforming at the Polish word). However, such a borrowing would be very isolated. Further, the Polish-like form of the root has been attested (in derivatives) already from 14th-15th centuries and it is spread in all East Slavic dialects. Another solution is to assume a contamination with ploskij 'flat'. The probability is disputable. Still another solution is to assume an irregular phonetic change driven or supported by the frequency. The phonetic circumstances are very favourable in this case. The (hipothetical) missing vowel was unstressed and East Slavic stress is dynamic and relatively strong (at least nowadays). Further, it stand between a stop and a liquid. In sequences / pR / there is always a short (prothetic, unphonological) vowel with a quality resembling the next vowel. An unstressed and therefore short, etymological vowel in / pVR / can be very easily interpreted as a prothetic, unphonological vowel articulation (and, in fact, vice versa), especially in cases as *polox- with two identical vowels. Further, we can deal with a dialectal, northern Russian feature in this case which could spread as a lexicalized inter-dialectal borrowing (cf. [Zaliznâk 2004](src-596):39-41). Note that the oldest, precisely located attestations of plox-forms are found in texts from northern Russia. A combination of some of the given solutions is also conceivable.

Source: 607[3: 157-158{The etymology of Belarusian drèn' 'muck, lousy, bad' (>drènnny 'bad') is not entirely clear. It is most probably parallel to Russian drân' 'muck, lousy, bad'. The Russian word is assumed to be related to drat' 'rip, tear' or to drâblyj 'flabby, deflated, weak'. In any case, the root vowel in Belarusian is not original (it has, however, a rather reasonable phonetic explanation| it can be also expressive).}];599[271{Russian drân' < dran'. It is a reflex of PS *der- / *dĭr- 'rip, tear'. Forms without secondary palatalisation of *r are attested in dialects. The palatalisation is by analogy.}];636[1: 248{Russian drân' is related to drat' 'rip, tear'. The palatalisation is late and secondary.}];608[134, 136{The etymology of Russian drân' is not clear. It is probably related to drat' 'rip, tear'. As to the unexpected palatalisation of *r cf. dialectal drânina 'something that is torn off' and other similar cases. The comparison with drâblyj 'flabby, deflated, weak' is less convincing.}];259[122{Polish drań 'scroundel, despicable man' is a loanword from Russian drân' which is probably related to Russian drâblyj 'withered, puckered, flabby, deflated' (PS drębnǫti 'loose freshness, power, get limp, moulder, rot').}];598[1: 546{Russian drân' is probably a reflex of *drębnĭ, related to drâblyj. It has been also linked to drat' 'rip, tear'.}];458[5: 112, 217, 218{Polish drań, Russian drân' and dialectal dran', along with other Slavic forms with different, usually negative meanings ('something useless, bad, with a low quality, pus, caning, something torn or cut off, scroundel, carcass, barren spoil') are listed as reflexes of PS *dĭranĭ < *dĭrati 'rip, tear'. PS *dĭrati < PIE *der- / *dr-. PS *drębnǫti is related to Lithuanian drìbti, drimbù, drebė'ti.}];141[119-121, 153-154{PS *dĭrati is a reflex of PIE *der-. Lithuanian drìbti, drimbù, drebė'ti are related to PIE *dʰrebʰ-.}];249[{The Belarusian lexeme along with its Slavic cognates is most probably related to PIE *der-. An alternative hypothesis, less frequenly adopted and, in my opinion, less plausible, links it to PIE *dʰrebʰ-.}]
Comment: PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split'

Source: 259[134{PS dialectal *duž- (*dug-j-) 'very strong, able-bodied, healthy, outstanding as to the size or number', PIE *dʰeu̯gʰ-. It is related to Lithuanian daũg 'much, a lot' and Latvian daũdz 'very, much, a lot'.}];458[150, 167-168{It is related to Lithuanian daũg 'many', German taugen 'be fit', Norwegian dyggr 'able, sure, worthy'. Derived from PS *dug-. PIE *dheugh-.}];141[148-149{See for the possible further cognacy.}];81[127-128{The Polish lexeme can be a loan from East Slavic (Ukrainian).}]
Comment: Some sources (cf. Derksen) suggest that the Polish word is an East Slavic (Ukrainian) loanword. The attestation is relatively late and there are some not fully certain phonetic clues.

Source: 259[536{It is derived from PIE *reu̯-t- < *reu̯- 'dig' (cf. Polish ryć ['dig'], rwać ['tear']).}];593[556-557{PS *ŕutiti, *rutiti is commonly linked to PIE *reu̯- 'dig, break'.}];141[510{*reu̯H- 'rip' with OCS ryjǫ, ryti 'dig' and rŭvǫ, rŭvati 'tear' listed as reflexes.}]

458[3: 53-56{PS *brŭsati with Russian brosat' 'throw', Bulgarian b"rša 'rub, grind' etc. listed as reflexes. Cf. also related PS *brŭkati.}];141[97{?*bʰreu̯k̑- with Bulgarian b"rša 'wipe' etc. listed as a reflex.}];81[65{PS *brŭsati, *brŭkati, *brŭsnǫti, *brŭknǫti (with meanings like 'throw, scutch flax, push, rush, kick, touch, shave, squeeze' attested in the daughter languages) is related to Lithuanian brùkti 'poke, thrust, press, scutch (flax)' and derived from PIE *bʰruk̑-.}]

Source: 178[I:105{S.v. Russ. большой 'groß' (cf. Skt. bálam 'Kraft', Gk. βελτίων, βέλτερος, βέλτατος, βέλτιστος 'besser, best', Lat. dē-bilis 'schwach').}];66[210{Cf. s.v. Gk. βέλτερος 'better', usually connected with Skt. bála- 'force', Lat. dē-bilis 'without power', OCS boljii 'bigger', etc. from a PIE root *bel-.}];81[52{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *boļьjь 'bigger, better' (ESSJa II 193-194), a comparative *bol-(i̯)is-io- from a PIE root *bel- 'strong' (cf. Skt. bálīyas- 'better', Gk. βελτίων 'better').}];458[II:193-194{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *bel'ьjь, *bol'ьši, *bol'e(je), from a PIE root *bel-.}]
Justification: Generally considered a derivative of a PIE *bel- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):52, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:193-194, [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) I:105).

Source: 249[{There is no Slavic etymology (the hypothesis of Machek assuming two irregural changes in a three/four-segment root is unreasonable) and in fact no really convincing etymology at all. The original restriction of this cognate set along with congates of these lexemes with another meanings to West Slavic (East Slavic forms are doubtless borrowed from Polish), the initial šp- cluster and the irregular variation of the root vowel in all languages (-e- / -a- / -o-) suggest a borrowing from German. However, it is complicated to find a convincing source of this hypothetical loanword. In the literature mainly two proposals are mentioned: Spat 'tumour on horse's leg' and Spott 'mockery' or spotten 'deride'. Both are semantically rather inconvincing, although a very broad semantic range of all špot- / špat- / špet- forms (cf. the cited sources) makes quite reasonable hypotheses possible. Another one links the lexeme to German spächtig / smächtig '(very) small, scrawny, meagre' which is semantically better but has phonetic flaws (the form "*špacht-ný" given by Králik 2015 is fully hypothetical and proposed ad-hoc). We can not exclude that the Slavic lexeme is a contamination of two original German etymona (a further contamination with Polish (wy)paczyć (się) 'buckle (about wood), misrepresent, garble' and its local cognates is also thinkable).}];259[606{Polish szpatny 'very ugly, disgraceful' along with Lower Sorbian špatny 'bad, etc.', Upper Sorbian 'bad, etc.', Czech špatný 'bad, etc.' does not have any convincing etymology. It is unlikely that it is related to older Polish szpat, szpata, szpot 'a horse's flaw (crooked leg)' < German Spat.}];609[553{Polish szpetny, szpatny, Czech szpata 'uglyness' are loanwords from German Spath 'a horse's flaw (crooked leg)'. The original meaning is attested in Polish: szpat, szpata, szpot, szpatawy, szpotawy. Also szpotlawy 'clumsy', szpocić 'defile', szpocić prawo 'garble the law'.}];627[577{Old Polish szpatny 'ugly' (ca. 1500), zeszpacić 'make ugly' (15th century), szpot 'tumour on horse's leg' (ca. 1455), szpotawy '(horse) with a leg tumour' (1472).}];593[637{The etymology is unclear. Some scholars assume here a borrowing from Middle High German spat 'tumour on horse's leg'. However, such a semantic generalization in Slavic does not seem to be probable.}];591[620{The etymology is unclear. If the original meaning is 'weak' (attested in dialects), the Czech word 'špatný' (along with its Slavic cognates) could be maybe related to Lithuanian pentù, petaũ, pèsti 'get tired' with an expressive š-, suffix -ĭnŭ and -a- by some old analogy.}];260[1467{Schuster-Šewc points to the interpretations of Brückner and Machek with no own conclusions.}];602[6: 460{The source of this loan in West Slavic can be German spächtig / smächtig '(very) small, scrawny, meagre'.}];598[472{Russian špetit' 'offend, deride' and Ukrainian špetiti 'offend crassly' are most probably directly borrowed from Polish spzpecić 'make dirty, break'. As the original source German spotten 'deride' is usually mentioned, which is, however, unsatisfying from the phonetic point of view. A comparison with German Spat, Spatz 'sickness of horse's leg' is also unconvincing.}];628[{Old Czech špatný 'bad, lame, paltry, awkward, weak' (attested from 14th century).}];589[410{Serbo-Croat (historical and/or dialectal) špotati 'chide, harass, deride, insult, curse, joke, ashame' < German spotten 'deride'.}];637[3/5: 561-563{Older Polish szpatny, szpecić, szpacić 'make ugly, filthy, impure'| szpecić, szpacić 'make ugly, also in the moral sence', 'bring disgrace'| szpocić 'make filthy, ugly', 'misrepresent (e. g. sacral texts like Holy Scripture)', 'chide, ubpraid'| szpotawy 'with croocked legs, bandy-legged, crooked, crosseyed'.}];590[5: 283-287{Kashubian (dialectal) špac 'thing that makes something ugly like rust, spot, dust, mud, spider-web'| špacëc 'make ugly'| špacëzna 'thing that makes ugly, scar'| špacelåk 'ugly person, scarecrow'| špacni 'ugly from the physical or moral point of view'| špet 'ugly person'| špat 'illnes of horse's ankle'| špot 'imp, tike| unfaitful husband'| špotav́ic 'make crooked, lopsided'| špotavi / špåtavi 'crooked, lopsided', 'ugly from the physical or moral point of view'| špotålc 'halting, lame, walking crookedly| imp, tike'| špotav́ėlc 'person with crooky legs, twisting his shoes| ugly person from the physical or moral point of view'. Cf. also špåcëc są 'bend, bucke (about wood)' (derived from PS *pakŭ, *opakŭ 'opposite, other way around') with an irregular initial š-.}];638[588{The etymology is unlclear. It has been linked to Old High German Spat 'tumour on horse's leg' or German spächt-ig 'small, tiny' (it could be borrowed from a form without umlaut *spacht-ig > *špacht-ný > špat-ný?). It was also claimed that it is   an inherited word, related to Lithuanian pèsti, petaũ 'get tired'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology.

Source: 458[13: 123-125{PS *kuriti is related to Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Icelandic hyrr 'fire', Armenian krak 'fire' and Lithuanian kùrti 'make fire'.}];259[276{PS *kuriti 'burn with smoke' is related to Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'make a fire', Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Icelandic hyrr 'fire', Old Indic kūḍayāti 'ignite', kunḍate 'burn' and Tocharian B kurk 'oven'. Ultimately, all these words are derived from PIE *ker(ə)- 'burn, glow'.}];531[327-328{Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'make a fire' and 'make', cf. Latvian kur̃t 'make a fire', Old Prussian kūra 'he made, did'. The word is derived from PIE *kʷer- 'cut, make, do' and related to Hittite kuerzi 'cut' and Vedic kóti 'make, do'. However, Lithuanian acute stress is an issue. No Slavic cognates given.}];260[733-734{PS *kuriti (according to Sławski) is related to Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'fire, heat'.}];594[{PS *kuriti is related to Lithuanian kùrti 'heat', Gothic haúri 'coal', Old Nordic hyrr 'fire', Old Indic kunḍate 'burn' and Tocharian B kark 'oven'. The details are obscure. The PIE root is probably *ker(H)- or *kʷer(H)- 'burn, smolder, smoke'.}];165[260{PG *hurja 'burning coal(?)', cf. Gothic hauri 'coal, burning charcoal, ember', Old Norse hyrr 'fire', Latin carbō 'piece of charcoal'(?), Lithuanian kùrti, kuriù 'to light, kindle', Old Church Slavonic kuriti 'to smoke, set fire to'. Derived from Germanic and Balto-Slavic root *kerh₃-.}];54[91-92{S. v. carbō 'piece of charcoal'. "The root with Pokorny 1959 postulates as 'to burn' is now no longer regarded as a verbal root (Lith. kùrti is simply 'to make'). The meaning of carbō is quite specific, and  the suffix not attested in the words outside Italic which are usually compared (e.g. Go. hauri 'charcoal', OIc. hyrr [m.] 'fire' < PGm. *hurja-), sot that PIE origin is uncertain.}];81[257{"If *kūrìti is cognate with Lith. kùrti, the vocalism *ū < *ou must be secondary. The Lithuanian verb, which also means 'make, create' has been connected with Skt. kr̥ṇóti 'do, make' < *kʷr-. This etymology is not implausible, though the fact that the East Baltic evidence points to a root-final laryngeal is problematic. One may consider an extended root *kʷrH-, which would not be unprecedented. A reconstruction with a labiovelar has the advantage that it explains why we find *ur instead of *ir. It seems to me that if we also wish to establish a link with Lat. carbō 'charcoal', Go. hauri n. 'coal', OIc. hyrr m. 'fire', it might be best to give up the above-mentioned etymology and simply reconstruct *kerH-".}]
Justification:
Many sources link the Slavic lexeme to PIE *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)' [LIV²](src-141). The meaning 'to heat' in Lithuanian kùrti is assumed to arise through an ellipisis of the objects in phrases like 'make a fire'. The Slavic lexeme and the Germanic ones are, however, not listed in LIV [LIV²](src-141).
Nor the Slavic lexeme, neither the possible Germanic cognates show any traces of the 'make/do' meaning. Moreover, PS *kuriti has a specified meaning and refers clearly to burning with smoke (pleas note that the Gemanic meaning referring to the 'coal' fits here semantically very well). The Baltic etymology seems to have some formal issues. It seems reasonable to join the view of [Derksen 2008](src-81) and {Kroonen 2013} and assume a root distinct from *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)', *kerH- or *kerh₃-.

Source:
598[1: 468-469{Russian guba 'lip' (cf. Ukrainian guba 'mouth', Czech huba (older húba) 'mouth', Polisk gęba 'mouth, snout', Upper Sorbian huba 'mouth' etc.) is probably related to Greek γαμβαί, γαμφηλαί 'cheekbone' and Lithuanian gémbė 'nail' (originally 'blade, protrusion).
Russian guba (modern stess gu'ba, older 'guba) 'sponge, mushroom' (cf. Ukrainian guba 'tree-fungus', OCS gǫba 'sponge', Serbo-Croat guba 'leprosy', Czech houba 'sponge, mushroom', Polish gąbka 'sponge') is related to Lithuanian gum̃bas, gumbras 'bump, burl', gum̃bulas 'gland', gùmulas 'clod', Old Icelandic kumpr 'bump', Afgan ɣumba 'bump' and Middle Persian gumbad, gubmað 'bulg'.
It is also possible that both words have a common origin.}];81[182{"I have adopted the widespread view that *gǫba 'tree-fungus' and *gǫba 'lip, mouth' are etymologically identical, the latter being secondary. Formally there are no problems. In the case of Cz. huba and houba we may be dealing with differentiation resulting from the generalization of either the short or the long variant of the root (the long variant originated from the so-called "Czech lengthening", see Kortlandt 1975a: 19). The connection with Gk. σπόγγος, σφόγγος 'sponge' is formally very difficult."}];593[211, 218{PS *gǫba 'mouth, snout' is usually linked to homonymic PS *gǫba '' on grounds of common semantic features ('something soft, swelled etc.'). Some authors, however, assume a relationship to Greek γαμφαί 'jawbone' (PIE *ghambh-).
PS *gǫba ['sponge, mushroom'] is related to Lithuanian gum̃bas 'protuberance'. It is sometimes linked also to Latin fungus, Greek σπόγγος and German Schwamm. However, it is problematic phonetically. A reconstruction *(s)gʷombʰo- is very uncertain.}];259[158{PS *gǫba 'soft excresence on a human, animal body or on a plant', 'mushroom, also growing on trees'. The meanings 'lip, snout, mouth' are metaphoric. Its exact analogue is Latvian gum̃ba 'excresence, bump', cf. also Lithuanian gum̃bas 'protrusion, excresence'. These words are derived from PIE *gʰeu̯b(ʰ)- '' with a nasal infix. The original meaning was 'something protuberant'.}];260[354-355{Upper Sorbian huba 'mouth' has the same origin as hubica 'tree-fungus, sponge'. PS *gǫba is related to Lithuanian gum̃bas and Latvian gum̃ba. It is derived from a nasalised variant (*gu-m-b-) of PIE *geu̯b 'bend'. Another forms of that root prestent in Slavic are *gŭb-, *ɡub-, *ɡyb-.}];458[7: 78-80, 164-165{The meanings 'mushroom' and 'lip' are doubtless related and the latter developed from the former (probably it referred originally to puckered lips of eldery people, cf. analogous phenomena in the semantic development of *gribŭ 'mushroom'). PS *gǫba is also related to *guba, a lexeme referring to different kinds of 'pleatings' and 'bends'. Both lexemes belong to verbal roots *gub-, *gŭb-, *ɡyb- 'bend, fold'. Comparisons to Lithuanian gum̃bas and Latvian gum̃ba are correct, the relationship, however, is probably not direct. The words can be deformations of an older form present in Greek σπόγγος, σφόγγος, Latin fungus (that is probably a loan from Greek) and German Schwamm. However, it is often assumed that these lexemes are derived from a wanderwort.}];141[188{?*gʰeu̯bʰ- 'bend'.}]
Justification:
The etymology is disputable.
Greek σπόγγος and Latin fungus are considered to be (parallel) loanwords from a non-IE language (*spʰong-), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66): 1385 and [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 250. Greek γαμφηλαί may be Pre-Greek or related to γόμφος, a cognate of PS *zǫbŭ 'tooth' [Beekes 2010](src-66): 260, 282.
Lithuanian lexemes like gùbti, gum̃ba, gùbo; gaũbti, gaubiù, gaubiaũ; gum̃bas with derivatives, referring, in general, to 'bending, folding' and various 'protrusions, bulges', are related to PS *gŭb-, *ɡub-, *ɡyb- [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 161-162, 207, 77 (addenda). (However, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) does not point to PS *gǫba directly.) Slavic and Baltic forms are derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. As this root is limited to Balto-Slavic, it has been proposed, that is is a metathese-deformation of PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ-, cf. Gothic biugan 'bend' and Vedc paribhuját 'enfold'. See [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 162 and [LIV²](src-141): 85-86, 188.
As it is convincing formally and semantically, I assume that PS *gǫba is derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. Its further relationship to PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ- is not excluded but remains speculative.

Source:
259[272-273{Polish kula 'ball', 'bullet' is a loan from Middle High German kūle 'ball, knob' (cf. German Kugel) and kula 'a kind of stick' is a loan from Middle High German kūle 'stick, club' (cf. German Keule').}];593[306{Czech koule etc. is a loan from Old High German kūle (a non-contracted variant is kugel(e), cf. German Kugel) which is derived from PIE *geu̯- 'bend, arch'.}];598[2: 413{It is a loan from Middle High German kûle 'ball, bullet'.}];458[13: 86-87, 96-100{PS *kuľa (with dialectal Bulgarian kula 'gnarl on a tree', Slovene kulj, kulja '[an animal] with broken horns or without horns', dialectal Slovak kuľa 'pole with a hook at the end', Polish kula 'crutch', peg (also a bended one) used for various purposes', (dialectal) Russian kul'tâ 'hand/foot without fingers/toes', 'person without fingers', 'lame person', dialect Ukrainian kulâ 'crutch' listed as reflexes) is derived from PS *kuliti.
PS *kuliti, *kuliti sę (with the meanigs 'roll, mill', 'skate, tumble', 'wrap up', 'huddle, squinch', 'creep down' attested in Slavic lanugages and dialects) is derived from PIE *keu̯-l-, *kou̯-l-, *kū̆l- 'compressed, shortened, maimed, bended' (cf. Old Indic kora 'movable joint' if < *kou̯la) and Greek κυλλός 'shrivelled, maimed'.
Cf. also related *kulakŭ 'fist' ('something round') and *kuľavŭ 'lame', 'inured' etc.
The whole word family described above is also related to PS *kuka 'hook' etc. < PIE *keu̯-k- / kou̯-k- 'bend'.}];260[718-724{It is assumed im many etymological sources that kula 'ball' etc. is a loan from Middle German kūle. However, in light of many dialectal Slavic attestations with meanings like 'hook, a bended object, gnarl, lump' it is very unlikely. This lexeme has also rather a PS origin, *kuľa < PIE *kou̯l-, cf. PIE *(s)keu̯l- 'something bent, puckered'. Kula 'stick' also belongs here.
German Keule etc. is derived from PIE *geu̯l- and related to Polish gula ['bump'].}];603[3: 114-116{Bulgarian kul, kulav 'gnarled' and kula 'gnarl, bump on a tree or human body' is derived from PIE *keu̯- / *kou̯- and related to Greek κουλλός. Kuka 'hook etc.' is derived from the same root.
Russian kulak 'fist' is an old, most likely a Turkic loanword, cf. Turkish kol and Bashkir kul 'hand'.}]
Justification:
The etymology is obscure. Although a single etymology of all Slavic lexemes listed in the citations below is formally and semantically possible, it can not be excluded that we deal here with more than one etymon (also with loanwords) with possible later mergers and contaminations. In any case, the hypothesis about an ordinary (Middle) German loanword in the case of the Sorbian, Polish and Czech lexemes for 'ball' seems to be at least an oversimplification.
However, even if we accept a single native etymon here, it is complicated to establish its further etymology and IE cognates without additional assumptions.
Cf. a semantically related PS leeme *gula, e.g. Polish gula 'bump'. Accordingly, expressive deformations are also possible.

Source: 294[639{Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor| frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.}];594[{PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.}];260[1149{Upper Sorbian prajić is derived from PS *praviti < *pravo 'law', *pravŭ 'right, straight'.}];81[418{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. "If *pràvъ < *proH-uo- […] we may compare the formation with Lat. probus ‘solid, decent’ provided that the latter form continues *pro-b ʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-."}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639, cf. [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1149).

Source: 594[{PS *tiskati was derived from PIE *tḗh₂isk-, ultimately from *tah₂- 'melt, dissolve'. IE cognates are Ossetic tayun 'thaw, melt', Welsh tawdd 'liquefy', Breton tuezi 'melt, smelt', Latin tābēre, tābēscere 'melt, wilt', Greek tḗkō 'melt'. Cf. also PS *tajati 'thaw'.}];141[616{*teh₂- 'melt, thaw' with OCS tajati 'thaw' and Welsh tawdd 'melt' listed as cognates.}];81[494{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tiskati 'press, squeeze'. The stem must contain -sk-, the root could be reconstructed as either *teiH- or *teh₁i-, neither of which have obvious cognates elsewhere in Indo-European.}]
Justification: Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ([Derksen 2008](src-81):494, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4:183, [Boryś 2005](src-259):77, 84 for various proposals.

Source: 260[1474{It is a loanword from East Middle German stomm, cf, Middle High German stam.}]
Justification: Loanword from (Eastern) Middle High German stomm, cf. Middle High German stam ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1474).

Source: 249[{An expressive variant of *ręd- 'rank, order' (Vasmer, Schuster-Sewc) with further IE cognates. Back formation with cutting the coda and inserting -x- is something productive, there are not so many words beginning wit rę- and the meaning matches. Parallels like njerjad with similar/identical meanings.}];458[24: 230-232{PS *neręxa / *neręxŭ (with meanings 'mess, trash, dirt, gauche, stupid or retarded person, person careless regarding to his clothing, slob' etc. attested in Slavic dialects) is a compound *ne-*ręxa/ŭ. The second part of it is an expressive derivative from PS *ręd- 'order'.}];81[436{PS *rędŭ is related to Lithuanian rindà 'row line' etc. There is no further cognacy beyond Balto-Slavic given. BSl *rind-.}];260[1013-1014{PS dialectal *ręxŭ is an expressive derivative from *rędŭ.}];594[{PS *rędŭ is derived from PIE *rn̥do- < PIE *rend- 'to arragne, order' and related to Latin ordīrī and ōrdō.}];54[434{No Slavic cognates (and other IE) in the entries ordīrī and ōrdō are listed. The Latin words are probably derived from PIE *h₂or-d-.}]

458[7: 47, 49{PS *gorniti (Polabian gornĕt and Lower Sorbian groniś, cf. also Serbo-Croat granati 'tell, speak with a great inspiration') is derived from PS *gornŭ / *gorno. The latter is obviously a derivative *gor-n- with no further internal Slavic etymology. I has been linked to Old Indic gṛṇā́ti 'call, praise' and Avestan gar- 'praise'. It can not be related to Lithuanian ger̃bti, as it is a result of a consonant metathesis.}];399[1: 343{Gṛṇā́ti 'calls, invokes, praises' is related to OCS granŭ 'verse, phrase', Lithuanian giriù 'praise', Albanian gërshás, grish 'invite to a wedding' and Old High German queran 'sigh'.}];105[115{Albanian gërshas 'invite' is derived from PIE *gʷer- and related to Sanskrit gṛṇā́ti ''call, invoke and Lithuanian giriù, gìrti 'praise', cf. also Celtic *bardos 'bard'.}];165[317{PG *kweran 'to sigh' (*gʷérH-e-), cf. Greek δερίαι 'cuss, expletive' (gʷerH-ieh₂-) and Lithuanian gurti 'scream' (*gʷrH-).
"The verb seems most closely related to Lith. gùrti, whose round vowel points to a root *gʷerH- rather than *gerH-. The form would then be unre­lated to Lith. gìrti, (giriù), Latv. dzir̃tiês, OPru. girtwei 'to praise' < *gʷrH-ie­- and Skt. gr̥ṇā́ti, gr̥ṇītḗ 'id.' < *gʷr-n(é)H-. Skt. járate 'to call| crackle (of fire)' continues a dissimilar root *ǵer(H)-."}];141[211{*gʷerH- 'express agreement' with Vedic gṛṇā́ti 'welcome, praise', Middle Welsh barn- 'judge', Iranian parāči ǰar- 'say', Lithuanian giriù, gìrti 'praise', OCS žiŕǫ, žrĭti 'sacrifice' etc. listed as cognates.}];54[271{Latin grātus 'thankful, grateful, pleasand, charming' is derived from PIE *gʷr̥H-to- 'praised (in a song)', cf. Welsh barnu 'judge', Sanskrit gṛṇā́ti 'praise, honour, welcome', Lithuanian girtas 'praised', OCS žrĭcĭ 'priest', žrĭti, žrěti 'sacrifice' and OCS granŭ, grano 'verse, line' (< *gʷorH-no-).}]
Justification: Although some IE comparisons can be disputable, the link to PIE *gʷerH- is formally and semantically convincing.

Source: 259[422, 424{PS *pǫčiti, *pučiti is certainly a derivative from *pǫkati, *pukati 'burst, fissure'. The root is ideophonic.}];260[1189{This word has an ideophonic origin.}];81[416-417{PS *pǫčiti, *pǫkti 'swell, burst', *pǫčati 'bud, germinate', *pǫkŭ 'bud' are derived from PIE *ponHk-, cf. Latin pānus 'tumour'.}];54[444{"In the meaning 'spool with thread', pānus may well be a loanword from Doric Greek *πα̃νης  [...]. In the meaning 'abcess', pānus is comared with Ru. puk 'bunch, bundel', OCS pǫ̀čiti sę 'be inflated', Ru. púčit' 'become swollen' < *ponHk-| a root *pnHk- is reconstructed from which Schrijver phonetically derives pānus. This is conceivable, but it is just as likely that the word for 'spool' was metaphorically used for 'abces', and certainly for 'tuft' of reed (pānicula) [...]."}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin ([Boryś 2005](src-259):422, 424, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1189. For a proposed comparison to Latin pānus 'tumour' see [Derksen 2008](src-81):416 (but cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):444).

Source: 259[171{The Slavic lexeme is related to German kahl 'bald'. PIE *galo-.}];458[6: 204, 7: 14-15{PS *golę 'unfledged hatchling, infant, small child' is derived from PS *gol- 'naked'. This Slavic lexeme is often assumed to be related to German kahl 'bald, hairless'. However, the Gemanic root is restricted to West Germanic only and needs itself to be explained etymologicaly. PS *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('naked, smooth, not overgrown' < 'smooth' < 'shining').}];249[{Most scholars assume the relationship of the Slavic root to German kahl 'bald' and its further Germanic cognates. The hypothesis of ESSJa (accepted by some other scholars) is reasonable but more complex.}];165[278{Proto-Germanic *kalwa (PIE *golH-uo-) > German kahl 'bald' etc. It is related to OCS golŭ 'naked' etc. (PIE *golH-o-). It is a Germanic-Balto-Slavic isogloss unrelated to Latin calvus and Sanskrit kulvá- (PIE *klH-uo-).}];593[208{PIE *gal-, related to German kahl 'bald' etc.}];594[{PIE *galo-, related to German kahl and English callow etc.}];598[1: 433{PS *gol- is related do Old High German kalo 'bald' etc.}];636[1: 185{The Slavic *gol- is derived from PIE *ghel- 'shine' ('shine' > 'smooth, not overgrown' > 'naked').}]
Comment: cognate/4841/, [cognate set 1291](cog-1291)
Justification: Most scholars assume the relationship of the Slavic root to German kahl 'bald' and its further Germanic cognates. The hypothesis of ESSJa (accepted by some other scholars) is reasonable but more complex.

Source: 593[731{The word is a compund of the preposition *za 'behind' and a derivative from PIE *dhe- 'put' with a original meaning 'thing that is put in the back' (the forms are nad 'over', pod 'under', and před 'in front of' have the same structure).}];259[725{Polish zad 'rump' < PS *zadŭ is a compound of *za- and *-dŭ (as nad 'over', pod 'under', and przed 'in front of') with a original meaning 'back part of something, something that is behind'.}];458[22: 15-16{The PS lexeme *nadŭ 'over' is a compound of *na 'on' with *-dŭ. The postpositive element *-dŭ is most probably related to the verbal root *dě-.}];595[4: 377-378{PS *zadŭ (*za-dŭ) has the same structure as *nadŭ (*na-dŭ), *podŭ (*po-dŭ), *perdŭ (*per-dŭ), and *pozdŭ (*pos-dŭ). The element *-dŭ can be an old adjective suffix or a reflex of *dheH 'put'. The hypothesis linking it to Avestan zaδah- 'buttock', Old Indic hadati 'he shits', χέζω 'shit' etc. (PIE *g̑ʰed- 'shit') is less plausible.}];598[73{Russian 'zad' is usually linked to Avestan zadah- 'ass', Greek χέζω 'shit', Armenian jet 'tai', Old Indic hádati 'he shits', Low German gead 'ass', Irish gead 'back side' etc. However, it can be also interpreted as *za-dŭ.}];249[{The interpretation of *zadŭ as *za-dŭ with *za derived from the PIE pronominal root *g̑ʰe- and PIE verbal root *dʰeh₁- 'put, make' with a meaning 'something that is placed behind' seems to be most reasonable.}]
Root_Gloss: back side, something that is at the back side

Source: 593[419{Czech obloha = ob-loha (literally 'something coating, wrapping') with the second part related to ležet 'lie'.}];141[398-399{Cf. s.v. *legʰ- 'sich (hin)legen' (IEW 658-9).}];458[28: 17-18{S.v. PS *obloga < *ob-legťi.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *legʰ- 'to lie (oneself) down' via Slavic *ob-log- 'wrap, belay' (cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593):419, [ESSJa](src-458) 28:17-18, [LIV²](src-141) 398-399).

Source: 141[316-317{S.v. ?*i̯eu̯t- 'wahrnehmen, erwachen' [IEW 346].}];352[409-410{Cf. s.v. OLith. jaũsti 'wach sein| fühlen, empfinden' (cf. OCS oštutiti 'fühlen, merken, begreifen', ORu. očutiti 'vernehmen, merken, hören, spüren) with further discussion on the Balto-Slavic background if the underlying root. No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic.}];81[381-382{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *otjutiti 'feel, perceive' and Proto-Slavic *otjьtnǫti, to a BSl. root *jout-/jut- (cf. Lith. jaũsti 'feel, sense', Latv. jàust 'feel, notice, heed, understand'| Lith. jùsti 'feel', Latv. just 'feel, notice').}]
Justification: Root only found in Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):381-382, [LIV²](src-141) 316-317, cf. also discussion in [ALEW](src-352) 409-410). For the Slavic forms in this class the initial consonant is a part of a prefix (*ot-), which was subsequently was morphologically re-interpreted in the history of Slavic (*ot-jut- > *o-tjut- > *o-ťut-).

Source: 458[3: 189, 4: 121-122{PS *čistŭ 'clean' along with *cěditi 'strain, filter' and *cěstiti (with meanings 'clean', 'castrate', 'tear off' in particular Slavic languages/dialects) is related to Latvian šķīsts 'pure, clean', Lithuanian skýstas 'fluid', Old Prussian skijstan 'clean', further to Lithuanian skíedžiu skíesti 'water down, split', skáistas 'light (adjective)'. Further IE cognates are Old Indic chinátti, Greek σχίζω, and Latin scindō 'split'.}];259[105{PS *čistŭ < *kīd-to- is most closely related to Lithuanian skýstas 'thin, fluid', Latvian šķīsts 'clean, light', and Old Prussian skīstan 'clean'. PIE *(s)kēi̯-d- < *(s)kēi̯- 'cut, split'. Polish cedzić 'strain, filter' is derived from the same root.}];598[4: 366-367{PS čistŭ is related to PS cěstiti and cěditi. These Slavic words are further related to Lithuanian skýstas, Latvian šķīsts, Greek σχίζω, Latin scindō and Old Indic chinátti.}];54[544{Latin scindō, scindere (with derivatives) is derived from PIE *ski-n-d- and *skid-to. IE cognates are Sanskrit chinátti, Greek σχίζω, Old Church Slavonic cěditi etc.}];81[90{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čistъ 'clean, pure', derived from PIE *(s)kid-to- (another derivatives with this root are cědìti and *cěstiti).
