It is related to Lithuanian skýstas 'thin (of liquids), Latvian šķīsts 'liquid, thin (of fabric), clean, clear', Old Prussian skijstan 'pure'.}];141[547-548{Sanskrit chinátti 'he cuts off', Latin scindō, scindere 'split, tear', Lithuanian skíedžiu skíesti 'separate, dilute', Greek σχίζω 'I split', Russian Church Slavic cěditi 'strain' are derived from PIE *sk̑ʰei̯d- 'split, cut, tear'.}];249[{All sources consulted (no all are directy cited here) are consistent regarding to the further IE cognacy of the Slavic lexeme(s). The meaning of *čistŭ 'clean' is very well explainable in the context of other Slavic derivatives as cěditi 'strain, filter' ('to divide a clean/needed part from a dirty/needless one, to clean something dividing it into two parts') and cěstiti (for which the both the primary meanings 'cut, tear (off)' and the innovative meaning 'clean' are attested). However, there is an issue with the PIE root form. LIV gives a form with a palatovelar -k̑- (-k̑ʰ-), whereas the other sources give a form with a plain velar -k-. The Slavic forms can not be derived from a form with a palatovelar. Conversely, if we assume a plain velar, all Slavic forms are phonetically regular. For now a PS root reference is given, the phonetic form of the PIE root should be investigated.}]
Comment: <*čid-t-.The word is a compound 'not-clean'.

Source: 423[IV:461-463, 465{S.v. Sp. pelear 'fight' (n.), derived to pelo 'hair' < Lat. pilus 'id.'.}];316[507{S.v. Lat. pilus, -ī 'poil, cheveu', no certain connections. There is no common Indo-European word for this concept.}];54[465{S.v. Lat. pilus 'hair' [No etymology given.]}]
Justification: Verb derived from Spanish pelear 'fight' (n.), in turn derived from Spanish pelo 'hair' regularly from Latin pilus 'hair' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:461-463, 465). Further etymological connections uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):507, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):465).

Source: 54[60{Cf. s.v. Lat. āter, -tra, -trum 'black' < PIE *h₂eh₁-t(-)r- 'fireplace' (cf. OIr. áith, W. odyn 'furnace, oven' < PCl. *āti-| Pal. hāri 'to be warm', Av. ātarš, gen.sg. āθrō 'fire' < PIr. *ātr-). The Latin derivative ātrium 'first main room in a Roman-style house' seems to indicate that this room originally contained the fire-place.  The development of Proto-Italic *ātr-o- appears to have undergone a semantic development 'fireplace-like' > 'having a fireplace-like colour, black'.}];279[54-55{S.v. U. adro (Umbrian, Latin script).}];141[257{S.v. *h₂eh₁- 'heiß sein' (not in IEW). The root is perhaps found verbally in Palaic ḫāri, ḫanta 'heiß sein' < *h₂eh₁-, which may be an unextended form of *h₂eh₁s- '(durch Hitze) vertrocknen' (IEW 68).}]
Justification: Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ([Untermann 2000](src-279):54-55, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):60, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257).

Source: 54[576{S.v. sordēs, -is 'dirt, filth, stain' < *su̯ord-o/i-, which may be cognate with Germanic words for 'black' [cognate set 188](cog-188).  Lat. sordidus is an adjective derived from the nominal form.}];49[1052{Cf. s.v. *su̯ordo-s 'schwarz, schmutzfarben'.}];269[{Generally connected to Proto-Germanic *swartaz 'black, dark' and derivatives (cf. IEW 1052, Ernout & Meillet 1985:637, de Vaan 2008:576| cf. also Lehmann 1986:333, Orel 2003:392| tentatively Kluge-Seebold 2011:833 cited in [cognate set 188](cog-188)) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic.}];316[637{Cf. s.v. Lat. sordēs, -is 'saleté(s) (sens concret)| condition sordide (sense propre et figuré)'. The only clear connection is with the group of lexemes in Germanic for the concept 'black' (Goth. swart, etc.).}]
Justification: Adjective derived from Latin sordēs 'dirt, filth, stain', generally further connected to Proto-Germanic *swarta- 'black' appearing to reflect an adjective *su̯ordo- 'black, dirt-colour' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):637, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):576, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1052, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):574-575, [Orel 2003](src-388):392).

Source: 81[434{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *rějati, from PIE *h₃roiH- (cf. Skt. rī́yate 'flow, whirl').}];141[305-306{S.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].}];594[{S.v. Sloven. ríniti, rȋnem nedov. lat.‛trudere, promovere’ (16. stol.),  derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'flow', cf. Old Indic rinā́ti etc.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):434, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [LIV²](src-141) 305-306).

Source: 54[615`{S.v. Lat. tergum 'back', interpreted in earlier literature (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1022-1027) as *terg-o- from a root *(s)ter- 'to be stiff' with a suffix *-g-, and the underlying assumption that tergum originally indicated the stiff hair on the back of animals. There is no evidence for this, so the etymology remains unclear.}];316[686{S.v. Lat. tergum 'dos (de l'homme et des animaux)', no known etymology.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):686, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):615).

Source: 564[243{S.v. 605 վատ vat 'schlecht, müssig, faul, feig'. A loan from Iranic, cf. NPers. bad 'böse, schlimm, schlect', pāz. vad 'evil, bad', comp. vadtar 'worse, viler', Phl. vat.}];180[908{S.v. vat 'bad' cf. MP wt', ManMP wd 'bad, evil'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Iranic (cf. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):243, [Olsen 1999](src-180):908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯at-a-].

Source: 180[906{S.v. seaw 'black', a loanword from Iranian (cf. MParth. sy'w, Av. siiāuua- 'black').}];740[IV:195-196]
Comment: Iranian loanword.
Justification: Loanword from Iranic (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):906, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:195-196). [MM: Proto-Armenian *seu̯-o-/-i-].

Source: 180[941{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:666f.).}];740[II:666-667]
Comment: uncertain.
Justification: Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941), [HAB](src-740) II:666-667). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kurts-i-].

Source: 389[{Cf. s.v. *sleh₁b- → *(s)leb- ‘schlaff werden’ (IEW 656). The Slavic forms go back to PIE *slob-o- with Lex Winter.}];595[3: 252-253];259[557];598[3: 664];81[452-453{S.v. Proto-Slavic *slabъ 'weak', from PIE *slob-o- (cf. Lith. slãbnas [Žem.]| slõbnas [E.Lith.], Latv. slãbs, MLG slap 'weak, slack').}];594[{Cf. s.v. Sloven. slab.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *slabъ 'weak', as though from PIE *slob-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):452-453, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) s.v. *(s)leb- ‘schlaff werden’).

Source: 66[1294-1295{S.v. ῥύπος 'filth, uncleanliness'. "No convincing etymology." Other derivatives of ῥυπός "dirt, filth" (including forms of the derived verb ῥυπάω "I am dirty, filthy") are also used in this basic sense. Possibly related to Church Slavic strupu 'wound' (ModSlav 'poison, pus, scab, crust, etc), but root connection is dubious (< *sreu- 'to flow'?).}];270[979-980{S.v. ῥύπος 'crasse', of unknown etymology. For hypotheses cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:665-666, [IEW](src-49) 1004.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek unclear ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):979-980, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1294-1295). For older hypotheses, cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:665-666, [IEW](src-49) 1004.

Source: 66[916-917{S.v. μάχομαι 'to fight, combat'. The root μαχ- is isolated in Greek and there has not yet been a convincing etymology proposed.  One clever proposal compares Iranian borrowings in Greek *ha-mazan- > Ἀμαζών 'Amazon', and glosses from Hesychius ἁμαζακάραν· πολεμεῖν. Πέρσαι 'to fight, Persian', ἁμαζανίδες· αἱ μηλέαι (a type of fruit), but this is very uncertain.}];270[673-674{S.v. AGk. μάχομαι 'combattre, lutter'. The etymology has not yet been established.}];648;141[422{Cf. s.v. *magʰ- 'können, imstande sein' (IEW 695, 697).}]
Justification: No consensus etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):673-674, [Beekes 2010](src-66):916-917); [Malzahn & Peters 2010](src-648) propose a connection to Tocharian B mäk- 'run', but the meanings are divergent (cf. 'run' in [cognate set 7203](cog-7203)). [LIV²](src-141) 422 assigns to *magʰ- 'to be able'.

Source: 66[1214-1215{S.v. πόα 'grass, herb, grass plot' < PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂ 'grass, meadow' (cf. Lith. píeva 'meadow).}];270[922{S.v. AGk. ποά 'herbe [collectif], herbage, herbes médicinales', from earlier *ποιϝᾱ and corresponding to Lith. pieva 'prarie'.}];352[769{Cf. s.v. OLith. píeva 'Wiese' (Latv. pieva) from PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂- 'Weise' (cf. AGk. ποίη [Hom., Ion.], ποία [Dor.], ποά [Att.] 'Gras, Kraut, Rasenplatz').}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes continuing PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂- 'grass, meadow', cf. Lithuanian píeva 'meadow' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):922, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1214-1215, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 769).

Source: 66[547{S.v. θήρ 'wild animal, beast of prey', from PIE *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r- 'wild animal'.  Cf. Lat. ferus 'wild', dialectal Lithuanian žvė́res < pl. g̑ʰu̯eh₁r-es (the normal forms in Balto-Slavic have been transferred into i-stems, Lith. N.sg. žvėrìs, OCS zvěrь).}];270[435-436{S.v. AGk. θήρ 'bête de proie, bête sauvage', with derived form θηρεύω 'chasser, donner la chase'| Gk. θήρ is an old root noun from PIE *gʷʰu̯ēr- (cf. East Lithuanian žvė́res vs. more common i-stem in Lith. žvėrìs, OCS zvěrĭ| Lat. fērus, etc.).}]
Justification: Greek θηρεύω is a secondary formation to an old IE root noun *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r- 'wild animal' (> AGk. θήρ) ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):435-436, [Beekes 2010](src-66):547).

Source: 269[{The traditional etymology ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270)) holds that κρύσταλλος a derivative of κρύος 'cold' (cf. [cognate set 1463](cog-1463)).  [Beekes 2010](src-66):787) rejects the traditional etymology as a derived noun based on κρύος 'cold' on the basis of the presence of a suffix -αλλο- which he considers a morpheme in Pre-Greek. Certainly, the suffix -αλλο- is derivationally opaque in IE terms, but a comparison of the semantics of κρύος 'cold, frozen' and κρύσταλλος 'ice' is very suggestive of some relationship between the terms. Pace Beekes, it may just as well be that we are be dealing with some sort of lexical contamination of inherited κρύος with some other unknown substrate element. In my own opinion, I think the traditional etymology according to Frisk and Chantraine is probably correct, with a caveat somewhere along these lines. In any case, for the purposes of establishing cognacy in the database this is presently an irrelevant argument, since only the Greek branch attests the disputed element κρύσ(τ)- as the (potentially) semantics-bearing element for in the meaning 'ice'. The root ref. form for this class has been given as κρύσταλλος. For further proposed connections to Tocharian A kᵤraś, Tocharian B krośce, cf. discussion in [cognate set 8386](cog-8386) and [cognate set 1463](cog-1463).}];66[787{Cf. s.v. κρύσταλλος 'ice, rock crystal'. Beekes argues for a 'Pre-Greek' origin of this word.}];174[II:28-29{S.v. κρύος 'Eiskälte, Frost', considers κρύσταλλος a derivative of κρύος.}];270[588-589{S.v. κρύος 'froid, qui glace, qui fait frissonner', under which κρύσταλλος is considered a derivative.}]
Justification: Generally considered a derivative of Ancient Greek κρύος 'cold' in the older literature (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:28-29, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):588-589), although the stem-formation is obscure. [Beekes 2010](src-66):787 therefore has rejected the older proposed etymology in favour of assuming a substratum borrowing from a 'Pre-Greek' language. A third possibility is that there has been some degree of contamination or blending of the lexical root underlying Ancient Greek κρύος with some other (substratum?) lexical material (cf. note by Scarborough in this class), although this too is a speculative solution.

Source: 141[645-646{S.v. *t⁽k̑⁾en- 'einen Schlag versetzen, verletzen' (not in IEW), cf. Ved. (Brāhmaṇa) kṣaṇóti 'verletzt' < *tk̑n̥-néu̯/nu-.}];66[789-790{S.v. AGk. κτείνω 'to kill, put to death', from PIE *tken- 'injure' (cf. Skt. kṣaṇóti 'to injure'| Skt. ákṣata-, OP axšata- 'uninjured').}];270[591{S.v. AGk. κτείνω 'tuer, condamner à mort'. It is possible that the present stem κτείνυμι (with a secondary e-grade replacing *κτανυμι) corresponds to Skt. kṣa-ṇó-ti 'blesser'| the verbal adjective *-κτατος supposed by ἀνδρο-κτασίαι to Skt. a-kṣa-ta-, OPers. a-xša-ta-.}]
Justification: Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)κτείνω 'to kill, put to death', derived from PIE *t⁽k̑⁾én-i̯e/o-, a derivative of the root *t⁽k̑⁾en- 'to injure' ([LIV²](src-141) 645-646, [Beekes 2010](src-66):789-790, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):591). Wakhi šay- (past stem šit-) has presumably undergone the same semantic narrowing to the meaning 'kill', as against Vedic 'injure' and Avestan 'destroy' ([Morgenstierne 1938](src-334): 543, [Cheung 2007](src-83): 453).

Source: 66[1106{S.v. ὄρνεον 'bird' < PIE *h₃er-n- 'bird'. Both ὄρνῑς and the alternative form ὄρνεον share an n-stem suffix with words in Germanic and Anatolian meaning 'eagle' *h₃er-n- (cf. Goth. ara, ONor. ari and ǫrn, OEng. earn, Hitt. ḫāran-.  Greek ὄρνῑς is expanded from a feminine stem (transponat) *h₃er-n-ih₂- which has added an extra -θ- in the oblique stem.}];141[299-300{Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).}];270[822-823{S.v. AGk. ὄρνις, ὄρνεον. The root of the Greek word is found in the word for 'eagle' in Hittite and Germanic: Hitt. ḫar-aš, gen. ḫaranaš, Goth. ara (gen. *arins), ON are and ǫrn, OEng. earn, OHG aro, aru. There exist parallel forms in -l- in Baltic and Slavic: Lith. erẽlis, arẽlis, Latv. ḕrglis (from *ḕrdlis), OCS ŏrĭlŭ 'aigle', cf. [IEW](src-49) 325f.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself in motion' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1106, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):822-823, [LIV²](src-141) 299-300).

Source: 66[798-799{S.v. κύκλος 'circle, ring, wheel' < PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o- 'circle| wheel' (cf. Skt. cakrá- Av. caxra-, OE hweol, etc.), based on the root *kʷel(H)- 'turn'. The Greek adjective κύκλιος is a derived relational adjective in -ιος.}];141[386-388{Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes in the meaning 'round' as a derived relational adjective from Ancient Greek κύκλος 'circle, ring, wheel' < PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o- 'circle; wheel', a derivative to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):798-799, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

Source: 66[530{S.v. AGk. θάλασσα 'sea'. A loanword from a Pre-Greek substratum language, but evidently quite an early one due to the differing reflexes of -ττ-/-σσ- among the Ancient Greek dialects.}];269[{Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Attic, Boeotian θάλαττα, Ionic, etc. θάλασσα) point to a pre-form *tʰálakʸːa, vel sim.}];270[420{S.v. AGk. θάλασσα (Att. θάλαττα), general term for designating the sea, of obscure origin.}]
Justification: Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):420, [Beekes 2010](src-66):530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).

Source: 66[1033{S.v. ξανθός 'yellow, golden yellow, reddish, brownish, blond'. Etymology unknown. Previous attempts by Walde (1930: 1.357f.) to suppose IE *kas- 'grey' (cf. Lat. cānus 'grey'), or Heubeck to Etruscan zamθic, supposedly, 'of gold' are tenuous.}];174[II:333{S.v. ξανθός 'gelb, goldgelb, rötlich, bräunlich, blond'. Unexplained. On the very remote proposed relationship with Lat. cānus 'grau(-weiß)' (cf. W.-Hofmann, IEW 533 (with literature). Of less value is the comparison with Etr. zamθic, supposedly, 'made of gold'.}];270[763-764{S.v. ξανθός 'jaune, doré, blond'. Etymology unknown. The connection with Lat. cānus recalled by Frisk and IEW 533 is not plausible, neither semantically nor formally. Likewise proposed connections to Etruscan zamθic 'd'or' is unlikely.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174): II:333, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):763-764, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1033).

Source: 66[1529-1530{S.v. ὕλη 'forest, wood, timber, firewood, shrubbery'. Earlier etymologies connecting Gk. ὕλη with Lat. silva [lexeme 20570](lex-20570) are to be rejected. There are two possible etymologies which assume the original meaning was 'firewood'.  The possibilities are either (1)  *su̯ol-h₂- > ὕλη from root *su̯el- 'to smoulder' (LIV² 609, IEW 1045), or (2), comparing ONor. usli 'burning ashes', from *h₁eu̯s-l-h₂, an l-stem formed to the root *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, singe', cf. εὔω lexeme 31502, Lat. ūrere lexeme 31504 'to burn', etc. (cf. LIV² s.v. *h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen', IEW 347-8).}];270[1154-1155{S.v. AGk. ὕλη 'region boisée, bois, forêt'. Etymology unknown. None of the earlier connections proposed in [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) are plausible. Lat. silva has the sense of Gk. ὕλη, but there is no common ancestor to both of these terms.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain; reminiscent of Lat. silva 'forest' but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1154-1155, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1529-1530).

Source: 66[679{S.v. κέρκος 'tail of an animal'. Etymology unknown.}];270[519-520{S.v. κέρκος 'queue mince d'un animal (sauf en principe pour les oiseaux), porc, chien, etc.). Etymology unknown.}]
Justification: No known etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):519-520, [Beekes 2010](src-66):679).

Source: 594[{Slovene kača (originally 'viper') is derived from PS *kačiti 'ascend'. The latter is related to PS *skakati, *skočiti ['jump']. The etymological meaning is 'jumper'. That corresponds to the behaviour of the viper, cf. also Serbo-Croat poskok 'viper' < poskočiti 'jump (up)'.}];595[2: 8{The etymology of Slovene kača is not entirely clear. It can be derived from PIE *keu̯k- 'bend, hunch'. [See also for a summary of further hypotheses.]}];458[9: 107-108{PS *kačiti is most probably related to Old High German hāhan 'hang' and further to German hangen, English hang (with nasal infix).}];165[208{PG *hangjan / *hankjan and *hanhan are derived from PIE *k̑onk-.}]
Justification: The etymology of this word is obscure.

Source: 81[196{PS *gvozdĭ, gvozdŭ 'nail' (Slovene gozd 'forest' is listed as a cognate) is perhaps cognate with PG *kwasta (Middle Low German quast(e) 'bundle, broom, besom'). Otherwise unclear.}];458[7: 185-186{PS *gvozdŭ, *gvozdĭ is derived from PIE *gu̯os-d- and related to German Quast, Quaste, Middle High German quast(e) 'bundle, whisk, broom'. Other comparisons (e.g. to Old Icelandic gaddr, gadd 'blade, nail' or Latin hasta 'lance') are inconvincing.}]
Justification: Traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *kwasta- 'pine brush', Albanian gjeth 'foliage' < *gu̯osd-o- ([ESSJa](src-458) 7:185-186, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):227 and discussion to Albanian words for 'leaf' in [cognate set 3390](cog-3390)), but considered to be of uncertain etymology according to ([Derksen 2008](src-81):196). The traditional etymology has been tentatively accepted here.

Source: 141[508-509{Cf. s.v. 1. *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (IEW 872). CS rŭděti 'become red' listed as a reflex.}];595[3: 207{S.v. Slov. rumȅn. PS *rumenŭ / *ruměnŭ is derived from PIE *rou̯dʰ-men-m̥ < PIE *reu̯dʰ- 'red, rust-colored, yellow'.}]
Justification: Ultimately derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'make red' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) III:207, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 508-509).

Source: 141[469-470{Cf. s.v. *pelh₁- 'in Schwung bringen' (IEW 801). Semantic connections with the meaning 'fear' are attested also in Germanic and Greek (the linking concept is swinging hearth).}];81[410-411{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *polšiti 'scare' and further s.v. Proto-Slavic *polxъ 'fear': "Etymology unclear. The connection with Gk. πάλλω ‘sway, swing’ from *pelh₁- is a possibility, cf. παλλομένη κραδίην (Il. XXII 461) 'with pounding heart' (LIV: 469-470). The *x of the suffix must have arisen secondarily for *s".}];259[444-445{PS *polxŭ is derived from PIE *polo-, ultimately from PIE *pel- and related to Old Nordic felms-fullr and Gothic us-filma 'frightened'.}]
Justification: Etymology unclear, perhaps further to PIE *pelh₁- 'to make swing' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):410-411, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 469-470).

Source: 309[543{S.v. Bret. oabr 'ciel, nues' corresponding to W wybr, also equivalent to Co. ebren 'firmament' and W wybren 'id.'| Bret. koabr coll. 'nues, nuages noirs' from k- + oabr supposing *com-oepr. First attested in the Catholicon (1499).}]
180[965{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:596).}];740[III:596]
Comment: Unknown origin; cf. lexeme 1878.
Justification: Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):965, cf. [HAB](src-740) III:596; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *oi̯/u̯łił-o-].

Source: 309[305-06{S.v. Bret. gwer 'vert'| presupposes an older form *guerz equivalent to Welsh gwyrdd (Old Welsh guird) which go back to a late Latin *virdis (Latin viridis).}];240[69{S.v. Old Welsh guird 'green' [gwyrdd], cf. OCo. guirt, gl. viridis, MB guezr, Ir. urdai. A borrowing from Lat. viridis.}]
Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Borrowing from Late Latin *virdis (Lat. uiridis), cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):69, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):305-306.

Source: 309[153{S.vv. Bret. chass 'chiens', 'dogs' a borrowing from Old French chace (chasse) 'hunt' (n.), the verb chasseal 'chasser' is productively formed within Breton from chass 'chiens'.}];275[{Verb formed productively from a borrowed base.}]
Justification: The Breton verb chasseal was productively formed within Breton to chass 'dogs', a loanword from Old French chace 'hunt' (n.) ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):153).

Source: 141[203{S.v. ?*gʰrei̯dʰ- 'schreiten' [IEW 456-7]. Probably cognate to Old Irish in:greinn, in:grennat 'follow', Gothic grid 'step' and Lithuanian grìdyti, grìdiju 'go'.}];594[{PS *gręsti is derived from PIE *ghrei̯dh- 'stride' and is related to Old Irish in:greinn, in:grennat 'follow', Gothic grid, Old Middle German 'step' and Lithuanian grìdyti 'go, walk'.}];81[188{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gręsti 'go' (ESSJa VII 123-124), from PBSl. *gri(n)d- (cf. Lith. grìdyti [Jušk.] 'go, wander') < PIE *gʰri-n-dʰ- (cf. Goth. grid 'step', MHG grit 'step'| OIr. ingreinn 'persecute').}]
Comment: With nasal infix.
Justification: From Proto-Slavic *gręsti 'go' and usually further derived from a PIE nasal-infix present *gʰri-n-dʰ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 203, [Derksen 2008](src-81):188, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:123-124).

Source: 595[4: 239-240{PS *truxlŭ 'rotten' is derived from *trou̯-so-, ultimately from PIE *ter(H)- 'rub'.}];141[632-633{Cf. s.v. *terh₁- 'bohren, reiben' (IEW 1071-2).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *truxlъ 'rotten' and ultimately derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:239-240, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 632-633).

Source: 81[91{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čuti 'sense, feel, notice'. No cognates outside of Slavic given.}];141[561{S.v. *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' (IEW 587-8).}];458[4: 134-136{PS *čujǫ, *čuti is derived from PIE *kēu̯-i̯- and related to Avestan čəvīšī 'I hoped' and to forms with o-grade like Old Indic kaví- 'prophet', Greek κοέω 'notice', Latin caveo 'beware', further to Greek ἀκούω 'hear', Gothic hausjan 'hear' and Old High German 'look'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to apprehend, behold' ([LIV²](src-141) 561, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:134-136, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):91).

Source: 595[4: 249-250{PS *turati, *turiti is probably a denominal derivation from PS *turŭ 'movement'. Its further etymology is uncertain. It can be derived from PIE *teu̯H- (a verbal root referrinɡ to motion), or *(s)teu̯- 'push' (both roots can be related to each other). Other comparisons are less probable.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:249-250, cf. also [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 4:123-124)

Source: 81[164{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ględati 'look at' (ESSJa VI 122-123), from PIE *gʰlend- (cf. Latv. glen̂st 'scarcely perceive, nùogleñst 'notice', OIr. as-gleinn 'investigate, examine', MHG glinzen 'shine').  "LIV (200) reconstructs *gʰlendʰ- because a proto-form with root-final *d would trigger Winter's Law, which is not in agreement with the circumflex of the Balto-Slavic forms. It is unclear to me, however, what exactly is the evidence for a Balto-Slavic circumflex." […] "I therefore prefer the reconstruction *gʰlend-, which has the additional advantage of corresponding with the Germanic forms."}];141[200{S.v. *gʰlendʰ- 'blicken, schauen, glänzen' (IEW 431).}];458[6: 122-124{PS *ględati has been linked to Middle High German glinzen 'shine'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes to be derived from PIE *gʰlend⁽ʰ⁾- 'to look at, see, shine' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):164, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:122-124, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 200).

Source:
458[4: 9-10| 9: 110-111{PS *čadŭ is related to *kaditi. The difference in the initial consonant (*k- / *č-) has been explained as a result of a root vowel alternation, it have, however, rather an expressive nature. PS *kaditi does not have any clear further IE cognates. It has been linked to Old Prussian accodis 'chimney' which has been interpreted as *at-codis for the purposes of this comparison. However, as there are no other Baltic parallels of PS *kaditi, this comparison is unreliable and the Prussian word should be treated as etymologically obscure.}];81[218-219{PS *kaditi 'burn incense'. "Due to the absence of reliable cognates, the reconstruction of the root presents difficulties."
PS *čadŭ 'smoke, fumes'. "Since the etymology is also unclear, there are a number of possible reconstructions, e.g. *k(ʷ)ed-o-, k(ʷ)eh₁d(ʰ)-o or [...] k(ʷ)ēd(ʰ)-o-."}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4: 9-10; 9: 110-111, [Derksen 2008](src-81):218-219 for further discussion).

Source: 595[4: 227{Macedonian trkalo 'wheel' etc. is derived from PS *tŭrkati, *tŭrčati 'run'. The further etymology is uncertain. It can be derived from PIE *ter-k-, cf. Middle Irish tricc 'fast'. Also Gothic þragjan 'run', Greek τρέχω 'run' and Gaulish ver-tragus 'fast running dog' (derived from PIE *trāgʰ-, *trē̆gʰ-) are related.}];165[544{Gothic þragjan 'run' is related to Greek τρέχω 'run' and Old Irelandic tethraig 'ran away, receded'. A link to OCS trk 'course, flight' (< *trk(ʷ)-o-) and Slovene trčati 'run' (< *trk(ʷ)-i-eh₂-) is less attractive.}];141[635{*terkʷ- 'turn, rotate' with Hittite tarukzi, tarkuanzi 'dance', Albanian tjerr 'spin', Latin torqueō, torquēre 'turn, wind' and Tocharian tetarku 'turned' listed as reflexes.}]
Justification: The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598), but it has formal and semantic issues, cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4: 227.

Source: 309[144{S.v. Bret. brum 'nuage de brume', a loanword from Old French brume 'hiver', in turn from Lat. bruma. First attested in Maunoir, Les dictionnaires... 1659. Productively formed from Middle Breton brume (1499). Only the latter is a loan-word.}]
Justification: Loanword from Old French brum ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):144).

Source: 50[90{S.v. Proto-Celtic *danto- 'tooth', from PIE *h₁dont- 'tooth' (cf. Lat. dēns, Skt. dánt-, Gk. ὀδών, Lith. dantìs, OHG zand). The reconstruction of the initial laryngeal is uncertain. Some prefer to see an original participle of the verb 'to eat' *h₁ed-, but others reconstruct *h₃- from which Gk. ὀδών is derived more straightforwardly.}];275[{Denominal verb based on the lexeme for 'tooth'. Parallel formations possible. CHECK}];269[{Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in [cognate set 6370](cog-6370) which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:693-694, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):352 no. 6152, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):170, [Matasović 2009](src-50):90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in [cognate set 328](cog-328).}];442[352{Cf. s.v. 6152 Ved. dánta- 'tooth' RV. [dánt- RV.]}];172[I:693-694{S.v. Ved. dant- 'Zahn', from PIE *h₁d-ónt- *'beißend' (~*h₁ed-) (cf. Gk. ὀδὠν, ὀδόντ- [Aeol. ἔδοντ-ες], Arm. atamn, Lat. dēns, dent-, OHG zan(d), Lith. dantìs 'Zahn', etc.).}];309[170{S.v. Bret. dant 'dent' corresponding to Co. dans, W dant. Denominal verbal formation dantañ (dantaff, 1499) 'denter, cranter, mordre'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in [cognate set 6370](cog-6370) which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:693-694, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):352 no. 6152, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):170, [Matasović 2009](src-50):90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in [cognate set 328](cog-328).  Late parallel derivations in Indo-Iranic:  Gawarbati and Raji: Barzoki.

Source: 50[248{S.v. Proto-Celtic *lugrā- 'moon', from PIE *leu̯g- 'to bend, twist' (IEW 685f.), cf. Gk. λυγίζω 'bend', Lith. lùgnas 'twisted', Skt. rujáti 'breaks'. Previous connections made by IEW 690 connecting the Celtic forms to PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' are implausible for phonological reasons since there is no evidence for the root having a voiced velar.}];305[332{Alternatively relates W lloer etc. to Lat. lūridus 'pale, yellow', from a putative PIE *lou̯s-, *leu̯s-, i.e. Late Proto-British *loer < *luðrā or *luθrā < *lusrā. A mere possibility.}];141[416-417{Cf. s.v. 2.*leu⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen' (IEW 685-686).}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes generally connected to PIE *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bend' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):248), but cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):332 for a speculative proposal to *leu̯s- in connection to Lat. lūridus 'pale (yellow)' (Schrijver himself admits "a mere possibility").

Source: 141[629{S.v. *tens- 'ziehen' (IEW 1068-9). LIV points out that the root *tens- could originate from the desiderative of *ten- 'wanting to stretch'. If this was the case, *tens- was perceived as an independent neo-root already in Late PIE.}];165[543-544{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸinsan- 'to stretch', from PIE *téns-e-. The root may be an s-extended form of a more primary PIE root *ten- 'stretch'.}];353[464{S.v. Lith. tę̃sti 'continue, proceed, stretch, extend' (OPruss. tiẽnstwei 'provoke'), from PIE *tens- (cf. Skt. taṃs- 'shake, move to and fro, tug', Goth. atϸinsan 'draw to oneself').}];352[1095{S.v. OLith. tę̃sti 'dehnen, spannen, ziehen' (BSl. OPr. tiēnstwei 'reizen'), from PIE *tens- 'ziehen' (cf. Ved. tam̆̇s- 'schütteln', hin und her bewegen, zerren', Goth. atþinsan 'heranziehen', OHG dinsan 'ziehen, schleppen').}]
Justification: Old Prussian tiēnstwei (inf.) may be derived from PIE *tens- 'to pull' ([LIV²](src-141) 629, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):366-367, [Derksen 2015](src-353):464, [ALEW](src-352) 1095). This root could well be secondary neo-root abstracted from a desiderative formation to *ten- 'to pull' already in PIE (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 629).

Source: 66[1031{S.v. νῶτον 'back'. No obvious etymology, perhaps may be compared to Lat. natis 'rump, buttocks' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54) s.v.) but the connection is tenuous.}];270[762{S.v. νῶτον 'dos'. No obvious etymology, cf. entry for various older proposals.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):762, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1031).

Source: 603[1: 465{Bulgarian d"rpam has the same origin as drapam 'scratch'.}];141[128-129{Cf. s.v. *drep- 'abschneiden, (ab)reißen' (IEW 211).}];81[115, 136{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dьrpati (ESSJa V 225), connected to Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch' (ESSJa V 101-102), cf. Gk. δρέπω 'pluck'.}]
Justification: Derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch', ultimately from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:465, [Derksen 2008](src-81):115, 136, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 128-129).

Source: 603[6: 14, 18{Bulgarian pušek is related to PS *pušiti, *puxati. PIE *peu̯s-, *pus-, *p(ʰ)ŭ-.}];81[423-424{Proto-Slavic *puxati, cf. *puxnǫti 'swell'. Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.].}];141[303-304{S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848). Slavic forms not connected by LIV².}];389[{"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.}];594[{PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.}]
Justification: Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).

Source: 589[152{A Balkan word of unknown origin.}];603[2: 633{It has been linked to Turkish karın 'belly' or to Greek χορμί 'body', χορμός 'trunk'. Most probably, it was borrowed from Proto-Bulgar. This assumption can explain best the internal -o- and final -m and is also better from the semantic point of view.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Loanword from Bulgar? (cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 2:633

Source: 598[1: 373{This lexeme is etymologically obscure.}];600[1034{PS *vyja. Its further etymology is obscure.}];141[663{Cf. s.v. *u̯eh₂- 'sich wenden' (IEW –). Cf. n1 "Vgl. ursl. vyja f. 'Hals' < *u̯h₂-i̯eh₂- 'Drehung, s. Reinart, MSS 49 (1988) 97-100.", cf. Hittite wēhzi. wahhuweni 'turn (over)'.}];80[993-996{Cf. s.v. Hitt. u̯eḫ- 'to turn (oneself)| to patrol', rejecting the etymology advocated by [Oettinger 1979](src-649):99-100, etc. that the Hittite forms are derivatives from an acrostatic root present *u̯ḗh₂-/*u̯éh₂- with Narten ablaut on the basis that the forms require the assumption of Eichner's Law (non-colouration of *ē in the vicinity of *h₂), the validity of which Kloekhorst rejects. Instead Kloekhorst tentatively sets up *u̯ei̯h₂- comparing Skt. véti 'to pursue, strive after, Lith. výti 'to pursue', etc.  [In re Eichner's Law, cf. also discussion in [cognate set 5403](cog-5403) –MJCS].}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vyja 'neck'. Further etymology obscure ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) I:373, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1034). Possibly cognate with Hittite u̯eḫ- 'to turn (oneself); to patrol' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 663), but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):993-996 with an alternative etymology for the proposed Hittite comparandum.

Source:
458[12: 65-69{PS *kǫsŭ 'short' is derived from PS *kǫsati 'bite' ('bitten of' > 'short').
PS *kǫsati, derived from PS *kǫd-. It has no certain further etymology beyond the Balto-Slavic.}];352[464-465{S.v. OLith. ką́sti 'beißen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kuôst 'beißen'). The (East-)Baltic group seems to based on a PIE root *kʷend-, which has no conclusive connections in related languages. From the Slavic languages words like OCS čęstь 'Teil, Anteil, Lohn', Pol. kęs 'Bisschen, Stück', kąsać, kęsać 'beißen', Russ. kuśat' 'beißen' can be gathered, which show a root form without final *-d. Further comparisons with Ved. khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen', Arm xacanem, 'beißen, stechen', are much sketchier.}];353[231-232{S.v. Lith. ką́sti (3.sg. kánda), Latv. kuôst 'bite', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd- (cf. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite'). The Proto-Balto-Slavic root might be formally be accounted for from either PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-. This may have been a nasalised variant of the root *k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂d- found in Skt. khādati 'bite, chew, eat' and Arm. xacanem. Earlier proposed connections to Gk. κνώδαλον 'wild animal' and κνώδων 'sword, (pl.) teeth of a sword or a javelin' are unlikely due to formal difficulties (cf. Beekes 2010:279, 726-727).}];81[243{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite' (ESSJa XII 65-66). In comparison to Baltic forms (Lith. ką́sti, Latv. kuôst) Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd-. If this Balto-Slavic is inherited, it would reflect a stem *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-. If this is so, then the root might be a nasalised variant of the root underlying Skt. khād- 'chew, bite, eat' and Arm. xacanem 'bite'.}]
Justification: Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):243, [Derksen 2015](src-353):231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to [ALEW](src-352), but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 12:65-66.

Source: 249[{This cognate class is not related to cognate/1196/, in spite of the superficial similarity. However, it is possible that irregular changes of the initial consonant in Polish, Polabian and Czech in cognate/1196/ etc. are due to a contamination of these two etymona. The irregularities can be explained also phonetically, though. There is no cetrain PIE etymology.}];458[199-201{Probably an expressive formation without any reliable IE cognates. Some existing hypotheses (linking this lexeme to Irish gerbach 'puckered' or Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle') are problematic phonetically and semantically. The Old Prussian garbis 'mountian' is most probably a loanword from Polish.}];259[155{Related to Old Prussian grabis (garbis) 'mountian', Middle Irish gerbach 'puckered' or Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle'. This is probably a reflex of PIE *ger- with an extention (*ger-b-) 'bend, skew, bundle'.}];593[214{It is sometimes linked to Old Prussian garbis 'mountian', Irish gerbach 'puckered' or Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle' that are reflexes of PIE *ger-b- 'bend'.}];595[1: 172{Most of authors assume here a reflex of PIE *ger 'bend, skew'.}];594[{Related to Old Prussian garbis 'mountian', Lithuanian gárbana 'curl', Old Irish gerbach 'puckered', Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle', Armenian karth 'hook, angle' which all go back to PIE *ger(H)-b- 'bend, skew'.}];589[610{Reflex of PIE *ger- 'bend'. IE cognates are Old Prussian garbiš 'hill', Lithuanian gárbana 'curl', Irish gerbach 'puckered', Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle', and Armenian karth 'hook, angle'.}];636[187{An expressive PS word without reliable IE cognates.}];603[287{Related to Old Prussian garbis 'mountian' and Lithuanian gárbana 'curl'.}];598[439{Related to Old Prussian garbis 'hill', Lithuanian gárbana,  gárbina 'curl', Irish gerbach 'puckered', Islandic korpa 'ruck, ruckle', and Armenian kart' 'hook, angle'.}];531[157, 211-210{Lithuanian gárbana / garbanà 'curl' (along with gur̃bti 'grow well') does not have any certain IE cognates. A possible one is PS *gŭrb-.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Slavic.

Source: 259[677{Polish walka 'fight' is borrowed from Old Czech válka, which is a derivative from váleti 'fight, pull'.}];593[698{Czech válka 'war' etc. is limited to Czech only. The Polish and word is a loanword. In Czech it is derived from váleti 'fight'. The Czech lexemes themselves can be loans from Old High German wal 'battelground', supported by (and contaminated with?) the native váleti 'pull, hit'. The ultimate source root is PIE *u̯el-.}]
Justification: It is assumed of the Polish word to be a loanword from Czech (which can be further a loan from German). If it is true, the Kashubian word is most probably a loanword from Polish. An additional survey would be needed here. The Czech lexemes have probably also a complicated history. A contamination of two different etymona (on of which can be a loanword) is probable. Cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):677, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):698.

Source: 607[3: 336-337{The Belarusian lexeme is derived from PS *mog- / *mag, which is also found in Belarusian magčy 'can'.}];141[422{Cf. s.v. *magʰ- 'können, imstande sein' (IEW 695, 697).}];81[321{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *mogtì 'be able' (ESSJa XIX 107-111), from PIE *mogʰ- (cf. Lith. magė́ti 'please, interest', OPr. massi 'be able', Skt. maghá- 'power, wealth, gift' Goth. mag 3.sg. 'has power, is able', OIc. mega 'be able', OHG magan, mugan 'be able').}]
Justification: Derived from Proto-Slavic *mog-/*mag- 'to be able' ([Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 3:336-337), further generally derived to an IE root *magʰ- 'to be able' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 422, [Derksen 2008](src-81):321, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:107-111).

Source: 81[415, 524{PS *vojĭ is derived from PIE *u̯oi̯h₁-o- and related to PS *povinǫti. The Slavic lexemes are related to Sanskrit véti 'persecute, strive, chase'.}];259[706-709{Polish wojna 'war', wojować 'fight', wojsko 'army', wój 'soldier' are derived from PIE *u̯ei̯- and related to Lithuanian výti, vejù 'chase', Old High German weidōn 'hunt', Old Indic véti, váyati 'chase', Greek ίεμαι 'hasten, go'.}];141[668-669{S.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4). Among listed cognates are Vedic véti, Lithuanian výti and OCS povinǫti.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- (Cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):706-709, [Derksen 2008](src-81):415, 524 [LIV²](src-141) 668-669).

Source: 458[8: 123, 160-161{PS *xytati is related to PS *xvatati ['catch'] and to PS *xotěti ['want']. The further etymology is obscure. It can be derived from an expressive form of the pronominal root *su̯e- (cf. PS *svojĭ ['one's own'], as to the semantic development cf. Russian prisvoit' 'grab').}]
Justification: Further connections outside of Slavic are uncertain ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:123, 160-161).

Source: 319[182{Clackson regards the connection between Greek ξηρός and Armenian չոր čʻor as doubtful.  (See p.182 for references.)}];79[546{S.v. Arm. cʻir 'dried fruit', cʻor 'dry'. The etymology with Greek ξηρός is usually doubted because one normally expects Armenian cʻ from PIE *ks, *sk, but Martirosyan considers (s.v. čʻir, čʻor) a viable comparison with Greek ξηρός, arguing (2.1.12) that čʻ- is the correct reflex of *ks- in initial position.}];180[965{Of uncertain origin. "The traditional comparison with Gk. ξηρός, Skt. kṣārá- seems to be incompatible with the sound laws. Even a metathesized *skoro- (cf. Solta l.c.) would probably yield *cʻor."}]
Justification: Connections outside of Armenian unclear; occasionally proposed to Gk. ξηρός 'dry' (cf. [cognate set 1471](cog-1471)), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):182, [Olsen 1999](src-180):965 [Beekes 2010](src-66):1035-1036, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546).

Source: 50[278{S.v. Proto-Celtic *moru̯i- 'ant', cf. PIE *moru̯i- 'ant' (IEW 749). "The PIE form is notoriously difficult to reconstruct. The PIE i-stem implied by the agreement between MIr. and Avestan is probably older than the thematic forms found in Skt. (which also involves metathesis) and Greek (with assimilation *moru̯o- > *mormo-, and subsequent change of *o > i̯ between a labial and a resonant)."}];66[982{S.v. μύρμηξ, -ηκος 'ant'. The stem of Ancient Greek μύρμηξ is derived from PIE *moru̯i- (directly continued by Avestan maoiri- Old Irish moirb, Old Russian morovij),  but like in many places elsewhere among the IE languages it appears to have undergone analogical or irregular developments.  The new suffix -ηξ is also found in other words for insects, e.g. σκώληξ 'worm, maggot', σφήξ 'wasp'.}];172[II:507{S.v. Ved. vamrá- 'Ameise' (IIr. cf. Av. maoiri- 'Ameise', Khot. muṃjaka-, MPers., NPers. mōr, Oss. mælʒyg/mulʒug, Pašto meẓ̌ay 'Ameise', etc.). "Ved. vamrº, valmº, iran. *maru̯º zeigen Umgestaltungen eines unter Tabu stehenden Tiernamens … dem entsprechen in den anderen idg. Sprachen Wortformen, die auf *u̯ormº ~ *moru̯º ~ *mormº."}];458[241-249{Cf. the cited page range for Proto-Slavic *morvь and various related forms. The archaic Proto-Slavic form *morvь (directly reflecting PIE *moru̯i-) was preserved in some dialects only. In the most Slavic languages and dialects there are various derivatives transferring the lexeme to *-a- and *-o- stem classes.}];79[482-483{S.v. mrǰiwn 'ant', since long connected with the PIE word for 'ant' (cf. Gk. μύρμηξ 'ant', Lat. formīca 'ant', Skt. vamrá- 'ant', YAv. maoiri- 'ant', NPers. mōr 'ant', etc.). One usually assumes taboo-forms *u̯orm- : *moru̯-.}];81[326{S.v. Proto-Slavic *morvi 'ant' (ESSJa XIX 246-249), from PIE *moru-iH (cf. Av. maoirī-, OIr. moirb).}];165[359{S.v. Proto-Germanic *maura- 'ant' < *mour-o- (cf. Skt. vamrá- 'ant' < *uomr-o-| YAv. maoiri- 'id.', NPers. mōr 'id.', Oss. mælʒyg / mulʒug 'id.' < *moru-i-| Skt. vamrī́-, Av. maoirī- 'id.' < *uomr-ih₂ / *moru-ih₂| Gk. μύρμηξ, -ηκος 'id.' < *morm-| Lat. formīca 'id.' < *bʰ(o)rm-| OIr. moirb 'id.', W myr 'id.' < PIE *moru-i-| CS mravii 'id.' < *moru-ih₂-, ORu. morovej, Ru. muravéj 'id.' < *moru-io-, SCr. mrȃv 'id.' < *moru-o-| TochB warme* 'id.' < *urm-i-). "The word is of IE origin, but the original form is difficult to reconstruct due to cross-dialectal tabooistic distortions and metatheses."}];54[243{S.v. Lat. formīca 'ant', from PIE *moru̯-o/ī̆-(?) (cf. OIr. moirb, W. myr, Bret. merien 'ant' < *moru̯i-| Skt. vamrá- 'ant', valmī́ka- 'ant-hill'| Av. maoiri-, Oss. mælzyg / mulzug, Pašto mežay, Sogd. ymʾwrc < PIr. *maru̯i(ka)-, Sogd. zmʾwrʾk, Khwar. zmwrk, MP, MoP mōr < *maru̯aka-| Gk. μύρμηξ, -ηκος 'ant', βύρμαξ, βόρμαξ, ὅρμικας (with β- and zero < *ϝ-)| RuCS. mravьjь, ORu. morovej, Po. mrówka, SCr. mrȃv 'ant' < moru-iH-| OIc. maurr < *mour-o-, Far. meyra < *maurōn-, Dan. myre, OE mȳre, ME mire, MDu. miere, Crimean Gothic miera < *meur(j)ōn- 'ant', TochB warme* nom.pl. warmi 'ant' < *u̯r̥mo-). "The word for ant is difficult to reconstruct because of the deviating forms| probably taboo distortions took place in many languages. This process can still be observed in modern dialects, for instance of Dutch and German. Latin f- might go back to *m- via a dissimilation *m- – m > *f – m. Meillet (1918) assumes an intermediate stage *[ƀ] (voiced bilabial fricative), which he regards as an argument for the view that all PIE *bʰ changed to *ƀ before yielding Latin f-. In IE branches, we find the stem structures *moru̯-o/ī̆- (Celtic, Iranian, Slavic, Gm.), *mormo/i- (Greek), and *uormo/i- (Skt., Toch., Greek?). Since the latter is quite similar to PIE *u(o)rmo/i- 'worm, insect' (see s.v. vermis), it may have been influenced by it| consequently, for 'ant' the form *moruo/i- is more likely to be old."}];345[630{S.v. TochB warme* 'ant', (as though) from PIE *u̯r̥mo-, a deformation of the *u̯ormo- that lies behind Sanskrit valmīka-, vamrá-, Greek βόρμαξ, βύρμαξ, ὅρμαξ, μύρμηξ, Lat. formīca.}];657[24{Cf. s.v. ANT *moru̯is ~ *morm- ~ *moruos for further discussion. "The number of phonological variants suggest that the designation for the 'ant' in IE traditions was more than usually subject to phonological deformation (via metathesis, etc.) owing to some sort of affective semantics of the word. Though it is hard to reconstruct the exact PIE shape of the word, it is clearly of PIE date."}];325[45{"The Š[ughni]Gr[oup] forms in ǰ/č have been influenced by Prs."}]
Justification: Many irregular developments, often assumed to be due to taboo deformation, but all the lexemes are generally assumed to come from a common Indo-European source. The metathesised stem *u̯orm- as found in Vedic, etc. is generally assumed to be a taboo-deformation while the forms found in Avestan maoiri-, Old Irish moirb are often assumed to be most closely reflect to the original ([EIEC](src-657) 24). For individual branches, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):630, [Beekes 2010](src-66):982, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):482-483, [EWAia](src-172) II:507, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:241-249, [Derksen 2008](src-81):326, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):359, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):243, [Matasović 2009](src-50):278.

Source: 276[{Obscure origin. This word is unattested in the classical language (cf. [lexeme 28586](lex-28586)).  A remote possibility is a dialectal development of CA գլոր gl-or '(in) rolling| tumbling down' (< *gil-or- < PIE/inner-Arm. *u̯ēlH-| cf. գելում gel-ow-m 'I squeeze, twist| (orig.) *roll' < PIE 2.*u̯elH-, cf. OCS valiti, OHG wallan| ?Lat. volvo) in a variety X with a three-way opposition of stops in which CA /T : D : Tʰ/ corresponds to /D : T : Tʰ/ (such as Kharberd, Middle Armenian, etc.), i.e. CA [gəlɔɾ] > variety X [kəlɔɾ] 'round'.  The latter was loaned in parallel prior to the Western Armenian shift, i.e., variety X [kəlɔɾ] → *[kəlɔɾ] (= EA) > WA [gəlɔɾ].  Needless to say, this is a speculation.}];79[366{S.v. *klor 'spheric, ball-shaped| round', probably to be connected with dialectal words from *klmp/b- of uncertain origin.}]
Justification: Of uncertain origin, unattested in Classical Armenian ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):366). [MM: < ⁽*⁾kəloɾ].

Source: 66[1632{S.v. χθές 'yesterday', from PIE *dʰgʰi̯es- 'yesterday'. According to Puhvel (1987:316-8), this is in turn derived from *dʰog̑ʰ-o- 'day' by adding a comparative suffix/original endingless locative -i̯es/-is. Germanic and Latin show an additional *-ter suffix.}];165[175-176{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gestra- adv. 'the previous or next day'. Following the etymology of Puhvel (1987), the Goth. gistra- and West Germanic forms point to Proto-Germanic *gestra- < *dʰg̑ʰes-ro- with t-epenthesis between *s and *r (cf. *swester 'sister'). The North Germanic forms are more difficult to account for: Kroonen favours explaining Faroese gjár and Old Icelandic gær as deriving from *gāʀ < *PGmc. *gēz with monosyllabic lengthening (cf. *ūt < *ud). [To account for Sanskrit hyás Kroonen assumes that it goes back to PIE *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es with an intrusion of the -i̯- in analogy to sadyás 'today' < *sm̥-di-és.]}];50[155{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gdesi 'yesterday', from PIE *dʰg̑ʰ(i̯)es(i), an adverb fossilised from a locative of an old root noun, e.g. ?*dʰg̑ʰ(i̯)ōs, designating 'the preceding day' (cf. Skt. hyás, Gk. χθές, Lat. heri, OHG gesterēn, Alb. dje). Alternatively possible is the derivation *g̑ʰ-di̯es- where *g̑ʰ- is the demonstrative particle and *di̯es- a derivative of the root *dei̯- 'day' (Lat. diēs etc., cf. Schindler 1977).}];156[IV:313-314{S.v. Oss. znon | æzinæ 'вчера', from Proto-Iranian *zyah, cf. Ved. hyas, Lat. heri, etc.}];588[315-318];369[138{S.v. Alb. dje 'gestern', generally agreed to go back to the inherited word for 'yesterday' *g̑ʰ-di̯es or *dʰg̑ʰi̯es.}];105[68{S.v. Alb. dje 'yesterday', from PAlb. *de and etymologically identical with Skt. hyás, Gk. χθές, Lat. heri, etc.}];172[II:822{S.v. Ved. hyás 'gestern', from PIE *g̑ʰdi̯és- (cf. NPers. dī, dīg, Oss. znon/æzinæ, Gk. χθές, Lat. heri, OHG gesteren, etc.).}];54[283{S.v. Lat. heri 'yesterday', from PIE *g̑ʰ-di-es 'yesterday' (cf. OIr. indé, MW doe, OCo. doy < PCl. *γdes(i?), Ved. hyás, Bal. zī, zīk, Oss. znon / æzinæ < IIr. *j́ʰias, Gk. χθές, Alb. dje, OIc. í gær 'yesterday', Goth. gistra-dagis 'tomorrow', OE giestron, OHG gesteron 'yesterday' < *g̑ʰes-t(e)ra-). "It has been suggested that the original PIE form was *g̑ʰ-di-es 'at that day' with the pronominal stem *g̑ʰe/o- and the gen.sg. of *di- 'day', the stem possibly reflected in Skt. sadyáḥ 'within one day'. The zero-grade of the pronoun *g̑ʰe/o- would then be a very archaic trait of the compounds. In simplifying the initial cluster *g̑ʰdi̯-, most languages have ousted one of the two stops."}];689;294[266-270{S.v. PIE *g̑ʰés- 'gestern' Adverb, temporal. Cf. for extensive discussion of attempted reconstructions underlying the lexemes in this class.}];269[{The cognacy of the lexemes in this class is not disputed, however there remains much disagreement in the literature how the forms are derived in the attested languages from a common reconstruction. The two most commonly held hypotheses include (1) derivations related to the Germanic word for 'day' (cf. [cognate set 200](cog-200), not without its own problems in derivation) as *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es- (zero-grade root + comparative suffix or endingless locative) or (2) a compound of the Indo-European deictic *g̑ʰo- ~ *g̑ʰ- (cf. LIPP 2 275-276) in the zero-grade + the root *dei̯- ~ *di- 'shine' (NIL 69-81, cf. esp. fn6), which underlies words for day in many other branches (cf. [cognate set 375](cog-375)). For a recent extensive discussion of these and other hypotheses, cf. LIPP 2 269-270. For the root ref. form in this class, I follow LIPP 2 for a reconstruction *g̑ʰés- as the basic particle from which the attested forms are derived.}];274[69-81{Cf. s.v. *dei̯-, *di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f., EIEC 513), specifically under the potentially derived form ?*(g̑ʰ)-di̯-es and discussion contained in footnotes 6-18.}]
Justification: Cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) s.v. *g̑ʰés- 'gestern' for extensive discussion of the attempted reconstructions of forms in this class, also [NIL](src-274) s.v. *dei̯-, *di- under ?*(g̑ʰ)-di-es (with discussion in footnotes 6-18). The cognacy of the lexemes in this class is not disputed, however there remains much disagreement in the literature how the forms are derived in the attested languages from a common reconstruction. The two most commonly held hypotheses include (1) derivations related to the Germanic word for 'day' (cf. [cognate set 200](cog-200), not without its own problems in derivation) as *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es- (zero-grade root + comparative suffix or endingless locative) or (2) a compound of the Indo-European deictic *g̑ʰo- ~ *g̑ʰ- (cf. LIPP 2 275-276) in the zero-grade + the root *dei̯- ~ *di- 'shine' ([NIL](src-274) 69-81, cf. esp. fn6), which underlies words for day in many other branches (cf. [cognate set 375](cog-375)). For a recent extensive discussion of these and other hypotheses, cf. LIPP 2 269-270. For individual branches, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1692, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):138, [Orel 1998](src-105):68, [EWAia](src-172) II:822, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:313-314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):175-176, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):283, [Matasović 2009](src-50):155). Cf. also [Schindler 1977](src-689) and [Puhvel 1987](src-588) for further discussion on aspects of the IE reconstruction.

Source: 320[164{S.v. Khot. dai (1) 'fire| caustic stuff'. Derived from base dag- 'to burn' < PIE *dʰegʷʰ- (IEW 240-1), cf. Ved. dāgha-, Goth. dags.}];141[133-134{Cf. s.v. *dʰegʷʰ- 'mit Feuer behandeln, verbrennen (tr.)' (IEW 240-1).}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to burn' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):164, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 133-134).

Source: 321[162-163{S.v. Wakhi δαy 'муж, мужчина, человек', IIr. *δaha-, Khot. daha- 'муж, мужчина', cf. Ved. dāsá- 'не ариец, раб', etc.}];172[I:723-724{Cf. s.v. Ved. dāsá- 'ein den ā́rya- feindlicher Volksstamm, Feind, feindlicher Dämon| Sklave, Diener' (IIr. cf. Khot. daha-, Waxi δay 'Mann', etc.). Probably not to be separated from dásyu- 'Götterfeind, Feind, Dämon (etc.)' < IIr. *dási̯u- 'Feind, Fremder, Fremdvolk', further connections are uncertain.}];320[155{S.v. Khot. daha- 'man, male person' in contrast to 'woman' .}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *dāsá-, cf. Vedic dāsá- 'non-Aryan; fiend, demon, evil-being; slave, servant', further connections uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:723-724, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):162-163, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):155).

Source: 141[394-395{S.v. *kʷi̯eu̯- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (IEW 539).}];156[I:307-308{Cf. Pers. šudan : šaw-, Chorezm. ciya-, Khot. tsu-, tsuta-, Av. šav-, šyav-, Ved. cyav-, Gk. σεύω.}];567[283{Bactrian þαο-/þοδο < Proto-Iranian *čyawa-/*čyuta- (cf. Ved. cyáva- 'to move, undertake', Av. š́auu(a)-, Khot. tsū-, tsuta- 'to go').}];83[40-42{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯au- 'move, go'.}];172[I:552-553{Cf. s.v. Ved. √cyav- 'in Bewegung geraten, sich bewegen, unternehmen', from PIE *ki̯eu̯-.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:307-308, [Cheung 2007](src-83):40-42, [EWAia](src-172) I:552-553, [LIV²](src-141) 394-395).

Source: 66[1055-1056{S.v. οἶκος 'house, dwelling of any kind, room, home, household, native land' < PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-/*u̯oi̯k̑- 'house' (= Lat. vīcus 'group of houses, village', Skt. véśa- 'house' < PIE *u̯ói̯k̑-o-).}];141[669-670{Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯k̑- 'eingehen in, eintreten' (IEW [1129] 1131).}];172[II:584-585{Cf. s.v. Ved. veśá- 'Insasse, Eingesessener' (cf. IIr. YAv. vaēsa-, Khot. bīsa), derived from √veś- < PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-.}]
Justification: Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-/*u̯oi̯k̑- 'house' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1055-1056, [EWAia](src-172) II:584-585, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 669-670).

Source: 274[385-387{S.v. *h₃nebʰ- 'Nabel, Nabe' (IEW 314f.).}];66[1080{S.v. ὀμφαλός 'navel, navel string' < *h₃enbʰ-, *h₃mbʰ-, *h₃nebʰ- 'navel'. The Greek words for navel correspond closely to Lat. umbilīcus and OIr. imbliu, reflecting a common derived base *h₃mbʰ-l-.}];172[II:13-14{S.v. Ved. nábhya- 'Nabe des Rades' (Av. nāfa- 'Nabel, Ursprung, Blutsverwandtschaft' MPers. nāfag, etc.), from PIE *h₃nebʰ-/*h₃nobʰ-/*h₃n̥bʰ- 'Nabel, usw.' (cf. Gk. ὀμφαλός, Lat. umbilīcus, etc.).}];353[562{S.v. OPruss. nabis 'navel' from PIE *h₃nebʰ- (cf. Skt. nā́bhi- 'Navel', Gk. ὀμφαλός 'navel| umbilical cord', Lat. umbilīcus 'navel, centre', OHG naba 'nave', nabalo, nabulo 'navel').}];165[380{S.v. Proto-Germanic *nablan- 'navel', as though from PIE *h₃nobʰ-l-on- (cf. Gk. ὀμφαλός < *h₃mbʰ-l̥-, Lat. umbilīcus < *h₃mbʰ-e/ol- + *-īko-, OIr. imbliu 'navel' < *h₃mbʰ-el-ion-).}];54[639{S.v. umbilīcus 'navel, centre', from PIE *h₃nebʰ-(e/o)l- 'navel'.}];50[33{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ambliyon- 'navel', generalised from the oblique stem of the PIE word for 'navel' *h₃nbʰ-l-.}];325[47{"S[arikoli] vïnuǰ < *nuvaǰ < *nābaka-?"}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃nebʰ- 'navel' ([NIL](src-274) 385-387, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1080, [EWAia](src-172) II:13-14, [Derksen 2015](src-353):562, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):380, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):639, [Matasović 2009](src-50):33)

Source: 141[154{S.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273).}];66[1506-1507{S.v. τρέχω 'to run, hurry', from IE *dʰregʰ- 'run' (cf. Gk. τροχός 'wheel', OIr. droch < *dʰrogʰ-o-).}];460[556-557{Cf. s.v. AGk. (Dor.) τράχω 'laufen' > Tsakon. τ͡σάχου.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1506-1507, [LIV²](src-141) 154). For the Tsakonian lexemes in this class, cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):556-557.

Source: 66[786-787{S.v. AGk. κρύπτω 'to conceal, hide'. Although reminiscent of some potential cognates in Balto-Slavic (cf. OCS kryti 'κρύπτω, ἀποκρύπτω', Lith. kráuti 'pile up') there is no good Indo-European etymology.  The alternation of stem-final π~φ~β verbal forms and derived forms leads Beekes to suppose that the word may be from a Pre-Greek language.}];270[589{S.v. AGk. κρύπτω 'envelopper pour cacher'. AGk. κρύπτω is very similar to καλύπτω 'cover' and the two verbs may have influenced each other. If one ignores the vowel quantity and the final labial the verb is very close to OCS kryjǫ, kryti 'cacher'.}]
Justification: No precise correspondences outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):589, [Beekes 2010](src-66):786-787). The closest possible correspondences are in Balto-Slavic (cf. OCS kryti 'hide', Lith. kráuti 'heap' in [cognate set 5275](cog-5275)), but the connection is uncertain.

Source: 66[1345-1346{S.v. σκέλλομαι 'to dry up, wither, languish, grow tired, harden' < PIE *skelh₁-i̯e/o-, with derived adjective σκληρός 'hard' is a derived adjective from the same root.}];269[{NB: σκληρός < *skl̥h₁-ró- is contains a regular reflex for syllabic resonants in the environment *CR̥HC- > CRV̄C- thus the postulation of a Schwebeablaut variant *skleh₁- is unnecessary.}];141[553{Cf. s.v. *(s)kelh₁- 'austrocknen, verdorren' (IEW 927).}];270[1012-1013{S.v. AGk. σκέλλομαι, to a root *skelh₁- with variant *skleh₁- (cf. Dor. σκληρός).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *skl̥h₁-ró-, an derived adjective to PIE *(s)kelh₁- 'to dry out, dry up' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1012-1013, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1345-1346, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 553).

Source: 66[976{S.v. μυῖα 'fly', from PIE *mus-ih₂.}];54[397{S.v. Lat. musca, from PIE *mu-s-, possibly originally formed from an onomatopoeic base *mu-.  The s-extended forms are found in Latin, Balto-Slavic, Greek, and Germanic.}];81[330-331{S.v. Proto-Slavic *muxa 'fly', cf. also Proto-Slavic mъxa 'midge'. The root of the former etyma apparently shows an o-grade *mou̯s-, whereas the latter continues the zero-grade *mus- found more widely in other branches. Cf. entry s.v. *muxa for discussion of the possibilities on the origins of the alternative root vocalism.}];369[270{S.v. Alb. míz/ë 'Fliege', usually connected with other IE words for 'fly', cf. Gk. μυῖα 'Fliege', ON mý 'Mücke', etc., from Proto-Albanian *mū- + suff. -zë.}];105[268{S.v. Alb. mizë 'fly', a derivative in -zë based on PAlb. *mūjā, identical to ON my, and further connected to Gk. μυῖα, Lat. musca, etc.}];353[326{S.v. Lith. mùsė 'fly' (Latv. muša 'fly', OPr. muso 'fly'), cf. Gk. μυῖα 'fly', Lat. musca 'mosquito'.}];352[673-674{S.v. OLith. mùsė (2), musė̃ 'Fliege' (BSl. Latv. muša 'Fliege', OPr. muso 'Fliege', OCS muxa 'Fliege', etc.), from PIE *mus- 'Fliege, Mücke' (cf. Gk. μυῖα 'Fliege', κυνάμυια 'Hundsfliege', Arm. mown 'Mücke, Insekt', Lat. musca 'Fliege').}];458[20: 170-172{The word is derived from PIE *mū, *mus- and related to Lithuanian musià, Latin musca, Old High German mucka etc.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *mus- 'fly, gnat', cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):976, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):270, [Orel 1998](src-105):268, [ALEW](src-352) 673-674, [Derksen 2015](src-353):326, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:170-172, [Derksen 2008](src-81):330-331, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):397).

Source: 66[65{S.v. ἀλέω 'to grind' < PIE *h₂elh₁- 'grind'.}];141[277{S.v. h₂leh₁- 'zermahlen' (IEW 28-9).  Reconstructs ?*h₂l̥h₁-i̯é- > Gr. ἀλέω 'mahle', ?Arm. ałam 'mahle'.}];271[62{S.v. αλέθω. The Modern Greek verbal stem has been remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀλέω on the basis of the analogy κλωσ- (aor.) :  αλεσ- (aor.) :: κλώθω : X --> αλέθω.}];79[26-27{S.v. ałam 'to grind', connected with Greek ἀλέω 'to grind' < *h₂elh₁- 'grind'.}];558[93{Points out that the stem formation of the Armenian forms can go back to either an n-infix present *h₂l̥-n-h₁- or a thematic root present *h₂alh₁-/*h₂l̥h₁-.}];320[22{S.v. Khot. ārr- 'to grind'. Base ar- 'to grind', pres. stem. *ar-na- > ārr-, cf. Av. -arəna- in yāv-arəna- 'tool for grinding'. To be connected with the root of Greek ἀλέω 'to grind', ἀλετών 'mill', ἄλεαρ 'flour', Armen. ałam 'to grind', aliur, aleur 'flour', alauri 'mill'.}];83[166{S.v. Proto-Iranian *HarH- 'to grind (grain)', from PIE *h₂elh₁- 'to grind'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Armenian, and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂leh₁- 'to grind up' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 277, [Beekes 2010](src-66):65, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):26-27, [Cheung 2007](src-83):166, [Bailey 1979](src-320):22, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):93).

Source: 320[78{S.v. Khot. gaḍaa- 'throat, neck', from *gartaka- to base *gart- 'to turn, roll' (Zor.P. gltn, gldn, *gartan, gardan 'neck', NPers. gardan, M.Pers.T. grdn 'neck', Sogd. γrδʾkh *γarδakā-.}];83[104-105, 110-111{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *gart- 'to turn'. "The Ir. root with no exact IE correspondences seems to be an enlarged root of *gar². It has probably been influenced by *u̯art-." Cf. s.v. *gar-² 'to turn, wind' "IE cognate forms of this apparently "unenlarged" Ir. root are uncertain. The nominal forms quoted by Pok. (l.c.) are set with problems. The enlarged variants are *gart- and *garš²." [Cf. IEW 385.]}];331[III:196-203{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *¹gart- / *garθ- : grt- / grθ- : grat-, *graθ-.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', without any clear correspondences outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):104-105, 110-111, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):78, [ESIJa](src-331) III:196-203).

Source: 320[40{S.v. Khot. urmaysde 'sun', from Ir. ahura- and mazdāh (Av. ahurō mazdā̊, OPers. a(h)uramazdā, Zor.Pahl. ’whrmazd, NPers. Hurmizd, Chores. rēmažd).}];780[{Cf. s.v. Ahura Mazdā}]
Comment: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism.
Justification: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism ([Bailey 1979](src-320):40). The name is often hypothesised to have originally meant 'wise lord' (vel sim.), although the grammatical relations in the noun phrase remain disputed (cf. [Encyclopædia Iranica](src-780) s.v.). Because of the substantivisation of the noun from a compound theonym, it is difficult to isolate a semantic head for etymological analysis. For etymological discussion of the individual elements of the original compound / noun phrase, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:147-148 (~ OAv. ahura-), [EWAia](src-172) II:378 (~ OAv. mazdā-).

Source: 141[76-77{S.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).}];567[201{S.v. Bactrian βαρ- < Proto-Iranian *bara-/*br̥ta- 'bear, carry'.}];83[6-10{S.v. Proto-Iranian *bar- 'bring, carry' < PIE *bʰer- 'bring, bear, carry'.}];172[I:246-249{S.v. Ved. √bhar- 'tragen, hegen, pflegen| bringen' < PIE *bʰer-.}];66[1562-1564{S.v. φέρω 'to bear, endure, carry off, bring away, provide, reach, move along, etc.' < PIE *bʰer- 'bear, carry'. The non-present stems in Ancient Greek are suppletive: fut. οἴσω < ?*h₃ei̯t- (LIV² 297), aor. ἤνεγκα, pf. ἐνήνοχα < *h₁nek̑- (LIV² 250-251, IEW 316-8).}];54[213-214{S.v. Lat. ferō, ferre (irregular verb) 'to carry, take' < PIE *bʰer- 'carry'. The suppletive perfect stem tuli and p.p.p. lātum < *tlh₂-to- 'lifted' are based on the root *telh₂- 'lift, take' (LIV² 622-623, IEW 1060-1), cf. Lat. tollō 'lift'.}];165[59{S.v. Proto-Germanic *beran- 1 'to bear, carry, give birth' < PIE *bʰér-e-.}];345[397-398{S.v. TochB pär- 'bear (away), carry (off)| take up, wear' < PIE *bʰer- 'bear, carry'.}];79[176{S.v. Arm. berem 'to bring, bear, give fruit' < PIE *bʰer- 'bear'.}];50[62{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry, bear, bring' < PIE *bʰer- 'carry'.}];364[965{S.v. Alb. bart 'tragen, transportieren', certainly continues an o-grade present stem from the root *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (LIV² 76f.) but it is unclear whether this is a reflex of a PIE iterative *bʰor-éi̯e/o- because umlaut is completely lacking in the Old Gheg present stem paradigm.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ([LIV²](src-141) 76-77, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):397-398, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1562-1564, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):176, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):965, [EWAia](src-172) I:246-249, [Cheung 2007](src-83):6-10, [Seebold 1970](src-556):104-106, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):59, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):213-214, [Matasović 2009](src-50):62).

Source: 141[391-392{S.v. *kʷer- '(ab)schneiden, schnitzen' (IEW 641-2).}];156[I:579-581];172[I:307-309{S.v. Ved. √kar- 'tun, machen, bewirken, handeln' < PIIr. čar-/kar- < PIE *kʷer-/kʷor- (cf. Hitt. kuer- 'schneiden', OIr. cruth, Wel. pryd 'Gestalt' (*kʷr̥-tu-), Lith. kùrti 'errichten, bauen').}];567[223{Bactrian κιρ-/κιρδο from Proto-Iranian *kr̥nu-/*kr̥ta- (cf. OPers. kun(av)-/kr̥ta-, Chor. ʾk-/ʾkt-).}];389[{Perhaps the IIr. verbs in from *kʷer- in LIV² could also be with 2. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden'.}]
Justification: Root assignment to PIE *kʷer- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 391-392, [IEW](src-49) 641-2). Alternatively, the IIr. cognates assigned to this root might be with *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 399[II: 540-542{S.v. Skt. mákṣā 'Fliege', 'fly'| also found in Iranian (cf. Av. maxšī- Buddh. Sogd. mwγšk-), but there are no certain connections for this Indo-Iranian lexeme to other Indo-European languages. IIr. *makš- does however appear to have been loaned into Uralic at an early period (cf. Finn. mehilänen, mordwin. mekš, meš, Hungar. méh, etc. < *mekš-).}];172[II:287{S.v. Ved. makṣ- 'Fliege (oder Biene)', cf. IIr. YAv. maxšī- 'Fliege', Sogd. mwxšk- 'Moskito', etc., from IIr. *makš-.}];442[554{S.v. 9696 Skt. mákṣā- 'fly' (RV.).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:287, [KEWA](src-399) II:540-542). For the Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):554 no. 9696.

Source: 54[184{S.v. Lat. dūrus 'hard, solid, endurable', from PIE *duh₂-ró-, where the same root ablaut is found in Indo-Iranian (Skt. dūrá- 'far, distant', Av. dūrāt̰ 'from afar' OPers. dūraiy 'far and wide'.  Greek and Armenian show forms with an e-grade: Att. δηρός 'long, too long', Arm. erkar 'long (in time)' < *du̯eh₂-ró-.}];389[{The meaning of the verbal root PIE *du̯eh₂- is 'entfernen, abtrennen'.}];172[I:739{S.v. Ved. dūrá- 'fern' (adj.), 'Ferne' (n.), IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. dūrat̰ 'von fern', OAv. dūirē, YAv. dūire 'fern', etc., from PIE *duh₂-ró- to PIE *du̯eh₂- 'sich entfernen, räumlich und zeitlich erstrecken'. Cf. *du̯eh₂-m > Gk. δήν, *du̯eh₂-ró- > Skt. dūrá-, Gk. δηρός, Arm erkar 'lange dauernd| Hitt. tūu̯a- 'fern' < *duh₂-i̯o-| Lat. dūdum.}];320[161{S.v. Khot. dūra- 'hard', from *daura- (cf. Oss. D. dor, I. daur 'stone', Lat. dūrus 'hard' ([IEW](src-49) 215).}]
Justification: Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *duh₂-ró- ([Bailey 1979](src-320):161, [EWAia](src-172) I:739, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):184; for the root *du̯eh₂- 'to remove, separate from' cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389))

Source: 66[{S.v. κλαίω 'to lament, bewail, weep over'. The present stem κλαίω is from Proto-Greek *κλάϝ-i̯ω by internal reconstruction (cf. future κλαύ-σ-ομαι).  The only comparable cognates are Albanian klan, qan 'to weep', from these it is possible to postulate a PIE root *kleh₂u̯-, but the given that there are no further comparanda the evidence is very slim.}];141[362{S.v. ?*⁽k̑⁾leh₂u̯- or 'weinen' (IEW 599).  Only Greek and Albanian attested as comparanda (cf. Old Tosk claàne (i.e. / klānë /). 'sie weinen').}];105[353-354{S.v. Alb. qaj ~ qanj 'to cry, to weep'. Tosk and Greco-Albanian forms preserve initial kl-, from Proto-Albanian *klaunja and cognate with Greek κλαίω (< *κλάϝιω).}];364[993{S.v. Alb. qan 'weinen', continuing PIE *⁽k̑⁾leh₂u̯- or *⁽k̑⁾lau̯- (cf. Gk. κλαίω 'weinen').}];174[I:865{S.v. Gk. κλαίω 'laut klagen, (be)weinen'. Only a reasonable connection is offered by Albanian klanj, kanj 'weinen' from *qlau-n-i̯ō with a combination of a nasal and yod-suffix.}];270[538{S.v. Gk. κλαίω 'pleurer, gémir bruyamment', etc. No etymology. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) recalls a connection with Albanian klanj, kanj 'pleurer' < *qlau-n-yō.}]
Justification: A probable Greek-Albanian isogloss (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 362, [Orel 1998](src-105):353-354, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):993, [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) I:865, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):538 [Beekes 2010](src-66):709).

Source: 172[I:241-242{S.v. Ved. ūrú- 'Schenkel, Oberschenkel'. Etymology outside of Indo-Iranian unclear.}];320[492{S.v. Khot. hurā 'thigh', from *urāva-, from *uru- (cf. Ved. ūrú- 'thigh').}];442[114{S.v. 2420 ūrú- m. 'thigh' RV.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:241-242, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):114 no. 2420); for Khotanese cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):492.

Source: 338[{Abaev derives from *sikita-, *sika-, *sikaya- or similar PIr. forms, and compares to Balochi six, Pashto šəga, Old Persian ϑikā- 'rubble', Khotanese siyatā- 'sand'. But Cheung rather considers it a Wanderwort, which may explain the diversity of forms.}];156[III:187-188{S.v. Oss. syǵyt | sigit, sik’it 'земля', continuing the Indo-Iranic word for 'sand, dust, earth' in forms *sika-, *sikaya-, *sikata-, *sika- (Bel. six, Afg. šǝga, Vanetsi sǝga, Par. sǝɣa, OPers. θikā-, etc.}];442[772{Cf. s.v. 13386 Skt. síkatā f. 'grain of sand', (usu. pl.) 'sand, gravel'. Nuristani and Dardic forms attest IA ś- corresponding to Ir. θ- and s- (OPers. θikā-, Bal. six, Pasht. šəga, etc.), suggesting that the s- forms of Skt. and Dardic may be loans or influenced by Iranic.}];172[II:728{Cf. s.v. Ved. síkata- 'Sand, Kies, Grieß' not to be separated from Iranian cognates: OPers. θikā- 'Kies, Schotter', Khot. siyata, Sogd. šykth, Pashto šəga, səga 'sand', Oss. syǵyt/sigit, sik’it 'Erde', etc.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes connected with other Indo-Iranic words for 'sand, dust' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:187-188). The correspondence of Indic *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):772, no. 13386); [EWAia](src-172) II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

Source: 66[227-228{S.v. γλυκύς 'sweet' < ?*dlku- 'sweet'. Mycenaean de-re-u-ko (perhaps /dleu̯kos/) makes the hypothesis of dissimilation *δλ- > γλ- possible, but the -υ- in the root is still unexpected, making a connection to Lat. dulcis via *dl̥k-u- (vel sim.) still problematic.}];269[{On the basis of Mycenaean and Classical Attic forms, I suggest a reconstructed Proto-Greek *dl(e)u̯ku- (vel sim.) for a root reference form.}];270[228-229{S.v. Gk. γλυκύς 'doux', a single ingenious hypothesis, but on narrow ground: if one admits a development *δλ- > γλ- supposing *δλυκύς one may connect Lat. dulcis.}]
Justification: Very similar in form and meaning to Latin dulcis 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):228-229, [Beekes 2010](src-66):227-228). Cf. further discussion in [cognate set 7772](cog-7772).

Source: 66[1190{S.v. AGk. πικρός < PIE *pik̑-ro- 'motley, painted'. The Greek forms are identical to Common Slavic *pьstrъ. Cf. Skt. piṃśáti 'to carve, cut to measure, ornament', OCS pьsati 'to write'.  In a different ablaut grade cf. Gk. ποικίλος 'many coloured, spotted, dappled' < *poik̑-.}];141[465-466{C.f. s.v. *pei̯k̑- 'heraushauen, herausschneiden' (IEW 794-5).}];270[900-901{S.v. AGk. πικρός 'qui pique, qui perce'. The root *pik- is attested in the Skt. nasal-infix present piṁśáti 'tailler, couper, façonner, orner', etc., Av. paēs- 'colorer, orner', Lith. piẽšti 'peindre, écrire', cf. OCS pĭsati 'écrire', as well as the adjective pĭstrŭ 'bariolé' which corresponds precisely to the form πικρός. Cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) for other hypothetical connections in Indo-Iranian.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from PIE *pik̑-ro-, a derivative to PIE *pei̯k̑- 'to cut out, carve out' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):900-901, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1190, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 465-466).

Source: 66[1350-1351{Cf. s.v. σκιά 'shade' (< PIE *skeh₂-ih₂, gen. *skh₂-ieh₂-s 'shadow') and s.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark' (< PIE *skeh₃t- or *skoto- 'shadow, dark'). Note p.1351 "The relation [of Gk. σκιά] with σκότος is unclear". (Cf. Skt. chāyā́ 'shadow', Av. a-saiia 'who casts no shadow'.)}];172[I:559-560{S.v. Ved. chāyā́- f. 'Schatten| Widerschein, Abbild' < PIE *sk̑eh₁-i̯éh₂- (cf. Gk. σκιά, Alb. hije, TochB skiyo 'Schatten').}];81[447{S.v. Proto-Slavic *sěnь 'shadow', from PIE *skoHi-n(-i)- (cf. Skt. chāyā́-, 'shadow, reflection', Gk. σκιά 'shadow'. Alb. hije 'shadow').}];460[498{S.v. AGk. σκία 'Schatten' > Cypriot and Italiot οσ̆σ̆ιά related to Ancient Greek σκία (cf. also s.v. the AGk. diminutive σκαδίον).}];269[{The communis opinio is that the relationship between the lexemes in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058) and [cognate set 8269](cog-8269) have irreconcilable root reconstructions and must be separated into *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂- and *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-. Cognacy has been thus assigned in this manner according to the main etymological authorities.  The reconstruction of two separate roots, however crucially hinges on the interpretation of the Greek evidence: Germanic lexemes from PGmc. *skadu- < *s⁽k̑⁾H-tu- appear to be a close parallel formation to Greek σκοτός 'darkness' which reflect earlier *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-tó-.  These are potentially different roots, but this is based entirely on the witness of the Greek evidence.  In any case, the difference is based on disagreement over root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃.  The identity of the laryngeal in σκία < *skh₂-ih₂ is assumed from Att.-Ion. σκηνή, West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́ 'tent' < 'cloth to provide shade' < (transponat) *skeh₂-néh₂ (cf. Beekes 2010, s.v. σκία).  In Ancient Greek does exist another example of a doublet of root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃, namely the dialectal doublet of Attic-Ionic πρῶτος 'first' (ostensibly from *pr̥h₃-to-) against West Greek πρᾶτος 'first' (ostensibly from < *pr̥h₂-to-), cf. Ved. pūrvá- 'first' (formally from *pr̥H-u̯ó-).  One could imagine there may have been some inner-Greek phonological or derivational reason to account for the discrepancy in vocalism. It seems therefore very possible, in view of the phonological and semantic similarities, that the Tocharian, Greek, Albanian, Indo-Iranian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058) and the Celtic and Germanic lexemes (+Gk. σκότος) in [cognate set 8269](cog-8269) go back to the same root etymology with differing derivational morphology. Cognacy has been coded, however, according to the prevailing opinion.}];345[773{S.v. TochB skiyo 'shade, shadow', from PIE *sk̑oihª (gen. *sk̑ii̯éhªs-) 'shade, shadow' (cf. Gk. σκιά 'shadow', Alb. hije 'shadow', Av. asaya- 'who throws no shadow', Skt. chāyā́ 'shade, shadow, etc.).}];105[147-148{S.v. Alb. hije 'shadow', a singularised plural of an archaic hē, going back to Proto-Albanian *skijā, connected with PIE *sk̑āi- ~ *sk̑ī- (cf. Skt. chāyā́-. Gk. σκιά, etc.).}];369[201{S.v. Alb. hí/e, -a 'Schatten', connected to Ved. chāya-, Gk. σκιά, TochB skio, etc. < *sk̑éh₁-ih₂.}];442[275-276{S.v. 5027 Ved. chāyā́- f. 'shade, shadow, reflection' RV.}]
