Comment: For the discussion on the Slavic cognates cf. [cognate set 5209](cog-5209) and [cognate set 5149](cog-5149).
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of a PIE root *s⁽k̑⁾eH- where the indeterminate laryngeal is probably *-h₂- on the basis of Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351). Also attested in Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although formally they may well be (sandhi?) variants of one another at the PIE level. For further discussion cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):773, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):498, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):201, [Orel 1998](src-105):147-148, [EWAia](src-172) I:559-560, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):275-276 no. 5027, [Derksen 2008](src-81):447).

Source: 141[650-1{S.v. *tres- '(vor Schreck) zittern' (IEW 1095).}];83[393-394{S.v. Proto-Iranian *θrah (*trs) 'to shake, tremble, fear, flee' < PIE *tres- 'tremble, be afraid'.}];172[I:678-679{Cf. s.v. Ved. √tras- 'zittern, erbeben, scheuen, ängstlich sein' < PIE *tres-.}];325[101{for Sarikoli: "*us-ϑrahāka-"}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tres- 'to tremble, be afraid' ([LIV²](src-141) 650-651, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):393-394, [EWAia](src-172) I:678-679).

Source: 66[1059-1060{S.v. οἴομαι 'to suspect, expect, think, believe, deem'. Etymological details are unclear.  If connectable to Skt. āviṣ 'evidently, before the eyes' then we may be dealing with a de-adverbial formation from a possible pre-form *h₂ou̯is > *h₂ou̯is-i̯é- which could have yielded οἴομαι.}];270[785-786{S.v. οἴομαι 'avoir l'impression que', etc. The variant forms appear to go back to *ὀϝις-yομαι, but the etymology is unknown.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek unknown, possibly to PIE *h₂eu̯- 'to perceive' if a de-adverbial formation as though from *h₂ou̯is-i̯é- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1059-1060, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):785-786).

Source: 68[223{"clearly of imitative origin. and may be ultimately related to Gk. καχάζω, Skt. kákhati, Lat. cachinnō, OHG kakhazzen (IEW 634| cf. T 122-23 and refs.)."}];269[{No lemma in [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80) presumably because the Hittite form is of obvious onomatopoeic origin, cf. [HED H](src-407). Unlikely to be etymologically related to the comparanda given by [Weeks 1985](src-68):223 for phonological reasons.}];407[7-8{Onomatopoeic word.  No further etymology.}]
Justification: Of imitative/onomatopoeic origin, cf. [HED H](src-407):7-8, HW² Ḫ. Unlikely to be etymologically related to the comparanda given by [Weeks 1985](src-68):223 for phonological reasons.

Source: 567[219{Bactrian καβογγο < *kapuna-ka- (cf. Pth. qfwn 'old' < *kafwana-).}];83[234{S.v. Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike (down)' Cf. Under NEIr." "The 'old' forms, MMP qhwn, BMP khwbn /kahwan/, Pth. kfwn, NP kuhan, Bal. kwahn (kwān) Khot. kuhana-, Bact. καβογγο also contain this root [...]", further from PIE *kop- 'to fell, chop' (LIV 555, IEW 930ff.), cf. Gk. κόπτω, Lith. kapiù (kàpti) 'I chop, I fell', Lith. kapóti, Latv. kapât 'to hack, strike, cut', Alb. kep- 'to hew, chisel, stitch').}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down', further connected to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, hew' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):234-235, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).

Source: 320[504{S.v. Khot. hvarra-, from base *hvar- with increment -z- (IE g̑, g̑ʰ) in Av. xvarəzišta- 'sweetest', Zor.P. xvarzist, NPers. xvālīdan 'to taste', Arm. LW axorž 'sweet', etc.}];325[97{"Generally (e. g. Gen. 27) derived < *hwarza-, cf. Av. x-arǝ-zišta-| Oss. xorz/xwarz good. But *rz regularly > Š[uγni] γ̌j, R[oshani], etc. wj, S[arikoli] rz| Y[azghulami] (w)z. Note also Psht. xōǧ, f. xwaǧa sweet (Wan[etsi] xōrž, xwarža), but *rz > ǧd. - Ir. *rž ( < lE *rǵh+s) might give Psht. ǧ. Wan. rž, Oss. rz, but not Š[uγni]Gr[oup] γ̌ (cf. s. v. wūrγ̌). The exact derivation of xīγ̌, etc., therefore remains uncertain."}]
Justification: If a derivative from Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'consume' (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):504) then perhaps to be linked with 'eat' in [cognate set 27](cog-27), 'drink' in [cognate set 3691](cog-3691).

Source: 66[1229-1230{S.v. πράσσω 'to pass through, travel' < PIE ?*per(h₂)- 'go through, cross'. All forms in Ancient Greek reflect a stem *πρᾱκ- or πρᾱγ-. This might reflect PIE *per- 'go through' with a *-k- extension of the root (cf. ἐρύ-κ-ω), but the root and stem are otherwise derivationally obscure.}];270[934-935{S.v. AGk. πρᾱ́σσω 'achever, accomplir, travailler à, traiter une affaire, pratiquer'. The Homeric usages guarantee that is may be derived from a more basic root πρᾱ-, cf. πραθῆναι and see s.v. πέρνημαι and that the whole family depends on the root of πείρω, πέρᾱ, etc. The final velar must connote the outcome of the process (cf. Schwyzer Gr. Gr. I:702).}]
Justification: Often connected with the family of Ancient Greek πείρω 'pierce, run through' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 472-473 s.v. 1. *per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren') with a velar extension to the root, but the root and stem formation remains nonetheless obscure (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):934-935, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1229-1230).

Source: 66[530{S.v. AGk. θάλασσα 'sea'. A loanword from a Pre-Greek substratum language, but evidently quite an early one due to the differing reflexes of -ττ-/-σσ- among the Ancient Greek dialects.}];269[{Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Attic, Boeotian θάλαττα, Ionic, etc. θάλασσα) point to a pre-form *tʰálakʸːa, vel sim.}];270[420{S.v. AGk. θάλασσα (Att. θάλαττα), general term for designating the sea, of obscure origin.}]
Justification: Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):420, [Beekes 2010](src-66):530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).

Source: 66[42{S.v. αἱρέω 'to take, grasp, sieze'. "No etymology." [No reference to new literature that has appeared since [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270), or even discussion of previous proposals in earlier works).}];141[535{S.v. 3. *ser- 'nehmen, ergreifen' [IEW 909-10]. A Greek-Baltic lexical isogloss. (cf. Latv. siŗu (sirt) 'Raubzüge machen').}]
Justification: Root etymology for the Hellenic lexemes in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 535 as though from PIE *sr̥-i̯é- to PIE 3. *ser- 'to take, seize, grasp', but cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) I:43-44, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):38, [Beekes 2010](src-66):42 (without reference to new literature in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 740[IV:463-464];180[42{Arm. cʻowrt 'cold' < *sk̑ū-do- (?) has been compared to OHG, OS, OE scūr 'Platzregen, shower' < *sk̑uH-ro-. The supplementary *-d- of the Armenian stem may not necessarily be an actual suffix, but one might consider the verbal stem *-dh₃o- 'giving' in which case cʻowrt could be an original compound. Alternatively one might consider influence from semantically related 'hail' karkowt.}];79[630-631{S.v. Arm. cʻurt 'cold| cold water'. The word has been compared with Pers. sard, Arm. saṙn 'cold', alternatively it has been compared with OCS sěverъ 'North, Northern wind', SCr. sjȅvēr 'North', Lith. šiáurė 'North' < *k̑eh₁uer-o-| Lat. caurus 'northwestern wind' < *k̑h₁-u̯er-o-.}]
Justification: Origin uncertain, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:463-464, [Olsen 1999](src-180):42, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):630-631 for various proposals. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsʰurt-o-].

Source: 172[II:660-661{S.v. Ved. √śya- 'gefrieren, gerinnen, erstarren', to which Ved. śītá- is a derived past passive participle. Outside of Indic cf. Kati šə, Oss. syjyn / sujun, Yagh. ši-. Etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not secure.}];399[III:383-384{S.v. śyā́yati 'macht gerinnen, macht gefrieren / causes to congeal, causes to freeze'. "Außerarische Anschüsse bleiben unsicher."}];83[39{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯aH-³ / *čiH- 'to freeze' > NPers. čā(h)īdan/čay- 'to become cold', Yaghn. ši- 'to freeze', etc.}];442[723{Cf. s.v. 12485 Ved. śītá- (1) 'cold' RV., śī́taka- 'cool' AV. [~ śīná -- . <-> √śyai-]}]
Justification: Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:660-661; cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:383-384 for various older proposals).

Source: 345[566{S.v. TochB yṣīye 'night, which together with TochA wṣe, is a derivative from PIE *h₂u̯es- 'stay, remain (the night)'.}];141[293-294{Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯es- '(ver)weilen, die Nacht verbringen' (IEW 72, 1170-1).}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ([Adams 2013](src-345):566, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 293-294).

Source: 172[II:544-545{Cf. s.v. Ved. vā́r- 'Wasser' (YAv. vāra- 'Regen', MPers. wārān-, NPers. bārān, etc.), from PIE *(H)u̯eh₁-r- (cf. Luw. u̯a-a-ar 'Wasser', TochA wär, TochB war 'Wasser', ONor. vari 'Flüssigkeit, Wasser').}];274[715-717{S.v. *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'Wasser' (IEW 80f., EIEC 636).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE r-stem *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water', cf. Vedic vā́r- 'water'. The root *u̯eh₁- is possibly a variant of PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:544-545, [NIL](src-274) 715-717).

Source: 323[40{S.v. Paš. kas- : kat- 'to look at, see', cf. Av. √kas-, Sgl. kas-, Sh čis-, etc.}];83[245-246{S.v. Proto-Iranic *kas- (1) 'to look, appear', from PIE *kʷek̑- 'to appear, show' (cf. Skt. kāś- 'to become visible, appear', Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'sign, mark').}];442[159{Cf. s.v. 3114 Skt. kā́śatē ʻ shines, is visible ʼ MBh. [√kāś-]}];172[I:344-345{Cf. s.v. Ved. √kāś- 'sichtbar werden, erscheinen', from which is derived ākāśá- 'freier Raum, Luftraum, Öffnung', perhaps to PIE *kʷek̑-, if the root is connected with Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Merkmal'.}];141[383-385{Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9).}]
Justification: Nuristani and Modern Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of', cf. Vedic kāś- 'to be visible, appear', Proto-Iranic *kas- 'to look, appear' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):159 no. 3114, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):40, [Cheung 2007](src-83):245-246, [EWAia](src-172) I:344-345, [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).

Source: 172[I:537{S.v. Ved. cárman- 'Haut, Fell, abgezogene Haut' (YAv. čarəman- 'Fell, Leder'). The Indo-Iranian forms reflect PIE *(s)ker-men- 'Abschnitt → abgezogene Haut', derived from PIE *(s)ker- (cf. Gk. κείρω 'schneide ab, schere', OE sceran 'scheren, abschneiden, usw.').}];141[556-557{Cf. s.v. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden' (IEW 938-40).}];81[234, 452{S.v. Proto-Slavic *skora 'bast, skin' (cf. Proto-Slavic *kora 'bark'), derived from PIE *(s)ker- (cf. Gk. κείρω 'shear', OIc. skera 'cut').}];259[553{PS *skora is derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.}];442[255{S.v. 4701 Ved. cárman n. 'hide, skin' RV.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off' ([EWAia](src-172) I:537, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):255 no. 4701, [Boryś 2005](src-259):553, [Derksen 2008](src-81):234, 452; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 556-557).

Source: 165[453-454{S.v. Proto-Germanic *slēpan- 'to sleep'. [No etymology outside of Germanic given.]}];141[565{S.v. ?*sleh₁b- 'schlaff sein' (IEW 656). If the forms under this lemma are cognate, then only Germanic and Balto-Slavic (if connected to Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'schwach werden').}];556[434-435{S.v. Gmc. *slǣp-a- 'schlafen'. No certain possibilities for comparison outside of Germanic. Perhaps a root *slāb- (or *slōb-) if connected to Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'schwach werden', OCS slabъ 'schwach'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):434-435, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):453-454. Perhaps to an IE root *sleh₁b- 'be slack'(?) if to be connected with Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'be weak' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 565).

Source: 83[413{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' "[T]he 'nose' word, MMP wynyg, BMP wynyk /wēnig/, probably contains *u̯ai(H)n-". The IIr. root is nominal in origin from the noun *u̯ai(H)na- 'watch, survey(or)', cf. Skt. vená- 'watch', YAv. vaēnā- 'nose', from PIE *u̯ei(h₁)-no- 'survey' (cf. Lat. vēnārī 'to chase, hunt').}];141[668-669{Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4).}]
Comment: Middle and New Iranic languages exhibit an additional nominal suffix (e.g. Middle Persian -īg).
Justification: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.

Source: 304[538-543{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ret-e/o- 'rennen, laufen', from PIE *ret- (LIV² 507).}];141[507{S.v. *ret- 'laufen' (IEW 866).}];50[310{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ret-o- 'run', from PIE *(H)reth₂- 'run' (cf. Lat. rota 'wheel', Skt. rathá- 'chariot').}];296[R:23{S.v. OIr. reth- 'courir', from IE *reth- ([IEW](src-49) 866), cf. Lith ritù 'je roule', Skt. ráthaḥ 'char'.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ret- 'to run' ([LIV²](src-141) 507, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:23, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):538-543, [Matasović 2009](src-50):310).

Source: 50[281{S.v. Proto-Celtic *musso- 'dirty' < *mud-so-, derived from PIE *meu̯d- ([IEW](src-49) 742), cf. Gk. μύσος 'filth'.}];309[525{S.v. Bret. mous 'rance, miasmatique', corresponding to W mws 'rance, fétide, puant' and MIr. mosach 'puant, infect, ignoble', from a root *meud- 'horreur, objet d'horreur'.}];296[M:65{S.v. OIr. mosar 'saleté', mosach 'sale'. The related Celtic words are to be connected with Gk. μύσος 'souillure, infamie' to a root *meud- via a formation *mud-so- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 742).}];66[985{Cf. s.v. Gk. μύσος 'pollution, defilement, horrible sight', without certain etymology. Traditionally compared to words meaning 'unclean' in Celtic, Germanic, and Slavic in IEW 742 (OIr. mosach < *mussāko-, LG mussig 'dirty', Ru. múslit' 'to suck, beslaver'), further compared to the root of μυδάω 'to be moist, decay' as *mud-s-o- but this remains hypothetical.}]
Justification: Traditionally derived from PIE *mud-so- ([Matasović 2009](src-50):281, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:65, [IEW](src-49) 742) in comparison to Greek μύσος 'filth', however the etymology of the Greek form is unclear (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):985).

Source: 352[681-682{S.v. OLith. nãgas 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle, Huf' < PIE *h₃nógʷʰ-/*h₃n̥gʷʰ- 'Finger- oder Zehennagel, Kralle'.}];66[1086-1087{S.v. ὄνυξ, -υχος 'nail, claw, hoof'. Greek form presupposes *h₃nogʷʰ- or *h₃nogʰ-u- to account for the raising of radical *-o- > -u- by Cowgill's Law (i.e. -o- > -u- between a labial and a nasal, cf. νύξ 'night' < *nokʷt-s). Similarly Classical Armenian eɫungn must also reflect the same forms, but is also a secondary n-stem from the accusative.}];172[II:4-5{S.v. Ved. nakhá- 'Nagel, Fingernagel, Zehennagel, Kralle, Klaue'. "Iir. *nā̆kʰ- ist von idg. *h₃Engʰ-/*h₃nEgʰ- 'Nagel, Kralle' (~ lat. unguis, lit. nãgas Nagel u.a. o. I 49) nicht zu trennen." Cf. notes to entry in Mayrhofer for further discussion of the phonetic difficulties of the Indo-Iranian forms.}];353[327{S.v. Lith. nagà 'hoof, nail' (cf. Latv. nagas Npl. 'both hands, hands and feet', OPruss. nage 'foot'), from PIE *h₃n(o)gʷʰ- (cf. Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').}];54[641{S.v. Lat. unguis 'finger-nail, claw', from PIE *h₃ngʰ-u- 'nail'. The PIE u-stem was remade into an i-stem in Latin.}];50[36{S.v. Proto-Celtic *angʷīnā 'nail', from PIE *h₃nogʰu-, gen. *h₃ngʰ-eu-s 'nail'. In Celtic the zero-grade stem of the oblique cases was generalised.}];458[25: 161-164, 170-173{The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian nagùtis 'claw, fingernail' and further to Old High German nagal, Old Icelandic nagl, negl, Old Irish ingen, Latin unguis, Greek ὄνυξ, Old Indic áṅghriḥ and nakhám etc.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1086-1087, [EWAia](src-172) II:4-5, [ALEW](src-352) 681-682, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164, 170-173, [Derksen 2008](src-81):355 [de Vaan 2008](src-54):641, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36). Indo-Iranian forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442), no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914

Source: 363[II:213{S.v. Kurd. rīšī 'корень', cf. Pers. rēša, rīša, Tal. rīša, Gil. rīša, Lar. rīša, Baxt. rīša, MPers. rēšag 'корень'.}]
80[997{S.v. Hitt. u̯ēlku- 'grass, vegetation', perhaps from  PIE *u̯élk̑-u-, if cognate with Skt. valśa- ‘sprout’, OCS vlasъ ‘hair’, Russ. vólos ‘hair’.}]
Justification: Perhaps from PIE *u̯élk̑-u-, if cognate with Skt. valśa- ‘sprout’, OCS vlasъ ‘hair’, Russ. vólos ‘hair’ ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):997).

Source: 80[646-647{S.v. Hitt. partāu̯ar / partaun- (n.) 'wing, feather', to be connected to a root *per- (via a pre-form pr̥-T-u̯r/n-), which may be connected to Ved. parṇá- 'wing, feather' and Lith. spar̃nas 'wing' (with a different morphological suffix -nó-).}];352[955-956{S.v. OLith. spar̃nas 'Flügel' (BSl. Latv. spā̀rns 'Flügel', Fittich', OLatv. spārna 'id.'), from PIE *(s)por-nó- (cf. Ved. parṇá- 'Feder, Flügel, Blatt', YAv. parəna- 'Feder', OHG farn 'Farn').}];353[419{S.v. Lith. spar̃nas 'wing' (Latv. spā̀rns 'wing'), from PIE *perH-o- (cf. Skt. parṇá- 'wing', OE fearn 'fern', OIr. raith 'fern'). The reconstruction of the laryngeal is based on the acute of forms such as Lith. papártis and Latv. papãrde.}];172[II:97{S.v. Ved. parṇá- 'Flügel, Feder, Pfeilfeder, Blatt' (IIr. cf. YAv. parəna- 'Feder', Khot. pārra- 'Flügel', MPers., NPers. parr 'Feder', etc.), probably from PIE *(s)por-no- (cf. OHG farn 'Farn', Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Schaufel, Blatt').}];141[579-580{Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)per- 'fliegen' [IEW 817, 850].}];594[{Cf. s.v. Sloven. perọ̑ -ẹ̑sa s lat.‛penna, pluma’ (16. stol.).}];81[396{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *pero 'feather', to be derived from PIE *perH-o- (cf. Skt. parṇá- 'wing', Gk. πτερόν 'feather, wing', OE fearn 'fern' and OIr. raith 'fern').}]
Justification: The PIE root underlying these lexemes is generally reconstructed as *(s)per- 'to fly' ([ALEW](src-352) 955-956, [EWAia](src-172) II:97, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 579-580; without s-mobile [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):646-647). [Derksen 2008](src-81):396 and [Derksen 2015](src-353):419 favour a reconstruction *perH- in view of the Baltic acute accent in forms such as Lithuanian papártis and Latvian papãrde (cf. also [Derksen 1996](src-678):79).

Source: 309[663{Borrowed from Old French grif (13th century) from Old High German grifân with the development *skrif > skirf and dissimilation.}]
Justification: Loan from Old French grif 'claw' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):663).

Source: 66[817-818{S.v. λᾶας. Etymology unknown.  The stem formation of λᾶας is unexplained, and therefore may well be an early borrowing from a Pre-Greek substrate language.}];269[{No generally agreed etymology ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174):64-66, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):609-610, [Beekes 2010](src-66):817-818. For a recent attempt, cf. [Nikolaev 2010](src-721).}];270[609-610{S.v. λᾶας 'pierre'. The declension and structure of λᾶας is obscure.}];174[64-66{S.v. λᾶας 'Stein'. The stem formation of λᾶας has not been resolved. Possible correspondences outside of Greek are few and not entirely unproblematic.}];721[{Cf. for a recent attempt at an etymology.}]
Justification: No generally agreed etymology ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174):64-66, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):609-610, [Beekes 2010](src-66):817-818. For a recent attempt, cf. [Nikolaev 2010](src-721).

Source: 141[650{S.v. 2. *trep- 'wenden' (IEW 1094).}];66[1503-1504{S.v. τρέπω 'to turn, revolve, put to flight| to turn oneself, change, take flight, etc.', from PIE *trep- to turn' (cf. Lat. trepit 'vertit' (Paul. Fest. p.367), Skt. trapate 'feels ashamed, beomes timid', Hitt. terepp- 'to plough'). "The connection of Myc. to-ro-qe-jo-me-no (meaning unknown| with q) and of Lat. torqueō is untenable."}];270[1132-1133{S.v. τρέπω 'tournet, diriger vers, se tourner vers, changer, mettre en fuite'. The etymology is a problem. On may connect Skt. trápate 'avoir honte, être embarrassé' which remarkably resembles the sense of ἐντρέπομαι| Lat. trepit (P.F. 504,23) may be the creation of a grammarian. One could also think of a base *trekʷ-/*trokʷ- in view of Mycenaean toroqejomeno which is confirmed by toroqo 'torsade', or 'façon' applied to wool, but these words could also be in turn be connected with στρέφω. One also considers Lat. torqueō, cf. also εὐτρόσσεσθαι· ἐπιστρέφεσθαι· Πάφοι (Hesych.) < *trokʷ-i̯e-?}]
Justification: IE root etymology difficult. This class tentatively follows [Beekes 2010](src-66):1503-1504, [LIV²](src-141) 650 s.v. *trep-, but cf. also [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1132-1133.

Source: 66[947{S.v. μηρός 'the upper meaty part of the shank, shank' < PIE *mē(m)s-ro- 'fleshy'. Greek forms may be accounted for from a *-ro-adjective formation from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat, flesh' (Ved. māṃsa-, Goth. mimz, OCS мѧсо, etc. cf. [cognate set 437](cog-437)).  There is an unexplained nasal-less variant, Ved. mās- 'flesh, meat' (vs. māṃs- 'flesh, meat') < *mēs-, to which the Greek form μηρός should go back via a reconstructable pre-form *mēs-ró- 'fleshy'.  The semantic extension is 'fleshy (part of the body)' > 'thigh'.}];274[486-488{S.v. *mē(m)s- 'Fleisch' (IEW 725, EIEC 374).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ([NIL](src-274) 486-488, [Beekes 2010](src-66):947).

Source: 54[210{S.v. Lat. fēmur, -inis 'thigh', An isolated r/n-stem: possibly *dʰen-u̯r̥, *dʰn̥-u̯én-s, following Steinbauer (1979), comparing Ved. dhánuṣ- 'bow' (cf. Mayrhofer, EWAia I:773-774).}];316[224{S.v. Lat. femur, -inis (-oris) 'cuisse', an isolated -r/n- stem with no clear comparisons.}];172[I:773-774{Cf. s.v. Ved. dhánuṣ- 'Bogen' (pre-Vedic *dhánvr̥ (cf. YAv. ˚uuarǝ), from PIE *dʰen-u̯r̥ ~ *dʰn̥-u̯én-s, probably in Latin femur, feminis 'Schenkel'.}]
Justification: An isolated archaic r/n-stem, probably connected with Vedic dhánuṣ- 'bow' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):210, [EWAia](src-172) I:773-774).

Source: 66[510{S.v. ἡδύς 'sweet, tasteful, pleasant, pleasing' < PIE *su̯eh₂d-ú- 'sweet'.}];345[795-796{S.v. TochB swāre 'sweet', which with TochA swār reflects Proto-Tocharian *swāre from PIE *swehₐdro- with loss of -d- before a resonant and the suffix *-ro- rather than the more usual -u- found in other cognates (cf. Skt. svādú- 'sweet', Gk. ἡδύς 'id.', Lat. svāvis 'id.', etc.).}];172[II:788-789{S.v. Ved. √svad- 'schmackhaft machen, (Med.) schmackhaft werden, schmecken', from which is derived the inherited word svādú-. From PIE *su̯ad- (~ TochA swār, B swāre 'süß' < *su̯ad-ro-).}];165[503{S.v. Proto-Germanic *swōtu- 'sweet', from PIE *sueh₂d-u- (Skt. svādú- 'sweet, tasting good, pleasant', Gk. ἡδύς 'sweet, tasteful, pleasant, pleasing', Lat. svāvis 'sweet, pleasant', cf. also TochA swār, Toch B swāre 'sweet' < *suh₂d-ro-, OAv. hudəma- 'sweetness' < *suh₂d-mo-).}];141[606-607{Cf. s.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (IEW 1039-40).}];274[670-675{S.v. *su̯eh₂d- 'schmackhaft werden' (LIV 606f., IEW 1039f.).}]
Justification: Tocharian, Indic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ([NIL](src-274) 670-675, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):795-796, [EWAia](src-172) II:788-789, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):503, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 606-607).

Source: 54[157-158{S.v. Lat. currō, -ere 'to run', from *kr̥s-e/o- 'to run'.  Cf. *kr̥s-o- 'running' > currus 'chariot'. Gaulish *karros > Lat. carrus, OIr. carr 'vehicle', Welsh car| cf. also OHG hros, ONor. hross, OE hors 'horse' if from Proto-Germanic *hursa- < *kr̥s-o-.}];141[355{S.v. 1. *⁽k̑⁾ers- 'laufen' (IEW 945).}];444[224{S.v. 2415 Lat. currere 'laufen'.}]
Justification: Latin currere 'to run' and Romance lexemes continuing a PIE zero-grade thematic present stem *⁽k̑⁾r̥s-e/o-, derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ers- 'to run' ([LIV²](src-141) 355, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):157-158, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):224 no. 2415).

Source: 66[299-300{δακρύω is a denominal verb from δάκρυ 'tear'.  For Ancient Greek δάκρυ Beekes accepts a reconstruction *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' where the first compound element is from *derk̑- 'see' and the second from *h₂k̑r-u- 'bitter'. For this proposed etymology cf. Kortlandt (1985a).}];54[322, 612{Cf. s.v. Lat. lacrimāre 'cry, weep', a denominal verb from Lat. lacruma, dacruma 'tear'. Lat. lacruma, dacruma is often considered to be a loanword from Gk. δάκρυμα 'tear' on the basis that an inherited preform *dakru-mn̥ would have yielded **dacrumen in Latin, and additionally the suffix -ma is not productive in Latin (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):336). [Hamp 1972](src-575):291-99, however, points out that Greek δάκρυμα is itself a recent formation in Greek, is not attested before the fifth century, and is never attested as the regular word for 'tear' (i.e. δάκρυον). Perhaps the Greek forms and the Latin forms can be reconciled via an dissimilation *d ... *n > d ... m of an earlier preform *dakruna > *dakruma (cf. the distance dissimilation *m … *b > n … b attested *temebrae > tenebrae, cf. tenebrae, s.v.), but this solution is admittedly speculative.}];316[336{Cf. s.v. Lat. lacruma (lacrima), -ae (OLat. dacrima according to Paulus ex Festus 60, 5), possibly a loanword from Greek δάκρυμα.}];574[59-61];575[291-299];269[{In spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. [Hamp 1972](src-575)). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):322, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299-300) generally follow the proposal of [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574), assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'. Under this interpretation the related Hittite form išḫaḫru- is considered an original compound of *skʷ-h₂k̑ru-, although this formulation has its own etymological difficulties (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):391 in [cognate set 8095](cog-8095)).}];270[249{S.v. AGk. δάκρυ 'larme', connected with the old words for tear in Armenian artasu-kʻ (pl.), Germanic (OHG trahan, etc.), and Celtic (OIr. dēr, etc.). The eastern group of Indo-European has a form without an initial dental (cf. Skt. áśru-, Av. asrū-, Lith. āšarà-, TochA ākrunt, TochB ākrūna). Lat. dacruma, lacrima is possibly a loan from Greek.}]
Justification: In spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. [Hamp 1972](src-575)). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):322, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299-300) generally follow the proposal of [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574), assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.

Source: 141[432-433{S.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-717).}];80[547-548{S.v. malla- / mall- 'to mill, to grind', from PIE *mólh₂-ei, *mlh₂-énti.}];81[307{S.v. Proto-Slavic *mlěti 'grind, mill', from PIE *melH- (cf. Skt. mr̥nā́ti 'crush, grind', Hitt. malla- 'grind', Lat. molere 'grind', Goth. malan 'grind', OIr. meilid 'grind', Arm. malem 'crush').}];165[351{S.v. Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', from PIE *mólh₁-e- (cf. Hitt. mallai- ~ mallanzi 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei, *mlh₁-énti| Lat. molō, -ere 'id.', Arm. malem 'to crush', Lith. málti (malù), Latv. mal̃t 'to grind' < *mólh₁-ei| OCS mlěti 'id.', Ru. molót' (meljú), SCr. mljȅti 'id.', OIr. meilid 'id.' < *melh₁-ie-| Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti 'crush, grind' < *ml-néh₁-).}];54[386-387{S.v. Lat. molō, -ere 'to grind in a mill', from PIE *melh₂-/*mlh₂- 'to crush, grind'.}];50[255{S.v. Proto-Celtic *mal-o-, *mel-o- 'grind', from PIE *melh₂- 'grind'. OIr. meilid preserves the full grade of the root via *melh₂-o-, whereas the Brittonic forms can be derived from zero-grade *mlh₂-o- > *malH-o- > Proto-Celtic *mal-o-.}];353[302-303{S.v. Lith. málti 'grind, mill', (Latv. mal̃t 'grind, mill'), from PIE *melH- (cf. Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti, 'crush, grind', Hitt. malla-i / malla- 'mill, grind', Lat. molere 'grind, mill', OIr. meilid 'grind', Goth. malan 'grind', OHG malan 'grind, mill', Arm. malem 'crush').}];352[610-611{S.v. OLith. málti 'mahlen' (BSl. Latv. mal̃t 'mahlen', OPr. malunis 'Mühle', OCS mlěti, etc.), from PIE *melh₂- 'mahlen, zerreiben' (cf. Hitt. malli, mallai 'mahlt', CLuw. mālhūta 'brach', Gk. μύλη 'Mühle, Handmühle', Arm. malem 'zerstoße', Lat. molō -ere 'mahlen', OIr. meilid 'mahlt', Goth. malan 'mahlen', etc.).}];458[18: 90-91{PS *melti is derived from PIE *mel- 'flake, grind'.}];296[B:58, M:32{Cf. s.v. OIr. bleith, mleith, verbal noun of the root mel- 'moudre' and s.v. OIr. mel-, verbal root 'moudre, écraser' (cf. Skt. mr̥ṇā́ti 'il écrase', Goth. malan, NHG mahlen, Lith. malù 'je mouds', OCS meljǫ, Lat. molō, etc.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ([LIV²](src-141) 432-433; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80) 547-548, [ALEW](src-352) 610-611, [Derksen 2015](src-353):302-303, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:90-91, [Derksen 2008](src-81):307}, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):351, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):386-387, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:58, M:32, [Matasović 2009](src-50):255).

Source: 341[579-581{S.v. kärs- 'wissen, verstehen, erkennen', 'know, recognize, understand' (tr), from PIE *√kers ‘(ab)schneiden’ (LIV² 355f.).}];141[335-336{S.v. 2. *kers- '(ab)schneiden' (IEW 945), cf. Hitt. karaszi 'schneidet ab| trennt| versäumt'.}];345[176-177{S.v. TochB kärs- 'know, understand, recognise', reflecting PToch. kärs-, probably from PIE *kers- 'cut off'.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *kers- 'to cut (off)' ([LIV²](src-141) 355-356, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):579-581, [Adams 2013](src-345):176-177, cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):92).

Source: 141[208{S.v. *gʷelh₁- 'treffen, werfen' (IEW 471-2).}];50[53{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'throw away, die', from PIE *gʷelh₁- (cf. Gk. βάλλω, perh. TochAB klā- 'fall').}];304[211-212{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'fortwerfen' → 'sterben', from PIE *gʷelh₁- (LIV² 208).}];296[A:98{S.v. OIr. at-baill 'il meurt', composed of a root bal- or ball- preceded by the preverb ess- with an infixed 3rd sg.n. pronoun.}]
Justification: Reflecting Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'to throw away, die', further derived from PIE *gʷelh₁- 'to throw' ([LIV²](src-141) 208, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:98, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):211-212, [Matasović 2009](src-50):53).

Source: 54[198-199{S.v. faciō, -ere 'to make'. Interficere is a compound of faciō, -ere 'to make, to do', from PIE *dʰh₁-k-.}];141[139-140{S.v. ?*dʰeh₁k- 'machen, herstellen'. Extension of *dʰeh₁- 'to put, to place, to make, to produce', mainly attested in Italic. The origin of the k-element is unknown.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *dʰeh₁-k- 'to make, produce' ([LIV²](src-141) 139-140), widely considered to be connected to PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ([LIV²](src-141) 136-138), but the origins of the k-element on the root remain obscure (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):198-199).

Source: 352[567, 577-578{Cf. s.v. OLith. lydė́ti 'begleiten, geleiten' (BSl. lidêt, lidu, lidẽju 'schweben, flattern', a zero-grade formation to Lith. léisti 'lassen, erlauben| loslassen, schicken, zapfen (Bier)' from PIE *lei̯d- '(los)lassen' (cf. Alb. lindet 'geboren werden, Lat. lūdō, -ere 'spielen').}];141[402-403{S.v. *lei̯d- '(los)lassen' (IEW 666).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯d- 'to let go, release' ([ALEW](src-352) 567, 577-578; [LIV²](src-141) 402-403).

Source: 352[480{Cf. s.v. OLith. kérsti 'ausplaudern, austragen, verkünden' (BSl. OPr. kirdītwei, kirdīt 'hören'. According to LIV² 352 from PIE *?k⁽ʷ⁾erd- 'to hear'. The root could originate from collocation *kerH-dʰeh₁-, i.e. *kerH- 'to praise' (LIV² 353) and *dʰeh₁- 'to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). This collocation was parallel to or influenced by the collocation *gʷer(H)-dʰeh₁- 'to give news, to make known' underlying Lithuanian girdėti 'to hear'. Although formally and semantically similar, the Lithuanian and Old Prussian verbs are not cognate.}];686[191{S.v. OPr. kirdīt, kirdītwei 'hören'. There is an uncertainty in connection to the value of the initial consonant. If <k-> really designates a voiceless stop, then we may have an etymological connection to Lith. kird-/kerd- in pakìrstu, -kìrdau, -kìrsti or pakirstù, etc. 'wach werden, aufwachen, erwachen| unruhig werden, in Unruhe geraten'. If <k-> is the result of a secondary devoicing (German influence?) from *girdīt (cf. krūt instead of *grūt) then kirdīt is to be connected with Lith. girdė́ti 'hören'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 480, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):191 for further discussion.

Source: 296[C:111-112{S.v. OIr. claidid 'il creuse' cf. in Brythonic in W claddu 'creuser, enterrer', Bret. vann. klaouein 'id.', the root is *klad-, cf. clad 'fossé', 1 clas 'id.', claideb 'épée'| with preverb ad- 'chasser', properly 'prendre à la trappe'.}];50[206{S.v. Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.).}];304[410-413{From Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'dig, bury', cf. PIE *kelh₂- 'hit, break' (LIV² 350, IEW 546f.) with a d-extension. }];275[{Proto-Celtic *kla-d- from a collocation / light-verb-construction *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o-, i.e. *kelh₂- + *dʰeh₁- 'to make a stroke/stab' > 'to dig'? }];269[{The precise Indo-European root etymology for this class is disputed. Therefore Proto-Celtic *klad-o- will be used the purposes of providing a root-ref. form, but cf. citations for possible further IE connections in the secondary literature.}]
Justification: Compound verb with preverb ad- + claidid 'dig'. The verb continues Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):410-413, [Matasović 2009](src-50):206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. [LIV²](src-141) 350, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:111-112)

Source: 81[97-98{S.v. Proto-Slavic *debelъ adj. o 'fat' (ESSJa IV 201-202) is based on a Balto-Slavic root *deb-. Cognate with Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debīkan Asg. 'big'| debica (Gr.) 'big'| OIc. dapr 'sad'| Nw. daper 'sad, with young'| dabb(e) (dial.) m. 'small, fat fellow'| OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set'. Derksen: "Formally, the Balto-Slavic and the Germanic forms do not match, considering that in the case of PIE *b the Balto-Slavic evidence would violate Winter’s law. It is by no means necessary, however, to assume that this etymon is of Indo-European origin."}];49[239{S.v. *dʰeb- 'dick, fest, gedrungen'.}];353[530-531{S.v. Latv. depsis 'small, fat boy', OPr. debica 'big', A.sg. debijkan, debīkan, debbīkan. From Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- (cf. Proto-Slavic *debelъ 'fat') ultimately from PIE *dʰebʰ- (cf. OIc. dapr 'sad', Nw. daper 'sad| with young' Nw. dabb(e) 'small, fat fellow' OHG tapfar 'firm, heavy, thick-set).}];165[89{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'heavy'  (cf. RuCS debelyj 'fat', Ru. debelyj 'plump, corpulent' SCr. dèbeo 'fat' < *dʰebʰ-lo-| OCS doblь 'strong', Ru. dóblij 'valiant', Latv. dabļš 'strong, lush' < *dʰobʰ-l-io-). "This adjective is usually directly compared to the aforementioned forms in Slavic, but the underlying root *dʰebʰ- can only be reconciled with PGm. *dapra- by assuming that it was derived from *dapōn-, an analogical variant belonging to the iterative *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' (q.v.) < *dʰobʰ-néh₂-."}];397[907{Cf. s.v. NHG tapfer (MHG tapfer, dapfer, OHG tapfar 'schwer, gewichtig', MLG dapper, MDu. dapper), from Proto-Germanic *dapra- 'schwer, gewichtig'. Also in ON dapr 'traurig, betrübt', NE dapper 'gewandt'. Comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain. One may compare OCS debelŭ 'dick', OPr. debīkan 'groß', TochA tpär B tapre 'hoch'. The meaning also fits to OCS dobrŭ 'gut', etc.}];269[{Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ([IEW](src-49) 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):97-98, [Derksen 2015](src-353):530-531, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89, [Kluge 2011](src-397):907 for further discussion.}]
Justification: Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ([IEW](src-49) 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):97-98, [Derksen 2015](src-353):530-531, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89, [Kluge 2011](src-397):907 for further discussion.

Source: 141[136-138, 139{S.v. *dʰeh₁- 'stellen, legen, setzen| herstellen, machen' (IEW 235-9). For Italic cf s.v. ?*dʰeh₁k- 'machen, herstellen' (IEW 236). Generally agreed to be an extension of *dʰeh₁- 'to put, to place, to make, to produce', mainly attested in Italic. The origin of the k-element is unknown.}];81[102-103{Proto-Slavic *dělati (ESSJa IV 231-232), a denominative of Proto-Slavic *dělo 'work, deed', from PIE *dʰeh₁-l- (cf. Ved. dádhati 'put, place, make', Gk. τίθημι 'put down, ground, create', Lat. fēcī (1.sg.perf.) 'made', OHG tuon 'do').}];54[198-199{S.v. faciō, -ere 'to make'. Interficere is a compound of faciō, -ere 'to make, to do', from PIE *dʰh₁-k-.}];165[98{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dōn- 'to do', an athematic verb continuing Pre-Gmc. 3.sg. *dʰóh₁-ti, 3.pl. *dʰh₁-énti. Other IE languages have a reduplicated present stem (cf. Skt. dádhati, Gk. τίθημι).}];458[4: 231-232| 5: 7-8{PS *dělati is derived from *dělo 'work' and ulimately from PIE *dhē-.}];556[157-160{S.v. Gmc. *dō- 'tun' belonging with certainty to the root *dʰē- (*dʰeə₁-) 'setzen, stellen, legen'.}];316[209-213{S.v. Lat. faciō, to the root *dhē-| the perfect fēcī is comparable to the Greek aorist ἔθηκα like iēcī to Gk. ἧκα.}];444[271-272{S.v. 3128 Lat. facere 'tun, machen'.}]
Justification: Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ([LIV²](src-141) 136-138; [ESSJa](src-458) 4:231-232; 5:7-8, [Derksen 2008](src-81):102-103, [Seebold 1970](src-556):157-160, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):98, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):209-213, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):198-199, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):271-272 no. 3128). The Italic forms in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although exhibiting an extension *-k- of unclear origin (listed as a separate lemma ?*dʰeh₁k- in [LIV²](src-141) 139).

Source: 600[198-199];458[8: 111-113{PS *xudŭ < PIE *ksoudo-, related to Old Indic kṣódati 'mash, flake', kṣudrá- 'small, tiny' and probably to Lithuanian skaudùs 'painful'.}];141[372{Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'zerstieben, in kleine Teile zerfallen' (IEW 625).}];595[1: 205-206{The etymology is not entirely clear. It is usually assumed that the Slavic word is related to Old Indic kṣódati.}];594[{Cf. s.v. Sloven. hȗd, related to Lithuanian skaudùs and Old Indic kṣódati. PIE *kseu̯d- 'small, flaked' > 'weak, bad'.}];81[205{S.v. Proto-Slavic *xudъ 'small, thin' (ESSJa VIII 111-113), from PIE *ksoud-o- (cf. Skt. kṣudrá- 'small').}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xudъ 'small, thin' and generally further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'to scatter, to crumble into small pieces' (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:111-113, [Derksen 2008](src-81):205, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):198-199, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Source: 141[250-251{S.v. *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen'.  Cf. Attic Greek aor. ἐνεγκεῖν < *h₁é-h₁nek̑-e-, pf. ἐνήνοχα < *h₁ne-h₁nok̑-}];352[698-700{S.v. OLith. nèšti 'tragen, ertragen' (BSl. cf. Latv. nest 'tragen, bringen', OCS nesti 'tragen', etc.), from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen' (cf. OAv. 1.pl.aor.subj. nāšāmā 'tragen', Gk. aor. ἐνεγκεῖν 'bringen', TochB eṅkastär, eṅktär 'ergreifen, nehmen').}];81[350{S.v. Proto-Slavic *nesti 'carry, bring' (ESSJa XXV 19-23), from PIE *h₁nek̑- (cf. Lith. nèšti, Gk. ἤνεγκον [aor.]).}];458[25: 19-23{PIE *(e)nek̑. The lexeme is related to Lithuanian nèšti, nešù 'carry', Gothic ganah 'enough', Avestan nasaiti 'obtain', Greek ἤνεγκον, ἐνεγκεῖν 'carry', Tocharian B eṅk 'carry', Hittite ninikzi 'pick up' etc.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'to take, to obtain' ([LIV²](src-141) 250-251, [Derksen 2008](src-81):350, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:19-23, [ALEW](src-352) 698-700).

Source: 141[625-626{*temk- 'get hard, stiffen, clot' > Hittite tamekzi 'attach', Vedic Indic ā́-tanakti 'make clot', Gothic þeihan 'succeed', Lithuanian tánkus 'dense, often' etc.}];531[659{If -nk- in Lithuanian tánkus 'often, dense' goes back to -mk-, then the lexeme is derived from PIE *temk- 'get hard, clot' and is related to Hittite tamekzi 'attach', Vedic Indic ā́-tanakti 'make clot', Old Irish técht 'clotted', Old Nordic þétir 'dense' and Old Church Slavonic tǫča 'rain, rainstorm, snow'.}];594[{Slovene toča, Old Church Slavonic tǫča is related to Lithuanian tánkus 'dense', Hittite tamekzi 'attach', Old Indic tanákti ‛bend’, Avestan taxma- 'brave', Old Nordic þéttr 'dense', Gothic þeihan ‛succeed', German gedeihen 'succeed'. PIE *temk- 'get hard, get dense'.}]
Comment: Reflexes of this root in Slavic have meanings 'hail', 'black, rain cloud', 'cloud', 'rainbow' etc.

Source: 81[92{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ (adj.) 'black' (ESSJa IV 155-157), from PIE *kr̥s-nó- (cf. Skt. kr̥ṣṇá- 'black').}];269[{As the only cognates are found in satəm languages, the possibility of a root reconstruction *k⁽ʷ⁾ers- with a labiovelar *kʷ cannot be excluded.}];458[4:155-157{S.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ(jъ), from PIE *kirno- or *kirsno- (cf. Ved. kr̥ṣṇá-).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- ([ESSJa](src-458) 4:155-157, [Derksen 2008](src-81):92).

Source:
600[872{PS *kutiti with no certain further etymology.}];598[2: 434{The Slavic lexeme is etymologically obscure. I has been unconvincingly linked to Greek σκεῦος 'vessel, utensil', σκευάζω 'prepare', Old Icelandic høyia, Old English hégan 'realize, fulfil, do'.}];259[556{PS *kutiti does not have any certain etymology.}];260[1298-1299{A relationship to Greek σκεῦος etc. is uncertain, as the Greek word itself has no convincing etymology. The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *skeu-(t)- 'cut, separate, scratch, poke, rummage' and related to Old Indic skāuti skunāti, skunṓti 'disturb, poke, rummage', Middle Irish scothaid 'cut', Lithuanian skutù, skusti 'scratch', skutas 'scrap'. The semantical development in Slavic is 'cut' > 'rummage, dig, poke' > 'make, do' (> 'make something bad').}];593[324{The etymology of PS *kutiti is not entirely clear, especially due to a very divergent meanings in the particular Slavic languages and dialects. It is maybe derived from PIE *keu-t- < *keu- 'bend, crook'.}];141[359, 561{?*skeu̯t- 'scratch'. Attested in Baltic (cf. Lithuanian skutù, skùsti 'scrape') and Middle Irish (cf. scotha- 'cut off') only.
?*k(ʷ)eu̯k- 'bend', cf. Vedic ut-kucant- 'bending', Old Irish cúar 'croocked', Lithuanian kaũkas 'bump', Serbo-Croat kuka 'hook' etc.}];458[13: 86-87, 139-140{Slavic lexemes derived from PS *kutiti have many different meanings: 'bend, hide, dig, look for, circulate, turn, escort, breed, protect, do/make, do/make something wrong, live immorally' etc. PS *kutiti is ultimately derived from PIE *keu-t-/*kou-t- with a probably participial -t- 'a bent thing, hook'. This meaning explains all particular meanings in Slavic languages and dialects. Another derivative of PIE *keu- 'bend, flex' is PS *kuka 'hook, needle'. Cf. Old Indic kucáti, kuñcate 'shrivel, get bent' and Lithuanian kaũkas 'bump'.}];81[258{The etymology of PS *kutiti is unclear.}]
Justification: Most of the scholars ascertain that the etymology of PS *kut- is obscure. The etymologies of [ESSJa](src-458) and [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260) assume PIE roots (root extentions) not supported by [LIV²](src-141). The etymologies are also hardly convincing semantically (the issue is, however, caused to a great extent by the semantic span within attested Slavic lexemes belonging here). Thus, they are not accepted here.

Source: 600[489-490{Derived from *PS *pŭk-, a variant of *puk-, cf. *pukati 'bang, knock, beat'. The semantic development would be 'bang, knock, beat' > 'fall with a loud noise' > 'fall' then. The hypothesis about a relationship to PS *potknǫti sę 'stumble' is phonetically and morphologically inconvincing. The interpretation of the Polabian attestations as representing PS *padati is misreading.}]
Justification: The etymology is not entirely clear but the word is probably related to Proto-Slavic onomatopoeic *pukati 'bang, knock, beat' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):489-490).

Source: 260[1263, 1279-1280{PS *sadŭ 'planting' is derived from PS *saditi 'plant, put' and related to Latin sedeō 'sit' etc.}];141[513-515{Cf. s.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (IEW 884-887).}];81[442-443{S.v. Proto-Slavic *sadъ 'plant, garden', cf. Proto-Slavic *saditi 'to plant' < *sod-eie- (cf. Skt. sādáyati 'to set').}];274[590-600{S.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (LIV 513f., IEW 785f.| 884ff.)| OCS sadъ 'Pflanze, Garten' < *sōd-u-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic  *sadъ 'plant', cf. Proto-Slavic *saditi 'to plant' from the causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to sit' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):442-443, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1263, 1279-1280, [NIL](src-274) 590-600).

Source: 81[501{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tvьrdъ adj. 'hard, firm, solid'.  Cf. Lith. tvìrtas 'strong, firm, solid', Latv. tvir̂ts 'id.'.  NB: the Slavic and East Baltic suffixes do not match.}];352[1143{Lit. tvìrtas, Latvian tvir̂ts as well as the Slavonic words OCS tvrъdъ 'hard, solid' go back to PIE *tu̯erH- 'to catch'.}];141[656{Cf. s.v. *tu̯erH- 'fassen' (IEW 1101). Lit. tvìrtas < *tu̯r̥H-tó-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *tu̯erH- 'to grasp' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):501, [ALEW](src-352) 1143, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 656).

Source: 274[185-189{S.v. *gʷi̯eh₃- 'leben' (LIV 215f., IEW 467ff.). Germ. forms reflect ?*gʷih₃-tu- > PGmc. *kʷiþu-, but cf. n5 for possible alternative explanations. Slavic forms reflect *gʷih₃-u̯o-to-.}];600[1054-1055{Polabian zaivåtăk 'heart' is derived from PS *životŭkŭ, a diminutive of *životŭ. Cf. also Polabian zaivåt 'life, belly, body, heart'.}]
Justification: As though from Proto-Slavic *životŭkŭ 'small stomach', the diminutive of *životŭ 'stomach' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1054-1055), cf. 'belly' in [cognate set 2238](cog-2238) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 54[178-179{S.v. Lat. domus, -ī, / -ūs. The Latin (and Slavic) forms are from a u-stem derivative of PIE *dōm, *dem- 'house' (Skt. dám-, Av. dam- < *de/om-| Skt. dáma- 'house', Gk. δόμος 'house, layer of bricks' < *dóm-o-, Russ. дом 'house', (L.sg. дому) < *dom-u-)}];79[618{S.v. Arm. tun 'house'. From PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house' (cf. Skt. dám-, Av. dam-, Gk. δῶ 'house',  δῶμα 'house, temple', Lat. domus 'house, household', OCS domъ 'house', etc.).}];172[I:697{S.v. Ved. dam- 'Haus' (IIr. OAv., YAv. dam- 'Haus, Wohnung', etc.). From PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house'.}];81[113{S.v. Proto-Slavic *domъ 'house', from PIE *dom-u- (cf. Lat. domus).}];353[328{S.v. Lith. nãmas 'house, (pl.) home'. Despite the enigmatic development *d- > n (possibly from a zero-grade *dm- before a vowel?), the connection with PIE *dem-/*dom- remains the best possible etymology.}];352[684-686{S.v. OLith. nãmas 'Haus' (BSl. Latv. nams 'Hüte, Sommerküche, kleines Gebäude', OCS domъ 'Haus', etc.), from PIE *dóm-/*dém- 'Haus' (cf. Ved. G.pl. damā́m 'Haus', thematic dáma- 'Haus, häuslicher Herrschaftsbereich', YAv. G.sg. də̄ṇg in də̄ṇg patōiš 'des Hausherrn', L.sg. dąm, dąmi 'im Haus', Gk. δεσπότης 'Hausherr', Arm. town 'Haus', Lat. domus 'Haus'). The n in initial position may be explained as a secondary assimilation to the following m.}];458[5: 72-73{PS *domŭ is derived from PIE *domu-s, cf. Latin domus etc.}]
Justification: Armenian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):618, [EWAia](src-172) I:697, [ALEW](src-352) 684-686, [Derksen 2015](src-353):328, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:72-73, [Derksen 2008](src-81):113, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):178-179).

Source: 141[661-662{Cf. s.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben| fahren' (IEW 1118-20), with OCS vezǫ, vesti etc. listed as a cognate.}];260[1608{It is derived from PS *vezti 'drive, carry', ultimately from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'move, go (by a vehicle)'.}]
Justification: The original meaning was 'cart with a tent, living cart, tent' > 'house', a derivative of Proto-Slavic *vezti 'drive, carry', ultimately from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'move, go (by a vehicle)'. (cf. [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1608, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 661-662),

Source: 81[417{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pǫpъ, *pǫpъkъ m. 'bud, navel', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *pomp- (cf. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell').}];259[424{PS *pǫpŭkŭ is related to Lithuanian pam̃pti, pampstù 'swell', Latvian pàmpt 'swell', Latin pampinus 'wine leaves' etc. and derived from a ideophonic PIE root *pamp- 'blow, swell'.}];531[435-436{Lithuanian pam̃pti 'swell' has an ideophonic oriɡin, exactly as Latvian paupt 'swell'. [No Slavic cognates listed.]}];353[343-344{Cf. s.v. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell' and Lith. pámpa 'swelling, lump', derivatives from Balto-Slavic *pomp- (cf. PS *pǫpъ 'bud, navel').}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):417, [Derksen 2015](src-353):343-344, [Boryś 2005](src-259):424, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):435-436). The verbal root is preserved in Baltic (cf. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell').

Source: 81[40-41{S.v. Proto-Slavic *běžàti 'run, escape', from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'davonlaufen, fliehen' (cf. AGk. φέβομαι 'flee', cs. φοβέομαι 'fear' [cognate set 1479](cog-1479)).}];141[67{S.v. *bʰegʷ- 'davonlaufen, fliehen' (IEW 116).}];353[85-86{S.v. Lith. bė́gti, from PIE *bʰegʷ- (cf. Gk. φέβομαι 'flee').}];352[103-104{S.v. OLith. bė́gti 'laufen, rennen, fliehen' (BSl. Latv. bêgt 'laufen', OCS běžati 'laufen, fliehen', etc.), from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'davonfliehen, fliehen' (cf. Gk. φέβομαι 'fliehe').}];458[2: 58-60, 92{PS běgti 'run' is derived from PIE *bʰeu̯ɡ- / *bʰeɡʷ- / *bʰūɡ(ʰ)- / *bʰu̯eɡ- and related to Greek φέβομαι 'run away, fear' etc.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 67, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:58-60, 92, [ALEW](src-352) 103-104, [Derksen 2008](src-81):40-41, [Derksen 2015](src-353):85-86).

Source:
81[492, 505{S.v. Proto-Slavic *těnь 'shadow'. "Probably a transformation of *sěnь on the basis of *tьma 'darkness' (cf. OCS tьmьnъ 'dark' derived from BSl. *timʔ-/*tomʔ- : Lith. tamsùs, Latv. tùmšs, tìmšs).}];259[80-81{PS *těnĭ is maybe derived from *tem-nĭ with a simplification of the cluster *-mn- and a lengthening of the root vowel. It would be ultimately derived from PIE *tem(ə)- 'dark' then. A derivation from PIE *ten- 'pull, extend' (cf. Polish cienki 'thin') with a motivation 'something getting longer and shorter, something mobile' is less likely.}];598[3: 602, 755| 4: 43{It is usually reconstructed as *tēmnĭ and linked to *tĭma ['darkness'], *tĭmĭnŭ ['dark']. Some scholars try to connect it to sten' or with sten' and sen'.
Russian sen' is related to Latvian sejs 'shadow', Gothic skeinan 'shine', Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow', Old Indic chāyā́ 'shadow, glare, reflex', Albanian hē 'shadow' etc. It has been tried to connect it with ten' and sten' with a taboo-deformations assumed.
A comparison of sten' to Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow' etc. has phonetic issues. It is probable that the connection of *sěnĭ and *stěnĭ is secondary and conditioned by a contaminaton of *sěnĭ and *těnĭ.}];593[602-603{The original form is probably sěnĭ which can be linked to German Schein, Greek σκιᾱ́, Old Indic chāyā́ etc. However, Slavic forms with st- and t- are an issue. Taboo-deformations and contaminations (with *tĭma ['darkness'] and *stěna ['wall']) can be assumed here.}]
Justification: The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' [LIV²](src-141): 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 472.

Source: 141[238{S.v. *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-9). LIV² reconstructs a preform *h₁r̥-sk̑e/o- for the Greek forms (= Ved. r̥ccháti 'erreicht, trifft, gerät in', OPers. -arsatiy 'kommt', Hitt. āraškizzi 'gelangt, wiederholt hin').}];66[468{S.v. Gk. ἔρχομαι 'to come', also 'to go, travel'. The precise Indo-European etymology is debated. Possible connection with PIE *h₁ergʰ- (cf. OIr. eirg [imptv.] 'go!', regaid [fut.] 'he will go', Skt. r̥ghāyáti 'tremble, rage', possibly within Greek as an iterative ὀρχέομαι 'dance' < *h₁orgʰ-éi̯e-) or PIE *h₁er- (cf. Ved. r̥ccháti 'to reach, arrive at', Hitt. arške/a- [iter.] 'to reach repeatedly, make incursions'.)}];270[377{S.v. AGk. ἔρχομαι 'aller, venir', sometimes 'marcher', without certain etymology.}]
Justification: The root etymology in this set tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):377, [Beekes 2010](src-66):468).

Source: 141[255-256{Cf. s.v. 1. *h₂eg̑- 'treiben' (IEW 4-5).}];66[18-19{Cf. s.v. ἄγω 'to drive, lead, bring, carry| draw etc.' < PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive, lead'.}];464[{In re Tsakonian εγγου: According to Andriotis (1974:270) < AG ἥκω, but according to HDMG < ΑG ἄγω. Τhe second interpretation seems more plausible.}];460[270{Cf. for an alternative etymology of the Tsakonian forms from Ancient Greek ἥκω 'I have come'.}];382[1097{S.v. πηγαίνω. Modern Greek present stem πηγαίνω backformed from aorist πήγα on basis of analogy έμαθα ~ μαθαίνω. Πήγα is from Medieval Greek *υπήγα, ultimately from Ancient Greek aorist ὑπῆγον, aorist of ὑπ-άγω 'lead, bring under'.}];240[3{S.v. Old Welsh agit v 3.sg.pres. 'to go', from IE *ag̑- 'treiben' (cf. Lat. agō).}];304[189-193{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ag-e/o- 'treiben, führen', from PIE *h₂eg̑- (LIV 255f.)}]
Justification: Hellenic and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1097, [Beekes 2010](src-66):18-19, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):3, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):189-193, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 255-256). The Tsakonian lexemes in this class might instead go back to AGk. ἥκω 'I have come' (so [Andriotis 1974](src-460):270), but a derivation from AGk. ἄγω 'go, drive' is more plausible (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Source: 593[272{Czech klacek is a borrowing from German Klotz.}];600[243-244{Polabian klac is a loanword from Middle German kloz.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from German (cf. [Polański 1962-1994](src-600) 243-244, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):272).

Source: 594[4: 287-288{PS *vedrŭ is certainly related to German Wetter 'weather'. The protoform was *u̯e-dʰro-, derived from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow'.}];81[513{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *vedro 'nice weather', from PIE *u̯edʰrom (cf. OIc. veðr 'weather', OHG wetar).}];165[583-584{S.v. Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather'. "The Walser German form wedar as in 's wedar dr fenstro 'windowpane' (Schott 1842: 340) points to a variant *weϸra- beside *wedra-. This means that the word may have been a mobile neuter in Pre-Gm., viz. *uétr-om, pl. *uetr-éh₂. This proto-form further implies that the received etymological link with OCS vedro n. 'clear sky' < *uedʰro- cannot be maintained. The connection with OCS vetro 'air, wind' < *ueh₁-tro-, Lith. vė́tra < *h₂ueh₁-treh₂- (see *wēan-) is formally problematic as well, because the underlying form would give PGm. *weϸra- (laryngeals are not lost before *CR-, pace Schindler apud Peters 1999). Olr. feth f. 'wind(?)' can theoretically be derived from *ueto- without a laryngeal, but is more likely to have developed out of *h₂ueh₁-tó- by pretonic shortening (Dybo's law). The only way to retain the connection of the Germanic word with the PIE root *h₂ueh₁- 'to blow' is to reconstruct it as *h₂uh₁-etr-o- (or *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- in view of OCS vedro) with the same suffix as found in e.g. Gr. Hom. λοετρόν 'bath, bathing site' (derived from λούω 'to bathe')."}];141[287{Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯eh₁- 'wehen' (IEW 81-4).}];269[{Traditionally compared to Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather' and further connected with PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- via *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- or *u̯edʰrom, although there are formal difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic comparanda (cf. discussion in [cognate set 9440](cog-9440)). The difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic form, however, do not preclude the possibility of the derivation of the Slavic form being ultimately derived from PIE **h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', however the uncertainty over the etymological identity of the proposed Germanic cognates weakens the case somewhat (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):513, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):583-584, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) 4:287-288).}]
Justification: Traditionally compared to Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather' and further connected with PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- via *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- or *u̯edʰrom, although there are formal difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic comparanda (cf. discussion in [cognate set 9440](cog-9440)). The difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic form, however, do not preclude the possibility of the derivation of the Slavic form being ultimately derived from PIE **h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', however the uncertainty over the etymological identity of the proposed Germanic cognates weakens the case somewhat (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):513, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):583-584, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) 4:287-288).

Source: 81[459{Proto-Slavic *sòldъkъ 'sweet', an enlargement of PIE *sh₂el- 'salt' (cf. Goth. salt).  The Slavic forms have an additional suffix in -k- from earlier Proto-Balto-Slavic *solʔdus (Lith. saldùs, Latv. sal̂ds).}];353[387-388{S.v. Lith. saldùs (Latv. sal̂ds 'sweet'). The root is an enlargement (with *d) of PIE *sh₂el- 'salt', cf. Goth. salt 'salt' which may have been added on analogy to *sueh₂du- 'sweet'.}];352[586-587{S.v. OLith. saldùs 'süß' (BSl. Latv. sal̂ds, 'süß, angenehm', OCS sladъkъ 'süß', etc.), IE cognates include Arm. ałtkʻ 'Salz', Lat. sallō, -ere, salsus 'salzen', OIr. saillid 'salzt', Goth. salt 'Salz', saltan 'salzen', etc. Lith. saldùs belongs to an array of words which phonologically have to go back to a pre-form *sald- and may be understood morphologically as a conjunction of PIE *sal- 'Salz' and the root *deh₃ - 'geben'.}];274[586-590{S.v. *sal- 'Salz' (IEW 878f., EIEC 498), reconstructing a stem *sal-dh₃-u- for the Balto-Slavic forms.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ({ref NIL 586-590, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 586-587, [Derksen 2015](src-353):387-388, [Derksen 2008](src-81):459. Cf. 'salt' in [cognate set 283](cog-283) for further discussion of the root reconstruction.

Source: 81[158, 533{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ęti 'take' (cf. Lat. emere '*to take > buy, purchase') + preverb *vъz- 'up, back'.}];141[236{S.v. *h₁em- 'nehmen' (IEW 310-1).}];353[200-201{S.v. Lith. im̃ti 'take' (Latv. jem̃t, OPr. īmt 'take'), from PIE *h₁m- (cf. OCS jęti 'take', Lat. emere 'take (in compounds), buy').}];352[395-397{S.v. OLith. im̃ti 'nehmen, fassen, erhalten' (BSl. Latv. jem̃t 'nehmen, fassen, packen', OPr. īmt 'nehmen', OCS jęti 'nehmen', etc.), from PIE *h₁em- 'nehmen' (cf. Lat. emō, -ere 'nehmen', OIr. ·eim 'nehmen').}];458[6: 71{PS *ęti, *jĭmǫ is derived from PIE *em-, cf. Latin emō, emere 'buy', older 'take' and Lithuanian imù, im̃ti 'take'.}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁em- 'to take' ([LIV²](src-141) 236, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 395-397, [Derksen 2015](src-353):200-201, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:71, [Derksen 2008](src-81):158, 533). The cognacy in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 236 s.v. *h₁em-, but cf. also [LIV²](src-141) 453 s.v. 1. *nem-; it is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE.

Source: 81[466{S.v. Proto-Slavic *stegnò- n. 'thigh'. If Proto-Slavic *bedro- 'thigh' contains the root *bʰedʰ- 'to stab', then *stegno 'thigh' < *stegʰ-nó-m may derive from a root 'to stab' as well (cf. Ru. stegát 'quilt', OIc. stinga 'stab, thrust'). No further etymology.}];269[{Reconstruction of an IE root *stei̯gʰ- 'stab' for this class would depend on the interpretation of Proto-Slavic *bedra, *bedro 'thigh' being derived from *bʰedʰ- 'stab', which is uncertain. Cf. notes in [cognate set 5207](cog-5207).}]
Justification: The etymology is considered as uncertain and relatively many different IE comparanda are given, cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 3: 315, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 613, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 74. However, the hypothesis of [Derksen 2008](src-81): 35, 466 is attractive and has been adopted here. For the semantic development see also [cognate set 7765](cog-7765).

Source: 259[110{PS *dǫbŭ is probably derived from PIE *dʰŭm-bʰo- 'dark, with a colour of smoke', a derivative of *dʰū-mo-, cf. dym ['smoke']. It was motivated by the dark colour of oak wood.}];593[147{PS *dǫbŭ does not have any certain etymology. It is a Slavic innovation, perhaps motivated by taboo reasons. It has been interpreted as a derivative from PIE *dem- ([cf. PS *domŭ 'house']). Other explanations link it to PIE *dʰeu-bʰ- 'dark', *dʰeu-b- 'deep' or *dʰamb(ʰ) 'beat'. A non-IE origin has been also proposed.}];458[5: 95-97{PS *dǫbŭ is a late Slavic innovation and all etymologies that link it to IE lexemes referring to 'wood' are doubtful. It has been derived from PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' with an original meaning 'lowland [tree]'.}]
Justification: Slavic innovation (maybe taboo-motivated) without certain etymology. There are two most popular hypotheses on its etymology: 1) *demh₂- 'build' > 'wood used/good for building' > 'oak'; 2) *dʰu̯eh₂- 'smoke' > 'dark' > 'tree with dark wood'. [ESSJa](src-458) links it to *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' > 'lowland tree'. None of the versions seems to be really convincing.

Source: 81[513, 536{S.v. Proto-Slavic *vьčera adv. 'yesterday', related to Proto-Slavic *vȅčerъ 'evening' from PIE *uekspero- (cf. Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, Arm. giser).}];460[259{Cf. s.v. AG ἑσπέρα 'evening' > Tsakonian επ̔έζ̌ι. [Database: επ̔έζ̌ι| printed as ἐπ‛έρι in Andriotis 1974]}];66[470-471{S.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος 'evening', an inherited word for 'evening' from *u̯e-kʷsp-er-o- *'towards the night, evening' (cf. Lat. vesper 'evening'). Element *-kʷsp- 'night' from PIE *kʷsep- 'spend the night' (cf. Ved. kṣáp- 'night').}];294[843{Cf. s.v. 1. *u̯é 'weg, ab| ohne'. A reconstructed compound *u̯é-kʷsp-ero- 'Abend' is commonly assumed to underlie Gk. ἕσπερος, Lat. vesper, MW ucher, ?PGmc. *u̯est(r)ō, Arm. gišer, OCS večerŭ, Lith. vãkaras, etc. (although LIPP rejects this reconstruction). Cf. p.843n20 for extensive references to further literature.}];353[485{S.v. Lith. vãkaras 'evening' (Latv. vakars 'evening'), from PIE *uekspero- (cf. OCS večerъ, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lat. vesper, MW ucher).}];702[59-62{For Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, Beekes argues for a connection with the root *kʷsep- '(spend the) night', with a prefix *u̯e- (of less certain origin, cf. article for discussion of alternative possibilities).}];352[1174-1175{S.v. OLith. vãkaras 'Abend', under which is included vãkar (adv.) 'gestern' (BSl. Latv. vakars 'Abend', OCS vьčera 'gestern', etc.), certainly cognate with Gk. ἕσπερος 'abendlich| westlich', ἑσπέρα 'Abend| Westen', Arm gišer 'Nacht', Lat. vesper (adj.) 'abendlich, zum Abend gehörig', vesper sf. 'Abend', MW ucher 'Abend'. The precise reconstruction is however disputed, cf. Beekes (2004) for the most recent attempt.}]
Justification: While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of [Beekes 2004](src-702), cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. For the lexemes in this class cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):259, [Beekes 2010](src-66):470-471, [ALEW](src-352) 1174-1175, [Derksen 2015](src-353):485, [Derksen 2008](src-81):513, 536. (–MJCS). The first vowel is irregularly reduced in Slavic, cf. Slavic večer- 'evening' with a regular reflex. (–LJ).

Source: 54[639{S.v. Lat. umbra 'shadow, shade', generally connected with Lithuanian ùnksna 'shade' and reconstructed as *unksrā-. The etymology suggests a root *(H)unk- (full-grade *(H)uenk-), but the only comparable root in LIV² is *u̯enk- 'to bend', which does not seem to be a good semantic match. No other root etymology.}];316[745{S.v. Lat. umbra 'ombre, ombrage'. A connection with Skt. andáḥ = Av. andō 'aveugle' and Ved. ándhaḥ 'obscurité' is plausible| for the suffix cf. Lat. tenebrae. Lith. ùnksnā 'ombre' has also been connected| umbra would be from *unks-ra.}];352[1147, 1149-1150{Cf. s.v. OLith. ùnksna, unksnà 'Schatten', connected with OLith. ū̃kas, ū́kas 'Dunst, Nebel'| no certain comparanda outside of Lithuanian, traditionally assumed to be related to Lith. vãkaras 'Abend', but this etymology is difficult to explain in terms of its derivational morphology.}];353[478-479{Cf. s.v. Lith. uñksnė 'shade, shady place'| possibly connected with Lat. umbra 'shade, shadow' if it reflects *unksra-, but cf. also variant ūksna without a nasal, possibly to be connected with vãkaras 'evening'.}]
Justification: Italic and Romance lexemes from Latin umbra, possibly to be further connected to Lithuanian ùnksna 'shade, shadow' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):639, [Derksen 2015](src-353):479, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1164) but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1147, 1149-1150, doubting connections outside of Lithuanian and with further discussion. Further connections outside of Italic consequently unclear.

Source: 382[1314{S.v. σπίτι < Medieval Greek σπίτι(ν) < Hellenistic Greek ὀσπίτιον, a loanword from Lat. hospitium.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Hellenistic or Roman period Greek *ὀσπίτιον, via Medieval Greek σπίτι(ν), either a Hellenistic or Late Antique loan from Latin hospitium 'lodging, guest-house' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1314).

Source: 54[37{S.v. Lat. amārus 'bitter', possibly from PIE *h₂h₃m-ro-? (cf. Skt. amlá- 'sour, acid', OIc. apr 'sharp, cold', etc.). Some morphological details remain unclear.}];316[25{S.v. Lat. amārus, -a, -um 'amer', one connects Skt. amlá- 'aigre', Sw. & ODu. amper 'aigre'.}];657[69{S.v. BITTER *h₂em-ro-s 'bitter, sour' (IEW 777-778: *om-): Lat. amārus 'bitter', ON apr 'sharp, hard, cold', OE ampre 'sorrel, dock', OHG ampfaro 'sorrel, dock', Alb. ëmbël 'sweet' (Tosk), tëmbël 'gall', Arm. amok' 'sweet', OInd. amlá- 'sour', from *h₂em- 'raw, bitter'.}];444[31-32{S.v. 406 amārus 'bitter', 2. 'gelb'.}]
Justification: Latin and Romance lexemes, traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):25, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):37; cf. [EIEC](src-657) 69). For Modern Romance forms, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):31-32.

Source: 274[451-453{Cf. s.v. *lei̯kʷ- 'zurücklassen, sich entfernen von' (LIV 406ff., IEW 669ff.), with OCS lixъ, etc. < ?*lei̯kʷ-s-o/ah₂-.}];458[15: 89-91, 99-102{PS *lixŭ 'superfluos, excessive' < PIE *leikʷ-so-, derived from *leikʷ- 'leave'. Cf. *otŭlěkŭ 'remainder' < PIE -*leikʷ-.}];259[287{Polish lichy < PS *lixŭ 'remaining, superfluous, useless' > 'worthless, paltry, poor'.}];595[2: 140];598[2: 505{Cf. s.v. Ru. лихой < PIE *leikso- (cf. Gk. λείπω, Lat. relinquō, etc.).}];81[278{S.v. Proto-Slavic *lixъ 'superfluous, incorrect' (ESSJa XV 99-102), reconstructing *lei̯kʷ-so-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lixъ 'superfluous, incorrect' and generally further derived as though from PIE *lei̯kʷ-so- (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 15:99-102, [Derksen 2008](src-81):278, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 2:505, [NIL](src-274) 451-453).

Source: 259[419{PS dialectal *pazurŭ / *pazorŭ. The etymology is unclear. It can be an expressive backformation from *paznogŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-] with *-urŭ / -orŭ suffix.}];598[3: 186{Most probably it is a shortened form with -urŭ from *paznoɡŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-]. The hypothesis about *paz-dor- [with PIE *der-] is unconvincing phonetically.}];602[4: 255{The etymology is not entirely clear. It is possibly derived from PS *paz- 'point of contact, connection, groove, joint' [PIE *peh₂g̑- 'harden, stiffen, firm' with cognates as Lating pangō, pangere etc.]. It can be also a backformation of from *paznoɡŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-].}];260[1053-1054{PS *paz-orŭ / *paz-urŭ. The root *paz- is a reflex of PIE [*peh₂g̑-]  'hard, firm'. The etymological meaning of the lexeme is 'hard, firm, strengthened protuberance on fingers and toes'. The interpretation as *paz-dor- or as a backformation fo *paz-nogŭtĭ is unconvincing.}];593[455-456{The etymology is not clear. It is maybe an expressive formation from PS *paznogŭtĭ [with PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ-].}];249[{None of the proposed etymologies is really convincing. The assumption of PS *paz-dor- fails tu explain attested forms phonetically. The assumption of a backformation from PS *paz-noɡŭtĭ is speculative because there is no single sound of *-noɡŭtĭ remaining in the forms *pazurŭ / *pazorŭ. Assuming the PIE *peh₂g̑- root seems to be unconvincing semantically. All certain Slavic reflexes of PIE *peh₂g̑- known to me are related to a joint of two elements and show any traces of 'hard, firm' meaning itself.}]
Justification: Origin and structure uncertain, cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):419, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 4:255, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):455-456, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1053-1054, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:186 for various proposals.

Source: 81[373{S.v. Proto-Slavic *orbiti 'do, work' (ESSJa XXXII 116-118), a derivative of *orbъ 'servant, slave' < *h₃erbʰ-, cf. Gk. ὀρφανός 'orphan', Lat. orbus 'deprived of, orphan'.}];165[32f.];458[32: 116-133{PS *orbiti is derived from PS *orbŭ 'slave'. It is most probably related to Old Indic árbha- 'young child', Latin orbus 'orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphan', Armenian orb 'orphan'. PIE *orbho-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *orbiti 'do, work', a derivative of *orbъ 'servant, slave' and ultimately derived from PIE *h₃erbʰ- ([ESSJa](src-458) 32:116-118, [Derksen 2008](src-81):373).

Source: 601[1: 149-150{Kashubian brzôd is derived from PS *brědŭ 'fruit, sprout', cf. dialectal Russian bred 'leaves and twigs used as fodder', dialectal Russian and Ukrainian bredina 'willow'. Some Slavic dialects show reflexes of a related protoform *brędŭ, cf. dialectal Polish  jabrząd 'poplar'. The most close cognates are Lithuanian brę́sti, brę́stu, bréndau 'grow, mellow' and brį̀sti, brį̀stu, brìndau 'swell'.}];458[1: 48-50, 3: 16{PS *brědŭ is related to a prefixed form *abrědŭ and *abrędŭ. These words are derved from PIE *brend- / *brei̯d- / *broi̯d- and related to brę́sti, bréndau 'swell, mellow'.}];141[95{*?bʰrend- with Lithuanian brę́sti listed as a reflex.}]

458[8:86-88{S.v. Proto-Slavic *xovati (sę). Goes back to a non-attested *skovati 'смотреть с вниманием', 'look with attention', cf. the related to and close in meaning *skumati > Cz. zkoumati 'исследовать', 'investigate'. Cf. also Gk. θυο-σκόος, OHG scouwōn, Germ. schauen, Goth. us-skaws, Ved. kaví-, Gk. κοέω, Lat. cavēre, Slav. *čuti.}];178[III:253{Cf. s.v. Ru. ховать 'erwahren, hüten', better to be connected to OHG scouwôn 'schauen', Gk. θυο-σκόος 'Opferschauer'.}];141[561{Cf. s.v. *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' (IEW 587-8), whence the primary verbal derivatives in OCS ču 'fühlte, merkte', Gk. κοέω 'bemerke, vernehme, höre', Lat. caueō, -ēre 'sich in acht nehmen', etc.}];165[442, 452{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwan- 'mirror' (Go. skuggwa 'id.', ON skuggi 'shadow, shade', OHG scuwo, scū 'id.'), from the PIE root *skeu- 'to see', cf. PGmc. *skawa- 'observant(?)' > Go. us-skaws 'sober' < *skou-ó- (cf. Gk. θυο-σκόος 'name of a sacrificial priest' < *-skou-o-| cf. also OE scēawian, OFri. skowia, OS skawon, Du. schouwen, OHG scouwōn, G schauen 'to see, inspect' < PGmc. skawōjan-).}];269[{NB: While the etymology for NHG 'schauen' etc. from *(s)keu̯h₁- is generally well accepted, cf. LIV² s.v., the etymology of the 'shadow' words from the same root as given by Kroonen (2013:442, 452) is less clear. Cf. 'hide' in [cognate set 8433](cog-8433) 'shadow' in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:86-88, [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) III:253, [LIV²](src-141) 561).

Source: 259[45{Polish budynek is a loanword from Middle German *buding 'building'. It was further borrowed from Polish into Ukrainian and Belarusian.}]
Justification: Loanword from Polish budynek 'building', itself ultimately a loanword from Middle German buding 'building' ([Boryś 2005](src-259):45).

Source: 259[663{PS *udŭ 'part of body, limb' is etymologically obscure. It can e related to sparsely attested PS *uděti 'swell', derived from PIE *eu̯dʰ- 'swell' (cf. Polish wymię 'udder'). The original meaning woudl be then 'swollen, fleshy part of body'. Other etymologies are less probable, e.g. an interpretation as *au̯-dʰo- with *dʰē-  'put' (with a hypothetical meaning 'part of body put aside the thorax').}];593[688{PS *udŭ is best explained as *au̯-dʰo- 'parto for body put aside the thorax'.}];598[4: 148{The etymology of ud 'part of body, limb' is obscure. [See further for a summary of the existing etymologies.]}]
Justification: Most often interpreted as containing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put' ([LIV²](src-141): 136-138), cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 688, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4: 255, see below. An alternative is to compare is with PIE *Hou̯Hdʰ-, cf. Russian udit' 'swell, fill with' and PS *vymę 'udder' and English udder, cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 149, [Derksen 2008](src-81): 507, 534-535 and {Boryś 2005}: 663. This latter etymology seems to be more attractive, however in light of the shortness of the root (2 phonemes) and the lack of any IE cognates with a similar meaning, it remains speculative.

Source: 352[87, 89-91{S.v. OLith. báltas 'weiß' (BSl. cf. Latv. bal̃ts 'weiß', OCS blato 'Sumpf', etc.). The East Baltic word for white is morphologically closest to the past passive participle of OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden'. The also lexicalised Slavic correspondence shows that the adjective was already Proto-Balto-Slavic. On the semantic development of 'white' > 'swamp' in Slavic, see ESSJa 2:180. Lith. bálti is a denominal incohative to Lith. bãlas 'weiß' which has been replaced by báltas. Lith. bãlas is put together with Gk. φαλός (Hesych.) 'weiß', φαλιός 'hell| weißfleckig' (cf. Frisk 1960-1972 2.988f.), Arm. bal 'Nebel, weißer fleck' (cf. Martirosyan 2010:162f.), and Alb. bálë 'weißer Fleck auf der Stirn von Tieren, Blässe' (cf. Demiraj 1997:87). Lith. bãlas is not to be separated from the Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS bělъ. Ru. bélyj, Cz. bílý, etc., which apparently have a reflex of Proto-Slavic *ē in the root. The morphological relationship within the family and the identification of a common is yet to be explained. The often assumed connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten' (cf. Ved. 3.sg.pres. bhā́ti, Gk. φάντα (Hesych.) 'leuchtend') is conceivable.}];81[40{S.v. Proto-Slavic *bělъ 'white' (ESSJa II 79-81), from earlier *bʰelH- (cf. Lith. bãlas 'white', Latv. bā̀ls, bãls 'pale'| bal̃ts 'white').}];353[80{S.v. Lith. báltas 'white' (Latv. bal̃ts 'white'), from PIE *bʰolH-to- (cf. PSl. *bòlto 'swamp', Alb. baltë 'mud, swamp', Mod.Gk. βάλτος 'swamp', Rom. baltă 'mud, swamp'). For the semantics cf. Lith. balà 'swamp' = PSl. bělъ 'white'.}];458[2: 79-81{An issue in the reconstruction of PS *bělŭ is the root vowel. However, it can be established that the output form was *belo-, with a short monophthong. It is related to Greek φαλός 'white', Breton bal 'white spot on the forehead (of a horse, cow, dog)' and Lithuanian bãlas 'white'. PIE *bʰel- / *bʰol-.}];269[{The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. [ALEW](src-352) (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable| [Derksen 2008](src-81):40 and [Derksen 2015](src-353):80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 2:79-81.}]
Justification: Shortened from 'white head', cf. older Polish białogłowa 'women'. Cf. 'white' in [cognate set 1190](cog-1190) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 458[8: 74-76{The etymology is not entirely clear. It can be reconstructed as PIE *skormo-.
