Then it would be related to Old High German scirm, scërm 'cover, shield' and Old Indic cárman 'leather, skin'. An alternative is to reconstruct *sor-mo- and assume a relationship to Latin serere 'tie, bind' and Greek ὅρμος 'chain, rope'. The second hypothesis is weaker phonetically (it does not explain the initial x- reasonably) and semantically (the original meaning would be 'plaited cover, plaited cabin', it would also denote a primitive construction, whereas PS *xormŭ refers rather to more sophisticated constructions, cf. the meaning 'temple, church' in some Slavic languages).}]
Justification: The etymology and further cognacy is obscure. It can be derived from PIE 2*(s)ker- 'scratch, cut off, shear' ([LIV²](src-141): 556-557), cf. [EWAia](src-172): 537 and [Kroonen 2013](src-165) or *ser- 'knot together' [LIV²](src-141): 534, [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 557-558 and [ESSJa](src-458): 8: 75. See [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) for a summary of existing hypotheses.

Source: 81[501{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tvoriti 'make', from PIE *tu̯orH- (cf. Lith. tvérti 'seize, form'| Latv. tvêrt 'seize, hold').}];141[656{S.v. *tu̯erH- 'fassen' (IEW 1101). The OCS form is based on an original cs.-iter. stem *tu̯orH-éi̯e-.}]
Justification: Continuing a causative stem formation *tu̯orH-éi̯e- to PIE *tu̯erH- 'to grasp' ([LIV²](src-141) 656, [Derksen 2008](src-81):501).

Source: 81[177{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ (ESSJa VII 23), from PIE *gʷʰon- (cf. Gk. θείνω 'kill', Skt. hánti 'strike, slay').}];458[7: 23, 196-197{PS *goniti (sę) is derived from PIE *gʷʰen- and related to Old Indic hánti 'hit, kill', Greek θείνω 'hit', Lithuanian genù, giñti 'chase', Hittite kuen-, kun- 'hit, kill', Latin de-fendere 'defend', Old Icelandic gunnr 'battle', Tocharian kuñac 'quarrel, battle' etc.}];141[218-219{Cf. s.v. *gʷʰen- 'schlagen' (IEW 491-3).}]
Justification: Derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti 'chase, persecute', ultimately derived from *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref ESSJa 7:23, 196-197, [Derksen 2008](src-81):177, [LIV²](src-141) 218-219).

Source: 259[175{PS *gotovŭ has no certain further etymology.}];595[165{It has been linked to PIE *gā- 'go'. An idea about a borrowing from Gothic gataws 'ready' is less probable.}];594[{The Slavic lexeme *gotovŭ is probably derived from PIE *gʷah₂- 'go, walk' (*gʷah₂-te/ou̯-) with a primary meaning 'ready to go', cf. German bereit and reiten, fertig and fahren. A hypothesis about borrowing from Gothig gataws 'ready' is less probable.}];598[1: 448-449{The Slavic lexeme is related to Albanian gat 'ready'. The Albanian cognate shows that the Slavic lexeme can not be a borrowing from Gothic *gataws.}];593[211{PS *gotovŭ is etymologically obscure. It can be related to Albanian gat 'ready' if the latter is not a borrowing from Slavic. It can be derived from PIE *gʷā- 'go'.}];141[205{*gʷeh₂- 'step, go'.}];105[111{Albanian "gat 'ready', gati id. are secondary formations based on the verb which is an early Slavic loanword, from *gotovati, *gotoviti".}];260[334{The etymology is hard to ascertain. The hypothesis linking it to PIE *gʷa- 'go, come' should be taken into account.}];458[7: 70-72{PS *gotovŭ 'ready' is derived from PIE *gʷā̆- 'go', from a supine *gʷătu > *ɡotŭ. Cf. German bereit and reiten, fertig and fahren, English ready and ride. Traces of the meaning 'go' in PS *gotovŭ 'ready' seem to be attested in Old Russian.}]
Justification:
The etymology of this root is not entirely clear.
The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic is rather speculative because the Gothic form *gataws itself is not attested and only reconstructed (as a nominal derivative of gataujan 'fulfil, act, accomplish') [ESSJa](src-458). The Albanian gat 'ready' etc. is most probably a loan from Slavic [Orel 1998](src-105), note also a suspiciously similar set of meanings [ESSJa](src-458) here.
The idea about a derivation of the Slavic lexemes from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'walk, go' with a semantic development '(get) ready to go, prepare(d) for a journey' > '(get) ready, prepare(d)' (> 'do, make') has good IE parallels (cf. German bereit and fertig with secondary derivatives as vorbereiten, zubereiten 'prepare, make', anfertigen 'make', English ready). An issue is that the meaning 'go' is hardly (if ever) attested in Slavic. Its hypothetical traces in Old Russian are very sparse and not unambiguous: negotovami dorogami 'untrodden roads'. However, this etymology seems to be reasonable and is adopted here.

Source: 594[{S.v. Sloven. hiša, a loanword from Germanic (PG *hūsa-).}];458[8:159-160{PS *xysŭ, *xyša is a loanword from Germanic, cf. Old High German hūs 'house'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Germanic *hūsa- ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:159-160, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Source: 141[620-621{S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-1060).}];81[489{S.v. Proto-Slavic *tekti 'flow, run', from PIE *tekʷ- (cf. Skt. tákti 'rush', OIr. techid 'flee').}];595[4: 159{PS *teťi 'go, run, flow' is derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'run, flow'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):489, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:159, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Source: 594[{The Slovene lexeme is derived from the interjection jo with the suffix *-ka- which is often used for deriving lexemes for unarticulated human sounds.}];595[232{The Slovene lexeme is derived fomr the interjection joj, joh.}];458[6: 69{Slovene jokati 'cry' is listed among Slavic cognates of *ękati / *ęcati.}]
Justification: Of onomatopoeic origin from the interjection 'joj, joh' (cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595):232, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Source: 594[{The lexeme is a loan from Middle German krempel 'claw' which is a diminutive of krampe 'claw, small axe, a kind of hoe'.}]
Justification: Loan from German Krampel, Krämpel 'claw' ([Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Source: 141[128-129{Cf. s.v. *drep- 'abschneiden, (ab)reißen' (IEW 211).}];81[115{S.v. Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch' (ESSJa V 101-102), cf. Gk. δρέπω 'pluck'.}];458[5: 101-102{PS *drapati 'scratch' is related to PS *dĭrati [PIE *der-].}];249[{PIE *drep- maybe related to PIE *der- (this view is supported by ESSJa) but according to the general policy and LIV a separate PIE root *drep- is assumed.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):115, [LIV²](src-141) 128-129, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 5:101-102 assuming a basic root *der- with a root extension).

Source: 165[260{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hūsa- 'house', an etymologically obscure word.}];415[1288-1290{S.v. OHG hûs 'Haus, Gebäude, Hütte, Zelt, Wohnung, Behausung, Unterkunft, Heim(statt), Hauswesen, Familie, Geschlecht', from Proto-Germanic χūsa-. There are two equally possible possibilities for a further etymology: (1) a derivation from a pre-form *kuHso- 'Schutz(ort)', a derivation from the IE verbal root *(s)keu̯H- 'bedecken', alternatively it may be (2) from Pre-Proto-Germanic *kudʰso- to the IE verbal root *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen'.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either to (1) pre-form *kuHso- '(place of) protection', a derivation from the IE verbal root *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover', or to (2) pre-Proto-Germanic *kudʰso- to the IE verbal root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. [EWA 4](src-415):1288-1290 for further details of either etymology, with references; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):260.

Source: 598[2: 275{It is related to Old High German hachit, hechit, German Hecht, Anglo-Saxon hacod 'pickerel', further to Old High German hakô and Anglo-Saxon hóc 'angle'.}];602[2: 443{It is related to German Hecht 'pickerel', German Hacken 'angle' etc. PIE *keg- / *kek- 'angle'.}];458[10: 109-110{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kogъtъ / *kogъtь. The Slavic lexeme is related to West Germanic lexemes for 'pickerel', e.g. German Hecht.}];165[203{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hakan- 'hook', a "word with several formal problems and no certain extra-Germanic etymology."}];388[154{Old English hacod, Old Saxon kahth, Old High German hehhit 'pike' are "derivationally similar to Slavic *kogŭtĭ 'claw'".}]
Justification: Traditionally considered cognate with Proto-Germanic *hakan- 'hook' ([ESSJa](src-458) 10:109-110, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 2:275, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):387), although extra-Germanic connections to the Germanic comparanda are doubted by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):203 on the basis of formal difficulties. [Not in [Derksen 2008](src-81)].

Source: 249[{The only proposed etymology is inconvincing from the semantic point of view.}];607[36{The Belarusian lexeme is a derivative from Proto-Slavic *kyp- 'seethe' [PIE *ku̯eh₁p- 'blow, puff'].}]
Comment: The Etymological Dictionary of Belarusian claims that this lexeme is a derivative from Proto-Slavic *kyp- 'seethe' (Proto-Indo-European ku̯eh₁p-). However, it seems unconvincing.

Source: 81[35{S.v. Proto-Slavic *bedro, *bedra 'thigh' (ESSJa I 175-176, 179-180). "The etymology of this word is not entirely clear. The connection with Ukr. bedrá (dial.) 'large pit, valley, swamp', Pl. ubiedrze 'slope, steep bank', and Lith. bẽdrė 'swamp, valley', Latv. bedre 'pit' (Anikin 1998: 30-31), which derive from *bʰedʰ- 'dig', is semantically unattractive. In Balto-Slavic, the meaning of this root seems to shifted to 'to stab', however, which makes on wonder if → *stegnò 'thigh' may derive from a root meaning 'stab' as well, cf. OIc. stinga 'stab, thrust'. Pokorny's reconstruction of a root *bed- 'swell' (IEW: 96) is impossible because of Winter's Law."}];458[179-180{PS *bedro is derived from *bed- / *bod- 'hit, stab' (cf. PS *bosti). As to the semantic development cf. German Bein 'leg' < PIE *bʰei̯- 'beat, hit'}]
Justification: The etymology is disputable and not entirely clear, cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 1: 15, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 28 or [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 74. However, the hypothesis of [ESSJa](src-458), considered also by [Derksen 2008](src-81): 35, is attractive. For the semantic development see also [cognate set 7765](cog-7765).

Source: 636[2: 240, 241{PS *prętati is related to PS *prǫtŭ 'sprout, sprig'. The PIE root is *preu- / *prou- / *prū- 'jump, burst', cf. also Russian prygat' 'jump'.}];608[372{Russian prâtat' ['hide'] is related to prut ['sprout, sprig']. The original meaning of the verb was 'wrap' (and that of prut 'sprout good for binding, intertwining, wrapping').}];599[2: 79{It is complicated to explain PS *prętati etymologically without linking it to *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig'], although it is not fully convincing semantically. However, if we assume that the meaning 'hide' is not original, this problem can be solved (*prętati could originally mean 'wrap, cover with sprouts' etc.).}];598[3: 396{It is usually linked to PS *prǫtŭ ['sprout, sprig']. However, it has not been proven, that PS *prętati had meanings like 'entwine, wrap'.}];259[482, 572{PS *prętati and *prǫtŭ have no certain etymology.}];593[510{PS *prǫtŭ is etymologically obscure. There are similar words in Germanic (cf. German Spross, English sprout, Old Icelandic sproti) but it is complicated to put them together with the Slavic lexeme (the Slavic form points to *pronto- and the Germanic one to *spreudo-). However, the Slavic and Germanic forms could be maybe linked to PIE *(s)per- 'splash, sparkle, sprout'.}]
Justification: There is no certain etymology ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:396). The relationship to Proto-Slavic *prǫtŭ and Russian prygat' is dubious.

Source:
81[467{S.v. Proto-Slavic *stěnь 'shadow'. See Proto-Slavic *sěnь [cf. [cognate set 5058](cog-5058)], the word-initial *st- may be explained by assuming contamination with *těnь [cf. [cognate set 5149](cog-5149)].}];259[80-81{PS *těnĭ is maybe derived from *tem-nĭ with a simplification of the cluster *-mn- and a lengthening of the root vowel. It would be ultimately derived from PIE *tem(ə)- 'dark' then. A derivation from PIE *ten- 'pull, extend' (cf. Polish cienki 'thin') with a motivation 'something getting longer and shorter, something mobile' is less likely.}];593[602-603{The original form is probably sěnĭ which can be linked to German Schein, Greek σκιᾱ́, Old Indic chāyā́ etc. However, Slavic forms with st- and t- are an issue. Taboo-deformations and contaminations (with *tĭma ['darkness'] and *stěna ['wall']) can be assumed here.}];598[3: 602, 755| 4: 43{It is usually reconstructed as *tēmnĭ and linked to *tĭma ['darkness'], *tĭmĭnŭ ['dark']. Some scholars try to connect it to sten' or with sten' and sen'.
Russian sen' is related to Latvian sejs 'shadow', Gothic skeinan 'shine', Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow', Old Indic chāyā́ 'shadow, glare, reflex', Albanian hē 'shadow' etc. It has been tried to connect it with ten' and sten' with a taboo-deformations assumed.
A comparison of sten' to Greek σκιᾱ́ 'shadow' etc. has phonetic issues. It is probable that the connection of *sěnĭ and *stěnĭ is secondary and conditioned by a contaminaton of *sěnĭ and *těnĭ.}]
Justification: The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' [LIV²](src-141): 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 472.

Source: 458[12: 70-78{It is widely assumed that PS *kǫtja is derived from PS *kǫtati 'clean up, hide'. However, such a derivation is improbable morphologically. It is better to assume a derivation from PS *kǫtŭ '(inner, concave) corner' here. PS *kǫtŭ is most probably derived from PIE *kompto- / *kampto- 'bend' and related to Greek κάμπτω 'bend' and Lithuanian kam̃pas, kum̃pas 'corner, edge'.}];81[244{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kǫtja 'hut' (ESSJa XII 70-74). "Etymology obscure. To all appearances, the etymon was originally limited to East and South Slavic."}];594[{Cf. s.v. Sloven. kọ́ča -e ž lat.‛casa’}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):244, [ESSJa](src-458) 12:70-74, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) for further discussion.

Source: 81[51-52{S.v. Proto-Slavic *bolgъ 'good' (ESSJa II 174). "Etymology unclear. The etymon has been compared with Skt. Bŕ̥haspáti- (name of a God) and Av. bərəg- f. 'rite', but this is highly speculative."}];458[173{The etymology of PS *bolgo is not entirely clear. It has been linked to Avestan bərəg- 'rite, custom'. However, this etymology is rather a question of belief. A comparison to bolĭjĭ ['better, bigger'] were formally possible (then *bolgo < *bol-g-o).}];259[32{PS *bolgŭ is rerived from PIE *belg̑- 'shine, glimmer'. The semantic development was 'shining, light' > 'good' (cf. Polish świetny 'very good, great' < 'light, shining').}];593[79, 81{PS bolgŭ does not have any convincing explanation. It has been assumed to be derived from PIE *bʰel-ɡ- 'shine' (cf. PS bělŭ 'white').}];594[{PS *blagŭ is derived from PIE *bʰelɡ- 'shine, glow' (cf. Old Indic bhárgas- 'brightness, glare'), a derivetive from PIE bʰel- (cf. PS *bělŭ 'white').}]
Comment: Note that the original Slavic meaning was 'good'. The meaning 'sweet' in some South Slavic languages is a later innovation.
Justification: Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain ([ESSJa](src-458) 2:174, [Derksen 2008](src-81):51-52). Some attempts have been made to connect the root to the same found in 'white' < PIE *bʰelH- (cf. [cognate set 1190](cog-1190)), but the additional *-g- found on the stem lacks a convincing morphological explanation.

Source: 141[513-515{S.v. *sed- 'sich setzen' (IEW 884-7) with OCS xoditi 'go' given as a cognate assumed from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e-.}];458[8: 49-52{PS *xoditi is derived from PIE *sed- / *sod- 'sit'. The semantic development can be related to an invention of a new form of transport in a sitting position, cf. Russian vsadnik, Old Indic sādín 'horse rider'. It can be also motivated by the concept of destination aprproaching ('to sit down at the end of the way'), cf. Old Indic ā-sad- 'to approach, reach'.}];81[202-203{S.v. Proto-Slavic *xoditi 'go, walk' (ESSJa VIII 48-49), from PIE *sod- (cf. Gk. ὁδεύω 'wander').}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes generally derived from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to seat (oneself)' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):202-203, [ESSJa](src-458) 8:49-52, [LIV²](src-141) 513-515).

Source: 595[4: 227{Macedonian trkalo 'wheel' etc. is derived from PS *tŭrkati, *tŭrčati 'run'. The further etymology is uncertain. It can be derived from PIE *ter-k-, cf. Middle Irish tricc 'fast'. Also Gothic þragjan 'run', Greek τρέχω 'run' and Gaulish ver-tragus 'fast running dog' (derived from PIE *trāgʰ-, *trē̆gʰ-) are related.}];165[544{Gothic þragjan 'run' is related to Greek τρέχω 'run' and Old Irelandic tethraig 'ran away, receded'. A link to OCS trk 'course, flight' (< *trk(ʷ)-o-) and Slovene trčati 'run' (< *trk(ʷ)-i-eh₂-) is less attractive.}];141[635{*terkʷ- 'turn, rotate' with Hittite tarukzi, tarkuanzi 'dance', Albanian tjerr 'spin', Latin torqueō, torquēre 'turn, wind' and Tocharian tetarku 'turned' listed as reflexes.}]
Justification: The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598), however it has formal and semantical issues (cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4:227)

Source: 81[418{S.v. Proto-Slavic *pravъ adj. 'right'. "If *pràvъ < *proH-uo- […] we may compare the formation with Lat. probus ‘solid, decent’ provided that the latter form continues *pro-b ʰ(u̯)o- and not *pro-bʰuH-o-."}];603[5: 577-581, 586-584{PS *pravъ < PIE *prō-wo-s. PIE *prō- is also retained in PS prefix prā- 'before, in front of'. The semantic development of PS *praviti was like 'put something straight, straighten' > 'put into an order, arrange' > 'build' > 'make, do'.}];594[{PS *praviti 'tell' is derived from PS *pravŭ in the meaning 'true, correct' and not 'straighten'. Its original meaning was 'tell the truth'. PS *pravŭ is derived from PIE *próh₃u̯o- (*prōu̯o-) and related to Old Indic pū́rva- 'first', English first etc.}];294[639{Cf. s.v. pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' (Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft mit Abl.), specifically under the proposed formation *pró-o, *prṓ 'vorwärts, hervor| frühmorgens', to which perhaps might be connected Proto-Slavic ?*pra- 'vor' as a compositional prefix in e.g. OCS pradědŭ 'Vorfahre, Urahne', ]OCS pravŭ 'recht, richtig', Russ. pravyj 'rechts'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639, cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 5:577-581, 586-584).

Source: 603[2: 201{Loan from Turkish kanca 'hook'.}]
Justification: Loan from Turkish kanca 'hook' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 2:201).

Source: 141[640{PIE *teu̯k- 'hit, beat' with Slavic tŭkǫ, tŭkati 'spin', tŭknǫti, tykati 'push' and Greek τέτυκον 'produced, prepared' listed as cognates.}]
603[1: 92{It is a loanword from Turkish but.}]
Justification: In [ESSJa](src-458): 3: 103 it is claimed that this word can be native. The support were East Slavic dialectal but referring to various kinds of 'onion' or 'beet', cf. also PS *buta, *butati, *butiti. However, it is possible that we deal with two different etyma here.

Source: 83[111-112{S.v. Proto-Iranian *garz- 'to lament, weep' cf. Skt. garh- 'to complain'. An IE origin for this IIr. root is uncertain.}];172[I:475, 495{Cf. s.v. Ved. √garh- 'klagen', PIE perhaps *galg̑ʰ- *gal-g̑ʰ- according to IEW 350 (cf. NHG klagen, MIr. glām 'Geschrei, Fluch'). The connections outside of Indo-Iranian remain uncertain.}];141[187{Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ- 'klagen' (IEW 350-1). Only Indo-Iranian.}];269[{From Proto-Iranian *garz- 'to lament, weep' and Skt. garh- 'to complain' one may reconstruct PIIr. *garj́ʰ-. LIV² 187 further mechanically reconstructs PIE ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ- 'klagen', but as there are no secure cognates outside of Indo-Iranian, this reconstruction is uncertain.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *garj́ʰ- 'to lament'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:475, 495, [Cheung 2007](src-83):111-112). [LIV²](src-141) 187 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ-.

Comment: Considering the Parthian form gwyʾw and the ZMP form gwbyʾ, one may reconstruct a bilabial glide. There is a possibility that this word is a compound of gauu- "cow" and a second element, cf. Old Ind. *Hyavas- "pasture" or  yáva- "wheat".

Source: 567[220{Bactrian καδαγο 'house' < *kata-ka- (cf. MPers. kadag).}];331[4:340-348{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *kata- / *xata-, *kāna- / *xāna- 'дом, хижина| сооржение|  укрепленное лоселение'. Derived from the verbal root * kan- / * xan-, Indo-Iranic *k(h)an- in the meaning 1) 'to dig', 2) 'to fill' as * kata- / xata- <* k(h)n̥to- and verbal noun * kāna- / * xāna- <* k(h)ā-na- (Cf. Abaev). Less likely to from the verb * kat- / * čat- 'to cover, cover, hide' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):50). The connection with the verb * kan- 'dig' is rejected by Bartolome [Barth. AiW, 432]. It is possible that these names were already lexicalized in common Iranian in most dialects as “house, structure, room”, in certain languages as “roof”}]
Comment: Bailey (1979: 50f.) connects the house word kata- and the city word kanthā- in Saka with a verbal root 'kan' "to cover, hide". Cheung (2007: 232) notes the Sogdian city word knδh (and variants) with the root 'kanH' "to dig". This would not work with the hourse word because kn̩Hta- would give kāta-. It may rather be the root 'kan'  "to throw, place, put; destroy' (Cheung 2007: 229, although the 'destroy' meaning may rather derive from 'kanH' "to dig"). Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the other Iranic house word xān-.
Justification: Etymology disputed. [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):232-233), although this etymology is rejected by [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):432. Alternatively [Bailey 1979](src-320):50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-341). If from a PIE root *kenH- 'to dig', the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. [cognate set 7327](cog-7327).

Source: 331[4:340-348{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *kata- / *xata-, *kāna- / *xāna- 'дом, хижина| сооржение| укрепленное лоселение'. Derived from the verbal root * kan- / * xan-, Indo-Iranic *k(h)an- in the meaning 1) 'to dig', 2) 'to fill' as * kata- / xata- <* k(h)n̥to- and verbal noun * kāna- / * xāna- <* k(h)ā-na- (Cf. Abaev). Less likely to from the verb * kat- / * čat- 'to cover, cover, hide' (Bailey 1979:50). The connection with the verb * kan- 'dig' is rejected by Bartolome [Barth. AiW, 432]. It is possible that these names were already lexicalized in common Iranian in most dialects as “house, structure, room”, in certain languages as “roof”}]
Comment: Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the Iranic ‘house’ word xān- (besides the kadag-forms). If it is related to “dig”, the question remains, why this verb usually appears with #k and not #x (cf. Mayrhofer 1992: 445), cf. also Cheung (2007: 231) “In many Iranian languages the roots *kan1 ‘to throw’, *kanH1 ’to dig’ and *kan2 ‘to fill’ forms are homonymous and therefore often show mutual interference.”
Justification: Etymology disputed. [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):232-233), although this etymology is rejected by [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):432. Alternatively [Bailey 1979](src-320):50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-341). If from *kenH-, the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. [cognate set 7327](cog-7327).

Source: 83[65-66{S.v. Proto-Iranian *dau-² 'to run', from PIE *dʰeu̯- 'to move, go' (LIV 147f.), cf. Skt. dhāv- 'to walk, hurry, flow' (RV+) AGk. θέω 'I walk', θοός 'quick'.}];141[147-148{S.v. *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen' (IEW 259-60, 262).}];172[I:789-790{S.v. Ved. √dhāv- 'laufen, eilen, fließen, strömen', from PIE *dʰeu̯- (cf. Gk. θέω 'laufe', θοός 'schnell').}];442[389{Cf. s.v. 6802 Ved. dhā́vati (1) 'runs, flows' RV. 2. dhāváyati (1) 'makes run, drives' ŚBr. [√dhāv1]}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *dʰeu̯- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:789-790, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):389 no.6802, [Cheung 2007](src-83):65-66, [LIV²](src-141) 147-148).

Source: 172[I:433{S.v. Ved. kṣīrá- 'Milch', IIr. cf. MPers. šīr 'Milch'}]
Justification: lit. 'milk', Iranic adjective formation *xšīraina-. No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:290, [EWAia](src-172) I:490).

Source: 83[119-121{S.v. Proto-Iranian *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take' < PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'grab, seize' (cf. OCS grabiti 'to rob', Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'to rob').}];141[201{S.v. *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).}];172[I:505-507{S.v. Ved. √grabh-ⁱ 'ergreifen, nehmen, fassen, festhalten' (Av. gərəβnāiti 'gewinnt, erlangt'), from PIE (prob.) *gʰreb⁽ʰ⁾H- (cf. Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'rauben', Latv. grebt 'greifen', OCS grabiti 'rauben').}];442[227{S.v. 4236 Ved. gr̥bhāyáti 'takes, seizes' RV. 2. gr̥hṇā́ti, gr̥bhṇā́ti 'takes, seizes' RV.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ([LIV²](src-141) 201, [EWAia](src-172) I:505-507, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):227 no. 4236, [Cheung 2007](src-83):119-121).

Source: 165[292{S.v. Proto-Germanic *klawō- 'claw' (OEng. clāwu, clā, Eng. claw, Du. klauw, OHG klāwa, klā, klō(a)| Germ. Klaue, ON kló, Far. klógv, Elfd. kluo).  Exclusively a Germanic word.}];397[496-497{Cf. s.v. NHG Klaue (OHG klāwa, klā 'Klaue'). There are no meaningful comparisons that can be made outside of Germanic.}];345[219{Cf. s.v. TochB kolyi '± hoof, paw' (?), in general 'animal's foot' (?)| suggests a derivation from *golu-h₁en- and a connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo-/*klēwo- 'claw' (OE clawu 'claw, hoof', OHG klāwo 'claw').}]
Justification: There is no generally accepted etymology for Proto-Germanic *klawō- outside of Germanic ([Kluge 2011](src-397):496-497, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):292). [Adams 2013](src-345):219 suggests a possible connection to with Proto-Tocharian **kolʸ- 'animal's foot'(?) but this remains uncertain.

Source: 165[190{S.v. Proto-Germanic *grindan- 'to grind'. Cf. OEngl. grindan, Engl. grind.  < *gʷʰrénHdʰ-e-.  Connects with Lat. frendō 'grind one's teeth', < *gʷʰréndH-e-, Lith. *grę́sti 'to plane, scour' < *gʷʰrenHdʰ-i̯e-.}];141[204{S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾ʰrend- '(zer)reiben' (IEW 459), doubting the connection of Lat. frendō, and Lith. gréndu 'schaben, scheuern' at a PIE level.  Cf. n1 "Ae. grindan 'reiben, zermalmen' usw. kann dann wegen d < dʰ  nur mittelbar vergleichen werden."}];322[{Given the difficulties of establishing a clear reconstruction for this root at the PIE level, for the purposes of the database it would be best to only reconstruct a cognate class for only Proto-Germanic, for now.}];269[{Root ref. form reconstructed only for Proto-Germanic level as further connections are uncertain.}]

83[241-243{Proto-Iranian *karš-/*xrah- 'to draw, plough' (YAv. karš- 'to draw (furrows), plough', Skt. karṣ- 'to pull, drag, plow' (RV+)) from PIE *kʷels- 'Furchen ziehen, einfurchen' (LIV² 388-389, IEW 639-640).  Cf. Hitt. gulšanzi 'they scratch into', AGk. τέλσον 'last furrow of the field'.}];141[388-389{S.v. *kʷels- 'Furchen ziehen, einfurchen' (IEW 639-640).}];172[I:319-320{Cf. s.v. Ved. √karṣ- 'ziehen, schleppen, pflügen', probably to PIE *kʷels-, cf. Hitt. gul-ša-an-zi 'sie ritzen ein', Gk. τέλσον 'letzte Furche des Ackers'.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *karš-/*xrah- 'to draw, plough', further to PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):241-243, [EWAia](src-172) I:319-320, [LIV²](src-141) 388-389).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. carry, a borrowing from Old Northern French carier.}]
Justification: Loanword from Anglo-Norman carier ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 594[{PS *skvĭrn- has not been entirely explained. It can be a derivative from PS *skverti, sed. *skvĭrǫ 'melt fat'. The etymological meaning would be 'smeared with fat'. A relationship to Latin squarrōsus 'scurfy, scabby' is less probable.}];593[579{The word does not have a certain etymology. One could assume a relationship to PS *skverti 'melt fat'. The original meanig would be 'smeary, stained with grease' then.}];249[{The etymology of this lexeme is obscure, even at the PS level. If we accept the relationship to *skverti 'melt fat', the root can hav an ideophonic origin. Any certain further IE cognates can be determined.}]

141[499-500{S.v. *reh₁dʰ- 'erfolgreich durchführen' (IEW 59-60).}];81[432, 437{S.v. Proto-Slavic *raditi 'care about, heed', cf. roditi I 'give birth, bear (fruit)' "Only Balto-Slavic. LIV’s reconstruction *(H)rod-eie- (497) of an aspirated voiced stop is based on Matasović’s modification of Winter’s law (only in closed syllables), which is why in a footnote *d is not completely ruled out. The often suggested connection with Skt. várdhate ‘grow, increase, thrive’ is formally problematic, since we would have to assume Schwebeablaut and loss of *u-."}]
Justification: Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 499-500 to PIE *reh₁dʰ- 'to successfully accomplish', but cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):432, 437.

Source:
81[212{Polish miano, dialectal miono and Slovincian mjʉ̀ɵ̯nɵ (along with Polish imię, imienia and archaic imiono) are listed among reflexes of PS *jĭmę.}];458[8: 227-228{Polish miano, dialectal miono and Slovincian mjʉ̀ɵ̯nɵ (along with Polish imię, imienia, archaic imiono, Slovincian ï̂mją Kashubian jiḿą) are listed among reflexes of PS *jĭmę.}];609[329-330{Polish miano (with derivatives as mianować 'appoint, name', wzmianka 'a mention', nadmienić 'mention, drop a hint', wymienić 'list, enumerate, mention') is related to German meinen ['think, mean']. It has nothing in common with imię (and miono).}];260[922-923{Polish miano and Kashubian miono are listed (along with imię and jimiã) as cognates of Upper Sorbian mjeno and reflexes of PS *jĭmę. However, the autor mentions an alternative etymology of miano.}];598[2: 129-130{Polish miano is listed among reflexes of PS *jĭmę, *jĭmene with an additional reconstructed form *jĭměn-.}];259[320{Polish miano, miono and Kashubian miono (cf. Upper Sorbian mjeno, Old Czech meno, méno, Slovak meno) are reflexes of West Slavic *měno 'name'. It was derived from PS *měniti 'call, give a name'. This lexeme was contaminated by forms of the synonymic PS *jĭmę (*-e- instead of *-ě- in older Polish miono and Kashubian miono).
PS *měniti 'think, mean, understand, consider, call, give a name' is related to German meinen 'think, say' and derived from PIE *mei̯-no- 'opinion, view, intention'.}]
Justification:
Despite of the formal similarity of Polish miano and Kashubian miono with doubtless reflexes of PS *jĭmę, *jĭmene, the relationship of the former to the latter is far from clear. The main formal problem is the root vowel (*-ě- vs. *-e-). The lack of initial i- in miano, miono is, in general, not a crucial issue.
Some sources entirely ignore the formal problems [Derksen 2008](src-81), [ESSJa](src-458). Vasmer proposes a protoform *jĭměn- for Polish miano [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 130, however he does not explain the nature of this irregular lengthening.
Polish etymologists assume that imię and miano are two distinct etymona, the former being a reflex of a common IE lexeme for 'name' and the latter being a derivative of a verbal root referring to 'thinking', 'mentioning', 'considering as', 'giving a name' etc. Cf. {Boryś 2005}: 320. The formal anlysis is hindered by morphological levellings and conaminations. If Kashubian miono is derived from PS *měno, -o- has been taken from plural forms of *jĭmę, *jĭmene, cf. Polish imiona 'names'. According to the general policy, a cautious view is adopted here. As to the root reference form *men-, see [LIV²](src-141): 435-436.

Source: 83[356-357{S.v. Proto-Iranian *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' (cf. Ved. śrav- 'to hear', Gk. ἔκλυον 'heard', κλυτός 'famous', Lat. cluēre 'to be called, to be mentioned', Toch. käln- 'to sound', Latv. sludinât 'to declare', etc.).}];172[II:666-667{Cf. s.v. Ved. √śrav- 'hören', from PIE *k̑leu̯- (cf. Arm. aor. low(a), pres. lse- 'hören', Gk. ἔκλυον 'hörte', κλυτός 'berühmt', Lat. cluēre 'heißen, genannt werden', OIr. ro-cluinethar 'hört', OHG hliumant 'Ruf, Gerücht, Leumand', Latv. sludinât 'verkünden', Toch AB käln- 'tönen').}];141[334-335{S.v. *k̑leu̯- 'hören' (IEW 605-7).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', further to PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):356-357, [EWAia](src-172) II:666-667, [LIV²](src-141) 334-335).

Comment: Bartholomae (1904: 1523) quotes the reconstruction *srān°. In Ossetic also "belt".
Justification: Modern Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *rāna- 'upper part of the leg, thigh', cf. Avestan rāna- 'id.' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:201, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):91). Further etymology uncertain, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:108, III:21 for proposed but uncertain cognates in Indic.

Source: 172[I:750{S.v. Ved. doṣā́- 'Dunkel, Abend', cf. Pkt. dosā 'Nacht', Aškun dōs 'gestern', YAv. daošatara- 'gegen Abend gelegen, westlich', MPers., NPers. dōš 'letztvergangene Nacht, vorangegangener Abend', etc. The form is sometimes connected with Gk. δείελος 'nachmittaglich, abendlich| Abend', but further etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are ultimately uncertain.}];269[{Based on Avestan and Vedic comparanda a Proto-Indo-Iranian stem *dau̯šā́- may be reconstructed.}];442[376{S.v. 6590 Ved. doṣā́ 'night, night personified' RV. > Phal. dohṓṛ, dhōṛ, doṛ 'yesterday'.}]
Comment: s, not š, in Nuristani.
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dau̯šā́- 'evening; night', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:750, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):376 no. 6590).

Source: 83[24{S.v. Proto-Iranic *bram- 'to cry, weep', from PIE *bʰrem- 'to cry' (cf. Lat. fremō 'I make a thud, mumble, moan', MWelsh bref- 'to roar', Pol. brzmię 'I sound, buzz', OE barmen, NHG barmen 'to complain, moan').}];141[94{S.v. *bʰrem- 'brummen, brüllen' (IEW 142-3).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰrem- 'to buzz, to bellow' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):24, [LIV²](src-141) 94).

TochB cake 'river' from Proto-Tocharian *cäke from PIE *tek- 'flow' (Skt. tákti 'hastens, rushes along', Avestan tačati 'runs, hastens, flows', Albanian ndjek 'follow', OIr. techid 'flees', Lith. tekù 'rush, flow').}];141[620-621{Cf. s.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-60).}];320[121-122, 182-183{S.v. Ved. √tak- 'stürzen, dahinschießen, eilen (von Tieren, Strömen) (YAv. tax-še 'du läufst, Khot. ttajs- 'laufen, fließen', MPers. tāxtan 'laufen, lassen, fließen', Parth. tč- 'laufen, fließen', etc.), from PIE *tekʷ- 'eilen, stürzen, laufen, fließen' (cf. OIr. tech- 'fließen', Lith. tekė́ti 'laufen, fließen', etc.).}]
Justification: Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ([Adams 2013](src-345):267, [EWAia](src-172) I:610-611, [Bailey 1979](src-320):121-122, 182-183, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Source: 141[630-631{Cf. s.v. *ter- 'sprechen' (IEW 1088-9).}];352[1076-1078{S.v. OLith. tar̃ti 'sagen, aussprechen' (BSl. cf. OPr. tārin 'Stimme'), from PIE *ter- 'sprechen' (cf. Hitt. ter- 'sprechen, sagen').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *ter- 'to speak' ([ALEW](src-352) 1076-1078, [LIV²](src-141) 630-631

Source: 141[679{S.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' (IEW 1144-5).}];389[{NB: In LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda Hitt. u̯alḫ- 'schlagen' (s.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' in LIV²) is separated toa new root *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen', and the Luwic forms (CLuw. walant-/ulant- 'tot', HLuw. wa-la/i- 'sterben', Lyc. lati 'stirbt') are assigned to *u̯elh₃- with an updated root gloss 'sterben'. Note, however, this root assignment is provisional, as the Proto-Luwic form could also formally reflect *gʷelH-.}]
Justification: Root ref. form follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but note that the Proto-Luwic form this class represents may also formally represent *gʷelH-. Cf. [LIV²](src-141) 679.

Source: 141[620-621{S.v. *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' (IEW 1059-60). Alb. v-des 'stirbt' from cs.-it. stem. *tokʷ-éi̯e- (cf. YAv. tācaiieiti 'läßt fließen', OCS точѫ (točǫ) точити (točiti) 'fließen lassen').}];105[496{S.v. Alb. vdes 'to die', from *awa-takja, derivative to *teka 'to run away, go away'.}];364[1001-1002{S.v. Alb. vdes 'sterben, zugrunde gehen, absterben'. The widespread derivation of this verb from *tokʷ-éi̯e/o- (iterative from the root *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' cf. LIV² 620f.) is not phonologically tenable, since a *t can only become voiced in an environment after *n. There are no other commonly accepted roots or present stem formations that this verb can be connected to. It is probable that the root contained a final *kʷ, and in initial position there was the preverb v-. [Schumacher & Matzinger continue to suggest a possible etymology to a root *dekʷs-, comparing Av. daxš- 'lehren', and Hitt. tekkussii̯e/a- 'sich zeigen' but are at pains to admit that this suggestion is highly speculative.]}];130[57{Rejects the connection to *tekʷ-, and suggests that a connection to LIV² 150 *dʰgʷʰei̯- 'hinschwinden, sterben / pass away, die' (cf. Gk. φθίνω).}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. [Orel 1998](src-105):496 and [LIV²](src-141) 620-621 assign the verb to *tekʷ-, against which cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1001-1002. [Holm 2011](src-130):57 also rejects *tekʷ-, instead suggesting *dʰgʷʰei̯- 'hinschwinden, sterben' as a more plausible alternative. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1001-1002 propose a speculative etymology to a root *dekʷs-.

Source: 141[664-665{S.v. *u̯eh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'brechen, zu Bruch gehen' (IEW 1110), cf. ἄγνυμι from -néu̯/nu- present *uh₂⁽g̑⁾-néu̯/nu- 'mache (zer)brechen' and TochA wākä[t] 'zerbrach'.  The Hittite form is possibly from an iterative ?*u̯oh₂⁽g̑⁾-éi̯e-.}];80[939-940{S.v. Hitt. u̯āk- / u̯akk- 'to bite', from PIE *u̯eh₂g̑- (cf. Gk. ἄγνυμι 'break', TochAB wāk 'to split, burst'. The Anatolian forms represent preforms 3.sg. *u̯óh₂⁽g̑⁾-ei, 3.pl. *uh₂⁽g̑⁾-énti to root.  Palaic u̯akk- 'to bite(?)' (3.pl.pret.act. u̯a-ak-ka₄-kán-ta) is a possible additional cognate within Anatolian.}]
Justification: An derivative of the root *u̯eh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to break' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):939-940, [LIV²](src-141) 664-665).

Source: 165[66{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- (adj.) 'bitter, sharp', a ra-stem created to PGmc. *bītan-, ultimately derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' (cf. Skt. binátti 'to split, break, destroy', Lat. findō, -ere, 'split, cleave' < *bʰi-né-d-ti, *bʰi-n-d-énti, Gk. φείδομαι 'to spare, save, refrain from').}];141[70-71{Cf. s.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).}];179[58-59{S.v. Goth. B13. *baitrs 'bitter', only N.pl. baitrai, adv. batraba 'πικρῶς', 'bitterly', from PIE *bʰei̯d- as in *beitan 'bite', with o-grade and PIE *-ro- suffix.}];397[127{S.v. NHG bitter (MHG bitter, OHG bittar, OS bittar) from Germanic *bit-ra- (adj.) 'bitter' (also in ON bitr, OE biter, beside full-grade *bait-ra- in Both. baitrs and *baiska- (from *bait-ska-) in ON beiskr. Before *r the High German sound shift does not occur.}];468[30{S.v. ON beiskr 'bitter, böse' (cf. Ic., Far. beiskur, Norw. beisk, Sw. Da. besk), from Proto-Germanic *baitska-, with a -sk- suffix to the same stem as Goth. baitrs 'bitter'.}];697[115,126-127{S.v. Proto-Germanic *baitra- 'bitter' > Goth. baitrs| s.v. Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'beißend, bitter' > North and West Germanic forms| verbal adjective in *-ra- to the strong verb *beita- 'beißen'.}]
Justification: There are several different nominal derivations within Germanic here that are based on PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' ([LIV²](src-141) 70-71); cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):66, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):115, 126-127, [Kluge 2011](src-397):127, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):58-59, [de Vries 1977](src-468):30).

Source: 80[620-621{S.v. Hitt. palḫi- / palḫai- 'wide, broad' (cf. CLuw. palḫai̯a- 'wide, broad'), from PIE *plh₂-(e)i- (cf. Lat. plānus 'flat, smooth', Lith. plónas, Latv. plãns 'thin, flat', Lith. plóti, Latv. plãt 'to flatten').}];274[562-564{S.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).}]
Justification: An i-stem adjective derived to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):620-621, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Source: 556[524{S.v. Gmc. *(-)ϸrūt-a- (?) '(schwellen)'. Only North Germanic, unless also with OE ϸrutian 'vor Hochmut oder Zorn schwellen'. No possibility at a certain etymological assessment| above all the vocalism makes difficulties.}];468[624{S.v. ON ϸrútinn 'geschwollen', ϸrutna 'aufschwellen'. Etymology disputed.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):524, [de Vries 1977](src-468):624 for further discussion.

Source: 141[243{S.v. *h₁eu̯- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 78).}];80[227-229{S.v. Hitt. au- / u- 'to see, look'. Connects Hitt. au-/u- 'to see, look' with Skt. āviṣ (adv.) 'evidently, before the eyes', Av. āuuiš 'id.', Gk. ἀΐω 'to perceive', αἰσθάνομαι 'to perceive', Lat. audiõ 'to hear' < *h₂eu̯-.  The Hittite form would reflect an *o ~ Ø ablaut, where initial *h₂- would merge with *h₁ before *o.}];654[77-108{Cf. for the argument for the development *h₂ > *h₁ / _o in Proto-Anatolian.}]
Justification: Root ref. form in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 243 s.v. *h₁eu̯-, but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):227-229 reconstructing *h₂eu̯-.

Source: 80[562-563{S.v. Hitt. maru̯āi- 'to blacken'(?), borrowed into Hittite. Cf. CLuw. marruu̯a- 'blacken', maru̯ai- (adj.) 'black, dark-coloured(?)'.  Potential cognates in Germanic ON myrkr 'dark', mjǫrkvi 'darkness', OSax. mirki, OE mierce 'dark' pointing to a PIE root *mergʷ-.}]
Justification: Possibly from PIE *mergʷ- if to be compared with Proto-Germanic *merkwa- 'dark' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):562-563, cf. also [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):409-410, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):366).

Source: 80[666{S.v. per / parn- 'house, household'. Older literature has often assumed a borrowing from Egyptian pr 'house', but the borrowing does not easily explain the archaic-looking inflection as an -r/n- stem.  From the attestation of the forms throughout Anatolian (Hitt. per/parna-,  CLuw. parna-, HLuw. parna-, Lyd. bira- 'house'| Lyc. *prñna- 'house' in prñnawa- 'tomb', prñneze/i- 'household') a Proto-Anatolian lexeme with heteroclitic inflection *Pér-r, *Pr-n-ós can be postulated.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):666).

Source: 66[1113{S.v. AGk. ὀρύσσω 'to dig (up, in, out), scrape, bury', from PIE *h₃reu-k-. The basis for the verb and derived vocabulary in Greek seems to be a stem *ὀρυχ-, but cognate forms appear to continue a stem *h₃reu̯k- (Lat. runcō 'weed out', Latv. rūkēt 'dig, scrape', Skt. luñcati 'pluck off'), thus Beekes assumes that the aspiration is an analogical innovation within Greek.}];141[307{S.v. *h₃reu̯k- '(aus)graben, (aus)rupfen' (IEW 869-870).}];270[828-829{S.v. AGk. ὀρύσσω 'creuser, faire, un canal, déterrer, enterrer, arracher', A formation in *-ye/o- resembling the root found in the Latin nasal present formation runcō 'sarcler', Skt. luñcati 'arracher', perhaps Latv. rūkēt 'fouiller, remuer la terre'| further isolated nouns, cf. in Celtic rucht < *ruqtu-, Alban. rrāh 'excavation, essart' < *rouq-so-.}]
Justification: The root reconstruction in this cognate set follows [LIV²](src-141) 307, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):828-829, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1113 for additional discussion.

Source: 141[447{S.v. *mneh₂- 'denken an' (IEW 726-7).  CLuw. form manāti /mnāti/ 'sieht' possibly from root present *mnéh₂-/mn̥h₂- attested elsewhere via Ved. ā-manati, 'erwähnt, überliefert', Homeric Gk. μνάομαι 'denke an, freie' (+ other stem derivations), but the etymology is not fully clear (marked with '?' in LIV²).  For the etymological proposal, cf. [Starke 1980](src-381):147.}];381[147]
Justification: From PIE *mneh₂- according to [Starke 1990](src-373):147; tentatively accepted by [LIV²](src-141) 447.

Source: 382[592{Modern Greek ίσιος, from Medieval Greek ἴσιος, with stem modification from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal'.}];66[600-601{S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'equal' in number, strength, size, status, etc. (dial. Arc., Cret. Boeot. attests ϝίσϝος). Formally, earlier *u̯itˢu̯o- would work, but the proposed connection to a zero-grade *ϝιδσ- from εἶδος 'shape' is hypothetical. Other proposed etymologies are unconvincing.}];270[470{S.v. ἴσος 'égal, en nombre égal, également partagé, égal en droit'. The original structure of the word ϝίσϝος is certain, but the etymology is not established.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):470, [Beekes 2010](src-66):600-601 for various proposals.

Source: 141[289-290{S.v. *h₂u̯elk- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 1145), cf. n1 for nominal comparisons suggesting the reconstruction of initial *h₂- and references to further literature.}];81[514{S.v. Proto-Slavic *velkti 'drag' < Proto-Balto-Slavic *welk-/wilk-.  Derksen doubts the Indo-European reconstruction offered by LIV², preferring only to posit a reconstructable lemma for Proto-Balto-Slavic.}];353[504{S.v. Lith. vil̃kti 'drag' (Latv. vìlkt 'drag'), from PIE *u(e)lk⁽ʷ⁾- (cf. Av. varək- 'draw').}];352[1244-1245{Cf. s.v. OLith. vil̃kti 'ziehen, schleppen' (BSl. Latv. vìlkt, vę̀lku, vìlku 'ziehen, schleppen', OPr. awilkis, OCS vlěšti 'ziehen, schleppen', etc.), from PIE *(h₂)u̯elk- 'ziehen, schleppen' (cf. YAv. vərək- 'scheppen').}]
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *(h₂)u̯elk- 'to drag, pull' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):514, [Derksen 2015](src-353):504, [ALEW](src-352) 1244-1245, [LIV²](src-141) 289-290).

Source: 81[254{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kryti 'cover, hide' (ESSJa XIII 71-72), from PIE *kruH- (cf. OE hrēodan 'cover').}];141[371{S.v. *kreu̯H- 'aufhäufen, bedecken' (IEW 616). Verbal only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, to this cf. also perhaps OIr. cró, W creu 'Stall' < *krawo-, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:240.}];458[13: 71-72{PS *kryti is derived from PIE *krū-. It is related to Lithuanian kráuti 'load, put as a pile, heap'. Further comparanda are uncertain. It has been linked to Greek κρύπτω 'hide' and Gothic hrot / hrōt 'roof'.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up; to cover' ([LIV²](src-141) 371, [Derksen 2008](src-81):254). For older hypotheses, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:71-72.

Source: 66[1525-1526{S.v. ὑγρός 'wet, moist, watery, fluid| weak, soft, flexible'. A PIE Caland adjective in *ugʷ-ro- from a root *u̯(e/o)gʷ- (cf. ONor. vǫkr from PGmc. *u̯ak-u̯a- and Lat. ūvidus from either *ugʷ- (√*u̯egʷ-) or *uh₁- (√*u̯eh₁-)).}];269[{Romanian ud < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class, but could also belong to PIE *u̯eh₁- in [cognate set 1578](cog-1578), cf. discussion in [cognate set 8427](cog-8427).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes from PIE *ugʷ-ro- 'wet', a Caland adjective in *-ro- to *u̯egʷ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1525-1526).

Source: 383[203-204{S.v. OHG âmeiza 'Ameise'. The word is probably a compound of the Proto-Germanic prefix *ǣ- 'weg, fort' and the stem of the Germanic verb *maitan- 'schneiden', with a -jōn- suffix for forming a nomen agentis *ǣmaitjōn 'die Abschneiderin', i.e. the insect that cuts up pieces of wood, leaves, and blades of grass.}];165[24, 349{S.v. Proto-Germanic *amaitjō- 'ant' (OE ǣ̆mette, NE ant, OHG ā̆meiza, NHG Ameise 'id.'). Origin unclear. Usually assumed to be a compound with the root of the verb *maitan- 'to cut', but K. finds the derivation of the first element of the compound difficult. To continue this etymology with the verb 'to cut' he offers PGmc. PGmc. *uz-mai̯ti̯ō- 'out-cutter', or alternatively PGmc. *ēmō-mai̯ti̯ō- 'larva cutter' (with haplology) > *ēmataijō-. A third option he offers is the possibility of a substratum borrowing which might also be seen in Gk. μίδας 'destructive insect in beans'. Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *maitan- 'hew, cut', further etymology unclear.}];397[38, 613{S.v. NHG Ameise (MHG āmeize, OHG āmeiza), from West Germanic *ǣmaitjōn, also in OE æmete to *ǣ 'ab, weg', and *maita- 'schneiden' (cf. NHG Meißel 'Schneidwerkzeug' and 'scheiden, hauen' in Goth. maitan, OHG meizan'). The word is to be explained as 'die aus Abschnitten Bestehende', 'made up of (cut) sections'. Cf. similarly 'insect' from Lat. īnsecta, the substantivized past passive participle of Lat. īnsecāre (īnsectum) 'einschneiden, zerschneiden'.}];179[241-242{Cf. s.v. Goth. M12. maitan- 'κόπτω', 'cut, hew', of unclear etymology. Perhaps from PIE *may-(d-) 'strike, cut off' if to be connected with OIr. mael (w/ -lo- suffix), but doubtful. Further hypotheses dubious.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes, generally considered a compound of Gmc. *ǣ- 'weg, fort' and the stem of the Germanic verb *maitan- 'schneiden', with a -jōn- suffix for forming a nomen agentis, cf. [EWA 1](src-383):203-204, [Kluge 2011](src-397):38, 613. Cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):24 for alternative hypotheses for the reconstruction of the initial prefix.

Source: 141[651-652{S.v. *treu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 1095-1096).}];54[630{S.v. Lat. trūdō, -ere 'to thrust, push', from PIE *treud-(e/o-) 'to push, thrust' (cf. W. cythrudd 'to vex', Lith. triũsas 'work, effort, pains', OCS trudь 'labour, work', Goth. us-þriutan 'to maltreat', etc.).}];316[704{S.v. trūdō, -ere 'pousser (par opposition à trahō 'tirer')', cf. Goth. us-ϸriutan 'κόπον παρέχειν' and OCS trudъ 'κόπος'.}]
Justification: From PIE *treu̯d- 'to strike' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):630, [LIV²](src-141) 651-652; cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):704).

Source: 352[242{S.v. OLith. dùlkė 'Staub'. No clear etymology outside of Lithuanian.}]
Justification: No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 242).

Comment: The Tocharian words derive either from ie. *dʰeu̯H- or *dʰu̯eh₂-, cf. cognate set 2463. On of these roots might in fact be the basis for ie. *dʰu̯ens- from which the Germanic 'dust'-words are derived (cf. [cognate set 2464](cog-2464)), but they cannot be assigned the same cognate class on this level of analysis and regarding the state of the art concerning root extensions. -  Also cf. 'ashes' cognate set 2463 and 'smoke' in [cognate set 123](cog-123).

Source: 165[572{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wambō- 'womb, belly'. No clear extra-Germanic etymology.}];179[393{S.v. Goth. W28. wamba 'γαστήρ, κοιλία', 'womb, belly'. No etymology.}];468[674{S.v. ON vǫmb 'Bauch'. Etymology uncertain. Cf. entry in de Vries for references to proposed etymologies in older literature.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *wambō- 'womb, belly'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):393, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):572, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):674).

Source: 54[448, 450-451{S.v. Lat. parvus 'small', from PIE *peh₂u-ro- with regular metathesis of *-u̯r- from intermediary *pau̯ro- (cf. AGk. παῦρος 'little' < id.| Goth. fawai (nom.pl.) 'few', OIc. fár 'little', OEng. fēa < PGerm. fawa- < *ph₂(e)u̯-o-)| from the same root is also Lat. paucus 'few, small in number' (cf. s.v. paucus).}];444[519{S.v. 6303 Lat. paucus 'wenig' > Catalan poc.}]
Justification: Latin and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂u̯- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):448, 450-451, although note that Catalan poc directly continues Latin paucus 'few, small in number', not Latin paruus 'small' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):519).

Source: 141[344-345{S.v. *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' (IEW 527-528)| in addition to Italic cognates are found in Germanic (NHG haben 'to have') and Greek (κάπτω 'gulp down').}];54[89-90{S.v. Lat. capiō, -ere 'to take', from PIE *kh₂p-i- or non-IE *kap-i- 'to seize' (cf. Gk. κάπτω 'to gulp down', Go. haban 'to have' < *kap-eh₁-i̯e/o-.}];269[{According to [de Vaan 2008](src-54):89-90 at the time of publication, Beekes's (then still forthcoming) Greek Etymological Dictionary (now [Beekes 2010](src-66)) doubts the semantic plausibility of the connection with Gk. κάπτω with Lat. capiō.  If the Greek cognates are removed from the equation, de Vaan considers that it is just as possible that the Italic and Germanic cognates may go back to a non-IE loanword.  In the dictionary as published, however, [Beekes 2010](src-66) s.v. κάπτω considers that the Greek and Italic forms 'might be identical' (presumably via a zero-grade yod-present *kh₂p-i̯é- as reconstructed by [LIV²](src-141)), with some caveats.}]

316[15-18{S.v. Lat. agō| Lat. cōgitō from agitō, a frequentative/intensive form of agō 'put in motion, lead, drive', compounded with co- used in a specialised sense of 'stir thoughts' → 'think'.}];141[255-256{Cf. s.v. *h₂eg̑- 'treiben' (IEW 4-5).}];54[30-31{S.v. Lat. agō, -ere 'to drive', from PIE *h₂eg̑-e/o-, cf. derivative cogitāre 'to think, consider'.}];444[192{S.v. 2027 Lat. cōgitāre 'glauben, denken'.}];443[2:838-842{S.v. Lat. cōgitāre 'denken, beabsichtigen' > OFr. cuidier.}]
Justification: Latin cōgitō 'to think, consider', a derived frequentative/intensive form of Latin agō 'to drive' < PIE *h₂eg̑- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):15-18, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):30-31). For the Romance forms in this class cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:838-842, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):192.

Source: 105[316-317{S.v. Alb. peshk 'fish', a borrowing from Lat. piscem 'fish'.}];130[63{A borrowing from Lat. pisce < Lat. piscis because of /-shk-/ and regular shift of Lat. ĭ > Alb. e.}];571[103{S.v. Alb. peshk 'fish', a loan from Latin piscem 'fish' (already [Meyer 1891](src-585):329).}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin piscem 'fish' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):329, [Huld 1984](src-571):103, [Orel 1998](src-105):316-317, [Holm 2011](src-130):63)

Source: 345[590{S.v. TochB laks 'fish' < PIE *lok̑s-i- 'salmon, salmon trout'.}];352[560{Cf. s.v. OLith. lãšišas 'Lachs' < PIE *lok̑(-s)- 'Lachs', ON lax, OE leax. The root is attested in the meaning in Balto-Slavic and Germanic in the meaning 'salmon'.}];49[653{Cf. the older reconstruction found in IEW: *lak̑- 'sprenkeln, tupfen', dazu wohl *lak̑-so-s 'Lachs'.}];657[497{Cf. s.v. SALMON *lok̑s 'large anadromous salmonid, salmon(-trout)'.}];695[92{Cf. for discussion regarding the possibility of an early loanword into Pre-Proto-Tocharian when the Pre-Tocharians were still in Eastern Europe and in contact with non-Iranian IE languages. In such a scenario the specific source of the borrowing, however, cannot be identified and other explanations remain possible.}]
Justification: Exact derivation of the Tocharian B word from the PIE root debated, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):590 and [ALEW](src-352) 560 s.v. lãšišas. Cognates in other branches specifically mean 'salmon' (cf. [EIEC](src-657) 497 for further discussion).

Source: 105[430{S.v. Alb. shpinë 'back, spine', borrowed from Lat. spīna 'id.'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin spīna 'thorn, spine; spine, backbone' ([Orel 1998](src-105):430).

Source: 534[II:227{S.v. Latv. slikts, loanwords from Middle Low German slicht.}]
Justification: Loanword from Middle Low German slichts ([Karulis 1992](src-534) II:227).

Source: 345[740{S.v. TochB sark* 'back (of the body)', to be connected with TochA särśi if, as usually assumed, the word means 'backbone'. Melchert (p.c.) suggests  a plausible connection to Anatolian sark- 'high' with an original meaning 'ridge, high point' vel sim.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):640 for discussion and suggestions.

Source: 54[225{S.v. Lat. flāvus 'yellow, blonde', from PIE *bʰleh₃-u̯o- (cf. MIr. blá 'yellow'| OHG blāo, OE blāw, OIc. blár 'blue' < PGerm. *blēu̯a-).}];141[88{Cf. s.v. *bʰleh₃- 'blühen' (IEW 122).}];296[B:54-55{Cf. s.v. OIr. 2 blá 'jaune', which may go back to *bhlō-wos and correspond to Lat. flāuus.}]
Justification: Latin flāuus 'yellow', from PIE *bʰleh₃-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):225, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 88). For Old Irish blá attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:54-55).

Source: 382[1562{S.v. φρούτο, a loanword from Italian frutto.}]
Justification: Loanword from Italian frutto 'fruit' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1562).

Source: 345[92-93{S.v. TochB enmetre 'bark', possibly from a pre-form *h₁n̥-tm(h₁)-o-tro- containing the roots *h₁en- 'in' + temh₁- 'cut off' + further derivational morphology (cf. Gk. τέμνω 'cut', Lat. tondeō 'shave, shear, clip| mow, prune', etc.}];141[625{Cf. s.v. *temh₁- 'schneiden' (IEW 1062-3).}]
Justification: Probably from a compound containing *h₁en- 'in' + temh₁- 'cut off' ([Adams 2013](src-345):92-93).

Source: 382[791-792{S.v. λουλούδι, from Medieval Greek λουλούδι(ν) / λιλούδι(ν), loanword + suffix -ουδι, perhaps a borrowing from Albanian lule 'flower' or from Latin lilium 'flower' with vowel assimilation /i/ … /u/ > /u/ … /u/.}]
Justification: Generally considered a loanword from Albanian lule 'flower' or Latin līlum 'lily' (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):791-792).

Comment: From Old French escorce which itself either goes back directly to Latin or is a loan from Medieval Latin scorcia, cf. http://www.etymologiebank.nl/trefwoord/schors. Thus ultimately connected to [cognate set 182](cog-182).

Source: 382[629{S.v. κάνω. From Ancient κάμνω 'exert oneself, build| be tired (from work)' → 'make something (using technical means)' → 'make, do'.}];141[323-4{S.v. *k̑emh₂- 'müde werden, sich abmühen' (IEW 557).  Greek present κάμνω via nasal-present stem *k̑m̥-né/n-h₂-.}];66[632{S.v. κάμνω 'to toil, labour, build| get tired, die, be in danger, be in need'. From PIE *k̑emh₂- 'exert oneself, get tired'.}];270[490{S.v. AGk. κάμνω 'se fatiguer, être fatigué, se donner du mal, souffrir, être malheureux'. A present thematic stem remodelled from an athematic stem *km-neh₂-/*km-n-h₂-.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κάμνω 'exert oneself, build; be tired (from work)' → 'make something (using technical means)' → 'make, do' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):629), ultimately derived from PIE *k̑emh₂- via a nasal-present stem *k̑m̥-né/n-h₂- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):490, [Beekes 2010](src-66):632, [LIV²](src-141) 323-324).

Source: 80[901-902{S.v. Hitt. tušk(ii̯e/a)- 'to be happy, to entertain (oneself), to play'. No certain etymology.}]
Justification: No certain etymology, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):901-902 for a critical appraisal of previous proposals.

Source: 345[158{S.v. TochB kāñm- 'play, be merry'. Etymology uncertain. [van Windekens 1976](src-76) suggests connections with *keh₂- 'love' (Skt. kāma- 'love, desire', Lat. cārus but the semantics are dubious. Hilmarsson suggests a connection with *kan- 'sing' (Lat. canō 'sing') but the semantics are also unclear.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):158 for various proposals).

Source: 66[951-952{S.v. μῑκρός 'small, short, little'. "The group of words has a familiar and colloquial aspect, as shwon [sic!] by the variants μικός and μικκός. The initial interchange in μικρός and (older) σμικρός is unexplained and (also) points to Pre-Greek origin. The connection with the comparative μείων, assuming that the κ was taken over from the opposite μακρός, fails because σμικρός is obviously older".}];174[II:236-237{S.v. μῑκρός, also σμικρός (occasional Hom., Trag. Att., etc.), μικκός (Dor., Boeot.), μικός (some Attic inscriptions, papyri). "Ohne genaue außergriechische Entsprechung." Sometimes compared with Germanic words for small (cf. OHG smāhi, etc.), but the correspondences are uncertain.}]
Justification: Without clear correspondences outside of Greek ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:236-237, [Beekes 2010](src-66):951-952).

Source: 66[983{S.v. μύρον 'sweet smelling oil, salve, perfume', from which μυρίζω 'to salve, perfume' is a denominal verb.  The lexeme is traditionally grouped with Germanic and Celtic words 'to smear, fat' (OHG smero 'smear', OIr. smi(u)r 'marrow') < *smer-u-, but as a culture word, μύρον may very well be an early loan. Cf. μύρρα 'myrrh, sweet-smelling word of the myrrh plant' which is clearly a Semitic loan (Aram. mūrā, Heb. mōr, Arab. murr 'myrrh').}];382[903{S.v. μυρίζω, from Ancient Greek μυρίζω 'I salve, perfume'.}];269[{It is likely that there was some cross-contamination between loaned Semitic lexemes with Gk. μύρρα 'myrrh' and potentially inherited material attested by Gk. μύρον 'oil, perfume'. Consequently the Greek lexemes are not necessarily the best evidence for IE *smer- in this class.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing an Ancient Greek denominal verb μυρίζω 'to salve, perfume', derived from Ancient Greek μύρον 'salve, perfume' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):903). Perhaps further cognate with Germanic Celtic words 'to smear, fat' (OHG smero 'smear', OIr. smi(u)r 'marrow') < *smer-u-, but a Semitic loanword may well be equally as likely; cf. AGk. μύρρα 'myrrh, sweet-smelling word of the myrrh plant', Aram. mūrā, Heb. mōr, Arab. murr 'myrrh' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):983).

Source: 382[327{S.v. γυρίζω, a denominal verb in -ιζω derived from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'ring, circle'.}];66[289-290, 293{Cf. s.v. γῦρος 'round, curved', γύαλον 'hollow (of a cuirass), vales, dells', and γύης 'the curved piece of wood in a plough'. Precise etymology unclear, possibly *gou- 'hand' or *geu̯(H)- 'bend' if cognate with Av. gu- 'hand'.}];270[243-244{S.v. AGk. γῡρός 'rond, courbé', recalls the root *geu-/*gu- in γύαλον, but note the u is long (popular variation?). [IEW](src-49) 397f. compares Arm. kuṙ-n 'dos' with another vocalism kor 'courbé'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):243-244, [Beekes 2010](src-66):289-290, 293).

Source: 316[11{S.v. Lat. āēr, āeris, an early borrowing from Greek ἄηρ, ἀέρος [cognate set 3111](cog-3111).}];444[18{S.v. 240 Lat. aer, -re 'Luft'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin āēr 'air' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):18), an early loanword in Latin (already attested by Ennius, late 3rd - early 2nd c. BCE) from Ancient Greek ἄηρ ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):11).

Source: 54[141{S.v. Lat. crassus 'thick', of unclear etymology. Cf. entry in de Vaan for a discussion of older, unconvincing proposals.}];316[147{S.v. Lat. crassus 'gros, épais (sens physique et moral)', no etymology.}]
Justification: No certain etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):147, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):141).

Source: 84[http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/15567{S.v. Engl. bark, a borrowing from Scandinavian bark- (cf. Old Norse börkr, Swedish, Danish bark from Germanic *barku-z).}]
231[36{S.v. ScG. bìd 'a very small portion, a nip, a chirp', from Scots English bite, bit, English bite, bit.}]
Comment: Loan from English 'bite'.
Justification: A borrowing from English 'bite, bit' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):36).

Source: 141[154{S.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273). Treats Old Norse draga, Gothic -dragan etc. as derivatives from the PIE root *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to drag, to carry, pull' and notes that the expected zero grade form †durgan was analogically replaced by dragan.}];165[99{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry', as though from PIE *dʰrógʰ-e-. Dismisses three possible IE connections: (1) Ancient Greek τρέχω which according to Kroonen should rather go with Proto-Germanic *þragjan- 'to run'. (2) Connections to Slavic words such as Russian doróga f. 'road, journey', because these words show a root-final voiced or glottalized stop. (3) Latin trahō 'to pull, haul', which is not relatable due to its initial t-.}];269[{NB: S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸragjan- 'to run' [Kroonen 2013](src-165):544 considers the root *tregʰ- underlying Greek τρέχω rather than *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- as per [LIV²](src-141) 154 s.v. and [Beekes 2010](src-66):1506-7 s.v. τρέχω.}];179[93-94{S.v. Goth. *dragan (only 3pl. pres. -and 'ἐπισωρεύειν', 'accumulate, take on'. Etymology uncertain| PIE *dh(e)rāgh- 'pull' Walde-Pokorny 1927-1932 I:862, possibly Lat. trahō 'pull' according to Walde 1906 IF 19:106 by dissimilation from *dhraghō.}];782[{Frisian < OFrisian drega with vowel harmony, but at the same time 'nicely' identical to Dutch, so may be a loanword}]
Justification: The root etymology in this cognate set follows [LIV²](src-141) 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165):99, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):93-94, [Seebold 1970](src-556):160-162.

Source: 165[566-567{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *wainaga- 'miserable, poor', a derivative of Proto-Germanic *wainōn- 'to whine', which appears to be an n-present *uai-néh₂- to the interjection *wai- 'woe' (cf. Av. vaii-ōi, Arm. vay, Lat. vae, OIr. fáe, W. gwae, Latv. vai 'id.').}];54[650{Cf. s.v. Lat. vae 'alas!' "Probably all independent onomatopoeic forms, although shared inheritance cannot be excluded."}];50[405{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *way 'woe, alas' "All of these interjections in different IE languages could be independent formations, but their similarity is obvious."}];397[979, 975{S.v. NHG weinen (MHG weinen, OHG weinōn, MLG we(i)nen, MDu. wenen), from Germanic *wainō- (weak verb), also in ON veina, OE wānian, OFr. wainia, weinia, wēnia| Goth. wainahs 'elend', presumably derived from the same root as NHG weh (MHG wē, OHG wah, OS wē) from Gmc. *wai, also in Goth. wai, ON vei, OE wā corresponding outside of Germanic to Lat. vae, MIr. fae, W. gwae, Lith. vaī, Av. vaiiōi, etc.).}]
Justification: Lexemes reflecting Proto-Germanic *wai̯nōn-, a weak verb presumably derived from Proto-Germanic *wai- 'woe'. Further connections among the Indo-European languages going back to a PIE interjection *u̯ai 'woe!' (e.g. Latin vae, Old Irish fae, Welsh gwae, etc.) may be possible, although parallel onomatopoeic formations cannot be ruled out in principle ([Kluge 2011](src-397):979, 975, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):566-567; cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):650, [Matasović 2009](src-50):405, [IEW](src-49) 1110-1111).

Source: 279[821-822{Superlative in -aimo- (cf. maimas 'largest, biggest').  The identification of the root is unclear.}];54[651-652{Perhaps to be connected with Lat. ualeō 'to be strong, healthy' < Proto-Italic *u̯al-ē- (cf. Oscan ϝαλε, Marrucinian uali, Paelignian ual[ 'farewell') < *u̯alē or loanword from Latin?) < PIE *h₂ulh₁-eh₁- 'be strong', but the precise identification is not entirely clear.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic unclear ([Untermann 2000](src-279):821-822, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):651-652).

Source: 279[765-766{S.v. O. trííbúm 'Haus'| A root noun *trēb- from the *treb- 'dwell', cf. MIr., W, Bret. treb 'Wohnung'.}];50[388-389{Cf. Proto-Celtic trebā- 'settlement' from PIE *treb- 'settlement' (cf. Goth. þaurp 'field', OHG dorf 'homestead, village', Lith. trobà 'house, parlour').}];352[1126{Cf. s.v. OLith. trobà 'Gebäude, Haus, Hütte', from PIE *treb- 'von Menschen besiedelter Ort (cf. Lat. trabs 'Balken', Osc. acc.sg. TRÍÍBÚM 'Haus', OIr. treb 'Haus, Gehöft', MW tref 'Gehöft, Dorf' Celtib. Contrebia, Goth. ϸaurp 'Feld, Acker' ON ϸorp 'Dorf, Gehöft', OHG dorf 'Dorf, Hof').}]
Justification: From PIE *treb- 'dwell', a Western Indo-European isogloss common to Celtic, Italic, Germanic, and Baltic ([Untermann 2000](src-279):765-766, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):388-389, [ALEW](src-352) 1126).

Source: 80[709-711{S.v. Hitt. šalli- 'big, great', which can be accounted for from PIE *solH-i-, a derivative from the same root underlying OIr. slán 'complete' < *sl̥H-no-, Lat. saluus, 'complete, intact', Gk. ὅλος 'whole, complete' Skt. sarvá- 'whole, all' < *sol-u̯o- (from earlier *solH-u̯o- with loss of laryngeal due to the o-grade).}];699[68-81{Cf. s.v. Hitt. sal(l)- 'swell, expand, extend', with derivative salli- 'big, large, tall high| adult, aged, great, grand| main principal chief, royal, regal', connecting the complex of related vocabulary to PIE *s(w)el(H)- also in ON svella, OHG swellan 'swell'. The adjective salli- has otherwise been connected since Sturtevant, Comp. Gr. 138 to Skt. sárva-, Av. haurva-, Gk. οὗλος, ὅλος, Lat. sollus, 'whole' from *solwo-, which remains semantically possible.}]
Justification: As though from PIE *solH-i- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):709-711). Cf. however [HED SA](src-699) alternatively considering connections to other vocabulary from a Hittite stem *sall- 'swell, expand' to be ultimately connected with Proto-Germanic *swellan- (but cf. 'swell' in [cognate set 315](cog-315), generally considered without certain etymology). Cf. also Tischler Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar 2/1:767-775 for further discussion.

Source: 345[296{Cf. s.v. TochB tapre 'high', 'fat', to which TochA tsopats may be connected if it is from *dʰēubotyo-.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, possibly to PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' if from *dʰēubotyo- (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):296-297).

Source: 66[451{Cf. s.v. Greek ἔρεβος (n.) 'the dark of the underworld' cognate with Arm. erek, -oy 'evening' whence erēk, Skt. rájas- (n.) 'dark (lower) air, dust', Gothic riqiz, ON røkkr (n.) 'dark, dusk'. All from PIE *h₁régʷ-os- 'darkness'.}];79[259-261{S.v. Arm. երեկ erek, to be connected with Skt. rájas- 'dust, mist, vapour, gloom' OAv. rajiš- 'darkness', Gk. ἔρεβος 'the dark of the underworld', Goth. riqis 'darkness, twilight' from PIE *h₁regʷ-os-.}];180[203{Generally agreed to be cognate with Skt. rájaḥ 'dusk, darkness', Gk. ἔρεβος 'Dunkel der Unterwelt', Goth. riqis 'darkness'. Cf. for a discussion of the stem formation in Armenian.}]
Justification: Generally derived from a PIE s-stem *h₁regʷ-os- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):203, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):259-261).

Source: 279[95-96{Oscan anafríss 'raingods' normally explained as a dat.pl. from PIE * n̥bʰr-i-bʰos as Lat. dat.pl imbribus (nom.sg. imber 'rain, rainshower, heavy rain'), cf. Ved. abhrá- 'stormcloud', YAv. aβra- 'raincloud, rainshower' < *n̥bʰ-ró-.}];54[299{S.v. Lat. imber 'rain, rain shower', from Proto-Italic *n̥fr-i- 'cloud' from PIE < *n̥bʰ-r-o- '(rain) cloud' (cf. Skt. abhrá- 'cloud', Av. aβra- 'rain, rain-cloud', Khot. ora- 'sky', Gk. ἀφρός 'foam, saliva', Arm. amb, amp 'cloud').}];274[499-504{Cf. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bewölkt, dunstig (werden)' (LIV 448, IEW 315f.), note 26.}];442[400{For Nuristani cognates, cf. s.v. 6955c *nabhalikā- 'cloud' (cf. Lat. nebula, Skt. nábhas-, etc.).}];172[I:94, II:13{Cf. s.v. Ved. abhrá- 'Gewitterwolke, Gewölk, Regenwolke' (IIr. Av. aβra- 'Regen[wolke]', a derivative of PIE *nebʰ- via *n̥bʰ-ró-, cf. s.v. Ved. nábhas- 'Feuchtigkeit, Wolke, Gewölk, Nebel', an s-stem noun from PIE *nebʰ- 'befeuchten'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:94, II:13, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):400 no. 6955c, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):299, [Untermann 2000](src-279):95-96).

Source: 66[1089{S.v. ὀξύς 'sharp, stinging'| 'sour, tartish (of taste)', etc. "Without correspondences outside Greek. It has been compared with ὄκρις, which is an o-grade of the root of ἄκρος, but there are no further examples for u-stem adjectives with o-vocalism. Alternatively, [Narten 1986](src-722) reconstructs a root *h₃ks- on the strength of the comparison with Skt. akṣṇoti 'to mark the ear', but this is doubtful."}];47[1069{Cf. for earlier proposed connections to PIE *ak̑- (*h₂ek̑-) 'sharp'.}];270[806-807{S.v. AGk. ὄξυς 'aigu, pointu'. The word ὀξύς shows the same difficulties in vocalism as ὄκρις, Lat. ocris with regard to the large family of words based on ἀκ-. On the other hand one tries to connect the s of ὀξύς the from the sigmatic root included in ἀκοστή, the compounds in -ήκης, Lat. acus. Cf. [IEW](src-49) 21.}];722[204-214]
Justification: Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 21-22, [Buck 1949](src-47):1069, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively [Narten 1986](src-722):204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1089).

Source: 79[45-46{Arm. am 'year, age' goes back to an old paradigm *s(e)m-eh₂-/*sm̥-h₂-ó-, cf. Skt. sámā- f. 'year, season', YAv. ham-, OIr. sam- 'summer'.}];172[II:704{Cf. s.v. Ved. sámā- 'Jahr, Halbjahr, Jahreszeit', probably originally from PIE *s(e)m-eh₂-/*sm̥-h₂- reanalysed as *semh₂-, cf. Arm. am 'year', amarn 'summer', OIr. sam, OHG sumar 'summer', etc.}];180[60{Arm. am 'year', seems to continue a deverbative stem in *-ah₂- to the root *sem-, (cf. Skt. sámā 'Halbjahr, Jahreszeit'| compare the root noun continued in Av. instr.sg. hama, gen.sg. hamō.}]
Justification: Classical Armenian am 'year' seems to continue an old deverbative stem *sem-(e)h₂- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):60, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):45-46; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:704).

Source: 141[616-617{S.v. *teh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'berühren, fassen' (IEW 1054).}];165[507{S.v. Proto-Germanic *takan- ~ tēkan- 'to touch' from PIE *th₂g̑-e- (cf. TochB täk- 'to touch' < *th₂g-, Gk. τεταγών 'taking' < *te-th₂g-ont-).}];556[498-499{S.v. Gmc. *tak-a- 'nehmen', without precise comparisons outside of Germanic. The Germanic verb may be an irregular development or secondary variant of IE *tag- ~ *teg- (cf. TochB tek-, tak- 'berühren', Lat. tangō, tetigī, tactus 'berühren', Gk. τεταγων 'fassend').}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *takan- 'to touch; take', probably further to be derived from PIE *teh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to touch, grasp' ([LIV²](src-141) 616-617, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):507, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):507).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. take, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic taka 'to grasp, seize, catch, receive, accept, touch, reach').}]
Justification: Continuing Old English tacan, an early borrowing from Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic taka 'to grasp, seize', etc. ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 54[482-483{S.v. Lat. portō, -āre 'to transport, carry'. Most likely to be a denominal verb from Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'passage, crossing', cf. Lat. porta 'gate'. Cf. elsewhere PIE *pr̥-to-, *pr̥-tu- (Gaulish ritu-, Old Welsh rit, Welsh rhyd 'ford' < PCl. φritu-| Av. pərətu- 'crossing, bridge'| OHG furt, Engl. ford < PGmc. furδú-).}];141[472-473{Cf. s.v. 1. per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren' (IEW 816-817).}];444[554{S.v. 6672 Lat. portāre 'tragen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):482-483, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 472-473).

Source: 54[497-498{S.v. Lat. pulpa 'fleshy parts of a body, best part of the meat', cf. Lat. derived lexeme pulpāmentum 'a small piece of meat'. The Latin forms reflect Proto-Italic *pelp-ā 'meat', *pelp-m(e)n- 'meat'. The Umbrian cognate pelmner (gen.sg.) reflects a stem *pelp-men-. There are no known cognates known outside of Italic.}];279[528{S.v. U. pelmner 'Wahrscheinlich "Fleisch"' < *pelp-men- as Lat. pulmentum 'Fleischspeise' < *pelp-men-to-, derived to Lat. pulpa 'Fleisch'| only in Umbrian and Italic. A Proto-Italic creation?}]
Justification: Umbrian pelmner from a Proto-Italic stem *pelp-men-, cf. Latin pulpa 'meat', pulmentum 'meat dish' < Proto-Italic *pelp-men-to-, pointing to a Proto-Italic root *pelp-. No further known cognates outside of Italic, however (cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):528, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):497-498).

Source: 141[195{S.v. ?*⁽g̑⁾ʰeHb- 'ergreifen, nehmen' (IEW 407-9). Root only Italic and Celtic, and belongs to the probably originally onomatopoeic roots for 'grasp, snatch' which show the structure velar-vowel-(laryngeal)-labial, cf. *gʰebʰ-, *keh₂p-. Umbrian 3.sg.imptv. hahtu 'let (one) take', Gaulish 2.sg.imptv. gabi 'take!', Old Irish -gaib, -gaibet 'take' < pres. *gʰHb-i̯é-, Lat. habeō 'have' < essive *gHb-h₁i̯é-.}];50[148-149{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gab-yo- 'take, hold', from PIE *gʰHbʰ- (IEW 407ff.), cf. Lat. habeō 'have'.}];54[277-278{Cf. s.v. Lat. habeō 'to have, hold', from Proto-Italic *χab/f-ē- 'has taken' > 'has, holds' (cf. Umbr. hahtu, etc., from PIE *gʰh₁b⁽ʰ⁾-(e)i- 'to take' (cf. OIr. gaibaid, -gaib 'to take' < PCl. *gab-i-).}];304[318-324{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gab-i̯e/o- 'nehmen, fassen' (PIE ?*gʰeHb- or ?*g̑ʰeHb- [LIV²](src-141) 195).}]
Justification: The Celtic and Italic lexemes in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although some aspects of the formal reconstruction of a common root are uncertain ([LIV²](src-141) 195, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):277-278, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):318-324, [Matasović 2009](src-50):148-149).

Source: 79[378{S.v. Arm. krak 'fire', some proposed Indo-European etymologies, but most likely an Iranian loan| cf. Persian kūra 'fireplace| furnace'.}];180[943{S.v. Arm. krak 'fire' ([HAB](src-740) II:678f.), perhaps Iranian.}];740[II:678-679]
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krak 'fire, flames', further origin uncertain, perhaps an Iranian loan ([HAB](src-740) II:678-679, [Olsen 1999](src-180):943), cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):378; cf. s.v. for less likely proposed Indo-European etymologies). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kur-aka-].

Source: 442[624{S.v. 10795 rúh f. 'growth, sprouting' RV.}];172[II:467-468{Cf. s.v. Ved. √rodh- (2) 'wachsen', daneben √roh- 'wachsen', to PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- 'wachsen' (cf. OE lēodan 'wachsen', OIr. luss 'Pflanze' etc.).}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic rúh 'growth, spurting' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):624 no.10795), further to Vedic √rudh- 'to grow' from PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- 'to rise, grow' ([EWAia](src-172) II:467-468, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 248-249).

Source: 397[536{S.v. NHG Kralle. First attested ca. 16th c., origins unclear. Perhaps to kratzen 'scratch'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Kluge 2011](src-397):536).

Source: 80[402{S.v. iškiš- 'back, backside, rear', the only proposed cognate is Greek ἰσχίον 'hip(s)', but the semantic connection is not very convincing.}];406[424-425{S.v. Hitt. iskis- 'back, backside, rear'.
