Possibly to be connected with Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint, hip(s)', but further connections are uncertain.}];269[{Possibly to be connected with Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint' ([HED A+E/I](src-406):424-425), but this is disputed (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):602-603). In view of the areal proximity it remains possible that both Greek ἰσχίον and Hitt. iškiš- are both independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):402).}];66[602-603{Cf. s.v. AGk. ἰσχίον 'hip-joint, haunches', no etymology.}]
Justification: Possibly to be connected with Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint' ([HED A+E/I](src-406):424-425), but this is disputed (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):602-603). In view of the phonological similarity and the areal proximity of the languages it could be possible that both Greek ἰσχίον and Hitt. iškiš- are both independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):402).

Source: 80[733{S.v. Hitt. šarḫuu̯ant- 'belly| innards| foetus, unborn child'. The only etymology that could possibly be credible is a connection to Arm. argand 'womb' (cf. [Čop 1955](src-580)), which if correct may go back to a possible PIE reconstruction *srh₂u̯ent- and the Armenian sound laws permit it.}];79[130-131{Rejects connection of Hitt. šarḫuu̯ant- with Arm. argand from the proposed reconstruction *sr̥Hu-u̯n̥t-h₂ (lit. 'full-of-sausages', cf. ὀρύα 'sausage') on the basis that the sequence *-r̥Hu- should have yielded *-araw-.}];580[403-406];269[{The only plausible etymology outside of Anatolian is the proposed connection with Armenian argand 'womb' with the proviso that the Armenian sound laws permit it ([Čop 1955](src-580), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):733), but this proposal rejected by [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):130-131.}]
Justification: The only plausible etymology outside of Anatolian is the proposed connection with Armenian argand 'womb' with the proviso that the Armenian sound laws permit it ([Čop 1955](src-580), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):733), but this proposal rejected by [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):130-131.

Source: 141[689{S.v. *u̯erH- 'heiß sein' (IEW 1166).  Cf. OCS vьritъ 'boil', Lith. vérda 'cook, boil'.}];80[923-925{S.v. ur-, u̯ar- (mid.) 'to burn (intr.), to be burned', from IE *urh₁-ó-ri (cf. Lith. vìrti, vérdu 'to cook', OCS vьrěti 'to cook').}]
Justification: From PIE *u̯erh₁- 'to be hot'; the root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):923-925, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 689 reconstructing *u̯erH- with indeterminate final laryngeal.

Source: 80[169{S.v. Hitt. alpa- 'cloud', often connected to Lat. albus 'white' and Gk. ἀλφός 'white leprosy| white' but the connection is formally difficult because *h₂elbʰo- would have yielded Hitt. †ḫalpa-, and also  difficult semantically because alpa- is associated with rain and thunder.  Some scholars attempt to get around this by reconstructing a second a-colouring laryngeal *h₄ which left no trace in Hittite, but the semantic connection is too weak to postulate the reconstruction of a new phoneme.}];269[{To maintain the connection with Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός, etc. (cf. [cognate set 955](cog-955)), one must postulate reconstructing a fourth laryngeal that is a-colouring but lost in Anatolian (i.e. *h₄elbʰo-)| alternatively one could reconstruct *albʰo- with an original *a in the root but this likewise a less satisfactory solution (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):169).}]
Justification: To maintain the connection with Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός, etc. (cf. [cognate set 955](cog-955)), one must postulate reconstructing a fourth laryngeal that is a-colouring but lost in Anatolian (i.e. *h₄elbʰo-); alternatively one could reconstruct *albʰo- with an original *a in the root but this likewise a less satisfactory solution (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):169).

Source: 80[440{S.v. Hitt. kappuu̯e/a- 'to count, to calculate'. No clear Indo-European etymology.  Some scholars have attempted to analyse the form as a compound *katt(a) + puu̯e/a- or *kom+puu̯e/a- with the latter element comparable to Lat. putāre, but the absence of other examples for such preverbal composition in Hittite makes this interpretation unlikely.}];408[66-72{Cf. s.v. Hitt. kappuwai- 'tally, reckon, calculate' for older etymological proposals.}]
Justification: No clear Indo-European etymology ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):440), cf. [HED K](src-408) 66-72 for older unconvincing proposals.

Source: 141[234-235{S.v. ?*h₁e⁽k̑⁾- 'sterben' (no IEW).  Only Anatolian.}];80[167-168{S.v. Hitt. āk-/akk- 'to die, be killed| be eclipsed (of sun and moon)' perhaps also related to Lyd. akτa 'of the dead'?? The Hittite forms might be formally accounted for by reconstructing an *o ~ *Ø ablauting root-present *Hók- / *Hk- ´. The only potential cognates are Skt. áka- 'pain', Av. aka- (adj.) 'bad, evil', which, if a correct comparison, the underlying root would be *h₁ek- or *h₃ek-, but this connection is not fully certain.}];654
Comment: Initial H may be either *h₁ or *h₃ (Kloekhorst 2008:167-168).
Justification: A root restricted to Anatolian. [LIV²](src-141) 234-235 mechanically reconstructs ?*h₁e⁽k̑⁾- 'to die'; [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):167-168 assumes *Hók- / *Hk- with indeterminable laryngeal under the assumption that laryngeals merged with *h₁ before *o in Anatolian (cf. [Kloekhorst 2006](src-654)).

Source: 141[255{S.v. *h₂ed- 'vertrocknen' (IEW 3, [69]).  Cf. Gk. ἄζομαι 'dry up'.}];80[328-329{Cf. s.v. ḫāt- / ḫat- 'to dry up, to become parched', from IE *h₂ód-ei, *h₂d-énti (cf. Gk. ἅζω 'to dry up').}]
Justification: Hittite ḫātant- 'dry' is originally an participle derived to PIE *h₂ed- 'to dry up' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):328-329, [LIV²](src-141) 255).

Source: 141[445-446{S.v. *mi̯eu̯h₁- '(sich) bewegen' (IEW 743).}];80[564-566{S.v. Hitt. mau- / mu-, maušš- 'to fall', from PIE *móu̯h₁-/muh₁- ´ (cf. Lat. moveō 'move', Ved. mīv-, mū- 'move, push').}]
Justification: Root ref. form follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):564-566 to *meu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself), but cf. [LIV²](src-141) 445-446 reconstructing *mi̯eu̯h₁-.

Source: 141[449{S.v. *neh₂- 'in Angst geraten' (IEW 754).}];80[591-592{Hitt. nāḫ- 'to fear, be(come) afraid, be respectful, be careful', from IE *nóh₂-ei, *nh₂-énti, *neh₂-sr. Plausibly connected with OIr. nár 'noble, modest' (< *neh₂sr-o-), which can be accounted for through a semantic development 'to fear > to  be respectful > to be modest, noble'.}]
Justification: Anatolian lexemes from PIE *neh₂- 'to become afraid' ([LIV²](src-141) 449, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):591-592).

Source: 80[358-360{S.v. Hitt. ḫulle- / ḫull- 'to smash, to defeat', proposes a root *h₂u̯elh₁-, which yielded Hitt. ḫulle-/ḫull- from a nasal-infix present *h₂ul-né-ti, *h₂ul-n-énti, comparable to OIr. follnadar 'to rule', Lat. ualeō 'to be powerful', and, with a *-dʰ- extension, Lith. véldu 'to own', Goth. waldan 'to rule', OCS vladǫ 'to rule'.}];407[363-368{S.v. Hitt. hulla-, hulliya- 'smash, defeat'. Cf. for older etymological proposals.}]
Justification: Root ref. form and analysis follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):358-360. For older proposals cf. [HED H](src-407):363-368.

Source: 68[125{Hitt. alil- 'flower' may be considered a member of the culture words meaning 'flower' widely attested in several language families, e.g. Lat. līlium, Coptic hrēri, hlēli 'lily', Alb. lule, Cushitic ilili, Basque lili, Estonian lill 'flower'.}];406[32-33{Cf. s.v. Hitt. alel- 'flower, bloom' for further references to loanword studies.}]
Justification: No clear etymology; often considered to be a non-Indo-European Wanderwort (cf. [Weeks 1985](src-68):125, [HED A+E/I](src-406):32-33 for further discussion).

Source: 80[234-235{Cf. s.v. Hitt. eka- 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *iég-o- (cf. OIr. aig, gen. ega 'ice', MCorn. yeyn 'cold', ONor. jaki 'ice-floe', jökull 'glacier'), from which ekae-/ikae- 'to cool down' is a denominal verb.}];49[503{Cf. s.v. *i̯eg- 'Eis'.}];269[{Indo-Iranian-Nuristani cognates from *yaja- 'cold' (cf. Turner 1962-1966:601, 'ice' in [cognate set 2741](cog-2741), 'cold' in [cognate set 982](cog-982)) probably imply a reconstruction *i̯eg̑- with a palatovelar.}];442[601{Cf. s.v. 10396 *yaja- 'cold' [IE. *yeg̑- 'ice' IEW 503?] (cf. Kt. yūċ 'cold', Pr. (y)ǖzu. Wg. yū̆z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz [→Wkh. yaz]).}]
Justification: Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ([IEW](src-49) 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):234-235, [HED A+E/I](src-406):257-259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):435).

Source: 80[749, 756-757{Cf. s.v. Hitt. (GIŠ) šēšatar / šēšann- (n.) 'fruit-tree?'. Hitt. šešan- may be further related to the verb šiš- 'to prosper, proliferate', however there is no good Indo-European etymology for this verb.}]
Justification: Maybe to be connected with Hittite šiš- 'to prosper, proliferate', but no further etymology outside of Hittite ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):749, 756-757).

Source: 80[314-315{S.v. Hitt. ḫaršar / ḫaršn- 'head| person| front| beginning'. Unlikely to be cognate with *k̑érh₂-s-r, *k̑rh₂-s-nós 'head' > Skt. śíras, śīrṣnas 'head' because PIE *k̑- cannot yield Hitt. ḫ-, nor is a situation of a distance assimilation *k̑ ... h₂ > *h₂ ... h₂ plausible.  Instead a connection with Gk. ὄρος 'mountain' [cognate set 1509](cog-1509) from an s-stem *h₃er-es- 'high' is more plausible (cf. also Ved. r̥ṣvá- 'high' which is also a secondary derivative), which has been secondarily derived as an -r/n- noun in Hittite (i.e. *h₃er-s-r, *h₃er-s-nos).}]
Justification: Probably an from an IE s-stem *h₃er-es- 'high' to PIE *h₃er- 'rise' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-300) that has been secondarily transferred into -r/n- inflection, which is morphologically productive in Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):314-315).

Source: 141[679{S.v. *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' (IEW 1144-5).}];80[945-946{S.v. Hitt. u̯alḫ- 'to hit, to strike', following interpretation of LIV² from root *u̯elh₃- 'hit, strike' (cf. Lat. vellō 'tear apart', Gk. ἐάλων 'is killed', TochA wälläṣtär 'dies').}];389[{Cf. s.v. Neu: *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' (IEW 1144-5) and n1 "Aus semantischen und lautlichen Gründen (anatol. Laryngalschwund) besser von *u̯elh₃- ['sterben'] zu trennen." Formerly merged with *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' in [LIV²](src-141).}]
Justification: For the root reconstruction, see [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) for [LIV²](src-141) 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben', cf. also [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):945-946.

Source: 141[229{S.v. 2. ?*h₁ai̯- 'warm sein' [IEW 11, 68]. Cf. n1: Only Anatolian| uncertain is the proposed relationship with *ai̯dʰ- 'entzünden', because this root can have *h₂, cf. h₂ei̯dʰ-.}];80[164-166{S.v. ā(i)- / i- 'to be hot' (part. a-a-an-t-). Earlier proposed connections with Gk. αἴθω, Skt. inddhé, etc. are to be rejected since these forms require *h₂ei̯dʰ-. Internal morphological analysis suggests a stem formation *h₁eh₃i- based on the Hittite morphological evidence.  This is, however, based solely on internal reconstruction, and there are no known cognates to such a formation.}]
Justification: Literally a participle to the verbal root ā(i)- 'to be hot'; further etymology uncertain. For competing IE root analyses cf. [LIV²](src-141) 229, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):164-166, with references to further literature.

Source: 80[372{S.v. Hitt. ḫuu̯arn-/ḫurn- 'to hunt', if of IE origin, could be accounted for by a nasal-infixed stem *h₂ur-n-H from a root *h₂u̯erH-.  This reconstruction, however, is based solely upon internal reconstruction.  Previous etymological connections with Lith. varýti 'to drive, chase' and Latv. vert 'to run' are to be rejected because of lack of evidence for a root final laryngeal (lack of acute intonation).}]
Justification: By internal reconstruction, possibly from a nasal-infix stem *h₂ur-n-H to a root *h₂u̯erH- although there are no certain cognates outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):372; not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 80[533-534{S.v. Hitt. lūli- 'pond, lake, spring, well, basin'. No IE Etymology.}];409[111-114, 127-128{S.v. Hitt. luli(ya)- (c.) 'pool, lake, pond| (well)basin, cistern, reservoir, tank, vat', assuming a connection with luwaressa- 'level ground, flatland' to a heteroclite stem *lewr-/lewn- (Gk. λευρός 'even, level, smooth').}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):533-534, cf. [HED L](src-409):111-114, 127-128).

Source: 80[525{S.v. Hitt. leš(š)i-, lišši- 'liver'. No convincing IE etymology| likely a word of foreign origin along with the practice of hepatoscopy.}];409[97-98{Perhaps to be connected to Arm. leard 'liver' [lexeme 28544](lex-28544) if from *lis-r̥t.}];79[306-307{Cf. s.v. Arm. leard 'liver'. A minority view has compared Arm. leard with Hitt. lišši- 'liver', but the Armenian lexemes are more usually considered to be connected to PIE *Hiekʷr(-t), *Hiekʷn-ós 'liver' [cognate set 718](cog-718) with an anomalous development of *i̯- > l-. Cf. entry for further discussion and references to literature.}]
Justification: No convincing etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):525). [HED L](src-409):97-98 suggests a connection to Armenian leard, but the Armenian forms are more generally considered to be connected to the inherited IE word for 'liver' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):306-307 and notes to [cognate set 718](cog-718)).

Source: 80[334-335{S.v. Hitt. ḫatk- 'to shut, to close', from a *o ~ *Ø ablauting present stem *h₂ódʰg̑ʰ- / *h₂dʰg̑ʰ- (cf. Gk. ἄχθομαι 'to be burdened, to be depressed', ἄχθος 'pressure, burden'). Hitt. ḫatku- / ḫatgau̯- 'tight, pressed, stressful' is a derived adjective from the verbal stem.}];141[255{Cf. s.v. *h₂edʰ⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'drücken' (not in IEW).}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *h₂edʰ⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to press' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):334-335, [LIV²](src-141) 255).

Source: 80[554{S.v. Hitt. maninku(u̯a)- 'near', cognate with CLuw. mannakuna/i- 'short'.  The variant forms in Hittite make the lexeme difficult to etymologise outside of Anatolian.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):554).

Source: 80[567-569{S.v. meḫuu̯ant- 'old, elderly'. The best possible etymology is to assume a relationship to mēḫur, mēḫun- n. 'time, period', further root etymology disputed.  Hitt. mēḫur is most plausibly related to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (Skt. minā́ti, Lat. minuō 'diminish', cf. LIV² s.v. *mei̯H-), pace [Eichner 1973](src-641), who attempts to connect to a root *meh₂- 'to be the right time' (Lat. mātūrus 'mature', mānus 'good') with a lengthened grade *mēh₂- generalised in the Hittite paradigm. Alternatively to *meh₁- 'measure', although the presence of -ḫ- makes this etymology unlikely.}];141[427{For the comparanda to the root etymology advocated by Kloekhorst (2008:567-569), cf. s.v. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).}];641[53-107{Argues for a derivation of Hitt. mēḫur from a root *meh₂- 'zeitlich passend sein, die/zur rechte(n) Zeit sein'.}];642[277-279{Returns to the older etymology for Hitt. mēḫur from PIE *meh₁- 'measure', arguing for a secondary laryngeal epenthesis within Hittite between -e- and -u-.}];269[{Always written using the Sumerograms LÚ.ŠU.GI, but probably to be related to Hitt. mēḫur 'time, period', from which a stem *meḫuu̯ant- can be reconstructed on the basis of derived vocabulary ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):568-569, cf. derived factitive verb meḫuu̯andaḫḫ- 'to make old| to age', etc.). Further root etymology disputed. According to [Eichner 1973](src-641):53-107, ultimately to PIE *meh₂- 'to be at the right time'| [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):567-568 to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (= [LIV²](src-141) 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, verschwinden sein'), or to *meh₁- 'measure' (semantically better, but formally more difficult). [Yakubovich 2011](src-642):277-279 argues to *meh₁-, with the presence of Hitt. -ḫ- explained by secondary epenthesis.}]
Justification: Always written using the Sumerograms LÚ.ŠU.GI, but probably to be related to Hitt. mēḫur 'time, period', from which a stem *meḫuu̯ant- can be reconstructed on the basis of derived vocabulary ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):568-569, cf. derived factitive verb meḫuu̯andaḫḫ- 'to make old; to age', etc.). Further root etymology disputed. According to [Eichner 1973](src-641):53-107, ultimately to PIE *meh₂- 'to be at the right time'; [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):567-568 to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (= [LIV²](src-141) 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, verschwinden sein'), or to *meh₁- 'measure' (semantically better, but formally more difficult). [Yakubovich 2011](src-642):277-279 argues to *meh₁-, with the presence of Hitt. -ḫ- explained by secondary epenthesis.

Source: 80[349-352{S.v. Hitt. ḫuett- / ḫuetti- / ḫuettii̯e/a- 'to draw, to pull, to pluck'. Etymology unclear.  Kloekhorst suspends judgement between competing alternatives.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):349-352 for a critical survey of previous proposals.

Source: 141[538-539{S.v. *seu̯h₁- 'antreiben, in Bewegung halten' (IEW 914).}];80[797-798{S.v. šuu̯e/a- 'to push (away), to shove, to cast off'. K. reconstructs to the same root as the LIV², but disagrees over the stem formation, preferring to reconstruct a yod-present *sHu-i̯é- (with laryngeal metathesis).}]
Justification: Generally agreed to be derived from PIE *seu̯h₁- 'incite, set in motion', but some debate remains over the precise details of the verbal stem formation (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 538-539, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):797-798).

Source: 80[340-341{S.v. 	ḫēu- / ḫē(i̯)au- 'rain'. Etymology unclear.  Possibly related to Gk. αἰονάω 'to moisten' (cf. Melchert 1994:102) pointing to a root *h₂ei̯h₃-, but the maintenance of intervocalic -i̯- in the Greek form is problematic for this etymology phonologically.}];368[102];407[301-304{S.v. Hitt. he(w)u-, he(y)au- (c.) 'rain'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, possibly connected with Ancient Greek αἰονάω 'to moisten' (cf. [Melchert 1994](src-368):102), but this proposal is not without some formal difficulties ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):340-341, cf. also [HED H](src-407):301-304).

Source: 80[493-494{S.v. kunna- ‘right (hand or side)| right, favourable, successful’: Two possible etymologies: (1) PIE *k̑un-no-, cf. Av. spənta-, Lith. šveñtas, OCS svętъ 'holy, sacred', Skt. śunám 'success(fully)' which reflect a root *k̑u̯en-. (2) *k̑uh₂-no- 'the strong one' (cf. Skt. śávas- 'might' < *k̑eu̯h₂-o-, śū́ra 'hero' < *k̑uh₂-ro-).  Both are semantically plausible, but Kloekhorst is inclined for follow the first one.}];408[245-248{Cf. s.v. Hitt. kunna- 'right (hand or side)| right, favourable, successful'.}]
Justification: IE root etymology disputed, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):493-494 for a critical discussion of competing alternatives; see also [HED K](src-408) 245-248.

Source: 141[239{S.v. *h₁erH- 'waschen' [IEW 337].  Only Hitt. ārr-/arr- 'wash' and TochA yär- 'bathe'.}];80[197-198{S.v. Hitt. ārr- / arr- 'to wash', from PIE *h₁órh₁-ei, *h₁r̥h₁-énti (from root *h₁erh₁- with *o ~ *Ø root ablaut), cf. TochA yär- 'bathe'.}]
Justification: Anatolian lexemes from PIE *h₁erH- 'to wash', cf. TochA yär- 'to bathe' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):197-198, [LIV²](src-141) 239).

Source: 141[450-451{S.v. *nei̯H- 'führen, leiten' (IEW 760).}];80[598-600{S.v. nē-, nai-, *ni- 'to turn, turn someone, to turn oneself, to send'| from PIE *néih₁/₃-, *nóih₁/₃-ei / *nih₁/₃-énti (cf. Skt. nay- 'to lead').}]
Justification: Anatolian lexemes derived from PIE *nei̯H- 'to lead' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):598-600, [LIV²](src-141) 450-451).

Source: 80[195-196{S.v. Hitt. ar- 'to stand (by), to be stationed, to remain standing| to be present, to occur', from PIE *h₃r̥- following the etymology of Oettinger (1979:523f.), a middle-zero-grade of *h₃er- 'to rise (to move vertically)'. On the development *h₃r- > *ʔr-, cf. Kloekhorst (2006:77-108).}];141[238, 299-301{S.v. *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-329)| now probably to be separated and listed under *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-329). See notes and discussion in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.}];389[http://www.martinkuemmel.de/liv2add.html#_Toc392257892 , http://www.martinkuemmel.de/liv2add.html#_Toc392257892{Listed in LIV² under *h₁er- 'wohin gelangen, geraten' (IEW 326-329) now probably to be separated and listed under *h₃er- 'sich in (Fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-329).}];654[77-106];649[523-524]
Justification: Etymology in this class follows [Oettinger 1979](src-649):523-524, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):195-196 to *h₃er-; but cf. [LIV²](src-141) assigning to *h₁er- (although [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) also listing *h₃er- as a possible root etymology).

Source: 80[971-972{S.v. Hitt. u̯arša- 'fog, mist'. Usually connected with Skt. varṣá- 'rain', and AGk.ἐέρση 'dew' to a postulated root *h₁u̯ers-, although PA *Horso- is expected to have assimilated to medial -šš- in Hittite.  This lack of assimilation is a formal problem in the connection of the Hittite form to the Sanskrit and Ancient Greek, but the semantic comparison is otherwise quite attractive.}]
Justification: Possibly to *h₁u̯ers-, if cognate with Vedic varṣá- 'rain', and Ancient Greek ἐέρση 'dew' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):971-972).

Source: 80[878-879{S.v. tii̯eššar / tii̯ešn- 'forest(?)'. The contexts of this word are uncertain, but the consistent use of the determinative GIŠ indicates the word has something to do with wood.  It is argued that the word may be connected with the Sumerogram (GIŠ)TIR 'forest' that is sometimes phonetically complemented with a -šar/-šn- flexional ending, and so the translation 'forest' has commonly been adopted for this lexeme, although the evidence for this identification is admittedly circumstantial.  There are no known cognates in Anatolian or elsewhere in Indo-European, but if the expression tii̯ēššar dai- (KUB 33.66 iii) is interpreted as a figura etymologica, then it might be related to *dʰeh₁- 'put, place' via a derived form *dʰh₁-i-éh₁sh₁-r.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):878-879 for a speculative proposal based on a possible etymological figure.

Source: 165[146{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fleugōn 'fly'. Derived from *fleugan- 'to fly'. Old Norse fluga shows the zero grade while Norw. fljuge as well as the West-Germanic lexemes show the full grade. The PIE root is the k-extended variant of *pleu̯- > *pleu̯k- (cf. LIV² 487-488).}];141[488{Cf. s.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837). An extension of *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben' (IEW 835-7), only Germanic and Baltic.}];441[385-388{S.v. OHG flioga 'Fliege' and vb. fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugōn 'fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):146, [EWA 3](src-441):385-388).

Source: 406[260-261{S.v. egdu-, igdu- 'leg'. Puhvel suggests a possible etymology to *ei̯-gʰ- (IEW 296) : Lith. eigà 'a going', Gk. οἴχομαι 'go off, be gone', ἴχνος 'footstep, track', TochB yku 'gone', thus egdu < *ei̯gʰ-tu- 'a going' > 'leg' by metonymy.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. [HED A+E/I](src-406):260-261 suggests to *ei̯-gʰ- ([IEW](src-49) 296) : Lith. eigà 'a going', Gk. οἴχομαι 'go off, be gone', ἴχνος 'footstep, track', TochB yku 'gone', thus egdu < *ei̯gʰ-tu- 'a going' > 'leg' by metonymy, but this is speculative. No lemma in [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80).

Source: 80[792-793{S.v. šurka/i- 'root' Unknown etymology.  Connection to Lat. surcus 'twig, sprout' proposed by [Melchert 1994](src-368):132 cannot be true because Lat. surcus is a ghostword.}];368[132]
Justification: Etymology unknown. [Melchert 1994](src-368):132 compares Lat. surcus 'twig, sprout', but [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):792-793 argues that the Latin comparandum is a ghost word.

Source: 80[212{S.v. Hitt. aruna- 'sea'. No generally accepted etymology.  The most promising connection is with Hitt. aru-/arau- 'high' < *h₃r-éu̯-no-, which is formally possible, and a semantic parallel can be found in Skt. árṇa- 'wave, flood, stream' < *h₃er-no- *'rising (water)'.  Cf. Puhvel HED A-E/I for this proposal and other alternative etymologies.}];406[178-182{S.v. Hitt. aruna- 'sea'. Etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain; cf. [HED A+E/I](src-406):178-182 and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):212 for various proposals.

Source: 80[980{Cf. s.v. Hitt. 𒌋 u̯ar(ru)u̯alan- 'seed, progeny'. No etymology.}]
Justification: No known etymology ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):980).

Source: 50[239{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *lim-ā- 'sharpen, polish'| "These words are probably related to Lat. līma 'carpenter's file', OHG slīm 'mud, slime', slīman 'make smooth', etc. The PIE root would be *(s)ley- (IEW 663), with the suffix *-mo- in Italic, Germanic, and Celtic. However, the length in OIr. límaid is unexpected (but cf. the short vowel in 3 pl. Pret. limsat)."}];236[{S.v. llym 'sharp, pointed', cf. MCo. lym, MBret. lemm, OIr. slim, possibly to *slibsmos < PIE *(s)leib- to the IE root *slei-.}];309[458{S.v. Bret. lemm 'pointu, acéré, aigu, coupant, taillant', from Old Breton lem, lim 'aigu', corresponding to Co. lym 'pointu, afflié, tranchant', W llym, llem 'pointu, tranchant' and Ir. slim 'lisse'| these words come from Celtic *slib-mo-.}];296[S:134{Cf. s.v. slim 'lisse, uni| plat', apparently from the root *slei- (cf. IEW 663)| one connects the Brythonic adjectives in W llymm, Bret. lemm, 'tranchant, aigu', OBret. lemhaam gl. acuo < *slibsmos (?), however with a certain semantic divergence.}]
Justification: From PIE *(s)lei̯-, perhaps via an extended variant *(s)lei̯b- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b- 'scheifen, gleiten', only Germanic), cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:134, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):458, [Matasović 2009](src-50):239, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236).

Source: 80[393-394{S.v. Hitt. išḫamai- / išḫami- 'to sing'. Related to the root *seh₂- 'to bind' (cf. LIV² s.v. *sh₂ei̯- 'fesseln, binden') with a root-extension *-m-, thus *sh₂em- (*sh₂m-ói-ei, *sh₂m-i-énti), which must have already been of IE date, cf. Skt. sā́man- 'song, hymn' < *sh₂óm-en-.}]
Justification: [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):393-394 considers the root to be an m-extended form of *seh₂- 'bind', but even if so Skt. sā́man- 'song, hymn' < *sh₂óm-en- demonstrates that such a formation must have already been of PIE date. The root ref. form for this class has therefore been given as *sh₂em- [Not in [LIV²](src-141).]

Source: 80[766-767{Cf. s.v. Hitt. šīu̯att- (c.) 'day', from PIE *di̯eu̯-ot- (cf. Skt. dyut- 'shine'). Cognates with Anatolian include Pal. tii̯at- 'Sun-god', CLuw. Tiu̯ad- 'Sun-god', and their derivatives.}];274[69-81{Cf. s.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f.).}];269[{The basic root is *dei̯-, from which *di̯eu̯- and *di̯eu̯-ot-. Cf. discussion in NIL and notes to *dei̯- 'shine' in 'day' [cognate set 375](cog-375).}]
Justification: Anatolian lexemes continuing PIE *di̯eu̯-ot-, further derived from PIE *dei̯- '(to be) bright, to shine' ([NIL](src-274) 69-81, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):766-767).

Source: 54[175-176{S.v. -dō, -dere 'to put'. Lat. verbal compounds in -dō can formally go back to either *deh₃- 'to give' or *dʰeh₁- 'to put', in the case of Lat. abscondere, etc. the root is arguably more likely to go back to *dʰeh₁-.}];141[136-138{Cf. s.v. *dʰeh₁- 'stellen, legen, setzen| herstellen, machen' (IEW 235-9). Cf. n12 on Lat. compound verbs.}];444[4{S.v. 41 Lat. abscondere 'verbergen'.}]
Justification: Latin abscondere 'to hide', unprefixed verb -dō, -dere from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put, place; do' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):175-176, [LIV²](src-141) 136-138). For the Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):4.

Source: 165[174-175{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gēn- 'go', from PIE *g̑ʰeh₁- (cf. Skt. jáhāti 'to leave behind', OAv. auua-zazat̰ 3.pl.pres.inj. 'id.'| Gk. κίχημι 'to overtake, reach, arrive, meet' < *g̑ʰe/i-g̑ʰeh₁-.}];141[196{S.v. *geh₁- 'kommen, gehen' [IEW 418-9, 1109]. Cf. Arm. gam 'komme', Gk. 3.sg. κιχήτην 'kamen heran'.}];556[216-217{S.v. Gmc. *gǣ- 'gehen'. Whether West Germanic *gai- is a secondary development or goes back to PIE *g̑ʰēi̯- is debated. The form is comparable to Greek and Vedic verbs going back to a proto-form *g̑ʰē- (cf. Gk. κιχάνω < *g̑ʰə-nw-| Ved. jihīte).}]
Justification: Generally connected to Gk. κιχάνω < *gʰeh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 196, [Kroonen 2013](src-165)174-175). Whether these forms are to be further connected on one hand to Arm. gam 'come' (so [LIV²](src-141)) or to Indo-Iranian lexemes (so {Kroonen 2013}) would decide whether to reconstruct initial *g̑ʰ or *gʰ.

Source: 416[224-225{CLuw. aruti- 'wing' is possibly an action noun in *-u-ti- (cf. Hitt. -u-zzi-) to the root *Har- 'fit' (cf. Gk. ἀραρίσκω 'fit together, join', Hitt. āra 'what is fitting', etc.).  For the semantics compare Lat. āla [lexeme 20565](lex-20565) < *h₂ek̑s-leh₂ 'shoulder(-joint)'. }];141[269-270{Cf. s.v. 1. *h₂er- 'sich (zusammen)fügen' (IEW 55-8)}]
Justification: As though from *h₂er-u-ti- to PIE *h₂er- 'to fit (together), join' ([Melchert 1988](src-416):224-225).

Source: 360[819-820{S.v. Lith. skrudė̃ 'Ameise'.}];531[568{S.v. Lith. skruzdėlė̃ 'mrówka, Formica'. Etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):568, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):819-820 for further discussion.

Source: 352[848-849, 877-878{Cf. s.v. OLith. rū́gti 'sauer werden, gären, aufstoßen' (BSl. cf. Latv. rûgt 'säuern, aufgehen, gären| aufstoßen, murren, verdrießlich sein', rûgts (adj.) 'bitter, berb', OCS otъrigati 'aufstoßen, ausstoßen', SCr. rìgati 'rülpsen', etc.), a zero-grade formation to OLith. ráugas (with -ū- from Winter's Law), in turn from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g- 'aufstoßen, rülpsen' (cf. Gk. ἐρεύγομαι 'erbreche', Arm. orcam 'erbreche mich', Lat. ērūgō 'rülpse aus', rūminō, -āre 'käue wieder', OE edroc (sm.) 'Wiederkäuen', OHG itarucken 'id.').}];353[385{Cf. s.v. Lith. rū́gti 'ferment, grow sour' (Latv. rûgt 'ferment, grow sour'), from PIE *h₁rug- (cf. Lith. ráugėti).}];534[II:134{S.v. Latv. rūgts, a derivative of the verb rūgt (cf. Lith. rū́gti 'skābt, rūgt', from PIE *reug-.}];141[509{Cf. s.v. *(h₁)reu̯g- 'rülpsen, erbrechen' (IEW 871).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g̑- 'to belch, to vomit' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 848-849, 877-878, [Derksen 2015](src-353):385, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:134, [LIV²](src-141) 509).

Comment: perhaps from PIE *sek- 'to cut'

Source: 141[421{S.v. *mag̑- 'streichen, schmieren' (IEW 696-7). The Germanic verbs Modern Icelandic maka 'to smear, to spread', English to make, German machen 'to do, to make' are denominative verbs Germanic *makō-. The semantic shift of 'schmieren'/'kneten' -> 'bilden' -> 'machen' is restricted to West Germanic.}];397[590{S.v. NHG machen (MHD machen, OHG mahhōn, OS makon), from West Germanic *mak-ō- 'machen', also in OE macian, OFr. makia, from (Eur.) IE *mag̑- 'kneten', also found in Gk. μάσσω 'ich knete, presse, wische ab, bilde ab', OCS mazati 'bestreichen, beschmieren, salben', Bret. meza 'kneten', Latv. iz-muõzêt 'anschmieren'.}];165[350{S.v. Proto-Germanic *maka- 'fit, comfortable', an adjective with an original meaning 'fit, suitable' (cf. *makan- 'match') and serving as a derivational base to the weak verb attested via OE macian 'to prepare, make', E to make, OFri. makia 'id.', OS (gi-)makon 'to make, form, fix', Du. maken 'to make', OHG mahhōn 'id.', G. machen 'id.' < *makōjan-. The verb is usually compared to Gk. μάσσω 'to knead, mold| wipe' < *mh₂g̑-ie- and OCS mazati 'to anoint', SCr. mȁzati 'to smear' < *meh₂g̑-eh₂- assuming the original meaning was 'knead'. As the original meaning was likely to have been 'to match, put together', these older connections are to be rejected. An etymological link with OIr. mám 'yoke' < *mag-mo-(?)| Lith. mė́gti (mė́giu) 'to like', Latv. mêgt 'to be able' < *meg-ie-. The reconstruction of an IE root *meg- nevertheless remains uncertain.}]
Justification: Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 421, [Kluge 2011](src-397):590, but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):350.

Source: 345[249{S.v. TochB klautso 'ear'. The words for 'ear' in Tocharian are certainly some derivation from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'hear', but the precise details of the word formation are debated.  Cf. Adams s.v. for discussion of alternative proposals.}];141[336-337{Cf. s.v. *k̑leu̯- 'hören' (IEW 605-7). Cf. n1: the root *k̑leu̯s- (LIV² 336) is probably originally a derived desiderative form from this root, probably already of PIE date.}];149[145-146{S.v. B klautso, A klots 'ear', related to PIE *k̑leu̯- 'hear', but there is some uncertainty over the exact stem formation, cf. for extensive discussion.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear', although some uncertainty remains over the precise nominal stem formation ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):145-146, [Adams 2013](src-345):249, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336-337).

Source: 345[115{Cf. s.v. TochB oko 'fruit', from which the Tocharian A form is likely to be a borrowing.}]
Justification: Probably a loan from Tocharian B ([Adams 2013](src-345):115, [Carling 2009](src-147)).

Source: 147[127{TochA kātse, related to kāts 'abdomen, belly' < PToch. *kātsān-. [Cf. Adams 2013:165-166).]}];345[165-166{TochA kāts, TochB kātso reflect Proto-Tocharian *kātsān-. Beyond Tocharian the etymology is obscure, but cf. the entry for various proposals.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections unclear, possibly to be connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kāts, B kātse 'belly', cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):112, [Adams 2013](src-345):165-166 for further discussion.

Source: 80[427-428{S.v. Hitt. kaka- 'tooth'. Etymology unclear. Attempts by Puhvel HED K to connect Hitt. kaka- with OEng. hōc 'hook' are unconvincing.}];408[14-15{S.v. Hitt. kaka- 'tooth', attempts to connect to OE hōc 'hook', etc.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):427-428); cf. [HED K](src-408):14-15 for unconvincing attempts to relate to Old English hōc 'hook', etc.

Source: 165[211{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hardu- 'hard, severe', often compared with Gk. κρατύς 'strong, powerful' and related forms, but the o-grade and Schwebeablaut remain unexplained. Better is the connection with Lith. kartùs 'bitter' and OCS kratъkъ 'short' (Strunk 1976, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):282).}];415[848-852];397[396-397{S.v. NHG Germ. hart (MHG herte, OHG hart, from PGmc. *hardu- 'hart' (also Goth. hardus, ON harðr, OE heard).}];697[280-282{S.v. Gmc. *hardu- 'hart, rauh'. The word is formally identical to Lith. kàrtus 'bitter (schmeckend)', CSl. kratъ-kъ 'kurz' (PIE *kortú-), cf. also Lat. curtus 'verkürzt, verstümmelt', Ved. kaṭu- 'scharf, beißend'.  In Germanic the original meaning of the adjective as 'rough, harsh' is confirmed though MLG hart 'scharfer, anhaltender (Ost)wind', MHG 'Schneekruste, fester Sandboden'. The semantic comparison with the Balto-Slavic lexemes is possible through assuming a basic meaning 'cutting'. The comparison with Gk. κρατύς 'stark, mächtig' is less likely because of formal and semantic difficulties, likewise the proposed connection to a root *kar- 'rauh' is simply a root etymology.}]
Comment: Kroonen writes that the Germanic words may either be related to forms such as Greek κρατύς and Sanskrit krátu- (with Germanic showing Schwebeablaut) or related to Lithuanian kir̃sti 'to turn sour'. According to ALEW, this verb is derived from the PIE root *(s)kert- 'to cut, to cut in two'.In the EWA, the two explanations Kroonen mentions are actually unified, the root reconstruction being "uridg. *(s)kret- (oder [s]kert- [?])".The LIV² only has a root *(s)kert-.
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *hardu- to be derived from PIE *kortú- from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (up)' (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):280-282, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):211).

Source: 686[33-34{S.v. ºauklipts: niauklipts 'unverborgen'. Etymologically reflects the zero-grade from klip- to *klep- 'verbergen', to PIE *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen' (cf. Goth. hlifan 'stehlen', Gk. κλέπτω 'stehle (heimlich), hintergehe').}];141[363-364{Cf. s.v. *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen, verbergen' (IEW 604).}];352[940-941{Cf. s.v. Lith. slė̃pti 'verbergen, verstecken, verheimlichen'| the root *klep- (Gk. κλέπτω, etc.) is found in OPr. niauklipts 'unverborgen', but it is not clear whether the Lithuanian forms are to be connected to the same root.}]
Justification: A derivative of PIE *klep- 'to (secretly) steal, hide' ([Smoczyński 2005](src-686):33-34, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 940-941, [LIV²](src-141) 363-364).

Source: 345[715{S.v. TochB ṣämṣ- 'count (as)', (as though) from PIE *sem-se/o-, a verbal derivative of *sem- 'one, a unity' (cf. Skt. samayati 'puts in order', ON semja 'put together, put in order, unite' < *som(H)ei̯e/o-).}];341[925-926{S.v. TochB ṣämṣ- 'zählen, betrachten als', 'count, count (as)'| traditionally to PIE *sem- 'one' but with some formal difficulties regarding the preservation of the nasal before -s-. Alternatively K. T. Schmidt apud [EWAia](src-172) II:836, Nachträge ad śaṁs-) compares the root to Ved. śaṃs- 'praise' from PIE *(s)k̑ens- '(zweckgebunden) zählen' with the line of semantic development in Vedic being 'sequentially counting' >> 'evaluate, assess'.}]
Justification: Traditionally to PIE *sem- 'one, a unity' (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):715, with references to earlier literature), but alternatively to PIE *(s)k̑ens- (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):925-926, [EWAia](src-172) II:836). The traditional etymology is not impossible, although the initial ṣ- is unexpected, and does not account for the root final *-s- (Ron Kim, p.c.), therefore the latter etymology is more preferable.

Source: 141[592-593{S.v. *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (IEW 1016-7).}];165[476{S.v. Proto-Germanic *stekan- 'to stick', from PIE *stig-e- (cf. Lat. īnstīgō, -ere 'to stimulate, set on, incite, rouse or urge' < *-steig-e-).}];397[879{Cf. s.v. NHG stecken (MHG stecken, OHG stehhōn, steckōn), a variant of stechen with a generalised, perhaps intensifying geminate. Cf. s.v. NHG stechen, from West Germanic *stek-a-. Outside of Germanic one may compare Lat. īnstīgāre 'anspornen', Gk. στίζω 'ich tätowiere, kennzeichne', and a variant without s-mobile Ved. tigmá- 'sharp'.}];757[4:272-273{Cf. s.v. Du. steken ww. 'prikken', cf. OHG stehhan (NHG stechen)| OFr. steka (NFr. stekke), < pgm. *stekan-, derivatives of PIE *(s)tei̯g-.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to stick; be pointy' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):879, [EWNl](src-757) 4:272-273, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):476, [LIV²](src-141) 592-593).

Source: 345[225-226{S.v. TochB kauṃ, which with TochA koṃ reflects Proto-Tocharian *kāunä- from a PIE verbal abstract *keh₂u-ni- 'burning heat (as of the sun)' from PIE *keh₂u̯- 'ignite, burn' (cf. Gk. καίω).}];141[345{Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').}];389[{Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).}];149[118-119{S.v. B kauṃ, A koṃ 'sun| day', the proposed connection with Gk. καίω 'I set fire to, kindle' is attractive', and simpler than and more preferable than the etymology to IE *kaih₂o- suggested by Hilmarsson 1991a: 187.}]
Justification: Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):118-119, [Adams 2013](src-345):225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) (formerly [LIV²](src-141) 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).

Source: 105[481{S.v. Alb. thua ~ thue '(finger) nail'. Orel prefers to derive from Proto-Albanian *atsāna, from PIE *ak̑- 'sharp', but alternative etymologies have been proposed comparing variously Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail', PIE * k̑er- 'horn', Gk. κεντέω  'to prick', and PGmc. *xanduz 'hand'.}];130[55-56{Alternatively from PIE *k̑ent- 'stechen, Nagel'.}];571[120{S.v. Alb. thua, thoi| thonj 'finger- or toe-nail'. A form *keEn-T- would account for the Albanian forms and a zero-grade *kEn-tú- is compatible with Germanic *xanðú- but there is some discrepancy in the semantics.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):120, [Orel 1998](src-105):481, [Holm 2011](src-130):55-56 for various attempts at an IE root etymology and further discussion.

Source: 341[972{TochB sruk- 'die' is related to the TochA sruk- 'kill', which is based on a causative formation.  Several possible etymological proposals: [Adams 2013](src-345):792 derives the root from PIE *streu̯g- 'streichen, abwischen' ([LIV²](src-141) 605, without Tocharian), while [Meillet 1911](src-584):461 assumed a k-extension of *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' ([LIV²](src-141) 588, without Tocharian).  More recently [Hackstein 2003](src-583):84 has preferred *su̯ergʰ- 'krank sein, sich sorgen' ([LIV²](src-141) 613-614, without Tocharian).}];345[792];583[84];584[461]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian disputed (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):972). Several possible etymological proposals: [Adams 2013](src-345):792 derives the root from PIE *streu̯g- 'streichen, abwischen' ([LIV²](src-141) 605, without Tocharian); [Meillet 1911](src-584):461 assumed a k-extension of *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' ([LIV²](src-141) 588, without Tocharian); [Hackstein 2003](src-583):84 has preferred *su̯ergʰ- 'krank sein, sich sorgen' ([LIV²](src-141) 613-614, without Tocharian).

Source: 345[641{S.v. TochB wät- 'fight, struggle', which with TochA wac 'combat, struggle' reflect Proto-Tocharian *wät- and derivatives, which can be connected with PIE *u̯edʰ- (Skt. vádhati 'strike (down)', etc.  Van Windekens's etymology to *du̯et-, a supposed derivative of the numeral 'two', is to be rejected.}];141[660{S.v. *u̯edʰh₁- 'stoßen' (IEW 1115). [Tocharian cognates not listed].}];341[876-877{S.v. TochB wät- 'kämpfen', 'fight', to be derived from PIE *u̯edʰ- 'strike down' (cf. Adams DoT 590) (*u̯edʰh₁- in LIV² (without Tocharian cognates).}];389[{Cf. s.v. ?*u̯edʰh₁- → 2.*u̯edʰ-?. Reconstruction of final laryngeal insecure.}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *u̯edʰ(h₁)- 'hit, strike' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):876-877, [Adams 2013](src-345):641, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 345[68{S.v. TochB īte 'full, abundant, profuse'. The etymology is uncertain.  Van Windekens plausibly connects the Tocharian A & B forms together, but further IE connections are unclear.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):68)

Source: 345[478{S.v. TochB matsi 'headhair' (collective). Etymology dubious, maybe to Latv. mats 'a hair', (pl.) mati '(head)hair'?}]
Justification: Connections outside of Tocharian unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):478).

Source: 345[61-62{S.v. TochB āśce 'head'. Etymology uncertain, cf. entry for discussion of various proposals.}]
Justification: No certain etymology, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):61-62 for a survey of various proposals.

Source: 345[96{TochB emalle 'hot, warm', (n.) 'heat', TochA omäl 'id.' reflect Proto-Tocharian *emäl(y)e-, which appears to be a gerund to a verbal root em-.  Further PIE connections are speculative.  See Adams s.v. for various proposals.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):96 for various proposals.

Comment: with parallel sound substitutions: kʰ for x
Justification: Parallel loanwords from Persian خون / xūn 'blood'.

Source: 323[35{S.v. Pašto haḍ 'bone', cf. T 13952 and Lhd, Pnj haḍḍ(ī) 'bone', etc.}];442[807{Cf. s.v. 13952 Skt. haḍḍa n. 'bone' lex. [Iranic loan as Par(ači). haḍḍ IIFL i 258]}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Indic lexemes continued by Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):807 no. 13952, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):35). The Pashto form represents a diminutive and matches Gawarbati haḍoki.

Source: 130[53-54{Loan from Bulgarian коцка or similar.}];105[187{S.v. Alb. koc 'bone, skull', borrowed from Slav. *kostъ 'bone' with a metathesis in the cluster *-st- > -ts-. The Slavic diminutive *kostъka is the source of Alb. kockë, koskë 'id.'. Not with Meyer (1891:202-203) who argues is a loan from Ital. coccio 'cracked pot'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic *kostъka ([Orel 1998](src-105):187, [Holm 2011](src-130):53-54).
Loanword from Low German borst 'chest' (cf. Middle Dutch borst 'id.').
Parallel loans from English breast.

Source: 442[646{Cf. s.v. 11097.3 *loṣati ʻburnsʼ}]

369[344{S.v. Alb. re, -(j)a 'Wolke, Dunst, Lufttrübung, Schleier (vor den Augen)'. Not fully clear, cf. entry for several proposed etymologies.}];130[56{Two possible etymologies: either (1) to PIE *h₂ers- 'to flow' (not followed by Demiraj 1997:345 and therefore not in LIV² 241), or (2) to *h₃rei̯H- 'wirbeln, fließen' > PAlb. *rina (cf. Ved. rinā́ti, Slav. rinǫ, Illyr. ῥίνος 'cloud' (so Orel 1998:366). The latter of which is Holm's preferred etymology.}];105[366{S.v. Alb. re ~ rê, 'cloud', which O. argues is a singularized plural of *ri, from PAlb. rina (cf. Illyr. ῥίνος· ἀχλύς) to be further connected to Skt. riṇā́ti 'to pour, to let flow', Gk. (Lesb.) ὀρίνω 'to move'.}];269[{Etymology in this class tentatively assigned to PIE *h₃rei̯H- following [Orel 1998](src-105):366, [Holm 2011](src-130):56, but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):344, [Holm 2011](src-130):56 for discussion of alternative etymologies.}]
Justification: The etymology in this cognate set is tentatively assigned to PIE *h₃rei̯H- following [Orel 1998](src-105):366, [Holm 2011](src-130):56, but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):344, [Holm 2011](src-130):56 for discussion of alternative etymologies.

Source: 442[723{Cf. s.v. 12487 Skt. śītalá 'cold' MBh. [śītá- 1].}]
Justification: Loan from Pāli sītala- 'cold', cf. Sinhalese hīl 'cold' as the inherited reflex from Sanskrit śītalá- 'cold' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):723 no. 12487).

Source: 468[438{S.v. ON reikna (schw.) 'berechnen, zahlen, ansehen, bewirten' (Ic. reikna, NNw. rekna, NSw. räkna, NDa. regne), a loanword from MLG rekenen.}]
Justification: From Old Norse reikna, a loanword from Middle Low German rekenen ([de Vries 1977](src-468):438).  Since this is already found in Old Norse, its presence in both Elfdalian and Swedish can be presumed to reflect a parallel shift to this meaning, not a parallel loan.

Source: 105[291{Cf. s.v. nëmëroj 'to number, to count', borrowed from Lat. numerāre 'id.'. Other similar forms, such as numër 'number', are of Italian or learned Latin origin.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin numerāre 'to count, enumerate' ([Orel 1998](src-105):291).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. count, from Middle English counte-n , a borrowing from Old French cunter, conter which in turn is ultimately from Lat. com-putāre.}]
Justification: Originally a loanword into Middle English from Old French cunter, conter ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. die (v.), from early Middle English dēȝen, dēghen, corresponding to Old Norse deyja, generally considered to be lost from Old English (where expressed by steorfan, sweltan, or periphrastic wesan déad) and re-introduced from early Scandinavian, although a minority view view a preservation of Old English díegan, dégan, in some dialects.}]
Justification: Loanword into Middle English from Old Norse deyja 'to die', replacing various Old English expressions steorfan, sweltan, or periphrastic wesan déad ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 309[377{Cf. s.v. Bret. kaw 'cave, creux, sous-sol', like W cau 'creux, fermé' a borrowing from Lat. cavus.}]
Justification: A denominal formation from Breton kaw 'hollow', originally a borrowing from Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):377).

Source: 392[{S.v. Sw. smutsig, like Da. smudsig, Nw. smussig, from NHG schmutzig.}]
Justification: Loanword from German schmutzig 'dirty' ([Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

Source: 105[356{S.v. Alb. qen 'dog' "A relatively late loanword from Lat canem id. […] or, rather, its Balkan continuations (Rum caine), reflecting no traces of rhotacism in Tosk."}];571[107{S.v. Alb. qen, -i| qene 'dog' "qen is regarded as a loan from Lat canis 'dog'| so [Meyer 1891](src-585):222, Tagliavani (1937:94), Haarmann (1972:47). The failure of Lat n to rhotacize implies lateness of borrowing or a Balkan origin, note Rum caină 'dog'."}]
Justification: Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ([Huld 1984](src-571):107, [Orel 1998](src-105):356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. [Tosk-based] Standard Albanian in [cognate set 5925](cog-5925)).

Source: 598[702-703{It is borrowed from Middle Iranian *sabāka-, cf. Persian, sabah, Avestan spā, spaka- 'dog's', Median σπάκα. The Iranian word is related to Old Indic çvā, çúnas and Greek κύων, κυνός. In his comments Trubačev claims that a borrowing from Iranian is hardly probable and that the source of the Slavic lexeme is Turkish köbäk 'dog'.}];599[2: 183{It is usually assumed to be an early, common Slavic borrowing from Iranian.}];608[419{It is an old loan from an Iranian language, probably from Scythian. A hypothesis about an indigenous origin (*sob-ak(a)) is unconvincing.}]
Justification: Loan into East Slavic from Iranic *sabāka- 'dog' ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:702-703, cf. [Černyh 1999](src-599) 2:183, [Šanskij et al. 1975](src-608):419).
Parallel loans from Persian گرد / gard 'dust'.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. egg. The inherited word for 'egg', attested via OE ǽg, was replaced in Middle English by a borrowing from Old Norse egg 'egg' (Middle English egge).}]
Justification: From Middle English egge, a loan from Old Norse egg 'egg', replacing Old English ǽg 'egg' which continued the inherited lexeme ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 141[223{S.v. *Hei̯k̑- 'sich aneignen' (IEW 298-9).}];341[543-544{S.v. TochB aik- 'wissen, erkennen', 'know, recognize', to be derived from √*Hei̯k̑- 'sich aneignen' (LIV² 223).}];345[107-108{S.v. TochB aik- 'know, recognise'| TochAB aik- and its derivatives come from PIE *hₐeik̑- 'to have as one's own, be master of' (Av. iše 'is master of', Goth. aih, aigum 'have, possess', OE āgan 'id.', etc.).}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of PIE *Hei̯k̑- 'to take possession of' ([LIV²](src-141) 223, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):543-544, [Adams 2013](src-345):107-108).

Source: 345[278{S.v. TochB ckācko* 'leg, (particularly) shin, calf'. Etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):278 for discussion of various proposals.

Source: 345[651{S.v. TochB wästarye 'liver', most closely related to the Greek words for ὑστρός 'stomach' (Hesych.) ὑστέρα 'womb, uterus| ovary' < *ud-tero-. Cf. Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Italic words for 'belly' in [cognate set 854](cog-854).}]
Justification: Probably to be connected with lexemes for 'belly' in [cognate set 854](cog-854) ([Adams 2013](src-345):651).

Source: 345[401{S.v. TochB pärśeri* '(head-)louse'. Etymology unknown.}]
Justification: No known etymology ([Adams 2013](src-345):401).

Source: 468[144{S.v. ON frykta 'befrachten' based on a loanword from MLG (cf. vrucht, vracht 'fracht, last')}]
Justification: Loans from Middle Low German (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):144).

Source: 309[587{No loanword, but inherited: The Brittonic words and Irish clúm *from Celtic *kʷluma.}];275[{Although Deshayes' suggestion is theoretically possible, it is not convincing. The supposed Celtic *kʷluma has no cognates outside Celtic, while Latin pluma does, cf. de Vaan (2003, 474).}];296[C-128{Borrowed from Lat. pluma [cognate set 999](cog-999).}]
Justification: Generally considered a loanword from Latin ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:128) but occasionally disputed (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):587). On upholding the loanword hypothesis, cf. comments by Irslinger in this class.
Unexpected vocalism points to parallel loans from Persian.
Parallel loans from Persian ناخن / nāxun 'nail', in some cases with sound substitution kh for x; Sanskrit nakha- 'nail' also may have had influence.

Source: 598[1: 279{Some scholars assume here a native word related to Avestan ātar- 'fire', Armenian airem 'burn', Irish áith 'oven' etc. Others consider the lexeme as a loanword from Romanian (where it can be, in turn, a loan from Albanian). The distribution of vatra/watra in Slavic and its abscence in older texts seem to support the loanword hypothesis. However, it can be still a native word (cf. Russian CS obaštritisâ 'get inflammate').}];603[1: 123-124{The word is related to Avestan ātar- 'fire' etc. and was borrowed into Slavic from Dacian.}];589[3: 569{It is a Balkan shepherd word which was probably diffused in the Serbo-Croat area by Vlachs and in the North by Romanians.}];593[701{It is a Carpathian shepherd term. It is assumed that the word was diffused by Romani language, where it could be borrowed from Iranian. It is also possible, that the word comes from substrate IE languages in the Balkans}]
Justification: A Wanderwort of obscure origin, cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:123-124, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):701, [Skok 1971-1974](src-589) 3:569, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:279 for various proposals.

Source: 231[176{S.v. ScG. flùr, plùr 'flower'. "Ir. plúr, M. Ir. plúr| from the M. Eng. flour, O. Fr. flour, Lat. florem, G. flùr is from the Scotch."}]
Justification: Loanword from Scots, cf. Middle English flour, Old French flour ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):176).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. flower, from Middle English flour, flur, borrowed from Old French flour, flur, flor (cf. Modern French fleur).}]
Justification: Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 269[{A register-loanword into Standard Modern Greek from Katharevousa (expected †μίχλη, vel sim.). A reflex of the expected word might be found in SMG μούχλα 'mould, mildew' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).}];271[{Cf. s.v. SMG ὀμίχλη 'fog'| for μουχλά 'mildew, mould', cf. s.v. @ http://www.greek-language.gr/greekLang/modern_greek/tools/lexica/triantafyllides/search.html?lq=%CE%BC%CE%BF%CF%85%CF%87%CE%BB%CE%B1&dq=}]
Justification: A register-loanword into Standard Modern Greek from Katharevousa (expected †μίχλη, vel sim.). A reflex of the expected word might be found in SMG μούχλα 'mould, mildew' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); cf. also respective entries in [Andriotis 1999](src-271).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. fruit, from Middle English frut, fruyt(e) (etc.), a borrowing  Old French fruit, in turn ultimately from Lat. frūctus.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from from Latin frūctus (or in some cases, its Old French derivative fruit).
Parallel loans from Persian میوه / mīwah 'fruit'.

Source: 105[103{S.v. Alb. fryt 'fruit', borrowed from Lat. frūctus 'fruit'.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin frūctus 'fruit' ([Orel 1998](src-105):103).

Source: 600[1095{Loan from German voll.}]
Justification: Loan from (Low) German voll 'full' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1095).

Comment: سبز with sound substitution uj for z
Justification: Parallel loans from Persian سبز / sabz.

Source: 600[187{The word is borrowed from Middle German grö̂ne 'green'.}]
Justification: Loan from Low German grö̂ne 'green' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):187).

Source: 600[802{Polabian svoră is borrowed from Middle Low German swâr 'heavy'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Middle Low German swâr 'heavy' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):802).
Parallel loans from Persian (شكار (كردن / šekār (kardan) 'to do a hunt; hunt'

Source: 468[289{S.v. ON jaga 'jagen, treiben', a (semantic?) borrowing from MLG jagen.}];97[{S.v. Da. jage, a borrowing from Middle Low German.}]
Justification:
Generally considered to be a (at least a semantic) loanword from Middle Low German ([de Vries 1977](src-468):289; no North Germanic cognates connected by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):271-272 s.v. Proto-Germanic *jakk/gōn-).
If this is only a semantic realignment by contact influence, then technically it is not to be considered a loanword in CoBL, but a semantic realignment of a still cognate word.  
But since this is analysed as a loanword from Middle Low German, by that period fragmentation of North Germanic varieties had already begun, so this is to be taken as a parallel loan.

Source: 601[2: 327-328{Kashubian jachta 'hunt', jachtowac 'to hunt' is a loanword from German, cf. German Jagd, Middle German jacht.}]
Justification: Denominal verb derived from Kashubian jachta 'hunt' (n.), a loanword from German Jagd ([Boryś & Popowska-Taborska 1994-2010](src-601) 2:327-328).

Source: 398[976-978{Cf. s.v. OHG lacha 'Sumpf, Morast, Suhle, schlammiges Wasser' from West Germanic *lakō(n). Middle English lāk(e) 'river, stream' (= 'Bach, Flüsschen') and Modern English lake 'river, stream' in archaic and dialectal language use are inherited from Western Germanic (Old English lacu f. 'river, stream'), but in the meaning 'lake' these words are a semantic borrowing from Old French lac 'lake, pit' < Latin lacus m. 'lake'. Contrary to older interpretations, Proto-Germanic *lākō(n)- is not connected to Lat. lacus, since Lat. must continue *-k̑-. The Germanic word is more likely to go back to PIE *le⁽g̑⁾- 'tröpfeln, sickern, zergehen', also attested in the Gmc. adj. *lek-e/a- 'undicht' and in the thematic present *lek-e/a- 'lecken, undicht sein' (> OHG lecken 'bewässern, benetzen'). Outside of Germanic this root is only further attested in Celtic (cf. OIr. lega* < Proto-Celtic *leg-e/o- 'schmelzen, [sich] auflösen', making the reconstruction of the original velar impossible.}];84[{S.v. Engl. lake n. (4). "Early Middle English lac , < Old French lac, < Latin lacus basin, tub, tank, lake, pond| the popular form of the word in Old French was lai . The present English form lake (recorded from the 14th cent.) may be due to confusion with lake n.3, or perhaps rather to independent adoption of Latin lacus."}];141[397{Cf. s.v. ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'tröpfeln' (IEW 657), only Germanic and Celtic.}]
Justification: The English word for 'lake' might be inherited from Germanic (cf. OHG lacha 'bog, mire'), but if so in the meaning 'lake' it would appear to be a semantic borrowing from Latin lacus (cf. similarly Greek: Italiot λάκκ̔ο in [cognate set 8394](cog-8394) which might be a semantic calque based on Italian); the cognate Germanic lexemes are unrelated to Lat. lacus, and probably further connected to PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 397), otherwise only attested in Celtic ([EWA 5](src-398):976-978). If from PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' then possibly to be connected with Armenian lič in [cognate set 607](cog-607).

Source: 165[321-322{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg| hollow bone| stalk', an etymologically unclear North Germanic word. English 'leg' is a loanword from this etymon via its Norse descendent.}];84[{S.v. Engl. leg, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic leggr 'leg').}]
Justification: Loanword from Early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic leggr 'leg' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 105[177{S.v. Alb. këmbë ~ kambë 'leg, foot', a loan from Romance *camba ~ *gamba- 'leg'.}];130[63{Loan from Lat. camba.}];571[80{S.v. Alb. këmbë, -a 'leg, foot'. Ultimately a loan from VLat. camba 'leg'. "The relation to the Vulgar Latin form is clear but the direction of the borrowing is uncertain."}]
Justification: Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ([Huld 1984](src-571):80, [Orel 1998](src-105):177, [Holm 2011](src-130):63).

Source: 260[796{It is a loanword from New High German laben.}]
Justification: Loanword from Modern High German leben 'to live' ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):796).
Parallel loans from Persian (زندگى (كردن  / zendegī (kardan) 'to live'.
Parallel loans into Modern Indo-Iranic languages from Persian جگر / ǰigar 'liver'

Comment: Parallel loans from Skt. yákr̥t [lexeme 22444](lex-22444)
Justification: Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Sanskrit yákr̥t 'liver'.
Parallel loans from Persian مرد / mard 'man, person'.

Source: 600[865-866{It is a loanword from Middle German kerl 'man'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Low German kerl 'man' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):865-866).
Parallel loans from Persian گوشت / gūšt 'meat'.
Parallel loans from the Sanskrit compound candrá- 'bright' [cognate set 2338](cog-2338) + mā́ḥ 'moon' [cognate set 2232](cog-2232).

Source: 600[396{It is a loanword from Middle German mân 'moon'.}]
Comment: Loan from Low German.
Justification: Loan from Low German mân 'moon' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):396).
Parallel loans from Persian کوه / kūh 'mountain'.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. mountain, a borrowing from French montain, montaigne.}]
Justification: Loanword into Middle English from Old French montaigne ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 105[120{S.v. Alb. gojë 'mouth'. From the variant golë is is clear that this is a loanword from It. gola.}];130[72{Loan from Lat. gula. The vocalism, however, is only accounted for by assuming a late loan from It. gola.}];571[66{S.v. Alb. gojë 'mouth', a borrowing from Lat. gula. The distribution of the variant gojë argues against a late loan source.}]
Comment: Loanword from Italian
Justification: Certainly a borrowing from Latin gula or Italian gola 'throat' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):126, although aspects of the loan chronology remain disputed (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):66, [Orel 1998](src-105):120, [Holm 2011](src-130):72).
Parallel loans from Persian تنگ / tang 'narrow'.

Source: 309[699{S.v. Bret. strizh 'étroit, strict, rigoureux, austère' from Old Breton strit 'serré, étroit| austère', borrowed from Lat. strictus.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Old Breton strit, a loanword from Latin strictus 'drawn together, close, strait, tight' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):699)

Source: 105[298{S.v. Alb. ngushtë 'narrow', a loanword from Lat. angustus.}];585[307{S.v. Alb. nguštε 'eng| karg, geizig', a loanword from Latin angustus (cf. also Rom. îngust 'eng').}];571[98{S.v. Alb. i, e ngushtë 'narrow, mean (metaphorically)' a loan from Latin angustum 'narrow, tight' with typical Albanian loss of the pretonic vowel.}]
Comment: Loan from Latin angustus 'narrow'.
Justification: Loanword from Latin angustus 'narrow' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):307, [Huld 1984](src-571):98, [Orel 1998](src-105):298).

Comment: cf. Persian نزدیک næzdi:k - via Urdu? - outside Urdu with sound substitution j for zd

Justification: Parallel loans from Persian گردن / gardan 'neck'.
Loanword from within Iranic, probably via Tajik or Persian.

Source: 105[512{S.v. Alb. vjetër 'old', a borrowing from Lat. veterem 'old'.}];571[131{S.v. Alb. vjetër 'old (of things)', semantics and final -r (never -rr) point to a loan from Latin veterem, the acc. of Lat. vetus 'old'.}];585[476{S.v. Alb. vjet , vit 'alt'| Alb. vjétεrε 'alt' is from Latin veterem.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin veterem 'old' (acc.sg.) ([Meyer 1891](src-585):476, [Huld 1984](src-571):131, [Orel 1998](src-105):512).

Source: 105[231-232{S.v. Alb. luaj ~ luej 'to move, to shake, to play'| either from Proto-Albanian *lādnja and connected with Alb. loz (to be etymologically connected with Slav. Iadъ 'order, peace'), or a borrowing from Lat. lūdere 'to play' (so [Meyer 1891](src-585):248).}];585[248-249{S.v. Alb. l'os 'spiele, bewege, reize', certainly a loanword from Latin ludere.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin lūdere 'to play' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):242-243, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):231-232).
Parallel loans from Middle Low German.

Source: 97[{S.v. Da. trække, a borrowing from Middle Low German trecken.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Middle Low German trecken 'to pull' (cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. push, a loan from Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle French pousser.}]
Justification: Loanword from Anglo-Norman, cf. Old French, Middle French pousser 'to push' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 309[595-596{S.v. Bret. pouls 'pouls, pousse, bourgeon| mal, toux'| from Old Breton  puls, corresponding to Co. pols 'battement de cœur, moment, instant', both words borrowed from Lat. pulsus 'pouls'.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin pulsus 'a pushing, beating, striking' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):595-596)

Source: 309[127{S.v. Bret. bou(n)t 'poussé', a borrowing from Old French boute 'coup', deverbal from bouter 'heurter, pousser'.}]
Justification: Based on Bret. bou(n)t, a loanword from Old French boute (deverbal from Old French bouter 'hit, push').

Source: 442[186{S.v. 3585 Skt. kravyá- 'bloody, raw' TS., n. 'raw flesh, carrion' Nir. 2. *kraviya- . [kráviṣ-] (2. > Kho. krui 'red, bloodshot, reddish brown, auburn, crimson').}];274[444-448{Cf. s.v. *kreu̯h₂- '(geronnenes) Blut, Blut außerhalb des Korpers' (IEW 621f.)}];172[I:411{S.v. Ved. kraviṣ- 'rotes, blutiges Fleisch', from PIE *kreu̯h₂-s- from *kreu̯h₂- ~ *kruh₂- with which AGk. κρέας 'Fleisch' is identical. Closely related is also Lat. cruor 'rotes, dickes Blut', Lith. kraũjas 'Blut', OPol. kry, etc.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *kraviya- 'bloody, raw' [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):186 no. 3585), cf. Vedic kraviṣ- 'red, bloody flesh', ultimately from PIE *kreu̯h₂-s-, a derivative of *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ([NIL](src-274) 444-448, [EWAia](src-172) I:411).
Loanword from Persian سرخ / sorx 'red'.
Parallel loans from Persian راست / rāst 'right'.

Source: 600[634-635{It is a loanword from Middle German recht or its derivative.}]
Justification: Loanword from Low German recht 'right' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):634-635).
(Parallel?) loan from Middle Low German.

Source: 345[657-658{S.v. TochB witsako 'root', probably (with [van Windekens 1976](src-76):644) a borrowing from Iranian *vityaka- or *vaityaka- 'root' (cf. Av. vāeti-, Pers. bēd) or *vaitāka- (Oss. uedāgä), although there is a lack of exact Iranian parallels and one may have expected *-ty- to yield Tocharian -cc-. Assuming Middle Iranian *wīδikā- (Winter 1971:222, [Tremblay 2005](src-732):426) makes things a bit easier, but -δ- > -ts- is still formally difficult.}]
Justification: Generally assumed to be a loan from (early) Middle Iranian, cf. [Tremblay 2005](src-732):426, [Adams 2013](src-345):657-658 for recent discussions and references to further literature.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. rotten, apparently a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic rotinn).}]
Justification: Loan from early Scandinavian, cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. round (adj.), a borrowing from Anglo-Norman rund, runt.}];397[777-778{S.v. NHG rund (MHG runt), a borrowing from French ronde 'Tafelrunde'.}];97[{S.v. Da. rund, from Middle Low German 'runt', in turn from Lat. rotundus.}];392[{S.v. Sw. rund, from OSw. runder, a borrowing from MLG runt.}]
Justification:
The North Germanic lexemes in this set are likely to be loans from Middle Low German, of a word originally borrowed from Old French.

See the other loan event cognate sets that also go back to this same Old French source:
[cognate set 9688](cog-9688) in Dutch;  
[cognate set 9689](cog-9689) in Upper German, 
[cognate set 9690](cog-9690) as a parallel loan into English and Frisian

Cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97). [Kluge 2011](src-397):777-778, [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84), [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

Source: 309[632{S.v. Bret. ront 'rond', a borrowing from French roont (1155), ultimately from Lat. rotundum.}]
Justification: Loan from Old French roont ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):632).
Parallel loans from Persian نمک / namak 'salt'.
Loan from Middle Persian.
Loan from Persian تخم / toxm 'seed'.

Source: 354[135{Cf. Middle Low German sât.}]
Justification: Loan from Low German, cf. Middle Low German sât 'seed' ([Polański & Sehnert 1967](src-354):135).
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Persian: Tehran تیز / tīz 'sharp'.

Source: 600[806{It is a loanword from Middle Low German scharp, scherp.}]
Justification: Loan from Middle Low German scharp, scherp 'sharp' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):806).

Source: 468[327{S.v. ON kortr, kurtr 'kurz' < MLG kort < Lat. curtus.}]
Justification: Modern North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse kortr, a loan from Middle Low German (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):327 s.v. kortr, kurtr).

Source: 105[425{S.v. Alb. shkurt 'short', borrowed from Gmc. *skurtaz 'short' (cf. OHG scurz, OE sceort).}]
Justification: According to [Orel 1998](src-105):425, a loanword from Germanic *skurta- 'short'.

Source: 105[178{S.v. Alb. këndoj 'to sing'. A loan from Lat. cantāre 'sing'.}];585[187{S.v. Alb. kεndóń 'singe, krähe lese, studiere', from Latin cantāre.}];571[80{S.v. Alb. këndoj 'sing', a loan from Latin cantāre.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin cantāre 'sing' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):187, [Huld 1984](src-571):80, [Orel 1998](src-105):178)
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Middle Persian pwst / põst 'skin', Persian: Tehran پوست	 / pūst 'id.'.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. skin, a loan from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic skinn, Old Norwegian skinn (Norwegian skinn), Old Swedish skin (Swedish skinn), Old Danish skindh, skin (Danish skind ), all in sense ‘skin, hide, fur’).}]
Justification: A loan from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Norse skinn), already attested in Old English schynn, scynn, scin ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 602[6: 432, 436{Taking into account its phonetic form and the geographical distribution, it is most probably a loanword from Polish.}];607[12: 167{The root vowel -u- points to a Polish origin.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Polish skóra 'skin' (cf. [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 12:167, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6:432, 436

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. sky, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Icelandic ský 'cloud').}]
Comment: Loan from early Scandinavian

Source: 296[S:177{S.v. OIr. spéir 'sphère' loanword either from sphaera or Franco-Norman spere.}]
Justification: Loanword from either Latin sphaera or Norman French spere ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:177)

Source: 105[360{S.v. Alb. qiell 'sky, heaven', borrowed from Lat. caelum 'id.'.}];571[107{S.v. Alb. qiell, -i 'sky, heavens', long recognised as a borrowing from Lat. caelum [Huld prints coelum], 'sky, heaven', so Meyer (1891:225-226) and others.}];585[225-226]
Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Loan from Latin caelum 'sky' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):225-226, [Huld 1984](src-571):107, [Orel 1998](src-105):360).

Source: 309[643{S.v. Bret. sant 'sensation', deverbal from santañ (santaff 1499), santiñ, santoud 'sentir| (se) ressentir', borrowings from Old French sentir, ultimately from Lat. sentire.}]
Justification: Loanword from Old French sentir 'to perceive' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):643).
Parallel loans from Persian هموار / hamwār 'smooth, flat, level'

Source: 415[478{Loan from New High German.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Middle Low German glatt 'smooth'.

Source: 468[513{S.v. ON slangi 'Schlange', a loan from Low German slange.}]
Justification: North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse slangi, a loan from Middle Low German slange 'snake' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):513).  But if the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Icelandic and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. [cognate set 126](cog-126)).

Source: 231[31{S.v. ScG. bat, bata 'stick', Ir. bata| from MEng. batte 'stick', now 'bat', which is in turn from OFr. batte, from Gaul. Lat. battuere. Bret. baz seems borrowed from Fr. though it may be native.}]
Justification: A loan from Middle English batte, in turn borrowed from Old French batte ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):31)

Source: 130[83{Rejects the loan hypothesis unquestioningly followed by Orel (1998:301) due to atypical features, preferring the solution of Huld (1984:148) who derives directly from PIE *(s)neh₂- (cf. LIV² 572 without Albanian forms listed) Alb. notim < *(s)néh₂-t-imo-.}];105[301{S.v. Alb. notoj 'to swim'. O. follows the hypothesis of a borrowing from Romance *notāre replacing Classical *natāre (so Meyer 1891:311).}];571[148{In the section on sound-changes Huld rather derives earlier notim 'swimming' < PIE *snéAt-imo-.}];585[311];269[{Two possibilities: Either (1) as a loan from Romance *notāre (with irregular root vocalism from Lat. natāre 'swim', so [Meyer 1891](src-585):311, [Orel 1998](src-105):301), or – perhaps better – (2) directly derived to PIE *(s)neh₂- (so [Huld 1984](src-571):148, [Holm 2011](src-130):83). No discussion in [Demiraj 1997](src-369) or [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364).}]
Justification: Two possibilities: Either (1) as a loan from Romance *notāre (with irregular root vocalism from Lat. natāre 'swim', so [Meyer 1891](src-585):311, [Orel 1998](src-105):301), or – perhaps better – (2) directly derived to PIE *(s)neh₂- (so [Huld 1984](src-571):148, [Holm 2011](src-130):83). No discussion in [Demiraj 1997](src-369) or [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364).
Parallel loans from Middle Low German swanz 'trailer; tail, penis' (cf. [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

Source: 309[677{S.v. Bret. soñj 'pensée, idée, intention, souvenir', a borrowing from an Old French continuant of Lat. somnium, derived verb soñjal 'penser, réfléchir, songer'.}]
Justification: Loan from Old French songer (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):677).

Source: 386[579{Northern Germanic forms with -nk- show same meaning as Middle Low Dutch denken 'think, remember', thus probably loan from Low German ("Ndd.").}];97[{S.v. Da. tænke, from Middle Low German denken.}];392[{S.v. Sw. tänka, just as Da. tænke a borrowing from MLG denken.}]
Justification: Parallel loan event from Middle Low German denken 'to think, remember' (cf. [EWA 2](src-386) 579).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. turn, from Old English tyrnan, turnian, both borrowings from Latin tornāre 'to turn in a lathe, round off'.}]
97[{S.v. Da. dreje, borrowed from MLG dreien.}]
Justification: Loan from Middle Low German dreien 'to turn'.
Parallel loans from Persian گرم  / garm 'hot'.

Source: 468[648{S.v. ON vaska 'waschen', probably a borrowing from Middle Low German waschen.}]
Justification: Since the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Faroese and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian (after p > f, but before ē > ī)

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. wing, from Middle English (first in plural forms wenge, wengen, wenges), ultimately borrowed from Old Norse vængir.}]
Justification: Loan from Old Norse vængir ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Parallel loans from Sanskrit strī- 'woman, female, wife'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3245

Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit jāṅgala- 'jungle, wild forest'.

Source: 386[474-476{S.v. OHG busc, bosc 'Busch, Strauch, Gebüsch, Brombeerbuch, frutex, silva, rubus'. In earlier literature the Germanic words words were considered to be a loanword from Medieval Latin buscus, boscus 'Wald, Gebüsch', but given that there is no satisfactory etymology for these Latin forms, more recent literature considers the forms to be inherited in Germanic. The Proto-Germanic form would be *ƀuskaz (maybe with a variant with long *-ū-) and is normally related to PIE *bʰeu̯-, bʰū- 'to inflate, to swell/to grow', either with an PIE -s- extension and then Germanic -k-extension, or with an -sk-extension as found e.g. in OHG frosc 'frog'. The semantic development is assumed to have been 'swelling' > 'voluptous, sumptous, ample' > 'ample growth of plants'. With Th. Braune 1912, EWA assumes that the Romance lexemes in [cognate set 347](cog-347) are loans from Germanic.}];397[165{S.v. NHG Busch (MHG busch, bosch(e), OHG busc, bosc, OS *(brāmal-)busc, from *buski-, *buskōn-. The word has no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. Medieval Latin boscus with Fr. bois, It. bosco, has no earlier origins in Classical Latin. Perhaps there was a common borrowing from a third source| there is no known corresponding word in Celtic.}]
Justification: Considered to be a loanword from Medieval Latin boscus in earlier literature, but given that the Medieval Latin form (and its descendants in modern Romance languages) have no clear etymology from earlier Italic, the Germanic forms are now generally considered to be inherited, although their further etymology is obscure. It remains possible that the Medieval Latin and the Germanic forms are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [EWA 2](src-386):474-476, [Kluge 2011](src-397):165).

Source: 141[456{S.v. ?2.*neu̯d- 'stoßen' (IEW 767).}];172[II:58{S.v. Ved. √nod- 'stoßen, hinstoßen, antreiben', further etymology unclear.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:58); [LIV²](src-141) 456 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 767).

Source: 345[356-357{S.v. TochB nätk- 'thrust/push (away)| thrust forward, urge'. TochA & TochB forms reflect Proto-Tocharian *nätk-. Proposed to PIE *nud-sk̑e/o- (Skt. nudati, otherwise isolated, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:176), but this is formally difficult from a Tocharian point of view. Further etymological connections are uncertain.}];341[682-683{S.v. TochAB nätk- 'fernhalten, wegstoßen', 'to push off, push away', formerly connected to *neu̯d- (LIV² ?2.*neu̯d-, without Tocharian) by Jasanoff (1978b:39) with a derived present *nud-sk̑e/o-, but the etymology does not fit the root-initial palatalisation found in the Tocharian B preterite forms (ñätka, etc.).  The phenomenon is better accounted for by assuming a pre-Proto-Tocharian form *n(e/i)T-sk-.}];645[39]
Justification: Proposed to Sanskrit nudati (otherwise isolated, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:176, [LIV²](src-141) 456 s.v. ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen') by [Jasanoff 1978b](src-645):39 via a pre-form *nud-sk̑e/o-, but this connection is formally difficult from a Tocharian perspective (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):682-683, [Adams 2013](src-345):356-357 for further discussion).

Source: 345[48{S.v. TochB āmp- 'rot, putrify', a probable loanword from Middle Iranian *hampu- 'rot, fester'.  Cf. Khotanese hambūtä- 'rotted, festering', Zoroastrian Pahlavi hambūsītan, Modern Persian ambūsīdan 'to rot, fester'.}]
Justification: Probably a loanword from Middle Iranian ([Adams 2013](src-345):48).

Source: 345[628{S.v. TochB waräñce* 'sand' "Clearly related to TchA wāryāñc 'id.', it is nonetheless not directly equatable. Neither the TchA long vowels nor the -y- are matched by anything in Tocharian B. Extra-Tocharian cognates are most unsure. The TchA *wār- might allow us to connect the word with the heretofore isolated Sanskrit vāluka- 'sand'"}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain ([Adams 2013](src-345):628).

Source: 341[343-344, 909-910{S.v. TochAB we-ñ- 'sagen, sprechen', 'say, speak'.
