Usually derived from PIE *u̯ekʷ-n-i̯e/o- from √*u̯ekʷ-, but this would not have yielded the Tocharian forms as attested if the form is regularly syllabified according to the rules of PIE syllabification (i.e. *u̯ekʷ-n̥-i̯e/o).  The Tocharian forms must therefore be derived from *h₂u̯edH- 'utter' ([LIV²](src-141) 286) via *h₂u̯od-n(h₂)-e/o- or *h₂u̯oden-i̯e/o-.}];345[658-660{Cf. s.v. TochB we- 'speak, say, state', tell'.}];141[286{Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯edH- 'tönen, sprechen' (IEW 76-7) [without Tocharian cognates].}]
Justification: For the root etymology, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):909-910, with references to further literature; cf. also discussion by [Adams 2013](src-345):658-660.

Source: 345[166-167, 686{S.v. TochB śäktālye 'seed' which with TochA śäktālyi reflect Proto-Tocharian *ćäktālye-, probably to be related to kät- ‘strew’.  The exact details of the stem formation are not clear but it is probably from a reduplicated present formation *ki-kₑd-ehₐ-.  Proto-Tocharian *kät- 'strew (on purpose)| sow (seeds)' goes back to PIE *(s)kedhₐ- 'scatter' (cf. Gk. σκεδάννυμι, σκίδνημι 'scatter, strew', Engl. 'shatter, scatter', Lith. kedė́ti 'burst', with possible other cognates in other IE branches.}];141[550-551{Cf. s.v. *(s)kedh₂- 'zersplittern, zerstreuen' (IEW 918-919).}];341[564-565{Cf. s.v. TochAB kät- 'streuen, strew', from PIE *(s)kedh₂- 'zersplittern, zerstreuen' (LIV² 550f.).}]
Justification: Probably a formation derived from TochAB kät- 'strew (on purpose); sow (seeds)' ([Adams 2013](src-345):686), further to PIE *(s)kedh₂- 'shatter, disperse' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):564-565, [Adams 2013](src-345):166-167, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 550-551).

Perfect medio-passive participle < *βρέγμενος to βρέχομαι, the medio-passive of Ancient Greek βρέχω 'to wet, moisten'. Further etymology obscure; older literature assumed a Schwebeablaut variant *mregʰ- to a root *mergʰ- 'to moisten' only otherwise found in Balto-Slavic, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):195, [Beekes 2010](src-66):238 for further discussion (not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 66[106{S.v. AGk. ἄνθρωπος 'man'| it resembles Hitt. antuu̯aḫḫaš, antuḫš- 'man', but this is superficial since the Hittite word can be derived from *h₁en-dʰu(e)h₂-s- 'having breath/spirit inside'. No IE explanation has been found, so the word is probably of substratum origin.}];269[{The Mycenaean attestation of a-to-ro-qo [antʰró̞ːkʷo-] necessitates postulating a labiovelar *-kʷ- in the Proto-Greek form.}];270[90-91{S.v. AGk. ἄνθρωπος 'homme, être humain'. Etymology unclear (see [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) for various older hypotheses). Mycenaean atoroqo could suggest the existence of a second term -ōkʷo- (expressing the idea of face or appearance?), cf. ὄψ 'eye', πρόσωπον 'face' but this remains speculative.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek unclear, possibly a prehistoric loanword (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):90-91, [Beekes 2010](src-66):106).

Source: 382[131{Cf. s.v. SMG ανασαίνω, from Medieval Greek ἀνασαίνω, formed as a denominal verb in -αινω from Ancient Greek ἄνεσις 'loosening, relaxing'.}];66[581-582{Cf. s.v. AGk. ἵημι 'send (away), let go, throw', from PIE *(H)i̯eh₁-. Gk. ἄνεσις is an abstract noun (adv. ἀνα- + ἕσις) from the same root.}];141[225{Cf. s.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).}]
Justification: Cf. Standard Modern Greek ανασαίνω, from Medieval Greek ἀνασαίνω, formed as a denominal verb in -αίνω from the Ancient Greek abstract noun ἄνεσις 'loosening, relaxing' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):131), further to Ancient Greek ἵημι 'to send away, let go, throw' from PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):581-582, [LIV²](src-141) 225).

Source: 66[727-728{S.v. κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter', a denominal verb from κόβαλος 'porter, transport worker'.  No known cognates outside of Greek.}];382[717{S.v. κουβάλω, from Ancient Greek κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter'.}];270[550{S.v. AGk. κόβαλος 'vaurien, filou, voyou'. Of obscure origins| the previously proposed connection to κοάλεμος 'stupid person' is very vague| likewise to καβάλλης, caballus remains indemonstrable.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter', a derived verb from the nominal κόβαλος ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):717); further origins obscure (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):550, [Beekes 2010](src-66):727-728}).

Source: 382[1207{S.v. SMG ράχη, from Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'lower part of the back| spine'.}];66[1277-1278{S.v. ῥαχίς, -ιος 'spine, back', often metaphorically 'ridge'. Older literature compares ῥάχις 'spine| back' to Lith. ražis 'stubble', from a preform *urág̑ʰ-i-, but Beekes rejects IE connections on the basis that the apparent *a ~ *ā ablaut found in ῥᾱχός (Ion. ῥηχός) 'thorn-hedge, twig' cannot be Indo-European in origin.}];270[968-969{S.v. ῥάχις, -ιος 'colonne vertébrale, échine'. One connects in view of [IEW](src-49) 1180 to Lith. ražỹs 'chaume' with rãžas 'chaume, pointe de fourche, branche sèche'.}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, back' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1207). Further etymology outside of Greek disputed; older literature compares to Lith. ražis 'stubble', from a preform *urág̑ʰ-i-, although the supposition of such a form would require postulating *a ~ *ā ablaut (with a full or lengthened grade in ῥᾱχός or ῥηχός) (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1180, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):968-969, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1277-1278).

Source: 382[1325{S.v. στεγνός 'dry', from Ancient Greek στεγνός 'watertight, waterproof' (as subst. τὸ στεγνόν 'covered dwelling').}];66[1393{S.v. στέγω 'to cover'. Ancient Greek στεγνός is a derived adjective from στέγω, ultimately from PIE *(s)teg- 'cover, roof' (cf. Lat. tegō 'to cover', OIr. teg 'house', OHG dah 'roof').}];270[1046{Cf. s.v. AGk. στέγω 'mettre à l'abri, couvrir, protéger'.}];141[589{Cf. s.v. *(s)teg- 'decken, bedecken' (IEW 1013-4).}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek στεγνός 'watertight, waterproof', originally as a substantive τὸ στεγνόν 'covered dwelling' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1325). Further derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'to cover' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1046, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1393, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 589).

Source: 66[59{Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἄκων, -οντος 'javelin, dart', derived from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp, point'. The verb ἀκοντίζω 'to hurl a javelin' is in turn derived from this noun.}];464[{Tsakonian Propontis κ̔ουντώ < MedG κουντώ, ασκουντώ < AG ἀκοντίζω.}]
Justification: Modern Greek forms in this class continue Ancient Greek ἀκοντίζω 'hurl a javelin' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), a derivative to Ancient Greek ἄκων, -οντος 'javelin, dart', in turn derived from the PIE root *h₂ek̑- 'sharp, point' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):59).

Source: 66[351{S.v. Gk. δραμεῖν 'run', from PIE *drem- 'run', originally a suppletive aorist stem to τρέχω 'run' (cf. Skt. pres. (gramm.) dramati).}];141[128{S.v. 1. *drem- '(wohin) laufen' (IEW 204-5).}];460[215-216{S.v. δραμ- aorist stem to τρέχω 'laufen' > Tsakon. δράγγε 'laufen', etc.}]
Justification: Tsakonian lexemes based on a new present stem backformed from the Ancient Greek suppletive aorist stem ἔδραμον to the old present stem τρέχω ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):215-216), further to PIE *drem- 'to run' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):351, [LIV²](src-141) 128).

Source: 442[191{S.v. 3677 Skt. *kṣāradhānikā 'receptacle for ashes'. [kṣārá- 'caustic substance',1 dhā́na- 'container'] > N. kharāni 'ashes'.}];399[I:288{S.v. Skt. kṣāráḥ 'beizend, brennend, scharf / caustic, sharp' to the same root as kṣā́yati 'brennt / burns'.}];172[I:430{S.v. Ved. √kṣā-¹ 'brennen', no secure connections outside of Indo-Iranic.}]
Justification: As though from a Sanskrit compound *kṣāradhānikā 'receptacle for ashes' (kṣārá- 'caustic substance', dhā́na- 'container'; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):191, no. 3677). Further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:430, [KEWA](src-399) I:288).
Parallel loans from Persian بد bad 'bad'
Parallel Sanskritisms, cf. [cognate set 754](cog-754).

Source: 321[409{S.v. Wa. xun 'дом, жилище'. An old borrowing from Tadj./Pers. xāna- 'house'.}]
Justification: An old borrowing from Persian/Tajik xān(a)- 'house' ([Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):409).

Source: 178[II:657{S.v. сладкий 'süß', a Church Slavic loanword used in place of the inherited Russian lexeme солодкий.}];598[III:666{S.v. Ru. сладкий, a loanword from Church Slavic, used in place of inherited солодкий.}]
Justification: Loan from Church Slavonic used in place of the inherited Russian lexeme солодкий ([Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) II:657, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:666).

Source: 271[{S.v. SMG υγρός, a inner-Greek borrowing from Ancient Greek ὑγρός 'wet'.}]
Justification: Learned re-introduction (or adaptation) of Ancient Greek ὑγρός 'wet', lacking the characteristic loss of initial unstressed vowels found elsewhere in Modern Greek (cf. [Andriotis 1999](src-271)).

Source: 600[3: 388{It is a loanword from Middle German made 'worm'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Middle Low German made 'worm' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600) III:388).
Parallel loans from Persian. The Pamir words (Wakhi, Sarikoli) are probably loaned from Tajik.

Source: 360[I:127{Loanword from Russian, cf. discussion s.v. Lith. gadyna 'Zeit, Stunde, Jahr' < WRu. godina and s.v. Lith. gãdyti 'versöhnen, aussöhnen' < WRu. goditъ.}]
Justification: Loanword from Russian год 'year' (cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) I:127).

Source: 680[120{S.v. Khw. pwst 'skin' from OPers. pawastā, as NP pūst.}];172[105 (Vol. II)]
Comment: Original meaning probably "Hülle, Decke". Note that Persian requires accent shift to *páu̯astā- for *áu̯a > ō and au̯á > awa (Klingenschmitt 2000: 214f.).

Source: 271[1068{S.v. πετσί, from Medieval Greek πετσί(ο)ν < πέτσ(α)-ίον or *πεσκίον, diminutive of Hellenistic Greek πέσκος 'skin'.}];66[1180{S.v. πέσκος 'skin, rind'. No clear etymology.}];270[890{S.v. πέσκος 'peau, écorce'. An obscure technical term. Cf. entry for references to various suggestions.}]
Justification: Ultimately from a diminutive formation from Ancient Greek πέσκος 'skin, rind', no clear etymology outside of Greek, cf. [Andriotis 1999](src-271):1168, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):890, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1180.

Source: 587[291{Cf. s.v. λάργος 'weit' (SMG ἀλάργα adv.), loan from It. largo.}]
Justification: Based on a loanword from Italian largo ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):291). Tsakonian αλάργα is treated as a separate loan event in [cognate set 6167](cog-6167).

Source: 587[301-302{S.v. Italiot *λούκιον 'Feuer', loanword from dialectal Italian lúći 'fire'.}]
Justification: Loanword from dialectal southern Italian ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):301-302).

Source: 172[I:684{S.v. Ved. tvác- 'Haut, Fell| die Haut des lebenden Menschen oder Tieres, in Kontrast zu cárman-'. Probably to be connected with Hitt. tu̯ekka- 'Körper, Person'.}];141[654{S.v. *tu̯ek- 'sichtbar sein' (not in IEW), cf. Hitt. dukkāri 'ist sichtbar, wird gesehen| ist wichtig'. Cf. n1, comparing the root-noun *tu̯ek- 'das sichbare, äußere Form' in Hitt. tuekk(a)-/tukk(a)- 'Körper', Ved. tvác- 'Haut' (cf. Schindler, BSL 67 (1972) 36-7).}]
Justification: Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:684, [LIV²](src-141) 654).

Source: 352[720-721{S.v. OLith. óda (1), odà (4) 'Haut, Leder, Fell' (BSl. Latv. âda 'Balg, Fell, Haut, Haut auf einer trocknenden Flüssigkeit, Hülse', etc.). No further connections outside of (East-)Baltic.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 720-721).

Source: 345[731-732{S.v. TochB ṣmare (adj.) 'smooth, even, slippery| greasy'| (n.) 'oil', from PIE *smer(u̯)os (cf. ON smjǫr 'grease, butter', OE smeoru 'grease', OIr. smiur 'marrow').}]
Justification: According to [Adams 2013](src-345):731-732 to be derived from PIE *smer-(u̯)o- 'fat, grease'.

Source: 345[778{S.v. TochB staukk- 'swell, bloat, be distended', probably from PIE *steu̯g- 'stiff' if to be connected with Balto-Slavic cognates (Lith. stúkti 'stand tall', Russian stugnuti 'to freeze' < *become stiff(?).}];269[{I have been unable to confirm the Balto-Slavic comparanda listed by Adams for this etymology (also not in LIV²).}];341[962{Cf. s.v. staukk- 'anschwellen', 'swell' (no etymological discussion).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Tocharian. Cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):778 for some proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda, but no etymology given by [Malzahn 2010](src-341). Not in [LIV²](src-141).

Source: 341[941-942{S.v. TochAB säl- '(auf)fliegen', 'fly, arise', certainly cognate with Lat. salīre 'jump, leap', etc.}];345[751-753{S.v. TochB (2) säl- 'throw, throw off, throw down| lay to rest [of the dead]', an inner-Tocharian formation to the same root as (3) säl- 'fly', which with TochA säl- reflect PToch. *säl- from PIE *sel- 'move quickly' (cf. Skt. ucchálati 'hurries forward', Gk. ἅλλομαι 'leap, jump', Lat. saliō 'spring, jump', etc.)}];141[527-528{S.v. 1.*sel 'sich losschnellen, springen' (IEW 899).}]

345[687-688{S.v. TochB śänm- 'bind [something] (up/together), tie [something] into a bundle| bind [something] on| establish| proclaim| determine (rules)| produce [of fruit]'. Of uncertain etymology, cf. entry for various uncertain proposals.}];341[920-921{S.v. TochB śänm- 'binden, fesseln| festlegen (Regeln)', 'bind| determine (rules)', of uncertain etymology, cf. for discussion of various proposals.}]
Justification: Of uncertain etymology, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):920-921 and [Adams 2013](src-345):687-688 for discussion of various proposals.

Source: 345[243-244{To PIE *kʷel- via a derived form *kʷl-eu̯-T-(sk̑e/o-) to account for Proto-Tocharian *kläutk- (cf. TochA lutk-).}];341[626-628];141[386-388{Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).}]
Justification: Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 386-388 to a causative-iterative stem *kʷolh₁-éi̯e- derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn'.

Source: 345[318{S.v. TochB tute 'yellow', which reflects a conflation of PIE *dʰuHto- and its *h₁en-stem counterpart *dʰuHte-h₁en-. PIE *dʰuHto- is exactly equivalent to Skt. dhūtá-, the past participle of Skt. dhū- 'shake, agitate, cause to tremble' from PIE *dʰeu̯H- '±(make) rise as a cloud of dust'. In Tocharian the meaning 'yellow' presumably arose from 'covered with dust'.}];141[149-150{Cf. s.v. *dʰeu̯H- 'rasch hin und her bewegen, schütteln' (IEW 261-3).}]
Justification: According to [Adams 2013](src-345):318 to be derived from PIE *dʰeu̯H- 'move quickly back and forth' via a semantic development 'make arise (a cloud of dust)' > 'covered in dust', 'yellow'.
Parallel loans in Modern Greek dialects from Turkish toz 'dust'.

Source: 79[373-374, 376, 382{S.v. Arm. kṙtʻ-un-kʻ '(anatom.) back'. [HAB](src-740) II:669 posits an unattested form *kiṙtʻn or kuṙtʻn and offers no etymology. The form is probably comparable CArm. kuṙn '(anatom.) back| side', which in turn – if the original semantic meaning was 'curved/bending body-part' – may be related to CArm. kor 'curved, crooked' (disputed etymology, cf. s.v.).}];740[II:669]
Justification: Connections outside of Armenian uncertain. Within Armenian probably to be connected with Classical Armenian kuṙn '(anatom.) back; side', which in turn – if the original semantic meaning was 'curved/bending body-part' – may be related to Classical Armenian kor 'curved, crooked' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):376, cf. id. 382, 373-374). [HAB](src-740) II:669 offers no etymology. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kuṙ(-tʰ)-un-].

Source: 79[466-467{S.v. Arm. mēǰ 'the middle| (anatom.) 'back' < PIE *medʰi̯o- via PArm. *meidi̯o- through regular palatalization *-dʰi̯- > -ǰ- and anticipation of *-i- or development *-e- > *-ei- before a palatal.}];274[465-466{S.v. *medʰ- 'mittlerer' (IEW 706f., EIEC 380). Arm. mēǰ- < *médʰ-i̯o-.}]
Justification: Cf. Classical Armenian mēǰ- 'the middle; back' < PIE médʰ-i̯o- ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):466-467, [NIL](src-274) 465-466).
Of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:546-547 for various proposals; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) or [Olsen 1999](src-180)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰam-ii̯o-].

Source: 180[441{Arm. hogi 'spirit', with the etymologically identical ogi 'spirit, breath' ([IEW](src-49) 847) probably going back to *p⁽ʰ⁾ou̯(H)io- from the root *p⁽ʰ⁾eu(H)-.}];276[{Cf. հոգի hogi 'spirit, soul| ghost' (< ?*pou̯(H)-i̯o-)| հեւամ hew-a-m 'I pant| puff, am breathless' (< *peu̯(H)-)| perhaps also հոգ hog 'care| worry, anxiety| mental pain' (< ?*pou̯(H)-os-) if originally from hypothetical "panting| (state of being) breathless, anxious".}];540[466{S.v. Arm. ՀՈՎ, from the IE inherited vocabulary and to be connected with the same root *pou-, *p(h)u- found in Arm. hewal, hog, hogi, etc.}];740[III:115-116]
Justification: To be connected to the same root as Classical Armenian hogi 'spirit, soul', hewam 'I pant, puff; am breathless', probably from a formation *p⁽ʰ⁾eu̯H-io- ([Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):466, [HAB](src-740) III:115-116, [Olsen 1999](src-180):441). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 79[415-416{S.v. Arm. hoł 'earth, ground, soil| burial, plot, cemetery' Since Meillet connected with OCS polje, Russ. póle, etc. 'field', Russ. pol 'floor', which are usually derived from PIE *pelh₂- 'wide and flat' (cf. Hitt. palḫi- 'wide', OHG feld 'field', Lat. plānus 'level, flat, plane, even', Lith. plónas, Latv. plãns 'thin, flat', etc.).}];274[562-564{Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).}]
Justification: Generally derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'wide, flat' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):415-416, [NIL](src-274) 562-564 for further discussion).

Source: 180[962{S.v. daṙn 'bitter' ([HAB](src-740) I:624f., [IEW](src-49) 258. "[E]tymologically unclear. The alleged relation to the verb daṙnam 'turn' (with reference to Gk. οἶνος τρέπεται 'the wine turns sour' as a semantic parallel) is no more than a possibility."}];740[I:624-625]
Comment: Unknown etymology.
Justification: No known etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):962, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:624-625). [MM: Proto-Armenian *daṙ-in-].

Source: 180[811{Arm. gēǰ 'moist' < PIE *gʰei̯dʰ(u)i̯-.}];79[210-211{S.v. Arm. gēǰ 'moist| lascivious' subst. 'moisture'. Generally connected with Ru. žídkij, SCr. žídak 'liquid, watery' as though from PIE *gʷʰe/oidʰ-io- (cf. [HAB](src-740) I:551, and others). Cf. for further discussion of the possibilities of stem formation.}];740[I:550-551]
Justification: Generally derived as though from PIE *gʷʰe/oidʰ-i̯o- and connected with Slavic lexemes for 'liquid, watery', although some debate remains over the more precise aspects of the stem formation in Armenian (see [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):210-211 for detailed discussion, cf. also [HAB](src-740) I:550-551, [Olsen 1999](src-180):811).

Source: 141[269-270{S.v. 1. *h₂er- 'sich (zusammen)fügen' (IEW 55-8).}];79[112{S.v. Arm. aṙnem 'to make, create' < PIE *h₂er- 'to fix, put together'.}]
Justification: Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂er- 'to fix, fit together' ([LIV²](src-141) 269-270, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):112).

Source: 79[249-250, 344-345{S.v. ka- 'to stay, stand, halt| to stop, rest| to wait, to appear| to dwell'. The etymology is handled s.v. ek- (suppl. aor. to gam 'to come'). It is widely assumed that Arm. ka- reflects *gʷeh₂- with an original meaning 'to step, put the foot, arrive, establish oneself' (cf. Skt. gā- 'to put the foot down (while going), step, stride', Gk. ἔβην 'to get ready to go', etc.).}];141[205{S.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4).}]
Justification: Generally assumed to reflect a derivative of PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step', originally a suppletive aorist stem to PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):249-250, 344-345, [LIV²](src-141) 205).

Source: 79[63{S.v. ayrem 'to burn'. There are two possible etymologies, either (1) derived to PIE *h₂eh₁- as a denominal verb from *ayr- 'fire' compared to Av. ātar-/āθr- 'fire', Lat. āter 'black, dark', OIr. āith 'furnace', Palaic ḫā- 'be hot' (cf. Hübschmann 1897:418), or (2) from PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. αἴθω 'to kindle, burn', Skt. edh- 'to set alight, kindle| shine' (Jasanoff 1979:145, Viredaz 2003:85). Alternatively Klingenschmitt (1982:98n16) has assumed an Iranian loanword.}];558[98n16];564[418];581[145];582[85]
Justification: Two possible Indo-European etymologies, either (1) derived to PIE *h₂eh₁- as a denominal verb from *ayr- 'fire' compared to Av. ātar-/āθr- 'fire', Lat. āter 'black, dark', OIr. āith 'furnace', Palaic ḫā- 'be hot' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):418), or (2) from PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. αἴθω 'to kindle, burn', Skt. edh- 'to set alight, kindle; shine' ([Jasanoff 1979](src-581):145, [Viredaz 2003](src-582):85). Alternatively [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):98n16 has assumed an Iranian loanword. (Cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):63).

Source: 353[228{S.v. Lith. kárštas 'hot, quick tempered'. The etymology of these Baltic forms is unclear. The suggestion of [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):278 that we are dealing with the root *kers- in Lat. currere 'run' is unlikely.}];352[455-456, 480-481{S.v. OLith. kárštas 'heiß, hitzig, eifrig' (BSl. Latv. kar̂sts 'heiß', etc.), generally considered an o-grade to-formation to the family of words surrounding Lith. *ker̃šti 'in Streit geraten, in Zorn geraten', for which some formal reconstructions are possible, but comparisons outside of Baltic remain uncertain.}];531[278{Cf. s.v. Lith. ker̃šti, no certain etymology.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 455-456, [Derksen 2015](src-353):228, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):278.

Source: 382[1260{Cf. s.v. SMG σέρτικος, based on a loanword from Turkish sert.}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish sert 'hard, stiff', cf. SMG σέρτικος 'heavy, strong (of blends of tobacco and cigarettes)' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1260).

Source: 464[{κατσίνου [katsinu]. Uncertain etymology. Pernot (1934:350) suggests τσακίνου (= MG τσακίζω ‘break’) with ad hoc metathesis tsak- > kats-, which is unlikely because τσακίνου [tshacinu] should have given [tshatsinu] (tsitacism). Maybe *κατα-δάκ- ‘to bite’ (see LSJ) > κα-(δ)ακ-ίνω (a remodelled present) > κατσίνου| for the deletion of intervocalic -δ- cf. πούα ‘leg’ < AG acc. πόδα, ύο ‘water’ < AG ὕδωρ etc. Apocope of prepositions (e.g. κατά- > κα-) is a well known Doric feature. Also cf. Pont. δάκινω ‘bite’, collateral form of Pont. δάκω ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):200).}]
Justification: Uncertain etymology (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). See further discussion below.
Loanword from Turkish göğüs 'chest'.
Loan from Turkish, cf. Turkish dövüş 'fight' (n.), dövüşmek 'to fight'.
Loanword from Turkish puslu 'misty, hazy'.

Source: 452[623{Cf. s.v. Capp.Gk. μεϊβά, cf. Turk. meïve.}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish meyve 'fruit', in turn a loanword from Persian mive 'fruit' (cf. [Dawkins 1916](src-452):623).

Source: 141[154{Cf. s.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273).}];66[1506-1507{S.v. τρέχω 'to run, hurry', from IE *dʰregʰ- 'run' (cf. Gk. τροχός 'wheel', OIr. droch < *dʰrogʰ-o-).}];587[510{Cf. s.v. τρέχω 'laufen'.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek τρέχω 'run' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):510). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'run' in [cognate set 5027](cog-5027).
Loanword from Turkish göl 'lake'.

Source: 382[915-916{S.v. νερό. From Medieval Greek νερό(ν) < Ancient Greek νηρόν, 'fresh', with meaning transferred from the collocation νῆρον ὕδωρ 'fresh water'.}];66[1018{S.v. νηρός 'fresh', from νεαρός 'young, youthful, tender, fresh' (with vowel contraction of medial -εα- > -η-. The r-formation is paralleled by Armenian նոր nor [lexeme 28560](lex-28560) 'new' < *neu̯-eró- vel sim.}];587[348{S.v. Gk. νηρὸν 'Wasser' > It. ta nerá 'le pioggie', nerò tu kjerú 'acqua piovana'.}]
Justification: A secondary semantic development from Modern Greek νερό 'water'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in [cognate set 1563](cog-1563).
Loanword from Turkish yuvarlak 'round'.

Source: 452[684{S.v. keskin 'sharp', a loan from Turkish.}]
Justification: Loan from Turkish keskin 'sharp' (cf. [Dawkins 1916](src-452):684).
Romance loanword, cf. Standard Italian coda 'queue, tail'.

Source: 382[1021{S.v. παίρνω, from Medieval Greek ἐπαίρνω, a remodelled present stem from Ancient Greek ἐπαίρω 'lift up'.}];66[23-24{S.v. ἀείρω 'to raise'.  No etymology outside of Greek, but internal reconstruction on dialectal variants and derived vocabulary point to a pre-form *h₂u̯er-.}];460[76{Cf. s.v. ΑGk. αἴρω > Tsakon. αζ̌ίκ̔ου (=*αρ-ίσκω).}];141[290{S.v. *h₂u̯er- 'hängen (intr.)' (IEW 1150). Only Greek and Albanian, cf. Alb. vjerr 'hängt auf' from a secondary e-grade thematic present.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes continuing Medieval Greek ἐπαίρνω, a remodelled nasal-present stem continuing Ancient Greek ἐπαίρω 'lift up' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1021), except Tsakonian: Peloponnese αζ̌ίκ̔ου < *αρ-ίσκω ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):76), both continuing the basic verbal root of Ancient Greek αἴρω ~  ἀείρω 'to raise'. Probably further to a PIE root *h₂u̯er- 'to hang' ([LIV²](src-141) 290, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):23-24).

Source: 382[899{S.v. SMG μπούτι, a borrowing from Turk. but 'thigh'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish but 'thigh, rump' (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):899).
Loan from Turkish kanat 'wing'.
Loan from Turkish kötü 'bad'.

Source: 452[607{Cappadocian Greek καρι̯ά, from earlier καρδία 'heart'.}];66[644{Cf. s.v. καρδία 'heart' < PIE *k̑ēr(d), gen. *k̑rd-(i)os 'heart'.}];274[417-423{Cf. s.v. *k̑ḗr, k̑r̥d-´ n. 'Herz' (IEW 579f.).}]
Justification: Semantic shift from Ancient Greek καρδία 'heart' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):607), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):644, [NIL](src-274) 417-423, and 'heart' in [cognate set 6458](cog-6458) for further etymological connections.

Source: 269[{The Tsakonian forms must reflect a Doric lexeme φύσκα 'large intestine' (cf. Att. φύσκη, which would have yielded **φύσκη [ˈfiski] in SMG).}];460[589{S.v. AGk. φύσκη 'Magen, (Dick)darm' > Tsakon. φούκ᾽α 'Unterleib, Bauch'.}];66[1599-1600{Cf. s.v. AGk. φῦσα 'breath, bellows' with derivative φύσκη 'intestine, sausage'. The exact root of the base noun φῦσα cannot be precisely determined. Comparisons have been made with Arm. pʻowkʻ 'breath, wind', but φῦσα cannot be derived from *φῡκ-i̯α-. Attempts at connections with other potential IE cognates are dubious.}]
Justification: Tsakonian lexemes as though from Ancient (Doric) Greek *φοῦσκα 'lower abdomen, stomach'; no certain further etymology ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):589), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1599-1600).

Source: 151[329f.{Proto-Celtic *krundi-. Lucht discusses two possibilities, which ultimately derive this word from the PIE root *(s)ker- ‘to turn’/'drehen, biegen' (IEW 935ff.): 1. as a derivation of the extended root form *(s)kreu̯- (cf. IEW 938). 2. taken as *kr-undi with a suffix also found in e.g. Latin rot-undu-s. 3. De Bernardo Stempel 1999 proposed to view it as Proto-Celtic *kro-n-do- where a -do-morpheme was affixed to an n-suffixed root form.}];49[933-947{5 PIE roots *(s)ker-: 1. *sker- as a basis for words meaning 'einschrumpfen, runzeln| rauhe Haut, Schorf, Kruste| vertrocknet, mager, verkümmert'| probably to 3. sker-. - 2. (s)ker-, skerə-:skrē- 'springen, herumspringen', "also and more accurately" '(sich) drehend bewegen, schwingen', "not to be separated from (s)ker- 'drehen'". - 3. (s)ker- 'drehen, biegen'. - 4. (s)ker-, (s)kerə-, (s)krē- 'schneiden'. - 5. (s)ker- onomatopoetic. -  He derives OIr. cor, curu (acc. pl.) 'circles', Cymr. cor-wynt, Bret. cor-uent 'turbo' of the root 3. (s)ker- 'drehen, biegen'. For this root, Pokorny (p. 936) also gives the extended forms *(s)kreng- and *(s)kregʰ-, *(s)krengʰ-. Of the latter, he derives inter al. OIc. hringr, OE, OS, OHG hring 'ring' as well as OCS krǫgъ 'circle', Curch Slavonic kruglъ, okruglъ 'round'. On these cf. [cognate set 2444](cog-2444).}];50[227f.{Proto-Celtic *krundi- 'round, compact'. Matasović favours the view that *krundi- is related to *krumbo- 'round, compact', as *krundi- < *krum-di-. He assumes that the PIE etymology for these words is "unknown", and that they thus might be loanwoards from a non-IE language.}];141[{LIV² does not refer to the IEW root 3. *(s)ker- 'drehen/biegen'/'to turn, to bend'. }];296[C-253{The feminine forms of the adjective MW cron (vs. mask. crwn) and OBr. cron have lowering of the root vowel which is normally caused by *-ā and thus unexpected in the case of the i-stem *krundi-. According to LEIA, this is the result of an assimilation to the o/ā-stems.}];301[123{Attested in cron gl. tornatili 'round', cronn main gl. cylindro, salin cron 'la saline ronde' and cronion pl. gl. assiles 'rounded, round'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic obscure, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:253, [Lucht 2007](src-151):329-330, [Matasović 2009](src-50):227-228 for further discussion.

Source: 172[I:226-227{S.v. Ved. úras- 'Brust' (IIr. cf. YAv. varah- n. 'Brust', paiti.varah- 'Nacken', pərəθu.varah- 'mit breiter Brust', MP var, NP bar). The IIr. word for 'breast' certainly belongs with urú- 'wide' and váras- 'width, extent'. The unusual weak stem of the s-stem úras- etc. probably originated in an ablauting paradigm. Cf. s.v. Ved. urú- 'weit, umfängreich, breit, gegräumig' (IIr. cf. YAv. vouru- in compounds, e.g. vouru.dōiθra- 'dessen Augen weithin gehen', Oss. urux, etc.), from PIE *u̯r̥H-ú- (~ *u̯erH- in váras-, *u̯erH-ú- in Gk. εὐρύς 'weit, breit', etc.).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes to be connected with the same root found in Vedic úru- 'wide' ([EWAia](src-172) I:226-227), cf. 'wide' in [cognate set 3090](cog-3090) regarding the root reconstruction *h₁u̯erH-.

Source: 105[356{S.v. Alb. qen 'dog' "A relatively late loanword from Lat canem id. […] or, rather, its Balkan continuations (Rum caine), reflecting no traces of rhotacism in Tosk."}];571[107{S.v. Alb. qen, -i| qene 'dog' "qen is regarded as a loan from Lat canis 'dog'| so [Meyer 1891](src-585):222, Tagliavani (1937:94), Haarmann (1972:47). The failure of Lat n to rhotacize implies lateness of borrowing or a Balkan origin, note Rum caină 'dog'."}]
Comment: Loan from Latin.
Justification: Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ([Huld 1984](src-571):107, [Orel 1998](src-105):356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. Gheg in [cognate set 5505](cog-5505)).

From Classical Armenian gēš 'corpse, carrion, dead body' (subst.); 'bad, ill' (adj.), further etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):944; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), for older etymological proposals cf. [HAB](src-740) I:550, [IEW](src-49) 1134).

Source: 156[I:560{S.v. Oss. īx | ex 'лед', from Proto-Iranian *aixa- (cf. Pers. yax, Kurd. yex, Yag. īx, Sogd. *yīx, Chores. ēx, Av. aexa-).}];49[301{Cf. s.v. 2. ei-s-, ei-n- 'Eis, Frost', where the Iranian lexemes are taken to be cognate with the 'ice' words in Germanic.}];165[271{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *īsa- 'ice'. There are no certain cognates outside of Germanic. "Av. aexa- can only be related if it continues a form *h₁eiH-ko- that developed into *HeikHo- by laryngeal metathesis."}];331[I:140-143{S.v. Proto-Iranic *aixa- : *īxa- 'лёд, холод, мороз'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ([ESIJa](src-331) I:140-143). Traditionally connected by [IEW](src-49) 301 to Proto-Germanic *īsa-, but this proposed cognacy remains uncertain, cf. [EWA 5](src-398):195-199, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):271.

Source: 260[51{It is a loanword from Middle German bom, boum.}]
Justification: Loanword from Middle High German bom, boum 'tree' ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):51

Source: 79[362-363{S.v. Arm. *kic-, kcanem 'to bite| to sting'. No etymologies accepted by [HAB](src-740) II:597. [IEW](src-49) 356 accepts a root reconstruction *gei̯d- 'stechen, kitzeln' in view of possible Germanic cognates (OIc. kitla, etc.), but in view of the lack of further proposed cognates outside of Germanic, and formal difficulties (cf. the proposed root structure with two voiced-unaspirated stops) the etymology remains uncertain.}];740[II:587]
Justification: No certain etymology (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):362-363, [HAB](src-740) II:587 for further discussion).

Source: 740[2:275];180[440{"Lełi or łełi (-woy, -wov) 'gall' cannot be traced back to an IE proto-form straightaway, but from a reconstruction *g̑ʰelh₃iom one would expect *jełi which might have been subject to (tabuistic?) distant assimilation or influenced by the semantically related leard 'liver'."}]
Justification: From Classical Armenian lełi 'gall', generally considered of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref HAB II:275), but cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):440 who suggests a reconstruction *g̑ʰelh₃iom 'yellow (substance)' > †jełi which could have been subject to a tabooistic deformation or influenced by semantically related leard 'liver'. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *leł-io-].
Origin unknown (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:202). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) or {OIsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃei̯r(-)ana-].

Source: 141[400-401{S.v. 1. *leh₂- 'bellen' (IEW 650-1).}];83[306{S.v. Proto-Iranian *raH- 'to howl, cry', from PIE *leh₂- 'to bark' (cf. Skt. rā- 'to bark' , Gk. λαίειν 'to sound' (Hes.), OCS lajati, Russ. lájat', Lith. lóti, Alb. leh-, Lat. lātrāre 'to bark').}];172[II:443{Cf. s.v. Skt. rā- 'bellen', IIr. cf. Pkt. rāi 'lärmt', etc., YAv. gāθrō.raiiaṇt- 'die Gesänge ausschreiend', Parth. ghr'y- 'prahlerisch sein', Khot. rrai- 'lärmen', BSogd. r'y 'weinen', Oss. ræjyn/ræjun 'bellen', etc., probably from PIE *leh₂- (cf. Lat. lātrāre, Lith. lóti, OCS lajati 'bellen', etc.).}];558[104-105{Arm. la- probably belongs to a group of probably not independently created sound-symbolic words, e.g. Alb. lot f., best. lodja 'Träne' (< *låti- < *lāti- or *lēti-), Lat. lāmentum 'Wehklage'. As a proto-form then we may consider *lah₂- or lah₂-i̯e/o-. Less probable is a connection with  Gk. κλαιε/ο-, Alb. (Old Gheg) kla-.}]
Justification: Armenian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₂- 'to bark'. The assignment of Armenian forms to this class follows [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):104-105, [LIV²](src-141) 400-401 (not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)); for Iranic cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:443, [Cheung 2007](src-83):306.

Source: 141[668-669{S.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4). Arm. forms probably go back to *u̯i-né/n-h₁-.}];740[I:567-568];558[95-96{Arm. gna- < Proto-Armenian *gina- or *guna- is phonologically ambiguous. Several root etymologies are possible. Most probable is a connection with Arm. ga- 'kommen' from *gʰh₁-.}]
Justification: Root etymology uncertain, probably connected in some way with Armenian gam 'to come' from PIE *gʰeh₁- according to [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):95-96 (cf. [cognate set 580](cog-580)); [LIV²](src-141) 668-669 suggests deriving from a nasal present stem *u̯i-n(e)-h₁- to *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach'. See [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):95-96 for further discussion. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), cf. [HAB](src-740) I:567-568.

Source: 141[590-592{S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (IEW 1004-8). Cf. n3 Arm. er-tʻa 'gehen' < *per-steh₂- (cf. Klingenschmitt 1982:96, 104).}];79[263{S.v. Arm. ertʻ(an)am 'to go| set off'. Usually linked with Gk. ἔρχομαι [cognate set 5151](cog-5151), usually linked to a root *h₁er-.}];558[96, 104]
Justification: From Classical Armenian ertʿa- 'go'. The etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 590-592, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):96, 104 to *per-steh₂-, but cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):263 who instead prefers a denominal formation from ertʿ 'going, journey' as though from a nominal stem *h₁r-sk-ti-, and in which case could be root-cognate with Greek ἔρχομαι 'come, go' in [cognate set 5151](cog-5151).

Source: 540[392{Apparently from *gr̥g̑-u-| Cf. Gk. γοργός 'terrible, fierce'| OIr. garg(g) 'fierce'.}];740[II:552];746[379];50[151-152{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *gargo- 'rough' ([IEW](src-49) 353 *garg̑o-, cf. OCS groza 'horror', Arm. karcr 'hard'). "This is presumably an onomatopoeic or expressive word, which may explain the a-vocalism in the root. The parallels in other IE languages may be accidental similarities."}];66[283{Cf. s.v. Gk. γοργός 'grim, fierce, terrible'. Not to be related with OIr. garg(g) 'raw, wild', OCS groza 'shiver', nor to Arm. karcr 'hard' (pace [Pedersen 1906](src-746):379).}]
Justification: Origin uncertain. Since [Pedersen 1906](src-746):379 connected with Greek γοργός 'grim, fierce, terrible', Old Irish garg(g) 'raw, wild' (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:552, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):392), but this proposed etymology is rejected by [Beekes 2010](src-66):283, [Matasović 2009](src-50):151. Not in [Olsen 1999](src-180) or [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 79[552{S.v. Arm. pind 'firm, tight, strong, fastened'. Comparing Skt. bandh- 'to bind, fasten', Gk. πεῖσμα 'bond, fetter', Goth. bandi 'fetter, bond', etc. < IE *bʰendʰ-. "Initial p- points to Grassmann's Law. Although we have no further secure examples of this law in Armenian … I see no compelling reasons for rejecting this etymology." Alternatively an Iranian loan (cf. Khot. piṇḍaa- 'lump'. [Olsen 1999](src-180):965 considers the word of unknown origin and adds "Probably Iranian".}];180[965{"Probably Iranian", but ultimately of uncertain origin.}];740[IV:82]
Justification: Of uncertain origin, possibly an Iranian loanword ([Olsen 1999](src-180):965, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:82). [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):552 considers the proposed etymology to PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind, fasten', but this requires the assumption of Grassmann's Law in Armenian, for which there are no other parallel examples.

Source: 79[280{S.v. Arm. ənkenum 'to cause to fall, throw down', generally connected ([HAB](src-740) II:128) with Arm. ankanim 'to fall down' < *sn̥gʷ- although there is some debate over the precise stem formation. Alternatively [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):249 and others propose a compound of ənd- and *ke- which they derive from *ges- (cf. OIc. kasta 'werfen' and Lat, gerere 'to carry on', but this is not convincing.}];740[II:128]
Justification: Generally derived as a causative to the same root as Armenian ankanim 'I fall' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):280, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:128), ultimately from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go down, sink'. Cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):280 for further discussion.

Source: 180[624{The phonetic shape is suggestive of an Iranian borrowing, but there is no certain etymology.}];740[II:409]
Justification: Denominal from Armenian xorh 'thought', probably an Iranian borrowing but there is no certain etymology (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):624, [HAB](src-740) II:409). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xorh-].

Source: 79[470-471{Cf. s.v. Arm. mit 'mind, intelligence', related to Gk. μήδεα 'counsels, plans, arts' (pl. of unattested *μῆδος), μέδω 'to protect, rule over', μέδομαι 'to provide for, be mindful of| to plan, contrive, devise', μήδομαι 'to be minded, intend| take care, keep watch', Lat. medeor 'to heal, cure', Umbrian mers 'law, justice', etc. The Armenian a-stem may be built on a neuter plural collective *mēd-es-(e)h₂-.}];296[M:48-49{Cf. s.v. OIr. mid- thème verbal 'juger, adjuger, estimer'| the same root *med- is found in Brythonic (cf. W meddu 'posséder, être maître', medd 'dit-il', meddwl 'pensée, jugement', arfedd 'dessein'. It continues a root developed in many Indo-European languages (cf. Lat. modus 'mesure', modius 'boisseau' meditārī 'réfléchir', Umbr. meřs 'droit', Osc. med-diss 'juge', Goth. mitan 'mesurer', mitōn 'réfléchir', etc., Greek μέδω 'he prends soin, je gouverne sur', μέδομαι 'je m'occupe de, je médite', μήδεα 'pensées, desseins', μήδομαι 'je prends soin').}];141[423{Cf. s.v. 1. *med- 'messen, für Einhaltung sorgen, sich kümmern' (IEW 705-6).}]
Justification: Armenian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *med- 'to measure' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):470-471, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:48-49, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 423).

Source: 79[10{S.v. Arm. azdr 'thigh'. Etymology uncertain. The proposed connection to Skt. sákthi- 'thigh', Gk. ἰσχίον 'hip joint' requires a metathesis *sa- > as- and a voicing of the stops and is highly improbable. Jahukyan and [Olsen 1999](src-180):149 independently propose a connection to Gk. ὀσφῦς, -ύος 'loin or loins, lower part of the back', etc. although noting that the formal divergences are not easily overcome. This proposed connection to the IE word for 'bone' is also improbable.}];180[149{"Azdr (-er, -erē) 'thigh| shoulder (of an animal)' is faintly reminiscent of both the group of oskr with cognates and Gk. ὀσφῦς 'Hüfte, Lende', but the formal divergences are not easily overcome"}]
Justification: No clear etymology. Perhaps from PIE *h₃st-dʰ- (cf. Gk. ὀσφύς 'loins') an extension of PIE *h₃ost- 'bone' but this remains an uncertain conjecture ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):10, [Olsen 1999](src-180):149).

Source: 79[275{S.v. Arm. zist 'the fleshy parts between the loin and the knee'. "Meillet p.c. apud [HAB](src-740) II:96 interprets zist as z- + hisdo- < IE *si-sd-o-, redupl. of *sed- 'to sit' as seen in nist 'seat, site'".}];180[72{Arm. zist 'thigh, flank', probably a compound comparable to nist 'nest' containing the prefix z- so that while nist is that which you sit in, zist may be interpreted as what you sit on (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:96).}];740[II:96]
Justification: From Classical Armenian zist 'thigh, flank', probably to be interpreted as a compound of Proto-Armenian collocation *(ə)z- < PIE *h₂mbi̯V 'around, about' and *hist-o- < PIE *si-sd-e/o- 'to sit' ([HAB](src-740) II:96, [Olsen 1999](src-180):72, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):275).

Source: 558[81{Arm. martncʻi- probably derives from a pre-Armenian root *mr̥d- or *smr̥d-. Further etymological connections are uncertain, perhaps *mr̥-d- stands beside *mr̥-h₂- in Gk. μάρναται 'kämpft' < *mr̥-n-h₂-, or to Lat. mordēre 'beißen', etc.?}];740[III:289];180[90{Arm. mart 'fight, struggle, combat' (vb. martncʻim, marteay cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):81, [IEW](src-49) 736) probably to a root or root variant *(s)merd-/(s)mrd-, cf. perhaps Lat. mordeō 'bite', OHG smerzan.}]
Justification: Denominal to Classical Armenian mart 'fight, battle, combat'. Connections outside of Armenian uncertain, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):81, [Olsen 1999](src-180):90. [HAB](src-740) III:289 for tentative speculations. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 740[III:184-185{S.v. Arm. ճանճ (čanč), a Caucasian loanword.}];180[939{Of uncertain origin, perhaps Caucasian (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:184f.).}]
Justification: Caucasian loanword, cf. e.g. Mingrelian č̣anǯi 'fly' ([HAB](src-740) III:184-185, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):939). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃantʃ-i-].

Source: 141[495{S.v. *pteh₂k- 'sich ducken' (IEW 825), based on tʻakʻeaw 'verbarg sich' < from an original fientive formation *pth₂k-éh₁/h₁- (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):70, 78-79, 84).}];558[70, 78-79, 84, 262{Classical Armenian tʻakʻowcʻanem 'verbergen' is derived from Classical Armenian tʻakʻcʻi- 'sich verbergen', to be derived from an enlarged -sk̑e/o- formation based on PIE *pth₂k-eh₁-.}]
Justification: Classical Armenian tʿakʿowcʿanem, secondarily derived from Classical Armenian tʻakʻcʻi- 'hide oneself' as though from PIE *pth₂k-eh₁-sk̑e/o- (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):79, 262; [LIV²](src-141) 495).
Apparently a loan from Tungusic according to [HAB](src-740) II:437. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsa(-)tsuk-a-].

Source: 296[N:8{S.v. OIr. nél 'nuage'. Attempts to reconcile to a pre-form *nebʰlo- (cf. Lat. nebula, Gk. νεφελή, OHG nebul, OE nifol) is phonetically impossible. Thurneysen's hypothesis of *miglos (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη) with the change of *m- > *n- under the influence of nigíd 'he washes' is less plausible. The Brythonic forms (Welsh niwl, nifwl, Corn. niul may be borrowings from Lat. nūbilus (< nībulus), and according to [IEW](src-49) 315 Ir. nél is borrowed from Brythonic.}]
Justification: The Goidelic forms from OId Irish nél cannot reflect an inherited formation based on IE *nebʰ-l- and consequently a loanword from Latin is generally assumed, possibly via Brythonic (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:8, [IEW](src-49) 315).

Source: 141[301{S.v. *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (not in IEW).}];558[215-216{The paradigm present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair of Proto-Armenian or Proto-Indo-European roots. Probably present to *h₃erg- 'umkommen' (cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'umkommen, zugrunde gehen', ḫarnik- 'vernichten, zugrunde richten'), aorist stem to *per- 'schlagen' (Lith. per̃ti '(im Dampfbad) mit dem Badequast schlagen', Latv. pḕrt 'schlagen, prüglen| (mit dem Badequast) schlagen'.}]
Justification: The Classical Armenian present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair in Proto-Armenian. The present stem may be derived from *h₃erg-, cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'perish', ḫarnik- 'destroy' ({ref LIV² 301, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):215-216 for further discussion). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 540[350{derive the item from PIE *(s)keu̯-, invoking Skt. sku-nā-ti 'covers', OHG scūr 'shower, precipitation', OE scēo 'sky| (lit.) *cover(ing)'| Lat. cucullus 'head-covering'| etc.).  The development *sk- > խ- x- has been, however, phonetically controversial, if completely abandoned.}];276[{Uncertain etymology. A denominative of խուփն xowpʿ-n 'lid, cover| (en)closed, shut'.  The semantic development apparently proceeded from "to close, shut, cover" presumably via "to shut abruptly or forcefully, slam' to 'attach, fasten, nail| (also) fire, shoot' and eventually 'hit, strike, beat'.}];180[211{Arm. xowpʻ 'cover' (vb. xpʻanem, xpʻi/xpʻem, -ecʻi < *sk⁽ʰ⁾upp-? cf. [IEW](src-49) 956).}];740[II:423]
Justification: Originally denominal to Classical Armenian xowpʿ-n 'cover', further etymology uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:423, [Olsen 1999](src-180):211, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):350 for various proposals). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xupʰ-].

Source: 156[I:141{Cf. Pahl. pūtak 'rotten', and in general [cognate set 2877](cog-2877).}];564[256{S.v. փուտ pʻut 'Fäulniss, Eiter, faul, verdorben, morsch, unecht', a borrowing from Persian (cf. NPers. pūda 'verfault', Pahl. pūtāk 'rotten, decayed, putrid').}];180[913{An Iranian loanword, cf. MP pwtk' 'foul, rotten', subst. Av. pūiti- 'Fäuligwerden, Verwesung'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Iranic, cf. Avestan pūiti- 'rottenness', Middle Persian pwtk' 'foul, rotten' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):256, [Olsen 1999](src-180):913). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰut-o-].

Source: 740[II:125-126];558[114-115];141[479{S.v. 2. *peth₂- '(auf)fliegen' (IEW 825-6). NB: "Präsens ?*pt-né/n̥-h₂- > arm. ən-tʻanam 'laufe'.}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}]
Justification: Probably from Armenian *əndi (< PIE *h₂ent-i) prefixed to *tʰana- (< PIE ?*pt-n(e)-h₂-) ([Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):114-115, [LIV²](src-141) 479). Alternatively [HAB](src-740) II:125-126, [IEW](src-49) 908 proposes to PIE *sent- 'gehen' but this is phonologically difficult (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):114).

Source: 564[242{Cf. s.v. վազք vaz-kʻ 'Sprung, Springen' whence vazem 'springen'| probably a loanword from Iranian (cf. NPers. bāxtan, bāzam 'spielen', Iranian root *vaz-).}];180[908{Armenian vaz* 'leap, jump', a loan from Iranian (cf. Parth. wz- 'blow (of the wind| move swiftly, fly', Av. vaz- 'fahren').}]
Justification: Either a direct borrowing from Iranic or a secondary denominal verb from a borrowed substantive vaz 'leap, jump' (cf. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):242, [Olsen 1999](src-180):908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯az-].

Source: 180[944{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:280).}];740[IV:280]
Justification: Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):944, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:280). [MM: Proto-Armenian *stu(-)u̯er-a-].

Source: 66[1223, 1239{S.v. πόρσω 'forward, beyond, far away from something, away' and πρόσω 'forward, onward, further'. There are two possible etymologies for Ancient Greek πόρρω. One option is that it is identical with Lat. porrō 'forward' if < *p(o)rsō(d), with an ending like other adverbial formations ἄνω 'upwards', κάτω 'downwards'. Alternatively Chantraine (1968-1980) prefers to derived πόρρω from πόρσω (from πρότι, πρός, with metathesis) since both words have a similar sense semantically.}];270[929{S.v. πόρσω 'en avant, devant, loin', [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) compares Lat. porrō < *porsō 'en avant'| one could also derive πόρσω from πρόσω, a better explanation, by metathesis of the syllable containing the liquid from πρόσω.}]
Justification: Two possible etymologies: Either identical to Lat. porrō 'forward' if from *p(o)rsōd, alternatively from *πόρσω, derived from πρός 'towards' (< PIE *próti) with a commonly found liquid metathesis. Since both derivations have similar semantic paths of derivation it is difficult to choose between the two possibilities ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):929, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1223).

Source: 274[69-81{S.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f., EIEC 513). Ved. dyáu- reflects a stem formation *di̯-éu̯-.}];172[I:750-752{S.v. Ved. dyav- 'Himmel, Himmelsgott, Vater Himmel, Tag', from PIE *di̯éu̯-/diu̯- 'Himmel, Tag' (also personified 'Himmelsgott'), (cf. Gk. Ζεύς, Lat. *dius in nudius tertius 'vorgestern' < *'und es ist der dritte Tag', from the root *dei̯- 'leuchten'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original u-stem *di̯éu̯- ~ *diu̯- 'sky, day' to PIE *dei̯- 'be bright, shine' ([NIL](src-274) 69-81, [EWAia](src-172) I:750-752).

Source: 353[273{S.v. Lith. lãpas 'leaf, sheet, metal plate', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *lop-, cf. Proto-Slavic *lopъ > Bulg. lop 'tulip-like aquatic plant in lake Ohrid, white water lily'.}];458[16:56-57, 16:77{S.v. Proto-Slavic *lopěnъ/*lopěno, derivatives in -ěnъ, -ěno to Proto-Slavic *lopъ (ΙΙ) (cf. Bulg. dial. лопъ), which is to be connected with Lith. lãpas, Latv. lapa 'лист'.}]
Justification: Lexemes derived from a Proto-Balto-Slavic root *lop-; no certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2015](src-353):273, [ESSJa](src-458) 16:56-57, 16:77).

Source: 81[441-442{S.v. Proto-Slavic *rygati 'belch', from PIE *h₁rug- (cf. Lith. ráugėti 'belch', Gk. ἐρεύγομαι 'belch out, disgorge, discharge, vomit, roar', Lat. rūgīre 'roar', ērūgere 'disgorge noisily, belch').}];79[714-715{Arm. orcam 'to vomit' from *orucam vs. Gk. ἐρεύγομαι < PIE *h₁reug-. [Etymology only mentioned in the discussion of aspects of historical grammar. There is no dedicated lemma to Arm. orcam in Martirosyan (2010).]}];141[509{Cf. s.v. *(h₁)reu̯g- 'rülpsen, erbrechen' (IEW 871). [Armenian and Slavic cognates not mentioned.]}];180[764{Assumes a form PIE *pro-h₁rug- > *oruruc- > Arm. orc- to account for the initial vocalism of Arm. orcam.}];259[536{PS *rygati is related to Lithuanian rū́gti, raugeti, Latin erugō, erugere and Greek ερευγομαι. PIE *reu̯ɡ-. Some Slavic cognates (e.g. Polish rzygać) show an irregular vowel change (*y > *i).}]
Justification: Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g- 'to belch, vomit' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):764, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):714-715, [Derksen 2008](src-81):441-442, [Boryś 2005](src-259):536, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 509).

Source: 740[III:555-556];50[244{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *lorgo- 'trace'. "[[Pedersen 1909](src-307):105] compares Arm. ołork 'smooth', but this is more likely to be a chance similarity."}];307[105];180[965{S.v. Arm. ołork 'smooth, soft' ([HAB](src-740) III:555f., [IEW](src-49) 679), of uncertain origin. "usually internally connected with lerk 'bald, hairless| soft' and derived from the same root as Old Irish lerg, translated by RIADict. by 'sloping expanse, stretch (of ground etc.)', in particular 'hillside' and 'surface, level', further lorc 'trace, track, path'. The semantic connection between Arm. and Celtic is quite weak, and even though the two Arm. words are probably interrelated they are difficult to account for in detail, so until we have a more striking external cognate it remains to be seen if they belong to the inherited part of the vocabulary."}]
Justification: Generally further connected with Classical Armenian lerk 'hairless, bald' and sometimes compared with Old Irish lerg 'surface, level' (cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):105), but this proposed etymology is quite uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):965, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):244). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), cf. [HAB](src-740) III:555-556.

Source: 180[964{Of uncertain origin, (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:58f.).}];740[III:58-59]
Justification: From Classical Armenian hartʿ 'flat, even, level', further etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):964, cf. [HAB](src-740) III:58-59).

Source: 364[983{S.v. OAlb. merr 'nehmen', which Schumacher & Matzinger relate to a present stem *arne/a-, which is thematicised from *arnu- and compounded with a preverb *me-. The stem *arnu- is in turn to be derived from PIE *h₂r̥-néu̯-/*h₂r̥-nu- also continued in Ancient Greek, Avestan, and Armenian from 2. *h₂er- 'nehmen, erwerben' (LIV² 270-271).}];105[246{S.v. Alb. marr 'to take, grasp', which O. derives from PAlb. marna, a deverbative based on the heteroclitic word for 'hand' preserved by Gk. μάρη, Lat. manus (without attempting to refute other proposed etymologies).}];369[257-258{S.v. Alb. marr 'nehmen, ergreifen| einannehmen, erhalten, bekommen'. The etymology of the word is disputed. Previous proposals have included connections to (1) Ved. mr̥śáti 'berühren' and/or Gk. μάρπτω 'fassen, ergreifen' (so Meyer 1891:261)| (2) Gk. μάρη 'Hand' (so Jokl 1911:53-54), PIE *mar-n(i̯)o-A₁ (so Huld 1984:89-90), a blending of a preverb m- (comparable to the prep. *me- 'mit' with the root underlying Gk. ἄρνυμαι, Arm. aṙnowm, thus from *(s)me(d)-A₂ernō 'take away' > PAlb. *me-harno- (so Hamp 1965:140). Demiraj offers yet another possibility, to PIE *merh₂- 'packen' (via *mr̥h₂-V-).}];571[89-90{S.v. Alb. marr, mora, marrë 'take, grasp'. Root etymology unclear, all earlier etymologies see a root *mar- with an n-present.}];661[53-54];666[140];269[{Root etymology disputed (cf. esp. Demiraj 1997:257-258). Possibly related to cognates from PIE 2. *h₂er- (LIV² 270-271 [cognate set 8293](cog-8293), so Hamp 1965:140, Schumacher & Matzinger 2013:983), but alternative etymologies are also possible.}];585[261]
Justification: Root etymology disputed (cf. esp. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):257-258); possibly related to cognates from PIE 2. *h₂er- ([LIV²](src-141) 270-271, so [Hamp 1965](src-666):140, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):983), but alternative etymologies are also possible (cf. also [Meyer 1891](src-585):261, [Jokl 1911](src-661):53-54, [Huld 1984](src-571):89-90, [Orel 1998](src-105):246).

Source: 673[103-104, 113{S.v. No. 49 kʻałcʻr 'sweet'| typically explained as a blend of two adjectives *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' and *dluku- 'sweet' (Ačaṙyan HAB IV 546). De Lamberterie (1990:502), considers alternatively *saldu- as part of the source. Not in Martirosyan 2010.}];740[IV:546]
Justification: Uncertain etymology. Typically explained as a blend of *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' and *dluku- 'sweet', *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' or *saldu- 'salty' ([Clackson 2017](src-673):113, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:546). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰałtsʰ-u-(r)].

Source: 564[99-100{S.v. Classical Armenian անոյշ anoiš 'wohlreichend, schmackhaft, angenehm, lieblich', a borrowing from Iranian (cf. NPers. nōš 'grati saporis, suavis, dulcis').}];180[864{S.v. Classical Armenian anoyš 'sweet', a borrowing from Iranian (cf. MParth. ʾnwšyn 'ambrosial, sweet' MP ʾnwš 'immortal', Av. anaoša- 'dem kein Verderben droht, unsterblich').}]
Comment: Loan from Iranian.
Justification: A loan from Iranic ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):99-100, [Olsen 1999](src-180):864). [MM: Proto-Armenian *anoi̯ʃ-i-].

Source: 540[642{traditionally connected with Proto-Slavic *bedro- 'thigh| hip'}];180[942{Of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:101, [IEW](src-49) 96).}];740[IV:101]
Justification: Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):942), traditionally connected with Proto-Slavic *bedro- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 96, [HAB](src-740) IV:101, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):642). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *port-o-].

Source: 276[{Perhaps a reflex of PIE *molh₂- (or *mu̯elh₂-) 'grind' (cf. Gk. μύλη 'mill').  Cf. also մամուլ ma(-)mowl 'press(ing machine)', մղեղ mł-eł 'dust', etc.}];740[III:331-332];180[953{Regarding młeł 'chaff| powder, ashes, dust': Of unknown origin.}]
Justification: Origin uncertain, perhaps from *m(u̯)elh₂- 'grind' (cf. młel 'chaff, dust', mamowł 'press(ing machine))? Cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):953, [HAB](src-740) III:331-332. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *muł-].

Source: 673[112{Arm. paranocʻ 'neck', possibly explained by [Pisani 1934](src-675):55 as a blend of an Iranian loanword and the second element connected with the Germanic neck words. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).}];675[55];276[{Perhaps ultimately a derivative of պար par 'circle| dance| choir, troop' (cf. պար- par- 'around' a calque on Gk. περι- or Lat. circum-, e.g. պարագրեմ par-a-gr-e-m 'I circum-scribe')| i.e. Proto-Armenian *par-an- (lit.) 'circling, circled| twisting, twisted' (cf. պարան par(-)an 'rope') → par-an-ocʿ-  (< PIE *-sko/a-), the latter suffix denoting instrument/tool. The connection of պար par with Gk. περί, Skt. pári, etc. (< PIE *per-i) is controversial.}];740[IV:56-57]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:56-57). Perhaps a blend of an Iranic loanword and an element connected to the Germanic 'neck' words according to [Pisani 1934](src-675):55, cf. [Clackson 2017](src-673):112. For further discussion cf. [HAB](src-740) and note by Macak to this class. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *par-].

Source: 564[189-190{S.v. Arm. ճերմակ čermak 'weiss', a loan from Iranian (cf. NPers. čarma 'equus albus').}];740[III:198]
Justification: Loanword from Iranic ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):189-190, [HAB](src-740) 3:198). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃerm(-)aka-].

Source: 79[390-391{S.v. Arm. hast 'firm, steady, standing still, tough| thick, dense, broad', since Hübschmann connected to the Germanic word for 'hard, steady, strong, dense' (OIc. fastr, OHG festi, fasti, Engl. fast, etc.)| possibly also Sanskrit pastyà-. On the basis of the limited distribution and the vowel -a-, not a PIE word. Possibly from a European substratum.}];180[201{S.v. hast 'firm, strong' ([IEW](src-49) 789), a cognate of ON fastr, etc. OHG festi 'firm' and may be derived from a vocalic stem *pastV-. Note that a *-tó- participle *ph₂k̑tó- to the root *pah₂k̑-/*pah₂g̑- 'fest machen' would probably yield the same result.}]
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian hast 'firm, steady, tough; thick, dense', generally connected with Germanic lexemes for 'hard, steady, strong, dense' (OIc. fastr, OHG festi, fasti) from PIE *past- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):201, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)390-391, but preferring the hypothesis of an old European loanword in PIE on the basis of medial *-a-).

Source: 180[941{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:517f.).}];740[II:517-518]
Justification: Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941), perhaps a Semitic loanword according to [HAB](src-740) II:517-518 (cf. Akkadian kūšu 'skin', Arab. qašʿa 'dry skin' [< Sumerian kuš 'skin']). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kaʃ-ii̯a-].
From Classical Armenian kayṙi, of uncertain origin ([HAB](src-740) II:507-509, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):380). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).
Loanword from Persian پست past 'low, inferior, small' (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:77 [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):636).

Source: 540[595{posit *k̑u̯ōk-o- from PIE *k̑eu̯(-k)-  ("aufflammen, ergluehen"| LIV², 331) presumably attested in Gk. κύκνος 'swan', Ved. śukrá- 'bright, white| pure', etc.}];740[III:541]
Justification: From Classical Armenian šowkʿ 'shadow', further etymology uncertain ([HAB](src-740) III:541, cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):595 for a more recent proposal). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), no etymology given in [Olsen 1999](src-180):17. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ʃukʰ-o-].

Denominal to Classical Armenian vax 'fear, dread; steep place, precipice'. Further etymology uncertain ([HAB](src-740) IV:294-295; not in [Olsen 1999](src-180) or [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯ax-].

Comment: Unknown etymology.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krem 'to bear, to carry'. Further etymology uncertain. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ki/ur-].

Source: 382[1259{S.v. SMG σέρνω, from Ancient Greek σύρω with regular development of /i/ > /e/ before /r/, and remodelled as a nasal present in -νω.}];66[1424-1425{S.v. AGk. σύρω 'to draw, trail, drag, pull, ravish, sweep', probably with AGk. σαίρω 'sweep' if both reflect a root *tuer- 'sweep', in which σύρω reflects *tur-e/o- with analogical *σ- (rather than *tuor-e/o- with Cowgill's Law as per [Vine 1999a](src-719):569ff.).}];141[655{Cf. s.v. *tu̯er- 'aufrühren, erregen, antreiben' (IEW 1100). [No mention of proposed Greek cognates.]}];719[570-571{Derives Gk. σύρω < *tu̯or-i̯e/o- (> *tu̯ur-i̯e/o- via Cowgill's Law, with zero-grade *tur-i̯e/o- yielding σαίρω).}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. [Vine 1999a](src-719):570-571, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1424-1425).

Source: 81[243{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite' (ESSJa XII 65-66). In comparison to Baltic forms (Lith. ką́sti, Latv. kuôst) Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd-. If this Balto-Slavic is inherited, it would reflect a stem *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-. If this is so, then the root might be a nasalised variant of the root underlying Skt. khād- 'chew, bite, eat' and Arm. xacanem 'bite'.}];353[231-232{S.v. Lith. ką́sti (3.sg. kánda), Latv. kuôst 'bite', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *konʔd- (cf. Proto-Slavic *kǫsati 'bite'). The Proto-Balto-Slavic root might be formally be accounted for from either PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾-.  This may have been a nasalised variant of the root *k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂d- found in Skt. khādati 'bite, chew, eat' and Arm. xacanem. Earlier proposed connections to Gk. κνώδαλον 'wild animal' and κνώδων 'sword, (pl.) teeth of a sword or a javelin' are unlikely due to formal difficulties (cf. Beekes 2010:279, 726-727).}];458[12:65-66{PS *kǫsati, derived from PS *kǫd-. It has no certain further etymology beyond the Balto-Slavic.}];352[464-465{S.v. OLith. ką́sti 'beißen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kuôst 'beißen'). The (East-)Baltic group seems to based on a PIE root *kʷend-, which has no conclusive connections in related languages. From the Slavic languages words like OCS čęstь 'Teil, Anteil, Lohn', Pol. kęs 'Bisschen, Stück', kąsać, kęsać 'beißen', Russ. kuśat' 'beißen' can be gathered, which show a root form without final *-d. Further comparisons with Ved. khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen', Arm xacanem, 'beißen, stechen', are much sketchier.}]
Justification: Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the Balto-Slavic acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):243, [Derksen 2015](src-353):231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to [ALEW](src-352) 464-465, but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 12:65-66.

Source: 172[II:360{S.v. Ved. múkha- 'Mund, Gesicht, Antlitz'. No secure connections outside of Indo-Iranian.}];442[585{S.v. 10158 Ved. múkha- n. 'mouth, face' RV.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic múkha- 'mouth, face'. No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:360, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):585 no. 10158).

Source: 165[374{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'muzzle' > Old Frisian mūla m. 'muzzle, mouth'. Extra-Germanic connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'muzzle', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):374, not in [Boutkan & Siebinga 2005](src-82)).

Comment: Not in Morgenstierne (2003).

Source: 352[135{S.v. OLith. brìnkti 'anschwellen, aufquellen' (BSl. Sloven. nabrẹ́kniti 'anschwellen, aufquellen', Ru. brjáknut' (dial.) 'Wasser ziehen, im Wasser aufquellen', Pol. nabrzęknąć 'anschwellen, dick werden', from PIE *bʰrenk- 'anschwellen', (cf. ON bringa 'Brust').}];353[100-101{S.v. Lith. brìnkti 'swell, bloat, grow dry', from Balto-Slavic *brinʔk- (cf. Proto-Slavic *bręknǫti 'swell').}];141[95-96{S.v. *bʰrenk- 'anschwellen' (IEW 167). [Without Baltic cognates.]}];81[62{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *bręknǫti 'swell' (ESSJa III 23), from PIE *bʰrnk- (cf. OIc. bringa 'chest').}]

66[1599-1600{S.v. φῦσα 'breath, bellows'. The exact root of the base noun φῦσα cannot be determined. Comparisons have been made with Arm. pʻowkʻ 'breath, wind', but φῦσα cannot be derived from *φῡκ-i̯α-. Attempts at connections with other potential IE cognates are dubious.}]
Justification: A verbal derivative of Ancient Greek φῦσα 'breath, bellows', further connections outside of Greek unclear (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1599-1600)

Source: 275[{Middle Breton niveraff is first attested in the Catholicon (1499). It can be analyzed as a denominal verb. The basis niver 'number' is borrowed from Latin numerus. This borrowing took place early, cf. Old Breton nimer 'number'. Middle Breton niveraff thus is either inherited from Old Breton or formed productively from niver.}];309[538{Cf. s.v. Bret. niver 'nombre' from Old Breton nimer, corresponding to Cornish nyver, Welsh nifer, and Irish uimhir, all borrowed from Latin numerus.}]
Justification: Lexemes based on loans from Latin numerus 'number', cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):538).

Source: 309[596{S.v. Bret. poultr 'poudre', like Corn. polter a borrowing from Old French poldre (< Lat. pulverem).}]
Justification: A borrowing from Old French poldre, itself ultimately from Latin pulverem, ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):596).

Source: 79[323-324{S.v. Arm. xacanem 'to bite, sting'. Uncertain. Traditionally connected with Skt. khā́dati 'to chew, bite, eat, devour', Greek κνώδαλον 'wild or hurtful animal', Lith. ką́sti, kándu 'to bite' ([HAB](src-740) II:317-318). The connection of non-Indo-Iranic forms to Skt. khā́dati, etc. is however uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:451-452). Cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):210 for various attempts to explain the voiceless affricate -c- to support the traditional etymology.}];740[III:317-318];558[210];172[I:451-452{Cf. s.v. Ved. √khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen, verzehren'. Cf. NPers. xāyīdan 'kauen' if from *kʰād-, Baluči khāδαγ 'eat', Khot. khaca 'food' (if from *xad-čā). Further connections are not certain.}]
Justification: Traditionally connected to Vedic khā́dati 'to chew, bite, eat, devour' ([HAB](src-740) III:317-318, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):210), but there are no certain cognates for Vedic khā́dati outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:451-452). See [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):323-324 for further discussion.

Source: 442[210{S.v. 3943 *khōla- (2) 'cavity, hollow'. 2. *khōlla- 2. 3. *khōḍa- . 4. *khōra -- 2. [Cf. Par. khur ʻ cave ʼ IIFL i 265] (> N. kholo 'small river, valley')}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):210 no. 3943 *khōla- (2) 'cavity, hollow', further etymology uncertain.

Source: 442[388{S.v. 6788 Ved. dhā́ra- (2) 'stream' in dhā́ra-pūta- RV., adj. 'streaming down' Suśr., m. 'heavy rain' Hariv. 2. dhā́rā- 1 f. 'stream, flood' RV.}];172[I:788-789{S.v. Ved. dhā́ra-¹ 'Strom, Strahl, Gus', perhaps from *dʰń̥H-reh₂- to √dhan-, originally the same as Ved. dhā́ra-² 'Schneide (des Schwertes, des Messers)' (cf. YAv. dārā- 'Klinge', tiži.dāra- 'mit scharfer Schneide', Khot. dārā- 'Schneide' CSogd. xγry d'r 'sword-blade', Pašto lōr 'Seite, Rand', from IIr. *dʰārā- 'Klinge, Schneide').}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic dhā́ra- 'cutting edge', etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):388 no. 6788, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:788-789).

Source: 172[II:83-84{S.v. Ved. √pay-ⁱ¹ 'schwellen, strotzen, voll sein, reichlich strömen', from PIE *pei̯(H)- (cf. Lith. pýti 'melk werden, Milch bekommen', Gk. πιμελή 'Fett, Schmalz').}];141[464-465{S.v. 1. *pei̯H- 'anschwellen' (IEW 793).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' ([EWAia](src-172) II:83-84, [LIV²](src-141) 464-465).

Source: 180[963{S.v. Arm. kełt 'filthy| filth'. Of unknown origin ([HAB](src-740) II:570f.).}];740[II:570-571]
Justification: Derived from Classical Armenian kełt 'filth'. Further etymology obscure ([Olsen 1999](src-180):963, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:570-571). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełt-].

Comment: Unknown etymology. (e)i̯-n-
Justification: Of uncertain etymology.

Source: 79[398-399{Cf. s.v. Arm. haw₁ 'bird', connected with Lat. avis, -is, and other words belonging to the PIE word for 'bird' (Gk. αἰετός < *awi-etos 'eagle', Skt. váy- YAv. vaii-, etc.).}]
Justification: A nominal compound, lit. 'bird-produce'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Armenian Arm. haw 'bird', continuing PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):398-399). PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg' is considered by some to be a vr̥ddhi-derivative of this stem (cf. 'egg' in [cognate set 28](cog-28) for further discussion).

Source: 180[895{Arm. mirg 'fruit' < *miδgV- ~ Sogd. mγδʾk 'id.' (cf. [Benveniste 1964](src-745):5).}];745[5]
Justification: From Classical Armenian mirg, a loan from Iranic, cf. Sogdian mγδʾk 'fruit' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):895, [Benveniste 1964](src-745):5). [MM: Proto-Armenian mirg]

Source: 540[511{a compound of (CA) մառ(ն) maṙ(-n) 'fog' and խուղ xowł 'hut, cot' (i.e. a dark place < *sku-, cf. [cognate set 5964](cog-5964)): the first member is derived from *mr̥-no- of (PIE?) *mer- (presumably) 'fade| dim'| cf. Gk. (Hes.) μορτός˙μέλας, φαιός (< *mr̥-to-)| Czech mrknout 'blink (of eyes)' (presumably originally ≈ "black/dim out")| cf. also մայր mayr 'darkness' (e.g. մայր արեւու mayr arew-ow 'sun-set| the west' (< *mr̥-i̯o-).}];180[944{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:262). The proposed connection (cf. [IEW](src-49) 734) with Gk. μεμορυχμένος 'beschmutzt, geschwärzt', Russ. maráju 'schmieren, sudeln' is formally unsatisfactory (cf. also [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:252).}];740[III:262]
Justification: Origin uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):944, cf. also [HAB](src-740) IIi:262, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):511). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *mar-].

Source: 66[331-332{S.v. δίδωμι 'give' < PIE *di-deh₃- 'to give'.}];382[374{Cf. s.v. SMG δίνω, from Hellenistic Greek δίδω with the present stem remodelled as a nasal present stem (cf. also πτύω → φτύνω, λύω → λύνω, κλείω → κλείνω, etc.).}];141[105-106{Cf. s.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5).}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Hellenistic Greek δίδω 'give' (Ancient Greek δίδωμι) with the present stem re-characterised as a nasal present stem δίνω ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):374), further to PIE *deh₃- 'give' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):331-332), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 105-106).

Source: 172[II:764-767{S.v. Ved. sthirá- 'fest, stark, haltbar, hart', probably to be derived from Ved. √sthā- < *steh₂-.}]
Justification: Probably to be derived from Vedic √sthā- 'to stand' < *steh₂- 'to stand' ([EWAia](src-172) II:764-767, [NIL](src-274) 641).

Source: 141[508{S.v. *reu̯dH- 'schreien, weinen' (IEW 867).}];352[847-848{Cf. s.v. OLith. raudóti 'klagen, wehklagen, heulen' (BSl. cf. Latv. raûdât 'weinen, beweinen', OCS rydati, etc.), from PIE *reu̯dH- 'weinen' (cf. Ved. rod⁽ⁱ⁾-, róditi| OAv. rud- (3.sg. raostā) 'weinen', OLat. rudō, -ere 'schreien, brüllen', OHG riozan 'heulen, weinen, trauern', roz 'das Weinen').}];172[II:465-466{S.v. Ved. √rod- 'weinen, beweinen' (cf. IIr. OAv. raostā 'weint, klagt, jammert', YAv. urūδaiiaṇt-), from PIE *reu̯d-H (athematic root present *réu̯d-H-ti/*rud-H-énti), cf. OLith. rausti 'weint', Lat. rudō 'schreie, brülle', OE rēotan 'klagen, weinen', Lith. raudà 'Wehklage', etc.).}];353[377{S.v. Lith. raudóti 'weep, lament' (Latv. raûdât 'weep, lament'), from PIE *(H)roud- (cf. Skt. rudanti 'they weep', Lat. rudere 'roar, bellow', OE rēotan 'weep, lament').}];442[627{For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 10840.2 Skt. rudáti 'weeps' (Ash. ẓū, etc.).}];83[194{S.v. Proto-Iranic *(H)raudH- 'to moan, (be)wail' > Av. raoδ- 'to moan, (be)wail', from PIE *(H)reudH- 'to weep, cry' (reconstructing and initial laryngeal assuming that IE roots cannot begin with *r-), cf. Lat. rudō 'to cry, roar', OCz. ruditi 'to sadden', Lith. raudà, Latv. raûda 'lament', ON rauta 'to roar', OE rēotan 'to complain, to weep'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯dH- 'to howl, to weep' ([LIV²](src-141) 508, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:465-466, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):627 no. 10840, [Cheung 2007](src-83):194, [ALEW](src-352) 847-848, [Derksen 2015](src-353):377).

Source: 598[3: 53{The standard Russian form nebo is a loanword from CS. The native and phonetically regular form, preserved in dialects and in the meaning 'palate' the standard Russian, is nëbo.}]
Justification: Loan from Church Slavonic нєбо 'sky' ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:53).
Loan from Italian petto 'chest'.

Source: 382[318{S.v. Standard Modern Greek γουλιά, a borrowing into Hellenistic Greek from Latin gula 'throat, gullet'.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes continuing a loanword from Latin gula 'throat, gullet' into Hellenistic Greek, cf. Standard Modern Greek γουλιά ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):318).

Source: 66[394{S.v. εἷς 'one' (gen.sg. ἑν-ός) < PIE *sem- 'one'.}];80[750-751{S.v. Hitt. šī- 'one', from PIE *sih₂, an old feminine form to *sem- 'one' which was later replaced by *sm-ih₂, (cf. [Beekes 1988](src-570):79-81).}];79[467-468{Arm. mi 'one', from the PIE feminine stem *sm-ih₂ (cf. Gk. μία '1' f.).}];570[79-81];345[721-722{S.v. TochB ṣe 'one', which together with TochA sa- are derived from PIE *sem- (cf. Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi).}];294[671-679{S.v. *sém- 'vereint| ein' adjectivische Wurzel, inklusiv| Singulare tantum.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Greek, and Armenian pexemes derived from PIE *sem- 'one (collective)' ([LIPP 2](src-294):671-679, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):750-751, [Adams 2013](src-345):721-722, [Beekes 2010](src-66):394, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):467-468).

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâm-viri âṣʹo, also âṣiʹo  NF.  Egg (of bird).  [âṣo]  [OIA. â-ri-:-â- ‘lets go| releases| defecates’  T. 10743 (+| < IE ri- < r̥ 'move away' in ri-: 'flow| melt'| ri-k *'move out| leave| empty'| ri-gh 'move'| ri-kh and ri-˜-kh 'move| crawl'| Kmv. form probably < Aṣkuňu, because of ṣ < ẓ)]}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though from OIA riya- 'release, let go', ultimately from PIE *lei̯- 'slimy; glide', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442): 621.

Source: 296[T:61-62{S.v. OIr. tibid 'il frappe, il se heurte| il frappe un sourire (un rire) à l'address de' No clear etymology| cf. entry for various doubtful suggestions.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:61-62 for various doubtful suggestions.

Source: 141[675{S.v. 2.*u̯el- 'drehen, rollen' (IEW 1140-2)| cf. 2. u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, wallen' [IEW 1140-3].}];364[1008-1009{S.v. vjell 'erbrechen', best connected to PIE 2. *u̯elH- '(sich) wälzen, wallen'.}];105[511{S.v. Alb. vjell 'to vomit', from Proto-Albanian *welwa- and related to Lat. volvō 'to turn' and other cognates.}];571[130{S.v. Alb. vjell 'vomit' to be connected with Lat. volvō 'turn' (for the semantics cf. the phrase 'turn one's stomach'.}]
Justification: Etymology in this class follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1008-1009 to PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 677), but cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):130, [Orel 1998](src-105):511 to 2. *u̯el- 'spin, roll' (cf. Lat. uoluō 'turn', etc.).
Loanword from Italian manco 'useless' (cf. also Albanian: Arbëresh manka 'left' in [cognate set 8517](cog-8517)). [Not in [Rohlfs 1964](src-587)]

Source: 66[1037-1038{S.v. ξύλον 'wood, timber', seems to correspond with Lith. šùlas 'post, pole, stave' < IE *ksulo-, Ru. šúlo 'garden-pole', SCr. šȗlj 'block' < *kseulo- (?). Germanic words like OHG sūl 'style, pole, Goth. sauls 'pillar' have a similar appearance, although the relationship between the Slavic, Baltic, and Germanic words have hardly been explained (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179) s.v. sauls). A European substrate term?}];270[767{S.v. AGk. ξύλον 'bois', one usually connects Lith. šùlas 'bâton, poteau, pilier' postulating IE *ksulo-, and with different vocalism forms in Slavic and Germanic  (Ru. šúlo 'pieu', OHG sūl 'poteau, colonne').}];352[1053-1054{Cf. s.v. OLith. šùlas 'Säule, Pfeiler, Stab' (BSl. cf. OPr. sulis 'Ständer', SCr. šȗlj 'abgesägter Baumstamm, Holzblock', Ru. šúlo (dial.) 'Zaunpfahl', from PIE *ksúlo- 'Holzblock (cf. Gk. ξύλον 'Holz, Baum| Balken, Stock'). Fully unclear is the connection of the Germanic lexemes in the group of Goth. sauls 'Säule', etc.}]
Justification: Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):767, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1037-1038; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.

Source: 452[665{Cf. s.v. Turk. av 'hunting, game' > Capp. ἄβι.}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish, cf. Turkish avlamak 'to hunt' (cf. also [Dawkins 1916](src-452):665).

Source: 452[674{Cf. s.v. deṇiz 'sea', a loanword from Turkish.}]
Comment: Loan from Turkish
Justification: Loanword from Turkish deniz 'sea' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):674).

Source: 81[178-180{S.v. Proto-Slavic *gorьkъ 'bitter' (ESSJa VII 55-56), a derivative from Proto-Slavic *gorěti 'burn', in turn from PIE *gʷʰer- 'become warm, hot'.}];141[219-220{Cf. s.v. *gʷer- 'warm werden' (IEW 493-5).}];458[7: 42, 55-56{Related to PS gorěti 'burn', PIE *gʷʰer-.}];274[196-199{S.v. *gʷʰer- 'warm werden' (LIV 219f., IEW 493ff.).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'become warm, hot' ([NIL](src-274) 196-199, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:42, 55-56, [Derksen 2008](src-81):178-180; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 219-220).

Source: 54[279{S.v. Lat. harēna 'sand'. No etymology.}];316[289{S.v. Lat. harēna 'sable', without certain etymology.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):289, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):279).

Source: 598[3: 102, 105{The Russian word is loan from Church Slavonic, cf. Russian dialectal oboloko.}];607[2: 174{The Belarusian lexeme is a loan from Church Slavonic.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Church Slavonic ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:102, 105, [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 2:174).

Source: 279[405-406{S.v. U.sp. cubrar. Perhaps a Proto-Italic primary adjective *kup-ro- (cf. Lat. cupere 'long for, desire, wish').  Identification made on basis of Varronian gloss ciprum 'bonum' (Varro 1.1.5, 159).}];54[155{Cf. s.v. Lat. cupiō, -ere 'to desire', from PIE *kup-(e)i-, *kup-eh₁- 'to tremble, desire', to which the Umbrian and South Picene forms might be related.}]
Justification: Perhaps to be connected to Latin cupiō, -ere 'to desire', but etymology ultimately unclear ([Untermann 2000](src-279):405-406, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):155).
