Source: 259[507-508{Polish rachować and Kashubian rachòwac / rechòwac are loanwords from Middle German rechen 'count'.}]
Justification: Loan from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):507-508).

Source: 442[463{S.v. 8201 Skt. pipīlá- m. 'ant' RV., °laka- m. 'large black ant' ChUp., pipī́likā- f. 'small red ant' AV., pīlaka- m. 'ant' lex.| also reconstructed *piphīla- . 3. *pippīla- . 4. *pipphīla- . 5. *pippīḍa- . 6. *pilīla-. [Variety of MIA. and NIA. forms for 'ant' may be due partly to its (unknown) non-Aryan origin (EWA ii 285), partly to contamination with kīṭá- and kŕ̥mi-, but mainly to some sort of taboo for a noxious insect. Although there appear to be six main types, not all NIA. forms can be grouped exactly under them]}];399[II:284-285{S.v. Skt. pipīláḥ 'Ameise / ant'. An unclear, probably non-Indic word.}];172[II:132-133{S.v. Ved. pipīlá- 'Ameise', of uncertain etymology.}]
Justification: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes based on Vedic pipīlá- 'ant', of unknown origin ([EWAia](src-172) II:132-133, [KEWA](src-399) II:284-285). The modern forms exhibit six main variants, for which cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):463, no. 8201.

Comment: with variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 316f., no. 5589ff., 5598f.; substrate?

Source: 66[1216{S.v. AGk. ποιέω 'do, make, produce (also of poetry), act', from PIE *kʷi-eu-, *kʷei-u- 'gather, deem' (cf. Skt. cinóti 'arrange, pile, erect', Av. cinuuaiti 'to select' < *kʷi-n(e)u-ti).}];141[378-379{S.v. 2. *kʷei̯- 'sammeln, schichten' (IEW 637-8).}];460[458{S.v. AGk. ποιῶ 'machen' (whence Mod. Cyp. ποιγῶ, ποίω, Pont. ποίου, Tsak. ποίγω).}];81[89{S.v. Proto-Slavic *činiti (ESSJa IV 112-113), as though from PIE *kʷei-n- (cf. Skt. cinóti 'gather, arrange, pile up). In view of the *-n-, the Slavic verb seems to be a derivative of the nominal *činъ (cf. OCS 'row, order, rank, file', Cz. čin 'affair, act, deed', Sln. čin 'act, deed' Bulg. čin 'rank' < *kʷei-no-).}];458[4: 112-115{PS *činiti is ultimately derived from PIE *kʷei̯-n-.}]
Justification: Modern Greek and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE 2. *kʷei̯- 'to gather, pile' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 378-379, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):458, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1216, [Derksen 2008](src-81):89, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:112-115).

Source: 442[637{Cf. s.v. 10991 *laṣṭi- 'stick'. Perhaps originally a blend of Old Indic lakuṭa- 'club' and yaṣṭi- 'stick, pole'?}];172[II:406{Cf. s.v. Ved. yaṣṭí- 'Stab, Keule, Stock', further connections uncertain.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *laṣṭi- 'stick', perhaps a contamination of Vedic yaṣṭí- 'stick, pole' with lakuṭa- 'club' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):637 no. 10991). Further connections are uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:406).

Source: 442[159{S.v. 3120 Ved. kāṣṭhá- n. 'piece of wood' ŚBr.}];172[I:345-346{S.v. kāṣṭhá- 'Holzstück| ein Längenmaß, ein Holzmaß', etymology uncertain.}]
Comment: not finally clear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic kāṣṭhá- 'piece of wood', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):159 no. 3120, [EWAia](src-172) I:345-346).

Source: 259[506{PS *pylŭ < *pū-lo-, derived from PIE *pū- 'blow'.}];593[521{The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *pū- 'blow' or PIE *pūl- < *pū- 'rot' (cf. German faul 'rotten', Lituanian piaũlas 'rotted').}];601[4: 156{The Kashubian lexeme is derived from PS *pyxati 'blow strongly'.}];598[3: 418{The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *p(ʰ)ū- 'blow', cf. Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow', Latvian pùst, pùšu 'blow', Greek  φυ̃σα 'blowing', φῡσιάω, φῡσάω 'blow'.}];165[158{PG *fūla- 'filthy, foul' < PIE *púH-l-o-.}];141[480{*peu̯H- 'rot, stink'.}]
Justification: Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed [LIV²](src-141). Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66). I assume the root *peu̯H-, cf. PG *fūla- 'filthy, foul' [Kroonen 2013](src-165). The meaning 'dust' could develop from 'rotten wood'. Cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593).

Source: 180[936{Arm. caṙ 'tree', of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:446f., unconvincingly [IEW](src-49) 392).}];743[600{Arm. caṙ, perhaps a loanword from Urartian ṣâre 'orchard', cf. Hurr. sar-me 'wood' attested in an Akkadian lexical text, both < PEC *c̣wāl₁hV 'wood, fire-wood| big stick'.}];740[II:446-447]
Justification: Attempts at an Indo-European etymology (cf. [IEW](src-49) 392, [HAB](src-740) II:446-447) are unconvincing ([Olsen 1999](src-180):936). The best etymological proposal so far is the suggestion of a Hurro-Urartian loanword, cf. Urartian ṣârə 'orchard'; Hurrian sarme 'wood' (cf. [Diakonoff 1985](src-743):600). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsar-o-].

Source: 602[5: 33{The Ukrainian lexeme was borrowed through Polish.}]
Justification: Loan from Polish rachować 'to count', itself ultimately a borrowing from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 5:33)

Source: 442[137{S.v. Skt. kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' AV., ʻcup, jar, bowlʼ.}];172[I:300{S.v. Ved. kapā́la- 'Schale, Schüssel, Hirnschale, Schädel'. No widely accepted etymology.}];69[73{S.v. कपाल् kapāl, s. Forehead| scalp| hair of the head. < *kappāla- (cf. Sk. kapā́lam n. crock, skull: Pa. kapālaṁ n., Pk. kavāla- n.)}]
Justification: From Vedic kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' ([Turner 1931](src-69):79, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):137 no. 2744), further etymology disputed (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:300).

Source: 172[II:169{S.v. Ved. √peṣ- 'zerstampfen, zermalmen, zerschmettern', from PIE *pei̯s- (cf. Gk. πτίσσω 'zerschrote, enthülse'. ἄ-πιστος 'unzerstampft', Lat. pīnsere 'zerstoßen', Lith. paisýti 'Grannen abschlagen, enthülsen'.}];442[460, 465{S.v. 8140 pāṣī́- (Sāy.), pāśī -- (Kauś.) f., gen. du. pāṣyṑḥ RV. 'stone, rock' & 8221 *piṣyatē ʻ is ground ʼ. [√piṣ].}];141[466-467{S.v. *pei̯s- 'zerstampfen, (zer)stoßen' (IEW 796).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ([EWAia](src-172) II:169, [LIV²](src-141) 466-467; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8140, 465 no. 8221).

Source: 442[511{Cf. s.v. 9085 *phutta 'insignificant'. [Cf. *phatta-] > Bshk. phut 'fly', phit 'mosquito'| Phal. phutto 'fly', phutti f. 'mosquito'.}]
Justification: As though from Indic *phutta- 'insignificant', cf. Bashkarik phut 'fly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9085). Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 442[580{S.v. 10092 mā́lā f. 'wreath, garland' Gr̥S., mālikā- f. lex. [← Drav., Tam. mālai ʻ wreath ʼ &c.]}];172[II:351{S.v. Ved. mālā- 'Kranz, Blumengewinde, Krone'| probably a loanword, cf. Dravid. Ta. mālai 'Kranz, Gewinde'.}];399[II:628{S.v. Skt. mā́lā f. 'Kranz, Blumengewinde', 'wreath, garland'| not to be separated from Tamil mālai 'Gewinde, Kranz'.}]
Comment: mālikā- f. derived from Late Vedic mā́la- f. 'wreath, garland', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 628; Turner 1062-66, p. 580, no. 10092; ultimately of Dravidian origin
Justification: From Late Vedic mā́la- 'wreath, garland', probably a loanword from Dravidian, cf. Tamil mālai 'wreath, garland' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):580 no. 10092, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:628, [EWAia](src-172) II:351).

Source: 172[I:48{Cf. s.v. Ved. áṅgāra- 'Kohle', probably not to be separated from Lith. anglìs, OCS ǫngь 'Kohle'. Everything else remains questionable. Possible connection to agní-, but the details are unclear.}];442[6-7{Cf. s.v. 125 Skt. áṅgāra- m. n. 'glowing charcoal'.}];352[41{Cf. s.v. OLith. anglìs 'Kohle' (cf. Ved. áṅgāra- 'Kohle'), probably from a noun *ángol-/*angl- or *Héngol-/*Hengl- already in PIE.}];431[{S.v. Kâmviri âŋʹo 'fire' [OIA. ʹa˜gâra- ‘glowing coal’  T. 125].}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Vedic áṅgāra- 'glowing charcoal' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):6-7, no. 125), probably further from a PIE nominal formation *ángol-/*angl- or *Héngol-/*Hengl- (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 41 s.v. OLith. anglìs 'coal'). A further connection to Vedic agní- 'fire' could be possible, but the details remain uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:48). For Nuristan languages, cf. [Strand 1998](src-431).

Source: 79[585-586{S.v. Arm. srun-kʻ 'shin, shank| the leg', continuing Proto-Armenian *sru-u̯an- (cf. GDAbl.Pl srow-an-cʿ) from *k̑rūs-, cf. Lat. crūs 'shank'. An Armenian-Italian isogloss. It is possible that the Armenian words could in principle be loans from Iranian (cf. Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip', NPers. surūn 'buttock' < PIE *k̑louni-| for further cognates cf. Lat. clūnis 'buttock, club, tailbone', Lith. šlaunìs 'hip, thigh', Gk. κλόνιον 'loin(s), hip-joint'), but the semantics are more difficult to account for in such a case.}];54[147{S.v. Lat. crūs, -ris '(lower) leg, shank', from Proto-Italic *krūs-, which with Arm. srunkʻ 'calf, shin' could go back to a root *k̑ruH-, but the Armenian word might be a loanword from Iranian *sraun-.}];180[79{Arm. srownkʻ 'leg, shank' is cognate to Lat. crūs, crūris 'id.'. "The traditional reconstruction *k̑rūs-ni- has been considered a contamination between two original lexemes, *k̑rūs- and *k̑lou̯ni- as continued in Skt. śróṇi- 'hip, buttock', Lith. šlaunìs 'hip, thigh', etc."}]
Justification: Armenian and Italic lexemes generally admitted to be cognates from a PIE s-stem *k̑ruH-s-, vel sim. In principle, however, the Armenian lexemes might be a loan from Iranic (cf. Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip'). Cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):79, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):585-586, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):147 for further discussion.

Source: 540[565];165[383];564[409];180[964{Arm. neł 'narrow', of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:439f.).}];740[III:439-440];276[{Traditionally connected with Proto-Germanic *narwa- 'narrow' (cf. [cognate set 2810](cog-2810)), presumably via *(s)ner-lo- (cf. J̌ahukyan and Sargsyan).  The Germanic form, however, ultimately goes back to PIE *neh₂r-u- (Kroonen).  Moreover, the connection with the Germanic forms was originally based on the once reasonable assumption that Armenian ղ ł may partially reflect PIE *R, which split in the European languages into *r and *l (see, e.g., Huebschmann)| cf. the formerly presumed correspondence between սրունք srownkʿ 'leg| shank' and Lat. clūnis 'rump| buttocks', Lith. šlaunìs 'hip| thigh' (< PIE *k̑lou̯-ni-) vis-a-vis Skt. śroṇi-, Av. sraoni- formerly believed to represent the original state of the proto-language (i.e. PIE *k̑Rou̯ni- > European *k̑lou̯ni-, with սրունք srownkʿ believed to sporadically represent the original rhotic).}]
Justification: Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):964). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). For older, now untenable proposed etymologies to Germanic *narwa- 'narrow', cf. [HAB](src-740) III:439-440, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):565, and further comments by MM in the cognate class citations. [MM: Proto-Armenian *neɫ-o-].

Source: 80[987{S.v. Hitt. u̯attai- 'bird' (hapax in KBo 4.2 ii 32: u̯a-at-ta-e-eš). According to Kloekhorst: "Because of the diphthong stem, it is likely that the word is inherited. Nevertheless, I do not know of any cognates."}]
Justification: Probably inherited from Indo-European in view of the morphology, but there are no known cognates outside of Hittite (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):987).

Source: 442[157{S.v. 3084 Ved. kālá- (2) 'time' AV. 'any fixed point in time' ŚBr. 'fate, death' MBh. "in many [NIA] forms the word or at least its meaning has been influenced throughout by contact with Sanskrit".}];172[I:343{S.v. Ved. kālá- 'Zeitpunkt, günstiger Augenblick, richtige Zeit, Zeit'. IIr. cf. Sogd. kry' 'succession in time', Oss. (Iron) kār 'Alter', Khot. karāvatä 'am Morgen'. Two main possibilities at an etymology: Either (1) an l-form  to kārá- (√kar-) if this means 'Erfolg(s-Augenblick)', 'entscheidende Handlung' (> kālá- 'richtige Zeit') or (2) to √car- (via *kʷōlH-o-?) as something like 'sich drehend, Turnus' ultimately to PIE *kʷelH- 'drehen'.}];323[38{S.v. Paš. kāl 'year', "Cf. T 3084 and Pamir languages kāl 'id.' (Ashkun, Kati, Prasun, Waigali, Dameli, Tirahi, etc.) [E]"}]
Justification: It is unclear whether Josef Elfenbein apud [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):38 is implying that Pashto kāl 'year' is cognate with the Indic lexemes in this class, or that it is a loanword. If cognate, together with the Indic lexemes from Vedic kālá- 'time, point in time' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):157, no. 3084) they would point to a Proto-Indo-Iranic *kālá-. The cognacy of these forms has been tentatively accepted here for now. No further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:343 for a discussion of the main possibilities.

Source: 79[5-7{S.v. Arm. agi 'tail'. No acceptable etymology listed in [HAB](src-740) I:77-78, and [Olsen 1999](src-180):940 considers it among the words of unknown origin. A tentative proposal may be to PIE *ph₂u̯-i̯o- and connected with Arm. haw 'beginning, origin, rise' (< *ph₂u̯-)| cf. kov 'cow' (< Proto-Armenian *kou̯-u- < PIE *gʷou̯-) with kog-i (< PIE *gʷou̯-ii̯o-).}];180[940{Of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) I:77-78).}];740[I:77-78]
Justification: No certain etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):940, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:77-78, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):5-7). Cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):6-7 for further discussion and a tentative proposal to PIE *p(e)h₂u̯- 'small'. [MM: Proto-Armenian *(h)ag-ii̯a-].

Comment: cf. Geiger, W. (1941): An Etymological Glossary of the Sinhalese Language. Colombo, p. 47, no.687: "The initial k for g shows Tamil influence."

Justification: Loan from Persian cf. [cognate set 1831](cog-1831)

Source: 442[273{S.v. 4994 *chapp- 'press, cover, hide'. 2. *chipp- .}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 273, no. 4994 s.v. *chapp- ~ *chipp-; further etymology unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from an Indic stem *chapp- ~ *chipp- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):273 no. 4994), further etymology obscure.

Source: 172[I:119-120{S.v. Ved. árbha- 'klein' (in opposition to mah- 'groß'), 'jung'| arbhaká- 'klein, schwach, jung, im Kindesalter befindlich'. Not to be separated from PIE *(h₂?)órbʰo-, cf. Gk. ὀρφανός, Lat. orbus.}];399[I:52{S.v. Skt. árbhaḥ 'klein, jung, schwach', 'little, young', cf. Gk. ὀρφανός 'verwaist', Arm. orb 'Waise', Lat. orbus 'beraubt', OIr. orpe, Goth. arbi 'Erbe', OCS rabъ 'Knecht', Cz. robě 'kleines Kind'.}];66[1113-1114{Cf. s.v. Gk. ὀρφανός 'orphaned, orphan', from PIE *h₃orbʰ-o- 'orphaned, bereft'.}];54[433{Cf. s.v. Lat. orbus 'deprived of, childless, orphaned' < PIE *h₃orbʰ-o-.}];269[{If the Vedic lexemes are related to Lat. orbus, Gk. ὀρφανός, then they would have underwent a secondary semantic shift (cf. [EWAia](src-172), [Weiss 2006](src-672):256n30). An up-to-date reconstruction of the lexeme would be *h₃orbʰ-o- (cf. [Weiss 2006](src-672), [de Vaan 2008](src-54) s.v. orbus, [Beekes 2010](src-66) s.v. ὀρφανός).}];672[256n30{"The meaning of Vedic árbha-, árbhaga-, arbhaká- 'small, young', if they are related [to Lat. orbis, orbus, etc.], is a later semantic development from the sense 'orphan'."}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Latin orbus 'deprived of, childless, orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphaned' ([EWAia](src-172) I:119-120, [KEWA](src-399) I:52, cf. also [Weiss 2006](src-672):256n30, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):433, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1113-1114).

Source: 442[643{S.v. 11072 *lukka- 'defective'}]
Comment: "B[ashkarik] [sic] lúkuṭ; K[ashmiri] lŏkuṭ, f. °küṭ 'small, shorter, younger'" (Turner q.v.)

Source: 442[738{S.v. 12732 Skt. ślakṣṇá 'slippery, smooth, soft, tender, gentle' AV., 'thin, small'.}];172[II:673{S.v. Ved. ślakṣná- 'schlüpfrig, glatt, weich', from PIE *slegh₂snó- (cf. Gk. λαγαρός 'schlaff, schmächtig' λαγαίω 'freilassen', ON slakr 'schlaff', Lat. laxus 'schlaff, weich', etc.).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic ślakṣná- 'slippery, smooth, soft' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):738), further to PIE *slegh₂snó- ([EWAia](src-172) II:673), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose').

Source: 172[II:673{S.v. Ved. ślakṣná- 'schlüpfrig, glatt, weich' (IIr. slakšna-, cf. parāčī lhanȫ 'schlüpfrig, NPers. lašn 'glatt', Oss. læǧz/liǧz), from PIE *slegh₂snó- (cf. Gk. λαγαρός 'schlaff, schmächtig' λαγαίω 'freilassen', ON slakr 'schlaff', Lat. laxus 'schlaff, weich', etc.).}];156[II:25-26{S.v. Oss. læǧz | liǧz 'гладкий, ровный, равнина', from Ir. *(h)laxš- < IE *sleg-sk- (cf. Ved. slakṣṇa-).}];269[{NB: Abaev further connects the Iranian lexemes to a common IE-base *(s)lei- (cf. Gk. λεῖος) with a root-extension *-g̑-, but whether these are actually the same root is unclear.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *slegh₂snó- ([EWAia](src-172) II:673, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:25-26), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose'). Considered by [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:25-26 to be a variant of PIE *(s)lei̯- with a root-extension *-g̑-, but this conjecture remains uncertain.

Source: 399[II:271{S.v. Skt. picchā 'Schleim, Schaum (von gekochtem Reis und anderen Fruchtkörnern)' / 'scum (of boiled rice and of other grain)' "Wohl eine unarische Wortsippe."}];442[460{S.v.  8152 picchala- 'slimy, slippery' MBh.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8152 s.v. 'slimy, slippery'
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit picchala- 'slimy, slippery' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8152). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loan from a non-Indic source ([KEWA](src-399) II:271).

Source: 84[http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/53367, http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/53354{S.v. Engl. dirty (adj.), derived from Engl. dirt + -y suffix. Engl. dirt in turn from Middle English drit, probably < Old Norse drit 'excrement'.}]
Justification: Derived within English, with metathesis, from Middle English drit + -y suffix, probably originally a loan from Old Norse drit 'excrement' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. dog. Of unknown origin.}];707[275-284{Cf. for a recent attempt to derive Old English *docga from the colour adjective dox 'dark haired, dusky'.}]
Justification: First securely attested as Middle English dogge, generally considered to be of unknown etymology (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84). Cf. [Gąsiorowski 2006](src-707) for a recent attempt to derive Old English *docga from the colour adjective dox (gloss) 'dark haired, dusky'.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. fog (n.) 2., Of uncertain origin. Perhaps a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. OIc. fok 'spray, flurry, windblown cloud (of snow, rain, grass, sand, etc.)', Nw. fok 'flurry, bustle, hurry', Da. fog 'shower, spray, flurry, windblown cloud (of snow, rain, dust, sand', etc.).}]
Justification: Of uncertain origin, perhaps a loan from early Scandinavian ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 66[1101{S.v. ὀρθός 'upright, straight, right, true'. Traditionally from PIE *h₃rdʰ-u̯o- and cognate Skt. ūrdhvá- 'raised, high' and derived from *u̯ordʰ-u̯o-. However, there is no evidence for initial u̯- in Mycenaean where it is expected.}];270[818-819{Cf. s.v. ὀρθός 'debout, dressé', cf. for an overview of competing etymological proposals.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ὀρθός 'upright, straight; right, true'. Further etymology disputed, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):818-819 and [Beekes 2010](src-66):1101 for various competing proposals.

Source: 452[600{From Ancient Greek ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace'.}];66[471-472{S.v. ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace, altar'. No clear etymology.  Identified in antiquity with Lat. Vesta 'goddess of the hearth', but there is not a satisfactory Indo-European etymology linking the two.}];270[379]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace, altar' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):600), no further etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):379, [Beekes 2010](src-66):471-472 for further discussion).

Source: 464[{άψιμο < aor. stem AG ἅψ- (of ἅπτω ‘kindle’, cf. MG αν-άβω) -ιμο| cf. MedG άψιμο ‘fever’.}];66[120-121{S.v. AGk. ἅπτω 'to join, attach| kindle' < PIE *h₂ep- 'join, fit' (cf. Hitt. ḫapp- 'join').}];141[269{S.v. *h₂ep- 'passen, sich fügen' [IEW 50-51]. (Greek cognates not mentioned.)}]
Justification: Pontic Greek άψιμο(ν) a derivative of the aorist stem ἄψ- to Ancient Greek ἄπτω 'to join, attach; kindle', cf. Medieval Greek άψιμο ‘fever’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; not in [Andriotis 1974](src-460)), further to PIE *h₂ep- 'to join, fit' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):120-121, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 269).

Source: 66[472{S.v. AGk. ἐσχάρα 'hearth, house, sacrificing hearth'. Without etymology. There are no known cognates in other IE languages and the word may well be borrowed from a substrate languages.}];464[{(ι)κ̔άρα < AG ἐσχάρα ‘hearth’.}];270[379-380{S.v. AGk. ἐσχάρα 'foyer bas, brasier'. A technical term, apparently a derivative in -ρα, no etymology.}]
Justification: Tsakonian (ι)κ̔άρα < Ancient Greek ἐσχάρα ‘hearth’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):379-380, [Beekes 2010](src-66):472).

Comment: Connected with SMG δουλεύω 'I work' in the sense 'worked, finished' > 'smooth'??? (-MJCS)

Justification: Loanword from Italian anca 'hip'.

Source: 66[1121{S.v. ὀσφραίνομαι 'to catch scent of, smell'. A compound verb containing two roots: *h₃ed-gʷʰreh₁-i̯é-. This class encodes the second member -φραίνομαι < PIE *gʷʰreh₁- 'smell (something)' (cf. Skt. jíghrati, ghrāti 'to smell').}];141[221{S.v. *gʷʰreh₁- 'etw. riechen' (IEW 495-6).}];172[I:520{S.v. Ved. √ghrā- 'riechen', considering the connection to Gk. ὀσφραίνομαι doubtful ("Ohne sicheren Anschluß").}];442[245{Cf. s.v. 4520 ghōṇā f. 'nose, beak (of owl)'| 4531 Skt. ghrāṇá- n. 'smelling'.}];399[I:362{Cf. s.v. Skt. ghoṇā 'Nase / Nose'| probably a dialectal variant of ghrāṇā 'id.'.}]
Justification: Connection to a common root *gʷʰreh₁- follows [LIV²](src-141) 221 and [Beekes 2010](src-66):1121, but cf. the reservations of [EWAia](src-172) I:520. For Modern Indic lexemes attached to this set, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):244, no. 4520, p.245 no. 4531; [KEWA](src-399) I:362. For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element -φραίνομαι.

Source: 66[746-747{S.v. κόνις 'dust, ashes',from IE *konis- (an s-stem), cf. Lat. cinis, cineris from e-grade *kenis-.}];269[{For Tsakonian κορνιαχτέ, Italiot κουρραθτό, cf. Standard Modern Greek  κουρνιαχτός, from Ancient Greek κονι-ορτός 'dust raised or stirred up, cloud of dust' (for ὀρτός, cf. ὄρνυμι 'stir up' < *h₃er-).}];382[706, 1284{Cf. s.v. ModGk. σκόνη, from AGk. κόνις, -εως, connected with Lat. cinis, cineris, cf. also κονιορτός.}];54[115{S.v. Lat. cinis -eris 'residue of fire, ashes, ashes of a dead person'. From an s-stem *ken-is-. de Vaan reconstructs the s-stem as an extension of an earlier PIE i-stem noun *kon(H)-i- / *ken(H)-i- 'dust', of which Latin cinis continues the e-grade. Compares to Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' from the o-grade, TochB kentse 'dust' < *koniso-. Dismisses Walde-Hofmann (1938-1954)'s connection to PIE *kneh₂- 'to plane, rub' (Ancient Greek -κναίω) as 'not compelling).}];270[562{S.v. AGk. κόνις, -ιος (Att. -εως) 'poussière| cendre, sable d'une arène', plausibly connected with Lat. cinis, -eris (with e-grade vocalism).}]
Justification: Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *ken(H)-is- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):562, [Beekes 2010](src-66):746-747, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):706, 1284, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):115). The connection of Albanian hi 'ash' to this class (cf. [cognate set 850](cog-850)) presupposes the reconstruction of an s-mobile root *(s)ken(H)- (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):74, [Orel 1998](src-105):47).
Based on a loanword from Italian largo. Greek: Italiot λάργκα treated as a separate loan event in in [cognate set 5868](cog-5868).

Source: 269[{The same as 'white' [cognate set 1565](cog-1565) in other Modern Greek varieties.  The meaning as ash was a secondary semantic shift from 'white' > 'white ash' > 'ash' in Italiot Greek (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).}];382[223-224{S.v. άσπρος. Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as in the phrase nummi asperi 'rough coins', i.e. new coins which had just been cut and had not yet been worn down from circulation. The semantic development appears to be one via a transferred adjective '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white'.}];66[154{S.v. ἄσπρος 'rough'. A loanword from Lat. asper.}]
Justification: Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):223-224, [Beekes 2010](src-66):154, cf. [cognate set 1565](cog-1565)). In Italiot Greek the semantics further developed 'white' → 'white ash' → 'ash'.

Source: 66[1606-1607{Cf. s.v. AGk. χαίρω 'to rejoice', with related i-stem noun χάρις 'grace', from PIE *g̑ʰer(H)- 'desire, enjoy'.}];382[246{Cf. SMG άχαρος ᾽without grace, elegance, beauty' from Ancient Greek ἄχαρις, remodelled as an o-stem άχαρος.}];141[176-177{Cf. s.v. 1. g̑ʰer- 'Gefallen finden, begehren' (IEW 440-1).}]
Justification: Cf. SMG άχαρος ᾽without grace, elegance, beauty' from Ancient Greek ἄχαρις, remodelled as an o-stem άχαρος ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):246), further to PIE *g̑ʰer(H)- 'desire, enjoy' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1606-1607, [LIV²](src-141) 176-177).

Source: 382[1444{From Ancient Greek (Hellenistic) τρανός, remodelled as an o-stem from earlier τρανής 'clear, distinct'.}];66[1498-1499{Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear, distinct, definite, sure', from PIE *tr̥h₂-n- from PIE *terh₂- 'pass through, cross'.}];270[1128{S.v. AGk. τρανής 'clair, distinct', the sense of the related vocabulary invites a comparison with the adjective τορός 'pénétrant| clair', then the family designating 'percer' cf. τείρω, τέρετρον, τετραίνω, etc.}]
Justification: Cf. Standard Modern Greek τρανός 'very big in power or importance', from Hellenistic Greek τρανός, morphologically remodelled from early Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear distinct' < PIE *tr̥h₂-n-, cf. PIE *terh₂- 'to pass through, cross' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1444, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1498-1499, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1128).

Source: 382[69{Standard Modern Greek αδρός 'sizable, stout' from Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky'.}];66[22{Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky', derived from ἅδην (adv.) 'to one's fill', which is in turn a derivative of PIE *seh₂- 'satiate'.}];270[20, 121-122{S.v. AGk. ἅδην, evidently from the root of ἄω, ἄμεναι| cf. s.v. ἆσαι (aorist infinitive), to go back to a root *seə₂-/*sə₂-.}]
Justification: Cf. SMG αδρός 'sizable, stout' from Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky', further a derivative of PIE *seh₂- 'to satiate' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):69, [Beekes 2010](src-66):22, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):20, 121-122).

Source: 460[285{Tsakonian κουβάνε < Ancient Greek κύανος}];66[793{S.v. κύανος name of a dark blue substance, 'enamel, lapis lazuli, blue copper carbonate' (cf. Myc. ku-wa-no).  Perhaps an early loan from Hittite kuu̯anna(n)- '(blue as) copper, ornamental stone'.}];270[593-594{S.v. AGk. κύανος 'smalt, émail de couleur bleue foncée, azurite'. A loanword, comparable to Hitt. kuwanna- 'azurite'| a Mediterranean culture word according to Kammenhuber, KZ 77 1961, 53.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek κύανος ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):285), the name of a dark blue substance, 'enamel, lapis lazuli, blue copper carbonate', attested already in Mycenaean via ku-wa-no. Possibly an early loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language, cf. Hittite kuu̯anna(n)- '(blue as) copper, ornamental stone' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):594-594, [Beekes 2010](src-66):793).

Source: 464[{Greek: Italiot λαλίτζω < ΜedG λαλ(ώ) ‘1. to talk, to speak, to sing 2. play a wind instrument (by blowing air into it)’ (< AG λαλέω ‘to talk, to speak’) -ίτζω.}];66[827-828{S.v. AGk. λαλέω 'to talk, chat, prattle' (Att.), 'to speak' (Arist., Hell.). A likely onomatopoeic formation in origin, as similarly Lat. lallāre, Lith. lalúoti, NHG lallen.}];270[615-616{Cf. s.v. AGk. λαλέω, rests on an onomatopoeic formation, cf. similarly Lat. lallō, 'chanter pour endormir un enfant', Lith. lalúoti 'bégayer', Ru. lála 'bavard', etc.}]
Justification: A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):615-616, [Beekes 2010](src-66):827-828).

Source: 66[551{S.v. θολός 'mud, dirt, ink of the cuttlefish'.  No clear etymology. Sometimes connected with some Germanic terms for turbidity of the mind (OS for-dwelan 'neglect, forsake', OHG gitwelan 'be deafened, linger', which may be further connected with a Celtic word for blind (cf. OIr. dall), but it not clear whether these IE forms are cognate.}];382[773-774{Cf. s.v. Modern Greek λερώνω 'soil, stain, smear' (vb.), derived from Hellenistic Greek (ὀ)λερ(ός), from Attic Greek ὀλερός, an idiosyncratic dialectal form of θολερός, 'muddy, foul, turbid'.}];270[438{Cf. s.v. AGk. θόλος 'saleté dans l'eau, liquide noirâtre et trouble', going back to *θϝολος and may be connected to some Germanic words that designate turbidity of the mind (cf. OS fardwelan 'négliger', OHG gi-twelan 'avoir l'esprit engourdi', etc.).}]
Justification: No convincing etymology outside of Greek ([Beekes 2010](src-66):551), but [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):438, [Beekes 2010](src-66):551 for older proposals to Germanic lexemes.

Source: 382[604{From Ancient Greek ἀ-κάθαρτος 'un-cleansed'.}];66[614-615{Cf. s.v. καθαρός 'clean, pure'.  No etymology.}];270[478-479{Cf. s.v. AGk. καθαρός 'propre', etc. No etymology.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἀ-κάθαρτος 'un-cleansed' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):604); no further etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):478-479; [Beekes 2010](src-66):614-615)

Source: 382[1565-1566{Standard Modern Greek φτιάχνω 'do' from Medieval Greek φτειάνω with the velar [x] introduced into the present stem from the aorist φτειάξα (i.e. *φτειάκνω > φτειάχνω with regular development of / k / > [x] / _n).  The original present φθειάζω is a de-adjectival verb in -ζω from Ancient Greek εὐθεῖα (fem. of εὐθύς 'straight, direct| straightforward').}];269[{NB: Pontic, Tsakonian, Cappadocian reflect a remodelled nasal-present ευθειάνω [e̞fθiˈano̞] without the intrusive velar from the aorist stem, as found in the SMG form.}];66[479{S.v. εὐθύς 'straight'. Etymology obscure| there are no known correspondences outside of Greek. "It may have taken the place of ἱθύς 'id.'. Perhaps a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθύς with assimilation ει : υ > ευ : υ". DELG suggests influence of εὖ 'good'.}];270[384-385{S.v. AGk. εὐθύς 'droit'. Without IE etymology. It evidently substituted Homeric and Ionic ἱθύς. Perhaps we are dealing with a cross of εἶθαρ and ἰθυς with an assimilation εἰ : υ > εὐ : υ, or a simple alteration of ἰθύς under the influence of εὖ 'bien, droit'?}]
Justification: Modern Greek forms to be derived from Ancient Greek εὐθύς 'straight' (via εὐθειάζω with various analogical re-characterisations of the present stem, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1565-1566 for further discussion); no further satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some possible explanations within Greek cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):384-385, [Beekes 2010](src-66):479.

Source: 274[698-700{S.v. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (LIV² 629f., IEW 1069f.).}];141[629-630{Cf. s.v. 1. *tep- 'warm sein, heiß sein' (IEW 1069-70).}];172[I:623-624{Cf. s.v. Ved. √tap- 'brennen, heiß sein, heiß machen', from PIE *tep- 'warm sein' (cf. Lat. tepēre, 'warm sein', OIr. tē 'heiß, OCS teplostь 'Wärme').}];81[490{S.v. Proto-Slavic *teplъ, a *-lo- derivative of *tep- 'be hot' (cf. Lat. tepidus 'lukewarm, warm', Skt. tápati 'burn, be hot').}];54[614{S.v. Lat. tepeō 'to be warm', from which the adjective tepidus 'warm' is derived. Ultimately from PIE *tep- 'to be warm'.}];50[375{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tefent- 'hot, warm', derived from PIE *tep- 'be warm' (cf. Skt. tápati 'burns', Lat. tepeō 'be warm', OCS toplъ 'warm'). On the etymology, cf. OIr. téit (gloss) luxoriatae ('wanton women') < *tefentes).}];442[323{S.v. 5679 Ved. taptá- 'heated, hot' RV. [√tap-]}];323[81{S.v. Paš. tod 'hot' (cf. Av. tafta-, Khot. ttauda-, etc.).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ([NIL](src-274) 698-700, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:623-624, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):323 no. 5679, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):81, [Derksen 2008](src-81):490, [Matasović 2009](src-50):375, [LIV²](src-141) 629-630).

Source: 66[113{Cf. s.v. AGk. Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak' (of unknown etymology), with denominative verb ἁπαλύνω 'to soften'.}];464[{απάλυστο < α- (privative prefix) + the verbal adjective of  (α)παλαίνω ‘to wet’ < AG ἁπαλύνω ‘to soften’, cf. WET. [The root form AG ἁπαλύνω is given by [Rohlfs 1964](src-587):43].}];587[43{Cf. s.v. Italiot ἁπαλύνω (SMG ἁπαλένω) 'weich machen'.}];270[95{Cf. s.v. AGk. ἁπαλός, -ή, -όν 'tendre, délicat, mou'. No etymology.}]
Justification: From α- (privative prefix) + the verbal adjective of (α)παλαίνω 'to wet', i.e. 'not wet' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); The verb (α)παλαίνω is a variant of ἁπαλύνω 'to soften', which is in turn derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak', with no further etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):95, [Beekes 2010](src-66):113).

Source: 464[{ψαχνέ < AG σαχνός ‘tender’. In MedG the word has the meaning ‘thin’| cf. MG ξερ-ακιανός ‘a thin and tall person’.}];66[1314{S.v. AGk. σαχνός 'tender, mellow'. "Derivation from σώχω, ψώχω 'to rub down' has been assumed, but the details remain unclear. The variations σ-/ψ- and -κ-/-χ- point to Pre-Greek origin".}];270[991{S.v. AGk. σαχνός 'tendre', one connects the present σώχω (Hdt.) but the but the alternation ω/α is rare.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek σαχνός 'tender' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), often further assumed to be connected to σώχω, ψώχω 'to rub down' but the details of the derivation are unclear; further etymology outside of Greek lacking ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):991, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1314).

Source: 453[224];442[616{S.v. 10648 raśmí m. ʻ rope, bridle, ray of light ʼ RV. (> Si. räs- a 'beam of light').}];172[II:440-441{Cf. s.v. Ved. raśmí- 'Zügel, Zugseil, Leitseil', Mi., dard., ni., pā. raṁsi- 'Strahl', etc. Vedic raśmí- and raśmán- are together with Vedic raśanā- derivatives to an otherwise unattested root *raś- (IIr. *rać-), probably 'to bind', cf. s.v. Ved. raśanā- 'Strick, Seil, Halfter' comparable to MPers., NPers. rasan, Chwarez. rsyn 'Strick, Seil', Arm. (< Iran.) erasan 'Zügel', etc.}]
Justification: Cf. Vedic raśmi- 'rein, ray of light', Sinhalese rasmiya 'rays', rasnaya 'heat' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):616 no. 10648). The root of Vedic raśmi- is not attested verbally, but cognates in Iranic allow for the reconstruction of a basic root *rać-, probably 'to bind' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:440-441).
Loanword from Italian l'occhio 'the eye' with the Italian definite article analysed as part of the nominal stem.

Source: 141[245{Cf. s.v. *h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen' (IEW 347-8).}];172[I:281{S.v. Ved. √oṣ- 'brennen, versengen', from PIE *(h₁)eu̯s- (cf. Gk. εὔω 'senge', Lat. ūrō 'brenne, versenge', etc.). Derived adj. uṣṇá- 'heiß'.}];442[112{S.v. 2389 Ved. uṣṇá- (1) 'hot' RV.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic uṣṇá- 'hot', derived to Vedic √oṣ- 'to burn' and further connected with PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'id.' ([EWAia](src-172) I:281, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):112, no. 2389; [LIV²](src-141) 245).

Source: 464[{κατσ̔αβάρα / κατσ̔ιφάρα < MedG κατσηφ-άρα ‘fog’ < AG κατήφεια ‘being downcast, sad’, cf. MG κατσούφης. A Medieval Greek loanword.}]
Justification: A loanword into Tsakonian from Medieval Greek (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
Parallel loans from Persian مکان 'place, location', ultimately from Arabic مکان 'id.'.

Source: 81[434-435{S.v. Proto-Slavic *rě̄kà- 'river', derived from PIE *h₃roi̯H- (cf. Lat. rīvus 'brook, stream', OIr. ríathor m. 'torrent').}];141[305-306{Cf. s.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' [IEW 330-1].}];165[413-414, 418{S.v. Proto-Germanic *runi- 'run, stream', whence Goth. runs 'run, course', a derived i-stem to Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'run' < *h₃ri-n-H-.}];444[606{S.v. 7341 Lat. rīvus 'Bach', 2. rīus.}];54[524-525{S.v. Lat. rīvus 'small stream, brook, channel', from PIE *h₃riH-uo- 'whirling' (cf. MIr. rīan 'river, sea' < *reino-, Skt. rī́yate 'to flow, whirl', riṇā́ti 'to make flow, run', Gk. ὁρίνω 'to whirl, stir', Ru. réjat' 'to stream fast, flow', OEng. rīð 'stream, brook', OHG rinnan 'to drip').}];259[532{PS *rěka < *roi̯-kā is derived from *(e)rei̯- and related to Latin rivus 'stream', Old Indic ráya- 'current' and Middle Irish rīan 'river, road'.}]
Justification: Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl, seethe' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):606, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):524-525, [Derksen 2008](src-81):434-435, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 305-306).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. river, a loan from Anglo-Norman rivere (etc.), from Anglo-Norman and Old French, Middle French riviere (cf. Modern French rivière).}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Old French.  See also [cognate set 9691](cog-9691), a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but including inheritance after the initial loan event..

Source: 464[{σκουλ̣λ̣ί. For the etymon (< dim. of AG σκόλλυς) see Rohlfs (1964:466-7).}];587[466-467{S.v. *σκουλλίον diminutive, cf. Modern Greek dialectal (Rhodos) σκοῦλος 'Hals', from Ancient Greek σκόλλυς.}];66[1356{S.v. σκόλλυς 'fringe of hair, a haircut in which a tuft of hair was left on the head'. "Perhaps related to σκολύπτειν 'to pluck out, cut short', although a Pre-Greek origin seems more likely."}];270[1020-1021{S.v. AGk. σκόλλυς 'toupet', a hypocoristic term with gemination, with the same root as in σκολύπτειν, cf. s.v.}]
Justification: Italiot Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation *σκουλλίον 'little neck' to Ancient Greek σκόλλυς 'fringe of hair' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):466-467). Further etymology disputed (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1020-1021, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1356).

Source: 66[1293{Cf. s.v. ῥύγχνος 'snout of a pig, snout, beak'. Gk. ῥύγχνος can be hardly separated from Arm. ṙng-un-kʻ 'nostrils, nose', which if inherited must go back to IE *srungʰ- or *sringʰ- (with secondary nasalisation). Possibly also connected to ῥέγκω 'snore'.}];460[482{S.v. ῥοῦγχος τὸ (Hesych.) > Tsak. σ̌ούκ̔ο 'Maul, Schnauze, Schnabel'.}];270[978-979{S.v. AGk. ῥύγχος. An expressive term for its sonority. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), among others connects Arm. ṙng-un-kʻ 'narines, nez' and supposes IE *srungh- or *sringh- with expressive nasalisation. These words evoke Gk. ῥέγκω, ῥέγχω and this connection may be etymological, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1002.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ῥύγχνος 'snout, beak' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):482). This is further connected to Armenian ṙngunkʻ 'nostrils, nose' by [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) and [Beekes 2010](src-66), but the lexeme may well also be expressive in origin (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):978-979).

Source: 66[27{S.v. ἀήρ 'mist, haze, clouds', later 'air, atmosphere', from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er-.}];382[70{S.v. αέρας, from Medieval ἀέρας, ultimately from Ancient ἀήρ, gen. ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds| air atmosphere'.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):70, [Beekes 2010](src-66):27).

Source: 50[60{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bek(k)o- 'beak, snout', probably an expressive word comparable to Lat. bucca 'mouth', cf. Gaul. beccus (Suetonius), *bekko- > Fr. bec. No further etymology.}];157[80{S.v. Gaul. bocca 'bouche'. A relationship with an IE onomatopoeic root *buk- meaning 'aboyer, hurler' has been proposed, cf. Skt. búkkati 'il aboie', Gk. βύκτης '(le vent) mugissent', Serb. búkati 'hurler', etc. The Gaulish inscription however shows bocca, not *bucca.}];309[98-99{S.v. Bret. beg 'bec, bouche| pointe, embouchure'. Old French bec is a loanword from Gaulish *beccos, Latinised as beccus.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic obscure ([Matasović 2009](src-50):60, cf. Deshayes 2003}:98-99). [Delamarre 2003](src-157) suggests an etymology to an onomatopoeic IE root *buk- 'bark, scream', although the vocalism of Gaulish bocca rather than *bucca is unexpected.

Source: 66[65-66{Cf. s.v. ἀληθής 'true, real', from which Ancient Greek ἀληθινός 'true, genuine', is a secondary derivative. Originally an s-stem adjective with privative ἀ- which may be derived from the same root as the verb λήθω 'escape notice' < *leh₂dʰ- 'be hidden'.}];141[401-402{Cf. s.v. ?*leh₂dʰ- 'verborgen bleiben' (IEW 651). Only Greek.}];587[25{S.v. ἀληθινός 'wahr', 'echt' > It. aliθinó 'rot'.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀληθινός 'true, genuine' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):25), further perhaps to be derived from PIE *leh₂d-, although the postulated root is based entirely upon internal reconstruction of the Greek evidence (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):65-66, [LIV²](src-141) 401-402).

Source: 460[227{S.v. AGk. ἐκκλύζω 'ausspülen, auswaschen' > Tsakon. κσ̌ύζου.}];66[718-719{Cf. s.v. Gk. κλύζω 'to wash (away), clean', from PIE *k̑luH-, *k̑leHu- 'wash, purify'.}];141[335{Cf. s.v. *k̑leu̯H- 'reinigen' (IEW 607).}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἐκκλύζω 'wash out, wash away' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):227), further to PIE *k̑leu̯H- 'purify' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):718-719, [LIV²](src-141) 335).

Source: 464[{(με)λιγκόνι. Andriotis (1974:370) proposes a reconstructed n.pl. *μελιγκόνια. If the first part of the word is μέλι(τ)- ‘honey’, it could be related to Hellenistic μελίτ-αξ > MG μελίτακας ‘ant’ (Andriotis 1983:203), and possibly to Cypriot (με)λίμπουρος ‘ant’ (Christodoulou 1963). Cf. MG μελίγκρα ‘aphid’ < AG μελί-κηρα (Babiniotis 2009:835).}];460[370{S.v. *μελιγκόνια τὰ: μελιγκόνι τὸ (Sam, Tsakon, etc). λίγκόνι Tsakon 'Ameise'. Elsewhere compare NGr. μελίτακας, ὁ, μυρμήγγι τὸ.}];382[835{Cf. MG μελίγκρα ‘aphid’ < AG μελί-κηρα.}];66[925-926{Cf. s.v. AGk. μέλι 'honey' < PIE *melit- 'honey' (cf. Hitt. milit- < *melit-| Goth. miliϸ, Alb. mjaltë < *melit-o-| OIr. mil, Lat. mel < probably *meli-t-).}]
Justification: Probably to be derived from the inherited word for 'honey' μέλι < PIE *melit- ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):370, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):925-926). Regarding the IE 'honey', cf. [EIEC](src-657) 271.

Source: 464[{σ̌σ̌ιάτζομαι < οσ̌σ̌ί(α) (< AG σκιά ‘shadow’) -τζομαι ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):462), cf. ΜG σκιάζομαι ‘to be frightened’.}];66[1350-1351{Cf. s.v. σκιά 'shade' (< PIE *skeh₂-ih₂, gen. *skh₂-ieh₂-s 'shadow') and s.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark' (< PIE *skeh₃t- or *skoto- 'shadow, dark'). Note p.1351 "The relation [of Gk. σκιά] with σκότος is unclear". (Cf. Skt. chāyā́ 'shadow', Av. a-saiia 'who casts no shadow'.)}];587[462{Cf. s.v. σκιάζομαι 'vor Schatten scheuen', 'sich furchten'.}];460[498{S.v. AGk. σκία 'Schatten' > Cypriot and Italiot οσ̆σ̆ιά related to Ancient Greek σκία (cf. also s.v. the AGk. diminutive σκαδίον).}]
Justification: Continuing Medieval Greek σκιάζομαι 'to be frightened' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):462, cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):498), denominal to Ancient Greek σκία 'shadow'. For further discussion of the etymology of this root, cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058).

Source: 382[1619{Cf. s.v. SMG χώνω, from Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'heap up, raise, fill with earth'.}];66[1654{S.v. χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth'. The present stem of the verb χώννυμι and the derivative χῶμα 'heap, rubbish, dam, wall' are built from the aorist stem χῶσαι, which replaced the unclear form χέαι, from χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯-, or alternatively a contracted denominative or intensive *χοῆσαι to χέω.}];141[179{Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰeu̯- 'gießen' (IEW 447-8).}];270[1281{Cf. s.v. χώννυμι 'amonceler, terrasser, combler'.}]
Justification: Cf. SMG χώνω, from Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'heap up, raise, fill with earth' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1619), further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1654, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1281, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 179).

Source: 455[252{Loanword from French jambe 'leg'.}]
Justification: Loanword from French jambe 'leg' ([Varella 2006](src-455):252).

Source: 464[{Cypriot ξημαρισμένος. P.p. of ξημαρίζω < ξη- (< ἐξ) μαγαρίζω. An Arabic loan in MedG: μαγαρ(ίτης) -ίζω < MedG μωαγαρ-ίτης < Arab. Muhādžir (Kahane 1979:344-54, 622).}]

66[800{S.v. κυλίνδω 'to roll', with connected verbal stem κυλί-. "The word is hardly IE."}];464[{τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος). P.p. of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ < Hellenistic κυλίω ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):282-3), cf. MG κυλιέμαι.}];587[282-283{Cf. s.v. κυλίω (SMG κυλῶ) 'rollen, wälzen'.}];382[744{Cf. s.v. SMG κυλώ < Med. Gk. κυλῶ, a morphologically remodelled form from AGk. κυλίω 'roll along'.}];270[598{Cf. s.v. AGk. κυλίνδω 'rouler'| Gk. κυλίνδω presents a structure comparable to that of ἀλίνδω (thematisation of a base to a nasal suffix + d?), which may be connected to κύκλος and the root *kʷel-.}];269[{Italiot τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος), the passive participle of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c., cf. [Rohlfs 1964](src-587):282-283). Further etymology disputed: possibly to IE *kʷel(h₁)- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):598, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388), but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):800, who sees the word based on a substratum borrowing.}]
Justification: Italiot τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος), the passive participle of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c., cf. [Rohlfs 1964](src-587):282-283). Further etymology disputed: possibly to IE *kʷel(h₁)- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):598, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388), but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):800, who sees the word based on a substratum borrowing.

Source: 464[{Possibly a compound of σ̌ομό (< θερμό) ‘food’ + ἐλατός ‘driven’, cf. Tsak. γαϊδουρο-άτα (< -ἐλάτης ‘driver’).}]
Justification: Possibly a compound of σ̌ομό (< θερμό) ‘food’ + ἐλατός ‘driven’, cf. Tsak. γαϊδουρο-άτα (< -ἐλάτης ‘driver’) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 460[482{S.v. ῥοΐζω 'ein Pferd in die Schwemme führen' > Pontic ροΐζω (1) trans. 'werfen' (2) intr. 'fallen' (3) krank werden, (4) kommen.}];270[970-971{Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥέω, with specialised derivative (based on a denominal formation) ῥοΐζω 'mener un cheval à l'eau', to the IE root *sreu̯-.}];66[1281-1282{Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥέω, with derivative ῥοΐζω 'to drench' (cf. ῥοϊκός 'fluid'). Based on the IE root *sreu̯- 'flow, stream' (cf. Skt. srávati 'flow', etc.).}];141[588{Cf. s.v. *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' (IEW 1003).}]
Justification: Greek: Pontic ροΐζω 'fall' from Ancient Greek ῥοΐζω 'to drench (of horses)', a derivative of PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):482, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1281-1282, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):970-971, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 588).

Source: 382[1210{S.v. Modern Greek ρέμα, from Ancient Greek ῥεῦμα 'that which flows'.}];66[1281-1282{Cf. s.v. ῥέω 'flow' from PIE  *sreu̯- 'flow'.}];141[588{Cf. s.v. *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' (IEW 1003).}];587[438{S.v. ῥεῦμα 'Strömung, Flut' > It. ῥέμα.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ῥεῦμα 'that which flows' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):438, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1210), further to PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1281-1282, [LIV²](src-141) 588).

Source: 455[268{Loanword from Turkish kelle 'head'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish kelle 'head' ([Varella 2006](src-455):268).

Source: 455[251{Loanword from Venetian rozza 'stone'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Venetian rozza 'stone' ([Varella 2006](src-455):251).

Source: 455[252{Loanword from Italian alata}];464[{αλάτη. According to Kriaras (5:403) this word is inherited (contra Varella): MedGr ελάτη(ς) ‘wing (of a bird), branch’ < AG ἐλάτη. Τhe presence of MedGr ελατήρ ‘the muscle that moves the wing of the bird’ (Kriaras, id.) makes Kriaras’ interpretation more plausible. The cognate λατός ‘branch’ is preserved in the neighboring south-eastern MG dialect of Dodecanese (Andriotis 1974:232).}];460[232]

Justification: Loanword from Turkish orman 'forest, woods'.

Source: 464[{This is an obscure form. Perhaps ΑG ἐξ- (αν)αλίσκω ‘consume’. The meaning ‘burn, destroy’ of cognate καταναλίσκω / καταναλώνω is already medieval. Suffix -ίγκω is the equivalent of Peloponnesian Τs. -ίντου [indu] < Lac -ίδδω = Att. -ίζω.}]
Justification: Of obscure origin, perhaps to Ancient Greek ἐξ-(αν)αλίσκω 'consume' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Source: 141[433-434{S.v. *melh₃- 'hervorkommen' (IEW 721-722).}];66[223{Cf. s.v. AGk. βλώσκω 'to go, come' (aor. μολεῖν), from PIE *melh₃- 'come'.}];460[381{S.v. μόλω, subj. aor. to AGk. βλώσκω 'gehen, kommen' > Tsakon. μόλου 'kommen'.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek μόλω, the aorist subjunctive to Ancient Greek βλώσκω 'go, come' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):381), further to PIE *melh₃- 'to come' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):223, [LIV²](src-141) 433-434).

Source: 382[786{S.v. SMG λόγγος, a loanword from Old Slavic logŭ.}]
Comment: Loanword from Slavic.
Justification: A loanword into Medieval Greek from Old Slavic logŭ ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):786).

Source: 66[1037-1038{S.v. ξύλον 'wood, timber', seems to correspond with Lith. šùlas 'post, pole, stave' < IE *ksulo-, Ru. šúlo 'garden-pole', SCr. šȗlj 'block' < *kseulo- (?). Germanic words like OHG sūl 'style, pole, Goth. sauls 'pillar' have a similar appearance, although the relationship between the Slavic, Baltic, and Germanic words have hardly been explained (cf. Lehmann 1986 s.v. sauls). A European substrate term?}];352[1053-1054{Cf. s.v. OLith. šùlas 'Säule, Pfeiler, Stab' (BSl. cf. OPr. sulis 'Ständer', SCr. šȗlj 'abgesägter Baumstamm, Holzblock', Ru. šúlo (dial.) 'Zaunpfahl', from PIE *ksúlo- 'Holzblock (cf. Gk. ξύλον 'Holz, Baum| Balken, Stock'). Fully unclear is the connection of the Germanic lexemes in the group of Goth. sauls 'Säule', etc.}];270[767{S.v. AGk. ξύλον 'bois', one usually connects Lith. šùlas 'bâton, poteau, pilier' postulating IE *ksulo-, and with different vocalism forms in Slavic and Germanic (Ru. šúlo 'pieu', OHG sūl 'poteau, colonne').}]
Justification: Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):767, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1037-1038; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.
Loanword from Turkish pus 'fog, haze'.

Source: 460[202{Cf. s.v. δεῖσα 'Schmutz, Schlamm, Nässe' with semantic development to 'Nebel' in Pontic.}];66[311{Cf. s.v. AGk. δεῖσα 'slime, filth'. Unknown etymology. [Solmsen 1909](src-715):236f. connects the word with OCS židъkъ 'succosus, ὑδαρός', and Ru. žídkij 'thin, fluid, slim'.}];715[236f.];270[259{Cf. s.v. AGk. δεῖσα 'boue, crotte'. [Solmsen 1909](src-715):236 connects to OCS židŭkŭ. Lasso de la Vega (Émerita 22, 1954, 89). Possibly a popular term derived from the aorist ἔδεισα 'horreur, chose à redouter'? A simple hypothesis.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek δεῖσα 'slime, filth' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):202). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):259, [Beekes 2010](src-66):311 for references to conjectural hypotheses).

Source: 464[{καμουλία < MedG καύμα, κάμα ‘excessive heat’.}];66[618{Cf. S.v. καίω 'to kindle', med-pass. 'to burn' < PIE *keh₂u- 'burn',  to which καῦμα 'fire, heat, glow' is a derived noun. Attic καίω may be explained as a yod-present from *κάϝ-ι̯ω, ultimately from PIE *keh₂u̯-i̯e/o-. The Greek forms are possibly related to Baltic material in Lith. kū̃lės 'Brandpilze, Flugbrand, Staubbrand des Getreides', kūlė́ti 'brandig werden', Latv. kūla, 'old, dry, grass of last year'.}];141[345{Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda (cf. Alb. than 'trocknet').}];389[{Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).}];587[192{Cf. s.v. καβοῦλα 'Nebel'. The origin of the Modern Greek word is unknown. In Italy it has evidently become blended with καῦμα, κάμα 'Hitze'.}]
Justification: Italiot καμουλία < Medieval Greek καύμα, κάμα ‘excessive heat’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; cf. also [Rohlfs 1964](src-587):192). Further connected to the same root as Ancient Greek καίω 'to burn', to which cf. 'burn' in [cognate set 1461](cog-1461) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 464[{A borrowing from Turkish (çayır ‘meadow, grass’). (Chatziioannou 1996:196).}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish çayır 'meadow, grass' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Source: 464[{Explained as onomatopoeia (Chatziioannou 1996:205, Giagkoulis 2009:503), cf. MG φάπα ‘smack, clout’.}]
Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Source: 141[371{S.v. *kreu̯s- 'stoßen' (IEW 622).}];382[736{Cf. SMG κρούω 'hit' from Ancient Greek κρούω.}];66[785-786{S.v. κρούω 'to strike, stamp, knock', from PIE *krou(s)- 'push, bump, strike' (cf. OCS sъ-krušiti, Ru. krušit', Latv. kràusêt, Lith. kraušýti).}];460[337{S.v. AGk. κρούω 'schlagen, stoßen' > Pont. κρούγω.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek κρούω 'to strike, stamp, knock' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):337, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):736), possibly further connected to TochAB kärn- if the lexemes in [cognate set 2701](cog-2701) reflect an unextended form of the same Indo-European root (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):785-786, [LIV²](src-141) 371).

Source: 464[{τσέα < Hell. κέλλα ‘room, chamber’ < Lat. cella (Costakis 1986-7, 3:263) [loan]. Deletion of -l- before a back vowel is regular.}]
Justification: From Hellenistic Greek κέλλα 'room, chamber', a loanword from Latin cella 'storeroom, chamber' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Source: 464[{σπάτζω < AG σφάζω (sf > sp dissimilation).}];66[1426-1427{S.v. σφάζω 'to slaughter (by cutting the throat), kill, sacrifice'. No known cognates outside of Greek.}];270[1073{Cf. s.v. AGk. σφάζω 'égorger', based on a Greek root σφαγ- (cf. compounds in -σφαξ), but there is no plausible etymology outside of Greek. See also φάσγανον 'sword'.}];587[493-494{S.v. σφάζω 'morden, töten'.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek σφάζω ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):493-494), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1073, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1426-1427).

Source: 460[246{S.v. ἐξευπορῶ 'beschaffen, liefern' > Calab. aor. ἐτσιπόρεα,  (α)σ̌σ̌ηπόρεα 'ich wußte'.}];66[1222{Cf. s.v. πορεῖν 'to provide, donate, offer, grant', from PIE *perh₃- 'give' (cf. Skt. pūr-dhi [1.sg.imptv.] 'give!' < *pr̥h₃-dʰi).}];141[474-475{Cf. s.v. *perh₃- 'verschaffen' [IEW 816-8].}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἐξευπορῶ 'to supply, deliver' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):246), further to PIE *perh₃- 'to provide, make available' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1222, [LIV²](src-141) 474-475).

Source: 464[{Tsakonian: Peloponnese σ̌οβλέ < AG στρεβλός.}];66[1412{S.v. στρεβλός 'turned, twisted, crooked, cunning'. Similar to στρέφω 'turn' with a different labial, but variants with prenasalisation and -ιλ- suffix may be indicative of a non-Greek origin.}];270[1062-1064{S.v. στρεβλός 'tortillé, tordu, enroulé', the voiced labial β marks the expressive and popular character of this family of words| the verbal in the general sense is στρέφω 'tourner, détourner', cf. s.v. [in [cognate set 1558](cog-1558)] where the lexical root forms a coherent system in Greek, but there is no known etymology outside of Greek. If connected to Mycenaean kusutoroqa, then we should reconstruct a final labiovelar.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek στρεβλός (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), perhaps further to be derived from Ancient Greek στρέφω 'to twist, turn' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1062-1064, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1412), but otherwise of obscure origin.

Source: 382[116{Cf. s.v. SMG αναγουλιάζω < ανα- + -γουλ(ιάζω) < Hellenistic Greek γούλ(α) 'λαιμός'.}]
Justification: A derived verb from Modern Greek γούλα 'throat, neck' (cf. SMG αναγουλιάζω 'feel sick, be inclined to vomit', [Babinotis 2010](src-382):116), in turn a loanword from Latin gula 'throat' (cf. 'neck' in [cognate set 6065](cog-6065)).

Source: 382[1259{S.v. SMG σέρνω, from Ancient Greek σύρω with regular development of /i/ > /e/ before /r/, and remodelled as a nasal present in -νω.}];66[1424-1425{S.v. AGk. σύρω 'to draw, trail, drag, pull, ravish, sweep', probably with AGk. σαίρω 'sweep' if both reflect a root *tuer- 'sweep', in which σύρω reflects *tur-e/o- with analogical *σ- (rather than *tuor-e/o- with Cowgill's Law as per [Vine 1999a](src-719):569ff.).}];141[655{Cf. s.v. *tu̯er- 'aufrühren, erregen, antreiben' (IEW 1100). [No mention of proposed Greek cognates.]}];719[570-571{Derives Gk. σύρω < *tu̯or-i̯e/o- (> *tu̯ur-i̯e/o- via Cowgill's Law, with zero-grade *tur-i̯e/o- yielding σαίρω).}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. [Vine 1999a](src-719):570-571, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1424-1425).

Source: 460[110{S.v. AGk. ἀνεμῶ 'aufblasen, aufblähen' > Tsakon. ανεμούκ̔ου 'dem Wind überlassen, wegwerfen'.}];66[101-102{Cf. s.v. AGk. ἄνεμος 'wind' < PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'wind' (= Lat. animus| cf. Skt. ánila- 'wind, air' < *h₂énh₂lo-| Arm. hołm < *h₂onh₁-mo-, with *n > l dissimilation).}];141[267-268{Cf. s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9).}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek *ἀνεμόω 'blow' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):110), a derivative to ἄνεμος 'wind', further to PIE *h₂enh₁- 'blow' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):101-102, [LIV²](src-141) 267-268).

Source: 464[{σ̌ίνα < ΑG ῥίς ‘nose’ (Andriotis 174:480) or, more likely, < AG θίς ‘heap, dune’ (the change θ > σ is already Laconian).}];460[480{S.v. AGk. ῥίς 'Nase' > Tsakon. σ̌ίνα 'Nase| Anhöhe, Berg'.}];66[549{Cf. s.v. AGk. θίς, θινός 'heap (of sand), beach, dune, shore', without explanation.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed: either to Ancient Greek. ῥίς 'nose' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):480, cf. [cognate set 2356](cog-2356)) or Ancient Greek. θίς 'heap, dune' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Source: 460[411{S.v. AGk. ὀξύς 'scharf, spitz' > Cal. οσ̌σ̌εία 'Gebirge'.}];66[1089{S.v. ὀξύς 'sharp, stinging'| 'sour, tartish (of taste)', etc. "Without correspondences outside Greek. It has been compared with ὄκρις, which is an o-grade of the root of ἄκρος, but there are no further examples for u-stem adjectives with o-vocalism. Alternatively, Narten 1986 reconstructs a root *h₃ks- on the strength of the comparison with Skt. akṣṇoti 'to mark the ear', but this is doubtful."}];47[1069{Cf. for earlier proposed connections to PIE *ak̑- (*h₂ek̑-) 'sharp'.}];270[806-807{S.v. AGk. ὄξυς 'aigu, pointu'. The word ὀξύς shows the same difficulties in vocalism as ὄκρις, Lat. ocris with regard to the large family of words based on ἀκ-. On the other hand one tries to connect the s of ὀξύς the from the sigmatic root included in ἀκοστή, the compounds in -ήκης, Lat. acus. Cf. IEW 21.}];722[204-214]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ὀξεῖα, the feminine stem of Ancient Greek ὀξύς (adj.) 'sharp' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):411). Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 21-22, [Buck 1949](src-47):1069, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively [Narten 1986](src-722):204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1089).

Source: 382[263{Cf. s.v. SMG βέργα, a medieval loanword from Latin virga 'twig, bough, branch'.}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek βέργα, a loan from Latin virga 'twig, bough, branch' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):263).

Source: 269[{From Ancient Greek συλλογίζομαι 'reckon, compute' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):526), from συν- 'with' + λογίζομαι 'count, reckon' a denominal verb in -ιζω from Ancient Greek λόγος 'computation, reckoning', and o-grade noun from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):841, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 397, [IEW](src-49) 658).}];460[526{Cf. s.v. AGk. συλλογίζομαι 'berechnen, schließen, folgern' > 'denken'.}];66[841{Cf. s.v. AGk. λέγω 'collect, gather| to count, recount| say', from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' (cf. Lat. legō 'collect', etc.).}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek συλλογίζομαι 'reckon, compute' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):526), from συν- 'with' + λογίζομαι 'count, reckon' a denominal verb in -ιζω from Ancient Greek λόγος 'computation, reckoning', and o-grade noun from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):841, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 397, [IEW](src-49) 658).

Source: 382[1626{From Medieval Greek ὀψές, with final -ς taken on analogy to (ε)χτές 'yesterday', from Ancient Greek ὀψέ 'a after a long time, at length, late'.}];66[1139{Ancient Greek ὀψέ from PIE *h₁op-s- (*h₁ep- 'on'), cf. Lat. ops- 'towards' in compounds, e.g. obs-tendō.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Medieval Greek ὀψές, with final -ς taken on analogy to (ε)χτές 'yesterday', from Ancient Greek ὀψέ 'a after a long time, at length, late' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1626), further from PIE *h₁op-s-, cf. *h₁ep- 'on' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1139).

Source: 460[185{S.v. AGk. βοῶ 'schreien' > Tsakon. βου 'shout'.}];66[224{S.v. AGk. βοάω 'to cry', there are some possible comparisons but it is probably onomatopoeic.}];270[182-183{Cf. s.v. AGk. βοή 'cri, clameur'.}]
Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek βοάω 'to cry, shout' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):185), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek βοή 'cry, shout'. No certain further etymology, possibly an onomatopoeic formation (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):182-183, [Beekes 2010](src-66):224).

Source: 460[284{S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'gleich' > Tsakon. ἴσε.}];66[600-601{S.v. AGk. ἴσος 'equal' in number, strength, size, status, etc. (dial. Arc., Cret. Boeot. attests ϝίσϝος). Formally, earlier *u̯itˢu̯o- would work, but the proposed connection to a zero-grade *ϝιδσ- from εἶδος 'shape' is hypothetical. Other proposed etymologies are unconvincing.}];270[470{S.v. ἴσος 'égal, en nombre égal, également partagé, égal en droit'. The original structure of the word ϝίσϝος is certain, but the etymology is not established.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):284). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):470, [Beekes 2010](src-66):600-601 for various proposals.

Source: 147[74-75{S.v. TochA eprer 'air space', a borrowing from Tocharian B.}];345[70{S.v. TochB iprer 'sky, air, atmosphere', from which TochA eprer is surely a borrowing.}]
Justification: Loanword from Tocharian B eprer ([Carling 2009](src-147):74-75, [Adams 2013](src-345):70).

Source: 600[655{It is a loanword from Middle German runt 'round'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Low German runt 'round' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):655).

Source: 728[37{S.v. Manx bodjal 'cloud' = ScG. baideal}];231[26{Cf. s.v. ScG. baideal 'tower, battlement, ensign', baidealach 'bannered| from Middle English battle, battlement.}]
Justification: Loanword from Middle English battle, cf. Scottish Gaelic baideal 'battle, battlement' ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):37, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):26).

Source: 80[660-661, 673-674, 803-805{S.v. Hitt. peda-/ped- 'to take (somewhere), to carry, to transport| to spend (time)'| Hitt. peda- may be historically analysed as the univerbation of the preverb pe- 'away, thither' with Hitt. dā- 'take' < PIE *deh₃-, thus by etymology lit. 'to take away'.  Cf. Hitt. pai- 'go' < pe + i- 'go' < *h₁ei̯-, uu̯e- 'come' < u- 'hither' + i- 'go'.}]
Justification: The root etymology in this set follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):673-674, assuming a prefix pe- 'away, thither' to verbal dā- 'take' < PIE *deh₃- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 105-106).

Source: 412[174-177{Cf. s.v. parta(i)- 'wing, pinion, feather', connecting to the family of words including Skt. parṇá- 'pinion, wing, feather', Lith. spar̃nas 'wing', etc.}]
Justification: NB: The Hittite lexeme is somewhat dubious in this meaning (cf. [CHD P](src-404), s.v.); Etymology unclear: According to [HED PA](src-412), from the same stem as Hitt. partāu̯ar 'wing' from PIE *(s)per- in [cognate set 5101](cog-5101), cf. also cautiously Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, p.506; however unconnected by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):646-647.

Source: 80[381-382{S.v. Hitt. i̯e/a- 'to do, to make' (Sum. DÙ), cf. CLuw. ā(i̯a)- 'to do, to make', Lyc. a- (act.) 'to do, to make'. K. rejects connection with *Hi̯eh₁- 'throw' on semantic and formal grounds. The form could be accounted for by mechanically reconstructing PIE *HH-i̯e/o-, but there are no known cognates to support such a reconstruction.}];141[225{S.v. *Hi̯eh₁- 'werfen' (IEW 502).}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps with PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'throw' according to [LIV²](src-141) 225, but rejected by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):381-382 on formal and semantic grounds.

Source: 464[{λεχουτέ < verb. adj. of λεχ-ούκ̔ου which, according to [Andriotis 1974](src-460):353, goes back to AG λεχώ ‘new mother’.}];460[353{Cf. s.v. AGk. λεχὼ 'Wöchnerin' > Tsakon. vb. λεχ-ούκ̔ου with semantic developments 1) '(ein Kind) ins Bett liegen', 2) 'ausbrüten, wärmen'.}];141[398-399{Cf. s.v. *legʰ- 'sich (hin)legen' (IEW 658-9).}];66[852-853{Cf. s.v. AGk. λέχεται 'lies down in bed', from PIE *legʰ- (cf. related noun λέχος 'bed').}]
Justification: In origin a verbal adjective to Tsakon. λεχούκ̔ου 'lay (a child) in bed; incubate, warm (smth.)' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); the verb is derived from Ancient Greek λεχώ 'a woman in childbed, a woman who has just given birth' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):353). Further to be connected to Ancient Greek λέχος 'bed', λέχεται 'lie down in bed' from PIE *legʰ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):852-853, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 398).

Source: 66[1637-1638{Cf. s.v. AGk. χλιαίνω 'to warm, soften', from PIE *g̑ʰlei̯(d)- 'gleaming, clear' (cf. OIr. glé 'clear, evident', MW gloew 'liquid, clear' < *g̑ʰloiuo-, ON gljá 'to shine, gleam' MHG glīmen 'to lighten up, gleam', Lith. žlejà 'darkness, twilight, dusk', which point to a root *g̑ʰlei̯-.}];587[569{S.v. *χλίος (SMG χλιός 'warm').}];382[1601{Cf. s.v. SMG χλιαίνω.}];270[1263{Cf. s.v. χλῑ̆αίνω| no etymology more precise than to Celtic and Germanic forms which signify 'brilliance', which only satisfies poorly| cf. OIr. glē 'brillant', MHG glīmen 'briller', etc.}]
Justification: Cf. SMG χλιός 'warm', χλιαίνω 'to make warm' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):569, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1601), probably further to an IE root *g̑ʰlei̯- 'gleaming, clear' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1637-1638), but cf. the reservations of [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1263 on the comparative semantics.

Source: 382[277{Cf. s.v. SMG βράζω, from which βραστός is a derived verbal adjective, further from Medieval Greek βράζω 'boil' (cf. SMG βράζω 'boil (water)'), from Ancient (Hellenistic) Greek βράζω 'boil, froth up',  Classical Attic βράττω, Ionic βράσσω 'shake violently, agitate, boil (up)'.)}];66[235-236{Cf. s.v. βράσσω 'to shake violently, agitate, boil (up), winnow'| older proposals perhaps to Latv. murdēt 'boil up', Lith. mùrdau, mùrdyti 'etwas im Wasser rüttelnd behandeln', but this is uncertain. No secure etymology.}];270[193{S.v. AGk. βράσσω 'agiter, vanner'| it has been long connected by Bezzenberger (BB 27, 152f.) to Latv. murdêt 'bouillonner', Lith. murdýnas 'source', mùrdyti 'agiter dans l'eau', etc., but this is only a simple possibility.}]
Justification: A verbal adjective derived from Hellenistic Greek βράζω 'boil, froth up' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):277). No further etymology, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):193, [Beekes 2010](src-66):235-236 for various uncertain proposals.

Source: 66[1653{Cf. s.v. AGk. χῡλός 'juice (of plants), gruel, broth'| traditionally connected with χέω < PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour', but the long-stem vowel -ῡ- is difficult to account for.}];464[{Tsakon. σ̌υλωμένο < p.ptcp of AG χυλόω, -ῶ}];270[1280{S.v. AGk. χῡλός 'jus', long connected to the root of χέω, but the zero-grade is χῠ-| two explanations have been proposed: 1) a popular expressive vocalism or 2) supposing a suffix -σλο- with cluster simplification and compensatory lengthening, abut the doublet in -σλο- is otherwise unparalleled.}]
Justification: Originally a passive participle of Ancient Greek χυλόω 'convert into juice; extract the juice from' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology difficult; traditionally connected the same root as χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯, but long -ῡ- is unexpected for the zero-grade of this root and difficult account for (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1280, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1653).

Source: 66[113{Cf. s.v. Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak', of unknown etymology.}];464[{(α)παλυμένο. p.ptcp of AG ἁπαλύνω ‘to soften’}]
Justification: Derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλύνω (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak' of uncertain etymology ([Beekes 2010](src-66):113).

Source: 460[344{S.v. AGk. κωφίας > Cypriot κουφή 'eine Schlangenart'.}];66[816{Cf. s.v. AGk. κωφός 'blunt, dumb, mute', from which κωφίας 'a kind of snake', not to be separated from κηφήν 'drone'. The vocalism could be accounted for by reconstructing *k/gʰ(e/o)h₂bʰ-, but there is no IE comparandum. If κηφήν is borrowed from a substratum language, then the same probably holds for this word.}];270[528, 607{S.v. κωφός 'émoussé', with derivative κωφίας (also gloss in Hesych. ὄφεως εἶδος, ὁ καὶ τυφλίας), surely to be connected to κηφήν 'faux bourdon', a derived substantive in -ήν, -άν of an adjective *κηφός (*καφός?), perhaps also connected to κέκηφε· τέθνηκε (Hesych.). These connections present a problem of an alternation ᾱ/ω which is exceptional but not without parallel.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek κωφίας 'a kind of snake' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):344). No clear cognates outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):528, 607; [Beekes 2010](src-66):816).

Source: 66[831-832{S.v. λάξ adv. 'with the heel or foot', to which λακτίζω is a derived verb. No convincing Indo-European etymology.}];460[347{S.v. AGk. λαχτίζω 'mit dem Fuß ausschlagen, einen Fußtritt geben' > λαχτῶ (Kapp.).}];270[619{S.v. AGk. λάξ adv. 'avec le pied, le talon' with denominative verb λακτίζω 'donner un coup de pied, de talon, ruer'. An adverbial formation comparable to γνύξ, ὀδάξ, πύξ| perhaps comparable to Lat. calx requiring an earlier *κλάξ with dissimilation, but Lat. calx is itself obscure. Other hypotheses even less likely.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek λακτίζω 'kick with the heel or foot' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):347), a derivative to λάξ (adv.) 'with the heel or foot' without convincing IE etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):619, [Beekes 2010](src-66):831-832).

Source: 460[528{Cf. s.v. *συμπιάζω (AGk. συμπιέζω) 'zusammenpressen' > Pont. συμπιάνω.}];66[1189{S.v. AGk. πιέζω 'to press, push, beset', the variant πιάζω is an innovation after verbs in -αζω. The etymology is uncertain.}];270[899-900{S.v. πιέζω 'presser, serrer, serrer, écraser, poursuivre'. Etymology disputed.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek *συμπιάζω (AGk. συμπιέζω), cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):528. Further etymology disputed, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):899-900, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1189, for references to further literature.

Source: 66[1206-1207{S.v. AGk. πλέκω 'to braid, knit, wind, twine' < PIE *plek̑- 'twine' (cf. extended root in *plek̑-t- in Lat. plectō, OHG flehtan 'braid', OCS plesti 'συρράπτειν', Ru. plesti 'to twine'| with original root found in isolated formations e.g. Skt. praśna- 'turban, headband', < *plok̑-no-, OHG flahs, OE fleax 'flax' < *plok̑-so-).}];141[486{Cf. s.v. *plek̑- 'flechten' (IEW 834-5). [NB: LIV² considers Lat. plectō, OHG flehtan, OCS plesti < *plek̑-te- rather than a root enlargement.]}];464[{Italiot Greek αμπλέκω < AG ἐμπλέκω ‘to entwine’ (Rohlfs 1964:145), cf. MG συμ-πλέκομαι ‘to clash’.}];587[145{Cf. s.v. ἐμπλέκω 'verflechten'.}];270[914-915{S.v. AGk. πλέκω 'tresser', cf. t-enlarged forms in Lat. plectō, OHG flehtan, non-enlarged forms in OHG flahs, OE fleax 'lin', etc. going back to an IE root *plek- (cf. also Skt. praśna- 'turban' < *plok-no-).}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἐμπλέκω ‘to entwine’ ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):145, further from Ancient Greek (ἐμ)πλέκω 'to braid, knit, wind, twine' and ultimately derived from PIE *plek̑- 'to braid, twine' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):914-915, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1206-1207, [LIV²](src-141) 486).

Source: 460[563{S.v. ΑGk. τύπτω 'schlagen, stoßen' > Tsakon. τύφου.}];66[1518-1519{S.v. Gk. τύπτω 'to poke, stab, beat with a weapon or stick', from PIE *steup- 'push, beat' (cf. Lat. stupeō 'to be(come) numb, amazed', stuprum 'dishonour', Alb. shtyp 'to crush', etc.).}];141[602-603{Cf. s.v. *(s)teu̯p- 'stoßen, schlagen' (IEW 1034).}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek τύπτω 'to hit, beat' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):563). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'hit' in [cognate set 7794](cog-7794).

Source: 460[395{S.v. AGk. νοῶ 'wahrnehmen, erkennen, begreifen' > Tsakon. νoίου νοιούκʻου 'hören'.}];66[1023{S.v. AGk. νόος 'mind, sense, intellect, reason| purpose, aim', from which νοέω 'to mediate, observe, think, devise, have in mind' is a denominal verb. Νόος appears to go back to an old o-grade verbal noun (cf. λόγος, φόρος, etc.) but there is no certain etymology outside of Greek.}];270[756-757{S.v. AGk. νόος, with denominative verb νοέω, clearly a nomen actionis with o-grade vocalism, but no known etymology outside of Greek.}]
Justification: Tsakonian νίου 'hear' from Ancient Greek νοέω 'perceive, observe, apprehend' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):395), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):756-757, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1023).

Source: 80[587-588{S.v. Hitt. munnae- 'to hide, conceal', from PIE *meu̯h₂/₃-, cf. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close the eyes'.  The Hittite form may reflect an original nasal-infix present *mu-né-h₂/₃-ti, *mu-n-h₂/₃-énti > **munāzi / munnanzi, which was later analogically remodelled as into the ḫatrae-class of inflection.}];66[988{Cf. s.v. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close, be shut'| of the eyes 'shut the eyes, abate'| can be formally derived from either a root *meu̯s- or *meu̯H-| a connection to Hitt. munnae- 'to hide, conceal' was proposed by [Oettinger 1979](src-649):161ff.}];649[161ff.]
Justification: From PIE *meu̯h₂ or *meu̯h₃- according to [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):587-588 (cf. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close the eyes'; [Oettinger 1979](src-649):161ff.); the proposed Greek comparandum is listed under ?*meu̯s- in [LIV²](src-141) (only Greek), and may formally reflect either *meu̯H- or *meu̯s- (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):988).

Source: 80[366-368{Plausibly connects Hitt. ḫuu̯ai-, CLuw. ḫui(i̯a)-, HLuw. hwia- to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', comparing English 'blow' used as 'to move as if carried or impelled by the wind' or 'to go away, move hurriedly' as a semantic parallel.}];141[287-288{Cf. s.v. *h₂u̯ei̯- 'laufen' (not in IEW), which reconstructs a perfect form ?*h₂e-h₂u̯ói-/u̯i- as a possible stem ancestral to the Hitt. form, following Puhvel, HED H, p.423, dismissing the stem formation *h₂uh₁-i̯é- to *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow' (cf. Oettinger 1979:480-481) as semantically problematic.}];269[{For this set, the etymology to *h₂u̯eh₁- is to be preferred, after Kloekhorst, as the proposed semantic development is plausible.}];407[423];649[480-481]
Justification: Root etymology in this set follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):366-368, [Oettinger 1979](src-649):480-481 to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ([LIV²](src-141) 287), however cf. [HED H](src-407) 423, [LIV²](src-141) 287-288 preferring to set up *h₂u̯ei̯- to a perfect stem ?*h₂e-h₂u̯ói-/u̯i- considering the semantics 'blow' > 'run' semantically problematic.

Source: 353[229-230, 247-248{S.v. Lith. kartùs 'bitter' (OPr. kārtai 'bitter'), Baltic forms to be connected to Lith. kir̃sti 'hew, sting, cut, strike' from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut', (cf. Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short' in OCS kratъkъ, etc.).}];531[260{S.v. Lith. kartùs 'gorzki'}];141[559-560{Cf. s.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' [IEW 941-942].}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes to be connected with PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):260, [Derksen 2015](src-353):229-230, 247-248, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Source: 80[727{S.v. Hitt. šar- (mid.), šarii̯e/a- (act.) 'to embroider(?), sew on(?)| to truss(?) / sew(?), from PIE root *ser-, inflected as a root present in the mediopassive, or as active *sr̥-i̯é/ó-.  Cf. Lat. serō, Gk εἴρω 'string together'.}];141[534-535{Cf. s.v. 2. *ser- 'aneinander reihen, verknüpfen' (IEW 911).}]
Justification: Generally derived from a PIE root 2. *ser- 'to string together, connect' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):727, [LIV²](src-141) 534-535).

Source: 353[561{S.v. OPr. lauxnos 'luminary', from PIE *louk-sneh₂- (cf. OCS luna 'moon', Av. raoxšna- 'shining', Lat. lūna 'moon').}];141[418-419{Cf. s.v. *leu̯k- 'hell werden' (IEW 687-9).}]
Justification: Old Prussian lexeme, generally derived from PIE *lou̯k-sneh₂-, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ([Derksen 2015](src-353):561, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Source: 141[540{Cf. s.v. ?*seu̯k- 'drehen, winden' (IEW 914).  Only Balto-Slavic cognates.}];352[988-989{S.v. OLith. sùkti 'drehen| verdrehen, lügen'.}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes as though from PIE ?*seu̯k- ([LIV²](src-141) 540, [ALEW](src-352) 988-989), although there are no certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic so an IE provenance is not assured. [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Source: 80[580-581{Hitt. maliddu- 'sweet' is a derivative of Hitt. militt- / malitt- 'honey' from PIE *mél-it / *ml̥-it-ós, cf. Gk. μέλι, μέλιτος, Goth, miliþ 'honey', Alb. mjaltë 'honey', Lat. mel, mellis 'honey'.}];369[169-170{S.v. Alb. ëmbël / ãmbël 'süß, mild'. Not certainly explained. The comparison with Ved. amlá- 'sauer' is semantically facile. Better is the proposed connection with Alb. mjaltë 'Honig' in the same semantic relationship as Ir. milis, W. melys 'süß' against OIr. mil 'Honig'. The Albanian derivation could be easily explained as prefixed Alb. *ambëlt < *an-blit < *(h₂)en-mlit- ‘which has honey (in it)’ with epenthesis or dissimilation.}];296[M:50-51{Cf. s.v. OIr. mil 'miel', from which OIr. milis 'doux, agréable au goût, suave'. The same word is found under the form mel in Gaulish, Cornish, and Breton, from which Gaul. melus and melys 'doux'. The stem (meli- is inflected as an i-stem, but the dental stem appears in milis < *melit-ti- (cf. Gk. μέλι, gen. μέλιτος, Goth. miliϸ).}]
Justification: Anatolian, Albanian, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *mel(it)- 'honey' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):580-581, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):169-170, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:50-51).
