Source: 80[803-805{S.v. Hitt. dā- / d- 'to take, to wed, to decide' Hitt. stem dā- is inflected in the ḫi-conjugation and exhibits *-o-/-Ø- root-ablaut, reflecting a pre-form *dóh₃-/*dh₃-. Elsewhere in IE cf. Skt. dádāti, Av. daδāiti, Arm. tam, Gk. δίδωμι, OLith. duosti, Lat. dō, dāre 'to give', OCS daxъ 'he gave'.}];141[105-106{S.v. *deh₃- 'geben' (IEW 223-5).}]
Justification: Anatolian lexemes from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):803-805, [LIV²](src-141) 105-106).

Source: 80[545-546{Cf. s.v. Hitt. māl- 'mental power(?)', connected with CLuw. māl- 'thought, idea' and its derivative mal(a)i- 'to think, to suppose'.  To be connected with Gk. μέλω 'to be an object of care and thought, to care for' which would point to a PIE root *mel-.}];389[{Cf. s.v. *melh₁- 'Sorge bereiten' (IEW 718).}]
Justification: For the etymology, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):545-546; for the root ref. form cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Source: 369[97-98{S.v. Alb. bëj (t.) / bãj (g.) 'machen, tun| werden, vorkommen| erscheinen, (statt)finden'. Inherited verb, compared since [Meyer 1891](src-585) with Gk. φαίνω 'sichtbar machen, ins Licht bringen' as an original *-ni̯o- formation.}];141[68-69{S.v. 1. *bʰeh₂- 'glänzen, leuchten, scheinen' (IEW 104-105).}];105[22{S.v. Alb. bëj ~ bâj 'to do, make', from PAlb. *banja compared with Gk. φαίνω 'to appear' and further connected with IE *bhā-. For the semantic development cf. OIr. bann 'deed' from the same root.}];571[43{S.v. Alb. bëj, bëra, bërë 'do, make', connected with Greek φαίνω 'appear', cf. OIr. bann 'deed' for the semantics.}];585[23-24{S.v. Alb. bąj (geg.) bεń (to.) 'mache, thue', originally a present *bani̯o- = Gk. φαίνω.}]
Justification: Albanian forms since [Meyer 1891](src-585):23-24 compared with Greek φαίνω 'appear', a remodelled nasal-present stem *bʰ-né/n-h₂- to PIE 1. *bʰeh₂- 'shine' ([LIV²](src-141) 68-69, [Huld 1984](src-571):43, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):97-98, [Orel 1998](src-105):22).

Source: 105[233{Cf. s.v. luftë 'fight, war', borrowed from Rum. luptă 'fight' < Lat. lucta 'wrestling'. Note the East Romance development of *-ct- in this word.}]
Justification: Borrowing from East Romance, cf. Romanian luptă 'fight' < Latin lucta 'wrestling' ([Orel 1998](src-105):233)

Source: 364[967{S.v. Alb. blúan 'mahlen, auspressen, verdauen', traditionally derived to PIE *melh₂- but the stem formation is not clear. The connection of this verb to the root *melh₂- is in no way certain.}];105[30{S.v. bluaj ~ bluej 'to grind'| O. considers the word a loan from Lat. molere.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. [Orel 1998](src-105):30 considers a loan from Latin molere; [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):967 consider the lexemes inherited, possibly but not certainly to be connected with PIE *melh₂- since the stem formation remains unclear.

Source: 105[101{S.v. Alb. fortë 'strong'. Loan from Lat. fortis 'strong'.}];585[110{S.v. Alb. fortɛ 'stark, fest', from Italian forte.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin fortis 'strong' or Italian forte 'id.' (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):110, [Orel 1998](src-105):101).

Source: 105[222{Cf. s.v. Alb. lëmoj 'to file, polish', borrowed from Lat. līmāre 'id.'.}]
Justification: Albanian forms derived to an original loan from Latin līmāre 'to file, polish, finish' ([Orel 1998](src-105):222).

Source: 585[193{S.v. Alb. kofšɛ 'Hüfte, Schenkel', a borrowing from Lat. coxa.}];105[188{S.v. Alb. kofshë 'hip, thigh', borrowed from Lat. coxa 'hip'.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin coxa 'hip' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):193, [Orel 1998](src-105):188).

Source: 105[370-371{S.v. Alb. rërë ~ ranë 'sand', borrowed from Lat. arēna 'sand'.}];130[76-77{Suggests an alternative etymology from *er- 'Erde, Sand, Locker' (IEW 332), cf. Lat. rārus, but "[e]ven in this case, no recent cognates with the exact meaning".}];369[295{S.v. nënte / nãntë 'neun', mentions in passing that Alb. rëre / rãnë 'sand' is a borrowing from Lat. arēna.}]
Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Generally regarded as a loan from Latin arēna 'sand' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):295, [Orel 1998](src-105):370-371), but cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):76-77 for a tentative proposal to the lexemes from PIE *h₁er- (cf. NHG Erde, etc. in [cognate set 207](cog-207)).

Source: 105[104{S.v. fsheh ~ mshef 'to hide', from Proto-Albanian Pr. *en-skepska- and compares Greek σκέπω, from PIE *skep- (so [Jokl 1912](src-750):192-195).}];750[192-195];141[555-556{Cf. s.v. ?2. *(s)kep- 'bedecken' (IEW 930), without Albanian.}]
Justification: Since [Jokl 1912](src-750):192-195 generally connected with Ancient Greek σκέπω 'to cover, protect' from PIE ?2. *(s)kep- 'to cover', cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):104, [LIV²](src-141) 555 (without Albanian cognates listed).

Source: 105[438{S.v. Alb. shtëpi 'house', a morphological adaptation of the metathesized Lat. hospitium 'lodging, inn, guest-chamber' (cf. ModGk. σπίτι 'house').}];585[415-416{S.v. Alb. štɛpī́, štpī́ 'Haus', most probably a derivative from Latin hospitium, from which Modern Greek σπίτι also derives.}];571[115{S.v. Alb. shtëpi 'house', a loan from Latin hospitía 'inns' with metathesis to *hostipía, cf. qingj 'lamb' < *acínglu metathesised from *agnículus < agnus 'lamb'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin hospitium 'lodging, inn' (with metathesis of p and t in the borrowed form), cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):415-416, [Huld 1984](src-571):115, [Orel 1998](src-105):438.

Source: 105[183{S.v. kërth (adj.) 'crosswise, askew', from which kërthiz 'navel' is derived. Ultimately derived from an adverbial form in -th based on a loanword from Lat. crucem 'cross'. Earlier [Meyer 1891](src-585):188 supposed a loanword from Latin cortīna.}]
Justification: Probably based on a loanword from Latin crucem 'crosswise, askew' ([Orel 1998](src-105):183); earlier [Meyer 1891](src-585):188 supposed a loan from Latin cortīna 'round vessel, cauldron'.

Source: 172[I:564{Cf. s.v. Ved. jáṅghā- 'unterer Teil des Beines, Unterschenkel, Bein' (cf. Av. zaṇga- 'Fußknöchel), probably a derivation from PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (cf. Goth. gaggan 'gehen', Lith. žeñgti 'schreiten', etc.).}];442[280{S.v. 5082 Ved. jáṅghā f. 'shank (ankle to knee)'}]

Comment: loan from Persian ران cf. [lexeme 47728](lex-47728)

Source: 172[II:684{S.v. Ved. sákthi- 'Schenkel' (Av. haxtiiā̊ gen.du. 'der (weiblichen) Schenkel'). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian difficult.}]

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9742; further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 294
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes connected with Vedic máṇḍala- 'circular, round' (adj.), 'disc' (n.) (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):559 no. 9742). No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:294).

Source: 352[1189-1191{Cf. s.v. OLith. var̃gas 'Elend, Not, Mühsal' (BSl. cf. Latv. vãrgs 'siech, elend', OPr. wargan 'Übel, Leid', wargans (adj.) 'böse', OCS vragъ 'Feind', SCr. vrȃg 'Teufel', etc.), from PIE *u̯orgʰó- 'verstoßen, geächtet', cf. Goth. gawargjan 'verdammen', ON vargr 'Wolf| Verstoßener, Geächteter', OE wearg (adj.) 'böse, verflucht, verdammt'. etc.}];353[489-490{Cf. s.v. Lith. var̃gas 'hardship, misery' (Latv. vā̀rgs 'misery', OPr. wargan 'misery, suffering, danger')| s.v. Lith. vargùs 'hard, difficult, tiresome' D. reconstructs the root as *(h₁)u̯org-o-, comparing Goth. wrikan 'persecute', OHG rehhan 'revenge'.}]
Justification: Old Prussian lexeme derived from PIE *u̯orgʰó- 'outcast, ostracised' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1189-1191, [Derksen 2015](src-353):489-490).

Source: 352[766{Cf. s.v. OLith. píepala 'Wachtel (coturnix coturnix)' (BSl. cf. Latv. paîpala 'Wachtel| junges Mädchen', OPr. penpalo 'Wachtel', SCr. prèpelka, Ru. pérepel, Cz. přepel (dial.) 'Wachtel')| probably also connected to OPr. pepelis, Acc.pl. pippalins 'Vogel'. No etymological connections outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Balto-Slavic; probably further connected to Lithuanian píepala 'quail (coturnix coturnix)'. Cf. discussion in [ALEW](src-352) 766.

Source: 352[545-546{S.v. OLith. kvė̃pti 'atmen, hauchen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kvêpt 'qualmen, rauchen', etc.). These lexemes are probably not to be separated from Lat. vapor, -ōris 'Dampf, Dunst', Gk. καπνός 'Raum, Qualm, Dunst', continuing a root *kʷu̯ap- or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-. Improbable is an etymological connection with Goth. afƕapjan 'ersticken', etc.}];269[{Frequently connected to a common root *kʷu̯ap- or *kʷu̯eh₂p- uniting the Baltic forms with Lat. vapor 'vapour, steam' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):654, and Gk. καπνός (cf. further discussion in [cognate set 1583](cog-1583)), but due to several irregular sound changes necessary to justify the comparison, the etymology is not fully certain.}];353[268{S.v. Lith. kvė̃pti 'inhale, breathe in, inspire', possibly from *k⁽ʷ⁾h₂uēp- and connected with Gk. καπνός 'smoke, Lat vapor 'steam, heat' (both probably < *k⁽ʷ⁾uh₂ep-).}]
Justification: Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ([ALEW](src-352) 545-546, [Derksen 2015](src-353):268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.

Source: 442[241{S.v. 4471 Ved. ghāsá- m. 'food, pasture grass' AV. [√ghas]}];172[I:514{Cf. s.v. Ved. √ghas- 'essen, verzehren' (nominal derivative ghāsá- 'Futter'), cf. MI, NI, Pāli ghāsa- 'Futtergras', IIr. YAv. gah- 'essen, fressen (von daēuuischen Wesen), further etymology not acertained.}];141[198-199{S.v. ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'essen, fressen, verzehren' (IEW 452). Only IIr., further connections uncertain.}]
Comment: some NIA forms may be blends with grāsa m. ʻmouthful', √gras- 'devour', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4379
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ghāsá- 'food, pasture grass' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):241 no. 4471), a derivative of Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, consume', cf. Young Avestan gah- 'to eat, devour'; further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:514; [LIV²](src-141) 198-199 mechanically reconstructs ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume').

Source: 352[1218-1219{S.v. OLith. ver̃kti 'weinen' (BSl. cf. Latv. ver̂šêt, ver̂kšķêt 'weinen, still weinen| schreien (Kinder und Ferkel), SCr. vríštati 'schreien, kreischen, winseln', ORu. vrěščati, vereščati 'schreien, weinen (Säuglinge), jammern', etc.). No known cognates outside of Balto-Slavic.}];353[497{S.v. Lith. ver̃kti 'cry, weep', from Proto-Balto-Slavic *werk- (cf. CS vrěštati| Ru. vereščat’ 'squeal, chirp'), from PIE *uerk- (cf. OIc. var 'rheum', Nw. var 'rheum', OSw. var 'mucus, rheum, pus'| OHG warah 'pus, liquid manure' < PGmc. uórk-o-| connection of the Germanic forms follows Kroonen 2013:574).}];165[574{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *warha- 'rheum'. "A word with an original meaning 'rheum' or 'serum'. I assume that it was derived from a root *uerk- 'to cry' as found in Baltic." [No further references given.]}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic according to [ALEW](src-352) 1218-1219. [Derksen 2015](src-353):497 connects the Balto-Slavic forms with Germanic *warha- following [Kroonen 2013](src-165):574, but this proposal has not yet been widely accepted.

Source: 442[258{S.v. 4755 Skt. cāra- (2) m. 'motion, course' ChUp. 2. '*grazing, *fodder'. [~ cāla- 2. √car].}];172[I:534-535{Cf. s.v. Ved. √car-ⁱ 'sich bewegen, wandeln, gehen, wandern, fahren', from PIE *kʷel(H)- (cf. Gk. πέλομαι, Lat. colō, etc.).}];141[386-388{Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-40).}]
Justification: As though continuing Sanskrit cāra- *'grazing, fodder' (< 'motion, course'), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):258 no. 4471. Further derived from Vedic √car-ⁱ 'to move oneself, go, walk, move, stir, roam about, wander', ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, turn oneself around' ([EWAia](src-172) I:534-535, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

Source: 352[576{Cf. s.v. Old Lithuanian liáuti 'aufhören, aufhören zu sündigen| Buße tun' (BSl. cf. Latv. ļaũt 'erlauben, zulassen'| OPr. aulāut 'sterben', Ukr. livýti 'nachlassen', OCz. leviti 'lindern'| IE cf. Goth. lewjan 'verraten', OE lǣwan 'id.'). The Baltic forms find the best generally agreed connection with Germanic lexemes, but further connections are disputed. The IE root identification for these forms is less clear, perhaps a u-stem to *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' (so LIV² 399), perhaps alternatively a root *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' with laryngeal metathesis.}];686[36{S.v. OPr. aulāut 'sterben', corresponds to Lith. liáuti + preverb au-.}];141[399{Cf. s.v. *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen' (IEW 666, 682-3), where a present stem ?*léh₁-/*l̥h₁-u- is suggested for Goth. lewjan 'verraten', Latv. ļaũju 'zulassen, erlauben', Ukr. livlijú 'nachlassen', etc.}]
Justification: Precise root identification uncertain. [LIV²](src-141) 399 suggests a connection to *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen', but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 576 which also suggests the possibility of connections to the root *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 681-682) with a laryngeal metathesis.

Source: 531[654{Cf. s.v. Lith. švarùs 'czysty', etymology unclear.}];360[1040]
Justification: Lit. 'not-clean', cf. Lithuanian švarùs 'clean', of uncertain etymology ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):654, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1040 for older proposals). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Source: 352[177-180, 193-194{S.v. OLith. darýti 'machen, tun' (BSl. cf. Latv. darît, 'tun, machen', derivative with an o-grade root from the word family from Lith. derė́ti 'abmachen, verhandeln, sich einigen, sich verpflichten, sich verloben' (Latv. derêt), from PIE *dʰer- 'fest machen' (cf. Ved. dhar- 'festhalten, stützen', OAv. dar- 'festhalten', OPers. dar- 'besitzen, haben', Lat. ferē (adv.), fermē (adv.) 'ungefähr, nahezu, fast', firmus (adj.) 'stark, fest| dauerhaft, beständig').}];141[145-146{S.v. *dʰer- 'befestigen, fixieren' (IEW 252-3).}];531[93-94{S.v. Lith. darýti 'robić, czynić, sprawać' (Latv. darît), to be derived from PIE *dʰer-, cf. Av. dərətā, Ved. dādā́ra, etc.}];353[116{S.v. Lith. daryti 'do', from PIE *dʰor-eie- (cf. Skt. dhārayati 'hold').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰer- 'to fix, make firm' ([LIV²](src-141) 145-146, [ALEW](src-352) 177-180, 193-194, [Derksen 2015](src-353):116, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):93-94).

Source: 352[896-897{Cf. s.v. OLith. sègti 'heften'. Old Prussian seggīt might be connected to the Old Lithuanian form, and if so from PIE 1. *seg- 'heften' (LIV² p.516, IEW 887-8), but the connection of the Old Prussian forms to the Old Lithuanian ones is not entirely clear.}];686[325-326{S.v. OPr. siggīt (inf.) 'tun'| the verb still lacks a clear etymology.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):325-326, [ALEW](src-352) 896-897 for further discussion.

Source: 66[1638{S.v. χλωρός '(pale) green' < PIE *g̑ʰl̥h₃-ró-.  The same root *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' occurs in Baltic, Slavic, and Latin, but with different derivations (e.g. Lith. žélti 'to green, sprout', OCS зєлєнъ (translating Greek χλωρός, πράσινος), Lat. holus 'green plants, vegetables, cabbage').}];50[160{S.v. Proto-Celtic *glasto- 'green, blue'. "In principle these forms could represent PIE *g̑lh₃-stó- > *glāsto- > *glasto- (by Dybo's shortening). The PIE root would have been *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ([IEW](src-49) 429ff.), as in *gel(w)o-. Cf. also MHG glasta 'shine', which may reflect a prehistoric borrowing from Celtic (if it is related at all)."}];172[II:805-806{S.v. Ved. hári- 'fahl, gelblich, grünlich' < PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-i- (cf. Gk. χλωρός 'pale green, green-yellow', OHG gelo 'yellow', Lith. žélti 'to flourish, turn green').}];81[541{S.v. Proto-Slavic *zelenъ, based on a full-grade formation from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-, cf. *žьltъ adj. 'yellow' [cognate set 7535](cog-7535) based on a zero-grade fromation *g̑ʰl̥h₃-.}];353[511-512{S.v. Lith. žãlias 'green', from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃-i- (cf. Skt. hári- 'fallow, yellowish, greenish').}];352[1285-1286, 1296{Cf. s.v. Lith. -žala, atžalà 'junger Zweig, Spross, Schössling' with derivatives žalė́tis 'grün werden' and žãlinti 'grün machen', o-grade formations to Lith. žélti 'grünen, sprießen', derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'hellgrün' (cf. Ved. hári- 'fahl, gelblich, grünlich', YAv. zairi-, zāiri- (adj.) 'gelb', Gk. χλωρός 'hellgrün, blassgrün, grüngelb, gelblich, blass| frisch, lebendig', Lat. holus, -eris 'Grünzeug, Gemüse').}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1638, [EWAia](src-172) II:805-806, [ALEW](src-352) 1285-1286, 1296, [Derksen 2015](src-353):511-512, [Derksen 2008](src-81):541, [Matasović 2009](src-50):160).

Source: 686[382{S.v. OPr. ūlint (inf.) 'kämpfen'. Without a suitable etymology| the traditional connection of ūlint with Cz. váleti 'bekriegen', válka 'Krieg' is questionable.}]
Justification: Without certain etymology ([Smoczyński 2005](src-686):382).

Source: 352[878-879{Cf. s.v. OLith. rū̃kti 'rauchen, qualmen' (derived noun rū̃kas 'Nebel, Rauch'). The word family of rū̃kti is best explained as a loan from Germanic (cf. ON riúka 'rauchen', OE rēocan 'rauchen, dampfen, qualmen' OHG riohhan 'rauchen, dampfen, dunsten' etc.).}];531[524{Cf. s.v. Lith. rū̃kti 'dymić się, kurzyć się, kopić się'| without etymology, transponat PIE *reu̯k-.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Germanic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 878-879, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):524).

Source: 352[1017{Cf. s.v. Old Lithuanian šė́kas 'Gras, Heu' (BSl. Latv. sȩ̂ks 'frisch gemähtes Gras als Viehfutter', OPr. schokis 'Gras', from PIE *k̑éh₁k⁽ʷ⁾o- 'gemähtes Gras, Heu' (cf. Ved. śāka- 'Küchenkraut, Gemüse', ONor. há 'Grummet, zweite Mahd'). The transmitted form of the Old Prussian lexeme is unexpected. Sch- does not correspond to Latv. s- as is the vowel o to Lith. ė, Latv. ȩ̂. The dependability of the IE reconstruction is impaired by these uncertainties in the Old Prussian form.}]
Justification: As though from PIE *k̑éh₁k⁽ʷ⁾o- 'mowed grass'; The Old Prussian form shows some unexpected deviations from the East Baltic cognates (Lith. šė́kas 'grass, hay', Latv. sȩ̂ks 'freshly cut grass as cow-fodder'). Cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1017 for further discussion.

Source: 269[{Probably a borrowing from Greek, if the etymology proposed by Andriotis (1974:370) for Tsakonian μελιγκόνι holds. Cf. discussion in at [cognate set 6209](cog-6209).}];105[257{Cf. s.v. Alb. merimangë 'spider' with variants merimagë, mirëmangë, milimangë, milingonë, and merimajkë, to be interpreted as tabooistic distortions of merming 'id.' borrowed from Modern Greek μυρμῆγγι 'ant, midget'.}]
Justification: More precise origins uncertain, but possibly a loanword from Greek (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):257 and discussion in [cognate set 6209](cog-6209)).

Source: 352[490{S.v. OLith. kíetas 'hart, fest' (BSl. Latv. ciêts, ciêss 'hart, fest| streng'). The Baltic material is traditionally connected with SCr. cȉtī 'genauso, gleich, zusammen', but there is no secure further comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Comment: cf. S, Cr. čȉt 'whole'
Justification: Extra-Baltic connections unclear. The traditional connection to the family of Serbo-Croat čȉt 'whole', etc. is improbable ([ALEW](src-352) 490, cf. also [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):252, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):285). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Source: 352[940-941{S.v. OLith. slė̃pti 'verbergen, verstecken, verheimlichen' (BSl. Latv. slèpt 'verbergen, verheimlichen, hehlen| heimlich, im Verborgenen gehen'. No clear etymology outside of Baltic. Often considered is a connection to *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen, verbergen' found in Gk. κλέπω 'stehle (heimlich), hintergehe', Lat. clepō, -ere, Goth. hlifan 'stehlen'. This root can be continued in OPr. niauklipts 'unverborgen'. Formally the East Baltic lexemes may continue *slep- (cf. also *slìpti 'schleichen, sich unbemerkt bewegen').}];141[363-364{Cf. s.v. *klep- '(heimlich) stehlen, verbergen' (IEW 604). Under the present stem *klép-e- ?Lith. slepiù (slė̃pti) 'verbergen' might be connected, if there is a secondary s-mobile and the initial cluster *skl- may be simplified to *sl- (cf. n4).}]
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Baltic. A connection with PIE *klep- '(secretly) steal', hide' is often considered, but is only possible if one considers a secondary s-mobile and if the initial cluster *skl- can be simplified to *sl- ([LIV²](src-141) 363-364, [ALEW](src-352) 940-941).

Source: 165[187-188{S.v. Proto-Germanic *grētan- 'to wail' (Goth. gretan- 'to cry', ON gráta- 'id.', from PIE *g̑ʰréh₁d-e-, cf. Skt. hrādate 'to sound' < *g̑ʰreh₁d-e-, W griddfan 'to groan' < *g̑ʰreh₁d-).}];141[202{S.v. ?*⁽g̑⁾ʰreh₁d- 'weinen' (IEW 439). Only Germanic.}];556[241{S.v. Gmc. *grǣt-a- 'weinen', without secure comparisons outside of Germanic.}];269[{Etymological connections outside of Germanic not certainly agreed (cf. Seebold 1970:241, LIV² 202), but cf. Kroonen (2013:187-188) for proposed connections in Indic and Celtic.}];179[160-161{S.v. Goth. G106. gretan. Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Older proposals (e.g. [IEW](src-49) 439) uncertain. No ascertainable cognates| possibly an onomatopoeic formation.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Germanic uncertain ([Seebold 1970](src-556):241, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):160-161, [LIV²](src-141) 202), but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):187-188 for proposed connections in Indic and Celtic.

Source: 54[96{S.v. Lat. casa 'cottage, hut'. Origins disputed| possibly an early loanword in Latin.}];316[103{S.v. Lat. casa 'hutte, cabane', popular word of unknown origin. The intervocalic -s- is suggestive of a loanword from a pre-Indo-European language.}];444[165-166{S.v. 1728 Lat. casa 'Haus'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin casa 'small house, hut, cabin' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):165-166). Further origins uncertain, possibly a loanword from one of the non-Indo-European languages of Ancient Italy ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):103, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):96).

Source: 353[161{S.v. Lith. gailùs 'sharp, bitter, cold, lamentable, cold, angry', Proto-Balto-Slavic *goilos (cf. Latv. gails 'voluptous, slender, without branches, glowing', OPruss. gaylis 'white', OCS dzělъ, Russ. zeló)| perhaps to PIE *gʰoi-lo- if comparable with OHG geil 'reckless, frolic, strong'.}];352[280-281{Cf. s.v. OLith. gaĩla 'schmerzlich, bedauerlich, schade'| Latv. gaîlêt, gàilêt 'glimmen, glühen' gàile 'Glimmen, Glut', and OPr. gaylis 'weiß' are probably not root-cognate on the basis of the divergent semantics.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Sometimes compared to Lithuanian gaĩla 'painful, unfortunate, pitiable', although the connection is uncertain due to the diverging semantics ([ALEW](src-352) 280-281, cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):161, accepting the etymology).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3890; compare 'fear' from *der- 'peirce, tear, split, burst' [cognate set 2259](cog-2259)

Source: 352[523{S.v. OLith. krẽklas 'weibliche Brust' (BSl. cf. OPr. kraclan 'Brust'). No clear comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Justification: Cf. Old Lithuanian krẽklas 'female breast'; no certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 523).

Source: 352[308{S.v. OLith. gėlė̃ 'Blume'. Etymologically isolated.  Traditionally connected with words for 'yellow' (gel̃sti 'become yellow') which are in turn often considered to be reflexes of PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow', but this root identification is uncertain due to the unexpected initial velar / g / (cf. žélti 'grünen, sprießen' < *g̑ʰelh₃- where the correspondence of *g̑ʰ- > ž- is lautgesetzlich).}]
Justification: No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 308).

Source: 442[316{S.v. 5582 Skt. *ḍhākka 'back, waist'}]
Justification: Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *ḍhākka- 'back, waist' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):316, no. 5582). No further etymology.

Source: 352[1304-1305{S.v. Old Lithuanian žíedas 'Blüte, Blume' (BSl. cf. Latv. ziêds 'Blüte, Blume| Geschenk, Gabe, Spende, Opfergabe| Angabe, Steuer'. An o-grade derivation with the semantics of a τόμος-derivative to Lith. žydė́ti 'blühen'. Etymologically isolated| Lith. žievė̃ , Latv. zievis 'Baumrinde' deviates too strongly to be certain of a root etymology. No reliable comparanda outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: Cf. Lithuanian žíedas 'blossom, flower'. No certain etymology outside of Baltic ([ALEW](src-352) 1304-1305).

Source: 352[153{S.v. OLith. butà 'Gebäude, Haus, Wohnung' (BSl. OPr. buttan 'Haus'). Lith. butà, bùtas, and OPr. buttan are not to be separated from Proto-Celtic *butā- 'Haus' (OIr. both 'Hütte', MW bod 'Wohnsitz, Haus'). This exclusively Baltic-Celtic lexeme doubtlessly belongs etymologically to Lith. bū́ti 'sein' (< PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'wachsen, entstehen, werden'), but the nouns have a short vowel in contrast to the verb. The short vowel, however, is not unexpected in Celtic and it is suggestive that the word might be a loanword from a continental Celtic dialect into Proto-Baltic. A further possible Celtic loanword into Proto-Baltic is kárvė 'Kuh'.}];353[107{S.v. Lith. bùtas 'flat, apartment| (dial.) house, cottage' (OPr. buttan 'house', from PIE *bʰh₂u-t- (cf. OIr. both 'hut', OIc. buð 'house, residence'). The short vowel found in the OIr. both < *bʰh₂u-téh₂- can be viewed as regular in pretonic position, but this explanation is problematic in Balto-Slavic. The short vowel found in this form is therefore problematic.}];531[82{S.v. Lith. bùtas 'do mieszkalny, chata| budynek gospodarski| obejście| (w mieście) mieszkanie'| corresponding to Old Prussian buttan (acc.sg.) 'dom'| it is normally connected with Lith. bū́ti 'być', but note that the problem of the short -u- in the form remains unresolved.}]
Justification: Cf. Old Lithuanian butà 'building, house, dwelling'; these Baltic lexemes are not to be separated from Proto-Celtic *butā- 'house' (cf. Old Irish buth, Middle Welsh bod); perhaps a derivative of PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, originate, become', although the short vowel found in the Baltic forms is problematic and has led some to consider an old loanword from Continental Celtic into Proto-Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 153, [Derksen 2015](src-353):107, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):83, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):68).

Source: 534[II:175{S.v. Latv. sēta, a derivative of the IE root *sē(i)- 'siet'.}]
Justification: Cf. Latvian sēta 'fence', generally considered to be a derivative of PIE *seh₂(i̯)- 'to tie, bind' ([Karulis 1992](src-534):175, for further discussion on the root reconstruction, cf. [cognate set 3055](cog-3055)).

Source: 442[474{Cf. s.v. 8370 Skt. pr̥ṣṭí-, °ṭī́ – f. 'vertebrae' RV., AV., 'back' & 8371 Skt. pr̥ṣṭhá- n. 'back, hinder part'.}];172[II:100-101{S.v. Ved. pr̥ṣtí- 'Rippe' (cf. IIr. in YAv. paršti-, etc. with full-grade), not to be separated from Ved. párśu- 'Rippe', connections outside of IIr. are uncertain. Possibly IE *perk̑- if to be connected with OCS prьsi 'breast'.}];336[{Shows that Middle Indic preserves i-stem o that Avestan and Indic can be matched and there is no advantage in connecting Avestan to Vedic prṣṭí- 'rib' instead of prṣṭhá- 'back'. So, all the words for 'back' can have one single source *pr̥-sth₂-o/i- cognate with Slavic words for 'finger'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult, possibly further derived from PIE *pr̥-sth₂-o/i- ([Catt 2014](src-336); cf. also [EWAia](src-172) II:100-101, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):474).

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 352[933{S.v. OLith. *skríeti 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen' (BSl. Latv. skrìet 'laufen, rennen, fliegen', with closest possible cognates found in OCS krilo 'Flügel' (etc.). Clear comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking.}];141[562{S.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). Verbal only Baltic. Present stem *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾réi̯-e- > Lith. skrejù (skriẽti) 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen', Latv. skreju (skriet) 'laufen, rennen, fliegen'.}]
Justification: Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ([ALEW](src-352) 933, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 562). Identical to 'fly_V' in [cognate set 2273](cog-2273).

Source: 352[1042-1043{S.v. OLith. šlaunìs 'Hüfte, Oberschenkel', from PIE *k̑lóu̯ni- (cf. Bed. śróṇi- 'Hüfte, Hinterbacke', YAv. sraoni- 'Hinterbacke, Hüfte', Lat. clūnis 'Hinterbacke, Hinterkeule, Steiß', Middle Welsh clun 'Oberschenkel, Hüfte, Hinterbacke', Bret. klun 'Hinterbacke, Gesäß', ONor. hlaunn 'Hinterbacke, Steiß').}];156[III:110-111{S.v. Oss. sīn | sujnæ 'бедро', from Proto-Iranian *srau̯ni- from PIE *k̑lou̯ni- (cf. Lith. slaunìs, OIc. hlaun, Lat. clunis, etc.).}];353[452{S.v. Lith. šlaunìs 'thigh, hip' (Latv. slaũna 'hip'), from PIE *k̑lou-ni- (cf. Skt. śróṇi- 'buttock, hip, loin', Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip', Lat. clūnis 'buttocks, haunch', OIc. hlaun 'loin, buttock').}];172[II:671-672{Cf. s.v. Ved. śróni- 'Hüfte, Hinterbacke, Lende' (Av. sraoni-), from PIE *k̑lou̯ni- (cf. Lat. clūnis 'Hinterbacke, Keule, Steiß', W clun 'Hüfte', Lith. šlaunìs 'Hüfte, Oberschenkel', Latv. slauns 'Schenkelstück', etc.).}];50[209{S.v. Proto-Celtic *klowni- 'thigh', from PIE *k̑lou̯ni- (IEW 607f.), cf. Lat. clūnis, OIc. hlaun, Lith. šlaunìs.}];442[738{For Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 12729 Ved. śrṓṇi f. usu. du. (lex. also m.) ʻ hip and loins, buttocks ʼ RV.}]

54[336{Cf. s.v. levis 'light in weight' from PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light', which has been remodelled as an i-stem *leχwī̆- in Proto-Italic.  Lat. levāre 'to relieve, lessen, lift up' is a derived verb from this adjective.}];423[III:636-638{Cf. s.v. Span. leve 'ligero, leve', from Lat. levis [from which llevar is a derivative].}];444[405-406{S.v. 5000 Lat. levāre 'heben'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):405-406, cf. [DCECH](src-423) III:636-638), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):336).

Source: 296[S:85-86{S.v. sengán 'fourmi', from seng 'mince' + a diminutive suffix. OIr. seng may perhaps be from a root *su̯eng- (or *su̯eg- with with a nasal-infix) expressing the idea of a movement of the body (cf. Germ. schwingen (IEW 1047).}];556[493{Cf. s.v. Germanic *swengw-a- 'schwingen', no secure comparisons outside of Germanic.}];397[836{Cf. s.v. NHG schwingen < PGmc. *swengw-a-, without clear correspondences outside of Germanic.}]
Comment: seng- 'thin, slender' and suffix -an
Justification: Goidelic lexemes from Old Irish sengán 'ant'. Etymology uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Proto-Germanic *swengwan- 'to swing' (so [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:85-86, but proposed connections for this verb outside of Germanic are rejected by [Seebold 1970](src-556):493, cf. {Kluge 2011}:836).

Source: 50[400{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wlkʷo- 'bad, evil' (cf. OIr. olc), from PIE *u̯l̥kʷo- 'wolf' (cf. Skt. vŕ̥ka-, Gk. λύκος, Lat. lupus, Lith. vil̃kas, OCS vlъkъ, Goth. wulfs). Less persuasive is a suggested connection to Lat. ulciscor 'take vengeance'.}];760[173-175]
Justification: From Old Irish olc and generally further connected with PIE *u̯ĺ̥kʷo- 'wolf' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):400, [McCone 1985](src-760):173–175; cf. also [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:20 for references to older literature).

Source: 296[U:21-22{S.v. OIr. uiseóg, later fuiseóg 'alouette', cf. further s.v. uis 'doux, soumis, convenable'. Seems to be confused early on with uisse 'juste, convenable' to the point that it is sometimes seen as the same word. If uisse is to be connected to the root of Lat. iūstus one should look for a different etymology. It is possible that two different words have merged in their meaning.}]
Justification: To be connected with Old Irish uis 'sweet, suitable, appropriate', but further etymology obscure ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:21-22).

Source: 50[113{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ed-o-, from PIE *h₁ed- 'eat'.}];141[230{S.v. *h₁ed- '(beißen →) essen' (IEW 287-9).}]
Justification: Possibly cognate with 'bite' in [cognate set 4968](cog-4968) if IE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth' is ultimately derived from *h₁ed- *'bite' → 'eat', cf. notes to 'tooth' in [cognate set 328](cog-328) for further discussion. In any case the denominal verbs in [cognate set 4968](cog-4968) are a secondary replacement from the inherited primary verbal stem derived from *h₁ed-.

Source: 50[363-364{S.v. Proto-Celtic *swerwo- 'bitter'. These Celtic words lack a persuasive IE etymology. A connection with *su̯er- 'wound' (postulated by IEW 1050) is possible (cf. Av. xᵛara- 'wound', OHG swero 'pain').}];296[S:90{S.v. OIr. (1) serb 'amer'. The Celtic forms suppose a root *swer- followed by a suffix -wo-. The root signifies without doubt 'faire souffrir' (cf. Av. xʷara 'blessure', OHG swero 'maladie, douleur, abcès').}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Matasović 2009](src-50):363-364), for various proposals cf. [IEW](src-49) 1050, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:90).

Source: 423[IV:498-502{S.v. Sp. perro, of uncertain origin, possibly an imitative/expressive creation.}]
Justification: No certain etymology, probably of expressive or imitative origin (cf. [DCECH](src-423) IV:498-502).

Source: 231[{S.v. ScG. giùlain 'a carrying' : *gesu-lo-, root *ges- 'carry' (Lat. gero, gestum).}];316[273-274{Cf. s.v. Lat. gerō, -is, gessī, gestum, gerere 'porter'. A verb like gerō has no chance of being a loanword, but there are no good comparisons among the Indo-European languages for a root *ges-. It is exceptional that a verbal root of this archaic type has no correspondences outside of Latin.}];679[18-19{"The connection of gerĕre, gessī, gestum with the root *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' goes back to Osthoff (BB. 19, 321). EM [[Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316)] do not even mention it, and WH [[Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954](src-175)] have reservations regarding its correctness. The pair *h₂eg̑-, *h₂eg̑-es- is probably paralleled by *h₂euh₁-, *h₂uh₁-es- in Gr. αὐλή vs. Hitt. ḫuiš-zi 'lives' (see Barton 1988, esp. 54-55). gerere is a possible case of *HC-."}];54[259{S.v. Lat. gerō, -ere 'to bear, carry', following the rehabilitation of the etymology to *h₂g̑-es- after the discussion of [Schrijver 1991](src-679):18-19.}];269[{[Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):195 suggested a connection to a basic root *ges- and to be compared with Latin gerere 'to carry, bear about' (past participle gestum), however the root etymology of Latin gerō, -ere is disputed. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):18-19 tentatively rehabilitates an old proposal by Osthoff to *h₂eg̑- via a perform *h₂g̑-és-, and this followed by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):259, but cf. the skepticism of [Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954](src-175) I:595-596, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):273-274. If the connection of Scottish Gaelic giùlain to a neo-root *ges- (< *h₂g̑-és-?) is to be maintained, this would be a unique Italo-Celtic lexical(-morphological) isogloss. Given the multiple degrees of speculation required to posit an ultimate root etymology to PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' for this exclusively Scottish Gaelic cognate set, the root reference form has been given as the Gaelic form itself.}]
Justification: [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):195 suggested a connection to a basic root *ges- and to be compared with Latin gerere 'to carry, bear about' (past participle gestum), however the root etymology of Latin gerō, -ere is disputed. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):18-19 tentatively rehabilitates an old proposal by Osthoff to *h₂eg̑- via a perform *h₂g̑-és-, and this followed by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):259, but cf. the skepticism of [Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954](src-175) I:595-596, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):273-274. If the connection of Scottish Gaelic giùlain to a neo-root *ges- (< *h₂g̑-és-?) is to be maintained, this would be a unique Italo-Celtic lexical(-morphological) isogloss. Given the multiple degrees of speculation required to posit an ultimate root etymology to PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' for this exclusively Scottish Gaelic cognate set, the root reference form has been given as the Gaelic form itself.

Source: 423[IV:66-67{S.v. Sp. miedo, from Lat. metus, -ūs.}];54[378{S.v. Lat. metus, -ūs 'fear, alarm', no clear etymology outside of Italic.}];316[402{S.v. Lat. metus, -ūs 'crainte', no agreed etymology.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin metus 'fear, alarm' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:66-67), no further etymology outside of Italic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):402, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):378 for various uncertain proposals).

Source: 443[8:86{S.v. Lat. pavor 'furcht' > Fr. peur.}];54[451{Cf. s.v. Lat. paveō 'to be frightened', derivative pavor 'sudden fear, terror'. The verbal stem is from *pou̯-eh₁- 'to fear' (cf. OIr. omun MW ouyn, MCo. own, Bret. oun, 'fear' < Proto-Celtic *ofno- < *pouno-, OIr. úath 'fear' < *pou-to-, W uthr 'terrible' < *pou-tro-).}];444[520{S.v. 6314 Lat. pavor, -ōre 'Furcht'.}];49[827{Cf. s.v. pēu- : pəu- : pū̆- 'schlagen, scharf, schneidend hauen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes in light verb constructions using on Latin pavor 'fear' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):520, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 8:86), further probably to a root *peu̯- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):451, cf. [IEW](src-49) 827, not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 141[124{S.v. *deu̯k- 'ziehen' (IEW 220-1).}];54[181{Cf. s.v. Lat. dūcō, -ere 'to lead, conduct', from PIE *douk-e/o- 'to draw' (cf. MW 1.sg. dygaf, 3.sg. dwc 'to lead, bring', OBret. 3.sg. duc  'carries' < *duke/o-| Hitt. tukzi-, tukkanzi- 'cultivation of plants and animals < *duk-(ent)-i-| Alb. n-duk 'to pull', Goth. tiuhan 'to draw').}];50[108{S.v. Proto-Celtic *duk-o- 'lead, carry', from PIE *deuk- (IEW 220f.), cf. Lat. dūcō 'lead', Goth. tiuhan 'pull'.}]
Justification: Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- ([LIV²](src-141) 124, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):181, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):250 no. 2785, {ref  [Matasović 2009](src-50):108).

Source: 236[{S.v. W cariaf: cario 'to carry, bear', a loanword from Engl. carry.}]
Comment: Loan from English.
Justification: Loanword from English 'carry' (first attested 1500s) ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 105[200{S.v. Alb. kthetër 'claw (particularly, of vulture)', a derivative in -ter of kthej 'to turn', a prefixal derivative of thyej 'to break'.}];369[391-392{Cf. s.v. Alb. thád/ër. -ra 'Tischlerhandwerkzeug, ἐργαλεῖον ξυλουργικόν', 'kleine Axt mit zwei Schneiden, deren eine axtartig, deren meißelartig ist', from which, among other derived vocabulary k(ë)tháder (< kë-thadër) 'Kralle, Fang| Klaue'.}]

728[83-84{S.v. Manx cleeau 'breast, chest, stomach, forehead', = Ir. cliabh.}];296[C:118{Cf. s.v. OIr. clíab 'corbeille, récipient tressé, ruche'| Zupitza has compared the word to ON hlíf 'bouclier' (BB 25 94), cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):116.}]
Justification: Identical to Irish cliabh ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):83-84) from Old Irish clíab 'basket, woven container, hive'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:118 for a suggestion to Old Norse hlíf 'shield'.

Source: 316[376{Cf. s.v. Lat. māchina, -ae 'invention, machination' with the concrete sense 'machine, engin', a loanword from (Doric) Greek μᾱχανᾱ́ 'moyen ingénieux employé pour obtenir un résultat, machine'. The Latin verb māchinō is denominal from the original loanword māchina.}];444[423{S.v. 5206 Lat. machināre 'mahlen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin machināre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):423), a denominal verb to Latin machina 'machine, mechanical device', in turn an early loanword from (West) Greek μᾱχανᾱ́ 'id.' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):376).

Source: 442[132{S.v. 2650 Skt. kaṭhiná- 'hard, stiff' Suśr. [EWA i 144 with lit. groups kaṭhiná-, káṭhōra-, ˚ōla-, kaṭhara-, kaḍḍati as ← Drav. Tam. kaṭṭu 'hardness', Tu. gaṭṭi, &c.]}];399[I:144{S.v. Skt. kaṭhiná- 'hart, fest', 'hard, firm', probably a Dravidian loanword, cf. Tamil taṭṭu- 'hart machen'. Cf. káḍḍati 'ist hart'.}]
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm', probably a loanword from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):132 no .2650, [KEWA](src-399) I:144).

Source: 443[16:73-80{Cf. s.v. *grîpan- (anfrk.) 'greifen'.}]
Justification: Romance nominal derivatives based on a loanword from Old High German grīfan 'to grasp, grab' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):330, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 16:73-80).
Loan from North Italian
Loanword from North Italian

Comment: Loan from Old High German

Source: 442[133{S.v. 2657 kaḍḍ 'be rough', káḍḍati Dhātup. [See kaṭhiná-] N. B. Or. kaṛā 'rough', H. kaṛā, kaṛṛā.}];399[I:144{S.v. Skt. kaṭhiná- 'hart, fest', 'hard, firm', probably a Dravidian loanword, cf. Tamil taṭṭu- 'hart machen'. Cf. káḍḍati 'ist hart'.}]
Comment: cf. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati, Turner 1962-66, p. 133, no. 2657; loan from a substrate (Munda or Dravidian), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p 144; perhaps related to [cognate set 6387](cog-6387)
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):133 no. 2657. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati 'is hard'. [KEWA](src-399) I:144 groups with kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm' as part of a group of probable loans from Dravidian (cf. Tamil kaṭṭu 'hardness').
Loanword from Middle Low German schrī(e)n.

Comment: cf. Persian سفت seft
Justification: Parallel loans into Indic from Persian.
Loanword from Italian or Latin combatt(u)ere 'to fight'.

Probably an onomatopoeic form in origin ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:241). Cf. also [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):109, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Deshayes 2003](src-309):425-426.

Source: 443[6/1:234{S.v. Lat. mansio 'aufenthalt, unterkunft' > Fr. maison.}];54[362{S.v. Lat. maneō 'to remain in the same place' < PIE *mn̥-eh₁-, (*men- 'stay') from which Lat. mansiō 'staying, lodging' is derived.}];141[437{Cf. s.v. 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' (IEW 729).}];444[433{S.v. 5311 Lat. ma(n)sio, -ōne 'Unterkunft'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin mansio 'a staying, a remaining; lodging' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):433, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 6/1:234). Further to PIE 2. *men- 'stay, wait' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):362, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 437).

Source: 105[421{S.v. Alb. shkoj 'to go'. Etymology unclear, cf. entry in Orel for various proposals. (Principally cf. Jokl 1911:80-82 < *shteg 'path', alternatively Meyer 1891:408, comparing Lat. sequor 'follow').}];585[408{S.v. Alb. škoń 'gehe vorüber, verfliesse'| the sounds satisfy a derivation from Lat. sequor, the meaning not quite ("Den Lauten genügt Herleitung aus lat. sequor, der Bedeutung nicht ganz.").}];661[80-82{Rejects Meyer's connection to Lat. sequor as semantically implausible and proposes instead a denominative formation to Alb. štek, štegu 'Weg'.}];571[114{S.v. Alb. shkoj '(move from one place to another)', following Jokl (1911:80-2)'s etymology to Alb. shteg 'path' akin to Gk. στοῖχος 'row, line', OCS stьdza 'path'.}];130[86{Rejects Jokl and others from PIE *stei̯gʰ 'schreiten / walk' on the basis that the tectal should be preserved in *stoiGh-, consequently considers the proposal of a loan from Lat. sequor (so Meyer 1891:406) more likely.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. Originally proposed a loanword from Latin sequor 'follow' by [Meyer 1891](src-585):408 and followed by [Holm 2011](src-130):86; alternatively considered since [Jokl 1911](src-661):80-82 to be connected with Albanian shteg 'path', cognate with Greek στοῖχος 'row, line' and derived from PIE *stei̯gʰ- (followed by [Huld 1984](src-571):114, [Orel 1998](src-105):421; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 593-594, without Albanian). [Not in [Demiraj 1997](src-369), [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364)].

Source: 728[93-94{S.v. Manx coontey 'counting, thinking, considering', cf. ScG. cunndadh.}]

423[II:290{S.v. Span. cumplir, from Lat. complēre 'llenar'. Cf. derived cumplido = Port. cumprido.}];54[472-473{Cf. s.v. Lat. -pleō 'to fill' (complēre 'to fill, complete'), from PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill'.}];141[482-483{Cf. s.v. *pleh₁- 'sich füllen, voll werden' (IEW 798-800).}]
Justification: Derived from Latin complēre 'to fill, complete' (cf. [DCECH](src-423) II:290), further to PIE *pleh₁- 'be filled, become full' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):472-473, [LIV²](src-141) 482-483).

Source: 309[281{S.v. Bret. gouel 'pleur(s)', apparently a loanword from English wail 'gémissement, plainte', with derivative goueliñ (ouilein, 1723) pleurer.}];305[223{"MoB gouelañ, V gouilein 'to weep', MW wyl-aw 'id' The MCo. equivalent is ole, wole 'id'. B g- is secondary ([Pedersen 1909](src-307): 321). The etymology is unknown: LPBr. *uil- may reflect PCl. *(φ)eil-, *(φ)idl-, *(φ)ugl-, or *(φ)udl-."}]
Justification: No certain etymology ([Schrijver 1995](src-305):223). [Deshayes 2003](src-309):281 considers a loanword from English wail.

Source: 728[243{S.v. Manx keayney 'crying' (= Ir. caoine).}];296[C:18-19{S.v. OIr. caínid, coínid 'il pleure, il déplore'. Probably a borrowing from Brythonic.}];749[177{A denominal verb caíne 'act of weeping, lamenting', borrowed from W cwyn following [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:18. OIr. caíne and W cwyn cannot be simple cognates and a borrowing would be a straightforward solution, however the same problem occurs with OIr. maín 'riches' and W mwyn, and in view of this perhaps there is a sound law that is not yet understood.}]
Justification: Probably a loanword from Brythonic, cf. Welsh cwyn 'complaint' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:18-19), but cf. the discussion of [Le Mair 2011](src-749):177.

Source: 105[301-302{S.v. Alb. nuhas 'to smell, to sniff', borrowed from Slav. *n’uxati 'id.', otherwise unattested in South Slavic. The same root is attested in SCr. njušiti 'id.'.}];585[311{Cf. s.v. Alb. nuhurít 'spüre, spüre nach, suche (vom Hünde)'. nuhár 'Feinschmecker', from se. njuh 'Geruch', njušiti 'schnüffeln (vom Hünde), cf. Slov. njuhati, Russ. njuchatь.}]
Justification: A loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian njušiti 'to smell' (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):311, [Orel 1998](src-105):301-302).

Source: 296[C:98{S.v. OIr. ciïd 'il se lamente, pleure'. Of uncertain etymology. Cf. entry for several doubtful proposals in older literature.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:98 for various proposals.

Source: 309[267{S.v. Bret. garm 'cri', corresponding to Co. garm, Wel. garm, and Ir. gairm, from Proto-Celtic *gar-(s)mn.}];50[152{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *gar(r)man- 'cry, shout', which may be derived from a zero-grade formation *g̑h₂r-smen-, cf. Proto-Celtic *gāri-, *garyo- 'word, command' (OIr. gáir), from PIE *g̑eh₂r- 'shout, call' (cf. Gk. γῆρυς 'voice, call', Lat. garrio 'chatter', OE cearu 'care, sorrow', Khot. ysār- 'to sing' (cs.)).}]
236[{Cf. s.v. cri² 'cry, clamour', a loanword from Middle English crye| and s.v. criaf : crio 'to cry, to shout| to cry, to weep'.}]
Justification: Denominal formation from Welsh cri 'cry', respectively a loanword from English cry ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 85[{S.v. Romanian bărbát, -ă, from Lat. barbatus.}];54[69{Cf. s.v. Lat. barba 'beard', from which barbātus 'bearded' is derived. Lat. barba may go back to Proto-Italic *farfā- 'beard' and compared with OPr. bordus 'beard', Lith. barzdà, Latv. bā̀rda, OCS brada, Ru. borodá 'id.' < PSl. *bordáʔ, OHG bart, OE beard, OFr. berd < Gmc. bard-a-. From PIt. farfa we expect Lat. *farba. Earlier sources (cf. Ernout-Meillet 1985) explain the initial b- from assimilation to -rb-. The *a is difficult to explain via ablaut and rather points to a non-IE borrowing into the European languages.}];352[97{Cf. s.v. OLith. barzdá 'Bart' (cf. OCS brada 'Bart', Lat. barba 'Bart', OE beard 'Bart', OHG bart 'Bart' < PIE *bʰarsdʰó- 'Bart').}]
Justification: From Latin barbatus 'bearded' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), a derivative of Latin barba 'beard'. For the IE reconstruction see [ALEW](src-352) 97, but cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):69 considering a European loanword on the basis of having to reconstruct PIE *a.

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. gât, a borrowing from Slavic glŭtŭ 'sip, gulp'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic *glъtъ 'sip, gulp' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Comment: Related to Turner no. 1935???

Source: 309[734{S.v. Bret. toull 'trou, embrasure, entrée| vide, lacune', from Old Breton tull and corresponding to Co. toll 'trou, terrier', W twll 'trou', Ir. toll 'creux' and ScG. toll 'creux', from Proto-Celtic *tuk-slo-.}];50[393-394{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tullo- 'pierced, perforated', derived from PIE *teu̯k- 'beat, perforate'.}];141[640{Cf. s.v 1. *teu̯k- 'stoßen, schlagen' (IEW 1032).}]
Justification: Generally derived from Proto-Celtic *tuk-slo- ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):734, but cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):393-394 preferring *tullo-), ultimately derived from PIE *teu̯k- 'beat, hit' ([LIV²](src-141) 640).

Source: 54[91{S.v. Lat. caput, -itis 'head', from Proto-Italic *kaput-. IE cognates exist in Celtic (OIr. cúāch, W. cawg 'cup') and Germanic (Goth. haubiþ 'head', ONor. hǫfuð, haufuð, OEng. hēafod, OHG houbit, NHG Haupt, etc), perhaps derived from PIE *keh₂p- 'fassen, schnappen' also found in Lat. capiō, -ere [cf. [cognate set 5290](cog-5290)].}];165[215{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ha(u)beda- ~ *ha(u)buda- 'head', from PIE *kh₂p-ut- (cf. Lat. caput, -itis 'head'| OIr. cúach, W cawg 'cup' < *kapuko-). Cf. entry in Kroonen regarding the variation of the root *hab- ~ *haub- in Germanic.}];397[530-531{S.v. NHG Haupt (MHG houbet, OHG houbit, OS hōbid), from Germanic *haubida- 'Haupt', also found in Goth. haubiϸ, ON haufið, OE hēafod, OFr. hāved, hā(u)d, hafd. May be compared with Lat. caput and probably from a formation with suffix ablaut *kapwet-, *kaput-. Other words from the same root like Skt. kapā́la- 'Schale, Hirnschale, Schädel' suggest semantics from 'Hirnschale'.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *ha(u)beda- ~ *ha(u)buda- 'head' and Italic lexemes from Latin caput, generally considered root and suffix cognate, but further identification of an Indo-European root etymology remains controversial. A frequent suggestion is to PIE *keh₂p- 'to grasp, seize' found in Latin capiō, -ere 'id.' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):215, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):91). Alternatively a frequent comparison is made to Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull' with a different nominal suffix, but this cognate relationship remains uncertain ([Kluge 2011](src-397):530-531, [KEWA](src-399) I:155, [EWAia](src-172) I:300).

Source: 728[366{S.v. Manx reuyrey 'digging, searching', cf. Ir. rómhar.}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish rúamor 'digging', derivative of rúam 'spade'. Further etymology unclear, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:48-49 for various previous proposals which remain uncertain.

Source: 364[265{Alb. gj- (< s-) speaks for an inherited word but in absence of a convincing IE etymology, a loan from Lat. sinus 'hallow, curve' has to be taken into consideration - but earlier than the bulk of Latin loanwords which show the development s > sh.}];130[54-55{Etymology dubious, cf. for discussion of various proposals.}];105[135{S.v. Alb. gji ~ gjî 'breast, chest'| Orel assumes PAlb. *sina, identical to Lat. sinus 'curve, fold'.}]
Comment: etymology unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):135, [Holm 2011](src-130):54-55, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):265 for further discussion.

Source: 50[72{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bowd-ro- 'dirty', from PIE *gʷeu̯-dʰ- 'excrement, defecate' ([IEW](src-49) 484), cf. Skt. guváti 'cacat', OE cwéad 'dirt'.}]

728[47-48{S.v. Manx broghe 'dirty, soiled' (= Ir. bróghach).}];296[B:94-95, 98-99{S.v. OIr. brod 'poussière, paille, éclat, tache'| derived adjective brodach 'sale'| same word as broth 'épi, poil, brin de paille'.}]

369[200-201{S.v. Alb. hídhët 'bitter, traurig, betrübt'. Jokl's connection to Gk. αἴθω 'burn' is impeccable. The Albanian basis *hið(-) appears to be a zero-grade formation *h₂idʰ- (cf. Gk. ἰθαρός 'heiter').}];141[259{Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'entzünden' (IEW 11-2).}];105[143-144, 147{S.v. hidhët 'bitter, sad', which O. derives from hidhem 'to jump, overflow', a reflexive of hedh 'to throw, shoot' < PIE *skeud- 'to throw, shoot' (Gmc. *skiutan 'to shoot').}];269[{Etymology of Orel (1998:147) seems too semantically remote| etymology here follows Demiraj (1997:200-201).}]
Justification: Cognacy in this class follows [Demiraj 1997](src-369):200-201 deriving to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle, ignite (smth.)', but cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):147.

Source: 50[163-164{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gn-iyo- 'beget, create, do', from PIE *g̑enh₁- (cf. Lat. gignō, Skt. jánati 'begets').}];141[163-165{S.v. *g̑enh₁- 'erzeugen' (IEW 390-1).}];296[D:149{S.v. OIr. do-gní 'il fait, agit, accomplit, produit'. Composed of the verb gní- 'faire' and the preverb di-.}];304[339-347{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gn-ii̯e/o- '(er)zeugen, tun, machen', from PIE *g̑enh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 163-165).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gn-ii̯o- 'to beget; to make, do', a derivative of PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce, beget' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:149, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):339-347, [Matasović 2009](src-50):163-164, [LIV²](src-141) 163-165). The Goidelic lexemes in this set continue a compound with the preverb de-, di- 'from, away from'.

Source: 50[429-430{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wreg-o- 'do, make' (cf. Myc.Gk. wo-ze / worzei /, Goth. waurkjan).}];141[686-687{S.v. 2. *u̯erg̑- 'wirken, machen' (IEW 1168-9).}];240[76{S.v. OW guragun 'to make', from PIE *u̯erg̑-, *u̯reg̑- 'wirken, tun'.}];304[707-711{S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯reg-e/o- 'tun, machen', from PIE 2. *u̯erg̑- (LIV2 686f.).}]
Justification: Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *u̯reg-e/o- 'to make, do', ultimately from PIE *u̯erg̑- 'to act, do' ([LIV²](src-141) 686-687, cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):76, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):707-711, [Matasović 2009](src-50):429-430).

Source: 84[{From Middle English byrd , bryd, in turn from Old English brid. There is no corresponding form in any other Germanic language, and the etymology is unknown.}]
Justification: From Old English brid, further etymology unknown ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 97[{S.v. Da. bitter, a loan from Low German.}]
Justification: Loans from Low German (cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)).  Given that Danish is the main lexical source of Riksmal, and the latter derives from it within the last few centuries, the loan event here should arguably have been into Danish before the derivation of Riksmal, and therefore not 'parallel'.

Source: 443[4:225{Cf. s.v. Lat. *granica.}];54[271{S.v. Lat. grānum 'grain, seed', from PIE *g̑rh₂-no- 'which has ripened, fruit, grain' (√*g̑erh₂-), to be connected with Celtic, Iranian, Baltic, Slavic, and Germanic words for grain (cf. OIr. grán, W. grawn, Co. gronen, Bret. greun, 'grain' < PCl. *grāno-, Pashto zaṇai, zaṛai 'kernel, seed', OPr. syrne 'grain', Lith. žìrnis, Latv. zir̃nis 'pea', OCS zrъno, Ru. zernó, SCr. zȑno 'grain' < BSl. *źirn-, Go. kaurn, OHG korn 'grain' < PGmc. *kurna-).}];165[312{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kurna- 'corn, wheat', from PIE *g̑r̥h₂-no- (cf. Lat. grānum 'grain, seed', OIr. grán, OCS zrъno < *g̑rh₂-no-| Lith. žìrnis, Latv. zir̃nis 'pea' < *g̑rh₂-n-io-| OPru. syrne 'grain').}];397[532{Cf. s.v. NHG Korn (MHG korn, OHG korn, OS korn), from Gmc. *kurna-, also in ON korn, OE corn, OFr. korn, Goth. kaurn 'Getreide', kaurno 'einzelnes Korn', from IE *gr̥Hnó- 'Korn', also in Lat. grānum, OIr. grán, OCS zrĭno, Lith. žìrnis.}];444[327-328{S.v. 3846 Lat. granum 'Korn'.}]
Justification: From PIE *g̑erh₂- 'wear down, make old' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):271, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):312; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 165-166); for the Romance lexemes in this class from Latin granum 'grain, seed', cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):327-328.

Source: 105[226, 494, 511-512{S.v. Alb. lëvore 'peel, skin, rag', a formation parallel to lëvere 'cloth, rag, laundry', being in turn a prefixal derivative of var 'to hang', being an ablaut variant of vjerr 'to hang', which continues PAlb. *wara and related to Gk. ἀείρω 'to raise up', Lith. veriù, vérti 'to weigh', sveriù, sver̃ti 'to open, to thread'.}];130[50-51{Rejects the etymology of Orel (1998:222, etc.) as from the same root as vjerr 'to hang' as semantically and derivationally too remote. A better solution is to connect to Alb. lëvozhgë 'hard shell, peel, skin' < *leu̯eHgʷʰ-ske, which should be an Albanian extension of PIE *leu̯H- with the semantically close Gmc *lawa- > Lohe 'tan / abgelöste Rinde als Gerbmittel', which might have been influenced by SCr. ljuska 'peel, crust', probably from the same root.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):226, 494, 511-512; [Holm 2011](src-130):50-51 for further discussion.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. chest (1), from Old English cest, apparently an early adoption of Latin cista, < Greek κίστη box, chest. Compare Old Frisian kiste, (Middle Dutch kiste, Dutch kist), Old High German chista (Middle High German and German kiste). Alternatively, some claim for Old English cest a native origin, comparing German kasten 'box'.}]
Justification: From Old English cest 'box, coffer', perhaps a loanword from Latin cista 'box, chest', but not fully clear (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. cloud, from OE clúd 'a mass of rock, hill'. The current sense 'cloud' is first attested in the 13th century.}]
85[{S.v. Rom. zăpadă, a loan from Slavic zapadati 'to fall'.}]
Justification: Loan from Slavic zapadati 'to fall' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 369[424{S.v. Alb. vrap 'schnell, flink', from which vrap(ë)tój 'laufen, rennen| sausen' is a derivative. Without etymology.}];105[514-515{S.v. Alb. vrap 'to run, make haste', to which O. proposes an etymological connection with rjep 'to strip off (skin or bark), to tear off'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):424, [Orel 1998](src-105):514-515 for various proposals and further discussion.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. cry (v.), a borrowing from French crier, in turn ultimately from Lat. quirītāre 'to raise a plaintive cry, to wail, scream, shriek out, cry aloud, bewail, lament'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Old French crier ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 556[564-565{S.v. Gmc. *wōp-ja- 'weinen'. No secure etymology outside of Germanic.}];468[684{S.v. ON œpa 'rufen, schreien' (< germ. *wōpjan), cf. Goth. wōpjan, OE wēpan 'weinen', OFr. wēpa 'schreien', OS wōpian, OHG wuoffan 'wehklagen', etc.).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):564-565, [de Vries 1977](src-468):684).

Source: 141[610{S.v. ?*su̯eld- 'verhungern, sterben' [IEW 1045]. Root only attested in Germanic. Cf. n1 "nach IEW urspr. 'verschmachten', d-Präs zu 1. *su̯el- 'schwelen, brennen'.}];165[499{S.v. Proto-Germanic *sweltan- 'to dwindle, starve, perish', possibly from PIE *suéld-e-, if to be connected with Arm. kʻalcʻ 'hunger' < *sul̥d-sko-(?). Further details unclear.}];179[336{S.v. Goth. *swiltan, ga-swiltan ᾽ἀποθνήσκειν', 'die'. Etymology uncertain, possibly an extended form of PIE *swel- 'burn, smoulder' + d, also in Arm. k'ałc 'hunger', k'ałc-nu-m 'be hungry' < swl̥d-sk̑o-, unextended form Skt. svarati 'shine'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sweltan- 'to dwindle, starve, perish'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly to a PIE root ?*su̯eld- 'to starve, die' if to be connected with Armenian  kʻalcʻ 'hunger' < ?*su̯l̥d-sk̑o- (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):336, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 610).

Source: 54[541{S.v. Lat. saxum 'rock, boulder'. Formally, the only potential cognates are OIc. sax, OHG sahs 'knife', but since the semantic connection between 'boulder' and knife' is not evident saxum has no certain etymology.}];316[597{S.v. Lat. saxum, -ī 'pierre'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic; previous proposals to Old Icelandic sax Old High German sahs 'knife' are unsatisfactory semantically and formally (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):597, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):541 for further discussion).

Source: 274[417-423{S.v. *k̑ḗr, k̑r̥d-´ n. 'Herz' (IEW 579f.).}];80[469-471{S.v. Hitt. ker / kard(i)- 'heart| center, core', from PIE *k̑ēr, *k̑rd-i-ós, *k̑rd-´.}];172[II:818{S.v. Ved. hŕ̥d- 'Herz', from IIr. *j́ʰā̆rd- /*j́ʰr̥d-, is not completely lautgesetzlich with PIE *k̑ē̆rd-/*k̑r̥d-. The presence of non-etymological *j́ʰ (> Vedic h) in Proto-Indo-Iranian is presumably due to contamination with the Proto-Indo-Iranian outcome of PIE *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- 'guts', cf. cognate set 2672.}];66[644{S.v. καρδία 'heart' < PIE *k̑ēr(d), gen. *k̑rd-(i)os 'heart'.}];79[576-578{S.v. Arm. sirt 'heart', since long derived from PIE *k̑ērd, *k̑r̥d-ós 'heart', etc.}];81[485{S.v. Proto-Slavic *sьrdьce 'heart', with a stem derived from the PIE zero-grade *k̑r̥d-.}];353[448-449{S.v. Lith. širdìs 'heart', from PIE *k̑ērd-, G.sg. *k̑r̥d-ós.}];165[222{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hertōn- 'heart', from a derived n-stem *k̑erd-n-.}];50[223-224{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kridyo- 'heart'.}];54[134-135{S.v. Lat. cor, cordis 'heart', from PIE *k̑ēr, k̑r̥d-os. Latin generalised the oblique (zero-grade) form of the stem *k̑r̥d- > *kord-.}];352[1032-1034{S.v. OLith. širdìs 'Herz, Sinn, Gesinnung' (BSl. cf. Latv. sir̂ds 'Herz| Mut, Zorn', OPr. seyr 'Herz', OCS srьcьce 'Herz', etc.), from PIE *k̑ḗrd-/*k̑r̥d- 'Herz' (cf. Hitt. ker 'Herz' CLuw. zārza 'Herz', Ved. hā́rdi, OAv. zərəd- 'Herz', Gk, κῆρ, 'Herz', καρδία 'Herz| Seele, Geist' Arm. sirt 'Herz', Lat. cor, cordis 'Herz| Geist, Seele', OIr. crude 'Herz', Goth. hairto, etc.).}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *k̑erd- 'heart' ([NIL](src-274) 417-423, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):469-471, [Beekes 2010](src-66):644, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):576-578, [EWAia](src-172) II:818, [ALEW](src-352) 1032-1034, [Derksen 2015](src-353):448-449, [Derksen 2008](src-81):485, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):134-135, [Matasović 2009](src-50):223-224). The irregular correspondence of Proto-Indo-Iranic word-initial *j́ʰ- (> Ved. h-, Av. z-) is presumably due to contamination with Proto-Indo-Iranic outcome of PIE *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- 'guts', cf. cognate set 2672.

Source: 443[339-354{S.v. Lat. prĕhĕndĕre 'ergreifen', whence Fr. prendre.}];54[487{S.v. Lat. prehendō, -ere 'to grasp, seize', from PIE *gʰ-n(e)-d- 'to grab' >> *gʰ(e)nd- (cf. OIr. ro-geinn, NW genni 'to be situated' < PCl. *gan-n-d-e/o-| Gk. χανδάνω 'to grab', Alb. gjen 'finds', Goth. du-ginnan 'to begin').}];141[194{Cf. s.v. *gʰed- 'fassen' (IEW 437-8).}];444[558-559{S.v. 6736 Lat. prehendere 'nehmen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin prehendere 'grasp, seize' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):558-559, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:339-354), further derived from PIE *gʰed- 'grasp' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):487, [LIV²](src-141) 194).

Source: 423[III:636-638{Cf. s.v. Span. leve 'ligero, leve', from Lat. levis [from which llevar is a derivative].}];54[336{Cf. s.v. levis 'light in weight' from PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light', which has been remodelled as an i-stem *leχwī̆- in Proto-Italic. Lat. levāre 'to relieve, lessen, lift up' is a derived verb from this adjective.}];444[405-406{S.v. 5000 Lat. levāre 'heben'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):405-406), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):336).

Comment: Loans in Kurdish would be old, viz. before *rd/rz > ł in Kurdish vs. l in Persian.

Source: 165[75, 170{S.v. Proto-Germanic *garwjan- 'to prepare, make ready'. A factitive verb from PGmc. *garwa- 'ready, quick', in turn probably a prefixed variant of *arwa- < *ga-arwa-. If so, (cf. s.v. *arwa- 'ready, fast') then (as though) from PIE *h₂/₃er-u̯o- and close to TochA ārwar, TochB ārwer 'ready' < PToch. *arwer < *h₂/₃er-ur-. Formally, the root of *arwa- could be either *h₂er- 'order, arrange, fit', or *h₃er- 'set in motion'.}];468[163-164{S.v. ON gera 'machen, tun, breiten', from Proto-Germanic *garwian. Further etymology uncertain. The often assumed explanation from *ga-arwa- is faintly appealing. Cf. entry for further references to older literature.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):163-164, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):75, 150 for proposed further connections.

Source: 443[2:1260{S.v. Lat. coxa 'hip' > Fr. cuisse}];54[140{S.v. Lat. coxa 'hip of a human, haunch of an animal', from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' (cf. OIr. coss 'foot', Skt. kákṣa-, Av. kaša- 'armpit', ToB kakse 'midriff loins').}];444[212{S.v. 2292 Lat. coxa 'Hüfte'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin coxa 'hip' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):212), further to PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):140).

Source: 165[74, 77, 86{S.v. Proto-Germanic *burzda- 'board', from PIE *bʰrzdʰ-o-, related to PGmc. *brezda- 'side, edge, board' < *bʰrezdʰ-o- (NHG Brett, etc.) and *brazda- 'edge, brim' < *bʰrozdʰ-o- (for which cf. OIr. brot 'goad, spike').}];468[50{S.v. borð (2) 'brett, speisetisch' following [IEW](src-49) 136 to a root *bʰerdʰ- 'schneiden', cf. OE bardha-ka- 'abschneidend', Gk. πέρθω 'zerstöre'.}];141[77-78{Cf. s.v. ?*bʰerdʰ- 'erbeuten, einnehmen' (IEW 138), only Greek lexical material discussed.}]
Justification: A semantic extension from Proto-Germanic *burzda- 'board; table'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared to a root *bʰerdʰ- 'to cut' ([IEW](src-49) 138, [de Vries 1977](src-468):50) but only uncertainly postulated as ?*bʰerdʰ- in [LIV²](src-141) 77-78. Alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):74, 86 proposes an etymology comparing a secondary zero-grade form *bruzda- > ON broddr 'tip, edge, shoot', OHG brort 'point, margin' and Old Irish brot 'goad, spike' from an o-grade formation to a postulated root *bʰrezdʰ-.

Source: 179[95{S.v. Goth. D35. *driusan, cf. OEng. drēosan, OSax. driosan 'fall', OIc. dreyra 'drip blood' from 'let drop', OHG trōran (= Goth. -drausjan) 'drip, pour away', etc. No certain extra-Gmc. cognates.}];165[102{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dreusan- 'to fall' (Go. driusan 'to fall down', Nw. drjosa 'id.', OE drēosan 'to rush, fall, perish', OS driosan 'to fall'), a strong verb for which Kroonen reconstructs a preform *dʰréuHs-e-. Cf. *drūsēn- 'fall asleep'.}];141[157-158{S.v. ?*dʰreu̯s- 'fallen, herabfallen' (IEW 274-5). Extra-Germanic comparisons given by IEW to justify a PIE root reconstruction are not entirely clear, cf. n1.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):95, [LIV²](src-141) 157-158, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):102 for further discussion).

Source: 443[17:195-206{S.v. *stakka (anfrk., got.) 'pfahl' > OFr. estache 'vine stake'.}];444[678{S.v. 8218 stakka (got.) 'Pfahl' > OFr. estache, MFr. attache 'Rebpfahl'.}]
Justification: Denominal verbs from a Germanic loanword *stakka 'stake, vine stake' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):678, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:195-206).

Source: 66[202-203{S.v. βαρύς 'heavy' < PIE *gʷr̥h₂-ú- 'heavy'.}];345[230-231{Cf. s.v. TochB krāmär 'weight, heaviness', from a putative PIE *gʷreH-mr̥ 'heaviness'.}];442[91{Cf. s.v. 1962 *udguru- 'very heavy' [Skt. gurú-] for Palula اُنگُروۡ uŋˈɡuɾo.}];172[I:490-491{S.v. Ved. gurú- 'schwer, gewichtig, hart, heftig, drückend, groß', from PIE *gʷr̥h₂-u- (cf. YAv. gouru- 'heavy', Gk. βαρύς 'schwer', etc.).}];165[312{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kuru- 'heavy' (Goth. kaurus* 'heavy'), from PIE *gʷrh₂-u-.}];54[272{S.v. Lat. gravis 'heavy| serious, weighty', from PIE *gʷreh₂-u-. As with other u-stems in Italic, the original PIE *-u- stem was remodelled as an i-stem. (cf. Skt. gurú- 'heavy', Khot. ggarka- 'heavy, respectable', Gk. βαρύς 'heavy', Latv. grũts 'heavy, pregnant' (< *gʷrh₂-u-to-), Goth. kaurjos 'weighty, opressive', TochB krāmär 'weight, heaviness', TochA krāmärts 'heavy').}];534[I:321{Cf. s.v. Latv. grūts, from Proto-Baltic *grūtas, from Proto-Indo-European *gʷru-to-s.}];444[328{Cf. s.v. 3855 Lat. gravis 'schwer', 2. grevis (nach levis).}];149[173-174{S.v. TochB krāmär 'weight, load', TochA krāmärts 'id.', probably from PIE *gʷreh₂-mr̥, gen.sg. *gʷr̥h₂-mén-s, with derived adj. B kramartstse* 'heavy, difficult'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic reflecting different derivatives from PIE *gʷerh₂- (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):173-174, [Adams 2013](src-345):230-231, [Beekes 2010](src-66):202-203, [EWAia](src-172) I:490-491, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):91 no.1962, [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:321, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):312, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):272, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):328 no. 3855).
No certain etymology ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):338).

Source: 728[238{S.v. Manx joan 'dust' (= Ir. deann).}]

231[387{S.v. ScG. ùir 'mould, dust, earth'. Ir., MIr. úir, E.Ir. úr, g. úire : *ûrâ, Norse aurr 'loam, wet clay, mud', Ag.S. eár 'humus'. Stokes hesitates between *ûrâ and *ugrâ, Gk. ὑγρός 'wet'}];296[U:26{S.v. OIr. úr (1) 'sol, terre'| without certain etymology. One has connected the words from the root *weg- (cf. Gk. ὑγρός etc.), without likelihood. The comparison with ON aurr 'gravier, terre', OE éar 'humus' but the vocalism doesn't have a clear correspondence.}]
Justification: Continuing Old Irish úr 'soil, earth' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):387), further etymology unknown (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:26 an evaluation of various uncertain proposals).

Etymology uncertain. No etymology given in [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236); not in [Falileyev 2000](src-240), [Matasović 2009](src-50), [Schumacher 2004](src-304), or [Stokes 1894](src-761).

Source: 81[402{S.v. Proto-Slavic *plàkati 'cry, weep', from PIE *pleh₂k- or *pleh₂g- (cf. AGk. πλήσσω 'beat', Lat. plangere 'beat, beat the breast as a sign of mourning, bewail', OEng. flōcan 'applaud').}];141[484-485{For Italic forms from Lat. plangō, cf. s.v. *pleh₂g- 'schlagen' (IEW 832-3), for the Slavic forms s.v. ?*pleh₂k- 'schlagen (auch als Gestus)' (IEW 831-3). Cf. n1 s.v. ?*pleh₂k-: certainly originally identical with *pleh₂g-, *k from forms with a voiceless suffix.}];54[469-470{S.v. Lat. plangō, -ere 'to beat, strike| mourn, bewail', from PIE *plh₂-n-g- 'to hit', *pl(e)h₂g-h₂- (cf. Gk. πλάζω 'to drive off course', aor. ἐπλήγην, ps. πλάγχθη 'was beaten', Goth. faiflokun 'to hit, flog', OS flōkan 'to curse').}];259[443{PS *plakati ist related to Latin plangō, plangere.}]
Justification: Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₂g- 'to beat'. There is anomalous devoicing of the velar in Slavic, but the two variants *pleh₂g- and ?*pleh₂g- are accepted to be the same root by [LIV²](src-141) 484-485). Cf. also [Derksen 2008](src-81):402, [Boryś 2005](src-259):443, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):469-471.

Source: 338[{From *dānu- 'river' [cognate set 2648](cog-2648).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *dānu-, probably to be further connected with Vedic dā́nu- 'dropping flow, dripping; drops, dew'(?); the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Iranic *dan- < Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰan- 'to run, flow' (< PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 144-145) is not to be excluded ([ESIJa](src-331) II:450-451, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:719-720, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:366-367).

Source: 399[184, 202-204{S.v. Skt. kalyam 'Tagesanbruch', 'day-break', kālyam 'id.', derived from Skt. kālaḥ 'Zeit, Zeitpunkt, Schicksal', 'time, fixed time, destiny, death' ultimately from PIE *kʷel(h₁)- 'turn' (cf. Ved. cárati).}];442[158{S.v. 3104 Skt. kālya- 'timely, seasonable' (> 'yesterday', 'tomorrow' in various Middle and New Indic languages).}];172[I:534-535{Cf. s.v. Ved. √car-ⁱ 'sich bewegen, wandeln, gehen, wandern, fahren', from PIE *kʷel(H)- (cf. Gk. πέλομαι, Lat. colō, etc.).}];141[386-388{Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-) wenden' (IEW 639-40).}]
Justification: Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 386-388.

Source: 172[I:39{S.v. Ved. áka- 'Leid, Schmerz', adv. ákam 'übel, auf schlechte Weise' (IIr. cf. Av. aka- 'schlecht, übel, böse', axti- 'Leiden'). No convincing comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic.}]
Justification: No convincing etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:39).

Comment: loan from Pashto

Source: 443[14:116-119{S.v. vadĕre 'gehen'. Fr. va < Lat. vādō, -ere.}];54[650{S.v. Lat. vādō, -ere, 'to advance, proceed', from PIE *ueh₂dʰ- 'to advance' (cf. W. go-di-wawd 'overtook' < *ueh₂dʰ-, OHG watan, OFr. wada, OIc. vaða 'to wade' < *uh₂dʰ-, OIc. vað, OE væd 'water, lake', etc.).}];141[664{S.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten' (IEW 1109).}];444[760{S.v. 9117 Lat. vadere 'gehen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin uadere 'to advance, proceed' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):760), further to PIE *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'to stride' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 664, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):650).

Source: 423[III:361-362{S.v. Sp. hilo, from Lat. fīlum 'thread, string', derived verb afilo 'sacar filo' (derived adj. afilado).}];54[220{S.v. Lat. fīlum 'thread, line| build (of a person)', from PIE *gʷʰiH-(s-)lo- 'sinew, sinew thread' (cf. MW gieu, W gïau 'sinew, nerves', OCo. goiuen < PIE *gʷiH-, Skt. jyā́- 'tendon, bowstring' < *gʷiH-o-, Av. jiia- 'bowstring', Gk. βιός 'bow| bowstring' < *gʷiH-o-| Arm. ǰil- 'sinew, cord' < *gʷiH-sl-| OPr. pettegislo 'back vein', Lith. gýsla, Latv. dzî(k)sla 'vein, sinew' < Proto-Baltic *giHla-, OCS žila 'vein'). The individual branches do not agree on whether the initial velar was aspirated or not. Indo-Iranian and Greek require *gʷ-, while Latin and Armenian require *gʷʰ-| in the Celtic and Balto-Slavic lexemes the velar is uncertain.}];49[489{Cf. s.v. *gʷʰeiə- : gʷʰī- 'Ader, Sehne, Band'.}];444[286-287{S.v. 3306 Lat. fīlum 'Faden'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes based on a denominal verb from Latin fīlum 'thread, string' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):286-287, [DCECH](src-423) III:361-362); further from PIE *gʷʰiH-(s-)lo- 'sinew, sinew thread'. The Italic forms require the reconstruction of initial voiced-aspirated *gʷʰ-, but other proposed cognates from Indo-Iranian and Greek suggest initial *gʷ- without aspiration (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):220; listed in [IEW](src-49) 489 with only Italic, Celtic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes connected).

Source: 423[II:42{S.v. cerco 'círculo', from Lat. circus 'círculo'.}];54[115{S.v. Lat. cīrcus 'circle, circus', probably a loanword from Gk. κρίκος 'ring', of uncertain origin.}];316[122-123{S.v. Lat. cīrcus, -ī 'cercle', etc. Probably a loanword from Gk. κίρκος, κρίκος 'anneau', a loanword in a technical sense (as also Lat. gȳrus and tornus').}]
Justification: Romance forms from Latin cīrcā, an adverbial form of Latin cīrcus 'circle; circus' ([DCECH](src-423) II:42). Further probably a loanword from Ancient Greek κίρκος, κρίκος 'ring' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):122-123, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):115).

Source: 444[476{S.v. 5772 Lat. mūsculus 'Muskel' > Sp. muslo 'Hinterbacke'.}];54[396-397{S.v. Lat. mūs, mūris 'mouse', with derivative mūsculus 'mussel, small fish, small rodent| muscle', from PIE *muH-s 'mouse' (cf. Skt. mū́ṣ- 'mouse, rat', YAv. mūš- 'name of a Parikā', Gk. μῦς 'mouse', OHG mūs, OCS myšь, TochB maścītse* 'mouse, rat').}];316[424{S.v. Lat. mūs, mūris 'souris, rat', derivative mūsculus 'petite souris| muscle (cf. l'emploi du fr. souris pour désigner un muscle du gigot)'. An Indo-European word (cf. Skt. mū́ḥ, Alb. mī, Gk. μῦς, OHG mūs, etc.).}];657[387{Cf. s.v. MOUSE *mūs ~ *múss (gen. *musós).}];269[{Precise stem analysis difficult| the attested languages consistently show a non-ablauting nom.sg. *mūs, but it is unclear whether this is inherited as such from PIE, or the result of secondary compensatory lengthening from laryngeal loss (e.g., [de Vaan 2008](src-54):396-397 assuming a stem *muH-, cf. also [EIEC](src-657) 387 assuming *mūs < *mus-s).}]
Justification: From Latin mūsculus 'muscle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):476), a derivative of Latin mūs 'mouse', from PIE *mūs, (gen. mūsós) (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):424, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):396-397). Precise stem analysis difficult; the attested languages consistently show a non-ablauting nom.sg. *mūs, but it is unclear whether this is inherited as such from PIE, or the result of secondary compensatory lengthening from laryngeal loss (e.g., [de Vaan 2008](src-54):396-397 assuming a stem *muH-, cf. also [EIEC](src-657) 387 assuming *mūs < *mus-s).

Source: 316[267{S.v. Lat. gamba, -ae 'patte, jarret du cheval et, plus généralement, des quadrupèdes'. A likely borrowing from Greek καμπή 'bending, winding' in the specialised language of Greek veterinarians or breeders.}];444[142{S.v. 1539 Lat. camba (griech.) 'Bein'.}];443[2:111-120{S.v. Lat. camba 'sprunggelenk der Pferde' > Fr. jambe 'Bein'.}]
Justification: This class is coded for Walloon jambe, from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):143, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):267).

Source: 423[I:524-525{S.v. Sp. barriga, possibly from barrica 'barrel', a loanword from Gascon barrique which presupposes *barrīca-, whose further origin uncertain, perhaps Gaulish.}]
Justification: Probable (parallel) loanwords from (Gascon) Occitan barrique 'barrel, wine cask' (cf. [DCECH](src-423) I:524-525).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. burtă 'abdomen, pântece'. Etymology unknown.}]
Justification: Etymology unknown (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 81[133{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dьlgъ adj. 'long' < PIE *dl̥h₁gʰ-ó-, (cf. Skt. dīrghá-, Gk. δολιχός).}];165[327{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic langa- 'long', identical to Lat. longus 'long', a nasalised version of the PIE root *dlh₁gʰ- 'long'. "The adjective thus implies a nasal present *dlénh₁gʰ-e-, which, however, is not attested."}];389[{Cf. in LIV addenda and corrigenda – Neu: ?2.*delh₁- 'verlängern' (IEW 194‑6), Präsens ?*dl̥h₁-éi̯o- aksl. (+) pro-dьľǫ, -dьliti 'verlängern' (Anm. 1 Verbal nur slav. (primär?), Basis vieler Nomina, z.B. aruss. dьlja ‘Länge’ und v.a. die Adj. *dl̥h₁-gʰó- in ved. dīrghá- = av. darəga-, aksl. (+) dlъgъ sowie *dolh₁-i-gʰo- > gr. δολιχός neben *dolh₁-u-Ki- > heth. daluki-, alle ‘lang’| *h₁ wegen gr. ἐν-δελεχής zu einem neugebildeten *δέλεχος n. < *délh₁gʰos, vgl. Stüber 172-4 mit Lit.).}];54[348{S.v. Lat. longus 'long' from PIE *dlongʰ-o- (cf. *dólugʰ- in Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long', PIE *dlh₁gʰ-o- in Skt. dīrghá- OAv. darəga-, OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas, Alb. gjathë (+ *-tā-)| Gk. δολιχός (< *dolh₁-i-gʰo-?), ἐνδελεχής 'lasting long, uninterrupted' < *delh₁gʰ-| PIE *dlongʰ-o- in Goth. laggs, OHG lang, OIc. langr, etc.). The root might be *de/olh₁-, cf. Cz. dél (poet.) 'length' < PSl. *dьlь, etc.}];269[{The same root as 'long' in [cognate set 257](cog-257). The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. citations to [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):819-821, [EWAia](src-172) s.v. Ved. dīrghá- cited in [cognate set 257](cog-257)), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed. The reconstructed root form for this class follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).}];458[4: 184-187{The Slavic lexeme is usually linked to PS *dĭlgŭ(jĭ). However, the apophonic relationship is somehow complicated. An alternative etymology links the Slavic word to Lithuanian tolì, tolùs 'far' (which has a pronominal etymology).}];444[415{Cf. s.v. 5116 Lat. langē 'fern', and s.v. 5119 Lat. longus 'lang'.}];697[360-361{S.v.
