Gmc. *langa- 'lang', an inherited adjective identical with Lat. longus 'lang' < PIE *dlongho-, next to this stands *dl̥əgho- in Ved. dīrghá-, OAv. darəga-, Gk. δολιχός, OCS dlьgъ, cf. also Hitt. dalugai- 'lang'. Probably related to Ved. drā́ghate 'macht lang, ermüdet, quält'.}]
Justification: The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated, but the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is generally agreed. For the Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes in this class, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4:184-187, [Derksen 2008](src-81):133, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):360-361, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):327, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):348, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):415 no. 5116, 5119. The reconstructed root form for this class follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Source: 423[VI:849-851{S.v. Sp. zarpa 'garra', a late word only existing in Castilian, but other derivatives are preserved elsewhere.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [DCECH](src-423) VI:849-851 for various proposals.

Source: 236[{S.v. Engl. cwffiaf, cwffio, a loanword from English 'to cuff' in the sense of 'to strike, buffet'.}]
Justification: Loanword from English 'to cuff', i.e. 'to strike, buffet' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 231[299, 354{S.v. sabaid 'a brawl, fight', see tabaid 'fight, brawl' cf. Scots debate}]
Justification: Loan from Scots English debate (?), cf. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):299, 354.

Source: 728[56{S.v. Manx caggey 'war' (= Ir. cogadh).}];296[C:47-48,137{S.v. OIr. cocad 'guerre, fait de mener la guerre', a compound of com- + cath 'guerre'| cf. s.v. (1) cath 'combat| bataillon, troupes', seems to be very close to a verbal noun *katu-, also found in Germanic (cf. OIc. hǫd and in the OHG onomastic element Hadu- in e.g. Hadu-mār, etc.), one may connect Skt. śátru- 'ennemi', śātayati 'il abat'.}];50[195{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *katu- 'battle' from PIE *k̑atu- 'fight' (IEW 534), cf. Hitt. kattu- 'enmity', Skt. śátru- 'enemy', OHG hadu- 'fight', OCS kotora 'fight'.}];172[II:607{Cf. s.v. Ved. śátru- 'Feind, Gegner, Rivale', not certainly explained ("Nicht sicher erklärt"). Commonly compared with words for 'Kampf' with initial k- in the western satəm languages, which isn't a insurmountable difficulty, cf. ON hǫd 'Kampf, Streit', OHG hadu- = Gaul. katu- in personal names, MHG hader 'Zank, Streit, Hader' Ru.CS., OCS kotora 'μάχη', Thrac. katro-.}];80[466{Cf. s.v. Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife', from PIE *k̑h₂et-(e)u- ?, generally compared with Gk. κότος 'spite, anger', OIr. cath 'strife, battle' (catu- in Gaulish personal names), OHG Hadu-, MHG hader 'fight, struggle', and Skt. śátru- 'enemy', pointing to *k̑h₂et- (with laryngeal needed to explain OIr. -a-).}];165[214-215{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *haϸu- 'battle', from PIE *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu- (cf. Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife', OIr. cath, OW cat, MW cad 'battle, strife' < *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu-| Gk. κότος 'spite, anger' < *⁽k̑⁾h₃-to-), a tu- stem to a root *⁽k̑⁾h₃-, perhaps the same underlying Gmc. *harōjan- 'sharpen'.}];49[534{Cf. s.v. *k̑at- 'kämpfen', *k̑atu-, *k̑at(ₑ)ro- 'Kampf'.}]
Justification: Identical to Irish cogadh ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):56), from Old Irish cocad 'war; means of waging war', a compound of com- + cath 'battle' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:137. The extent to which there are further Indo-European connections is debated; generally further connected to Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife' (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):466), and Proto-Germanic *haϸu- 'battle' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):214-215), and perhaps further to Sanskrit śátru- via a different stem formation (but cf. the reservations of [EWAia](src-172) II:607). Traditionally reconstructed as *k̑atu- ([IEW](src-49) 534, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):195), but because the Leiden school denies the reconstruction of an Indo-European phoneme *a, alternative reconstructions *k̑h₂et- and *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu- are proposed respectively by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80) and [Kroonen 2013](src-165). Here the traditional reconstruction of [IEW](src-49) has been tentatively followed.
Loan from Standard German kämpfen 'to fight'.

Source: 444[333{S.v. 3920 Lat. gurdus 'dumm, tölpelhaft' > Sp., Pg. gordo 'dick, fett'.}];423[III:173{S.v. Sp. gordo, from Lat. gurdus 'boto, obtuso| necio'.}];54[275{S.v. Lat. gurdus 'blockhead, dolt', possibly an o-stem *gʷr̥d-o- if root cognate with the u-stem found in Gk. βραδύς 'slow', Lith. gurdùs 'id.', Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', OCS grьdъ Ru. górdyj 'proud, haughty'. Of Spanish origin according to Quintilian, but there is no proof of this.}];316[285{S.v. Lat. gurdus 'lourd (sens propre et figuré)| épais, lourdaud, balourd', possibly comparable to Gk. βραδύς, if it goes back to an initial *gʷrd-, but for a popular word of this sort an Indo-European etymology does not impose itself. A word of Spanish origin according to Quintilian (I 5.57), but there is no proof of this.}];269[{NB: A root *gʷr̥d- with two voiced-unaspirated plosives violates Indo-European root structure constraints (no roots of shape *DED- permitted).}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gurdus 'blockhead, stupid person' ([DCECH](src-423) III:173, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):333). A root-etymology to a zero-grade form *gʷr̥d-  might be found with the family of lexemes found in Greek βραδύς 'slow', Lithuanian gurdùs 'id.', Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', OCS grьdъ 'haughty, proud' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):275, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):275); in antiquity the grammarian Quintilian considered Latin gurdus a word of Spanish origin.

Comment: Preserved -d- in Modern Indic presupposes parallel loans from Sanskrit nadīḥ, cf. [cognate set 808](cog-808).
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit nadī- 'river'

Source: 423[III:102{S.v. Sp. garra 'mano de las fieras y aves de rapiña, armada de uñas corvas, fuertes y agudas’, 'hand of beasts and birds of prey, armed with nails, strong and sharp' probably a loan from Andalusian Arabic ġárfa 'puñado', 'handful'.}]
Justification: Probably a loanword from Andalusian Arabic ġárfa 'handful' ([DCECH](src-423) III:102)
Generally assumed to be a loanword from Continental Celtic, cf. Gaulish *banno- 'horn'.
Loan from Old Spanish chifle 'whistle; container made of horn'.

Source: 444[44{S.v. 540 appectorare 'an die Brust drücken' > Port. apertar, from which Port. preto, perto 'eng, knapp', 'schwarz'.}];54[453{Cf. s.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'breast, chest'. Originally a proto-Italic s-stem formation *pektos-. The root is likely to be cognate with OIr. ucht < *puktu-, if from earlier *pektu-.}];316[491{S.v. Lat. pectus, -oris 'poitrine de l'homme ou des animaux'. A similar word differing in -o- root vocalism and u-stem inflection is found in Irish ucht 'poitrine'. There are no other correspondences outside of these two languages.}]
Justification: A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):491, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):453, and further discussion in [cognate set 4015](cog-4015).

Source: 572[84-85{Portuguese ontem < oonte < aōite < *a nocte.}];54[416-417{Cf. s.v. Lat. nox. Lat. nocte is abl. of nox 'night' < PIE *nokʷt- (o-grade of *nekʷt-, cf. Hitt. nekuz).}];274[504-513{Cf. s.v. 1. *negʷ- 'dunkel werden, dämmern' (LIV 449, IEW 762f.). PIE nom.sg. *nokʷt-, gen.sg. *nekʷt- 'night' from the root *negʷ- 'to become dark' (LIV 449) with devoicing of the final consonant next to *-t-. See fn. 1 with a discussion of the different stem analyses and inflectional patterns which have been suggested for PIE.}];444[491{S.v. 5973 Lat. nox, nocte 'Nacht' > OPg. aontem 'gestern'.}]
Justification: Portuguese from Latin ad noctem 'at night' ([Williams 1962](src-572):84-85, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):491), from PIE *nekʷt- 'night', a t-stem derivative to PIE *negʷ- 'become dark' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):416-417, [NIL](src-274) 504-513).

Source: 54[140{S.v. Lat. costa 'rib' "Costa has been compared with Slavic *kost-i- 'bone', yet it is unlikely that it is cognate. In Slavic, kostь may be the reflex of PIE *Host- 'bone', since there is no other word which qualifies for this. This would then be a unique case of kV- < *HV- in Slavic. Yet in Latin, PIE *Host- is reflected by os, ossis, so that costa cannot reflect the same etymon. Since it also does not mean 'bone' but 'rib', which may have different semantic roots, we must regard costa as an isolated word without etymology."}];423[II: 278–279{Cf. s.v. Sp. cuesta 'espalda', from Lat. cŏsta 'costilla', 'costado, lado'.}];444[211{S.v. 2279 Lat. costa 'Seite, Rippe'.}];316[146{S.v. Lat. costa, -ae 'côte, flanc', there are no precise correspondences. It is sometimes compared with OCS kostь 'os', but this same word seems inseparable from the group of Lat. os, Skt. ásthi, etc., perhaps there was a prefix k-, but the existence of such a prefix has been contested.}]
Justification: From Latin costa 'rib, side' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):211, [DCECH](src-423) II:278-279), further etymology obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):146, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):140)

Source: 442[99, 764{No. 2096, No. 13236: Parallel loans from Sanskrit (partly via Hindi?), but the nasalization points to cognacy with Old Awadhi samuṃda with -m- from samudra, presupposing the existence of previously more directly inherited forms, which were hyper-corrected on the model of Sanskrit samudra-| compare *unda- 'wetted' < udna- (cf. Vedic udán-).}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit samudrá- 'gathering of the waters, sea, ocean', cf. [cognate set 730](cog-730)

Source: 443[2:809{S.v. Lat. *coacticāre > Fr. cacher.}];444[188-189{S.v. 2001 Lat. *coacticāre 'zusammendrücken', 2003 Lat. coactus 'gepreßt'.}];54[30-31{Cf. s.v. Lat. agō, -ere 'to drive', < PIE *h₂eg̑- (prefixed cōgere 'to collect, compel' [pf. coēgī, p.p.p. coāctum]).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes derived from Latin coactāre 'press together' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):188-189, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:809), a derivative of Latin agere 'to drive' from PIE *h₂eg̑- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):30-31).

Source: 443[3:762-764{S.v. frap-| [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444) assigns the lexemes to No. 3173 faluppa, but this is unlikely for semantic reasons. More likely we are dealing with an onomatopoeic formation.}];444[275{Cf. s.v. 3173 Lat. faluppa 'Spänchen', 'Strohfaser'.}]
Justification: Contrarary [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):275, probably an onomatopoeic formation (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:762-764).

Source: 443[19:161-164{Fr. sucré 'sweet' < *'sugared', from sucre 'sugar' (Old French çucre) a borrowing from Arabic sukkar via Sicilian zúccaru, Italian zucchero}]
Justification: A derived adjective from Old French çucre 'sugar', ultimately a loanword from Arabic sukkar 'sugar' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 19:161-164).

Source: 141[259{Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'entzünden' (IEW 11-2).}];157[35-36{S.v. aidu- 'feu, ardeur', a word that may be adduced from the name of a Gaulish tribe, Aedui < *aidu̯oi, which could be understood as 'les Ardents'| thematisation of aidu 'fire' comparable to OIr. aed 'feu'. An old IE word *aidh- 'feu', cf. Lat. aedēs 'foyer, pièce où l'on fait le feu, temple, maison', Gk. αἶθος 'incendie', Lith. íesmē (< *aidh-smi̯ā) 'bois à brûler', Skt. édha- 'id.', etc.}]
443[2:1362-1365{S.v. *krosu- (?gall.) 'hŏhl' > OFr. crues, NFr. creux.}]
Justification: Derived from Old French crues, cf. French creux 'hollow'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps Gaulish? (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:1362-1365).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. săpa, from Lat. sappare.}];316[594{Cf. s.v. Lat. sappa, -ae 'sorte de hoyau' (Fr. sape, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444) No. 9599).}];444[801{Cf. s.v. zapp- (illyr.) 'Ziegenbock' > Rom. sapă, It. zappa (> Friul., Fr. sape) 'Hacke' after the comparison with the horns of a billy-goat.}]
Justification: East Romance lexemes from Latin *sappere ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), originally a denominal verb from Latin sappa 'a kind of mattock'. Further etymology obscure; an Illyrian loanword? (Cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):801, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):594).

Source: 50[229{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kuli- 'mosquito, fly' < PIE *kul- (cf. Lat. culex 'gnat, midge'). The connection with Skt. śūla- 'spear' can only be from the same root if one assumes the short *u in Italic and Celtic is due to Dybo's Law.}];54[150{Cf. s.v. Lat. culex 'gnat, midge' < PIE *k̑uH-ló- 'sharp', accepting the connection of Skt. śū́la- to these words.}];49[626-627{For the older, pre-laryngeal theory etymology, cf. s.v. *k̑ū- 'spitz, Spieß'.}]
Justification: Derived from a PIE base *k̑uH-, if to be connected with Skt. śū́la- 'spear' with the shortened vowel length in Celtic and Italic due to Dybo's Law (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):150, [Matasović 2009](src-50):229).

Source: 50[181-182{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷrimi- 'worm' < PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' (cf. Skt. kŕ̥mi-, Alb. krimb, Lith. kirmìs, Slovene črm).}];236[{S.v. W pryf (1) 'insect, esp. (house)fly, also of other similar animals' Cf. Old Cornish prif, gl. uermis, Middle Cornish pref, Middle Breton preff, Late Breton preñv, Gaulish Prim(antia), Old Irish cruim: < IE. *ku̯r̥mi-.}]
Justification: Welsh lexemes continuing PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):181-182, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'worm' in [cognate set 172](cog-172).

Source: 50[185{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kallī- 'wood, grove'. Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain. A connection with PIE *kl̥do- (Gk. κλάδος 'branch', ON holt 'woody hill') is impossible because one would expect Proto-Celtic *klido-. Perhaps a derivation from *kelH- 'cut', but details are obscure.}];296[C:13{S.v. OIr. caill 'bois, forêt', cf. entry for various etymological proposals.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:13, [Matasović 2009](src-50):185); cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) for a survey of older proposals.

Source: 309[669{S.v. Bret. skorn 'glace', a word of obscure origin.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):669).

Source: 316[703{S.v. Lat. trīstis, -e. Without etymology.}];54[630{S.v. Lat. trīstis 'depressed, unhappy', according to [Hill 2003](src-735):128 trīstis may go back to *trenksti- and cognate with Germanic words such as OE thriste, but in view of tēmō < *tenksmōn-, the raising of *e > i postdates the cluster simplification so that *trenksti- could at most yield *trēsti-. No other etymology.}];735[128];444[741{S.v. 8918 Lat. trīstis 'traurig', 2. trīstus.}]
Justification: Without clear etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):703). Cf. [Hill 2003](src-735):128 for a recent attempt to connect with Germanic, but also the critical appraisal of [de Vaan 2008](src-54):630).

Source: 728[298{S.v. Manx mess 'fruit' (= Ir. meas).}];50[268-269{S.v. Proto-Celtic *messu- 'acorn'| usually connected to IE *med- 'measure'. Goth. mats, OE mete 'food', etc. < *meh₂d- 'be wet', but this is formally difficult for Proto-Celtic *messu-. Alternatively PCl. *messu- may have borrowed from a non-IE language.}];274[463-465{S.v. *med- 'voll werden, satt werden' (LIV 423f., IEW 706), from with *med-tu- > OIr. mess 'Eichelmast, Mastfutter, Baumfrucht', MW, etc. mes 'Eicheln'.}];231[246{S.v. ScG. meas 'fruit'. Ir. meas 'fruit' especially 'acorns' E. Ir. mess 'fruit', W. mes 'acorns', Cor. mesen 'glans', Br. mesenn 'acorn'.}]
Justification: Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish mes(s) 'tree fruit, mast' ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):298, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):246). Further IE root etymology in this set follows [NIL](src-274) 463-465 to PIE *med- 'to become full, sated', but cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):268-269.
Loanword from Persian سایه / sāyeh 'shadow'.

Comment: Sanskritisms, cf. Old Bengali chāa ~ chāva 'shade', Hindi chāī̃, see Turner 1962-66, p. 257f., no. 5027
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit chāyā- 'shadow'.

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. rece, from Lat. recens 'freshly, recently'.}];54[516{S.v. Lat. recēns, -ntis 'of recent origin, new, fresh'. Probably a compound of re- 'again, back' and *kent(i)- 'young, first' (< PIE *ken-t- 'young, new', cf. MIr. cana, cano 'wolf cub', Gaul. cintu-gnatus, OIr. cét- 'first', MW cynt MCo. cens, Bret. kent 'earlier' < PCl. *kento/u-, Skt. kanyā-, Av. kaine, kainīn- 'girl' < PIE *ken-i-Hn-, Skt. kanīna- 'young', Gk. καινός 'new, unheard of', etc.).}];141[351{Cf. s.v. *ken- 'entspringen, beginnen' (IEW 563-4).}]
Justification: East Romance lexemes from Latin recēns 'of recent origin, fresh' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):516, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 351).

Source: 443[2:1484{S.v. Lat. quirītāre 'kreischen' > Fr. crier.}];54[509-510{S.v. Lat. quirīs, -ītis 'name for Rome's citizens in their peacetime function' (derived verb: quirītāre 'to make a public outcry'). Indo-European connections uncertain.}];316[559{S.v. Lat. quirīs, -ītis, of obscure origin.}]
Justification: Romance forms from Latin quirītare 'to make a public outcry' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:1484), a verbal derivative to Latin quirīs, -ītis 'name for Rome's citizens in their peacetime function'; further origins obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):559, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):509-510).

Source: 443[4:486-487{S.v. Lat. horridus 'scheusslich' > Fr. ort 'sale'.}];54[290{Cf. s.v. Lat. horreō 'to be stiffly erect, shudder' (derived adj. horridus 'rough, crude, horrible'), from PIE *g̑ʰrs-eh₁- 'to be stiff, surprised' (cf. Skt. hárṣate 'to be delighted', YAv. zarǝšiiamma- 'excited', Sogd. wɣš- 'to be glad').}];141[178{Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰers- 'sich sträuben, erstarren' (IEW 445-6).}];444[350{S.v. 4188 Lat. horridus 'struppig' > Frz. ord.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin horridus 'standing on end, rough, shaggy, bristly, prickly' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):350, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:486-487), further derived from Latin horreō 'to be stiffly erect, shudder' and ultimately derived from PIE *g̑ʰers- 'to bristle, stiffen' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):290, [LIV²](src-141) 178).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. murdar, a loan from Turkish murdar 'unclean'.}]
Justification: Loan from Turkish murdar 'unclean' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. praf, a loanword from Slavic prachŭ.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic prachŭ 'dust' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. pământ, from Lat. pavimentum 'paved area, pavement'}];54[451-452{S.v. Lat. paviō 'to thump, pound| strike', derived form: pavīmentum 'pavement', derived from PIE *pi̯eh₂-.}];141[481-482{Cf. s.v. *pi̯eh₂- 'schlagen' (not in IEW).}]
Justification: From Latin pavimentum 'pavement' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), derived from Latin paviō 'to thump, pound, strike' and further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- 'beat' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):451-452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 481-482).

Source: 728[99, 112{S.v. coyrt 'giving' = Ir. tabhairt contaminated with cur| and s.v. cur 'putting, giving, planting, setting, sending' = Ir. cur.}]
Justification: Continuing older Irish cor 'put, place; let go; twist, turn', traditionally connected to a root *(s)ker- 'turn, bend' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:204-206, though now generally rejected. [Schrijver 1997a](src-800):297 instead suggests a possible root *kur- for related vocabulary for the proposed connection to Latin curvus 'curved, bent', Greek κυρτός 'curved', but cf. also discussion of [de Vaan 2008](src-54):158, [Beekes 2010](src-66):758-759 respectively regarding the proposed Latin and Greek cognates.
Lexemes continuing denominal verb pappāre from Latin pap(p)a, a child language word for 'food' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):511 No. 6214, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):511).

Source: 141[438{S.v. *menH- 'treten, stampfen' (?) (IEW 726).}];50[276{S.v. Proto-Celtic *mon-ī- 'go', from PIE *menH- 'tread, stamp on' (cf. Umbr. menes 'will come', Lith. mìnti 'tread on', CS męti 'tread, knead').}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *menH- 'to step, stamp on' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):276, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 438).

Source: 141[593-594{S.v. *stei̯gʰ- 'steigen, schreiten' (IEW 1017-8).}];50[376{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tēg- 'go', from PIE *stei̯gʰ- (cf. Gk. στείχω, Goth. steigan).}];304[637-640{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ti-n-g- and *teig- 'gehen', from PIE *stei̯gʰ- ([LIV²](src-141) 593f.) > OIr. téit, ·tét 'gehen', etc.}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, to stride' ([LIV²](src-141) 593-594, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):637-640, [Matasović 2009](src-50):376).

Source: 442[178{Cf. s.v. 3441 kr̥śá- 'lean, thin' RV.}];172[I:318-319, 395-396{Cf. s.v. Ved. kr̥śá- (adj.) 'mager, hager, abgemagert, schlank, schwächlich' (IIr. cf. YAv. kərəsa- in proper names with animal words as the compound member, e.g. kərəsaoxšan-, kərəsāspa-, etc.). To Ved. √karś- from PIE *kerk̑- (*kark̑-?), cf. ON horr 'Abmagerung' Lith. káršti 'alt werden, alterschwach werden, siechen', Cz. krsati 'abnehmen', etc.}];141[355{Cf. s.v. *k⁽ʷ⁾erk̑- 'abmagern' (IEW 581).}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):178 no. 3441, to Vedic kr̥śá- 'lean, thin', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾erk̑- 'to emaciate' ([EWAia](src-172) I:318-319, 395-396, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 355).

Source: 325[113-114{divūsk, etc.| dǝγůfs "The Š[uγni]Gr[oup] -sk can hardly be original (-*sku??), but goes back to *-sx < -*xs ( = Ishk[ashmi] S[an]gl[echi]), from which also W[akhi] -ks. Initial Š[uγni] div- [...] can be derived < *dw- [...] B[artangi]O[roshori]S[arikoli] t-f- < d-v- is prob. due to taboo. [...] Poss. < *dwaxsa-, cf. Av. dvag- to flutter”}];83[83{"An IE origin for this apparently IIr. root cannot be ascertained: only the Germanic forms, OHG tuoh, MHG tuoch, NHG Tuch, OSax. dōk, MLG dōk, OFr. -dok ‘cloth’, might be considered, as suggested by Mayrhofer, EWAia, l.c. It is quite striking that initial *du̯° is shared with the semantically similar roots *du̯anH and *du̯ar: these "roots" are perhaps extended formations of *dau² (Skt. dhāv) ‘to run’, which may have risen in IIr. (differently *du̯ar ?)."}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes with no certain etymology. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325): 113 connects them with the Indo-Iranic root for 'flap, flutter'. [Cheung 2007](src-83): 83 follows this proposal for the words of the Shughni group, but omits Wakhi (presumably an oversight.

Source: 54[79{S.v. Lat. caecus 'blind', from *⁽k̑⁾eh₂i-ko- and to be connected with with OIr. cáech 'one-eyed', coeg 'empty', W coeg-dall, OCo. cuic 'one-eyed' < PCl. *kaiko-, Goth. haihs 'id.'.}];85[{S.v. Rom. ceață, from Lat. caecus 'blind'.}];316[82{S.v. Lat. caecus, -a, -um 'aveugle, qui ne voit pas', only comparable to lexemes in adjacent language families, cf. Ir. cáech, W coeg, Goth. haihs.}]
Justification: Romanian ceață, from Latin caecus 'blind' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further to be connected with Old Irish cáech 'one-eyed', Goth. haihs 'id.' via PIE *⁽k̑⁾eh₂i-ko- or similar ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):82, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):79).
Loan from Persian ستاره / setāreh 'star'.

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. pădure, from Lat. padule.}];444[507{S.v. 6183 palus, -ūde 'Sumpf', 2. padūle > Rom. pădure 'Wald'.}];54[442{S.v. Lat. palūs, palūdis 'fen, swamp' (cf. Skt. palvala- 'pond, pool', OPr. pelky 'marsh', Lith. pélkė 'marsh', Žem. 'puddle', Latv. pel̃ce 'puddle' < *pelHk-iH-h₂). "If the Baltic words for 'swamp' are cognate, Latin palūs could be connected with pall- 'grey, pale'. However, [[Schrijver 1991](src-679):210f.] rightly objects that the semantic connection between 'grey' and 'swamp' is uncompelling."}];172[II:105{Cf. s.v. Skt. palvala- 'Pfuhl, Teich, kleiner Wasserbehälter', cf. Lat. palūs, palūd- 'Sumpf, Pfütze, stehendes Wasser', Lith. pal̃vas 'fahl', OHG falb.}];352[753{Cf. s.v. OLith. pélkė 'Moor, Sumpf, Bruch', without clear connections outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: Romanian pădure, as though from *padule(m) < Latin palūde(m) 'fen swamp' (nom.sg. palūs) with metathesis ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):507, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further generally compared to Skt. palvala- 'pond, pool' and Lith. pélkė 'bog, marsh' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):442, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:105, but [ALEW](src-352) 753 against the connection of the Baltic lexemes).
Loanword from Germanic *brekan- 'break' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:267, cf. French broyer 'grind').

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. tare, from Lat. talem.}];444[705{S.v. 8543 Lat. talis 'solcher', 'so beschaffen' > Rom. tare 'stark, fest'.}];54[605{S.v. Lat. tālis 'of such kind', from PIE *teh₂-li- 'such' (cf. W talu 'to pay', Gk. τηλίκος 'of such an age', Lith. tõlei 'until', OCS toli 'to such a degree', tolь 'so much, many') [a derivative from the pronominal stem *teh₂-].}];294[490{Cf. s.v. *li, *le 'dort, drüben, fern| dann' (Partikel, ferndeikt.| Adverb, temporal). Based on *tah₂li- < *téh₂-h₁ li.}]
Justification: From Latin tālem 'of such kind' acc.sg., ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):705 s.v. talis), further from PIE *teh₂li- 'such', either an adjective derived to the pronominal stem *teh₂- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):605) or a univerbation of a decollective adverb *téh₂-h₁ with a deictic particle *li (so [LIPP 2](src-294) 490).

Source: 54[256{S.v. gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice', from PIE *g̑el-u- 'cold, frost, ice' (cf. Goth. kalds 'cold', OE calan 'to freeze', OIc. kala 'to freeze'). Connections with Gk. γελανδρόν 'cold' (Hesych.) are uncertain. Slavic lexemes, e.g. OCS xladъ 'coolness, cool breeze', Ru. xolod' 'cold' < Proto-Slavic *xoldъ '(the) cold' may be from an extended root *g̑oldʰo-?}];423[III:353-354{S.v. Sp. hielo, from Lat. gĕlŭ 'id.'}];444[317-318{S.v. 3718 Lat. gelu 'Frost'.}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):317-318, [DCECH](src-423) III:353-354), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):256).

Source: 442[594-595{S.v. 10299 Skt. mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, washed, pure' RV., 'prepared, savoury' R., 'sweet, pleasant' MBh., miṣṭa- 1 'dainty, sweet' MBh. [√mr̥j or √mr̥ś].}];172[II:325-326, 331-332, 373{S.v. Ved. mr̥ṣṭá-, either to Ved. √marj- 'putzen, reinigen, abstreifen, streichen' < PIE *h₂merg̑- 'abstreifen' or to Ved. √marś- 'berühren, anfassen' < PIE *melk̑- (cf. Lat. mulceō 'streiche, streichle, berühre leicht'.}];141[226-227,{Cf. s.v. *Hmelk̑- 'streichen, berühren' (IEW 724) and *h₂merg̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (IEW 738).}];269[{IE root etymology uncertain: either to LIV² 226-227 *Hmelk̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (> Ved. √marś- 'touch, stroke, handle') or LIV² 280-281 *h₂merg̑- (> Ved. √marj- 'wipe, rub, cleanse'). A blend may also be possible.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10299, s.v. mr̥ṣṭá-, either from marś- (< Hmelk̑-) or marj- (or blend), cf. LIV, p. 280f. with Anm. 1
Justification: IE root etymology uncertain: either to [LIV²](src-141) 226-227 *Hmelk̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (> Ved. √marś- 'touch, stroke, handle') or [LIV²](src-141) 280-281 *h₂merg̑- (> Ved. √marj- 'wipe, rub, cleanse'). A blend might also be possible. (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594-595 no. 10299, [EWAia](src-172) II:325-326, 331-332, 373.

Source: 172[II:302-303{Cf. s.v. Ved. mádhu- 'süßer Trank, Süßigkeit, Honig, Soma, Milch', from PIE *médʰu- 'Süßtrank, Honigmischung, Rauschtrank, Honig' (cf. YAv. maδu- 'Beerenwein', maδumaṇt- 'Wein enthaltend', Gk. μέθυ 'Rauschtrank, Wein', OHG mito 'Met', OCS medъ 'Honig', etc.).}];442[562{S.v. 9793 Skt. madhurá- 'sweet' ĀśvGr̥. [~ madhulá- – mádhu- ]}]
Justification: Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic madhurá- 'sweet', a secondary derivative of Old Indic mádhu- 'honey, mead' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):562 no. 9793), further from PIE *medʰu- 'mead, honey; sweet drink; alcoholic drink' ([EWAia](src-172) II:302-303, cf. [EIEC](src-657) 271).

Source: 260[1658{PS *o-pušĭ, *o-pyšĭ 'tail' is derived from PS *puxati 'blow, breathe strongly'.}];81[423-424{Proto-Slavic *puxati, cf. *puxnǫti 'swell'. Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.].}];141[303-304{S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848). Slavic forms not connected by LIV².}];389[{"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.}];594[{PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.}]
Justification: Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).

Source: 83[183-184{S.v. Proto-Iranian *Hnas- (Has-) 'to reach, attain, take', from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, attain' (Av. nā̆s- 'to reach, attain', Skt. nāś-).}];141[282-283{Cf. s.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-8).}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *Hnas- 'to reach, attain, take', further to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, attain' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):183-184, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 282-283).

Source: 54[244{S.v. Lat. frōns, -ondis 'foliage, leaves'. No widely accepted etymology, cf. entry for various proposals.}];85[{S.v. Rom. frunză, from Lat. frondea (frons, frondis).}]
Justification: Romanian lexemes from Lat. frondea ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further etymology uncertain (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):244 for further discussion).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. stâng, from Lat. *stancus (= stanticus).}];444[679{S.v. 8225 *stancus 'müde'.}]
Justification: As though from Latin *stancus ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):679, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further to Latin stant-, the participle of stāre 'to stand' (cf. [cognate set 309](cog-309) for further etymological discussion).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. trăi, loanword from Slavic trajati.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic trajati, cf. Serbo-Croatian trȁjati 'to last, continue' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 54[275{S.v. Lat. gula 'throat, gullet', probably of onomatopoeic origin.}];85[{S.v. Rom. gură, from Lat. gula 'gullet'.}];316[284-285{S.v. Lat. gula, -ae 'partie de la bouche par laquelle on avait gosier, cou'.}]
Justification: From Latin gula, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):284-285, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):275 for further discussion).

Source: 444[297-298{S.v. 3465 Lat. fracidus 'sehr weich'.}];54[238{S.v. Lat. fracēs, -um 'fragments of olive pulp left after pressing', derivative fracidus 'soft, pulpy', from Proto-Italic *frak- (cf. OPr. dragios 'yeast', Lith. drãgės, Latv. dradži, OCS droždьje 'dregs', OIc. dregg 'dregs', Alb. dra 'dregs, sediment'). The Gmc., BSl., and Latin words for 'dregs' belong together, but the vowels don't match and point to a non-IE *a. The velars don't match either. It appears that we are dealing with a loanword from an unknown, non-IE language, or a lost IE language in which the root *dʰregʰ- 'to drag' or *dʰreh₂gʰ- 'to soil' yielded a form *dʰragʰ- 'dredges of wine, oil, fat'.}];316[251{S.v. fracēs, -um 'marc d'olives', attested since Cato. A rare technical term. One has connected words like OIc. dregg 'levain, lie' OPr. dragios, OLith. dragės which go back to *dʰregʰ- 'lie, dépôt', on the other hand OIr. mraich or braich, W brag 'malt', alternatively maybe a loanword.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin fracidus 'very soft' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):297-298), a derivative of Latin fracēs 'grounds, dregs (from olive pressing)'. Further etymology obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):251, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):238 for various proposals).

Source: 54[327{Cf. s.v. Lat. lārgus 'generous, bountiful'. Etymology unclear. The formal derivation and semantics from earlier attempts at an etymology in Walde-Hofmann and Pokorny IEW as though from *lajes-ago- 'carrying fat' are not convincing.}];316[342{S.v. Lat. largus, -a, -um 'abondant', without certain correspondences.}];85[{S.v. Rom. alerga, from Lat. *allargare (< largus).}];444[28{S.v. 352 *allargāre 'in die Weite gehen'.}]
Justification: Romanian alerga, as though from Latin *allargāre, a verbal derivative of lārgus ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):28, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):342, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):327).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. nisip, a loan from Bulgarian nasip.}]
Justification: Loan from Bulgarian nasip 'bank, embankment' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 141[643-644{S.v. *tk̑ei̯- 'Landbau treiben, siedelen, wohnen' (IEW 626). Lat. ponō < *tk̑i-néH-nH-? Cf. discussion in n6.}];54[479{S.v. Lat. pōnō, -ere 'to place, set, put' (repōnere 'to put back, down, replace'), from Proto-Italic *po-sine/o-, from PIE *po- + *tk̑-i-n-(e/o-) 'to build, live' via *po-sinō > *po-snō > *poznō > pōnō.}];85[{S.v. Rom. spune, from Lat. exponere.}]
Justification: From Latin ex-pōnere 'to put out, set forth' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- 'settle, inhabit' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 643-644, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).
Loanword from German schwach 'weak' [Not in [Karulis 1992](src-534)].

Source: 352[547-548{Cf. s.v. OLith. lãbas 'gut' (BSl. Latv. labs 'gut, vollkommen', OPr. labs 'gut, tüchtig', etc.). The common Baltic word for 'good'. Slavic connections are lacking. The proposed connection to Vedic rabh-, rábhate 'to seize, to grasp' / labh-, lábhate 'to get' and Greek ἀμφιλαφής 'comprehensive', λαφύρα 'haul, spoils' is only possible if the root form is *labʰ- (cf. LIV² 412n1 s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen').}];269[{Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. lãbas, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 speculatively considered a connection with Arm. law (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8081](cog-8081)), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352). A lemma for Lith. lãbas is lacking in [Derksen 2015](src-353). Besides the still uncertain proposal to Ved. rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.}]
Justification: Lit. 'not-good'. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. discussion under 'good' in [cognate set 678](cog-678).

Source: 444[589-590{S.v. 7110 recentāre 1. 'erfrischen', 2. 'mit Wasser abspülen', 3. 'reinigen'.}];54[516{S.v. Lat. recēns, -ntis 'of recent origin, new, fresh'. Probably a compound of re- 'again, back' and *kent(i)- 'young, first' (< PIE *ken-t- 'young, new', cf. MIr. cana, cano 'wolf cub', Gaul. cintu-gnatus, OIr. cét- 'first', MW cynt MCo. cens, Bret. kent 'earlier' < PCl. *kento/u-, Skt. kanyā-, Av. kaine, kainīn- 'girl' < PIE *ken-i-Hn-, Skt. kanīna- 'young', Gk. καινός 'new, unheard of', etc.).}];141[351{Cf. s.v. *ken- 'entspringen, beginnen' (IEW 563-4).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin recentāre 'refresh; wash with water; clean' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):589-590), a derivative of Latin recēns 'of recent origin, new, fresh', further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):516, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 351).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. învârti, cf. Slavic vrŭtĕti.}]
Justification: Probably a borrowing from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian vrtjeti 'spin', Bulgarian въртя 'turn' + prefix în- (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 442[635{S.v. 10948 Skt. lábhatē 'catches, takes'.}];172[II:434-435{S.v. Ved. √rabh- 'ergreifen, fassen', perhaps from PIE *lembʰ-/*lm̥bʰ-.}];141[411-412{Cf. s.v. *lembʰ- 'ergreifen, fassen' (IEW 652).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10948 s.v. lábhate (~ rábhate), analogically influenced by MIA deti and neti 'takes', thus e instead of a
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Old Indic √labh- 'to grasp, seize', ultimately from PIE *lembʰ- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):635 no. 10948, [EWAia](src-172) II:434-435, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412).

Source: 686[267{S.v. OPr. pijst (inf.) 'tragen'. Without a good explanation. Some attempts to relate to PIE *ped- 'treten' through semantics 'to transport a heavy burden by foot'.}]
Justification: No satisfactory etymology. Some attempts have been made to relate to PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink', cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):267 for further discussion.

Source: 172[II:354-355{S.v. Ved. mitrá- 'Vertrag, Kontrakt, Bündnis' (personified as Mitrá-, god of contract), from Proto-Indo-Iranian *mitrá-. The origin of PIIr. *mitrá- is disputed.}];780[{Cf. s.v. Mithra (i). Mitra in Old Indian and Mithra in Old Iranian.}]
Comment: From older Iranian *miθra-, name of the sun god
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *mitrá- 'contract; god of contract', further etymology disputed (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:354-355, [Encyclopædia Iranica](src-780) s.v. Mithra).

Source: 274[580-584{S.v. *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (LIV 508f., IEW 872ff.).}];141[508-509{Cf. s.v. *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (IEW 872-3).}];165[406{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rauda- 'red' from *h₁roudʰo- (cf. Lith. raũdas, Russ. (dial.) rúdyj 'blood-red', SCr. rȗd 'reddish', Lat. rūfus 'red, tawny, red-haired', OIr. rúad 'red').}];442[650 no. 11168 and 11165{Palula < *lohila}];66[465-466{S.v. ἐρυθρός 'red' < PIE *h₁reudʰ- 'red'.}];345[570-571{S.v. TochB ratre, which along with TochA rtär reflect Proto-Tocharian *rŭtäre from PIE *h₁rudʰ-ró-.}];172[II:471{S.v. Ved. róhita- 'rot, rötlich' (cf. Av. raoiδita- 'rot, rötlich'), from PIE *h₁reu̯dʰ- 'rot sein' (cf. also Ved. rudhirá-).}];353[376-377{Cf. s.v. Lith. raũdas 'reddish brown, bay, reddish', from PIE h₁roudʰ-o- (cf. Lat. rūfus 'red haired, reddish', OIr. ruad 'red', W rhudd 'red', Goth. rauþs 'red').}];54[527{S.v. Lat. ruber, -bra, -brum 'red', from PIE *h₁rudʰ-ró- 'red' (cf. Skt. rudhirá- 'red, bloody', Gk. ἐρυθρός RuCS rodrъ, TochB rätre 'red', OIr. rondaid 'to paint red').}];50[315{S.v. Proto-Celtic *rowdo- 'red', from PIE *h₁reu̯dʰ- 'red'.}];352[847{Cf. s.v. OLith. raudà 'Röte', from which the derived adjective raudónas 'rot' (BSl. cf. Latv. ràuda 'Rotauge (ein Fisch)', OCS ruda 'Irz', SCr. rȗd 'rötlich, rotbraun', Russ. dial. rúdyj 'rot', etc.) from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'rot machen' (cf. Ved. lohá- 'rötlich, kupferfarben, eisern', MPers. rōy 'Kupfer, Messing', Lat. rūfus, 'rot, hellrot', rōbus 'rot (Rinder)' OIr. rúad 'rot', MW rud 'rot', etc. Goth. rauþs 'rot', OE rēad, OHG rōt, etc.).}];595[3: 161{S.v. rdeč and rdeti.}];594[{Cf. s.v. Slov. rdẹ́ti -ím nedov. lat.‛rubescere’ (19. stol.). With derivative rdeč 'ruber', derivatives from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ-.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- '(to make) red' ([NIL](src-274) 580-584, [EIEC](src-657) 480-481, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):570-571, [Beekes 2010](src-66):465-466, [EWAia](src-172) II:471, [ALEW](src-352) 847, [Derksen 2015](src-353):376-377, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Kroonen 2013](src-165):406, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):527, [Matasović 2009](src-50):315, [LIV²](src-141) 508-509).

Source: 66[316-317{S.v. δεξίος '(to the) right (side) < PIE (transponat) *dek̑s-i-u̯o- (*dek̑s- 'right').}];54[168{S.v. Lat. dexter, -(e)ra, -um 'right, (opposite of left)'. Lat. dexter, alongside Umb. testru and Osc. destr- may be derived from PIE *dek̑s-tero- 'right, right-hand side' (*dek̑s- 'right').}];141[112{Cf. s.v. *dek̑s- 'taugen, tüchtig sein' [IEW 189].}];105[67-68{S.v. Alb. djathtë 'right'| Old Albanian texts (Buzuku) preserve djäthe 'right (side)' showing that the djathtë is a relatively new formation in -të based on Proto-Albanian *detsa, to be connected PIE *dek̑s- 'right' (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa-, Gk. δεξιός, Lat. dexter, etc.).}];172[I:690-691{S.v. Ved. dákṣiṇa- 'recht, rechts gehend, südlich', from (East?) Indo-European *dek̑s-i-no- (cf. Lith. dẽšinas, OCS desnъ 'rechts', beside *dek̑s-(i-)u̯o- in Gk. δεξιός 'rechts', Goth. taihswo 'die rechte (Hand)', etc.).}];353[124{S.v. Lith. dẽšinas 'right', from PIE *dek̑s-(i)no- (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa- 'right, southern', Av. dašina- 'right', Gk. δεξιτερός, Lat. dexter 'right', Goth. taihswa 'right').}];81[100-101{S.v. Proto-Slavic *desnъ 'right' (ESSJa IV 218-219), from PIE *dek̑s-(i)no- (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa- 'right, southern', Av. dašina- 'right', Gk. δεξιτερός, Lat. dexter 'right', Goth. taihswa 'right').}];165[512{S.v. Proto-Germanic *tehswō(n)- 'right hand', from PIE *dek̑s-u̯eh₂- (cf. Skt. dákṣiṇa- 'right, southern', OCS desьnъ 'right', Lith. dešinė̃ 'right hand' < *dek̑s-ino-, Lat. dexter < *dek̑s-tro-, OIr. dess < *dek̑s-o-).}];50[97{S.v. Proto-Celtic *dexs(i)wo- 'right, south', from PIE *dek̑s-u̯o- 'right' (cf. Lat. dexter, Gk. δεξιτερός, OCS desnъ, Alb. djathtë).}];369[137-138{S.v. Alb. djáthtë 'rechter'. Since long generally agreed to be derived from the root *dek̑s- 'rechts' (cf. OHG zeso, Gk. δεξιός 'rechts', etc.). The further analysis of the original morphological structure remains disputed.}];352[199{Cf. s.v. OLith. dẽšinas, -à 'rechte(r, s)' (BSl. OCS desnъ, etc.), from PIE *dek̑s-, *dek̑s-i-no- 'rechts, südlich' (cf. Ved. dákṣina- 'rechts, rechts gehend', südlich', YAv. dašina- 'rechts', Gk. δεξίος 'rechts, glückverheißend', Alb. djathtë 'rechts', djathë (dialectal Old Albanian) 'id.', Lat. dexter 'rechts', OIr. dess 'rechts, südlich', MW deheu 'rechts, südlich| geschickt, recht', Goth. taihswa 'rechts', etc.).}];458[4: 218-219{PS *desnŭ is derived from PIE *dek̑s- and related to Latin dexter, Lithuanian dẽšinas, Old Indic dákṣiṇa-, Greek δεξιτερός etc.}];442[349{S.v. 6119 Ved. dákṣiṇa 'right (hand)' RV.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting different derivations from PIE *dek̑s- 'to be suitable' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):316-317, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):137-138, [Orel 1998](src-105):67-68, [EWAia](src-172) I:690-691, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):349 no. 6119, [ALEW](src-352) 199, [Derksen 2015](src-353):124, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:218-219, [Derksen 2008](src-81):100-101, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):512, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):168, {Matasović 2009}:97, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 112)

Source: 364[239{Schumacher & Matzinger assume an Early Albanian pre-form *kakii̯a/ā-, comparing Ancient Greek κακός with a simple thematic suffix (i.e. *kak-o-).}];269[{The potential connection to Proto-Greek *kako- is worth considering, but the connection is too speculative to merge this class with [cognate set 7332](cog-7332). This has been indexed as a proposed cognacy relationship at a 50/50 level. Whether these forms could be further projected back to a PIE root with zero-grade vocalism *k̑h₂k-, *kn̥k̑-(vel sim.) remains unclear.}];369[216-217{S.v. Alb. keq 'schlecht, schlimm, böse, elend'. "Bildung und Etymologie umstritten." Considers the question of a loan from Greek open.}];105[175{S.v. Alb. keq 'bad, evil', which O. considers to be from PAlb. kakja, related to Gk. κακός (so [Meyer 1891](src-585):184-185). Cf. entry for references to many other alternatively proposed etymologies.}]
Justification: Possibly to be connected with Greek κακός (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):175, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):239, [Beekes 2010](src-66):619-620), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):216-217); cf. discussion in [cognate set 7332](cog-7332).

Source: 320[482{S.v. Khot. hätänai 'red', may be connected with *hita- of MPers. 'hyd, ''hyd 'stain', Av. āhiti-, anāhitā- 'not defiled', OInd. (RV) ásita-, ásikni- 'dark'.}];172[I:146{Cf. s.v. Ved. ásita- 'dunkelfarbig, schwarz', connected to the Iranian lexemes via Khot. hätänai 'rot', YAv. āhita- if 'befleckt, unrein'. Perhaps further to be connected with Hitt. hanzana- 'schwarz', Gk. ἄσις  'Schlamm, Unrat' (but ultimately unclear).}]
Justification: Generally connected with Vedic ásita 'dark coloured, black' and Young Avestan āhita- (if meaning 'spotted, unclean'). Further etymology unclear (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):482, [EWAia](src-172) I:146).

Source: 442[610{S.v. Skt. rakta- (1) 'coloured, dyed' ŚBr., 'red' ŚāṅkhGr̥., n. 'blood' Mn., °aka -- 'red' VarBr̥S. [√rañj].}];172[II:424-425{Cf. s.v. Ved. √raj-¹ 'sich färben, sich röten, rot werden', from PIE *(s)reg- (cf. Gk. ῥέζω 'färbe', ῥῆγος 'Teppich', ῥογεύς 'Färber' etc.).}];141[587{Cf. s.v. *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- '(sich) färben' (IEW 854).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. [cognate set 1814](cog-1814); LIV, p. 587
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit rakta- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):610, no. 10539; [EWAia](src-172) II:424-425, [LIV²](src-141) 587).

Source: 83[362{S.v. Proto-Iranic *stamb(H)- 'to withstand, be stiff, stern, unmoving' (MMP ʿstft, BMP stpt /staft/ 'hard| firm, strong, cruel| savage, fierce', from PIE *stembʰ(H)- 'to be firm, unmoving', vel sim. (cf. Ved. stambhⁱ 'to support, prop up', Lith. stem̃bti 'to oppose', Gk. ἀστεμφής 'unshakable', TochA ṣtäm, B stäm 'to stand').}];442[788{S.v. 13676 stabdha- 'firmly fixed' ŚvetUp. 2. 'stiff, paralysed, dull' MBh., 'solidified (as water)' Hariv. [√stambh] (> Si. tada 'firm, hard').}];172[I:754{S.v. Ved. √stambh- 'befestigen, stützen' from PIE *stembʰH- something like 'stützen, versteifen, festtreten', cf. Gk. ἀστεμφής 'fest, starr', Lith. stem̃bti 'widerstreben' etc.}];141[595-596{Cf. s.v. *stembʰH- 'sich stützen, sich stemmen' (IEW 1012-3).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *stembʰH- 'to support, to lift' ([EWAia](src-172) II:754, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):788 no. 13676, [Cheung 2007](src-83):362, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 595-596).

Source: 66[1498-1499{S.v. AGk. τρανής 'clear, distinct, definite, sure' from *tr̥h₂-n-, with verbal derivative τρανόω 'make clear, plain, distinct' a derivative from τρανής (PIE *terh₂- 'pass, cross').}];141[633-634{Cf. s.v. *terh₂- 'durchkommen, überqueren (IEW 1074-5).}];452[652{Cf. s.v. Capp. τρανῶ 'I see'.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek τρανόω 'make clear, plain, distinct', a secondary verbal derivative via Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear, distinct', ultimately from PIE *terh₂- 'to pass, cross' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):652, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1498-1499, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 633-634).

Source: 460[101-102{S.v. AGk. ἀνανοῶ 'wieder bedenken' > Kapp. ἀνανοῦμαι.}];66[1023{S.v. AGk. νόος 'mind, sense, intellect, reason| purpose, aim', from which νοέω 'to mediate, observe, think, devise, have in mind' is a denominal verb. Νόος appears to go back to an old o-grade verbal noun (cf. λόγος, φόρος, etc.) but there is no certain etymology outside of Greek.}];270[756-757{S.v. AGk. νόος, with denominative verb νοέω, clearly a nomen actionis with o-grade vocalism, but no known etymology outside of Greek.}]
Justification: Cappadocian ανανούμαι 'think' from Ancient Greek ἀνανοέω 'call to mind' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):101-102), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):756-757, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1023).
Parallel loans from Sanskrit hr̥dayam 'heart'.

Source: 460[104{S.v. AGk. ἀνασθμαίνω 'schwer atmen' > Pontic ἀνασμαίνω 'atmen, Luft schöpfen'.}];66[148{Cf. s.v. ἄσθμα 'short-drawn breath, panting', with denominative verb ἀσθμαίνω 'to pant, breathe with difficulty'. Etymology unclear. -θμα is a possible suffix but older proposed derivations to PIE *h₂enh₁- 'breathe' (cf. ἄνεμος) is impossible as one would expect a base †ἀνε-.}];270[122-123{S.v. AGk. ἄσθμα 'respiration difficile, halètement, essoufflement'. "On cherche à rattacher le mot à la R. de ἄνεμος en posant *ἀν-σθμα avec un suffixe -σθμα | un suffixe -θμα est connu | le σ est isolé, mais cf. ἰσθμός (Schywzer, Gr. Gr. 1,337 avec la bibliographie) | dans le cas de ἄσθμα le σ confère au mot une certaine valeur d'harmonie imitative."}]
Justification: Pontic Greek ανασμαίνω from Ancient Greek ἀνασθμαίνω 'to breathe with difficulty', a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἄσθμα 'short-drawn breath, panting' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):148). Older attempts to connect Ancient Greek ἄσθμα to ἄνεμος 'wind' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):122-123) are formally impossible ([Beekes 2010](src-66):148) as one would expect a base ἄνε- from the root *h₂enh₁-. Consequently, there is currently no known etymology outside of Greek.

Source: 460[477{S.v. AGk. ῥάχις 'spine, backbone' > Pontic ρασ̌ί(ν).}];66[1277-1278{Cf. s.v. ῥάχις 'spine, back'. Compared in [IEW](src-49) 1180 with Lith. ražis 'stubble' for a preform *urag̑ʰ-i-, but the alternation between ϝρᾰχ- / ϝρᾱχ- with *-a-/-ā- ablaut is suspicious from the point of view of Indo-European. Perhaps an early loan from a Pre-Greek source.}];270[968-969{Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥάχις, -ιος 'colonne vertébrale, échine', generally compared to Lith. ražỹs 'chaume', rãžas 'chaume, pointe de fourche, branche sèche' to a root *u̯rā̆gʰ- cf. [IEW](src-49) 1180.}]
Justification: Pontic ρασ̌ί(ν) 'mountain' < Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, backbone' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):477). Further traditionally compared with Lithuanian ražis 'stubble' to a putative PIE *u̯rā̆gʰ- ([IEW](src-49) 1180, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):968-969), but the necessity to reconstruct *a ~ *ā ablaut to account for the Greek forms is suspicious from an IE point of view ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1277-1278). Perhaps the assumption of a prehistoric loanword is a better hypothesis.
Linked by Horn (1893: 160) to the Sanskrit verb śak- "to be able", cf. also śakti- "power" etc.

Source: 66[1189{S.v. AGk. πιέζω 'to press, push, beset'. Of uncertain etymology.}];464[{Related to MG πιάνω ‘catch’ < Hell. πιάζω < AG πιέζω 'press, press down| bear down upon'.}];382[1099{Cf. s.v. SMG πιάνω, remodelled from Hellenistic πιάζω, Ancient Greek πιέζω.}]
Justification: From Hellenistic Greek πιάζω, analogically remodelled into the -νω class inflection ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1189, Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further to Ancient Greek πιέζω, of uncertain etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):899-900, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1189 for various proposals).

Source: 130[64{Loan from Lat. galbinu and gilvus 'gelb', so Orel (1998:131).}];105[131{S.v. Alb. gjelbër ~ gjelbën 'green', borrowed from Lat. galbinus 'greenish-yellow'.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin galbinus 'greenish-yellow' ([Orel 1998](src-105):131, [Holm 2011](src-130):64, cf. 'yellow' in [cognate set 1409](cog-1409)).

Source: 269[{Greek: Italiot ῥοδινός is a derived adjective in -ινός to Ancient Greek ῥόδος 'rose'. The derived form ῥόδινος 'pink' already in Hellenistic Greek (–Nikos Liosis, p.c.).}];66[1289-1290{S.v. ῥόδον 'rose'. Lesb. βρόδον confirms that an earlier form must have been ϝρόδον, probably like Armenian vard 'rose' from Old Iranian *u̯r̥da-, cf. NPers. gul.}];270[976-977{S.v. AGk. ῥόδον 'rose', a borrowing from a language of the east, probably from Iranian *u̯r̥da- from which Persian gul, likewise Armenian vard.}]
Justification: A denominal adjective from Ancient Greek ῥόδος 'rose', in turn a loanword from the East, probably from Old Iranian *u̯r̥da- 'rose' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):976-977, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1289-1290).

Source: 460[477{S.v. Medieval Gk. ραπίς (cf. AG adj. χρυσόρραπις ‘with a golden stick’) > Cal. ραμίδα, with contamination from Lat. ramus.}];587[435{S.v. Gk. ῥαπίς 'Rute' > It. ramíδa 'verga', 'lungo bastone'| the -m- is due to contamination with Lat. ramus.}];66[1275{Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥαπίζω 'to beat with a stick, a rod, by hand', (pass.) 'to be beaten'. The simplex ῥαπίς may have been extracted from χρυσό-ρραπις where -ις can be explained as a compound suffix. Further analysis of the basis is uncertain, with several possibilities either to an unattested noun *ῥάψ, *ῥαπ-ή vel sim., or as a primary verb, or a zero-grade formation of ῥέπω, cf. also ῥώψ, ῥάβδος, ῥάμνος, ῥάπτω. A final possibility is a substratum origin.}]
Justification: From earlier Greek ῥαπίς, with contamination from Lat. ramus ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):435, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):477). Further etymology within Greek uncertain ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1275).

Source: 464[{χωρώ < ΑG θεωρῶ (Karanastasis 2:446-9)}]
Justification: Derived from Ancient Greek θεωρέω 'to view, look, behold' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), no certain etymology outside of Greek: for further etymological details cf. 'see' in [cognate set 8257](cog-8257).

Source: 460[285{Cf. s.v. AGk. ἰσχίον 'Hüftgelenk, Hüfte' > Tsakonian ίσ̌α 'Rücken'.}];66[603{S.v. AGk. ἰσχίον 'hip-joint, haunches'. No etymology.}];270[472{S.v. ἰσχίον 'os de bassin où s'emboîte le fémur, hanches'. No clear etymology.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip, hip-joint'. No further etymology (cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):285, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):472, [Beekes 2010](src-66):602-603).

Source: 460[285{Cf. s.v. AGk. ἵστημι| > Tskaon. τ̔αίνου.}];66[601{Cf. s.v. Gk. ἵστημι, derived from PIE *steh₂- 'stand'.}];464[{Tsakon. τσ̔ιτ̔αίνου: τσ̔ι- ‘un-’ (< AG ἐξ-, cf. τσ̔ι-μού < AG ἐξ-εμῶ ‘vomit’) τ̔αίνου ‘to get up’ (< AG ἵστημι) ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):285)}]
Justification: As though from *ἐξ-ίστημι > Tsakon. τσ̔ιτ̔αίνου, i.e. τσ̔ι- 'un' < ἐξ- + τ̔αίνου 'to get up' < ἵστημι 'stand' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). For further etymology, cf. 'stand' in [cognate set 309](cog-309).

Source: 399[I:349{S.v. Skt. golaḥ 'globe, ball, jar in the form of a ball'. Not to be separated from kuṇḍám, kholakaḥ, guṭikā, guḍáḥ. etc. Probably of Dravidian origin.}];442[232{S.v. 4321 gōla- (1) m. 'ball' BhP., ˚aka- m. 'ball' BhP., 'glans penis' Sāy., ˚likā- f. ʻ little ball ʼ SāmavBr. 2. *gōḍa- . [Cf. 4181 guḍá- (1) m. 'globe, ball']}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing derivatives of Sanskrit gola- 'ball, round object' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):232 no. 4321), cf. also variant guḍá- (1) m. 'globe, ball' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):223 no. 4181), presumably a Dravidian loanword (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:349).

Source: 172[II:404{Cf. s.v. Ved. yáva- 'Getreide, Korn, Feldfrucht, Gerste', from PIE *i̯éu̯o- (cf. Hitt. eu̯a- [e-u̯a-an, e-u-u̯a-an] 'eine Feldfrucht, wohl Gerste', Lith. jãvas 'Getreidepflanze', Gk. ζειαί (f.pl.) 'Spelt, Dinkel'). For the forms in this class, cf. specifically the derived form Ved. yávasa- 'Weide, Futter, Wiese, dem Weiden des Viehs dienendes Gras', Av. yauuaŋha- 'Weide'.}];442[603{S.v. 10436 Ved. yávasa- m.n. 'grass' RV.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes derived from the same root as Vedic yávasa- 'grass' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):603 no. 10436), further derived from PIE *i̯éu̯-o- ([EWAia](src-172) II:404).

Source: 172[II:128{Cf. s.v. Ved. píṇḍa- 'Klumpen, Fleischklumpen, Fleishkloß, runde Masse, Kugel'. Etymology unexplained.}];442[462{Cf. s.v. 8171 *piṇḍara- 'round like a lump'.}]
Comment: Cf. Vedic (RV) píṇḍa- m. 'lump, clod, piece' *piṇḍara-, Turner 1962-66, no. 8171, 8168; Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 128; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing *piṇḍara- 'round like a lump' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):462 no. 8171), derived to Vedic pinḍa- 'lump, clod'. Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:128).

Source: 320[84{S.v. Khot. ggīsai 'grass', from base gai-s- 'to twist' in Av. gaēsa- 'hair', cf. also base gai-p- 'to twist'.}];83[96-97{Cf. s.v. *gaip/b- 'to spin (thread)'. Bailey's proposed connection of Khot. ggīsai 'grass' to a simplex base *gai- with a different "increment" is unclear. Bailey's base form *gai- cannot be related to any known IE root. More likely, we are dealing with borrowings from a non-IE substrate language.}]
Justification: Cf. Avestan gaēsa- 'hair'. According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):84 the Avestan and Khotanese forms may be related via a more basic root *gai̯- to a group of Iranic words also found in Proto-Iranic *gaip/b- 'to spin (thread)', but the proposed derivational morphology in such a connection is entirely unclear (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):96-97).

Source: 464[{τσ̌όχανε < AG τραύσανον (Ηesych) / τραύξανα.}];66[1500{S.v. AGk. τραύξανα 'dry wood, brushwood', with variant τραύσανον· ξηρὸν πᾶν ἢ φρύγανον 'all dry items or firewood' (Hesych.). "Acc. to [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), it may replace τρώξανα (see τρώγω) after θραύω. However, the variation αυ : ω betrays a Pre-Greek word ([Furnée 1972](src-665):286)".}];270[1129{S.v. AGk. τραύξανα 'bois sec, petit bois', a doublet of τρώξανα (cf. τρώγω) on the model of θραύω 'briser'.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek τραύσανον 'firewood' (Hesych.) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further etymology disputed (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1129, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1500).

Source: 442[378-379{S.v. 6624 Ved. drávati 'runs' RV. [√dru-], 6634 Ved. drāváyati 'causes to run, makes flow, melts' RV. [√dru-].}];172[I:755-756{S.v. Ved. √drav- 'laufen, eilen', from PIE *dreu̯-.}];141[129{S.v. *dreu̯- 'laufen' (IEW 205-6).}]
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √dru- 'to run, hurry', ultimately to PIE *dreu̯- 'to run' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):378-379 no. 6624, 6634, [EWAia](src-172) I:755-756, [LIV²](src-141) 129).

Source: 172[II:407-408{S.v. Ved. √yā-¹ 'fahren, dahinziehen, sich bewegen', from PIE *(H)i̯eh₂-.}];141[309-310{S.v. 1. *i̯eh₂- 'dahinziehen, fahren' [IEW 296].}];442[604{S.v. Skt. 10452 yā́ti 'goes, approaches, comes to' RV. [√yā]}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to go, advance, set out, travel', further to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- ([EWAia](src-172) II:407-408, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):604, no. 10452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 309-310.

Source: 442[211{S.v. 3955 Ved. gácchati 'goes' RV., 'falls to the share of' Mn., 'understands' MBh. [√gam] (> K. gaċhun 'to go, become, be right').}];172[I:465-466{Cf. s.v. Ved. √gam- 'sich bewegen, gehen, kommen' (cf. OAv. ǰamaitī, ǰimaitī, YAv. gata-), from PIE *gʷem- (cf. Gk. βαίνω, Lat. veniō, Goth. qiman, etc.).}];141[209-210{S.v. *gʷem- '(wohin) gehen, kommen' (IEW 464-465).}]
Justification: Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √gam- < PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come', present stem gaccha- < *gʷm̥-sk̑e/o- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):211 no. 3955, [EWAia](src-172) I:465-466, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 209-210).

Source: 442[379{S.v. 6634 Skt. drāváyati 'causes to run, makes flow, melts', under which Pa. dāpēti 'causes to run' rather from < drāpáyati [cs. stem to √drā-]}];172[I:757{Cf. s.v. Ved. √drā-¹ 'laufen, eilen', from PIE *dreh₂- (cf. Gk. ἀπο-διδρᾱ́σκω 'laufe weg').}];141[127{Cf. s.v. *dreh₂- '(weg)laufen' (IEW 204).}]
Comment: perhaps from Vedic (ud- +) drāpáyati (ŚB), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 379, no. 6634

Source: 83[184-185{S.v. Proto-Iranian *Hrab/f-¹ 'to go'. An IE origin of this Iranian root is uncertain.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing an Iranic root *Hrab/f-, further connections outside of Iranic uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):184-185).

Source: 460[340{S.v. AGk. κύπτω 'sich vorwärts neigen, sich bücken' > Tsak. τ͡σι̬ούφτω 'schlafen'.}];66[805-806{S.v. AGk. κύπτω 'to bend forward, stoop to, run with the head down'. Not to be separated from AGk. κυφός 'bent forwards, hunchbacked'. Etymology outside of Greek uncertain. AGk. κυφός has been compared to Skt. kubhrá-, but a Munda origin has also been claimed for the Sanskrit lexeme. Other IE words that might be compared only show a root final *-p- (cf. Lith. kuprà 'hump', OHG hovar 'id.', etc. The variation κυφ-/κυπ- probably points to a substratum borrowing.}];270[601{S.v. AGk. κύπτω 'se pencher en avant, se courber, baisser la tête', maybe backformed from the perfect stem κέκυφα, maybe further connected to Skt. kubhrá- 'buffle bossu', but this is doubtful.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):601, [Beekes 2010](src-66):805-806 for various proposals.

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri tʹüruk  NAnF.  Fly.  [türᴺukᴺ]  [OIA. tur-ʹa- ‘quick’  T. 5874 (+?| cf. tvar 'hasten')]}];442[335{Cf. s.v. 5874 turá- (1) 'quick' RV. [√tvar]}];172[I:684-685{S.v. Ved. √tvar- 'eilen, in Eile sein' < PIE *tu̯er- (cf. Gk. ὀ-τρύνω 'treibe an', ὀτραλέως 'hurtig, rasch').}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes continuing a derivative of the same root found in Vedic turá- 'quick' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):335 no. 5874), further to PIE *tu̯er- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:684-685, [LIV²](src-141) 655).

Source: 83[350{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *spaič- (*spaiǰ) 'to shine| to bloom'. "The root appears to be Iranian, with no further IE cognate forms. It may have ended in a originally voiced velar consonant"}];320[437{S.v. Khot. spätaa- 'flower', from base spaik- : spik- 'to issue, burst out (of light or buds)', MPers.T. 'spyz-, 'spyxt, noun xwr-spyg 'sun-shine', Pahlavi Psalter 131.17 cs. spču- rendering Syriac 'dnḫ 'make to rise, cause to shine', Zor.P. škōf spēčīhēnd 'the buds burst out', noun spyg *spēk gloss to Av. frasparǝɣa- 'bud', Orm. ispēk, spēg 'barley'.}]
Comment: original meaning "to shine, to bloom"
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *spaič- 'to shine; to bloom'; further etymology outside of Iranic uncertain (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):437, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):350).

Source: 296[C:250-251{S.v. OIr. crúaid 'dur, rude, cruel'. May go back to *kroudi- and consequently have the same origin as Lat. crūdus < *kroudo-.}];54[146{Cf. s.v. Lat. crūdus 'raw, bloody, rough, cruel' from ?*kreuh₂-odʰ-o- perhaps cognate with MIr. crúaid 'hardy, harsh, stern'.}];274[448n30{Cf. for discussion against the etymology with Lat. crūdus, with references to further literature.}]
Justification: Often considered cognate with Lat. crūdus 'raw, bloody, rough' although aspects of the nominal stem formation remain unclear, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:250-251, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):146; against a connection with Lat. crūdus, cf. [NIL](src-274) 448n30, with references.

Source: 728[174{S.v. Manx follaghey or follagh 'hiding, concealing', cf. Ir. folachadh.}]
Justification: Cf. Old Irish folach 'hiding'. For various etymological proposals, cf. [Bergin 1938](src-766):220-222.

Source: 50[199{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kel-o- 'hide', from PIE *k̑el- 'hide'.}];141[322-323{S.v. 1. *k̑el- 'verbergen' (IEW 553-4).}];296[C:53-54{S.v. OIr. ceilid 'il cache, dissimule', corresponding to Lat. *-celō in the compound occulo, OHG hellan, from IE *k̑el- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 553).}];165[218{S.v. Proto-Germanic *helan- 'to conceal, hide' < *k̑él-e- (cf. Lat. occulō 'to hide, conceal', OIr. ceilid, MW kelu 'id.' < *k̑él-e-).}];556[252-253{S.v. Gmc. *hel-a- 'verbergen', with certainty to be related to the IE root *kel- 'verbergen' also attested in Latin occulō, OIr. celid, etc.}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE 1. *k̑el- 'to hide' ([LIV²](src-141) 322-323, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):252-253, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):218, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:53-54, [Matasović 2009](src-50):199).

Source: 360[1169{Cf. s.v. ùpė 'Strom, Fluß'. OPr. wupyan 'Wolke' possibly to be connected on the basis of semasiological parallels (but remains conjectural).}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. For a conjectural proposal to the family of words surrounding Lithuanian ùpė 'river' < PIE *h₂ep- 'water', cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1169. [Not in [ALEW](src-352) or [Derksen 2015](src-353).]

Source: 353[219, 256-257{S.v. Lith. kairỹs 'left' and Lith. kreĩvas 'crooked, curved, wrong'. The Balto-Slavic evidence could continue a PIE basic form *krei-uo- for Lith. kreĩvas (cf. Proto-Slavic *krivъ 'crooked, bent'), but there is little external evidence supporting a reconstruction outside of Balto-Slavic.}];352[522-523{Cf. s.v. OLith. kreĩvas 'schlief, krumm| unrichtig, falsch' (BSl. cf. SCr. krȋv 'schlief, krumm| unrichtig, falsch| schuldig', ORuss. krivyi 'krumm, verwachsen| falsch, schlecht, ungerecht', Russ. krivój 'krumm, schlief, schräg', Cz. křivý 'krumm, schlief, falsch'. The same root probably also underlies Latv. krèiss 'der linke', but there are no good comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 522-523, [Derksen 2015](src-353):219, 256-257 for further discussion.

Source: 172[II:161-163{S.v. Ved. pr̥thivī́- 'die Erde, Mutter Erde, vergöttliche Erde', originally the feminine stem to pr̥thú- 'wide' as an epithet of the earth| cf. s.v. Ved. pr̥thú- 'breit, weit, ausgedehnt groß, zahlreich, umfänglich' (cf. IIr. OAv. pərəθu- 'breit, weit'), from PIE *plth₂-ú- (cf. Gk. πλατύς 'weit, breit, flach, eben', Lith. platùs 'weit, breit, ausgedehnt', etc.). p.179 "práthas- n. Weite, Breite, Ausdehnung [...] Iir., jav. fraϑah- n. "Breite" - Idg. *pléth₂-es-"}];274[564{S.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (LIV 486f., IEW 833).}];141[486-487{Cf. s.v. *pleth₂- 'breit werden, sich ausbreiten' (IEW 833).}]
Justification: Originally a feminine adjectival form of Vedic pr̥thú- 'wide, broad' <*pl̥th₂-ú- as an epithet of the earth, further to PIE *pleth₂- 'to become wide, broad; to spread out' ([EWAia](src-172) II:161-163, [NIL](src-274) 564, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 486-487).

Source: 320[394-395{S.v. Khot. śśandā 'earth, ground, piece of ground, place', from *śuantakā-, fem. adj. to *śuanta- 'beneficient, making to increase and prosper', Av. spənta-, Zor.P. spand, to base *sau- 'increase, have profit', to PIE *k̑eu̯- 'swell', Ved. śváyati, śuná-, śūná-, śávas-, Greek κόοι 'holes', κοῖλος 'hollow', Lat. cauus 'hollow', Lith. šaunùs 'active', etc.}];172[II:678, 623-624{Cf. s.v. Ved. śvāntá- in the further discussion: OAv. YAv. spəṇta- 'heilvoll, heilkräftig' belongs with OAv. spǝ̄ṇ, Ved. śuná- probably ultimately to Ved. √śavⁱ-| Ved. √śavⁱ- 'anschwellen, stark werden, zunehmen, gedeihen' continues PIE *k̑eu̯h₁- 'anschwellen' (~ *k̑u̯eh₁-) (cf. Gk. κυέω 'bin schwanger', κῦμα 'Woge, Welle', Lat. cauus 'hohl', W cyw 'Tierjunges', OE hūn 'Junges', etc.).}];141[339-340{Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯eh₁- 'anschwellen' (IEW 592-4).}]
Justification: Comparable to Avestan spəṇta- 'beneficent' and further to PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):394-395, [EWAia](src-172) II:678, 623-624; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 339-340).

Comment: cf. Vedic (ŚB) abhyàkta- 'anointed', nasalization due to blend with abhyaṅga- 'anointed' (Mn.) (both from √añj-), palatal due to *bhiyajyate 'is smeared, get wet'; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 542; parallel derivations
Justification: Derivatives of Vedic √añj- 'smear, anoint' + abhi- 'towards, on, upon' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):542 no. 9500-9503). Root further to PIE *h₂engʷ- 'to anoint, smear (smth. on smth.)' ([EWAia](src-172) I:52, [LIV²](src-141) 267).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 19b)  connects this word to Saka ā̮ye 'ground, sole of foot' from āy- with Av. āi. He mentions a reconstruction by Morgenstierne (1942) proposed for NP xāk from *āhaka- 'ashes', which is followed by Klingenschmitt (2000: 213, fn.77).
Justification: Identical to a word for 'ashes' with special development of the semantics

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 331, no. 5812 and p. 789, no. 13693; Sinhalese e in teta from temanavā < *temayati
Justification: Continuing an Indic stem *tinta- with medial -e- vocalism taken over from temanavā < *temayati. Further connections difficult (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):331 no. 5812).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. rău, rea, from Lat. reus 'accused, guilty'.}];54[520-522{Cf. s.v. Lat. reus 'party in a lawsuit| defendant', from PIE *Hreh₁-i-unt- 'possessing wealth'?. Connected with Lat. rēs 'property, goods, thing, affair' from PIE *Hreh₁-i- 'wealth, goods' (cf. Skt. rayí- 'property, goods', Av. raii-i- 'wealth'). The root is probably the same as that of IIr. aor. *rā-s- 'bestow'.}];141[499{Cf. s.v. *reh₁- 'geben, schenken' (IEW 860).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin reus 'defendant, accused' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)) and also related to Latin rēs 'property, goods; thing, matter, affair', further to PIE *(H)reh₁- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):521-522 for discussion of the Italic stem formation; for the root reconstruction cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):520-521, [LIV²](src-141) 499).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. omorî, a loanword from Slavic umoriti.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian, Slovenian umoriti 'to murder, kill' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 360[859{S.v. Lith. spalvà 'Farbe', cf. Latv. spal̃va 'Haarfarbe von Tieren, Haar von vierfüßigen Tieren, Feder, Gefieder der Vogel'. [No further etymology given.]}];534[II:256]
Justification: Etymology outside of (East) Baltic obscure, see [IEW](src-49) 986, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:256 for various older proposals. Cf. also [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):859 s.v. Lith. spalvà 'colour'.

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. gândi, derived from Rom. gând 'thinking', a loanword from Hungarian gond.}]
Justification: Derived from Hungarian gând 'thinking, thoughts', a loanword from Hungarian gond ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 736[252{A loanword from Thraco-Dacian or Albanian.}];85[{S.v. Rom. copac, a loanword, cf. Alb. kopač.}]
Justification: Balkan loanword from Albanian or Thraco-Dacian (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), [Schulte 2009](src-736):252).

Source: 54[530{S.v. Lat. runcō, -āre 'to grub up (plants), weed', from PIE *h₃ru-n-k- 'to dig out' (cf. Skt. luñcati 'to pluck' (ep.), Gk. ὀρύσσω 'to dig, grub').}];85[{S.v. Rom. arunca, from Latin eruncare.}];444[258{S.v. 2908 Lat. eruncāre 'ausjäten'.}];141[307{Cf. s.v. *h₃reu̯k- '(aus)graben, (aus)rupfen' (IEW 869-870).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin eruncāre ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):258), further to PIE *h₃reu̯k- 'to dig, pluck (out)' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):530, [LIV²](src-141) 307).

Source: 141[441{S.v. *mesg- 'eintauchen (intr.), versinken' (IEW 745-6).}];54[375{S.v. Lat. mergō, -ere 'to plunge, immerse', from Proto-Italic *mezge/o-, from PIE *mesg-e/o- 'to sink, wash' (cf. Skt. májjanti 'to sink, plunge under, Lith. mazgóti, Latv. mazgât 'to wash').}];85[{S.v. Rom. merge, from Lat. mergere 'to sink'}]
Justification: Romanian merge 'to go' from Latin mergere 'to sink' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), further to PIE *mesg- 'to plunge, sink' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):375, [LIV²](src-141) 441).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. mare (1), probably from Lat. mas, maris.}]
85[{S.v. Rom. frică, a loanword from Gk. phrikē.}]
Justification: Loanword from Greek φρίκη 'horror' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 54[43{Cf. s.v. Lat. animus 'mind, spirit', from PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'breath'.}];141[267-268{Cf. s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' (IEW 38-9).}];85[{S.v. Rom. inimă, from Lat. animus 'soul, spirit, heart'.}]
Justification: East Romance lexemes for 'heart' from Latin animus 'soul, spirit, heart' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further from PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'breath' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):43, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 267-268).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. lovi, a borrowing from Slavic loviti 'hunt, catch, fish'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian loviti 'hunt', etc. ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), cf. 'hunt' in [cognate set 1145](cog-1145)).

Source: 54[442-443{S.v. Lat. pāngō, -ere 'to beat, strike| mourn, bewail', from nasal-present stem *ph₂-n-g̑- to PIE *peh₂g̑- (cf. Skt. pajrá- 'solid, firm', pā́jas- 'surface, face', Gk. πήγνυμι 'to attach, to join').}];141[461{Cf. s.v. *peh₂g̑- 'fest werden' (IEW 787).}];444[266{S.v. 3048 Lat. expingere 'ausstoßen' (zu pangere) > it. spingere, etc.| 4309 Lat. impingere 'hineinstoßen' > Rum. împinge.}]
Justification: Romanian împinge continues Latin im-pingere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):358 no. 4309), the remaining Romance lexemes continue Latin ex-pingere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):266 no. 3048). The non-prefixed verb, Latin pāngere 'to beat, strike' continues a nasal-present stem formation to PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):442-443, [LIV²](src-141) 461).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. mic, probably from Lat. *miccus.}];444[456{S.v. 5559 Lat. mīca 'Krümchen'.}];316[402{S.v. Lat. mīca, -ae 'parcelle, miette, grain', attested since Cato. Etymology uncertain, cf. Gk. (σ)μικρός?}];54[378{S.v. Lat. mīca 'grain, crumb'| according to [Nyman 1987](src-739) the word originally meant a 'grain of salt' and was subsequently generalised to mean any kind of 'glittering crystal(line) particle'. As such he derives mīca from the same root as micāre 'to quiver, dart, flash' in the sense 'the glittering particle', this seems semantically possible and no better etymology has yet been proposed.}];739[221-239]
Justification: Probably to Latin mīca 'small grain, crumb' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):456, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further etymology difficult. The best recent proposal is of [Nyman 1987](src-739), who argues for an original meaning 'grain of salt' and derives from the same root as Latin micō, -āre 'to quiver, dart, flash' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):378, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):402).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. mirosi, a loan from Slavic mirosati.}]
Justification: A loan from South Slavic mirosati, cf. Serbo-Croatian mirisati 'to smell' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 165[339{S.v. Proto-Germanic *lītila- 'small'. The derivation of the word is problematic, and the radical alternation in the closely related OE lȳt, OS lū̆t, MHG luz 'few' *līt- ~ *lūt-, *lutt- remains unexplained. Until this alternation has been resolved it will be difficult to find a good etymology.}];398[1559-1561{S.v. OHG luzzi 'klein, winzig, gering' in other Germanic languages corresponding to OS lut 'wenig', OE lyt 'wenig, klein' if the vowel in both is short.}];179[231{S.v. Goth. L33 leitils 'μικρός', 'little'. No etymology.}];697[371-372{S.v. Gmc. *leitila- 'klein'. From the root *leit- there also are *leitena-, *leitika-/*littika-. Beside these is a root *lū̆t- in *lut(t)i-, *luttika-, *lūtila-/*luttila-. It alternates also a) ei/i and ū/u, b) t and tt, c) the suffixes -ena-, -ika-, and -ila-. The root *leit- is common Germanic, while *litt- and lūt- are only West Germanic. Close possibilities for comparisons outside of Germanic are lacking.}];698[353-354{For the Frisian form, cf. s.v. leitika- 'klein'.}];269[{Root ref. form *leit- in this class follows Heidermanns 1993.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):231, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):339; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):371-372 for discussion of variant forms within Germanic).

Source: 54[410{S.v. Lat. niteō 'to be radiant, shine', from which nitidus 'bright, elegant' is a derived adjective. The Latin words connected to niteō are most easily understood as a formation based on a past passive participle *nitos 'made bright, shining', but there is no known IE verbal root that fits the form and meaning.}];85[{S.v. Rom. neted, from Latin nitidus 'bright, shining'.}];316[442{S.v. Lat. niteō, -ēre 'briller, être luisant, éclatant', one hypothesis by Vendryes connects Ir. niam 'éclat' from a hypothetical root *nei- 'briller', but this is very uncertain.}]
Justification: Romanian neted is from Latin nitidus 'bright, shining' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), but further connections outside of Italic are obscure ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):442, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):410).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. băț, etymology unknown.}]
Justification: No known etymology ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 423[I:614{Cf. s.v. Sp. boira 'niebla', an Aragonese word taken from Catalan boira from Lat. boreas 'viento Norte'.}];316[73-74{Cf. s.v. Lat. boreās, -ae 'vent du nord et région d'où souffle ce vent, nord', a borrowing from Gk. βορέας 'north wind'.}];444[107{S.v. 1219 Lat. boreas 'Nordwind'.}]
Justification: From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):107, cf. [DCECH](src-423) I:614), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):73-74).

Source: 423[I:227-229{Cf. s.v. Sp. amagar 'hacer ademán de ir a ejecutar alguna cosa en dãno de otro', of unknown origin.}]
Justification: Of unknown origin (cf. [DCECH](src-423) I:227-229 for discussion of various hypotheses).
Etymology uncertain.

Source: 54[482-483{Cf. s.v. Lat. portō, -āre 'to transport, carry'. Most likely to be a denominal verb from Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'passage, crossing', cf. Lat. porta 'gate'. Cf. elsewhere PIE *pr̥-to-, *pr̥-tu- (Gaulish ritu-, Old Welsh rit, Welsh rhyd 'ford' < PCl. φritu-| Av. pərətu- 'crossing, bridge'| OHG furt, Engl. ford < PGmc. furδú-).}];141[472-473{Cf. s.v. 1. per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren' (IEW 816-817).}];444[554{S.v. 6672 Lat. portāre 'tragen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):482-483, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 472-473).

Source: 352[545-546{Cf. s.v. OLith. kvė̃pti 'atmen, hauchen' (BSl. cf. Latv. kvêpt 'qualmen, rauchen', etc.). These lexemes are probably not to be separated from Lat. vapor, -ōris 'Dampf, Dunst', Gk. καπνός 'Raum, Qualm, Dunst', continuing a root *kʷu̯ap- or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-. Improbable is an etymological connection with Goth. afƕapjan 'ersticken', etc.}];353[268{Cf. s.v. Lith. kvė̃pti 'inhale, breathe in, inspire', possibly from *k⁽ʷ⁾h₂uēp- and connected with Gk. καπνός 'smoke, Lat vapor 'steam, heat' (both probably < *k⁽ʷ⁾uh₂ep-).}]
Justification: Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ([ALEW](src-352) 545-546, [Derksen 2015](src-353):268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.

Source: 352[663{S.v. OLith. mìškas 'Wald' (BSl. nar. miʃzta 'Wald'), no known etymology.}];531[406-407{S.v. Lith. mìškas 'las', without etymology.}]
Justification: No known etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 663, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):406-407).

Source: 172[II:402-403{Cf. s.v. Ved. √yav-¹ 'verbinden, festhalten, anschirren' < PIE *i̯eu̯- 'verbinden' (cf. Lith. jáuti, jaũti 'vermischen').
