The meaning 'eat' found in Aškuni yū- 'eat' and Wakhi yaw- 'eat' is a secondary semantic development.}];141[314{Cf. s.v. 1. *i̯eu̯- 'festhalten, an sich ziehen, verbinden' (IEW 507, 508).}];442[607{S.v. 10507 yuvátē 'yokes' RV., yauti 'takes hold of' AV. 2. *eats}];321[423{S.v. Wax. yaw- : (y)it- 'есть, кушать' < OIr. *yav(a)- : *yauta-, *yūta-.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *i̯eu̯- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):607 no. 10507, [EWAia](src-172) II:402-403, [LIV²](src-141) 314, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):423).

Source: 320[447{S.v. Khot. haḍā 'day', from *harta- or *hr̥ta-, *haḍāka- masc. to base har- 'go up| pass' (Sogd.Man. xrṭyẖ 'passed'). Further root etymology uncertain| either to PIE er- 'to go' or ar- 'to rise' (cf. s.v. hada- 'attained').}]
Justification: According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):447, from Proto-Iranic *harta- or *hr̥ta- to an Iranic base *har- 'go up; pass'. Further root etymology uncertain: [Bailey 1979](src-320):447 suggests either to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' ([IEW](src-49) 326-9, [LIV²](src-141) 238) or *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref IEW 326-9, [LIV²](src-141) 299).

Source: 442[205-206{S.v. 3890 *khucc- 'pierce, tear'. 2. *khōcc- . 3. *khuñc- . 4. *khōñc- . [Poss. formations fr. *sku-. For list of poss. enlargements of IE. *sqeu -- see √sku].}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indic *khucc-, possibly an extended form of the same root found in Vedic √skav- 'to tear, pluck'? ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):205-206, no. 3890; for Ved. √skav- cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:751). Further origins uncertain.

Source: 50[376{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tegos- 'house', from PIE *teg-os 'cover, roof' (cf. Lat. tegō 'cover', Gk. τέγος 'roof', Germ. Dach).}];141[589{Cf. s.v. *(s)teg- 'decken, bedecken' (IEW 1013-4).}];296[T:39-40{S.v. OIr. tech, teg 'maison', from *tegos, gen. *teges-os, corresponding exactly to Gk. τέγος 'toit, construction' and from the verbal root *teg- 'couvrir', cf. Lat. tegō, togā, etc.}];274[635{PIE *(s)tég-es- n. 'covering'}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'cover' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:39-40, [Matasović 2009](src-50):376; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 589).

Source: 50[304-305{S.v. Proto-Celtic *rād-ī- 'talk', from PIE *(H)reHdʰ- 'perform successfully' (cf. Skt. rādh- 'perform successfully', OCS raditi 'take care of, work', Goth. rodjan 'talk', Lith. rodýti 'show').}];296[R:3{S.v. OIr. rád- 'dire, parler', from a root *rēdh-, *rōdh- in the sense 'parler' (cf. Goth. rodjan, OIc. roda, OHG redon| also Skt. rádhayati, rādhnóti 'il satisfait, réussit, OCS raditi 'prendre soin de', Goth. ga-redan 'id.', etc.).}];141[499-500{S.v. *reh₁dʰ- 'erfolgreich durchführen' (IEW 59-60).}]

141[353-355{S.v. 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' [IEW 933-5]| cf. n8: fo-ceird 'wirft, legt' < *kérH-dʰe- is synchronically suppletive within Irish to -cuirethar 'wirft, setzt in Bewegung, legt' < *korH-éi̯e-, but they share the same root etymology.}];50[202-203{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-o- 'put, lay, move', from PIE *kerd- 'swing' ([IEW](src-49) 934f.), cf. Gk. κραδάω 'swing, wave'.}];296[C:72{Cf. s.v. cerd- (3), principally in fo-ceird 'il lance', jette'.}];304[401-403{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-e/o- 'setzen, legen, stellen', from PIE *//kerdʰ-//, a secondary formation from a nominal compound *ker-dʰh₁o- < *kerH-dʰh₁-o-), the root being PIE 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' (LIV² 353-355).}]
Justification: Root ref. form in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 353-355, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):401-403, but cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:72, [Matasović 2009](src-50):202-203 for older proposals.

Source: 296[C:24{S.v. OIr. caithid 'il utilise, mange, jouit, de, lance'. Etymology difficult to explain. Cf. entry for various proposals. Probably connected to Gaul. cateia 'projectile' a gloss given by Servius ad Aen. 7.741, to which Pokorny (ZCPh 20 p.404) connected to Cz. kotiti 'retourner, tourner'.}];157[110{Cf. s.v. Gaul. cateia 'sorte de projectile', a word reported by the Latin grammarian Servius (ad Aen. 7.741), glossing 'tela gallica' designating a projectile similar to a boomerang. Generally connected to the OIr. verb cathaid, with numerous senses among with 'il lance' and Cz. kotiti 'retourner, tourner' (cf. Pokorny ZCPh 20 1936 p.44, LEIA C-24).}]
Justification: From Old Irish caithid 'use, spend; hurl, throw'; the diverse semantics of the verb make the etymology difficult to explain. Probably further connected to Gaulish cateia, glossed in Servius's commentary to the Aeneid (7.741) as a 'tela gallica' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:24; cf. [Delamarre 2003](src-157):110).

Source: 296[S:131-132{S.v. OIr. sliasat, sliasait 'cuisse'. May go back to a base *(s)pleigh- 'écarter les jambes' (cf. Skt. pléhate 'il marche, il se meut', Gk. πλίσσομαι 'marcher à grands pas'), further to an unextended root *(s)plei- (cf. IEW 1000).}];399[II:387{Cf. s.v. Skt. plehate 'geht, bewegt sich / goes, moves' (Dhātup.). Maybe (?) an explanation can be contrived to plīhán- 'Milz', however hardly a continuant of IE *(s)pleig̑ʰ- (IEW 1000).}];66[1211{Cf. s.v. Gk. πλίσσομαι 'to cross the legs'. Etymology uncertain. Perhaps to be related to OIr. sliassait 'shank' < *spleigʰ-s-ont-ih₂ or Skt. plehate 'to go' < *pleig̑ʰ-e/o- according to [IEW](src-49) 1000.}]
Justification: Traditionally considered a derivative of a putative PIE *(s)plei̯g̑ʰ- 'spread the legs' according to [IEW](src-49) 1000, but the proposed cognates justifying this root reconstruction are very uncertain (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:131-132, [KEWA](src-399) II:387, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1211).

Source: 50[179{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷetwores 'four', from PIE *kʷetu̯ores (cf. Skt. catvā́ras, Lat. quattuor, Gk. τέτταρες, Goth. fidwor, Lith. keturì, OCS četyre, ToA śtwar, Arm. čorkʻ).}];300[{Cf. s.v. Ir. cethramthu 'quarter, fourth part', from Ir. cethair 'four'.}]
Justification: Cf. MIr. cethramthu 'quarter, fourth part' in the sense of 'quartered human body; thigh' ([Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)](src-300)), further to OIr. cethair 'four' from PIE *kʷetu̯or- 'four' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):179).

Source: 309[522-523{S.v. Bret. morzed 'cuisse', corresponding to Co. môrdhos (OCo. mordoit) and W morddwyd 'id.', the words are derived from Proto-Celtic *mar-yeito-.}];236[{Cf. s.v. W morddwyd 'thigh(-bone), haunch, ham' (cf. OCo. mor[þ]oit, gl. femur uel coxa, MCo. morʒosow (ll.), Late Cornish morzat, Bret. morzhed).}]
Justification: A securely Brythonic family of words, cf. Welsh morddwyd 'thigh(-bone), haunch, ham', but outside connections remain difficult to ascertain (cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):239-240, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):522-523, [Pedersen 1909](src-307):70, and [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) for further discussion).

Source: 296[B:76{S.v. OIr. bráen, bróen 'goutte, averse, pluie', without etymology, cf. entry for various proposals.}]
Justification: No certain etymology ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:76).
Loan from Latin baptisma.

Source: 50[194{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kasso- 'curly, woven, twisted' "The connection to the root *kes- 'to comb' ([IEW](src-49) 585, cf. OCS česati, PCelt. *kīsrā 'comb') is semantically appealing, but the a-vocalism in Celtic is unexplained (a secondary zero-grade *kasto- instead of the expected *ksto-, with epenthetic *a?).}];296[C:44-45{Cf. s.v. OIr. cas 'bouclé, embrouillé, tordu, etc.' for a survey of older etymological hypotheses.}]
Justification: Derived from Old Irish cas 'curly, woven, twisted'; formerly proposed to PIE *kes- 'to comb' (so [IEW](src-49) 585, but the -a- vocalism is difficult to account for ([Matasović 2009](src-50):194; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:44-45 for a survey of earlier hypotheses.

Source: 231[202{S.v. ScG. gorm 'blue, green', Ir. E.Ir. gorm 'blue', W gwrm 'dusky'. "gorsmo- root gor, warm ("warm colour") as in G. gar (Stokes)."}];50[169{S.v. Proto-Celtic *gurmo- 'dun, dark' (MIr. gorm 'blue', MW gwrm, OBret uurm-haelon 'with brown eyebrows'). "There does not seem to be any cognates in other IE languages, so this adjective was probably borrowed from some non-IE source."}];761[114{S.v. *gorsmo-s 'warm, roth' > Ir. gorm 'blau', W. gwrm 'niger, nigricans, infuscus', OBret. uurm in Uurm-haelon, Uuorm-haelon 'aux sourcils bruns', etc. [a subheading of PCl. *gorô 'Wärme' to be connected with *gʷʰer-].}];49[1152{"ags. tourma m. ,Purpurschnecke, Waid, Purpur', daraus entlehnt abret. uurm , dunkel', cymr. gwrm ,dunkel (blaa)*, woraus wiederum air. gorm ds."}]
Justification: Scottish Gaelic gorm 'green', continuing Old Irish gorm 'blue, green'; within Celtic cf. also Middle Welsh gwrm 'brown', Old Breton uu(o)rm- 'brown'. Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain: Previous proposals have included (1) [Stokes 1894](src-761):114, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):202 as a derivative of PIE *gʷʰer- in the sense 'the warm colour', (2) [IEW](src-49) 1152 considering a loanword from Anglo-Saxon wurma 'Purpurschnecke; woad; purple'. [Matasović 2009](src-50):169 does not consider any IE etymology to be viable.

Source: 442[161{S.v. 3157 Skt. kiṭṭāla m. 'copper vessel' lex. (Ash. čitā'l 'bowels', Kt. kṭyȧl, Pr. kṭal| Bashg. ktol 'belly' (NTS ii 252 prob. ← Ind.?).)}]
Justification: Probably loans from Old Indic kiṭṭāla- 'copper vessel' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):161).

Source: 231[15{S.v. ScG. amhach 'neck', < *om-âk-â- (cf. Lat. humerus 'shoulder' < *om-es-os, Gk. ὦμος, Goth. amsa, Skt. amsas).}]
Justification: According to [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):15 to be connected with Latin umerus 'shoulder', Ancient Greek ὦμος 'id.', Goth. amsa 'id.', Skt. áṃsa- 'id.', although without clear antecedents in earlier Celtic. If so, then to PIE *h₃ems-o- (cf. 'back' in [cognate set 7111](cog-7111)). [Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)].

Source: 231[68{S.v. ScG. can 'say, sing' (Ir. canaim, OIr. canim, W. cana 'sing', cf. Lat. canō 'sing', Engl. hen).}];50[187-188{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-o- 'sing', derived from PIE *kan- (cf. Lat. canō 'sing', Goth. hana 'cock').}];141[342-343{Cf. s.v. *⁽k̑⁾an- 'singen, klingen' (IEW 525-6).}];304[387-390{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kan-e/o- 'singen', from PIE *kan- or *k̑an- (LIV 342f., IEW 525f.).}]
Justification: Scots Gaelic can, from Old Irish canim 'sing' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):68, further to PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'sing' ([LIV²](src-141) 342-343, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):387-390, [Matasović 2009](src-50):187-188).

Source: 442[260{S.v. 4798 Skt. cíti- f. 'layer, pile, stack of wood' TS. [√ci1].}]

50[205{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kiw-o- 'fog', generally connected to PIE *k̑ei̯H- 'gray' (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'gray', Lith. šývas, but Matasović comments "The derivation from the PIE root is doubtful both formally and semantically (for the phonetic development cf. OIr. béo from PCelt. *biwo- 'alive'). The vowel length could have been lost by Dybo's law if PIE end-stressed *kiH-wó- is posited. OE héow, hiw 'appearance' and the related Germanic words probably do not belong here (Orel 2003: 171 relates them convincigly (sic!) to OE heawan 'to hew')."}];296[C:68-69{S.v. OIr. ceó 'nuée, brume, brouillard'. One may compare Goth. hiwi 'apparence', OE héow, hiw 'apparence, forme, visage, couleur', also with enlargement *kiē-wo- (cf. Skt. śyāvá- 'brun foncé') or *kī-wo- (Lith. šývas 'blanchâtre', OCS sivŭ 'gris foncé').}];269[{Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:68-69, [IEW](src-49) 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ([Matasović 2009](src-50):205, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, [EWAia](src-172) II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this class).}]
Justification: Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:68-69, [IEW](src-49) 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ([Matasović 2009](src-50):205, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, [EWAia](src-172) II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).

Source: 728[287{S.v. Manx maidjey 'stick' (= Ir. maide).}];50[260-261{S.v. Proto-Celtic *mazdyo- 'stick' (cf. PIE *mazdo- [IEW](src-49) 702, Lat. mālus, OIc. mastr 'mast'), cf. also OIr. mátan 'club' which could be from *māzd-ān-o-. "In principle it would be possible to explain all the Celtic-Italic-Germanic correspondences by assuming ablaut *meh₂sd-/*mh₂sd-, but I think it is more probable that these words were borrowed from some pre-IE source."}]

309[97{S.v. Bret. bazh 'bâton| barreau', from Old Breton bath and corresponding to Cornish bath (Old Cornish bat) 'pièce de monnaie', W bath. The word is a low register Latin loan *batto- from *batta- in Gaulish (cf. Latino-Gaulish bata, from which Fr. batte).}]
Justification: According to [Deshayes 2003](src-309):97, a loanword from regional Latin *batto-, in turn borrowed from Gaulish batta (cf. Fr. batte).

Source: 231[115{S.v. ScG. cuir 'put', Ir., EIr. cuirim, OIr. cuiriur.}];141[353-355{S.v. 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' [IEW 933-5]| cf. n8: fo-ceird 'wirft, legt' < *kérH-dʰe- is synchronically suppletive within Irish to -cuirethar 'wirft, setzt in Bewegung, legt' < *korH-éi̯e-, but they share the same root etymology.}];300[{Cf. s.v. OIr. do-cuirethar 'puts'.}];296[C:276-277, C:72{Cf. s.v. OIr. cuirethar 'mettre, placer, jeter' and s.v. cerd- (3), principally in fo-ceird 'il lance', jette'.}];304[401-403{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *kerd-e/o- 'setzen, legen, stellen' > OIr. -ceird.}]
Justification: Lit. 'to throw, cast out'. Cognacy is coded for the verbal head cuir 'throw' from Old Irish -cuirethar (cf. eDIL); synchronically suppletive to fo·ceird 'throw' within Irish but from the same Indo-European root ([LIV²](src-141) 353-355, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):401-403), for older hypotheses cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:276-277.

Source: 442[732{Cf. s.v. 12620 Skt. śōcís- 'flame, glow' (RV.)| Waigalī šoč 'war', Kati šuč.}];172[II:655-656{Cf. s.v. Ved. √śoc- 'leuchten, glühen, brennen' (IIr. cf. OAv. saočaiiat̰ 'inflames', sūčā 'durch den Glanz', etc.), if from IE, then from PIE *k̑eu̯k-, but connections outside Indo-Iranian remain uncertain.}];141[331{Cf. s.v. ?1. *k̑eu̯k- 'aufflammen, erglühen' (IEW 597). Cf. n1: Only Indo-Iranian, if Gk. κύκνος 'Schwan' as *'der leuchtend Weiße' doesn't belong here.'}]
Justification: Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):732 no. 12620, [EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331).

Source: 172[Ι:757{Cf. s.v. Ved. √drā-¹ 'laufen, eilen' < PIE *dreh₂- (cf. Gk. ἀπο-διδρᾱ́σκω).}];141[127{S.v. 1. *dreh₂- '(weg)laufen' (IEW 204).}];431[{S.v. Kâmviri unrʹâ-  [undrʹavoa-]  VI.  Fly.  [uᵈnrâ-ᵛ]  [OIA. ud-drâ-ti ‘flees| flies’  T. 2001 (whence n?)]}];442[93{S.v. 2001 *uddrāti 'flees, flies' [Cf. uddrāvá -- ʻ running away ʼ VS., m. ʻ going upwards ʼ Pāṇ.: √drā].}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Indic *uddrāti 'flees, flies' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):93 no. 2001), further connected to Vedic √drā- 'to run, make haste' and ultimately to PIE *dreh₂- 'to run (away)' ([EWAia](src-172) I:757, [LIV²](src-141) 127).

Source: 728[121{S.v. Manx diane 'earthworm, lugworm in the earth', cf. Ir. daoi 'embankment, sandhill', also dhiane.}]

50[140{S.v. Proto-Celtic s.v. *freswo- 'strong cold', which may be from PIE *preu̯s- 'freeze' (cf. Skt. pruṣvā́- 'drops of dew', Lat. pruīna 'hoarfrost', Goth. frius 'hoarfrost'), but one must assume a metathesis *-u̯s- > *-su̯- from earlier *preu̯s-o-.}];141[493-494{Cf. s.v. *preu̯s- 'sprühen, spritzen' (IEW 809-10, 846).}];240[137{Cf. s.v. Old Welsh reulaun 'icy' (lit. ice-full), with W rhew 'frost, ice', OIr. réud, < *preuswo-.}];296[R:24-25{S.v. OIr. réud 'grand froid'. The connection with Skt. pruṣvā́- 'glace', Lat. pruīna < pruswinā-, Goth. frius 'gel' is not certain as the Proto-Celtic form is difficult to reconstruct.}];236[{S.v. W rhew '(hoar-)frost, ice' (cf. OCo. reu, Bret. rev, etc. < PIE *prēuso-, cf. Goth. *frius).}];269[{The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class to PIE *preu̯s- follows [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):140, but cf. doubts in [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:24-25, [EIEC](src-657) 287.}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- following [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):140, but cf. doubts in [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:24-25, [EIEC](src-657) 287. Cf. 'freeze' in [cognate set 226](cog-226).

Source: 50[387{S.v. Proto-Celtic *towto- 'left, north'. Old Breton tut 'good, favourable' appears to be the same word as OIr. túath 'left, north'. "It is unclear if the meanings 'left', 'good', and 'magic' can be brought together, since the associations of the left hand side are almost universally negative. Perhaps some sort of taboo replacement is involved, but in any case the IE part of this etymology remains somewhat conjectural." Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good'.}];296[T:164-165{Cf. s.v. OIr. 2 tuath 'gauche'.}];269[{Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:164-165| cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):387 with some doubts). However, the connections with the Italic and Germanic lexemes are judged difficult by [Lehmann 1986](src-179):362-363 and not even discussed by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):632-633. For possible semantic parallel for a euphemism, cf. Greek ἀριστερός in [cognate set 1504](cog-1504).}];179[362-363{Cf. s.v. Goth. Ϸ45. ϸiuϸ 'τὸ ἀγαθόν', 'the good'. Etymology difficult.}];54[632-633{Cf. s.v. Lat. tueor 'to look at, watch over' (p.p.p. tūtum) [No Celtic cognates listed.]}]
Justification: Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:164-165; cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):387 with some doubts). The proposed connections with the Italic and Germanic lexemes are judged difficult by [Lehmann 1986](src-179):362-363 and not considered by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):632-633. For possible semantic parallel for a euphemism, cf. Greek ἀριστερός in [cognate set 1504](cog-1504).

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri kâc̣ʹavec̣ 'fruit' [OIA. kʹakṣa- ‘undergrowth’  T. 2589 (+)]}];442[128{Cf. s.v. 2589 kákṣa- (2) 'undergrowth'.}];172[I:288{Cf. s.v. Ved. kákṣa- (2) 'Gebüsch, Gestrüpp', certainly distinct from kákṣa- (1) 'Achselhöhle', perhaps to be connected with NHG Hag, Hecke?}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes, to be connected with Vedic kákṣa- 'undergrowth' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):128 no. 2589). No certain further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:288).

Source: 728[284{S.v. Manx lurgey 'leg, shin-bone' (cf. OIr. lurga).}]

728[12{S.v. Manx arrane 'song, ditty, hymn| singing' [= Ir. amhrán]. Cf. also goaill.}];296[A:65{S.v. OIr. amar 'chagrin, souffrance', corresponding to W. afar 'tristesse, lamentation', deriv. amrán 'chant| sorte de poème', further etymology unknown.}]
Justification: Manx lexemes representing a light-verb construction 'to make a song' where for the purposes of cognacy Manx arrane 'song' is encoded as the semantic bearing head (cf. [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):12). From Old Irish amrán 'song; a kind of poem', a diminutive of amar 'sorrow, suffering'. Further to Welsh afar 'sadness, lamentation' but of uncertain etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:65).

Source: 728[422-423{S.v. Manx soar 'smell' (Engl. savour).}]
Justification: A borrowing from English savour ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):422-423).

Source: 442[128{S.v. 2587 Skt. kakkhaṭa- , kha˚ 'hard, solid' lex. 2. *kakkhāṭa-, 3. kakkaṭa-.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit kakkhaṭa- 'hard, solid' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):128, no. 2587). No further etymology.

Source: 442[25{S.v. 560 Ved. amā́ 'at home, in the house' RV.}];172[I:95{S.v. áma- (2) pron. 'dieser (hier)', to which probably amā́ 'zu Hause'. In view of the deixis perhaps to be compared with Gk. ἐμοῦ 'meiner', but uncertain.}]
Justification: Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic amā́ 'at home, in the house' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):25 no. 560). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:95.

Source: 442[410{S.v.7165 *nigāti 'learns', cf. nyágāt 'went down' RV. [Cf. nigan- tavya- 'to be learnt' Āpast., nigacchati 'acquires knowledge' lex., Pk. ṇiacchaï 'sees'. – √gā-] (> Pk. ṇiaï 'sees'| Ash. niṅā- 'to know, recognize'| Wg. niṅā- 'to understand').}];172[I:482{Cf. s.v. Ved. √gā-¹ 'den Fuß aufsetzen (beim Gehen), treten, schreiten' (cf. IIr. OAv. gāt̰ 'soll hingehen', YAv. gāman- 'Schritt', Khot. jsā- 'gehen', etc.), from PIE *gʷeh₂- (cf. Gk. aor. ἔβην 'ging, machte sich auf', βῆμα 'Fußtritt, Schwelle', Lith. (dial.) góti 'gehen', etc.).}];141[205{Cf. s.v. *gʷeh₂- 'den Fuß aufsetzen, treten' (IEW 463-4).}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic *nigāti (ni- 'down' + √gā- 'to take a step'), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):410 no. 7165. Root etymology further to PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ([EWAia](src-172) I:482, [LIV²](src-141) 205).

Source: 442[18{S.v. 395 Ved. ánna- 'food' RV. Ash. andá ʻ meat ʼ, Wg. andá, ána, Kt. anṓ (< *adnāka -- NTS xvii 226), Gaw. āˊnda, Shum. ã̄də.}];172[I:79-80{S.v. Ved. ánna- 'Speise, Nahrung', a substantivization of *anná- 'gegessen' < *ad-ná- (*h₁ed-).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic ánna- 'food' reflecting PIE *h₁éd-no-, cf. PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):18 no. 395, [EWAia](src-172) I:79-80).

Source: 83[32{S.v. Proto-Iranian *čam-? 'to walk'. No IE origin| might be a blend of Proto-Iranian *čarH- and *gam-¹.}]

83[429-432{S.v. Proto-Iranian *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, transport, fly' (cf. Gk. (Pamph.) ϝεχέτω 'he must bring', Lat. vehō, vēxī 'I ride, bring', OCS vezǫ 'I ride' Lith. vežu 'I ride, procure' OHG wegan 'to move' etc.).}];141[661-662{S.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben| fahren' (IEW 1118-20).}]

Justification: Cf. Turner 1962–1966:262, no. 4822 *cimb- 'pinch' > Hindi cimṭā, cyū̃ṭā m. 'pincers'???

Source: 442[594{Cf. s.v. 10298 mr̥ṣā 'in vain' RV., 'falsely' AV., miṣa- n. 'false appearance' Kāv. [√mr̥ṣ?]}];431[{Cf. s.v. Kâm-viri mišʹa- 'play' [PrAr. *mr̥sa- ‘in vain| falsely’  T. 10298].}];399[II:678-679{S.v. Skt. mŕ̥ṣā 'umsonst, irrig', 'in vain, uselessly, wrongly' to Skt. mŕ̥ṣyate 'vergißt, vernachlässigt, ist lässig' / 'forgets, neglects', outside of Indo-Iranian cf. Arm. moṙanam 'vergesse', Lith. mir̃šti, už-mir̃šti 'vergessen', maršùs 'vergeßlich', TochAB märs- 'vergessen'.}];172[II:332{S.v. Ved. √marṣ- 'vergessen', from PIE *mers- 'vergessen', cf. Arm. moṙana-, Lith. už-mir̃šti, TochAB märs- 'vergessen'.}];141[440-441{Cf. s.v. *mers- 'vergessen' (IEW 737-8).}]
Justification: Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing a derivatives of Vedic mr̥ṣā 'in vain, wrongly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594 no. 10298, [Strand 1998](src-431), further derived from Vedic √marṣ- 'to forget' and further to PIE *mers- 'to forget' ([KEWA](src-399) II:678-679, [EWAia](src-172) II:332, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 440-441).

Source: 338[{no good Iranian cognates. Abaev links to PIE *rebhyo (PIr. *raibya), cf. English rib, Russian rebro, etc.}];156[III:414-415]
Justification: No certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.), [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:414-415 proposes connections to PIE *(H)rebʰ-ró- (cf. Old Church Slavonic reboro 'rib, side', Old High German rippi, ribbi 'rib').

Source: 442[318{S.v. 5610 Skt. ḍhaukayati 'brings near' Kathās., pp. ḍhaukita- MBh. [√ḍhauk].}];399[I:465{S.v. Skt. ḍáukate 'nähert sich / approaches'. Of unclear origin "kaum arischen Ursprungs" (Wack. I 148).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √ḍhauk- 'approach, bring near'; of uncertain etymology, probably a loanword ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):318 no. 5610, [KEWA](src-399) I:465).

Comment: Proto-Indo-European *mo[u]-lo-

Source: 320[469{S.v. Khot. haryāsa- 'black', from base har- 'of dark colours', Av. harəta-, harəδa-, harəda- 'red', Oss. xärä- 'dark', from [IEW](src-49) 910-1 *ser-, *sor- 'red' (cf. Lith. sar̃tas 'red (of a horse)', Latv. sârts 'red in face', sarks 'reddish'.}];352[891{Cf. s.v. OLith. sar̃tas 'rotbraun (Pferd)' (cf. Latv. sā̀rts 'rot, frisch aussehend', sar̂kans 'rot'), the (East-)Baltic colour adjective can be connected to a PIE root *ser- 'rot' (IEW 910f.), but closer correspondences in related languages are lacking.}];49[910-911{S.v. 3. *ser-, *sor- 'rot, rötlich'.}];531[534{Cf. s.v. Lith. sárkanas 'pink, ruddy, with healthy appearance', to a root *ser-.}]
Justification: According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):469, to be connected with Baltic adjectives meaning 'red, ruddy' from a basic root *ser- ([IEW](src-49) 910-911). The extra-Baltic connections to the proposed comparanda in Lithuanian sar̃tas 'red-brown, chestnut (of a horse)', etc.  have been recently doubted by [ALEW](src-352) 891, but cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):534.

Source: 442[132{S.v. 2641 Skt. kaṭú-, káṭuka- 'pungent, bitter' RV.}];172[I:290{Cf. s.v. Ved. káṭuka- 'scharf, beissend'. Not satisfactorily explained.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):132, no. 2641; [EWAia](src-172) I:290).

Source: 338[{cf. Persian māst, Balochi mastaɣ, Old Indic mastu- 'sour milk'}];172[II:336{Cf. s.v. Ved. mástu- 'saurer Rahm', probably *másd-tu- to PIIr. *masd-. No certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):218n74 for further discussion).}];156[II:76-77{S.v. Oss. mast 'горький', cf. NPers. māst.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:336, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:76-77.

Source: 442[203{Cf. s.v. 3865 Skt. khā́dati 'chews, bites| eats'}];141[359-360{Cf. s.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- '(zer)quetschen' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Only Indo-Iranian cognates.}];172[I:451-452{S.v. Ved. √khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen, verzehren'. Cf. NPers. xāyīdan 'kauen' if from *kʰād-, Baluči khāδαγ 'eat', Khot. khaca 'food' (if from *xad-čā). Further connections are not certain.}]
Justification: No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:451-452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 359-360). Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):203, no. 3865.

Comment: Erratum!  This lexeme in Old Spanish was mistakenly entered as an independent cognate set (6794), rather than the correct analysis that it belongs within cognate set 948.  This error has been corrected in the IE-CoR database for future releases.  The effect on a phylogenetic analysis is a very slight extension to the length of the independent branch leading to Old Spanish.

Source: 338[{Probably onomatopoeic.}];156[I:336{S.v. Oss. c’īw | c’ew 'птичка'. Onomatopoeic word, cf. c’īw-c’īw 'chirping'.}]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:336).
Lexemes belonging to the complex field of **paṭ- 'membrane, covering, leaf', which seems to blend several original roots.

Source: 444[747{S.v. 8975 tŭm(b) (Schallwort) 'Fall, Plumps'.}];423[5:539-543{S.v. Sp. tomar, a word peculiar to Castilian and Portuguese of uncertain origin.}]
Justification: Of uncertain origin, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):747 no. 8975, [DCECH](src-423) 5:539-543 for further discussion.

Source: 54[126{S.v. Lat. colubra 'snake, serpent'. Walde-Hofmann and IEW propose a preform *(s)kelo-dʰro- 'winding itself', while Ernout-Meillet consider a possible loanword from Gk. χέλυδρος. The former etymology is unlikely because the suffix *-dʰro- normally makes instrument nouns, whereas the latter is also unlikely because Gk. χέλυδρος is attested too recently and the meaning 'serpent' is probably secondary (χέλυς means '(kind of) tortoise'). A connection with colus 'distaff' could be possible, since a distaff is used to wind thread or fibre around it, thus *kolos-ro- might mean 'distaff-like' and a snake which winds about its own axis could be called a 'distaff-like animal'. This solution is not morphologically straightforward, however, since colus probably continues a u-stem, and one would have to assume an unattested s-stem *kʷelh₁-os- existed alongside it, from which the putative PIt. *kolos-ro- could be derived.}];316[133-134{S.v. colubra, -ae f. & coluber, -brī, -bris m. Without a clear etymology, perhaps a borrowing from Gk. χέλυδρος?}];444[195{S.v. 2060 colubra 'Schlange', 2. *culǫbra.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin colubra 'snake' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):195), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):133-134, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):126 for various proposals).

Source: 172[I:46{S.v. Ved. aghá- 'böse, schlimm, gefährlich' (adj.)| 'Übel, Gefahr, Schaden' (n.). See YAv. aγa- 'schlecht, böse'| probably to be connected with Goth. aglaiti 'Unzucht', agl 'Bestrafung', etc.}];179[10{Cf. s.v. Goth. A49. *agls (only n.sg. agl), from PIE *agh-(lo-) 'disagreeable' (cf. Skt. aghás, Av. aγō- 'evil', MIr. ālad 'wound').}];165[4-5{S.v. Proto-Germanic *agla- 'painful' (Goth. agls* 'disgraceful') < PIE *h₂egʰ-lo- (cf. Skt. aghá- 'evil, bad, dangerous', YAv. aγa- 'bad, evil' < *h₂ogʰ-o-, Gk. ἄχνυμαι 'to grieve, lament for' < *h₂egʰ-néu̯-).}];141[257{Cf. s.v. *h₂egʰ- 'in Furcht geraten, betrübt werden' (IEW 7-8). Cf. n1 also comparing Ved. aghá- n. 'Leid, Gefahr', Gk. ἄχος 'Leid, Schmerz' = Goth. agis 'Furcht, Angst'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Proto-Germanic *agla- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:46, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):10, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):4-5). For the root etymology to PIE *h₂egʰ- 'become afraid, sad', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257.

Source: 443[9:27{S.v. Lat. plānus 'flach, eben' > Fr. plain.}];54[470{Cf. s.v. Lat. plānus 'level, flat', from PIE *pl(e)h₂-nó- 'flattened' (PIE *pleh₂-), cf. Hitt. palhi-, pahlai- 'wide, broad' < *plh₂-i-, OPr. plonis 'threshing floor', Lith. plónas 'thin', Latv. plãns 'flat, even, thin' < *pleh₂-no-.}];274[562-564{Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes derived from Latin plānus 'level, flat' and further derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'id.' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:27, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):470, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Source: 303[88{S.v. pa-si (II), equivalent to Attic φημί 'speak' (Dor., Aeol. φᾱμί).}];141[69-70{S.v. 2. *bʰeh₂- 'sprechen, sagen' (IEW 105-6).}];66[1566-1567{S.v. φημί 'to say, explain, argue', from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'say'.}]
Justification: Mycenaean pa-si (= Attic φησί), derived from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to speak, say' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1566-1567, [LIV²](src-141) 69-70, cf. [Aura Jorro 1993](src-303):88).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. departe, from Lat. dē + parte.}];54[445-446, 448{S.v. Lat. pars, -tis 'part, piece', from Proto-Italic *parti- 'part', a late Inner-Latin formation connected with Lat. pariō 'to give birth, to bear' from the root *perh₃- 'to provide'.}];316[485{Cf. s.v. Lat. pars, -tis 'part accordée à un individu sur un ensemble', to be connected with Lat. pariō.}]
Comment: From Lat. de 'from' parte (abl. of pars, partis 'part').
Justification: An adverb based on the Latin phrase dē parte ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), from Latin pars, partis 'part' a late inner-Latin derivative to the same root as Latin pariō 'to give birth to, bear' derived from PIE *perh₃- 'to provide' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):485, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):445-446, 448, [LIV²](src-141) 474-475).

Source: 442[219{Cf. s.v. 4104 Skt. gavēdhuka- m. 'a kind of snake'.}];172[I:480{Cf. s.v. Ved. gavédukhā- 'Name eines Vieh nicht gefressenen Grases, Coix barbata'. Unclear. Loanwords?}];399[I:332{S.v. Skt. gavedukhaḥ 'eine Schlangenart', 'a kind of snake'. Unclear.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):219 no. 4104, [KEWA](src-399) I:332, [EWAia](src-172) I:480).

Source: 423[V:321{S.v. Sp. soto, from Lat. saltus, -ūs 'pastizales| pastizales con bosque| desfiladero, quebrada'.}];54[535-536{S.v. Lat. saliō, -īre 'to jump, leap' with derivative saltus, -ūs 'jump, leap| narrow passage, woodland'. Lat. saltus may be derived from PIE *sh₂l-to- (cf. OIr. saltraid 'to trample' MW sathar 'trampling' < *sal-tro-, Gk. ἅλλομαι 'to jump' < *sl-i̯e/o-, etc.).}];141[527-528{Cf. s.v. 1. *sel- 'sich losschnellen, springen' (IEW 899).}];316[590{Cf. s.v. Lat. saliō 'sauter, bondir', with derivative saltus 'passage étroit, pas'| the verbal root can also be found Gk. ἅλλομαι in the same sense.}]
Justification: From Latin saltus 'jump, leap; narrow passage, woodland' ([DCECH](src-423) V:321), further to PIE *sel- 'jump' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):590, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):535-536; for the root reconstruction cf. [LIV²](src-141) 527-528).

Source: 54[462{S.v. Lat. pēs, pedis 'foot', from PIE nom.sg. pōd-s, acc. po/ed-m, loc.sg. ped-i.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes with nominal *ped- (from Lat. pēs, pedis) as semantic-bearing morpheme in a light verb construction. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'foot' in [cognate set 225](cog-225).

Source: 443[10:269-270{S.v. Lat. repōnere 'zurücklegen' > OFr., MFr. repondre 'cacher'.}];54[479{S.v. Lat. pōnō, -ere 'to place, set, put' (repōnere 'to put back, down, replace'), from Proto-Italic *po-sine/o-, from PIE *po- + *tk̑-i-n-(e/o-) 'to build, live' via *po-sinō > *po-snō > *poznō > pōnō.}];141[643-644{Cf. s.v. *tk̑ei̯- 'Landbau treiben, siedeln, wohnen' (IEW 626). Lat. ponō < *tk̑i-néH-nH-? Cf. discussion in n6.}]
Justification: From Latin repōnere 'to put back, down; replace' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 10:269-270), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- 'settle, inhabit' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 643-644, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).

Source: 443[6/3:193{S.v. Lat. *mukyare (gall.) 'verstecken'. Of Celtic origin, cf. OIr. múchaim.}];444[471{S.v. 5723 *mūkyāre (gall.) 'verstecken, entweichen' (cf. OIr. mūchaim).}]
Justification: As though from Latin *mūkyāre, a denominal verb from a stem *mūc- (cf. Old Irish múchaim 'I hide'), cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443):6/3:197, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):471).

Source: 443[3:581-582{S.v. Lat. fissum 'gespalten' > Fr. fesse.}];54[221{S.v. Lat. findō 'split' < *bʰi-n-d-, from PIE *√bʰei̯d- 'split'.}]
Justification: Old French fesse, from Latin fissus 'split' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:581-582), the past passive participle of Latin findere 'to split' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):221).

Source: 156[IV:47{Probably from *warron from *war- 'rain' (i.e. 'rainworm').  Alternatively, if gemination *r > -rr- occurred, possibly may be related to TochA walyi, TochB yel (< *u̯el-) [cognate set 3141](cog-3141).}]
443[16:139{S.v. *handjan- (anfrk.) 'beißen', a loan from Germanic *handjan-, cf. aignier (1366) 'mordre'.}]
Justification: A loan from Germanic *handjan- (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 16:139).

Source: 443[17:288-289{S.v. sûr (anfrk.) 'sauer' > Fr. sur 'sour'}];444[698{S.v. 8471 sūr (fränk.) 'sauer'.}]
Justification: Borrowing from Old Low Franconian sûr 'sour' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:288-289, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):698).
Etymology unknown, cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 21:57 for further discussion.

Comment: Originally based on a compound of må (< Lat. malum) + sir 'pur' (Walloon Wiktionary).

Source: 443[17:272-282{S.v. Gmc. *sunni- 'sorge, gram'.}];444[667{Cf. s.v. 8089a sọnium 'Sorge' > OFr. soin 'Sorge', perhaps a loan from Goth. bisunja 'Fürsorge' > It. bisognio, Fr. besoin, etc.}]
Justification: Loanword from Germanic *sunni-, cf. Old French songne 'worry, concern' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:272-282, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):667 no. 8089a).

Source: 443[I:420-423{S.v. *bot-, probably of onomatopoeic origin.}]
Justification: Probably to a Romance root *bot- of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) I:420-423).

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 442[661{S.v. 11342 Skt. varṇayati 'relates, describes' MBh., 'observes' Kathās., 'praises' W. [varṇa- 2] (> K. wanun 'to describe, name, call, recognize'), cf. s.v. 11339 varṇa- (2) m. 'sound, syllable' AitBr.}];399[III:154{S.v. Skt. várṇaḥ 'Farbe| Stamm, Art, Gattung| Menschenart, Kaste' / 'colour| race, species| class of men, caste' (cf. Av. varənah- 'Farbe'), to vr̥ṇoti (1). várṇaḥ in the meaning 'Laut, Silbe, Wort' is probably a special development of the word for 'Art, Gattung, Farbe' and not evidence for *u̯er- 'to speak' in Indo-Iranian (pace Turner IAL no. 11339]).}];172[II:512-513{Cf. s.v. Ved. √var- (2) 'umschließen, zusammenhalten, einschließen, zurückhalten, einhüllen' (IIr. cf. YAv. hąm.vaori- 'mit dem Rahm', Oss. wart 'Schild, Schutz', etc. The assignment of Indo-Iranic *var- to Indo-European sources is difficult. (Cf. for further discussion).}];141[226-227, 674, 684-685{Cf. s.v. *Hu̯er- 'einschließen, stecken, hineintum' (IEW 1150, 1160), 1. *u̯el- 'einschließen, verhüllen' (IEW 1138), and 1. u̯er- 'aufhalten, (ab)wehren' (IEW 1160-2).}]
Comment: < varṇáyati (denominal) 'relates, describes' (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 661, no. 11342; from varṇá- m. 'sound, syllable' (AitBr.)
Justification: As though from Sanskrit varṇayati 'relates, describes', a denominal formation to Sanskrit varṇa- 'sound, syllable' and probably a specialised semantic development of Sanskrit várṇa- 'type, kind, colour', a derivative of Vedic √var-² 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'. Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:512-513, [LIV²](src-141) 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).

Source: 443[7:169{S.v. Lat. *nōdicare 'knüpfen'.}];54[412{Cf. s.v. Lat. nōdus 'knot'. Possibly from PIE *nōdo-, *noHdo-, or *neh₃do- (cf. OIc. nót 'net'). The root etymology is uncertain and an analysis as a loanword is also possible.}];444[489{Cf. s.v. 5944 Lat. *nōdicāre 'knüpfen'.}];165[384{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *natja- n. 'net', from PIE *nHd-io- (cf. Lat. nassa 'wicker-work basket', OIr. nassae 'bound' < nHd-to/eh₂-| Lat. nōdus 'node' < *noHd-o-).}];179[263-264{Cf. s.v. Goth. N8. nati 'ἀμφίβληστρον', 'casting net'| 'δίκτυον', 'fishing net'. Etymology uncertain. *ned- 'tie, bind' only reconstructed with certainty on the basis of Germanic, possibly connected to Latin nōdus 'knot' and others.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *nōdicāre 'to knot' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 7:169, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):489), a verbal derivative from Latin nōdus 'knot'. Further root etymology uncertain, possibly to Germanic lexemes meaning 'net', cf. Gothic nati, Old Icelandic nót 'net' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):412, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):384, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):263-264 for further discussion).

Source: 442[694-695{S.v. 12011 Skt. vistr̥ta 'spread, expanded, wide' MBh. [√str̥].}];172[II:756-757{Cf. s.v. Ved. √star-ⁱ 'ausbreiten, streuen', from PIE *sterh₃- (cf. Gk. ἐστόρεσα 'habe ausgebreitet', Lat. sternere, 'hinbreiten', OIr. sernaid 'breitet aus', etc.).}];141[599-600{Cf. s.v. *sterh₃- 'hinbreiten, ausbreiten' (IEW 1029-30).}]
Comment: Nu. forms from OIA. vi-str̥-ta- ‘spread; wide’  T. 12011 (-Strand).
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *vi-str̥ta- 'spread, expanded, wide', Sanskrit vistr̥ta- 'id.' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):694-695 no. 12011), a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew', and ultimately further to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:756-757, [LIV²](src-141) 599-600).

Source: 442[565{S.v. 9837 Ved. mantráyate 'speaks' RV., 'consults with' ŚBr., 'advises' MBh. [mántra-]}];172[II:311, 305-306{S.v. Ved. mántra- 'Spruch, heilige Formel, Ausspruch, (formulierter) Gedanke, Plan', derived to Ved. √man- (1) 'denken, meinen, dafürhalten', from PIE *men-, cf. Gk. μέμονα 'habe in Sinn, strebe' Lat. meminī 'erinnere mich', OIr. do-moiniur 'meine, glaube', Goth. man 'meine, glaube', Lith. miñti 'gedenken', etc.}];141[435-436{Cf. s.v. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' (IEW 726-8).}]
Comment: < Vedic mantráyate (denominal) 'speaks (*recites mantras)' (RV), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 565, no. 9837
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mantráyate 'speaks', a denominal formation to Vedic mántra- 'speech, sacred text or speech, a prayer', a nominal derivative from PIE 1. *men- 'to think' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):565 no. 9837, [EWAia](src-172) II:311, 305-306, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 435-436).

Source: 352[341-343{Cf. s.v. OLith. glabstýti 'umarmen, umfassen, anfassen', a st-iterative to Lith. *glė́bti 'umfassen, umarmen', cf. also other secondary formations such as Lith. glabóti 'umarmen, umschlingen| zusammenlegen, zusammenfalten', Latv. glabât, -ãju 'hüten, schützen', see further s.v. OLith. *glė́bti 'umfassen, umarmen' comparing Latv. glabât 'hüten, schützen| pflegen, beaufsichtigen, nähren| vergraben, verbergen', SCr. zglȍb 'Gelenk', Ru. glóba, globá (dial.) 'Querbalkan, Querstange auf Heuschober', etc.| from PIE *gleh₁bʰ- 'umfassen', cf. ON klafi 'Joch für Rinder', MLG klave 'Joch für Kühe' klachter 'Maß der ausgespannten Arme, Klafter' OHG klāftra 'Klafter'.}];353[180-181];531[187]
Justification: Cf. Latv. glabât 'keep, guard, protect; bury, hide', from PIE *gleh₁bʰ- 'to encompass, cover' according to [ALEW](src-352) 343, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):187 assumes *glebʰ-. Cf. also discussion of [Derksen 2015](src-353):180-181. (Not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 352[674-675{S.v. OLith. mùšti 'schlagen' (BSl. Latv. mušît 'quälen, würgen, töten', from PIE *meu̯s- 'schlagen' (cf. Ved. muṣṭi- 'Faust', YAv. mušti.masah- 'faustgroß', TochB maśce 'Faust'). Cf. ALEW for references to further literature.}];353[326-327{S.v. Lith. mùšti 'beat' "In Latvian, the East Baltic root *muś- occurs once in mustavas Npl. 'warping beam', cf. Lith. muštùvai 'id'. This etymon has been connected with Gk. ἀμύσσω 'scratch, tear, lacerate', ἀμυχή 'rent, wound', and Lat. mūcrō f. 'point (of a sword etc.)'. If this is correct, we would have to reconstruct < *h₂muk̑-, with unclear consonantal variation in Greek. This etymology seems highly uncertain, however (cf. De Vaan 2008:392)."}];269[{Root ref. form follows ALEW (cf. for further discussion), but cf. also Derksen (2015:326-327), although Derksen does not seem at all persuaded by his proposed connection to the Greek forms.}]
Comment: For the IE reconstruction, see ALEW.
Justification: The root assignment for this set follows [ALEW](src-352) 674-675 in connection to Vedic muṣṭi- 'fist', Young Avestan mušti.masah- 'fist-sized', and Tocharian B maśce 'fist', cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):326-327 dismissing earlier proposals to Ancient Greek ἀμύσσω 'scratch, tear, lacerate', ἀμυχή 'rent, wound', and Latin mūcrō f. 'point (of a sword etc.)' from a putative root *h₂meu̯k̑-, also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):413.

Source: 686[192{S.v. OPr. kyrteis (Ipv.2.sg.) 'schlage!'}];352[495-496{Cf. s.v. OLith. kir̃sti 'hacken, hauen, mähen' (BSl. Latv. cìrst 'hacken, hauen, schlagen| bahnen, bauen', OPr. kyrteis 'schlage', OCS črьta sf. 'Streich, Balken', etc.), from PIE *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' (cf. Hitt. kartae- 'abschneiden', Ved. kart- 'schneiden, abschneiden, spalten, brechen', YAv. kərəṇtaiti 'schneidet', Arm. kʻertʻem 'ziehe die Haut ab').}];141[559-560{Cf. s.v. *(s)kert- '(zer)schneiden' [IEW 941-2].}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):192, [ALEW](src-352) 495-496, [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Source: 444[341{S.v. 4054 harpa (germ.) 1. Egge, 2. Harfe.}];423[I:344-345{Cf. s.v. Sp. arpa 'instrumento músico', a loanword from Germanic. The original meaning in Germanic was that of a curved instrument or an instrument that was played with curved fingers, from which Old Occitan arpa 'rake', Fr. harpe 'claw', harper 'to grab'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Germanic *harpa 'curved instrument' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):341, [DCECH](src-423) I:344-345 for further discussion).

Source: 444[279{S.v. 3214 Lat. fascis 'Bund, Bündel' > Cat. feix 'bundle', with secondary derivative feixuc 'heavy' (adj.).}];54[203{S.v. Lat. fascis 'bundle, faggot| (symbol of) power' (cf. OIr. basc 'necklace', W beich 'burden', Bret. bec'h 'load' < PCl. *baskio-). A unique Italo-Celtic isogloss that can accounted for via *bʰaski-(o-). (Cf. also [Schrijver 1991](src-679):102-103).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes derived from Latin fascis 'bundle of rods; (symbol of) power' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):279), further to be connected with Celtic lexemes, cf. Old Irish basc 'necklace', Welsh beich 'burden', Breton bec'h 'load' < PCl. *baskio-, as a unique Italo-Celtic isogloss from *bʰaski-, probably a non-Indo-European loanword in origin (cf. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):102-103, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):203).

Source: 534[I:561{S.v. Latv. māja, loan from Finnic *mā- 'earth'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Finnic (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534):561).

Source: 534[II:188-189{S.v. Latv. sist "Vārda cilme nav pilnigi noskaidrota." Etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:188-189 s.v. Latvian sit 'to hit' for further discussion.

Source: 457[393-394{S.v. (UZU) titita- n.? 'Nase, Schnauze', probably a nursery word, but cf. entry for various other proposals.}]
Justification: A probable nursery word, but cf. [Tischler 1991](src-457):393-394 for various alternative proposals.

Source: 352[510-511{Cf. s.v. OLith. klùpti 'auf die Knie niedersinken, stolpern, straucheln' (BSl. Latv. klupt 'stolpern, straucheln, umfallen', OPr. klupstis 'Knie'). OPr. klupstis corresponds to Lith. (dial. südaukšt.) klùpstas. For the etymology cf. OLith. klaũpti 'hinknien, niederknien', without any clear comparanda outside of Baltic. The Baltic family of words is traditionally connected to Goth. ushlaupan 'aufspringen', ON 'hlaupa 'hüpfen, springen', OE hlēpan 'springen, laufen' (cf. LIV² 364), but these are not very close semantically, and only possible if the phonological difficulties are not unsurmountable.}];531[293, 301-302{Cf. s.v. Lith. klaũpti "klękać, padać na kolana" and klùpti "potykać sią, kląkać", connecting OPr. klupstis "kolano, Kny", and deriving from PIE *kleu̯b- (cf. Goth. ushlaupan "skoczyć, poderwać się na nogi", OIc. hlaupa "biec, skakać").}];141[364{Cf. s.v. *kleu̯b- 'stolpern, hüpfen' [IEW 630].}]
Justification: Cf. Old Lithuanian klùpti 'to fall on the knees, stumble', traditionally connected to an IE root *kleu̯b- 'to stumble, hop' ([LIV²](src-141) 364, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):293, 301-302), but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 510-511 objecting to the comparative semantics. [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)]. Cf. also 'run' in [cognate set 6948](cog-6948) and 'walk' in cognate set 332 for the proposed Germanic comparanda in Gothic us-hlaupan, etc.

Source: 80[668-669{S.v. Hitt. peru / perun- 'rock, cliff, boulder', generally assumed from PIE *pér-ur / *pér-un- (cf. Skt. párvata- 'rocky, rugged| mountain' < *pér-u̯n̥-to-) with dissimilation of final -r in the nom.sg. form.}];413[23-26{S.v. peru- 'rock', generally compared to Ved. párvata- 'mountain', via an earlier heteroclite *per-u̯r̥, *peru̯(e)n-, although Puhvel is skeptical of aspects of the stem-formation.}];172[II:99{Cf. s.v. Ved. párvata- adj. 'felsig', m. 'Berg, Gebirge, Fels', from PIE *péru̯n̥to- 'felsig, mit Fels versehen', cf. Hitt. peru- (peruni, dat.-loc.) 'stone' < *perur < *peru̯r̥, *perun-/*peru̯n̥-.}]
Justification: The root of the Hittite formation is generally compared with Ved. párvata- 'mountain' < *pér-u̯n̥-to- (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):668-669, [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413):23-26; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:99).

Source: 80[757-758{S.v. Hitt. (UZU) šiššai- 'body part of animals (bear, lion, leopard, šāša-). "We have to conclude that the ši(e)ššai is a body part of bears, šāša-s, lions and leopards, but it is not totally clear what body part is referred to. Perhaps we have to assume that here 'tails' are meant that have to be plaited together (which would explain 'unite them'| see also s.v. šumumaḫḫ-)." Semantics, and therefore etymological identification, rather uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):757-758).

Source: 259[594{PS *ščapa, *ščapŭ 'flaked piece of wood' (cf. Serbo-Croat štap 'stick', Polish szczapa 'chip of wood' etc.) is derived from PIE skep 'chop, split'.}];141[55{Cf. s.v. 1. *(s)kep- 'hacken, hauen' cf. n1 with Russian ščepa 'woodchip' listed as a reflex.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop, hit' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):594, [LIV²](src-141) 555).

Source: 352[295-296{Cf. s.v. OLith. garbiniúoti 'krausen', a derivative of Lith. garbinỹs, garbìnis 'Locke'. Traditionally OPr. <grabis> 'Berg' is considered connected with this noun, as found in mountain names such as Smaydegarbs, Nirtegarbe, Wittergarbe, but the substantial semantic distance between 'Locke' and 'Berg' makes this etymology doubtful. No certain comparisons outside of Baltic.}];49[387{Cf. s.v. *gerb- 'sich kräuseln, runzeln, einschrumpfen, sich zusammenkrampfen' relating OPr. grabis 'Berg' and Lith. gárbana, garbanà 'Haarlocke'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology. Traditionally compared to Lithuanian garbinỹs, garbìnis 'lock of hair', but the semantic distance makes this etymology doubtful ([ALEW](src-352) 295-296, cf. [IEW](src-49) 387 reconstructing *gerb-, but note that this reconstruction violates the known restriction on IE roots beginning and ending with voiced-unaspirated stops).

Source: 352[92-93{S.v. OLith. bámba (1), bambà (4) 'Nabel' (BSl. Latv. bam̃ba 'Kugel, Ball, Schlägel', Ru. búba 'Beule, Schwellung| Erbse, Waldbeere', Ukr. búba 'im Wasser aufgequollene Erbse oder Bohne| Beere| Beule| Abszess'. The alternating accentuation in Lithuanian is historically unclear. No comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic.}];531[46{S.v. Lith. bámba 'pępek', cf. Latv. bam̃ba 'kula, gałka| tłuczek'. Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain.}];360[33{Cf. s.v. Lith. bámba 'Nabel', assuming a connection with OHG naba 'Nabe', Gk. ὀμφάλος, Lat. umbilicus, etc.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 92-93, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):46 for further discussion. Older etymological works assumed a connection to PIE *h₃nebʰ- in [cognate set 5026](cog-5026), cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):33.

Comment: Loan from Russian

Source: 83[312-313{S.v. Proto-Iranic *rand- 'to scrape, smoothen' (> MPers. lnd- /rand-/ 'to scratch, grate, abrade, rake'), from PIE *lendʰ- 'to lower, go down' (cf. Skt. √randh- 'unterliegen', Lith. lendù 'I crawl, crouch', OPr. lindan 'valley').}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *rand- 'to scrape, smoothen' (+ *fra-), further to PIE *lendʰ- 'to lower, go down' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):312-313, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 412-413).

Source: 165[28-29{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *angwu- adj. 'narrow', from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ-u- 'narrow' (cf. Skt. aṃhú- 'narrow', Arm. anj-uk 'narrow, difficult', OCS ǫzъkъ 'narrow'). From PGmc. *angwu- OHG angust, NHG Angst 'fear' are derived forms via PGmc. *angusti-.}];397[45{S.v. NHG Angst (MHG angest, OHG angust), from West Germanic *angusti- 'Angst', also in OFr. angst. This is a (s)ti-formation or (or ti-formation to an s-stem) to IE *ang̑ʰu- 'eng, bedrängend'. The s-stem is continued in Ved. áṃhas- 'Bedrängung, Angst', Lat. angor 'Würgen, Angst', Lat. angustus 'eng, schmal' and CS ǫzoti 'Beengigung'.}];141[264-265{Cf. s.v. *h₂emg̑ʰ- '(zu)schnüren' → 'beengen' (IEW 42-3).}];757[I:216{Cf. s.v. Du. bang 'angstig'}];782[{The Frisian form is probably a calque from Dutch bang zijn, as OFri. has words such as angia, fruchta}]
Justification: West Germanic lexemes in light verb constructions with derivatives of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to restrict, hinder' as the nominal semantic-bearing head. ([Kluge 2011](src-397):45, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):28-29). The Dutch and Frisian lexemes are prefixed with initial *be- ([EWNl](src-757) I:216). For the PIE root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 264-265.

Source: 83[51-52{S.v. PIr. *dais- (1) 'to show' (> Pth. (+ ham-) ʾndyš 'to think, contemplate') from PIE *dei̯k̑- 'to show, point out, announce', cf. Gk. δείκνυμι, OHG zeigen, Lat. dīcere 'to utter, say, proclaim', etc.}]
Justification: Parthian and Middle Persian lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ham-dais- (PIr. *dais- 'to show'), further to PIE *dei̯k̑- 'to show, indicate' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):51-52, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 108-109).

Source: 259[404{PS *ovoktĭ, formerly probably *ou̯oɡ-tĭ, derived from PIE *au̯eg- / *u̯ōg- / *au̯g- 'multiply, increase, grow', related to Lithuanian áugti 'grow', Latvian augt 'grow', German wachsen 'grow', Latin augēre 'grow'. The semantic development was 'growth' > 'something that grows'.}];593[437{PS *(o)voťe is probably derived from PIE *au̯eg- / *u̯ōg- / *au̯g- 'grow' (cf. Lithuanian áugti 'grow', Latvian augt 'grow', German wachsen 'grow', Latin augēre 'grow'). A similarity to German Obst 'fruit' etc. is probably a coincidence.}];589[3: 610-611{This word is assumed to be a loanword from Old High German (cf. German Obst 'fruit'). It has been also explained as a reflex of PIE *au̯eg- 'grow'.}];599[1: 591{The etymology is obscure. It can be a loanword from German dialects. However, the exact source has not been determined. An alternative is to assume here a reflex of PIE *au̯eg- / *aug- / *u̯ōg- 'grow'.}];598[3: 115{The widespread hypothesis about a borrowing from Old High German is phonetically inconvincing. Furthermore, a very wide distribution of this word in Slavic makes the Old High German origin improbable. The lexeme is probably derived from *voksti, a form related to Gothic wahsjan, Old High German wahsan 'grow', Avestan vaχšaiti 'grows', Lithuanian áugu 'grow', áukštas 'high', Greek αὔξω 'multiply', Irish úasal 'high' etc.}];603[4: 769{The PS lexeme is related to Gothic wahsjan 'grow' etc. and derived from PIE *aweg-. The hypothesis about a West Germanic origin shows phonetic and chronological issues.}]
Justification: There are two widespread hypotheses as to the etymology of this root. It has been assumed that it is a loan from Germanic *óƀāt-. However, it seems that the exact source of this (Proto-Slavic) loanword has not been identified. There are also phonetic issues (*-o-, -ť-) which should be explained if the loanword hypothesis is accepted. Another possibility is to assume a derivation from PIE root *h₂u̯eg- 'grow, rise, become large' > PS *(o-)voktĭ > *(o-)voť-. Then the word would be related to German wachsen 'grow' etc., cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 566.

Source: 757[{S.v. Du. pluim zn. ‘(grote) veer, verenbos’, an early borrowing, in the context of trade in goose feathers and down with Rome, from Latin plūma 'down| feather'.}]
Justification: According to [EWNl](src-757), an early loanword from Latin plūma 'feather'.

Comment: ? cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4883

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron iš-ən 'take' is from *ais- 'own', cf. Avestan aes- 'own'.}];83[158{Cf. s.v. *Hais- 'to be able, rule', only assigning Av. is- 'be able, rule'.  Cheung does not list the Ossetic forms as cognates: "Further Ir. cognates are unknown."}];141[223{Cf. s.v. *Hei̯k̑- 'sich aneignen' (IEW 298-9).  The connection of Oss. īs-/es- 'nehmen' to this root is not entirely certain, cf. fn2a "Falls dieses Verb ein altiran. *ais-a- fortsetzt und nicht anderer Herkunft ist, vgl. Abaev I 552| Kümmel, Perfekt 124⁷⁶⁻⁷⁷."}];156[I:552]
Justification: Ossetic lexemes of disputed further etymology, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:552, [Cheung 2007](src-83):158, [LIV²](src-141) 223 for proposals and further discussion.

Source: 397[200{Cf. s.v. NHG diesig 'dunstig', a borrowing from Low German sailor-language. Cf. Low German disig, dialectal Dutch dijzig, Modern Danish diset, Modern Swedish disig, North Frisian dīs. Cf. Middle Low German disinge 'Nebelwetter'. No clear comparisons. Perhaps with the loss of the nasal and compensatory lengthening from Germanic *ϸemsa- 'dunkel' (with variant *ϸemza-?). Cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):619.}]
Justification: Etymology obscure (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):200 for discussion)

Source: 442[555{S.v. 9710 *macyate 'is produced, grows, is kindled, is rubbed. 2. *macya- . 3. Pp. *makta- . [mácatē 'grinds, is arrogant', máñcatē 'id., grows high, shines' Dhātup. <-> It is difficult in NIA. to separate forms of √mac meaning 'excite, excited' from √mad (mādyati, mattá-) of which in MIA. pres. st. majj- was partially replaced by macc- after the type sitta- ~ siccaï. -- The meanings in NIA. support IE. origin (Gk. μάσσω, &c.) IEW 730. -- √mac]}];399[II:548{S.v. Skt. mácate, a Dhātupāṭha verb for which numerous meanings are given. Cf. entry for further discussion.}]
Justification: Apparently continuing a verbal root √mac- attested in various meanings by Sanskrit lexicographical works which may have further IE connections but ultimately uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):555 no. 9710, [KEWA](src-399) II:548).

Source: 165[128{S.v. *faran- 'to go', from PIE *pór-e- (cf. Skt. pí-parti 'to bring across' < *pi-por-| OAv. (fra)-frā 1.sg.subj.aor. 'to cross' < pre-pr-e-, OCS pariti 'to fly' < *por-éie-| Gk. πείρω 'to pierce, to penetrate' < *per-ie-).}];141[472-473{S.v. 1. *per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren' (IEW 816-7).}];556[186-188{S.v. Gmc. *far-a- 'fahren', probably going back to a proto-form *por- 'tragen, bringen', etc. which was an ablaut form of IE *per- 'durchbohren, hinüberbringen' (cf. Lat. portāre < *pr̥-tā-| W rhyd 'Furt', CS na-perjǫ, -periti 'durchbohren', Ru. poróm 'Fähre'| Gk. πείρω 'durchstoße, durchsteche', Ved. píparti 'bringt hinüber, rettet, schützt, übertrifft').}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives from PIE 1. *per- 'to cross, go through' ([LIV²](src-141) 472-473, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):186-188, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):128).

Source: 406[426-428{S.v. Hitt. iškuna(ḫḫ)- 'to stain, stigmatise, denounce, degrade, disgrace, demote'.  The lemma iškunant- is literally an act. participle to this verb.  Puhvel compares Gk. αἰσχύνω 'make ugly, disfigure, dishonour' but does not provide a reconstruction to account for the proposed etymology.}];578[404{S.v. Hitt. iškunant- 'fleckig, schmutzig', etymology unclear.}]
Justification: A derivative of Hittite iškii̯e/a- 'to daub, salve'. Further etymology unclear, cf. [Tischler 1983](src-578):404, [HED A+E/I](src-406):426-428 for various proposals.

Source: 165[135{S.v. Proto-Germanic *felhan- 'to hide'. An extra-Germanic etymology is difficult.}];179[115{S.v. Goth. F49. filhan 'θάψαι| κρυβῆναι', 'bury| conceal', perhaps to PIE *pel- 'cover, skin' + -k- suffix, but somewhat dubious. Cf. entry for references to older suggestions.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic difficult (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):135, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):115).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron ad-ǯən 'sweet' is derived from ad 'taste', whose etymology is unknown. Abaev hypothesizes relation to root *ed- 'eat', but considers it speculative.}];156[I:28{Cf. s.v. Oss. ad | adæ 'вкус'. Etymology unclear. Possibly from *ed- 'eat'? Speculative.}]
Justification: Derived from Ossetic ad | adæ 'taste', possibly further to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' but this proposal is quite speculative (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:28).

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri sṭʹâla  [-i fem]  Aj.  Straight| true| honest.  [sṭâla>]  [OIA. sthʹal-a- ‘flat surface’  T. 13744]}];442[793{S.v. 13744 Skt. sthála n. 'dry land' TS., 'ground, place' Mn., 'flat surface, roof' Kālid.}];399[III:525{S.v. Skt. sthálam 'Erhebung, Anhöhe, trockenes festes Land' / 'elevation, dry land, firm earth', connected with the Dhātup. root sthal- '(fest)stehen'. Further etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Indo-Iranic *stʰala- 'dry land, ground place; flat surface, roof'. Traditionally connected to the Sanskrit (Dhātupāṭha) root √sthal- 'to stand (firm)', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Strand 1998](src-431), [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):793 no. 13744, [KEWA](src-399) III:525).

Comment: < 'fine, minute, thin, small' according to Turner 1962-66, no. 13548 s.v. *sūṅkṣa-

Source: 442[535{S.v. 9406 bhálatē 'expounds, describes' Dhātup. [√bhal- (1)]}];399[II:482-483{Cf. s.v. Skt. bhal-, attested only ni-bhālayati 'nimmt wahr/perceives' (Up., etc.) and sam-bhālayati 'vernimmt, erfährt, hört' (Naiṣadhacarita) and found in Middle, Modern Indic continuants. Etymology not certainly explained.}]
Justification: As though from Vedic √bhal- 'to expound, describe', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):535 no. 9406, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:482-483).

Source: 442[162{Cf. s.v. 3175 Skt. kiri- 'scattering, heap'.}];172[I:311{Cf. s.v. Ved. √karⁱ-² 'ausschütten, ausgießen, ausstreuen'.}];141[353-354{Cf. s.v. 3. *kerH- 'ausstreuen, schütten' [IEW 933-5], whence Ved. √karⁱ-² (e.g. kiráti, -te 'streut aus, schüttet aus' < *kérH-/*kr̥H-). Cf. n1 against the reconstruction of a root *skʷal- ~ *skʷalH- assumed by Mayrhofer EWAia ('unberechtigt').}]
Comment: cf. ākhu-kirí- (MS), Turner 1962-66, no. 3175; thus < PIE *kerH- (3.) "austreuen, schütten" (LIV, p. 353)
Justification: Cf. Dameli kīr 'snow' < Sanskrit kiri- 'scattering, heap' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):162 no. 3175). Further to Vedic √karⁱ-² 'to scatter, disperse' and ultimately to PIE 3. *kerH- 'to scatter, disperse' ([EWAia](src-172) I:311, [LIV²](src-141) 353-354).

Source: 320[395{S.v. Khot. śśaysda- 'snake', according to Bailey from IE *k̑ei- 'beside' IEW 538-9 *kei- 'move', with increments *k̑i-es-d-.}];269[{The derivation proposed by Bailey (1979:395) is unclear. If his root etymology is correct, the modern reconstruction of the proposed IE root is *k̑ei̯h₂- 'sich in Bewegung setzen' (LIV² 346), but the morphological 'increments' proposed to satisfy the etymology are uncertain.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. [Bailey 1979](src-320):395 proposed *k̑i-es-d- derived to PIE *k̑ei̯h₂- 'to move' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 346, [IEW](src-49) 538-539), but the function of the nominal morphemes ('increments') proposed in order to satisfy the etymology formally remains unclear.

Comment: cf. Old Indic namrá- "untertan, ergeben, demütig, unterwürfig", lit. "biegsam". This cognate set may rather mean 'soft'.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Digor qwæcæ 'smoke' is probably a Caucasian loanword, but phonetic correspondences are not perfect and it is difficult to establish the source. This is a uniquely Digor borrowing. Meanwhile the Iron term fɜždɜg does exist in Digor (fɜzdɜg), but is less frequent (it may theoretically be a "back‑loan" from Iron, but it is impossible to verify, as the correspondences are perfect).}];156[II:320]
Justification: Probably a Caucasian loanword, although the exact source language is difficult to ascertain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:320).

Source: 165[60{S.v. Proto-Germanic *bergan- 'to keep (safe)', from PIE *bʰérgʰ-e- (cf. OCS brěšti 'to care', Lith. bìrginti 'to save'| OIr. commairge 'protection, security' < *k̑om-bʰorgʰ-ieh₂-).}];141[79-80{S.v. ?*bʰergʰ- 'beachten, bewahren' (IEW 145).}];556[106-107{S.v. Gmc. *berg-a- 'bergen', may be compared with Balto-Slavic *berg- (*bʰerg̑ʰ-) 'verwahren, bewahren' (cf. Lith. berginti 'nicht viel ausgeben, sparen, geizig sein', OCS nebrěgǫ, -brěšti 'außer Acht lassen, sich nicht kümmern, mißachten', perhaps also Oss. æmbærzyn 'bedecken' < Ir. *ham-barz- according to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156)).}];782[{The Frisian form is probably a calque from Dutch verbergen| EFri. has hille}]
Justification: Root etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 79-80, cf. also [Seebold 1970](src-556):106-107, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):60 for further discussion.

Source: 442[587{S.v. 10187 1. *muṭṭa- 'defective'.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though from Indic *muṭṭa- 'defective' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):587 no.10187.1).

Source: 698[372-374{S.v. Gmc. *lufta- 'schlaff| link'. Possibly a primary verbal adjective in *-to- to the IE root *(s)leup- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 964f.) only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic.}];84[{S.v. Engl. 'left' "A word apparently inherited from Germanic." Cf. West Frisian lafter, East Frisian läft, North Frisian leeft, lääft, Old Frisian lufter, lōftra, Middle and Early Modern Dutch lucht, locht, luft, Middle Low German lucht, locht, all in sense ‘left’| further etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Perhaps a primary verbal adjective in *-to- to the IE root *(s)leup- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 964f.) only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. [Faltings 2010](src-698):372-374. Etymology otherwise obscure.

Source: 325[39{"Cf. W[akhi] jǝqlai, etc. < *jǝl-qai? But cf. also Y[azghulami] cǝl-důr younger?"}]
Justification: A regional word with no etymology. A mechanical root preform might be *čal-, assuming Wakhi has undergone metathesis, but the sound -q- has been taken as a loan indicator, so the Wakhi form could be loaned from Khowar tseq, excluding the Sarikoli and Shughni forms.

Source: 141[305-306{S.v. *h₃rei̯H- 'wallen, wirbeln' (IEW 330-1).}];165[413-414{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'run' < *h₃ri-n-H- or *h₃ri-nu-e- (cf. Skt. riṇā́ti 'to make flow, set off', etc.).}];556[375-377{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *renn-a- (< *ri-nw-) 'rinnen, laufen' for references to older literature.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'to run', a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):375-377, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):413-414, [LIV²](src-141) 305-306).

Source: 141[364{S.v. *kleu̯b- 'stolpern, hüpfen' [IEW 630]| cf. n1 *kleu̯p- with 'hardening' (Verhärtung) in certain contexts, partially paradigmatically generalised.}];165[229, 232{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hlaupan- 'to jump, leap', a strong verb back-formed to iterative *hluppōn- 'to run' < *klup-néh₂- (cf. Latv. klupinât 'keep stumbling' < *klup-neh₂-).}];556[259-260{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *hlaup-a- 'laufen', no immediately useful comparanda. Perhaps the base can be found in Lith. keliáuti 'wandern, reisen', Gk. κέλευθος 'Weg, Pfad, Bahn, Reise'.}];179[382-383{Cf. s.v. Goth. U55. *us-hlaupan 'ἀνίστημι', 'leap up'. Etymology unknown.}];352[502-503{Cf. s.v. OLith. klaũpti 'hinknien, niederknien', where the connection to the Gmc. forms given in [LIV²](src-141) 364 s.v. *kleu̯b- are rejected on semantic grounds.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Generally compared with Baltic material via Lith. klaũpti 'kneel down', etc. (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 364, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):229, 232), but the connection is uncertain on semantic grounds (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 502-503}).  For older hypotheses, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):259-260, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):382-383.

Source: 141[583{S.v. *(s)prengʰ- 'springen' (IEW 998).}];165[470{S.v. Proto-Germanic *spring/kan- 'to break out, leap', from PIE *spré-n-gʰ-e- (cf. Skt. spr̥hayati 'to be eager, strive after, desire' < *sprg̑ʰ-eie-, Gk. σπέρχω, σπέρχομαι 'to come in rushing, huddle, be impassioned < *spérg̑ʰ-).}];556[457-458{S.v. Gmc. *spreng-a- 'aufspringen', with no direct comparisons| perhaps to non-nasal *spergʰ- in Gk. σπέρχω 'setze in rasche Bewegung', Ved. √spr̥h- 'sich sehnen nach, verlangen, beneiden'.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Old Norse springa from Proto-Germanic *spring/kan- 'to break out, leap', ultimately from PIE *(s)préngʰ-e- ([LIV²](src-141) 583, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):470, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):457-458).
Loan from Arabic جلد 'leather, skin'

Source: 165[329-330{S.v. Proto-Germanic *lawiz- 'ham, thigh'. OSw. and ON lær go back to *lawaz-, but OE lēow presupposes a proto-form *lawiz-, the formation may be related to *lagja- 'leg' [cf. [cognate set 1352](cog-1352)].}]

165[540{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸeuha- 'thigh', from PIE *téuHk-o- (cf. Lith. taukaĩ, Latv. tàuki (m.pl.) 'lard', OPr. taukis 'id.', OCS tukъ, Ru. tuk 'fat' < *toukH-o-| OIr. tón 'behind, bottom', MW tin 'bottom, arse, rear' < *tuHk-neh₂-). A European IE word for 'thigh, hip'.}];269[{Cf. discussion in ALEW & Derksen (2015:459-460) regarding the Baltic evidence for the root reconstruction, and further discussion regarding Balto-Slavic lexemes meaning 'fat' in cognate set 6104.}]
Justification: Root reconstruction difficult. A contamination between two (possibly related) roots *teu̯h₂- and *teu̯k- is a possibility. Cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):540 and 'thick' in [cognate set 1247](cog-1247) for further discussion. The PIE root reference form *teu̯(h₂)k- is provisional only.

Source: 165[49{S.v. Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ-i-, an i-stem related to PGmc. *belgan- 'swell' < *bʰelg̑ʰ- (cf. Skt. barhíṣ- 'bundle of straw' Av. barəziš- 'pad, pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-is-, OPruss. balsinis 'pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-ino-, etc.).}];141[73-74{Cf. s.v. bʰelg̑ʰ- 'schwellen' (IEW 125-6).}];50[70{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ- 'skin bag, bolster' (cf. Av. barəziš- 'bolster, cushion', OE belg 'stomach', OPr. balsinis 'cushion', Croat. dial. blàzina 'pillow'). Ultimately derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ-.}];236[{S.v. W bol 'belly', from Proto-Celtic *bolgos, from PIE *bʰolgʰ- (cf. Goth. balgs, Engl. belly, bellows).}];84[{S.v. Engl. belly-button 'navel'. Colloquialism, first attested 1877.}]
Justification: This set is coded for PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'swell', whence Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag' > 'belly, stomach' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):49), Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):70, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236). NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri lʹâalu, also lʹâa˜lu  NF.  Song| music.  [OIA. *lalla- ‘inarticulate noise’  T. 10972.1]}];442[636{Cf. s.v. 10972 *lalla- 'inarticulate noise', 2. lallara- 'stammering' lex., lalalla- Kathās.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes in this set represent a light-verb construction 'to make a song', where cognacy in this set is assigned to the semantic bearing head 'song', as though from Old Indic *lalla- ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):636 no. 10972), probably further of onomatopoeic origin.

Comment: variant of kūdak < *kau̯tá-?

Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *kamb- 'lesser', further to PIE *kemb- assuming a connection with Hittite kappi- / kappai- 'small' (cf. [Schmitt 2014](src-358):198-199, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):439).

Comment: Sanskritism, cf. tīkṣṇa-, Vedic tīkṣṇá-
Justification: Loanword from Sanskrit tīkṣṇa- 'sharp'.

Source: 320[363{S.v. rräjsaa- 'sharp', from *ričaka-, derived from PIE *reik(h)- (IEW 858), cf. Gk. ἐρείκω 'break up', Lith. riekiù, riẽkti 'cut', Ved. rikháti, likháti 'scratch'.}];141[504{Cf. s.v. *rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'ritzen, kratzen (tr.)' (IEW 858).}];172[II:457{S.v. Ved. √rekh- 'ritzen', from perhaps PIE *(h₁)rei̯k-h₂- (cf. Gk. ἐρείκω 'zerbreche, zerreiße', Lith. riẽkti 'schneiden', OHG riga, MHG rīhe 'Reihe, Linie' (~ Ved. rekhā-, lékhā-).}]
Justification: Lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *ričaka-, cf. Vedic √rekh- 'to scratch', further to PIE *(h₁)rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'to scratch, score' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):363, [EWAia](src-172) II:457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 504).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron awwon 'shadow' has no clear etymology. It may be from *āyavana-, cf. Avestan ayaona- 'dwelling' (then 'shadow' would be through the meaning 'shelter', also attested in Ossetic)}];156[I:87{S.v. Oss. awwon 'тень, прикрытие'}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps from Iranic *āyavana-, cf. Avestan ayaona- 'dwelling' with the meaning 'shadow' arising via *'shelter' (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:87).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. pull, of uncertain origin.}]
Justification: Of uncertain origin (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. smell, from early Middle English smellen and smüllen, no doubt of Old English origin but not recorded. No cognates outside of English.}]
Justification: Continuing Middle English smellen, smüllen, further etymology uncertain ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 83[29{S.v. Proto-Iranian *čaiH-¹ 'to sew'. No clear IE etymology.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čai̯H- 'to sew', without certain etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):29).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron məkːag 'seed' from məg 'sperm' + suffix -ag.  Abaev compares məg to Lat. mucus, PIE meuk- and sees it as a "Scytho-European" term.}];156[II:137-138{S.v. myggag | muggag 1. 'семя, семена', from Oss. myg 'сперма' + suffix -ag, cf. s.v. myg | mugæ, comparing Lat. mucus, Gk. μύξα, deriving from PIE *meuk- (IEW 744).}];269[{Semantics of the PIE root *meu̯k- are reconstructed as 'losbinden, abstreifen' after LIV² pp.443-444.  The development of the more restricted semantics '(aus)schneuzen| blow one's nose' (Gk. ἀπομύσσω) and development of a noun in Lat. mūcus 'snot, mucus' < *mou̯k-o- appears to be restricted to Latin and Greek.  Abaev's semantic comparison to PIE *meu̯k- is therefore less convincing, and is at best an independent parallel semantic development that is unattested elsewhere in Indo-Iranian.}]
Justification: Derivatives of Ossetic myg | mugæ 'sperm', according to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:137-138 to be further connected to Latin mūcus 'snot, mucus', Ancient Greek μύξα 'mucus, discharge from nose' to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, remove (smth.)' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 443-444) as a Scythian-European isogloss.

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. straight, from Middle English streȝt, straȝt, originally an adjectival use of the past participle of strecchen 'to stretch'.}];388[380{S.v. Proto-Germanic *strakkjanan, derived from *strak(k)az}];697[559-560{Cf. s.v. *strakka- 'gestreckt'? The adjective may have been back-formed to the ja-verb strecken.}]
Justification: Originally a participle to the weak verb 'to stretch' (OE streccan), possibly to be further derived from *strak(k)a- 'tight, taut' ([Orel 2003](src-388):380), but cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):559-560, who considers that the adjective may have been back-formed from the verb. Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 442[696{S.v. 12041 Ved. vī́kṣatē 'looks at, sees' ŚBr. 2. *vēkṣatē (vēkṣayati Dhātup., vēkṣaṇa- n. 'looking after, care' Mn. v.l. cēkṣaṇē) with ē after prḗkṣatē, ávēkṣatē: or poss. < *vyēkṣatē, cf. vyādr̥śyatē. [√īkṣ]}];172[I:203{S.v. Ved. √īkṣ- 'wahrnehmen, bemerken, erblicken, sehen', a secondary root within Vedic from PIE *h₃i-h₃kʷ-s-, cf. Ved. ákṣi- 'eye' < *h₃ekʷ-s-}];141[297-298{S.v. *h₃ekʷ- 'ins Auge fassen, erblicken' (IEW 775-7).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vī́kṣate 'looks at, sees' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):696 no. 12041), further to Vedic √īkṣ- 'to perceive, view, see' continuing a reduplicated desiderative stem *h₃i-h₃kʷ-s- to PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ([EWAia](src-172) I:203, [LIV²](src-141) 297-298).

Source: 320[383{S.v. Khot. vāma- 'sea, flood', which B. connects to Ved. aváni- 'stream' assuming a base au-, va-, vā- to IEW 78-81 au- 'be watery'.}];172[I:131{Cf. s.v. Ved. aváni- 'Flußbett, Fluß, Strom'| connections of the Iranian material to that of the Indic are uncertain. Etymology of Iranian materials consequently unclear.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. First connected by [Bailey 1979](src-320):383 to Vedic aváni- 'stream', but this proposal has been judged to be unclear by [EWAia](src-172) I:131.

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri âčʹuṇa-  [âčʹuṇoa-| âčʹuṇavoa-]  VI.  Run.  [âčuṇa-]  [PrAr. *â-čsu˜d-a- ‘tramples’  T. 1030 (whence ṇ?)]}];442[46{S.v. 1030 *ākṣundati 'tramples'. [Cf. ākṣōdana- n. 'hunting' lex.: √kṣud] (> Kt. ačune- 'to run').}];172[I:439{Cf. s.v. Ved. √kṣod- 'zerstieben' (IIr. cf. OAv., YAv. xšusta- 'geschmolzen, flüssig (vom Metall)', Khot. kṣusti- 'serum', MPers., NPers. šustan 'waschen', etc., further comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic disputed.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes as though from Old Indic *ākṣundati 'tramples' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):46 no. 1030, [Strand 1998](src-431)), derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic √kšud- 'to disperse, scatter', further etymology uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:439).

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron žʁor-ən 'run': cf. Avestan ɣžar- 'flow'. Might be related to Turkic zügür (Abaev believes that /o/ in both dialects is due to contamination with this word| but it may also simply be a borrowing)}]

338[{Ossetic Digor leʒun is from PIr. *raič‑, cf. Avestan raeč‑, raek‑ 'leave'. The word exists in Iron, but not as the Swadesh term (its semantics are more like 'run away'). Conversely, the Ossetic Iron Swadesh term žʁor‑ən also exists in Digor as zʁor‑un, but this lexeme is less basic.}];83[307-308{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *raič- 'to leave, let, abandon' from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'leave, let'.}];141[406-408{Cf. s.v. *lei̯kʷ- 'zurücklassen, sich entfernen von' (IEW 669-670).}]
338[{Probably onomatopoeic.}];156[III:330-335{S.v. Oss. tymbyl | tumbul 'круглый'.}]
Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:330-335).

Source: 165[136{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fergunja-. An etymologically debated word. Perhaps to *ferhwa- (1) 'oak', *furhwōn- 'fir', or the feminine equivalent to *ferga- 'god' (ON fjǫrg 'gods') with a feminine -unjō suffix, in which case the proto-form could continue *perk⁽ʷ⁾-n-ieh₂- and could perhaps be related to Lith. perkū́nas, Latv. pȩ̄̀rkuôns 'thunder' < *perkʷ-u-Hn-o-.}];179[104-105{S.v. Goth. F11. fairguni 'ὄρος', 'mountain, mountain range', from PGmc. *fergunjō (cf. OE firgi/en- + holt 'mountain wood', -strēam 'mountain stream'. Other connections within Germanic and outside Germanic widely disputed, principally because of proposed etymologies to with names of gods and mythological beings, among such proposals include OI Fjǫrgynn 'father of Frigg (Freya)', Fjǫrgyn 'mother of Thor' = Jǫrð 'mother earth, earth, country'. Alternatively PIE *perkʷ- 'oak' (OI fura, OE furh, OHG for(a)ha 'pine', OHG fereh-eih 'oak', Lang fureha 'Italian oak', cf. also Lith. Perkū́nas 'thunder, Thundergod'. Postulations of relations between other IE branches rest on conclusions made through comparative mythology (in which folk-etymological reshaping may have been a factor in lexical developments) and therefore debate over these etymologies will doubtlessly continue.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):104-105, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):136 for various proposals.

Source: 338[{Etymology unknown, probably a loanword, most likely from South Caucasian.}];156[I:631{S.v. Oss. k'væda 'дождь, ненастье', Of uncertain origin, perhaps a loan from Caucasian cf. Gruz. k'ad-va 'flow'}]
Justification: Origin uncertain, perhaps a loanword from South Caucasian (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:631).

Source: 468[636, 680{S.v. ON ýta 'aussetzen, ausstossen' (< Germ. ūtian) (cf. OE ytan, ūtian 'vertreiben, verbannen', OFr. ūtia, OHG ūzōn 'ausschließen'. Denominal to út 'hinaus' (cf. Ved. ud- 'hinauf, hinaus' Gk. (Cypr.) ὑ-, etc.).}];294[823-828{Cf. s.v. *úd- 'empor, hinauf| hinaus' (Adverb, lokal). See p.824 s.v. Adverbiale Ableitungen PIE *ū̆́d-na > Proto-Germanic *ūta- 'aus, hinaus' whence Goth. ūt, ON út, OHG uz.}]
