Justification: Forms from Proto-Germanic *ūtian-, secondarily derived to Proto-Germanic *ūd- 'out' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):680), further to PIE *úd- 'upwards, up; out' (cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) 824).

Source: 397[219{Cf. s.v. NHG drücken (MHG drücken, drucken, OHG thruken, drucchen, drucken), from West Germanic *ϸrukk-ja-, also in OE ϸryccan, an intensive formation to Gmc. *ϸrūg- (cf. ON ϸrúga- 'drücken').}];386[813-815{S.v. OHG drucken '(nieder)drücken, pressen, bedrücken, quälen, bedrängen, untertänig machen' from Proto-Germanic *ϸrukk(i)jan-, an intensive formation from Pre-Proto-Germanic *trūk-, possibly an enlargement of the IE root *terh₁-, which may be compared with Lith. trū́kti 'entzweireißen, bersten, einen Bruch bekommen'.}];352[1118-1119{Cf. s.v. Lith. tráukti 'ziehen, schleppen', for which there are no clear connections outside of Lithuanian. the proposed comparison with ON ϸruga- 'drohen', OHG drucken 'drücken' etc. could go back to a common PIE root *treu̯Hk- ~ 'gewaltsam in Bewegung setzen(?)', but this would be structurally striking and still required to be more precisely semantically determined.}]
Justification: An intensive formation to Proto-Germanic *ϸrug-. The root occasionally compared to Lith. trū́kti 'break, tear in two' (cf. [EWA 2](src-386) 813-815, but this connection is not fully certain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1118-1119).

Source: 697[577-578{S.v. Gmc. *swenϸa- 'kräftig'. Not to be connected with an IE root *su̯ent-/*su̯n̥t-, rather with Seebold to be derived from a stem *sg̑ʰ-u- to the root *seg̑ʰ- 'festhalten| (im Kampf) überwältigen' (cf. Ved. kṣu- 'Macht', Gk. ἰσχύς 'Kraft, Stärke, Macht'| cf. r/n stem in OIr. sáhuri 'gewaltig, überlegen', Gk. ἐχυρός 'haltbar, fest, sicher' based on *ség̑ʰu̯r̥| Sogd. xšawan- 'Macht', Gk. σθένος 'Kraft, Stärke, Macht' based on oblique stem *sg̑ʰu̯én-).}];179[336{Cf. s.v. Goth. S188. *swinϸs 'ἰσχυρός', 'strong'. No satisfactory etymology| may be restricted to Germanic. Hardly to Skt. suváti 'set in motion', Lith. siunčiù| cf. IEW 1048 reconstructing *su̯ento-, *sunto-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):336 s.v. Goth. *swinϸs. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):577-578 s.v. PGmc. *swenϸa- favours a comparison with IE *seg̑ʰ- 'overpower, seize' (LIV² 515-516), cf. ad loc. for references to further literature. For older comparisons to Lith. siunčiu 'send', cf. [IEW](src-49) 1048, reconstructing *su̯ento-, *sunto- (but qualifying the entry "nur Germ.?").

Source: 442[227{Cf. s.v. 4236 Skt. gr̥bhāyáti 'takes, seizes' RV.}];172[I:505-506{S.v. Ved. √grabh- 'ergreifen, nehmen, fassen, festhalten' from a PIE root probably to be reconstructed *gʰreb⁽ʰ⁾H- (cf. Lith. grė́bti, gróbti 'rauben', Lett. grebt 'greifen', OCS grabiti 'rauben').}];141[201{S.v. *gʰrebh₂- 'ergreifen' (IEW 455).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived to Vedic √grabh- 'to take, seize' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):227 no. 4236), further to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize, grasp' ([EWAia](src-172) I:505-506, [LIV²](src-141) 201).

Source: 442[149{S.v. 2922 Skt. kalaha m. 'quarrel, fight' MBh. (<-> Kt. kəle 'war, fighting').}]
Justification: Loanword from Indic? (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):149 no. 2922).

Source: 442[61{Cf. s.v. 1356 *ālagyati 'adheres to', 2. ālagna- 'fastened to' lex. [Cf. ālagati ʻ adheres ʼ Kāvyād.: √lag]}];431[{S.v. Kâmviri âlʹaŋo  [-i fem]  Aj.  Heavy.  [â-laŋvo]  [OIA. â-lag-na- ‘fastened to’  T. 1356.2 (+| gn > ŋ?)]}];172[II:473{S.v. Ved. √lag- 'an etwas haften, sich anheften'| etymology unexplained.}]
Justification: As though continuing ā-lagna- 'fastened to', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *√lag- 'to stick, attach', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):61 no. 1356.2, [Strand 1998](src-431), [EWAia](src-172) II:473).

Source: 165[452{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwan- 'mirror' (Go. skuggwa 'mirror'| ON skuggi, etc. 'shadow'), an n-stem derived from the PIE root *skeu- 'to see'.}];388[347{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwōn (Goth. skuggwa 'mirror', ON skuggi 'shade, shadow', OE scúwa 'id.' etc.), related to Skt. skunā́ti, Arm. cʻiw 'roof', OIr. cúl 'back', from PIE *(s)k̑euə- 'to cover'.}];179[313{Cf. s.v. Goth. S95 *skuggwa 'ἔσοπτρον', 'mirror'. Two possible etymologies: either (1) to PIE *(s)keu̯ə- / *(s)kū- 'cover' (Skt. skunā́ti 'cover', Gk. σκῡ́νια (pl.) 'brows', or (2) to PIE *skeu̯- 'pay attention to, observe', although this root is primarily West Germanic.}]
Justification: Root etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):313, [Orel 2003](src-388):347, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):452 for further discussion.

Source: 397[793{Cf. s.v. Schale 'Hülse' (MHG schal(e), OHG scala), from West Germanic *skalō(n) 'Schale', also in OE scealu. With corresponding meaning but deviating meaning is Goth. skalja 'Ziegel' (probably originally 'Schuppe'), ON skel, OE scill, scell 'Muschel'. Outside of Germanic the closest comparison is Ru. skalá 'Birkenrinde', skol'ka 'Muschen', whether these can go back to an (IE) root *skel- 'spalten, trennen' must remain open.}];165[443{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skēlō- 'bowl', an ō-stem probably derived from skeljan-. If so, then derived from PIE *skelH-.}];141[553{If to be derived from PIE *skelH- as suggested (but not certain) by Kroonen 2013, Kluge 2011, cf. s.v. *skelH- 'aufschlitzen, spalten' (IEW 923-6).}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):793, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):443 for various proposals).

Source: 697[485{Cf. s.v. PGmc. *skanka- 'schief', from which E scanca 'Unterschenkel, Schienbein' etc.}];397[800{S.v. NHG Schenkel (MHG schenkel, MLG schinkel, MDu. sc(h)enkel), a diminutive formation to OE sceanca, MLG schinke 'Schenkel', To this perhaps a with a dissimilated initial position Ved. sákthi- 'Schenkel'. Cf. also 'hinken' in Ved. kháñjati, Gk. σκάζω, and without s-mobile NHG hinken.}];165[446{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skinkan- ~ *skankan- ~ *skunkan- 'shank, ham', from *skéng-on- (cf. Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skng-ie-, Skt. khañjati 'id.' < *skeng-e-). The Germanic forms reflect an ablauting n-stem from the PIE verbal root *skeng-.}];141[555{Cf. s.v. *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'hinken' (IEW 930).}];388[334{S.v. PGmc. *skankaz ~ *skankōn- sb.m. (Norw. skank 'shank', OE sceanca, LG schanke, OHG scanc 'rack, cupboard'), derived from *skankaz adj. related to Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skn̥gi̯ō, MIr. scingim 'to spring'.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):446, [Orel 2003](src-388):334, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):485, [Kluge 2011](src-397):800). For the root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555). The semantics of Luxembourgish Schank appear to have shifted from the sense 'leg, thigh, shinbone' found elsewhere in Germanic.

Source: 397[414{Cf. s.v. NHG heulen (MHG hiulen, hiuweln| OHG hūwilōn, hūlōn, MLG hulen), probably originally 'screech like an owl' to MHG hiuwel, hūwel, OHG hūwo 'Uhu, Eule'. The nouns as well as the verb are probably imitative in origin.}];757[II:475{S.v. huilen ww. (NN) ‘schreien, wenen’. Originally an mimicking/onomatopoeic word.}]
Justification: West Germanic lexemes probably originally based on an onomatopoeic formation ([Kluge 2011](src-397):414, [EWNl](src-757) II:475).

Source: 397[540{Cf. s.v. NHG kreischen (Late MHG krīschen, MLG criscen), a -sk-formation to the stem underlying NHG kreißen, an onomatopoeic verb form.}]
Justification: West Germanic formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):540 s.v. Standard High German kreischen.

Source: 165[258{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hurhwa- 'dirt, mucus', possibly related to MIr. corcach < *kork-āko-??, if so then perhaps *kork-uo-.}]
Justification: Adjective derived from Proto-Germanic *hurhwa- 'dirt, mucus'. Further connections unclear, perhaps to Middle Irish corcach 'moor'? (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):258).

Source: 397[137{Cf. s.v. NHG Boden (MHG bodem, boden, OHG bodam, OS bođom) from Pre-German *buϸma- 'Boden', while the other Germanic languages go back to *butma- (ON botn, OE botm), clearly coming from IE *bʰudʰ-men- (cf. Ved. budhná- 'Boden, Grund, Wurzel' with a *-mno- suffix| Gk. πυθμήν 'Boden eines Gefäßes, des Meeres, Wurzel', further probably with Lat. fundus 'Boden', MIr. bonn 'Sohle, Grundlage').}];165[82{S.v. Proto-Germanic *budman- ~ *buttman- 'bottom', as though from PIE *bʰudʰ-mén- (cf. Gk. πυθμήν 'bottom, depth, root' < *bʰudʰ-mén-, Skt. budhná- 'bottom', Lat. fundus 'id.', MIr. bond 'foot, sole' < *bʰudʰ-no-). "The PIE root *bʰudʰ- itself seems to have been metathesized from *dʰubʰ-, for which cf. [PGmc.] *deupa- 'deep'."}];172[II:228-229{Cf. s.v. Ved. budhná- 'Boden, Grund, Tiefe', to be connected with Gk. πυθμήν 'Boden, Grund, Unterlage', Lat. fundus 'Boden, Meeresgrund, Grundstück', MIr. bond 'Sohle, Grundlage', OHG bodam, NHG Boden, etc., going back to an IE formation with a *-men- suffix to a root *bʰudʰ-.}];386[222-225{S.v. OHG bodam 'Boden, Grund, Schiffsboden, -kiel, -deck'. Comparisons outside of Germanic including Ved. budhná- 'Grund, Boden', Gk. πυθμήν 'Boden, Fuß eines Gefäßes' point to an IE proto-form *bʰudʰ-m(e)n(o)-. Attempts to analyse the root *bʰudʰ- as a metathesis of the root *dʰeu̯b-, *dʰeu̯p- 'tief' (cf. OHG tiof) remain purely speculative.}]
Justification: Cf. Standard German Boden, continuing PIE *bʰudʰ-men-; the root appears to only be attested in the zero-grade. It is unclear whether the full-grade form would be *bʰeu̯dʰ- or *bʰu̯edʰ- ([EWA 2](src-386):222-225, [Kluge 2011](src-397):137, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):82, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:228-229).

Source: 397[637{Cf. s.v. NHG Mücke (MHG mücke, mucke, mügge, mugge, OHG mugga, muck, OS muggia), from Germanic *mugjōn (also in OSw. mugga, OE mycg, mygg). Presumably not related to the IE word for 'fly', which goes back to *mus-, but rather a zero-grade form to a word for 'fly' which goes back to *mek̑- (cf. Ved. maśáka-, Lith. mãšala[s]. mãkatas).}];165[379-380{S.v. Proto-Germanic *muwī- 'mosquito' < PIE *muH-ih₂-. The velar in West Germanic arose due to velarisation of the *-w- in the nominative *muwī. Velars in the related forms in OSw. mygga, etc. arose by regular Verschärfung of *-jj- > -gg(j)-. Appears to be related to *musī- 'mosquito, fly' < PIE *mus-(i)eh₂- (cf. MDu. meusie 'mosquito, fly').}];388[278{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mūjan (ON mý 'midge, gnat') an isolated form distantly connected with *mūsō ~ *mūsīn (> Flem. meuzie).}]
Justification: Perhaps an extension to an original onomatopoeic base *mu- and connected to the more widely attested PIE *mus- in [cognate set 5031](cog-5031), but this proposed connection remains speculative. Cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):278, [Kluge 2011](src-397):637, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):379-380.

Source: 556[565{S.v. Gmc. *wreib-a- 'reiben'. Germanic *wreib-a- 'reiben' has no secure comparisons. It is generally considered as an enlargement of the root *wer- 'drehen, verdrehen', which is in principle possible, but is not fully sufficient to support an etymology. Compare striking similar structures in words of similar meaning in Lat. trī-vī (pf.), Gk. τρίβω.}];397[755{S.v. NHG reiben (MHG rīben, OHG rīban, MLG (w)riven, MDu. writven, NWFr. wriuwe, based on pre-German *wreib-a- (str.vb.). Outside of Germanic corresponds to Gk. ῥίπτω 'werfen'.}];66[1287-1288{Cf. s.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'to throw, hurl, thrust, bolt'. Based on a root *(ϝ)ριπ- within Ancient Greek. No clear etymology outside of Greek| formally matches MLG wrīven 'to rub, wipe, scour, draw', MHG rīben 'to turn rubbing' (IEW 1159), but the semantic gap is considerable.}];270[975{S.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'jeter violemment, brandir, jeter à bas, arracher'. Etymology obscure. The forms go back to a root *ϝριπ- with a present suffix -ye/o-| [IEW](src-49) 1159 supposes *wrī-p- and a connection to Germanic lexemes meaning 'frotter, tourner' in OHG rīban, MHG rīben, MLG wrīven.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; may be a formal match to Ancient Greek ῥίπτω 'throw' but the semantic match is quite difficult (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):565, [Kluge 2011](src-397):755, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):975, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1287-1288 for further discussion).

Source: 165[440-441, 444{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skarpa- ‘sharp’, an o-grade adjective derived to Proto-Germanic *skerban- ~ *skerpan- ~ *skrepan- 'to scrape, scratch', a strong verb based on the IE root *skrebʰ- (cf. Russ. skrestí, Latv. šķir̃ba 'fissure', Lith. skir̃bti 'to become sour', Lat. scrobis 'hole in the ground, pit').}];141[557-558{Cf. s.v. *(s)kerbʰ- 'scharf sein' (IEW 943-4).}];697[487{S.v. Gmc. *skarpa- 'zusammengeschrumpft, rauh'. Only attested in North and West Germanic. The adjective can have a precise correspondence in Latv. skarbs 'scharf, streng, rauh' (if it is not a loanword). The ablauting adjective in ORu. ščьrbъ 'unvollständig, schadhaft' and OIr. cerb 'scharf, schneidend' (without s-mobile). The basis of these words is IE *(s)ker- 'schneiden'.}]
Justification: Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 557-558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):487.

Source: 757[{Cf. s.v. Du. stoppen w.v. ‘dichtmaken, insteken’, cf. MLG stoppen, OHG stopfōn, stupfen, stoppōn, stopfōn, (dial.) stupfen, OFr. stoppia, NFr. stopje, OE forstoppian, NE stop < PGmc. *stuppōn-| further to Latin stupēre, Grieks τύπτειν, Sanskrit tupáti, Latv. stups, stupe| < PIE *(s)teup-/*(s)teub-, a root with labial extensions from a basic PIE *(s)teu- ‘stoten, slaan’ (IEW 1034). Proto-Germanic *-pp- is probably from *-bhn- (Kluge's Law).}]
Justification: According to [EWNl](src-757), to be connected with PIE *(s)teup-/*(s)teub- 'to hit, beat' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 602-603 s.v. *(s)teu̯p-, without Germanic lexical material listed).

Source: 165[218{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop', from PIE *kóuh₂-e- (cf. TochB kāw 'kill' < *keh₂u-| Lith. káuti 'to murder, beat, hew', Latv. kaût 'to fight' < *ke/oh₂u-| OCS kovati, Ru. kovát' 'to forge, hammer' < *kouh₂-eh₂- (with laryngeal metathesis)).}];141[345-346{S.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).}];556[251-252{S.v. PGmc. *haww-a- 'hauen', going back with certainty to the verbal root *qou- 'hauen, schlagen' (cf. Lith. káuju, káuti 'schlagen, hauen, umbringen', OCS kovǫ, kovati 'schmieden, verfertigen', TochB kau- 'töten').}];397[399{S.v. NHG hauen (MHG houwen, OHG houwan, OS hauwan), from Gmc. *haww-a-, from PIE *kowə- 'hauen, schlagen' (cf. Lith. káuti 'schlagen, hauen, umbringen', OCS kovati 'schmieden', TochB kau- 'töten').}]
Justification: Cf. Standard German hauen, from Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop' and further derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, to split' ([LIV²](src-141) 345-346, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):251-252, [Kluge 2011](src-397):399, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):218).

Source: 397[152, 940{Cf. s.v. NHG umbringen 'um etwas bringen'. The modern meaning has been simplified from 'ums Leben bringen'. For NHG bringen < PGmc. *breng-a- (cf. Goth. briggan, OE bringan), the root may be compared with Welsh hebrwng, hebryngaf 'führen, bringen' and perhaps TochAB pränk- 'sich zurückhalten' to IE *bʰrenk-, and if so may be a root contamination of IE *bʰer- 'tragen' and *(e)nek- 'erreichen'. Both of these roots are suppletive in Greek so this assumption seems reasonable.}];556[136-137{Cf. s.v. PGmc. *breng-a- 'bringen', generally assumed since Karl Brugmann (IF 12 1901, 150-158) to be contamination of the roots *bʰer- 'tragen' and *(e)nek̑- 'erreichen'. Since both of these verbs are suppletive in Greek this assumption seems reasonable. Otherwise still unclear. Cf. perhaps W. hebrwng 'führen, bringen' perhaps from *sem-bhronk-, TochB pränk- 'sich zurückhalten'.}];165[77{S.v. Proto-Germanic *bringan- 'to bring'. A verb of obscure origin. Perhaps to be analysed as a conflation of *bʰer- 'to carry' and *h₂enk̑- 'to arrive'. Alternatively one may analyse the perfective ga-bringan as a remodelling of *kom-pro-h₁énk̑- (cf. OIr. ro-ic W rynghu 'to meet' < *pro-h₁(e)nk̑-) with the initial *b < *p explained by Verner's Law.}]
Justification: Simplified from the phrase 'ums Leben bringen', cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):940. Further IE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally analysed as a conflation of the roots *bʰer- 'to carry' and *h₁nek̑- 'take, receive' (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):136-137, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):77).
Loanword from Sanskrit tvác- 'skin, bark'.

Source: 442[274{S.v. 5005 Skt. challi- 'bark'. Probably of non-Indic origin.}];399[I:405-406{S.v. Skt. challī- 'Rinde / bark' (Pāli challi, Prākrit challī), probably from the same non-IE source as colakam (coḍaḥ). Probably Dravidian, but a Munda origin is not to be ruled out.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5005: "H. chāl f. ʻbark, skin, peelʼ, chālī f. ʻsmall blisterʼ, chālā m. ʻskin, hideʼ (→ P. N. chālā m.)"
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:405-406).

Comment: re-sanskritized forms of the respective inherited forms, cf. cognate set 6949 - note that this phenomenon is different from a simple loan event

The Palula aspirate is unclear and does not appear in older sources (drakaṛ Turner ad rem). dr > l is regular in Gawri and Gawarbati. The -i- in Gawarbati might be due to the influence of līgāla- < dīrgha- 'long', as already suggested by Buddruss (apud Turner) for the Woṭapuri cognate.
Justification: Indic lexemes as if from *drakk-, only reflected in 'Dardic'.

Source: 442[228{S.v. Skt. gēnduka -- , °dū°, gin° m. 'ball for play'.}]

320[466, 1-2{S.v. Khot. haysga- 'nostril', pl. 'nose', from *hazg- to fra-zga- 'to smell' from following the scent as in Av. vohuna-zga- 'clinging to the blood', Arm. LW zgam 'feel, hear, know, to scent', cognates cf. s.v. aysagamu-, ajs- 'to cling to, pursue', to be connected with Ved. sájati, saktá- 'cling to'.}];83[128-129{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *ha(n)j- 'to hang (on), cling on', from PIE *seg- 'to adhere' (cf. Skt. sa(ñ)j- 'to adhere, hang (on)', Lith. segù 'I adhere', ?OIr. sén 'safety net (for catching birds)'.}];172[II:688-689{Cf. s.v. Ved. √sañj- 'heften, hängen', IIr. cf. OPers. frahǰm /frāhaǰam/ 'ich hängte', Khot. ajs- 'verfolgen, nachsetzen', probably from PIE *seg-, cf. Lith. segù 'hefte, beschlage', MIr. sén 'Fangnetz (zum Vogelfang)', etc.}];141[516{Cf. s.v. 1. *seg- 'heften, anhängen' (IEW 887-8).}]
Justification: According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):466, probably from the same root as Khotanese ajs- 'to cling to, pursue' (with the semantic development in the sense of 'cling to the scent of' vel sim.). Further probably to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, cling to' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):128-129, [EWAia](src-172) II:688-689, [LIV²](src-141) 516).

Source: 172[I:137-138{Cf. s.v. Ved. áśman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Fels' (Av. asman- 'Stein, Schleuderstein, Himmel'), from PIE *h₂ek̑-mon- (cf. Gk. ἄκμων 'Amboß (auch 'Meteorstein' und 'Himmel'), Lith. ašmuõ (pl. ãšmens) 'Schneide, Schärfe', akmuõ, -ẽns 'Stein'). To PIE *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz'.}]
Comment: from PIE *h₂ek̑  'sharp, pointed; stone, rock'; cognate with 'stone' [cognate set 1179](cog-1179) - NB. sky (and daylight) was mythically seen as coming out of the rock (cf. the Vedic Vala-myth) and thus as originating from/being made from rock/stone.
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ([EWAia](src-172) I:137-138).

Source: 410[124-125{S.v. mel(ul)i-, mil(ul)i-, maluli- 'flesh(y) tissue, soft parts, body fat, marrow', perhaps to be related to Gk. μέλος 'limb', Lat. membrum, Ved. márman- 'soft spot', Lith. mélmenys 'small of the back, lumbar adipose'.}];457[210-211{Cf. s.v. mīluli-, maluli-, meluli- 'Haut (?), Fleisch (?), weiches Gewebe(?)'.}]
Justification: The dubious semantics of the Hittite lexeme make etymological identification difficult (cf. [CHD L-N](src-403):253). For various uncertain proposals, cf. [Tischler 1991](src-457):210-211, [HED M](src-410):124-125.

Source: 325[48{S.v. nǟj Š| nēj XR, nōj BO| noj S| neǰ Y 'nose', "cf. Sogd. nyc 'nostrils' < *nāh(y)a-či-| not (with Meillet, BSL 23, 108) < *nahya-či, or (with Gersh. 247) < *nāhikā-. Khwar. nʾc, f. nʾh, but Yaghn. nays < *nāsya-, if not for *nayc."}]
442[243{S.v. 4485 *ghummati 'revolves'. 2. *ghumati. [Replaces ghūrṇati| poss. < *ghūrma- : *ghūr- ] Addenda: B. ghumā read B. ghumā̆na.}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *ghum(m)ati, further root etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):243 no. 4485).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian.

Source: 80[722-723{Cf. s.v. Hitt. šani- 'the same, one and the same' (within Anatolian cf. HLuw. sanawa/i- (adj./n.) 'good/goods', sanawazi- (adj.) 'good', sanawastar- 'goodness'. Etymology unclear.  Perh. to PIE *sem 'one', but this identification is formally difficult.}]
Justification: To be connected with Hittite Hitt. šani- 'the same, one and the same', but further etymology outside of Anatolian unclear (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):722-723).

Source: 80[471-472{Cf. s.v. Hitt. keššar / kiššer- / kišr- 'hand'. Hittite kiššar- reflects forms reflect an original r-stem from PIE *g̑ʰes-r-. The forms found in the Luwic subgroup, CLuw. īš(ša)ra/i-, HLuw. istra/i- and Lyc. izre/i- reflect a secondarily thematised form (as though from) *g̑es-r-o-, from Proto-Anatolian *g̑es-r- 'hand'. CLuw. išarili(a)- (adj.) ‘of the right hand (> favourable)’ is a derived adjective.}];274[170-173{Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰes- *'fassen?', 'Hand', 'Griff' (IEW 446f.).}]
Justification: Related to Luvian īš(ša)ra/i- 'hand' via an unattested derivative *išaru-/išaru̯a- 'right-hand' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):471-472, cf. [NIL](src-274) 170-173). For further etymological details cf. 'hand' in [cognate set 411](cog-411).

Source: 80[166-167{Cf. s.v. Hitt. aiš / išš- 'mouth', from PIE *h₁eh₃-es- (cf. within Anatolian: CLuw. āaš- 'mouth', āaša- 'to speak(?)', HLuw. ásaza- 'to speak'| elsewhere in IE: Skt. ā́s-, Av. āh-, Lat. ōs, OIr. á 'mouth').}];274[387-390{Cf. s.v. *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os n. 'Mund' (IEW 784f., EIEC 387).}]
Justification: Denominal verb, cf. Cuneiform Luvian āaš- 'mouth' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):166-167, cf. [NIL](src-274) 387-390). For further etymological discussion cf. 'mouth' in [cognate set 796](cog-796).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 476

Source: 457[345-346{S.v. Hitt. tetana- c. 'Haar', possibly a nursery word with reduplication.}]
Justification: Generally assumed to be a nursery word (cf. [Tischler 1991](src-457):345-346).

Source: 442[147{S.v. 2900 Skt. karmín, kármika- 'active' (~ Ved. karmán-).}];172[I:307-309{S.v. Ved. √kar- 'tun, machen, bewirken, handeln' < PIIr. čar-/kar- < PIE *kʷer-/kʷor- (cf. Hitt. kuer- 'schneiden', OIr. cruth, Wel. pryd 'Gestalt' (*kʷr̥-tu-), Lith. kùrti 'errichten, bauen').}];399[I:176{Cf. s.v. Skt. kárma- 'Werk, Arbeit (usw.) / work, labour (etc.)' to Skt. kr̥ṇóti 'machen, tun'.}]
Justification: To be derived from Vedic √kar- 'to make, do' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):147, no. 2900, [KEWA](src-399) I:176, [EWAia](src-172) I:307-309).

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 80[683{S.v. Hitt. putkii̯e/a- 'to swell (said of fermented dough and of a tumor or boil on the head'. Etymology unclear.  Earlier proposals relying on assuming PIE 'thorn' clusters *-Kþ- are now to be discarded.}];413[146{S.v. Hitt. putkiya- 'swell, be tumescent'. "A plausible cognate is Lith. pùsti 'swell' […]. The verb putkiya- can be denominative from e.g. put-ko- 'swelling, edema, tumor' (vel sim.)| cf. Belorussian potka (< *pŭtĭka) 'penis' beside Lat. prae-pūtium 'foreskin'."}];352[831-833{Cf. s.v. Lith. pùsti 'anschwellen, sich aufblähen', an anticausative formation to Lith. pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen', without clear correspondences outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, see [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):683 for a critical discussion of earlier proposals. [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413):146 considers a connection to Lithuanian pùsti 'swell', but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 831-833 s.v. pùsti 'anschwellen' and pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen' against any clear correspondences outside of Baltic for the proposed comparandum.

Source: 531[767{Cf. s.v. Lith. võras 'bardzo stary', the etymology remains a mystery.}];360[1274{Cf. s.v. Lith. võras 'alt', cf. Pr. urs, uraisins 'Eltern'.}]
Justification: Cf. Lith. võras 'old', further etymology uncertain ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):767, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1274).

Source: 352[1285{S.v. OLith. žaĩsti 'spielen'. No reliable comparanda outside of Lithuanian.}]
Justification: No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 1285).

Source: 377[173{S.v. Luw. pa/ušūriya- 'dust' (??) "I assume single word with Laroche, DLL 81. Object is sprinkled and may belong to hand or foot (also then to *pes- 'rub'?)."}]
Justification: Semantic identification not fully certain, therefore etymology also uncertain (cf. [Melchert 1993a](src-377):173).

Source: 442[521{S.v. 9235 Ved. bā́hya- 'external' AV.}];172[II:220{Cf. s.v. Ved. bahíṣ (adv.) 'draußen, von außen, hinaus, außerhalb', probably from IE *bʰeg̑ʰ- (cf. OCS bez, Lith. bè, Latv. bez 'ohne').}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic bā́hya- ʻexternal, being outside' (AV), via 'foreign, strange' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):521, no. 9235. Further to PIE *bʰeg̑ʰ- according to [EWAia](src-172) II:220 on the basis of proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda (Lith. bè, Latv. bez, OCS bez 'without', cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):38a), but more recently cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):38, [ALEW](src-352) 101-102 without connection to the Indic lexemes.

Source: 377[9{S.v. Luw. al(l)attar / *allattn- 'fruit' (?)}]
Justification: Semantic identification not entirely clear ([Melchert 1993a](src-377):9), therefore etymology also uncertain.

Source: 442[161{S.v. 3153 Skt. *kicca 'mud, dirt '. 2. *kacca- 2. 3. *khacca- . [Cf. Drav. words quoted s.v. *gicc -- and further groups s.vv. kiṭṭa- and kaccara- 1, and *cikka- 2]}]
Justification: Of uncertain origin, possibly a Dravidian loanword? Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442)161, no. 3153.

Source: 352[1111{S.v. OLith. tìnti 'schwellen', from PIE *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (cf. Ved. tan- 'spannen, ausbreiten', Gk. τείνω 'spanne, dehne aus', τιταίνω 'id.', Alb. nden 'breitet aus, spannt aus', Lat. teneō, -ēre 'halten', MW tannu 'Ausbreiten, Aufspannen', Goth. ufϸanjan 'ausdehnen', OHG donēn 'hingestreckt sein').}];141[626-627{Cf. s.v. *ten- 'sich spannen, sich dehnen' (IEW 1065-6).}];353[467-468{S.v. Lith. tìnti (II) 'swell, bloat', from PIE *tn- (√*ten-), cf. OE ϸunian 'stretch, swell'.}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ten- 'to stretch, span' ([ALEW](src-352) 1111, [Derksen 2015](src-353):467-468, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 626-627).

Source: 80[936{Cf. s.v. Hitt. uzuḫri- 'grass', a Hurrian loanword.  The sequence of cuneiform signs might alternatively be read as Ú (plant determinative) + zuḫri-.}];377[285{S.v. (Ú)zuḫrit- 'grass, hay'| Hurrian loanword. Cf. Starke (1990:220).}];373[220]
Justification: A loanword from Hurrian ([Starke 1990](src-373):220, [Melchert 1993a](src-377):285, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):936).

Source: 352[584-586{S.v. OLith. lýgus 'eben, gleich, ähnlich' (BSl. Latv. lĩdz 'gleich, ebenso wie, zugleich, mit', OPr. a.sg. līgan 'Gericht', a.sg. lijgan 'Urteil', līgint 'richten'), the most likely connection within IE to Germanic lexemes from Goth. leik 'Körper, Leib| Leichnam, Fleisch', swaleiks (adj.) 'solch', leikan 'gefallen', ON lík 'Körper, Gestalt', líkr 'gleich, ähnlich', OHG līh 'Körper, Leichnam', līhhōn 'ebnen, glätten', etc. The forms could then be considered derivatives of a root *lei̯g- 'gleich'. Cf. entry in ALEW for further discussion.}];353[286{S.v. Lith. lýgus 'flat, even, equal' (Latv. lĩdzs 'flat, even, equal', OPr. polĩgu 'similarly'), from PIE *lig-u- (cf. Goth. galeiks 'equal', OIc. glíkr, líkr, OE gelīc 'id.').}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing a PIE u-stem *lig-u-, further to a PIE root *lei̯g- 'equal, similar, alike' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 584-586, [Derksen 2015](src-353):286).

Source: 141[252-253{Cf. s.v. *h₁rem- 'ruhig werden' (IEW 864).}];442[616{S.v. 10636 Ved. ramyà- 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ŚBr. [√ram]. (> N. rāmro 'beautiful, good').}];172[II:435-436{S.v. Ved. √ram- 'zur Ruhe kommen, stillstehen, ausruhen, rasten', from PIE *h₁rem- (cf. Gk. ἠρέμα 'ruhig, sanft', Goth. rimis 'Ruhe', Lith. rãmas 'Ruhe', rìmti 'ruhig werden').}]
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ramyà- 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):616 no. 10636), further derived from PIE *h₁rem- 'to be calm' ([EWAia](src-172) II:435-436, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 252-253).

Source: 352[933-935{S.v. OLith. *skrìsti 'kreisen| rund machen, runden' with derived noun apskritìs 'Kreis'. The nominal forms with dental suffixes were backformed to a root *skrit- to which belong the verbs *skrìsti and Lith. skríesti 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen' (with secondary e-grade). The the closest possible comparisons outside of Baltic found in OCS krilo 'Flügel', etc.}];141[563{Cf. s.v. ?*(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'einen Kreis beschreiben' (IEW 936). Verbal only Baltic. Present stem *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾réi̯-e- > Lith. skrejù (skriẽti) 'einen Kreis beschreiben, kreisen', Latv. skreju (skriet) 'laufen, rennen, fliegen'.}]
Justification: Root reference form for this class tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 562, but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 933-935 for further discussion.

Source: 352[1022{S.v. OLith. šešė́lis (1), šešė̃lis (2) 'Schatten'. No clear comparanda outside of Lithuanian.}]
Comment: Etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *k̑elH- 'cold'.
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Lithuanian (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1022).

The lexeme is doubtless a loanword whose the ultimate source is Latin frūctus. However, the direct source is disputable. Some scholars assume Polish [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 208, [Šanskij et al. 1975](src-608): 474, some German or Dutch {Černyh 1999}: 2: 325, some mention the ultimate source only [Šapošnikov 2010](src-636) 2: 485, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6: 134.

Source: 80[853-855{S.v. Hitt. daššu- / daššau̯- 'strong, powerful| heavy| well-fed,| difficult| important'. Possibly to be connected with Skt. dáṃsas- 'miraculous power', cf. Skt. daṃs- 'to have miraculous power', Gk. διδάσκω 'to learn' < *deNs-.  If this etymology is correct, then Hitt.  daššu- would reflect a PIE u-stem *de/oNs-u-.}];141[118-119{Cf. s.v. *dens- 'kundig werden, kunstfertig werden' (IEW 201-202).}]
Justification: Possibly to be derived from PIE *dens- 'to become informed; skilled' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):853-855, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 118-119).

Source: 345[127-128{S.v. TochB orotstse ~ wrotstse 'big, great, large'. Cf. entry for various proposals, of which a remote suggestion is a connection to Hitt. ura- 'great' (Melchert, marked as 'p.c.' in the entry).}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):127-128 for various proposals.

Source: 345[219{S.v. TochB kolyi '± hoof, paw' (?), in general 'animal's foot' (?)| suggests a derivation from *golu-h₁en- and a connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo-/*klēwo- 'claw' (OE clawu 'claw, hoof', OHG klāwo 'claw').}];397[496-497{Cf. s.v. NHG Klaue (OHG klāwa, klā 'Klaue'). There are no meaningful comparisons that can be made outside of Germanic.}];165[292{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *klawō- 'claw' (OEng. clāwu, clā, Eng. claw, Du. klauw, OHG klāwa, klā, klō(a)| Germ. Klaue, ON kló, Far. klógv, Elfd. kluo). Exclusively a Germanic word.}]
Justification: [Adams 2013](src-345):219 suggests a possible connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo- 'claw' but this remains uncertain. For the proposed Germanic cognates, cf. discussion in [Kluge 2011](src-397):496-497, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):292.

Source: 352[289-290{S.v. OLith. galvà 'Kopf, Haupt| Kapitel', with derived verb OLith. galvóti (BSl. cf. Latv. gal̂va 'Kopf, Haupt', OPr. galwo 'Haupt| Schuhspitze', OCS glava 'Kopf| Hauptstück| Kapitel', etc.), IE cf. Arm. glowx, G.sg. glxoy 'Kopf| Ende, Spitze, Anführer'.}];353[162-163{Cf. s.v. Lith. galvà 'head' (Latv. gal̂va 'head', OPr. galwo 'head'), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *golʔwáʔ, from PIE *golH-ueh₂- "[Contrary to what is printed in Derksen 2008:176, a]n etymological connection with Lat. calva 'skull' is formally impossible. Nevertheless, it is tempting to seek a link with these forms, as the same irregular *k : *g correspondence is observed in words for 'bald', where we have Lat. calvus 'bald' and Skt. kulva- 'bald, thin haired' vs. OCS golъ, OHG kalo 'bald'." [No connection given to Armenian lexemes.]}];269[{For proposed cognacy to Armenian lexemes meaning 'head', cf. discussion in the main Balto-Slavic set for 'head' in [cognate set 1142](cog-1142).}]

345[330{S.v. TochB taur '± dust, ashes| rubbish-heap', together with TochA tor from Proto-Tocharian *teurä (as though) from PIE *dʰou(hₓ)-ro- (Ru. dur 'folly', Belorussian dur ~ dura 'giddiness, vertigo'), a derivative of *dʰou(hₓ)- 'move agitatedly'.}]
Comment: Wider connections uncertain

Source: 165[482{S.v. Proto-Germanic *stōra- ~ *stura- adj. 'big', reflecting PIE *stéh₂uro-  ̴ *sth₂uró-, two variants of a heteroclitic adjective PIE nom.sg. *stéh₂-u̯(ō)r, gen.sg. *sth₂-un-ós, root *steh₂- 'to stand' (LIV² 590-92, IEW 1004-8). (Pre-Germanic *stūró- shortened to *stŭro- by Dybo's Law of pretonic shortening). Cf. Skt. sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick, massy', YAv. stūra- 'strong', Oss. styr / (i)stur 'big, great' < *sth₂u-ró-| Skt. sthávira- 'broad, thick' < *steuh₂r-ó- (with laryngeal metathesis)| Skt. sthāvará- 'standing firm, immovable, lasting' < *steh₂-uer-| Arm. stuar 'fat' < *sth₂-ur-o-(?).}];274[637-659{S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.). Ultimately derived from *steh₂- 'stand' from a heteroclitic stem **sth₂-u̯r- > *stuh₂r-, which is found as a thematised o-stem *stuh₂r-ó- in Indo-Iranian (Ved. sthūrá-, etc.) and Germanic. Cf. discussion p.652n75.}];156[III:158-159{S.v. Oss. styr | (æ)stur, (i)stur, (u)stur 'балшьой, великий', from Iranian *stūra- (Pers. suturg 'big', etc.) from PIE *steuro-.}];567[266{Bactrian στοργο (alternative forms αστοργο, στορογο) from *stūra-ka- (cf. MPers. sturg).}];172[II:768-769{S.v. Ved. sthūra- 'groß, stark, dick, wuchtig' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (cf. Old Swedish stūr 'groß', Middle Dutch stūr 'groß, stark').}];442[795{For Nepali, cf. s.v. 13776 sthūlá 'large, thick, stout' AV. [~ sthūrá-].}];697[557-558{S.v. Proto-Germanic *stōra- 'gewichtig', inherited adjective, identical with Lith. stóras 'dick, grob', 'tief, rauh', OCS starъ 'alt', derived from PIE *stā- 'stand', cf. Ved. sthávira- 'breit, dick, derb' and 'alt, angesehen'.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ([NIL](src-274) 639, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):795 no. 13776, [EWAia](src-172) II:768-769, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):266, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:158-159, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):557-558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):482).

Source: 345[639{S.v. TochB wālts- 'crush, grind, agitate, trouble', perhaps from PToch. wäl(t)s- either as a denominative verb *wel(t)sā- from a nominal derivative *wel(t)se from *wäl(t)s- or directly from *wäl(t)s- by analogical extension of the root vowel -ā- regular as the result of ā-umlaut in the subjunctive and/or preterite. Alternatively a Tocharian descendant a putative PIE o-grade ehₐ-iterative-intensive *wolh₂-s-ehₐ from *welh₂- 'strike' (cf. Hitt. walh- 'strike').}];341[872-873{S.v. TochB wālts- 'zerstampfen, mahlen', 'crush, grind', either a denominative or o-grade eh₂-stem based on PIE *(h₂)u̯elh₂- 'strike' (Hitt, walaḫzi), as per Adams DoT, 589.}];389[{Cf. s.v. Neu: *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' (IEW 1144-5) and n1 "Aus semantischen und lautlichen Gründen (anatol. Laryngalschwund) besser von *u̯elh₃- ['sterben'] zu trennen." Formerly merged with *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' in [LIV²](src-141).}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *u̯elh₂- 'hit, strike' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):872-873}, [Adams 2013](src-345):639; for the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 442[220{S.v. 4118 gāḍha 'dived into' Kālid., 'pressed together, thick, firm' MBh. [√gāh]}];172[I:486{Cf. s.v. Ved. √gāh- 'eindringen, eintreten, ins Wasser steigen, hineinwaten' (deriv. ep. + gāḍha- 'fest, dicht' < *'tief eingedrungen'), probably only to Slavic words like Sloven. gáziti 'waten', SCr. gȁziti 'treten, waten' from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾āg̑ʰ- vel sim.}];141[183{Cf. s.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- '(ins Wasser) eindringen, hineinwaten' [IEW 465].}]
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit gāḍha- 'dived into; pressed together, thick, firm' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):220 no. 4118), derived from Vedic √gāh- 'to dive into, bathe in, plunge into; penetrate, enter deeply into' and ultimately to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to go into water, wade into' ([EWAia](src-172) I:486, [LIV²](src-141) 183).

Source: 345[700-701{S.v. TochB ścīre 'hard| harsh (of words), rough, crude', from PToch *scärēn-, (as if) from PIE *sterh₁-eh₁-en-, cf. Gk στερεός 'solid, firm, strong', ONor. starr 'stiff, rigid, solid' OHG starēn 'stare (at)', OPruss. stūrnawiskan 'earnestness', Russ. starátьsja 'exert oneself, strive', etc.}];49[1022{Cf. s.v. *(s)ter-, *(s)terə- : *(s)trē 'starr, steif sein, starrer, fester Gegenstand', etc.}]

353[555{S.v. Old Prussian aglo 'rain'. Traditionally connected with Gk. ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness', which would be reconstructed as *h₂egʰlu-.}];66[184{Cf. s.v. Gk. ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness', which if cognate with OPruss. aglo then from PIE *h₂egʰlu-. An additional possible connection is to Arm. ałǰa-m-ułǰ-kʻ 'darkness' which requires a metathesis of -gʰlu- and subsequent palatalisation *gʰ > ǰ. The reduplication is typical of Armenian.}];79[37-39{S.v. Arm. *ałǰ- 'darkness, fog, twilight' : ałǰ-utʻiwn-kʻ 'darkness', derived  by Meillet from a root *ałǰ- and connected with Gk. ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness' and OPr. aglo 'rain'. Etymology rejected by [HAB](src-740) I:335-336, but the etymology remains very plausible.}]
Justification: Generally further connected to Greek ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness' and Armenian *ałǰ- in ałǰutʻiwnkʻ 'darkness' ([Derksen 2015](src-353):555, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):184, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):37-39 for further discussion).

Source: 165[25{S.v. Proto-Germanic *amsa- 'shoulder' < PIE *h₃ém-so- (cf. Skt. áṃsa- 'shoulder', Oss. wæn, won, on / iwonæ 'shoulderblade', TochA es, TochB āntse 'shoulder', Arm. us 'shoulder', Gk. ὦμος 'shoulder, shoulder with the upper arm' < *h₃em-so-| Lat. umerus 'shoulder' < *h₃em-es-o-).}];338[{fɜšon-tɜ 'back' : from fɜs- 'behind' and on 'shoulderblade'. on goes back to PIr. *anha- (*amha-). Abaev gives Old Indic aṅsa-, Germanic *amsa (Gothic ams 'in umero'), Tocharian B āntse 'shoulder', Greek ὡμός 'id.'.}];156[I:461, II:227-228{S.v. fæson 'спина' & on 'лопатка'.}];66[1679-1680{Cf. s.v. Gk. ὦμος 'shoulder, upper part of the arm'| the forms in most IE branches point back to *h₃ems-o-.}];179[30{S.v. Goth. A139. *ams or *amsa 'ὧμος', 'shoulder', from PIE *omsos 'shoulder' (Skt. áṁsas, Gk. ὧμος, Lat. umerus, Arm us, TochA es, B āntse).}];172[I:37{Cf. s.v. Ved. áṁsa- 'Schulter' (IIr. cf. Oss. on 'Schulterblatt < *anha- [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:227f.), from PIE *Homso-, cf. Goth. amsans (acc.pl) 'die Schultern', TochA es 'Schulter'.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₃ems- 'shoulder, upper part of the arm' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:461, II:227-228, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:37). Cf. Proto-Germanic *amsa- 'shoulder' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):30, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):25), Ancient Greek ὦμος 'shoulder' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1679-1680).

Source: 345[134{S.v. TochB ost 'house', which along with TochA waṣt 'house' reflects Proto-Tocharian *wostŭ. This is clearly cognate with Skt. vāstu 'house, dwelling', vástu 'place, seat, thing' and Gk. (ϝ)ἀστυ 'city'. The reconciling the reconstructed stem for these forms as a derivative of a specific IE root, however, is disputed.}];172[II:549{Cf. s.v. Ved. vā́stu- 'Wohnstätte, Hofstatt, Haus', not to be separated from Gk. ἄστυ 'Stadt' < *u̯astu- (Myc. wa-tu[-o-ko]), TochA waṣt, TochB ost 'Haus'. These words may be united under a reconstruction *u̯āstu- ~ *u̯astu-| the forms are not compatible with an etymology from PIE *h₂u̯es- 'dwell, spend the night'.}];66[158-159{Cf. s.v. Gk. ἄστυ 'town', comparing Ved. vā́stu- 'residence, abode', Messapic vastei (dat.), and TochA waṣt, TochB ost 'house', PIE *u̯eh₂stu- 'town', postulating an ablauting u-stem *ueh₂stu-, *uh₂steu-, which the latter was generalised in Gk. ἄστυ.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes, generally compared with  Vedic vā́stu- 'residence, abode' and Ancient Greek ἄστυ 'town', which may continue a proto-form *u̯ā̆stu- (< *u̯éh₂stu- ~ *uh₂stéu̯-?). Further root etymology unclear. A connection with PIE *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1170-1171, [LIV²](src-141) 293-294) is semantically attractive but uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):134, [EWAia](src-172) II:549, [Beekes 2010](src-66):158-159 for discussion and references to further literature).

Source: 352[1106-1108{Cf. s.v. OLith. tìkras 'wahr, echt, wirklich| eigen, eigentümlich' (BSl. Latv. tikrs 'gut, tauglich, wert', OPr. tickars 'recht' tikrōmien 'die Rechte, die rechte Hand'). Common Baltic adjective, can be related to OLith. tìkti 'sich eignen, passen, gefallen'). Further etymology outside of Baltic unclear. Possibly either to PIE *tekʷ- 'laufen, fließen' LIV² 620f., or to *tek- 'die Hand ausstrecken' LIV² 618f.}];353[465{Cf. s.v. Lith. tìkras 'true, authentic, correct, right, certain' (Latv. tikrs 'good, sound', OPr. tickars 'right'), a derivative of the root found in Lith. tikė́ti 'believe, trust'. Probably to be cognate with OHG dingan, MHG dingen < Proto-Germanic ϸingjan 'to believe' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):542)}];165[542{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic ϸingjan- 'to believe' < *ti-n-k-ié- (cf. Lith. tikė́ti 'to believe').}]
Comment: orig. 'right, true'
Justification: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1106-1108, [Derksen 2015](src-353):465 for further discussion and various proposals.

Source: 345[691-692, 706-707{S.v. TochB śwālyai 'right' (as opposed to left). A fossilized feminine accusative singular of the gerund śwālle ‘suitable for eating’ from śu- 'eat' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.}];141[168{Cf. s.v. *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen' (IEW 400).}]
Justification: According to [Adams 2013](src-345):706-707, a fossilised feminine accusative singular of the gerund śwālle ‘suitable for eating’ fromśu- 'eat' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.

Source: 345[317{S.v. TochB tuk- 'be hidden, hide oneself'.
