Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):662-664, [Adams 2013](src-345):317 for various proposals.

Source: 345[211{S.v. TochB kele 'navel, umbilicus| center', from PIE *kʷolo-, a derivative of *kʷel- 'revolve, turn'.}];141[386-388{Cf. s.v. *kʷelh₁- 'eine Drehung machen, sich umdrehen, sich (um-, zu-)wenden' (IEW 639-640).}];149[126{S.v. B kele 'navel', from CT *kælæ < *kʷælæ < IE *kʷolHo-s, cf. Gk. πόλος 'turning point', OIr. cul 'wagon', cf. also B kokale 'wagon'.}]
Justification: Tocharian lexemes continuing PIE *kʷolh₁-o- 'turning point' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):126, [Adams 2013](src-345):211), a derivative of PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

Source: 345[567, 788{S.v. TochB ysape 'near by, close', a derivative of spe 'nearby, closely' < *(s)h₄upo 'under, below' (cf. Lat. sub 'under', Lat. suppus, '(head) downwards', Arm. hup 'near').}];294[746-751{S.v. *súp 'unten', *súpo 'hinab' (Adverb, lokal| oft mit Akk., Lok.).}]
352[1307-1308{Cf. s.v. OLith. žieždrà 'Sand' (BSl. OPr. sixdo 'Sand'). No certain comparisons outside of Baltic.}]
Justification: Likely to be connected to Old Lithuanian žieždrà 'Sand', but there are difficulties in reconciling the forms to a single Proto-Baltic reconstruction; no certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1307-1308 for further discussion).

Source: 345[151{Cf. s.v. TochB karītsñe* '±wetness' (??). The identification of the meaning 'wetness' is contextual. If the abstract is correctly identified, it would be derived from an adjective of possession *karītstse (i.e. kāri + -tstse). No further etymology given.}];149[87{S.v. B karītsñe (hapax) '?', probably also to an adj. *karītstse*) "In its context one might guess that karītsñe means 'heat', vel sim. but that is quite uncertain […]. Etymological speculation is futile."}]
Justification: Precise semantics uncertain, therefore etymological comparisons remain speculative (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):87, [Adams 2013](src-345):151).

Source: 141[187{S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'hören, tönen' [IEW 478].}];353[178{Cf. s.v. Lith. girdė́ti 'hear', possibly from a PIE zero-grade formation *g⁽ʷ⁾rdʰ- (cf. OLith. gardas 'rumour, prank, messenger', OPr. gerdant [gerdaut] 'say').}];352[331-332{S.v. OLith. girdė́ti 'hören' (BSl. Latv. dzìrdêt), from a univerbation of a PIE collocation or light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- dʰeh₁- 'Kunde geben', cf. Arm. kardam 'rufe', OIr. bard 'Barde', MW bardd 'id.', cf. *gʷer(H)- 'to consent' (LIV² 210f.) and *dʰeh₁- ''to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). See also PIE *gʷerdʰ- 'to hear, to sound' (LIV² 187).}]
Justification: To be derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ([LIV²](src-141) 187); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ([ALEW](src-352) 331-332). Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 210-211.

Source: 338[{Ossetic forms from PIr. *kū-, *kav-, cf. Old Indic kāuti, kavate 'scream'.}];156[I:591{S.v. Oss. kæwyn : kₒyd | kæwun : kud 'плакать', from an Iranian root *kū- *kav-, IE *kū-, *kau- 'кричать, вопить', cf. Skt. kāuti, kavate, OCS kyti, Gk. κωκύω.}];399[I:274{Cf. s.v. Skt. káuti 'schreit / cries'. An onomatopoeic family, cf. κωκύω 'schreie', Lat. cavannus 'Nachteule', W cuan 'id.', MHG hiulen 'heulen', Lith. kaũkti 'heulen', Ru. kúkatь, TochB śauk- 'rufen'.}];49[535-536{Cf. s.v. *kā̆u-, *kē̆u-, *kū- 'heulen' "Schallwurzel, teils mit anlaut k-, teils mit *k̑-."}]
Justification: [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:591 supposes a connection to Sanskrit káuti 'cries'. The Indo-Iranic forms are traditionally connected to a wide range of sound-imitative words from a root *kā̆u-, *kē̆u-, *kū- according to [IEW](src-49) 535-536, but a parallel onomatopoeic origin may well be possible (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:274). [Not in [Cheung 2007](src-83).]
Etymology unclear, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:266-268 for further discussion.
Light verb constructions with parallel loans from Persian نخجیر / naxčīr 'hunt, prey' as the semantic head.

Source: 686[164-165{S.v. OPr. grīmons 'gesungen' (Ptz. II). Belongs to the Baltic group of lexemes including Latvian gremt 'murmeln, im Affekte reden', to be derived from PIE *gʰrem- 'dröhnen, wüten, donnern'.}];141[204{Cf. s.v. *gʰrem- 'dröhnen, wüten' (IEW 458-9).}];83[122{S.v. Proto-Iranic *gram- 'to thunder, roar| to anger', from PIE *gʰrem- 'to roar, be angry' (cf. Goth. gramjan, OHG gremmen 'to become angry', OE gremman 'to scorn', etc., NHG grimm, Engl. grim, Lith. gramù, etc.).}]
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *gʰrem- 'to roar, rage' ([Smoczyński 2005](src-686):164-165, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 204). For non-target Khwarazmian maγmeda in this set, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):122.

Source: 345[64{S.v. TochB ātstse 'thick', which with TochA ātsäts reflects PToch *āts(ä)tse or *āt(ä)tse, but there are no known extra-Tocharian connections.}]
Justification: No known extra-Tocharian connections ([Adams 2013](src-345):64).

Source: 345[517{S.v. TochB mlyuwe* 'thigh', as though from PIE *m(e)lewe/os- from PIE *mel- 'member, joint' (cf. Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body').}];66[927-928{Cf. s.v. Gk. μέλος 'member'. No clear cognates, perhaps to Bret. mell, Co. mal.}];531[386{Cf. s.v. Lith. melmuõ 'krzyż, częśc kręśc kręgosłupa w okolicach miednicy| pachwina', 'cross, part of the spine in the pelvic area| groin', with related form mélmenys 'częśc pleców, która otacza nerki', 'part of the back that surrounds the kidneys'. Without etymology.}];172[II:329{S.v. Ved. márman- 'verwundbare Stelle des Körpers', perhaps originally 'tödliche Stelle' to √mar- [< PIE *mer- 'disappear, die'].}];269[{Etymology dubious. [Adams 2013](src-345):517 connects to a putative PIE *mel- 'member' comparing Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body', but the etymologies of these compared lexemes are all for the most part considered to be unknown or dubious (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):927-928, [EWAia](src-172) II:329, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):386).}]
Justification: Etymology dubious. [Adams 2013](src-345):517 connects to a putative PIE *mel- 'member' comparing Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body', but the etymologies of these compared lexemes are all for the most part considered to be unknown or dubious (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):927-928, [EWAia](src-172) II:329, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):386).

Source: 442[232{S.v. 4336 Ved. gōṣṭhá- m. 'cow-house' RV. [gṓ- , stha-]}];172[I:502, I:478-480, II:764-766{Cf. s.v. Ved. goṣṭhá-, º-ṣṭhā́na- > √sthā-.}]
Justification: Continuing Vedic goṣṭhá- m. 'cow-house', a compound of Vedic gav- 'cow, steer' < PIE *gʷou̯- 'id.', and *steh₂- 'to stand', lit. 'standing place for cows' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):232 no 4336, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:502, I:478-480, II:764-766). This cognate set is coded for *steh₂- 'to stand' (> ºṣṭá- ºṣṭā́(na)- 'standing place').

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron χɜzar 'house' may be a compound of *kata- 'house' (well-attested in Iranian) and car 'roof, ceiling' (South Caucasian loanword). But this is somewhat speculative.}];156[IV:159-161{S.v. Oss. xæʒar | xæʒaræ 'дом, сакля, жилище'. This important cultural word does not yet have a completely certain etymology. (Cf. for further discussion).}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:159-161 for various proposals.

Source: 397[109{Cf. s.v. NHG Bengel 'ungezogener Junge' (MHG bengel 'Knüppel, Stange', MDu. bengel 'Knüppel, Stange', like Schlegel to schlagen this is derived from Low German bangen (cf. NE to bang, ON banga 'klopfen, schlagen').}];388[35{S.v. PGmc. *ƀanʒōjanan wk.vb.: (Icel banga ‘to hammer’ E bang, G dial. bangen ‘to knock’). "If not of imitative origin, probably related to Skt bhanákti ‘to break’, Arm bek ‘broken’, Lith beñgti ‘to finish’").}];757[I:265]
Justification: Continuing a nominal derivative from Proto-Germanic *bangōn- 'to beat, hit', if not onomatopoeic possibly further connected to verbs continuing PIE *bʰ-né/n-g- from *bʰeg- 'to break' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):109, [EWNl](src-757) I:265, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):35, not listed in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 352[1228-1229{Cf. s.v. OLith. vė̃zdas 'Knüppel, Stock| Hebebaum, Hebestange' (BSl. Latv. vȩ̄zda sf., vȩ̄zds sm. 'Stock, Prügel'), similar words are found in the Lithuanian and Latvian dialectal areas, but a clear etymological explanation is lacking. Perhaps a recent borrowing from WRuss. vjaz 'Ulme' according to Smoczyński (2007:745).}];531[745]
Justification: Cf. Lith. vė̃zdas 'stick'. No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 1228-1229), perhaps a loanword from Belarusian vjaz 'elm' according to [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):745.

Source: 338[{Turkic or West Caucasian loan.}];156[I:404{S.v. Oss. ʒykku | ʒikko 'коса женская, локон'| Shtakel'berg considers Turkic čika 'коса'| closer is Ubykh šequ 'волосы на голове'.}]
Justification: Probable loanword, either from Turkic or West Caucasian ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:404).

Source: 352[967{Cf. s.v. OLith. stãbas 'Götzenbild, Götze' (BSl. Latv. stabs 'Pfosten, Pfahl, Säule, Pfeiler', OPr. stabis 'Stein'), from ?IE *stobʰ-ó- 'Erstarren' (cf. Goth. stafs 'Stab| Buchstabe', ON stafr, OHG stab 'id.').}]
Justification: Cf. discussion s.v. Old Lithuanian stãbas 'graven image, idol' < ?*stobʰ-ó-  in [ALEW](src-352) 967. The status of this IE reconstruction remains uncertain, cf. Proto-Germanic *staba- 'stick' in [cognate set 2980](cog-2980) and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):471.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron šš-ən 'grind' is from Iranian *han-sā-, cf. Persian sūdan (prs. stem sāy-) 'rub'.}];83[340-341{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *sauH- 'to rub, wear, whet', which reflects either a rare *u̯a-stem earlier Proto-Iranian *saH- (cf. Skt. śā- 'to sharpen, whet') or the result of contamination of semantically similar roots *dauH- and *skauH-.  Cheung considers the latter possibility more likely.}];156[IV:278{Cf. s.v. yssyn : yssad | insun : insad, inst.}];172[II:627{Cf. s.v. Skt. śā- 'schärfen, wetzen', from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- (cf. Arm. sowr 'sharp', Lat. cōs, cōt- 'Wetzstein', catus 'scharf, scharfsinnig', etc.}];141[319-320{Cf. s.v. *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'schärfen' (IEW 541-2).}];680[120{S.v. Khw. psʾw 'grind', from *pati-sāwa- to √saw-.}]
Justification: Iranian root *sau̯H- 'to rub, wear, whet', either a u-stem derivative of Proto-Iranian *saH- (from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)-, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:627), or a contamination of two semantically similar roots *dauH- and *skauH- (so [Cheung 2007](src-83):340-341); cf. also [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:278, [MacKenzie 1990](src-680):120.

Source: 69[379{connection with Sanskrit pinaṣṭi, piṁṣati is not clear}];442[491{S.v. 8714 *prabhindati, prábhinatti ʻ splits ʼ RV. [√bhid] > N. pĩdhnu, pĩdnu, pinnu 'to grind corn' (infl. in meaning by pisnu < piṁṣáti?)}];172[II:273-274{Cf. s.v. √bhed- 'spalten, zerbrechen, zerschlagen, zerschneiden', from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'spalten, brechen' (Lat. findō 'spalte', OE bītan, NHG beißen', etc.).}];141[70-71{Cf. s.v. *bʰei̯d- 'spalten' (IEW 116-7).}]
Comment: connection with Sanskrit pinaṣṭi, piṁṣati is not clear, cf. [cognate set 6111](cog-6111)
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *prabhindati 'splits' from Vedic √bhid- 'to split; to break, cut (to pieces)', perhaps influenced in its semantics from Sanskrit piṁṣáti, cf. [cognate set 6111](cog-6111) ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):491 no. 8714, cf. [Turner 1931](src-69):379). Further to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ([EWAia](src-172) II:273-274, [LIV²](src-141) 70-71).

Appears to be related to Lithuanian taukaĩ, Latvian tàuki 'fat'. There are, however, enormous difficulties in reconciling this group of related Balto-Slavic lexemes to a PIE proto-form. Cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1081, [Derksen 2008](src-81):499-500, [Derksen 2015](src-353):459-460 for further discussion. A contamination or blend of between two roots *teu̯h₂- ([LIV²](src-141) 639-640) and *teu̯k- ([LIV²](src-141) 641) is a possibility. Cf. also Proto-Germanic *ϸeuha- 'thigh' in [cognate set 6956](cog-6956). The PIE root reference form *teu̯(h₂)k- is provisional only.

Source: 353[308, 543-544{Cf. s.v.  Latv. maût 'submerge, swim', connected with Lith. máuti 'put on, tear, pull, stab, strike, dash', from PIE *mouH- (< *miouH-) cf. Skt. mī́vati 'push, shove', Lat. movēre 'move'.}];141[445-446{Cf. s.v. *mi̯eu̯h₁- '(sich) bewegen' (IEW 743).}];352[621-622{Cf. s.v. OLith. máuti 'aufziehen, anziehen, abstreifen' (BSl. Latv. maût 'anziehen, aufziehen, zäumen| untertauchen, schwimmen', OPr. A.sg. aumūsman 'Abwaschung', OCS myti 'waschen', etc.), from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- '(sich) bewegen' (cf. Ved. mīv- 'schieben, drängen, drücken', YAv. mīuu- 'beseitigen', Lat. moveō, -ēre '(sich) bewegen', OIr. mún 'Urin', TochA miw- 'beben', TochB miw- 'beben, zittern').}]
Justification: Cf. Latvian maût 'to submerge, swim', Lithuanian máuti, further to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself)' ([ALEW](src-352) 621-622, [Derksen 2015](src-353):308, 543-544, [LIV²](src-141) 445-446).

Source: 345[81-82{S.v. TochB eṅk- 'take, grip, seize| conclude| understand', which with TochA eṃts- goes back to PIE *h₁nek̑- (possibly *h₂nek̑-).}];341[538-539{S.v. TochB eṅk-, TochA eṃts- 'ergreifen, annehmen, halten, begreifen', 'seize, take, understand', from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen' (cf. LIV² 250f.).}];141[250-251{S.v. *h₁nek̑- 'erhalten, nehmen' (IEW 316-8).}]
Justification: Derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'take, obtain' ([LIV²](src-141) 250-251, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):538-539, [Adams 2013](src-345):81-82).
Loan from Russian лытка 'leg, calf, shin, thigh, heel'.

Unclear, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534):298 for older hypotheses and [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):600 s.v. Lith. stel̃bti. (Not in [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353), [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360)).

Source: 338[{The origin of the Ossetic lexemes is unclear.  Abaev proposes *bin + *če(r), for former cf. German Biene 'bee'| for latter, Georgian cʼeri 'fly', but then he gives Slavic bǐčela as "composed of the same elements". Not convincing.}];156[I:280]
Justification: Etymology uncertain (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.; cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:280 for an earlier, unconvincing proposal).

Source: 534[I:223{S.v. Latv. doma 'thought, idea', a loanword from Old Russian дума. Also borrowed was the verb domāt 'to think' < Old Russian думать.}]
Justification: Loanword from Old Russian думать 'to think' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:223).

Source: 156[I:387-388{S.v. ʒag | iʒag 'полный', goes back to *vi-čak-. for *čak: Khwaresmian cāk 'full', Persian čāq, čāǧ 'full, healthy'.}];764[213{S.v. Khw. cʾk 'voll' [= Prs. čāq, Pšt. čāγ, waxī çak 'id.'].}]
Justification: Lexemes based on an Iranic root čak- ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156):I:387-388, cf. [Benzing 1983](src-764):213).

Source: 338[{loan from E. Caucasian}]
Justification: Loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

Source: 338[{Loan from Turkic.}];156[II:278{S.v. Oss. qæbær 'твердый, жесткий, сильный', probably from Turkic qabar, qapar- 'выпуклый, опухоль, мозоль'.}]
Justification: Probably a loan from Turkic qabar, qapar- 'bulging, swelling' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:278).

Source: 338[{*ham- + *bæxs-. Root may be from *barg-s-, which may be related to Avestan barəg- 'receive'.}];156[I:138{S.v. Oss. æmbæxsyn : æmbæxst | æmbæxsun : æmbæxst}]
345[804{Cf. s.v. TochB tsäm- 'grow' < PIE *demh₂- 'build'.}];341[984-987{Cf. s.v. TochB tsäm-, TochA tsäm- 'grow, increase, come into being', from PIE *demh₂- '(zusammen)fügen, bauen'.}]
Justification: A derivative of Tocharian tsäm- 'to grow', in turn derived from PIE *demh₂- 'to build' (cf. ref Adams 2013}:804, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):984-987).

Source: 338[{*war-āka, from *war 'crookedness, bend'. No good Iranian cognates, but many "European" ones (e.g. Latin vārus 'crooked-legged').  But I find the lack of Iranian cognates suspicious, and I am not sure about the phonetic correspondences. There are some similar E. Caucasian (Nakh) terms, which have been interpreted by Abaev as loanwords from Ossetic (Alan). But it is not inconceivable that the direction is opposite.}];156[IV:88-89{S.v. Oss. wærag 'колено', from *warāka- or *war- 'bend' (cf. Lith. rankà (< wra-n-ka-) 'leg', OCS raka).}]
Justification: [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:88-89 interprets the Ossetic lexemes as from a *warāka- to a root *war- 'bent', although good correspondences within Iranic are lacking; there are similar East Caucasian terms which Abaev interprets as loanwords from Alanic (cf. Bats varang 'shoulder', Ingush voruv, Chechen vare 'thigh'), but it is possible the loans occurred in the opposite direction (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

Source: 338[{Nursery word.}];156[I:397{S.v. Oss. ʒiʒa (1) 'мясо' similar to a group of 'child' words for 'meat' in the Caucasian languages, cf. Gruz. čičia, Svan. ʒiʒil, Chech., Ing. žižig.}]
Justification: Similar to nursery words for 'meat' in Caucasian languages, cf. Gruz. čičia, Svan. ʒiʒil, Chech., Ing. žižig ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:397).

Source: 338[{Ossetic kʼɜˈzɜχ is of unclear origin| the first part kʼɜ(j) is most likely a loanword.}];156[I:623]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156):623 who tentatively suggests maybe originally compound k'æj-zæx 'stone-earth'.

Source: 345[70{S.v. TochB iprer 'sky, air, atmosphere', presumably reflecting zero-grade *m̥bʰ-ro- (cf. Ved. abhrá- 'cloud', Lat. imber 'rain', etc.) from PIE *nebʰ-.}];274[503{Cf. s.v. *nebʰ- 'feucht, bevölkt, dunstig (werden) (LIV 448, IEW 315f., EIEC 110, 477). See under n21 to *n̥bʰ-ro-, the connection of TochA eprer 'Atmosphäre, Himmel, Firmament' and TochB iprer is also to be connected to this preform is disputed. Van Windekens (II.1 66) alternatively suggests a connection to TochA prār, B prāri* NPl.f. 'Finger' to be connected with Gk. πείρω 'durchbohren, -stechen, -dringen', according to which would be a proto-form *per-o/ēr with an intensive prefix i-/e- added.}];76[II.1:66]
Justification: Connected to PIE *nebʰ- by [van Windekens 1976](src-76) and [Adams 2013](src-345):70, but this etymology remains uncertain; cf. [NIL](src-274) 503n21 for further discussion.

Source: 338[{Loan from E. Caucasian.  The phonological correspondence between Iron and Digor forms is irregular, but the borrowing is probably Proto-Ossetic.}];156[I:408-409{S.v. Oss. ʒyx | ʒux, c'ux. Has close parallels to Caucasian languages, cf. Veynakh. z'ok, ʒok, Balk. ǯux, Abkh. a-č'ǝ, Ubykh č̣ɛ, Abadz. že, Kab. žeh.}]
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:408-409).

Source: 338[{Probably onomatopoeic.}]
338[{Nursery word (the other term gəcːəl is the same).}];156[I:614{S.v. Oss. ḱysyl 'маленький', 'мало', 'немного'. A nursery word.}]
Justification: Generally considered a nursery word (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:614).

Source: 338[{probably related to Sogdian *frāxš- (βrʼxš) 'shoot (from bow)'. May be related to Avestan vaxš- 'throw'.}];156[I:221-222]
338[{Ossetic Digor sor 'dry' is probably a South Caucasian loanword. This word also exists in Iron, but is not the Swadesh term.}]
Justification: Probably a loanword from South Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.)

Source: 338[{Ossetic Digor æfsnajun 'hide': *æf‑ + *snā‑. Only in Digor, but same root as Iron 'wash' cf. [cognate set 3079](cog-3079).}];83[348-349{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *snaH- 'to wash, swim' (> NEIr. (+ *apa-, *abi- ?) Oss. I. æfsnajyn/æfsnad, D. æfsnajun/æfsnad ‘to clean up’), from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to wash, swim' (cf. Skt. snā- 'to bathe, to wash', Lat. nāre 'to swim', OIr. snaid, -sná 'swims', TochB näsk- 'to bathe').}];156[I:111-112{S.v. Oss. æfsnajyn : æfsnajd | æfsnajun : æfsnajd| from Ir. *apa- or *abi- + *snā-.}]
Justification: From Proto-Iranic *abi- or *apa- + *snaH- 'to wash, swim', via an intermediate meaning 'to clean up', further to PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:111-112, [Cheung 2007](src-83):348-349, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 572-573).

Source: 156[III:351{S.v. t’af(f)æ 'лист'. West Caucasian loanword (cf. Kabardian tẖapä, Adyghe tẖap 'leaf').}]
Justification: West Caucasian loanword, cf. Kabardian tẖapä, Adyghe tẖap 'leaf' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:351).

Source: 165[207{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ham(m)ō- 'shank', from PIE *konh₂-m-éh₂-.}]

442[699{S.v. 12073 Ved. vr̥ddhá- 'grown, large' RV., 'grown-up, old' TS. [√vr̥dh- 2].}];172[II:520-521{Cf. s.v. Ved. √vardh- 'wachsen lassen, mehren', connected with Avestan vərəzda- 'vermehrt, zugewachsen, groß'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are difficult. Sandhi evidence argues for a laryngeal in initial position, for Proto-Indo-Iranian.}];141[228{Cf. s.v. ?*Hu̯eRdʰ- 'groß/stark werden' (IEW 1167). No certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic.}]
Justification: Middle Indic lexemes from Vedic vr̥ddhá- 'grown, large', a derivative to Vedic √vardh- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):699, no.12073), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are difficult (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:520-521; [LIV²](src-141) 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

Source: 338[{Digor isolate. Origin unclear. Possible from *kal-s- with initial voicing. Then related to kalun 'pour, throw', cf. Persian kāštan, Av. kar- 'sow, plough'.}];156[I:512]

320[437{S.v. syandaa- 'of the left side', from Iranian *sai- 'be unfavourable' > 'left-side' (cf. Gk. σκαιός, Lat. scaeuus).}];66[1339{Cf. s.v. Gk. σκαιός 1 'left, western', from PIE *skeh₂-i-uo- which is formally and semantically identical with Lat. scaeuus 'left, inauspicious'| possibly identical with σκαιός 2 'shady' (cf. σκία 'shadow' [cognate set 5058](cog-5058)).}]
Justification: According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):437 to be connected with Ancient Greek σκαιός 'left, western', Latin scaeuus 'left, inauspicious' < as though from *skeh₂-i-uo- 'shaded; left' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1339, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):541-542). For further discussion regarding the root reconstruction cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058).

Source: 544[8{"Toch. A śaru / B śerwe 'hunter' may be taken as reflecting *k̑ēru̯o-, a vr̥ddhi derivative ('he of the stag' or the like), of *k̑eru̯o- 'stag' (as in L. ceruos […]." Cf. also n18 "The etymology given by Pedersen (Tocharisch, 48), who identifies this root as that of χαίρω, etc., and offers Skt. lubdha- 'hunter' as a semantic parallel, is not satisfactory. The g̑hēr-u̯o- it requires would have to be a deverbative adjective in -u̯o-, a formation in which a lengthened-grade root is out of place." This analysis is credited to Jasanoff.}];345[694-695{S.v. TochB śer- 'hunt', attested once. A denominative verb (as if) from PIE *gʷʰēru̯e-i̯e/o-, from śerwe, 'hunter'. S.v. TochB śerwe 'hunter' Adams considers the lexeme with TochA śaru to reflect PToch *ćerwe, but extra Tocharian connections are uncertain, but favours an analysis from PIE *g̑ʰu̯ēr- (or *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r-) 'wild animal' + -u̯o- (cf. Lat. ferus 'wild', Lith. žvė́ris 'wild beast', Gk. θήρ 'wild animal'). Alternative proposals include a connection with Oss. sorun/sūryn 'hunt', Khot. hasūra- 'quarry' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):474, followed by Pinault and Cheung) from Proto-Iranian *ćarw- 'hunt', and loaned from an Iranian language into Tocharian, although if it were a borrowing it would have to be early, before the depalatalisation and deaffrication of Proto-Iranian *ć. Adams considers less likely the derivations from PIE *gʷēru̯o- (cf. Lat. verū 'dart, javelin', Goth. qairu), or [Nussbaum 1986](src-544):8 who derives from *k̑ēru̯-o- 'he of the stag' from *k̑(e)r(e)u- 'horn'. Cf. entry in Adams for references to further literature in full.}];695[11{Accepts the analysis of Jasanoff apud [Nussbaum 1986](src-544):8 of TB śeruweṃ (obl.sg.), nom *śeruwe < PT *śerwë < PIE *k̑ēruos (vr̥ddhi formation to *k̑erwos 'stag', Lat. cervos).}];269[{Denominative verb to TochB śerwe 'hunter', further etymology disputed. A popular analysis (Jasanoff apud [Nussbaum 1986](src-544):8, followed by [Ringe 1996](src-695)) considers TochB śerwe to a vr̥ddhi formation from PIE *k̑er-u̯o- 'stag' (*k̑er-, cf. 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457), 'head' in [cognate set 53](cog-53)), but other analyses are possible (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):694-695). Proto-Tocharian root ref. form *śerwë follows Ringe (1996:11).}]
Justification: Denominative verb to TochB śerwe 'hunter', further etymology disputed. A popular analysis (Jasanoff apud [Nussbaum 1986](src-544):8, followed by [Ringe 1996](src-695)) considers TochB śerwe to a vr̥ddhi formation from PIE *k̑er-u̯o- 'stag' (*k̑er-, cf. 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457), 'head' in [cognate set 53](cog-53)), but other analyses are possible (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):694-695). Proto-Tocharian root ref. form *śerwë follows Ringe (1996:11).

Source: 431[{S.v. ṭâkʹoa-  [ṭâkʹavoa-]  VT.  Conceal, hide.  [ṭâka-ov-]  [optionally with directional pointer] cf. ṭâkʹa-  [[no causative| cf. ṭâkʹoa- ʹconcealʹ]]  VI.  Be stuck| be bound.  [ṭâka-V]  [OIA. *ṭakk- ‘remain| stop’  T. 5420.1 (+)]}];442[300{S.v. 5420 *ṭakk- (1) 'remain, stop'. 2. *ṭikk- . 3. *ṭēkk- usu. tr. [Cf. *ḍakk- 3, *ṭhēkk-]}]
Justification: According to [Strand 1998](src-431), to be connected with Old Indic *ṭakk- (1) 'remain, stop' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):300 no. 5420).
Strand (4/14/20): = “down go”; < Nur. *vü < *üva < PIE *upo?

Source: 442[698{S.v. 12064 Skt. vr̥kká- m. du. 'kidneys' AV., vŕ̊kya- TS., vr̥kkā- f. 'heart' lex. 2. *vrakka- . 3. bukka- 1 n. 'heart'.}];172[II:571-572{Cf. s.v. Ved. vr̥kká- 'Nieren', from IIr. *u̯r̥t-ka- (cf. variant form *vŕ̥tya-) and probably to √vart- ('kidney' ~ 'round').}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vr̥kká- 'kidney', apparently a semantic development from 'kidneys' > 'heart' > 'chest' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):698, no. 12064). Possibly further to Vedic √vart- 'turn, roll' < PIE *u̯ert- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:571-572).
Parallel loans from Persian سينه sīneh 'chest'.

Source: 345[238-239{S.v. TochB klāy- 'fall', while clearly related to TochA klā(w)- 'id.' extra-Tocharian cognates are very uncertain.}];341[619-620{S.v. TochB klāy- 'fallen', 'fall', TochA klāw- 'fallen', 'fall'. The different root finals of TB -w and TA -y are best explained by setting up PToch *klāw’ā- with a palatal *w’ > TochB y by regular sound change. Two possible root etymologies, to PIE *kleu̯h₂- (so Hilmarsson, cf. LIV² 365 *kleu̯H- 'wohin geraten'), alternatively PToch *klāw’ā- could be derived from pre-PToch *klou̯Pi̯ā-, derived from PIE *kleu̯b- 'stolpern, hüpfen' (LIV² 364).}];149[147-148{S.v. B klāy- 'to fall'.}]
Justification: Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):147-148, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):619-620, [Adams 2013](src-345):238-239 for various proposals.

Source: 345[483-484{S.v. TochB mäk- 'run', probably not from PIE *meuk- 'slip away (from)' as usually supposed (cf. [van Windekens 1976](src-76))| [Malzahn & Peters 2010](src-648) suggest a relationship with Greek μάχομαι 'fight' < *megʰh₂-, but the meanings are divergent (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):917 who considers μάχομαι to be possibly Pre-Greek).}];648[265-268];66[917]
Justification: Etymology unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):483-484); [Malzahn & Peters 2010](src-648) suggest a relationship with Greek μάχομαι 'fight' < *megʰh₂-, but the meanings are divergent and the etymology of μάχομαι remains disputed (cf. 'fight' [cognate set 4897](cog-4897)).

Cf. Standard German hauen 'to chop, hit', continuing Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop' and further to PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to hit, split' via metathesised *keuh₂- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):218, [Seebold 1970](src-556):251, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 345-346).

Source: 397[891{Cf. s.v. NHG Strick (MHG stric, stricken, OHG stric, stri(c)k, stricken, MLG strik, MDu. stric) (also NHG stricken), cf. OE strician 'stricken, Netze ausbessern', probably to Lat. stringere in the meaning 'schnüren, zusammenbinden'.}];141[603-604{Cf. s.v. *strei̯g- 'streichen' (IEW 1028).}]
Justification: Probably to be connected with Latin stringere 'to bind fast, tighten' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):891, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 603-604).

Source: 345[529-531{S.v. TochB yām- 'to do, commit, make, handle act| treat as'. Etymology uncertain.}];341[787-789{S.v. TochB yām- 'machen', 'do', TochA yām- 'id.', from *√i̯em- according to Adams DoT¹ 492, Peters 2004 [FsRasmussen] 429ff.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):787-789, [Adams 2013](src-345):529-531 for further discussion.

Source: 345[675{S.v. TochB śakāto* 'stick, club'. Etymology unknown| previous proposals to *sek- 'cut' unlikely because it requires the assumption of expected **ṣ to ś under the influence of a following -k-.}]
Justification: No known etymology ([Adams 2013](src-345):675).

Source: 345[230{S.v. TochB krāñi(ye)* '(nape of the) neck', which is an exact match to Gk. κρανίον 'top of the head' < *k̑rh₂sníi̯om. The base stem is *k̑rh₂sn- (cf. Skt. śīrṣ(a)n- and Gk. κρα(h)ατ-).}];269[{For *k̑er- as the basic root, cf. 'head' in [cognate set 53](cog-53) and 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457).}];149[175{S.v. TochB krāñi 'neck, nape (of the neck)', probably reflecting CT *krāñ-äy- < *krāñ-än-, ultimately (as though) reflecting PIE *k̑r̥h₂-n-en-, an n-stem formation to *k̑r̥h₂-n- to the root of *k̑er-h₂- 'head'.}]
Justification: Generally agreed to continue a derived n-stem to PIE *k̑er-h₂- 'head' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):175, [Adams 2013](src-345):230). For further etymological discussion regarding the basic root *k̂er- cf. 'head' in [cognate set 53](cog-53) and 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457).

Source: 345[243-244, 248{S.v. TochB klutk- 'to turn, become', klautk- 'to turn, return, become'| to be derived from PIE *kʷel- 'turn'.}];341[626-628{S.v. TochB klutk- 'sich umdrehen, werden', 'to turn, become', TochA lutk- 'werden lassen, machen zu', 'to turn, make into', to be derived from Proto-Tocharian *kläwtk- based on the assumption that TA l- is due to dissimilatory loss of initial *k-. Generally further derived from a u-extension of PIE *kʷelh₁- 'turn' (cf. LIV² 387ff. without this root), from which we should expect a stem *kluh₁-T-sk̑- which possibly was to turn into PToch *kl’äwtk-.}]
Justification: Probably to be derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):626-628, [Adams 2013](src-345):626-628, with references to further literature), but not fully certain (Ron Kim, p.c.).

Source: 269[{From PGmc. *uber- 'over' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):557) + *geban- 'to give'. For the problems in the reconstruction of the root underlying PGmc. *geban- < PIE *gʰebʰ-, cf. 'give' in [cognate set 228](cog-228).}]
Justification: From PGmc. *uber- 'over' + *geban- 'to give'. For the problems of the IE root reconstruction, cf. 'give' in [cognate set 228](cog-228).

Source: 592[71{Argues for an etymology from *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'sting' rather than *denk̑- 'bite' [cognate set 1456](cog-1456), as frequently proposed elsewhere.}];141[117-118, 142{Cf. s.v. *denk̑- 'beißen' (IEW 201) and *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'hineinstecken, stechen' (IEW 243-244). According to the Tocharian evidence *Η should be either *h₂ or *h₃ (cf. n1).}];341[975-976{S.v. Tocharian AB tsāk- 'to pierce, bite', belonging either with Gk. δάκνω  or PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷʰ- 'hineinstecken, stechen'.}];345[800{S.v. TochB ²tsāk- 'pierce, bite (of a snake)'. Etymology uncertain. Generally either to PIE *denk̑- or *deihₓgʷ-.}]
Justification: These Tocharian lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 142, [Ringe 1988-1990](src-592):71), although are sometimes considered derivatives of *denk̑- 'to bite'. Cf. also [Malzahn 2010](src-341):975-976, [Adams 2013](src-345):800.

Source: 156[II:400-401{Cf. s.v. Oss. rdū | ærdo 'волос, волосинка, шерстинка', from Proto-Iranian *drau̯- with metathesis of dr → rd.}];320[170{S.v. Khot. dro 'hair', from *dravu- (cf. Yaghn. dirau, BSogd. ẓ̌wy, Oss. D. ārdo, I. ärdu, Orm. drī, Nūristānī Aškun dro).}];269[{Sometimes connected in older literature (cf. IEW 276) to Gk. θρίξ, τριχός via root IE *dʰreu̯- with alternative root extensions *dʰr-ei̯-gʰ-, *dʰr-ei̯-kʰ-, however these theories of root morphology are now outdated and we can only securely postulate an Indo-Iranian etymon.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Indo-Iranic *drau̯- ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:400-401, [Bailey 1979](src-320):170). Further etymology uncertain, conjecturally connected in older literature (cf. [IEW](src-49) 276) to Gk. θρίξ, τριχός via root IE *dʰreu̯- with the assumption of root extensions *dʰr-ei̯-gʰ-, *dʰr-ei̯-kʰ-.

Source: 165[328, 342{S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'roof, air', a *-tu- stem related to *lauba- 'leaf, foliage'. No clear IE etymology.}];179[237{Cf. s.v. Goth. L58. *luftus 'ἀήρ', 'air'. Etymology unclear.}];398[1488-1491{S.v. OHG luft 'Luft, Luftraum, Atmospäre, Äther, Himmel, Lufthauch', from Proto-Germanic *luftu-, with no correspondences in the other IE languages.}];397[586{Cf. s.v. NHG Luft (MHG, OHG luft), from Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'Luft' (cf. Goth. luftus, OE lyft). Provenance unclear.}]

50[185{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kaleto- 'hard, cruel, strong', from PIE *k̑lH-eto- 'cold', cf. Av. sarəta- 'cold', Lith. šálti 'be cold, freeze', OE haeled 'hero'. If this etymology is correct then the semantic development would have been 'cold, frozen' > 'hard'.}];141[323{Cf. s.v. *k̑elH- 'kalt werden, frieren' (IEW 551).}];274[416-417{S.v. *k̑elH ‘kalt werden, frieren’ (LIV 323, IEW 551)}]
Justification: Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to become cold, freeze' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):185, cf. [NIL](src-274) 416-417, [LIV²](src-141) 323).

Source: 172[I:314-315{S.v. Ved. kárṇa- 'Ohr', cf. YAv. karəna-, Khot. kārra- from Proto-Indo-Iranian *kárna- 'ear'. Etymological connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not securely determined.}];442[143-144{S.v. 2830 Ved. kárṇa- m. 'ear, handle of a vessel' RV.}]
Justification: This class encodes Proto-Indo-Iranic *kárna- 'ear'. The Khowar and Kalaṣa-alâ lexemes represent light verb constructions. Cf. 'ear' in [cognate set 768](cog-768) for further etymological discussion/

Source: 442[310{Cf. s.v. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'.}]
Justification: Cf. s.v. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):310 no. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'.

Source: 236[{S.v. W fflio, loanword from English '(to) fly'.}]
Justification: Loanword from English '(to) fly' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 236[{S.v. W bogail, bogel 'navel, umbilicus, belly button'.}];309[99{S.v. Bret. begel 'cordon ombilical, zeste (de noix)', from Old Breton becel, of uncertain origin. Corresponds to Cornish begel, Welsh bogail.}]
Justification: A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):99, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 50[62, 214{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-o- 'bring together', cf. Proto-Celtic *ber-o- 'carry' from PIE *bʰer-.}];141[76-77{Cf. s.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).}];236[{S.v. cymeraf: cymryd, cymrud, cymeryd 'to take, seize, take possession of', from Celtic *kom-ber- to PIE *bʰer- 'carry' (cf. Lat. ferō, etc.).}];309[382-383{S.v. Bret. kemer 'prise', from Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-o-.}];304[218-223{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ber-e/o- 'tragen, bringen' < PIE *bʰer-, cf. composita with preverb *kom-.}]
Justification: Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-e/o- 'bring together', whose basic verbal root *ber- continues PIE *bʰer- 'to carry, bring' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):218-223, [Matasović 2009](src-50):214, 62, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Deshayes 2003](src-309):382-383).

Source: 341[892{S.v. TochA wärs- 'atmen', 'breathe', a hapax with the same root as TochA wraseṃ 'breath' and TochA wrasom 'being'.}];141[685-686{Cf. s.v. 3. *u̯er- 'beobachten, wahrnehmen' (IEW 1164), under which ?*u̯r̥-sk̑é- > TochB warṣṣäṃ A wräṣ 'riecht (intr.).}]
Justification: Tocharian A wräṣ 'breathe', a derivative of PIE 3. u̯er- 'to observe, perceive' ([LIV²](src-141) 685-686, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):892).

Source: 341[892-893{S.v. TochA wäl- 'sterben', 'die', either from PIE *u̯elh₃- 'be killed (in battle)' or *welH-/*gʷelH- 'die'.}]
Justification: Root etymology uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):892-893 for further discussion.

Source: 377[90{Cf. s.v. ipalāt(i)- 'sinisterness'.}];368[254{Connected to Proto-Anatolian *g(e)ib- 'left' > CLuw. ip- > ipala/i- adj. 'left(-hand)', HLuw. i-pa-ma/i- 'west', CLuw. iparwašša/i- 'western', ipattarma- 'west'.  Follows the etymology given by Starke (1990:504ff.).}];373[504-509{Connects the complex of Luwian words from ip- to PIE *gei̯bʰ- 'biegen' (IEW 354), Lat. gibber 'humpbacked', Lith. geibùs 'frail'.}]
Justification: Generally connected to PIE *gei̯bʰ- 'bend' ([IEW](src-49) 354, cf. Lat. gibber 'humpbacked', Lith. geibùs 'frail') after [Starke 1990](src-373):504-509; etymology followed by [Melchert 1994](src-368):254.

Source: 686[205{Cf. s.v. OPr. krūt (inf.) 'fallen'.}];352[368, 521-522{Cf. s.v. Lith. griū́ti 'einstürzen, zusammenbrechen| sich stürzen' and s.v. Lith. kráuti 'laden, zusammentragen, aufeinanderschichten, bewahren, behüten'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):205, [ALEW](src-352) 368, 521-522 for further discussion.

Source: 147[168{[No etymology given.]}];76[225-226{S.v. A kñuk 'cou, nuque' For this term we may connect either IE *gneug- with OIc. knjūkr 'cime d'une montagne', MHG knock 'nuque' or with IE *qnequ̯- with OE hnecca, OIc. hnakki 'nuque', or with IE *qneug- with OIc. hnūka 'se tenir accroupi, s'accroupir', Mod. Ic. knjūkr 'cime de montagne ronde', etc.For these three interpretations cf. Van Windekens, Orbis 11 (1962) 506. In any of these cases TochA kñuk may have a common etymon with Germanic.}];165[234-235{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck'. "In view of the close formal and semantic similarities to To. kñuk, it seems possible to reconstruct a PIE n-stem *knék-ōn, gen. kn̥k-n-ós, acc. *knok-n-ń̥s (cf. Kroonen 2011:167ff.). The regular outcome of this paradigm, viz. *hnehō, *hunkkaz, *hnakkuns was apparently remodelled into *hnekkō, *knukkaz, *hnakkuns. […] [I]t is possible that G Hunke 'hillock' is a vestige of the original genitive form. It is therefore likely that OIr. cnoc, W cnwch m. 'hill' was borrowed from Germanic rather than the other way around."}];149[162-163{S.v. A kñuk 'neck'. Two early propsals to either OIc. knjúkr 'round mountain summit', MHG knock 'neck' < *gneugo- (van Windekens 1941: 42), or to IE *kneugo-, cf. OIc. hnjúkr 'rounded mountain summit' (Duchesne-Guillemin 1941: 157) are semantically satisfactory. Pedersen's (1944: 29) connection to OE hnekka- 'neck', OIc. hnakki 'id.' is semantically more satisfactory but there is no evidence in Germanic for a *-kw-. "This proposal might therefore be rejected as well. Instead the following might be considered. Assuming A kñuk, through *kñäkw, reflects CT *kñäkwæ, this word may go back to IE *knigʷʰo- 'neck (lit. 'the one that bows or bends')' to the root *kneigʷʰ- 'to bow', cf. Goth. hneiwan 'to bow', OHG hnīgan 'to bow, bend', OIcel. hníga 'to sink down', hneigja 'to bow' etc."}]
Justification: Perhaps cognate with Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- 'neck', although there remains some uncertainty over formal aspects of the etymology ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):162-163, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):234-235), [van Windekens 1976](src-76):225-226).

Source: 50[334{S.v. Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff' (cf. MIr. sond 'stake, beam, palisade'), from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' (cf. Lat. sponda 'bedstead, bed', OE spōn 'sliver, shaving', Gk. σφήν 'wedge'). An alternative etymology derives PCelt. *sfondo- and Lat. sponda from PIE *(s)pend- 'to spin' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):582), but the semantics of this comparison are less appealing.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):334).

Source: 236[{S.v. W botwm 'button', a loanword from Middle English botoun 'button'.}]
Justification: This set is coded for the Welsh botwm 'button' a loan from Middle English botoun 'button' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)). NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.

Source: 236[{S.v. W hitiaf (1): hitio, a loanword from English '(to) hit'.}]
Justification: Loanword from English '(to) hit' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 50[180{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kʷokʷ-o- 'cook, bake', from PIE *pekʷ-. The Welsh forms come from a passive participle form PIE *pokʷto- > *kʷokʷto- (distance assimilation *p … *kʷ > *kʷ … *kʷ) > Proto-Celtic *kʷoxto-.}];141[468{Cf. s.v. *pekʷ- 'reif machen, gar machen' (IEW 798).}];442[430{S.v. 7641 Skt. *pakṣya- (2) 'hot' [√pac-].}];172[II:46{Cf. s.v. Ved. √pac- 'kochen, braten', from PIE *pekʷ- (cf. OCS pekǫ 'backe, brate', Lat. coquō 'koche', Gk. πέσσω, etc.).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to become ripe; to cook' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):430 no. 7641, [EWAia](src-172) II:46, [Matasović 2009](src-50):180, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 468).

Source: 309[199{S.v. Bret. douss 'doux', a borrowing from Old French dous, ultimately from Lat. dulcem.}]
Justification: Loan from Old French dous ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):199).
Derviative within Breton to Middle Breton czucr, a loan from Old French çucre 'sweet'.

Source: 309[689{S.v. Bret. stank 'étang, lavoir', a borrowing from Old French estanc (< Lat. stagnum).}]
Justification: Borrowing from Old French estanc 'pond', itself ultimately from Latin stagnum 'body of standing water, pond, pool, fen, etc.' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):689).

Source: 309[639{S.v. Bret. sabl 'sable de carrière', a loanword from French attested at the end of the 11th century, itself ultimately from Lat. sabulum.}]
Justification: A loan from Old French ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):639).

Source: 309[666{S.v. Bret. sko 'frappe, heurt', from Old Breton sco, further origins obscure.}]
Justification: From Old Breton sco 'stroke, blow', further etymology obscure ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):666).

Source: 345[691, 706{Cf. s.v. TochB śwāl* 'food', from TochB śu- 'eat', cf. TochA śwāl 'meat'. Cf. also s.v. TochB śu- 'eat (at)| consume, devour', where TochA & TochB śuwa- reflect Proto-Tocharian *ćäuwā- from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂- (cf. Pers. jāvīdan, OCS žьvati 'to chew', Lith. žiáunos (f.pl.) 'jaws', OEng. cēowan (> Engl. chew)).}];141[168{Cf. s.v. *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen' (IEW 400).}]
Justification: Generally derived to PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ([Adams 2013](src-345):691, 706, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 168).

Source: 236[{S.v. W miniog 'sharp' < min + -iog, cf. s.v. W min 'lip, mouth| margin, side, bank| margin, border, edge', cf. MCo. myn, MBret. min, ?MIr. men 'mouth'?.}];309[512{S.v. Bret. min 'mine, minois' corresponding to Co. myn 'bouche, museau| bord, rive', W min 'lèvre, bouche| marge, côté', Ir. meàn 'bouche', derived from Proto-Celtic *mikna- 'bouche'.}]

Justification: A word with uncertain further connections outside of Brythonic (cf. Middle Breton lencquernenn, Late Breton lenkernenn). [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) suggests doubtfully perhaps to PIE *slenk- at the root of Old High German slango 'snake' (cf. [cognate set 302](cog-302)).

Source: 309[243{S.v. Bret. flour (adj. qual.) 'doux', a borrowing from Old French flor 'fleur| choix, élite', ultimately from Lat. florem.}]
Justification: Loanword from Old French flor 'flower; choice, elite' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):243).

Source: 309[582{S.v. Bret. plac'h 'fille', from Lat. pallaca via popular Latin *placca.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin pallaca (Late Latin *placca) 'concubine; girl' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):582).

Source: 236[{Cf. s.v. W tyrchaf, tyrchiaf: tyrchu, tyrchio 'to burrow, dig (up)| root up (of pigs, &c.), nuzzle| rummage, delve| also fig.', a denominal formation to W twrch 'hog, (wild) boar| mole', from IE ?*tu̯ork̑os, cf. Av. θβərəsa-.}];50[395{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tworko- 'boar' (OIr. torc, MW twrch 'young pig, boar'), from PIE *tu̯ork̑o- 'cutter, boar' (cf. Av. θβərəsa- 'piglet', perh. Gk. σάρξ 'flesh').}];657[425{Cf. s.v. PIG ?*tu̯ork̑ós 'boar' (OIr. torc 'boar', Av. θβərəsa- 'boar', a derivative to PIE *tu̯erk̑- 'cut' (cf. Gk. σάρξ 'flesh' < *tu̯r̥k̑s 'that which is cut off').}];141[656{Cf. s.v. *tu̯erk̑- 'schnitzen, zurechtschneiden' (IEW 1102).}]
Justification: A denominal formation to Welsh twrch 'hog, (wild) boar; mole' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)), further to Proto-Celtic *tworko- 'boar' from PIE *tu̯ork̑-o- 'cutter, boar', a derivative to PIE *tu̯erk̑- 'to cut' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):395, [EIEC](src-657) 425, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 656).

Source: 373[313-316{Considers CLuw. u̯inal- 'Stock, Stab, Stange' a derivative of PIE *gʷʰen- 'beat'.}];377[269{Follows the etymology proposed by Starke (1990:313-316).}]
Justification: Probably to be derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'beat' ([Starke 1990](src-373):313-316, [Melchert 1993a](src-377):269).

Source: 442[263{S.v. 4847 *cīssa- 'sharp pain' > P. cīs f. 'sudden pain'| Ku. cīs 'keen pain, scorching'| N. ciso 'cold'| H. cīs f. 'sudden pain'| G. cīs f. 'scream'.}]
Justification: As though from *cīssa- 'sharp pain' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):263 no. 4847). No further etymology.

Source: 442[no. 1288{s.v. ā́yāti ʻcomes nearʼ (RV), āyāta- (MBh.) (√yā-)}];172[II:407-408{S.v. Ved. yā-¹ 'fahren, dahinziehen, sich bewegen' < PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- (cf. Lith. jóti, Latv. jât 'reiten, fahren', TochA yā- 'gehen, fahren', Lat. iānus 'Durchgang, Torbogen', etc.).}];141[309-310{S.v. *i̯eh₂- 'dahinziehen, fahren' [IEW 296].}]
Justification: Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to drive, move oneself', ultimately to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):58 no. 1288, [EWAia](src-172) II:407-408, [LIV²](src-141) 309-310).

Source: 141[232-233{S.v. *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (IEW 293-6).}];352[259-261{S.v. OLith. eĩti 'gehen, kommen', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'gehen' (cf. Ved. ay- 'gehen', OAv. aē- 'gehen', Gk. εἶμι 'gehen', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', etc.).}];460[437{Tsakonian παρίου < Ancient Greek present ptcp. παριών of πάρειμι.}];80[992-993{S.v. Hitt. u̯e-/uu̯a- 'come', from PIE *h₂ou 'hither' + *h₁ei̯- 'go'.}];567[214{Bactrian present stem ηρσ- reflects ā-isa-, while the suppletive past stem αγαδο from Proto-Iranian *ā-gata- (cf. Sogd. ʾʾys-/ʾʾγt, Pth./Chor. ʾs-/ʾγd- 'come').}];172[I:102{S.v. Ved. √ay-¹ 'gehen, wandern, fahren, gelangen' (cf. OAv. āitī 'kommt heran', YAv. aēiti 'geht'), from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Hitt. i-it 'geh!', Luw. i-ti 'geht', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', OLith. eimì 'gehe', Lith. eĩti, OCS iti 'gehen', etc.).}];81[216{S.v. Proto-Slavic *jьti 'go' (ESSJa VIII 247-248), from Proto-Balto-Slavic *ei- (Lith. eĩti, Latv. iêt 'go') from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Skt. éti, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. īre).}];353[151{S.v. Lith. eĩti 'go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go' (cf. OCS iti, Skt. éti, Gk. εἶμι, Lat. īre).}];66[388{S.v. Gk. εἶμι 'to go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'go', an old thematic root present with exact correspondences in many languages (Skt. é-mi, Lith. ei-mì,  Hitt. pāi-mi (with preverb *pe-, pa-), Lat. ī-s, i-t, etc.).}];458[8: 247-248{PIE *ei̯- / *ī- / *i̯-.}];83[154-157{S.v. Proto-Iranic *Hai- 'to go', from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' (cf. Hitt. i-it 'go!' Luw. i-ti 'he goes', Gk. εἶμι 'I go', Lat. īre, OCS iti, Lith. eĩti 'to go', etc.).}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-SlavicLexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ([LIV²](src-141) 232-233, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):992-993, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):437, [Beekes 2010](src-66):388, [EWAia](src-172) I:102, [Cheung 2007](src-83):154-157, [ALEW](src-352) 259-261, [Derksen 2015](src-353):151, [ESSJa](src-458) 8:247-248, [Derksen 2008](src-81):216).

Source: 141[209-210{S.v. *gʷem- '(wohin) gehen, kommen' (IEW 464-465).}];54[661{S.v. Lat. veniō, -īre 'to come', from PIE *gʷm̥-i̯é-.}];345[170-171{S.v. TochB käm- 'come', which with TochA kum- reflects Proto-Tocharian *k(w)äm-, from PIE *gʷem- 'come, go' (cf. Skt. gácchati 'goes', Av. jasaiti 'id.', Gk. βαίνω 'go', Lat. veniō 'come', Goth. qiman 'come', Lith. gemù 'be born', etc.).}];172[I:465-466{S.v. Ved. √gam- 'sich bewegen, gehen, kommen' (cf. OAv. ǰamaitī, ǰimaitī, YAv. gata-), from PIE *gʷem- (cf. Gk. βαίνω, Lat. veniō, Goth. qiman, etc.).}];83[98-101{S.v. Proto-Iranian *gam-¹ 'to come', from PIE *gʷem- (cf. Ved. gam- 'to move, to go, to come').}];165[316{S.v. Proto-Germanic *kweman- ~ *kuman- 'to come', from PIE *gʷ(é)m-e- (cf. Skt. gácchati, Av. jasaiti, Gk. βάσκω < *gʷm̥-sk̑e-| Gk. βαίνω, Lat. veniō < *gʷm-ie-, etc.).}];556[315-317{S.v. Gmc. *kwem-a- 'kommen'.}];444[767{Cf. s.v. 9200 Lat. venīre 'kommen'.}]
Justification: Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' ([LIV²](src-141) 209-210, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):170-171, [EWAia](src-172) I:465-466, [Cheung 2007](src-83):98-101, [Seebold 1970](src-556):315-317, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):316, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):661, Meyer-Lübke 1935}:767 no. 9200).

Source: 141[424-5{S.v. *meh₁- '(ab)messen' (IEW 703-4).}];156[II:199-201{S.v. Oss. nymajyn : nymad | nimajun : nimad 'считать', from *ni + IIr. *mā- (IE *mē-).}];442[596{S.v. 10329 Skt. mḗya 'to be measured' AV., 'discernible' Prab [√mā]. Marathi form has "unexplained o".}];382[852-853{S.v. μέτρο < Ancient Greek μέτρον 'measure', from which Modern Greek μέτρω 'I count' is a denominal verb.}];66[939-940{S.v. μέτρον 'measure, goal, length, size| metre', from PIE *meh₁- 'measure' (cf. Skt. mā́-ti 'measures').}];172[II:341-343{Cf. s.v. Ved. √mā-² 'messen, abmessen, zumessen, zuteilen' (IIr. cf. OAv. fra-mīmaθa 'ihr ordnet an' [Y 32,4], YAv. māta- 'gebildet', etc.), from PIE *meh₁- (cf. Lat. mētior 'messe, messe ab', Goth. mel 'Zeit, Stunde', OHG māl 'Zeitpunkt', Ru. méra, Sloven. mẹ́ra 'Maß, Maßregel', etc.).}]
Justification: Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ([LIV²](src-141) 424-425, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):852-853, [Beekes 2010](src-66):939-940, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:199-201, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):596 no. 10329, [EWAia](src-172) II:341-343).

Source: 442[185{S.v. 3574 Ved. krándati 'roars, neighs, laments' RV. [√krand1].}];172[I:408-409{Cf. s.v. Ved. √krand- 'schreien, wiehern, dröhnen' (MI, NI cf. Pā. kandati 'jammert, schreit, Bengali kā̃dā 'weinen', etc.). Connections outside of Indic uncertain.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √krand- 'to neigh (of a horse), roar (of clouds, wind, water); cry piteously, lament, weep' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):185), further etymology outside of Indic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:408-409).

Comment: perhaps from vad- 'raise one's voice, sound, speak', vádati (RV)
cf. Sanskrit buk-kāra- m. 'the roaring of a lion, cry of any animal', bukkati 'barks' (Dhātup.)

Source: 83[232-233{S.v. Proto-Iranian *kanH¹ 'to dig' < PIE ?*kenh₁- 'to dig'.}];567[237{Bactrian νακαν- (attested via past stem νακανδο) from Proto-Iranian *ni-kanta- (cf. Av. ni-kaṇta-).}];141[344{S.v. ?2. *k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂- 'graben' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Cf. n1, comparing IIr. *kʰā́- 'spring'| from the nasal-present *k⁽ʷ⁾-né/n̥-h₂- a new PIIr. root *kanH- was abstracted.}];172[I:445-446{S.v. Ved. √khan-ⁱ 'graben' (IIr. cf. YAv. us-kəṇti 'gräbt aus', ni-kaiṇti 'gräbt ein', MPers. NPers. kandan 'graben', etc.). PIE probably *kenh₁- (cf. OPhryg. keneman 'probably … a monument or part of it).}];269[{Root ref. form for this class follows the reconstruction of LIV², but cf. EWAia and Cheung 2007. We may be dealing with a specifically IIr. root *kʰanH- (< ?*kenh₁-, if the comparison to Phrygian keneman (a monument or part of it) is correct).}]
Justification: Root ref. form for this class follows the reconstruction of [LIV²](src-141) 344 ?*k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂- 'to dig', but cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:455-456 and [Cheung 2007](src-83):232-233. We may be dealing with a specifically IIr. root *kanH- (< ?*kenh₁-, if the comparison to Phrygian keneman (a monument or part of it) is correct). [LIV²](src-141) 344n1 assumes the creation of a neo-root within Indo-Iranic on the basis of the nasal-present stem *k⁽ʷ⁾-né/n̥-h₂-.
loan from Arabic اخسأ

Source: 80[857–858, 870–871{S.v. tē- 'to speak, to state', from PIE *dʰeh₁- (cf. OCS děti 'to do, say', Skt. dhā- 'to put', Gk. τίθημι 'to put', etc.). Suppletive with ter- / tar- < PIE *tér- / *tr-énti.}];141[136-138{S.v. *dʰeh₁- 'stellen, legen, setzen| herstellen, machen' (IEW 235-9).}]
Justification: The Hittite stem is paradigmatically suppletive; this cognate set is coded for 3.sg.pres.act. tēzzi < *dʰeh₁-ti ≠ ter-/tar- (< PIE *ter- 'to speak'), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):857–858, 870–871; [LIV²](src-141) 136-138.

Source: 66[619-620{S.v. κακός 'bad, awful, worthless'. No clear etymology. Beekes assumes Phrygian κακο(υ)ν is a loan from Greek. There are some further possible IE comparisons, none of which is fully convincing. The most promising of these is to Standard Albanian keq 'bad'.}];364[239{Assumes a relation to Albanian keq 'bad' through a Proto-Albanian pre-form *kakii̯ā̆-, cf. [cognate set 6597](cog-6597), whereas Proto-Greek would show the same root with a simple thematic suffix (i.e. *kak-o-).}];269[{The possible connection to Proto-Albanian *kakii̯ā̆- is worth considering, but the connection is too speculative to merge this class with [cognate set 6597](cog-6597).  This has been indexed as a proposed cognacy relationship at a 50/50 level. Whether these forms could be further projected back to a PIE root with zero-grade vocalism *k̑h₂k-, *kn̥k̑-(vel sim.) remains unclear.}]
Justification: Possibly to be connected with Proto-Albanian *kakii̯ā̆- (cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):239), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):619-620. Cf. further in [cognate set 6597](cog-6597).
Loanword from French cacher 'to hide'.

Source: 353[90{Cf. s.v. Lith. bylóti 'speak' (OPruss. billītwei 'speak') and bìlti, derived from PIE *bʰelH- (cf. OHG bellan 'bark', OIc. belja 'roar').}];141[74{S.v. ?*bʰelH- 'tönen, dröhnen' (IEW 123-4). Only Germanic and Balto-Slavic, difficult to distinguish from *bʰelh₁- 'heulen'.}];352[113-115{Cf. s.v. OLith. bìlti 'zu sprechen beginnen, sprechen' (BSl. bil̂st, bil̂stu, bil̂du 'sagen, sprechen', OPr. billīt (III), bilītwei, billitwei (III) 'sagen, sprechen', etc.), from PIE *bʰelH- 'tönen' (cf. OE bellan 'brüllen (Löwe, Eber)' OHG bellan 'bellen', TochA pällātsi 'loben, preisen', TochB 3.sg.pres.med. pällātär 'loben, preisen').}];686
Justification: Derived from PIE *bʰelH- 'to sound' ([ALEW](src-352) 113-115, [Derksen 2015](src-353):90, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):54ff. [LIV²](src-141) 74).

Source: 442[164{S.v. 3219 *kuccura- 'dog'. [Cf. kurkurá -- and Par. Orm. kučuk IIFL i 263.]}]
Justification: Possibly to be connected with Vedic kurkurá- 'dog'? Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):164, no.3219. Otherwise uncertain.

Source: 442[778{Cf. s.v. 13493 súmahānt- (nom. súmahān, voc. sumahaḥ) 'very great' RV.}];172[II:337-338{Cf. s.v. Ved. mahā́nt- 'groß, ausgedehnt, mächtig, bedeutend'. The IIr. forms are based upon PIE *meg̑- 'big' with an ablauting suffix *-(é)h₂-. Cf. entry in Mayrhofer for detailed discussion of the stem formations to this root in Indo-Iranian.}];274[468-478{S.v. *meg̑- 'groß' (IEW 708f., EIEC 344). Cf. entry for extensive discussion of stem derivations found in individual IE branches.}]
Justification: Cf. Vedic sú-mahānt- 'very great, huge' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):778, no. 13493), for further etymology ultimately to PIE *meg̑- 'big' cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:337-338, [NIL](src-274) 468-478).

Source: 442[511{S.v. 9092 Skt. phulla 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' MBh. > N. phul 'flower, menstrual flow, egg'.}];399[II:398{S.v. Skt. phullaḥ 'aufgeblüht, blühend / blossoming', possibly from a p.p.p. *phal-na- to phálati 'birst', corresponding to Buddh. phulla- 'gebrochen', Pāli phulla- 'gebrochen' and 'blühend'| the formation no-longer associated with the verb *phalla- would have then would have taken on a labial vowel -u-.}]
Justification: As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ([KEWA](src-399) II:398).

Source: 442[301{Cf. s.v. 5441 *ṭaḍḍha- 'distant'}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):301 no. 5441 s.v. *ṭaḍḍha 'distant'; further etymology uncertain.

Source: 294[607-614{S.v. 1. *pér, *pérā̆, *pérām, *pérti- 'durch, darüber, hinaus, über| sehr' Adverb, lokal| oft mit. Akk. steigerndes Präfix.}];165[137{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ferrai (adv.) 'far', from PIE *per-n-oi-, a locative adverb originally ending in -noi.}];79[404{S.v. Arm. *haṙ- 'far' : haṙi adv. 'far (of time and space)| isolated, foreign', adj. 'distant, far off, of long duration'. Since long connected with Goth. fairra 'far', OHG ferro, Skt. parás 'far, further', etc.}]
Justification: Armenian and Germanic lexemes derived from the PIE local adverb *per- 'through, beyond, over; very' ([LIPP 2](src-294):607-614, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):404, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):137).
Probably a loanword from French ciel 'sky'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4671ff.

cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10063 s.v. māra- m. ʻdeathʼ (VarBr̥S.), ʻkillingʼ (Rājat.); New Indo-Aryan words meaning ʻstriking, blowʼ from mārayati which continues the polysemy of Vedic hánti (han-) 'beat, slay, kill'; cognate with [cognate set 712](cog-712)

Justification: As though continuing Latin *reiectāre 'to throw back' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):594-595), a frequentative of Lat. iaciō, -ere + prefix re- with root etymology going back to PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw, let go' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):292-293, [LIV²](src-141) 225).

Source: 442[229{S.v. 4272 *gōḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee' [Cf. the word-group ʻ heel-ankle, knee-wrist' s.v. *kuṭṭha- : → Brah. goḍ ʻ knee ʼ]}]

Source: 442[219{S.v. 4094 *gavatta- 'cattle-fodder'. [gṓ- , *atta- (1)]}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4094 s.v. *gavatta- ʻcattle-fodderʼ, gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 1 'eaten'
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *gavatta- 'cattle-fodder', a compound containing Skt. gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 'eaten' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):219 no. 4094). The cognacy in this cognate set reflects the element *atta- 'eaten' continuing a derivative of PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' (cf. 'eat' in [cognate set 210](cog-210)).

[KEWA](src-399) I:292, 397, [LIV²](src-141) 372).

Valid under the assumption that this is the same etymon as d(h)yūm in Morgenstierne 1941:34.

Source: 442[670{S.v. 11480 Skt. vāṭa- (1) m. 'enclosure, fence' MBh. [Early east MIA. < *vārtra-| √vr̥1]. Addenda: vāṭa- 1 [Perhaps < *vārta- < IE. *worto- rather than < *vārtra- T. Burrow BSOAS xxxviii 68]}];769[68{"Classical Sanskrit vāṭa- 'fence| enclosure', vāṭī 'enclosed ground', vāṭīkā 'idem' are of Middle Indo-Aryan orgin. R. L. Turner (BSOAS, xxx, 1, 1967, 77| cf. also CDIAL nos. 11480 and 11565) reconstructs *vārtra- and *vārti- regarding them as formations with derivative vr̥ddhi from vártra and vr̥ti- respectively. Of these the former is possible but hardly the latter. Alternatively we may have in both cases long -ā- from original -o-, and if vāṭī is to be derived from *vārti- (or *vārtī), then vāṭa- may not have to be connected with the tra-formation but could be from a stem with suffix -ta and o-grade of the root, i.e. *vārta- < *worto-."}];141[226-227, 674, 684-685{Cf. s.v. *Hu̯er- 'einschließen, stecken, hineintum' (IEW 1150, 1160), 1. *u̯el- 'einschließen, verhüllen' (IEW 1138), and 1. u̯er- 'aufhalten, (ab)wehren' (IEW 1160-2).}];172[II:512-513{Cf. s.v. Ved. √var- (2) 'umschließen, zusammenhalten, einschließen, zurückhalten, einhüllen' (IIr. cf. YAv. hąm.vaori- 'mit dem Rahm', Oss. wart 'Schild, Schutz', etc. The assignment of Indo-Iranic *var- to Indo-European sources is difficult. (Cf. for further discussion).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11480 s.v. vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence' (MhB.): "Early east MIA. < *vārtra-", from 1. var-
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence', a formation originating in Middle Indic as though from Sanskrit *vārtra- or Sanskrit *vārta- < PIE *u̯orto- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):670 no. 11480 + addenda; cf. [Burrow 1975](src-769):68). For the root, cf. Vedic 2. √var- 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'. Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:512-513, [LIV²](src-141) 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).

Source: 172[II:708{S.v. Ved. sáras- 'See, Teich', from PIE *séles- (cf. Gk. ἕλος 'feuchte Niederung, Sumpf').}];269[{Both Ved. sálas- and Gk. ἕλος -εος are s-stem neuters < *sél-os-Ø, *sel-es-os, therefore we are dealing with an original root *sel-.}];442[765{Cf. s.v. 13254 Skt. sáras- n. 'lake, pool' RV. [√sr̥].}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *sáras-, an s-stem to a root *sel- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:708, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):765 no. 13254).

OHG farn 'Farn', Lith. spar̃nas 'Flügel, Schaufel, Blatt').}];141[579-580{Cf. s.v. 2. *(s)per- 'fliegen' [IEW 817, 850].}];442[446{S.v. 7918 Ved. parṇá- sg. or pl. 'plumage, foliage (of tree)' RV., 'betel leaf' lex.}]

Source: 49[692{Traditionally reconstructed as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) 'Laus', with frequent tabooistic distortions in individual branches.}];172[II:415{S.v. Ved. yūkā- 'Laus' "Mit Bildungen anderer idg. Sprachen wie ahd. lūs = nhd. Laus, kymr. llau, Läuse, lit. liū̃lė Laus u.a. zu verbinden| die formalen Abweichungen (auch in pā. ūkā- f., aškun. wū u.a.) erklären sich durch Sprachtabu. S. die Lit. in KEWA III 25, 784 und bei Karulis II 459."}];269[{Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.}]
Comment: perhaps PIE *li̯ú-, if *li̯ > Vedic y but Germanic l-, cf. 'liver' (if from *li̯ekʷ- ~ *li̯ep- but not *Hi̯ekʷ-); Proto-Germanic *lūs < *li̯ú-s etc. with reanalysis of the ending -s (?) (R.P.); not fully clear.
Justification: Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Comment: re-sanskritized? not among Turner 1962-66, no. 9827f. mánuṣa- and manuṣyà-

Source: 442[292{S.v. 5301 Skt. jyṓtsnā f. 'moonlit night' TBr., 'moonlight' MBh. 2.}];172[I:604-606, 750-754{S.v. Ved. jyótsnā- 'mondhelle Nacht, Mondnacht, Mondschein', formed to Ved. √jyot- 'leuchten', a phonetic variant of √dyot- 'blitzen', a dental-enlarged stem from PIE *di̯eu̯- 'leuchten'. The stem formation of jyótsnā- is probably parallel to Lat. lūna < *lou̯k-s-neh₂-. On the details of the phonetic development *dy- > *jy- cf. the discussion in the etymological notes s.v. √jyot-. Cf. further s.v. Ved. dyav- 'Himmel, Himmelsgott, Vater Himmel, Tag', from PIE *di̯éu̯-/diu̯- 'Himmel, Tag' (also personified 'Himmelsgott'), (cf. Gk. Ζεύς, Lat. *dius in nudius tertius 'vorgestern' < *'und es ist der dritte Tag', from the root *dei̯- 'leuchten'.}];274[69-81{Cf. s.v. *dei̯-, di- 'hell (sein), scheinen' (IEW 184ff., 416f., EIEC 513), where Ved. dyáu- reflects a stem formation *di̯-éu̯-.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jyótsnā- 'moonlight night' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):292 no. 5301), derived from Vedic √jyot- 'to shine' a phonetic variant of Vedic √dyot- 'to shine', a neo-root further to the same root as Vedic dyáv- 'sky', itself a derivative of PIE *dei̯- 'shine' via *di̯-éu̯- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:604-606, II:750-754, [NIL](src-274) 69-81).

((a) > Si. kaṭa 'throat, mouth').}];172[292{S.v. Ved. kaṇṭha- 'Hals'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps to the family of Kan. gaṇṭ(a)lu- etc. 'throat' ([Burrow & Emeneau 1984](src-756):127).}]

The stem must contain -sk-, the root could be reconstructed as either *teiH- or *teh₁i-, neither of which have obvious cognates elsewhere in Indo-European.}];259[77, 84{PS *těsnŭ (< *těsknŭ < *toi̯sk-no) is related to *tiskati 'squeeze, press'. It is ultimately derived from PIE *tei̯sk- 'squeeze, press'.}];594[{PS *těsnъ is derived from *tiskati. It was derived from PIE *tḗh₂isk-, ultimately from *tah₂- 'melt, dissolve'. Ts. γρούσσα but Pr. Ts. γουώσσα (< AG γλῶσσα).}];66[767-768{Cf. s.v. AGk. κράζω 'to croak, to cry', of onomatopoeic origin.}];270[575-576{Cf. s.v. AGk. κράζω, of onomatopoeic origin.}]

(AV) lumpáti 'zerbricht etw.'}];172[II:482{Cf. s.v. Ved. √lop- 'zerbrechen, beschädigen, beseitigen, zunichte machen', originally with Ved. √rop-, also PIE *reu̯p-/*rup-/*ru-N-p-e- (Lat. rumpere).}]

81[354-355{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *noga 'foot, leg', as though from PIE *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. Lith. nagà 'hoof'| nãgas 'nail, claw', Gk. ὄνυξ 'nail, claw, hoof', Lat. unguis 'nail, claw', OIr. ingen 'nail', OHG nagal 'nail').}];458[25: 161-164{PS *noga is derived from PIE *onogh- (: *ongh-, *nogh-, n̥gh-) and related to Lithuanian nagas 'fingernail', Latvian nags 'fingernail, claw', Old High German nagal 'fingernail', Old Irish ingen 'fingernail', Latin unguis 'fingernail', Greek ὄνυξ 'fingernail, claw' etc.

[Derksen 2008](src-81):354-355, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164).

[√viś] and s.v. 2249 upavēśana n. .act of sitting down. ĀśvŚr. [√viś]. NB: Contamination with vásati which by itself provides a verb 'to sit'.}];172[II:584{Cf. s.v. 269[{For Ancient Greek ὀφθαλμός, variants are Boeotian ὄκταλλος, a gloss reported in the grammarian Herodian's treatise Περὶ ὀρθογραφίας (On Correct Spelling), and West Greek ΟΠΤΙΛΛΟΣ (epigraphic at IG IV²,1 121, etc.). [Beekes 2010](src-66) attempts to assign ὀφθαλμός to a Pre-Greek substrate language, however most other etymological authorities (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270)| [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174)) prefer to analyse the beginning of the word as identical with PIE *h₃ekʷ- found elsewhere in Greek as a compositional member °οψ, in a derived noun ὄμμα < *h₃ókʷ-mn̥, etc. The variants may support a connection of initial ὀφ- with PIE *h₃ékʷ-, but a convincing explanation that accounts for the remainder of the word is lacking (cf. [NIL](src-274) s.v. h₃ekʷ- p.376n24). Contamination of inherited material with a substrate language remains possible| as the nominal derivation of the ὀφθαλμός words is unclear, I am inclined to separate them from the ὄμμα words for the purposes of cognate coding. Note Tsakonian (ε)ψιλέ is a reflex of Ancient Doric variant ὀπτιλλός (cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):413).}];460[413, 423{Cf. s.v. AGk. (dor.) ὀπτίλος 'das Auge' > Tsak. (ἐ)ψλὲ| AGk. ὀφθάλμιον, dim of AGk. ὀφθαλμός 'Auge' > Italiot αρτάρμι.}];66[1133-1134{S.v. ὀφθαλμός 'eye'. Attempts have been made to try to reconcile this word with the root ὀπ- 'to see', but no explanation has been completely convincing.}];174[II:452-453{S.v. Gk. ὀφθαλμός 'Auge', attempts to analyse the root of the stem as a continuant of the inherited word for 'eye' also found in Gk. ὄμμα, ὄσσε, ὄπωπα, etc.}];270[811-813{S.v. Gk. ὄπωπα, ὄψομαι, ὄψ, ὤψ, with root meaning 'voir', arguing for ὀφθαλμός as a derivative of the IE root *okʷ- (*ə₃ekʷ), cf. Lat. oculus, etc.}]
Justification: Root etymology possibly to PIE *h₃ekʷ- as in Ancient Greek ὄσσε 'eyes' (dual), but the stem formation is very unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:452-453, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):811-813}, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1133-1134). Cf. note by Scarborough in cognate set citations for further justification and discussion.

Source: 464[{σ̌σ̌ερό is a reflex of AG ξηρός (Rohlfs 1964:355). For the change ξ > σ̌σ̌, cf. (η)σ̌σ̌έρω ‘know’ < MedG εξεύρω, σ̌σ̌ύω ‘scratch’ < AG ξύω etc.}];587[355{Cf. s.v. ξερός (AGk. ξηρός 'trocken').}];66[1035-1036{S.v. ξηρός 'dry, arid'. Possibly from PIE *ksē̆ro-? Proposed etymologies outside of Greek are unclear.}];79[546{Martirosyan connects Greek ξηρός with Armenian čʻir 'dried fruit' čʻor (o-stem) 'dry'. This proposed etymology is usually doubted because one normally expects Armenian cʻ from PIE *ks, *sk, but Martirosyan argues (2.1.12) that čʻ- is the correct reflex of *ks- in initial position. The etymology is possible, but this word is the only example that Martirosyan cites in favour of this sound law.}];319[182{Clackson (among others) regards the connection between Greek ξηρός and Armenian չոր čʻor as doubtful.}]
Justification: From Ancient Greek ξηρός (adj.) 'dry' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):355), further connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. [cognate set 5006](cog-5006)), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):182, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1035-1036, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546).

Source: 316[642{S.v. Lat. spīna, -ae 'épine (arbrisseau épineux, églantine)', from which 'pointe, piquant, arête| épine dorsale', to be connected with Lat. spīca and Umbrian spina, spinia 'columna'? in uncertain sense. No certain etymology outside of Latin.}];444[673{S.v. 8150 Lat. spīna 'Dorn'.}];54[580-581{S.v. Lat. spīna 'thorn, prickle', from PIE *spein-/*spiHn- (cf. Latv. spina 'rod', OPo. spina 'spine', Ru. spiná 'back, spine', OS/OHG spinela, spenula 'hairpin', MHG spenel 'needle'). "Might be derived from the same basis *sp-i(H)- as spīca."}];279[692-693{Cf. s.v. Umb. spinia (uncertain meaning). Usually connected to Latin spīna (with uncertain attempts at an etymological explanation).}]
Justification: From Latin spīna 'thorn, prickle; spine' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):673). Further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):642, cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):692-693). [de Vaan 2008](src-54):580-581 (following [IEW](src-49) 981-982) suggests a possibly cognate relationship to Slavic lexemes, e.g. Ru. спина 'back', but it is not certain whether these forms are actually root cognate or loanwords from Latin (cf. discussion in [cognate set 2059](cog-2059)).

Lat. sōpīre 'einschlafen', OE swefan 'schlafen', etc.).}];338[{Ossetic Iron fən-ɜj kɜn-ən 'sleep': light verb kɜn-ən 'do' [cognate set 5037](cog-5037). Hitt. šupp- 'to sleep' (mediopassive inflection, derived to the root), šupparii̯e/a- 'to sleep' (active inflection, secondarily derived from nominal 'sleep' as through from PIE *sup-r-i̯e/o-).}];69[613{MIA & NIA forms derived from Skt. suptáḥ 'sleep'.}];79[667-668{S.v. Arm. kʻun 'sleep', kʻnem 'to sleep', kʻunem 'to sleep', etc., long since related to the PIE word for 'sleep' from *su̯ep- (cf. nominal *su̯op-no- > Skt. svápna- 'sleep, dream', Av. xᵛafna-, Gk. ὕπνος, Lat. somnus 'sleep', Lith. sãpnas 'dream', OCS sъnъ 'sleep' etc.).}];83[145-147{S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ap/f- 'to sleep', from PIE *su̯ep- 'to sleep' (cf. Lat. sōpīre 'to fall asleep', OCS sъpati 'to fall asleep', Russ. spat', OE swefan 'to sleep', etc.).}];165[489{S.v. Proto-Germanic *sufan- 'to sleep', from PIE *sup-e- (cf. Hitt. šupp(t)ari 'to sleep' < *sup-e-, Skt. svápiti 'to sleep', Av. xᵛap- ~ xᵛaf- 'id.' < *suep-).}];556[482-483{S.v. Lat. sōpio, -īre 'einschläfern', OIr. súan 'Schlaf', Lith. sãpnas 'Traum', OCS sъpati 'schlafen', Gk. ὕπνος 'Schlaf', Ved. sváptu 'schläft', Hitt. šup-, šupparija- 'schlafen', TochB ṣpäne 'Schlaf, Traum').}];442[803-804{Cf. s.v. 13902 Ved. svápati 'sleeps' RV. and *supati.}]

[Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):787-789, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):667-668, [EWAia](src-172) II:791, [Cheung 2007](src-83):145-147, [Derksen 2008](src-81):481, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):489, [Seebold 1970](src-556):482-483).

Source: 66[1139-1140{S.v. ὄψον 'side-dish, especially meat'| in Athens and other places especially 'fish'. < PIE *h₁op-s. Analysed by Taillardat in DELG Supplement as a noun thematised from the adverb *ὄψ, which is reconstructed for ὀψέ 'late' and also found in Lat. obs-. The semantics would have been ὄψον 'supplementary dish (eaten on top of grain, bread)' < *h₁op- 'on, upon' (cf. Gk. ἐπί 'on, upon' < *h₁ep-i, Myc. o-pi < *h₁op-i).}];294[244-253{Cf. s.v. *épi 'auf, darauf| auf – hin'.}];382[1624{S.v. ψάρι, from Ancient Greek ὀψάριον. Diminutive of ὄψον 'cooked or prepared food', but esp. at Athens 'fish' (cf. LSJ s.v. ὄψον, meaning 1.3).}]
Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀψάριον 'little side-dish', a diminutive formation to Ancient Greek ὄψον 'cooked or prepared food', but esp. at Athens 'fish' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1624), further from an o-grade derivative *h₁op-s to *h₁ep- 'on, upon' with the sense of being a supplementary dish eaten on top of grain or bread ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1139-1140).
