The same root *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' occurs in Baltic, Slavic, and Latin, but with different derivations (e.g. Lith. žélti 'to green, sprout', OCS зєлєнъ (translating Greek χλωρός, πράσινος), Lat. holus 'green plants, vegetables, cabbage').}];165[174{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gelwa- ~ *gulu- 'yellow', from PIE *g̑ʰ(e)lh₃-u(o)- (cf. Lat. helvus 'yellow, dun', Lith. žel̃vas 'greenish' < *g̑elh₃-uo-| Skt. hári-, Av. zairi- 'yellow, greenish' < *g̑ʰelh₃-i-| Gk. χλωρός 'pale green, greenish yellow' < *g̑ʰelh₃-ró-| Lith. žélti (želiù) 'to grow, flourish', Latv. zel̂t < *gʰelh₃-ie-| OCS zelenъ, Russ. zelënyj < *g̑ʰelh₃-en-o-).}];353[169-170{S.v. Lith. geltónas 'yellow', derived from Lith. geltas 'yellow', ultimately derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- (cf. Skt. hári- 'fallow, yellowish, greenish'| Gk. χλωρός 'pale, greenish, yellow'| Lat. helvus 'yellowish', OHG gelo 'yellow'. The depalatalised velar must have originated in a zero-grade, where the palatovelar was originally followed by a syllabic resonant. This suggests that the Baltic e-grade in this adjective is secondary. The regular reflex before a full grade is found, e.g., in Latv. zȩ̀lts 'gold'.}];442[809{For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 13990 haridra- '*green, *yellow' (m. 'yellow sandal tree') to Ved. hari-.}];352[309{Cf. s.v. OLith. gel̃sti 'gelb werden' with derived adj. geltónas 'gelb' (BSl. Latv. dzȩltãns 'gelb', OPr. gelatynan 'gelb', SCr. žȗtī. Ru. žëltyj, etc.).}]
Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'. Regarding the irregular correspondence of the initial velar in Lithuanian and Old Prussian, see [Derksen 2015](src-353):169-170 (but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 309). For individual branches cf. [Dawkins 1916](src-452):661, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1638, [EWAia](src-172) II:805-806, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):809 no. 13990, [ALEW](src-352) 309, [Derksen 2015](src-353):169-170, [Derksen 2008](src-81):565-566, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):174).

Source: 54[226-227{Cf. s.v. Lat. flō, flāre 'to blow', from PIE *bʰleh₁-/*blh₁- 'to blow', many compounded forms with preverbs.}];141[87{S.v. *bʰleh₁- 'heulen' (IEW 121-2| 154-5).}];579[{Neapolitan sciatà < Lat. flatāre, a derivative of flātu(m), cf. It. fiatare.}];85[{Cf. s.v. Rom. sufla, from Latin sufflare.}]
Justification: Romance forms based on Latin flō, flāre 'to blow', ultimately derived from PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref {de Vaan 2008}:226-227, [LIV²](src-141) 87).

Source: 442[526{S.v. 9289 *bura 'defective' 2. *bōra-.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Old Indic *bura- 'defective' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) 526 no. 9289). No further etymology.

Source: 442[562{Cf. s.v. 9793 Skt. madhurá- 'sweet' ĀśvGr̥. (Pā. madhura- 'sweet', Pk. mahura-).}]
Justification: Uncertain, perhaps to in some way to Sanskrit madhurá- 'sweet' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):562 no. 9793)? If so, then to be connected with PIE *médʰu- 'sweet drink, honey' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:302-303).

Source: 442[668{Cf. s.v. 11456 vahana- n. 'carrying' MBh., 'flowing of water' Nir., 'ship' Kathās. [√vah].}];172[II:535-537{S.v. Ved. √vah- 'fahren, Wagen lenken, Wagen ziehen, herbeiführen, befördern, bringen' < PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ-.}];141[661-662{Cf. s.v. *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'schweben, fahren' (IEW 1118-20).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11456 s.v. vahana- n. 'carrying' (MBh.)
Justification: Light verb construction, coded for Bengali bahan < Sanskrit vahana- 'a carrying' derived from Vedic √vah- 'to drive, ride (a cart, chariot)' and further to PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to float, drive' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):668 no. 11456, [EWAia](src-172) II:535-537, [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).

Source: 442[527{S.v. 9311 *bōkk 'carry' [Poss. < 'carry on the back': cf. bukka- (1) s.v. vr̥kká-]}];69[460{S.v. N. बोक्नु boknu, vb. tr. 'to lift, carry'. Perh. orig. 'to carry on the back or neck' der. Sk. vr̥kkáu, vŕ̊kyau m. du. 'kidneys'.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain; perhaps originally 'to carry on the back', cf. Skt. vr̥kká- 'kidney' ([Turner 1931](src-69):460, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):527, no. 9311).

Source: 442[341];399[I:516, 528{S.v. tolā́yati, tulā, derived from PIE *telā- [*telh₂-] (cf. Gk. τλῆναι, Lat. tollō, etc.)}];141[622-623{S.v. *telh₂- 'aufheben, auf sich nehmen' (IEW 1060-1).}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):336 no. 5884 tulayati 'lifts' > K. tulun 'to lift', further to PIE *telh₂- 'to raise' (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:516, [LIV²](src-141) 622-623).

Source: 442[264{Cf. s.v. 4855 *cuccu- 'female breast, nipple', 2. *cucci-. [Onom. cf. cūcuka- n. 'nipple'].}];399[I:394-395{Cf. s.v. Skt. cuciḥ 'die weibliche Brust', 'the female breast', onomatopoeic rendering of the sound of suckling.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin, imitative of suckling, cf. Skt. cuci- 'female breast' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):264, no. 4855; cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:394-395).

Source: 156[IV:250-251{S.v. Oss. xūs 'сухой', from PIr. *hauša- (cf. Persian xūšidan, MP xōšitan, Avestan haoš- / hušata- 'to dry', Khotanese hūš- 'to dry'), PIE *sauso- (cf. Ved. śoṣa-, Lith. saũsas, Gk. αὗος, etc.).}];172[II:648-649, 658{S.v. Ved. śúṣka- 'trocken, ausgetrocknet, dürr', from PIIr. *súška- (cf. YAv. huška- 'dry', OPers. uška- 'mainland', Khot. huṣka-, MPers. hušk, NPers. xušk, Oss. x˳ysḱ/xusḱ(æ), Pashto wuč, etc. 'dry').  Cf. Ved. √śoṣ- 'dry out' < PIE *sau̯s- (Gk. αὕω 'dry out', OEng. sēar 'dry', Lith. saũsas 'trocken', etc.).}];141[285{Cf. s.v. *h₂seu̯s- 'trocken werden' (IEW 880-881).}];353[390{S.v. Lith. saũsas 'dry', from PIE *h₂sous-o- (cf. OCS suxъ 'dry', Skt. śúṣka- 'dry, barren', Gk. [Hom.] αὖος 'dry', OE sēar 'dry').}];81[473-474{S.v. Proto-Slavic *suxъ 'dry', from PIE *h₂sous-o- (cf. Lith. saũsas, Skt. śúṣka- 'dry, barren', Gk. [Hom.] αὖος 'dry', OE sēar 'dry').}];352[892-893{S.v. OLith. saũsas 'trocken, dürr' (BSl. cf. Latv. sàuss 'trocken, dürr, nüchtern', OPr. sausā (adj.| adv.?) 'trocken', OCS suxъ 'trocken, dürr', etc.). The inherited adjective for 'dry' with the IE root to be reconstructed either as *h₂seu̯s- or *sau̯s- (cf. Ved. śoṣa- 'austrockend', Gk αὗος 'trocken, dürr', OE sēar 'trocken, dürr', Middle Low German sōr 'id.').}];442[724, 727{S.v. no. 12548 Ved. śúṣka- 'dried' RV., śuṣkaka- R. [√śuṣ1] and no. 12508 *śukṣa 'drying up' (> Kho. c̣uc̣hú, c̣huc̣u 'dried (of fruit)').}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'to become dry' ([EWAia](src-172) II:648-649, 658, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):724, 727 no. 12548, 12508; [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:250-251, [ALEW](src-352) 892-893, [Derksen 2015](src-353):390, [Derksen 2008](src-81):473-474, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 285).
Uncertain, loan from Iranic (cf. [cognate set 68](cog-68))?

Source: 415[774-777{S.v. OHG halôn, holôn 'holen, herbeiholen, (herbei-)rufen', einladen, berufen, sich jemandes annehmen, zurückbringen, fordern (MHG hol(e)n '(herbei-)holen, erreichen, erwerben und mit sich fortführen', NHG holen 'hingehen und etwas herbeibringen'). The word only has West Germanic correspondences. Modern Danish hale, Swedish hala, and OIc. (of questionable attestation) hala are probably Low German loanwords. Only once attested in Old English as giholian 'get, receive'. Further etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Cf. Standard German holen 'to fetch, get'. Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ([EWA 4](src-415):774-777).

Source: 269[{Possibly cognate with Hittite idālu-, Luwian ādduu̯āli- 'bad' ([Adams 2013](src-345):555-556| tentatively mentioned but not explicitly rejected by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):420-422). Alternatively a loan from Old Turkish ([Peyrot 2016](src-676):327-335).}];345[555-556{Accepts connection of TochB yolo 'bad, evil' to earlier PIE *h₁edu̯ol-ōn-, a derivative of *h₁edu̯ol- 'that which eats', which is possibly connected to the family of words found in Gk. ὀδύνη 'pain, suffering', Arm. երկն / erkn / 'birth pangs, great pain' < *h₁edu̯on-.}];676[327-335{Argues for a possible loanword from Old Turkic yavlak 'bad, evil' via Khotanese.}];80[420-422{Cf. s.v. Hitt. idālu-, idālau̯- 'bad, evil, evilness'. K. mentions a possible connection to TochB yolo, but does not explicitly reject it.}]
Justification: Possibly cognate with Anatolian lexemes for 'bad' in [cognate set 3299](cog-3299) (so [Adams 2013](src-345):555-556; tentatively mentioned but not explicitly rejected by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):420-422). Alternatively a loan from Old Turkish ([Peyrot 2016](src-676):327-335).

Comment: parallel Persian loans, with sound substitutions j for z in Magahi, Marathi, Nepali

Source: 141[477-478{S.v. *peth₁- 'fallen' (IEW 825-826).  See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into a single root *pet-.}];442[35{for Palula cf. no. 792 s.v. avapatita- 'fallen down'}];66[1195-1196{S.v. πίπτω 'to fall (off), drop down, fall out' < PIE *petH- 'fly, fall'.}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}];172[II:71-72{Cf. s.v. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschließend fliegen, stürzen, fallen', from PIE *pet- (cf. Gk. πέτομαι 'fliege', Lat. petō 'eile, begebe mich wohin' Old Welsh hedant 'volant', Hitt. pít-ti-i̯a-an-zi 'sie laufen', etc.).}]
Justification: Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived traditionally assigned to a root *peth₁- 'to fall' ([LIV²](src-141) 477-478, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):905-906, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1195-1196). See now [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) considering a more basic PIE root *pet- 'to fall; to fly' merging also 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ([LIV²](src-141) 479). Cf. also [EWAia](src-172) II:71-72).

Source: 442[435-436{S.v. 7721 Skt. pataṅgá- 'ep. of divine (flying) things' RV., m. 'bird'. Palula phaaṭ < *phaṭ-, also in *phaṭṭiṅga- 'flying insect', cf. Vedic (RV) pataṅgá- 'flying', m. 'bird', 'flying insect', 'sun' < *pet- +| ph is due to blending with "some non-Aryan word". For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 7733 Skt. páttra- n. 'wing, feather'.}];80[658-659{S.v. Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- 'wing, feather', from PIE *póth₂-r / *pth₂-én- or *péth₂(ō)r / *peth₂-én- (cf. OHG fedara, ON fjǫðr 'feather', fiðri 'feathers', Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna, Skt. pátra- 'wing').}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}];66[1248{S.v. πτερόν 'feather, wing, pinion', a derivative from PIE *pet- 'fly'.}];172[II:75-76{S.v. Ved. pátra- Flügel (eines Vogels), Feder', derived from a heteroclitic *pat-r-/*pat-n- and cognate with Germ. Feder, Engl. feather, Old Welsh eterin 'bird', atan 'wing', etc., cf. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschießend fliegen, stürzen, fallen' from PIE *pet- (cf. Lat. petō, Gk. πέτομαι, etc.).}];141[476{Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.}];165[138-139{S.v. Proto-Germanic *feϸrō- 'feather', from PIE *péth₂-r/n- (cf. Hitt. pattar ~ pattan-, pettar ~ pettan- 'feather, wing' < *peth₂-r, *pth₂-én-s| Skt. pátra- 'wing, feather' < *peth₂-ro-, Gk. πτέρον 'wing' < *pt(h₂)-er-o-| Lat. penna 'feather' < *peth₂-n-eh₂-| OW atar 'bird', MW adar 'id.', OIr. én 'bird', W edn 'id.' < *peth₂-no-).}];54[458{S.v. Lat. penna 'wing, feather', from PIE *pet-n-h₂- 'wing, feather' (cf. OW eterin 'bird', atan 'wing' < *pt-r/n-| Hitt. pattar / pattan- or pettar / pettan- < *póth₂-r, *pth₂-én-s or *peth₂-(ō)r, *peth₂-én-| Skt. pátra- 'wing (of a bird), feather', pátaṅga- 'flying| bird', Av. patarə-ta- 'winged', NHG Feder 'feather'.}];151[151-152{OIr. ette, eitte 'a wing, pinion| fin', 'a feather, plume'| no correspondences to other Celtic languages. Proto-Celtic *fet-no- 'bird' and *fet-o- 'fly' as derivatives of PIE *pet-. [Matasović does not discuss the origins of Goidelic forms from OIr. ette.]}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):658-659, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1248, [EWAia](src-172) II:75-76, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):435-436 no.7721, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):138-139, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):458, [Lucht 2007](src-151):151-152, [Matasović 2009](src-50):129). For the root reconstruction *pet-, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Source: 442[355{S.v. 6216 Skt. dálati intr. 'cracks, splits' Suśr., dalayati tr. Dhātup. (> M. daḷṇẽ 'to grind').}];399[II:24{Cf. s.v. Skt. dálati 'brist, springt auf' / 'bursts, cracks, flies open' (ep., etc.). Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6216
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit dálati 'cracks, splits', probably an l-form of the same root as Vedic √dar- 'to scatter, split' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):355 no. 6216, [KEWA](src-399) II:24), further to PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ([EWAia](src-172) I:701-703, [LIV²](src-141) 119-121).

Source: 172[I:707-708{S.v. Ved. √darh- 'festigen, fest sein, stark sein', cf. OAv. dīdərəžō 'du begehrst zu festigen', YAv. darəziieiti 'fesselt, bindet fest'. The origin of IIr. *d⁽ʰ⁾arjʰ- is unexplained.}];442[371{S.v. 6508 dr̥ḍhá- , dr̥ḷhá- 'firm, hard, strong' RV. [√dr̥ṁh]}]

Source: 279[477-478{S.v. O. min[s (adv.) 'weniger', cf. O. minstreis (N.A.sg. of the comparative), probably to be derived from *minus (cf. perh. Goth. mins, Lat. minuere 'mindern').}];54[381-382{S.v. Lat. minus 'less', minor 'smaller, less', from a u-stem derived from a nasal-infix stem of PIE *mei̯H- 'to lessen, diminish'| PIE *mi-n(e)-H- 'to make less' >> *min(e)-u-.}];141[427{Cf. s.v. 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, schwinden' (IEW 711).}];269[{Note that the Oscan form in this class is actually the comparative form of the adjective (the positive is not attested). Comment: presumably ideophonic nursery word
Justification: Presumably a nursery word in origin (cf. [Turner 1931](src-69):30, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):45 no. 997).

Source: 399[III:36{Cf. s.v. Skt. ráṭati 'heult, brüllt, schreit' / 'howls, shouts', probably onomatopoeic.}];442[59{Cf. s.v. 1301 Skt. āraṭa- n. 'crying out' and s.v. 1302 Skt. āraṭati 'shrieks' Kathās. [√raṭ].}]
Comment: from Sanskrit raṭati 'howls, shouts', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1301 s.v. āraṭa- n. ʻcrying outʼ (Pāṇ.), 2. āraṭi- f. ʻnoiseʼ (Kathās.), √raṭ-
Justification: From Sanskrit √raṭ- 'to howl, shout' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):59 no. 1301, 1302); no certain further etymology, probably onomatopoeic (cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:36).

Goth. gards 'Haus, Haushalt', Lith. gar̃das 'Pfersch', OCS gradъ 'Burg, Stadt', etc.).}];141[197{Cf. s.v. *gʰerdʰ- 'umschließen, umgürten' (IEW 444).}];165[169{S.v. Proto-Germanic *garda- 'courtyard' (Goth. gards 'house, household, enclosure, courtyard'), from PIE *gʰordʰ-o- (cf. Lith. gar̃das 'fold, pen', OCS gradъ 'city, town', Alb. gardh 'hedge, fence' < *gʰordʰ-o-| cf. also Skt. gr̥há- 'house' < *gʰr̥dʰ-ó-).}];442[239{For Middle and Modern Indic forms, cf. s.v. 4428 Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit ghara- (Pāli ghara-).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *gʰr̥dʰ-ó- ~ *gʰordʰ-ó- 'enclosure' ([EWAia](src-172) I:495, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):239, no. 4428; [Kroonen 2013](src-165):169, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 197).
Probably to a root *ṭan- 'be tight' found in NIA languages (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):301 no. 5443), further etymology obscure.

Source: 399[III, p. 88f.{ideophonic/onomatopoetic}]
Comment: cf. lápati (AV) 'chatters, talks'; via 'whisper', 'talk secretly, make secrets'
ideophonic - compare Lithuanian [cognate set 6872](cog-6872) (parallel ideophonic creations?)

Source: 399[II:233{Cf. s.v. Skt. pálāyate 'flees, escapes, vanishes'. Probably after Middle Indic *pra-lāya(ya)te, cf. Ved. párā-i- 'weggehen, davongehen'.}];442[448{S.v. 7955 Skt. pálāyatē 'flees' TS.}];172[I:102{Cf. s.v. Ved. √ay-¹ 'gehen, wandern, fahren, gelangen', from PIE *h₁ei̯- (cf. Hitt. i-it 'geh!', Gk. εἶμι 'gehen', Lat. eō, īre 'gehen', OLith. eimì 'gehen', OCS iti 'gehen', etc.).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7955 s.v. Vedic pálāyate ʻfleesʼ (TS); cf. Vedic párā + i (áyate?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 233

Source: 389[{"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.}];141[303-304{S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848).  Slavic forms not connected by LIV².}];81[423-424{S.v. Proto-Slavic *puxnǫti v. 'swell' Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.]}];594[{PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.}]
Justification: Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  [LIV²](src-141). Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).

Source: 442[460{S.v. 8151 Skt. piccha- n. 'tail-feather' MBh.}];399[II:270-271{S.v. Skt. piccham 'Schwanzfeder', 'tail-feather' (since Mahābh.), Pāli piccha-, piñja- 'id.', Prākr. piccha-, piñcha- 'Schwanzfeder, Schwanz'. Without convincing explanation.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit piccha- 'tail-feather' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8151), further etymology unclear ([KEWA](src-399) II:270-271; cf. also 'tail' in cognate set 1260 ???).

Source: 172[II:660-661{S.v. Ved. √śyā- 'gefrieren, gerinnen, erstarren', also found in Iranic (Oss. syjyn/sufun 'gefrieren', Yaghnōbī ši- 'frieren, gefrieren', etc.). Connections outside of Indo-Iranian are not certain.}];442[723, 731{For Kashmiri, cf. s.v. 12485 śītá (1) 'cold' RV.| For Nuristan languages cf. s.v. 12614 śaítya n. 'coldness' Yājñ. 2. *śaitiya- > Wg. šēi, šē 'ice', Kt. šē̆.}];83[39{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *či̯aH-³ / *čiH- 'to freeze' > NPers. čā(h)īdan/čay- 'to become cold', Yaghn. ši- 'to freeze', etc.}];399[III:383-384{S.v. śyā́yati 'macht gerinnen, macht gefrieren / causes to congeal, causes to freeze'. "Außerarische Anschüsse bleiben unsicher."}]
Justification: Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:660-661; cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:383-384 for various older proposals). For Kashmiri šuh, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):723 no. 12485 śītá- 'cold' (i.e. the regularly past passive participle formed to Vedic √śyā-), for Nuristan languages cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):731 no.12614.

Source: 442[48, 745{For Marathi, cf. s.v. 1074 *ācikhyati 'communicates' [√khyā-]| for Nuristan languages, cf. s.v. 12842 sáṁkhyāti (*saṁkśāti) 'reckons' [√khyā-].}];172[I:420-421, I:456-457{S.v. Ved. √khyā- 'schauen, anblicken, scheinen', a phonetic variant of Ved. √kśā- 'blicken, schauen'.}];141[383-385{Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9). Verbal only IIr., cf. Gk. τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Ziel' < *kʷék̑-mr̥.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from Vedic khyā- 'to see', ultimately from PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ([EWAia](src-172) I:420-421, I:456-457; [LIV²](src-141) 383-385). For Marathi, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):48 no. 1074 *ācikhyati 'communicates'; for Nuristan languages, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):745 no. 12842 sáṁkhyāti (*saṁkśāti) 'reckons'.

Source: 172[II:543-544{S.v. Ved. vā́ma- 'link', presumably a euphemistic replacement from Ved. vāmá- 'lieb', similar to Gk. ἀριστερός 'left' (ἄριστος 'best').}];442[672-673{Cf. s.v. no. 11533 Skt. vā́ma- 'left', 11534 Skt. vāmá- 'lovely'}];399[III:189{S.v. vā́maḥ 'left'. Etymology not convincingly explained.}]
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic vā́ma- 'left', presumably a euphemistic replacement from Vedic vāmá- 'dear', no further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) II:543-544, [KEWA](src-399) III:189, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):672-673, no. 11533).

Source: 442[333{S.v.5853 Skt. tuṇḍa- n. ʻbeak, trunk, snoutʼ (TĀr., MBh.), ʻcontemptuous term for mouthʼ Bādar., túṇḍika- ʻhaving a trunkʼ (AV)| certainly non-Aryan and prob. ← Mu.}];399[I:509-510{S.v. Skt. tuṇḍam 'Schabel, Rüssel, Schauze, Maul' / 'beak, trunk, snout, mouth', a not quite clear, probably non-Indic word.}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5853 s.v. tuṇḍa- n. ʻbeak, trunk, snoutʼ (TĀr. MBh.); cf. ibid. no. 10163 s.v. mukhatuṇḍaka m.n. (?) ʻmouthʼ Divyāv. (múkha- + tuṇḍa-) cf. [cognate set 6016](cog-6016)
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):509-510 s.v. tuṇḍa- 'beak, trunk, snout'. Etymology uncertain, probably a loanword of non-Indic origin (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:509-510).

Comment: blends of word of different origins, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4111 s.v. *gāṭṭa- ʻneck, throatʼ and no. 4459 s.v. ghāṭā- f. ʻnape of neckʼ (Suśr.), no. 4124; cf. Vedic gā́tram

Source: 399[I:310{Cf. s.v. Skt. khúraḥ 'Huf / hoof', probably a Dravidian word, cf. Tel. korije, gorije, gorise, Kan. gorasu, gorise = Drav. *kŏr- 'Huf' with typical Dravidian variants (Burrow BSOS 9, 718| 12, 376).}];442[207{S.v. 3906 Skt. khura- m. ʻhoofʼ (KātyŚr̥), 2. *khuḍa (khuḍaka, khula° ʻankle, boneʼ Suśr.) ← Dravidian origin.}];172[I:454{S.v. Skt. khura- 'Huf, Klaue'. "Nicht überzeugend erklärt.'}];759[376{Cf. s.v. no. 114 Skt. khura- 'hoof', KatySrS., Mn., etc. ~ Ta. kuracu, kuraccai 'horse's hoof', Ka. gorasu, gorise, Te. gorije, gorise, korise 'id.'}]
Justification: Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):207 no. 3906; [KEWA](src-399) I:310, [EWAia](src-172) I:454, cf. [Burrow 1948](src-759):376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in [cognate set 9629](cog-9629), but these could also be parallel loans.

Source: 80[614-616{S.v. Hitt. pai- / pi- 'to give, to pay, to grant, to hand over'. Kloekhorst prefers to split the Anatolian lexemes from Tocharian and Greek (αἴνυμαι), instead setting up a derived form *h₁p-ói̯-ei̯/*h₁p-i̯-énti, in comparison to Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'to take, seize'.}];141[229{S.v. *h₁ai̯- 'geben| nehmen' (IEW 10-11).}];269[{Etymology outside of Anatolian disputed. The lexemes in this class might be related to Tocharian lexemes in [cognate set 7599](cog-7599) (cf. [LIV²](src-141)). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. [Adams 2013](src-345):107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.}];341[542-543{S.v. TochB ai- 'geben', 'give'| mid. 'nehmen', 'take', TochA e- 'geben', give'. Precise root reconstruction disputed. May be derived from PIE *h₂ei̯-, or perhaps *h₁ai̯- (LIV² 229). Adams (2013:107) sets up *h₄ei̯-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Anatolian disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in [cognate set 7599](cog-7599) ([LIV²](src-141) 229, [Adams 2013](src-345):107, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. [Adams 2013](src-345):107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

Source: 341[542-543{S.v. TochB ai- 'geben', 'give'| mid. 'nehmen', 'take', TochA e- 'geben', give'. Precise root reconstruction disputed. May be derived from PIE *h₂ei̯-, or perhaps *h₁ai̯- (LIV² 229). Adams (2013:107) sets up *h₄ei̯-.}];141[229{S.v. 1.*h₁ai̯- 'geben, nehmen' (IEW 10-1), connected with Anatolian forms.}];269[{Etymology disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in [cognate set 7599](cog-7599) ([LIV²](src-141) 229, [Adams 2013](src-345):107, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. [Adams 2013](src-345):107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.}];80[614-616{S.v. Hitt. pai- / pi- 'to give, to pay, to grant, to hand over'. Kloekhorst prefers to split the Anatolian lexemes from Tocharian and Greek (αἴνυμαι), instead setting up a derived form *h₁p-ói̯-ei̯/*h₁p-i̯-énti, in comparison to Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'to take, seize'.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in [cognate set 7599](cog-7599) ([LIV²](src-141) 229, [Adams 2013](src-345):107, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. [Adams 2013](src-345):107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

Source: 442[538{Cf. s.v. 9440 Skt. bhāṇḍa- (1) n. 'pot, dish, vessel, ornament, wares'.}];399[II:491-492{Cf. s.v. bhāṇḍam 'Gefäß, Topf, Schüssel / vessel, pot', no satisfactory explanation.}];172[II:243-244{Cf. s.v. Ved. bhaṇḍa- 'Hausgeräte', of unclear etymology.}]
Justification: No satisfactory etymology (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):538, [KEWA](src-399) II:491-492, [EWAia](src-172) II:243-244).
Parallel loans from Persian.

Comment: cf. Middle Persian kamar "waist, belt, girdle"; Horn (1893:193) relates this word to Av. kamarā- "belt".

Source: 54[651{S.v. Lat. vāgiō, -īre 'to cry'. Cf. for various etymological proposals.}];316[711{S.v. Lat. uāgiō, -ire 'vagir, chevroter'. An expressive formation similar to Lat. ragiō.}]
Justification: Friulian vaî is from Latin uagiō, -īre 'to cry' (G. Cadorini, p.c.), further etymology unclear ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):711, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):651).

Source: 444[193{S.v. 2035 cōlāre 'durchseien' (> friaul. kolá 'herabfallen').}];316[134{S.v. Lat. cōlum 'passoire, filtre à vin', technical term in rustic language doubtlessly non-Roman. Without a clear etymology. (Denominative verb cōlāre 'filtrer [couler]'.}]
Justification: From Latin cōlāre 'to percolate, sieve' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):193), a denominal verb to Latin cōlum 'sieve, wine filter', no further certain etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):193).

Source: 444[547{Cf. s.v. 6586 plattus (griech.) 'flach', derivative friaul. platási 'sich verstecken'.}]
Justification: From Latin *plattare, a derivative of Latin plattus 'flat, level', in turn a loan from Greek πλατύς ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):547)

Comment: "From a pre-Indoeuropean root meaning "to cut", attested in Romanian and Bulgarian too." (–G. Cadorini)

Source: 389[{Cf. s.v. ?2.*delh₁- 'verlängern' (IEW 194‑6).}];54[348{S.v. Lat. longus 'long' from PIE *dlongʰ-o- (cf. *dólugʰ- in Hitt. *taluki- / talugai- 'long', PIE *dlh₁gʰ-o- in Skt. dīrghá- OAv. darəga-, OCS dlъgъ, SCr. dȕg, Lith. ìlgas, Alb. gjathë (+ *-tā-)| Gk. δολιχός (< *dolh₁-i-gʰo-?), ἐνδελεχής 'lasting long, uninterrupted' < *delh₁gʰ-| PIE *dlongʰ-o- in Goth. laggs, OHG lang, OIc. langr, etc.). The root might be *de/olh₁-, cf. Cz. dél (poet.) 'length' < PSl. *dьlь, etc.}]
Justification: From Latin longa (G. Cadorini, p.c.); for further cognates and the etymology cf. 'long' in [cognate set 257](cog-257).
Etymology unknown. Derivation from Lat. suburgere or superurgere? From a verb in some German language related to Old High German sweran? (G. Cadorini, p.c.)

Source: 228[{Friulian nasâ is derived from Friul. nâs < Lat. nāsus, -ī 'nose' (–G. Cadorini, p.c.).}];269[{Cf. notes to the inherited PIE word for 'nose' in [cognate set 267](cog-267).}];49[755{S.v. *nas- 'Nase'.}]
Justification: Derived from the inherited word for 'nose'. For further etymological discussion, cf. [cognate set 267](cog-267).
Loan from Slovenian modrak (G. Cadorini, p.c.)

Source: 141[622-623{Cf. s.v. *telh₂- 'aufheben, auf sich nehmen' (IEW 1060-1).}];54[621-622{S.v. Lat. tollō, -ere 'pick up, raise, remove', formed from nasal-infix stem *tl̥-né/n-h₂- (cf. OIr. tlenaid*, -tlen 'to lift, take away' < PCl. *tlina-| Gk. aor. ἔτλην, Goth. ϸulan 'to endure, bear', TochB tallaṃ 'raises').}];444[727{Cf. s.v. 8769 Lat. tollere 'wegnehmen'.}]
Justification: Friulian cjoli, from Latin tollere (G. Cadorini, p.c., cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):727), further a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *telh₂- 'raise up' in origin ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):621-622, [LIV²](src-141) 622-623).

Source: 141[264{S.v. *h₂elh₂- 'ziellos gehen' (IEW 27-8).}];54[38{S.v. ambulō, -āre 'to walk', from Proto-Italic *ala- 'to wander' < PIE *h₂elh₂- (cf. Gk. ἀλάομαι 'to wander, roam', Latv. aluôt 'to roam').}];444[33{S.v. 412 Lat. ambulāre 'gehen' (> friaul. lâ, frz. aller, ambler).}]
Justification: From Latin ambulāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):33 no. 412), further to PIE *h₂elh₂- 'go aimlessly, randomly' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):38, [LIV²](src-141) 264).

Source: 442[89{S.v. 1921 Ved. udaká- n. 'water'. RV. 2. Skt. daka- n. Suśr., BHSk.| Si. diya continues the variant having lost initial u-.}];172[I:215-216{Cf. s.v. Ved. udán- 'Wasser', from PIIr. *ud-r-/*ud-n-, derived to PIE *u̯ed- (cf. YAv. vaiδi- 'Wasserlauf', Gk. ὕδωρ, Umbr. utur, OS watar, ON vatn, OCS voda 'Wasser', etc.).}];274[706-715{Cf. s.v. *u̯ed- 'quellen' (LIV² 658f., IEW 78f.). Originally a heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥-/*u̯ed-en-.}]
Justification: Lit. 'congealed/frozen water'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Sinhalese දිය diya 'water' < Vedic udaká- 'water', further derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):89 no. 1921, [EWAia](src-172) I:215-216, cf. [NIL](src-274) 706-715). For the modifer 'congealed/frozen', cf. 'freeze' in [cognate set 7652](cog-7652).

Source: 80[384{S.v. Hitt. illui̯anka-, ellii̯anku- 'snake, serpent'. According to K., the stem alternations between ilui̯anka-, ellii̯anku-, and possibly illiunki- point to a non-IE origin of the word. The proposal of [Katz 1998](src-456) attempting to explain the word as a compound *eel-snake consisting of elements *illui̯- (cf. PGerm. ǣla- 'eel') and *anka- 'snake' (Lat. anguis, Gr. ὄφις) is therefore to be rejected.}];456[317-334{Attempts to reconcile Hitt. illuyankaš with other words for 'snake' in Indo-European. [NB: Katz's proposal has not been widely accepted.]}];406[358-359{S.v. Hitt. illuyanka-, elliyanku- 'snake, serpent'. "Autochthonous term, used especially of the serpent or dragon fought by the storm-god in the etiological myths of the Hattic-origin EZEN purulliyas".}]
Justification: Pace [Katz 1998](src-456) who argues for a compound 'eel-snake' consisting of elements *illui̯- (cf. Proto-Germanic *ǣla- 'eel') and *anka- 'snake' (Latin anguis, Greek ὄφις), Hittite illui̯anka- is generally considered a Hattic loanword ([HED A+E/I](src-406):358-359, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):384).

Source: 442[751{S.v. 12961 Ved. sáṁbharati 'brings together, prepares, rolls up' RV. (> Si. am̆baranavā 'to twist, grind').}];172[I:246-249{Cf. s.v. Ved. √bhar- 'tragen, hegen, pflegen| bringen' < PIE *bʰer-.}];141[76-77{S.v. *bʰer- 'tragen, bringen' (IEW 128-32).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12961
Justification: Continuing Vedic sáṁbharati 'brings together, prepares, rolls up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):751 no. 12961), a derivative of Vedic √bhar- < PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ([EWAia](src-172) I:246-249, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77).

Source: 442[85{Cf. s.v. *ut -- śrayati, úcchrayati 'raises', °tē 'rises' RV. 2. *ut-śrāpayati, ucchrāpayati 'raises' VS. 3. *ut -- śrāpaṇa- . [√śri]. Variant 2 > Si. osavanavā, usuv°, ussanavā 'to raise'.}];141[332-333{Cf. s.v. *k̑lei̯- 'sich anlehnen' (IEW 601-2).}];172[II:665{Cf. s.v. Ved. √śray- 'sich anlehnen', from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lehnen' (cf. Gk. κλίνω 'neige, lehne, beugen', Lat. clīnāre 'biegen, beugen', OIr. clī 'housepost', OHG hlinēn 'lehnen', Lith. šliẽti, Latv. slìet 'anlehnen', TochA kalyme, B kälymiye 'Richtung, Himmelsgegend', etc.).}]
Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1858
Justification: Sinhalese osananavā 'to carry', as though from Sanskrit *ut-śrāpayati > ucchrāpayati 'raises' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):85), further derived from Sanskrit √śray- 'to lean' and ultimately from PIE *k̑lei̯- ([EWAia](src-172) II:665, [LIV²](src-141) 332-333).

Source: 442[511{S.v. 9090 Skt. phupphusa m. 'lungs' Suśr., phuphusa- n. ŚārṅgS., pupphusa- m. lex. (Si. papuvā, pl. papu 'heart and liver and lungs, breast, bosom'.)}];399[II:307{Cf. s.v. Skt. puppuṭaḥ 'swelling of the palate and the gums' to which also probably pupphulaḥ 'Blähung', pupphusaḥ, phupphusaḥ| Pāli papphāsa- 'Lunge'. Probably sound-symbolic of breathing.}]
Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic/imitative origin (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511, no. 9090; [KEWA](src-399) II:307).

Source: 442[591{S.v. mū́rchati ʻbecomes solidʼ (AV), mūrchayati ʻcauses (milk) to coagulateʼ Kauś. (√mūrch-), Pali mucchati ʻcurdlesʼ| Prakrit mucchaï ʻcongealsʼ| Si. midenavā ʻto coagulateʼ < MIA *mūch-| Prakrit mucchāvia- ʻcaused to curdleʼ > Si. mudavanavā. (No. 10240)}];172[II:367-368{S.v. Ved. √mūrch- 'fest werden, gerinnen, sich verdichten' < PIE *mr̥H-sk̑e- (*merH-).}]

602[354, 421{Ukrainian kelûh, kalûh 'gut, anus, stomach of a young calf or lamb', kelûhi, kalûhi 'guts'. It is derived from kal 'excrement, garbage'.}];81[220{However, the reconstruction *kʷeh₂l-o- (cf. Greek πηλός ‘clay, earth, mud, mire’) would be in conflict with Hirt’s law.}];458[125, 127-129{PS *kaľux (attested in Russian and Ukrainian dialects with meanings 'dirty container for feeding of livestock' and respectively 'belly, guts(s), stomach') is derived from PS *kalŭ. Modern Slavic reflexes of PS *kalŭ refer to 'dirt, dirty objects, mud, excrement' etc. It has for sure PIE origin and can be a reflex of PIE *kālo-s or kʷālo-s.  PS *kalŭ has been linked to Greek πηλός 'mud, clay' (if Greek π- < PIE kʷ- and not p-). However, this word is described as unclear in etymology dictionaries of Greek. Other comparisons (to Latin cālidus, Latin squālus, Greek κηλίς, Old Indic kāla-) are less convincing or just wrong.}];66[1186{Greek πηλόσ: "Without a convincing etymology. Pre-Greek?".}];595[2: 10-11{The etymology of kal is not entirely clear. The most probable hypothesis is to assume a relationship to Greek πηλόσ 'mud, clay' and a PIE form *qʷālos. However, the Greek word can be related to Latin palleō 'go pale' with an initial *p- and not kʷ-. The comparisons to Latin squāus and Old Indic kāla- are less probable.}];249[{All existing etymologies are somehow dubious. However, the relationship to Greek πηλός and hence a PIE root reconstruction *kʷeh₂l- seem to be the most reasonable.}]

81[325{PS *morkŭ 'darkness' is related to Lithanian mérkti 'close one's eyes' and Gothic maurgins 'morning'. PIE *morHk-ó-}];458[19: 234-236, 21: 133-135{PS *morkŭ is related to Lithuanian mérkti, mérkiu 'close one's eyes', Gothic maurgins, Old High German morgan 'morning', possibly also Old Indic markás 'solar eclipse'.}];165[377{German Morgen < *mr(H)k-e/on-, OCS mrakŭ < *mork-o-, OCS mrĭknǫti < *mrHk-ne-, Lithuanian mérkti < mérHk-e.}]

602[6: 161{The etymology is not entirely clear. It has been linked to PIE *kes- or to PS *xvorstŭ and *xvastŭ.}];259[57{Polish chaszcze 'thicket, bushes' is derived from older *charszcze and *chwarszcze, cf. dialectal forms like charszcz or chwarsty. All these words are derived from chwarszczeć 'scrunch, swish, hiss', PS *xvŭrščati, *xvŭrstiti, *xvŭrstati. The root is ideophonic.}];458[8: 122-123, 129-135{S. v. *xvorstŭ, xvostŭ etc.}]
Justification: The root has an onomatopoeic origin and and its reflexes show various instances of an irregular phonological development. No certain further IE cognates (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:122-123, 129-135; [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6:161, [Boryś 2005](src-259):57).

Source: 602[1: 317-318{It is a loanword from Old High German, probably via Polish.}]
Justification: Loanword from German, possibly via Polish ([Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 1: 317-318).

Source: 259[57{PS *xata 'primitive kind of house, hut, cabin' is doubtless a loanword, most probably from Iranian *kata- < *kn̥-ta-, a participle of Iranian *kan- 'dig'.}];458[8: 21-22{PS *xata is a loanword from Iranic. [The exact source is disputable].}]
Justification: Loanword from Iranic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:21-22, [Boryś 2005](src-259):57).

Source:
259[418, 642-643{Russian potroh, potroha, Ukrainian potruh, potruhy 'guts, giblets' etc. are derived from PS *troxa 'mite, driblet'.
PS *troxa does notd have any certain etymology. It can be related to PS *troska 'sliver, splinter'.
PS *troska is probably derived from an unattested *troskati 'burst, crack', probably related to Polish trzaskać 'crack'.
Polish trzaskać < PS 'trěskati 'make a dry, sharp sound, crack (by breaking of a hard thing), hit strongly' has an ideophonic origin a was probably derived from an interjection as *trěsŭ (cf. Polish dialectal trzas!, Bulgarian trjas!).}];598[3: 346{Russian potroh is apparently related with Polish trocha, trochę 'a bit' etc.}];593[675{PS *troxa is morphologically and etymologically obscure. However, it can be possibly linked to *troska, *trěska, *trěskati. One had to assume a metathesis sk>ks(>x) then, cf. Lithuanian trekšė́ti 'crack'.
PS *trěskati is related to Lithuanian trekšė́ti 'crack', Gothic þriskan 'thresh', German dreschen 'thresh', English thrash, thresh. All these words are derived from PIE *tre-sk-, which can have an ideophonic origin or be derived from PIE *ter- 'rub'.}]
Justification: A relationship of this lexeme to PS *trěskati, a lexeme referring to sounds made by splitting or cracking things, seems reasonable. For the semantic development cf. PS *drobŭ *drobŭ (>)'guts' and PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush' (cognate/1153/). However, taking into account ideophonic origin of the PS root(s) and the irregular sound shape of PS *troxa that has to be assumed by accepting this relationship, no reliable further etymology can be found.
Loanword from Arabic قرن / qarn 'horn'.
Loanword from Arabic (dial.) salj (cf. Standard Arabic ثلج / thalj 'snow').
Loan from Arabic جناح / janāḥ 'wing'.

Source: 602[2: 135, 5: 656, 661, 680{Ukrainian druliti, driliti. A relationship to Serbo-Croat drljati 'harrow, scratch' and Czech droliti 'crumble, crush' is doubtfull. It is probably a variant form of trulâti. The latter is a contamination of trutiti (PS *trǫtiti) and turlâti (related to PS *turiti, turati without a convincing etymology).}];593[143, 145, 147{Czech drolit is related to drát and dřít (< PIE *der-). This form exists only in Czech.}];458[5: 132-133{PS *druľati is (along with *drolĭ, *droľa and *dĭrľati, *dĭrliti) an expressive derivation (extention) of [PIE] *der-.}]
Justification:
The etymology is not entirely clear due to possible expressive deformations and contaminations.
I adopt here the view of [ESSJa](src-458), see below. However, it has to be treated with caution. Another possibilities, proposed in [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) (see below), are a relationship to PIE *trenk- (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259): 641 and [LIV²](src-141): 649) or to cognate/4961/ (without certain further etymology).

Lith. kapóti 'chop, hew', Latv. kapât 'chop, hew', Gk. κόπτω 'beat, hit').}];458[11: 18-20{The Slavic lexeme is related to Lithuanian kapóti 'chop', Latvian kapât 'chop', Old Prussian en-kopts 'buried', further with Armenian kop'em 'chop, cut', New Persian kāvad, kāfat 'dig' and Greek κόπτω 'chop', σκάπτω 'dig'.}]

Source: 594[{Párkelj, dialectal also špárkelj. Source: 249[{There is no certain etymology. The proposed relationship to PS *karati, *koriti 'punish, humble etc.' is at first glance semantically  unconvincing. However, this lexeme shows a strong semantic variation in Bulgarian and Macedonian dialects: 'put into motion, force, drive (a vehicle or cattle), chase, lead out, jet etc.' and it would be possible to build a reasonable chain of semantic changes from 'punish' to 'carry'. In any case, it would be speculative, though. The hypothesis about the borrowing from a Romance language should be checked.}];603[2: 235-236{It can be related to PS *karati 'punish' which is related to Latin carinō 'insult' and Old Irish caire 'reprimand'. However, some scholars assume here a loan from Balkan Latin, cf. Romanian a cărá, car, Latin *carrare, carrus.}];458[9: 152-154, 11: 74-77{PIE *kar- (with an expressive *-a-), related to Latin carināre, Irish caire, Greek κάρνη.}];66[646{The traditional comparisons with Latin carināre, Balto-Slavic  words like Russian kor, etc. is probably wrong. The Greek lexeme can be Pre-Greek.}]
Justification: No satisfactory etymology.

Source: 141[343{?*keh₁u̯- 'shake' with Church Slavonic po-kyjǫ, po-kynǫti 'nod (with one's head)' and Latin cēueō, cēuēre 'shake' given as cognates.}];458[13: 279-280, 283-284{PS *kyta is derived from PS *kyti, a sparsely attested verb related do PS *kyvati. This word family is related to PS *kyjĭ 'stick' and *kovati 'hammer (also about blacksmith)'.}];259[232{PS *kyta 'bunch, tuft, bundle' is likely to be derived from *kyti 'shake' which is related to PS *kyvati and further to Latin cēvō cēvere / cēveō, cēvēre 'waggle'.}]
Comment: The semantic development in Slavic is 'something that waves, nods' > 'plant, flower' (> 'bouquet (Czech)', 'ponytail (Polish)' etc).
Justification: The etymology suggested by [ESSJa](src-458) points to PIE *keh₂u̯- but is less convincing semantically.

Source: 603[1: 496{The word is borrowed from Turkish yemiş 'fruit'.}]

PS *smukati 'make quick movements, smoothe, rub' and *smykati 'pull, draw' are derived from PIE *(s)meu̯k- 'slippy, to glide, to smoothe, make quick movements'.}];595[3: 272{Slovene smok 'dragon', smokulja 'kind of viper', Serbo-Croat smuk, smok 'dragon', Bulgarian and Macedonian smok 'grass snake' etc. are probably derived from PS *sŭmŭkŭ. If the PS protoform is *smokŭ, it is derived from PS *smokati 'suck'. Less probably it is a loanword from Germanic, cf. Only Slavonic, perhaps related to ?2. *ter⁽g̑⁾- 'abwischen. entfernen'?}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):507-508 for further discussion.

Source: 316[186-187{S.v. Lat. dulcis, -e 'doux au goût' "On est tenté d'établir un rapport avec gr. γλυκύς «doux», γλεῦκος «vin doux», en admettant que γλυκύς reposerait sur *dluku- et qu'il y aurait eu assimilation.  Hypothèse non vérifiable. Pas d'autre rapprochement."}];54[182{S.v. Lat. dulcis 'sweet', which may be accounted for by Proto-Italic *dulkwi- 'sweet'.  Due to difficulties in phonetic developments in both Greek and Latin, it is quite possible that Lat. dulcis, Gk. γλυκύς are common borrowings from an unknown source.  (Cf. entry for further discussion.)}]
Justification: Very similar in form and meaning to Ancient Greek γλυκύς 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):186-187, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):182). Cf. further discussion in [cognate set 5055](cog-5055).

As though continuing Sanskrit *saṁgōpayati 'hides' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):745 no. 12851). The verbal root, √gop- ~ √gup-, was backformed in Vedic from gopā́- (n.) 'cowherd', itself a nominal compound *gʷou̯-peh₂- 'cow-protector' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:499-500). Of the two elements, *peh₂- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 460 *peh₂(i̯)- 'schützen, hüten, weiden') is arguably the original semantic head here (i.e. 'to protect (cattle)' > 'to hide') although I am hesitant to consider PIE *peh₂- as the root-reference form here because of the process of backformation that occurred to create the new root √gop- within Vedic.

Perhaps to a root noun *(h₁)ros-.}]

442[693{S.v. 11987 Skt. viṣṭara- m. 'anything spread out, handful of grass or rushes for sitting on' Gr̥Śr., m.n. 'any seat' MBh., m. 'tree' lex. 2. vistara- m. 'spreading, diffuseness' MBh., vistarakēṇa 'in detail' Pat. [√str̥]. (Si. vatura 'water, flood' < 2. vistara-).}];172[II:756-757{Cf. s.v. Ved. √star-ⁱ 'ausbreiten, streuen', from PIE *sterh₃- (cf. Gk. ἐστόρεσα 'habe ausgebreitet', Lat. sternere, 'hinbreiten', OIr. sernaid 'breitet aus', etc.).}];141[599-600{Cf. s.v. *sterh₃- 'hinbreiten, ausbreiten' (IEW 1029-30).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit vi-stara- 'spread-out', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):693 no. 11987, [EWAia](src-172) II:756-757, [LIV²](src-141) 599-600).

Source: 172[I:344-345{Cf. s.v. Ved. √kāś- 'sichtbar werden, erscheinen', from which is derived ākāśá- 'freier Raum, Luftraum, Öffnung', perhaps to PIE *kʷek̑-, if the root is connected with Gk. τέκμωρ, τέκμαρ 'Zeichen, Merkmal'.}];442[45{S.v. 1008 Skt. ākāśá- m. 'sky' ŚBr. [√kāś].}];141[383-385{Cf. s.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9).}]
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ākāśá- 'sky' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):45 no. 1008), to be further connected with Vedic √kāś- 'to be visible, appear' and further to PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ([EWAia](src-172) I:344-345, [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).

Source: 81[92{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ (adj.) 'black' < PIE *kr̥s-nó-.}];458[4: 155-157{PIE *kirno- or *kirsno-.}]
Justification: Lexemes in this set coded for Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black' < PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4:155-157, [Derksen 2008](src-81):92). For further etymological discussion, cf. [cognate set 1111](cog-1111) 'black'.

Source: 141[602{S.v. *(s)teu̯p- 'stoßen, schlagen' (IEW 1034). For the Luw. & Lyc. forms cf. [Oettinger 1979](src-649):417, 535, [Hajnal 1995](src-380):127.}];66[1518-1519{S.v. τύπτω 'to poke, stab, beat with a weapon or stick' < PIE *steup- 'push, beat' (cf. Lat. stupeō 'to be(come) numb, amazed', Alb. shtyp 'to crush', etc.).}];269[{The cognacy in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) to PIE *(s)teup- after [Oettinger 1979](src-649):417, 535, [Hajnal 1995](src-380):127. Note however disagreement of [Melchert 1994](src-368):242, [Neumann 2007](src-414):384-385, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω suggesting a root-variant *(s)teubʰ- (after [IEW](src-49) 1034| not in [LIV²](src-141)). According to [Beekes 2010](src-66):1418-1419, however, Gk. στυφελίζω has no secure connections outside of Greek.}];414[384-385{S.v. Lyc. tubi- something like "erschlagen", corresponds to Gk. ἀπόλλυμι "zugrunderichten, vernichten". Identical to CLuw. dupai-/dupi- 'schlagen, hauen| bestrafen', HLuw. tup(a)i- 'to smite'. "Wegen des lyk. b nicht unmittelbar zu griech. τύπτω, idg. *teup- zu stellen, sondern zu dessen Wurzelvariante *(s)teub-, vgl. Pokorny, IEW 1034, Melchert AHPh 242: griech. στυφελίζω 'schlagen, stoßen, drängen, treiben, treffen'".}];368[242{Connects Luw. dūpi-/dūpāi- 'strike' < PA *(s)toubéyo-, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω.}];380[127{Derives Lyc. 3.sg.pres. tubidi 'er schlägt' < *tūbī́di < *tūbéidi < *tūbéii̯idi < anatol. *toubéi̯edi < (iterative) *(s)toupéi̯eti (cf. CLuw. 3.sg.pres. <tu-ú-pi-ti> tūbīdi, HLuw. <tu-pi-ri+i> to PIE *steup- (cf. Gk. τύπτω).}];649[417, 535{Connects Luwic forms to *(s)teup-.}]
Justification: The cognacy in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) to PIE *(s)teup- after [Oettinger 1979](src-649):417, 535, [Hajnal 1995](src-380):127. Note however disagreement of [Melchert 1994](src-368):242, [Neumann 2007](src-414):384-385, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω suggesting a root-variant *(s)teubʰ- (after [IEW](src-49) 1034; not in [LIV²](src-141)). According to [Beekes 2010](src-66):1418-1419, however, Gk. στυφελίζω has no secure connections outside of Greek.

Comment: probably loans from New Persian (Tajik: garon)

Source: 81[234{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kora 'bark', derived from PIE *(s)ker- (cf. Gk. κείρω 'shear', OIc. skera 'cut').}];458[44-45{PS *kora < PIE *ker-.}];595[3: 246{PS (s)kora < PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.}];259[250, 553{PS *kora, *skora < PIE *(s)ker- 'cut'.}];141[556-557{Cf. s.v. *(s)ker- 'scheren, kratzen, abschneiden' (IEW 938-40).}]
Justification: Derivatives from PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):234, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:44-45, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 556-7), PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ({cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560) is often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of this root.

Source: 141[68{S.v. *bʰeh₁dʰ- 'bedrängen' (IEW 114). Cf. probably Lith. bėdà 'Not, Kummer' = OCS (+) běda (if not to *bʰedʰh₂-).}];246[693{S.v. Pā. sambādha, cf. Skt. sambādha-.}];172[II:222{S.v. Ved. √bādh- 'verdrängen, bedrängen, bedrücken', mi., dard. ni., pā. bādhati 'bedrückt, behindert', usw. (IIr. cf. YAv. auui.bāδ(a)-) without certain further connections.}]

Justification: Cf. Sanskrit sambādha- 'contracted, narrow' ([Pali Text Society 1921–1925](src-246):693), further to Vedic √bādh- 'to press, force', probably further to PIE *bʰeh₁dʰ- 'to press, oppress' ([LIV²](src-141) 68, however more sceptically [EWAia](src-172) II:222).

Parallel loans from Sanskrit bī́ja- 'seed'.

Source: 442[725{S.v. 12516 Skt. śuṇḍā- (1) f. 'elephant's trunk' MBh.|'*lip, *mouth'| '*navel'.}];399[354{S.v. Skt. śuṇḍā f. 'Elefantenrüssel / an elephant's trunk'. Probably non-Indo-European.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit śuṇḍā- 'elephant's trunk' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):725, no. 12516). Further etymology uncertain; probably a loanword from a non-Indo-European source (cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:354 for discussion of various proposals).

Source: 274[195-196{?*gʷr̥d- 'slow, languid' > Greek βραδύς, Lithuanian gurdùs, Latvian gur̃das etc. The reconstruction of this root is uncertain, it can be also related to *gʷreh₂- 'heavy'. The relationship of Latin gurdus 'stupid' to ?*gʷr̥d- is dubious. According to Blažek's interpretation of Slavic *gŭrdŭ, South Slavic forms like Bulgarian g"rd / gr"d 'ugly, bad', Macedonian grd 'ugly', Slovene  grd 'ugly' would belong here.}];81[198{PS *gŭrdŭ 'proud' may be cognate with Lithuanian gurdùs 'weak, slow, uncommunicative, stiff' and Latvian gur̃ds 'tired, weary', even though some irregular correspondence in stress. If the Slavic and Baltic words are related, they can be connected with Greek βραδύς 'slow, dull, sluggish' < PIE *gʷrdus.}];249[{In spite of the general constistence of the literature regarding to the possible IE cognacy, the etymology of this lexeme and the PIE root it was derived from remain uncertain.}];458[7: 207{Further IE cognacy of PS *gŭrdŭ is problematic. It has been linked to Lithuanian gurdùs 'slow', Latvian gur̃ds 'tired' and Greek βραδύς 'slow' (< *gʷr̥dus). The coexistence of two distinct meanings 'proud, arch' and 'terrible, ugly' and the unclear further cognacy suggest an innovative and expressive nature of this lexeme.}];594[{PS *grъdъ is probably derived from PIE *gu̯r̥Hdu/o- 'heavy' (< PIE *gu̯erH- 'heavy'), cf. Lithuanian gurdùs, Latvian gur̃ds, less probably Greek βραδύς.}];54[275{Latin gurdus 'blockhead, dolt' is derived from PIE *gʷrd-o- and related to Greek βραδύς 'slow', Lithuanian gurdùs 'slow', Latvian gur̃ds 'tired', Old Church Slavonic *gŭrdŭ and Russian gordyj 'proud, haughty'.}];66[234{"[...] βραδύς may morphologically be identical with Lith. gurdùs, Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', reflecting *gʷrdú- [...]. Lat. gurdus 'dolt, heavy' can be connected as well [...]".}]
249[{Loan from German Forst 'forest'.}]

595[187{Most authors reconstruct PIE *mele-k-, *mlāk- 'soft, weak, turbid' and link it to Greek βλᾱ́ξ 'faint, weak, blunt'. More probably it is related to PS *smola 'pitch'.}];594[{The lexeme is derived from PS *molka 'puddle, mud' (PIE *melk- 'wetness, dampness', cf. Greek mélkion 'spring', Gothic milhma 'cloud', Lithuanian mal̃kas, let. màlks 'gulp'). It is less probable that this lexeme is related to Greek blā́ks 'turbid, soft' or derived from PIE *(s)mel- 'burn slowly, smolder'}];458[19: 150, 188-189| 18: 84-88{The adjective *molčĭnŭ(jĭ) is derived from PS *molka and related to *melko 'milk'. These lexemes are derived from PIE *melk- (*mel-k-) 'drain, spill, swell'.}]
Justification: The etymology and further cognacy is uncertain. For the discussion on the nativity of PS *melko 'milk' and its relationship to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk' see [ESSJa](src-458): 18: 87-88 (the authors claim that PS *melko 'milk' is not derived from / related to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk').

Source: 249[{See [cognate set 7768](cog-7768).}]

274[311-317{Cf. s.v. *h₂ep- 'Wasser, Fluß' (IEW 1,51f., 1149| EIEC 486, 636).}];269[{Perhaps root-cognate with of Anatolian and Celtic lexemes meaning 'river', if the Celtic lexemes are to be analysed as from ?*h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 311-317 and further discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)).}];432[{Cf. s.v. Kâtʹa vari gulʹava 'River (in a steep-sided valley)' (to be analysed as gul-âva 'valley-water').}];442[19{For MIA, NIA and Nuristani forms, cf. s.v. 407 áp f., pl. ā́paḥ 'waters' RV.}];353[483{S.v. Lith. ùpė 'river, stream' (Latv. upe 'river, stream', OPr. ape 'brook, stream'), from PIE *h₂ep- (cf. Skt. áp- 'water', TochB āp 'water').}];352[1155-1156{S.v. OLith. ùpė (2), upė̃ (4) 'Fluss, Strom, Bach' (BSl. Latv. upe 'Fluss, Bach', OPr. ape 'Fluss', etc.), from PIE *h₂óp-/*h₂ep- 'Wasser, Fluss' (cf. Ved. áp- 'Wasser, Strom', OAv. ap-, YAv. āfš, OPers. ap-, TochA āp-, TochB āp- 'Wasser, Fluss'.}]
Justification: Baltic and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ep- 'water, river' ([NIL](src-274) 311-317, [EWAia](src-172) I:81-82, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):19, [Strand 2011a](src-432), no. 407, [ALEW](src-352) 1155-1156, [Derksen 2015](src-353):483). Perhaps root-cognate with of Anatolian and Celtic lexemes meaning 'river', if the Celtic lexemes are to be analysed as from ?*h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 311-317 and further discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)).

Source: 84[{Origin unknown.}]

Source: 49[675];236[{Cf. s.v. W llefaf : llefain 'to cry out, exclaim, cry, shout, lament| call, entreat| weep, shed tears' cf. Middle Cornish lefes ‘?gwaeddodd’, Middle Breton leffaff, leuffal, Modern Breton leñvañ, leanein.}];309[459{Cf. s.v. Bret. leñvañ 'pleurer, crier'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Brythonic uncertain. Traditionally connected to a PIE root 2. *lem- ([IEW](src-49) 675), but not in [LIV²](src-141) or [Schumacher 2004](src-304). For probable cognates in Breton cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Deshayes 2003](src-309):459 (without comparing Welsh lexemes).

Demiraj (1997:314) who attempts alternative etymologies.}];369[314]
Justification: Generally considered a loan from Latin penna 'feather, wing, pinion' ([Orel 1998](src-105):315, [Holm 2011](src-130):62), but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):62 who attempts alternative etymologies.
Loan from Romanian.

Source: 141[172{Cf. s.v. *g̑ʰed- 'scheißen' (IEW 423).}];369[290-291{S.v. Alb. ndoh 'beschmutzen'| connected by [Meyer 1891](src-585):301 with (g.) ndyj, (t.) ndyr| [Jokl 1911](src-661):61-62 instead suggests an inner-Albanian connection to dhjes 'scheißen'.}];105[287{S.v. Alb. (T) ndohtë 'dirty, foul', based on ndoh 'to make dirty', an inchoative desiderative form of ndyj ([Meyer 1891](src-585):301), alternatively [Jokl 1911](src-661):61-62 to dhjes, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):290-291.}];661[61-62];585[301]
Justification: Root etymology in this class follows the proposal of [Jokl 1911](src-661):61-62 to an inner-Albanian connection with dhjes 'shit (on), ruin' to PIE *g̑ʰed- ({ref IEW 423; tentatively followed by [LIV²](src-141) 172, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):290-291); cf. alternatively [Orel 1998](src-105):287 following [Meyer 1891](src-585):301 assumes a connection to Albanian ndyj 'to make dirty, soil, to dip, immerse' connecting to Gk. δύω 'to sink, cause to sink, to plunge in' < *du̯eH- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 129-130, without Albanian).

Source: 141[274{S.v. *h₂eu̯- 'genießen' (IEW 77-8). The Albanian forms are perhaps from a thematic present stem ?*h₂éu̯-e-.}];364[975-976{S.v. Alb. ha 'essen', plausibly a derivation *h₂éu̯-e/o- to the root *h₂eu̯- 'genießen' (LIV² 274)| connections to IE ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- (LIV² 359f.) are problematic.}];105[140-141{S.v. Alb. ha 'to eat', which O. derives from IE *ed- 'to eat'.}];130[59-60{Rejects all previously proposed etymologies and regards the etymology of Alb. ha 'still [an] open case'.}]
Justification: Root etymology follows [LIV²](src-141) 274, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):975-976, tentatively also [Huld 1984](src-571):72. However, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):140-141 who proposes to PIE *h₁ed- 'eat', and [Holm 2011](src-130):59-60 who rejects all previously proposed etymologies.

Source: 364[994-995{S.v. Alb. rri 'sitzen| sich setzen, sich niederlassen| bleiben, verweilen'. It is usually considered to be unexplained, but there is no good reason not to connect it with PIE ?*(h₁)rei̯d- '(sich) anlehnen' (LIV² 503).}];105[388{S.v. Alb. rroj 'to live, to stay', continuing PAlb. *rānja and identical with Lith. róju, róti 'to cope, to be ready', further connected with ríeti 'to stack (wood)' and derived from IE *rēi-. Other proposals include to Gk. ῥώομαι 'to move strongly, to dance' (Camarda I 92), to Lat. regere 'to direct' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):375), from Romance *remanāre (Mann, Language 17 p.12).}]
Justification: Root etymology disputed, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):388, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):994-995 for various proposals.
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. [cognate set 126](cog-126)).

Source: 444[59{S.v. 744 astrātum 'gestirnt' (> Log. astráu, ástrau 'Eis', bistradu 'Eis' (with bi- taken over from biddia).}];54[585{S.v. Lat. stēlla 'star', from PItal. *stērla-, derived from PIE *h₂stēr-s, *h₂ster- 'star' (cf. OIr. ser, W. seren, Co. sterenn, Bret. sterenn < PCl. *ster-, OIr. sell 'iris' < *stillo-, MIr. sellaid 'to see', MW syllu 'to gaze', Bret. sellout 'to watch' < PCl. stīrlo- 'star' < PIE *h₂stēr-lo-| Hitt. hašter(a)- 'star' < *h₂ster-| Skt. tā́raḥ (nom.pl), stŕ̥bhiḥ (instr.pl.), Av. star-, Khot. stārra- 'star', Gk. ἀστήρ, -έρος, Arm. astł, Goth. stairno, TochB ścriye 'star'). The Italic forms reflect an additional adjectival suffix *-lo- added to nom.sg. stem *h₂stēr-, from which the new substantive 'star' was taken from the feminine form, i.e. Proto-Italic *stēr-lā- > Lat. stēlla.}];274[348-354{S.v. *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ f. 'Stern' (IEW 1027f. EIEC 543).}]
Justification: From Latin astrātum 'starred' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):59), a derivative of Latin aster 'star' < PIE *h₂ster- 'star', cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):585, [NIL](src-274) 348-354, and 'star' in [cognate set 131](cog-131) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 157[183-184{S.v. graua 'sable, gravier'. A word attested in Romance dialects that have been attributed to a Gaulish origin on the basis of correspondences in Insular Celtic (cf. Fr. grève, gravier, dial. groue, Provençal, Catalan grava, Venetian grava, Friulian grave = Welsh gro, Old Cornish grou 'arena', Breton gro 'sable de rivière' from Proto-Celtic *grau̯ā < *grou̯ā, further OIr. griän 'gravier', and river names Grosne (Saône-et-L.) and Grouesme (Côte-d'Or) < *Grauonā, *Grauisamā 'rivières graveleuses'. Perhaps to an IE root *gʰreu- 'écraser, broyer' ([IEW](src-49) 460, among others)| a pre-IE word according to [Campanile 1974](src-730).}];730[131-138];444[328{Cf. s.v. 3851 grava (gall.) 'Stein', cf. Welsh gro 'Kieselstein'}]
Justification: Probably from Proto-Celtic *grau̯ā (cf. Old Irish griän 'gravel', Welsh gro 'gravel, shingle'), postulated for Gaulish on the basis of loanwords attested in Romance ([Delamarre 2003](src-157):183-184, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):328 no. 3851). Further etymology uncertain: [IEW](src-49) 460 suggests a root etymology *gʰreu- 'to crush, grind', [Campanile 1974](src-730):131-138 argues for a pre-IE loanword.

Comment: Cheung (2007: 368) assumes a root su(m)p/b "to make up, beautify" together with the prefix ni- "down"

Comment: cf. Henning "Sogdica" (1940: 51): "Here, ʾʾywz is clearly "pond, fish-pond", or "lake" ("river", as the obvious etymology might suggest, is perhaps less likely)." Could this word be related to Sogdian ʾwzy "lake"? The Parthian reading may then be 'āywaz' or similar.
