Source: 585[379{S.v. sarí 'gelbsüchtig' (geg.) from Turk. sarε 'gelb'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Turkish sarı 'yellow' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):379).
Brythonic lexemes continuing derivatives of a Proto-Celtic lexical root *su̯ek- (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):163, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Source: 50[353-354{S.v. Proto-Celtic *stagrā 'river, stream', which may be derived from IE *steh₂g- 'pool' (cf. Lat. stāgnum 'pool', Gk. στάζω 'drip').}];309[687{S.v. Bret. staer 'rivière, ruisseau| berge, étier', from Old Breton staer 'fleuve', from Proto-Celtic *stag-ra}];141[592{S.v. ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'träufeln| tropfen, tröpfeln' (IEW 1010). Only as a verbal root in Greek, cf. Lat. stāgnum 'body of water', Old Breton staer f. 'river, creek'. Alternatively perhaps from *sta⁽g̑⁾-.}];772[649-657{Does not accept the Celtic etymology *stagrā originally proposed by Henry (1900, 253) and repeated by several recent etymological dictionaries.  He follows Trépos 1954 instead, who suggested that OBr. staer, ModBr. ster 'river' was borrowed from Latin aestuarium, Vulgar Latin estuarium, esterium 'étier, an inlet, etc., covered by the sea at high tide, tidal opening| a river estuary'. There are no words supporting the alleged Celtic *stagrā in the other Celtic languages. The oldest attestations for OBr ster are the rivernames found in the Cartulaire de Redon (10th or 11th c.) like Stergavale, Stergaule fluvius. In the 13th c., the Cartulaire of Landévennec notes "an-Staer " (containing the definite article) as a name of an estate. At the same time, legal documents contain place-names like Banastère (1300-1305), Benester (1300), Beneistier, Benetier (1365), Staerguezel (1366), Lestoer, Listoir (1434). While some of these names render Breton in Old French orthography, others are hybrid forms employing estoir, estier, the Old French continuation of Latin aestuarium.  OBr. staer has become the word for 'river' in the Modern dialects of Léon, Landéda, a part of Cornouaille and around the Golf of Morbihan. But iits original meaning is broader like in Latin. Regionally, ster means 'river mouth, estuary', 'saltworks' or 'washhouse, washplace'. Latin estuarium is neuter, while Breton ster has feminine instead of the expected masculine gender. Trépos argues it could have been influenced by aven f., the word for river used by the Brittonic immigrants.}];773[392{Br. ster from Latin estuarium, esterium 'étier| an inlet, etc., covered by the sea at high tide, tidal opening| a river estuary' is found in place-names, either on its own or compounded. Ster as first element: Ster-goz, Ster-zu, Ster-Kreiz, Sternalé, Sterlan, Stervins, etc. Ster as second element: Pen-er-Ster, Pont-Ster, Kerester, etc.}];348[253{From Proto-Celtic *stagrā and cognate with Gk. σταγών 'drop', στάζω 'drip', Lat. stāgnum 'pool'.}];307[103{Compares OBr. to Latin and Greek.}];775[79-80{ModBr. stêr 'river' originates from Old French estier 'canal', which comes from Lat. aestuarium 'estuary'. Its use in the modern dialects is restricted to Vannetais and Western Cornouaille. At a very early time, it superseded the Brittonic word avon. Gives a list of place-names and river names containing stêr.}]
Justification:
Although the "Celtic" etymology of OBr. staer figures in the etymological dictionaries, there was never a real discussion of this isolated word, which shares with the Latin and Greek words only the root, not the suffix(es). Bernier, on the other hand, convincingly points out the extensive parallelism in the semantics of staer, ster and estoir, estier and of their use in onomastics.
It seems possible, that Old Breton, being exposes to intense linguistic contace, had several words for river. These were regional varieties or linked to different speaker groups respectively.

Source: 309[301{From OBr. guoath, guoeth, goeth 'stream. Cognate with OCorn. guid, MCorn. gwyth, goth, MW guyth, W gwyth 'vein, sinew| stream, brook| channel| estuary', OIr. féith 'fibre, sinew| swamp, marsh'. Further cognate: Latin vitta 'ribbon, cord'.}];50[419{In Olr. there is also feith [f] which means 'sinew', but also 'kidney' (in the glosses)| this is probably just a homonym of feith 'swamp' (as suggested by DIL). It is probably the same word as W gwythi [p] 'veins'. These words are usually derived from the root *weyh₁- 'twist, turn' (IEW 1122), but this is dubious on semantic grounds. PIE *weyh₁- 'wither' (IEW 1123) is a better candidate (cf. PCelt. *wiwo- 'withered'). The Brit. reflexes point to a double stop (*-tt-) in PCelt., but the Olr. form is derivable from PCelt. *weta with a single *-t-.}];299[202-204{Discusses the formal problems of this difficult cognate set, i.e. different suffixes in Irish and Brittonic, simple -t- in Irish vs. -tt- in Brittonic, underlying PIE roots.}];301[178, 149{OBr. goed 'stream, ruisseau' (with d representing [θ]) is first attested in dol goed, a plant-name 'potamot, epis d'eau| caprifolium, woodbine'. The literal meaning is 'leaf/leaves of the stream'. The Breton word corresponds to Middle Irish duille féithe 'caprifolium, woodbine'.}]

Justification: Loan from English river

Not in [Deshayes 2003](src-309), but an obvious recent loan from French poitrine (< Late Latin *pectorīnus 'belonging to the breast', a derivative of Latin pectus, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):521).

Source: 309[361-362{S.v. Bret. kalon 'cœur| âme (de cordage)', from Old Breton calonn, corresponding to Cornish calon and Welsh calon, from Celtic *kal-ona-.}];348[50-51{S.v. Bret. kalon, kaloun 'cœur' (Co. colon, W calon 'id.') Proto-Celtic *kal-onā may be cognate to 1) Latin calidus 'warm, hot' or to 2) Latin callidus 'experienced' (the heart was conceived as the organ of intelligence).}];236[{No etymology outside of Brythonic given s.v. W calon.}]
Justification: Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50); no etymology given in [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [Henry 1900](src-348):50-51 for various older proposals.

Source: 309[677{S.v. Bret. son 'son', a borrowing from Lat. sonus from which also Old French son 'son, chanson, mélodie'.}]
Justification: Loan from Latin sonus 'a noise, sound' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):677).
Indic lexemes going back to phaṇati 'swells, rises, boils', presumably contaminated with phūṭ- 'blowing, puffing'. Details are unclear and both roots are probably onomatopoetic in origin.

Source: 309[399-400{S.v. Bret. klor 'cosses, gousses, écorces dures, bogues, carapaces', supposes Old Breton *clotr without correspondences in other Celtic languages.}]

Justification: Loan from English cloud.

Source: 782[{The archaic West Frisian is flesk (no longer used)}]
Justification: Loanword from Dutch vlees 'meat'.

Source: 782[{The Old Frisian form is threwia, so this must be a loanword}]
782[{Possible loanword, although in this meaning the Frisian lexeme is contrastive with Standard Dutch, the original Fr. word being the extinct tsjea (OFri. thiach).}]

Justification: Cognate with [cognate set 8503](cog-8503) via semantics 'cloud of (dust)'?
Continuing Latin lignum 'wood' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):408 no. 5034). Further root etymology disputed, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):340-341 for further discussion.

Comment: < Lat. bēstia 'wild animal'???

Source: 54[252{Cf. s.v. Lat. fuscus 'dark-coloured, dusky| (of persons) dark-skinned', from PIE *dʰus-ko-| cf. Lat. furvus 'dark-coloured, dusky' < *dʰus-u̯o- 'dark, black, brown' (cf. OIr. donn 'dun, light brown', MW dwnn 'dusky', OE dox 'dark-haired, dusky', MoE dusk, OE dosen 'dun, dingy-brown, dark-coloured').}];444[308{S.v. 3611 Lat. fuscus 'dunkel'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Lat. fuscus 'dark-coloured, dusky' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):308), further derived from PIE *dʰeu̯s- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):263-264, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):252).

Comment: Via Lat. restāre?
Cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935 9355 viria 'Armband'?

Source: 443[4:493-498{Cf. s.v. Lat. hospitalis 'gastfreundlich' > 1. Unterkunft.}];54[291{S.v. Lat. hospes, -itis 'guest, visitor| host, entertainer', from Proto-Italic *χosti-pot- (cf. Paelig. hospus 'stranger')| IE cognates in OCS gospodь, Ru. gospód' 'the Lord, god' < *gʰost(i)-pot-, a compound of hostis and potis.}];279[335-336{Cf. s.v. P. hospus 'Fremder', probably *gʰosti-pot-s with syncope of the second syllable and weakening of the vowel o > u, closely comparable to Lat. hospes 'Gastgeber, Gast'.}]
Justification: Continuing Latin hospitalis, -e 'hospitable' in a nominalised sense of 'accommodation; house' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:493-498). Latin hospitalis is further a derived adjective from Latin hospes, itis 'guest, visitor; host, entertainer', probably an old compound containing the roots of hostis 'foreigner; enemy' < PIE *gʰosti- and potis, -e 'having power' < PIE *poti- 'master, in control of' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):291, [Untermann 2000](src-279):336, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):300-301).

Continuing a Latin verb bāiulāre 'to carry' with a later semantic evolution 'to bring (over)' > 'to give' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 1:206, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):71 no. 887). Latin bāiulāre is further a denominal verb to Lat. bāiulus 'porter', of obscure etymology ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):68, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):64).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan tuosto < Lat. tŏstu(m), cf. It. tosto.}];269[{Lat. tostum = p.p.p. of torreō 'heat so as to dry up, burn, scorch, parch' (OLD).}];141[637-638{Cf. s.v. *ters- 'vertrocknen| durstig werden' (IEW 1078-9), where Lat. torreō from PIE cs. stem *tors-éi̯e-.}];54[624-625{S.v. Lat. torreō 'to scorch, roast', from PIE *tors-eie- 'make dry' (cf. Hitt. tarš- 'to become dry', Skt. tr̥ṣyant- (act.part.), tr̥ṣa- (aor.) 'to be thirsty', YAv. taršu- 'dry, not fluid'), derived from PIE *ters-.}];444[731{S.v. 8814 Lat. tostus 'gebacken' (> Neap. tuoste, Venez. tosto, Trient. tost 'hart').}]
Justification: From Latin tostum, cf. It. tosto ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):731 no. 8814), originally the past passive participle of Latin torreō, -ere 'to scorch, roast' from PIE *ters- 'become dry' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):624-625, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 637-638).

Source: 444[377{Cf. s.v. 4635 Lat. jūstus 'gerecht, recht'}];54[316-317{S.v. Lat. iūs, -ris 'law', with deriv. adj. iūstus 'lawful, just', from PIE *h₂oi-u-, gen. *h₂i-eu-s 'vital force, eternity' >> s-stem *h₂ieu-os-, -es-.}];274[283n17{"Zu lat. iūs, das wegen alat. iovestod (iūstō? CIL I² 1, Forum-Inschr.) iovesat (iūrat?) CIL 1² 4, Duenos-Inschr.) zunächst auf *i̯ou̯-es- zurückgeführt werden kann, s. auch WH I 733f., Schrijver 1991, 273f. Szemerényi loc. cit. 170f. bevorzugt Anschluß an *i̯eu̯- 'verbinden' (LIV 314), Willi HS 114 (2001) 136f. erwägt Zusammenhang mit *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'in Bewegung geraten' (LIV 225f.), dessen eigene Rekonstruktion freilich zu modifizieren sei, schleißt aber Verbindung zu ved. yóḥ, aav. yaoš- wiederum nicht aus. s. ferner Willi, Ériu 52 (2002), 235ff."}]
Justification: As though from Latin iūstus 'lawful, just', a derived adjective from Latin iūs 'law'. Further etymology disputed (cf. [NIL](src-274) 283n17, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):316-317 for various proposals and further discussion).
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.

Romance lexemes continuing a secondary derivative from Latin vāstāre 'to make desolate, lay waste', itself a derivative verb from Lat. vāstus 'empty, desolate', as though continuing PIE *h₁u̯eh₂-sto- ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):765 no. 9168, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):655-656, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):714-715, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 254).

Source: 444[546{Cf. s.v. 6578 Lat. plāntare 'pflanzen'.}];54[470{Cf. s.v. Lat. planta 'sole of the foot', from PIE *pl(e)h₂-nt-h₂- 'the flat one' (cf. Lat. plānus 'level, flat'). Lat. planta 'shoot of a plant' is commonly hypothesised to be backformed to an unattested verb *plantāre 'to level the earth' or 'to plant crops with the sole of the foot' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):512 s.v. II. planta). If so, then planta 'shoot of a plant' would ultimately go back to the PIE root *pelh₂- found in Lat. plānus 'level, flat', Hitt. palḫi- 'wide, broad', Lith. plónas 'thin', etc.}];274[562-564{Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).}]
Justification: As though from Latin *plantāre, a verbal derivative from Latin planta 'sole of the foot' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):470, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):512, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Source: 444[308-309{S.v. 3618 Lat. fūstis 'Knüppel'.}];54[253{S.v. Lat. fūstis 'stick, rod'. Uncertain, maybe to be connected with Germanic *bosk- 'wood' words.}];316[264{S.v. Lat. fūstis 'bâton'. Uncertain etymology.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin fūstis 'stick, rod' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):308-309), no certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):264; cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):253 for discussion of some recent proposals).

Source: 444[445{S.v. 5424 Lat. matta 'Decke', 2. natta.}];316[390{S.v. Lat. matta, -ae f. 'natte' (late), also found in Germanic (cf. OE matte, meatta 'Matze'), doubtlessly a loanword.}]
316[596{S.v. Lat. sāpō, -ōnis 'savon', a loanword from Germanic or Celtic (cf. Bret. sebon, Germ. Seife').}];444[628{S.v. 7589 Lat. sāpō, -ōne 'Seife'.}]
Justification: Denominal verbs from Latin sāpō 'soap' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):628). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loanword from either Celtic or Germanic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):596).

Source: 444[263{Cf. s.v. 2998 Lat. excutere 'herausschlagen', with derivative log. iskuttinare.}];54[504-505{Cf. s.v. Lat. quatiō, -ere 'to shake, toss, hurry along', with derivative excutere 'to shake out, throw off', from PIE *(s)kuot-i-? (cf. Lith. kùsti, 3s. kùnta 'to recover', OS scuddian, OHG scutten 'to shake', OIc. hossa 'to throw').}];316[552-553];141[563-564{S.v. *(s)ku̯eh₁t- 'durchschütteln, aufrütteln' (IEW 632, 957-8)| *(s)kuh₁t-i̯é- > [lat. quatiō, -cutiō 'schütteln, erschüttern, stoßen'.}]
Justification: Cf. Latin ex-cutere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):263 no. 2998), further to PIE *(s)ku̯eh₁t- 'to shake thoroughly, to startle' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):504-505, [LIV²](src-141) 563-564, cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):552-553).

Source: 444[46{S.v. 570 Lat. aqua 'Wasser'.}]
Justification: Continuing Latin aqua 'water' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):46 no. 570), cf. 'water' in [cognate set 953](cog-953) and 'river' in [cognate set 2649](cog-2649) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 579[{Neapolitan ruosso < Lat. grŏssu(m).}];54[273{S.v. Lat. grossus 'immature fig| thick, unripe'. Etymology unclear. IEW had earlier connected Lat. grossus with Welsh bras 'thick'.}];444[330-331{S.v. 3881 Lat. grossus 'dick'.}]
Justification: From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):273), formerly connected by [IEW](src-49) 485 with Celtic *brasso- in [cognate set 4355](cog-4355).

Source: 54[332-333{Cf. s.v. legō, -ere 'to gather, collect| read' (w/ preverb con- > colligere 'to gather, collect'), from PIE *leg̑-e/o- 'to collect' (cf. Gk. λέγω 'to collect, count| speak', Alb. mb-ledh 'to collect').}];141[397{Cf. s.v. *leg̑- 'sammeln, auflesen' (IEW 658).}];444[194{Cf. s.v. 2048 Lat. colligere 'sammeln, pfücken'.}]
Justification: Continuing Latin colligere 'to gather, collect; read' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):194 no. 2048), in origin a compound con-legere, further to PIE *leg̑- 'to gather, pick up' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):332-333, [LIV²](src-141) 397).

Source: 165[18-19{S.v. Proto-Germanic *akrana- 'tree fruit, acorn' (cf. OIr. áirne 'sloe, fruit of the blackthorn, kernel', MW eirin 'sloes, berries, plums' < PCl. *agrn-io-| W aeron 'fruits, berries' < PCl. *agr-on-ā| Lith. úoga 'berry' < *h₂og-eh₂-| OCS agoda 'fruit', Ru. jágoda 'berry', SCr. jȁgoda 'wild strawberry, berry'| ToB oko 'fruit, effect'). "A clear Europeanism." To be derived with a suffix -ana- (also found in ONor. aldin, Far. aldan, OSw. aldon 'tree-fruit, mast' < *aldana-) on root *agr- which is "derivationally obscure", but is similar to the base reconstructed for account to for Celtic forms (e.g. OIr. áirne 'sloe', Wel. aeron 'fruits, berries' < Proto-Celtic *agrn-io-). "[T]he appurtenance of ToB oko (see Adams 1999:109-110) is uncertain, as it may have been derived from the PIE root *h₂eug- 'to grow'."}];179[25{S.v. Goth. A106. akran 'καρπός', 'fruit, results', from PIE *ōg 'grow, fruit, berry' (cf. OIr. āirne < *ag-rīn-ya 'sloe', Wel. aeron 'fruits, berries', Corn. aeran 'plum', Lith. úoga, Latv. uôga, OCS (j)agoda 'berry').}];352[1151-1152{Cf. s.v. OLith. úoga 'Beere'. No secure comparanda outside of Balto-Slavic| perhaps root cognate with TochB oko 'Frucht', possibly conceivable is a further connection to the Celtic family of OIr. áirne 'Frucht des Schlehdorns', MW aeron 'Früchte, Beeren', eirin 'Pflaumen, Zwetschgen| Früchte des Schlehdorns| Beeren', which must have started with Proto-Celtic *agr-. Corresponding in Germanic is Goth. akran 'Frucht', akranalaus 'unfruchtbar', and with metathesis ON akarn, OE æcern 'Eichel'. The hypothesis that the Celtic and Germanic words go back to PIE *h₂eg̑ró- or *h₂ég̑ro- 'Feld' (cf. Ved. ájra-, Gk. ἀγρός, Lat. ager, Goth. akrs) is questionable on semantic grounds.}];345[115{[NB: This entry supersedes Adams (1999:109-110) cited in Kroonen (2013:18-19)] Cf. s.v. TochB oko 'fruit| result, consequence'. Clearly related to Tocharian A oko, but the shape of the form suggests that one was borrowed from one language to the other rather than being true cognates. There are two possible etymologies: (1) to PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'grow, increase' (cf. TochB auk- 'grow, increase'), however this assumes that the TochB lexeme would be a borrowing from TochA, but it is difficult to see the B word being borrowed from A rather than A from B, which is far more often the case| more attractive is (2) that the word may be related to PIE *h₂ógeh₂- 'fruit, berry' (cf. Lith. úoga 'berry, cherry', Latv. uôga 'berry| pustule, pockmark', OCS (j)agoda 'berry', Ru. jágoda 'berry', and more distantly with Goth. akran 'fruit', ON akarn 'fruit of a wild plant', OE œcern 'acorn', NHG Ecker 'id.', Old Irish áirne 'plum', aeron 'fruit, berry'| The underlying verb survives in Arm. ačem 'grow'.}];81[27{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *agoda 'berry' (ESSJa I 57-59). From PIE ?*h₂og-eh₂- (cf. Goth. akran 'fruit (of trees, corn)'). Adams connects TochB oko 'fruit, effect' also to the Balto-Slavic forms (with the Germanic forms being more remote), although the vocalism of the Tocharian form is not without its problems.}]
Justification: Possibly related to TochB oko in [cognate set 2653](cog-2653), and Balto-Slavic and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn', but the exact etymological connection is uncertain because of problems in formal reconstruction. Cf. further discussion in [Kroonen 2013](src-165):18-19, [ALEW](src-352) 1151-1152, [Derksen 2008](src-81):27, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):25.

Source: 564[451{S.v. 168. լաւ law. Hübschmann proposed two possible comparisons: either to Gk. λωίων 'better' (from *λωϝιων)? or to Lith. lãbas 'good' [cognate set 678](cog-678), but Hübschmann marks both with '?' to indicate that both are uncertain proposals.}];319[181-182{Considers the etymological connection of Arm. լաւ law with Gk. λωΐων doubtful, following Hübschmann.}];269[{Etymology uncertain. No connection to Lithuanian lãbas, etc., as suggested by [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 is accepted by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352) (cf. [cognate set 678](cog-678)). [Clackson 1994](src-319):181-182 likewise finds Hübschmann's proposed connection to Gk. λωΐων doubtful. Arm. law seems to be etymologically isolated.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. No connection to Lithuanian lãbas, etc., as suggested by [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 is accepted by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352) (cf. [cognate set 678](cog-678)). [Clackson 1994](src-319):181-182 likewise finds Hübschmann's proposed connection to Gk. λωΐων doubtful. Arm. law seems to be etymologically isolated.

Source: 567[259{S.v. Bact. ραγο 'bad'. "Etymology unknown."}]
Justification: No certain etymology ([Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):259).

Source: 442[84{Cf. s.v. 1832 *utpruṣati 'bubbles up'. [utprúṣ- f. 'bubble' VS.: √pruṣ-1].}];431[{S.v. Kâmvʹiri âpsʹa- 'swell up' cf. T.1832 *ut-prus-a- 'bubbles up' but with (â- instead of ud-).}];172[II:192-193{Cf. s.v. Ved. √proṣ- 'träufeln, beträufeln, sprühen, besprengen, bespritzen, ausschütten' (Mi., Nu.(?, s. Tu. 1832))| cf. Ir. frau̯š-/fruš in words for milk-drinks, from PIE *(s?)preu̯s(H)-, probably to be connected with West IE words for 'Reif, Frost', Lat. pruīna-, OHG frost, etc.}];141[493{Cf. s.v. *preu̯s- 'sprühen, spritzen' (IEW 809-10, 846).}]
Justification: As though from *ā-prus-a- 'bubble up' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):84 no. 1832), further to PIE *preu̯s- 'to spray, spatter' ([EWAia](src-172) II:192-193, [LIV²](src-141) 493).

Source: 80[391{S.v. Hitt. išḫaḫru- 'tear(s)', from which išḫaḫruu̯e/a- 'to weep' is a derivative. If one assumes a base *h₂ek̑-ru- the Hittite word for tear might be cognate with Skt. áśru-, TochA ākär, ākrunt (nom.pl.), Lith. ãšara, ašarà 'tear', but to make the etymology work one must assume the Hittite lexeme had a prothetic *s- and an assimilation of *h₂ek̑- to *h₂eh₂-. (This assimilation is, however, unparalleled elsewhere in Hittite.), further this might then perhaps be related to other Western IE words for 'tear' following the proposal of [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574) that words such as Ancient Greek δάκρυ, OHG zahar, Arm. artaswr, Lat. lacrima 'tear' reflect an earlier compound *dr̥k̑-h₂(e)k̑ru- 'eye-bitter'.}];574[59-61{For further discussion of Kortlandt's proposed etymology *dr̥k̑-h₂(e)k̑ru- 'tear' elsewhere among the IE languages, cf. [cognate set 5111](cog-5111).}]
Justification: Perhaps root cognate with Western IE words for 'tear' (Gk. δάκρυ, OHG zahar, Arm. artaswr, etc.), if both are based on earlier *h₂k̑ru- 'bitter' as a derivative from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'be/make sharp' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):391, cf. [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574):59-61 and further discussion in [cognate set 5111](cog-5111)).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan campà is a derivative of Lat. campu(m), cf. It. campare.}];54[86{S.v. Lat. campus 'flat land, field', from Proto-Italic *kampo- 'field', usually derived from a putative PIE root *kamp- 'bend' (cf. Gk. κάμπω 'to bend, curve', καμπή 'bow, curvature', Lith. kam̃pas 'corner', kum̃pti 'to bend', kum̃pas 'curved', OCS kǫtъ 'corner', Goth. hamfs 'mutilated, lame', OHG hamf). However initial ca- is difficult to explain| [Beekes 2010](src-66) suggests that the proposed Greek cognates come from a substratum language. Perhaps Latin campus may also be originally borrowed from a European substratum word in the semantic area of agricultural terminology.}];66[632-633{Beekes considers that the IE reconstruction would require *kh₂mp- 'a root structure that is suspicious'.}];141[342{S.v. *kamp- 'krümmen, biegen' (IEW 525), cf. n1 'fraglich lat. campus m. 'Feld'.'}];444[145-146{S.v. 1563 Lat. campus 'Feld'.}]
Justification: A derivative of Latin campus 'field', cf. Italian campare 'to live' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):145-146 no. 1563). Traditionally further to an Indo-European root *kamp- 'bend, curve' in the sense 'broad, curved (valley)' > 'field' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 525, [LIV²](src-141) 342n1 'fraglich'). The necessity of reconstructing PIE *a (a root structure *kh₂mp- appearing unusual) has renewed the hypothesis that Latin campus is in fact a European substratum word from agricultural terminology ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):86, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):632-633).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan vuttà loaned from Germanic, either Franconian bōtan or Gothic bautan. Cf. It. buttare and Walloon and Anglo-Norman bouter [cognate set 1042](cog-1042).}]
Justification: Loan from Germanic.

Source: 579[{Neapolitan ammulato is a derivative of Lat. mŏla(m) 'millstone', cf. It. molàre 'affilare'.}];54[386-387{S.v. Lat. molō, -ere, 'to grind in a mill', from which Lat. mola 'millstone' is a derivative. Ultimately derived from PIE *melh₂- 'crush, grind'.}];141[432-433{Cf. s.v. *melh₂- 'zerreiben, mahlen' (IEW 716-7).}]
Justification: A derivative of Latin mola(m) 'millstone' (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), further to PIE *melh₂- 'grind' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):386-387, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 432-433).

Source: 579[{Etymology unknown.}]
Justification: Of uncertain etymology (Giovanni Abete, p.c.).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan avutà < Lat. *voltāre, cf. It. voltare.}];269[{Lat. *voltāre < Lat. uolutāre, an intensive formation from Lat. uoluō 'cause to revolve, roll'.}];54[689-690{S.v. volvō, -ere 'to (cause to) go round, roll', from PIE *uel-u- 'to wind' (cf. OIr. fillid < PCl. *u̯el-n-o- 'bend', Bret. goalenn 'green twig' < *u̯el-, Gk. εἰλύω 'to wind round', Arm. egel 'he turned', Goth. walwjan, OE wealwian 'to revolve (oneself)', TochB wäl- 'to curl (intr./tr.)').}];316[752{S.v. Lat. uoluō 'rouler, faire rouler'.}];141[675{S.v. 2. *u̯el- 'drehen, rollen' (IEW 1140-2).}];444[789{S.v. 9446 Lat. *volvitāre 'wenden', 2. *voltāre.}]
Justification: Neapolitan avutà as though from Latin *voltāre 'to turn' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935}:789), an unattested intensive/iterative formation to Latin voluō 'to turn' and further to PIE 2. u̯el- 'to turn, roll' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):752, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):689-690, [LIV²](src-141) 675).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan chianta < Lat. plănta(m).}];54[470{Cf. s.v. Lat. planta 'sole of the foot', from PIE *pl(e)h₂-nt-h₂- 'the flat one' (cf. Lat. plānus 'level, flat'). Lat. planta 'shoot of a plant' is commonly hypothesised to be backformed to an unattested verb *plantāre 'to level the earth' or 'to plant crops with the sole of the foot' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):512 s.v. II. planta). If so, then planta 'shoot of a plant' would ultimately go back to the PIE root *pelh₂- found in Lat. plānus 'level, flat', Hitt. palḫi- 'wide, broad', Lith. plónas 'thin', etc.}];316[512{S.v. II. planta 'tige, rejeton', a new substantive backformed from plantō 'enfoncer avec le pied', specialised in the language of farming in the sense 'enfoncer les rejetons, planter' and identical to planta 'plante des pieds'.}];444[546{Cf. s.v. 6575 Lat. planta 'Pflanze'.}];274[562-564{Cf. s.v. *pleh₂- 'flach, breit' (IEW 805, EIEC 205f.).}]
Justification: From Latin planta 'plant' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):470, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):512, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Source: 579[{Neapolitan ruppio < Lat. dŭplum, cf. It. doppio.}];54[183{Cf. s.v. Lat. duo 'two'.}]

579[{Neapolitan mazza from spoken Lat. *măttea(m), cf. It. mazza.}];54[366-367{Cf. s.v. mateola 'wooden hammer', a diminutive of a noun *matea 'hoe' (vel sim.), perhaps from PIE ?*mot-(i-), cf. Ved. matyá- 'club, harrow, roller', OCS motyka, Russ. motyga 'hoe' OHG medela 'plough'.}];444[445{S.v. 5425 Lat. *mattea 'Keule'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):445 no. 5425), further etymology uncertain, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):366-367 for various proposals.

Source: 579[{Neapolitan from late Lat. pileāre? Cf. It. pigliare.}];444[537{Cf. s.v. 6503 Lat. *pīliāre 'nehmen'.}]
Justification: Apparently continuing a late Latin verb *pīliāre 'to take' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):537 no. 6503).

Source: 397[819{Cf. s.v. NHG schnaufen, a (first attested 16th c. MHG snūfen) High German variant to NHG schnauben (cf. MHG snūben 'schnarchen, schnauben'. The words belong to a large group of formations designating to noises made with the nose, mucus, sneezing, etc. They are frequently phonetically similar, but they are unable to be brought together as a single initial form.}]
Justification: Of onomatopeic origin, first attested as Middle High German snūfen, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):819 s.v. New High German schnauben 'to sniff, snort' for further discussion.

Source: 397[215{S.v. NHG Dreck (MHG drec, OHG drec, MLG dreck, MDu. drec), from Gmc. *ϸrekka- 'Dreck, Kot' also in ON ϸrekkr, OE ϸreax, OFr. threkk. The basis is an IE root *(s)terg- which may be connected with Gk. στεργάνος 'Dung' and with variation in root final voicing Lat. stercus 'Dünger', cf. also Lith. ter̃šti '(be)schmutzen'.}];270[1052{Cf. s.v. Gk. στεργάνος· κόπρων (Hesych.).}];66[1400{Cf. s.v. Gk. στεργάνος· κόπρων 'place for dung'. No etymology. Not related to Lat. stercus 'excrements'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Pace [Kluge 2011](src-397):215, the etymologies of proposed Greek and Italic cognates are themselves quite uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1052, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1400).

Source: 397[939{S.v. NHG überlegen (MHG überligen 'auf etwas liegen, belagern'| 14th c.| in present meaning 16th c.)| cf. s.v. NHG legen (MHG legen, OHG leg(g)en, lecchen, etc., OS leggian| from Gmc. *lag-eja- 'legen', also in Goth. lagjan, ON leggja, OE lecgan, OFr. ledza, lega, leia, etc. Outside Germanic correspondes to OCS -ložiti.}];165[322{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *lagjan- 'to put', from PIE *logʰ-éie-, the causative to PGmc. *leg(j)an- and formally identical to Hitt. lāki 'to knock out| fall, be felled, be toppled', CS ložiti 'to lay', etc.}];556[324{Cf. s.v. Gmc. leg-ja- 'liegen', with derived stem lag-eja- 'legen', from the PIE verbal root *leg̑ʰ- 'sich legen'.}];141[398{Cf. s.v. *legʰ- 'sich (hin)legen' (IEW 658-9).}]
Justification: Cognacy in this class for the verb is coded for NHG -legen (cf. NHG überlegen 'to consider, reflect, think'); cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):939 for the history of the formation.

Source: 397[804{Cf. s.v. NHG schießen (MHG schiezen, OHG skiozan, OS skiotan), from Gmc. *skeut-a- (also in ON skjóta, OE scēotan, OFr. skiāta, Crim.Goth. schieten). Outside of Germanic one compares, if necessary Lith. šáuti 'schießen, schnell laufen', OCS sovati 'drängen' < PIE *k̑eu̯-| otherwise no clear possibilities for comparison.}];165[445{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash'. Etymology outside of Germanic unclear. Kroonen proposes that the verb was back-formed to the iterative *skut(t)ōn-, which may have been formed to a pre-Gmc. root *sket-, and consequently rejects older etymological connections to *skeu-(d)- (Lith. šiáuti 'to shoot', etc.).}];556[417-418{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *skeut-a- 'schießen'.}]
Justification: In works on Germanic etymology, the etymology outside of Germanic is generally considered uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):417-418, [Kluge 2011](src-397):804, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):445), but cf., however, [LIV²](src-141) 560 connecting with PIE *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben'.

Source: 172[I:154{S.v. Ved. áhan- (~ áhar, Heterokliton) 'Tag, Tageschelle'. In IIr. cf. OAv. G.pl. asnąm 'der Tage', YAv. L.sg. asni 'am Tage' Perhaps from PIE *(h₂)eg̑ʰ-r/n-, which one attempts to connect with Germanic words for 'day' (OHG tag 'Tag', ON dægr, dægn 'Halbtag', etc.).}];269[{Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. EWAia I:154 and Kroonen (2013:97) s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.}];442[44{S.v. 993 Skt. áhar n. 'day', nom. °ar, loc. áhan-i RV.}]
Justification: Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:154 and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion. For Middle and Modern Indic forms from Vedic áhar, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):44, no. 993.

Source: 105[331-332, 335{S.v. pluhur ~ pluhun 'dust, powder'. Argued to be a phonetic development of *plëhur ~ plëhun derived from pleh ~ plêh 'sweepings, dung, rubbish', in turn derived from plah ~ plaf 'to cover' < PAlb. p(e)laska- incohative formation < IE *pl̥H-sk̑e/o- (cf. -πέλας 'skin', Lith. palà 'linen kerchief', plenė̃ 'thin skin, membrane' ONor. fjall 'skin' etc., cf. Demiraj (1997:323-324). Alternatively Meyer (1891:346) from Rom. *pluverem < Lat. pulverem 'dust, powder'.}];585[346{Loanword from Romance *pluverem < Lat. pulverem 'dust'.}];369[323-324]
Justification: Generally considered a loanword from Romance *pluverem < Latin *pulverem 'dust' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):346, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):323-324; but cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):331-332, 335 for an alternative proposal.

Source: 352[831-833{S.v. OLith. pùsti 'anschwellen, sich aufblähen', anticausativum to pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen'. Clear correspondences outside of Baltic are lacking. There are many roots among IE languages in *pu-, *pʰu- related to words for blowing and swelling (cf. Gk. φῦσα, Arm. pʻowkʻo, Lat. pustula) of possible (independent) onomatopoeic origin.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 831-833).

Source: 156[I:560{Cf. s.v. Oss. īx | ex 'лед', from Proto-Iranian *aixa- (cf. Pers. yax, Kurd. yex, Yag. īx, Sogd. *yīx, Chores. ēx, Av. aexa-).}];331[I:140-143{S.v. Proto-Iranic *aixa- : *īxa- 'лёд, холод, мороз'.}]
Comment: For the onset cf. Persian *ai̯u̯a-ka- > yak.
Justification: Adjectival derivatives from Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ([ESIJa](src-331) I:140-143). Further connections disputed, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 5932](cog-5932).

Comment: see 3414 for the discussion of etymology
Justification: [Cheung 2007](src-83):151 suggests a derivation of this family of words from Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar-da- to Proto-Iranic 5. *hu̯ar- 'to paint, colour, stain', and further to PIE 2. *su̯er- 'to ache, fester'?.
the Sogdian form is a compound "bird-born", since Mazanderani has been put here as well, the "bird"-component will be given as root reference form

Comment: Loanword from Persian.
Bailey (1979: 412 "ṣṣai") relates the Sogdian word to Yaghnobi čukēr-. Not in Cheung (2007).

Justification: Loanword from Arabic شر / šar 'evil, iniquity' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:297).

Source: 83[31-32{S.v. Proto-Iranian *čak/g 'to strike, hit' (Iranian only). "This root is no doubt expressive in origin."}]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *čak/g 'to strike, hit', probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Cheung 2007](src-83):31-32).
Parallel loans from Persian ماهى / māhī 'fish'.
Assumed to be Persian loans.

Comment: ultimately *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur-

Justification: Derived verb within Kurdish from a noun ǰamad, ultimately borrowed from Arabic ǰamad ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:486).

Source: 363[I:352{Cf. s.v. Kurd. fēkī 'фрукт, плод', loan from Arabic fākiha 'фрукт, плод'.}]
Justification: Loan from Arabic فاكهة / fākiha 'fruit' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:352).
Loan from Persian خوب / xūb 'good'.

Source: 567[284{Alternatively one may consider a derivation from *srīra-, cf. Sogd. šyr-, Khot. śśära- „good“, with adaptation of the ending to the antonym βιζαγο „bad, evil“.}]
Comment: Cf. Ossetic Digoron äxsidzgä "pleasant", Khotanese kṣiṃj- "to desire, long for".
Parallel loans from Persian
loan from Persian, because old *t would appear as t.
original meaning "snake"
Gharib suggests *yaunikā- for Sogdian
Borrowing from Arabic?
Not related to bāzu-forms, because *b would appear as β. Cheung (2007: 430) puts the Sogdian word to the verbal root *waz- "to carry, drive".

Source: 83[292-293{S.v. Proto-Iranian *paiš 'to crush, grind' < PIE *pei̯s- 'to grind' (cf. Skt. peṣ- 'crush, grind, destroy', Gk. πτίσσω 'I ground, husk', Lat. pīnsere 'to crush, grind (finely)' Lith. paisýti 'to cut off the beards of chaff, peel', etc.).}];141[466-467{S.v. *pei̯s- 'zerstampfen, (zer)stoßen' (IEW 796).}];172[II:169{Cf. s.v. Ved. √peṣ- 'zerstampfen, zermalmen, zerschmettern', from PIE *pei̯s- (cf. Gk. πτίσσω 'zerschrote, enthülse'. ἄ-πιστος 'unzerstampft', Lat. pīnsere 'zerstoßen', Lith. paisýti 'Grannen abschlagen, enthülsen'.}]
Justification: From Proto-Iranic *paiš 'to crush, grind', further connected to PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):292-293, [EWAia](src-172) II:169, [LIV²](src-141) 466-467).
Modern Iranic lexemes, possibly to be connected with Sanskrit karká- 'white' according to [KEWA](src-399) I:171 but etymology ultimately uncertain ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:222).
No certain etymological connection outside of Iranic. Mayrhofer (q.v.) asserts cognacy with Vedic kṣod-.

Source: 83[141-143{S.v. Proto-Iranian *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh| [incoh., intr.] to become tired' (+ *pati- > MSogd. ptxw’y ‘to kill, put to death’). No clear IE provenance for this exclusively Ir. root.}]
Justification: From Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' + preverb *pati-; further etymology uncertain (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):141-143).

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount', further to PIE *(s)mer- 'to think about, remember' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):137-138, [EWAia](src-172) II:78-79, [LIV²](src-141) 569-570).

Source: 83[38];141[346{*k̑ei̯h₂- 'sich in Bewegung setzen'}]
Comment: unclear why Cheung suggests k instead of k̑ despite his reference to LIV; ki̯ > čy and k̑i̯ > ϑy/sy would both result in Sogdian š

Justification: Parallel loans from Persian برگ / barg 'leaf'.
Parallel loans from Persian بلند / buland 'long'.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit párvata- 'mountain'.

Source: 50[306-307{S.v. Proto-Celtic *rēdi- 'simple, easy', to be connected with PIE *(H)rei̯dʰ- 'ride, drive' (cf. OHG bi-reiti 'ready').}];141[502{Cf. s.v. *rei̯dʰ- 'sich schwankend bewegen' (IEW 861).}];296[R:16-17{S.v. OIr. réid adj. 'plat, uni, aisé, simple' and subst. 'terrain plat, plaine', within Celtic to OW ruid gl. uacuum, W rhwydd 'aisé, faxile', Corn. rŷth 'aisé, clair, plat'| outside of Celtic to Gmc. Goth. garaid 'bien disposé', Engl. ready, OHG bi-reiti NHG bereit 'prêt' all to the IE root *reid- 'aller en voiture'}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *rēdi- 'simple, easy', further derived from PIE *(H)rei̯dʰ- 'to shake, wobble' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:16-17, [Matasović 2009](src-50):306-307, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 502).

Source: 567[262{S.v. Bactr. σαδγο 'levelled, level, flat' < *sātaka-, NP sāda 'smooth, even, etc.' (?)}];320[424{From base sā- 'to cut', sāta- 'cut, smoothed, even'}];83[325-326{Cf. s.v. PIr. saH- 'to whet, cut' < PIE *k̑eh₃- 'to sharpen, whet' (cf. Lat. cōs 'whetstone', OIr. cath 'wise', Arm. sur 'sharp', ON hein 'whetstone'.}];325[72{"Cf. W[akhi] (Sh.) sūδγ, id., but neither S[arikoli suγδ] nor W[akhi] can be phonetically derived < * sātaka- (cf. sǟδ)."}]
Comment: Morgenstierne (1974: 72) only notes suγδ for Sarikoli, which could be a dialectal variant of sleʁ with metathesis and δ/l alternation.
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing *sāta(ka)- 'cut, smoothed, even', a p.p.p. to Proto-Iranic *saH- 'to whet, cut' and further to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):424, [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):72, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):262, [Cheung 2007](src-83):325-326, [LIV²](src-141) 319-320).

Source: 54[512{S.v. Lat. rādix 'root' < Proto-Italic wrād-i- (cf. W. gwraidd 'roots', Gk. ῥάδιξ 'branch, twig', Goth. waurts, Alb. rrëzë 'root' < all from forms of PIE *ur(e)h₂-d-iH- ‘root’.}];66[1271, 1285{S.v. ῥίζα 'root'. Beekes is not convinced that the words are inherited, but cf. Vine (1999) who attempts a regular solution to the problem as a zero-grade formation through schwa secundum. Cf. s.v. ῥᾱ́διξ 'branch, twig', which forms a much closer etymological match to Lat. rādix 'root', Goth. waurts, etc. < *u̯reh₂d-.}];606[5-30{Cf. for the stem-formation of Gk. ῥίζα within this root class.}];165[601{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *wurti- '(medicinal) root, herb'.}];50[430{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wridā 'root', from PIE *u̯re(h₂)d- 'root' (IEW 1167).}];369[350-351{S.v. Alb. rrënj/ë, -a 'Wurzel, Stück (bei Baumzählung), Stein-, Stieleiche, Quercus, Quercus robur, etc.'. Without doubt from the same origin as Lat. rādix 'Wurzel', Goth. waurts 'ds.'.}];130[76{From PIE *u̯h₁reh₂d- > urh₂d-(nieh₂) > radniā (cf. IEW 1167).}];105[384{S.v. Alb. rrënjë ~ rranjë 'root| oak', from PAlb. wradnjā and etymologically connected with Gk. ῥάδιξ 'branch', Lat. rādix 'root', W. gwraidd, etc.}];782[{The phonology of the Frisian is influenced by Dutch wortel. The form wurtel is dialectal and continues rather the original Frisian form}]
Justification: The cognacy of the Hellenic, Germanic, Italic, Celtic, and Albanian lexemes in this set is generally agreed, but the precise root reconstruction is disputed, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1271, 1285, [Vine 1999](src-606):5-30, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):350-351, [Orel 1998](src-105):384, [Holm 2011](src-130):76, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):601, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):512, [Matasović 2009](src-50):430).

Source: 66[1287-1288{S.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'to throw, hurl, thrust, bolt'. Based on a root *(ϝ)ριπ- within Ancient Greek. No clear etymology outside of Greek| formally matches MLG wrīven 'to rub, wipe, scour, draw', MHG rīben 'to turn rubbing' ([IEW](src-49) 1159), but the semantic gap is considerable.}];270[975{S.v. AGk. ῥίπτω 'jeter violemment, brandir, jeter à bas, arracher'. Etymology obscure. The forms go back to a root *ϝριπ- with a present suffix -ye/o-| [IEW](src-49) 1159 supposes *wrī-p- and a connection to Germanic lexemes meaning 'frotter, tourner' in OHG rīban, MHG rīben, MLG wrīven.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):975, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1287-1288; cf. [IEW](src-49) 1159 for unconvincing older proposals to Germanic lexemes via OHG rīban, etc.).

Source: 303[366-367{S.v. to-ro-qe-jo-me-no. Generally interpreted as *τροκʷεyόμενος and compared to Lat. torqueō 'twist' < *terkʷ-.}];141[635, 650{Cf. s.v. *terkʷ- 'sich drehen' (IEW 1077) and 2. *trep- 'wenden' (IEW 1094). (No Mycenaean forms given in these entries.)}];270[1132-1133{S.v. τρέπω 'tournet, diriger vers, se tourner vers, changer, mettre en fuite'. The etymology is a problem. On may connect Skt. trápate 'avoir honte, être embarrassé' which remarkably resembles the sense of ἐντρέπομαι| Lat. trepit (P.F. 504,23) may be the creation of a grammarian. One could also think of a base *trekʷ-/*trokʷ- in view of Mycenaean toroqejomeno which is confirmed by toroqo 'torsade', or 'façon' applied to wool, but these words could also be in turn be connected with στρέφω. One also considers Lat. torqueō, cf. also εὐτρόσσεσθαι· ἐπιστρέφεσθαι· Πάφοι (Hesych.) < *trokʷ-i̯e-?}];66[1503-1504{S.v. τρέπω 'to turn, revolve, put to flight| to turn oneself, change, take flight, etc.', from PIE *trep- to turn' (cf. Lat. trepit 'vertit' (Paul. Fest. p.367), Skt. trapate 'feels ashamed, beomes timid', Hitt. terepp- 'to plough'). "The connection of Myc. to-ro-qe-jo-me-no (meaning unknown| with q) and of Lat. torqueō is untenable."}]
Justification: Generally compared to Lat. torqueō from a causative-iterative stem *torkʷ-éi̯e/o- 'twist' ([Aura Jorro 1993](src-303):366-367); whether this is to be identical with Ancient Greek τρέπω, τροπέω (cf. [cognate set 5106](cog-5106)) is less certain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1132-1133, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1503-1504).

Source: 141[154{Cf. s.v. *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'schleppen, ziehen' (IEW 257, 273). The Latin and Romance cognates may go back to this root, but one must accept an irregular dissimilation of the aspirates and devoicing of the initial consonant *dʰr- > *dr-, *tr- in order to account for Lat. trahere.}];54[626-627{S.v. Lat. trahō, -ere 'to pull, drag, haul'. Etymologies outside of Italic are difficult. There are possible Celtic cognates (OIr. tethraig* 'ran away, receded' < PCl. *te-trāg-, OIr. tráig 'ebb, beach') which could be explained by a meaning 'pull away'. Formally possible are also Goth. þragjan 'to walk', OIr. traig W. troëd, Bret. troad 'foot', but these would require a non-IE root structure *T–Dʰ. A connection with Germanic *dragan is formally impossible.}];444[734-735{S.v. 8841 Lat. trahere 'ziehen, schleppen'.}];269[{IE root etymology disputed. The Italic and Romance lexemes in this class might be connected with the lexemes from Proto-Germanic *dragan- in [cognate set 2839](cog-2839) via PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- but this would require the assumption of an irregular dissimilation of aspirates and devoicing in initial position. Alternatively some Celtic cognates are formally possible (cf. Old Irish tethraig* 'ran away, receded'), but note that the required reconstruction *tre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- violates Indo-European root structure constraints. Cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):626-627 and [LIV²](src-141) 154 for further discussion.}]
Justification: IE root etymology disputed. The Italic and Romance lexemes in this class might be connected with the lexemes from Proto-Germanic *dragan- in [cognate set 2839](cog-2839) via PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- but this would require the assumption of an irregular dissimilation of aspirates and devoicing in initial position. Alternatively some Celtic cognates are formally possible (cf. Old Irish tethraig* 'ran away, receded'), but note that the required reconstruction *tre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- violates Indo-European root structure constraints. Cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):626-627 and [LIV²](src-141) 154 for further discussion.

Source: 165[220{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair', from PIE *k̑ē̆s-ró- (cf. Hitt. kišzi ~ kišanzi 'to comb, card' < *kes-ti, *ks-énti| OCS česati 'to scratch, pluck' < *kes-eh₂-, etc.).}];81[238{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kosa 'hair, braided hair', an o-grade derivative of the root *kes- 'comb, scratch'. Cf. Proto-Slavic *česati 'scratch, comb' < *kes- (cf. Hitt. kiszi 'combs', OIr. cír 'comb', OEng. heord 'hair').}];141[357{Cf. s.v. *kes- 'ordnen' (IEW 585).}];458[11: 133-135{The Slavic lexeme is derived from PIE *kes-.}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):238, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:133-135; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 357). Perhaps also connected to Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):220 and further discussion in [cognate set 9647](cog-9647)).

Source: 50[427-428{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wolto-, perhaps to be connected with OCS vlatъ, OE weald 'wood' if from PIE *u̯olt- (cf. IEW 1138-1139).}];269[{Connected by [Matasović 2009](src-50):427-428 to Slavic and Germanic words for 'wood' (cf. [cognate set 3130](cog-3130)) following [IEW](src-49) 1138-9, but since this explanation this on postulating different root-extensions to a base root *u̯el-, *u̯elə- in [IEW](src-49) this remains somewhat tenuous.}]
Justification: Connected by [Matasović 2009](src-50):427-428 to Slavic and Germanic words for 'wood' (cf. [cognate set 3130](cog-3130)) following [IEW](src-49) 1138-9, but since this explanation this on postulating different root-extensions to a base root *u̯el-, *u̯elə- in [IEW](src-49) this remains somewhat tenuous.

Source: 79[220{S.v. glux 'head| end, summit, chief'. Commonly considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for head [cf. [cognate set 1142](cog-1142)]. This is possible, but many details are unclear. The underlying form for Balto-Slavic may be reconstructed *gʰolHu-eh₂ and for Armenian, if cognate, something like *gʰolHu-k-h₂-o- (with the inclusion of a suffixal element *-k- and thematization) or simply *gʰolHu- + substratum suffix *-xo-.}];180[43-44{Arm. glowx is generally considered to be root-cognate with Lith. galvà, but there are difficulties with the reconstruction of the Armenian form. See for further discussion of the stem formation.}];269[{Generally considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for 'head' (cf. Lith. galvà, etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. Olsen 1999:43, Martirosyan 2010:220). Cf. further discussion regarding the Balto-Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 1142](cog-1142). Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.}]
Justification: Generally considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for 'head' (cf. Lith. galvà, etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):43, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):220). Cf. further discussion regarding the Balto-Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 1142](cog-1142). Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.

Source: 54[554{S.v. Lat. sentiō, -īre 'to sense, feel', from Proto-Italic *s(e)nt-ii̯e/o- / *s(e)nt-(e)i, PIE *sent- 'to perceive' (LIV² 533, fn. 1).}];141[533{Cf. s.v. *sent- 'gehen' → 'wahrnehmen' (?) (IEW 908).}];444[645-646{S.v. 7824 Lat. sentīre 'fühlen, wahrnehmen'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):645-646), further to PIE *sent- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):554, [LIV²](src-141) 533).

Source: 54[322-323{S.v. Lat. lacus, -ūs 'lake', from PIE *lok-u- 'lake' (cf. OIr. loch 'lake', OCS loky (gen.sg. lokъve) 'puddle, pool, reservoir', Gk. λάκκος 'pond').}];50[243{S.v. Proto-Celtic *loku- 'lake, pool' (cf. Lat. lacus, Gk. λάκκος, OE lagu, OCS loky).}];49[653{S.v. *laku- 'Wasseransammlung in einer Grube, Lache, See'.}]

316[244{S.v. folium, -ī 'feuille'. There are two possible etymologies. Either (1) with Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰel- (cf. [cognate set 252](cog-252)) or (2) to be connected with Celtic words (Ir. duille, duillen, etc.) from *dʰal- (cf. [cognate set 1025](cog-1025)).}];54[230{S.v. folium 'leaf', from PIE *dʰolH-io-, connecting the Italic forms with W. dail 'foliage' and Gk. θάλλω 'to flourish, grow'. Otherwise often compared with Gk. φύλλον 'leaf' < *bʰol-io-.}];269[{The IE root etymology for this class is disputed. It seems equally plausible that the Italic forms from Lat. folium can go with either the Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰleh₃- in [cognate set 252](cog-252), or with the Celtic words for 'leaf' from *dʰal(h₁)- in [cognate set 1025](cog-1025)| cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):244| [de Vaan 2008](src-54):230.}];444[293-294{S.v. 3415 Lat. folium 'Blatt'.}]
Justification: The IE root etymology for this class is disputed. It seems equally plausible that the Italic forms from Lat. folium can go with either the Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰleh₃- in [cognate set 252](cog-252), or with the Celtic words for 'leaf' from *dʰal(h₁)- in [cognate set 1025](cog-1025); cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):244; [de Vaan 2008](src-54):230. For the Romance lexemes in this class cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):293-294.

Source: 165[353-354{S.v. Proto-Germanic *mannan- 'man'. The etymology is disputed. Many scholars connect Proto-Germanic *mannan- with Skt. mánu- and OCS mǫžъ (cf. Ringe 2006:139) [cognate set 76](cog-76), but underlying *men-u- (not *mon-u-) would have yielded *minn- in Germanic. Consequently Kroonen proposes an alternative etymology as a secondary form of  *guman- [cognate set 907](cog-907), arising through regular loss of the initial stops of original *dʰg̑ʰm-on-, giving result to a secondary Proto-Germanic root *man-.}];269[{The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in [cognate set 76](cog-76), alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' [cognate set 907](cog-907). The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority class into their own separate class, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing classes.}]
Justification: The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in [cognate set 76](cog-76), alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' [cognate set 907](cog-907). The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority set into their own separate set, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing sets.

Source: 172[II:750{S.v. Ved. skandhá- 'Schulterknochen', along with Pāli khandha- 'Schulter, Baumstamm, OAv. skəṇdō, probably 'Beschädigung', YAv. skəṇdō 'Gebrechen, Körperschaden', seem to continue a lost IIr. root *skandh- 'brechen, abbrechen'.}];442[786{S.v. 13627 Ved. skandhá m. 'shoulder, upper part of back' AV.| in Si. kan̆da 'shoulder, tree trunk, collection, mass', kan̆du 'mountain' (< -- aka -- ).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic skandhá- 'shoulder, upper part of back', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):786 no. 13627, [EWAia](src-172) II:750).

Source: 274[387-391{Either to *h₃eh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'Mund' (IEW 784f., EIEC 387), or to ?*h₃óu̯st-ó- 'Mund, Lippe' (IEW 785, EIEC 387).}];81[509{S.v. Proto-Slavic *ūsta 'mouth', from Balto-Slavic *oust- (or *aust-?), from PIE *Hous-t- (*h₂/h₃eus-t-?), cf. Skt. óṣṭha- 'upper lip'.}];353[481-482{Cf. s.v. Lith. úostas 'port, harbour, (dial. arch.) mouth of a river' (Latv. uõsta 'port, harbour, mouth of a river', OPr. austo 'mouth'), from PIE *Hous-t- (*h₂/₃eus-t-?), cf. Skt. óṣṭha- '(upper) lip'.}];259[671{PS *usta is derived from PIE *ōu̯s-t- / *əu̯s-t-, a derivative from PIE *ōu̯s- 'mouth', and related to Old Prussian austo 'mouth', Lithuanian uostà, úostas 'estuary, bay', Latvian uosts, uōsta 'harbor, bay', Latin ōstium 'door, entrance', Old Indic ṓṣtha- 'lip', Avestan aošta 'lip', further to Latin ōs, ōris, Old Indic ā́ḥ and Avestan āh- 'mouth'.}]
Justification: The IE root etymology of the Balto-Slavic forms in this class is disputed: the two main candidates are either to PIE *h₃eh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ([NIL](src-274) 387-390) or to ?*h₃óu̯st-o- 'mouth, lip' ([NIL](src-274) 390-391, [Derksen 2008](src-81):509, [Derksen 2015](src-353):481-482). The root reference form for this class tentatively follows the Balto-Slavic reconstruction of [Derksen 2008](src-81) and [Derksen 2015](src-353).

Source: 165[551, 556{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ϸunhjan- 'to press', an old ie-present related to Proto-Germanic *ϸwinhan- 'to force', from PIE *tu̯enk- 'to force'.}];141[655{Cf. s.v. *tu̯enk- 'bedrängen, einzwängen' [IEW 1099-100].}]

353[567{S.v. Old Prussian wormyan 'red' < PIE *urmi- (cf. Lat. vermis 'worm', Goth. waurms 'snake', OEng. wyrm 'snake, worm'). Other colour adjectives derived from *urmi- 'worm' are Ukr. vermjáty 'red', OHG wormo 'purple', MoFr. vermeil 'scarlet' < *vermiculus.}];443[14:288-291{Cf. s.v. Lat. vermiculus 'kleiner Wurm' > Fr. vermeil.}];54[665{Cf. s.v. Lat. vermis 'worm, maggot', from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' (cf. Goth. waurms 'snake', OIc. ormr, OEng. wyrm, OFr. wirm 'snake', OS wormo, OHG wurm, 'worm' < PGmc. *wurma/i-). Cf. the PIE doublet *kʷrmi- 'worm, maggot', possibly secondarily from PIE *kʷrmi- > *wrmi- in Lat. and Germanic.}]
Justification: Italic (and Baltic, in late parallel derivations) lexemes in the meaning 'red' are derived from IE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 14:288-291, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):665, [Derksen 2015](src-353):567), cf. also [cognate set 1163](cog-1163). See 'worm' in [cognate set 348](cog-348) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 141[534{S.v. 1. *ser- 'aufpassen auf, beschützen' (IEW 910).  In Greek the forms are thematised from a root-present and have taken on the o-grade on the basis of the nouns *sor-ó- and *sor-ā́- (from which the denominal form ὁράω was created).}];382[574{S.v. SMG θωρώ, from Ancient Greek θεωρέω 'to be a θεωρός (spectator)| to view, look, behold'.}];66[545, 1095-1096{S.v. ὁράω 'to look, perceive, contemplate, see', from *u̯er- connecting the Greek forms to TochA wär- TochB wär-sk- 'to smell', Latv. veruôs, vērtiês 'to inspect, observe'. For the Modern Greek forms, cf. s.v. θεωρός 'spectator, envoy to a festival or to an oracle', properly a compound *θεᾱ-(ϝ)ορός 'one who views or watches a spectacle', from which θεωρέω is a denominal verb.}]
Justification: Two possibilities for a root etymology: Either to *ser- ([LIV²](src-141) 534) or to *u̯er- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1095-1097, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 3. *u̯er- 'to observe, perceive', [IEW](src-49) 1164).

Source: 364[996{S.v. Old Albanian sheh 'sehen', where the traditional etymology from *sekʷ- (Orel 1998:435f., LIV² 535f.) is objected to on phonological grounds. The root identification is unclear, but the present stem ought to continue a primary derivative with a *-sk̑e/o- suffix.}];105[425-426{S.v. Alb. shoh ~ shof 'to see', from Proto-Albanian *sāksa with dissimilation of sibilants, further connected to PIE *sekʷ- 'to follow, see' (cf. Skt. sácate 'to accompany, follow', Gk. ἕπομαι, Lat. sequor, etc.).}];141[525{Cf. s.v. *sekʷ- 'sich anschließen' (IEW 896-7), under which Alb. sheh 'sieht, schaut' is tentatively derived from a cs.-it. stem *sokʷ-éi̯e-, but (marked with ?[| cf. n9.).}];130[77-78{With LIV² from PIE *sekʷ- 'anschließen / to follow (with the eyes)' via a cs.-iter. *sokʷ-éi̯e- > PAlb. saśā́j-sk̑-.}]
Justification: Traditionally connected to IE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):425-426, [LIV²](src-141) 525), but this etymology is unclear on phonological grounds; cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):996, [LIV²](src-141) 525-526.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron χɜštɜg 'near' is from *aštaka-. Cf. Avestan asna- 'close (adj.)', ašta- 'friend', MP aštak.}];156[IV:190-191{Cf. OInd. ā-sanna- < *ā-sad-na-.  The Iranian form attested by Av. asna- reflects a zero-grade from *ā-zd-na-.  Proto-Iranian *ašta- may likewise be explained as from Proto-Indo-Iranian *ā-zd-ta- >> *ā-z-ta-.}];269[{Proto-Iranian *ašta-, which was later expanded with a common denominal adjective forming suffix -(a)ka-.}];172[II:692-693{Cf. Ved. √sad- 'sitzen' from PIE *sed- 'sit'.}]

105[480{S.v. Alb. thom 'to say', from athematic PAlb. tsānsmi, connected with Lat. censeō 'to assess, to value' and cognates.}];364[1001{S.v. Old Albanian thótë 'sagen'. The present stem thotë is a continuation of the middle of the Narten-present of the root *k̑eHs- 'anweisen' (LIV² 318f.).}];141[318-319{S.v. *k̑eHs- 'anweisen' (IEW 533).}];130[77{With LIV² 326, rejects the derivation to *k̑eNs- 'speak formally' > *k̑eh₁nsmi > Alb. thom (Orel 1998:480), rather with LIV² 318 *k̑eHs- 'anweisen / to advise'.}]
Justification: Generally derived to PIE *k̑eHs- 'to instruct, advise' ([LIV²](src-141) 318, [Holm 2011](src-130):77, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1001, pace [Orel 1998](src-105):480 who assumes a connection with PIE *k̑eNs- ([LIV²](src-141) 326, cf. cognate set 464).

Source: 79[149-150{S.v. Arm. awaz 'sand, dust', connected with Gr. ἄμαθος, ψάμμος, Lat. sabulum 'sand', OHG sant, MHG sampt, etc. Probably of non-IE origin.}];657[499{Cf. R.S.P. Beekes s.v. SAND: "?*samh̥ªdhos 'sand' [IEW 146 (*bhes-)| Wat 8 (*bhes-)| Buck 1.215]. Lat. sabulum 'sand' ?saburra 'sand in a ship as ballast', ON sandr 'sand', NE (dial.) samel 'sand bottom', OHG sant, MHG sant ~ sampt 'sand', Grk ἄμαθος 'sand'. The Greek form cannot be separated from ψάμαθος and ψάμμος 'sand', while the MHG sampt can hardly represent an old variant and, even if it is one, it can hardly be an alternative development of a PIE form. A reconstruction along the lines of *samhªdhos is impossible and the a vocalism suggests a non-IE status for the word. This is even more evident if Lat. sabulum is regarded cognate. The status of Arm awaz 'sand' is unclear."}];47[22-23{Under 1.215 SAND, Buck connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to an original stem *samdʰo-.}];269[{Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.}];395[11, 101];165[426]
Justification: Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Source: 66[89{S.v. ἄμμος 'sand'. Generally the word is considered to be a contamination of ἄμαθος 'sand' with ψάμμος 'sand'. Of non-Indo-European origin.}];47[22-23{Under 1.215 SAND, Buck connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to an original stem *samdʰo-.}];657[499{Cf. R.S.P. Beekes s.v. SAND: "?*samh̥ªdhos 'sand' [IEW 146 (*bhes-)| Wat 8 (*bhes-)| Buck 1.215]. Lat. sabulum 'sand' ?saburra 'sand in a ship as ballast', ON sandr 'sand', NE (dial.) samel 'sand bottom', OHG sant, MHG sant ~ sampt 'sand', Grk ἄμαθος 'sand'. The Greek form cannot be separated from ψάμαθος and ψάμμος 'sand', while the MHG sampt can hardly represent an old variant and, even if it is one, it can hardly be an alternative development of a PIE form. A reconstruction along the lines of *samhªdhos is impossible and the a vocalism suggests a non-IE status for the word. This is even more evident if Lat. sabulum is regarded cognate. The status of Arm awaz 'sand' is unclear."}];269[{Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.}];395[11, 101{Reconstructs *sámh₂dʰos > (cf. Gk. ἄμαθος) > *sámədʰos > *sámdʰos > PGmc. *samdaz > ONor. sandr, OEng. sand, OHG sant.}];79[149-150];165[425-426{S.v. Proto-Germanic *samda- 'sand'. "Most forms point to *sanda- but MHG sampt can only be explained from *samda- < *samdʰ-o-, which is close to Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ-o- […]. Given the formal irreconcilabilities between Gm. *samda-, Lat. sabulum < *sadʰ-lo- and Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ- (the ψ of ψάμαθος was used to substitute s- after the Greek shift to h) the conclusion must be that the word is of non-IE origin ([Kuiper 1995](src-658):67): it was probably adopted from a set of linguistically affiliated languages when Germanic, Italic, and Greek arrived in West-Europe. In view of the meaning 'sand', it is extremely unlikely, at any rate, that the word spread across Europe as a Wanderwort."}];658[67]
Justification: Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Source: 54[531{S.v. Lat. sabulum 'coarse sand, gravel', from Proto-Italic *(p)saϸlo- / *(p)saflo- / *(p)sablo-, a substrate word *(p)sam- or *sab⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. IE cognates Gr. ψάμμος, (ψ)άμαθος, ψόμμος| OIc. sandr, OHG sant, MHG samt).}];657[499{Cf. R.S.P. Beekes s.v. SAND: "?*samh̥ªdhos 'sand' [IEW 146 (*bhes-)| Wat 8 (*bhes-)| Buck 1.215]. Lat. sabulum 'sand' ?saburra 'sand in a ship as ballast', ON sandr 'sand', NE (dial.) samel 'sand bottom', OHG sant, MHG sant ~ sampt 'sand', Grk ἄμαθος 'sand'. The Greek form cannot be separated from ψάμαθος and ψάμμος 'sand', while the MHG sampt can hardly represent an old variant and, even if it is one, it can hardly be an alternative development of a PIE form. A reconstruction along the lines of *samhªdhos is impossible and the a vocalism suggests a non-IE status for the word. This is even more evident if Lat. sabulum is regarded cognate. The status of Arm awaz 'sand' is unclear."}];47[22-23{S.v. 1.215 SAND, Buck connects Greek, Germanic, and Romance cognates to an original stem *samdʰo-.}];269[{Earlier literature (cf. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.}];395[11, 101{Reconstructs *sámh₂dʰos > (cf. Gk. ἄμαθος) > *sámədʰos > *sámdʰos > PGmc. *samdaz > ONor. sandr, OEng. sand, OHG sant.}];79[149-150];165[425-426{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *samda- 'sand'. "Most forms point to *sanda- but MHG sampt can only be explained from *samda- < *samdʰ-o-, which is close to Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ-o- […]. Given the formal irreconcilabilities between Gm. *samda-, Lat. sabulum < *sadʰ-lo- and Gr. ἄμαθος < *sam-ndʰ- (the ψ of ψάμαθος was used to substitute s- after the Greek shift to h) the conclusion must be that the word is of non-IE origin ([Kuiper 1995](src-658):67): it was probably adopted from a set of linguistically affiliated languages when Germanic, Italic, and Greek arrived in West-Europe. In view of the meaning 'sand', it is extremely unlikely, at any rate, that the word spread across Europe as a Wanderwort."}];444[619{S.v. 7486 Lat. sabulum 'Sand'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin sabulum 'sand' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):619). Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Source: 81[532{S.v. Proto-Slavic *vъšь 'louse' "It is unclear if and how Slavic *vъšь and Baltic *ut- are related. The forms may have been distorted for reasons of taboo. It cannot be excluded that OHG lūs f. 'louse' also belongs here."}];269[{Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.}];49[692{Traditionally reconstructed as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) 'Laus', with frequent tabooistic distortions in individual branches.}];259[685{PS *vŭšĭ (< *(u̯)ŭxĭ- < *(u̯)ŭsĭ-) is a taboo deformation of PIE lŭs-, cf. German Laus, Welsh llau etc. Various deformations appear also in other languages, e.g. Latvian uts etc.}]
Justification: Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

The forms may have been distorted for reasons of taboo. It cannot be excluded that OHG lūs f. 'louse' also belongs here."}];269[{Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.}];49[692{Traditionally reconstructed as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) 'Laus', with frequent tabooistic distortions in individual branches.}];352[1158-1159{S.v. OLith. utėlė̃ 'Laus (Pediculus)' (BSl. Latv. uts 'Laus', etc.). Lith. utėlė̃ is a diminutive of a form utìs that is preserved dialectally. There is no certain comparative material outside of Baltic. The often assumed root cognacy with the Slavic word for louse (cf. e.g. Derksen 2008:532) is uncertain due to phonological difficulties.}]
Justification: Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

ToA lu 'animal' (ToB luwo) might also be ultimately from the same PIE root, but with an unusual generalization of meaning."}];388[252{S.v. Proto-Germanic *lūsz, Related to W (pl.) llau 'lice', Corn. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Source: 80[980{S.v. Hitt. 𒌋 u̯ar(ru)u̯alan- 'seed, progeny'. The use of gloss-wedges as well as the occurrence of a Luw. erg.sg. u̯aru̯alanteš indicates we are dealing with an originally Luwian word. No further etymology.}]
Justification: Loanword from Luvian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):980).

Source: 165[438{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skadu- 'shadow', from PIE *skh₃-tu- (cf. Gk. σκότος 'darkness, dark' < *skh₃-to-, OIr. scáth 'shadow', MW ysgawd 'shade, darkness' < *skoh₃-to-).}];50[340{S.v. Proto-Celtic *skāto- 'shadow', from PIE *skeh₃t- (cf. OE sceadu, Gk. σκότος).}];66[1350-1351, 1359-1360{Cf. s.v. σκιά 'shade' (< PIE *skeh₂-ih₂, gen. *skh₂-ieh₂-s 'shadow') and s.v. σκότος 'darkness, dark' (< PIE *skeh₃t- or *skoto- 'shadow, dark'). Note p.1351 "The relation [of Gk. σκιά] with σκότος is unclear".}];269[{The communis opinio is that the relationship between the lexemes in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058) and [cognate set 8269](cog-8269) have irreconcilable root reconstructions and must be separated into *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂- and *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-. Cognacy has been thus assigned in this manner according to the main etymological authorities.  The reconstruction of two separate roots, however crucially hinges on the interpretation of the Greek evidence: Germanic lexemes from PGmc. *skadu- < *s⁽k̑⁾H-tu- appear to be a close parallel formation to Greek σκοτός 'darkness' which reflect earlier *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-tó-.  These are potentially different roots, but this is based entirely on the witness of the Greek evidence.  In any case, the difference is based on disagreement over root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃.  The identity of the laryngeal in σκία < *skh₂-ih₂ is assumed from Att.-Ion. σκηνή, West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́ 'tent' < 'cloth to provide shade' < (transponat) *skeh₂-néh₂ (cf. Beekes 2010, s.v. σκία).  In Ancient Greek does exist another example of a doublet of root-final *h₂ vs. *h₃, namely the dialectal doublet of Attic-Ionic πρῶτος 'first' (ostensibly from *pr̥h₃-to-) against West Greek πρᾶτος 'first' (ostensibly from < *pr̥h₂-to-), cf. Ved. pūrvá- 'first' (formally from *pr̥H-u̯ó-).  One could imagine there may have been some inner-Greek phonological or derivational reason to account for the discrepancy in vocalism. It seems therefore very possible, in view of the phonological and semantic similarities, that the Tocharian, Greek, Albanian, Indo-Iranian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058) and the Celtic and Germanic lexemes (+Gk. σκότος) in [cognate set 8269](cog-8269) go back to the same root etymology with differing derivational morphology. Cognacy has been coded, however, according to the prevailing opinion.}];301[183, 303{In OBr. only attested in the compounds guascot and pl. guascotou gl. frigora 'shadowy/sheltered places'. Compounded with the prefix guo- 'under' (developed into gua-) and scot 'shadow', i.e. *u̯o-skātu- < *upo-skātu-. The OBr. word has exact cognates in MW gwascaut m. 'shadow' and Oir. foscad (n., u, later o) 'shadow, shelter'.}];299[125-127{Discusses the different morphological analyses that have been suggested for the Celtic material. The preforms *scātu-, scōtu- or *scōto- could be tu- or to-formations of a root *sk̑eh₂- or *sk̑eh₃-, or, less likely, a root noun *skōt- with later thematisation.}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing a root *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-, probably lexically distinct from PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- on the basis of both forms having reflexes in Greek (cf.
