Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351 versus Ancient Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although they may well have been (sandhi?) variants of one another in PIE. For further discussion cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):438, [Matasović 2009](src-50):340).

Source: 180[963{Of unknown origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:556f.).}];740[II:556-557];540[394{S.v. Arm. ԿԱՐՃ 'կարճ', follows [Bailey 1979](src-320):65, who suggests a loan from Iranian *kart-čā.}];320[65{Cf. s.v. Khot. ke̮ca 'cleft, ravine', where it is suggested "Armen. karč 'short', and kirč 'defile, pass' may be Iranian loan-words."}]
Justification: Of uncertain etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):963, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:556-557), but cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540) considering a possible Iranian loanword, following the suggestion of [Bailey 1979](src-320):65. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Source: 81[236{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short' (ESSJa XI 101-104), cf. Lith. kartùs 'bitter', derived from PIE *(s)kert- (cf. Ved. kr̥ntáti 'cut (off), split, break' etc.).}];458[11: 99-104{PS *kortŭkŭ is derived from PIE *kert- ['cut'], cf. Lithuanian kertù, kir̃tsti 'chop', kar̃tas 'time [(as in (once, twice,) three times...)]'. Cf. PS *čersti, čĭrtǫ.}];141[559-560{*(s)kert- 'cut, split' with Lithuanian kertù, kir̃tsti and CS črĭtu, črěsti listed as cognates.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short', further derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):236, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:99-104, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. short, "The Germanic adjective is commonly regarded as a popular Latin *excurtus ( < Latin ex- + curtus ). On this view it would be parallel in origin with the synonymous Old Frisian, Old Saxon kurt , Dutch kort , Old High German (Middle High German, modern German) kurz , a West Germanic adoption of Latin curtus . The Romanic languages, however, afford no evidence of a popular Latin *excurtus , and it is unlikely that such a form existed. It is possible that Germanic *skurto- may be an altered adoption of Latin curtus , with prefixed s either due to some Germanic analogy or attracted from the ending of a preceding word in some Latin context. Some scholars, however, regard *skurto- as a native Germanic word, < a root *skert- (supposed to be evidenced in Middle High German scherze , scherzel small piece) < pre-Germanic *skerd-, an extension of *sker- to cut."}];165[444{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *skertan- 'to cut off'. "The root final t points to influence from an iterative *skurtōn- < *skrdʰ-neh₂-, cf. OHG, MHG schurz, OE scort, sceort 'cut off| short' < *skurta). There is no compelling reason to assume that the latter adjective was borrowed from an unattested Lat. *excurtus".}];388[346{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skurtaz, probably related to OIr. scerdid 'to scrape off', Lith. skérdžiu, skérdėti 'to get fissures, to crack'.}];141[558{Cf. s.v. ?*skerdʰ- 'schneiden, stechen' (?) (IEW 940-1). Cf. n1 "Vgl. […] viell. ae. scort, OHG scurz 'kurz', dann *skerd-".}]
Justification: Often assumed to be a loanword from an unattested Lat. adj. excurtus (similarly cf. OHG kurz, kurt, etc. < non-prefixed Lat. curtus in [cognate set 292](cog-292)), alternatively inherited from Proto-Germanic *skurta- to Proto-Germanic *skertan- 'cut off' and perhaps further to be connected to PIE *skerd⁽ʰ⁾- and comparable to Lith. skérdėti, OIr. sceirtid (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 558 s.v. ?*skerdʰ- 'schneiden, stechen' (?), [Orel 2003](src-388):346, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):444.

Source: 81[455-456{S.v. Proto-Slavic *slyšati 'hear', from PIE *k̑lous- (cf. Skt. śróṣati 'listen to, obey').}];141[336{S.v. *k̑leu̯s- '(zu)hören' (IEW 606-7). Cf. n1: this root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- (LIV² 334-335) already in the protolanguage.}];345[250-251{S.v. TochB klyaus- 'hear, listen to', which with TochA klyos- reflects Proto-Tocharian *klyeus-, as though from PIE *k̑lēus-, a lengthened grade iterative-intensive of PIE *k̑l(e)us- (cf. Skt. śróṣti 'hears, listens', OHG hlosēn 'listen', OCS slyšati ~ slušati 'hear', Lith. klausaũ 'hear').}]
Justification: Tocharian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to hear, to listen to' ([LIV²](src-141) 336, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):250-251, [Derksen 2008](src-81):455-456). The root is probably a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336).

Source: 105[66-67{S.v. Alb. ditë 'day', from Proto-Albanian *dītā and etymologically connected with Gmc. *tīdiz 'time', Skt. dīti 'brightness, splendour', other scholars connecting with the IE word for 'day' (cf. Lat. diēs), still others to Ved. dína- 'day', OCS dьnь. Cf. entry for references to further literature.}];571[51-52{S.v. Alb. ditë 'day', connected by [Meyer 1891](src-585):68 to OCS dьnь with a common -të suffix (cf. also Lith. dienà, Ved. dina- 'day'), but rejected by Vasmer on the grounds that there is no trace of expected nasalisation and instead proposing to NHG Zeit, OEng. tīd, etc. 'time'.}];165[516{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *tīdi- 'time' < *dh₂i-tí- (cf. Arm. ti, tioy 'age, time' < *dh₂i-to-| Skt. dáyate 'to divide, distribute', OAv. d(a)ii- 'to allot(?)', Gk. δαίομαι 'to divide' < *dh₂-ei-). [Proposed Albanian cognates not mentioned.]}];141[103-104{Cf. s.v. *deh₂(i̯)- 'teilen' (IEW 175-6).}];388[407{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *tīđiz 'time', etymologically close to Arm. ti 'age', Alb. ditë 'day'.}]
Justification: Albanian lexemes generally connected with Germanic *tīdi- 'time', derived from PIE *deh₂(i̯)- 'to divide, split into parts' (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):51-52, [Orel 1998](src-105):516 with references to further literature; [Orel 2003](src-388):407, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):516); for verbal derivatives to the same root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 103-104.

Source: 369[392{S.v. Alb. tha/j '(etwas Feuchtes am Feuer oder an der Luft) austrocken, trockenlegen, dörren, räuchern, erstarren, erfrieren'. Meyer's connection with Lith. saũas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', etc. must rely on an uncertain dissimilation of sibilants which is very uncertain. D. suggests perhaps to Gk. ἅζω 'dörren, trocknen' instead.}];105[471, 473{S.v. Alb. thatë 'dry', a derivative of the verb thaj 'to dry', from PAlb. *sausnja, a derivative of PIE *sauso- 'dry' (Gk. αὗος, MHG sôr, Lith. saũsas, Slav. *suxъ). Note the dissimilation of the sibilants leading to *s- > th- (Meyer 1891:88).}];585[88{S.v. Alb. θań 'trockne, dörre, wische ab, mache steif', cf. Lith. saũsas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', Gk. αὔω < *σαυσω.}];364[1000{Cf. s.v. Alb. than '(aus)trocknen, trockenlegen'. On the basis of phonological grounds it would be better to assign this verb to a root *k̑eh₂u̯- (LIV² Add. *k̑eh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen', cf. Gk. καίω).}];130[58-59{Considers the forms to be cognate with the forms from PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'dry'.}];389[{Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).}];141[345{Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.}];269[{Etymology here follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1000 and [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but be aware some scholars [Orel 1998](src-105):471, [Holm 2011](src-130):58-59, following [Meyer 1891](src-585):88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in [cognate set 7551](cog-7551) (cf. the skepticism of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):392).}]
Justification: Etymology here follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1000 and [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but be aware some scholars [Orel 1998](src-105):471, [Holm 2011](src-130):58-59, following [Meyer 1891](src-585):88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in [cognate set 7551](cog-7551) (cf. the skepticism of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):392).

Source: 105[269{S.v. Alb. mjegull 'cloud' (variants mjergull, njegull, which O. considers to be secondary). O. prefers a derivation from Proto-Albanian *meg(u)lā, related to Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist'.}];369[271-273{S.v. Alb. mjégull/ë 'Nebel, Wolke, Dunkel, Finsternis'. It may be necessary to separate the different variants into different etymologies. For mje(r)gull(ë) Jokl's suggestion from PIE *mergʷ- > PAlb. *merg- > Alb. mjerg-ull(ë) is the best formal solution. [Cf. entry for further discussion of inner-Albanian variation.]}];585[283-284{Considers the word either a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'cloud' or a cognate of Slav. *mьgla, etc.}];269[{Three main possibilities: Either connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so Orel 1998:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- [cognate set 42](cog-42)), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so Demiraj 1997:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by Meyer 1891:283-284, cf. [cognate set 2150](cog-2150)). Ultimately unclear.}];571[93{S.v. Alb. mjegull 'raincloud'. Cf. for various hypotheses considering lexical contamination.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so [Orel 1998](src-105):269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- [cognate set 42](cog-42)), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so [Demiraj 1997](src-369):271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by [Meyer 1891](src-585):283-284, cf. [cognate set 2150](cog-2150)). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of [Huld 1984](src-571):93). Ultimately unclear.

Source: 105[145{S.v. Alb. heq ~ hek 'to draw, pull'. In dialects a more conservative helq is also attested. From Proto-Albanian *skalkja, cognate with Greek ἕλκω 'draw'.}];364[974-976{S.v. Alb. heq 'herausziehen, wegnehmen'. Traditionally this verb is connected to PIE *selk- (cf. LIV² 530-531), but the phonological development is irregular. The underlying reconstruction seems to reflect *su̯elk- (cf. Schumacher 2005:614n59) and this suggests a possible contamination of the root *selk- with the root *h₂u̯elk- 'schleppen, ziehen' (LIV² 289-290). Alternatively also possible *sk̑ek- 'vorübergehen' (not in LIV²), but this must assume an l-contamination in the root from elsewhere to account for Old Tosk / hjelk /.}];664[614n59];141[530-531{S.v. *selk- 'ziehen' (IEW 901), a Tocharian, Greek (and Albanian?) isogloss.}];389[{S.v. *sk̑ek- 'vorübergehen', to which ?alb. heq, ageg. /hjek/ ‘zieht’, /hiqetë/ ‘geht vorüber’ after the suggestion of Schumacher & Matzinger (2013:974-976).}];269[{IE root etymology uncertain. According to [Orel 1998](src-105):145) to PIE *selk- (tentatively cf. [LIV²](src-141) 530-531)| according to [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974-976) a straightforward derivation from PIE *selk- is impossible and may represent a contamination of *selk- (cf. [cognate set 451](cog-451)) and *h₂u̯elk- (cf. [cognate set 5274](cog-5274))| alternatively Schumacher & Matzinger suggest possibly *sk̑ek- with contamination of -l- in the Old Tosk form of the root (see now [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).}]
Justification: IE root etymology uncertain. According to [Orel 1998](src-105):145) to PIE *selk- (tentatively cf. [LIV²](src-141) 530-531); according to [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974-976) a straightforward derivation from PIE *selk- is impossible and may represent a contamination of *selk- (cf. [cognate set 451](cog-451)) and *h₂u̯elk- (cf. [cognate set 5274](cog-5274)); alternatively Schumacher & Matzinger suggest possibly *sk̑ek- with contamination of -l- in the Old Tosk form of the root (see now [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 443[4:24-27{Cf. s.v. Lat. gălbĭnus 'grüngelb', p.26. It. giallo is a loan from Old French.}]
Justification: A loan from Old French jalne ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:26).

Source: 345[176{S.v. TochB kärweñe* 'stone', (coll.) 'rock'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps with Skt. grā́van- 'stone for pressing the soma', OIr. bráu 'millstone, quern', if so, then to be from a putative PIE *gʷr̥Hu̯on-en-, a derivative of *gʷr̥Hu̯on- underlying the Celtic and Indic forms. Alternatively possible is a derivative of *k̑érh₂u̯n- found in Gk. κέραυνος. If so the Tocharian would reflect *k̑r̥h₂u̯on-en- and the meaning would be generalised from 'thunderstone' (the stones that are supposed to be the result of a lightning strike).}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):176 for a survey of various proposals.

Source: 369[171-172{S.v. Alb. ë(n)j 'schwellen, zunehmen, entzünden, erzürnen'. The meaning 'blow (of wind)' (so [Huld 1984](src-571):63) probably does not exist. The almost exclusively followed connections to Ved. ániti 'atmen', Gk. ἄνεμος 'Hauch, Wind' and inner-Albanian end 'blühen' is semantically difficult. Another assessment by Çabej of an etymological assessment with Gk. οἰδάω, οἰδαίνω, Arm. aytnowm 'schwellen' (also Ölberg KZ 86 [1976] 128) should be considered.}];571[63{S.v. Alb. ëj 'blow (of inanimate things like wind)', to be connected with Ved. ániti 'it blows', Gk. ἄνεμος 'wind', derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- (so [Meyer 1891](src-585):5), rejecting the suggestion of Çabej that it should be connected with Gk. οἰδέω 'swell' as phonetically implausible'.}];105[91{S.v. Alb. ëj ~ âj 'to blow, to swell', from PAlb. *anj and to be related to Skt. ániti 'to breathe', Goth. us-anan 'to blow out', etc. (so [Meyer 1891](src-585):5).}];269[{IE root etymology uncertain. Two main possibilities: Either to (1) PIE *h₂enh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 297-298, so [Huld 1984](src-571):63, [Orel 1998](src-105):91, and others), or (2) to PIE *h₂ei̯d- ([LIV²](src-141) 258-259, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):256-257, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):171-172).}];141[258-259, 267-268{Cf. s.v. *h₂ei̯d- 'schwellen' (IEW 774), note 1, with reference to [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):256-7, and s.v. *h₂enh₁- 'atmen' to which Alb. ënj 'blase (auf)' is listed as an uncertain Neubildung formation ?R(e)-i̯e- Präs., cf. n9 with reference to [Huld 1984](src-571):155 and [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):256-7.}];558[256-257]
Justification: IE root etymology disputed. Two main possibilities: Either to (1) PIE *h₂enh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 297-298, so [Huld 1984](src-571):63, [Orel 1998](src-105):91, and others), or (2) to PIE *h₂ei̯d- ([LIV²](src-141) 258-259, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):256-257, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):171-172).

Source: 79[112-113{S.v. Arm. aṙnum 'to gain, obtain, win, plunder, take, grasp, etc.', generally agreed to be derived from PIE *h₂r-nu-, cf. Gk. ἄρνυμαι, aor. ἀρόμεν 'to win, gain', and probably also Av. ərənauu- 'to grant, allot, provide' (on which cf. de Vaan 2003:371).}];183[371{Cf. for a possible comparison to Av. ərənauu- 'to grant, allot, provide'.}];141[270-271{S.v. 2. *h₂er- 'nehmen, erwerben' (IEW 61).}]
Justification: Armenian lexemes continuing PIE *h₂r-nu-, derived to PIE *h₂er- 'to take, acquire' ([LIV²](src-141) 270-271, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):112-113).

Source: 316[131{Cf. s.v. Lat. colaphus 'taloche, coup de poing', a transcription of Gk. κόλαφος, already in Plautus colaphizō| reflexes in Romance reflect a popular word colpus with syncope of interior -a-.}];444[193{S.v. 2034 Lat. colaphus 'Schlag', 2. *colpus, 3. kolaphos (griech.).}]
Justification: Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):131).

Source: 165[220{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hemina- ~ *hemna- 'heaven'. On the PIE level the Germanic word is often analysed as a distorted continuant of *h₂ek̑-mōn, gen. *h₂k̑-mn-ós, loc. *h₂k̑-mén-i. Because the regular outcome of this in Germanic would be *ahmōn, *humnaz, *meni, it would seem that the paradigm was remodelled into *hemō, *hemnaz, *hemeni, on the basis of the genitive.}];179[183-184{S.v. Goth. H64. himins 'οὐρανός', 'heaven'. Uncertain etymology. Related by some scholars with PIE *Hek̑mon 'sharp thing', but with severe phonological and semantic difficulties. Otherwise possibly to PIE *k̑em- 'cover' (cf. Goth. af-hamon), cf. Hitt. kammara- 'cloud, vapor, smoke', however the formation is also problematic.}];274[287-300{S.v. *h₂ek̑- 'scharf, spitz (sein / werden / machen)' (LIV 261, IEW 18ff.). There are no certain Germanic cognates listed under the derived form *h₂ák̑-mon-| cf. pp.290-291, n7 where it is considered that a zero-grade formation must have existed if Germanic *hemena 'Himmel' reflects a post-PIE vr̥ddhi-formation (as if *h₂k̑-e-men-o-), however the semantics of such a formation are require further justification. Derivation ultimately unclear, possibly of non-IE origin in Germanic (cf. Boutkan 1998:113f.).}];669[113-115{No reliable IE etymology. Cf. for discussion with references.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Attempts to relate to PIE *h₂ek̑-mōn in [cognate set 7058](cog-7058) are made with great difficulty (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):183-184, [Boutkan 1998](src-669):113-115, [NIL](src-274) s.v. *h₂ek̑-), although this connection is still frequently assumed in secondary literature (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).

Source: 165[456{S.v. Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small'. "Probably an o-grade adjective related to Nw. smula w.v. 'to grind' < *smulēn- (< *smlH-eh₁-?). In spite of ON smali m. 'cattle', the adjective cannot be related to Gr. μῆλον n. 'small cattle, sheep and goats' and OIr. míl n. 'small animal' < *meh₁l-o-, which rather belong to OLFra. māla, Du. maal c. 'young cow' < *mēlo-."}];388[353{S.v. Proto-Germanic *smalaz, probably to be related to Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle', Lat. malus 'bad', Slav. *malъ 'small' ([Solmsen 1904](src-712):17).}];179[316{Cf. s.v. Goth. S106. smals, to be connected with PIE *(s)mēlo- 'small animal' (cf. Gk. μῆλον, OIr. míl, Arm. mal).}];697[517-518{S.v. Gmc. *smala- 'klein'. The common Germanic adjective signified 'klein', in West Germanic especially 'schmal, dünn'. The adjective has no precise correspondences. Frequently compared are OCS malъ 'klein', Lat. malus, Osc. mallo- 'schlecht, böse'| in other cases to IE *mēlo- in Du. maal 'junge Kuh', OIr. míl 'Schmalvieh', Gk. μῆλον 'Schaf', the morphological connections are however unclear.}];712[17]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):517-518, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456}). A connection has been proposed with Lat. malus 'bad', OCS malъ 'small', and Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle, sheep, goat' since [Solmsen 1904](src-712):17-18, but the semantics and morphological structure are unclear.

Source: 338[{Ossetic Iron šmud-ən 'smell' is from *əš-bud-ən < PIr. *uz-baud-. Cf. Sogdian βwδy 'smell (feeling)', Khotanese butte 'smell'.}];269[{For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, we tentatively follow [Cheung 2007](src-83):15-16 in distinguishing two separate Proto-Iranian roots, although the semantic shift *'to perceive, notice' > 'smell' is not entirely inconceivable and the lexemes could very well belong to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- ([LIV²](src-141) 83-84, [IEW](src-49) 150-2).}];83[15-16{S.v. Proto-Iranian *bau̯d-² 'to smell'. "In view of the well-defined, semantic distribution of 'to feel, sense'/'to smell' it seems necessary to assume two separate Ir. roots. But on the other hand, *bau̯d-² may be ultimately an ancient specialisation of the root *bau̯d-¹, cf. Engl. 'sense'." If also from *bau̯d-¹ 'to feel, sense', then from PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'to become attentive, be awake, perceive' (LIV² 83-84).}]
Justification: For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, we tentatively follow [Cheung 2007](src-83):15-16 in distinguishing two separate Proto-Iranian roots, although the semantic shift *'to perceive, notice' > 'smell' is not entirely inconceivable and the lexemes could very well belong to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- ([LIV²](src-141) 83-84, [IEW](src-49) 150-2).

Source: 165[328, 342{S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'roof, air', a *-tu- stem related to *lauba- 'leaf, foliage'. No clear IE etymology.}];179[237{Cf. s.v. Goth. L58. *luftus 'ἀήρ', 'air'. Etymology unclear.}];388[249-250{S.v. Proto-Germanic *luftuz, which O. prefers to relates to Skt. lumpati 'to break, to injure'. Other etymologies possible (cf. entry for references).}];398[1488-1491{Cf. s.v. OHG luft 'Luft, Luftraum, Atmospäre, Äther, Himmel, Lufthauch', from Proto-Germanic *luftu-, with no correspondences in the other IE languages.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing a derivative of Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):237, [EWA 5](src-398):1488-1491, [Kluge 2011](src-397):586, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):328, 342).

Source: 397[180{Cf. s.v. NHG Dampf (MHG dampf, tampf, OHG dampf, MLG damp, MDu. damp), from Gmc. *dampi- 'Ausdünstung, Dampf', considered to a be a labial extension of the same root also found in OHG toum 'Dampf, Dunst' and with s-mobile OE stēam, NE steam (cf. Lat. fūmus < *dʰūmo-), based on a meaning 'blasen, fauchen' (cf. similarly Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen, schnuppern', with labial extension dùmples 'Blasebalg').}];165[88{S.v. Proto-Germanic *dampa- 'vapour', derived from PGmc. *dimban- ~ *dimpan- 'to fog' < PIE *dʰembʰ-e-.}];388[68{S.v. Proto-Germanic *đampaz, based on strong verb *đempanan > MHG dimpfen 'to steam, to smoke', and related to Lith. dùmpti 'to blow'. ([IEW](src-49) 247-248 to Skt. dhámati 'to blow').}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ([IEW](src-49) 247-248, [Orel 2003](src-388):68, [Kluge 2011](src-397):180; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158). Alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in [LIV²](src-141).).

Source: 50[281{S.v. Proto-Celtic *muk-V- 'smoke' [Noun]. The Brittonic forms must be from *muk- with a short vowel. A connection with PIE *(s)meu̯g̑ʰ- 'smoke' (IEW 971) appears probable, but there are many irregularities in the reflexes of this root. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'burn in smouldering fire' presupposes PIE *smuHg̑ʰ-, while OE smeocan 'to smoke' appears to be from *smeu̯g̑-.}];296[M:69-70{S.v. OIr. múch 'fumée'. The root appears to have the form *smeugʰ- in Greek σμύχω 'je broule à petit feu' (cf. Arm. mux, gen. mxoy 'fumée'), and the form *smeug- in Gk. σμυγῆναι and in Germanic (cf. OE smocian 'fumer', smoca 'fumée'. Is there also a connection between these words and the root of Lat. mūcus, Gk. ἀπομύσσω and the Germanic words designating 'le nuage, l'humidité' in OIc. mygla, 'moisissure' and mugga 'pluie fine'? Starting from a root *smeu- with various enlargements we can account for a series of forms which occur among the languages (cf. [IEW](src-49) 971).}];79[484{Cf. s.v. Arm. mux 'smoke', cf. MIr. múch 'smoke', W mwg 'fire', MBret. mog, moug 'hearth', MHG smouch 'smoke', OE smoca 'smoke', smēocan 'to smoke', Gk. σμύχω 'cause to carbonise, be consumed in a slow fire, smoulder away'. "The etymon presents as with difficulties concerning the vocalic length and the velar. We may be dealing with a European substratum word *(s)m(e)u/ūK/G⁽ʰ⁾-."}];352[947{Cf. s.v. OLith. smáugti 'würgen, erwürgen', from PIE *smeu̯g- 'ersticken', cf. OE smēocan 'rauchen, räuchern'. Outside of Balto-Slavic a similar root is found in words for σμῡ́χω 'lasse verschwelen', Arm. mowx 'Rauch', NIr. múch, MW mwg 'Rauch, Dunst' which seem to expect deviant forms like *(s)muHgʰ-, *muk- and this still requires an explanation.}];165[458-459{S.v. Proto-Germanic *smeukan- ~ *smūkan- 'to smoke', from PIE *smeugʰ-e-(?). Cf. Gk. σμῡ́χω 'to burn up, smoulder away' < *smuHgʰ-e-| Lith. smáugti (smáugiu) 'to choke' < *smouHgʰ-ie-, Arm. mux, mxoy 'smoke' < *smoukH-o-| OIr. múch 'fire' < *smuHk-| MW mwg 'fire' < *smukH-. The underlying root is difficult to reconstruct| extra-Germanic evidence points to three different roots *smeuHgʰ-, *smeuHk-, and *smeukH-.}];556[440-441{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *smeuk-a- 'rauchen'. Germanic smeuk-a- can be connected with some extra-Germanic words, but the formal and semantic aspects are less secure. The Germanic forms formally correspond to Lith. smáugiu, -ti 'erwürgen, quälen' and Gk. (aor.) ἐσμύγην 'schwelte' (auch vom Schmerz), but because of the semantics the comparison is very uncertain. Formally less secure, but semantically better are *smeu-k- found in OIr. múch 'Rauch' and *smeu-gh- in Gk. σμύχω 'schwele'.}];66[1371{Cf. s.v. Gk. σμύχω 'to cause to carbonise, be slowly consumed in a fire, smoulder away' < IE ?*smeug⁽ʰ⁾- 'smoke'. "Beside the primary verb σμύχω, we find a noun in Arm. mux, gen, mxoy 'smoke'. In Celtic, OIr. múch, MW mwg 'fire' may go back to IE *muk-. In Germanic, there is a primary verb with a diphthong and a root-final IE voiced stop, e.g. OE smēocan 'to smoke, fumigate' < IE *smeug-, beside the zero-grade smoca [m.] 'smoke' < IE *smug-on-, smocian 'to smoke'. An Indo-European reconstruction for all these forms is difficult, as a voiceless aspirate *kʰ (PIE *(s)mūkʰo-| Meillet MSL 8 (1894): 294, followed by Frisk) is not reconstructed anymore for PIE. Lith. smáugti, 1sg. smáugiu 'to strangle, string together, plague' should probably be explained differently (Fraenkel 1955 s.v.), while for Ru. smúglyj 'dark, brown' etc., other interpretations are possible (Vasmer 1953 s.v.)."}]
Justification: Possibly related to Germanic [cognate set 647](cog-647) and Armenian cognate set 8305 lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 947 (Baltic material), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1371 (Greek material), [Seebold 1970](src-556):440-441, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):458-459 (Germanic material), [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:69-70, [Matasović 2009](src-50):281 (Celtic material), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):484 (Armenian material).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. root, a borrowing from early Scandinavian (cf. OIc. rót, Far. rót, Norn (Shetland) reithin (dative plural, with (analogical) mutated stem vowel), Nw. rot, OSw. rot (Swedish rot), ODa. root, rot (Da. rod)).}]
Justification: Loanword from early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic rót 'root' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Parallel loans from Turkish toz 'dust'.

Comment: the Arabic noun is used as a verbal stem in some languages

Source: 363[I:461{S.v. Kurd. ḥilī 'красивый, приятный на вид', from Arabic ḥulw 'красивый, прелестный'.}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Arabic حلو / ḥulw 'sweet, nice' (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:461).

Source: 83[292{"Because of the wide-ranging meanings this Kurdish verb may have two different origins, viz. *paiš and *pais, but not from *(H)u̯aiǰ, YAv. vij- ‘to shake, swing ?’ (pace Cabolov 2001, ibid.)."}]
Justification: Probably continuing a derivative of the Proto-Iranic root *paiš- 'to crush, grind', and further to PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat', although cf. the reservations of [Cheung 2007](src-83):292.

Source: 353[363{S.v. Lith. plaũkti 'swim, float, sail', from PIE *plouk- (cf. OIc. fljúga 'fly', OE flēogan 'fly', OHG fliugan, fliogan 'fly' [*pleuk-]), an enlarged variant of *pleu- 'float' (cf. Lith. pláuti 'wash, bathe').}];141[488{S.v. ?*pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (IEW 837).}];352[789-790{S.v. OLith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, spülen, abspülen', from PIE *pleu̯k- 'schweben, schwimmen' (cf. ON fliúga, OHG fliogan 'fliegen'). The root is formally an semantically close to PIE *pleu̯- 'schwimmen, schweben', but the relationship between the two roots is not fully explained. Perhaps a Germanic-Baltic (Germanic-Lithuanian?) isogloss.}];441[385-388{Cf. s.v. OHG fliogan 'fliegen', going back to a pre-Proto-Germanic root *pleu̯k-, also found in Baltic *pleu̯k- 'schwimmen, schweben' (Lith. plaũkti 'schwimmen, durch die Luft dahinfahren', etc., whose root also is to be connected to words for 'Haar, Flocke, Feder'. (cf. Lith. pláukas 'Haar, (Haar-)Farbe, Art, Gattung', Lith. plùnksna 'Feder', and probably also Lat. plūma 'Flaumfeder, Flaum'. This root is generally considered to be an enlargement of the IE root *pleu̯- with various meanings.}]
Justification: Often considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488), however the *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 789-790, [Derksen 2015](src-353):363, [EWA 3](src-441):385-388).

Source: 172[I:668-669{S.v. Ved. √tej- 'scharf machen, zuspitzen', PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (cf. Gk. στίζω [pf.pass. ἔστιγμαι] 'steche, tätowiere', στίγμα 'Stich, Brandmerkung', Lat. īn-stīgāre 'anspornen', NHG stehen, Stich', etc.).}];442[330{S.v. 5806 Skt. tiktá- 'pungent, bitter' [√tij-].}];141[592-593{Cf. s.v. *(s)tei̯g- 'stechen, spitz sein' (IEW 1016-7).}];320[129{S.v. Khot. ttīrä 'bitter', from Ir. *tigra- 'sharp, bitter' (from PIE *(s)teig-, cf. Skt. tejate 'be sharp', tiktá- 'sharp, bitter', Gk. στίζω 'prick', etc.).}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to prick, be pointed' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5806, [Bailey 1979](src-320):129, [EWAia](src-172) I:668-669; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 592-593).

Source: 141[282-284{S.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-8).}];50[36-37{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ank-o- 'reach', from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'reach, attain' (cf. Skt. aśnoti 'reaches', Lat. nanciscor).}];296[D:151{S.v. OIr. do-icc 'il arrive, il vient'| from preverb *to- + vb. icc-, cf. [Pedersen 1913](src-308):557.}];304[200-204{S.v. Proto-Celtic *-an-n-k-e/o- 'erreichen' (PIE *h₂nek̑-, LIV 282-284),}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach' ({ref LIV² 282-284, cf. [Pedersen 1913](src-308):557, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:151, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):200-204, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36-37).

Source: 141[593-594{S.v. *stei̯gʰ- 'steigen, schreiten' (IEW 1017-8).}];50[376{S.v. Proto-Celtic *tēg- 'go', from PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'tread, go' (cf. Gk. στείχω, Goth. steigan).}];296[T:57-60{S.v. OIr.  tíag- 'aller, s'avancer, partir', to be connected with the IE root *(s)teigh- (cf. Gk. στείχω, Goth. steigan, Skt. stíghnute, etc.).}]
Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, stride' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:57-60, [Matasović 2009](src-50):376, [LIV²](src-141) 593-594).

Source: 165[415{S.v. Proto-Germanic *rōbōn- 'tail', in ablaut relation to Ice. rafi 'strip (of land)', Far. ravi 'strip of halibut| side of a ray', Nw. rave 'rag| strip of land', possibly from < *h₁rop-on- or *h₁rh̥₁p-on-. Unrelated to PGmc. *rōbjōn- 'turnip'.}];468[450{S.v. ON rófa 'schwanz, steissbein'. The etymology varies between either (1) MLG rœve, OHG ruoba, ruoppa, to Lat. rāpa| (2) to répij 'pfahl', or (3) Germ. *wrōbōn to Lat. verpa 'penis', Gk. ῥαπίς 'rute'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):450, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):415 for various proposals.

Source: 423[IV:744-746{S.v. Span. rabo, probably to be derived from Lat. rāpum 'turnip'.}];54[514{S.v. Lat. rāpum 'turnip', from Proto-Italic *rāpo- (cf. Gk. ῥάπυς, ῥάφυς 'turnip', ῥάφανος ῥαφάνη 'radish', Lith. rápė 'turnip', RuCS rěpa, OHG ruoba, ruoppa 'turnip'). "This cannot be a regular PIE word: Latin, Baltic, and OHG ruoba require *aH, Slavic has /ē/, and Greek has single -a-. There is no prothetic vowel in Greek, and the vacillation between π and φ also suggests a loanword."}];269[{Widely regarded to be cognate with other words for 'turnip' in other IE languages. There are, however, formal difficulties in reconstruction which may point to a common borrowing or parallel borrowings from a pre-PIE source language. Cf. Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 2329](cog-2329) and *rap- in DIEAT http://dieat.inss.sc.ku.dk/display/entry.php?lemma_id=2139}];316[564{S.v. Lat. rāpum 'rave'. The absence of prothesis in Greek ῥάπυς and ῥάφυς 'rave' ῥάφανος, ῥαφάνη 'radis' and the -ě- of Church Slavic rěpa 'rave' make it difficult to see this as an old Indo-European word, as OCS ruoba 'rave', and Lith. rópė. The way in which these words are related is uncertain.}];352[875{Cf. s.v. OLith. rópė, ropė̃ 'Rübe'. In general a Wanderwört of unknown origin, which has come into various European Indo-European languages in different forms.}]
Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes, probably to be derived from Latin rāpum 'turnip' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:744). Further etymology uncertain, possibly an early non-Indo-European loanword (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):514, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):564, [ALEW](src-352) 875 for further discussion).

Source: 442[808{S.v. 13980 Skt. hárati 'carries, brings' RV., 'takes away' Mn. 2. Pass. *hr̥yatē. [√hr̥] (> K. hyonu, pp. hyotu 'to take').}];172[II:803-804{S.v. Ved. √har-¹ 'nehmen, bringen, herbeiholen, tragen, darbringen'. Without convincing etymological connections.}];141[177{Cf. s.v. ?2.*g̑ʰer- 'nehmen, holen' (IEW 442). Root only attested in Indic.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √har- 'to carry, bring' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):808 no. 13980). No certain etymology outside of Indic ([EWAia](src-172) II:803-804), [LIV²](src-141) mechanically ?2.*g̑ʰer- 'to take, get'.

Source: 141[175-176{S.v. *g̑ʰengʰ- 'schreiten' (IEW 438-9).}];165[166-167{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gangan- ~ *gungen- 'to go', from PIE *g̑ʰóngʰ-e- (cf. Lith. žeñgti [žengiù] 'to stride' < *g̑ʰengʰ-ie-).}];556[213-216{S.v. Gmc. *gang-a- 'gehen'. May be compared with an e-grade Lith. verb žengiù, žeñgti 'schreiten' from a proto-form *g̑ʰengʰ- further connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ([LIV²](src-141) 175-176, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):213-216, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):166-167).

Source: 83[299-301{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *pat- under the Choresmian forms. "The etymology of hwβ is uncertain.", cf. entry for further discussion of problematic hypotheses that have been proposed.}];724[92-93{S.v. Khw. hwβ '(herab)fallen, einstürzen| geraten (in Kummer, usw.)', from a stem *hauba-? A root *haub-/hub- is otherwise unknown.}]
Justification: Khwarazmian hwβ would appear to continue a present stem *hauba-, but there is no certain etymology (cf. [Samadi 1986](src-724):92-93, [Cheung 2007](src-83):299-301).

Source: 84[{S.v. Engl. kill, of obscure origin| not found in the cognate languages. "If in Old English, its type would be *cyllan , conjecturally referred to an Old Germanic *kuljan , ablaut-variant of *kwaljan , whence Old English cwellan to quell v.1| but the original sense is against this. Known first in Layamon, and in southern texts, in form cüllen , küllen . In midl. dialect normally kille(n , kill , the common form in Middle English| kelle is rare."}]
Justification: Of obscure origin, first attested in Middle English ME culle(n), kulle(n), kille(n), kylle, etc. ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Source: 83[96{S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaHz- 'to run, start' (cf. Skt. gāh- 'to enter (the water), wade'), from PIE *g⁽ʷʰ⁾eh₂g̑ʰ- 'to wade' (cf. Slov. gáziti 'to wade', SCr. gȁziti 'to step, wade').}];141[183{S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- '(ins Wasser eindringen, hineinwaten' [IEW 465]. Khwarazmian γ’z- 'laufen, eilen' is marked '?' from a reconstructed present stem *g⁽ʷ⁾ḗg̑ʰ-/*g⁽ʷ⁾ég̑ʰ-.}];325[111{S.v. žoz- ŠRB, žǟx̌t Š, žēx̌t RB, žuz : žux̌t S, γaz : γex̌t Y 'to run', cf. Khwar. γʾz, Mj. Yd. γaz-, Ishk. γəz-.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gaHz- 'to run, start', probably further to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to enter (water), wade' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):96, [LIV²](src-141) 183, cf. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):111).

Source: 673[112{Arm. sermn is tentatively explained as a contamination of the root *k̑erh₁- 'grow' with *sper- (as found in Gk. σπέρμα 'seed'), cf. Olsen (1999:504). Not in Martirosyan (2010).}];180[504{Explains Arm. sermn as a *-mn̥(t)- stem, either from the root *k̑erh₁- (IEW 577) or a contamination of this root and *sp⁽ʰ⁾er- found in Gk. σπέρμα, -ατος.}]
Justification: Usually explained as a blend of PIE *k̑erh₁- 'grow' with *sper- 'strew' (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):504, [Clackson 2017](src-673):112).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian culírcia 'winged / reddish ant'.

Source: 369[243{S.v. Alb. lig 'schlecht, böse| krank| mager'. No further connections within Albanian, but outside one may compare Lith. ligas 'schlecht, krank', ligà 'Krankheit', Latv. liga 'Seuche', further probably Gk. λοιγός 'Verderben, Unheil, Tod'. Since long connected further to words with deviating semantics like Gk. ὀλίγος 'klein', Arm. ałkʻat 'arm, wenig, dürftig'.}];585[245{S.v. Alb. l'ik-gu 'böse, mager', cf. Gk. ὀλίγος, Lith. ligà 'Krankheit'.}];571[87{S.v. Alb. i lig, ligë 'bad, ill', akin to Gk. ὀλίγος 'few', Lith. ligà 'illness' since [Meyer 1891](src-585):245, and accepted by others.}];105[227{S.v. Alb. lig 'bad, ill' reflecting PAlb. *liga and further connected with Gk. ὀλίγος 'small, few', λοιγός 'destruction, death', Lith. ligà 'illness', Latv. liga 'id.'.}]
Comment: *(h₃)lig-o-
Justification: Connected since [Meyer 1891](src-585):245 to Greek ὀλίγος 'few, little', Lith. ligà 'illness', cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):87, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):243, [Orel 1998](src-105):227.
Loan from Calabrian-Italian sco̧rza 'bark' ([Rohr 2000](src-687):111-112).

Source: 353[430{S.v. Lith. stóras 'thick, fat', from PIE *steh₂-ro- (cf. Proto-Slavic *starъ 'old' > OCS starъ, etc., OIc. stórr 'big' < *steh₂uro-).}];172[II:768-769{S.v. Ved. sthūra- 'groß, stark, dick, wuchtig' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (cf. Old Swedish stūr 'groß', Middle Dutch stūr 'groß, stark').}];564[523{S.v. Arm. ստուար stvar 'dick', an inherited word. Cf. Skt. sthávira- 'breit, dick, massig', sthūra- 'dick, breit', etc.}];274[637-659{S.v. *steh₂- 'wohin treten, sich hinstellen' (LIV 590ff., IEW 1004ff.).}];352[979{S.v. OLith. stóras 'dick, stark, grob' (BSl. OCS starъ 'alt', etc.), outside of Balto-Slavic to be connected with ON stórr, 'groß, gewaltig, wichtig', etc. Only precise formal correspondences are found in Germanic and Slavic. It is generally considered to be an adjective with a *-ró- suffix to the full grade of the root *steh₂-.}];180[199{Arm. stowar 'thick' < PIE *stuh₂-ró- (< *sth₂u-ró-), cf. Skt. sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick', Av. stūra-, MLG stūr).}]
Justification: Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-) to PIE *steh₂- ([NIL](src-274) 639, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):199, [EWAia](src-172) II:768-769, [ALEW](src-352) 979, [Derksen 2015](src-353):430).
Loanword from Italian lordo 'dirty, filthy'.
Loanword from Italian contare 'to count'.

Source: 141[73-74{Cf. s.v. bʰelg̑ʰ- 'schwellen' (IEW 125-6).}];165[49{S.v. Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ-i-, an i-stem related to PGmc. *belgan- 'swell' < *bʰelg̑ʰ- (cf. Skt. barhíṣ- 'bundle of straw' Av. barəziš- 'pad, pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-is-, OPruss. balsinis 'pillow' < *bʰolg̑ʰ-ino-, etc.).}];50[70{S.v. Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach', from PIE *bʰolg̑ʰ- 'skin bag, bolster' (cf. Av. barəziš 'bolster, cushion', OE belg 'stomach', OPr. balsinis 'cushion').}]
Justification: Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):49, [Matasović 2009](src-50):70, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 73-74).
Proto-Albanian loan (cf. Std. zgavër  'cavity, cave', also indicated by inflection) from Vulgar Latin *skavare (cf. Ital. scavare)

Source: 105[467{Cf. s.v. Standard Albanian trup 'corpse', borrowed from Slavic *trupъ 'id.'}];585[438-439{S.v. Alb. trup 'Leib, Körper' = OCS trupъ 'venter, truncus membrum', also Rom. trup 'Körper'.}]
Justification: Identical to Standard Albanian trup 'body, trunk', a loanword from Slavic  *trupъ 'id.' (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):438-439, [Orel 1998](src-105):467).
Loan from Italian volare 'to fly'.
Loanword from Italian, either directly from macinare 'to grind', or a denominal formation to a loan from macina 'mill, millstone, grinder'.

Source: 345[139-140{S.v. TochB aurtstse ~ wartstse 'broad, wide', which with TochA wärts 'id.' reflect Proto-Tocharian *wärtse. The more commonly found TochB aurtstse is a compound of this proto-form + *en-. The PIE antecedents of this form are not completely clear. Two main possibilities: (1) Van Windekens takes the word to be the equivalent of Skt. vr̥ddhá- 'enlarged, augmented, big', but the past participle of the root vr̥dh- is only known from Indo-Iranian. Alternatively (2) Sieg, Siegling, & Schulze connect with Sanskrit váras- 'width, breadth, expanse, space', urú- 'broad, wide'.}]
Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):139-140 for various suggestions.
Light verb construction with Arbëresh kaça 'hunt' (n.) as the semantic head, a loanword from Italian caccia 'hunt'.
Loanword from Italian lago 'lake'.
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.

Source: 369[230-231{S.v. Alb. la 'waschen, spülen, reinigen', probably to continue a verb of the productive *-n(i̯)o- class: *lh₃-eu̯- > PAlb. *lau̯- > Alb. la-.}];105[210{S.v. Alb. laj ~ lâj 'to wash', from PAlb. *launja and related to Gk. λούω, Lat. lavō 'id.'.}];585[237{S.v. Alb. l'ań 'wasche, bade', borrowed from Lat. lavāre.}];571[85{S.v. Alb. laj 'wash', contra Meyer (1891:237) if laj is a loan from Lat. lavāre, then that would have yielded *lëv-oj or *loj.}];54[330-331{S.v. Lat. lavō, -āre 'to bathe', from Proto-Italic *lowa- (cf. Umb. vutu [3.sg.iptv.]), from PIE *(le-)louh₃- 'to wash' (cf. Gk. λούω 'I wash', Arm. loganam 'to bathe', lowanam 'wash', OAlb. laa 'to wash').}];66[872-873{Cf. s.v. Gk. λούω, -ομαι 'to bathe, wash (the body)', from PIE *louh₃- 'wash, bathe'.}];364[980{S.v. OAlb. lan 'waschen', attested through Old Gheg la (Buzuku) probably continues PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix.}];80[511-513{Cf. s.v. Hitt. lāḫu-, laḫu- 'to pour, to cast (objects from metal)| (intr.) to (over)flow' (Anat. cognates: CLuw. lā(ḫ)un(a)i- 'to wash', lū- 'to pour'). The Hitt. forms may be derived from PIE formations *lóh₂u-ei, *lh₂u-énti [but no cognates outside of Anatolian are given].}];141[401, 418{Cf. s.v. ? 2. *leh₂- 'gießen' [IEW 692]. and s.v. *leu̯h₃- 'waschen' (IEW 692).}];389[http://www.martinkuemmel.de/liv2add.html#_Toc392257980 , http://www.martinkuemmel.de/liv2add.html#_Neu:_*leh₃u̯-_‘gießen,{It is no longer necessary to postulate two separate roots *leh₂(u̯)- 'pour' for Anatolian and *leu̯h₃- for Italic and Albanian. The two roots can be reconciled to *leh₃u̯- (cf. Melchert 2011:127-132).}];690[127-132];269[{For root ref. form *leh₃u̯-, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) and [Melchert 2011](src-690):127-132.}]
Justification: Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₃u̯-'to pour; to wash' ([LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) and [Melchert 2011](src-690):127-132; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):511-513, [Beekes 2010](src-66):872-873, [Meyer 1891](src-585):237, [Huld 1984](src-571):85, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):230-231, [Orel 1998](src-105):210, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):980, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):330-331).

Source: 54[269-270{S.v. Lat. grāmen, -inis 'grass', from Proto-Italic *grāsmen-/*grasmen-, from PIE *g̑ʰr̥h₁-(s-)mn̥- 'grass', cf. Goth. gras, OHG gras, OIc. gras 'grass'| OE grōwan, OIc. gróa, OHG gruoen 'to grow' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ie/o-| OS grōni, OHG gruoni 'green' < *g̑ʰroh₁-ni-.}];269[{Proto-Germanic *grasa- is generally compared with Lat. grāmen [cf. [cognate set 8369](cog-8369)] but details of the etymology remain disputed. The Leiden dictionaries ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):187 s.v. PGmc. *grasa-, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):269-270) argue to reconcile the reconstructions through postulating a root *⁽g̑⁾ʰreh₁- (not in LIV²) underlying PGmc. *grōan- 'grow', from which the Germanic forms would be a secondary s-stem. [Seebold 1970](src-556):242-243 also suggests the possibility of a connection of Gmc. *grōan- with Lat. grāmen, but has reservations whether the two forms can be compared. Similarly, cf. [Kluge 2002](src-350):370 s.v. NHG Gras, where two possibilities are offered: Either to (1) PGmc. grōan- (as [Kroonen 2013](src-165):187 and tentatively [Seebold 1970](src-556):242-243), or alternatively to PIE *gras- (cf. Gk. γράω 'I devour', Ved. grásate 'devours', [LIV²](src-141) 192 s.v. *gres-) with an variant in initial position| cf. also [Pooth 2015](src-693):116 arguing for an onomatopoeic root *g⁽ʰ⁾ras- ~ *kras- (Gk. κράστις 'grass, hay'). It seems very likely that there is a connection between the Germanic lexemes and Latin grāmen, but the problem has not yet been solved in a satisfactory way. [Cogsets for Proto-Italic *grā̆men- [cognate set 8369](cog-8369) and Proto-Germanic *grasa- [cognate set 230](cog-230) have been cross-indexed at value 5/6: large majority view]}]
Justification: Latin grāmen is very likely (but not absolutely certainly) cognate with Proto-Germanic *grasa- 'grass' in [cognate set 230](cog-230); cf. note by Scarborough in citations for further discussion. For the appurtenance of Brazilian Portuguese grama to this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):327 no. 3835.
Loan from Calabrian Italian χatari 'to breathe'.

Source: 345[739{S.v. TochB samudtär 'sea, ocean', loan from Buddhist (Hybrid) Sanskrit samudra-.}];269[{Cf. other parallel loans from Sanskrit samudrá- in Modern Indic languages in [cognate set 6525](cog-6525). The (parallel?) loans from Buddhist Sanskrit in Tocharian A & Tocharian B should probably be separated from the parallel loans in the Modern Indic languages.}]
Justification: Loans from Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit samudra- 'the sea, ocean' ([Adams 2013](src-345):739).

Comment: Sardinian forms formerly with Balto-Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 1109](cog-1109). ALEW doubts cognacy outside of Balto-Slavic. This needs to be double-checked. (-MJCS 19.10.2017).

Justification: Loan from Calabrian ad(d)urare, -ari 'to smell' with apheresis, cf. Sandard Italian odorare < Lat. odōrāre.

Source: 50[126, 129{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *fet-no- 'bird', derived from PIE *pet- 'fly'. The thematic stem *fetno- is presumably generalised from the heteroclitic stem *fatar (gen. *fetnos). Cf. also s.v. Proto-Celtic *fatar / gen. *fatanos, *fetnos 'wing, bird' (to which may be compared Hitt. pattar, Skt. pátra-, Gk. πτερόν, Lat. penna).}];141[476{Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.}];131[221{The Albanian word originates from *su-petno-t- ([Huld 1984](src-571):154)}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}];79[286-287{Cf. s.v. Arm. *tʻiṙ- 'to fly', derived from the same root as *tʻer 'leaf, etc.' < PIE *pter-, probably a derivative of PIE *pet- 'to fly' (cf. Gk. πτερόν 'feather', πτέρυξ 'wing of a bird', πέτομαι 'to fly', etc').}];679[212, 495];423[IV:342-343{S.v. Sp. pájaro, from old pássaro which is from vulgar Latin passar 'id.', cf. Classical Latin passer, -ĕris 'gorrión'.}];571[154{Alb. shpend 'bird' < *sV-pétno+to-.}];105[315, 429{S.v. Alb. shpend 'bird'. Orel regards Alb. shpend 'bird' a derivative of pendë 'feather| pair of oxen', which (cf. s.v.) he in turn regards a borrowing from Lat. pinna, penna. Alternatively cf. Meyer (1891:413) who regards as a prefixal derivative of *pet-no-.}];585[413{S.v. Alb. špesε f. špes m. 'Vogel' (geg. špent-di-, špen). There is no direct connection to the loanword pendε. Rather, the word is to be derived from š-pen and pen is comparable to OIr. en, W. etn 'bird', from *petn-.}];54[449{S.v. Lat. passer 'small bird', from Proto-Italic *pattro-, via PIE *p(e)t-tro- 'who flies, bird' (so [Schrijver 1991](src-679):212, 495). "Schrijver proposes *pttro- 'bird' > *pattro- > nom.sg. *passros, gen.sg. *passrī > *passr̥s, *pazrī > *passer, *pārī. This paradigm would have been skewed, yielding two nouns: passer 'sparrow' and pārus 'tit'. It must be remarked that the expected meaning of a form *pt-tro- would rather be instrument for flying, wing' vel sim."}]
Justification: Armenian, Albanian, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):286-287, [Meyer 1891](src-585):413, [Huld 1984](src-571):154, [Orel 1998](src-105):315, 429, [de Vaan 2008](src-54), [Schrijver 1991](src-679):212, 495, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):516 no.6268, [DCECH](src-423) IV:342-343, [Matasović 2009](src-50):126, 129).

Italic lexemes from Latin frīgere 'to be cold', a derivative of Latin frīgus 'cold, frost' (n.) < PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):254, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):243, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):301 no. 3510; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 587)

Source: 369[250-251{S.v. Alb. 2. madh (i) 'groß', from PIE *meg̑-, but with some difficulties in establishing the exact stem formation.}];105[240{S.v. Alb. madh 'big, large' < Proto-Albanian *madza and related to Hitt. mekkiš, Skt. mahā́nt-, Gk. μέγας, Lat. magnus, etc.}]
Justification: Identical with Albanian madh 'big' < PIE *meg̑- in [cognate set 360](cog-360).

Source: 369[238-239{Cf. s.v. Alb. lesh, -i 'Wolle| Haar| Vlies', an inherited word without certain correspondences outside of Albanian. The designation of the PIE word for 'wool' *Hu̯l̥h₁neh₂- (cf. Lat. lāna, Lith. vìlna, Gk. λῆνος 'wool' etc.) is semantically attractive, setting forth a different derived proto-form: lesh < Alb. laš- : prob. *Hu̯l̥h₁-so-/-seh₂-, cf. Lat. vellus 'Wolle, Schaffell, Vlies'}];105[219-220{S.v. Alb. lesh 'wool, fleece, hair', from PAlb. laiša, etymologically connected with the Balto-Slavic word for foliage : Lith. laĩškos 'leaf', Latv. laĩska 'leaf on a linen stalk| stalk', Slav. listъ 'leaf'.}];130[65{Under 'hair' 3. lesh|i 'wool, fleece, hair'| [Orel 1998](src-105):219 to Balto-Slavic forms for foliage without a reference "semantically too far, and not mentioned in Pk [[IEW](src-49)]"| Perhaps with [IEW](src-49) 681 to *leu̯H-so- 'abgeschnitten/cut off', alternatively [IEW](src-49) 1139 *u̯elH- 'hair, wool' > *Hu̯l̥h₁-so- > PAlb. (u)laś 'wool, hair, fleece' similarly cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):85, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):238.}];571[85-86]
Justification: Cf. Standard Albanian lesh 'wool; hair; fleece'; further etymology uncertain. A popular hypothesis considers a derivative to the same root as the Indo-European word for 'wool', *Hu̯l̥h₁neh₂-, if to be morphologically segmented *Hu̯l̥h₁-neh₂- via an alternative preform *Hu̯l̥h₁-so- (so [Demiraj 1997](src-369):238-239, similarly [Huld 1984](src-571):85-86). [Orel 1998](src-105):219-220 considers a connection to the Balto-Slavic word for 'foliage'; against which cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):65.

Source: 156[IV:60{S.v. Oss. wazal 'холодный, холод, стужа'. Hübschmann and Bielmeier derive from *wa-sal and connect this to šɜl-ən 'freeze' (cf. [cognate set 1857](cog-1857)). But Abaev thinks this is phonetically implausible, and considers it a "Scytho-European" term with no Iranian cognates. He links *zal to Latin gelu 'frost', gelidus 'cold', German kalt etc.}];269[{Etymology disputed. Either to PIE *k̑elH- (cf. 'cold' in [cognate set 14](cog-14), 'freeze' in [cognate set 1857](cog-1857)) or to PIE *g̑el- (cf. 'cold' in [cognate set 196](cog-196), 'ice' in [cognate set 6560](cog-6560)).}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. Either to PIE *k̑elH- (cf. 'cold' in [cognate set 14](cog-14), 'freeze' in [cognate set 1857](cog-1857)) or to PIE *g̑el- (cf. 'cold' in [cognate set 196](cog-196), 'ice' in [cognate set 6560](cog-6560)); cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:60.

Source: 345[236{S.v. TochB krośce ~ kroṣce 'cold', which with TochA kᵤraś reflect Proto-Tocharian nom.sg. *kʷroscē, acc.sg. kʷroscänä(n) which can reflect PIE *kʷrus-tēn, *kʷrus-tén-m̥. The assumption of a labiovelar explains the TochA nom.sg. kᵤraś, and medial -o-. "The nearest relatives are in Gk. κρυσταίνομαι 'congealed with cold, freeze' (cf. also κρύστάλλος 'ice| numbness| crystal,' κρυμός 'icy cold, frost' < *krusmó-), κρύος (nt.) 'id.' … [Beekes 2010](src-66):786 surprisingly, and surely wrongly, hesitant."}];269[{If [Adams 2013](src-345):236 is correct in his postulation of initial *kʷ-, then the proposed Greek cognates would have yielded †πρύος, †πρυσταίνομαι with regular development of *kʷ- > p / _C in Greek. Adams's reconstruction cannot be correct as such.}];66[786{Cf. s.v. κρύος 'icy cold, frost'. The etymology is difficult to assess. There are two alternatives: Either (1) Possibly from IE *kreu̯s- 'shiver', cf. ON hrjósa 'to shiver', OHG hroso 'ice', to the root *kreus- 'to stamp, strike'. Semantically TochB krośce 'cold' would be a perfect comparison but the -o- in the TochB form is difficult to account for| or (2) a connection of the group of words connected to Av. xrūma- 'horrible' < *kruh₂-mo- and connected with the *kruh₂- 'blood' root.}];149[182-183{S.v. B krośce, A krośśaṃ 'cold'}]
Justification: Further etymology outside of Tocharian unclear. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):182-183, [Adams 2013](src-345):236 attempt to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):786).

Source: 83[67-68{S.v. Proto-Iranian *dauH-¹ 'to burn', from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to burn, be(come) on fire' (cf. Skt. dav- 'to kindle, burn', Gk. δαίω 'I kindle', OIr. dóïd 'singes, burns', OIr. condud 'firewood', OHG zuscen 'to burn').}];460[200{S.v. AGk. δαίω 'anzünden, brennen' > Tsak. δαίσου.}];141[104-105{S.v. *deh₂u̯- 'in Brand geraten' (IEW 179-81).}];66[298-299{S.v. AGk. δαίω 'to kindle', from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'burn'. The perfect stem δέδηα < *δέ-δᾱϝ-α resembles Skt. du-dāv-a (gramm.) to which pres. du-nó-ti 'to burn' is related. OIr. dóim 'to burn' and OHG zuscen 'id.' may also be related.}];296[D:111-112{Cf. s.v. OIr. dó- 'brûler, se consumer', to be connected with the root *duwə-, *dū- (cf. Skt. dunóti 'il brûle, il afflige, il fait du mal' Gk. δαίω 'j'allume', etc.).}];269[{The connection of Irish: Gaelic dóigh to this class assumes that it is cognate with OIr. dó- 'burn' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:111-112, [LIV²](src-141) 104-105). There remains the possibility that there may have been contamination in the Middle Irish period with OIr. daig 'flame, blaze' derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:8-9 s.v. daig, [Matasović 2009](src-50):93).}];321[374{S.v. Wakhi θaw- : θət- 'жечь, гореть'}]
Justification: Hellenic, Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₂u̯- ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):200, [Beekes 2010](src-66):298-299, [Cheung 2007](src-83):67-68, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:111-112). The connection of Irish: Gaelic dóigh to this class assumes that it is cognate with OIr. dó- 'burn' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:111-112, [LIV²](src-141) 104-105). There remains the possibility that there may have been contamination in the Middle Irish period with OIr. daig 'flame, blaze' derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:8-9 s.v. daig, [Matasović 2009](src-50):93).

Source: 341[777-778{S.v. TochB mai- '± abschätzen, ermessen', '± gage, gauge, estimate'| TochA me- 'ermessen', 'gage' (?). "In order to connect all of these forms, one can set up a PT root *m(’)æy- 'measure, gage'. The PIE root involved then may have been either *√meh₁ 'messen' (²LIV, 424, with fn. 1, where the connection of TB maistär is doubted) or *√med 'messen, für Einhaltung sorgen, sich kümmern' (²LIV, 423 with Toch.)"}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Tocharian *m⁽’⁾æy-, further IE root etymology uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):777-778 for further discussion.

Source: 165[167, 171-172{S.v. Proto-Germanic *gauma- 'heed, attention', from which the denominal verb *gaumjan- (cf. Goth. gaumjan 'to notice'), where the semantic development 'heed' > 'hide' is a secondary development. K. considers "[i]n spite of the apparent similarities, the word cannot be related to ON gá w.v. 'to heed', as this verb continues *ganhēn-, not *gawēn-. I therefore propose a relationship with the Indo-Iranian root *g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeug̑ʰ- 'to hide', assuming that this meaning developed from a more primary 'to heed, guard'." Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *ganhēn- 'to inspect| take into account'(?) "The widely accepted etymological connection with OCS gověti 'to revere (cf. Torp 1909: 121) and Lat. faveō 'to be favorable' < *gʷʰou-eh₁- (cf. Schrijver 1991: 441-2), implying a PGm. form *gawēn-, is contradicted by the nasal vowel of Elfd. gą̊ […]. It follows that the apparently obvious link with *gauma- 'attention' must be abandoned.}];468[151, 158, 165-166{S.v. ON geyma 'beachten, sorgen für', cf. gaum 'aufmerksamkeit', which probably belongs to ON gá, whose etymology is disputed.}];179[151{S.v. Goth. 672. gaumjan 'βλέπειν, διαβλέπειν, ἰδεῖν, κατανοεῖν', 'see, observe'. Possibly an extended form of PIE *ghou- 'perceive, pay heed to' (cf. Lat. foveō 'be favourable', OI. gá < *gawōn 'pay heed', OCS gověti 'honor').}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain. If [Kroonen 2013](src-165):167 is correct, then the traditional etymology (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):165-166, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):151) within Germanic to Proto-Germanic *gawēn- (and perhaps further to OCS gověti 'to revere and Latin faveō 'to be favorable' < *gʷʰou-eh₁-) is to be abandoned. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):167 alternatively proposes cognacy to the Indo-Iranic root ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 199), but this proposal has not yet met with widespread acceptance (not in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 83[114-115{S.v. Proto-Iranian *gaud- 'to cover', from PIE *gʰeu̯dʰ- 'to hide' (cf. Gk. κεύθω 'I hide').}];141[199, 358-359{Cf. s.v. ?*gʷʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 450) and s.v. *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 952). Cf. S.v. n1 in both entries: it is possible that the parallel root *gʰeu̯dʰ- unnecessary, as a blend between these two roots.}]
Justification: For the provisional root ref. form, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):114-115, but this IE root reconstruction is uncertain; it is possible that we are dealing with a contamination of two separate roots (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 199, 358-359 s.v. ?*gʷʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' and *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen').

Source: 141[199{Cf. s.v. ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 450). Only Indo-Iranian.}];567[281{Bactrian ωγοζ- reconstructed from past stem ωγοτο, of uncertain meaning, possibly 'to conceal' < *awa-gušta- from Proto-Iranian *gauz-. Cf. Manichaean Bactrian ʾwγwt used as a noun, possibly 'secret'.}];568[259, 261{Cf. commentary to the Manichaean Bactrian fragment v5 for the connection of Bactrian ωγοτο with Manichaean Bactrian ʾwγwt, to be interpreted as 'secret' or 'secrecy' and a possible etymology *awa-gušta-.}];172[I:502-503{S.v. Ved. √goh- 'verbergen, verhüllen' (IIr. cf. YAv. guzaēta 'er würde verbergen', aguze 'ich versteckte (mich)', etc.).}];83[117{S.v. Proto-Iranian *gauz- 'to hide, conceal' (cf. Skt. goh- 'to hide'). The root appears to be of IIr. origin. IE connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯j́ʰ- 'to hide', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:502-503, [Cheung 2007](src-83):117). [LIV²](src-141) 199 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen'.

Source: 587[288{S.v. Gk. λάκκος 'Grube, Wasserloch', (bov. lákko, otr. lákko, kal. lákku, lákkə, salent. lákku, luk. lákkə 'pozza d'acqua') from a Romance plural *laccora (cf. lecc. le lákkure) regg. lákkuru 'terreno basso da un fiume'. Lákku is often river name in Calabria and Sicily.}];66[827{Cf. s.v. λάκκος 'pond, cistern, pit, reservoir' perhaps from a PIE zero-grade *l̥ku̯o-, but the phonetic development *-ku̯- > -κκ- is unexpected.}];269[{[Rohlfs 1964](src-587):288 considers the Italiot Greek words to be borrowings from Romance. Note, however, that AGk. λάκκος does exist, and might possibly be derived from *l̥ku̯o- (PIE *laku- or *loku-, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):827 s.v. λάκκος and further discussion in [cognate set 8246](cog-8246)). It is difficult to exclude in principle the possibility of contamination or blending of inherited material with that of local Romance varieties. Similarly cf. Engl. lake in [cognate set 5612](cog-5612) which may well be a semantic calque from Romance.}]
Justification: [Rohlfs 1964](src-587):288 considers the Italiot Greek words to be borrowings from Romance. Note, however, that AGk. λάκκος does exist, and might possibly be derived from *l̥ku̯o- (PIE *laku- or *loku-, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):827 s.v. λάκκος and further discussion in [cognate set 8246](cog-8246)). It is difficult to exclude in principle the possibility of contamination or blending of inherited material with that of local Romance varieties. Similarly cf. Engl. lake in [cognate set 5612](cog-5612) which may well be a semantic calque from Romance.

Source: 83[48{S.v. Proto-Iranian ?*daH-⁶ 'beat, strike'. "The forms [attested] seem to suggest a separate root *daH⁶ 'to beat, hit, strike' in Ir., which is perhaps expressive in origin, cf. Engl. thud, tick, tap, etc."}];331[II:441-443{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian ⁵dā-, *dai-, dī̆- 'бить, ударять, гнать, бросать, падать'.}]
Justification: Possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):48).

Source: 603[1: 181-182, 212-213{Bulgarian vrat is related to v"rtâ 'turn'. The etymological meaning is 'movable, turning part of body'. It is related to Lithuanian verčiù, ver̃sti 'turn', German werden 'become', Latin vertō 'turn', Old Indic vartate 'turn'. The PIE protoform is *wer-t-.}];595[4: 351{PS *vortŭ < *PIE *u̯órto- 'turning' is derived from PIE *u̯er-t- 'turn'. As to the semantic development cf. Latin collus, Gothic hals etc., all derived from PIE *kʷel- 'turn'.}];141[691-692{Cf. s.v. *u̯ert- 'sich umdrehen' (IEW 1156-8).}]
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:351, [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) I:181-182, 212-213, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 691-692).
Loan from Standard Italian fumata 'smoking, a smoke'.

Source: 83[110-111{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *gart- 'to turn'. The root has no secure extra-Iranian comparisons and appears to be a dental-enlarged form of the root *gar-² 'to turn, wind', probably influenced by *u̯art-.}]
Justification: Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', a root first attested in Middle Iranic without clear correspondences outside of Iranic. Possibly the same root as Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind' in [cognate set 8719](cog-8719) with a dental enlargement possibly under the influence of Proto-Iranic *u̯art- 'to turn', cf. YAv. varət- 'to turn' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):110-111).

Source: 316[414{S.v. Lat. mordeō, -ēs, momordī, morsum, -ēre 'mordre'. Ernout-Meillet consider the only possible form for comparison Sanskrit mardayati 'il broie', whose stem is formally identical to Lat. mordeō.}];54[389{S.v. Lat. mordeō 'to bite', from a PIE iterative present *h₂mord-éi̯e-, accepting Ernout-Meillet's comparison with Sanskrit mardáya-, but also comparing Ancient Greek ἀμέρδω 'to deprive of' and Old English smeortan 'to hurt'.}];141[280{S.v. *h₂merd- 'ein Leid antun, mißhandeln' (IEW 736-7).}];443[6/3:126-129{S.v. Lat. mŏrdĕre 'beissen' > Fr. mordre, etc.}];423[III:143-145{Cf. s.v. Sp. morder (< Lat. mordere)| Catalan mossegar, It. dial. mosegar < Lat. *mossĭcare, an assimilation from Lat. morsicare, derived from the passive past participle morsus (from the same root as Lat. mordere).}];444[465{S.v. 5679 Lat. mordere 'beißen'.}]
Justification: Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂merd- 'to hurt, mistreat' ([LIV²](src-141) 280, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):414, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):389, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):465 no. 5679, cf. [DCECH](src-423) III:143-145, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 6/3:126-129).

Source: 156[II:122{S.v. Oss. (Di.) mingi(j) 'маленкий, мало, немого, варианты', cf. Lith. meñkas, TochB menki, Ved. manā́k| cf. IE 4. *men- in (IEW 728-9).}];338[{Digor isolate. Abaev compares this (or rather the variant mingi) to Lithuanian meñkas 'minuscule, insignificant' and Old Indic manāk 'few'. The Iron term čəšəl is an Iron isolate.}];172[III:386{Cf. s.v. Skt. manāk (ep. kl.), which is not satisfactorily explained. The Vedic formant in °āk seems to be a formation °āñc-| the element man° is with Gk. μᾱνός, μανός 'dünn, locker', Lith. meñkas 'gering, klein', etc., cf. esp. Oss. mingi(j) 'klein, wenig'.}];269[{The basis of the Ossetic lexeme may go back to a root *men- (cf. IEW 728-729) if Abaev and EWAia are correct in connecting the lexeme to the basis of Skt. manāk 'a little, slightly, in a small degree', but there are many unclear details of this etymology.}]
Justification: The basis of this Ossetic lexeme may go back to a root *men- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 728-729) if [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:122 and [EWAia](src-172) III:386 are correct in connecting the lexeme to the basis of Sanskrit manāk 'a little, slightly, in a small degree', but there are many unclear details of this etymology.

Source: 66[844{S.v. λεῖος 'smooth', probably from a root PIE * lei̯- 'smooth' with a derived u-stem that has been later thematised, i.e. *lei̯-u̯-o- > *λεῖϝο-, cf. Lat. lēvis 'smooth'.}];54[336-337{S.v. Lat. lēvis 'smooth', from PIE *leh₁i-u- 'smooth' (cf. Gk. λεῖος 'level, smooth' < *leh₁-u-o-, λίς, λῑτός 'smooth' (adj.), 'smooth linen' (m.) < *liH-t-), following the derivation of Schrijver (1991:283f.).}];50[346{S.v. Proto-Celtic *slimono- 'polished, smooth', from PIE *slei̯- 'smear (with grease), polish' (cf. Lat. līmō 'polish', OHG slīmen 'polish'). The Proto-Celtic word appears to contain the suffix *-ono- also found in *antono- 'forehead').}];240[103{Cf. s.v. Old Welsh limnint (3.pl.pres.) 'to make smooth, polish' [llyfn-], traditionally from PIE *(s)lei- 'schleimig, durch Nässe glitschiger Boden, ausgleiten' (cf. IEW 663).}];49[662-664{Traditionally connected to a common IE root *lei- 'schlemig, durch Nässe glitschiger Boden, ausgleiten, worüber hinschleifen oder -streichen, auch glättend worüber fahren', where the Celtic forms exhibit s-mobile| Lat. & Gk. without.}];269[{NB: The usual reconstruction *(s)lei̯- is given for this root. de Vaan (2008:336-337) gives *leh₁-i-u- with *h₁ in order to include a connection to Gk. λίς, λῑτός 'smooth' (adj.), 'smooth linen' (m.) < *liH-t-, but this seems unnecessary from the point of view of Lat. lēvis alone. A PIE u-stem noun *lei̯-u- can account for both the Lat. lēuis and Gk. λεῖος| if one assumes *leh₁i-u̯-o- as a preform for Greek, one might expect *λῇος.}];301[242-243{OBr. limn gl. lentum 'soft, supple, flexible'. Also in the compounds   limn-collin gl. tilia 'lime-tree', limn-collou gl. tiliiae 'lime-trees' (literally: 'soft hazel-tree(s))| gur-limun or gur-limnn gl. diliniti 'softened, corrupted'.}]
Justification: Hellenic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes traditionally reconciled to a basic root *lei̯- 'smooth', although the Celtic forms here may also require s-mobile (cf. ([IEW](src-49) 662-664, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):103, [Matasović 2009](src-50):346, [Beekes 2010](src-66):844, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):336-337). The Germanic forms derived from PIE *slei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth' in [cognate set 8680](cog-8680) might be an extended form of this root. See further discussion in that cognate class.

Source: 54[491-492{S.v. Lat. procul 'some distance away, (far) away, apart' [adv.], from PIE *pro 'in front of', perhaps via Proto-Italic *pro-k(w)o- 'at the front'?}];294[490, 643{Cf. s.v. *pr̥-, *pró, *prí 'vorwärts, vorne' Adverb, lokal, temporal| oft mit Abl.| and s.v. *li, le 'dort drüben, fern| dann' Partikel, ferndeikt.| Adverb, temporal.}];316[537-538{S.v. Lat. procul 'à distance, au loin| loin de'. The word is probably composed of prō̆- and an old adverb connected to W. pell 'loin', Gk. τῆλε 'loin', πάλαι 'autrefois', Skt. caramáḥ 'le dernier'. The semantics of 'far' would have come from the second part of the compound (similarly cf. abhinc, exinde, etc.).}]
Justification: Usually interpreted as based on PIE *pro- 'forward, to the front' with adverbial suffixes ({cf. [LIPP 2](src-294):490, 643; [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):537-538, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):491-492).

Source: 83[226{S.v. Proto-Iranic *ǰi̯au̯H- 'to chew' (> CSogd. (zbʾqy) ˣžybʾmnty 'the biting (of their tongues)' "Sogd. -β- (CSogd. -b-) is perhaps due to the influence of zβʾk (CSogd. zbʾq) 'tongue, language'."| NWIr. > Bal. jāθ-, jā-). "On the development of initial *g̑i̯- > Ir. *ǰi̯- see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. This development suggested by Rasmussen may also account for the doublet roots *ǰi̯aH ~ *zaiH ‘to perish| to destroy’ and *či̯aH³/čiH ~ *saiH/siH ‘to freeze’, but both cases have no clear IE etymology." From PIE *g̑i̯euH- ‘to chew, bite’ (cf. Toch. śu- ‘to eat| consume, devour’, OCS uju, Russ. ujú ‘I chew’, OHG kewa, OE cēowan, Engl. to chew, Lith. (f. pl.) iáunos ‘jaws’, etc.).}];141[168{Cf. s.v. *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'kauen' (IEW 400). (> mp. manich. žw- 'kauen', etc.)}]
83[445{"the IE preform *k(ʷ)H₂eǵ- (cf. Arm. xacanel ‘to bite’) reconstructed by Klingenschmitt 1982: 210 and Kümmel, LIV: 360 has little to recommend."}]
Comment: The Lari form may contain an inchoative suffix. Not noted in Cheung (2007).
could be derived from *fra-dmās- with fra- > ha-, assimilation fo dm > dn and subsequent loss of d

Justification: Strand: from PIE stebʱ- 'post'; cf. OIA stambʱa-, T. 13682.

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. ud, from Lat. udus.}];54[648{S.v. Lat. ūvidus 'soaked', with derivatives ūvor 'moisture', uvēscere 'to become wet', ūdus 'liquid, wet, drunken', ūdor. "The order of attestation suggests that ūdus is a recent contraction of ūvidus, but Weiss (1995[:141ff.]) reckons with the possibility that ūdus was older, and that ūvidus was back-formed to it as a hyperarchaism. Lat. ūdus might reflect *we/ogʷ-ϸo-, *ugʷ-iϸo- or *uh₁-iϸo-. Alternatively, Weiss suggests that ūvidus acquired ū- from its close semantic cognate ūmidus, thus hiding an earlier stage *uwidos." [Ultimately de Vaan seems to accept the etymology with PIE *uegʷ- as more likely than to *ueh₁-].}];316[745-746{Cf. s.v. Lat. ūmeō, -ēs, -ēre 'être humide (surtout poétique)': The origins of the group comprising ūueō, ūuēscō, ūuidus (ūdus), ūlīgō are less clear. We suggest a connection to Greek ὑγρός 'humide', which resembles Arm. oyc 'frais' and OIc. vokr 'humide'. One would start from *ug-sm- or *oug-sm-, and from *e/oug-w-. One cannot trace a precise history.}];700[141-143{Lat. ūvidus usually argued to continue *u̯egʷ-, but Weiss makes the case for the possibility that it could just as well continue *u̯eh₁-. The root etymology of Lat. ūvidus, ūdus is ultimately uncertain.}];269[{Rom. ud is from Lat. ūdus 'wet, moist' (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85) s.v. ud). The IE root etymology remains unclear. The traditional etymology of Lat. ūdus is to PIE *u̯egʷ- 'make damp (so [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):745-746, with references to earlier literature, tentatively also [de Vaan 2008](src-54):648| cf. [LIV²](src-141) 662-663, [IEW](src-49) 1118), but [Weiss 1994](src-700):141-143 makes a convincing case that a derivation to PIE *u̯eh₁- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 715-717 s.v. *u̯eh₁-r-. *uh₁-r- 'Wasser'| [IEW](src-49) 80f., [EIEC](src-657) 636) may also be a strong possibility. The prevailing majority opinion seems to judge the connection to *u̯egʷ- for Lat. ūdus to be more likely than *u̯eh₁- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):639-640 s.v. ūmeō and notes to [cognate set 1578](cog-1578)), albeit still uncertain.}]
Justification: Rom. ud is from Lat. ūdus 'wet, moist' (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85) s.v. ud). The IE root etymology remains unclear. The traditional etymology of Lat. ūdus is to PIE *u̯egʷ- 'make damp (so [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):745-746, with references to earlier literature, tentatively also [de Vaan 2008](src-54):648; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 662-663, [IEW](src-49) 1118), but [Weiss 1994](src-700):141-143 makes a convincing case that a derivation to PIE *u̯eh₁- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 715-717 s.v. *u̯eh₁-r-. *uh₁-r- 'Wasser'; [IEW](src-49) 80f., [EIEC](src-657) 636) may also be a strong possibility. The prevailing majority opinion seems to judge the connection to *u̯egʷ- for Lat. ūdus to be more likely than *u̯eh₁- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):639-640 s.v. ūmeō and notes to [cognate set 1578](cog-1578)), albeit still uncertain.

Source: 369[392{S.v. Alb. tha/j '(etwas Feuchtes am Feuer oder an der Luft) austrocken, trockenlegen, dörren, räuchern, erstarren, erfrieren'. Meyer's connection with Lith. saũas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', etc. must rely on an uncertain dissimilation of sibilants which is very uncertain. D. suggests perhaps to Gk. ἅζω 'dörren, trocknen' instead.}];130[58-59{Considers the forms to be cognate with the forms from PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'dry'.}];141[345{Cf. s.v. 1. *keh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595), now reconstructed as *k̑eh₂u̯- in LIV² Addenda & Corrigenda.}];389[{Cf. s.v. 1.*keh₂u̯- → *k̑eh₂u̯-¹ 'anzünden, verbrennen' (IEW 595).}];585[88{S.v. Alb. θań 'trockne, dörre, wische ab, mache steif', cf. Lith. saũsas, OCS suchъ 'trocken', Gk. αὔω < *σαυσω.}];105[471, 473{S.v. Alb. thatë 'dry', a derivative of the verb thaj 'to dry', from PAlb. *sausnja, a derivative of PIE *sauso- 'dry' (Gk. αὗος, MHG sôr, Lith. saũsas, Slav. *suxъ). Note the dissimilation of the sibilants leading to *s- > th- (Meyer 1891:88).}];269[{Etymology here follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1000 and [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but be aware some scholars [Orel 1998](src-105):471, [Holm 2011](src-130):58-59, following [Meyer 1891](src-585):88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in [cognate set 7551](cog-7551) (cf. the skepticism of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):392).}];364[1000{Cf. s.v. Alb. than '(aus)trocknen, trockenlegen'. On the basis of phonological grounds it would be better to assign this verb to a root *k̑eh₂u̯- (LIV² Add. *k̑eh₂u̯- 'anzünden, verbrennen', cf. Gk. καίω).}]
Comment: 'kindle, burn'
Justification: Secondary semantic shift from 'dry' > 'hard'. Etymology here follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1000 and [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but be aware some scholars [Orel 1998](src-105):471, [Holm 2011](src-130):58-59, following [Meyer 1891](src-585):88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in [cognate set 7551](cog-7551) (cf. the skepticism of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):392).

Source: 369[150-151{S.v. dushk 'Hauptbegriff für verschiedene Laubbäume (evtl. mit Eicheln als Früchte) bzw. für dicht verwachsene hohe Sträucher, deren Laub als Winterfutter verwendet wird.' There are no certain inner- or outer Albanian correspondences.}];105[79{S.v. Alb. dushk 'oak', to be connected with dru 'tree' on the basis of the variant drusk.}];687[18{S.v. Arb. dúshku 'Wald'. (=StAlb dushk). Because of the larger family of words in Albanian, it is certainly an old word, whose further etymology cannot, however be more precisely determined.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):150-151 for discussion of various proposals. [Orel 1998](src-105):79 wants a connection to PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- on the basis of the dialectal variant drusk 'oak', but the priority of this form is uncertain and could well be a contamination with the word for 'tree' in [cognate set 503](cog-503) (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):151).
Loanword from Calabrian ficatu 'liver'.

Source: 442[594{Cf. s.v. 10286 s.v. mŕ̥ttikā- f. 'earth, clay' (VS), and s.v. 10287 s.v. *mr̥ttya- ʻearthʼ < *mr̥tti-, cf. Prakrit macca- n. ʻdirtʼ| Ash. (Wama) mič ʻclayʼ.}];399[II:675-677{S.v. Skt. mr̥tsná- 'Staub, Pulver', 'dust, powder', to be connected with the root of mr̥dnā́ti 'drückt, presst, reibt', 'presses, squeezes,  rubs', (√mr̥d-, cf. Gk. μέλδω).}];172[II:386-387{Cf. s.v. Ved. √mrad- 'sanft machen, weich machen', not to be separated from Ved. mr̥dú- (PIE *(h₂)ml̥d-ú-).}];141[431{Cf. s.v. *meld- 'weich werden' (IEW 718).}]
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594 no. 10286, 10287, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ([KEWA](src-399) II:675-677, [EWAia](src-172) II:386-387, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 431).

Source: 431[{S.v. Kâmviri pâřʹasa  [-i fem]  Aj.  Gray| dusty.  [pâřasaN]  [OIA. pʹuri:ṣa- ‘fullness| filling| rubble| dung’  T. 8287 (-T. 8019 pâ˜šu- 'dust'| prob. < Ind., cf. Hindi puras 'dust')]}];442[452, 469{Cf. s.v. 8019 pāṁśu- 'crumbling soil, dust, sand' or s.v. 8287 púrīṣa- 'fullness(?)' (Pk. purīsa- 'dung', Ku. paraso 'manure', H. puras 'dust, manure').}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, either to be grouped with Vedic pāṁśu- 'crumbling soil, dust, sand' or púrīṣa- 'fullness(?)' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):452 no. 8019, 469 no. 8287).

Source: 468[495-496{Cf. s.v. ON skjól 'Obdach, Zufluchtsort, Schuppen' (< Germ. *skeula-), cf. Ic., Far. skjól, Norw. skjol, OSw. skīūl, Dan. skjul. (cf. Gk. σκύλος 'abgezogene Haut', σκυλόω 'verhülle', OIr. cúl 'Winkel).}];388[339, 347{Cf. s.v. PGmc. *skeulan ~ *skūlan (ON skjól 'shelter, cover'), related to Gmc. *skuwwōn (cf. ON skuggi 'shade, shadow', OE scúwa, OHG scūwo 'look', Arm. cʻiw 'roof', OIr. cúl 'back', continuing IE *(s)k̑eu̯ə- 'to cover'.}];165[442, 452{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *skuwwan- 'mirror' (Go. skuggwa 'id.', ON skuggi 'shadow, shade', OHG scuwo, scū 'id.'), from the PIE root *skeu- 'to see', cf. PGmc. *skawa- 'observant(?)' > Go. us-skaws 'sober' < *skou-ó- (cf. Gk. θυο-σκόος 'name of a sacrificial priest' < *-skou-o-| cf. also OE scēawian, OFri. skowia, OS skawon, Du. schouwen, OHG scouwōn, G schauen 'to see, inspect' < PGmc. skawōjan-).}];269[{Danish skjule is a derivative from skjul, in turn from Norse skjól ‘shelter, cover’ (de Vries 1977:495-496). Further etymological connections are unclear, although there are a few quite tempting comparisons formally and semantically.  1.	de Vries (1977:495-496) reconstructs Proto-Germanic *skeula-, and considers connections to Gk. σκύλος ‘animal skin’ and its derivative σκυλόω ‘to veil, cover’ (Hesych.), also to OIr. cúl ‘nook, corner’, ultimately a derivative of an IE root *(s)keu- ‘to cover (smth.)’, cf. further Ved. skunā́ti ‘covers’, Lat. obscūrus ‘covered, dark’, Ir. cuarān ‘shoe’. 2.	Orel (2003:339) reconstructs Proto-Germanic *skeulan- ~ *skūlan- > ON skjól and considers connections within Germanic to *skuwwōn ‘shadow’ (ON skuggi, etc.), ultimately to IE *(s)k̑eu̯ə- ‘to cover’, comparing Skt. skunā́ti ‘to cover’, Arm. cʻiw ‘roof’, OIr. cúl ‘back’. To the particular connection with the ‘shadow’ words, there is an additional complication: It is unclear whether the proposed connection to *skuwwōn ‘shadow’ is has the same root etymology. Lehmann (1986:313) indicates two possible etymologies from formally similar roots: either to *(s)kewə-, *(s)kū- (cf. Skt. skunā́ti ‘to cover’, Gk. σκῡ́νια ‘brows’, or to *(s)kew- ‘pay attention to, observe’ (whence also OE scēawian, OS skauwōn, OHG skouwōn = NHG schauen). LIV² reconstructs the root underlying the ‘see, pay attention to, observe’ words found in NHG schauen, etc. as *(s)keu̯h₁-, which could be formally identical to the proposed root of the ‘hide| shadow’ words found in Germanic *skuwwōn.
