As the formal similarity exists, it is tempting to consider a single root. Kroonen EDPG, for instance, considers Proto-Germanic *skuwwōn to a basic root *skeu- ‘see’ (without laryngeal). The common semantic denominator to both proposed forms seems to be whether or not something is visible or not, but it is unclear to me how these opposite meanings can be easily reconciled. To return to the known facts, Kroonen EDPG does not discuss Norse skjól anywhere and it is unclear to me whether this is an omission due to neglect, or due Kroonen considering this North Germanic lexeme not cognate to anything else in Germanic (and by extension, in Indo-European). On the formal level, the derivation of skjól is likewise unclear. I do not know of any productive l-stems in Germanic (but this may well be due to my own ignorance). If the connections to LIV² *(s)keu̯h₁- 'wahrnehmen, schauen' hold, then this lexeme might be cognate with [cognate set 5182](cog-5182) with a root etymology, but due to many uncertainties in semantics and processes of secondary derivation, it is ultimately unclear. Cf. also the uncertainties regarding the Germanic words for 'shadow' in [cognate set 7022](cog-7022).}];97[{Cf. s.v. Da. skjul 'hide, cover' (n.), from Old Norse skjól, to the same root as sky 'cloud'.}]
Justification: A denominative verb formed to Danish skjul 'hide, cover', further to Old Norse skjól 'cover, shelter', probably to the same root as Danish sky 'cloud' ([Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)), but further etymology uncertain (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):495-496, [Orel 2003](src-388) 339, 347, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):442, 452 for various hypotheses).

Source: 50[219{S.v. Proto-Celtic *kowdo- 'hiding place' < PIE *k̑ou̯dʰo- (*√k̑eu̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. κεύθω, Arm. suzanem 'submerge, hide'). The Celtic verbal forms (Welsh cuddiaf, MBret cuzaff and Cornish cuthe 'hide') are denominative verbs. Note that Matasović assumes root-initial palatal k̑- instead of velar k- for the PIE root.}];141[358-359{Cf. s.v. *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen' (IEW 952). [Note the Celtic forms are not primary stem formations and therefore not listed.]}];309[442{S.v. Bret. kuz 'caché' < Proto-Celtic koud-o- (denom. vb. kuziñ 'cacher').}]
Justification: Denominal formations to Proto-Celtic *kowdo- 'hiding place' < PIE *k̑ou̯dʰo- ([Matasović 2009](src-50):219, cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):442); for the root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. [LIV²](src-141) 358-359.

Source: 84[{Cf. s.v. Engl. hide (v.), from Old English hýdan, from PGmc. *hûdjan (cf. Middle Dutch hûden (huyden , hueden ), Middle Low German hûden to hide, Low German (ver)hüen), either to be connected with the same root as Old English hýd 'hide, skin', or to *keudʰ-, kudʰ-, seen in Greek κεύθειν 'to hide, cover up, conceal'.}];388[196{S.v. Proto-Germanic *xūđjanan- (OE hýdan, OFris. hēda 'id.', MLG hūden 'id.'), related to Greek κεύθω 'to cover, hide'.}]
Justification: Etymology disputed. Either to the Germanic word for 'hide, skin' in [cognate set 820](cog-820) or to Celtic words for 'hide' from PIE *keu̯dʰ- in [cognate set 8434](cog-8434) (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84), [Orel 2003](src-388):196). Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165) or [Seebold 1970](src-556).

Source: 309[515{S.v. Bret. moan (adj.) 'mince, étroit, grêle', from Old Breton moin 'gracieux', corresponding to Co. môn (OCo. muin), W. mwyn 'gentil, doux, cher', and OIr. min, Scots Gaelic min 'délicat', all from Celtic *mein-no-.}];50[270, 278-279{S.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object'. "The development of meaning in Breton and Cornish was from 'beautiful' to 'gracile' and (in Breton) 'thin'. The original meaning may have been '(precious) piece of property for exchange'. From PIE *mei̯-n- 'exchange' (IEW 710), cf. Lat. mūnus 'duty, charge, task', Skt. mení- 'revenge', Goth. ga-mains 'common', Lith. maĩnas 'exchange'. Less likely, but also possible in principle is a connection to Proto-Celtic *mēto-, *mēti- 'fat, soft' < *mei(H)-t-, via a different stem formation PIE *miH-no- > PCelt. *mīno- (cf. OIr. mín 'tender, soft').}];141[426{Cf. s.v. 2. *mei̯- 'wechseln| tauschen, ändern' (IEW 710). Possibly *h₂mei̯- if *h₂mei̯gʷ- (LIV² 279, cf. Gk. ἀμείβω 'exchange') is an enlarged root to this one.}]
534[II:270{S.v. Latv. spēle, loan from Low German (cf. LG spel(e), NHG Spiel)| verbal spēlēt.}]
Justification: Loan from Low German (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:258).

Source: 442[511{S.v. 9093 Skt. phúllati 'expands, opens (as a flower)' (cf. Skt. phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)'.}];399[II:398{S.v. Skt. pullaḥ 'aufgeblüht, blühend', 'blossoming' (Mahābh.) from which probably the denominative phullati 'blossoms. Perhaps from a p.p.p. *phal-na- to phálati 'birst', 'burst', taking over a labial vowel -u- after no longer being associated with the verbal stem.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9092-9093). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps originally a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit √phal- 'to burst, split' with an irregular labial vowel -u- (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:398).

Source: 529[{Proto-Indo-Iranian pres. *bʱána- may continue *bʰn̥h₂ó/é- << *bʰn̥h₂ó, 3sg middle of infixed *bʰ~n~éh₂-: Marathi mh, may be due to blend with PIIr. *mlau̯h- [cognate set 2031](cog-2031) or *maR-, cf. Vedic malmalāyati (ŚBK) with m- [cognate set 813](cog-813)}];442[534{S.v. 9383 Skt. bhánati 'calls aloud, speaks' (RV.). EWAia considers an IE origin for Skt. bhanati, but Kuiper, Proto-Munda Words in Sanskrit proposes a Munda origin for Skt. √bhan-.}];172[II:244{S.v. Ved. √bhan- 'reden', perhaps to IE *bʰen- (~ *bʰeh₂-) (as similarly the root-pair *gʷem- : *gʷeh₂-?).}];141[69-70{Cf. s.v. 2. *bʰeh₂- 'sprechen, sagen' (IEW 105-6), with Ved. bhánati 'spricht' possibly to a nasal-infix pres. stem ?*bʰ-né/n̥-h₂-, cf. n6: If thematised from *bhanā́- (with a trivial accent shift) and not to a parallel root *bʰen(H)-, which could also exist in OHG(+) bannan 'aufbieten, vorladen' (hardly with Seebold [1970:]89 from *bʰh₂-nu̯-).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhan- 'to speak' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):534 no. 9383), further IE root etymology disputed, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:244, [LIV²](src-141) 69-70 for further discussion.

Source: 353[414-415{S.v. Lith. smė̃lis, smėlỹs 'sand', Latv. smẽlis 'fine sand', from PIE *(s)melH-? (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal', mel 'chalk', OIc. melr 'sand-bank', Sw. mjåg (dial.) 'sand-hill, high riverbank', smula 'chunk', Nw. smola (dial.) 'smash'| smol (dial.) 'dust'. "The Baltic and Slavic forms mentioned are formally compatible with the root *melH- 'grind' (→ mélti), the Baltic word showing s-mobile."}];531[576{S.v. Lith. smė̃lis 'piasek', a derivative of PIE *(s)mel-.}];360[842-843, 846-847{S.v. Lith. smėlỹs 'Sand', further related to the family of lexemes around Lith. smiltìs 'Sand' and to be connected with OSw. smola, smula, smule 'Brokken', Nw. smola 'zermalmen', smol 'Staub, Splitter, Abfall', Goth. smals 'klein, gering', Ir. smal 'Staub'.}];269[{PIE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with North Germanic lexemes in the meaning 'dust| small bits' etc., which with Slavic cognates (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal') one may reconstruct a common root *(s)melH-. This root might be identical with PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' with s-mobile (cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):414-415), or alternatively connected with Germanic words for 'small' ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):842-843, 846-847| but cf. discussion in [cognate set 5112](cog-5112), without Baltic lexemes connected).}]
Justification: PIE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with North Germanic lexemes in the meaning 'dust; small bits' etc., which with Slavic cognates (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal') one may reconstruct a common root *(s)melH-. This root might be identical with PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' with s-mobile (cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):414-415), or alternatively connected with Germanic words for 'small' ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):842-843, 846-847; but cf. discussion in [cognate set 5112](cog-5112), without Baltic lexemes connected).

Source: 423[III:732-733{S.v. Sp. llorar, from Lat. plōrare.}];443[9:76-79{S.v. Lat. plōrare 'laut weinen' (> Fr. pleurer).}];54[473-474{S.v. Lat. plōrō, -āre 'to cry, weep'. No etymology.}];316[516{S.v. Lat. plōrō, -ās, -āuī, -ātum, -āre 'se plaindre, se lamenter, pousser des cris de douleur'. Without any satisfying connections, probably an expressive word like fleō.}];444[548-549{S.v. 6606 Lat. plōrāre 'weinen'.}]
Justification: Romance forms from Latin plōrāre 'to cry, weep' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):548-549, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:76-79, [DCECH](src-423) III:732-733), further etymology unclear (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):516, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):473-474).

Source: 352[744-745{S.v. OLith. paũkštis 'Vogel'. No generally accepted etymology. A connection with Lith. paũtas 'Ei' is semantically close, but phonologically difficult. Cf. entry in ALEW for further discussion.}]
Justification: No generally accepted etymology, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 744-745, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):443 for further discussion.

Source: 352[983-984{S.v. OLith. stùmti 'stoßen, schieben' (BSl. cf. Latv. stùmt, 'stoßen, schieben', etc.). The (East-)Baltic verbs seem to presuppose a zero-grade of a PIE root form *stemH-. Outside of Baltic the Germanic family from ON stemma 'stemmen, dämmen, hindern' are close.}];531[611{S.v. Lith. stùmti "pchać, popychać, trącać, szturchać, sunąć, suwać, odsuwać zasuwą drzwi, wtłaczać, wypychać, odpychać, naglić, nacierać". Without good etymology. If -um- is a reflex of *m̥, then it is possible to posit *stm̥H- to * stemH- "to push"}]
Justification: Possibly derived from a putative PIE *stemH- 'to push', cf. [ALEW](src-352) 983-984, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):611 for further discussion.

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966
Not in Turner 1962–1966
Not in Turner 1962–1966

Justification: Continuing a derivative of Vedic cíti- 'layer', a derivative of the root √cay- 'to arrange in order, heap up, pile up' and ultimately to PIE 2. *kʷei̯- 'to collect, layer' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):260 no. 4798, [EWAia](src-172) I:541, I:532, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 378-379).
Continuing an Indic stem *ḍala- 'lump' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):311 no. 5536).
Continuing an adjective *pittaka- 'relating to bile', derived from Vedic pittá- 'bile' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):462 no. 8182). No further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) II:131).

Source: 701[669{S.v. Kho. ṣā 'black' (cf. Wkh. ṣ̌īu, Sgl. ṣ̌ūi).}]
Justification: Probably a loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi ṣ̌ʉw 'black' ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):669).
Same as 'fly_V' in [cognate set 9512](cog-9512)?
From Vedic hŕ̥daya- 'heart' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):818 no. 14152), further to PIE *k̑erd- 'heart' ([EWAia](src-172) II:818, cf. [NIL](src-274) 417-423).

Source: 701[662{Kho. pāz 'breast' < Wkh. pūz, Sar. puz, etc.}]
Justification: Loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi pʉz 'chest', Sarikoli puz 'id.', etc. ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):662).

Source: 442[125{S.v. 2561 Skt. ṓṣati 'burns' RV., uṣyatē 'is burnt' Suśr. [√vas3]. Dm. oṣḗ -- 'to be frostbitten' (NTS xii 157 < uṣ -- ?)| Kho. uṣák 'cold'| K. wuhun 'to glow, smoulder' or poss. < vyuṣati.}];141[245{Cf. s.v. h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen' (IEW 347-8)}];172[I:281{Cf. s.v. Ved. √oṣ- 'brennen, versengen', from PIE *(h₁)eu̯s- (cf. Gk. εὕω 'senge', Lat. ūrō 'brenne, versenge', ustus 'gebrannt', etc.).}]
Justification: Derived from Old Indic √oṣ- 'to burn' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):125), further to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'to burn' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:281, [LIV²](src-141) 245).

Source: 701[666{Cf. Kho. išmärēik 'to count', loan from Iranic.}]
Justification: Loanword from Iranic (cf. [Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):666).

Source: 172[I:300{S.v. Ved. kapā́la- 'Schale, Schüssel, Hirnschale, Schädel'. No explanation that has reached unanimous acceptance. Perhaps to PIE *kap- 'fassen' (cf. Lat. capere 'nehmen', capula 'Schöpfgefäß', etc.), others see 'Hirnschale, Schädel' as primary and compare OE hafola 'Kopf' and the family from Lat. caput. Certain irregularities in the Middle and Modern Indic consider Turner (1966) to consider "at least influence" from Austroasiatic.}];442[137{Cf. s.v. 2744 kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' (AV.) 'cup, jar, bowl' (TS.). Cf. note: "Although IE. (cf. OEng. hafola 'head') EWA i 155, the variant MIA. and NIA. forms suggest at least influence by Austro-as. ND 73 b 27".}];269[{The Proto-Indic base *kap- is often considered to be cognate with Lat. caput, OEng. hēafod, etc., but there is some uncertainty over the etymology of the Modern Indic lexemes from Ved. kapā́la-, and of Ved. kapā́la- itself, cf. discussion in Mayrhofer EWAia I:300, Turner (1962-1966:137), and further discussion in the references to the cognate class containing the Italic and Germanic lexemes in [cognate set 6432](cog-6432).}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull'. The Proto-Indic base *kap- is often considered to be cognate with Lat. caput, OEng. hēafod, etc., but there is some uncertainty over the etymology of the Modern Indic lexemes from Ved. kapā́la-, and of Ved. kapā́la- itself, cf. discussion in Mayrhofer [EWAia](src-172) I:300, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):137 no. 2744).

Source: 352[152{S.v. OLith. burnà 'Mund, Maul' (BSl. Latv. pur̂ns, pur̃ns, pur̂na 'Schnauze, Rüssel', Bulg. bъ́rna, bъ́rla 'Lippe', Sloven. brnẹ́ti, ím 'summen, brummen', IE cf. Arm beran, G.sg. beroy', OIr. bern 'Lücke, Öffnung, Kluft'). The Latvian forms with voiceless p- is attributed to influence from pur̃slas, pur̂slas 'Schauze, Maul'. The Balto-Slavic forms appear to reflect a zero-grade, while Armenian beran a full-grade. The vocalism of the Celtic word is difficult to determine. Since PIE roots cannot end in two resonants, the nasal in Lith. burnà and its extra-Baltic correspondences is of suffixal origin. Consequently attempts at further connections are made in the literature to, for example, Lat. forō, -āre 'bohren', OHG borōn, OS boron 'bohren'.}];564[429{S.v. բերան beran 'Mund', connected with Lith. burnà 'Mund', OIr. bern 'Kluft'.}];353[106{S.v. Lith. burnà 'mouth, face' (Latv. pur̂ns 'snout'), cf. Proto-Slavic *bъrna 'snout' (Sloven. bŕna 'carnival mask depicting an animal'| Bulg. bắrna (dial.) 'lip', Maced. brna 'nose ring (of animals)', IE beran 'mouth'. The root can be reconstructed as a zero-grade *bʰrH-, which may be identical with Lat. forāre, OHG borōn 'perforate'. The inital p- of Latv. pur̂ns 'snout' is usually attributed to a Finnic substratum. If, however, Slovak perna 'lip' is connected to the Baltic words, then the Indo-European reconstruction is in doubt.}];269[{Traditionally Lith. burnà 'mouth' and Arm. beran 'mouth' have been connected etymologically (cf. {ref {Hübschmann 1897}:429, [Olsen 1999](src-180):297, [ALEW](src-352) 152, [Derksen 2015](src-353):106). Although this etymology is accepted, further morphological analysis and the isolation of an IE root remains unclear| further connections have been postulated to derive an n-stem noun from the same root underlying Lat. forō, -āre 'bore' OHG borōn 'bore', from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80), but these connections are not fully clear (cf. [ALEW](src-352)). However, if with [Derksen 2015](src-353):106), who notes that if the Slovak perna 'lip' belongs with the Baltic forms, then the usually reconstruction to a root *bʰrH- is in doubt. As [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353), and [Olsen 1999](src-180) are in agreement about the cognacy, it has been accepted for this class, although the precise IE root etymology is in question. [NB: Arm. beran 'mouth' is not discussed in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).]}];180[297{"Beran […] 'mouth' (IEW 134, Solta 291f) is etymologically connected with Lith. burnà 'mouth', OChSl. bъrna 'lip', MIrish bern 'fissure', all derived from the root *bʰer- 'cleave' by a suffix containing *-n-. The BSl. forms point to a proto-form *bʰrnáh₂ which could be explained as a secondary derivative of a *-men- stem with a zero grade in the root and selection of *-no- (*-nah₂-) after a root containing a labial. Beran, -oy, on the other hand, immediately seems to reflect *bʰern̥no- with suffixal *-n̥no-, a possible variant of *-m̥no-, also found after roots involving a labial element"}]
Justification: Traditionally Lithuanian burnà 'mouth' and Armenian beran 'mouth' have been connected etymologically (cf. {ref {Hübschmann 1897}:429, [Olsen 1999](src-180):297, [ALEW](src-352) 152, [Derksen 2015](src-353):106). Although this etymology is accepted, further morphological analysis and the isolation of an IE root remains unclear; further connections have been postulated to derive an n-stem noun from the same root underlying Lat. forō, -āre 'bore' OHG borōn 'bore', from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80), but these connections are not fully clear (cf. [ALEW](src-352)). However, if with [Derksen 2015](src-353):106), who notes that if the Slovak perna 'lip' belongs with the Baltic forms, then the usually reconstruction to a root *bʰrH- is in doubt. As [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353), and [Olsen 1999](src-180) are in agreement about the cognacy, it has been accepted for this class, although the precise IE root etymology is in question. [NB: Arm. beran 'mouth' is not discussed in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).]

Source: 353[336{S.v. Lith. nókti 'grow ripe', Latv. nākt 'come', from PIE *h₂ne-nok̑- (cf. Lat. nancīscī 'obtain', OIr. t-ánaic 3.sg.pret. 'came'), following Kortlandt (1994:192).}];352[708{S.v. OLith. nókti II 'jagen, treiben| folgen' (BSl. Latv. nãkt, 'kommen'). No reliable comparanda outside of Baltic. The comparison by Endzelins KZ 61 (1935:257-261) to Goth. nēƕ, OHG nāh 'nahe' is phonologically difficult. Similarly difficult is the comparison of Kortlandt with Ved. 3.sg.perf. ānám̆̇śa, ānāśa, Lat. nancio, -īre 'erreichen' by Kortlandt Linguistica Baltica 3 (1994:191-193).}];141[282{Cf. s.v. *h₂nek̑- 'erreichen' (IEW 316-8), to which the Lith. pres. nẽša 'reicht hin bis' is only tentatively connected to the root aorist stem *h₂nék̑-/*h₂n̥k̑-.}];704[191-193];269[{Etymology outside of Baltic disputed. According to [Kortlandt 1994](src-704) (followed by [Derksen 2015](src-353)) from PIE *h₂nek̑-, but this root etymology has not been met with widespread acceptance elsewhere (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 282-283| [ALEW](src-352) 708).}]
Justification: Cf. Lithuanian nókti 'to hunt, pursue; follow'. Etymology outside of Baltic disputed. According to [Kortlandt 1994](src-704) (followed by [Derksen 2015](src-353):336) from PIE *h₂nek̑-, but this root etymology has not been met with widespread acceptance elsewhere (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 282-283; [ALEW](src-352) 708).

Source: 352[1269{Cf. s.v. OLith. vyžà 'Pareske, Bastschuh'. The often assumed connection with OPr. winsus 'Hals' is not certain because of the semantic distance.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1269 for further discussion). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353). cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):765].

Source: 571[85{S.v. Alb. laj 'wash', contra Meyer (1891:237) if laj is a loan from Lat. lavāre, then that would have yielded *lëv-oj or *loj.}];369[230-231{S.v. Alb. la 'waschen, spülen, reinigen', probably to continue a verb of the productive *-n(i̯)o- class: *lh₃-eu̯- > PAlb. *lau̯- > Alb. la-.}];389[http://www.martinkuemmel.de/liv2add.html#_Toc392257980{It is no longer necessary to postulate two separate roots *leh₂(u̯)- 'pour' for Anatolian and *leu̯h₃- for Italic and Albanian. The two roots can be reconciled to *leh₃u̯- (cf. Melchert 2011:127-132).}];585[237{S.v. Alb. l'ań 'wasche, bade', borrowed from Lat. lavāre.}];105[210{S.v. Alb. laj ~ lâj 'to wash', from PAlb. *launja and related to Gk. λούω, Lat. lavō 'id.'.}];364[980{S.v. OAlb. lan 'waschen', attested through Old Gheg la (Buzuku) probably continues PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix.}];690[127-132]
Comment: Only non-active forms in Alb. denote 'to swim'
Justification: Albanian lexemes probably continuing PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix ([Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):980, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389); for the root reconstruction, cf. [Melchert 2011](src-690)). For older literature, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):237, [Huld 1984](src-571):85, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):230-231, [Orel 1998](src-105):210.

Source: 442[740{S.v. 12761 Skt. śvásiti 'breathes heavily' RV. (śvásantu AV.). [√śvas1] and 12769 Skt. śvāsá- m. 'breath, breathing' MBh., 'asthma' Suśr. [√śvas1].}];172[II:677{Cf. s.v. Ved. √śvas- 'schnauben, schnaufen, zischen' (mi. Pā. sasati 'breathes', etc.), from PIE *k̑u̯es- (cf. ON hvæsa 'zischen, schnauben', etc.).}];165[266{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hwēsan- 'to wheeze' (OE hwǣsan 'id.'), from PIE *k̑u̯ḗs- (cf. Skt. śvásati 'to hiss, breathe, sigh', Lat. queror 'to complain' < *k̑u̯es-| YAv. suši du.f. 'the lungs' < *k̑us-ih₁. Cf. also ON hvæsa 'to hiss', Far. hvæsa 'to wheeze', Elfd. węsa 'to breathe' (with secondary nasal vowel) < hwēsjan-.}];141[341{Cf. s.v. *k̑u̯es- 'schnaufen, schnauben, seufzen' (IEW 631-2). Cf. n1 ON hvę́sa 'zischen, schnauben' can also reflect *hwēs-i̯e-, based on an original acrodynamic present *k̑u̯ḗs-.}]
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯es- 'to pant, breathe heavily'. In this class Pāli sasati continues the primary verb < Sanskrit śvasati 'breathe heavily' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:677, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):740 no. 12761), the modern Indic forms are light verb constructions with the nominal semantic-bearing morpheme deriving from Skt. śvāsá- 'breath' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):740, no. 12769). For Elfdalian, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):266.

Source: 179[255{S.v. Goth. M63. milhma 'νεφέλη', 'cloud'. Only possible Gmc. cognate OSw. molin, Sw. moln 'cloud', a dialectal replacement for PIE *nebʰ-. Many conjectures at an etymology, perhaps to Lith. mìlšti(s) 'gather (of a storm)', Latv. milzt 'become dark or foggy', Russ. molostь 'thunderstorm'. If there was a metathesis of -l-, possibly further to Lith. miglà, Latv. migla, OCS mьgla 'fog', Gk. ὀμίχλη 'cloud' from PIE *mei̯gʰ- 'cloud', other conjectures less likely.}];165[363{S.v. Proto-Germanic *melhman- 'cloud' (Goth. milhman 'id.' as though from *melk̑-mon-| cf. Lith. mìlšti 'to become overcast' < *mlk̑-ske-| Ru. (dial.) molost' 'bad weather' < *molk̑-ti). An mn-stem created to a lost verbal root *melh-, continuing a Germanic-Balto-Slavic isogloss *melk̑- (cf. Fraenkel 1965:453). The same root is continued in OSw. moln, molen, Elfd. muoln 'cloud' < *mulhna-. Possibly both formations arose through a paradigm split of different ablaut forms.}];360[453{Cf. s.v. Lith. mìlšti(s) 'sich zusammenziehen, vom Gewitter', maybe to be connected to Goth. milhma 'Wolke'.}];269[{Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Often compared to Lith. mìlšti(s) and other Balto-Slavic forms with various degrees of confidence of the etymology (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):255, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):403). [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):453 suggests possibly related ('eventuell'). No lemma for Lith. mìlšti(s) in [ALEW](src-352) or [Derksen 2015](src-353).}]
Justification: Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Often compared to Lith. mìlšti(s) and other Balto-Slavic forms with various degrees of confidence of the etymology (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):255, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):403). [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):453 suggests possibly related ('eventuell'). No lemma for Lith. mìlšti(s) in [ALEW](src-352) or [Derksen 2015](src-353).

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian or Iranic

Source: 179[342{S.v. Goth. T16. taujan 'ποιεῖν, ποιεῖσθαι, πράσσειν', 'to do, make', from PGmc. *tawjan 'prepare, make' (cf. Runic (Gallehus Horn) 1sg tawido, OHG zawjan, zowjan, MHG zouwen, zöuwen 'hasten'). No accepted etymology.}];165[511{S.v. Proto-Germanic *taujan- 'to do, make'. Possibly connected to TochB tsuwa 3.sg.pret. 'to join, adjust', Gk. δύναμαι 'to be able' (cf. LIV² 123). If so, then a de-adjectival formation from *dou̯h₂-o- (the original adjective only attested in Slav. LWs such as OCS gotovъ, Ru. gotóv).}];141[123{Cf. s.v. deu̯h₂- 'zusammenfügen' [IEW 218]. Goth. taujan is listed under Kausativ ?*dou̯h₂-éi̯e-, but cf. n4 where it is noted that the absence of Germanic Verschärfung (i.e. not †taggwjan) is unclear, therefore the reconstruction for the form remains uncertain.}]
Justification: Perhaps continuing an original causative formation *dou̯h₂-éi̯e- to PIE *deu̯h₂- 'to join, fit together' but the details remain unclear (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 123, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):342, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):511). Cf. also Runic (Gallehus Horn) 1.sg.pret. tawido 'I made'.

Source: 443[13/2:238-240{S.v. Lat. trĕmĕrĕ 'zittern'. OFr. criembre, with apparently contaminated initial *tr-  > *kr- under influence of the Celtic root *krit- (cf. Bret. kridien, W crith 'das Zittern').}];54[628{S.v. Lat. tremō, -ere 'to tremble', from PIE *trem-e/o- (cf. U. tremitu 3.sg.imptv.II. perh. 'to scare', Gk. τρέμω 'to tremble', Lith. trem̃ti 'to shake up', trimti 'to tremble', TochA, trämäṣ, tärmiñc 'to tremble').}];141[648-649{S.v. *trem- 'zittern (vor Angst)' (IEW 1092-3).}];105[463{S.v. Alb. tremb 'to frighten', continuing Proto-Albanian *trema and related to TochA tärm- 'to get angry', Gk. τρέμω 'to tremble (of fear)', Lat. tremō 'id.'.}];369[388-389{S.v. Alb. tremb 'jmdm. Angst machen, erschrecken', structural grounds argue for inheritance from IE *trem- rather than a loanword from Lat. tremō (expected Lat. tremō > Alb. **tremój).}];444[738{S.v. Lat. tremere 'zittern', with contamination with Gaul. crem : OFr. criembre, Fr. craindre, Prov. cremer 'fürchten'.}]
Justification: Albanian and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *trem- 'to tremble (in fear)'. The Romance lexemes apparently continue Latin tremere 'to tremble' contaminated with the Celtic root *krit-, cf. Old Irish crith 'trembling, shaking' ([LIV²](src-141) 648-649, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):388-389, [Orel 1998](src-105):463, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):738 no. 8877, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:238-240, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):628).

Source: 165[152{S.v. Proto-Germanic *fraisan- 'to tempt', a strong verb attested only by Goth. fraisan. The original strong verb gave rise to a noun attested via OFri. frēs, OS frēsa, OHG freisa 'danger, scare' < *fraisō-, whence OE frāsian 'to try', OS frēson 'to try, risk', Du. vrezen 'to fear', etc. Of uncertain etymology. Perhaps from *pro-h₂is- 'to ask forth'?}];179[123{Cf. s.v. Goth. F75. fraisan (cf. OFris. frēs, OS frēsa, OHG freisa 'danger', OS frēson 'bring into danger, temptation', OHG freison 'be in danger', MHG vreist 'danger'). Etymology obscure, possibly a compound *fra-isan (cf. OIc. eisa 'plunge ahead', Skt. ī́ṣate 'hastens', Gk. ἱαρός, ἱερός 'powerful'), or + PIE *ays- 'desire' as in Skt. iccháti, Av. isaiti 'seek for', OE āskian, OHG eiscōn 'ask', Lith. ieškati, OSl. iskati 'seek'. Less likely from PIE *per- + *ey- (cf. Gk. πεῖρα 'attempt', Lat. experior 'test').}];556[207{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *frais-a- 'versuchen'. No certain etymology. The best connection is to the root *per- 'versuchen, prüfen'.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):207, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):123, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152).

Source: 165[387{S.v. Proto-Germanic *neman- 'to take' from PIE *kom-h₁ém-e- (cf. Lat. emō, -ere 'to take, buy'). The stem is a back-formation based upon the reanalysis of the compound verb *gan-eman- < *kom-h₁em-e- as containing the perfective prefix *ga-: *ga-neman-.}];141[453{S.v. 1. *nem- 'zuteilen' (IEW 763).}];179[266-267{S.v. Goth. N20. niman 'λαμβάνειν', 'take (away), accept, get'| 'αἵρειν', 'take away, take up', 'δέξεσθαι', 'receive'. Etymology disputed. Probably to be associated with PIE *nem- (cf. Gk. νέμω) in the basis of the meaning 'receive legally', cf. also the parallel between Gk. κληρονόμος 'heir' and Goth. arbinumja 'heir'. Attempts to relate to Lat. emō 'buy' (in cpds 'take'), OIr. em- in ar-fo-em 'receive', Lith. im̃ti, OCS jęti 'take' formally less likely.}];556[357-359{S.v. Gmc. *nem-a- 'nehmen'. There are two possibilities for an etymology. Either (1) as a rhyme-variant of *em- 'nehmen, kaufen' (from complete dissimilation from *nem-?) cf. Lat. emō, OIr. do-em, Lith. im̃ti, OCS jęti, etc., or (2) to *nem- (cf. Lat. numerus 'Zahl, Anzahl, Menge', OIr. nem 'Gift, verdebliche Kraft, Härte', Lith. núoma 'Miete, Pacht', Latv. ņémt 'nehmen', Gk. νέμω 'teile aus, eigne mir an, besitze, weide, verzehre', OAv. nəmah- 'Darlehen', Ved. námati 'biegt, beugt'). One may prefer to assume an original root *nem- to account for all forms, with *em- as a rhyme-variant.}]
Justification: Baltic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *nem- 'to portion out'. Cognacy in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) s.v. 1. *nem-, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):266-267), but [LIV²](src-141) 236 s.v. *h₁em-. It is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):357-359); cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):387 for an attempt to reconcile the Germanic lexemes to *h₁em- by assuming a reanalysis of the compound verb *gan-eman- < *kom-h₁em-e- as containing the perfective prefix *ga-: *ga-neman-.

Source: 556[337{S.v. Gmc. *(-)leuk-a- 'rupfen' (cf. OE lūcan, OFr. lūka 'ziehen', OHG -liohan). There are only uncertain comparisons outside of Germanic.}];398[1345-1347{Cf. s.v. OHG liochan 'zupfen, rupfen', going back to a Proto-Germanic stem *leu̯ke/a- with no precise correspondences, but in different ablaut grade related to MLG lūken 'ziehen, zupfen', OFries. lūka, NWFries. luke, Saterfries. luke 'ziehen', MEngl. louken, louke, going back to PGmc. *lūka-. Proto-Germanic *leu̯ka- and *lūka- (with secondary lengthened grade) are both secondary developments from the PIE root *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (cf. Ved. rujáti 'zerbricht, bricht auf', Arm. lowci 'machte los, löste'| more doubtful are the connections to Palaic luki(ye)- 'teilen', and Lat. lugēre 'trauern' < ?*lug-ēh₁- with unexpected zero-grade).}];141[415-416{Cf. s.v. 1. *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (IEW 686).}]
Justification: From Proto-Germanic *lūka- (with secondary lengthened grade), beside OHG liochan from Proto-Germanic *leu̯ke/a- based on PIE *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (cf. [EWA 5](src-398) 1345-1347, [LIV²](src-141) 415-416. See [Seebold 1970](src-556):337 for references to older literature.
Loanword from Calabrian Italian manca 'left-hand' (cf. also Greek: Italiot μανκούσο 'left' in [cognate set 6082](cog-6082)).
Loanword from Calabrian mbuttare 'throw, push, introduce'

Comment: Extended root *h₁ei̯- (of the "facere" type), attested in Albanian only.

Source: 81[423-424{Proto-Slavic *puxati, cf. *puxnǫti 'swell'. Derksen considers Proto-Slavic *pux- with PIE *peu̯s- (cf. Skt. púṣyati 'thrive, flourish'). [Cf. LIV² 303-304 s.v. ?*h₃peu̯s-, without Slavic cognates listed.].}];141[303-304{S.v. ?*(h₃)peus- 'sich mehren, reich werden an' (IEW 848). Slavic forms not connected by LIV².}];389[{"Gr. ὀπυίω besser mit J. Katz (Vortrag Kopenhagen Okt. 2009) mit ved. vapuṣyá- zu vergleichen (vgl. unten zu *u̯ep-), womit die Grundlage für den Ansatz von *h₃ entfällt (und die Reduplikation von ved. pupóṣa auch diachron völlig regulär wird)." Discounting Gk. ὀπυίω as cognate, reconstruction of initial *h₃- to the root is superfluous.}];594[{PS *puxati, derived from an ideophonic PIE root *p(ʰ)eu̯s-. It is related to Lithuanian pū̃sti, Latvian pùst, probably also to Greek phȳ̃sa, phȳsáō.}]
Justification: Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  [LIV²](src-141). Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).

Source: 600[1: 103{It is a loanword from Middle Low German denken 'think'.}]
105[527{S.v. Alb. zhur (shur) 'gravel', a borrowing from Latin saburra 'sand ballast'.}];585[420{S.v. Alb. šūr, žūr 'Sand, Kies', a borrowing from Latin saburra 'Sand, Schiffsballast'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin saburra 'sand; ship's ballast' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):420, [Orel 1998](src-105):527).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian uχχare 'to blow up, swell'.

Source: 369[271-273{S.v. Alb. mjégull/ë 'Nebel, Wolke, Dunkel, Finsternis'. It may be necessary to separate the different variants into different etymologies. For mje(r)gull(ë) Jokl's suggestion from PIE *mergʷ- > PAlb. *merg- > Alb. mjerg-ull(ë) is the best formal solution. [Cf. entry for further discussion of inner-Albanian variation.]}];571[93{S.v. Alb. mjegull 'raincloud'. Cf. for various hypotheses considering lexical contamination.}];585[283-284{Considers the word either a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'cloud' or a cognate of Slav. *mьgla, etc.}];105[269{S.v. Alb. mjegull 'cloud' (variants mjergull, njegull, which O. considers to be secondary). O. prefers a derivation from Proto-Albanian *meg(u)lā, related to Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist'.}];269[{Three main possibilities: Either connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so Orel 1998:269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- [cognate set 42](cog-42)), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so Demiraj 1997:271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by Meyer 1891:283-284, cf. [cognate set 2150](cog-2150)). Ultimately unclear.}]
Comment: Further connection unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so [Orel 1998](src-105):269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- [cognate set 42](cog-42)), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so [Demiraj 1997](src-369):271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by [Meyer 1891](src-585):283-284, cf. [cognate set 2150](cog-2150)). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of [Huld 1984](src-571):93). Ultimately unclear.
Loanword from Italian foglietto 'slip, small piece of paper'.

Source: 105[407{S.v. Alb. shalë 'saddle| inner side of thigh, pair of legs', borrowed from Latin sella 'seat, saddle'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ([Orel 1998](src-105):407).

Source: 105[407{S.v. Alb. shalë 'saddle| inner side of thigh, pair of legs', borrowed from Latin sella 'seat, saddle'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ([Orel 1998](src-105):407).

Source: 105[229{S.v. Alb. lis 'oak, high tree', a borrowing from Slavic *lesъ 'wood, forest, tree' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):247). "The Slavic dialect from which the word was borrowed must have had a narrow *ě > Alb. i, i.e. it may be identified as "ikavski" Serbo-Croatian" ([Jokl 1923](src-751):177).}];751[177, 187-188];585[247{S.v. l'is 'Eiche, Baum' "cal. gr. 'Eiche' für alle Arten, wie ngr. δένδρον". From Sl. lêsъ 'Wald' (Se. lijes, with i for e).}];571[87{S.v. Alb. lis 'oak(tree), tree', because of the difficulties of the root vocalism, instead considering an inherited term akin to lëndë 'material, lumber' and lende 'acorn' with lis reflecting *lent-to- with the dental cluster becoming -s- and *en becoming i before spirants as in mish 'meat' and vidh 'elm', ultimately comparable to OE lind 'linden', Gk. ἐλάτη 'pine' OCS latъ 'linden'.}]
Justification: Generally considered a loanword from South Slavic, possibly via the Ikavian dialect of Serbo-Croatian ([Jokl 1923](src-751):177, 187-188, [Orel 1998](src-105):229, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):247), but cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):87 who proposes an IE etymology. (Not in [Demiraj 1997](src-369)).

Source: 105[43{Cf. s.v. Alb. bushtër 'bitch' (f., pl.), adj. 'raging, wild', an early borrowing from Slav. *bystrъ. Cf. also for alternative etymologies proposed by others.}]

Justification: Loan from Italian liscio 'smooth'.

Source: 66[1403-1404{S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'breast, chest'. [More or less directly translates/paraphrases the discussion of [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:795.]}];270[1054-1055{S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'poitrine' (de l'homme et de la femme). The etymology is obscure. One frequently compares Hesych. στήνιον· στῆθος, which is directly comparable to Skt. stána- 'poitrine d'une femme', Arm. stin (gen. stean), however the suffix -θος then remains unclear.}];174[II:795{S.v. AGk. στῆθος 'männliche od. weibliche Brust'. Origin unclear, the similarity to στήνιον· στῆθος (Hesych.) (to Arm. stin, Ved. stána- 'weibliche Brust' is hardly coincidental ("kaum zufällig"). (Perhaps an analogy along the lines of στήνιον : στῆθος similarly like Lat. plēnus : πλῆθος???)}];49[990{S.v. *speno-, *stē̆no-, *p(ǝ)stē̆no- 'Zitze, Brustwarze, Brust', under which is connected Gk. στηνίον· στῆθος Hes. "daß στῆθος verwandt sei, ist schwer glaublich| hat neben θήνιον, τιθήνη einst ein *θη-θος, *τῆ-θος bestanden, das neben στηνίον eine Parallelbildung στῆθος ins Leben treten ließ??"}]
Justification: The connection of the forms in this class to those from PIE *pstḗn in [cognate set 2217](cog-2217) is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:795, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1054-1055, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1403-1404, cf. [IEW](src-49) 990).

Proto-Germanic *sak-e/a-, OIr. saigid, ·saig).}];389[{S.v. *seh₂g-, also to root present [aalb. gjegjetë ‘hört’.}];141[520{Cf. s.v. *seh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'einer Fährte nachgehen' (IEW 876-7).}]

Source: 54[322, 612{S.v. Lat. lacrimāre 'cry, weep', a denominal verb from Lat. lacruma, dacruma 'tear'. Lat. lacruma, dacruma is often considered to be a loanword from Gk. δάκρυμα 'tear' on the basis that an inherited preform *dakru-mn̥ would have yielded **dacrumen in Latin, and additionally the suffix -ma is not productive in Latin (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):336). [Hamp 1972](src-575):291-99, however, points out that Greek δάκρυμα is itself a recent formation in Greek, is not attested before the fifth century, and is never attested as the regular word for 'tear' (i.e. δάκρυον). Perhaps the Greek forms and the Latin forms can be reconciled via an dissimilation *d ... *n > d ... m of an earlier preform *dakruna > *dakruma (cf. the distance dissimilation *m … *b > n … b attested *temebrae > tenebrae, cf. tenebrae, s.v.), but this solution is admittedly speculative.}];316[336{S.v. Lat. lacruma (lacrima), -ae (OLat. dacrima according to Paulus ex Festus 60, 5), possibly a loanword from Greek δάκρυμα.}];575;269[{Occasionally considered a loanword from Ancient Greek δάκρῡμα (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):336). Elsewhere, in spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru- 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. [Hamp 1972](src-575)). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):322, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299-300) generally follow the proposal of [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574), assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'. Under this interpretation the related Hittite form išḫaḫru- is considered an original compound of *skʷ-h₂k̑ru-, although this formulation has its own etymological difficulties (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):391 in [cognate set 8095](cog-8095)).}];66[299-300];574
Justification: Occasionally considered a loanword from Ancient Greek δάκρῡμα (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):336). Elsewhere, in spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. [Hamp 1972](src-575)). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):322, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299-300) generally follow the proposal of [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574), assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.
Light verb construction, literally 'to make wind' with semantic head bād 'wind' a loanword from from Persian (cf. [cognate set 3436](cog-3436)).

Source: 83[401{S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ab/f- 'to call, utter (sing, speak, sim.)', cf. OAv. uf- 'to sing', no clear etymology outside of Iranic.}];323[94{S.v. Paš. wāy- : way- 'to speak' < *waf/bya-, cf. Av. vaf- 'to sing', Bal. gwap- 'to summon', but Sogd. wʾβ, C wʾb 'to speak'.}]

Source: 83[442-443{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranian *xand- 'to laugh'. "This root is most likely expressive/onomatopoeic in origin, cf. Gk. καχάζω 'I laugh', Lat. cachinnō 'laugh loudly', OCS xoxotati 'to laugh loudly', Lith. kikénti 'to giggle', etc."}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *xand- 'to laugh' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):442-443). In view of the Nuristani cognates to this root (cf. 'laugh' in [cognate set 68](cog-68)) we reconstruct Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand-.

Justification: Connected to Proto-Iranic *kart- 'to cut' by some scholars, however this is difficult to justify semantically (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):243-244 for discussion and references to further literature).

Source: 80[660-661, 670-671, 694-695{S.v. Hitt. peššii̯e/a- 'throw away, to cast, shove| abandon, cast off' *h₁poi̯ + šai-/ši- 'to propel, shoot, throw' < *h₁s-i̯e/o- (cf. Skt. ásyati 'throw')| a univerbation of the preverb pe- 'away, thither' < *h₁poi̯ + šai-/ši- 'to propel, shoot, throw' < *h₁s-i̯e/o- (cf. Skt. ásyati 'throw').}];269[{Root etymology disputed. Cf. also [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413) 27-37, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, pp.581-584.}];141[242-243, 518{S.v. 2. *h₁es- 'werfen, schießen' (not in IEW) with ?siēzzi 'wirft, schleudert'| 1. *seh₁(i̯)- 'loslassen' (IEW 889-891) with ?siēzzi 'schießt'.}]
Justification: Root etymology disputed. Either to *h₁es- 'throw' ([LIV²](src-141) 2. *h₁es-; cf. [Kimball 1987](src-725); [Kimball 1999](src-726):215, 391; [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):670-671 with references to earlier literature), alternatively others (cf. [Melchert 1994](src-368):133) see a connection with the Hittite verb šii̯e/a- 'to shoot' and šai- 'to press' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 1. *seh₁(i̯)-).
