Proto-Celtic 3. *rig-e/o- 'gehen', from PIE *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'gehen', originally a suppletive future to OIr. téit.}];296[R:15-16{S.v. regaid , future to the verb tiagu, going back to a form *r̥gh- connected to the Gk. verb ἔρχομαι.}];231[285{S.v. ScG. rach 'go' (Ir. rachad 'I will go', E. Ir. ragat 'ibo', OIr. doreg 'veniam').}]
Justification: Formerly connected to Gk. ἔρχομαι 'go' via *r̥gʰ- (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:15-16, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):285), now a separate root *h₁erg̑ʰ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 238-239, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):548-550).

Source: 728[204-205{S.v. Manx goll (cf. NIr. gol).}]
Justification: Cf. Old Irish dul 'going', further etymology obscure. Since [Pedersen 1913](src-308):648 usually compared with Albanian dal 'to go out' from PIE *dʰalh₁- 'to bloom' in the sense 'to appear, come out' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:220, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):257-259, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):54, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):968-969). [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):138) seems to imply that dul should be connected to the finite verb do·luid where ·luid continues PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- (cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):456-458). For the initial g- instead of d-, possibly from an allegro-pronunciation of ag dul 'at going' > /əgol/, or influenced by gabháil, the verbal noun of gaibid (David Stifter, p.c.).

Source: 79[522{S.v. Arm. šunčʻ 'breath| soul, person| blowing, wind', denominal verb šnčʻem 'to breathe, blow', according to Ačaṙyan (HAB 3: 535b) an onomatopoeic formation composed of š- and the suffix -nčʻ which is frequent in onomatopoeic words. "Though this is basically correct, the connection with cognate forms should not be excluded, cf. Skt. śvasiti 'to hiss, pant, snort', Lith. švañkšti 'to wheeze', OIc. hvæsa 'to hiss, snort'."}]
Justification: Probably an onomatopoeic formation, but cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):522 for some proposed cognates outside of Armenian.

Source: 179[314{S.v. Goth. S99. *slaihts 'λεῖος', 'smooth', probably from PIE *(s)ley- + -g-, cf. OIr. slig- as in ad-slig 'persuade', fo-sligim 'besmear, anoint' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:133, without s- Gk. λίγδην 'scraping').}];697[512-513{S.v. Gmc. *slihta- 'glatt, eben', an old verbal adjective to the strong verb *sleika- 'schleichen'.}];556[428-429{S.v. Gmc. *sleik-a- 'schleichen', from an extended form of IE *(s)lei̯- (cf. OIr. fo-slig 'überschmiert', OCS slьzъkъ 'schlüpfrig, glatt', Gk. λίγδην 'oberflächlich berührend, streifend').}];141[566-567{Cf. s.v. *slei̯g̑- 'schmieren, glatt machen' (IEW 663-664).}]
Justification: From Proto-Germanic *slihta-, an adjective derived to the strong verb *sleikan- 'to creep, sneak' ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):512-513, [Seebold 1970](src-556):428-429), traditionally considered to be an extended form of the root *(s)lei̯- ([IEW](src-49) 663-664; cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):428-429, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):314), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 566-567 for the revised reconstruction of a separate root *(s)lei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth'.

Source: 323[39{S.v. Pashto kor 'house', OPers. kāra- 'people, army', cf. Sh. čōr 'husband', Kurd bē (kas ū) kār 'without relatives'. Note the semantic change 'social group, family' > 'house (building)'.}]
Justification: As though from Proto-Iranic *kāra- 'people, army' via an intermediary sense 'social group, family' > 'house', cf. Old Persian kāra- 'people, army' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):39).

Source: 323[56{S.v. Pashto nuk 'fingernail, claw'| n'uka 'tip, point, nib'. A connection with Ir. *nā̆xa- (Prs nāxun, etc.) is unlikely. Perhaps *nau- as Prs nauk, nōk, Sogd. nwk 'tip, point'?}]
Justification: Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):56).

Source: 323[56{S.v. Pashto nuk 'fingernail, claw'| n'uka 'tip, point, nib'. A connection with Ir. *nā̆xa- (Prs nāxun, etc.) is unlikely. Perhaps *nau- as Prs nauk, nōk, Sogd. nwk 'tip, point'?}]
Justification: Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):56).

Source: 323[95{S.v. Pashto xānd- : xand- 'to laugh', probably a LW from Prs xandīdan.}]
Justification: Probably a loan from Persian xandīdan 'laugh' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):95).

Source: 325[24{"A derivation < *traxra- < *taxra-, Prs. talx, etc., seems phonetically impossible. Prob. < *ϑraxša- (with xš > ŠGr. x̌, Y š), in its turn < *tarxša-, although this form is not known from other Ir. languages." [Note that Kurdish tırš probably < *tarxša-.]}]

Justification: Parallel loans from Turkish pis 'filthy, dirty'.

Source: 363[I:174{Cf. s.v. Kurd. bihīstin 'сльшать, спушать| узнавать', from Old Iranic *vi-vaid-, cf. Av. vaēd-, etc.}];83[408-409{S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯aid- (1) 'to know' (NWIr. + *u̯i- > Kurd. (Kurm.) bihīstin/bihīs-, bihīz-, bihē-, (Sor.) bīstin/bīya- 'to hear, listen, get to know'), from PIE *u̯oi̯d- (pf. stem) 'to know' (cf. Skt. ved- 'to (get to) know', Gk. οἶδα 'I know', Arm. gitel, OIr. ro-fetar, MWelsh gwyr, OCS vědě, Goth. wait, ON vitum, etc.).}];141[665-667{Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯d- 'erblicken' (IEW 1125-7).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *u̯i-u̯ai̯d-, further to PIE *u̯oi̯d- 'to know', to perfect stem of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:174, [Cheung 2007](src-83):408-409, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 665-667).

Source: 363[I:486{S.v. Kurd. ǰamad 'мороз, лед', a loanword from Arabic ǰamad 'лед, льдина'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Arabic ǰamad 'ice, ice floe' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:486).

Source: 363[II:282{S.v. Kurd. stu, stū, stō 'шея' (K.) 'затылок' (S.). Continuing Old Iranian *stū-, *stav-, a variant of the root *stā- 'стоять', cf. Av. stūna-, Ved. sthūṇa- 'столб', Oss. astæw 'поясница', etc.}];172[II:768{Cf. s.v. Ved. sthū́ṇā- 'Pfosten, Pfeiler, Säule', IIr. cf. YAv. stūnā-, OPers. stūnā- 'Säule', Khot. stunā- 'Pfeiler', MPers. stūn, NPers. sutūn 'Säule, Pfeiler', etymologically probably to be connected with Ved. sthūrá- 'groß, stark, dick' < *stuh₂-ró-.}]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *stūnā-, cf. Young Avestan stūnā-, Old Persian stūnā- 'pillar', and probably further connected with Vedic sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick' < *stuh₂-ró-, a derivative to PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:282, [EWAia](src-172) II:768). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in [cognate set 7106](cog-7106).

Source: 363[I:656-657{S.v. Kurd. mil (m.) 'плечо, шея| рука, рукав', from IIr. *mr̥z-, cf. Av. mərəzu-, OPers. *mrdu- 'позвонок', MPers. mrd' (*mrda-) 'шея', Gor., Zaza mil, Avrom. möł 'затылок, шея', Lur. mell 'шея'.}];184[1173-1174{S.v. YAv. (1) mərəzav- n. ''Wirbel' des Halses und Rückens'. Et. & Bed.?}]
Justification: Modern Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *mr̥j́u- 'vertebra' (cf. YAv. mərəzu- 'vertebra', Old Persian *mr̥du- implied by Middle Persian mrdʾ 'throat' and other reflexes among modern West Iranic languages), further etymology unclear ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:656-657, [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):1173-1174).

Source: 363[II:190{Cf. s.v. Kurd. r̄amil 'гадание, предсказание, колдовство', from Arab. raml 'песок' in darb-ar-raml 'гадание на песке'.}]
Justification: Loanword from Arabic رمل / raml 'sand' (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:190).

Source: 309[543{S.v. Bret. oabr 'ciel, nues' corresponding to W wybr 'ciel' to Proto-Brythonic *oepr. Bret. oabrenn 'cloud' is formed with the singulative suffix -enn, which is also contained in Corn. ebren, W wybren.}];236[{Cf. s.v. W wybr 'sky, firmament, heaven| cloud', cf. Old Cornish huibren, Middle Cornish ebron, ebren, Middle Breton noabrenn, Modern Breton oabl, oüaber.}];348[213{Brittonic *oepr possibly cognate with Lat. aequor 'level surface, the sea'| cf. l'expression aequora caeli.}];305[221{ModBr oabl m. 'sky, firmament', V èbr (< *oebr), MW wybyr f. 'sky' < Proto-Brittonic *ẹ̄pl-V- or *ẹ̄pr-V-}];307[38{From the root PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to see', Br. oabl, W wybren 'sky' lit. 'horizon, Gesichtskreis'.}]
Justification: From Proto-Brythonic *oepr ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):543) or *ẹ̄pl-V- or *ẹ̄pr-V- ([Schrijver 1995](src-305):221) (the latter is preferable, BI).

Source: 236[{S.v. W. synhwyraf, synhwyriaf: synhwyro, synhwyrio 'to sense, smell, sniff, etc.' derived from W. synnwyr 'sense, wisdom, sensibleness', borrowed from Lat. sentīre 'perceive'.}]
Justification: A secondary formation to Welsh synnwyr 'sense, wisdom, sensibleness', borrowed from Latin sentīre 'to perceive' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236).

Source: 728[373{S.v. Manx rollage 'star', cf. Ir. réaltóg with metathesis of -lt- and assimilation of -lt- > -ld- > -ll-. Early Manx has redlayg.}];231[290{S.v. ScG. reul 'star' (Ir. reult, OIr. retglu < rét glé 'bright thing', perhaps rét 'thing' + *gland 'shining').}];50[309-310{S.v. Proto-Celtic *rentu- 'thing, matter' (OIr. rét). Sometimes compared with Skt. rátna- 'possession, precious object', but this etymology is speculative because the reflexes of the IE root are limited to two branches and a metathesis *-nt- > -tn- must be assumed for Sanskrit. [EWAia](src-172) s.v. Ved. rátna- considers the word without IE etymology.}];296[R:22-23{S.v. rétglu 'étoile', cf. s.v rét 'chose, matière, substance', the form rétglu is generally assumed to form a compound (Corm.² 1086). OIr. rét < *rn̥tu-, perhaps to be connected with Skt. rátna- < *rn̥t-no-? (cf. [IEW](src-49) 865).}]
Justification: Generally assumed to be a compound based on Old Irish rét 'thing' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):290, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:22-23). Old Irish rét is occasionally compared to Sanskrit rátna- 'possession', but this etymology remains doubtful ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:22-23, [Matasović 2009](src-50):309-310, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:428-429 s.v. rátna-).

Source: 83[269-270{S.v. Proto-Iranic *mauč- (1) 'to release, let loose/free' (> Chor. (+uz-) m|zmxs- 'to (go to) sleep', from PIE *meuk- 'to take, untie', etc. (cf. Skt. moc- 'to release, be(come) free| to liberate, free', Gk. μύσσομαι 'I blow my nose', Lat. e-mungō 'I blow out, snuff', Lith. maũkti 'to take off').}];141[443-444{Cf. s.v. *meu̯k- 'losbinden, abstreifen' (IEW 744).}];172[II:382{Cf. s.v. Ved. √moc- 'losmachen, losbinden, lösen, befreien', from PIE *(s)meuk-, probably 'streifen, abstreifen', cf. Lith. smaũkti 'abstreifen, abwischen', Gk.μύσσομαι 'schneuze mich', Lat. e-mungō 'schneuze aus' etc.}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *mau̯č- (1) 'to release, let loose/free', further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):269-270, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:382, [LIV²](src-141) 443-444).

Source: 172[II:232{Cf. s.v. Ved. br̥hánt- 'groß, umfänglich, reichlich, erhaben, hoch, kräftig, weit, dicht, laut' (YAv. bərəzaṇt- 'hochragend, hoch, laut', Oss. bærzond 'hoch', MP, NP buland 'hoch, groß'), from PIE *bʰr̥g̑ʰ-ént-.}];320[299{Cf. s.v. Khot. bulysa- 'long', to Av. bərəzant- 'high', BSogd. βrzʾk, βrz 'long', Waxī vərz, vorz 'long', Pašto ūẓ̌d, etc., from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ-.}]
Justification: Identical to Khwarazmian 'long' in [cognate set 3381](cog-3381), further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'be(come) tall, raise oneself' (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):299, [EWAia](src-172) II:232, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 78-79, [NIL](src-274) 30).

Source: 764[299{S.v. Khw. γwnyk 'Haar' [cf. šγn. brt. gūnǰ 'id.', Av. gaona- 'Farbe', originally maybe 'Fell', cf. Mackenzie BSOAS 32 (1969) 398.]}]
Comment: In Avestan, gaona- is also attested with the meaning "hair", probably "body hair" or "hairy meat" (probably animal meat with hair on it), cf. the Nerangistan 47.4/9 and the forms gaonauuaṇt- "hairy" and pouru.gaona- "having much hair".
Justification: Cf. Avestan gaona- 'hair' ([Benzing 1983](src-764):299), further etymology uncertain.

Source: 724[17];83[93{S.v. Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to gorge' (cf. Av. gah- 'to gorge'). For Choresmian cf. γš 'tooth'| (+ *apa-) bγʾh- 'to bite' ([MacKenzie 1975](src-783): 392), cf. [Samadi 1986](src-724):17f.). Plausible further cognates in IE are lacking.}];783[392];172[I:514{Cf. s.v. Ved. √ghas- 'essen, verzehren' (IIr. YAv. gah- 'essen, fressen (von daēuuischen Wesen)', no further connections are certain.}];141[198-199{Cf. s.v. ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'essen, fressen, verzehren' (IEW 452). Only IIr., further connections uncertain.}]
Comment: cf. Avestan gah- and Sanskrit ghas-.
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to gorge, devour', further from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. The Khwarezmian lexeme would contain the preverb *apa- ([MacKenzie 1975](src-783):392, [Samadi 1986](src-724):17, [Cheung 2007](src-83):93), while the Sogdian form probably continues a form with preverb *uz- as though *uz-gahaya- vel sim. (Nicholas Sims-Williams, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. [LIV²](src-141) 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.
[Samadi 1986](src-724):247 suggests *xšiwya-, [Cheung 2007](src-83):452 connects with Avestan xšī- 'misery' and suggests a root *xšai-.

Source: 83[108-109{S.v. PIr. *garH-³ 'to steep, soak, moisten' (Chor. (+ *fra-) šɣr- 'to become wet, moist'), from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾elH- 'to drip, well' (cf. Hitt. ku(u̯a)lii̯a- 'to flow| run smoothly, be calmed', OHG quellan).}]
Justification: As though continuing Proto-Iranic *fra-garH-, to Proto-Iranic *garH-³ 'to steep, soak, moisten', and further to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾elH- 'to drip, well' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):108-109, cf. also discussion of Skt. √gal-ⁱ 'to drip, drop' in [EWAia](src-172) I:476-477).

Source: 83[389{S.v. PIr. *tāp- 'to twist, wind' (> ? (+us-) m|(w)stnb 'to throw up, vomit'). "The consistently long stem vowel of these Iranian (verbal) forms is puzzling (the inclusion of Chor. m|(w)stnb- is uncertain): it cannot be explained from a zero grade *tm̥p- (> Ir. *tap-), cf. LIV, ibid. Explaining the forms as a secondarily arisen causative is difficult in the absence of the corresponding regular formation. Perhaps, the long vowel has been imported from the semantically and formally similar Ir. causative continuations of *u̯ab/f (2) ‘to weave’"}]
Comment: Cheung tentatively connects this PIE root with an assumed Proto-Iranic root *tāp-, which is problematic. The connection to Khwarazmian ustamb-, however, is probable.
Justification: Etymology disputed. [Cheung 2007](src-83):389 tentatively connects to Proto-Iranic *tāp- 'to twist, wind' (with prefix *us-), while [Samadi 1986](src-724):186 suggests a Proto-Iranic preform *us-stamba- but not without its own difficulties.

Comment: The Avestan verb vaxš- means "to sprinkle" (not found in Cheung 2007). MacKenzie (1970: 553) "The Khwarezmian Glossary I" (BSOAS 33): derives the noun from *waxšu-.

Source: 724[69{Samadi considers a development "jdn. mit einer Hymne befriedigen, loben" > "singen" with reference to New Persian āf(a)rīn "Hymne". However, the imperfect would be expected to be formed with the augment m-, which is not the case.}];83[87-88{S.v. Proto-Iranic *fraiH- 'to rejoice? to atone, [med.] please', from PIE *preiH- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy' (cf. Skt. pray- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy, satisfy', OCS prějǫ 'I take care', OHG frīten 'to look after' NHG Friede 'peace', Engl. free, etc.).}];141[490{Cf. s.v. *prei̯H- 'vertraut, lieb sein/werden' (IEW 844).}]
Comment: original meaning "to praise"
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *fraiH- 'to rejoice? to atone, [med.] please', further from PIE *prei̯H- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):87-88, [LIV²](src-141) 490, cf. [Samadi 1986](src-724):69).

Source: 320[504{S.v. Khot. hvarandaa- 'right side, right hand' from base hvar- 'be fit', see  hvara- 'proper, fit' to PIE *su̯er- Pok. 1049.}]
Comment: via verbal meaning "to fit", however Bailey's link to the PIE root is not very convincing
Justification: [Bailey 1979](src-320):504 suggests an etymology to a verbal root *hu̯ar- 'be fit' further to a putative PIE *su̯er- referencing [IEW](src-49) 1049 although the semantics are not obvious. Cf. Canevascini in [Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997](src-777):176-179 for extensive further discussion objecting to Bailey's etymology and tentatively proposing a connection to the Proto-Iranic root *hu̯ar- 'to eat, drink' invoking the common right-hand = good euphemism found widely throughout the Indo-European language family, suggesting a semantic development along the lines of the right hand being the 'eating hand' or the one that is suitable for eating with. For Khwarazmian, cf. [Benzing 1983](src-764):685.

Comment: Verbal meaning in Avestan "to press together", PP ϑraxta-, this is taken by Benzing (1983: 100) as the input of Khwarazmian ˀšxt "near", which is formally possible.

Justification: Derived from the verb γyr- 'to turn' and further to Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind', without clear correspondences outside of Iranic ([Samadi 1986](src-724):84, [Cheung 2007](src-83):104). Probably further related to Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn' in [cognate set 8398](cog-8398).

Comment: pǝrǝtu- means "passage" in Avestan, etymology follows Humbach (CLI, 1989: 195), derived from the verbal root PIE *per- "to transfer, come, bring across" (Cheung 2007: 294)

Source: 83[244{The only other witness of this root in Iranic would be the "spider" kārtana(k).}];724[128{Alternative suggestions: *ham-kana- as "Gegenbildung" to *wi-kana-, i.e. "to repaire (?)" vs. "to destroy".}]
Comment: Suggested by Cheung (2007: 244) *ham-kr̩nta- "to twist, braid together". Samadi (1986: 128) suggested a "Gegenbildung" to *wi-kana- "to destroy" (i.e. *ham-kana- "to repaire" ?) of the root *kan- "to dig".

Source: 442[222{S.v. 4157 *giḍḍ- 'fall' > metath. P. ḍiggaṇā, H. ḍignā}]
Justification: Continuing Indic *giḍḍ- 'to fall' with metathesis > *ḍigg- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):222 no. 4157). Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 442[280{S.v. 5085 Skt. *jañjāla- 'worry, affairs'.}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *jañjāla- 'worry, affairs' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):280, no. 5085).

Source: 442[601{Cf. s.v. 10396 *yaja 'cold' (Wg. yū˘z, yoz → Kal. Kho. yoz).}]
Justification: Loanword from Waigali yū̆z, yoz 'cold' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601 no. 10396).

Source: 442[23{Cf. s.v. 497 Skt. ápaiti 'goes away' RV. (√i-). [Turner is ok here for Khowar, but incorrect in formulating Palula bii < ápaiti (H. Liljegren, p.c.)].}]

442[531{S.v. 9348 bhagín- 'prosperous, happy' AV.}];172[II:239-240{S.v. Ved. bhága- 'Wohlstand, Glück, Besitz, Vermögen| Zuteilung', from PIE *bʰag-o- 'Zuteilung' (> 'Gott Zuteilung', 'Gott'), from Ved. √bhaj- 'zuteilen, als Anteil geben'.}];141[65{Cf. s.v. *bʰag- 'als Anteil bekommen' (IEW 107).}]
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit bhagín- 'prosperous, happy' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):531, no. 9348), further derived from Vedic √bhag- 'to apportion' from PIE *bʰag- ([EWAia](src-172) II:239-240; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 65).

Indo-Aryan lexemes derived from *vidharga- 'without movement', cf. Turner 11751 Bashkarik bilɔg 'ill, sick', implying polysemy; cf. also Morgenstierne 1940: 227.
Cognacy with Prakrit vilakkha- 'ashamed' from vi-lakṣayati 'be embarrassed' < 'be observed' from lakṣáyati 'mark, distinguish' is unlikely as -kṣ- should result in Gawri -c̣h- and borrowing from a Prakrit is not very likely.

Source: 442[381{Cf. s.v. 6663 dvā́ra- n. 'door' ŚBr., dvārī- f. ŚāṅkhŚr.}];172[I:764-765{Cf. s.v. Ved. dvā́r- 'die beiden Türflügel', from PIE *dʰu̯er-, *dʰu̯or-, *dʰur- 'Türe, Tor', cf. TochB twere 'Türe', OCS dvorъ 'Hof', Gk. θυρ-, OHG duri, etc. The lack of aspiration in the Old Indic form can be explained in different ways, possibly originally from Graßmann's dissimilation from case -bh-| also thinkable is lexical influence from dva 'two'.}]
Justification: Cf. Vedic dvā́ra- 'door' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):381 no. 6663), further from PIE *dʰu̯er- with an irregular dissimilation of the initial aspirate (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:764-765).

Source: 442[350{S.v. 6128 Ved. daṇḍá- m. 'stick, club' RV. (> Gaw. ḍaṇḍ-bār 'large broom' (bārik 'broom'), dōṇḍī́k 'stick', ḍḗṇḍī 'calf of leg, shinbone').}];399[II:11-12{S.v. Skt. daṇḍáḥ 'Stock, Stab, Prügel', 'stick, staff, club' (since RV). A disputed, still undecided etymological problem.}];172[I:692{S.v. Ved. daṇḍá- 'Stock, Stab'. Etymology unexplained.}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick, club' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):350 no 6128). No certain further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:692, [KEWA](src-399) II:11-12).

Source: 442[319{S.v. 5617 takrá n. 'buttermilk with a third part of water' Mn. 2. '*bitter'. With further semantic developments 'rotten' > 'old' (Gaw. λaka, λag 'rotten, old').}];172[I:611-612, 614-615{S.v. Ved. takra- 'Buttermilch mit Wasser gemischt', evidently to √tañc-, close to Ic. ϸēl 'Buttermilch'. S.v. Ved. √tañc- 'zusammenziehen, gerinnen lassen' to PIE *tenk- 'gerinnen, sich zusammenziehen, verdichten' (cf. MIr. tēcht 'geronnen', ON ϸettr 'dicht', Lith. tánkus 'dicht, häufig', etc.).}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic takrá- 'buttermilk with a third part of water' (n.), *'bitter' (adj.) with further semantic developments 'sour' > 'rotten' > 'old' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):319, no. 5617), further to Vedic √tañc- 'to coagulate' from PIE *tenk- ([EWAia](src-172) I:611-612, 614-165).

Source: 442[774{S.v. 13415 Ved. síndhu- f. 'river, the Indus', m. 'flow (in general), sea' RV. (> Kho. sin).}];172[II:729-730{S.v. Ved. síndhu- 'Fluß, Strom| der Indus'. Etymology unexplained.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic síndhu- 'river; the Indus', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):774 no. 13415, [EWAia](src-172) II:729-730).

Source: 442[404-405{S.v. 7047 Ved. nāḍī́- 'tubular stalk of any plant, tubular organ, tube' RV.}];399[II:127-129{S.v. Skt. naḍáḥ 'Schilf, Schilfrohr / reed' under which also nāḍī́- 'Röhre, Kanal, Pfeife, Flöte (RV, AV, etc.). Probably not to be separated with Ved.  nadá- (in RV mostly 'Stier, Brüller' to nádati, possibly identical with Ir. *nada- 'Rohr' in Av. naδa-, MParth. nd 'Flöte', MPers. n'y 'id.' Not fully clear is the relationship to naḍa-. There are possible comparisons in Dravidian (Kannada naḷḷu 'reed', verbal Tamil ñeḷ 'to be hollow'. Perhaps an Indo-Iranic word *nada- became influenced in India by an indigenous word?}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāḍī́- 'tubular stalk of any plant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):404-405, no. 7047). Further etymology difficult, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:127-129 for various possibilities.
Parallel loans from Arabic خراب / kharāb 'destruction, ruin' (via Persian?).

Source: 363[I:368-369{S.v. Kurd. ganī 'гнилой, вонюочий', ultimately from IE *gʷedʰ- ~ gʷendʰ- cf. Av. ganti- 'вонь' OPers. gasta- 'тошнотворный, отвратительный', Ved. gandha- 'запах, аромат', MPers. gand 'вочь' etc.}];172[I:461-462{Cf. s.v. Ved. gandhá- 'Geruch, Duft',  not to be separated from YAv. gaiṇti- 'übler Geruch', duž-gaiṇti- 'übelriechend, stinkend', Parth. gnd'g 'stinkend', MPers., NPers. gand 'Gestank', etc. Further etymology uncertain.}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', cf. Vedic gandhá- 'smell', Young Avestan gaiṇti 'bad smell', further connections remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:461-462, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:368-369).

Lexemes from OIA avarati- 'ceasing [of activity]'. Turner (q.v.) has Khowar orói m. 'sleep' < avarati-, whence the verb oréik and Pashai ōráč m. 'sleep' < *avaratya-. Morgenstierne (q.v.) also supplies the forms areč and urač from other dialects. It stands to reason that the verb is formed from this noun (with č>š/_t), though it is not attested by Morgenstierne, who has only light verb constructions and the verb stem oreč-, urač-.

Source: 442[436{S.v. 7722 Ved. pátati 'flies' RV. 'falls' Mn. 2. Pp. patitá- [√pat-]. (> Gaw. pēi- 'to fall, lie down, go to sleep').}];172[II:71-72{Cf. s.v. Ved. √pat-¹ 'dahinschließend fliegen, stürzen, fallen', from PIE *pet- (cf. Gk. πέτομαι 'fliege', Lat. petō 'eile, begebe mich wohin' Old Welsh hedant 'volant', Hitt. pít-ti-i̯a-an-zi 'sie laufen', etc.).}];389[{Now s.v. *pet-, merging earlier *peth₁- and *peth₂- in the published version of LIV².}];141[476{Cf. s.v. *peth₂- 'fliegen' (IEW 825-6). See now in LIV² Addenda and Corrigenda that the roots *peth₁- and *peth₂- are collapsed into *pet-.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic √pat- 'to fall; fly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):436, no. 7722), further from PIE *pet- 'to fall; fly' ([EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, [LIV²](src-141) 436, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Source: 442[655{S.v. 11236 Skt. vaṇṭa- (2) 'tailless' Gaut., 'unmarried, dwarf' lex.}];399[III:131{S.v. vaṇṭaḥ 'schwanzlos / tailless', probably not to be separated from baṇḍáḥ and a series of words for defects, mistakes, and flaws.}];172[II:206{Cf. s.v. Ved. baṇḍá- 'verstümmelt, verkrüppelt'. Etymology unclear.}]
Justification: Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vaṇṭa- 'tailless' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):655, no. 11236), further etymology obscure (cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:131, [EWAia](src-172) II:206).

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966.
Not in Turner 1962–1966.
Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 442[221{S.v. 4131 *gāndha- 'perfumed'. [gandhá-]. (> Khow. gán 'wind').}];172[I:461-462{S.v. Ved. gandhá- 'Geruch, Duft', not to be separated from Av. gaiṇti- 'übler Geruch', duž-gaiṇti- 'übelriechend, stinkend' Parth. gndʾg 'stinkend', MPers, NPers. gand 'Gestank', etc. Further connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: Khowar gaan 'wind' from Old Indic gandhá- 'smell, scent' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):221, no. 4131). To be separated from comparable lexemes in Iranic (cf. Av. gaiṇti- 'bad smell', Parthian gndʾg 'stinking' etc.), but no secure connections outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:461-462).

Source: 442[170{S.v. 3303 Ved. kumārá- m. 'boy' RV., 'prince' Ragh., °aká- m. 'little boy' RV. (*°akā- f. in Kho.), °rī- , °rikā- , f. 'young girl' AV. (Kho. kiméri 'woman' < kumārikā́-)}];172[II:368-369{S.v. Ved. kumārá- 'Kind, Knabe, Edelknabe, Jüngling, Sohn'. "Nicht sicher gedeutet."}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Vedic kumārikā́- 'girl', cf. Vedic kumārá- 'child, boy' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):170, no. 3303). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:368-369 for various uncertain proposals).
Parallel loans from Modern Iranic, cf. Persian شیرین / širin 'sweet'.
Loanword from Iranic (via Persian?), cf. [cognate set 2456](cog-2456), [cognate set 9297](cog-9297).

Source: 85[{S.v. Rom. gheară| etymology unknown.}]
Justification: Etymology unknown (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Source: 323[53{S.v. Paš. m'ewa f. 'fruit' "LW < Prs, like Bal mewag, nīwag 'id.', cf. Man. MPrs myw, Pth mygdg, Sogd. mγδʾk < *migda- (v. Henning, BSOAS 12/1, 1947, 56)"}]
Justification: Loan from Persian (cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):53).

Source: 323[81{Imperf. 3 sg. m. tǝ prob. < *taxta-, cf. Sh[ughni] tūyd- (EVShG 82, s.v. ti(y)-), Ishk[ashmi] tōyd 'went', etc. But l has beeen introduced from the other pret. forms, and we find in many dialects also a 3 sg. m. tl(ǝl)o, etc. A borrowing from Dardic (Torwali, etc. til- 'to go', cf. S[ans]k[ri]t til-, T 5856 tillati 'id.') is unlikely. Pres. j- (but Afr[idi, Pashto dialect], Waz[iri Pashto], etc. c-) < *t-j- < *tač-, cf. Sh[ughni] 3 sg. tīzd- (< ti(y)-), Sar[iqoli] tej- (v. above)| Yaghn[obi] taž-| rather than < *cyaw-.}]
Comment: Cheung (2007: 375) seems to prefer a derivation from *teh₂- "to flow, stream; to melt" partly "(certainly influenced by *tač)".
Pashto would simplify /xt/ > /t/. Kurdish: Vxt > v̄t.
Mayrhofer (EWAia I 415) mentions doubtful relation with an OInd. root kroḍ and Wurzelerweiterungstypus *°EU̯-s-d-. It may fit to Celtic *krou̯di- and Slavic *krǫt-?

Source: 172[II:702, I:105-106{Cf. s.v. Ved. sám, under which in compound sam-áraṇa- 'Treffen, Kampf'| for the root of -áraṇa-, cf. s.v. Ved. √ar- (1) 'in Bewegung setzen, senden, bringen| sich bewegen| erregen, anregen' < PIE *h₃er- (cf. Hitt. arnuzi 'bringt fort, liefert, befödert', Gk. ὄρνυμι 'treibe an, lasse losstürzen', Lat. orior 'erhebe mich', etc.}];358[187-188{S.v. OPers. hamarana- n. 'Kampf (allgemein)| Gefecht, Schlacht', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *samárana- 'Kampf, Schlacht'| literally 'Zusammentreffen', a verbal abstract to *sám-ar- = YAv. hamarəna, Ved. samárana- 'id.'}];141[299-301{Cf. s.v. *h₃er- 'sich in (fort-)Bewegung setzen' (IEW 326-9).}]
Comment: Old Persian ham-arana- "zusammenwogend"
Justification: Light verb construction with Old Persian ham-arana- 'fight' < *'coming together' as a the semantic head. The root etymology of the semantic-bearing element of the compound ºarana- is to the Indo-Iranic verbal root *ar- < PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ([Schmitt 2014](src-358):187-188, [EWAia](src-172) II:702, I:105-106, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-301).

Source: 83[83-84{S.v. Proto-Iranic *du̯ar- 'to run' (> Av. duuā̆r- 'to run'). Etymology uncertain. According to Kellens 1984: 108n11 metathesized from IIr. *drau-| otherwise possibly contaminated with Proto-Iranic *θu̯ar-/tur-.}]
Comment: duuaraiti suggested to be derived from *dreu̯- with metathesis (also suggested by Cheung 2007: 84, or ϑu̯ar/tūr). However, since this root is also attested in its expected form drauu-/drūta- (daevic), this seems less likely. [but Schwartz JRAS 1966: 119ff. considers the latter to belong to dhreu̯- “deceive”]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *du̯ar- 'to run', further etymology difficult (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):83-84 for discussion).

Comment: cf. Turkish fena “bad” < Arabic faniya “vernichten” (fanāˀ) ?

Source: 83[445-446{S.v. Proto-Iranic *xāz- 'to fight, struggle', first attested in Middle Iranic and with no certain cognates outside Iranic. Cf. Cheung 2002, Studies in the historical development of Ossetic vocalism, Wiesbaden: Reichert, p.211.}]
Justification: No etymology outside of Iranic (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):445-446).

Comment: There is mrγ “pasture”, which is given in Sogdian for “forest”, formally *ati-margā- would work, but does it make sense?

Source: 764[540{S.v. Khw. pθk (2) 'Haus' [< ?paδa- ([Henning 1955](src-768):43)].}];768[43{Cf. n3 "Recte pθk (پثک), perhaps from paδa- with change of -δ- to -θ- (as in Younger Avestan)."}];767[194{"pθk 'house' < padakā-"}]
Justification: As though from Iranic *padakā- according to [Humbach 1989](src-767):194, cf. [Henning 1955](src-768):43, [Benzing 1983](src-764):540), further etymology uncertain.
probably simply „what is to be eaten“

Source: 83[55-56{S.v. *damH- (3) 'blow, breathe, swell' (> Choresmian m|δmʾs- 'to become fat, strong'), from PIE *dmeH- 'to blow' (OCS dъmǫ, Lith. dùmti 'to blow')}]
Comment: via "swollen" > "thick", cf. Benzing (1983:256)
Justification: Derivative adjective to Khw. (ʾ)δmʾs- 'to become thick', further to Proto-Iranic *damH- 'to blow, breathe, swell' and ultimately to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ([Benzing 1983](src-764):256, [Cheung 2007](src-83):55-56, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:775-776, [LIV²](src-141) 153).

Source:
363[II:36-37{S.v. Kurd. nēčīr 'дичь, охота', cf. NPers. naxčīr, Z.MPers. naxčīr, M.MPers. nhčyhr, Sogd. nɣšʾyr, nɣšyr, Khot. načira, Yaghn. naxšir, naxčir, etc.| according to Bailey 1946:774, from Iranic *naxti-čiθra- 'originating in the night'.}];770[774n1{"I explain this word by an Old Iranian *naχti-čiθra- 'originating in the night' with allusion to the epithet Zor.Pahl. tam-tōχmak (a translation of Av. təmasčiθra-) applied to the wild beasts in Zoroastrian terminology.}];771[44{"Important for Indo-Iranian interpretation is also Lit. nókti, Let. nãkt. The basic meaning was 'reach, arrive '. Thus we find Lit. nókti 'to ripen' (like NPers. rasīdan 'arrive, ripen') and pranókti, panókti 'overhaul, overtake' beside Let. nãkt 'come', ie-nãkt 'enter', ie-nãkties 'to ripen', panãkt 'over-take'. These assure a base *nãk-. From a similar *nak- we can trace some Iranian words with the sense of 'extension' (from which 'extend up to, reach' is derived). Ossetic näx- in näxstar can be well taken to mean 'extension, open space'. It occurs in rānäxstär un 'to betake oneself' and in fännäxstär with känun and känyn. The word stär, with adjectival stäron, stäjron, refers to a man on expedition or wandering in difficult ways. In Miller's dictionary we have the Nārty stärtä, and in a translation of the Russian Igor poem we have the stärtä for the 'heroes' on a foray. In the first component näx- of näxstäron we have reference to the place of the wandering or foray.
The same *naxa- is to be seen in the first component of Mid. Pers. nxšyr, Mid. Parth. nxšyr- 'wild animals, quarry, hunting' in the Šāhpuhr I inscription as part of the title of the naxčīrpat 'huntsman' (Persian line 30, Parthian 24). This I would now explain as containing *naxa-čarya- 'moving about in the expanse, open spaces, the wilds'. It is equivalent to the Avestan ravasčarāt- rendered by Zor. Pahl. frāxv raftār 'ranging widely'."}]
Justification: Light verb constructions with nominal 'wild animals, quarry, hunting' as the semantic-bearing head. The etymology of Middle Persian naxčīr was originally interpreted by [Bailey 1946](src-770):774n1 as though from Iranic *naxti-čiθra- 'originating in the night' (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:36-37). [Bailey 1958](src-771):44 later revised his view in light of new Middle discoveries and alternatively considered as though from Middle Persian *naxa-čarya- 'moving about in the expanse, open spaces, the wilds'. If so, we could consider to either *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, arrive' → Iranic *naxa- 'expanse, wilderness', or to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to move, turn' > Proto-Iranic *carH- ([Cheung 2007](src-83):33-34) depending on which morpheme is best considered the original semantic head of the nominal compound.

Comment: This could be the name of a specific snake. If derived from garz- 'to lament', it might a kind of viper (similar to the puff adder, e.g. the Persian False Horned Viper).
related to xvaēδa- 'sweat'? < PIE *su̯ei̯d? EWAia 799 (Vol. II)

Source: 81[114-115{S.v. Proto-Slavic *dǫti 'blow' (ESSJa V 99-100), from PIE *dʰ(o)mH- (cf. Skt. dhámati 'blow').}];141[153{S.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8).}];83[55{S.v. Proto-Iranic *damH-³ 'to blow, breathe| swell', from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. Skt. dham- 'to blow, play a wind instrument, fan the fire', OCS dъmǫ, ORu. dъmu 'I blow', SCr. dȕti 'to blow', Lith. dùmti 'to blow (also of wind)'.}];321[273];458[5: 99-100{PS *dǫti. It is related to Old Indic dhámati 'blow' and Lithuanian dumiu, dùmti 'blow'.}]
Justification: Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):55, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):273-274, [Derksen 2008](src-81):114-115, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:99-100, [LIV²](src-141) 153).

Source: 83[211{S.v. PIr. *i̯am- 'to hold| to stretch, reach out' (> BSogd. ''s-, CSogd. 's- 'take, receive') < PIE *i̯em- 'to hold'.}];321[432]
Justification: Continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *i̯am- 'to hold; to stretch, reach out' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):211, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):432). No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic; [LIV²](src-141) 312 provisionally reconstructs ?*i̯em- 'to stretch out'.

Source: 325[50];701[662{Kho. do'γ̌ūr 'finger-nail' < Wkh. 'dəg∈r, dǝ̇γ̌ǝr, etc.}];321[146-147{Cf. s.v. Wakh. diγ̌ə́r, digə́r 'ноготь, коготь'.}]
Justification: Loan from Wakhi diγ̌ə́r, digə́r 'fingernail' ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):662, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):146-147).

Source: 701[662{Kho. γarik, γerik 'to turn (into)', etc. < Wkh. γ̌īr 'to turn around'}];321[188{Cf. s.v. Wakh. γ̌īr : γ̌īrd 'вращаться, превращаться'. Khowar γarik, γerik a loan from Iranic? cf. Morgenstierne Irano-Dardica 246).}]
Justification: A probable loan from Wakhi ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):662, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):188).

Source: 701[666{Khowar 'ā̆yukun 'egg' < Ir. *ā(w)yak, cf. Pers. xāya, etc. (But -un?).}]
Justification: Loan from Iranic *ā(w)yak ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):666).

Source: 83[227{S.v. Proto-Iranic *kaH- 'to take pleasure, desire' (> BSogd. kʾtʾk 'game, play' Chor. kʾt 'game', etc.), from PIE *keh₂- 'to love, desire' (cf. Skt. kā- 'to desire, wish', Lat. cā-rus 'dear, beloved', Goth. ho-rs 'adulterer', Engl. whore, etc.).}];172[I:334{Cf. s.v. Ved. √kā- 'begehren, gern haben', from PIE *keh₂- cf. Lat. cā-rus, 'lieb, wert', Goth. ho-rs 'Ehebrecher, Hurer' etc.}];141[343{Cf. s.v. *keh₂- 'begehren' (IEW 515).}]
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *keh₂- 'to desire' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):227, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:334, [LIV²](src-141) 343).

Comment: original meaning "to smell badly, stink", note the MP term gannāg mēnōg "evil spirit" and note that the Zoroastrian hell is stinking badly.
Gharib (1995: 217 §5434) translates the Sogdian word mrγ by "wood, meadow" and relates it to mrγ- "straight, flat".

Bailey (1979: 478) relates the Saka word hāysiñä "fountain (?)" to the Sogdian word ʾwʾz, which he relates to Ossetic awazun etc. "to dam up". The latter is given by Cheung as a cognate of *waz-, which also means "to swim" in some Iranic languages.

Bailey (1979: 420) connects the Saka word samuvā "covering parts" with CS sʾpt 'left (< crooked) side' and derives both from PIE *k̑am- "bend over, cover" with reference to *kamp- (cf. LIV p.342, not in Cheung 2007). Bailey also puts NP čap here.
Gharib (1995: 454, #11143) derives the Sogdian word from *δrām.

Source: 320[303{"From *upāntai, Pašto bānde 'upon' < *upăntai, possibly joining with Sogd. pnt 'near'."}]

Comment: Gharib (1995: 429 #10568) suggests a connection with Av. vǝrǝzra, which is not attested in Bartholomae (1904)

Source: 320[440{S.v. Khot. haṃga- 'sour' "Sogd. Man. nˀmry 'sweet' is *an-āmara-ka- ‘not sour’, as the reverse, Khotan Saka āhvarai ‘sour’, is ‘not sweet’."}]
Comment: Bailey (1979: 440) < *an-āmara-ka- ‘not sour’, as the reverse, Khotan Saka āhvarai ‘sour’, is ‘not sweet’. Reference to Pokorny om- and Old Indic amlá-, amblá- 'sour; sorrel'.
Justification: According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):440, to be derived from *an-āmara-ka- 'not sour', and connected to Vedic amlá- 'sour', traditionally compared to Italic and Germanic lexemes, e.g. Latin amārus 'bitter', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, hard, cold', cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:46, [EIEC](src-657) 69).

To be connected with Avestan paitištāna- 'leg', further a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to stand', cf. Vedic stā́na- 'place for standing' ([Gharib 1995](src-136):320, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:764-766, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 590-592).

Comment: maybe identical with 1584 *sem-; Nyberg "Manual" (1974: 93) derives this word from *hama-van- without indicating the meaning of the elements. (There is only van "tree" in his word list.)
Bailey (1979: 153) suggests a derivation from the verb dar- "to split"
Justification: [Bailey 1979](src-320):153 suggests a derivation from the verb *dar- 'to split' connecting to [IEW](src-49) 194-196 *del- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 114 *delh₁-, without IIr. cognates listed; note that [LIV²](src-141) 119-121, [EWAia](src-172) I:701-703, [Cheung 2007](src-83):59-60 assign Indo-Iranic *dar- to PIE *der-).

Source: 83[79{S.v. Proto-Iranic *drauH- 'to cut (down), mow, reap', cf. Skt. drav- 'to cut down'. A root attested in Indo-Iranic only| perhaps an enlarged form of IE *der- 'to tear, split', or at least contaminated with it.}];172[I:756{Cf. s.v. Ved. √drav- 'niederschneiden'. Uncertain. [Bailey 1979](src-320):168b considers an IE extended form *dr-euH- connected with √dar-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):79, [EWAia](src-172) I:756 for further discussion.

Source: 320[407{S.v. Khot. ṣaṃbajsa- 'claw' "The second component may be traced to vak- 'be crooked' (with the badzä of Oss. D. kärd-badzä), to Zor.P. w'hr *vahr *vaxr 'crooked', Pāzand *avāhar for *huvahr, *huvaxr, M.Pers.T. xwhr 'crooked', Pahlavī Psalter hwhly. IE Pok. 34 u̯enk-, u̯ek-, 1148 u̯eng-, and 1120 u̯āg- 'bend', O.Ind. vancati, vakrá, vánkri- 'rib'| with u̯ek, Av. nivaštakō.srva- 'with bent horns'."}]

Comment: Cheung (2007: 20) mentions a suggestion by Rastorgueva/Edel'man (2003: 159) to sort the Khotanese verb to *bād < PIE *bʰēdʰ-, viz. *pati-/api-bād-. They also suggest (not mentioned by Cheung) that this word could derive from api-šad- "oppress" < had "sit" (cf. Emmerick 1968: 85).

Source: 83[75{S.v. Proto-Iranic *drafš-? 'to "behave" like a banner, fly up, shine, tremble"? Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain. The etymology of [Bailey 1979](src-320):168 is difficult.}];320[168{Cf. s.v. Khot. drāh- 'dart about, range, fly'}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain, the earlier proposal by [Bailey 1979](src-320):168 to PIE *der- 'to run' via an extended form *dr-ep(h)- is no longer tenable (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):75).

Source: 83[106{S.v. Proto-Iranic *gard- (1) 'to call', from PIE gʷerdʰ- 'to raise the voice, call, sing' (cf. Arm. kardam 'to raise the voice', OPr. gerdaut 'to say', Lith. girdė́ti, Latv. dzìrdêt 'to hear', Gall-Lat. bardus, OIr. bard, W. bardd 'poet, singer').}];141[187, 210-211{S.v. *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'hören, tönen' [IEW 478]. Arm. kardam 'rufe', OIr. bard 'Barde', MW bardd 'id.', cf. *gʷer(H)- 'to consent' (LIV² 210f.) and *dʰeh₁- ''to put, to place, to make' (LIV² 136ff.). See also PIE *gʷerdʰ- 'to hear, to sound' (LIV² 187).}]
Justification: A derivative from Proto-Iranic *gard- 'to call', from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):106); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ([ALEW](src-352) 331-332). Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 210-211.

Comment: identical with the Romanian word that was loaned from Turkish (6544)

Gk. ἵεμαι (= ϝῑ́εμαι) 'strebe, trachte nach, begehre, eile' Lith. výti 'treiben, verfolgen, nachjagen'.}];141[668-669{Cf. s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach' (IEW 1123-4).}]

Light verb constructions, whose semantic heads are loans from Persian parvāz 'flight'.

Source: 323[67{S.v. Paš. px̌a, Northeastern dialects xpa, Wan špa 'foot'. Darmesteter 1888-1890 suggested a connection with Avestan pāšna- 'heel', cf. Skt. pā́rṣṇi-. "A derivation via *pªğa < *paẓn'ā < *pāršnā (dual?) raises both semantic and phonological difficulties, but no other explanation offers itself."}]

Kurd. kutān (kut-) | kutān (kutē-) 'бить, колотить, ударять| стучать| молотить, биться (о сердце)', from Old Iranic *kup- (Parth. kwbg, MPers. kōv-, kōftan, Pers. kōb, kōbīdan, etc.).}]

Further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *párću- 'rib', with further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult to ascertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:100-101).

*su̯elk̑s- cf. Middle Persian xwaš, Parthian wxaš
possibly a Turkish loan word: kol "arm", if it was used for all extremities
This word is most likely related to the armpit, cf. Av. kaša-, with suffix -ka- and a modern diminutive (?) suffix -ıḷa.
zāk could represent a nasalised zãk (?) < *zank- (?) < *zang-a-k, cf. Av. zaṇga- „ankle“, alternatively one would have to assume zāk < *zaγ-k < *zaγ-ak < *zaga- < *j́nͅgʰ-

Origin unclear, l can derive from *rd/rz if this verb had originally a prefix. It is also possible that there is a kind of r/l alternation. Then it could be related to cognate set 6659 *Hrab/f-: raw- > *rū- (?), though this is pretty wanted.

Source: 83[287-288{S.v. Proto-Iranic *pad- 'to fall, be stuck in' ((+ ni-) > NWIr. Kurd. [Rix 1976](src-586):278f.}]

Source: 83[184{S.v. *Hrab/f- 'to go' (> NEIr. Sariq. warofs-/warůvd, Wa. wr(f)s-/wr(f)st-, vr(f)-/vr(f)st-). "An IE origin of this Ir. root is uncertain. The WIr. forms, Pth. rf- ‘to attack’ and NP rav- ‘to go’, have been connected to MHG reben ‘to move’, Lat. rabiō ‘I rage’ in LIV: l.c. This can be doubted. Pth. rf- may point to a different root. MHG reben ‘to move’ has probably a different etymology (it is compared to OIrish reb ‘play’, Russ. rebënok ‘child’ by Häusler 2000: 144). Source: 323[44{S.v. Paš. lanḍˈay 'short, cut short| a kind of quatrain' "LW < Lhd lanḍā, lunḍā 'crop-tailed', cf. T 11081, where the Lhd form given ('lundā "tailless, shameless"') is an error.}];442[645{Cf. 11081.4 *lunda- > L.mult. lundā 'tailless, shameless'.}]

Source: 323[27{S.v. Paš. ganḍ- 'to sew' "Despite the retroflex -ḍ-, prob. < OId Ir *han-gan-" cf. Skt. sam-han- 'put together, unite' < PIE *gʷʰen-.}]

[LIV²](src-141) 344). [Not in [Cheung 2007](src-83)].

Comment: probably related with Parthian wiδān "tent"

Source: 83[420{S.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ar(H)- (1) 'to choose, convince| (med.) believe' (+ *u̯i- > Khw. ywʾry- 'to know, experience, understand'), from PIE *u̯elh₁- 'to want, wish' (cf. Skt. var- 'to choose, pick', Lat. volō, OCS velitъ 'wants, orders', Lith. vélti 'to wish, prefer', Goth. wiljan 'to want', Engl. will, etc.).}];141[677-678{Cf. s.v. *u̯elh₁- '(aus)wählen' (IEW 1137).}]
Justification: From Proto-Iranic *u̯ar(H)- 'to choose, convince; (med.) believe' + preverb *u̯i-; root etymology further to PIE *u̯elh₁- 'to choose, select' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):420, [LIV²](src-141) 677-678).

Source: 83[401{The often assumed relationship between OAv. ufiia- ‘to sing’ and *u̯ab/f ‘to weave’ (as quoted in for instance EWA II: 506| Porzig, Gliederung: 186), should be given up, in view of the evidence from the other Ir. languages, which clearly point to two separate roots. Ir. *u̯ab/f¹ is probably expressive or onomatopoetic in origin, of the type woof. The root has been connected to OCS vabiti ‘to summon’, Goth. wopjan ‘to call loudly, call out’, Engl. to weep (etc.) by H.W. Bailey (his notes can be found on his copy of Pokorny, IEW: 1109). This proves to be phonologically difficult as the Slavo-Germanic forms point to a structure that is not typical for an IE form, having long *ā followed by *-b-.}]
Comment: proposed relation to PIE *u̯ebʰ- "to weave" rejected by Cheung (2007)

Justification: Lit. 'not-good', cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):106, cf. 'good' in [cognate set 9287](cog-9287) for further etymological discussion.

Source: 728[161{S.v. Manx fedjag 'feathers, whiskers', cf. ScG. eiteag.}];231[156{Cf. s.v. éiteag 'white pebble, precious stone'| from Engl. hectic, lapis hecticus, the white hectic stone, used as a remedy against dysentery and diarrhea.}]

Comment: The Persian develoment would have been *siš < *ϑiš < *k̑u̯is or *ϑiš < *siš < *k̑u̯is, cf. Klingenschmitt (2000: 202).
Wakhi šiš might belong here as well. The assimilation of siš > šiš is frequently attested (for Balochi examples cf. Korn 2005: 180).

Emmerick/Skjærvø (1982: 55) follow Henning's suggestion to derive the Khotanese word from *drigu- (cf. Avestan drigu- "arm, bedürftig, schwach"). The Avestan word is considered an Iranian innovation by Mayrhofer (EWAia I: 68): "Konträrbildung zu dem ererbten indoiran. *ádhri-gu-, aus irriger Auffassung *a-dhrigu-".
Justification: The etymology of Khotanese dīra- 'bad' given here follows the proposal of [Henning 1944](src-801):141n7 proposing to connect the word to Avestan drigu- 'poor, weak' via metathesised *dirgu- (cf. [Emmerick & Skjærvø 1982](src-802):55-56, and Maggi on the word again in [Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997](src-777):77-78). Possibly further related to Vedic á-dhrigu-, an epithet of Indra, Agni, Soma, the Aśvins, and the Maruts, [EWAia](src-172) I: 67-68 for further discussion. Note, however, that [Bailey 1979](src-320):159 preferred to see a connection instead to the PIE root *du̯ei̯- 'to fear'.

Source: 321[348{проблематична связь с тадж., перс. saxt}]
Justification: Historical phonology rules out any etymological relation to Persian saxt. The Wakhi sound <x> could imply a loanword from another Iranic language, as it is not usually found in the native vocabulary.

Source: 444[236{S.v. 2758 *dēramāre 'entästen' (> Vegl. dramuor 'schlachten, töten').}];54[513{S.v. rāmus 'branch, twig', from PIE *u̯r(e)h₂-(d-)mo-? "Possibly from *rād-mo- < *wrād-mo-, if cognate with rādix 'root'. The semantics can be justified by referring to Gr. ράδιξ, -ικος 'branch, twig', showing that *ur(e)h₂d- could mean either 'branch' or 'root'."}];316[564{S.v. Lat. rāmus 'branche, rameau', cf. rādix.}]
Justification: As though from Latin *dē-ramāre 'to dismember' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):236), a derivative of Latin rāmus 'branch, twig' which is traditionally further connected to the root of Latin rādix 'root' if *rādmo- < *wrād-mo-, cf. Ancient Greek ῥάδιξ, -ικος 'branch, twig' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):564, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):513).

Source: 141[245{S.v. h₁eu̯s- 'verbrennen, sengen' (IEW 347-8)}];444[757{Cf. s.v. 9097 ūstulāre 'sengen', 'verbrennen'.}];443[14:75-82{S.v. Lat. ūstulāre 'sengen' > Fr. brûler. The origin of initial br- is uncertain, perhaps by influence of Italian, etc. bruciare < *brūsiare or Germanic brennen.}];316[755{S.v. Lat. ūrō 'brûler', with secondary derivative ūstulāre attested already by Catullus. Lat. ūrō corresponds to Gk. εὔω, Skt. óṣāmi 'je brûle' and nominal forms in OIc. ysia 'feu', etc. The expressive verb ustulāre is formed like postulāre.}];54[645{Cf. s.v. Lat. ūrō 'to burn, scorch', from PIE *h₁eus-e/o- 'to burn' (cf. Skt. oṣati 'to burn, scorch', uṣṇá- 'hot', Gk. εὕω 'to singe', OIc. usli, OE ysle 'hot ashes', OIc. ysja 'fire'.}]
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin ūstulāre (on the unexpected initial br-, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):757, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 14:75-82), a secondary form of Latin ūrō derived from PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, singe' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):755, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):645, [LIV²](src-141) 245).

Source: 397[378{Cf. s.v. NHG Grund (MHG grunt, OHG grunt, OS grund), from Gmc. *grundu- 'Grund, Boden', also in Goth. grundu-, ON grunnr, OE grund, OFr. grund. The possibilities for comparisons outside of Germanic are problematic. On one hand OIr. grindell 'Grund eines Sees, Untergrund', which would require PIE *gʰrn̥dʰ- which contradicts the Nordic, which seems to require *gʰrn̥t-. On the other hand Lith. pãgrindas 'Grundlage, Fundament' with the same formal problem and further clear connections to words for 'Brett, Bohle' so that in this case one is to think of an artificial floor. For the time being, the etymology must be regarded as unexplained.}];165[192{S.v. Proto-Germanic *grumϸu- ~ *grundu- 'floor' "Usually reconstructed as a tu-stem to a root *gʰren- (cf.
