Related to Skt. harmyá-  'permanent building' < *g̑ʰer-m-io-?"}];388[144{S.v. Proto-Germanic *ʒrunđuz ~ ʒrunϸuz, continues *ghrn̥-tu- based on *ghren- (Gk. χραίνω 'to touch slightly, to smear', Lith. pã-grindas 'lake bottom').}];179[161{S.v. Goth. G109. grundu-waddjus, possibly from PIE *gʰrendʰ- (PGmc. *grundu- < *gʰrn̥-tu-) is in *grinda-fraϸjis| *grundus then was something crushed, crushed ground like malma to *malan.}]
Justification: From Proto-Germanic *grundu- 'floor' (Old Frisian grund); further etymological connections problematic, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):161, [Orel 2003](src-388):144, [Kluge 2011](src-397):378, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):192 for various proposals and further discussion.

Comment: from root *k̑eh₃-, expected output would be hīne etc.

Source: 364[1009-1010{S.v. Alb. zë (trans.) '(an)fassen, fangen| erfassen| anfangen'. This verb and its compounds are eminently polysemous, moreover on phonological grounds several root structures are conceivable: *gʷen(H)-, *gʷʰen(H)-, *g̑u̯enH- and *g̑ʰu̯en(H)-. There are no convincing cognates anywhere else in Indo-European. Phonologically it would be possible to derive this verb from the root *gʷʰen(H)- whose meaning is 'schwellen', but semantically this is improbable.}];369[426-427{S.v. Alb. 2. zë 'fassen, anfassen| fangen| erfassen| (mit) etw. anfangen| verstopfen, blockieren'. Otherwise unclear, up to now the most frequent attempted derivation is to a root *gʷ⁽ʰ⁾en- which can explain developments in initial position, but not the lowering of the root vowel.}];105[521{S.v. Alb. zë, zâ 'to seize, grasp, touch', from PAlb. džeina, a derivative in *-no- based on IE *gʷei̯H- 'to overpower' (cf. Skt. jyā́ 'force, power', jáyati 'to win, to conquer', Gk. βίη 'power').}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):426-427, [Orel 1998](src-105):521, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1009-1010 for various possibilities and further discussion.

Source: 556[162{S.v. Gmc. *(-)drǣd-a- '(fürchten)'. No certain comparisons outside of Germanic. Cf. OS -drādan (MLG ontraden), OHG -trātan (MHG entrātan).}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Seebold 1970](src-556):162).

Source: 50[319{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *salā 'dirt' (OIr. sal 'filth, impurity', OW halauc 'dirty' W halog). Cf. Old English salu 'dirty'. OIr. salach 'dirty' < *salāko-. Some have postulated that the word can be derived from PIE *seh₂l- 'salt', but this is semantically dubious| further connections with Lat. salīua are possible but unconvincing.}];296[S:16{S.v. sal 'saléte', outside of Celtic to be connected with an adj. in -wo-, cf. OHG salo 'sombre, sale', OE salu 'id.' OIc. sǫlr 'jaune, sale', and Latin salebra 'saleté'. Russian solovój 'couleur isabelle' might also be added here, if we compare the colour term in Scandinavian.}];165[425{S.v. Proto-Germanic *salwa- 'yellowish brown', from PIE *solH-uo- (cf. Ru. solóvyj 'light bay' < *solH-uo-). A Germanic-Slavic isogloss.}];697[466-467{S.v. Gmc. salwa- 'dunkel, schwärzlich'. Inherited adjective, identical with the basis of CS slavo-očije 'bläuliche Augenfarbe' and Russ. solovoj 'gelblichgrau (Pferd)'.}];81[460{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *solvъ, from PIE *sal-uo- (solH-uo-?), cf. OIc. sǫlr 'dirty yellow', OHG salwo 'dirty yellow', MoE sallow 'sickly yellow, pale brown', OIr. salach 'dirty'. "I suspect that we are dealing with a root *sal- with "European a". According to [Schrijver 1991](src-679): 212-213, ablaut *solH- : *slH- is an alternative solution."}];679[212-213{Cf. for further discussion of these words possibly in connection to Lat. salīva 'spit', reconstructing a zero-grade root form *slH-.}]
Justification: A European isogloss with proposed cognates also in Italic and Slavic; cf. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):212-213 for further discussion. The Germanic forms in this class may go back to Proto-Germanic *salwo- as though from PIE *solH-u̯o- (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):466-467, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):425), while the Celtic forms require a Proto-Celtic derived stem *salāko- (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:15-16, [Matasović 2009](src-50):319).

Source: 697[199{S.v. Gmc. *flaka- 'flach', to be connected with Latin plaga 'Fläche' and to be considered a g-enlarged form of PIE *pelə- / *plā- 'flach, ausbreiten'.}];165[143-144{S.v. Proto-Germanic *flaka- 'flat' < PIE *plók-o- (cf. Gk. πλάξ, -ακός 'plane, plain| flat stone, board table' < *pl̥k-| Lith. plãkanas, Latv. plakans 'flat' < *plokono-).}]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Germanic *flaka- 'flat'. Traditionally considered to be a *-g- extended form of the root *pelh₂- (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):199), alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):143-144 proposes cognacy to Greek πλάξ, -ακός 'plane, plain; flat stone, board table' < *pl̥k-; Lithuanian plãkanas, Latvian plakans 'flat' < *plokono- (cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 785-786, reconstructing *pleh₂k- 'mit flacher Hand schlagen, klatschen').

Source: 556[406{S.v. Gmc. *skald-a- 'stoßen'. No convincing comparisons outside of Germanic.}];397[794{Cf. s.v. NHG schalten (MHG schalten, OHG scalten 'fortschieben, fortführen', OS skaldan < Gmc. *skald-a- 'stoßen').}]
Justification: Attestation restricted to West Germanic, without clear comparisons outside of Germanic (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):406, [Kluge 2011](src-397):794).

Source: 697[348-349{S.v. Gmc. *kʷǣda- 'schlecht, böse', stands next to a substantive in the meaning 'Kot, Dreck, Dung' which could have been adjectivised in predicate position (cf. OE cwēad 'Dung').}];757[{S.v. Du. kwaad 'slecht, ontstemd', from Proto-Germanic *kwēda- and possibly related to Lithuanian gė́da 'shame'| OCS gadŭ- 'creeping things' (Russian gad 'reptile, amphibian') < PIE *gʷeh₁dʰ-, *gʷoh₁dʰ- (IEW 483-485).}];388[229{S.v. Proto-Germanic *xwēdaz (adj.), related to Lith. gė́da 'shame', Slav. gydъkъ 'disgusting', Alb. zi 'black < *gʷedi-.}];352[303-304{Cf. s.v. OLith. *gė́da 'Schande, Scham', from PIE *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'eklig' (cf. OCS gadъ 'Kriechtier, Gewürm, Ungeziefer' SCr. gȁd 'Reptil, Schlange', MLG kwād 'böse, schlecht', etc.).}]
Justification: From Proto-Germanic *kwēda- 'shit, excrement' (n.). 'bad' (adj.) ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):348-349), generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ([EWNl](src-757), [Orel 2003](src-388):229, cf. ALEW} 303-304, [Derksen 2008](src-81):160-161 [not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)]).

Source: 388[334{S.v. PGmc. *skankaz ~ *skankōn- sb.m. (Norw. skank 'shank', OE sceanca, LG schanke, OHG scanc 'rack, cupboard'), derived from *skankaz adj. related to Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skn̥gi̯ō, MIr. scingim 'to spring'.}];141[555{Cf. s.v. *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'hinken' (IEW 930).}];165[446{S.v. Proto-Germanic *skinkan- ~ *skankan- ~ *skunkan- 'shank, ham', from *skéng-on- (cf. Gk. σκάζω 'to limp' < *skng-ie-, Skt. khañjati 'id.' < *skeng-e-). The Germanic forms reflect an ablauting n-stem from the PIE verbal root *skeng-.}];397[800{S.v. NHG Schenkel (MHG schenkel, MLG schinkel, MDu. sc(h)enkel), a diminutive formation to OE sceanca, MLG schinke 'Schenkel', To this perhaps a with a dissimilated initial position Ved. sákthi- 'Schenkel'. Cf. also 'hinken' in Ved. kháñjati, Gk. σκάζω, and without s-mobile NHG hinken.}];697[485{Cf. s.v. PGmc. *skanka- 'schief', from which E scanca 'Unterschenkel, Schienbein' etc.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):446, [Orel 2003](src-388):334, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):485). The 'Schenkel' from Middle High German onwards are diminutive formations ([Kluge 2011](src-397):800). For the root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).

Source: 172[II:823{S.v. Ved. √hras- 'verringern, klein machen, kürzen' (Skt. hrasvá- 'kurz, klein'| mi., ni., pā. rassa- pkt. hassa-, rahasa- 'klein, leicht', etc.), probably from PIE *g̑ʰres-/*g̑ʰers- (MIr. gerr 'kurz').}];49[443{S.v. *g̑ʰeres-, *g̑ʰres-, *g̑ʰers- (Ved. hrasvá- 'minder, kurz, klein', MIr. gerr 'kurz').}];733[68n57{Cf. in discussion to OIr. gar 'short| near', garait 'short'(?), with synonymous gerr with e-grade| not necessarily continuing an s-extension as commonly assumed, but could perhaps be accounted for due to expressive gemination.}];269[{Alternatively to [IEW](src-49) 443, [EWAia](src-172) II:823, [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):68n57, perhaps an original s-stem adjective to a root *g̑ʰer- could also be considered.}];442[819{Cf. s.v. 14184 Skt. hrasvá- 'short, weak (of voice)' VS. (> Pk. rahassa-).}]
Justification: Celtic and Indic lexemes from a root *g̑ʰers-/*g̑ʰres- ([EWAia](src-172) II:823), traditionally considered to be derived from an s-extended form of the root *g̑ʰer- 'short, small, slight' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 443, [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):68n57; not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)).

Source: 172[I:117-118{S.v. Ved. √ard- 'zerstieben, sich schütteln', with derivative ārdrá- 'feucht, naß', perhaps to be connected with YAv. arəduš- 'Verletztung, Hieb' and outside of IIr. ON erta 'aufstacheln, aufreizen', Lith. ardýti 'zerlegen, auftrennen'.}];442[60{S.v. 1340 Skt. ārdrá- 'wet' RV. 2. *ālla- < *ārdla-.}];141[223-224{Cf. s.v. *Herd- 'ins Schwanken geraten' [IEW 329-30, 334].}]
Justification: Indic lexemes derived from PIE *Herd- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 223-224, [EWAia](src-172) I:117-118). For Modern Indic lexemes connected to this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):60, no. 1340.

Source: 81[513{Cf. s.v. Proto-Slavic *vedro 'nice weather', from PIE *u̯edʰrom (cf. OIc. veðr 'weather', OHG wetar).}];468[649{S.v. ON veðr 'wetter, witterung| geruch'. Probably PIE *u̯edʰro- to OCS vedro 'heiteres wetter' and then a -dʰro- derivative to the root *u̯ē- 'blow' (cf. vindr).}];165[583-584{S.v. Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather'.  "The Walser German form wedar as in 's wedar dr fenstro 'windowpane' (Schott 1842: 340) points to a variant *weϸra- beside *wedra-. This means that the word may have been a mobile neuter in Pre-Gm., viz. *uétr-om, pl. *uetr-éh₂. This proto-form further implies that the received etymological link with OCS vedro n. 'clear sky' < *uedʰro- cannot be maintained. The connection with OCS vetro 'air, wind' < *ueh₁-tro-, Lith. vė́tra < *h₂ueh₁-treh₂- (see *wēan-) is formally problematic as well, because the underlying form would give PGm. *weϸra- (laryngeals are not lost before *CR-, pace Schindler apud Peters 1999). Olr. feth f. 'wind(?)' can theoretically be derived from *ueto- without a laryngeal, but is more likely to have developed out of *h₂ueh₁-tó- by pretonic shortening (Dybo's law). The only way to retain the connection of the Germanic word with the PIE root *h₂ueh₁- 'to blow' is to reconstruct it as *h₂uh₁-etr-o- (or *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- in view of OCS vedro) with the same suffix as found in e.g. Gr. Hom. λοετρόν 'bath, bathing site' (derived from λούω 'to bathe')."}];49[81-82{Cf. s.v. *au̯(e)-, *au̯ē(i)-, *u̯ē- 'wehen, blasen, hauchen', under c. *u̯e-dʰro- presumably ("vermutlich") in ON veðr n. 'Wind, Luft, Wetter', OS wedar n. 'Witterung, böses Wetter', OHG wetar 'Wetter, Witterung, freie Luft' and OCS vedro 'heiteres Wetter', vedrъ 'heiter (vom Wetter)'.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Traditionally assumed to be a derivative in *-dʰro- to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' and connected with OCS vedro 'nice weather' ([IEW](src-49) 82; cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):649, [Derksen 2008](src-81):513), but cf. the discussion of [Kroonen 2013](src-165):583-584.

Source: 468[632{Cf. s.v. ON ugð 'angst, fürcht', ugga 'fürchten'. Perhaps to a PIE root *ak̑-, ok̑- 'scharf, spitz sein' ([IEW](src-49) 18).}]
Justification: Traditionally conjectured to be a derivative to PIE *h₂ek̄- 'to be(come) sharp' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):632, [IEW](src-49) 18), but this etymology is no longer continued by the more recent handbooks (cf. [NIL](src-274) 287-300; not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).

Source: 179[45{S.v. Goth. A215 atisk, only acc sg in ϸairh atisk 'διὰ τῶν σπορίμων', 'grainfield'. Elsewhere in Germanic cf. MLG esch < *etisc, OHG ezzesc, MHG ezzisch 'sown grainfield', Du. esch 'cultivated fields of a village'. Cognates elsewhere uncertain.}];165[39{S.v. Proto-Germanic *atiska- n.(?) 'grainfield', a derivative from an old PIE word for 'spelt' or other type of cereal, cf. ?Hitt. ḫātar 'unknown foodstuff' (Watkins 1975)| YAv. āδū.frāδana- 'abounding in grain'| Arm. hat 'grain, seed'| 'piece, fragment, section', Lat. ador, -oris 'coarse grain, spelt, barley' < *h₂ed-(o)r-.}]
Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):45 for various proposals). [Kroonen 2013](src-165):39 considers a root etymology *h₂ed- for an old PIE word for a type of cereal grains.

Source: 296[D:161{S.v. OIr. do-léci 'il lâche, relâche, laisse aller, concède, accorde, décoche, lance, jette, rejette, abat…', originally a compound of the verb léic- 'laisser, lâcher' and the preverb to-, later interpreted as a simple verb teilcid, tarlaicid.}];728[451-452{S.v. Manx tilgey 'casting, vomiting' (=ScG. tilgeadh).}];141[406-408{S.v. *lei̯kʷ- 'zurücklassen, sich entfernen von' (IEW 669-70).}];50[240{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *li-n-kʷ-o- 'leave, let' (OIr. léicid, -léici 'leaves, lets, allows') from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'leave' (cf. Skt. riṇákti, Lat. linquō, Gk. λείπω, Go. leihwan, Lith. lìkti).}];442[492{S.v. 8743 *prarēcayatē 'is abandoned' [Cf. prárecayati 'abandons' RV. √ric-].}];172[II:457-458{S.v. Ved. √rec- 'verlassen, lassen, überlassen, loslassen, freimachen', from PIE *lei̯kʷ- (cf. Arm. lkʻane-, aor. lkʻ[e]- 'verlassen', Gk. λείπω, λιμπάνω 'lasse, verlasse', Lat. linquō 'überlasse', Lith. liekmì 'bleibe', OPr. po-līnka 'bleibt', Goth. leiƕan, etc.).}]
Justification: Indic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):492, no. 8743, [EWAia](src-172) II:457-458, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):451-452, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:161, [Matasović 2009](src-50):240, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 406-408).

Source: 341[606-607{S.v. TochB kau- TochA ko- 'zerschlagen, töten| destroy, kill'. From PIE *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 345f., [Hackstein 1995](src-731):54ff.).}];83[251-252{S.v. Proto-Iranian *kau̯š- 'to fight, struggle| kill'. This root goes back to a PIE ingressive formation *keh₂u-se/o- (cf. TochA koṣ-, TochB kauṣ- 'to kill, strike down, destroy'), non-ingressive forms are attested via Lith. káuti 'to murder, beat, hew', OHG houwan, OE hēawan, Engl. to hew, etc.}];731[54-56];345[222{S.v. TochB kau- 'kill, strike down, destroy| chop up', which with TochA ko- reflect PToch. *kāu- from PIE *kehₐw- 'hew, strike' (OHG houwan, OE hēawan 'beat, hew', Lith. káuju 'beat, strike| forge', OCS kovǫ 'forge', and more distantly Lat. cūdō 'beat, pound, thresh'.}];141[345-46{S.v. 2. *keh₂u̯- 'schlagen, spalten' (IEW 535).}];149[115-116{S.v. TochB kau- 'to kill, slay, strike down', A ko- 'id.', derived from PIE *keh₂u- 'to hew, cut down, strike' (cf. Lith. kaúti 'to strike, hammer| fight', OHG houwwan 'hew', etc.).}]
Justification: Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to hit, split' ([LIV²](src-141) 345-346, cf. [Hackstein 1995](src-731):54-56, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):115-116, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):606-607, [Adams 2013](src-345):222, [Cheung 2007](src-83):251-252).

Source: 444[624{S.v. 7547 salo, salawer (langob., ahd.).}];443[17:12-15{S.v. *salo (anfrk.) 'trübe, schmutzig' (> Fr. sale).}]
Justification: Loanword from West Germanic ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):624, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:12-15).

As though continuing Sanskrit *rāyaṇika- 'barking', a derivative of Vedic √rā- 'to bark, bark at' and further to PIE *leh₂- 'to bark, bark at' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):620 no. 10713, [EWAia](src-172) II:443, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 400-401).
Derivatives to Vedic ghaná- adj. 'thick, compact' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):828 no. 14468). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:512, I:184-185 for further discussion.

Source: 369[342{S.v. Alb. qúaj, qú(e)j 'benennen| betrachten als, halten für', dial. quhem 'heißen'. To be connected with *k̑leu̯- 'hören', cf. entry for further discussion on the verbal stem formation in Albanian.}]

Justification: The alternative suggestion piśitá-, 'meat' in Prakrit and Pashai, is not convincing as we would expect -ita to result in Khowar -ir, e.g. Khowar bʌsir 'he-goat' < vāsita- (Turner q.v.), but kur 'where?' < kútaḥ (Turner q.v.). There is no reason to assume u~i fluctuation in Khowar – on the contrary, we would expect umlaut before -i-.

Source: 442[614{S.v. 10620 Ved. rápati 'talks, chatters' RV. [~ lápati – √rap- (1)]}];172[II:432-433{S.v. Ved. √rap- 'vertraulich sprechen, vertraut reden, undeutlich sprechen, schwatzen', maybe to an onomatopeic root *lep-, cf. Ru. lépet 'Stammeln, Lallen', etc.}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Vedic √rap- 'to talk, chatter' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):614 no. 10620). Further etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:432-433, not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Source: 443[10:415-417{S.v. Lat. *rīparia 'Ufergelände' > Fr. rivière.}];444[605{S.v. 7328 Lat. rīpa 'Ufer'.}];54[524{S.v. Lat. rīpa 'river bank', from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' (cf. Gk. ἐρείπω 'to throw down, fall down', ἐρίπνη 'slope', OIc. rifa 'to demolish, tear down, ONo. rīp 'upper side of a boat', East Frisian rip(e) 'shore').}];316[574]
Justification: Italic lexemes derived from Latin rīpa 'riverbank' from PIE *h₁rei̯p- ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):605, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 10:415-417, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):524; cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):574).

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966
Not in Turner 1962–1966

Justification: As though continuing Sanskrit *skambha- 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):786 no. 13640). Further etymology uncertain.

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966.
Not in Turner 1962–1966

Justification: Indic and Nuristani lexemes tentatively connected with Prakrit cikka- and Marathi cikkar 'small', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442): 259 and [Degener 1998](src-798): 406. Coincidence and recent formation through sound symbolism are impossible to exclude.

Source: 79[39-40{S.v. Arm. ałt 'filth' (adj. ałt-ełi). Etymology disputed, cf. for various proposals.}]
Justification: Denominal adjective from Classical Armenian ałt 'filth'. Further etymology outside of Armenian disputed, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):39-40 for various proposals.

Source: 442[154{S.v. 3023 Ved. kā́ṇḍa- (kāṇḍá- TS.) m.n. 'single joint of a plant'}];172[I:336-337{S.v. Ved. kā́ṇḍa- 'Abschnitt, Stück, Halmglied'. Uncertain origin, probably of Middle Indic or non-IE origin.}]
Justification: Khowar kan < Old Indic kāṇḍa- 'single joint of plant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):154, no. 3023), further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:336-337).

Source: 442[272{4979 Skt. chadana- n. 'cover' R., 'leaf' Suśr. [√chad1]}];172[I:554-555{S.v. Ved. √chad- 'bedecken, zudecken, verhüllen', perhaps further related to YAv. sāδaaiianti 'lange Hose', but uncertain. Further connections are unclear.}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit chadana- 'cover; leaf', a derivative of Vedic √chad- 'to cover', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):272 no. 4979, [EWAia](src-172) I:554-555).

Source: 442[215{S.v. 4015 *gandhapūrikā- 'flower'. [gandhá- , pūra- 1] > Kal. gambhūri 'flower', Kho. gambùri}];172[I:461-462{S.v. Ved. gandhá- 'Geruch, Duft', not to be separated from YAv. gaiṇti- 'übler Geruch', duž-gaiṇti- 'übelriechend, stinkend', Parth. gndʾg 'stinkend', MPers., NPers. gand 'Gestank', etc. Further connections are uncertain.}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *gandhapūrikā-, an substantivised form of an adjective derived from gandhá- 'smell', and pūra- 'filling, making full' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):215, no. 4015. This class is coded for Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', which appears to be the semantic bearing head of the original compound. Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:461-462).

Source: 442[27{S.v. 612 Skt. aru- m. 'sun' lex. > Kho. yor}]
Justification: Apparently as though from Sanskrit aru- 'sun', only attested in lexicographical works ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):27, no. 612).

Source: 172[I:666{S.v. Ved. tr̥prá- 'ein Beiwort für Soma-Säfte', etc. Etymology unclear.}];442[338-339{S.v. 5934 Ved. tr̥prá- (3) 'pungent' (Geldner) RV., 'salty' KātyŚr. (> Kho. trup 'salt').}]
Justification: Continuing Vedic tr̥prá-, originally an epithet of soma of debated semantics. Further etymology obscure ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):338-339 no. 5934, [EWAia](src-172) I:666).

Source: 701[671{Khowar zērč 'yellow', loan from *zërt + č, cf. Seistani zerča or zardi 'rust disease of wheat '. Shgh. zereč ' rust '. Kho. zērbali 'yellow rose' < *zērd-wali?}]
Justification: Loan from Iranic (cf. [Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):671).

Source: 442[351{S.v. 6145 Ved. dádhāti 'places, lays on, gives, seizes' RV. [Already in RV. there was some contact of meaning with dádāti, and in meaning ʻbeatsʼ it collides with it also phonetically in Kaf. and Dard. There is similar confusion in Iranian (e.g. Shgh. dā- ʻto giveʼ and dā- ʻto put, strikeʼ)]}]
Justification: NB: [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):351 no. 6145 compares Iranic forms which [Cheung 2007](src-83):48 assumes to be a separate root of onomatopoeic origin.

Source: 701[666{Cf. istā̆ri 'star'. "Prob. IA., cf. Ashkun is'ta, etc."}]
Justification: Probably a loanword, cf. Saṇu-viri istˈã 'star' ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):666).

Source: 701[669{Cf. Kho. sor 'head'. "The o indicates a rather early borrowing. Yd. soro 'ear of corn' from Kho."}]
Justification: An early borrowing from Iranic ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):669).

Source: 442[675{S.v. 11586 Ved. vāśáyati 'causes to roar or resound' RV. [√vāś] > Kho. bašeik}];172[II:547-548{S.v. Ved. √vāś- 'brüllen, blöken', a root of onomatopoetic origin without connections outside of Indo-Iranic.}];83[432{Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *u̯ās- 'to make a noise (roar, shout, vel sim.)', an IIr. root probably of onomatopoetic origin without certain IE connections.}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √vāś- 'to roar, resound' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):675 no. 11586), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic √*u̯āć-, cf. Proto-Iranic *u̯ās- 'to make a noise, roar, shout', but without clear correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:547-548, [Cheung 2007](src-83):432).

Source: 442[735{S.v. 12684 śraya- m. 'refuge' W. [√śri]}]

442[96-97{S.v. 2061 Ved. údricyatē 'is prominent' RV. 2. *udriñcati 'empties'. 3. údrikta- 'superfluous' TS. 4. *udrēcati 'leaves'. 5. udrēcayati 'causes to increase' Rājat. 6. *udrēcyatē 'is poured out'. [ud + √ric-]. From (5) > Kho. uléik 'to throw away, pour out, sprinkle' whence intr. ulúik 'to fly away, fall' and its caus. uluwéik 'to make fly'.}];172[II:457-458{Cf. s.v. Ved. √rec- 'verlassen, lassen, überlassen, loslassen, freimachen', from PIE *lei̯kʷ- (cf. Arm. lkʻane-, aor. lkʻ[e]- 'verlassen', Gk. λείπω, λιμπάνω 'lasse, verlasse', Lat. linquō 'überlasse', Lith. liekmì 'bleibe', OPr. po-līnka 'bleibt', Goth. leiƕan, etc.).}];141[406-408{Cf. s.v. *lei̯kʷ- 'zurücklassen, sich entfernen von' (IEW 669-70).}]
Justification: Continuing a derivative of PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' via Indic udrēcayati 'causes to increase' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):96-97 no. 2061, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:457-458, [LIV²](src-141) 406-408).

Source: 442[163{S.v. 3193 Ved. kīṭá- (1) m. 'insect, worm' ŚBr.}];172[I:355-356{Cf. s.v. Ved. kīṭá- 'eine Wurm-Art'. Etymology unclear. Perhaps a loanword.}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):163 no. 3193, [EWAia](src-172) I:355-356).

Source: 442[786{S.v. 13640 *skambha- (2) 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage'.}]
Justification: As though continuing Sanskrit *skambha- 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):786 no. 13640). Further etymology uncertain.

Source: 442[595{S.v. 10302 Ved. meghá- m. 'cloud, rain' RV. [√*mih- (2)] (> P. meh, mẽh, mīh (f. PhonPj 121), mīhī˜ m. 'rain').}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic meghá- 'cloud' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):595 no.10302), further generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ([EWAia](src-172) II:374-375).

Source: 442[758{S.v. 13095 Skt. sajya- 'strung (of bow)' Kauś., sajja- 'id., put in place on bow (of arrow)' MBh., sajjā- f. 'equipment, dress' lex. (> P. sajjā 'righthand').}];172[II:688-689{Cf. s.v. Ved. √sañj- 'heften, hängen', IIr. cf. OPers. frahǰm /frāhaǰam/ 'ich hängte', Khot. ajs- 'verfolgen, nachsetzen', probably from PIE *seg-, cf. Lith. segù 'hefte, beschlage', MIr. sén 'Fangnetz (zum Vogelfang)', etc.}];141[516{Cf. s.v. 1. *seg- 'heften, anhängen' (IEW 887-8).}];399[III:419-420{S.v. Skt. sajjaḥ 'mit Bogensehne versehen| fertig, bereit' / 'having a bow-string| ready, prepared', cf. sájati.}]
Justification: As though from Sanskrit sajya- 'strung (of bow); prepared, ready', a derivative of Vedic √sa(ñ)j- 'to adhere to' and further to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, to cling to' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):758 no. 13095, [KEWA](src-399) III:419-420, [EWAia](src-172) II:688-689, [LIV²](src-141) 516).

Comment: Not in Turner 1962–1966

Source: 442[783{S.v. 13578 sr̥ṣṭá- 'released' RV., 'thrown, emitted, produced' AV. [√sr̥j].}];172[II:709{Cf. s.v. Ved. √sarj- 'loslassen, entlassen, abschießen', probably to PIE *selg̑- (cf. OIr. selg 'Jagd', MHG selken 'tropfend niederfallen, sich senken (von Wolken), perhaps also Hitt. salk- 'kneten, vermengen').}];141[528-529{Cf. s.v. *selg̑- 'loslassen, entsenden' (IEW 900-1).}]
Justification: Derived from Vedic sr̥ṣṭá- 'released' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):783, no. 13578), further derived from Vedic √sarj- 'to let go or fly, discharge, throw, cast, hurl' and ultimately from PIE *selg̑- 'to release, throw' ([EWAia](src-172) II:709, [LIV²](src-141) 528-529).

Source: 442[385{S.v. 6733 Ved. dhamáni- f. 'vein, nerve' AV., 'throat, neck' lex. [√dham].}];172[I:775{S.v. Ved. √dham-ⁱ 'blasen, ein Blas-Instrument spielen, anfangen [das Feuer]', from PIE *dʰemH- ~ *dʰmeH- (cf. Lith. dùmti 'blasen, wehen', OCS dъmǫ 'blase').}];399[II:92-93{S.v. Skt. dhamániḥ 'Ader / vein', clearly derived from √dham- 'blasen'| dhamani- 'Hals, Nacken' probably comes from a intermediate meaning *'Röhre / pipe'.}];141[153{Cf. s.v. *dʰmeH- 'blasen' (IEW 247-8).}]
Justification: Continuing Vedic dhamáni- 'vein, nerve; throat, neck', ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):385 no. 6733), further derived from Vedic √dham-ⁱ 'to blow' probably via an intermediate meaning 'pipe' and further to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ([KEWA](src-399) II:92-93, [EWAia](src-172) I:775, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 153).
Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor 'flower' (via Middle English flour, flur 'flower'?).
Loan from Middle English smọ̄th(e) 'smooth'.
Loan from English serpent 'snake, serpent'.
Related to Old Breton trinc 'sour', but no further etymology known outside of Brythonic (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):741).

Comment: Connected with [cognate set 8436](cog-8436)?

Source: 316[73-74{Cf. s.v. Lat. boreās, -ae 'vent du nord et région d'où souffle ce vent, nord', a borrowing from Gk. βορέας 'north wind'.}];444[107{S.v. 1219 Lat. boreas 'Nordwind'.}]
Justification: From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):107), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):73-74).

Source: 444[142{Cf. s.v. 1534 calx, -ce 'Ferse'.}];54[86{Cf. s.v. Lat. calx 'heel| hoof', doubtfully compared with BSl. *kulʔk- 'some part of the leg'| perhaps a non-IE (Etruscan?) origin, but a concrete comparandum is lacking.}]

Justification: Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian црн дроб, Bulgarian черен дроб 'liver'.

Source: 444[762{S.v. 9134 Lat. vallis 'Tal'.}];54[652{S.v. Lat. vallēs, -is 'valley'. No certain etymology.}];316[712{S.v. Lat. valles, vallis 'val, vallée', maybe to the group of uoluō 'turn'?}]
Justification: Continuing Latin vallis 'valley' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):762 no. 9134), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):712, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):652).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. OCS лѣвъ 'left', Macedonian лев 'id.', etc.
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian блато 'marsh, swamp, bog' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), see also Albanian baltë 'swamp, marsh'.
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian лови, Serbo-Croatian loviti 'to hunt'.
Loan ultimately from Turkish yemiş 'fruit' (via Macedonian imìš?).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian магла 'fog'.

Source: 444[605{S.v. 7328 Lat. rīpa 'Ufer'. (> megl. råpă „Abhang", „Stein").}];54[524{S.v. Lat. rīpa 'river bank', from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' (cf. Gk. ἐρείπω 'to throw down, fall down', ἐρίπνη 'slope', OIc. rifa 'to demolish, tear down, ONo. rīp 'upper side of a boat', East Frisian rip(e) 'shore').}];316[574]
Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin rīpa 'shore, riverbank' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):605 no. 7328), further from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):524, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):574).

Source: 444[294{S.v. 3422 Lat. 1. 'Balg', 'Schlauch' 2. 'Blasebalg'. 3. 'Hülle der Seele'| 1. > Rum. dial. foale 'Bauch'.}];54[230{S.v. Lat. follis 'bag, sack| ball, testicles'| possibly connected with Proto-Celtic *bol- in OIr. ball 'member, body part', W. balleg 'sack, purse' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B-12). No further etymology.}]
Justification: From Latin follis 'bag, sack' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):294). Further connections outside of Italic not fully certain (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):230).

Source: 444[565{Cf. s.v. 6826 Lat. *pullius 'junges Tier'.}];54[502-503{Cf. s.v. Lat. putus 'boy' with derivative pullus 'foal, chick, young of an animal'. from PIE *put-lo- 'little boy, young of an animal'| pullus < *put-slo-.}];316[544{S.v. Lat. pullus, -ī 'petit d'un animal' especially 'poulet'. Lat. pullus may be explained by *put-slo-.}]
Justification: Eastern Romance lexemes from Latin *pullius 'young animal' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):565 no. 6826), further to PIE *putslo- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):544, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):502-505; cf. Ved. putrá- < *put-lo-).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian дише, Bulgarian дишам 'breathe'.

Source: 85;444[320{S.v. 3750 Lat. geusiae (gall.) 'Kehle'.}];316[274{S.v. Lat. *geusiae, -ārum 'gosier'. Without doubt a loan from Gaulish (cf. ML 3750).}]
Justification: East Romance lexemes continuing Latin geusiae 'throat' (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), a probable loanword from Continental Celtic (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):320 no. 3750, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):274).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian корен 'root'.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian песок 'sand'.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian мазен 'smooth'.
Borrowing from Slavic koža 'skin', compare Macedonian koža 'skin' in [cognate set 1171](cog-1171) (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. [cognate set 1171](cog-1171).

Comment: (< Lat. dūcere 'to lead'?)
Loan from Macedonian? [cognate set 4966](cog-4966)

Justification: Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian плива 'to swim'.

Source: 369[197-198{S.v. Alb. hedh 'werfen, schleudern, schließen, losstürzen, worfeln (Getreide)'. Normally compared with Germ. *skeu̯(d)- (ON skjóta 'schießen, werfen', OE scēotan 'schießen, schleudern', etc.) to PIE *(s)keu̯d- 'werfen, schießen'. The connection with Germ. *skeu̯d- cannot however explain the variant hjedh.}];364[976{S.v. Alb. hedh = hjedh 'werfen' / përhjedh / (Budi) 'verstreuen, zerstreuen'. Two different roots underlie these forms: *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben' (LIV² 560) and *(s)kedh₂- 'zersplittern, zerstreuen' (LIV² 550-551). In Old Albanian the root *skedh₂ is attested especially by Bogdani via hjedh 'zerstreuen' and by Budi in the compound përhjedh 'verstreuen, zerstreuen'. The root *(s)keu̯d- can better explain the semantics of non-active hjidhet 'eilen'. In Modern Albanian the form hedh can only be phonologically regular from PIE *skeu̯deti, not from *(s)kedh₂-.}];571[72-73{S.v. Alb. hedh 'throw', maintaining Meyer (1891:150)'s connections to Germanic words for 'shoot' < *sk̑eu̯d- (IEW 956 *(s)k̑eu̯d- 'werfen, schliessen, hetzen').}];141[560{Cf. s.v. *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben' (IEW 955-6), under which ?Alb. hedh 'wirft' < *(s)kéu̯d-e-.}];585[150{S.v. Alb. heθ 'werfe', from < *heδō and to be connected with Germ. skeudō in OS skeotan, ON skjóta, OHG scioʒan 'schiessen'.}];389[{Adds to √*(s)kedh₂- under the present formation ?*(s)kedh₂-e- Alb. hjedh 'zerstreut| wirft' after Schumacher & Matzinger (2013:976).}];105[143-144{S.v. Alb. hedh 'to throw, to shoot' (variant hjedh), from PAlb. *skeuda and connected with ON skjóta, OHG scioʒan and other Germanic continuants of PGmc. *skiutan 'to shoot' < IE *skeud- 'to throw, to shoot'.}];458[13:253-254{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kydnǫti}];81[265{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kydnǫti 'throw, fling' (ESSJa XIII 252-253), from PIE *kud-, cf. also Proto-Slavic *kydati 'throw, fling' < PIE *(s)kud- (cf. Skt. códati 'impel', OIc. skjóta 'shoot, shove').}]
Justification: This cognate class codes Albanian hedh 'to throw' which may be regularly derived from PIE *skeu̯d- 'to propel (forth)' ([LIV²](src-141) 560); the Modern Albanian variant hjedh was semantically distinct in Old Albanian and is to be derived instead from *(s)kedh₂- 'to shatter, disperse' ([LIV²](src-141) 550, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) and [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):976 for further discussion. For older discussions connecting to PIE *(s)keu̯d-, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):150, [Huld 1984](src-571) 72-73, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):197-198, [Orel 1998](src-105):143-144. For the Slavic forms attached to this class, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:252-254, [Derksen 2008](src-81):265 (not in [LIV²](src-141)). Regarding the proposed cognacy to Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash' ([LIV²](src-141) 560), cf. discussion in [cognate set 8120](cog-8120).

Source: 165[305-306{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *kringan- ~ *krinkan- 'to fall' as though from PIE *gréng̑ʰ-e- (cf. Lith. grę̃žti 'to turn, wring| bore, perforate' < *greng̑ʰ-) and derivative Proto-Germanic *kringa- 'circle'.}];141[191{Cf. s.v. ?*greng̑ʰ- 'drehen' (IEW 386). Only Germanic and Baltic.}];468[330{Cf. s.v. ON kringr (1) 'kreis, ring', to be connected with Lith. grėžiù 'wenden, drehen' from a root *greng̑ʰ-.}]
Justification: Germanic lexemes appearing to continuing derivatives of a PIE root *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn', although the evidence for this root is restricted to Baltic and Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):330, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):305-306, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 191).

Source: 352[933-934{S.v. OLith. skrìsti, perhaps to a neo-root *(s)krei̯dʰ-, which could go back to a *-dʰ- present to *(s)krei̯- (cf. skríeti) and be sought after also in OCS okrьstь 'ringsherum, umher' and OE scrīðan 'gleiten, schweben, schreiten', OHG skrītan 'gleiten, schreiten'.}];141[563{S.v. ?*(s)krei̯t- 'im Kreis gehen' (?) (IEW 937).}]
Justification:
Root reference form for this class tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 563, but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 933-934 regarding the possibility that the lexeme goes back to a secondary neo-root *(s)krei̯-dʰ- and connected to Latvian skrìet 'fly_V' in [cognate set 2273](cog-2273).
'

Source: 397[96{Cf. s.v. NHG Bauch (MHG būch, OHG būh), from Gmc. *būka- 'Bauch', also in ON búkr, OE būc, OFr. būk, būch. The word goes back to a root with different initial labials designating fat, belly-like things (cf. Ru. púzo 'Bauch, Wanst'), perhaps originally a sound-symbolic word for blown up (and hence fat) cheeks. Perhaps to this also OIr. abach 'Eingeweide' (< *ad-bhug-).}];757[1:395{S.v. Du. buik. There are no certain cognates outside of Germanic. Some attempt to see a connection with the same root in Du. buigen 'to bend', but this is formally problematic as Proto-Germanic has *-g- for that verbal stem. As a body part, perhaps it is of substrate origin.}]
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic. Earlier assumed to be from an IE root *b⁽ʰ⁾(e)ū̆- with an extension -g- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 100). For various other uncertain proposals, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):96, [EWNl](src-757) 1:395.

Source: 740[IV:498];79[287-294{Cf. s.v. Arm. tʻitʻełn 'butterfly', pp.293-294 where a case is made attempting to consider Arm. pʻetowr an inherited derivative of PIE *pet-.}]
Justification:
Etymology uncertain, the lexemes have been attempted to be related to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall', however this is phonologically problematic since one expects PIE *pe- to develop to he- in Classical Armenian, however cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):293-294 attempting to maintain the traditional etymology. Perhaps a loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language (cf. Hitt. pattar- 'wing, feather')? See also [HAB](src-740) IV:498.
For multiple explanations of initial pʿ from PIE *ped- and/or *peth₂- cf. [Kölligan 2019](src-795): 273ff.

Source: 236[{S.v. W niwl 'fog, mist, vapour, haze, cloud(s)| also fig. and transf.| obscured eyesight', loanword from Lat. nūbilus?}];274[502{Cf. n15: The late Latin *nibulus (for nūbilus) was loaned into Celtic, cf. MW nyfel, NW niwl, nifwl, Co. niul 'Wolke, Nebel' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 315).}];296[N:6{S.v. OIr. nél 'nuage'. Attempts to reconcile to a pre-form *nebʰlo- (cf. Lat. nebula, Gk. νεφελή, OHG nebul, OE nifol) is phonetically impossible. Thurneysen's hypothesis of *miglos (cf. Gk. ὀμίχλη) with the change of *m- > *n- under the influence of nigíd 'he washes' is less plausible. The Brythonic forms (Welsh niwl, nifwl, Corn. niul may be borrowings from Lat. nūbilus (< nībulus), and according to IEW 315 Ir. nél is borrowed from Brythonic.}]
Justification: Brythonic lexemes generally assumed to be loanwords from Latin nūbilus 'cloudy, overcast' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [NIL](src-274) 502n15, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:8).

Source: 442[206{S.v. 3894 *khuṭṭa- (2) 'leg'. [Perh. same as *khuṭṭa- (1) 'peg']}]
Justification: Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in [cognate set 2792](cog-2792), 'leg' in [cognate set 9630](cog-9630).
Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in [cognate set 2792](cog-2792), 'foot' in [cognate set 9629](cog-9629).
Loanword from Arabic اخسأ

Source: 172[I:451-452{S.v. Ved. √khād- 'kauen, zerbeißen, essen, fressen, verzehren'. Cf. NPers. xāyīdan 'kauen' if from *kʰād-, Baluči khāδαγ 'eat', Khot. khaca 'food' (if from *xad-čā). Further connections are not certain.}];141[559-560{Cf. s.v. ?*k⁽ʷ⁾h₂ed- '(zer)quetschen' [IEW 634 Anm.]. Only Indo-Iranian cognates.}];83[445{S.v. Proto-Iranic *xād- 'to devour, eat, gorge' (Parth. x'z, Khot. khāś-, NP xāyīdan/xāy- 'to chew, gnaw, eat', Bal. kʰāδiθ-/kʰāδ- 'to chew'. To Sanskrit khād- 'to chew, bite, eat'. "An IE provenance for this IIr. root is uncertain: the IE preform *k(ʷ)h₂eg̑- (cf. Arm. xacanel ‘to bite’) reconstructed by Klingenschmitt 1982: 210 and Kümmel, LIV: 360 has little to recommend."}];442[203-204{Cf. s.v. 3865 Ved. khādati ʻ chews, bites ʼ RV. & 3867 khādana n. 'eating'.}]
Comment: {Kashmiri form after pyonu dat. pĕnas ʻto drink' (cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3867)?, cf. Armenian kc(an)em "bite" (5942)}
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes likely to be continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰād-, further connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):445, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):203-204 no. 3865, 3867, [EWAia](src-172) I:451-452, [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Source: 304[189-193{S.v. Proto-Celtic *ag-e/o- 'treiben, führen', from PIE *h₂eg̑- (LIV 255f.)| with preverb tu- > Welsh dyfot '(an)kommen, sich ereignen', Middle Breton donet 'kommen' (1.sg. deuaff, 3.sg. deu)| Middle Cornish devones, dones, dos 'kommen'}];50[27{Cf. s.v. Proto-Celtic *ag-o- 'drive', from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. Skt. ájati, Lat. agō, Gk. ἄγω, Arm. acem).}];141[255-256{Cf. s.v. 1. *h₂eg̑- 'treiben' (IEW 4-5).}]
Justification: Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic preverb *tu- + *ag- 'to drive', ultimately cognate with PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):189-193, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):27, [LIV²](src-141) 255-256).

Source: 442[633{S.v. 10920 *laḍ- (2) 'fight'. 2. *laḍḍ- 2. 3. *laḍh- > H. laṛnā (→ N. laṛnu, Mth. laṛab, Bhoj. laṛal).}];69[548{S.v. लड़्नु laṛnu ², vb. intr. To fight| (c. sita) fight against. [K. laḍun to fight (prob. lw. H. P.)]}]
Justification: Parallel loans from Hindi लड़ना / laṛnā ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):633 no. 10920, [Turner 1931](src-69):548).

Source: 165[586{S.v. Proto-Germanic *wī̆han- 'to fight' < *uik-e-, cf. Lat. vincō 'to conquer, overcome' < *ui-n-k-e-| OIr. fichaid 'to fight', W. amyn 'id.' (< ambi-wik-) < *uik-e-.}];179[397-398{S.v. Goth. W45. weihan, only in waurdam weihan 'λογομαχεῖν', 'dispute', from PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'exert force' (cf. Lith. veĩkti, Latv. veìkt 'carry out', OIr. fichim < *wik-yo- 'I fight', Lat. vincō 'conquer', etc.).}];50[421{S.v. Proto-Celtic *wik-o- 'fight', from PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'fight, conquer' (cf. Lat. uincō 'conquer', ON vega 'fight, kill').}];304[683-688{S.v. Proto-Celtic *u̯ik-e/o- 'kämpfen', from PIE 2. *u̯ei̯k- (LIV² 670f.)}];141[670-671{S.v. 2. *u̯ei̯k- 'überwinden, besiegen' (IEW 1128-9).}]
Justification: From PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'to overcome, conquer' ([LIV²](src-141) 670-671, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):683-688, [Matasović 2009](src-50):421).

Source: 442[293{S.v. 5321 *jhagaḍ 'quarrel'. 2. *jhaggaḍ- . 3. *jhaggaṭṭ-}]
323[37{S.v. Paš. ǰagṛ'a 'fight, quarrel, dispute, war', cf. T. 5321, Panj. jhagṛā 'id.', Lhd jhagṛaṇ 'to quarrel, dispute', etc.}]
Justification: Loanword from Dardic, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):37.

Source: 236[{S.v. W pysgod 'fish(es), sometimes used loosely to include cetaceans, crustaceans, molluscs, &c., also fig.', a loanword from Latin piscātus, cf. Middle Cornish puskes, Middle Breton pesqued, Late Breton pesked| Cf. also Welsh pysg 'fish' < Lat. piscis.}]
Justification: Loanword from Latin piscātus 'a catch of fish' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).
Parallel loans from Persian گل / gol 'flower'.

Source: 423[I:636-637{S.v. Sp. bosque, a loanword from Catalan or Occitan bǫsc.}]
Justification: Loanword from Catalan or Occitan bǫsc 'forest' ([DCECH](src-423) I:636-637).

Source: 423[II:919{Cf. s.v. Sp. floresta, a borrowing from Old French forest, of uncertain origin.}];444[297{Cf. s.v. 3459 forum 'Marktplatz'| under derivatives Fr. forêt, Prov. forest loaned into It. foresta, sp., pg. floresta 'Wald').}]
Justification: Loan from Old French forest (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):297, [DCECH](src-423) II:919).

Source: 352[67-69{Cf. s.v. OLith. áugti 'wachsen' (BSl. cf. Latv. aûgt 'wachsen, größer werden, zunehmen' and Latv. aûglis 'Frucht, Baumfrucht, Erzeugnis'), from PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'stark werden' (Ved. ojmán- 'Kraft, Macht' Lat. augeō, -ere 'vermehren', Goth. aukan 'sich mehren', TochA oks- 'wachsen', TochB auks- '(heran)wachsen', gedeihen', etc.).}];556[532-533{Cf. s.v. Gmc. *wahs-ja- 'wachsen', with derived stem *wahs-t-ma- (OE wæstm 'Wuchs, Gestalt, Frucht', OS wastom 'Gedeihen, Wachstum, Frucht', going back to an enlarged form of *aug- 'mehren'.}];165[566{Cf. s.v. Proto-Germanic *wahs(j)an- 'to grow', an s-extension to the more common IE base *h₂eug- 'grow' (cf. Goth. aukan), cf. also PGmc. *wahstu- 'growth, stature' (Goth. wahstus, ON vǫxtr 'growth| stature| yield', Fa. vøkstur 'id.', and PGmc. *wahsman- > ODu. wa(h)smo, OHG wahsamo 'growth, fruit'.}]
Justification: Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'to grow, become strong' ([ALEW](src-352) 67-69, [Seebold 1970](src-556):532-533, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):566).

Source: 323[79{S.v. Paš. šin (m.), šna (f.) 'green, blue'. Cf. Av. axšaēna-, etc. 'dark coloured, dark blue', Khot. āṣṣeina, Phl. axšēn, Prs. xašēn| Oss D. æxsin, Orm. ṣ̌īn, Kurd. šīn.}];442[2{S.v. 24 akṣa- (4) n. 'blue vitriol' lex. [Cf. Av. axšaēna -- ʻ dark- coloured ʼ, Yid. axšin ʻ blue ʼ Horn NPE 109, Morgenstierne IIFL ii 195, W. S. Allen The Classical Quarterly xli 88 note 1]}];399[I:543{S.v. Skt. akṣam n. 'blauer Vitriol / blue vitriol', cf. Khowar oč̣ 'light blue', Av. aḫšaēna- 'dunkelfarbig'(?), Morgenstierne 74, Burrow ArchLing. 6 (1954) 61.}];172[III:3{S.v. akṣa- 'blauer vitriol' (Lex.) – Eine Farbezeichnung? "Man hat Dardisches (wie Kho. oc[h] 'green, blue') und Iranisches (wie jav. axšaēna- 'dunkelfarbig' u.a.) herangezogen| s. die Lit. in KEWA I:543, III:623, Tu 24, Hinz NÜ 25, Bai, Dict 26bf. 346b"}]
Justification: For Khowar, cf. Vedic akṣa- 'blue vitriol' only attested in lexicographical works, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):2, no. 24; for Pashto from Proto-Iranic axšai̯na- 'dark coloured, dark blue', cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):79. For the probable cognate relationship between the two on the basis of Proto-Indo-Iranic *akša-, cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:543, [EWAia](src-172) III:3.

Source: 165[220{S.v. Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair', from PIE *k̑ē̆s-ró- (cf. Hitt. kišzi ~ kišanzi 'to comb, card' < *kes-ti, *ks-énti| OCS česati 'to scratch, pluck' < *kes-eh₂-, etc.).}];397[382{S.v. NHG Haar (MHG hār, OHG hār, OS hār), from Gmc. *hǣra- 'Haar' also in ON hár, OE hǣr, hēr (in Gothic instead tagl, cf. Zagel). The closest thing that may be compared is an original s-stem, cf. Lith. šerỹs 'Borste, (Tier-)haar', Lith. širỹs 'Haar' (IE *k̑er-, *k̑r̥-)| with an s extension (reflex of an s-stem?) Ru. šerštь 'Wolle', further origin unclear.}];757[II:360{S.v. Du. haar 2 zn. ‘draadvormige huidbedekking bij mensen en dieren’| Further etymology unclear. Traditionally related to Lithuanian šerys 'animal hair'| Old Russian sĭrstĭ 'hair, wool' (Russian šerst' 'wool')| < PIE *ker(s) 'spine, hair of plants' (IEW 583). Another possibility is that PGmc. *hēra- with grammatical change and rhotacism going back to PIE *kēsó-, from the root * kes- 'combing', which also includes: OCS kosa 'haar', česati 'combing'| Lithuanian kasà 'braid'| Hittitisch kis-zi 'he combs'. Maybe Old Irish cír 'comb, rake' is also related < PIE * ḱēs-. Partly because of the field of meaning and the limited geographical spread, this is possibly a pre-Indo-European substrate word.}]
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair'. Further etymology disputed, either (1)  with Lithuanian šerỹs 'bristle' < *k̑er(H)- ([Kluge 2011](src-397):382, cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):443), or (2) from PIE *k̑es- 'to arrange in order; comb' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):220; if so, cf. lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *kosa 'hair, braided hair' in [cognate set 8240](cog-8240)). A third option considered by [EWNl](src-757) II:360 is the possibility of a European substratum loanword.
Loanword from Persian (if inherited, expected Anlaut z-, cf. zangun 'knee' < *zānukāna- derived from PIE *g̑enu-).

Source: 442[223{Cf. s.v. 4164 gilana- n. 'swallowing' Bhpr. [√*gal- (2)]. (> Paš. gilāˊn m. 'mouth').}];172[I:469-470{Cf. s.v. √gar-ⁱ (2) 'verschlingen' (Mi., ni. s. pkt. giraï, gilaï 'verschlingt' etc.), to PIE *gʷerh₃-, cf. Arm. e-ker 'aß', Gk. βιβρώσκω 'esse, verzehre' Lat. vorāre 'verschlingen, gierig essen', Lith. gérti 'trinken', etc.}];105[126{Cf. s.v. Alb. grykë 'throat', from PAlb. *grīwīkā and related to IE *gʷrīu̯ā 'neck' (Skt. grīvā́, Av. grīvā, Latv. grĩva 'river mouth', Slav. *griva 'mane' (Orel Linguistica XXIV 438). Camarda 65 (correctly links grykë to IE *gʷer- 'to swallow, eat').}];687[31{S.v. Alb. Arb. gríka 'Mund' (= Std. grykë). Perhaps to IE *kreu-k- to *(s)ker- 'drehen, biegen' (IEW 938).}];369[297-298{Cf. s.v. ngrë́në / ngrãnë 'essen, verzehren| speisen| fressen| verschlingen| beißen| abnagen', without doubt that the stem of the formation -grënë / (-)grãne (< Alb. (-)*granⁿǝ) to be connected to Ved. giráti 'verschlingen', Lat. vorō 'id.'. [Jokl 1937](src-662):139ff. further connects grýkë, gurmaz 'Hals'. etc. To root *gʷerh₃-.}]
Justification: Albanian and Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 211-212). Albanian Arbëresh gríka 'mouth' is equivalent to Standard Albanian grýkë 'throat' ([Rohr 2000](src-687):31; for the root etymology see [Demiraj 1997](src-369):297-298; cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):126). The Modern Indic lexemes are as though from Sanskrit gilana- 'swallowing', continuing a derivative of Vedic √gar-ⁱ (2) 'to devour' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):223 no. 4164, [EWAia](src-172) I:469-470).

Source: 389[551{*skek- 'to move around, to jump'}];296[S-30{OIr. scál n. o 'phantom, supernatural being, hero' is probably cognate to MW ysgawl 'young hero'. O'Brien, Ériu 11 (1932) 89 compares this to Goth. skōhsl, which translates Gr. daímōn 'demon' in the Bible. Both are based on *skōk-slo- from the PIE root *skek-. Further cognates are Ir. scuchid 'parts, disappears' and possibly Ir. scén 'horror, panic'.}];305[433{Follows the analysis proposed by  Vendryes et al. 1959–1996 Pages: S-30.}];774[89{OIr. scál is a neuter o-stem, but in later sources, it is also fem.}]
Justification:
This cognate class is based on the assumption that ModIr. scáil f. 'shadow' continues OIr. scál m. 'phantom', involving a semantic shift and a change of gender or MIr. scáile masc. and fem. 'shadow, reflexion, image, illusion'. 
If one rejects this connection, it would be possible to postulate *skeh₃-lā- vel sim. for Ir. scáil, Sc. sgàil and connect them with [cognate set 8269](cog-8269). However, this has not been suggested so far, probably because there does not seem to be any evidence for a feminine word denoting 'shadow' before Late Middle / Early Modern Irish.

Source: 81[222{S.v. Proto-Slavic *kāzàti 'show'.  Derksen regards the interpretation of the LIV (383, 385) that *kazati may be a causative *kʷōg̑-i̯e-, a variant of the root *kʷek̑- 'see, behold', as the best etymological solution.}];141[383-385{S.v. *kʷek̑- 'sehen, erblicken' (IEW 638-9), cf. n11 which assumes a voicing of root-final *-k̑- > *-g̑- as a root variant in the Slavic causative formation * kʷṓg̑-i̯e- 'betrachten lassen' (formed to the acrodynamic root-present).}];458[4: 100-101| 9: 168-170{The etymology of PS *kazati is complicated. However, it is most probably derived from PIE *kek̑- / *keg̑-. A reconstruction as *kʷeg̑- is also thinkable.}];442[47{S.v. 1041 Skt. ākhyāti 'tells' Ep. [ākhyāyatē ŚBr., aor. ākhyat RV.: √khyā]}];172[I:456-457{S.v. Ved. √khyā- 'schauen, anblicken, scheinen'. √khyā- is a phonetic variant of √kśā- 'blicken, schauen'}]
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes reflecting Sanskrit ākhyāti 'tells' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):47 no. 1041) and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kāzati, both probably to be derived from PIE *kʷek̑- ([LIV²](src-141) 383-385, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:456-457, [Derksen 2008](src-81):222, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:100-101, 9:168-170).
Loanword from Turkic, cf. [cognate set 3329](cog-3329).
Phonology excludes inheritance
Parallel loans from Sanskrit sū́rya- 'sun'.
Loanword from Arabic جلد 'skin, leather'.

Source: 777[146-150{S.v. Khot. śśau 'one'. The earlier proposal of [Bailey 1979](src-320):404 to Proto-Iranic *aiu̯a- is unsatisfactory. No satisfactory etymology has yet been agreed upon. [Cf. with extensive discussion].}]
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997](src-777):146-150 with extensive discussion and rejecting the etymology of [Bailey 1979](src-320):404 to Proto-Iranic *aiu̯a- 'one').

Source: 444[241, 257{S.v. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade' and 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus (> it. erta 'Anhöhe', all'erta 'aufwärts, aufgepaßt').}];54[517-518{S.v. Lat. regō, -ere 'to direct, guide, govern', from Proto-Italic *reg- (cf. U. rehte 'right'), from PIE *h₃reg̑-e/o-. Lat. rēctus is the regularly formed past passive participle to the verbal stem [< *h₃reg̑-to-].}];141[304-305{Cf. s.v. *h₃reg̑- 'gerade richten, ausstrecken' (IEW 854-7).}]
Justification: Light verb constructions using verbal nouns of Latin regere 'to guide, direct, govern' as the semantic-bearing head. For Neapolitan all'erta cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):257 no. 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus. Further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ([LIV²](src-141) 304-305, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):517-518).  Parallel late derivation in Old Occitan drech, dreit cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):241 no. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade'.

Comment: Loan from Persian
Justification: Parallel loans from Persian سگ / sag 'dog'.

Source: 442[19{Cf. s.v. 407 áp f., pl. ā́paḥ 'waters' RV.}]
Justification: Nuristani lexemes in light verb constructions. Cognacy in this set is coded for 'water', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):19 no. 407 s.v. Vedic áp-, pl. ā́paḥ 'waters'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in [cognate set 157](cog-157).
See discussion under cognate set 5512

See discussion under [cognate set 5697](cog-5697).  And see also [cognate set 9689](cog-9689).
The loan is so early that it is inconsistent to call it a parallel loan into both Middle and modern Dutch, rather than a loanword event type that at least Modern Dutch did inherit by transmission from Middle Dutch (or a closely related variety).

See discussion under [cognate set 5697](cog-5697).  And see also [cognate set 9688](cog-9688).
Inclusion of Luxembourgish here is questionable, as not directly derived from Middle *High* German, but it is not clear that this loanword appears so early that there was likely little real separation of the Luxembourgish lineage from those that led to the other languages included in this cognate set.

The West Germanic lexemes in this set are parallel loans from Old French. 
The same original Old French source was also loaned into other West Germanic languages. 
 Given the timing of the loans after the basic Dutch/German fragmentation is taken to have already begun, these define separate loan event cognate sets:   
[cognate set 9688](cog-9688) in Dutch;  [cognate set 9689](cog-9689) in Upper German. 

A later, follow-on loan-event from Middle Low German into North Germanic languages, is [cognate set 5697](cog-5697).  

Cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97). [Kluge 2011](src-397):777-778, [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84), [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).
Parallel loans from Old French.  See also [cognate set 6198](cog-6198), a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but parallel loans into English and Frisian..
Old Frisian has berna while the Modern West Frisian variant is baarne, which is not a loanword
Frisian doesn't have open syllable lengthening - cannot be Frisian; OFri. liwere
comp. EFri. dialects säie, sii etc.
the archaic form is tsjok - rarely used nowadays
[frɔu] - likely from Middle Dutch; Also 'person'. AF: mins.

Although also the name of the internal organ 'stomach', in the variety of English targeted here, i.e. standard British English and following majority usage in England, the word 'stomach' has broadened to refer to the abdomen in general, and is has become the default, unmarked word for the target sense here.  The lexeme 'belly' is more marked in register, often with overtones of a protruding 'pot belly'..
See also the independent loan of the same ultimate Greek source lexeme into a variety of Macedonian, at [cognate set 7400](cog-7400).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):398-399, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):434, 491 for further discussion.

Source: 83[93{S.v. Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to gorge' (cf. Av. gah- 'to gorge'). For Choresmian cf. γš 'tooth'| (+ *apa-) bγʾh- 'to bite' ([MacKenzie 1975](src-783): 392), cf. [Samadi 1986](src-724):17f.). Plausible further cognates in IE are lacking.}];141[198-199{Cf. s.v. ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'essen, fressen, verzehren' (IEW 452). Only IIr., further connections uncertain.}];172[I:514{Cf. s.v. Ved. √ghas- 'essen, verzehren' (IIr. YAv. gah- 'essen, fressen (von daēuuischen Wesen)', no further connections are certain.}];323[33{S.v. Pashto γāx̌ 'tooth' "Not < *gastra-, Av. √gah- 'to devour' as in EVP 28, but rather *gaštra-, √gaz- 'to bite', cf. Khwar. γš, Orm K gas (< *gaš-), pl. L giši| also Gilaki gāz 'tooth' [Wkh γ̌aṣ̌, Yazgh γax̌ 'mouth', with semantic development via 'bite, Gebiss'? MK]."}]
Justification: Cognacy in this set follows [Cheung 2007](src-83):93 to Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to devour', but cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):33 suggesting instead to *gaz- 'to bite'. Outside of Iranic further cf. Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. [LIV²](src-141) 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.
